column2: A general summary on Maine inland fishing can only come under the heading of "excellent," with plenty of bass being taken from the northern lakes, good catches of trout from the streams, land-locks and togue plentiful in the larger lakes, and some salmon coming from the Dennys and Narraguagus.

An economic loss of $300,000,000 was suffered in New York City in 1948 as the result of 3,778 deaths and 400,000 serious injuries through accidents, it was reported yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council.

Yonkers will offer $2,942,000 worth of various purpose bonds on June 23, it was announced yesterday. The issue will be marketed at interest rates not to exceed 4 per cent and will be dated Aug. 1, 1949, and payable on Aug. 1, 1950-1974.

The fifty-ninth annual Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior championships at Randalls Island and the revival of the international dual competition between combined Princeton-Cornell and Oxford - Cambridge squads at Princeton's Palmer Stadium will conclude major track and field activity in this section today.

PARIS, June 10 -- The seizure by the French Customs of 10,000 volumes of the "History of the Communist Party," translated into French and sent to France from Moscow, has revealed the existence of a small war between publishers in the U. S. S. R. and the Communist press in France.
BOULDER Col., June 10 (AP) -- A Colorado University sophomore was beaten to death last night in the second student slaying at the school in seven months.

LONDON, June 10 -- Former Albanian Vice Premier KotchiDrodze was sentenced to death today by the Supreme Court in Tirana, the capital, on charges of having collaborated with Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia and of having attempted to submit Albania to his rule, the Tirana radio reported.
GRINNELL, Iowa, June 10 (UP) -- Assistant Secretary of State George V. Allen said tonight that the United Nations could not be successful as long as Russia remained a dictatorship.

TRIESTE, June 10 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi told a crowd of wildly cheering Triestenes this evening that the Italian Government expected the entire Free Territory of Trieste to be returned to Italy. However, he made it clear that Italy would seek redress of what she considered an injustice only through peaceful diplomatic means.
LONDON, June 10 -- With operators not inclined to open up fresh commitments to be carried over the week-end, the stock markets here today finished the week on a quiet note.

The stock market suffered a fresh relapse yesterday and again touched the two-year lows of Tuesday. A slight rebound in the afternoon allowed a reduction in the extreme losses and prices ended steadier. Activity on the Stock Exchange speeded up on the new decline during the second hour, but operations were slow during the other periods.
An interesting contrast in methods of protecting -- or failing to protect -- basic rights of the individual was afforded by three Congressional committees this week.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Average primary market prices were unchanged in the week ended June 7, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 10 -- Carroll Binder editorial editor of The Star and The Tribune, Minneapolis newspaper, warned a United Nations subcommission of journalists today that attempts to effect a compromise between the free press systems of the Western nations, and the regimented, controlled press of police states, would "lead to the destruction of the freedom we are trying to preserve."

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 10 -- A group of 170 members of the Congressional Secretaries Club, all employed by members of Congress, reached here at noon today for their annual three-day spree in New York.

Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan approved yesterday a certificate of incorporation for the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Foundation, Inc., which, according to its organizers, was formed to promote the humanitarian ideals of the religious leader of India.
ALBANY, June 10 (AP) -- A representative of King Gustav V of Sweden presented a silver medal today to Acting Gov. Joe R. Hanley in recognition of his role in the Swedish Centennial last year.

HARRISON, N. Y., June 10 -- The annual Greenwich horse show, first stop on the Connecticut circuit which includes Ox Ridge and Fairfield the following two weekends, opened its three-day stand at the Blind Brook Polo Club grounds today. Twenty classes were completed, some in the ring, others on the improved outside course.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 10 -- Repeated taunts by fellow officers over the Jewish origin of his wife led 27-year-old Soviet Air Force Flight Lieut. Ilya Moutchec to flee by air to Sweden with the LA-11 fighter entrusted to his care.

Negotiating committees of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, and the Bethlehem Steel Company met yesterday afternoon in the company's offices at 25 Broadway in the opening discussion of a wage review of a contract that runs through June 23, 1950.

PARIS, June 10 -- The Cross of the Legion of Honor was presented today to the little village of Oradour Sur Glane, where four years ago the Germans destroyed every building and shot or burned alive 700 men, women and children.

LONDON, June 10 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration, the British Government and British business have begun an intensive study of the prices of British exports as compared with similar United States goods.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 10 -- Arriving here this afternoon for the reunion with his former buddies of the Thirty-fifth Division, President Truman will use the occasion tomorrow for a major address, with the quest for world peace his central theme.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 10 -- Two famous sportsmen, Henry J. Kaiser and Guy Lombardo, whose divergent careers are worlds apart but who have as a common denominator the hobby of making speed boats go faster, will attempt soon after dawn tomorrow to set a new all-time international record.
PARIS, June 10 -- Interrupting a discussion of the military budget, the National Assembly today voted by 397 to 182 the provisional defense budget for the month of June.

BUENOS AIRES, June 10 -- A long-standing but widening split between the State Department and the Economic Cooperation Administration over policy on Argentina lies behind a United States protest to London and an expected protest to Buenos Aires over the Anglo-Argentine trade accord, it appeared here today.

Man's best friend in an ordeal by paint and pencil "sat" for artists at the Greenwich Village outdoor art show yesterday with little impairment of the traditional relationship. An experience that might well have left artists dog-shy, the pooches easel-shy and the owners exhausted, resulted happily in pictures and mutual forgiveness.

WESTFIELD, N. J., June 10 -- J. Wolcott Brown of Manasquan River had a keen putter today that sent him into the quarter-final round of the forty-eighth New Jersey State golf championship at the Echo Lake course.

TROY, N. Y., June 10 -- The outcome of the struggle between "American principles of life and growth and another philosophy now challenging them" will be determined not only on how well we learn to understand our principles but "how we act to carry them out," Admiral Ben Moreell (retired) told Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's largest graduating class at the 141st commencement exercises today.

SEOUL, Korea, June 10 -- President Syngman Rhee said at his weekly news conference today that the Korean Government would seek the early conclusion of a treaty of commerce and friendship with the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Paul G. Hoffman, who left a lucrative position in private industry to head the Economic Cooperation Administration, was told today by Senator Kenneth McKellar, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, that his resignation would be "a very good thing" for the people of Europe and America.

Austenal Laboratories, Inc., of 224 East Thirty-ninth Street, was charged in a civil anti-trust filed in Federal Court yesterday with attempting to monopolize interstate trade and commerce in a chromium-cobalt alloy widely used in dentures.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Testimony on proposals to amend the Natural Gas Act ended today with opposing arguments that they do not go far enough and that they would make consumers pay more.

PARIS, June 10 -- After having played sixty-eight boards of a scheduled ninety-six the United States bridge team composed of John Crawford, Peter Leventritt, Samuel Stayman, and George Rapee forged ahead of Baron de Nexon's French team today in the United States-French bridge challenge match here.

Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson will speak at an outdoor ceremony tomorrow at 2:30 P. M. opening Yeshiva University's Dedication Week, to mark the growth of America's first university under Jewish auspices. The ceremony will be held outside the university at West 185th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Five youths accepted the hospitality of a man in Brooklyn yesterday and ended up last night in Queens booked on grand larceny charges for allegedly removing $200 worth of jewelry and a radio from the home of their host.

VIENNA, June 10 -- Julius Raab, leading representative of the industrialists in the Austrian People's party, admitted today he had conducted authorized negotiations with spokesmen of the National Socialists "to broaden the electoral basis of the People's party," as charged yesterday by the Austrian Socialists.
The letter of Elizur Yale Smith in THE TIMES of June 5 seems to me likely to cause confusion, while its political statements are unwarranted.
LONDON, June 10 (Reuters) -- Worcestershire consolidated its English county cricket championship lead today with an unexpected victory, its fifth of the season, by 94 runs over Kent.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The National Military Establishment and the Army moved with almost unprecedented speed today to defend, fully and without reservation, the loyalty, character, and public service of Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

More than 1,000 persons attended the commencement exercises of St. Francis College last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It was the largest class in the ninety-one years of the Butler Street institution. Three honorary degrees and eighty-two bachelor degrees were conferred.

PARIS, June 10 -- Today for the first time Germany was present at the Conference table. When Mr. Vishinsky made the speech he was expected to make at the opening of the Foreign Ministers' Council he launched the opening broadside in the propaganda war.

PARIS, June 10 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky made to the Council of Foreign Ministers today his long expected proposal for a peace treaty with Germany and for withdrawal of the occupying forces from that country.

At least $10,000,000 worth of new business opportunities, as I read them in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 5, is further evidence to me that the current gloom over a possible depression is either imagined or manufactured by some ghouls who really think they can make a killing without getting hurt in the process.

A new picture and a revival constitute today's openings. The new entry is "Saraband," a British production in Technicolor, which will be presented at the Little Carnegie. Stewart Granger and Joan Greenwood are co-starred in this Seventeenth Century romantic drama, and the cast of featured performers includes Francoise Rosay, Flora Robson, Frederick Valk and Peter Bull . . . .

BELFAST, June 10 (AP) -- Harrison Dillard, holder of the world mark for the high hurdles, and Dave Bolen of Colorado scored double victories tonight to lead American track stars to victory at the Royal Ulster Constabulary international meet.
Gifts to the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York totaling $355,000 were announced by the organization's Wine and Spirits Division at a luncheon meeting at the Astor Hotel yesterday.

Defense counsel in the "lonely hearts" murder trial announced yesterday that a plea of insanity would be made in an attempt to save the defendants, Mrs. Martha Jule Beck, 29 years old, and Raymond Martinez Fernandez, 34, from the electric chair. The announcement came as four additional jurors were chosen in the first-degree murder case now before Justice Ferdinand Pecora in Bronx Supreme Court.
FRANKFORT, Germany, June 10 -- Tomorrow is the eighty-fifth birthday of Richard Strauss, often described as the world's greatest living composer.

TEL AVIV, Israel June 10 -- Peace plans seemed to be getting nowhere on all fronts today. The Syrians have declined to discuss the latest proposals for line straightening in the north; the Government House area in Jerusalem is a matter of considerable concern and the Lausanne conference apparently is producing only dissension.

NANKING, June 10 -- The diplomatic corps in Nanking is expected to be heavily pruned by the end of the month in an exodus headed by the Ambassadors of the three major powers still represented here -- United States, Britain and France.

In your issue of June 3 you report the address given by our former Ambassador in Moscow, Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, before the New York State Chamber of Commerce, in which he told his audience that the "Soviet Government was not threatened internally * * * the Russian people have no real understanding of democratic processes, are satisfied politically, and the secret police is much more efficient than it ever was in the Czarist regime."

LONDON, June 10 -- Private Delbert Hill, who deserted from the United States Air Force here during the war for a successful British stage career as the "only lady fire eater in the world" was found guilty of desertion today by a United States Air Force court-martial at the Burtonwod air depot.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Registration statements covering $13,750,000 of bonds and 20,000 shares of preferred stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Japan has been utterly disarmed and this country is resolved to prevent the emergence of the Japanese war-making machine, the State Department announced today.
Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh found yesterday that his inquiry into theatre ticket scalping had led him into the off-lobby activities of the hotel business.

Even the die-hards, who steadfastly had refused to view the situation with the proverbial alarm, yesterday conceded that the Giants are in a slump. For Leo Durocher's lads dropped their fifth straight decision, this one a convincing 6-1 rout by the last-place Pirates at the Polo Grounds, where the home team currently is suffering with its longest losing streak of the season.

As a boy of 8 years, my greatest pleasure used to be calling on grandpa every Sunday morning and having him take me for a ride on the Fifth Avenue bus. During the twenty-five years that followed I have found increasing need for the bus, but diminishing enjoyment.

NEWARK, N. J., June 10 -- Federal Court Judge Guy L. Fake dismissed today a motion by Federal Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods for a temporary restraint to prevent a landlord from proceeding with a county court eviction against a veteran.

Cardinal Spellman accepted last night at a ceremony at Columbus Circle a six-room furnished house and a 1949 automobile, donated to the New York Foundling Hospital as prizes to be given away in the hospital's campaign to raise $200,000.

BOSTON, Mass., June 10 -- Conflicting driver regulations of New York and Pennsylvania create highway hazards, the closing session of the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators was told today.

Southpaw Jerry Greene pitched and batted St. John's Prep of Brooklyn to a 6-2 triumph over St. Ann's Academy of Manhattan in the city final of the Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association baseball championship at Fordham Field yesterday.
MANCHESTER, Vt., June 10 -- New England business men were told bluntly today that they must "wake up buying power" if they hoped to restore confidence in the nation's economy.

Somewhat more than a decade ago the American Medical Association maintained that all was well with American medicine, and that whatever the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care might say there was no need of any health insurance plan. County and state medical societies, integral parts of the national association, were reproved and forced back into line when they disagreed.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) -- The losing streak of the Red Sox swelled to four in a row tonight as the White Sox scored all their runs on two singles, a walk, a hit batsman and Bill Goodman's error to gain a 4 to 2 decision before a crowd of 28,073.

The confirmed withdrawal of Mayor O'Dwyer as a candidate for re-election has greatly altered the political prospects for the November city election. The most obvious change is that whereas with Mr. O'Dwyer as a candidate the Democrats were virtually sure of victory, without him their prospects are on the chancy side.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 10 -- A 100 per cent successful result in the treatment of the highly fatal bulbar type of infantile paralysis was reported today at the closing sessions of the ninety-eighth annual meeting of the American Medical Association by Dr. Thomas G. Galloway and Dr. Martin H. Seifert of Northwestern University Medical School.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 10 -- United Nations staff workers have insisted that their housing division turn down flatly all apartments and homes where "discriminatory" practices are demanded as conditions of renting.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 10 -- President Truman directed Secretary Johnson at a Cabinet meeting in Washington to get at the bottom of the Army action that placed Mr. Clapp under a cloud and barred him from eligibility for an assignment in Germany.
The Toni Harper Concert Revue, featuring Toni Harper, 11-year-old singer, will be presented tonight at 8:45 in Carnegie Hall.

A program sponsored by the entire liquor industry to deal directly with drunken driving and other similar social problems caused by alcohol will be started immediately on a national scale, it was announced here yesterday.

PARIS, June 9 -- Stockings -- printed, embroidered, lace incrusted or sprinkled with rhinestones, especially designed for each gown -- are shown by nine leading couturiers. In collaboration with hosiery makers, at a manikin parade in the salons of the George V Hotel, couturiers demonstrated the charm that stockings with a touch of fantasy, of the individual, can add to a gown.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- American corporations publicly reported dividends aggregating $474,400,000 in April of 1949, 3 per cent more than the $460,000,000 disbursed during April of last year, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce announced today.

Every business man, whether he is running a small-town grocery store or helping run a great corporation, knows that there comes a time when, in order to make profits later on, he must spend money now. A situation somewhat similar in its nature has now arisen in the investment the United States is making in European recovery.

The Dodgers blew two leads to the Reds at Ebbets Field last night, but exploded a six-run rally in the seventh inning, capped by Carl Furillo's third homer of the season, to win, 10 -- 5, and maintain their half-game first-place lead over the champion Braves.

The important job of providing the choreography for the forthcoming "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes," the musical comedy based on Anita Loos' novel of the same name, will be handled by none other than Agnes de Mille, it was learned yesterday.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 10 -- Bulgaria announced tonight that she had sent a note to Yugoslavia demanding the immediate release from imprisonment of ten Bulgarians. The Foreign Ministry, which handed the note to the Yugoslav Legation in Sofia, said it had received information that other Bulgarians had been arrested in Yugoslavia.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 -- At least nineteen officers and business agents of labor unions were put on the state payroll in the administration of former Gov. Dwight H. Green of Illinois. The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported today. The nineteen collected $124,793 in pay, the newspaper said.

Testifying in direct contradiction of the statement by Alger Hiss that he had never seen Whittaker Chambers after Jan. 1, 1937, Mrs. Chambers said yesterday that she and her husband had been invited to a New Year's Eve party in the Hiss home in Washington on Dec. 31, 1937.

NEW DELHI, India, June 10 -- India is considering a new customs agreement with the five French Indian colonies to modify certain regulations that are said to have caused economic hardship to residents of the French holdings, it was understood here today.

"Very considerable progress" was reported last night in the efforts of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to avert a crippling East and Gulf Coast maritime strike when the contracts of three Congress of Industrial Organizations seagoing unions expire on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- The wheat market made a good response today to active buying on the Board of Trade by mills in the forepart of the session today, with some unfavorable reports on crop conditions in the Southwest a factor also but later there was free local selling as well as some hedge pressure, which scaled down the day's gains materially.

SHAWANO, Wis., June 10 -- The wave of post-war -- and particularly, post-OPA -- prosperity that has borne milk prices in this dairy area to record highs in the last three years has receded. This June finds the dairy farmer's milk income cut 34 per cent from last June, while the cost of things he has to buy has come down only an estimated 5 per cent.
ST LOUIS, June 10 -- The decision of the St. Louis Stock Exchange to merge into the new Midwestern Exchange in Chicago has produced a fight within financial circles here, it was learned today.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 10 (UP) -- A gunman robbed a branch bank of $63,504 today, then was captured at near-by La Porte, Ind., thirty-five minutes later.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 10 -- The Czechoslovak Ministry of Education has appointed to Roman Catholic theological seminaries political instructors who will teach compulsory courses that priests must pass to continue their studies or to be graduated.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 10 -- President Truman has again been invited to lay the cornerstone for the United Nations world capital, and is expected to come to New York to take part in ceremonies either in August or on Oct. 24, United Nations Day.
Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices at the close were 6 points higher to 4 points lower.
CLEVELAND, June 10 - Punishment of the parents of juvenile delinquents was strongly opposed today by Judge Paul W. Alexander, one of the country's leading juvenile and domestic judges.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, today attacked the Taft-Hartley act as "setting up a governmental system for the direct and detailed intervention of government in areas of economic activity always heretofore reserved to the parties in the field of industrial relations."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 10 -- On a morning just seven years ago German troops surrounded a village of some 500 poor farmers and coal miners called Lidice near Kladno while S. S. and Gestapo men went to work to annihilate the village and the villagers.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 10 -- A hearing has been postponed on charges that John T. Dunn Jr. of West Hartford, the state Liquor Control Commission chairman, was guilty of misconduct in office.

More will be known about the caliber of the 3-year-olds shortly after 4:40 o'clock this afternoon. At that time, if the starting fee of $750 is paid for each, eight colts of that age will go into the starting gate at Belmont Park for the eighty-first running of the Belmont Stakes, "test of the champion" in the division.
With no rain in the metropolitan area for eleven days to two weeks, commercial crops and private gardens were in danger yesterday of burning up in the early summer sun and drying northwest winds.

The American Airlines, in a letter mailed yesterday to stockholders, reported unaudited results for the first four months of 1949 showing revenues increased to $30,618,000 from $21,252,000 for the corresponding period of last year.

"One of you Is lying." That charge was made to Alger Hiss by a member of the House Committee on Un-American Activities after Mr. Hiss and his accuser, Whittaker Chambers, had testified several times in August, 1948. It still stands unadjudicated.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Roosevelt College of Chicago, one of the few institutions in the land where academic freedom and equality of opportunity are fully practiced as well as preached, will graduate tomorrow the first students who came to it as freshmen.

MONTREAL -- American travelers bound for Europe who are finding trans-atlantic passage hard to get from United States ports during the peak summer tourist season will find ship and airline space from Canada heavily booked by Canadians.

AMHERST, Mass., June 11 -- Amherst went on a hitting spree before 2,500 commencement day fans today and pounded out a 10-1 victory over Williams. The victors thereby finished their Little Three baseball season in a triple tie for first with Willams and Wesleyan.

THE first demonstration by the dance department of the new High School of Performing Arts (which a good many people still do not seem to know is a proud part of the city's public school system) will take place on Thursday evening at 8 in the auditorium of the Straubenmuller Textile High School, 351 West Eighteenth Street.

In retail promotions here last week emphasis was given to canvas and pyroxylin coated luggage, upholstered occasional chairs, men's ties and sports shirts, cotton dresses and sunbacks, cotton goods and mahogany tables, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

ALBANY, N. Y., June 11 -- Making bedlam this afternoon along the capital city waterfront with their explosive putt-putts, over 300 outboards are tuned and adjusted for tomorrow's seventeenth running of the annual 140-mile Hudson River marathon.

I KNOW that naturalists generally reject observations based on domesticated animals. Yet it seems to me that we could often draw some particularly profitable lesson from such observations; for however deformed they may be, such animals are closer to us than wild animals, and, besides, we too are domesticated.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 11 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay and Dr. Ralph J. Bunche will be among nine recipients of honorary degrees at Rutgers University's 183d commencement here tomorrow afternoon, it was announced today by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president.

Wherever slum clearance is needed and urgent, the fact is well known in the area where the slums exist. The stigma is upon the city authorities, and public opinion should be aroused to press them into action for improving such conditions.

The mounting production curtailments in the steel industry are expected to be the keystone of the industry's effort to resist any substantial concessions to labor in the wage negotiations opening in Pittsburgh on Wednesday.

GENEVA, June 11 -- The Industrial Relations Committee of the International Labor Organization conference began debate today on a proposed convention on the right of workers to organize and bargain collectively.

THERE are few volumes on the American Revolution, or any phase of it, written with the insight, freshness and color of this book. Furthermore, with two general exceptions, later discussed, the work stands up well in scholarship.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 11 -- United States Military Government officials in Bavaria, largest food producing state in the United States zone, have initiated a new drive for agricultural land reform based on a direct appeal to big landowners to give up their own properties.

The Giants, their engines apparently still stalled and an adverse tide sweeping them farther and farther from the top, executed an almost miraculous recovery at the Polo Grounds yesterday just as the clock atop the clubhouse was pushing its way past 4:30.

I am interested in the letter of Dr. Benjamin P. Sandler in THE TIMES of May 29 taking me to task for making proposals which he feels are not in accord with the best practices of nutrition. Had Dr. Sandler taken the trouble to refer to the complete article (which had been published at the time of his letter) he would have seen the following footnote:

THE least known, yet one of the most important, places on the globe where American interests are involved today is the picturesque but impoverished and almost unbelievably backward nick of northwest Africa which is known as Tangier.

Tomorrow in Paris the conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers enters upon its fourth week -- and possibly its last. Thus far there has been much talk -- but no sign of a break in the basic deadlock between East and West. Yet the atmosphere has been less tense than at previous conferences of the Foreign Ministers.

FREQUENCY modulation radio station WFDR, operated by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, will be formally opened at 8 P. M. Thursday with a two-hour program originating from Carnegie Hall. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who gave the station permission to use her late husband's initials as call letters, is expected to attend the opening.

Efforts to establish a national monetary commission to study the nation's entire monetary and credit system received an unexpected setback last week when John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, asserted that there was "little benefit to be gained" from such a project.

TOKYO, June 11 -- Eight hours after a peremptory order from Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Headquarters that Japan's striking railmen must resume their jobs, service had not been restored to normal tonight. Some trains were running on all affected Tokyo suburban lines, but the traffic was widely spaced.

UNQUESTIONABLY considerable gratitude is due John Scarne for his exposure of the methods used by dishonest gamblers. He has prevented countless GI's, and presumably many persons other than soldiers, from being cheated at cards and dice. The present volume continues his exposures, and will, one hopes, prove discouraging to card sharks.

IF a business is large it becomes a social unit, full, of internal stresses. If it is very small, it is likely to be uninhibited within but beset by difficulties and dangers without. Both situations are the theme of countless books intended to tell business how to deal with what ails it.
WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The atomic energy investigation faced an uncertain future today as issues of procedure in the inquiring committee's handling of classified data were raised anew.

PARIS offers the tourist the same choice of vacations as any other city in the world; you can live at one of the top-flight luxury hotels and pay top prices, or follow the students to the little hotels near the Sorbonne and spend only 25 to 27 cents a night.

Soviet Russia and the Amtorg Trading Corporation, its American trading agency, have a total of $72,000,000 in gold and dollar credits to their account in the United States, it was disclosed here last week.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- Women's apparel stores in Philadelphia reported sales last week were off 8 per cent from a year ago and 6 per cent for the four weeks ended June 4. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 101,920 as against 133,515 a year ago, decrease of 23.7 per cent, and for this year to date totaled 2,445,816 to compare with 2,751,750 last year, a decrease of 11.1 per cent.

In answer to our Vassar contemporaries (who wrote with reference to J. Anthony Lewis' "Harvard Goes Co-Ed, but Incognito") we Radcliffe undergraduates wish to defend our position in a college world of "distracting influences."

HONOLULU, June 10 -- Some of Hawaii's vast sugar-cane plantations are beginning to stop harvesting operations for lack of storage space for raw sugar as a result of the longshore strike which began in the islands forty days ago.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., June 11 (AP) -- Coaltown flew home 12 lengths in front today in the Roger Williams Handicap at Narragansett Park.

IT was just like old times on sound stage twelve at Warner Brothers. There was James Cagney with a gun in his hand, a scowl on his face and a gang of hoodlums at his heels, snarling "copper" at Federal agent Edmond O'Brien, while director Raoul Walsh, a specialist in slugfests, maneuvered the actors through a scene for "White Heat."

Don Newcombe, upon whose strong right arm Branch Rickey last winter placed a $500,000 price-tag -- give or take a few goldbacks -- pitched the Dodgers to an 11 -- 3 victory over the Reds yesterday at Ebbets Field.

FOLLOWING upon President Truman's warning of some ten days ago that "the frightful slaughter on our streets and highways continues," programs for the protection of both motorists and pedestrians were outlined last week at the Eastern Regional Conference of the Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators in Boston.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 11 -- President Truman threw cold water on a suggestion this morning that he might again be a candidate for the Presidency in 1952.

A TINY masterpiece, isolated from the vast panorama of Mozart's creative life, is placed under the microscope in this unique book. The poem, "Das Veilchen," written by Goethe in 1775 for one of his dramatic works, the Singspiel "Erwin und Elmire," attracted the efforts of a score of composers before Mozart provided it with his musical setting a decade later.

WILLIAM MCDOUGALL, now a newspaper man in Washington, was a young United Press correspondent when his ship was sunk off Java in the Netherlands East Indies in the early days of the war. He made shore safely through what he called 'my private miracle," the theme of a previous book titled "Six Bells Off Java."

DELAWARE, Ohio, June 11 -- The address of former President Herbert Hoover at today's exercises here marking the formal inauguration of Dr. Arthur S. Flemming as ninth president of Ohio Wesleyan University follows:

FREDRIC WERTHAM'S brilliant review in your May 15 issue of Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman," Pulitzer Prize-Book-of-the-Month play, misses the point. The truth brought out by Mr. Miller is that of human inadequacy.
OARSMEN -- like poets who also find their moment of glory in June -- have to be a bit "teched" in the head to put their bodies on the rack for so fleeting and ephemeral rewards as come their way.

THE Shasta Daylight, Southern Pacific's new coach streamliner, will be placed in service on July l0, operating daily between San Francisco and Portland on a fifteen and a half hour schedule over the 718-mile scenic Shasta Route.

NEW DELHI, India, June 11 -- India's Congress party, which completely dominates the Dominion Government under Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and Deputy Prime Minister Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, faces its first serious challenge tomorrow in a South Calcutta by-election for one seat in the West Bengal Provincial Assembly.

MOST of the news that flows out of Japan concerns top-level decisions of the occupation authority, reports on distinguished visitors and such matters. Yet the true impact of American policy is being determined chiefly by the little known Military Government "teams" -- the one American institution in Japan in daily contact with the average citizen.

WHETHER it is a sign of changing times and customs remains for trend spotters to decide, but the idea of mass honeymoons is certainly gaining in popularity. Encouraged by the success of resorts that cater especially to newlyweds, the Canadian Pacific Railway plans to send its first "Honeymoon Special" out of Oakland, Calif., on June 25.

NEW sets, lights and props -- $250,000 worth -- are in the works for Shubert Alley. By October only the characters of the Alley's daily drama will be recognizable. For the first time since the Alley replaced a couple of brownstone houses thirty-seven years ago, it will be as glittering as the rest of Times Square's real estate productions.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- Dr. Condon demanded tonight a "personal apology" from J. Edgar Hoover, FBI chief, for "smearing" his wife in the FBI report.

TROY, N. Y., June 11 -- Scoring six times in the final period, the Southern All-Stars powered their way to their first victory since 1943 with an 11 -- 6 decision over the North All-Stars in college lacrosse's eighth renewal of the classic before 5,000 sun-drenched fans.
HERE is a fine combination of adventure and suspense -- the kind of suspense which sets you to wondering not why something happened or who caused it to happen but what happens next.

ORIENTAL poppies are now furnishing a brilliant splash of color in the garden. But many gardeners fail to benefit from the decorative value of these blooms in the house. They make gorgeous cut flowers that will last, once the knack of preserving them is learned.

TRIESTE, June 11 -- Trieste will vote tomorrow ostensibly in communal elections but actually on the deeper political issue of communism versus anti-communism or East against West, as Italians here say.

"SWORD IN THE DESERT," the first picture to be made in Hollywood about the struggles in Palestine, has gone to the cutting rooms at Universal-International after fifty days of production travail and an expenditure of more than $1,000,000.

PARIS, June 11 -- The United States-French bridge challenge match ended today with the American team of John Crawford, Peter Leventritt, Samuel Stayman and George Rapee winning by the comfortable margin of 2,700 points.

BOSTON, June 11 -- Retail trade in New England is making a poorer showing in comparison with the corresponding period of 1948 than at any time since before Easter. Department store sales in Boston, however, still are better than for the country as a whole relative to a year ago.

A general wage increase of 1.56 per cent monthly and other benefits were awarded yesterday to tanker engineers of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, by Frederick R. Livingston, arbitrator, giving the tanker men parity in wages with dry cargo engineers.

Why is there delay on the genocide convention? Why the pigeonholing of one of the most widely approved, most inspiring documents to come out of the United Nations since its birth? Why, above all, does our Government allow the treaty to gather dust instead of signatures?

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 11 (AP) -- Eleven companies have formed a new corporation to supply underdeveloped Latin-American countries with machine tools. It will be known as Amertool Services, Inc. Temporary headquarters will be in Cincinnati.

ONE of the most thorough of the many books of golf instruction to come out this year is "Short Cuts to Better Golf" by Johnny Revolta and Charles B. Cleveland. Revolta, who has given more than 13,000 lessons and who helped Ellsworth Vines make the jump from tennis to golf and showed Frank Stranahan how to slice the ball around a tree, has leaned lightly on illustrations and heavily on text.

MR. SMITH dedicates his book to the free Russia which is to come, and later states his thesis more explicitly: "The government is rotten but the people are wonderful. Czars and Stalins come and go, but the Russian people live on."
Edwin B. George, economist and assistant to the president, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., has been elected president of the Institute of Trade and Commerce Professions, Inc.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 11 -- Roger Bannister of the invaders caught the eye with a strikingly impressive 4:11.1 mile, but Americans set the only two meet records as the combined Princeton-Cornell squad downed Oxford-Cambridge, 9 -- 4, on a count of first places, in the post-war resumption of a colorful international track and field fixture today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 -- Business was told today by Thomas G. Spates, vice president of the General Foods Corporation, to compete with Government and labor for leadership in a "welfare" economy on the basis of a proposition that "every one of the millions of people on payrolls is entitled to be treated like a human being."

JOHN ENGLAND was an Irish priest who became the first Bishop of Charleston, S. C., 1820-1842. He was an interesting character, humane, energetic and original. Full of ideas, he was an innovator and a controversialist. He therefore got on poorly with his colleagues and superiors.

FIFTY years ago when John L. Stoddard's fifteen volumes of "Lectures" on the bookshelves stamped a household as worldly wise, America didn't demand much from professional travelers. Between Stoddard and Nicol Smith the business of traveling for a living has become much tougher.

CHRISTOPHER DAWSON'S 1947 Gifford Lectures, delivered at the University of Edinburgh, present a closely reasoned study of the nature of religion and culture and their interrelations. Like A. J. Toynhee, T. S. Eliot, Paul Tillich and Emil Brunner, he recognizes this as the major problem confronting contemporary civilization.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, has appropriated $100,000 to be used in helping to organize all telephone workers in the United States into "one great international union."

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 11 -- A four-point proposal designed to break the six-week deadlock in the Palestine Conciliation Commission's work was submitted today by the Israeli delegation. Although the commission had scheduled another meeting with the Israelis on Monday, the initial reaction of the French and Turkish members amounted to a rejection of the proposals.
The Rev. Dr. Luman J. Shafer, secretary for Japan, China, and Africa of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Church in America, will leave here for Seattle on Tuesday, en route to Japan.

WEEKLY sailings to Nova Scotia and Newfoundland have been scheduled for the summer by the Furness Red Cross Line. The twelve-day cruise will leave Piers 95, 96 and 97, North River, at 9:30 A. M. each Saturday through Sept. 24.

The 117th commencement season will open formally today at New York University with the baccalaureate service at 4 P. M. in the Gould Memorial Library chapel, Hall of Fame campus, 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP) -- The Cardinals broke the Phillies' winning streak at four contests and raised their string of triumphs to fifteen in the last eighteen games as they defeated the Phils, 6 -- 2, today in the second game of the series.
BUENOS AIRES, June 11 -- The generally dark outlook for American business in Argentina is especially black for the motion picture industry, film men indicated this week.

For the first time since the end of the war, both manufacturers and distributors of industrial products are now offering "downward escalator clauses" as an inducement to purchasing agents to place immediate orders. Similar offers have been made in both Eastern and Midwestern industrial areas.

It has been pointed out that our clash with the Soviet Union involves two basically different concepts of the character of the state. There is a deadlock in Paris over the future of Germany because in insisting that a German government be freely elected we offer our support to government by consent.

PARIS, June 11 -- For the first time since the war France consumed gasoline this week with no restriction other than that imposed by the price. The price differs according to the class of users and represents a compromise that, incidentally, saved the Government considerable embarrassment, if not an adverse vote, in the National Assembly.

BILLY'S adventure with the bear is just the kind that a small boy dreams up for himself on a lazy summer afternoon. Its setting is a friendly small town where Billy is spending his vacation. He has, with Grandma's aid, set up a candy stand on Main Street so that he can earn money to buy a bicycle.

Robert Burns, the Scottish poet, was honored yesterday on the Mall in Central Park when the Robert Burns Memorial Association of America held its twenty-third annual parade and commemorative exercises before a crowd of 750 persons.

Would you please correct the statement in Gertrude Samuels' article, "American Traitors: A Study in Motives," that Elizabeth Bentley was educated at Bennington College? Miss Bentley was at no time enrolled at Bennington.
Sales in New York department stores last week were down approximately 7 per cent in a continuation of the declining dollar volume trend apparent since the beginning of the year.

CRIME has been and is a fascinating subject for examination and inquiry. Richard Harrison is a lecturer for the Cambridge University Board of Extramural Studies, and during the war worked for Military Intelligence in England.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A Washing machine that squeezes by air pressure the water out of the clothes while still in the washer, just awarded a Government patent, is said by the inventor to be economical, simple, safe and efficient in use, and to remove more of the water than other types of machines.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 11 -- The Government announced today that it had broken off trade negotiations with Yugoslavia and ceased all deliveries of goods to the Yugoslavs.

THE average stamp collector who has paid relatively scant attention to air letter sheets and cards may be surprised to learn that to date forty-three governments have released approximately 200 major and minor varieties of this form of postal stationery.

The Octet in F, Op. 166, by Franz Schubert is a long work. Its six movements take almost an hour to play, and in Decca's fine recording by the Vienna Octet the composition requires an album of six twelve-inch disks.

THE experience of driving across the continent with two young children may not be on your program this summer. Little did we expect to find it a concern of ours until asked what to do to relieve the monotony of long days of motoring for a boy of 2 and a girl of 4.

PARIS, June 11 -- Mark F. Ethridge, retiring chairman of United States delegation to the Lausanne conference where the United Nations Conciliation Commission, a three power agency, is seeking to arrange a settlement of the Palestine question, reported to Secretary of State Dean Acheson today that the negotiations were at a stalemate.

FOR some time now this department has not touched on one of its favorite topics: words. Words, as a subject for talk or written comment, are almost on a par with the weather in their universality of appeal. We all use them, poorly or well, and for good or ill; and even the least articulate among us have some interest in them.

IN circles that are supposed to know, the talk is that the fall season should see several additional railroads following the lead of the New Haven, which last week ran its fourth "show train," this one to "As the Girls Go." The success of the New Haven has brought interest from the other lines and it's understood that they've had representatives on the trips studying methods and techniques.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 11 -- The battle of Yugoslavia between Yugoslav Communist leaders and the Soviet Union is being fought out and will be resolved in such basic industries as the famous Trepcha lead mines in South Serbia, which this correspondent has just visited.

MOST people would agree that it would be a rare and unusual privilege for an ordinary man to be allowed to watch a great literary stylist engaged in composition. Yet thanks to the motion pictures and radio, that privilege has been granted to countless millions in the world today.

Two collegians, Stan Lampert of N. Y. U. and Jim Fuchs of Yale, who have been creating quite a stir with their feats in the shot put, took over the spotlight yesterday at the fifty-ninth Metropolitan A. A. U. senior track and field championships on Randalls Island.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The name of a man now a suicide was added today to the long list of people mentioned in Federal Bureau of Investigation "data" slips that have been read at Judith Coplon's espionage trial.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va. -- The carefully preserved decorum of this 250-year-old town is somewhat ruffled these days as busy workmen put the finishing touches to the latest exhibition unit, which will be opened on July 4 as a new part of Colonial Williamsburg.

Political developments in Europe might have been quite different and -- perhaps -- World War II been avoided had the men who were then in charge of foreign affairs appreciated to its real value the importance of Austria as the keystone of European equilibrium.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 11 (AP) -- The United States Junior Chamber of Commerce came out today against "any veteran pension system which is based solely on previous service to our country."
Following is the text of President Truman's address at Little Rock, Ark., as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Financial markets were jolted early last week by a burst of selling on the New York Stock Exchange which sent prices tumbling to the lowest levels since May, 1947. Uncertainty and confusion surrounding both domestic and foreign affairs, coupled with declines in statistical indices and a bleak outlook for early reconciliation of labor-management difficulties, only served to heighten the gloomy atmosphere of Wall Street.

LONDON, June 11 -- Hungary swept in to the semi-final round of the European Davis Cup tennis today when it completed a 5-0 rout of Switzerland, while the favored Czechslovak team fell behind by 2-0 in its quarter-final match with France.

With unemployment increasing and domestic business activity continuing to show a steady decline, demands for the levying of higher import duties on many items to hold at least the local markets may be expected to grow.
GLASGOW, June 11 (AP) -- American Athletes bettered four Scottish track and field records and equaled another at an international meet today. A crowd of 50,000 attended.

SHORTLY after Murray Rossler's death is declared suicide by Sergeant Senstrom of the police department, Janet, Murray's wife, goes away from their beautiful old house in Charleston to travel and try to forget. She returns after an unhappy year -- and finds a dead man in the room in which her husband had died a year earlier.

Lower prices were evident in openings of fall lines of coats, suits, dresses and sportswear in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office. Many out-of-town buyers attended the first phase of the openings, but the greatest number of buyers is expected this week.

THE fall buying season which got under way last week in wholesale markets here shaped up as "a slow start but better than expected." Retail buying representatives are shopping values thoroughly and nevertheless express satisfaction for the most part with the readjustment of price lines to brackets which ought to bring improved consumer response.

LOS ANGELES, June 11 -- Figures released this week by the State Chamber of Commerce disclosed that farmers, factories and general business firms made more money in 1948 than in many years. New construction for last year was given as $1,099,703,000.

"BORN YESTERDAY," Garson Kanin's Broadway comedy which Columbia bought in 1947 for a million dollars (to be paid at the rate of $100,000 a year for ten years), has become something of a problem to the studio because the investment it represents must be recouped in the face of a declining box-office.
The name of Richard Savitt of Orange, N. J., and Cornell University yesterday was added to the long list of winners of the Brooklyn championship tennis trophy.

THE eighth annual award of the Music Critics' Circle of New York was made only in the field of orchestral music, the prize work being Norman Dello Joio's "Variations, Chaconne and Finale." No award was made in the category of dramatic music as none heard during the year was considered worthy.

THE United States - Canada air-transport agreement, announced suddenly and simultaneously in Ottawa and Washington last week, has been received by the air carriers of this country with widespread disapproval.

MOST gardeners at some time think about building a waterlily pool. This applies to the city or penthouse gardener, as well as to the acre-or-two property owner in the country. Actually, the construction of such a pool is fairly simple. And, once finished, so is the gardening itself, for it entails no weeding or watering.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 11 (AP) -- A young atomic scientist, accused of recruiting for the Communist party, has left his job as Associate Professor of Physics at Fisk University.

OMAHA, June 11 -- The price position of American farmers looks fairly comfortable as the halfway mark of 1949 approaches and as Democratic leaders gather in Des Moines, Iowa, to woo the vital farm vote for 1950.

THIS month a new crop of women college graduates, diplomas in hand, start off on the road from campus to career; this month, too, another group of college women return to the campus at a time marking a significant milestone in their lives -- their fifteenth class reunion.

Their book is a kind of personal by-product of their story, for by profession Miss Marriott is an ethnologist and Miss Lefranc a painter.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Upholsterers International Union, AFL, has called on Government officials to challenge the non-Communist affidavit of Max Perlow, secretary-treasurer of the United Furniture Workers of America, CIO, who announced he had resigned from the Communist party and would file an affidavit so his union could use facilities of the National Labor Relations Board.

America can and will do business with the new People's Government in China, according to George Killion, president of the American President Lines, who returned to the United States last week from a six weeks' business survey tour of the Far East.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico -- The Spanish conquerors used Guadalajara as a base for exploration and discovery four centuries ago, and modern tourists can profit by their example. In its beauty, variety and attractive modernism, and in its nearness to places of natural and historical interest, Mexico's second largest city is almost a match for the capital itself.

NEW ENGLAND hillsides are pink with blossoms of mountain laurel this weekend. Perhaps the delicate charm of these evergreen shrubs in bloom is partly forgotten between one season and the next. But, for some reason, clusters of bloom seem to be rosier and more abundant this June than they have been for many years.
THOUGH the New Look has by now become a generally accepted part of our daily lives, it is still creating a good deal of trouble for the people who prepare the costumes for television programs.
FOREST PARK, Pa., June 11 -- In a departure from previous union policy, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, voted today to install a system of political shop stewards.
Led by a 7-year-old "queen" and a 6-year-old "king," the Horton Center of the Police Athletic League, 12 West 108th Street, yesterday held its first annual "June Walk."

A YEAR ago the big question in television was: What is the future of the new medium? Today the question is: What is the future of those who look at television? How will it change their lives and habits? What effect will it have on their children?

JAMES JOYCE, in the person of Stephen Daedalus, made a now famous distinction between static and kinetic art. Great art is static in its effects: it exists in itself, it demands nothing beyond itself. Kinetic art exists in order to demand: not self-contained, it requires either loathing or desire to achieve its function.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 11 (AP) -- Robed and hooded night riders dragged a 42-year-old white woman from her home last night, and in the eerie light of a burning six-foot cross threatened to burn her at a stake.

AS far back as evidence can be traced -- some 3,500 years -- perfumes have been based on the scent of plants. Yet, the matter of fragrance is often overlooked in making selections for the garden. It is true that some of our plants have no scent, but there are others which combine beauty of flower and other desirable qualities with the added attraction of a delightful perfume.

I believe that an impression which may have been created by your editorial of June 7, "A Civil Rights Bill," should be corrected. The editorial states that "the measure follows the recommendations made some months ago by the President's Committee on Civil Rights" and adds: "As the President's committee noted, the constitutionality of some parts of the measure now recommended has been questioned."

THE suspicion has been growing for some time that there are people who actually write the copy on the flaps of book jackets. Let me make a clean breast of it straight off. For a number of years I was a book blurbist.

BOSTON, June 11 (AP) -- The lowly Cubs pounded Vernon Bickford for 11 of their 15 hits to break his five-game winning streak today with a 5-2 decision over the Braves. Boston fell to third place, three percentage points behind the Cards, as a result.

Last March a "junior officer" of the United States Military Government in Germany decided that Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, was "unemployable" as a temporary lecturer "on personnel practices in creation of a sound German civil service." What was in this officer's mind is unknown.

THE announcements for the thirty-second season of the Stadium Concerts are exceptionally interesting. The season begins June 20 and continues for the customary eight weeks, into August. The performances will have the great advantage of the new, modern and thoroughly equipped stage which, thanks to Mayor O'Dwyer and his administration, has been built for the Stadium Concerts and for other public purposes of the Lewisohn Stadium by the city.

GLASGOW, June 11 -- The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, guardian of Britain's golfing morals, today announced a tightening of its amateur rules which prohibited the payment of expenses to simon-pures, effective July 1.

ONLY within the past few decades has the study and treatment of allergy become one of the more important branches of medicine. In addition to the familiar hives, hay fever and asthma, more and more conditions have been shown to have an allergic basis until, as Dr. Swartz notes, at one time or another, one person in every two suffers from some sort of allergy.

CANTON, China, June 11 (UP) -- Nationalist China's Central Political Council formed a supreme policy committee today headed by Generalissimo Chiang Kai - shek. The council also approved the new Nationalist Cabinet under Marshal Yen Hsi-shan.
The largest graduating class in the history of City College, 3,719 students, will receive degrees Thursday evening at Lewisohn Stadium at the 103d commencement exercises.

LIKE uncounted others over the country, the young people in Mr. Stavis' new novel could do with a larger apartment. But there is none to be had for luck and money -- at least not for the money Johnny and Emily Singleton have.
ALTHOUGH most of television's regularly sponsored programs will be off for the summer, television set owners still will find a varied fare available.
Brooklyn College will award degrees this evening to 2,210 candidates of the largest graduating class in the institution's history.

HONOLULU, June 11 (AP) -- Striking CIO stevedores made a conditional offer today to unload feed and food from strikebound ships in Hawaii and to let the passenger liner Lurline resume sailings.

BLACK - AND- WHITE originals may be converted into full-color prints by the Kodak Flexichrome Process, which was introduced by Eastman here last week. The technique, which was demonstrated in a motion picture film and a display of prints made by this process, employs color dyes applied to the print with water-color brushes.

LIKE the author's "Denmark Caravan," written several years ago, this is an informal travel book in which young people go off on an interesting journey. Ken and Donnie were dreaming of pirates and lost treasure when their freighter left New York for a voyage among the Caribbean islands.

RIFLE, Col. -- With the coming of the motoring season, the United States Bureau of Mines has hung out the welcome sign at its experimental oil shale development mine and plant on the craggy western slopes of the Colorado Rockies.

The last in the series of evening recorded concerts presented by the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, since last fall, will be held at 8:15 P. M. Wednesday in Room 213. Liturgical music will be heard, among the selections being da Palestrina's "Missa papae Marcelli," sung by the Singers of St. Eustache, and "De Profundis," a psalm for soli, chorus and orchestra by de Lalande.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 -- Horse racing burgeoned into a major public issue here this week.
The beer strike that cost millions of dollars and brought a flood of bottled brews from out-of-town to the metropolitan area was settled late yesterday afternoon on its seventy-second day.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., June 10 (UP) -- The South's educators formally pooled their higher education in specialized fields today in an interstate plan called the Southern Regional Education Program.
The Preakness champion beat the Kentucky Derby champion in the eighty-first running of the Belmont Stakes at sunny, humid Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UP) -- Coal industry sources today predicted that John L. Lewis would soon open a "third front" in contract negotiations between his United Mine Workers and the soft-coal operators.

The fire-fighting personnel of Engine Company 74 and Hook and Ladder 25 -- holding adjoining quarters in the three-story building at 205 West Seventy-seventh Street -- reluctantly marked one down for the record at 12:36 P. M. yesterday.

The appointment of Gordon Gray, who was an Army private in 1942, as Secretary of the Army -- a military version of the American "rags-to-riches" saga -- opens a new chapter in the long and often bitter history of the Army's "civilian components."

BERLIN, Sunday, June 12 -- The railroad strike, which has blocked rail traffic to Berlin for three weeks, appeared to be close to a settlement early this morning. This development followed a conference between Brig. Gen. Frank L. Howley, United States commandant in Berlin, and Soviet transport officials.

The American Optical Company will adopt a new policy of publicizing views adverse to management as well as those favorable to it in its house magazine space devoted to informing employes on economic issues, H. S. Woodbridge, industrial and public relations director, disclosed last week.

Since the end of the war the educational profession of this country has been faced with the question of what role teachers can play in making the peace lasting and effective. The "cold war" and the battle of ideologies now taking place have placed heavy burdens on the teachers. It is important to know just what American youth should be taught in these critical days of international tension.
A substantial reduction in commission charges for the short-term investor, or speculator, is expected to go into effect on the New York Stock Exchange next fall, it was learned yesterday.

The National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, 1790 Broadway, needs more than $100,000 in addition to its regular income to carry out its 1949 budget, Mason H. Bigelow, president of the organization, said in a report on the first forty years of the society, made public yesterday.

AT first glance the house pictured above may not seem to be radically different from dozens of other contemporary houses built during the past decade. It was designed by Paul Beidler for Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rose, in Easton, Pa., and it scores high on all the points that make any kind of house a satisfactory home for its owners -- careful orientation, pleasing lines, and a plan that works.

STANTON, Del., June 11 (AP) -- Greentree Stable's Wine List led from wire to wire today in the 11th running of the $25,000 added Kent Stakes for 3-year-olds in 1:424-5, one-fifth of a second slower than the Delaware Park record for one mile and a sixteenth.

CLEVELAND, June 11 -- The once proud name of Rapid Robert Feller was hammered into the dust at expansive Municipal Stadium today by the rampant Yankees before a ladies' day gathering of 61,523 of his worshipers.

"This job of mine is great," he resumed.

Contrary to popular belief, postwar corporate profits have been exceptionally low when compared to previous years of high peacetime production and full employment, according to an analysis published by the Machinery and Allied Products Institute, spokesman for American capital goods manufacturers.

A LOYAL parishioner of this column has raised a critical point with respect to an "obvious error" which he finds that this reviewer "consistently repeats." That is the "error" of "comparing" a film which is based upon a play or a novel with the original and "condemning it if it doesn't shape up."

LIKE so many humorists, H. Allen Smith, author of a number of funny books including "Low Man on a Totem Pole," and now co-author of a baseball book, "Low and Inside," is a pretty morose fellow. In appearance, he resembles Fred Allen (a handsomer version) and looks just as dour and melancholy.

Opening of fall lines last week drew thousands of buyers to New York's wholesale markets in what promises to be an intensive shopping tour for women's apparel. The coming week will bring an even greater influx of merchandise men and women, it was predicted in the trade, with buying activity continuing briskly until the end of the month.

EXCEPT for Frank Harris, I suppose, no serious writer of our time has been as much maligned as Ford Madox Ford. Ford moves through the literary memoirs of the last twenty years, almost always in the same role -- an untrustworthy reporter of facts, a liar, and a boaster.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 11 -- Favored by a fine southwest breeze, a clear overhead and a litle jump of water, the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today held its first regatta of the season for the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association craft. There were 99 of them. It also was the farthest east they had been this year.

THE author of that fine novel, "The Garretson Chronicle," now offers his public a lighter-than-air commedia dell'arte, complete with a mysterious island, a cast whose resemblance to the people of a certain famous comedy is not accidental, social comment that (on occasion) comes off brilliantly -- and a romance that never fails to charm, even in its more lyric moments.
Next Tuesday will be Flag Day, the 172nd anniversary of Congress' adoption of the American Flag. Several observances win take place in the city on that day and today.

Department stores and other large television retailers have adopted a hand-to-mouth buying policy on television receivers, buyers disclosed last week. They said manufacturer and distributor refusal to grant rebates on inventories in the face of "almost daily" list price reductions leaves them no other course to pursue.

LONDON, June 11 -- George Isaacs, Minister of Labor, threw the weight of the Government into the troubled labor situation tonight with a broadcast appeal to unofficial strikers on the nationalized railways and docks to go back to work.

HARRISON, N. Y., June 11 -- Miss Jean M. Cochrane of Westport, Conn., rode her bay gelding, My Chance, to a big lead in the working hunter division of the Greenwich Horse Show in the second part of the three-day program at the Blind Brook Polo Club grounds today.

THE subject of "the freedom of radio" has come to the fore again as the result of the Federal Communications Commission's "report" deciding that a station can editorialize on the air in its own name. A broadcaster now is free to make known his personal views on current issues providing he satisfies the commission that his station as a whole maintains "a reasonably balanced presentation of all responsible viewpoints."

THIS distinguished volume lifts a current subject from the hot sands of political controversy to the cooler atmosphere of history and philosophy. About two years ago the New York Academy of Medicine brought together a notable group of physicians, public health administrators, psychiatric social workers and social scientists in the symposium reported in this book.
JERUSALEM, June 11 -- Jerusalem gradually is returning to normal, although there still is a lot to be done before it can fully recover its charm and vitality of pre-war days.
