Endorsement of most of the International Trade Organization charter was announced in Washington yesterday by the Committee for Economic Development. It was the group's seventeenth national policy statement.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat, of Tennessee, has asked Cordon Gray, Secretary of the Army, to appear before a special Armed Services subcommittee on Tuesday to explain the Army's admitted error of finding Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, "unemployable" for an assignment in Germany.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 11 -- Pageantry rivalling that of a three-ring circus was the order of the day as nearly 5,000 Princeton alumni staged the climax of their reunion week-end this afternoon with traditional "P-Rade" antics.

PETER, who is spending the summer on his uncle's ranch in Utah, dreams of owning a pinto called Checkers. How this dream comes true forms the narrative of the Buffs' book. They tell also of how, in spite of his being a city boy, Peter quickly adapts himself to ranch life and of how he displays courage in time of a crisis.

THE next best thing to owning an island is to visit one. Or better still, to visit a series of islands, something that was formerly harder to do than at present. Now planes and fast steamers have connected up dozens of them -- from atolls covered with strange jungles to isles with calypso singers and paved roads.

CLEVELAND, June 11 -- An organization known as the Opera Television Theatre, which is headed by Lawrence Tibbett and Henry Souvaine, producer of the Saturday afternoon Metropolitan Opera broadcasts, plans to stage operatic productions exclusively for the television audience, Mr. Tibbett revealed today. The noted baritone is here for a "pop" concert given in Public Hall tonight.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 11 -- The Puerto Rican Transportation Authority today tightened regulations on nonscheduled airlines, hoping to prevent repetition of the tragic crash Tuesday in which fifty-three persons lost their lives.

THE local yachting and powerboat season opens formally1 today with the running of the annual Outboard Marathon on the Hudson River from Albany to New York City. And from the list of races which have been scheduled between now and mid-September, it is evident that boating fans along this section of the East Coast are in for a busy summer.

THE play of a bridge hand can be planned in either of two ways: by counting its winning tricks, or by counting its losing tricks. Since there are precisely thirteen tricks to be won and lost, it would seem that these methods must come to the same thing; that if you have three tricks to lose, you must be able to win ten, and so on.

MEXICO CITY, June 5 -- Oil prospecting in the Isthmus of Tehuantepec and a recent international convention of civil engineers here have revived serious consideration of building a canal across Mexico's narrowest span to connect the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.

SIXTY per cent of the ducklings savored in America come from a surprisingly small area on Long Island. Is it because the land is low and water near that the district has become headquarters for raising the amphibious birds?

Approbation is certainly due Caroline K. Simon for her straightforward article, "Causes and Cure of Discrimination." As most Americans have finally realized (or must come eventually to understand), people are born free of both fears and prejudices and learn to hate other humans only through the influence of narrow-minded relatives or friends.

As one who has passed his six months' probationary period in California and so earned the title of "Native" I would like to point out what we here would consider a glaring error in Cabell Phillips' "The War for Water in the American Desert."

MORE evidence of the mysterious decline of the American Literary Female, noted here with fraternal alarm on several occasions, comes to hand with the news of the 1949 winner of the Dodd, Mead Intercollegiate Literary Fellowship.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- A young man who chose to become a golf professional two years ago instead of practicing dentistry won the United States open title over the rugged Medinah Country Club's No. 3 course today.
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WESTFIELD, N. J., June 11 -- Defending champion Joe McBride of Arcola moved into the final of the New Jersey State amateur golf championship today by defeating Bobby Jacobson of Hollywood, 4 and 2. His opponent in tomorrow's 36-hole final at the Echo Lake Country Club will be J. Wolcott Brown of Manasquan River, champion in 1928 and 1934, who trounced Homer O. Lichtenwalter Jr. of Baltusrol, 6 and 5.

MR. BAER'S protagonists in his first novel are a man and his fear, and so closely entwined are the two that the second drives the first to destruction. He has kept his tale framed rigidly between its murky beginnings in a seacoast town and its bloody conclusion in tropical Panama; between those points he has drawn a Walpurgisnacht of suffering and flight and of physical and mental suffocation.

THE tractor which decorates the jacket of this attractive little volume is shown being hoisted off-ship to land in Israel. From there the tractor is driven to a cooperative farm settlement, or Kvutza, where it helps willing workers to convert a barren hillside into fertile fields.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- That the nation's economy in many of its parts is somewhat out of whack is not disputed in any responsible quarter in Washington today. Whether to call it "disinflation," "recession," "depression" or, perhaps, "just a healthy readjustment" is largely a matter of semantics.

BOSTON, June 11 -- A gift of $1,000,000 from Alfred P. Sloan Jr. for a metals-processing laboratory topped the $5,100,000 in contributions announced tonight by President James R. Killian Jr. of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Britain's Labor party last week held its forty-eighth annual party conference. It met at Blackpool, England -- a "Coney Island on the Irish Sea," the chief summer resort of industrial Lancashire and Yorkshire. While the conference was in session in Blackpool's huge Empress Ballroom, an English revue called "Mid-summer Madness" and a touring company of "Annie Get Your Gun" played at near-by theatres.

SAN REMO -- That international dream -- a little place on the Mediterranean, beautiful, away from it all and dirt cheap -- is getting a bit hard to track down these days. But because of the restrictions on British travel today, it can for the moment be found along the Italian Riviera.

A powerful electron gun sterilizes food without cooking it or altering its flavor by firing invisible bullets directly at the reproductive mechanism of bacteria and viruses. The machine is called a "capacitron." It generates 3,000,000 volts, but each blast of electrons lasts a mere thousandth of a second.
YOU take about eighty musicians, a conductor and a deficit, and you have the making of a symphony orchestra. If you doubt it, ask Fort Wayne, Ind.

AFTER acting in "A Streetcar Named Desire" since Dec. 3, 1947, Jessica Tandy, Marlon Brando and Kim Hunter have withdrawn from the cast. No one can blame them, especially Miss Tandy. The only wonder is that she had the physical and nervous strength to play the part of Blanche du Bois for nearly a year and a half.

ALBERT GUERARD Jr. in review of Philip Wylie's "Opus 21" misses some important facts in his devastating judgment of a highly entertaining and amusing book. It is so, it seems, because certain people don't like to hear truths even if presented in the most extravagant and unique form.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 11 -- Guy Lombardo flew a lot of airplane miles over Adirondack mountain peaks and across New England valleys in the pre-dawn darkness today and again at noon, but the main purpose of coming to Lake Placid was defeated.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The unidentified writer of "scare letters" to the nation's prospective women school teachers apparently has given up the campaign. The flow of letters which reached a peak this spring has stopped, according to Belmont Farley, press relations director for the National Education Association.

BECAUSE visual training is so neglected in America, many people are denied understanding and enjoyment of art. But perhaps a graver consequence of this denial is that taste in matters remote from art, with a capital A, is also underdeveloped.

CLEVELAND, June 11 -- The money spent by state governments on institutions for the care of children committed by courts is in large part wasted because there are so few programs for after-care, it was charged today by Clinton W. Areson, superintendent of the State Agricultural and Industrial School, at Industry, New York.
ROME, June 11 -- An American tourist who landed in Naples shortly after the end of the war asked his porter on the way down the gangplank how things were going in Italy.
With little more than half of the calendar year to go, retailers here last week estimated that total profits for 1949 will be off as much as 40 per cent, compared with last year.

Although I was happy to see you so splendidly honor Frank Lloyd Wright on his eightieth birthday, my civic and esthetic pride were hurt that you neglected illustrating his recent job in San Francisco. It is the remodeling of the C. V. Morris store, which sells silver, china and glassware.

VIENNA, June 11 -- Accusations by the Czechoslovak Government that Yugoslavia had been trying to drain Czechoslovakia of valuable exports and refusing to give trade value in return echo a charge made by Deputy Premier Matyas Rakosi of Hungary. They are believed here to herald a general embargo on trade with Yugoslavia by Soviet satellites.

MOSCOW, June 11 -- One single event has dominated the Soviet press this week, relegating all other news to secondary positions and on several days almost causing it to disappear from the papers. This event is the 150th anniversary of the birth of Russia's great poet, Alexander Sergeivich Pushkin.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, spoke out today in favor of Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, and against any "arbitrary" cuts in ECA funds that might make the European Recovery Program "useless" and lessen the chances of peace.

THESE twenty-three stories vary in length, place, amount of suspense and activity. A few are quiet glimpses into the childhood of famous people, incidents which point to the kind of fame which will be achieved. Some are about encounters between fictional characters and real people -- Audubon, Johnny Appleseed, Edgar Allan Poe.

High above Manhattan, on the thirteenth floor of the United States Court House in Foley Square, a pair of walnut-paneled doors bearing a neat blue marker -- "Room 1306, Judge Kaufman" -- open each weekday morning on the strange and compelling drama of Chambers vs. Hiss.
DETROIT, June 11 (AP) -- The Washington Senators literally stole a ball game from the Detroit Tigers today as the Senators posted a 9-8 victory after being seven runs behind in the sixth inning.

MR. MOONEY proved his point -- and then some! In his letter in THE TIMES last Sunday he gives us a breakdown of nine movies which he saw in three days, and reports that two were excellent, a third was pretty darn good, and a fourth provided some entertainment.

We have lost one of the most valiant of our contemporaries in the death of Sigrid Undset. The world somehow feels a poorer place today, morally as well as artistically, because of her passing. She had so fully typified for us the good things that we expect from Norway that we have lost a symbol that we honored and enjoyed.

CAIRO, June 11 -- The extent to which terorism has developed in Egypt has been described in detail by Premier Ibrahim Abdul Hadi's Saadist party through its official party organ in a review of the raids made upon whole sections of Cairo, Alexandria and various sections of the country by the police.

Friends of Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora moved yesterday to get support to put him forward as a compromise candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, and met with a good deal of success.

Cary Middlecoff of Memphis took the national open title with a seventy-two-hole total of 286, two over par, at Medinah in Chicago, yesterday. Sam Snead and Clayton Heafner shared second place, one stroke back, both missing good chances to tie the leader in the closing stages.

FOR the benefit of souvenir-collecting Americans, homeward bound after vacations abroad, the Treasury Department has prepared a useful pamphlet entitled "Customs Hints for Persons Entering the United States."

RANGOON, Burma, June 11 (AP) -- Communists and PVO-dissident forces fled in full retreat across the Irrawaddy River tonight from Yenangyaung, Burma's biggest oil town, with Government troops in hot pursuit.

HOBOKEN, N. J., June 11 -- Engineers invite disaster when they decide to leave politics to politicians, Charles Edison, former Governor of New Jersey, told the graduating class of Stevens Institute of Technology at commencement exercises here today.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, June 11 -- Declining livestock prices and rising bitterness between stockmen and Federal forest officials loomed large in Western minds this week.

Max Beloff in "It Is the System, Not the Men, in Russia," touches upon the controversial subject of the Soviet purges. Noting that such qualities as "revolutionary audacity" are currently held in diminishing esteem at the Kremlin, he ascribes these liquidations to Stalin's realization that administrative ability is the major consideration in today's Russia. * * *

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 11 -- William Fales and Richard W. Fales, unattached, eliminated the medalists, Reinert M. Torgerson and Joseph Murphy, Oakland, 1 up at the nineteenth in the opening round of match play in the annual Cherry Valley invitation member-guest golf tournament today.
DELAWARE, Ohio, June 11 -- Former President Herbert Hoover urged the graduating class of Ohio Wesleyan University today not to forsake self-reliance for the "security" of the "New Era."

THE May 15 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review has a dialogue between Fredric Wertham, New York psychiatrist, and Arthur Miller, author of "Death of a Salesman," entitled "Let the Salesman Beware." If I am not mistaken this will draw forth the wrath of thousands of salesmen.

FISHERMEN and fisherwomen seem out of place in Pennsylvania Station at the crack of dawn Saturdays and Sundays, but non-fishing early risers find the terminal abustle week-end mornings, now that the Long Island Rail Road's Fishermen's Special is back on schedule. This train, that runs out of Pennsylvania Station at 5:10 A. M. for Montauk and way fishing stations, will operate through October.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 11 -- Answering the most recent Government moves, Archbishop Josef Beran has ordered the Roman Catholic clergy to boycott Government sponsored organizations and publications professing to be "Catholic."

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Democratic leaders of the Eighty-first Congress, which derisive Republicans are calling "the Eighty-Worst," are working with somber determination to save in this session as much as possible of the President's program.
OMAHA, Neb., June 11 -- People traveling through the wide-open Great Plains States would have a hard time believing it, but the subject of trees was a lively topic here this week.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Local cattle receipts last week were the largest this year, while dressed meat trade was quiet. The results of the two factors were lower prices for all grades of cattle except strictly high choice steers. Cattle receipts were 39,600 head compared with 30,900 head the previous week.

WHEN Gilbert Roland gave up practicing to be a bull-fighter, it was a great relief to the goats of Chihuahua, Mexico. His father, grandfather and great-grandfather had all been bull-fighters in Spain and Mexico.

The Fair Deal Democrats, composed of young members of the party, formerly opend their campaign to recognize the Democratic party in Manhattan at a convention in the Woodstock Hotel yesterday and will designate today a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Borough President to oppose Hugo E. Rogers, leader of Tammany, in the primary election on Sept. 6.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The opening of Senate debate on labor legislation this week marked another milestone on the path of what many hope may lead to a law that will be satisfactory to labor and industry and in accord with the public welfare.

The first report on methods of determining the variation of costs with volume has been completed by the committee on research of the National Association of Cost Accountants. Additional field work is now planned to determine the extent to which a variety of these methods are used throughout business, it was reported by I. Wayne Keller, chairman of the research committee, in a summary to be released to members this week.

FAR too often the small garden is never really completed. For it is that final selection of a bench, piece of sculpture, or even a sundial or bird bath that will be tie whole together. That is, of course, if the feature is properly placed.

Three hundred and fifty officials of Rotary International arrived here last night in a special train from Lake Placid, N. Y., to attend the fortieth annual Rotary convention that will begin at Madison Square Garden today and continue through Thursday.

HANOVER, N. H., June 11 -- The University of Pennsylvania knocked Dartmouth, defending champion, out of the Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball lead by downing the Indians, 14 -- 10, before a commencement crowd of 3,000 today.

CAMPANULAS, popularly known as bell flowers or Canterbury bells, seldom play the stellar role in gardens that they so richly merit. The reason is simply that the average gardener does not know how easy they are to grow and what lavish returns they give.

AS for dancing this summer, the woods will be full of it. New York will have little or none of it, for this year even the Lewisohn Stadium will omit it from its schedule. NANKING, June 11 -- The economic difficulties confronting the Chinese Communists, especially with regard to the dislocating effect of Shanghai's skittish economy on other large cities, were reflected here in the latest weekly statistical bulletin issued by the University of Nanking's department of agricultural economics.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 11 -- President Truman declared today that the democracies had turned the tide against Communist pressures in favor of freedom and peace, but he pointedly warned those who would slash the European Recovery Program that they would destroy the hopes of the Western nations.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 11 -- Most people, when asked to name a few wildflowers will mention the dandelion, buttercup or daisy. But S. LeRoy King of East Hampton, whose hobby is growing specimens of Long Island's wildflowers in his back yard, has a more interesting and informative answer.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- All of August and the first week in September constitute the height of the tourist season in New Mexico and Arizona. The three big attractions are the Intertribal Indian Ceremonials at Gallup, N. M.; the Hopi snake dances in northern Arizona and the Santa Fe fiesta.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 11 -- A message from President Truman was read tonight at the opening session of the eleventh national biennial convention of Pioneer Women, the woman's labor Zionist organization of America.

JUST two years ago New Zealand's Labor Government, "anxious to encourage literary art in New Zealand," established a State literary fund to be fed by an annual grant of 2,000 from the profits of State-supervised lotteries.

TOKYO, June 11 (UP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters today announced the execution of fifteen Japanese war criminals, including two who were convicted of ordering the infamous Bataan death march.

Miss Bonham's "Edwardian shadows," her passionless sluts, deluded spinsters and stodgy practitioners of planned parenthood are always on the verge of being badgered.

A study program covering the Scandinavian area, the first to be offered at the University of Wisconsin, will be introduced in the fall term. The program is intended to contribute to the liberal education of students and to train specialists in the techniques needed for successful business or educational activities in the Scandinavian countries. It will cut across department lines and will include courses in economics, history, political science, literature and sociology.

THE tides of taste swirl capriciously, but they do not budge the rock that is Rembrandt for, though successive generations have read different meanings into his vast oeuvre, his grip on the imagination has never slackened.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., June 11 -- George Huntoon of Miami, Fla., in an Alfa Romeo, won the 100-mile feature for unlimited automobiles in a road race over a four-mile course today. He finished in 80 minutes 7.9 seconds.

Now is the time to know a garden intimately. The patch of soil which you approached on bended knee a few weeks ago, marking rows and planting seeds, has by now assumed a definite character. If you are both fortunate and industrious, it is now an orderly design of green and growing things.

FROM a commercial point of view the one-act play has been at a disadvantage for many years. But not any more. With the advent of television one-act material has been much in demand. Miss Mayorga's "The Best One Act Plays of 1948-49" takes on a new light with the possibility of television use.

MOST growers have little trouble harvesting fruit once they have a well-grown crop. However, the strawberry is one of the most perishable fruits, and much damage frequently is done in picking. This is particularly true when the weather is very hot or wet.

FOR more than forty years Henry L. Mencken, now an unlikely 68, has conspicuously displayed the talents of a demolition expert and a scholar. During much of that period he was a commanding influence on American thought.

ARMONK, N. Y., June 11 -- An orange sable pomeranian that will be 3 years old next Thursday, Champion Little Tim's Chipper, took best in show today in the 921-dog seventeenth annual Greenwich Kennel Club event, transplanted the last few years from its normal Connecticut heath to the Windmill Farm here.

PARIS, June 11 -- By the end of this week a great many serious-minded people in Paris were asking one another, "Just why did the Soviet Union want this Council of Foreign Ministers if, as appears to be the case, the Kremlin's position on all points discussed is to remain utterly without change?"

Whether or not the penalty should be imposed for failure to file a personal holding company return, a topic discussed in this column a week ago, may depend upon the degree of caution exercised by the corporation in ascertaining its obligation to file such return.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 11 -- The big Midwest Democratic powwow to be held here next week shaped up today as the kickoff for the 1950 Congressional elections in the farm belt.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- The grain market on the Board of Trade overcame the influence of a highly optimistic official crop report and bounded up in late dealings today. Trading was active and a good deal of short covering accounted for much of the market's strength.

Recent allegations that the Israeli Government had been hostile to interests of the Roman Catholic Church in Palestine were denounced yesterday by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.

The Parke-Bernet Galleries closed its auction season last week with the final dispersal of the Joseph Brummer art collection. The building it has occupied for years at 30 East Fifty-seventh Street will soon be torn down to make way for a twenty-two-story office building.
HERE, in the habitat of the bearded seal and the Polar bear, hard by the shores of the forbidding Arctic Ocean, is the Navy's "farthest north."

Mr. Truman's address at Little Rock yesterday was an appropriate one for the occasion. He was dedicating a park to the memory of American soldiers who died in two world wars. It was natural that he should do what he could to lift the shadow of a possible third war and to remind his hearers of what this nation is doing to prevent such a war.

For too long a time I have waited for such an article on Finland as Raymond Daniell's "In the Forepaws of the Russian Bear." As a true, patriotic Finn I have been amazed at opinions about Finland. One day I have been called a Nazi, the next a Communist.

EDWARD DMYTRYK, one of the ten Hollywood men banned from the major studios for refusing to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee whether or not they were Communists, is slated to return from England to direct "Dreadful Summit," it was learned last week.

The third annual one-day convention of the New York State Association of Junior Republican Clubs was held yesterday at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, with 120 delegates between the ages of 14 and 21 attending.
MADISON, N. J., June 11 (AP) -- Some 700 Methodist clergymen and lay representatives from three states today backed Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam as "no representative of Joe Stalin."

PRINCETON, N. J., June 11 -- Hurling one of the most meaningful games of his career, Princeton's Bob Wolcott limited Yale to four hits and notched a 5-0 victory before 12,000 partisan spectators on University Field today.

PARIS, June 11 -- The Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France met today to discuss the narrow field that remained for possible agreements at the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers that will enter its last lap tomorrow.

MANCHESTER, Vt., June 11 -- Disagreement between labor and management over the basic importance of "work loads" was established today as a factor in planning for the future of New England's textile industry.

The situation of the 7,000 Indians who reside on recognized reservations in New York State became more complicated last week when representatives of the Seneca Nations demanded an end to moves to bring Indian affairs within the jurisdiction of the state courts.

The City of Brooklyn, a new combination cargo-passenger vessel of the Ellerman Bucknall Steamship Company's post-war fleet, will get the city's traditional greeting tomorrow morning when she makes her way up the harbor to Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, completing her maiden voyage across the Atlantic.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 11 -- While most people in the cities in this area were largely concerned this week with hot weather and with plans for week-end trips and vacations, many farmers found rising temperatures and scattered rains much to their liking because they were enabled to step up their planting and other operations in the fields.

BUENOS AIRES, June 11 -- Relations between Argentina and Uruguay, which have been fretful for many months, again were jarred last night when the Foreign Office rejected a request by Uruguay for a safe conduct for Argentine Opposition Deputy Augustin Rodriguez Araya, who took refuge in the Uruguayan Embassy Thursday after having been outed by the Peronista majority.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The National Board of Americans for Democratic Action urged President Truman and his Council of Economic Advisers today to present to the nation "an unvarnished analysis of the current economic situation, without panic but also without sugar-coating."

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 12 -- With a new farm plan to dangle before farmers and their city cousins, Democrats faced the 1950 Congressional elections today with unusual optimism as they opened their biggest Midwest meeting in years.

Cotton future prices, after covering a somewhat wider trading range than usual, ended last week at mostly firmer levels. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close of trading on Friday were 62 points higher to 22 points lower than at the end of the previous week.

There is a queen in Queens. Susan D. Vilendrer, 21 years old, of 3528 Seventy-seventh Street, a student at Adelphi College, received the crown of rose queen yesterday afternoon at the opening of the second annual Rose Festival week in Queens Botanical Gardens in Flushing Meadow Park.

The reckless anti-Communist who calls everyone who disagrees with him a Communist "throws up a smoke screen behind which the real Communist can effectively hide," Leo M. Vassar College has assured Ruth M. Graham of Corona, Queens, a tuition scholarship of $1,350, upon her entrance into the college next fall, it was announced yesterday by Dean Harry J. Carman of Columbia College, chairman of the board of the National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students, 31 West 110th Street.
MANHASSET, L. I., June 12 -- Manhasset's new, $500,000 First Congregational Church was dedicated here today.

TRIESTE, June 12 -- Democracy in Trieste, which had been dead for more than a quarter of a century, was reborn here today under auspices of the United States and Great Britain, when an estimated 86 per cent of Trieste's eligible voters went to the polls to elect officers for their city's administration.

MARION, Ohio, June 12 (AP) -- Thomas S. Mitchell, 30 years old, of Cleveland, director of the violence-torn Ohio Associated Telephone Company strike, escaped assassination when he was shot at today through a window at City Hospital.

News that the State Department of Public Works has let a $736,996 contract for immediate start on the extensive reconstruction of the Washington Bridge over the Harlem River is of interest not only in itself, but also as an indication that construction of the entire $53,000,000 Cross Bronx Expressway is about to begin.

Although Fanny H. Hogan rarely leaves the parish of St. Patrick's Cathedral, she receives mail from all over the world. Living a secluded existence, she is known to many Broadway figures, some of whom have helped her without knowing her name.

Parents looking forward with small pleasure to summer train travel with their youngsters might consider the case of J. P. McMillan. Mr. McMillan arrived in New York yesterday morning with seventy-one boys of assorted ages and personalities after an all-night trip from Charlotte, N. C.

Hilliard was ready to revive "shovel-leaning and leaf-raking under the guise of work relief -- the 'boondoggling' of all too recent vivid memory," the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., urged yesterday appointment of a committee of business men "to investigate every angle of the city's relief picture."

This year's winners of the Music Education League contests appeared in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. They played and sang in solo and ensemble groups and ranged in age from too-small-to-reach-the-pedals to a special adult vocal competition.
New Yorkers will get their first glimpse of Adolf Hitler's private yacht, one of the largest and most luxurious afloat, when the all-white, single-stacked vessel arrives here on Wednesday.
The United States is "vastly stronger" than the Soviet Union because of a superior philosophy of life, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today called an industry-wide conference on Sept. 15 to formulate rules to prevent deceptive "packing" practices in the sale and financing of automobiles purchased on the installment plan.

Beaches in the metropolitan area attracted 1,500,000 visitors yesterday, the largest turnout of the season, as the temperature soared to 89.1 degrees, only .7 below the record for the date, set in 1933.

BUFFALO, June 12 -- The need for industry to "explain itself" to the American public on a "grass roots level" will be stressed before industrialists who began arriving here this afternoon to attend the annual conference of the National Industrial Advertisers Association at the Statler Hotel.
LONDON, June 12 -- The tense labor situation in Britain's vital transport industries eased slightly today, but remained a source of grave concern to Government and union leaders.

The Cunard White Star Line is negotiating with the Department of Marine and Aviation for use of Pier 92, North River, at West Fifty-second Street, as a berthing point for its medium-size liners, the Caronia and the Mauretania, it became known yesterday.

In a deal in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, the three-story brownstone dwelling for two families at 589 Seventh Street, between Prospect Park West and Eighth Avenue, was sold by Mrs. Mae Wynne Evans to Anthony Areas, who insured title with the Home Title Guaranty Company.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., June 12 -- Here is a classroom that young students hate to leave, one that would confound pedants and makes learning a pleasure. Grim lines of desks have given way to fern and leaf-carpeted nature trails. Fresh air takes the place of chalk dust from blackboards.

BERLIN, June 12 -- Russian insistence on retention of complete control over transport facilities between Berlin and Western Germany deadlocked the four-power talks aimed at an East-West trade and transport agreement here today.
Full effects of the seventy-two-day beer strike on the New York market may not be known for two to four weeks, brewers' spokesmen said yesterday as they laid plans to reopen their plants.
Taxpayer properties figured prominently in Long Island real estate deals reported over the week-end.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 12 -- Under a warm sun and before a galaxy of New York City's guiding fathers, including Mayor O'Dwyer, the softball team of the Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City courageously held a 1-to-0 lead over the Police Department's team here today until the fifth inning.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- A warning that "when the farmers of America lose their freedom through the permanent application of Government controls and penalties, there will be little hope left for maintaining democracy in America" was voiced here today by Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, of Vermont.

Having gained six soccer victories in nine matches before coming to the Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island yesterday, the Belfast Celtics failed to make it seven because of stout resistance offered by the team representing the Kamraterna Football Club of Goeteborg, Sweden.

Victor Scott, 32-year-old airplane inspector from Levittown, L. I., shot his leaping, splashing, droning outboard rig across the finish line off West Seventy-second Street just after noon yesterday to win the biggest, and in one way, the fastest Albany-to-New York motor boat race.

MOSCOW, June 12 -- The newspaper Communist of Tadjikistan calls for a strengthened drive against religion, which it describes as aiding the perpetuation of a number of reactionary feudal elements in daily life and particularly the encouragement of a superstitious attitude toward disease and health problems.

The Jewish Institute of Religion awarded degrees of Master of Hebrew Literature to a class of eight men and ordained them as rabbis at the annual ordination and commencement exercises held yesterday afternoon in the Free Synagogue, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 12 (AP) -- Toronto knocked Jersey City out of first place today by coming back to take the second game of a double-header, 3 -- 2, after the Little Giants had captured the opener, 7 -- 2, before a crowd of 5,417.
BUENOS AIRES, June 12 -- The barring in the United States zone of Germany and of Austria of the German-language monthly magazine the Weg has touched off a minor diplomatic incident here.
Five new films, including importations from France and Russia, will arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:...

PARIS, June 12 -- Serious concern is developing here over the slump on the Bourse that increased further last week and appears to have been a result of the depression in New York. Between January, 1949, and last Friday the general index for French metropolitan stocks has fallen 18.7 per cent.

Your editorial "Policy in the Pacific" and J. J. Singh's letter published in your paper are of great significance, though the conclusions therein are based on inadequate understanding of the Asian region. It will be of no avail to have a sort of Marshall Plan on a "paternal plane" for these countries, though the need to acquire capital and industrial assistance is urgent.

PITTSBURGH, June 12 -- The steel ingot rate for the country last week had sagged 13.5 points from the high point reached at the middle of March. It was 89 per cent of rated capacity, down 3 points from the week before. There appeared in the trade no reason to believe that the downward trend had been checked.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 12 -- Official Czechoslovak optimism as to the country's economic prospects -- not entirely shared by foreign observers -- has been vastly stimulated by a rainy May followed by predictations that crop yields will exceed the average of the past ten years and be 25 per cent better than last year.

NOT so many years ago when authors wrote about life in the future they generally portrayed the world of their imagination as blissful indeed compared with the unhappy present. Utopia was just around the corner; if science couldn't solve all our problems political and social reorganization could. But that was in another century and, besides, such hopes are dead.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 12 -- Two Rembrandt etchings and a Degas drawing in pencil, valued together at $11,800, disappeared Saturday from the art museum of Princeton University, it was made known today.

PARIS, June 12 -- Last week Secretary Acheson asked John Foster Dulles, Republican adviser to the American delegation, to draft a memorandum presenting our position on the resumption of trade between East and West Germany. This is a pretty clear indication of what the American delegate expects to come out of the present session of the Foreign Ministers.

VIENNA, June 12 -- The Austrian Government's decision to permit the country's rich store of art treasures to be exhibited in New York, Washington, Chicago and San Francisco has thrown Austrian and Russian Communists into a mild frenzy.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 12 -- Man's long dependence upon fire as a chief necessity of civilization has depleted world fuel deposits so alarmingly that other power sources -- wind, water and nuclear fission -- must be rigorously exploited, according to a report submitted to the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources.
The foreign exchange market moved along evenly last week and except for a soft tone in the Canadian free dollar all currencies were quiet and steady.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 12 -- On the picturesque grounds of the Longshore Beach and Country Club overlooking Long Island Sound, Ch. Twin Ponds Belle, pert, beautifully coated Welsh terrier, was named best in show at the seventeenth annual all-breed event of the Longshore Kennel Club today.

WESTFIELD, N. J., June 12 -- Joseph A. McBride of Arcola retained his New Jersey state amateur golf title at the Echo Lake Country Club today by defeating 46-year-old J. Wolcott Brown of Manasquan River, 4 and 2, in the thirty-six-hole final.

CLEVELAND, June 12 -- The American Association of Social Workers, official organization of the social workers of the country, went on record today condemning the "undemocratic practices" used by Government representatives in their loyalty investigations.
Miss Marjorie Corbin has been appointed a vice president of the Butterick Company, Inc. Formerly sales and promotion manager, she will be in charge of the company's designing staff.

Municipal bond issues scheduled for sale this week aggregate $50,498,600, compared with $147,423,391 last week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date now stands at $67,802,854.

Rotary Club members and their families from more than fifty countries moved into New York yesterday 10,000 strong, with another 10,000 expected today, for the fortieth annual convention of the Rotary International, which will last through Thursday.
A disgruntled fan, leaving the Polo Grounds yesterday after the Pirates had registered a marathon 6-5 victory, had the best explanation. "The heat was bearable -- the Giants weren't," he scoffed...

CHICAGO, June 12 -- The Government's unexpected announcement last week that loans would be granted to wheat growers for grain piled on the ground or held in temporary shelters at 75 per cent of the normal loan rate changed the wheat market picture drastically.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 12 -- There is a great sense of urgency among the handful of engineers who are helping to fight the battle of Yugoslavia against the Soviet blockade in the Tepcha lead mines of South Serbia, which this correspondent visited several days ago.

SHANGHAI, June 12 -- A number of foreign businessmen who have closely observed this city's economy for several decades believe that if no foreign aid or loan is granted the new regime a serious crisis will arise here, possibly within a month.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 12 -- Back in the western part of Long Island Sound, the fleet of the Yacht Racing Association engaged today in the regatta of the Orienta Club. It was another of the championship series and 123 craft competed.

In Britain last week negotiations over wage demands between the Railway Executive, which manages the nationalized railways, and two of the country's biggest railway unions broke down completely. Meanwhile, locomotive engineers on long-distance trains in the northeast have been striking each Sunday since mid-May against a "lodging turns" system which compels them to spend nights away from home.

Don G. Mitchell, president of Sylvania Electric Products Company, has been elected chairman of the executive committee of the American Management Association, it was announced over the week-end following the election and appointments to offices and committees of the AMA for the coming year.
Poultry and fish are two excellent answers to the question of what to serve in place of the meats that are now so prohibitively expensive.

A fourteen-point program of revisions proposed for Government procurement contracts is now being submitted to members of the American Ordnance Association, it was learned here at the week's end. The AOA is a national association of industrial executives interested in the country's military preparedness.

NORTON, Mass., June 12 -- William O. Douglas, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, said today that utilization of "our brain power in the lower economic levels" was a challenge to every community as part of the requirements of "our new internationalism."

The H. J. Heinz Company of Pittsburgh will soon start an intensive newspaper campaign for its "57 Varieties" of food products, according to H. J. Heinz 2d, president, who said "the time is ripe for the biggest campaign ever." Large-space ads will appear in 140 daily newspapers in 110 key markets, with special spring and fall campaigns covering 300 secondary markets.

No more do youthful mothers-to-be hibernate in Mother Hubbardish creations -- the stork has blossomed forth into a bird of fashion. Now the anticipating shopper can find cottons gay and pretty to her heart's delight.

The mystery of the Holy Trinity never can be explained in words or mathematical formulas, the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan, Pro-Synodal Judge of the New York Tribunal, said yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Mass shipment of Bibles to European countries on both sides of the Iron Curtain is the surest way to bolster Christianity against communist attacks, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church told delegates from twenty-five countries yesterday at the current sessions of the Council of the United Bible Societies.

HONOLULU, June 12 -- The psychological effect on the people of Hawaii is the most striking accompaniment of the walkout of 2,000 CIO longshoremen now passing its sixth week, according to a reporter's observation on the island of Oahu and conversations with residents of other islands.

DETROIT, June 12 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers tightened the American League race today by sweeping a double-header from the Washington Senators, 9 to 0 and 6 to 5. The victories left the second-place Tigers only three games behind the league-leading Yankees.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- There's just no "one best way" for every woman to make beds, the Agriculture Department concludes.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- With a Senate-House conference committee still divided on a key reorganization bill, Dr. Robert L. Johnson, national chairman of the Citizens Committee for Reorganization of the Executive Branch of the Government, came here today for a talk with President Truman.

Two four-story buildings containing thirty-two apartments and nine stores at 4301 to 4311 Bergenline Avenue, Union City, N. J., were sold by the Dugold Realty Corporation of Passaic, N. J., to an investing client of the Shafer Realty Company.
Aqueduct, the home base of the Queens County Jockey Club, opens its summer race meeting today. The third session of the New York turf campaign, it will run for three weeks.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Charles P. Skouras, the movie theatre operator, was listed by the Treasury tonight as this country's highest paid corporation executive in 1947. He received $810,000.

The total revenue of the municipal transit lines for the fiscal year ended June 30 will be about $9,252,000 less than required to meet operating and maintenance charges and to redeem budget notes issued in previous years to cover operating deficits, it was indicated yesterday.

Now that Iran's seven-year plan has been approved, American exporters of machinery, motor vehicles and agricultural and construction equipment may expect to do a substantial business with that country, according to Frederick W. Richmond, president of the United States Foreign Corporation.

PARIS, June 12 -- Completely remodeled from stem to stern and incorporating many technical improvements, the 23-year-old luxury liner Ile De France will take to sea for trial runs June 28 prior to her maiden voyage to New York July 21, the French Line said today.

LANGHORNE, Pa., June 12 (UP) -- One driver was killed and another injured seriously today in crack-ups on the Langhorne Speedway, where more than 20,000 spectators turned out for the 150-mile National midget auto championship race.

A. H. Raskin's article in THE TIMES of June 5, advocating general extension of the impartial chairman system, leaves certain important points untouched. Consequently, it is easy to conclude from his article that the impartial chairman system is a "surefire" panacea for labor relations ills.

The Fair Deal Democrats, at their convention in the Woodstock Hotel, adopted yesterday a resolution urging the five Democratic county leaders to designate Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, director of the National Bureau of Standards, said tonight he would not take "no comment" as an answer to his demand that J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, apologize to Mrs. Condon for references to her in an FBI report made public in the Judith Coplon espionage case.

The Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government -- better known as the Hoover Commission -- went out of existence yesterday after completing its truly monumental task. Under the direction of former President Herbert Hoover, 300 men and women, each a specialist in a given field, have produced more than two million words, the essence of which is embodied in nineteen reports.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 12 (AP) -- Forty-eight girls and a golf course get together tomorrow in the annual scramble for the women's intercollegiate championship held by Miss Grace Lenczyk of John B. Stetson University.

The Four-Power conference in Paris begins its fourth and possibly last week with no agreement on anything except the agenda and a call for agreement on the complete lifting of the Berlin blockade, which was supposed to have ended before the Paris meeting started.
NEWARK, N. J., June 12 (AP) -- Rochester swept a twin bill from the Bears today, 6 -- 3 and 4 -- 3, with the nightcap going two overtime innings.

Eight thousand persons gathered on the Central Park Mall yesterday to witness the re-enactment of the ancient festival of Chag Bikkurim, the offering of the first fruits of the year to the Lord. One thousand children from Hebrew schools and Jewish youth organizations took part.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 12 -- The United Nations should not be expected to resolve in the near future all the conflicts of ideology and interest between the Soviet Union and the United States, Trygve Lie, Secretary-General of the United Nations, said today.

PARIS, June 12 -- There is a growing demand on the part of Arab leaders, Israeli Government officials and influential Americans that a coordinated United States policy for the entire Middle Eastern area should be developed as soon as possible.

A history of American treason, up to and including current trials involving disloyalty, is scheduled for publication early this fall by Public Affairs Press of Washington. "Treason in America" was written by a Washingtonian whose name is being kept secret.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UP) -- A group of stockholders in the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Company, headed by Sherman M. Fairchild, founder of the concern, made it known today that they had obtained from the Securities and Exchange Commission approval of their plan to solicit proxies from other stockholders for a new annual meeting on July 6.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox exploded three homers today, good for seven runs, in a 15 to 3 victory over the Chicago White Sox. Boston then came from behind to chase Billy Pierce and make a sweep of the twin bill with a 7 to 5 triumph in the nightcap.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark said tonight that alien Communists "are fleeing the country" and the number of foreign Reds here is about one-third smaller than the total three years ago.

Pairs of single-armed chairs or loveseats on either side of square lamp tables in corner arrangements are favored for many of the furniture groupings in the newly decorated showrooms of M. Singer Sons, 30 East Nineteenth Street. These same pieces, many in modified Lawson styles, might also be used together against a wall to form sectional settees or long couches.
As the metropolitan art season moves toward summer, the number of new exhibitions declines, but there are still openings that merit attention.

Frederick R. Livingston, a New York attorney and former assistant to the Secretary of Labor, has been made a member of the firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman Hays, it was announced yesterday. He joined the law firm in 1947 as a specialist in labor, and has figured in a large number of disputes as arbitrator.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 12 -- Before 2,000 persons attending Princeton University's annual baccalaureate service, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, today suggested that society's fear of man himself explained its present willingness "to run for salvation to external authority, such as the state."

Judge Louis E. Levinthal of Philadelphia asserted yesterday that the Jewish people must transmit to future generations "our cultural and religious heritage as Jews, so that our community may make its specific, its finest contribution to the total civilization of our country."

LONDON, June 12 -- Nothing has occurred in the last week to rescue the stock markets here from their dreary plight. Wall Street has not set a good example, and persistent harping on an American business recession has been much to the liking of bear speculators.

Here since Jan. 13, "Along Fifth Avenue" drops out of contention Saturday night at the Imperial. The revue had its premiere at the Broadhurst and was transferred to the Imperial on Feb. 21. Despite a local run of 180 performances, it has been buffeted by ill luck.

Luigi Criscuolo, financier and a Grand Officer of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre, took issue yesterday with a statement made Saturday by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum to the effect that Israeli soldiers and the Israeli Government have shown "meticulous regard and reverence" for the Holy Places in Palestine.
MARLBORO, Vt., June 12 -- An old New England farm on a wooded hilltop in Southern Vermont has been transformed, in the space of two years, into a flourishing liberal arts college.

PARIS, June 12 -- Just as Charles de Gaulle was maintaining today in Brittany that his movement was getting hold of the guiding levers in France, a quarrel over de Gaullism was causing a split in one of the parties, of the Government coalition.
HANOVER, N. H., June 12 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg declared here today that appeasement was "simply surrender on the installment plan."

CLEVELAND, June 12 -- A couple of left-handed flippers gave a slightly left-of-center touch to Yankee fortunes at huge Municipal Stadium today before the largest baseball crowd of the season, so the American League pacesetters left for New York tonight with only a three-game lead over the second-place Tigers.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- A spot check by the House Un-American Activities Committee for Red propaganda in school books drew strong protests from educators today.

The infantile paralysis epidemic of 27,894 cases last year led the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis to spend $4,250,000 more than its income in 1948, exhausting epidemic aid reserves, according to the annual report yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 -- San Francisco employers of the striking Honolulu longshoremen today rejected a complicated union offer of service to the stranded Matson liner Lurline for one round trip as a "relief" ship, according to word received here from Hawaii.

There was no doubt in the minds of the 30,000 men, women and children on Fordham University's campus yesterday -- including a boy from Bohola named William O'Dwyer -- that Irish culture was the finest in the world. It was the seventeenth annual feis of the United Irish Counties Association of New York, in which nearly 3,000 contestants engaged in a hundred and one games, from poetry to hurling.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 12 -- Irving Allen and Franchot Tone have concluded a deal to take over James Ramsey Ullman's novel, "The White Tower," which RKO has owned since 1946, and to produce it in France in Ansco color for RKO release, they announced yesterday.

SHANGHAI, June 12 -- The People's Liberation Army threw its net over the Shanghai Stock Exchange on Friday, it was learned today. Late yesterday, while the troops guarded the doors, plain-clothes men combed the building for evidence of illegal money speculation.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 12 -- One of the most bitter chapters in Israel's brief history was commemorated today when the former Irgun Zvai Leumi, now known as Herut, laid a wreath on the ill-fated Altalena, which had tried to land ammunition and troops during the first United Nations armistice.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., June 12 (AP) -- Mules' shoes are putting the kick into a campaign to raise funds for the Truman Foundation.
PRESTWICK, Scotland, June 12 -- Two stateless women coming from Germany became mothers this morning a few minutes after having been taken from a New York-bound plane.

Additional light on the several post-war foreign policies weighed by authorities in the Soviet Union is given in the text of Academician Eugen S. Varga's recantation of his "errors" in analyzing the influence of World War II on the economy of capitalism, published in complete translation in the latest issue of The Curent Digest of the Soviet Union, published by American experts on Soviet affairs.

Negotiations between East and Gulf Coast vessel operators and three maritime unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations move this morning into the final three days before the expiration of contracts, with little likelihood of a strike this year.

First purchases of fall ready-to-wear, including merchandise for early August and back-to-school events, were made by buyers in the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CLINTON, N. Y., June 12 -- "How do you keep in such good trim?" former Representative I. Lee of Brooklyn, back for his fiftieth reunion at Hamilton College here today, asked a classmate, Daniel Wells, 73, retired Detroit lumber manufacturer.
A labor-management situation regarded as likely to have a profound effect on economic developments throughout the United States take shape this week in the coal, steel and manufacturing industries.

The new small business division of the Economic Cooperation Administration, now being set up in Washington, will begin supplying small export concerns with "live leads" on Marshall Plan requirements by the end of this month, it was learned last week.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP) -- Andy Seminick slammed three home runs, two with two men on bases, as the Phillies split with the Cardinals today. Philadelphia lost the opener, 7 -- 3, but took the nightcap, 8 -- 3, with Robin Roberts halting Start Musial's hitting streak at fourteen games.

The "NBC Arena Theatre," which made its bow a few weeks ago with the staging of "Romeo and Juliet," will offer for its second presentation a musical show written especially for television. The program, titled "Summer Formal," with original music and lyrics written by Marty Donovan and Gerry Kenyon, will be carried by the National Broadcasting Company television network next Sunday, from 9 to 10 P. M.
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) - Ted Williams, slugging Red Sox outfielder, was in a familiar role today in the tabulation of first returns for the All-Star baseball game at Ebbets Field July 12.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 12 -- After approval by the Swiss Federal Council last week, the new French-Swiss trade and payments agreement, valid for one year, came into force as from June 1, ending the deadlock that had existed from the beginning of May.

TOKYO, Monday, June 13 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur castigated Russia today as "an inciter of disorder and violence in an otherwise orderly Japanese society." This remark was a highlight in a reply by the Supreme Commander, Allied Powers, to a letter from Lieut. Gen. Kuzma N. Derevyanko, Soviet member of the Allied Council for Japan, complaining against police suppression of demonstrations here last month.

ST. LOUIS, June 12 (AP) -- The Browns and Athletics divided a pair of free-swinging contests today. St. Louis rallied for four runs in the eighth inning to take the opener, 6 to 4 while Philadelphia pounded extra-base hits all over the premises to grab the afterpiece, 13 to 10.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 12 -- Prospects for a permanent settlement of the Palestine question are less promising than at any time since the fighting came to a halt last spring, well-informed United Nations sources said today.

Not being of voting age, there is nothing I can do about the disgraceful conditions to be found upon visiting the Statue of Liberty. It is in the harbor of the richest city in the world, but looks as if it belonged to a very bankrupt nation. I went to Bedloes Island expecting to be thrilled to the very marrow of my bones.
AMSTERDAM, June 12 -- Three bills have been submitted to Parliament designed to provide relief to industry and trade.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, ordained seven deacons and four priests yesterday during a service of holy communion in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.
Yale University and Vassar College announced separately yesterday that each had received a gift of $2,000,000 from the Old Dominion Foundation of Washington.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 12 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former commander of the United States forces in Germany, told the graduating class of Rutgers University today that "America is the hope of all people who believe that the purpose of government is to express the will of the people."

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Senate will get tomorrow at least a day's respite from the debate on a labor law aimed to replace the Taft Hartley Act. The Labor discussion is being put aside to bring up for ratification the international wheat agreement.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 12 -- The University of California disclosed today that its Board of Regents would require all 4,000 full-time faculty members and administrative officers on its eight campuses to take an oath disavowing belief in forceful or "illegal" overthrow of the Federal Government and disclaiming membership in any organization espousing such belief.

PARIS, June 12 -- At a secret session tonight the Foreign Ministers of the Big Four powers were reported to have discussed how they would wind up their meeting this week as gracefully as possible in view of its negative character.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 12 -- Tomorrow's meeting of the Palestine Conciliation Commission with the Israeli delegation may well be decisive in determining the commission's success in translating the uneasy armistice in the Palestine war into a stable peace.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 12 -- Everybody in Budapest is still busy providing his or her version of what has happened to Laszlo Rajk, former Foreign Minister, and to others of lesser importance who are said to be no longer in their offices.

A wider choice in decorative fabrics for those who like small, neat modern prints is now possible with the addition of two new groups. One by Sterling Blazy has crisp geometric motifs in one or two colors on white. The other consists of a few new designs by Erno Fabry, who favors light abstract designs, fairly small, and printed in color combinations that are becoming more prominent in furnishings.

Before 24,020 eyewitnesses at Ebbets Field yesterday, the league-leading Dodgers ran their winning streak to seven games by beating the Reds, 20 to 7 -- a new high in scoring for a major league team this season -- in a nine-inning game that required 3 hours 14 minutes.

Enchanting as is your editorial of June 5 on the "Whippoorwill," you picked out an old bird showing decrepitude and decay. He could only utter his call seventy-five times in succession without stopping even momentarily for a breath! Why, man, at Quoque, on the South Shore of Long Island, my ears have rung from a thousand calls in steady and unrelenting succession.

BOSTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Cubs closed Charlie Grimm's long National League managerial career by splitting a double-header with the Braves today before a crowd of 19,802. After taking the opener, 6 -- 2, Chicago was blanked, 2 -- 0, by Lefty Johnny Antonelli's four-hit pitching.

MOSCOW, June 12 -- The newspaper Izvestia proposed satirically today that directors whose factories produce shoddy products be punished by sentencing them to use the shabby goods that they turn out for six months or a year.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, June 12 (UP) -- Josef Palada, a veteran of sixteen years of Davis Cup tennis, gave Yugoslavia a 1 to 0 lead over Sweden in the quarter finals of the European Zone eliminations today by defeating young Lennart Bergelin, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

CAPETOWN, Union of South Africa, June 13 -- To beat the deadline for imports from the sterling area an "airlift" has been developing between London and Johannesburg and all signs today point to its intensification until a few days before the end of the month when the ban becomes effective.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Southern Coal Producers Association will challenge the legal right of the United Mine Workers to order a week's stoppage of coal production when contract negotiations are resumed in Bluefield, W. Va., tomorrow.

While the Four-Power conference in Paris still seeks to salvage at least local agreements from the fundamental disagreement between East and West, the Soviet bloc is already shaping a new and double-edged campaign against the West in general and the heretic in the Soviet camp -- Yugoslavia -- in particular.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Federal Government won a highly important anti-trust suit today when the Supreme Court by 5 to 4 held illegal agreements with independent gasoline dealers in the Far West to buy all fuel from Standard Oil Company of California.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The certificated regular airlines today charged the Civil Aeronautics Board with approving new regular freight services at the very time the board was studying the question whether air services were not too abundant for the demand for them.

Animated graphs projected on screens by market researchers are successful in catching the eye of top executives when reporting studies, William M. Hayden, manager, industrial research department, Anaconda Copper Mining Company, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The conviction of Dalton Trumbo and John Howard Lawson, movie writors, for contempt of Congress was upheld today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals. The tribunal ruled that a committee of Congress had the right to demand that a witness state whether he was Communist.

The cooperation of motion picture theatre operators is being sought by the National Council on Freedom From Censorship, an providing for censorship of films affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union, to challenge the legality of city and state laws before public exhibition.

Twenty-three hotels became involved yesterday in Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh's investigation of ticket scalping for hit shows. The commissioner issued subpoenas ordering delivery of records by these hotels at his office tomorrow morning.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 13 -- Degrees were conferred on 259 seniors today at the eighty-fifth annual commencement exercises of Vassar College. Ten young women, too, received masters degrees. Two young men, both war veterans, who took the Vassar course got degrees of the University of the State of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Senate ratified the international wheat agreement today. It acted by voice vote after several members, including Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, expressed misgivings about it.
LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet note rejecting three-power discussions on alleged treaty violations by Rumania, Bulgaria and Hungary, as broadcast tonight by Moscow follows:

Posthumous publication of a new Willa Cather book has been set for September by Knopf. "Willa Cather on Writing" will include all her essays and letters about literature, including articles on Defoe, Stephen Crane, Sara Orne Jewett and Katherine Mansfield. There is also a critique of five of her own books. The foreword is by Stephen Tennant.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Administration's bill to open wider the country's doors to the displaced persons of Europe was said today by its backers to be all but lost at this session of Congress.

A fresh manner of decorating dinnerware with designs that harmonize instead of matching was used on two new patterns displayed yesterday by the Edwin Knowles China Company at its new showroom, 212 Fifth Avenue. The new sets, which are made of white earthenware, have just arrived in the stores.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- A proposed constitutional amendment that would divide each state's electoral vote for President in proportion to the popular vote was approved today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 9 -- Admittance of small numbers of Asiatics to Australia annually under a quota system similar to that prevailing in the United States has been repeatedly suggested as a means of allaying the resentment evoked in Asiatic countries by Australia's total exclusion of Asiatic settlers.

CLEVELAND, June 13 -- An individual child trapped in a sewer or suffering from leukemia, or in need of skin-grafting to prevent death from body burns, will stir the sympathy of the nation, but it is difficult to get the public concerned with the larger welfare needs of children, Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the United States Children's Bureau of the Social Security Administration, declared today.

The two New Yorks -- the city and state -- were cited yesterday at the Rotary International convention in Madison Square Garden as examples of how people of all races and nations can live together peacefully and as signposts to the success of the United Nations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 13 -- Israel's Knesset [Assembly] tonight authorized the Government to issue bonds of unspecified amounts, putting up state-owned immovable property as security. The proceeds will be usable to cover issues of Israeli bank notes and finance self-liquidating investments.

Whittaker Chambers was defended as "a decent citizen and a great man" by his wife Esther yesterday under harrowing cross-examination by Lloyd Paul Stryker, counsel for Alger Hiss in the latter's Federal perjury trial.

Eastern ship-owners and three maritime unions were reported yesterday near understandings that would assure continuation of shipping out of Atlantic coast ports. The West Coast, however, still faced the strong possibility of a strike of engineer officers tomorrow.

LONDON, June 13 -- The Soviet Union has rejected requests of the United States and Britain to hold three-power discussions on alleged violations of the peace treaties with Rumania Bulgaria and Hungary, the Moscow radio announced tonight.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 13 -- The United Nations Subcommission on Freedom of Information and the Press decided today, by a vote of 5 to 4, to consider a memorandum from the International Federation of Free Journalists of Central and Eastern Europe and the Baltic and Balkan countries, and to decide tomorrow whether or not to give an oral hearing to the organization's representative.

Texas Technological College sold yesterday an issue of $2,800,000 of bonds due on June 15, 1950 to 1957 and supported by state ad valorem taxation, to Stifel, Nicolaus Co. and associates at a bid which designated an interest cost of 1.59 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to reconsider its recent five-to-four decision that a speaker may not be punished for making remarks that stir people to anger and created public unrest.

Increased public acceptance of contemporary architecture is reflected by financing appraisals of the modern house on exhibition in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art, museum officials said yesterday. Two New York savings and loan associations have agreed to make loans of $15,000 to $18,000 on houses built to the specifications of the exhibit house, it was disclosed.

TRIESTE, June 13 -- Results of the elections in Trieste showed today that the city wanted to be reunited with Italy and that it felt spiritually as well as politically allied to the Western democracies in the current struggle between the West and Eastern Europe.

CAIRO, June 13 -- News reports and commercial information from the United States to the effect that cotton interests in the United States are believed to have developed an adequate rival to Egyptian long staple cotton have been a bombshell here not only among cotton exporters but importers of American goods.

SOPERTON, Ga., June 13 (AP) -- Mayor James Peterson lost the first round today in an effort to convict three men from whom he tore Ku Klux Klan masks. Charges of disorderly conduct against the men were dismissed in Recorder's Court for lack of evidence.

Hambro Trading Company, subsidiary of Hambro's Bank, London, yesterday opened a showroom at 19 East Fifty-third Street and introduced a line of hand-woven British upholstery and drapery fabrics for sale to American retailers and decorators.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- John L. Lewis failed today in his effort to persuade the steel industry to take the lead in writing a new national coal contract.

A sculptured head of the late Dr.. Hugh Auchincloss, cancer surgeon was unveiled yesterday at a ceremony in Presbyterian Hospital, 168th Street and Broadway, with which he had been associated for thirty-five years.

New issues of public utility company bonds and preferred and common stock having an aggregate value of more than $9,000,000 were sold yesterday at competitive bidding to banking syndicates, as follows:
New York's brewery workers rejected yesterday by an overwhelming margin a proposed settlement of their seventy - four - day - old strike that had been endorsed by their own leaders.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A modified bill designed to give some $314,000,000 in pay increases annually throughout the armed services was cleared by the House Committee on Rules today. Debate on the measure was scheduled to start tomorrow, with voting tests Wednesday.

A county fair will be held in the City Center Casino from noon to midnight on Friday, Saturday and Sunday for the benefit of the National Urban League, a social service organization that works for better job opportunities for Negroes and better racial understanding.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, writing as president of Columbia University, today attacked proposals for universal Federal aid to education as efforts to promote more centralized government control of the country.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Council of Economic Advisers asserted today that there was a "remarkable degree" of agreement throughout the agency "as to the present economic situation and the prudent and constructive course in dealing with it."

BOSTON, June 13 -- The very existence of the House Committee on Un-American Activities suggests a wide spread of fear of Americans' choice between statism and freedom, Dr. Mildred McAfee Horton, retiring president of Wellesley College. said today in a farewell address.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., June 13 (AP) -- Branch Rickey, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, praised sport as a road away from war to peace today in accepting five bronze plaques of baseball heroes for the National Baseball Hall of fame.

" Vic and Sade," one of the old-time radio teams, will make their television debut over the NBC network on July 11 as a replacement for "The Colgate Theatre" on Monday nights, 9 to 9:30 o'clock. Format of the program is small-town situation comedy. "Vic and Sade" started in radio around the early 1930's, but they have been off the air for the last two years.

Appeals for reinstatement by two City College instructors dismissed this spring were referred yesterday to the Board of Higher Education by the City College Administrative Committee of the board. The Committee unanimously recommend that the appeals be referred to the Executive Committee of the board for "prompt consideration and early report" at a "special meeting if necessary."

Those of us who oppose Communist dictatorship are seriously handicapped by indiscriminate and false labeling of loyal Americans. The recent crop of newspaper stories resulting from the trial of Judith Coplon is a perfect illustration of how Communists are helped to camouflage their identity.

The Republican quest for a candidate for Mayor this fall, which has been hanging fire for many months, was resumed yesterday at a luncheon conference at the Roosevelt Hotel. All five Republican county chairmen met with William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, and discussed the situation.

The Transocean Air Line plane that barely made the airport at Prestwick, Scotland, on Sunday morning before two women passengers gave birth to babies arrived here yesterday with fifty-two displaced persons, including seventeen other exp ctant mothers.

Eagle-Lion, which ceased production activities last November, will start cameras turning on Monday, the company announced yesterday. More than sixty former employes were recalled to duty in preparation for two Bryan Foy productions.
It is inconceivable why the parking of cars should be permitted on Ninth Street where crosstown and some Fifth Avenue buses demand the right of way.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Soviet Government, which began systematic efforts six weeks ago to keep "Voice of America" radio broadcasts out of Russia, is now operating an increasingly effective and vast "jam network," George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, reported today.

It is probably reasonable to conjecture that few of the permanent residents of Cape Cod will be visiting Greenwich Village between now and Friday evening. The fewer the better. For some of the goings-on that began last night at New Stages would be enough to cause the bile of the most composed Capester to froth.

PARIS, June 13 -- During the past two days informal discussions on Yugoslavia have been taking place in Paris. Sir Charles Peake, Britain's Ambassador in Belgrade, reported yesterday on the situation there to Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin, who saw Marko Ristitch, Yugoslav Ambassador to Paris, today.

The Mayor's reception room at the southwest corner of City Hall, known throughout the world to celebrities who have received there "the keys" to the city, will soon have a "new look" under plans approved tentatively yesterday by the Art Commission.
The arithmetic of the State Department in Washington, by means of which three plus three can be twelve if you count on four fingers, was upheld here yesterday by a Columbia University professor.

I read with considerable interest your editorial of May 26, "Coddling the Airlines," and Carleton Putnam's letter to you dated May 27, criticizing your editorial stand, and in particular your praise of Mr. Rickenbacker's belief that the airlines have been coddled.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 ---- Paramount has made an offer to John Ringling North of the Ringling Brothers' Circus for the right to make a motion picture about "The Greatest Show on Earth," the studio disclosed today. If Mr. North accepts the offer, Cecil B. de Mille will produce and direct the picture, according to the studio.
LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- Promoter Jack Solomons claimed today he has received a tempting offer to move his "world championship" bout between Bruce Woodcock and Lee Savold to New York.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 13 -- While Princeton University was announcing an intensified investigation of the disappearance of two Rembrandt etchings and a Degas drawing from its art museum on Saturday, a second week-end case, involving the loss of a one-eighth inch cube of radioactive cobalt was reported to the borough police today.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 13 -- Dr. Edmund Ezra Day's resignation as president of Cornell was announced today at the university's annual commencement exercises. Dr. Cornelis W. de Kiewiet, Provost of the university for the past year, has been chosen as acting president.
CHICAGO, June 13 -- Allan B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, said today he did not believe the Brannan farm program would be passed this year.

Beating Boston College yesterday afternoon and again last night at Dexter Park in Woodhaven, Queens, St. John's University qualified for the finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball championship at Wichita, Kan., June 22-24.
