BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 13 -- In a statement to Tanyug News Agency today, Slobodan Penezitch, Minister of Interior for the Republic of Serbia, said that 800 Bulgarians, including members of the Communist party and the Fatherland Front, had fled from Bulgaria and received asylum in Yugoslavia since the break in the Communist Information Bureau world.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 13 -- The Palestine Conciliation Commission appeared tonight to be back where it started more than six weeks ago after an inconclusive private meeting between the United States, Turkish and French members of the commission and Dr. Walter Eytan, head of the Israeli delegation to the so-called peace talks.

The letter of C. Monteith Gilpin on Swiss-held German assets, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 6, had the merit of drawing the attention of the American public to a subject given far too little consideration here. It is, indeed, of the greatest importance that in any future war the potential aggressor should know that if he loses he will also lose his "nest eggs" in neutral countries.
Russell T. Woodward has been named manager of marketing of Telechron, Inc. He has been with the company for sixteen years in various sales capacities.

Central Illinois Public Service is offering to holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for 446,000 new shares of common stock at $14.125 a share on the basis of one new share for each five shares held. The offering, which will expire on June 23, is being underwritten by a syndicate of fifty-one banking firms headed by First Boston Corporation.

Acts of politeness or service beyond the call of ordinary duty by members of the 10,000-man street cleaning force of the Department of Sanitation will be rewarded with a $25 cash prize for ten successive Wednesdays, beginning June 29, Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell announced yesterday.

Good demand by local trade houses and hedge-lifting held coffee futures steady most of the session on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Profit-taking supplied the selling. Prices dropped in the last few minutes as weakness in the market brought out commission-house selling.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was irregular yesterday and closed 10 points lower to 8 points higher than on Friday.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., June 13 -- Frank Smith and Stanley Remsen of North Hills scored 34, 32 -- 66 to tie with Pete Brown and Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills, who shot 35, 3l -- 66, for first place in the weekly amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association at the Rockville Country Club today.

On the recommendation of Lee Tracy, Jed Harris is perusing a new script called "Where We Came In," written by Seymour Gross. It is Mr. Tracy's belief that the opus has possibilities as a Broadway vehicle for himself, and he would prefer Mr. Harris as the sponsor.

The Public Education Association recommended yesterday the discontinuance of New York's released-time program for religious education on the ground that it has been a contributing factor to truancy and that "inherent difficulties" in its operation "cannot be eliminated."

Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., announced yesterday plans for the public flotation of $50,000,000 of twenty-five-year debentures intended to finance prepayment of $45,000,000 of 2 per cent notes maturing serially through 1952, and of $5,000,000 of ninety-day 2 1/4 per cent notes.

Field Marshal Viscount Alanbrooke, former chief of the British Imperial General Staff, and Viscountess Alanbrooke were among 1,957 passengers who arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth. She docked at Pier 90, North River, at 8:35 A. M., a few minutes before the French liner De Grasse, also inbound from Europe, tied up at an adjacent pier with 637 passengers.

No good citizen could possibly object to stating in public that he does not belong to or support "any party or organization that believes in, advocates, or teaches the overthrow of the Government of the United States by force or by any illegal, unconstitutional methods."

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- The lavish new musical comedy, "Miss Liberty," already a sellout for months ahead, made a hit tonight at its world premiere before a capacity audience, including many Broadway celebrities, at the Forrest Theatre.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Arrangements for new price support programs for tobacco and peanuts were announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

TOKYO, June 13 -- As a result of its experience in the recent railway strike, Japan's Cabinet has decided that the national police force is too weak. The Cabinet will undertake a study immediately to see how the force may be strengthened.
LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., and Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills tonight drew the No. 1 seedings in singles tennis play starting at Wimbledon next Monday.
How to look cool and chic when midsummer temperatures soar might have been the title of Russeks' showing of shadowy sheers, crisp taffetas and glistening satins yesterday at the St. Regis Roof.

With Brooklyn officialdom turning out in full force for the occasion, the harbor gave a noisy welcome yesterday to the S. S. City of Brooklyn as the newest of the Ellerman and Bucknall Lines' passenger-cargo ships steamed up the Narrows on her maiden voyage.

Representatives of four mediation agencies failed yesterday in a five-hour session to find a settlement formula for a dispute between the Good Humor Corporation and four locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- James E. Webb, Acting Secretary of State, and Alexander S. Panyushkin, Soviet Ambassador, agreed in a brief meeting today to begin talks soon on Russia's $11,000,000,000 lend-lease account with the United States.

CLEVELAND, June 13 -- Public and private welfare leaders throughout the country were charged today with taking part "as offenders or supporters" in violation of civil rights. The accusation was made by Dr. Benjamin E. Youngdahl, one of the country's leading social work educators.

Municipal politics, particularly the selection of a Democratic candidate for Mayor, was the main background topic last night at a testimonial dinner given for Lazarus Joseph, City Controller at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of his election to the "Hall of Fame" of the Educational Alliance Alumni Association.

Two witnesses came to the defense yesterday of Capt. Ragnar Ecklund, master of the cargo ship Exmouth, at the Coast Guard hearing into the causes of the crash on May 5 between that vessel and the Hellenic Beach off the Delaware coast.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- S. J. Solomon, who has long been active in aviation, told the Senate Commerce Committee today that the airlines might need "the spur of new contestants" to develop low-cost, large-volume air travel.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Gordon Gray, Secretary of the Army, reported to President Truman today that he had got to the bottom of the action by which Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, was classed as "unemployable" for a temporary assignment in Germany.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 13 -- Gus Salerno, pro. and Morton Cummings of the home club, combined their cards for a winning best-ball score of 33, 32 -- 65, six under par, in the one-day pro-amateur tournament conducted by the Westchester County Golf Association at the Hampshire Country Club today.

A forward echelon of forty-five officers from the Quartermaster School at Camp Lee, Va., toured the kitchens of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday in a combined operation of the Army, Air Force, Navy and the British Army Catering Corps.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, one of the nation's leading atomic experts, unequivocally endorsed today the job being done by the Atomic Energy Commission.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- The following statement was made today by the Standard Oil Company of California:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, said today that its policy was not to allow an emergency shortage of food or any other essentials to develop in strikebound Hawaii.

This week marks the real beginning of the long-planned general offensive by the nation's big labor unions to impose a "fourth round" of wages on the nation's industry and, through industry, on the national economy as a whole.

Speaking to dispel any doubts about the firmness of woolen goods for fall, American Woolen Company yesterday announced a 10 cent a yard price rise on fourteen numbers in its medium range of broadcloths and fleeces for women's coatings.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 13 -- Only a "show of force" by a battalion of fully armed Belgian occupation troops, acting in cooperation with British military authorities, made it possible today for the dismantling program to proceed in one of four Ruhr plants prohibited by Allied agreement.

The decision yesterday of the United States Supreme Court against the use of exclusive dealer contracts by the Standard Oil Company of California will affect only slightly the marketing practices of the major oil companies. East of the Rocky Mountains virtually all the companies do not require their dealers to sign exclusive marketing agreements.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Both retail and wholesale grocers are selling a larger tonnage of merchandise this year than in 1948 despite the lower dollar volume that has followed price declines, trade associations in the two fields said today.

MOSCOW, June 13 -- A new declaration by the Greek rebels of their willingness to accept Soviet proposals for settlement of the Greek civil war was printed prominently by Pravda today. It intensified interest in the possibility of further exploration by the United States and the Soviet Union of the Greek problems.

Part of Senator Hickenlooper's charge that the Atomic Energy Commission had been guilty of "incredible mismanagement" rested on the shipment of isotopes to foreign countries. These isotopes are variations of a given element, differing only in weight. Most are radioactive, some are not.

Three Rings, bought by Mrs. Evelyn L. Hopkins of Cleveland for $7,500, ran his earnings for her to ten times that amount when he scored a front-running victory in the $22,925 Queens County Handicap as the spruced-up Aqueduct track opened its three-week meeting yesterday.

With City College's 103d commencement exercises scheduled for Thursday evening at Lewisohn Stadium, special wards and ceremonies began at the college yesterday and will continue through today and tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Plans are being made here for the Presidential appointment of a fact-finding board to take up the dispute in the steel industry that is expected to threaten an industry-wide strike.

For the sudden and widespread attacks that must be expected in any future war, the United States would have to rely on "citizens trained in advance and so diffused throughout the nation that some would be instantly available no matter where the need arose," Brig. Gen. Wendell Westover declared yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, June 13 -- As a result of the recent United States protest to Britain concerning her bilateral pact with Argentina, the leading peronista paper, Democracia, printed this morning the biggest anti-United States headline since the alleged assassination plot of last September.
Details of two apartment buildings to be erected on sites in East and West Side areas of Manhattan were given in plans filed yesterday. Each building will cost $500,000.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, of Vermont, charged on the Senate floor today that United States farmers have lost "hundreds of millions of dollars" by the failure of the Secretary of Agriculture, Charles F. Brannan, to support prices "when he has full authority to do so."
BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- Just as the Red Sox' pitching staff appeared to be sinking for the third time, owner Tom Yawkey rushed to its rescue today with his usual life preserver.
CHICAGO, June 13 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, struck vigorously today at both communism in trade unions and "rapacity" in American business.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- A resolution directing the President to cut 5 to 10 per cent from appropriations made to the executive branch for the fiscal year starting July 1 was approved, 8 to 2, by the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the executive departments today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 13 -- Neither the Marshall Plan nor the North Atlantic Pact will produce lasting world peace unless this country pursues the policies that led to the lifting of the Berlin blockade, Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, told 200 labor education leaders here tonight.

While opinions differ widely as to the extent and duration of the present decline in business activity, corporations now are believed to be in a stronger financial position to withstand the readjustment in prices and production than they were after other inflationary periods, according to recent surveys.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 13 (AP) -- Leonard Steiner of Cornell University scored an easy 6-2, 6-0 victory over Harvey Burdick of Syracuse University to spotlight the first day's activity in the twenty-seventh annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis tournament today at the Montclair Athletic Club.
Deaths by drowning in the city last year amounted to 222 persons as compared with 459 deaths in 1924 when the population was 2,000,000 less.

BERLIN, June 13 -- Four-power talks on trade and transportation arrangements between Berlin and the Eastern and Western zones of occupation ended today without any agreement being reached but with what was described as "an area of agreement" in sight.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today voided a decision which held that the United States Government, in taking over ships in wartime, should pay the same price the owners could have gotten in private sales.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The deeper thinkers among the Administration politicos have worked out an ideal solution from their viewpoint of the problem of Communist espionage in the United States. They hope that the outcome of the several trials and inquiries now proceeding will be this:
No displaced person in New York State has become a public charge, Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 13 -- Dr. George Dimitrov Sotirov, the United Nations social affairs officer who was described on Saturday in a Federal Bureau of Investigation report as "an espionage suspect," today categorically denied any undercover activities and asked for a speedy inquiry to establish the truth.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Pelham G. Wodehouse, British writer and creator of the immortal "Jeeves," was told by the Supreme Court today that he must pay the Federal Government taxes on $127,000 paid to him by American publishers for stories he wrote in 1938 and 1941.

Conferences of the Port of New York Authority with representatives of the airlines seeking use of New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, broke up in bitterness yesterday. They had been in progress since Jan. 25. The principal points at issue, including the authority's asserted immunity to lawsuit, will go for adjudication before Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff at Jamaica.

With the trading deadline drawing close, the Giants yesterday effected a swap of catchers with the Reds, dispatching Walker Cooper to Cincinnati for Ray Mueller in a straight player deal. The Giants, who left for Cincinnati early in the evening, will pick up Mueller at Crosley Field.

While City College honors one of its most brilliant students at the 103d commencement Thursday evening at Lewisohn Stadium the student presumably will be asleep in Cairo, Egypt. He is Junior Warrant Officer Walter Richard Davis, 27 years old, an administrative assistant in the office of the military attache to the United States Embassy in Cairo.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration today allotted $7,400,000 to France for the purchase of American coal and $6,811,000 to Western Germany for the purchase of American cotton and linters.

Measuring the packaging industry's ability to produce new materials and types of packaging for a possible war conversion will be a major task of the new Munitions Board advisory committee on packaging, storage and materials handling, it was learned yesterday.

In reply to a letter from Walter Hoving, president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, suggesting the appointment of a Citizens Committee to inquire into the costs and practices of relief, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard wrote yesterday that such a committee was named by Mayor O'Dwyer in October, 1948.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 13 -- Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, today protested to the Security Council against the British Government's decision to resume arms shipments to the Arab states.

LONDON, June 13 -- A mass meeting of 1,400 shirt-sleeved and perspiring railwaymen voted overwhelmingly tonight to call for a "go-slow" movement among London's 50,000 railway workers unless their wage demands were settled by July 4.
Outstanding open-market paper showed a 13 per cent decline last month, registering the sharpest monthly drop since April-May, 1946, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

BUFFALO, N. Y., June 13 (AP) -- Some 1,500 members of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, struck today at the Bell Aircraft Corporation plant. Their demands center on a fifteen-cent hourly wage increase.
The calling of the Rev. John O. Mellin as pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, was confirmed yesterday by the Presbytery of New York.

CLEVELAND, June 13 -- Lou Boudreau's world champion Indians won a game that won't help in the American League standings and, by the same token, the Dodgers lost one that will have no effect on the seven-game National League winning streak they brought into the huge Municipal Stadium tonight.

LONDON, June 13 -- Although the end of the seventeen-day Liverpool dock strike gave a brighter appearance to the stock market here today, there was no appreciable increase in the volume of public buying.

To anyone who scans rooftops in an average city's downtown area it will be apparent that there are to be seen a surprisingly large number of flagpoles. Scarcely an old building is without its staff; on some newer structures this appointment seems to have been omitted.

QUEBEC, June 13 -- With the declared objective of seeking out the road of freer trade and markets the twelfth congress of the International Chamber of Commerce got under way here today and immediately ran into major difficulties.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today to give prompt approval to "simple changes" in a proposal to modify outstanding securities of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.
LEEDS, England, June 13 (Reuters) -- New Zealand practically accomplished its objective of avoiding defeat in the first cricket test against England today but came perilously near disaster.

NANKING, June 13 -- Neutral military observers here have written off Southeast China as a strategic base for Nationalist military operations. With the Communists now apparently regrouping and readying themselves for the next phase of their sweep below the Yangtze, these observers are watching for new signs of a Communist offensive aimed at 300,000 Nationalists still guarding the approaches to the West and Southwest China.

PARIS, June 13 (AP) -- France's surprising tennis players swept on to a 3-2 upset victory over Czechoslovakia today in the quarter-finals of European Zone Davis Cup competition and qualified to tackle Hungary in the next round.

The New York City Police Department pushed across a run in the seventh inning and defeated the New York City Fire Department, 1 -- 0, in their twentieth annual baseball struggle last night at the Polo Grounds. A crowd of 12,000 witnessed this well-played, tense duel for the benefit of the welfare funds of both departments.

Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended with last April a net profit of $9,762,216, equal to $1.11 a share on the common stock. Net profit for the April quarter a year ago was $7,890,632, or 90 cents a common share.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The San Jose Waterworks, San Jose, Calif., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 39,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, Series B, $25 par value, that is to be offered to the public.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- John L. Lewis and a vast segment of the Northern coal industry are in agreement on creation of an industry coordinator to aid in the "permanent stabilization" of the bituminous fields.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 9 per cent last week, compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 12 per cent.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N. Y., June 13 -- Construction of a rehabilitation hospital in Tel Aviv, Israel, at a cost of $100,000 as a memorial to Col. David Marcus, killed on June 10, 1948, while leading the Israeli forces against the Arabs, was voted at today's session of the annual convention of the Independent Order of Brith Abraham.

Last December the Board of Transportation recommended to the city's Board of Estimate a six-year transit construction program requiring $900,000,000. At about the same time Controller Joseph estimated that no more than $655,000,000 would be available in the capital budget in the next six years for all permanent city improvements, including transit, schools and other costly projects.

The Federal Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday after a hearing on the appeal of John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, from his thirty-day jail sentence for contempt of court in refusing to answer questions at the Communist trial.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday the settlement of one Supreme Court action and the start of another as a result of his fourteen-month investigation of cemeteries alleged to "profiteer on sorrow."

Conflicting "recipes" for democracy will continue to postpone the establishment of a centralized government for Germany, Maj. Gen. Frank Keating, head of the First Service Command, declared yesterday. The former Military Governor of the American sector of Berlin spoke on "Berlin and the Russians" at a luncheon for eighty-five persons at the Lotos Club, 5 East Sixty-sixth Street.

PARIS, June 13 -- The Foreign Ministers of the Big Four powers, assembled in council here, spent today waiting for the Kremlin to decide whether their session would achieve at least a limited agreement for a kind of prolonged and reinforced truce in Berlin.

Action at this time on tax treaties pending before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee would be a practical move toward establishing basic conditions that would tend to aid and stimulate the flow of American capital abroad, according to a statement issued by the National Foreign Trade Council.

An extra dividend of $3.50 and the regular semi-annual dividend of $1.50 were declared for payment on July 15 by the Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company of Canada, Ltd. On Jan. 15 an extra of $4.50 was distributed, while in July of last year $3.50 was paid.
The big fresh water news comes from the Battenkill, near Manchester, Vt., where Vincent Bushee surprised the local trout fishermen as well as himself by bringing in a twelve-pound brown trout.

Fossilized mammals, whose remains were found in Alaska's frozen tundra with hair and skin still attached to skeletons, although some of the animals have been extinct for 400,000 years, will go on exhibition this morning at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- The wheat market showed considerable strength in the early part of the session on the Board of Trade this morning, but reacted later on scattered selling. Some buying by millers was in evidence early, but outside buying in general was not very active.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., June 13 -- Mrs. George Stern of Century won the qualifying medal with a round of 47, 43 -- 90 in the women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class B tournament on the Leewood links today. A slim field of thirteen competed for places in the match play which starts tomorrow.

LONDON, June 13 -- Ten prominent business men and bankers and one labor leader have been named to the Dollar Export Board, newly formed private organization to promote Britain's sales to the United States and Canada.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 13 -- Farm Delt Democrats of the Middle West made clear today that they would make the new Brannan plan for support of farmers' income the major issue of the 1950 Congressional elections.
PRINCETON, N. J., June 13 -- The attention of Princeton's 675-man senior class, the largest in the university's 202-year history, turned today to class day ceremonies.
Jacob S. Potofsky, head of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, said yesterday that the Israeli Government would need $800,000,000 to carry out its four-year austerity program.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 13 (UP) -- Miss Barbara Canine of Western Michigan College shot a par 78 on the soggy Ohio State University course today to capture medalist honors in the eighteen-hole qualifying round for the national intercollegiate women's golf tournament.

The stock market plunged yesterday to a five-year low under renewed liquidation, which produced losses of 1 to more than 4 points. It was the widest break in the series of retreats extending over the last month, and left only a few issues on the higher side at the close.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- President Truman reiterated today that he wanted a "clean" reorganization bill exempting no agency from the proposals to streamline the Government, according to Dr. Robert L. Johnson, chairman of the Citizens Committee for Reorganization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 13 (AP) -- Turkey gave a hero's burial today to a Turkish diplomatic courier who died of gunshot wounds last week in Russia.

The climate of the Equator, which Chiquita Banana prefers so strongly to the refrigerator, is copied as closely as the A. P. can do it in six ripening rooms in the company's newest warehouse at 650 Stuart Avenue, Garden City, L. I.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Administration's $4,000,000,000 Marshall Plan appropriation was further jeopardized today by "suggestions" from a Congressional "watchdog" committee that the amount could be cut $740,000,000 "without retarding European recovery" in fiscal 1950.

BUFFALO, June 13 -- Salesmen of America, supported by engineers, production and transportation men and by the firepower of advertising, will have more effect upon the permanence of peace than all the diplomats and more effect on wages and real prices than all the negotiators, David S. Austin, vice-president of the United States Steel Corporation of Delaware, declared here today.

PARIS, June 13 -- Total world food production is nearing pre-war levels, but distribution is uneven and deficient, Sir Herbert Broadley, Deputy Director General, today told the Food and Agriculture Organization's Council when it opened a two-week meeting here today.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 14 (AP) -- Lieut. Charles Oliver of the United States Military Academy took only one day to reach the round of 16 in the twenty-seventh annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships as he combined a first-round bye with a pair of easy triumphs today.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- A House Commerce subcommittee was told today that shippers and consumers throughout a great portion of the country had benefited through operation of the Federal Barge Lines.

In an effort to evade obligations it assumed under the first peace treaties following the war, the Soviet Government has rejected the formal demands of the United States and Britain for three-Power discussion regarding the flagrant violations of these treaties by the former Axis satellites in the Balkans, with respect to human rights and fundamental freedoms.
The bass season will get under way in New Jersey today and in the St. Lawrence region of upper New York tomorrow, with reports indicating excellent prospects for early fishing in both areas.
Theatre tickets are being sold regularly at nine leading hotels in the city without a license, John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A Senate-approved bill to permit manufacturers to absorb freight rates and quote delivered prices, provided they are acting independently, is a "classic example" of business "getting what it wants," Walter B. Wooden, associate general counsel of the Federal Trade Commission, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- For the first time since union officers have been required to sign non-Communist oaths, the compliance affidavits of three labor leaders were submitted today to the Department of Justice for investigation.
Those individuals who have special ideas as to the kind of desk they want may now design their own by using a new group of integrated units planned by Alexander F. Styne.

For more than four weeks a conference committee representing the Senate and the House of Representatives has been wasting time, and frittering away opportunity, in a deadlock over the issue of giving the President power to reorganize the executive departments of the Government along the lines so persuasively recommended by Herbert Hoover and his fellow-experts.

DETROIT, Mich., June 14 -- Good advertising can reflect and create public inclination to buy, John Giesen, director of the retail division of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, told delegates to the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association today in the Book-Cadillac, Hotel.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 3,173 against 2,663 last week and 3,054 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,457 arrivals yesterday, compared with 1,365 last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 15 -- The Washington Times-Herald said today in a copyrighted story that J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was reported to have resigned.

LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- Top-seeded Americans, led by favorite Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., scored one-sided victories in the Queens Club tennis tournament today, but some of the lesser known women invaders were eliminated.

Democratic county leaders indicated yesterday that they were in no hurry to press for a decision on the party's mayoralty nominee and that they probably would not meet in conference until early next week.

HONOLULU, June 14 -- A stalemate appeared certain today over the offer of Hawaii's striking longshoremen to unload all strikebound food and feed cargoes in the island's harbors and return the Matson liner Lurline to regular service.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- While in negotiation with two groups of bituminous coal operators, John L. Lewis today asked two other major groups to confer on the terms of an agreement to take the place of one expiring June 30.

Your admirable editorial "Freedom Comes First" underlines the importance of making a clear distinction between the crassly opportunistic "liberalism" of Communists and the genuine liberalism of American progressives.

Degrees and certificates will be awarded to 9,088 regular candidates -- the largest number in the history of New York University -- while six public figures will receive honorary degrees at the 117th commencement today on the Hall of Fame Campus, 181st Street and University Avenue.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 14 -- It was announced tonight that fresh drilling under police supervision on Erfdeel Farm near Winburg in Orange Free State had extracted a much smaller gold yield than that reported in the "fabulous" gold strike on the farm announced on June 3.

Saadeddine Hassani, 21-year-old son of the late Sheik Taj Eddin Hassani, first president of the Syrian Republic, was found dead at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon on the bathroom floor of his room in the Statler Hotel.

The enactment of an amendment to the city's zoning law that would reduce the city's traffic congestion by easing zone restrictions on the building of parking garages is being studied by the City Planning Commission, Robert F. Wagner Jr., the commission's chairman, said yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 14 -- Prace, organ of the Czechoslovak trade unions, asserted today that the formation of a "Catholic Action" by a group of laymen and priests endorsing cooperation with the Government was "not an anti-church rebellion but a sincere effort of upright and educated Christians to prevent a schism in their own ranks and to prevent falsification and distortion of the words of the Bible."

SHANGHAI, June 14 -- Several hundred workers from tank farms, filling stations and other plants of the Texas Company (China) moved into the headquarters of the United States firm today, locked the doors of the modern-style office building and would let none of the staff leave until their demands had been met, according to company officials.
School children from Brooklyn and Queens paid a visit yesterday to a dairy farm within New York's city limits.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 14 -- A group of fifteen United States newspaper, magazine and radio correspondents arrived here today en route to Batavia to look into the Indonesian question at the invitation of the Netherlands, Government.

Apparently there are three categories of Senators so far as the issue of budget economy is concerned. There are the members of the so-called economy bloc, dominated by the Republicans, who have sought on several occasions to reduce individual appropriation bills and have been repulsed in each attempt.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 14 -- Highly pleased with the results of the Midwest farm belt conference that firmly forged their farm program into a political weapon, Democrats may soon set up other regional meetings to consolidate forces for the 1950 Congressional elections.

TOKYO, June 14 -- Japan's Communist party will instigate a "revolution through violence in August or September," Kozen Hirokawa, chief secretary of the Liberal party, told the press today following a conference with Premier Shigeru Yoshida.
A campaign to prevent Israeli from developing as a free and strong state is now being waged on several fronts, it was asserted yesterday.

Spokesmen for the State Department of Labor, in noting that the employment situation in New York State was becoming "progressively worse," said yesterday that a record had been set last week by workers seeking state unemployment benefits.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. embarked on his political career today. He took the oath that made him a member of the House of Representatives. Ordinarily a freshman does not make much of a stir on his first day. It was obvious from the attention he received, however, that many were speculating whether he had started up the path to the Presidency.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 14 -- Finance Minister Eliezer Kaplan submitted to the Knesset [Assembly] today the Government's proposals for a budget of 34,000,000 Israeli pounds for regular services to be covered by internal revenue. He also presented an extraordinary budget of 62,000,000 Israeli pounds for a development program financed by other sources, including the Export-Import Bank.

Sixteen thousand persons from fifty-one countries applauded yesterday an emphatic assertion by Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, that "no war of importance will ever be started while the General Assembly is in session."
NANKING, June 14 -- The Chinese Nationalists have, on paper, an army still estimated here at about 1,000,000 men.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company yesterday announced an average reduction of 5 per cent in wholesale prices of its woven carpet line, effective today. The company took the action to meet public demand for lower prices although labor rates have not been reduced and materials costs have not declined sufficiently to offset the cut, according to G. C. Denebrink, vice president for sales.
Twenty-two students in this area received prizes yesterday in the American Automobile Association's annual school safety poster contest.

The stock market's attempt to rally yesterday was only of short duration and lacking in force. While some of the rails and oils managed to advance as much as a point, the heavy industrials either closed unchanged or with fractional increases.

An 11-year-old Jewish child who was saved by a Gentile couple from probable death at Nazi hands in Warsaw eight years ago was reunited yesterday with the woman who acted as the child's mother for five years.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 14 (AP) -- An investigation into conduct of the office of executive secretary of the New York State Mayors' Conference was asked today by a Rochester delegation.

Although it is only in a tentative stage the limited program for work relief which is being considered by Welfare Commissioner Hilliard has already come under sharp attack from the Commerce and Industry Association. The association speaks of "shovel-leaning," of "leaf-raking," of "boondoggling."

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture today opposed a new plan for controlling planting and marketing of cotton backed by twenty-eight Senators and leaders of the cotton-producing states.

BERLIN, June 14 -- The striking railroad workers of Western Berlin today rejected by an overwhelming majority a compromise proposal to settle their grievances and end the strike. Thus the twenty-three-day-old strike, which paralyzes rail transport between Berlin and Western Germany, will continue.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Council of Economic Advisers, which is preparing an important mid-year analysis of the country's economy for President Truman, was urged today by leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations boldly to attack rising unemployment under the (full) Employment Act of 1946.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 14 -- The Connecticut Legislature finally adopted a budget tonight. The Democratic-controlled Senate gave in to the Republican House and accepted its terms.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, June 14 -- Encouraging signs have appeared in reports of the rate of reduction of manufacturers' inventories of lead, Robert L. Ziegfield, secretary, Lead Industries Association, New York, told members of the Idaho Mining Association here today.

Cookie sales, baby-sitting and fairs paid off for thirteen members of Senior Girl Scout Troop 65 of Washington who sail today on the George Washington to visit Girl Scout Troops in England, Holland, Switzerland and France.

"WHAT a pity!" exclaimed one of the most influential Communists in Yugoslavia, "what a pity it is that the world is divided into two hostile spheres! You on your side, with all the wealth and material resources! We on ours, with all the brains and wisdom!" The speaker was addressing John Gunther and was perfectly serious.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, disclaimed further responsibility today for proving laxity by the Atomic Energy Commission in guarding against the employment of possible subversive individuals.

LONDON, June 14 -- Prices in the stock market here today were unable to weather the sharp overnight break in Wall Street, and with the sole exception of a minor flurry in Orange Free State gold favorite, poor conditions were seen throughout.

Many a mother's little lamb will gambol on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park this Saturday at 2 P. M. Some will dress like dolls. Others will wear kilts. And 100 will dance under paper parasols sent by the children of Gifu City in Japan.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 14 -- A subcommission of journalistic experts called upon the United Nations today to help develop domestic news agencies in underdeveloped areas by rendering unspecified assistance -- which might take the form of financial subsidies, technical aid, supply of equipment or other action.

Autumn was in the air yesterday at the Ritz Carlton Hotel when the Millinery Creators' Guild gave a glimpse of hats to come. The eight member houses all seemed to be thinking along much the same line, with variations.

Department store profits from February through April were down 48 per cent in comparison with the corresponding period last year, the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, reported yesterday. The study was based on stores throughout the country having more than $1,000,000 sales annually.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, still the nation's top military man though now president of Columbia University, put himself flatly on record today in support of a pay increase for members of the armed forces.

QUEBEC, June 14 (Canadian Press) -- Advertising must have no aim which is in conflict with the interests and desires of the consumer, said a resolution passed today at a meeting of the International Chamber of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Exports of motion-picture films and equipment during the first quarter of 1949 were valued at $5,572,065 against $7,770,460 during the first quarter of 1948, the United States Department of Commerce announced today.

BOSTON, June 14 (AP) -- Representatives of 1,000 members of the National Maritime Union, CIO, and five colliers companies continued talks today in an effort to negotiate a new contract by midnight tomorrow.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 14 -- A meeting of faculty members of the University of California passed tonight a resolution urging that the university's board of regents "eliminate or change" a loyalty oath prescribed for the 4,000 teachers and administrative employes on the university's eight campuses.

Small businesses can fight off the threat of declining sales by adopting the research techniques developed for the country's larger enterprizes, according to speakers in a panel discussion on marketing sponsored by the Sales Executives Club yesterday in the Roosevelt Hotel.

Two issues of Texas state educational institution bonds totaling $15,000,000 and secured by the interest earnings of the state's Permanent University Fund were sold yesterday at competitive bidding to a banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. at an interest cost of 1.647 per cent.

The House of Representatives is expected to vote today on a much-needed bill to raise pay scales throughout the armed forces. This bill, revision of an earlier measure, is based on a thorough study of the subject by a committee appointed by the late Secretary of Defense James Forrestal.

Some pleasant young people, educated at Yale in the cool season, are giving a pleasant performance of the late Federico Garcia Lorca's "The Shoemaker's Prodigious Wife," which opened the hot season at the Provincetown Playhouse last evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- A. P. Giannini, who founded the multi-billion-dollar Bank of America financial empire, but disliked the idea of dying wealthy, left an estate of only $480,000, it was disclosed today.
A drought that has lasted for nineteen days in this city and for twenty-three days in northern New Jersey set yesterday a record for this season of the year.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Administration forces in the House, battling to obtain final passage of a national housing bill, scored a preliminary victory today in forcing the Rules Committee to clear the legislation for floor debate and a vote.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- Paul Robeson's triumphal return to the Soviet Union drew toward a close today amid greater acclaim than had been given in recent years to any United States visitor to the nation that Mr. Robeson publicly hailed as "my second Motherland."

"F. D. R. -- My Boss," a book of memoirs by Grace Tully, who was President Roosevelt's private secretary from 1928 until his death, has been scheduled for September publication by Scribners. The book was originally planned for publication in 1947 by Simon Schuster.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- A former Communist who won War Department praise for his part in developing the atomic bomb talked freely about himself before the House Committee on Un-American Activities today. He refused, however, to discuss political affiliations or activities of associates during or since his Communist party membership.

An impending country-wide shortage of galvanized steel sheets because of greatly expanded agricultural construction was disclosed here yesterday. Robert Marsand, manager of exports of Eastern Metals Corporation, Newark, N. J., said government officials had turned down applications to increase export quotas because of bumper crop reports throughout farming areas. Sheets will be needed for building additional grain elevators, he said.
CHICAGO, June 14 (UP) -- Retail prices of meats and some canned goods will rise this summer at the corner grocery store, experts forecast today.

BERLIN, June 14 -- A committee of the Bremen Senate is redrafting a press law for the state of Bremen to remove all ambiguities and bring the law into line with the desires of the United States Military Government in Bremen, it was reported officially today.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 14 (AP) -- A team of ten women has been chosen to represent the United States in the world ski championships to be held next Feb. 13-18 at Aspen, Col., a National Ski Association representative said today.
HELSINKI, Finland, Wednesday, June 15 (UP) -- Premier Karl A. Fagerholm's Government squeaked through by a two-vote margin on a vote of confidence today.

PARIS, June 14 -- The critical hour in the Paris Conference has arrived. Today's session was held in secret at the request of Mr. Vishinsky. It was the Soviet delegate also who asked for the recess on Saturday and Monday. After Sunday's meeting, moreover, he exacted a pledge from his fellow-delegates that no word of what was going on in these private seances should be given to the press.

A petition of the Federal Landlords Committee, Inc., for an increase of 15 per cent over the maximum rentals frozen on March 1, 1943, was denied without prejudice yesterday by the New York City Rent Advisory Board.

QUEBEC, Jan. 14 -- Monetary stability and convertibility are on their way but they cannot be hurried. They still demand herculean effort on the part of the debtor and liberal policies on the part of the creditor nations, the twelfth congress of the International Chamber of Commerce was told here today by speakers for the United Kingdom, the United States delegation, a representative of the International Monetary Fund and others.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) -- Authorities on Russian religion today accused Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky of faking Bible quotations to back his arguments at the Paris meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

A two-year contract bringing wage increases to 2,000 workers was signed last night by representatives of Bloomingdale's and the Department Store Union, Local 3, independent. The pay rises are retroactive to Feb. 28.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 -- Van Johnson has been named by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to appear with Robert Walker, Deborah Kerr and Peter Lawford in "Please Believe Me," which Norman Tautog will direct starting early next month.
LOS ANGELES, June 14 -- Within four years, for $2,000, the public will be able to buy a gigantic photographic map of the universe to be made from Palomar Mountain with the giant Schmidt telescope.
A clear, feminine voice, reading into a microphone, illustrated yesterday how a group of women has been contributing lately to the efforts of blind students to cope with their academic examinations.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., June 14 -- The medalist, Mrs. George Stern of Century, and other leading scorers in the qualifying round were winners of their first matches in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class-B championship flight today at Leewood Golf Club.

The John and Michael Flynn Playground was opened yesterday by the Department of Parks at ceremonies presided over by Commission Robert Moses. The playground occupies the square block from Third to Brook Avenue, between 157th and 158th Streets in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.
Releasing an impressive burst of speed in the final stage of the race, Mrs. Benjamin F. Whitaker's Miss Request rushed to victory in the Corvette Classified Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

RANGOON, Burma, June 14 (AP) -- Prime Minister Thakin Nu said today the crisis in Burma had passed. He said the future of the country still depended on the outcome of the current conflict with several rebellious groups, but there was no likelihood of a return to "the bleak days of February, March and April," when the people lived in a "terrible state of suspense."

IRWINTON, Ga., June 14 (AP) -- An all-white grand jury freed two white men today of any guilt in connection with the lynch-murder of Caleb Hill Jr., on May 20. After an all day investigation in this rural Georgia county seat, the jury ruled that there was not enough evidence to bring the pair to trial.

Coffee futures were mixed and moderately active on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange here yesterday. After declining in early trading on commission-house selling induced by weakness in other markets, prices rallied sharply on trade demand and short-covering.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 14 (AP) -- The president of the National Association of Retail Druggists declared today that the association "strongly opposes" any plan that will deprive medicine and allied professions of "private enterprise status."

PARIS, June 14 -- Examining reports that indicate an adverse food situation in a large part of the world, members of the Executive Council of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization today decided to urge on governments steps for better distribution and for expanding trade pending the annual conference to be held at Havana in November.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., June 14 -- Southern coal operators and representatives of the United Mine Workers went through the motions of collective bargaining today while the operators waited for some first-hand information on the reported plan to set up a "coordinator" for the soft-coal industry.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The net income of American farmers in the first half of 1949 is probably running at least 10 per cent below the same period last year, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

CINCINNATI, June 14 -- Despite a twenty-four-hour stretch of bewildering managerial moves and player manipulations, it remained for the long, willowy right arm of Larry Jansen to get the Giants off on the right foot as they opened their second Western invasion tonight.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 14 -- Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador to the United States, and Henri Bonnet, the French Ambassador, were among eight distinguished persons who received honorary degrees today at Princeton University's 202d annual commencement.

I have read your editorial "Freedom Comes First" with a great deal of interest. It is unfortunate that the average American's memory of things is so short. Those following communism and other movements never lose an opportunity to collect articles, advertisements, etc., supporting this and that, or opposing it, whatever the question of the moment may have been.

On April 11, 1949, Senator McCarran, who by grace of the voters of Nevada and the seniority rule of the Senate is chairman of the Judiciary Committee, was speaking to reporters about proposed changes in the displaced persons law. "This matter is not going to be pigeonholed," said Senator McCarran.
The success of Russia's Communist armies in China is "one of the major catastrophes of all history," the Most Rev. Paul Yu-Pin, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Nanking, said last night.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 14 -- In view of the present status of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, former German Minister of Finance, there is nothing to prevent his appointment by the projected West German government as an official. Maj. Gen. George P. Hays, United States Deputy Military Governor, declared today at a press conference.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- A railroad executive told superintendents tonight they could cultivate good community relations by dependable cooperation with the local press.

Effective today, the new agency, Charles Schlaifer Co., Inc., takes over the Twentieth Century-Fox advertising account for all media, it was announced yesterday. These are newspapers, magazines, outdoor posters, radio and television. Included also is the account of the Roxy Theatre.

Twenty originals of confidential State Department documents that Whittaker Chambers says Alger Hiss gave him in 1938 were introduced in evidence by the prosecution yesterday as the Hiss perjury trial went into its eleventh day in Federal Court.

Signs that the New Jersey milk price war had spread to New York were seen yesterday when three large local milk dealers announced a cut of 1 cent in the price of quart containers of homogenized milk sold in stores.

Thirty years ago this morning a Vickers-Vimy biplane, stained with fog, salt spray and ice, settled down on a deceptive bog at Clifden, Ireland, sank to its hubs and nosed up on its propeller. In it were Capt. John Alcock, D. S. C., the British flier, and his British navigator, Arthur Whitton Brown.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Ellis O. Briggs, now Ambassador to Uruguay, will succeed Joseph E. Jacobs as Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, the White House announced today. Christian M. Ravndal will succeed Mr. Briggs as Ambassador to Uruguay.

The largest senior class in the history of Manhattan College was graduated yesterday at the college's ninety-eighth commencement exercises on the Riverdale campus in the Bronx. Five thousand persons attended.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- All grain futures closed at about the best levels of the session today, after following a decidedly irregular price course. Wheat shorts turned the market strong in the last few minutes, their buying apparently being due to apprehension in regard to continued wet weather in the Southwest where harvesting is badly delayed.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- John L. Lewis indicated today that he would make no move to call a formal strike of 80,000 Pennsylvania anthracite miners before Aug. 15.
LONDON, June 14 -- The loss of wages began to tell on the British strikers today, and a major improvement took place in the troubled labor situation.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The way to make Army officers' uniforms more uniform is to send them all to the same cleaner exactly the same number of times, a House Armed Services subcommittee was told today.

Estimated earnings of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile manufacturers, amounted to $11,913,774 after taxes and special charges for the six months ended on April 30, according to the consolidated report of John P. Stevens Jr., president, issued yesterday.

If education is committed to belt-line, mass production, schools must strive to be "high class" factories, Prof. George W. Sherburn of the English Department of Harvard University declared last night at the initiation of fifty-six Hunter College students into Phi Beta Kappa, national scholarship honor society.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 23 I read with interest a news report of a statement by Mrs. Anne X. Alpern, city solicitor of Pittsburgh, made on April 22 at the New School for Social Research in New York, in which she is quoted as saying, "I have yet to see a woman's organization go direct to the Governor or Legislature."

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 14 -- Further steps in an obviously speeded-up Allied anti-trust program in Germany were announced today as reports reached here that John J. McCloy, newly appointed High Commissioner, would bring a handpicked decartelization staff when he assumes office next month.
The shortage of dollars outside the United States seems to be the principal problem on the minds of the foreign Rotarians and their guests attending the international convention in New York.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 14 -- The leadership of the Yugoslav Communist party today accused the Cominform of "murdering" Kotchi Drozde, former, head of the Albanian Communist party who was executed in Tirana on the midnight of June 11.
New York's strike-bound breweries closed the door yesterday on further concessions to members of the United Brewery Workers, CIO, who on Monday rejected a proposed settlement.

Vic Raschi became the first pitcher in the majors to attain ten victories and the Yankees achieved a new season's scoring high last night as Casey Stengel's pace-setting Bombers celebrated their return to the Stadium by walloping the White Sox, 15 -- 3, before 37,683 spectators.

The ultra-conservative New York Zoological Society learned late yesterday afternoon that 200 new animals were on their way to the Bronx Park Zoo and promptly began to panegyrize with the courage and enthusiasm of a circus press agent before the tent is up.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Preston T. Tucker, rear-engine automobile promoter, today was invited to go before a Federal grand jury and elaborate on a statement he made after having been indicted.

A continuance of cautious buying by both consumers and outlets in the garment and allied industries until the end of the year was predicted last night by Harry J. Delaney, executive vice president of Meinhard, Greeff Co., Inc. He spoke as a member of a panel at a round table discussion in the Woodstock Hotel, sponsored by the Conference of Apparel Credit Men, Inc., affiliate of the New York Credit Men's Association.

MOSCOW, June 14 -- The authoritative journal New Times proposed today that millions of unemployed Americans and West Europeans as well as idle plants and industries be put to work on orders for the Soviet Union and East European countries.

At 2042 Continental Avenue, the Bronx, noise means nothing. Yesterday, for instance, a couple of men bounced a 450-pound safe three flights of stairs without attracting much attention from the three families in the building.

PARIS, June 14 -- After members of the Foreign Ministers Council had met off and on for more than five hours today, it was learned authoritatively that they had come to no decision regarding even the narrowly limited agreement on Berlin that they had sought.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Frankie Frisch made his debut as manager of the sagging Cubs today, but the Bruins, continuing their losing ways, took a 9-2 licking from the Phillies. The Cubs' loss was their thirty-second against only nineteen victories.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Joe Ostrowski's six-hit pitching gave the St. Louis Browns their first victory of the season over Washington, 7 -- 2, tonight after eight straight defeats by the Senators.

The Lighthouse of The New York Association for the Blind has completed plans for vacations for 509 blind adults and children at a cost of $26,000. The first party of forty-five blind women will go to River Lighthouse at Cornwall-on-the-Hudson. The little blind Nursery School children will go to their new cottage on June 22, built on the grounds of River Lighthouse.

"Lost Boundaries," the Louis de Rochemont production filmed in Portsmouth, N. H., and Kittery, Me., and dealing with a Negro family who "pass" as white, will have its premiere at the Astor Theatre on Thursday, June 30, it was announced by Film Classics, which is releasing the drama.

The heavyweight boxing match between Jersey Joe Walcott and Ezzard Charles, which will mark the debut of Joe Louis as a promoter, is slated to be televised by NBC video on June 22, it was learned yesterday. NBC also will carry the radio account.

Federal mediators brought about yesterday afternoon a settlement between East and Gulf Coast steamship operators and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, whose contract expires at midnight tonight.

Ninety thousand New York youngsters -- all ages, all races, all religions -- are dusting off their duffle bags and hunting up their country clothes in anticipation of free or low-cost vacations at the 180 camps and summer homes operated by local social agencies, the Children's Welfare Federation reported yesterday.

Attentive to his duty as Works Progress Observer, our special sidewalk superintendent has paid one of his periodical visits to the site now being "improved," as the realtors put it, as the United Nations headquarters.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 14 -- Four young golfers from the Hill School led the field in team play at the halfway mark in the opening round of the annual Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today as sixty-seven competitors from fifteen private schools battled par over the first half of the 36-hole qualifying route.

Maurice Evans' search for a new vehicle is likely to wind up with the acquisition of Terence Rattigan's bill of two short plays, "The Browning Version" and "A Harlequinade," which were successfully done in London. Mr. Evans intimated that much yesterday when he said he "likes the plays very much" and would get busy at once in tying them up.

VIENNA, June 14 -- The announcement today from Sofia of the expulsion of Traicho Kostov from the Communist party and the news from Budapest that not only has former Foreign Minister Laszlo Rajk disappeared from the Government but with him a half-dozen of his associates indicates that the struggle between communism and national communism has claimed more victims.

Roderick Beebe, coach, headed a party of fourteen as the Tabor Academy crew sailed yesterday aboard the S. S. Marine Flasher of the United States Line for England to compete in the Henley Regatta starting June 29.

Lenox Hill Hospital incurred a net deficit of $215,530 last year despite an increase of $296,182 in receipts for services, William H. Zinsser, the president, reported yesterday. The revenue increase was more than offset by additional costs of $397,499.
Led by the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, four Europe-bound ships will sail from North River piers between 11 A. M. and 11:30 P. M. today. They will carry 5,000 passengers.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Army sent around the world today orders that its records be purged of stigmas upon "a very considerable" number of American civilians who admittedly might have been unfairly labeled as "unemployable" in the occupation programs.

BALDWIN, L. I., June 14 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of the home club shot 40, 41 -- 81 to finish in a deadlock with Mrs. Jerome Herbert of Old Oaks, 40, 41 -- 81, for low gross honors during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Willow Brook Club today.
PITTSBURGH, June 14 (AP) -- Wally Westlake scored practically a one-man victory tonight as he rapped a homer, a triple and a ninth-inning double to lead the Pirates to a 4-3 victory over the Braves.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Federal Government has 125 outstanding college graduates in training, on the job, to fill important junior administrative posts, the National Institute of Public Affairs said today. It has been experimenting with such a program for fourteen years.

Although the Yankees and Giants will be playing for charity when they clash at the Stadium on the night of June 27, both sides will field the strongest club possible. This was announced yesterday by President Daniel R. Topping of the Yankees at a luncheon given by Mayor O'Dwyer at Gracie Mansion.

The Republican State Committee raised $130,000 from a fundraising dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. More than 1,800 Republican office-holders, either attending the affair or reserving a seat in lieu of a campaign contribution, made the dinner a record one from the point of view of a major party treasury.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 14 (AP) -- Miss Grace Lenczyk of Hartford, Conn., the favorite, opened defense of her women's intercollegiate golf crown today with a 6-and-5 victory over Miss Clara Jane Mosack of Detroit.
The sharp crack of revolver fire resounded yesterday in the subbasement of Brooklyn's General Postoffice Building. But the reports caused no alarm.

GENEVA, June 14 -- In the first important vote at the International Labor Organization conference the committee on industrial relations today rejected the amendment submitted by the employers to the proposed convention on the rights of workers to organize and bargain collectively.

When the speeches about the privileges that come with the attainment of the bachelor degree are made tomorrow night at City College's 103d commencement exercises, Martin Sternberg of 1236 Ward Avenue, the Bronx, will be unable to hear them.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 14 (AP) -- Jersey City squared its five-game series with Toronto at two games apiece tonight by defeating the Leafs, 5 -- 3, before 1,147.

DETROIT, June 14 -- Marcel Cerdan, ring product of French Morocco, who holds the world middleweight championship, and Jake La Motta, his challenger from New York's Bronx, were resting easily here tonight, on the eve of their title struggle.

BOSTON, June 14 (AP) -- Romping to six runs in the opening inning when Joe Gordon blasted a four-run homer and Manager Lou Boudreau angrily resented being hit with a pitch, the Indians tonight whipped the Red Sox, 10 -- 5, before 35,137 fans, Fenway Park's largest night crowd.

Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, Commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, asserted yesterday that education of all citizens in "the true meaning of communism, its motives and techniques," was vital to the protection of American liberties.

JERUSALEM, June 14 -- Israeli and Arab forces evacuated positions held in the neutral ground around the Government House in Jerusalem at noon today under a decision reached in meetings of the Mixed Armistice Commission.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 -- Neither the weather nor the Cardinals, who pulled the second triple play of the major league season, could stop the Dodgers under the Sportsman's Park lights as the Brooks swept to their eighth straight victory by a 7-2 score and achieved the longest first place lead of the season -- three full games.

Corn is coming from Florida now that's as fresh and sweet in flavor as that which is harvested on nearby farms and rushed to market in a matter of hours. Bohack stores have this vegetable, three six-inch ears in a cellophane package for 29 cents.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) -- College graduates are not having enough children to replace themselves. The Population Reference Bureau said today. It posed the question:

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Administration told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that its Point Four program for assisting the underdeveloped areas of the world would add an additional $48,000,000 to the United States budget.

Decorations and medals for special service in both the military and civil division of the Order of the British Empire were conferred yesterday by Sir Francis Evans, British Consul General, at a ceremony in his residence at Beekman Place.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today opposed a bill which would permit the Interstate Commerce Commission to require railroads to install radio communications as a safety device.

PARIS, Wednesday, June 15 -- One million French civil servants started a twenty - four - hour "warning" strike at midnight and confronted the country with virtually complete paralysis of normal governmental activity for a full day.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP) -- Virgil Trucks held the Athletics to one hit tonight as the Tigers started their Eastern invasion with a 4-0 victory. Hank Majeski's fifth-inning single was the only blow off Trucks' right-handed slants as he registered his ninth victory of the season.

AT the instant the contract was signed, the temptation was almost overwhelming. The urge was fierce to run right out to Briggs Stadium in Detroit and snuggle up to a ringside pew so as not to miss one thrilling, nerve-tingling, pulse-quickening moment of the Jake LaMotta- Marcel Cerdan bout for the middleweight championship of the world.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was moderately active and steady and final prices were 5 to 15 points net higher than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Senator Wayne Morse, Republican, of Oregon, today attacked as "sophomoric" a statement by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday that Federal aid to education would endanger local control.
LONDON, June 14 -- Discussion of Britain's immediate economic future now revolves almost entirely around the problem of pound sterling devaluation.

LONDON, June 14 -- Freedom to publish was emphasized as the essential principle of the press, at the annual meeting of the Empire Press Union here today, by the president, Col. John Jacob Astor, publisher of The Times of London.

Barring an appeal by the Government within thirty days, officers of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service will receive back overtime pay amounting to more than $400,000, as a result of a decision of the United States Court of Claims last week.

Views expressed by Ernest K. Weir that steel operations will go down to 85 per cent of capacity by July 1, and decline further in the second half of the year, found ready endorsement among steel company officials here yesterday. They added that Mr. Weir's opinions -- presented in a letter to stockholders of the National Steel Corporation, of which he is chairman -- were sound and should serve to strengthen the market.

New issues of common and preferred stock to be put on the market today by underwriting syndicates here include offerings of public utility and industrial shares valued at more than $10,000,000. The offerings are as follows:

CALCUTTA, India, June 14 -- The Congress party, dominant party of the Indian Government, suffered its first serious defeat in a by-election in Calcutta, the result of which was announced today. The election for the seat in the West Bengal Provincial Assembly was won by Sarat Chandra Bose, who polled about 20,000 votes against 6,000 for his Congress party opponent.
The 8-year-old Queens girl, with whom a Sing Sing life-term prisoner exchanged blood in a desperate effort to save her from leukemia, died Friday morning, it was learned yesterday.

The case of acute indigestion harassing the primary market for tax-exempt bonds has seemingly passed following the successful marketing of the latest "jumbo" state borrowing -- the $84,000,000 Minnesota bonus issue. The pricing of the Minnesota obligations was not only a triumph for the banking syndicate which bought the bonds, but a needed revelation for the market as a whole.

LONDON, June 14 -- Fitting Israel into the pattern of British policy for the Middle East will be one of the problems discussed by British ministers and ambassadors in eight middle eastern countries who will attend a conference at the Foreign Office during the last week of July.

SEOUL, Korea, June 14 -- The Most Rev. Patrick J. Byrne, Apostolic Delegate to Korea, was consecrated here today Titular Bishop of Gaza in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Mary Immaculate. Bishop Byrne, a member of the Maryknoll Mission in Korea, is a veteran missionary in the Far East.
ROME, June 14 -- The Italian Government announced today that oil deposits had been found in northern Italy for the first time in such quantity as to permit their exploitation for commercial purposes.
ASCOT, England, June 14 (AP) -- Royal Ascot opened today with all its old elegance and some new plunging necklines which caught the eyes of fashion critics.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The National Association of Retail Grocers, at its golden jubilee convention, adopted today a five-point program calling for strengthening amendments to the Robinson-Patman Act and repeal of Federal oleomargarine taxes.

Gilbert Green, Illinois chairman of the Communist party and former head of the Young Communist League, took the Stand at the Communist trial yesterday as the second party leader to testify in his own defense.
A muscular ex-convict was indicted yesterday on charges of extorting $8,638 from two non-union dress jobbers on threats to shut down their plants by strikes.
Advocates of the released time program of religious education sharply criticized the Public Education Association yesterday for "rejecting" and "misstating" a survey prepared by its own investigator.

An explosion of illuminating gas in a fourth-floor Greenwich Village apartment at 1 Jane Street at Greenwich Avenue at 11 A. M. yesterday led to the discovery in the apartment of the body of Miss Dorothy Jean Carson, 27 years old, formerly of Toronto, Ont., a secretary of the Textile Research Institute, here.

Sweeping changes in the Puerto Rico, formerly the Agwilines' Borinquen, will reduce her passenger accommodations from 377 to 199 persons when she begins service to San Juan and Trujillo City Aug. 18, the Bull Line announced yesterday.

DETROIT, Mich., June 15 -- In the interests of reducing store operating costs, standardization of terminology and accounting methods in workrooms must be accomplished, Lawrence Lachman, treasurer of Bloomingdale Bros., declared today.

The record-setting drought passed yesterday its twentieth day here and its twenty-fourth in northern New Jersey with little prospect for alleviation of water supply and crop problems in the metropolitan area.

The Singer Manufacturing Company increased its earnings in 1948 to $15,169,779, equal to $16.85 a share, from $13,707,536, or $15.23 a share, earned the year before, M. L. Lightner, president, reported at the annual stockholder meeting yesterday.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People appealed yesterday by letter to Governor Dewey for the appointment of a special prosecutor and special grand jury to investigate the circumstances in the death of Herman Newton, who was shot by Patrolman Donald Mullen last May 27 in Brooklyn.

SHANGHAI, June 15 -- Nationalist sources in Formosa and Canton assert their ships have laid no mines in the mouth of the Yangtze, according to reports reaching this seaport whose ocean shipping has been at a standstill six days. The Canton reports appear to be from official quarters.
Housing is the most acute problem in Israel today, Mrs. William Prince, president of the Women's League for Israel, declared yesterday at the Delmonico Hotel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 15 (AP) -- Miss Grace Lenczyk's march to the 1949 women's intercollegiate golf title showed no signs of slowing up today. The 21-year-old defending champion from Newington, Conn., defeated Miss Carol Clark of Wyoming, Ohio, a Miami (Ohio) University junior, 5 and 4, in today's quarter-finals.

Four hand written memorandums summarizing State Department documents were described yesterday by Miss Eunice A. Lincoln, State Department private secretary in 1938, as being in the handwriting of Alger Hiss.
Gilbert Green, Ohio chairman of the Communist party, made three vital admissions yesterday in his testimony at the Communist trial. He admitted:
A planeload of 203 rare and exotic creatures for the Bronx Zoo had an exciting arrival at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday morning after a 7,500-mile flight from Africa.

The Reading Tube Corporation, maker of copper tubing and brass pipe, has leased the new warehouse and office building, owned' and built by William and Richard l Walsh, at 36-12 to 36-16 Fortyseventh Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens, according to RomanCaswell Company, broker.
PITTSBURGH, June 15 (AP) -- The Pirates rallied for four runs in the ninth inning today to defeat Braves, 8 to 7, for their second victory of the series.

CINCINNATI, June 15 (AP) -- The board of directors of the American Oak Leather Company today recommended dissolution of the sixty-eight-year-old organization. Declining business was given as the reason for liquidating the $7,000,000 concern, said James E. Mooney, president.

PARIS, June 15 -- At a hastily called meeting at the French Foreign Ministry tonight the Western representatives pressed Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky for a quick settlement of the Berlin railway strike through a promise by Soviet authorities not to retaliate against the strikers.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- With only a handful of votes in opposition, the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill increasing pay throughout the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Spokesmen for the House capitulated to the Senate today and agreed to accept a bill under which a single branch of Congress could veto any governmental reorganization plan prepared by the President.

Directors of the Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., have voted a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share, payable to common stockholders on July 20. This is double the previous quarterly disbursements, the last of which was on April 20, and places the stock on a $1 annual basis.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 15 -- The tents were up, the camp counselors were ready and $1,400 expense money was in the bank today in preparation for a social service program that Hackley School, a private preparatory institution for boys, will begin Monday.

The New York Curb Exchange came yesterday to the rescue of confused members on the issue of proxies in the current contest between the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Company and its founder, Sherman M. Fairchild. Prior to recent disclosure that a contest existed, some member firms had exercised proxies for the accounts of customers.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Continuing increases in gasoline prices, which since 1946 have raised American motorists' bills by an estimated $1,300,000,000 annually, were booked today for Senatorial investigation.
WASHINGTON, June 15--The Air Force announced today the re. tirement, effective June 30, of Maj. Gen. Leo -4- Valton, Deputy Director of the Secretary of the Air Force Personnel Council.

Beginning later this month, Columbus Circle will undergo a "face-lifting" operation that will involve removal of trolley tracks, repaving and rearrangement of its roadways, according to plans disclosed yesterday by Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan.

Shorn of all but one small Swastika, though still bearing her original name in large Gothic letters, the glittering white and buff Grille, once the proud yacht of Adolf Hitler, made her debut in New York harbor yesterday.

Claire Giannini Hoffman, daughter of the late A. P. Giannini and sister of L. M. Giannini, president of the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association of San Francisco, was elected a director of the bank yesterday. Mrs. Hoffman, first woman director to take a seat on the board of the world's largest bank, fills the vacancy left by the death of her father, founder of the bank.

The youngsters on the children's floor at Roosevelt Hospital, 428 West Fifty-ninth Street, had a new course of treatment added to their regimen this week -- and every one of them loved it. With the opening of a "diversional therapy room" at the hospital, play has become part of their daily routine.
