CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15 -- Harvard University dedicated to scientific research today a 125,000,000-volt synchro-cyclotron, described as "filling a gap in the tool chest" of the physicists.

A second arrest in connection with the alleged shakedown of garment district dress jobbers was announced yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, who said a 35-year-old certified public accountant had been indicted on forgery and conspiracy charges.

Allie Reynolds racked up his seventh pitching triumph while Larry Berra and Bobby Brown hit home runs yesterday as the Yankees, without undue strain, turned back the White Sox for the second straight day, 9 -- 4.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 15 -- Mrs. Arthur K. Atkinson Jr. of the Creek Club shot 42, 39 -- 81 to win low gross honors during the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Nassau Country Club today.

QUEBEC, June 15 -- Development of regional unions for the mutual expansion of trade with their borders was endorsed today by the third plenary meeting of the International Chamber of Commerce here. Such regional unions, it was argued, did not prejudice and could help re-establishment of a wider flow of world trade.

The British national health service could not be carried by the British Government except for the Marshall Plan money it receives from the United States. This and other sharp criticisms of the service were reported last night to the Bronx County Medical Society at the Concourse Plaza Hotel by William Alan Richardson, editor of Medical Economics, after a two-month survey of the system in England, Scotland and Wales.

The issue of Government spending to combat recession, debated lately in your letter columns by Miles Pennybacker, Raymond K. Price and Alfred Baker Lewis, is continued in your news story of June 11, quoting an address by Leon Keyserling.

Government mediators, led by William N. Margolis, assistant director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, last night continued efforts to effect a settlement between East and Gulf Coast vessel operators and the two remaining unsigned Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 15 -- The three Western Military Governments took under serious consideration today a plan for the elimination of licensing restrictions on political parties -- a practice that has been in force in all zones as a security measure since the beginning of the occupation.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Eddie Waitkus, star first baseman for the Philadelphia National League baseball team, was shot and seriously wounded late last night in the Edgewater Beach Hotel on Chicago's North Side by a girl fan whom he did not know.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Longstanding differences between the Pan American Airways Corporation and James M. Landis, former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, flared today with official charges by Mr. Landis that the airline had given the public a false impression with its reports and emphatic denials by the company.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- An installation employing production-line techniques in processing plutonium for use in the improved type of atomic bomb tested at Eniwetok will go into operation this month at the Hanford (Wash.) works, a Congressional investigating committee was told today.

" Roughshod," an RKO Western drama with Robert Sterling, Gloria Grahame, John Ireland and Claude Jarman Jr., which arrives at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Mark Robson directed and Richard H. Berger produced from a screen play by Geoffrey Homes and Hugo Butler and a story by Peter Viertel.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 -- Although the issue of musicians' royalties on commercial use of phonograph recordings, which caused a halt in recording work throughout last year, is momentarily quiescent, indications are developing that these is more friction ahead.

There is no moral satisfaction to be had out of saying "I told you so" at the expense of the misery of our faithful friends, the good Chinese. Nevertheless the things that are happening in the Yangtze Valley may show us wherein some of our judgments have been at fault.

The Seventy-seventh Division Association installed its new officers for the year 1949-50 at ceremonies last night in the association's memorial building, 28 East Thirty-ninth Street. William A. Restle replaced Arthur C. Brucks as president of the association.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A bill has been approved by the Senate Expenditures Committee to create another commission -- this one to study federal-state government relations with a view to their coordination. But a large part of the work this commission would do already has been done.
Leaders of both branches of organized labor served notice yesterday on both major political parties that they expected to be consulted in the selection of "desirable" candidates for Mayor.

Investment interests who pur-I chased the Yorkville property at' 1220, 222 and 224 East Eighty-nintht Street, near Third Avenue, a few lyears ago,'have widened their hold!ings at this point by buying 216 from Anna Maltese and 218 from Josephine iV[. Brautigam, it was announced yesterday by Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, brokers in assembling the plot.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The $17,500,000,000 light and power industry is "over the hump" in its nip-and-tuck battle to meet rising demands for electricity, Elmer L. Lindseth, president of the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, said today.

FRANKFORT, Thursday, June 16 -- A request transmitted by the Military Government for assignment of Dr. George S. Counts, of Columbia University, and Prof. Louis Wirth, of the University of Chicago, for special work in Germany has met with silence from the Department of the Army in Washington, it was disclosed today by Dr. Alonzo G. Grace, director of the Military Government education division.
PITTSBURGH, June 15 (AP) -- The leading purchaser of Pennsylvania grade crude oil today announced price increases of 13 to 16 cents a barrel.

PARIS, June 15 -- Today's twenty-four hour "warning" strike of organized civil servants throughout France failed to develop into a general walkout and disappointed union hopes for complete paralysis of functions of government.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Columbia Gas System, Inc., New York, has requested the Securities and Exchange Commission to issue an order authorizing it to invest $6,100,000 in 3 1/4 per cent installment, promissory notes of its subsidiary, the Manufacturers Light and Heat Company, Pittsburgh.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Commission and mill buying took the slack out of the wheat market on an early setback on the Board of Trade today, and later trade became more active, with heavy short covering which resulted in a big upturn.
Freedom, even in this country, is on the defensive, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase declared yesterday before 20,500 persons attending New York University's 117th Commencement.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 15 (AP) -- The New York State Mayors' Conference called today for "financial home rule" for all cities and villages in the state through extension of permissive tax powers.

The recent excitement resulting from the arrival of big striped bass on Long Island and New Jersey beaches has died down to a faint pulse, but the surfcasters are persistent, for who knows when the bass will hit in again.

The program proposed by President Truman for the development of underdeveloped areas is beginning to assume more concrete form as both the American Government and the United Nations whip their separate but complementary plans into shape for presentation to their respective deliberative bodies.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 15 -- Dr. Dirk U. Stikker announced today the Netherland Government's platform for a roundtable conference projected for a final settlement of the Indonesian question.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 15 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett told the Knesset [Parliament] today in his first appearance since his return from the United States that Israel would not bow to pressure for territorial concessions from any quarter and asked that the problem be left to the parties concerned. This remark was principally directed at the United States.

The Moscow correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in a dispatch June 12, reported that the newspaper Communist published in Stalinabad, Tadjikistan, had called for a strengthened drive against religion, deploring the continued strength of Moslem beliefs among the Tadjik people.

Government labor officials from four Latin-American countries and a labor relations specialist from India will be welcomed today at 10 A. M. by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, in his offices at 80 Centre Street.

NEW DELHI, India, June 15 -Newspaper editorialists and commentators in Government circles here regard the by-election in Calcutta in which the Congress party condidate was beaten almost 4 to 1 as a clear warning to the dominant party of the people's dissatisfaction with the Congress Government after almost two years.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The following tables show the present pay scale of officers and enlisted men in the armed services and the scale of pay that would prevail under the bill passed by the House today:

In a deal adding to its realty holdings on the West Side in the I vicinity of new POrt Authority bus terminal, Webb Knapp, Inc., }yesterday reported the purchase of virtually the entire city block [bounded by Eleventh and Twelfth ! Avenues, West Forty-third and iForty-fourth Streets, from the United States Trust Company, executor of the Eugene Higgins estate.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House Rules Committee, whose job it is to clear major measures for action, or to block them, has demanded a complete picture of Government spending before it gives the right of way to further appropriations.

The advisability of lower commissions for the in-and-out trader, as distinct from a retail rate for infrequent dealers in securities, was under discussion at a quarterly meeting of the National Association of Customers' Brokers in Oscar's Oldelmonico yesterday afternoon.

FLORENCE, Italy (AP) -- Italian furniture makers have dropped ultra-modernistic designs for the sober, comfortable styles of the past. This was the theme in three furniture pavilions of the thirteenth National Handicrafts Fair held here from May 14 to June 2.
The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn conferred 660 degrees, the largest number in its history, at its ninety-fourth annual graduation exercises, held in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids on June 22 on issues of temporary loan notes totaling S15,148,000 dated July 18, 1949, and due on Jan. 15, 1950. Proceeds of the sale will be used to continue the temporary financing of three state-aided projects, Melrose Houses in the Bronx; Stephen Foster Houses in Manhattan, and Farragut Houses in Brooklyn.

The City Planning Commission reserved decision yesterday after a public hearing on the proposed closing of sections of four city streets crossing the site of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, for which ground was broken on June 7.

Charges that dollar shortages are being used as an excuse by foreign countries in discriminating against American exporters were aired yesterday at a meeting of the American Office Supply Exporters Association in the Governor Clinton Hotel.
Finalists in both the men's individual saber and the women's individual foil fencing championships were decided last night at The Henry Hudson Hotel gymnasium.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday, and final prices were 10 to 21 points net higher.

Dollar outlay for all advertising last year was estimated yesterday at the new high of $4,830,700,000. The estimate, made by Printer's Ink, represented a gain of 13.4 per cent over that of 1947. Newspapers accounted for the largest portion of the total with 36.2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 15---The Administration's Point Four program for the underdeveloped areas of the world is on the President's desk after a long arid acrimonious dispute between the State and Treasury Departments ovr how to finance the operation.

The vacant land measuring 175 by 107 feet at the northeast corner of Hillside Avenue and 120th Street, in Richmond Hill, Queens, will be improved with an apartment house by the Birch-Hillside Corporation, which bought the property from Sevander Nelson, it was reported yesterday by the Home Title Guaranty Company, which provided title insurance.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The United States Government intends to press its charges of violations of human rights against the Governments of Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary, despite the refusal of the Soviet Union to cooperate in settling the dispute, it was indicated today by James E. Webb, Acting Secretary of State.
DETROIT, June 15 -- Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of General Motors Corporation, said tonight that he believed there was no serious and lengthy depression ahead.

SEABROOK, N. H., June 15 -- A New England version of a modern, but bloodless, "war between the states" opened today in this border town as Henry F. Long, Massachusetts' Tax Commissioner, deployed agents to record the registration numbers of Bay State motorists who patronized New Hampshire's newest state liquor store, just across the line.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 15 -- The Hill School won the Horace D. Taft Trophy in the qualifying round of the Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association tournament at the Greenwich Country Club today with a four-man aggregate of 638 for 36 holes, 7 strokes better than that of the nearest rival, Hotchkiss.

Gasoline stocks last week dropped 1,622,000 barrels to 117,484,000, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil supplies, however, gained 1,805,000 barrels to 60,402,000 and heavy fuel oil stocks were up 1,838,000 to 65,901,000.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 15 -- Two Princeton University laboratory employes, one a laborer and the other a stock clerk, lost out today to a group of scientific adversaries. The latter employed lie detectors and Geiger counters to find first the thieves and then the loot of a week-end theft from the university's Palmer Laboratory.

It was Eddie Arcaro vs. Ted Atkinson, and Eugene Jacobs' Colonel Mike vs. Greentree Stable's One Hitter, in the closing yards of the $22.875 Shevlin Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday, with Arcaro and the Colonel holding on for the decision in what is known to the trade as a whingding finish.

PARIS, June 15 -- With the Council of Foreign Ministers hovering on the verge of fateful decisions, an increasing number of diplomats here tonight were speculating that if a final Big Four trade were made this week involving an agreement to sign an Austrian peace treaty, Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky might make a last minute effort to obtain an over-all "Balkan settlement."

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted unanimously today to investigate a plan sponsored by coal operators in five Northern states to set up a coordinator for the industry and to establish a permanent organization for collective bargaining with the United Mine Workers of America.

" Inside USA," the Broadway hit show produced by Arthur Schwartz which is now running in Chicago, will be packaged as a half-hour musical revue for the CBS television network next fall if current negotiations are successful. The series would alternate with Jack Benny's television program in the Thursday 9 P. M. time period, both programs to be presented twice a month.

The first vote in the Senate yesterday on the new labor bill marked a defeat for the Administration and a victory for the moderates who are willing to revise or repeal the Taft-Hartley Act but who want a fair and well-balanced measure in its place.
GENEVA, June 15 -- The closed shop was described today as the "legitimate objective" of labor by a United States Government delegate to the International Labor Organization conference.

NEVIS, N. Y., June 15 -- A summer colony of 165 hardy Puerto Ricans is taking root in the rolling fruit-laden farmland of Dutchess County in a highly successful experiment aimed at easing the local farm labor shortage.

LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy, 34-year-old Miami (Fla.) tennis star, powered his way into the quarter-finals today in the Queens Club tournament, annual tune-up for the Wimbledon championships.

CLEVELAND, June 15 -- Emotionally disturbed children who receive psychiatric treatment get along better at home and in school than those who do not, it was reported today by Herschel Alt, executive director of the Jewish Board of Guardians, New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 15 -- West Coast shipowners and the National Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, reached a labor agreement today forestalling a threatened strike and establishing wage parity between the West and East Coasts.
John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, who has been conducting an inquiry into overcharges for theatre tickets, moved yesterday to stop the sale of tickets at nine hotels.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- A published story that J. Edgar Hoover had resigned as head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation because of use of confidential FBI files in the Judith Coplon trial was denounced today as "ridiculous" by Attorney General Tom C. Clark.

Television receiver manufacturers are producing more television-radio - phonograph combinations than they are selling, according to a market survey of more than 800 set owners released yesterday by Sylvania Electric Products, Inc. The survey revealed that 35 per cent of all television-radio-phonograph combinations produced since 1946 are still in supply pipelines (factory, distributor and dealer stocks).

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- The "demand that Israel resettle the Arab refugees" was denounced as a "grave injustice" in a resolution adopted today, by delegates to the eleventh biennial convention of Pioneer Women, the women's labor Zionist organization of America.

ROME, June 15 -- Attempts that Italian oil interests are understood to be making to obtain a monopoly on exploitation of oil and gas resources in Italy were said in authoritative circles today to represent a threat to economic relations between Italy and the United States that might eventually affect the European Recovery Program here.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's stand on Federal aid to education was criticized before a Senate subcommittee today by a New York City Board of Education spokesman.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today the following principal changes for the week ended June 8:

With the exception of newsprint, the paper industry is turning into a new price decline averaging 10 per cent, key officials reported yesterday. A few declared that some drops were as high as 15 per cent, and nearly all agreed that further declines were in prospect.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11 -- More than $1,000,000 of United Nations relief funds for the Middle East have been wasted in excess profits for middlemen here in the past four months, an official investigation has revealed. The purchasing system is being reorganized and means are being sought to prevent similar practices in the future.

WATERBURY, Conn., June 15 -- Fifteen - year - old Joseph Mayo was doing nicely tonight in St. Mary's Hospital reading comic strips as his own prescription for recovering from a collapse today from diabetes while touring with the Ringling Brothers, Barnum and Bailey Circus.

LONDON, June 15 -- The executive committee of the National Union of Railway Men promised the Ministry of Labor today that there would be normal working complements on the railways next Sunday as far as its members were concerned.

Cucumbers, radishes, lettuce and zucchini (green Italian squash) are so abundant and attractively priced now that it's thrifty to serve them often. This is the right time, too, to experiment with appetizingly novel ways of offering them.

A group of AFL and CIO unions have given financial support totaling $12,500 to the newly organized National Film Cooperative, 270 Broadway, it was announced yesterday by Robert Delson, chairman, in a report to the cooperative's organizing committee.

Decrying the current emphasis on loyalty oaths for teachers, two college presidents declared yesterday that the suspicion placed on the teaching profession was creating hysteria and endangering academic freedom. They said that most educators in this country were loyal, conscientious American citizens.
BLUEFIELD, W. Va., June 15 -- Contract negotiators for the Southern Coal Producers Association and the United Mine Workers held a three-hour meeting and reported a blank today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer recommended today that Congress provide about $10,000,000 to modernize equipment of the Federal Barge Line so it could be operated at a profit -- and then sold.
SAIGON, Indo-China, June 15 (AP) -- Emperor Bao Dai, who has assumed the leadership of a French-sponsored government of Viet Nam, has announced the liberation of about 1,000 political prisoners.

The strongest and most effective weapon in the United States arsenal is the mutual respect and forbearance that exists among members of different religious faiths, Secretary of the Navy Francis P. Matthews asserted last night.
Since Thomas J. Hamilton reported under dateline Lake Success, June 8, that "Chinese delegates seek U. N. positions," I would appreciate it if you will publish the following corrections:
LONDON, June 15 -- No extension of yesterday's setback was seen in the stock market here today. Neither was there any evidence of buying, and most sections were lethargic.

The Park Association of New York City, Inc., urged the Board of Estimate yesterday to transfer 885 acres on the north shore of Jamaica Bay, already owned by the city, to the Department of Parks for eventual development of a park and wildlife preserve.

Max N. Bollay, associated with the company since 1938, has been named metropolitan division manager of Bacardi imports, Inc. The division covers metropolitan New York, up-state New York and Connecticut.

The apartment house for fortynine families at 1266 Grand Concourse, northeast corner of 168th Street, the BroW, was sold by Steel Co. to the Sanalis Corporation in a transaction negotiated by Mrs. Anne Inse]stein, broker. It fronts 100 feet on the Concourse land is assessed for $160,000.

Boys who throw stones and fire air rifles Long Island Rail Road trains set in May a record thus far in 1949, Horace B. Stetson, road superintendent, reported yesterday. In such attacks on fifty-three trains, forty-eight windows were broken and ten passengers and an employe suffered slight injuries from flying glass, he said in appealing to parents, educators and civic leaders for assistance in curbing the rise in juvenile misbehavior.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 15 -- Kale and Company, manufacturer of acetates, has been designated as the first of the I. G. Farben chemical trusts units to be placed on sale in the initial Western Allied program for breaking up the huge monopoly.

Fifteen workmen were injured, two seriously, yesterday afternoon when shoring collapsed under a floor under construction in the building being erected to house the Parke-Bernet Galleries. The building is on the west side of Madison Avenue near Seventy-seventh Street.
VILLANOVA, Pa., June 15 (AP) -- A young executive of the Hanover Shoe Company was killed today in the crash of his plane on a Main Line estate fifteen miles west of Philadelphia.

CLEVELAND, June 15 (fP)-- Dresser Industries, Inc., reported today net earnings of $2,157,186 for the six months ended April 30, compared with $3,069,323 in a like period of the previous fiscal year. The earnings, and the 1948 corn Continued on Pao z S7, Column 3

Feeling a need for more time to work on the show, the sponsors of "Miss Liberty," which had its world premiere at the Forrest Theatre in Philadelphia on Monday, have decided to extend its engagement in that city.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 15 -- A truck driver, honored for his driving record by the National Safety Council, was held by the police here today after the death in traffic of a 6-year-old schoolgirl.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate swung into action today after more than a week of debate on labor relations and adopted three "bipartisan" amendments to the Administration's labor bill.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 15 -- "I have no deep desire to leave this post," Ambassador Joseph E. Jacobs said today in commenting on a Washington announcement of his "resignation" from his Prague post.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The American Farm Bureau Federation today supported legislation to revise the system of Federal controls over planting and marketing of cotton.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House Labor Committee refused today to approve a bill to raise the national minimum wage from 40 cents an hour to 75. The vote was on a measure designed as a compromise to get past the Rules Committee, which has blocked action by the House on broader legislation previously approved by the rules group.

Guy Lombardo, orchestra leader who recently purchased the site at the foot of South Grove Street in Freeport, L. I., formerly occupied by Liotta's East Point House, has erected a modern two-story restaurant building there and will open it tomorrow.

SHANGHAI, June 15 -- The preparatory committee of the new Political Consultative Conference was due today to begin a series of meetings in Peiping which, it was believed, would outline the pattern for a new government in China.

CHICAGO, June 15--If we have "anything approaching a major depression'' this year or next, it will be "under the strangest circumstance ever known," Tyre Taylor, general counsel of the National Association of Retail Grocers, told the organization's golden jubilee convention today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 15 -- It was officially announced tonight that Laszlo Rajk, former Foreign Minister and Minister of the Interior, and Tibor Szonyi, another high-ranking Communist, had been expelled from the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party as "spies and Trotskyist agents of foreign and imperialist powers."

The basic search of every man is for tranquillity, known otherwise as peace of mind. When young, the search leads him into marriage, poor senseless wanderer. A little older and the search leads him into the rearing of children.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, June 16 -- An inspection party of the United Nations Commission to Korea was fired upon by North Koreans yesterday ten miles north of Chunchon, capital of Kangwon Province, and fifty miles northeast of here.

Increases of $2,500 in the annual salaries of Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh and Marine and Aviation Commissioner G. Joseph Minetti were approved informally yesterday at an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Ray Scarborough blanked the Browns on two hits tonight as the Senators pounded Bill Kennedy and Karl Drews for fifteen hits and a 9-0 victory.

Underwriting syndicates here will place on the market today new issues of public utility securities valued at more than $11,500,000, including preferred stock, common stock and first mortgage bonds. The offerings are as follows:

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 15 (AP) -- Top-seeded Lieut. Charles Oliver of the United States Military Academy, six other seeded stars and one little known player today qualified for the quarter-finals of the twenty-seventh Eastern Inter-collegiate tennis championship.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) -- Eddie Joost's fourteenth home run was the margin of victory as Dick Fowler recorded his fourth straight in hurling the Athletics to a 2-1 victory over the Tigers tonight.

TOKYO, June 15 -- Under the spur of Communist agitators Japanese labor is making plans for a general offensive against the Occupation policy that Government and industry in this country must balance their books by discharging excess workers.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration told Congress today that economies of $740,000,000 suggested by its foreign aid "watch-dog" committee would "wreck" the European Recovery Program and prolong the period of dependence on American aid, scheduled to end in 1952.

ST. LOUIS, June 15 -- The league-leading Dodgers' eight-game winning streak sailed into the left-field bleachers at Sportsmans Park tonight on the wings of a three-run homer by Nippy Jones, three of whose four circuit blows have been made off Brooklyn pitching.
TRENTON, N. J., June 15 -- The special session of the New Jersey Legislature ended tonight after the Assembly had approved the Senate bill restoring a state utility anti-strike law.

Coffee futures resumed their advance on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Hedge covering of the near-by delivery positions and demand by local trade houses, coupled with some new buying of the more distant positions, advanced prices of the "S" contract 19 to 35 points.

Robert L. Riggs, former national amateur and professional tennis champion from California, heads the list of forty-eight players who were drawn yesterday for competition in the national professional championship. The tournament will start Monday in the Forest Hills Stadium and continue through Sunday, the 26th.

CLEVELAND, June 12 -- Walter Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, CIO, suggested here tonight an immediate conference in Washington of leaders in Government, labor, industry and agriculture to make plans to avert a serious break in the national economy.

On May 31 THE TIMES, in a condensed version of remarks made by me at a meeting of the Association for Improvement of Mental Hospitals, quoted a statement by me referring to the state mental hospital system as a form of legalized malpractice.

Plans for remodeling the three buildings consisting of a loft and two garage buildings for church purposes at 293 Balnbridge Street, in Brooklyn, were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by Joseph Thomas and fary F. L. Keith from the Dansker Realty and Securities Corporation.
CAIRO, June 15 (AP) -- A religious leader from Turkestan in Soviet Central Asia charged here today that Russia had been conducting an anti-Moslem purge ever since the end of the war.
CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- Preston T. Tucker drove to the United States Courthouse in one of his hand-made rear-engine cars today and won a reduction in his bond on a Federal indictment.

" A Tent on Corsica," a first novel by Martin Quigley, will be brought out by Lippincott on July 13. It is a story about an air-bomber crew on seventy-five missions over Italy. The author, a former police reporter on The Kansas City Star and public relations man, has based his story on material gathered overseas as a sergeant in the Twelfth Air Force.

Alfred B. Cohen, of Kirby Block Co. has been chosen to receive the annual reward of the Fur Garment Traveling Salesmen's Association as the man who did most to advance the interests of the fur industry in 1948, it was announced yesterday.

IT probably is just as well that the Chicago Cubs lost their first game under the managerial guidance of Frank Frisch and thereby dropped into the cellar. The Old Flash now has no direction in which to move except up. But in all the excitement over the elevation of the one-time proprietor of the Gas House Gang to the top field command of the Bruins one chap has been completely ignored, almost forgotten.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Declaring that the financial position of most consumers was "relatively strong" in the first two months of 1949, the Federal Reserve Board reported today that consumers were looking forward to lower prices this year and were expecting continued good times for the country and themselves.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 15 -- Alberto Baltra, Chilean Minister of Economy and Commerce, proposed today that the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America be used in making studies to carry out President Truman's program for the economic development of backward areas.

2, new tenant for the City's price-controlled parking lot on the !site of the old Tombs and Criminal Courts Building was chosen yea. i terday when the Bureau of Real Estate awarded a five-year lease to a group of individuals now operating twenty parking lots here and in Newark. The new rental, $83,500 annually, was the highest bid at an auction, conducted in Room 1013 of the IVfunicipal Building.
ROME, June 15 (UP) -- An estimated 2,000,000 Italian farm laborers quit the fields today in a twenty-four-hour general strike in support of 1,000,000 seasonal farm workers who walked out May 16.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it had presented to Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson a four-point program designed to protect employes in private firms, working on defense contracts, from unfair discharges on security grounds.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 15 (AP) -- A white-robed mob dragged a Navy veteran from his home last midnight and lashed him twenty times with a leather belt.

New York, New Jersey and much of the Eastern seaboard is suffering from a prolonged drought. Locally there has been no measurable rainfall since May 27. In consequence, home gardeners, commercial vegetable growers and farmers are sorely troubled. If relief does not come soon there will be disaster to many leafy crops, serious damage to hay and corn, and checks all along the food production line which even good rains, too long postponed, cannot repair.

Total resources of state-chartered banks amounting to $87,274,539,000 on Dec. 31, last year, were at the highest point in their history, according to the eighteenth annual study of state banks published today by the American Bankers Association.

ASCOT, England, June 15 (AP) -- Race fans will forget royalty, Rita Hayworth and fashions at Royal Ascot tomorrow for five minutes -- long enough to see one of the most ballyhooed British turf duels since the war.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 15 -- Jonathan Daniels, editor of The Raleigh News and Observer, demanded immediate action today on the scores of petitions that have been received here asking United Nations help to prevent discrimination or mistreatment of minorities.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Powerful pressure was publicly applied today for Congressional approval at this session of the Administration's $1,130,000,000 program of military aid to Europe as a companion piece to the North Atlantic treaty.

The stock market yesterday scored the second widest rally of the year. As cautious buying replaced selling, the list bounded forward to raise the composite rate 1.67 points, with the motors, oils, chemicals and rails in the van.
Fifty thousand New York cloak and suit workers will now receive pensions of $65 a month when they become eligible for retirement at the age of 65, it was announced yesterday.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., June 15 -- Mrs. George Stern of Century, tournament medalist, reached the semi-final round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class B championship at Leewood Golf Club today.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 15 -- From chicken farming to murder; from carpet weavers to coast guardsmen, the historic Stamford Harbor lighthouse opposite Shippan Point, in Long Island Sound, has run the gamut of dramatic experience and lightkeepers in its seven decades of existence.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- The University of Pennsylvania had to hire a hall -- the Municipal Auditorium adjacent to the campus -- to accommodate today the thousands of relatives and friends of the largest graduating class in the 209 years since its founding by Benjamin Franklin.

LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- While Ted Schroeder will open his initial bid for the Wimbledon tennis championship the hard way in the lower bracket against Gardnar Mulloy, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales was placed in the upper bracket and drew Jackie Brichant of Belgium, as his first opponent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -Columbia has revived "A Mother for May," a screen story by James Edward Grant which the studio bought in 1944 as a vehicle for Bing Crosby, and has assigned the property to S. Sylvan Simon for production.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The National Labor Relations Board today found both a company and a labor union guilty of violating the Taft-Hartley Act.

DETROIT, June 15 -- The world middleweight championship bout between Marcel Cerdan, French fighter who holds the title, and Jake LaMotta, rugged challenger from New York's Bronx, was postponed tonight because Briggs Stadium was transformed into a muddy quagmire by a day of steady rain.
Chicago, June 15 (AP) -- The Phillies, shocked by the shooting of Eddie Waitkus, nevertheless carried on today to sweep a double bill with the Cubs, 4 to 1 and 3 to 0, before a crowd of 18,809.

The United States will not repeat its maritime errors of the past and there will be no merchant marine "slump" this time, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, USA, the new chairman of the Maritime Commission, declared yesterday.
LONDON, June 15 -- Some of the best economic brains in Britain believe that the country is heading for yet another economic crisis.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Defense questions about secret atomic data were blocked by shouted Government objections today as Dr. Edward U. Condon, atomic scientist, testified in the Judith Coplon espionage trial.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 15 -- Negotiations on atomic control were suspended today by the working committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission until the Big Five and Canada are able to come to some sort of agreement through private talks.

BOSTON, June 15 (AP) -- Three runs driven home by Rookie Ray Boone's first two major league homers provided the victory margin for the world champion Cleveland Indians today as they vanquished the Boston Red Sox, 8 -- 5, for their fourth consecutive victory. A paid crowd of 15,255 was in the stands.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 15 -Academic honors were awarded today to outstanding students of the Yale University School of Medicine and the School of Music.

HONOLULU, June 15 -- A five-member emergency board was appointed today by Gov. Ingram M. Stainback to ascertain facts and recommend within one week a basis for settlement of the long-shore strike which for forty-six days has kept Hawaii virtually isolated from the rest of the world by surface transport.

MOSCOW, June 15 -- Two of the top literary figures in the Soviet Union -- a distinguished elder poet and an equally distinguished young playwright -- joined today in a sharply phrased attack on Judge Harold R. Medina and his conduct of the trial of the eleven American Communist leaders in New York.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Argentina, in addition to Britain, has been asked to reconsider certain aspects of the bilateral trade agreement being negotiated between them, it was disclosed today by James E. Webb, acting Secretary of State.

MOSCOW, June 15 -- Two of the top literary figures in the Soviet Union -- a distinguished elder poet and an equally distinguished young playwright -- joined today in a sharply phrased attack on Judge Harold R. Medina and his conduct of the trial of the eleven American Communist leaders in New York.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Argentina, in addition to Britain, has been asked to reconsider certain aspects of the bilateral trade agreement being negotiated between them, it was disclosed today by James E. Webb, acting Secretary of State.

PITTSBURGH, June 15 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, served formal notice today that the union expected to win pensions for its 1,000,000 members despite the steel industry's contention that the existing contract barred discussion of pensions this year.
Bachelor and master degrees will be conferred on 3,719 students in Lewisohn Stadium tonight at the 103d commencement of City College, the graduating class exceeding by 621 last year's record total.
The Rotary International voted yesterday to spend $750,000 during the next three years to promote better understanding and friendlier relations among the peoples of several nations.

RYE, N. Y., June 15 -- All four seeded teams advanced through two rounds and into the quarterfinals as play started in doubles in the seventeenth annual Eastern private schools tennis tournament at Manursing Island Club today. Play halted for the day in singles, which are already up to the semifinals.

Frank Goldman of Lowell, Mass., president of B'nai B'rith, announced yesterday that a drive for $2,000,000 would be started Sunday night to establish a Henry Monsky Foundation designed to sponsor religious, charitable and educational projects "to enrich American Jewish life."

In a rare action, Charles T. Douds, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, set aside yesterday a collective bargaining election held among 3,000 Bloomingdale workers and ordered a new poll.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- There were indications in some quarters today that the Administration may hasten submission to Congress of its legislative request for military assistance to western Europe and other foreign countries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- Margalo Gillmore, legitimate stage actress, will make her screen debut in Warner Brothers' "Perfect Strangers" with Ginger Rogers and Dennis Morgan, it was learned today. Robert Ross, her actor-husband, also has been recruited from Broadway for the film, which Jerry Wald will produce and Bretaigne Windust will direct, starting Monday.

Paul Robeson, baritone and Communist sympathizer, returned yesterday from a four months tour of Europe and the Soviet Union, denouncing the trial of leaders of the Communist party as "a type of domestic fascism."

ANNECY, France, June 16 -Bowing to the opposition of several delegations the United States has withdrawn its proposal to grant most-favored-nation treatment to Japan from the agenda of the world tariff conference.
Homemakers may treat wood furniture to a rubdown with oil and wash the curtains when they need it, but they are not kind to their rugs, according to rug repair experts interviewed yesterday.

BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Indians cashed in four walks, an error and a Joe Gordon double for four runs in the opening inning today and defeated the Red Sox 6 -- 3, for their fifth consecutive victory and a sweep of a three-game series.

Cameron F. MacRae, an attorney for the Consolidated Edison Company, told Ernest A. Bamman, an examiner for the Public Service Commission, yesterday that the company was willing to accept the recent interim increase in gas rates as permanent, even though it believed the rise was insufficient.

The letter by George Field which you published in your columns cleared certain people whose names have recently been smeared as Communist. It was quite natural that Mr. Field should write only of those whose activities he knew in connection with the Committee to Defend America.

First samples of steel made by the direct reduction of iron ore in a process using a hydrogen atmosphere were shown yesterday in the Brooklyn plant of Pluro, Inc., 60 East Forty-second Street. Rene Planiol, inventor of three kinds of equipment used in the process, and Benjamin R. Payn, secretary and treasurer of the corporation, were present.

BERLIN, June 16 (UP) -- The Russians stopped movement of Allied motor traffic from Berlin for four tense hours tonight in a move that United States authorities feared might foretell a full resumption of the economic blockade of the city.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- This country is experiencing a wave of hysteria as a result of current spy trials and loyalty inquiries, President Truman suggested today, but he asserted emphatically that we were not going to hell.

City College conferred degrees last night on 3,719 students at exercises in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The size of the graduating class exceeded by 621 students the record set last year, with 14,000 persons watching the exercises in the amphitheatre.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A sharp reporter was outfoxed by President Truman today in a fast-talk transaction over a dollar.

There has been too much talk both in the United States and Britain about a devaluation of the pound sterling in the immediate future, Donald L. Gill, secretary of the American Chamber of Commerce in London said here yesterday.
Relief from the drought, which finished its twenty-first day here yesterday, was seen last night with the development of a weak storm off South Carolina.
Jockey Merlin Fife played a waiting game with Homogenize, a son of Milkman, in the $11,175 Hitchcock Steeplechase Handicap at sunny, windy Aqueduct yesterday. It paid off.

PITTSBURGH, June 16 -- The chances for peaceful negotiations of a new steel labor contract receded today as the United States Steel Corporation clashed with Philip Murray's United Steelworkers, CIO, on all major points at issue in the contract talks.

The inspiration behind many of the popular priced suits and dresses that will be worn next season was illustrated last evening by the Society of New York Dress Designers, an organization consisting of about 150 manufacturers. At a show presented at the Astor Hotel for the trade, 110 costumes were shown, all created after research on the theme, "Mirror of Yesteryear."
DETROIT, June 16 (AP) -- A stockholder in Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., yesterday filed a Federal court suit to cut off salary payments to former Willys vice president Charles E. Sorenson.

Today the world's oldest living democracy, now a partner of the United States under the North Atlantic Treaty, celebrates its "Fourth of July," or Independence Day. That democracy is Iceland, which on June 17, 1944, peacefully dissolved its union with the Kingdom of Denmark, and with the blessings of the Danish King, and amid the rejoicing of its people, proclaimed itself a free and independent republic.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 11 were 5 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:
BAY PARK, L. I., June 16 -Ground was broken here today for a $7,000,000 sewage disposal plant that, when completed in a year and a half, will be one of the most modern such plants in the world.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 -- Blowing a 2-0 lead in the sixth inning, the Dodgers found it no problem to continue succumbing to charitable impulses and lost the rubber game of the series with the Cardinals, 6 -- 2, today.

Several hundred customers of depositors in the East Rockaway National Bank and Trust Company are going to receive some badly singed and charred checks in their next month's statement but, except in one instance, they will be spared the necessity of making out duplicates for the damaged checks.

The arrest of two youths and a 14-year-old boy who were said to have been living temporarily in a cave under the Paerdegat Basin Bridge of the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn with a cache of stolen jewelry was disclosed yesterday when the youths were taken to the line-up at Police Headquarters.

" High Button Shoes," the second longest-run show on the boards, enters its final two weeks at the Broadway Theatre next Monday. When it closes July 2, the Jule Styne-Sammy Cahn-Stephen Longstreet musical (George Abbott directed it and Jerome Robbins did the choreography), will have attained a marathon run of 727 performances.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The excursion of Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court into political philosophy this week produced more of a social-economic thesis than a judicial opinion. That is nothing new in the history of the court. Some of its most distinguished members throughout its existence have written political papers in reviewing legal issues.

Senator McCarran's joint Congressional "watchdog" committee, whose accepted function seems to be to keep ECA appropriations down regardless of results, proposed on Monday that $740,000,000 be cut out of next year's allowances. The committee thought this slash could be made "without retarding European recovery."
Donald Budge, former world champion from California, will play the opening match in the stadium when the national professional championship starts Monday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Six persons prominent in education and community affairs, including James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, will receive honorary degrees today at the eighteenth annual commencement exercises of Yeshiva University. Seventy students will receive undergraduate and advanced degrees and diplomas.
NEW DELHI, India, June 16 -Najibullah, Khan, Afghan Ambassador to India, accused Pakistan today of a "provocative" attitude toward Afghanistan.

The dollar amount of export drafts sent to Latin America for collection and not yet paid increased for the sixth consecutive month and in May reached a new high level of $145,300,000. Divergent tendencies were in evidence last month, however, in the export collection experience of the twelve monthly reporting New York City banks, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee set out today to cut "$1,000,000,000 or more" from the $15,000,000,000 approved by the House for the armed services in the approaching fiscal year.

David L. Cole, arbitrator handed down an award yesterday denying a request by the Newspaper Guild of New York for a general wage increase for its bargaining unit on The New York World-Telegram, Scripps-Howard newspaper.

LONDON, June 16 -- A moderate degree of unemployment may be the only way in which to bring the British workers to a realization of the essential poverty of their country, The London Economist will say in a leading editorial to appear tomorrow.

Francis K. McCune, assistant to the general manager of the General Electric Company's Apparatus Department in Schenectady, has been appointed assistant general manager of the GE Nucleonics Department with headquarters in the Hanford Works at Richland, Wash.
Your editorial of June 8 supporting public subsidy for housing raises more questions than it answers.

CINCINNATI, June 16 -- Dr. Jacob R. Marcus, Adolph S. Ochs Professor of Jewish History at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion here, will be elected president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis at its convention in Bretton Woods, N. H., June 23-28.

The atom bomb was described yesterday by one of its originators, Dr. Arthur Holly Compton, as only a dramatic incident in "an atomic crusade" that may change man's way of living in ways not yet predictable.

Henry Silver, president of Silver Dresses, Inc., has been re-elected president of the National Dress Manufacturers Association for the twelfth successive term, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors in the Astor Hotel.

In forecasting the positions of the Netherlands Government in the forthcoming round-table conference on Indonesia Foreign Minister Stikker on Wednesday laid some emphasis on the projected economic program. He declared that the Dutch would not seek special economic privileges in the projected United States of Indonesia and that the economic doors of the state would be kept open for other countries.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 -Six thousand of the 15,000 unionized warehouse workers in San Francisco and Oakland went on strike today in a dispute over wage increases.
The hand-wrought lamps of the luxurious yacht Grille and Curt Tasse, former German lamp manufacturer, will meet again today.
Two interesting group exhibitions now open demonstrate that talent in the art world shows its face in the summer as well as during the overcrowded winter weeks.

Tariffs on three lamb cuts are 10 cents a pound lower today than last Friday. These and several other reductions in meat prices indicate that retailers are attempting to overcome the resistance shoppers have shown to the high cost of this food.

BASEBALL'S trading deadline has come and gone with its usual disappointing results. A fellow should know better than to expect too much but somehow or other he never does. The temptation is irresistible to make all sorts of deals in his mind. The Yankees have an extra second baseman but need an outfielder. The Tigers have extra outfielders but need a second baseman.

Robert L. Hamill, senior partner of Sanderson Porter, engineers, has been elected to the advisory board of the 30 Broad Street office of the Chemical Bank Trust Company, it has been announced by N. Baxter Jackson, chairman of the bank.
Hope for a two-year period of maritime labor peace was expressed here yesterday by union men and shipping employers after negotiating committees agreed on new contracts for CIO seamen and radio men.

The National Convention of the Catholic Press Association, which ends its Denver sessions today, has awarded gold medals to The New World, official newspaper of the Archdiocese of Chicago, as the best Catholic paper of the year, and to The Sign, national magazine published by the Passionist Fathers in Union City, N. J., as the best Catholic magazine, it was announced here yesterday.

A detailed analysis of the nation's 123 leading investment trusts, having assets of more than $2,250,000,000 and in excess of 1,000,000 stockholders, is revealed in the ninth annual edition of Investment Companies, released yesterday by Arthur Wiesenberger.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Relief pitcher Alex Konstanty singled across the decisive run in the ninth inning today when the Phillies edged the Cubs, 4 to 3, before a chilled crowd of 4,899. It was the fifth straight victory for Philadelphia and the fifth loss in a row for Chicago, the last four under the managership of Frankie Frisch.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Philadelphia Gas Works Company received permission today from the Securities and Exchange Commission to borrow $2,500,000 from three banks in Philadelphia on its 2 5/8 per cent promissory notes. The borrowings would be made this month and in August and would be payable semi-annually beginning on Dec. 1, 1949, and ending on June 1, 1954.
ASCOT, England, June 16 (AP) -Three British horses ganged up on the American favorite, Black Tarquin, today and beat him out of the Gold Cup, most prized race in Royal Ascot's turf extravaganza.

The stock market returned yesterday to inaction after its violent performances on Monday and Wednesday. In reverting to the pattern which is characteristic of the market after major swings, the volume also shrank to the lightest in a week.

A provision for retirement on a pension of $25,000 a year has been eliminated from the employment contract of J. Carlton Ward Jr., with the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, of which he is chairman, it was disclosed yesterday by L. B. Richardson, president, in a letter being sent to stockholders.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- A prediction that Eddie Waitkus, 29-year-old star first baseman of the Philadelphia Phillies, will recover to play major league ball again -- though perhaps not this season -- was made tonight by Dr. L. L. Braun, Chicago Cubs physician and one of several doctors attending Mr. Waitkus.

Members of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, Inc., will be asked to vote, on July 11, upon a new type of sugar contract to be known as raw sugar contract No. 6. The board of managers of the exchange at a special meeting yesterday approved the new contract recommended by the sugar committee and fixed the date upon which members will vote on the proposal.
ROME, June 16 (AP) -- A priest-politician from Communist-dominated Czechoslovakia led a Soviet satellite attack today on United States policy in the World Health Organization.

ALBANY, June 16 -- The trustees of the new State University recommended today, by a vote of 10 to 1, that the university locate its metropolitan medical center in Brooklyn and its up-state medical center in Syracuse.
The Transport Workers Union, CIO, and three private bus companies opened contract talks yesterday that became deadlocked immediately when the lines rejected the union's wage demands.

An appeal for the passage of the McGrath-Neely bill, which would amend the Displaced Persons Act of 1948, was issued yesterday by prominent citizens and business leaders from all parts of the United States.

ROME, June 16 -- Vatican circles said this evening they were waiting for confirmation by their own representatives in Prague of press reports that Archbishop Beran was under house arrest and predicted that if the news proved correct the first Vatican step would be the ex-communication of all those responsible for what they called an "outrageous act."

PATCHOGUE, L. I., June 16 -This village's volunteer firemen got up close to a roaring inferno today to stop a blaze from spreading to fourteen storage tanks containing nearly 1,000,000 gallons of gasoline and fuel oil. The fire apparently started at 9:20 A. M. on or near a tank truck being loaded at the Patchogue oil terminal on the Patchogue River.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., June 16 -Wage negotiations between the United Mine Workers and the Southern Coal Producers Association continued today without any measurable progress, enlivened only by a public display of mutual dissatisfaction at the end of their daily three-hour session.

ROME, June 16 -- Delegates today accused Father Plojhar of having used the World Health Organization congress as a platform for the dissemination of anti-United States propaganda. He alleged that the United States was "deliberately withholding" technical information for the manufacture of penicillin and other antibiotics and that as a result of this policy a great many people were dying from diseases and malnutrition in countries behind the Iron Curtain.

Part of a half-million-dollar bequest that has put the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the very nice position of possessing the finest collection of antique French silver in the country is presented in an exhibition that opens today.

LONDON, June 16 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Staford Cripps, gently but firmly told the United States today that interference with Britain's "policies and plans" in the course of administering the European Recovery Program would be fatal to that program.
LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Six American tennis players -- two men and four women -- swept into the semi-finals of the Queens Club tournament today.

DETROIT, June 16 -- We are perhaps one-third to one-half the way down the slope of business readjustment, Malcolm P. McNair, Professor of Marketing, Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration, declared here today. He addressed delegates to the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which ends tomorrow in the Book-Cadillac Hotel.
Arthur George Ingram, a slim, straight, 73-year-old steward, folded the last blanket in a first-class stateroom on the United States liner America yesterday ending a sixty-year career at sea.

Paul V. Shields, newly elected chairman of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, in a letter to be mailed today to stockholders accompanying the second quarter dividend, explained the difficulties involved in the management reorganization of the corporation.

DETROIT June 16 (AP) -- Bob Hamilton, former PGA champion, cashed in on his devastating short game today as he fired a 63 to set a new course record and take an early lead in the $15,000 Motor City Open golf tournament.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 -- Harry R. Bridges, West Coast longshore leader, and two union aides today entered pleas of not guilty in United States District Court to charges that they had concealed Communist party connections of Mr. Bridges during his naturalization in 1945.

ALBANY, June 15 -- Publication by the State Department of Commerce of the 1949 edition of the Directory of Children's Summer Camps was announced today by Herbert C. Campbell, director of the Division of State Publicity.
Ewing Township, N. J., School District announced yesterday that it would receive bids June 29 on an issue of $1,200,000 of bonds dated Aug. 1, 1949, and due on Aug. 1, 1951 to 1980.

PARIS, Friday, June 17 -- The four-power Council of Foreign Ministers decided just before 1 o'clock this morning to close its sessions Monday with a plenary session. The ministers agreed to hold one more secret session Sunday in a final effort to come to an agreement on a modus vivendi for Berlin and a treaty for Austria.

A fifth book in Elliot Paul's "Items on the Grand Account" has been scheduled for Sept. 9 publication by Random House. "My Old Kentucky Home" is a record of the people, houses and vehicles, love, skullduggery and jazz in Louisville.

PRAGUE, June 16 -- The Czechoslovak police placed the palace of Archbishop Josef Beran under guard today after a search of the Archbishop's consistory and the arrest of the chancellor of the consistory and another priest yesterday afternoon.
GREAT NECK, L. I., June 16 -Stanley (Pete) Probstein and John Humm of Rockville, Long Island amateur champion, won the annual member-guest tournament at Glen Oaks today with a best-ball score of 64.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A $1,000,000,000 cut in Marshall Plan funds this year would cause a tenfold drop in the combined income of participating countries and "would have a disastrous impact on political and social conditions in Western Europe," Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, told the Senate Appropriations Committee today.

Giant blowers to provide the equivalent of speed of 700 miles an hour, and atmospheric equipment to simulate altitudes up to 65,000 feet and temperatures down to 67 below zero will be utilized in the $22,750,000 Navy aeronautical turbine laboratory on which work will be started soon at Mercer Field, near Trenton, N. J.

LONDON, June 16 (UP) -- The General Stud Book, England's register of thoroughbred horses which has considered Man o'War and other American champions half-breeds, today was thrown open to foreign horses.

In their most active day so far this month rubber futures continued their upward trend on the Commodity Exchange here, yesterday. A sharp upswing in prices in London and Singapore markets was a cause of the stronger trend here. The day's transactions in the local market amounted to 1,770 long tons.

The Coast Guard hearing into the causes of the crash on June 5 between the cargo vessels Exmouth and Hellenic Beach off the Delaware coast was resumed yesterday with testimony by three witnesses, all members of the crew of the American Export Lines ship.
CHICAGO, June 16 -- The National Association of Retail Grocers expressed today "firm opposition" to the farm program advanced by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan.

PARIS, June 16 -- Charles de Gaulle's Reunion of the French People plastered the walls of Paris today with posters announcing Saturday's celebration, during which the Avenue d' Orleans will be renamed Avenue du General Leclerc in memory of Maj. Gen. Jacques-Philippe Leclerc, hero of the Fighting French.

IN the last twelve years Clyde Brion Davis has written eleven books. Although all of them were adroit entertainment, the first two, "The Anointed" and "The Great American Novel" possessed a wry humor and a sort of upside-down originality that won them a host of loyal fans who have never been able to feel an equal enthusiasm for any of Mr. Davis' subsequent works.

In mid-July of 1927 an editorial in this newspaper described "a peculiarly fascinating sport," as follows: "You see a train standing on Track Four and walk toward it, around the corner of the other tracks, dodging the pillars. By the time you get to Track Four the train has moved out.

An apparent "major break" in the unsolved slaying of William Lurye, garment union organizer, loomed up yesterday as a 36-year-old trucking concern operator, described as a "business partner and close friend of the killers," was held in $100,000 bail as a material witness.

Anglers who have been watching the bright sun this week are convinced that such weather conditions cannot possibly continue over the week-end, for the experience this season has made pessimists of most of them.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Truman denied today that the unemployment situation amounted to a crisis, but promised that the Administration viewpoint on the problem would be expressed in his mid-year economic message to Congress next month.

The eventual development of the north shore of Jamaica Bay as a park and wildlife preserve was assured yesterday when the Board of Estimate voted unanimously to transfer 885 acres in the region from the city's Real Estate Bureau to the Park Department.

Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien announced yesterday the promotion of 177 patrolmen to the rank of sergeant at exercises held in the gymnasium at Police Headquarters. He also separated the functions of the forgery and automobile squads, which had been merged in November, 1946, as a wartime measure.
The Deutsche mark, currency of the western zones of Germany, has risen 5 cents in value in the last seven weeks on the Yorkville gray market and has more than doubled in value since last winter.

Mayor O'Dwyer, expressing grave concern yesterday with the number of tuberculosis carriers unwittingly roaming New York streets, described the city's lack of adequate detection and treatment facilities for such persons as "a health hazard as dangerous to the well as it is to the sick."

A new electronic business machine which does the work of approximately ten punch card machine operators in "reading" merchandise tags and translating all information to standard business machine cards has been adopted by Sears Roebuck Co., it was learned here yesterday.

ERIE, Pa., June 16 (By Science Service) -- America's first gas turbine-electric locomotive was demonstrated to a group of railroad men, engineers and scientists here today. Its primary power is a gas turbine engine, a power plant already widely used in stationary installations and coming rapidly into use in speedy airplanes.

TOKYO, June 16 -- Although deliveries against old contracts are still running two and three times those of a year ago, new Japanese export sales have dropped about 50 per cent since establishment of a single foreign exchange rate on April 25. April saw a jump in anticipation of the setting of the rate because many communities enjoyed incidental rates considerably above the 360 yen to the dollar finally set.

With a strong hint that commuters had not been paying all the fares they should, the Long Island Rail Road came forward yesterday with what it called "a distinct innovation in the field of railroad ticketing." This leaves the price of tickets unchanged, but is expected to increase sales to some who have been evading part of the costs of their travels.

A declaration from the bench that a defense attorney was in contempt of court marked the trial of four men before County Judge Carmine J. Marasco in Brooklyn yesterday. The incident occurred during opening statements by counsel after completion of a blue-ribbon jury.
WASHINGTON, June 16, 1949 -- during the week ended June 15 member bank reserve balances increased $436,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Justice Robert H. Jackson of the Supreme Court refused today to order release on bail of John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker and a defendant in the Communist conspiracy trial in New York City.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 11 were 808,156 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 109,332 cars, or 15.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, 98,507 cars, or 10.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 87,136 cars, or 9.7 per cent fewer than during the corresponding Week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The bigger and faster post-war airplanes used in civil air transport have reduced job opportunities and morale of fliers to a dangerous level, David L. Behncke, president of the Air Lines Pilots Association, asserted today.

QUEBEC, June 16 -- After years of heavy taxation that limited his purchasing power and of patient standing in line for products said to be in short supply, the consumer and his pocket book were today presented to the International Chamber of Commerce as the essential link in prosperity.

VIENNA, June 16 -- Hungary's Communist Government will open a war on Zionisn tomorrow by arraigning ten leading figures in the Hungarian Zionist movement for having allegedly promoted the illegal emigration of Jews from the country.

The Federal Reserve Board has just made public the results of a survey of consumer finances conducted during the first two months of this year. The general conclusion of the report is that the financial position of most consumers is -- or was at that time, at least -- "relatively strong," with people encouraged by the prospect of lower prices and expecting a continuation of good times.
After nearly six months of study the Board of Education approved yesterday a $42,370,000 priority program for the construction of thirty-two elementary and junior high schools in 1950.

Retail sales of refrigerators are running from 10 to 15 per cent behind last year, a much better showing than was expected at the beginning of the active selling season in April, buyers reported yesterday. They said price reductions by manufacturers are the most important reason for increased business.
Governor Dewey returned yesterday from a six-week tour of Europe convinced that continued Marshall Plan aid is absolutely essential if we hope to keep the Continent stable and united.

Operations of the Celotex Corporation in the six months ended with last April, resulted in a net profit of $506,739, in contrast to the $3,359,455 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year, according to the report issued yesterday by O. S. Mansell, president.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Truman reiterated today that he would favor an official loan for the increased production and marketing of Mexico's oil and that various Government departments and agencies were working on such a proposal.

The Board of Estimate adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution calling on the Port of New York Authority and the major commercial airlines "to effect an immediate settlement" of the controversy that for more than two years has held up full development of the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

DETROIT, June 16 -- Jake LaMotta is the new world middleweight champion. The rock-ribbed, steel-jawed little warrior from New York's Bronx, won the title tonight at Briggs Stadium, where before 22,183 wildly enthusiastic fans he knocked out stout-hearted Marcel Cerdan from French Morocco in the tenth of a scheduled fifteen-round struggle.

PARIS, June 16 -- Discussion of commodity problems in the World Food Council here today brought out some fears of surpluses and lower prices. In general, the consensus of the conference so far has been that abundance is a problem only in those parts of the world where the production means are the greatest and that the large proportion of the peoples of the world are still facing a shortage.

Edward J. and Harry Lee Danziger of the Eastern Sound Studios, 550 Fifth Avenue, whose initial production, "Jigsaw," was released recently, have purchased "St. Benny the Dip," an original story and screen play by George Auerbach, for $100,000, it was learned yesterday.
Absenteeism is rare among students taking one of the most popular courses taught in more than a quarter of the high schools in New York State -- how to drive a car safely.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -The Army will buy $4,382,000 worth of beef and other meat in Argentina and elsewhere in South America for feeding troops overseas, it announced tonight. It said the purchase would save $3,837,000 over the cost of the same amount of meat purchased in the United States.
Private borrowings from insurance companies totaling $23,350,000 were announced yesterday by two industrial corporations and one finance company.

WNLK in Norwalk, Conn., is one of the first stations in the country to schedule editorials since a redefining of the Mayflower decision by the Federal Communications Commission. Starting next week, the station will broadcast "In Our Opinion" on Mondays and Fridays at 6:25 P. M. and on the following days, Tuesdays and Saturdays, will schedule "In Your Opinion."

Dr. Mary Ely Lyman, dean of Sweet Briar College, has been elected the first woman faculty member of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, it was announced yesterday. Her term will begin with the academic year 1950-51.

Negotiations being carried on by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) for the sale of a long-term bond issue are understood to be making favorable progress. It is reported that Morgan Stanley Co., which has acted for the company in many of its financing operations, is making arrangements for the proposed financing, which is expected by the financial community to be between $100,000,000 and $150,000,000.

The first evidence of a leveling-off in the uninterrupted decline in business loans over the last four months came yesterday when figures released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed a practically stationary basis during the week ended on Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -Eddie Joost hit his fifteenth home run to move into a tie for the major league lead and Lou Brissie hurled one-hit ball the last five innings as the Athletics defeated the Tigers, 7 -- 3, today. The victory sent Philadelphia within one game of second-place Detroit Tigers.

Fred Sanford paid a belated installment on his $100,000-plus-players purchase price yesterday by pitching the Yankees to a 5-4 triumph over the White Sox in the nightcap of a double-header at the Stadium. Chicago ended a string of seven straight defeats at the hands of the Bombers by taking the ragged opener, 10 -- 6, before 21,801 spectators.

PARIS, June 16 -- Important shifts are taking place in the internal political structure of two of the Soviet Union's most loyal Eastern European states, Bulgaria and Rumania. Their full significance canont yet be gauged, but it is obvious that their principal purpose is to strengthen control of disciplined elements loyal to the Communist Information Bureau.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 16 -- Mrs. Margaret Bondfield, first woman to hold a British Cabinet post when she was Minister of Labor from 1929 to 1931, declared here tonight that the United States should "absorb the spirit" of her homeland's public health program.

Reporting on operations of the Holly Sugar Corporation at its annual meeting yesterday, Wiley Blair Jr., chairman, told shareholders that current beet sugar plantings were falling behind those of last year. He added, however, that crop prospects were better than those of a year ago.

LONDON, June 16 -- Yesterday's recovery on Wall Street helped the stock market here to make a better showing today. Other helping factors were better political news and reports of a possible settlement of the British rail dispute.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The dissents of Lewis L. Strauss as a member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission were no cause for his resignation, President Truman suggested today in dismissing reports to that effect.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 16 -Mrs. Edwin Longcope of Siwanoy gained her second one-day victory of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association season by carding 42, 41 -- 83, nine over par, at the Woodway Country Club course today.

BUENOS AIRES, June 16 -- The newsprint crisis, which the publishers of daily newspapers here have been expecting by August or September, seems likely to be postponed at least until the end of the year. Shipments of 30,000 to 40,000 tons are due to begin arriving in July from Finland, Italy and France, it was learned today.

The textile, apparel and retail trades are capable of self-regulation in establishing national standards for rayon fabrics, J. D. Runkle, vice president and general manager of the Crowley-Milner Company, Detroit, asserted yesterday.

One may take a little heart from the report of the Greater New York Safety Council which has just been issued under the title of "Hazards and Horizons." It shows that accidental fatalities from all causes decreased 2.4 per cent in New York City in 1948, as compared with the previous year.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, put his stamp of approval today on the House-approved military pay rise bill in urging that the Senate complete action on the measure as quickly as possible.

Pessimism about the economic future of this country was decried last night by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora. He spoke at the annual award dinner to Alfred B. Cohen, fur buyer of Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers, sponsored by the Fur Garment Traveling Salesmen's Association, Inc., in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A charge of "economic and religious bias and prejudice" was aimed today at a Board of Consultants of the Civil Service Commission on whose findings the commission recently "effectively dismissed or demoted twenty-six of the twenty-seven highest rated trial examiners" of the National Labor Relations Board.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Judith Coplon swore at her espionage trial today that she never stole United States secrets for Russia and was innocent of any offense against the United States.
For the third time in recent weeks, the Textile Workers Union, CIO, decided yesterday not to ask for wage increases for a segment of its membership because of poor conditions in the industry.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The national board of the Young Men's Christian Association in a report issued today to the national council of that organization, meeting here, said its world program had been able to continue in the midst of ideological struggles.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 16 -Robert Black of Blair School, medalist in the eastern interscholastic golf tourney at the Greenwich Country Club today, scored twice in match play. He defeated his first-round opponent, Dan Perry of Woodberry Forest, by 4 and 2, then triumphed over Woodberry Forest's George Mountcastle by 8 and 7.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Senate provisionally adopted today, for the new labor law toward which it is slowly working, a requirement upon employers as well as union leaders to take oaths disavowing communism and fascism as well.

CLEVELAND, June 16 -- The "branding" of children as "juvenile delinquents" should be stopped both by the general public and by the heads of state and private institutions that care for children, it was urged today by Norman V. Lourie, director of Hawthorne-Cedar Knolls School, Hawthorne, N. Y.

" There are no chain gangs in Georgia," and prisoners are not mistreated there but have good food, modern sanitation and recreational facilities, witnesses testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N. J., won the women's Eastern Golf Association championship for the seventh time today when she finished the 54-hole competition at the Philmont Country Club course with a 240.
