CHICAGO, June l5 -- Wheat was active today on the Board of Trade, but the price trend was the reverse of that of yesterday, the elimination of many shorts leaving the market without much support. Outside buyers showed no inclination to follow upturns, and there was free liquidation by traders who loaded up on yesterday's flurry.

As a result of exceptional results from the gas appliance industry's "Court of Flame" advertising and promotion campaign for gas water heaters this year, a larger and more extensive program is being contemplated for the new year, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, June 16 -- Revolutionary labor reforms have been achieved in Japan since the end of the war under the "broad minded and liberal" labor policies of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, Chester E. Hepler, chief of the labor division of the American Military Government, told the International Labor Organization conference today.

In the issue of May 14 THE TIMES gave an accurate account of the hearing of the previous day before the Deputy Superintendent of Insurance, Walter F. Martineau. Among other things, you highlighted the strong protest lodged by a delegation representing the United Insurance Brokers Association against the discriminatory practices of the companies in the issuance of automobile liability policies.

NANKING, June 16 -- All members of the United States Consulate General at Mukden are safe and their morale is "good," according to a message sent to United States authorities at Peiping by Consul General Angus I. Ward.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- The Communications Workers of America, CIO, is prepared to take strike action if necessary to uphold contracts now in effect with affiliates of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. This authorization was given to the union's executive board by unanimous action of the CWA convention today.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 16 -- Argentina moved in the Security Council today to put another batch of Soviet membership vetoes on the record by demanding new votes on the applications of seven already-vetoed countries.

" Music Under the Stars" lived up to only half of its name last night at Ebbets Field. The concert, for the benefit of the American Fund for Palestinian Institutions, was twice moistened by showers and saw no stars at all. But the event came to a successful conclusion through the determination of an estimated 30,000 listeners to hear the music out, and that of the Philharmonic-Symphony to play to the end.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Speculation on the possibility of espionage in the disappearance of some uranium 235 from a Chicago atomic laboratory was discounted as "a little on the fantastic side" today by the installation's head.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 16 -- The economically backward countries that are seeking technical assistance under the proposed United Nations phase of President Truman's "bold new plan" must look largely to their own financial resources to translate the global project into terms as practical as they are monumental, it was emphasized today in a special analysis prepared by Secretary General Trygve Lie.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 16 -Forty-two sailing yachts, thirty-five up to 72 feet long on deck, tugged at anchors out in the harbor or lay in slips here today making ready for the ocean race down the coast to Annapolis, Md., to starts Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Sid Hudson's five-hit pitching dealt the St. Louis Browns a second successive shutout tonight as Washington capitalized on its seven hits off Red Embree to win, 5 -- 0. It was the Senators' tenth victory in eleven games with the Browns this year.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A proposal, seemingly foolproof, was advanced today whereby the broad Presidential reorganization powers, finally enacted by voice vote in both House and Senate a few hours earlier, could be put to effective use this year.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 16 (AP) -- Fifth-ranking Harold M. Burrows of the University of Virginia scored an upset today by defeating top-seeded Lieut. Charles Oliver in the quarter-finals of the twenty-seventh Eastern Intercollegiate tennis championship.

PITTSBURGH, June 16 (AP) -Vern Bickford hurled a snappy five-hitter today as the Braves beat the Pirates, 7 -- 2, to salvage the final game of the series. It was Bickford's eighth victory of the year and his third over Pittsburgh. He has lost three.

SHANGHAI, June 16 -- A week after the reported mining of the Yangtze River mouth, one British and one United States river pilot set forth today to sweep the channel and again open to shipping the world's largest city under the Communist flag.

Two of font thugs accused of abducting, beating and robbing a Harvard youth were trapped yesterday on a Harlem rooftop after their stolen automobile overturned in a wild three-mile chase. Policemen who raced after the car when it passed a red signal light fired ten shots, all of which missed.

You state very correctly in your editorial "A Drifting Transit Policy" on June 14, "What is the city doing to set its house in order to meet this transportation emergency involving nearly a billion dollars? So far as we are aware it is doing nothing."
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, June 16 (AP) -- The line-up for the semifinals in the European Zone Davis Cup tennis eliminations was completed today when Yugoslavia ousted Sweden, three matches to two.

LONDON, June 16 -- A new element in the labor troubles of Britain's nationalized industries was introduced today by a threat of the workers in the London power stations to give notice of their intention to strike. They maintain that their wages will be cut by the new agreement reached with the British Electricity Authority to eliminate bonuses in a consolidation of rates.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 16 -- Stanton Griffis, director of the United Nations Relief for Palestine Refugees [UNRPR] tonight issued a statement expressing his belief that "every bit of food" purchased in the Near East for consumption by refugees "has been bought at fair prices comparable with world markets which have been consistently studied and checked."

Directors of the United States Smelting, Refining Mining Company reduced its dividend yesterday to half the amount previously paid on the common stock with the declaration of 25 cents a share. The dividend, which will be distributed on July 15, "is not to be considered as establishing a regular dividend rate," the company explained.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were unchanged to 15 points net lower.
Henry Julian Wadleigh, former State Department economist, testified yesterday that he had given State Department documents to Whittaker Chambers for transmission to a Russian spy ring.
New York's seventy-seven-day-old beer strike has cost the breweries $75,000,000 in gross volume to date and set the stage for an unprecedented battle for markets.
TOKYO, June 16 -- The Conservative Japanese Government today mustered its forces to combat a Communist-inspired "labor offensive" that has been causing strikes and rioting in various parts of Japan.

NANKING, June 16 -- The Nanking power plant, the largest industrial enterprise in this former Kuomintang [Government party] capital, has long been a losing proposition. Under the Communists, as under the Kuomintang, it is still borrowing money from the banks and will go into the hole this month to the extent of about 100,000,000 Chinese dollars [$65,000 United States].

A neighbor called and, as though overwhelmed by such good fortune, said that she had been invited out for supper. She wished to go, she said, for reasons quite aside from the new dress, purchased just that day on the tangibilities of a marital victory of some weight.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -The Air Force announced today that it had recovered the body of Maj. Thomas B. McGuire of Ridgewood N. J., who had thirty-eight Japanese planes to his credit when he was shot down in the Philippines over four years ago.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 16 -- An important consideration in the acceptance by the University of Minnesota of the resignation of Dr. Frank F. Oppenheimer, assistant physics professor and atomic scientist, was that Dr. Oppenheimer two years ago had made a written statement denying that he ever had any connection with the Communist party.

HONOLULU, June 16 -- Hawaii's public watched with a mixture of hope and skepticism today as an emergency fact-finding board created by Gov. Ingram M. Stainback charted the course of its investigation aimed at providing a basis for settlement of the longshore strike that has paralyzed shipping since May 1.

Gilbert Green, Illinois chairman of the Communist party, admitted on the witness stand yesterday that Jacques Duclos of France influenced American Communist leaders to change their policy in 1945. M. Duclos formerly was a member of the executive committee of the Communist International, and is a founder of the present Communist Information Bureau.

Often the most chic girl in town is dressed for a fraction of what another spends on her clothes. The credit for this is due in part to her good taste and in part to the designers who create the clothes that sell, as the ones photographed, for less than $10.

A complete overhaul of the traffic light system in Harlem so that every intersection in the heart of the community will be controlled by direct signals was approved yesterday by the Traffic Commission.

Summer evenings that start out in cool harmony on the outdoor terrace often end up with everyone's tripping indoors to the living room, considerably hotter after a losing hattie with flies, gnats and mosquitoes. Even city apartment dwellers, who are not blessed with window screens, suffer stinging attacks from these light-loving insects.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 17 -- Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University and of the American Association of Universities, said tonight that the Committee on Un-American Activities of the House of Representatives had invaded one of the few areas heretofore left to local control -- instruction in schools and colleges -- with its request to more than seventy institutions of higher learning and public schools for a list of their textbooks.
BERKELEY, Calif., June 17 -- The University of California, at its eighty-sixth commencement, awarded degrees and certificates ito 2,500 students on its campus here.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Congress, Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson and the Joint Chiefs of Staff will make major decisions in the near future that will influence materially the organization and composition of the armed services.

Abolition of ticket agencies was urged yesterday by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh. In a report to Mayor O'Dwyer he suggested that the present web of ticket brokers be replaced by a central ticket agency operated by theatrical producers.

"A TREASURY OF BROOKLYN"* is a wonderful book. It is an ornament in contemporary American letters and a monument to a fabulous national institution. In page upon page of rich, redolent prose, a distinguished clutch of eminent writers pays homage to the glories of Brooklyn (and some brisk attention to the shame), setting forth in immensely enter taining detail the human comedy of life and death beyond The Bridge.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 17 (UP) -- The Alabama Senate, on an urgent demand by Gov. James E. Folsom, passed a bill forbidding the wearing of masks today as public indignation mounted over outrages in the Birmingham area.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 17 -- Far-reaching steps to liberalize the status of the Roman Catholic Church and other non-Lutheran churches in Sweden are incorporated in a bill to be introduced in Parliament next year.

CLEVELAND, June 17 -- Of the 50,000 children who go each year into adoptive homes throughout the country, thousands are living with families who are not ready to give the child "full status in their hearts as an own child," it was charged today by Stuart R. Stimmel, state director of the Boys' and Girls' Aid Society of Oregon.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- With the Administration's multi-billion-dollar National Housing Bill coming up for action in the House on Wednesday, President Truman opened an intensive campaign for its passage today with an attack upon the "real estate lobby."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Sigmund Janas, president of Colonial Airlines, one of the smaller certificated services operating in the East, today threw back a challenge to E.V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Airlines, Inc., one of the "Big Four."

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 17 -- Negotiations between the Singer Manufacturing Company and Local 401, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, will be resumed here next Thursday, it was announced by both sides today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 17 -- The Rhode Island department of the American Legion is organizing a blood bank to provide blood for all the veterans in the state and members of their immediate families without charge.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 17 -- The office of the Controller of the Currency observes no "rigid" rule regarding the ratio of bank capital to deposits, or so-called risk assets, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, reassured bankers gathered here today.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 17 -- Westchester golf professionals gained a 19-to-5 edge over their amateur adversaries today in the first half of the second annual Westchester trophy competition staged as a benefit for the county Cerebral Palsy Association at the Briar Hills.

UTICA, June 17 -- Ten Uticans, including Rufus P. Elefante, Democratic leader of East Utica, and Alderman Thomas J. Ruggiero, were indicted today by the special grand jury on charges of conspiracy to violate the election law.

ALBANY, June 17 -- The Board of Regents appointed today a group of college professors to assist the Department of Education in revising the courses and the state syllabus in American history and world backgrounds.

A new version of "bringing coals to Newcastle" will be started this morning when an American merchant takes off by plane for Saudi Arabia, where he will supervise the placing of American luxury carpets on the floors of a fabulous eighty-five-room palace belonging to Prince Faisal.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was strong yesterday, and final prices were 7 to 17 points net higher.
CINCINNATI, June 17 (AP) -Three players, acquired in trades in the last week, today hoisted the Reds out of a seven-game losing streak.

Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh said yesterday that the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, one of the city's largest suppliers of milk to retail stores, had been giving "secret discounts" to more than 1,000 stores.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A six-year-old plan for effecting huge savings in Government spending through centralized buying and coordinated use of supplies and equipment worth billions of dollars was slated by leaders today for early action by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Judith Coplon swore today that her superior officer in the Department of Justice insisted that she jot down extracts from a "decoy" memorandum that was planted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The notes were found in her purse when she was arrested later the same day, last March 4, with a Russian employe of the United Nations in New York City.
MADISON Wis., June 17 (AP) -- The University of Washington's varsity crew crossed the finish line a scant eight feet ahead of Wisconsin today for its first victory of the season.
SALEM, Mass., June 17 (UP) -- The president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards tonight accused President Truman of sponsoring "political housing."

An intensive police search was under way yesterday to ferret from their hiding place the suspected slayers of William Lurye, garment union organizer, as Assistant District Attorney George P. Monaghan continued questioning of persons who were reported to have seen the fatal stabbing.

OSLO, Norway, June 17 (UP) -- Italy and Hungary each took two titles in the European amateur boxing champoinships today before a crowd of 8,000 fans, headed by Norway's Crown Prince Olav, at Bislet Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Soviet Government blames the United States, Britain and France for its failure to repatriate an estimated several hundred thousand German prisoners of war, according to a note the State Department made public today. It was dated June 4, and was a reply to a United States note of March 15.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's letter to Speaker Sam Rayburn on housing:
DETROIT, June 17 (AP) -- Dr. Cary Middlecoff proved himself a pretty good mudder as he moved into a two-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the Motor City open golf tournament today.

LUXEMBOURG, June 17 -- The meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the five Western European nations linked under the Treaty of Brussels -- Britain, France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg -- opened here today as scheduled, despite the threat of delay occasioned by the slow pace of the Paris Big Four conference.

Retail sales declined again during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales were believed to be about 11 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 7 per cent below last year.

BERLIN, June 17 (AP) -- The Berlin rail strike ended its fourth week today without prospects of a settlement. There were no new negotiations planned by the union, the city government or the Western Allies.

KANKAKEE, Ill., June 17 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles may carry the heaviest poundage of his career against Jersey Joe Walcott in their N.A.B. heavyweight championship bout at Chicago's Comiskey Park next Wednesday night.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer reserved decision yesterday on a suit brought by Clarence Jackson, 35-year-old Negro, to prevent his return to the Ben Hill Prison Camp, near Atlanta, Ga., from which he escaped last year after serving four years of a twenty-year sentence.

GENEVA, June 17 -- The United Nations Relief for Palestine Refugees will buy as much as possible of the food supplies needed from Middle East sources directly from the various Governments, under a new purchasing policy, it was learned today.

Seeking $550,000 damages and injunctive relief, two interstate trucking companies filed civil suits yesterday in Federal Court against Local 807, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America, AFL, because of an alleged illegal strike against both concerns.

A program for coordinating a projected expansion of the campaign against door-to-door selling "rackets," will be drawn up shortly by the National Better Business Bureau, it was learned yesterday. Deceptive use of marketing research techniques has already resulted in strong support by advertising and marketing interests.
PITTSBURGH, June 17 -- The presidents of two Pittsburgh district railroads were injured, one seriously tonight when their chauffeur-driven limousine was wrecked on Route 19 in Perrysville.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Wheat on the Board of Trade had a rally of 2 cents a bushel from the early low spots today, but met free selling and turned weak again in the late trade. The March position was relatively firm, while there was pressure on the July.

PITTSBURGH, June 17 -- Floored for four runs in the opening round, the Giants tonight made a noble effort to come back. But they were baffled by old Ernie Bonham's tantalizing fork ball and wound up losing the opener of their three-game series to the Pirates, 6 to 4, before a cheering crowd of 32,615.

To meet increasing demand abroad, THE NEW YORK TIMES International Air Edition -- until now flown daily to Europe -- will be printed in Paris from stereotype mats flown from New York, beginning with the issue of Monday.

PITTSBURGH, June l7 -- Northern coal operators were hopeful tonight that their contracts with the United Mine Workers would be extended, even though the union rejected a suggestion by Southern mine owners that their agreement be lengthened.

Mayor O'Dwyer forecast yesterday that in the not too distant future Staten Islanders would be traveling to Manhattan by airplane instead of the famous ferry that plies between the two boroughs and provides for riders a good view of the Statue of Liberty and the towering skyscrapers of lower New York.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 17 -- Air supremacy for the United States and other democracies at minimum cost to Americans in wealth and liberty, and "real unification" within the National Military Establishment were listed today by Secretary W. Stuart Symington as the principal Air Force objectives.

When William Gillis, a 26-year-old disabled veteran, leaves his paper stand for lunch, a woman seated elegantly in a wheelchair takes over his chores from noon to 1 P.M. as "newsie" on the northwest corner of Seventy-second Street and Third Avenue.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 17 -- The way was paved today by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to permit individuals and organizations as well as sovereign governments to bring charges of human rights violations before the world organization.

The New York City Omnibus System and the Surface Transportation Corporation, serving a total of 2,500,000 daily riders in Manhattan and the Bronx at a 7-cent interim fare, have been denied the city's permission to file with the Public Service Commission the interim 8-cent fare tariffs authorized by that body on June 2, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday.

In the spring of 1948 the average American family spent $25.57 a week for food. Though the figure is undoubtedly somewhat lower today, it's still quite a distance from the $14.23 that was the mean in 1942.

PARIS, June 17 -- A special police mobilization to protect tomorrow's ceremony for the inauguration of Gen. [Jacques-Philippe] Leclerc Avenue from possible disruption by Communists was announced by the Paris Prefecture of Police today.
Plans for holding the first inter-American conference of advertising groups early next year in Montevideo, Uruguay, were announced yesterday at the Advertising Club of New York.

DETROIT, June 17 -- Jake LaMotta today was hustling back to New York and a welcome true to tradition for a ring champion, while Marcel Cerdan beat a hasty retreat from the scene of his disappointment and heartache.

While it is not pleasant to have a vital midtown section torn up during the summer months, most of us will bear willingly the inconvenience caused by the removal of trolley tracks, repaving and rearrangement of roadways planned for Columbus Circle. This is one of the many Manhattan points where traffic congestion at times is alarming, and we welcome an improvement such as the one about to begin, designed to speed up vehicular movement.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, lost his fight today for a full public hearing on the case of a commission employe who handles top secret information despite derogatory information developed against him by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Senate Appropriations subcommittee did the sensible thing when it obtained an office for one of its witnesses and asked him to get right at the facts of his statement that a billion dollars could properly be cut from the military budget. At the present time it is more than ever important that the money spent on our armed services be well used.

Norman Lewis of Salle Santelli who retained the epee title, was joined by three first-time winners in the other divisions as the week-long national fencing championships came to a close before a packed gallery at the Hotel Roosevelt last night.
LANSING, Mich., June 17 -- Gov. G. Mennen Wiliams signed today a bill abolishing Michigan's one-man grand jury system. The law becomes effective Sept. 23.

MADRID, June 17 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco presided, today at the weekly council of his ministers at Pardo Palace on his return from a fortnight's sojurn in Barcelona, industrial capital of Spain.

WABD and the DuMont television network next Wednesday at 9 P.M. will offer the premiere of "Program Playhouse," a series of new programs, and, the same night, also will begin televising the boxing bouts at Jerome Stadium in the Bronx.
How much longer is the "wildcat" plane service between Puerto Rico and New York, with its appalling loss of life, to be permitted to continue?
MONTREAL, June 17 (Canadian Press) -- President Harry Davis of the Canadian Seamen's Union tonight offered a four-point proposal as settlement for Canada's East-Coast deep-sea shipping strike.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- A deal is being worked out for theatrical release in feature-length packages of the twenty-six television films produced recently by the Grant-Realm Company for sponsored transmission by the American Tobacco Company, it was learned today.

SHANGHAI, June 17 -- This great port was declared open to shipping of the world this morning after two river pilots -- one from Atlanta, Ga., -- and one from Liverpool, England -- dragged a 1,000-yard cable over the approach channel and proved it free of mines.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Showing improvement termed by his physicians "little short of miraculous," Eddie Waitkus, star first baseman of the Philadelphia National League baseball team, told today how "that silly honey," Miss Ruth Ann Steinhagen, shot him in her room in the Edgewater Beach Hotel last Tuesday night.

Dr. Albert Schweitzer, one of the world's foremost authorities on Bach and Goethe and for the last thirty-six years a medical missionary in the jungles of French Equatorial Africa, will arrive in New York on June 28 for his first visit to America, it was learned yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I, June I7 -- All was in readiness tonight for the start off here tomorrow of the 466-mile ocean race down the coast and up Chesapeake Bay to Annapolis.
DETROIT, June 17 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports today predicted a new all-time production record for August in automotive plants of the United States and Canada.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman denied two defense motions to dismiss the two-count perjury indictment against Alger Hiss yesterday after the prosecution completed its case at 10:43 A.M. on the fourteenth day of the trial.

After the explosion in the Holland Tunnel on May 13 it was brought out that infractions of the Port Authority's safety regulations are subject only to the lightest penalties -- specifically, a $50 fine and five days in jail. The deterrent effect of such punishment on truckers who flout the Tunnel rules is, of course, virtually nil.

Merle Miller, author of "That Winter," has turned in to William Sloane Associates the manuscript of his new novel about a political witch hunt in Washington, covering a span of thirty-six hours. The title is "A Sure Thing," suggested by Laura Z. Hobson, a fellow-novelist. The book is planned for August publication.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Johns-Manville Corporation of New York has filed a registration statement covering 145,300 shares of its no par value common stock, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

A plan for the combination of the businesses and properties of Beaunit Mills, Inc., and North American Rayon Corporation and the American Bemberg Corporation was approved at meetings of the boards of directors of the three corporations on Thursday.

DETROIT, June 17 -- Retailers who want to know their operations on a day-to-day basis must use some form of unit control. Arthur W. Einstein, vice president of The Strouss-Hirshberg Co., Youngstown, Ohio., declared today. He addressed delegates to the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which ended today in the Book-Cadillac Hotel.

Cottonseed oil futures were active and independently strong on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. Prices advanced 20 to 35 points. New high levels were established and prices closed at the best figures of the day. July was up 142 points from the season's lows. There was rather general buying and covering in cash oil markets in the South. Demand was satisfied by profit-takers and some hedging.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Social security payments were restored this month to Navajo and Pueblo Indians in New Mexico and Arizona on a level with other residents, the Federal Security Agency reported today.

There is much common sense and good reasoning in your somewhat wistful editorial Loyalty Oaths, in the June 14 issue of THE TIMES. But if the logic is sound, it ought to receive the widest possible application.

QUEBEC, June 17 -- In twenty-one resolutions and some speeches, the International Chamber of Commerce, which closed its twelfth conference here today, reaffirmed its belief that free action by the many gives better assurance of happiness, prosperity and progress for all than the restrictive actions of the few acting as cartels or governments.

No real break in the drought, now in its twenty-third day, is yet in sight, a Weather Bureau spokesman said last night. Prospects for scattered showers were improving, however, and the chances were better than even that they might become fairly general in the New York and suburban area.

In his testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee Mr. Hoffman has warned again that any further reduction in the funds for the European Recovery Program beyond the cuts already made by the House would prolong Europe's dependence on the United States and play into the hands of the Communists.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Still another new aid-to-farmers bill was unveiled in tentative form tonight by a House Agriculture subcommittee.
Every few days the telephone operator at the Marseilles Hotel nearly goes crazy because her board is tied up completely with calls between rooms.

The annual series of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts by the Goldman Band, under Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, opened last night on the Mall in Central Park. This 1,797 concert of the series attracted an enthusiastic audience officially estimated at more than 5,500.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 17 -- Despite the fact that American automobile driving is predominantly in the cities and suburbs, most road-building funds are being spent on highways, Prof. Philip Kissam of the Department of Civil Engineering at Princeton University said here today in an address before fifty leading New Jersey corporation executives.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 17 -- With Porter Roberts pacing him soundly all the way, H.W. Fincher's Air Attack sped to victory in the Kingston Purse, six-furlong race for 3-year-olds that featured the first program of the forty-seven day meeting of the Monmouth Park Jockey Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Termination of further Marshall Plan aid to the United Kingdom, if necessary, to prevent a pending trade agreement between that country and Argentina was suggested today by Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator.

ROME, June 17 -- Vatican circles predicted today that Archbishop Beran would suffer the same fate as Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty and Archbishop Aloysius Stepinatz of Zagreb, Yugoslavia. The trend in Prague, they declared, followed the same pattern of persecutions in Hungary and Yugoslavia with the same objective of destroying religious freedom.

An ingratiating smile flattens out the scars. A glass eye's not so bad when you have a good one left. Anyway, it's good to be able to walk, to talk with friends. The six machine-gun slugs that were removed from your leg * * * well, that happened way back in December, 1944.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The United States Savings and Loan League, reporting today on a country-wide public opinion survey, said that about half the American people favored Government housing.

At a fifteen-minute Coast Guard hearing yesterday morning representatives of towing companies, barge lines and other coastal maritime operators objected to the proposed discontinuance of Scotland Lightship.

High delivery costs in the brewery industry, which amounted to $14,720,000 in 1947 in the New York-New Jersey area, represent the industry's number one headache and the reason for the prolonged strike.

The precarious future of American legs, which have already suffered a sad decline in strength and endurance, has very properly been brought to public attention in a recent assembly of physical educators in Syracuse.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 17 -- For the first time in its ninety-six-year history, the Western District of the Lutheran Church, Missouri Synod, will admit Negro congregations into membership, it was announced today.

The Low administration (1902-03) left a mark on the history of New York City that has not been erased. I refer to the introduction of the control of street traffic by what is known as the block system.

Longshore workers on Pier 58 at West Thirteenth Street yesterday refused for eight hours to handle a shipment of export tin plate when the trucking concern hauling the material brought its own unloading equipment to the pier.

The stock market indulged yesterday in another breathing spell. Although prices were mixed at the close, the morning developed fresh downward tendencies which were partly corrected in the later trading. Exaggerated movements among quotations were few, and the composite rate ended with a net loss of 0.16 point.

PARIS, June 17 -- Discussion in the World Food Council turned today upon proposals for a continuing study of commodity problems with a view to settling them by international commodity arrangements. Behind the debate was the question whether the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization would keep up its work in the matter or would be eclipsed by other international organizations.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, awarded yesterday four sets of cash prizes totaling $1,660 to five girls and five boys who overcame physical or financial handicaps to achieve outstanding success in the public schools.

Reports from Bob Elliot up in Maine indicate that the fresh-water fishing throughout the state is now approaching its peak, with plenty of trout, togue, landlocked salmon and bass being taken from the lakes and streams.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Arabs and Israelis should recess their deadlocked negotiations for peace treaties, which have been in progress for six months at Lausanne, Switzerland, Mark F. Ethridge said today. He is the retiring United States member of the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission.

Fall production of men's and boys' suits will be down at least 25 per cent from a year ago as the result of current manufacturing curtailment, it was predicted yesterday in the trade. Operations for fall output, it was pointed out, have reverted to the familiar prewar pattern of a production period of less than twenty weeks for the majority of manufacturers.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP) -- Young Robin Roberts tossed a 5-hit masterpiece at the St. Louis Cardinals tonight while the Fightin' Phils from Philadelphia cut loose with a long-ball barrage to ring up their sixth straight victory, 8 to 0.

The New York State Board of the Communist Party announced yesterday that it had ratified unanimously the action of the party's upper East Side region, East Harlem section, and Cacchione Club in expelling Dr. Bella V. Dodd, veteran legislative director of the Teachers Union, CIO, from party membership.

Bob Lemon had little, but Ed Lopat had less and the Indians romped to a 10-4 victory over the Yankees in their series opener at the Stadium yesterday. The home side never quite recovered from the first-inning shock of successive homers by Ken Keltner and Larry Doby. Keltner, who propelled another 2-run wallop in the seventh, was the big gun in the attack that brought Cleveland its sixth straight triumph.

ALBANY, June 19 -- The State Banking Department announced today that the Long Island State Bank and Trust Company, Riverhead, L.I., had been authorized to increase its capital stock from $200,000 consisting of 2,000 shares of the par value of $100 each, to $250,000, consisting of 5,000 shares of the par value of $50 each.

Three hundred seventy of the 400 new cars ordered by the city for the Independent Division of the subway have been delivered and the remainder are expected by the end of June, William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, announced yesterday.

CAIRO, June 12 -- Cairo has been clamoring for "nylon" street cars so long that the transit company has finally been warned that it stands to lose its franchise if it does not do something. "Nylon," an American gift to the colloquial vocabulary, is the slogan used in any demand for something modern, shiny and up with the times.

NEWARK, N.J., June 17 -- A campaign among the lower echelons of the Democratic party and in labor circles in New Jersey to eliminate State Senator Elmer Wene as Democratic candidate for Governor was developing today after Mr. Wene's refusal to repudiate Frank Hague as State Democratic leader.

More than 155 summer theatres, perhaps the largest number since the advent of regular drama activities in the country, will be operating along the Atlantic seaboard before the hot-weather season officially gets under way, a survey showed yesterday.

The O'Dwyer Administration plans to spend $15,000 to bring up to date the $42,500,000 plan drafted in 1945 for a wholesale produce market on the lower West Side to replace the antiquated Washington Market, it was learned yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 17 (AP) -- The United States embassy said today it was trying to obtain the release of a United States Navy veteran sentenced by a Czechoslovak court to three years' imprisonment on charges of spying.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 17 -- At the risk of "misunderstanding and suffering" the churches must attempt to reconcile Christianity and communism, the sixth International Council of Congregational Churches was told at its opening service tonight.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 -- To Edwin T. Coman Jr. of Stanford University was awarded today $100 for notable achievements at the closing session of the Special Libraries Association at the Biltmore. Mr. Coman is assistant professor of business history at the Stanford Graduate School of Business Administration.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -The Athletics advanced within four and one-half games of the American League lead tonight in defeating the Browns, 6 -- 5. The victory was costly, however, as Second Baseman Pete Suder was carried from the field with a spike wound in the ninth inning.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate is expected to defeat by a heavy margin on Monday the proposal of Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, of Illinois, to authorize government seizure of plants affected by national emergency labor disputes if they threatened national health and safety.

This month finds New York City's 1,200 florists busily creating thousands of bridal bouquets to keep pace with the march of June weddings. "Smaller, more compact and stylized" designs are the order of the day, a revolt against the mammoth arrangements that not too long ago -- in effect -- preceded the bride down the aisle.

Last year the Rotary International, representing 6,800 clubs in eighty-one nations or areas, spent $150,000 to help people in this wide and troubled world to get better acquainted. This year it will spend $250,000. The money goes largely to scholarships and to lectures in the cause of international friendship.

ELSINORE, Denmark, June 17 -- The United States Guest company's performance of "Hamlet" at the Kronberg Festival opened tonight before the greatest and most representative audience gathered for any of the international companies who have staged "Hamlet" in its original settings in Kronberg Castle.
Patients of New York's Triboro Hospital staged a fashion show last evening of clothes which they had made and in some cases designed.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 17 -- Robert Black of Blair School and Paul Kelly of Hackley will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the Eastern interscholastic match play tourney at the Greenwich Country Club.

The basic real estate tax rate for the fiscal year beginning July 1 will be $2.89 per $100 of assessed valuation, continuing the rate in effect in 1947-48 and 1948-49. This was revealed yesterday when Controller Lazarus Joseph made public his final estimate of the city's general fund revenue for 1949-50.
ALBANY, June 17 -- Governor Dewey, who left Albany May 4 for a six week visit to Europe, returned to his Capitol desk today and immediately started work on a mass of accumulated state business.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Factory jobs dropped in May for the eighth month in a row, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The Bureau estimated the drop at 320,000, but said some of it was traceable to strikes, particularly the Ford Motor Company strike.

TOKYO, June 17 -- Pushed by the occupation authorities, the conservative Japanese Government is planning a comprehensive system of unemployment relief as a means of combating the "labor offensive" that is now under way against Premier Shigeru Yoshida's program for mass dismissals of surplus industrial and government employes.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 17 -Election of Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt to the board of trustees of Brandeis University was announced today by George Alpert, president of the board.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 17 -- The Holland festival, which opened Wednesday, displayed its first opera tonight, a performance of Bizet's "Carmen" by the Netherlands Opera Company, conducted by Pierre Monteux and featuring Jennie Tourel as guest star.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Paul Bunyan, gigantic legendary figure of the North Woods' tall tales, came to "life" today on the Chicago North Western exhibit at the Railroad Fair in Grant Park. He will not be unveiled for public inspection, however, until the fair opens June 25.
LONDON, June 17 -- With no fresh lead from Wall Street, the stock market here lapsed into pre-week-end idleness today.
The following books of a religious or inspirational nature have been published recently:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 17 -- Bank officers from every part of the nation will arrive here over the week-end as students at the fifteenth annual summer session of the Graduate School of banking at Rutgers University.

The future of a two-year contract signed recently between Bloomingdale's and Local 3, independent union, was a matter of conjecture yesterday after two actions by the rival Retail Clerks International Association, AFL.

NEWARK, N J., June 17 -- The New Jersey Moose Association will introduce an international flavor in a ceremony at the City Hall here tomorrow honoring 16-year-old Kenneth Lee Miller Jr., Cape May high school student, as New Jersey's "outstanding young citizen."

PARIS, June 17 -- Officials of the three Western powers emphasized today the limited and tentative character of the double agreement that they thought the Council of Foreign Ministers might complete Sunday on the basis of a provisional understanding on some points reached last night.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- A preview of Wimbledon's outstanding opener was assured today when Ted Shroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., and Gardner Mulloy of Miami, Fla., powered their way into the final of the Queens Club tennis tournament.

ROME, June 17 -- A bill urging Italy's participation in the North Atlantic pact was approved today by the Chamber of Deputies' Foreign Affairs Commission after strong opposition by extreme right-wing and left-wing members who wanted to delay ratification until after the approval of the pact by the United States Senate.

Local department stores and other large retail outlets are ready to "dump" overstocked name brand television receivers at the first sign that "anybody else of size or consequence" follows the example of Macy's, New York, On Thursday, Macy's advertised more than 250 sets at substantial reductions from original fair-traded prices and specifically named receiver producers -- the first advertisement of its kind in the New York area.
BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Red Sox pounded out fifteen hits, including three homers, to sweep an afternoon-night twin bill from the White Sox, 10 -- 8, tonight before a crowd of 31,446.

As an incurable optimist I would like to agree with Isaac Schwartz, who in his letter to you June 6 sees in "at least $10,000,000 worth of new business opportunities" which appeared in THE TIMES of June 5, reason to suspect that the current depression is non-existent, or maybe, in fact, being "manufactured" or "imagined" by those with ulterior motives.

ROME, June 17 (AP) -- Steps to halt the spread of venereal disease by intensive control work in port cities and along inland waterways received tentative approval of the World Health Organization assembly today.

PITTSBURGH, June 17 -- If a strike develops out of the steel industry's refusal to discuss pensions this year, the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, is likely to seek Government help in collecting full pay for the lost work time of its striking members.

HONOLULU, June 17 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, served notice today that the stevedores' strike would continue until all individual port disputes were settled, even if an agreement was reached first on the basic wage controversy that led to the walk-out.
MEXICO CITY, June 17 -- The: Mexican peso was again stabilized, effective tomorrow, at 8.65 to $1 after remaining on the free market for nearly a year.

While Communists and sympathizers picketed the Federal Court House, the Court of Appeals heard argument and reserved decision yesterday on the appeal of Henry Winston and Gus Hall for release on bail.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP) -- Performing pretty much according to form, varsity athletes from around the country went through preliminary trials today in qualifying for tomorrow's finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field meet.

A tolerance of differing opinions and views rather than an insistence on conformity of ideas is the strongest weapon of a democratic government, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, declared yesterday. It was this tolerance, he said, that gave America the power and strength to defeat the Axis powers in the last World War.

The Police Sports Association, whose athletes have made remarkable progress under the direction of Ernie Hjertberg, the sprightly octogenarian, will stage its third annual track and field championships at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island today.

Guaranty Trust also has been appointed paying agent for $350,000 of Vineland, N.J., electric light plant and water bonds and paying agent for Greenville County, S.C., auditorium bonds of Nov. 1, 1948.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 17 -- Police in plain clothes continued their search of the consistory of Roman Catholic Archbishop Josef Beran's palace all day while other plainclothes men at the porter's lodge just inside the entrance to the palace checked the identities of visitors and others kept supervision of telephone conversations.

A tiny, frightened squirrel "invaded" Mickey's Contour Hair Stylist Beauty Parlor, 819 Flat-bush Avenue, Brooklyn, at 9:40 A.M. yesterday and caused an uproar in the shop. The proprietor, Mickey Bennett, 34 years old, of the Towers Hotel was bitten on the right thumb.
MEXICO CITY, June 17 -- The: Mexican peso was again stabilized, effective tomorrow, at 8.65 to $1 after remaining on the free market for nearly a year.

While Communists and sympathizers picketed the Federal Court House, the Court of Appeals heard argument and reserved decision yesterday on the appeal of Henry Winston and Gus Hall for release on bail.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP) -- Performing pretty much according to form, varsity athletes from around the country went through preliminary trials today in qualifying for tomorrow's finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field meet.

A tolerance of differing opinions and views rather than an insistence on conformity of ideas is the strongest weapon of a democratic government, Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, declared yesterday. It was this tolerance, he said, that gave America the power and strength to defeat the Axis powers in the last World War.

The Police Sports Association, whose athletes have made remarkable progress under the direction of Ernie Hjertberg, the sprightly octogenarian, will stage its third annual track and field championships at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island today.

The report of the National Linen Service Corporation issued yesterday for the nine months ended May 31 disclosed a net profit of $1,624,479 after all deductions, equal to 81 cents a share on the common stock. This compares with $1,261,412 or 63 cents a common share for the similar period of the preceding fiscal year.

LONDON, June 17 -- The National Union of Railwaymen, which has now undertaken to dissuade its members from carrying out further Sunday strikes, uncompromisingly rejected today the wage increases offered by the management of the state-owned railroads.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.8 per cent in the week ended June 14, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 154.8 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.8 per cent below four weeks ago and 6.5 per cent lower than one year ago.
A new kind of psychiatric center has been quietly functioning here for a little more than a year, it was learned yesterday.

The proposal to set aside as a park and wildlife preserve a strip of city land bordering the northern shore of Jamaica Bay shows vision and imagination. The area in question, larger in total extent than Central Park, was originally acquired as part of the plan to make Jamaica Bay into the world's greatest seaport.
CAMDEN, N.J., June 17 -- Simon Cherivtch, 35-Year-old Mayor of near-by Millville, was found guilty today by a jury in the United States District Court here on two counts of income tax evasion.

The first national survey of raw materials resources for future expansion of the domestic synthetic fuel industry has started. Army approval of the project was received here yesterday by Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., New York consulting engineers, conducting the survey.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, June 17 -- An abortive plot to overthrow the present government on June 10 and establish Col. Osmin Aguirre Salinas as dictator was charged here today in a manifesto issued by the Revolutionary Government Council.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 17 -- Rough water caused postponement of the decisive race today, but Phillips Andover Academy led finalists in the fourteenth annual Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association regatta.

After a two-block chase through the Chelsea district, two executives and an employe of a slide fastener concern yesterday captured one of two men who had tried to steal a $1,485 payroll from their bookkeeper as she was returning from the bank.

BERLIN, June 17 -- A groundswell of uneasiness over the continued partition of Germany is becoming evident. Although German sentiment generally applauds Western policy at the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris, fears for the future of a partitioned Germany are expressed with increasing vehemence.
CHICAGO, June 17 -- Gil Hodges rifled a single to left with one out in the ninth inning to score Duke Snider from second base and give the Dodgers a 2-1 victory over the Cubs today.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 17 -- Excavations to determine, if possible, the origin of the Old Stone Tower here, which are to be financed by Robert R. Young, the New York financier who owns a summer home in this community, will commence on Monday under the direction of William S. Godfrey Jr., the archeologist. He will be assisted by L.T. Hosmer, of Havard University, also an archeologist.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- An agreement has been signed supplementing the United States-Mexican stabilization agreement of May, 1947, the Treasury announced tonight. The new agreement increases to $25,000,000 the balance available from the United States Stabilization Fund for the purchase of Mexican pesos to stabilize the dollar-peso rate of exchange.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 17 -- Five leaders of the American Labor party applied here today to Judge Elbert T. Gallagher in Westchester County Court for reversals of their convictions in White Plains City Court on charges of disorderly conduct.

New Capital Issues New capital issues in both variety and volume are scheduled to occupy securities distributors next week. Among the substantial blocks of public-utility common stock to be marketed are 550,000 shares of Kansas Gas and Electric Company on Wednesday; 242,785 shares of Illinois Power Company on Monday, and 251,033 shares of Portland General Electric Company on Tuesday.

LONDON, June 17 -- The British Foreign Office issued today the text of a Soviet note rejecting British, French and American protests alleging that the Soviet Union had not complied with the agreement for the repatriation of German prisoners of war.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 17 -- Georgi Dimitrov, Communist Premier of Bulgaria, is so ill that Czech newspapers have been told to prepare his death notices, a Czech newsman said today.

PANGKALPINANG, Banka Island, Indonesia, June 16 (AP) -- Indonesian Republic leaders said today the Dutch would have to return them to their capital at Jogjakarta, Java, before they could work out details for a cease-fire.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The Government is going to turn over more of the grain export trade to private dealers, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

CAIRO, June 17 -- An announcement that Egypt was prepared in the near future to ease and largely abandon the searching of British and other vessels was interpreted here today as an indication of a slow but evident change in relations between Britain and the United States on one hand and the Arab states, particularly Egypt, on the other.

Fillies will provide the entertainment in the main acts of today's show at Aqueduct. Fourteen 3-year-olds have been named for the $20,000-added Gazelle Stakes, and eleven 2-year-olds are to fight it out in the $10,000 Astoria Stakes.

Mayor O'Dwyer indicated yesterday that his sympathies were with the Port of New York Authority in that agency's dispute with major airlines over landing charges at New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Truman will sign, on Monday, the bill that authorizes reorganization of the Federal government. At the same time he will send at least two of seven implementing plans to Congress for action.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Truman today stood in a semi-circle of nineteen Hi-Y boy "governors" in his private office and told them they were doing right to study Government.

CLEVELAND, June 17 -- Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat, of Illinois, called tonight on the Government to "break up" the business monopolies of the nation, which he charged were destroying free enterprise.
LONDON, June 17, -- The British Treasury confirmed today that a final effort to break the deadlock over the new intra-European payments agreement would be made next Thursday in Brussels.

TOKYO, June 17 -- Japanese Conservatives today turned down demands of opposition parties for a special session of the Diet this summer to debate the deflationary policy of Premier Shigeru Yoshida's Government and the "labor offensive" against the administration's austerity program and the proposed mass dismissal of surplus employes.

NOVELS deaiing with theatre people have many strikes against them. It should be clear enough by now that an actor is by nature something of an extrovert and has a large share of ego. Perhaps a novel that exploded this theory would be interesting.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Angry members of the House Committee on Un-American Activities said today that they were not even consulted about a textbook checkup that has involved the group in its hottest controversy of the year.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, June 18 -- A random sampling of Western views on the spy investigations and Communist trials, taken by polling visitors from eight Mountain States at Zion National Park in southern Utah, indicated grave public misgivings concerning both the need for such investigations and the manner in which they were being conducted.

IF Mr. Lewis' intent is to compliment American readers -- and he submits that his book "is the work of a great friend of America" -- then I hope that he will not be disturbed by whatever ungenerous responses it may provoke.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- People on the Pacific Coast this week shared the evident perplexity of the nation at large about the merits of the numerous anti-Communist proceedings.

THE yellow columbine, blue flax, spicy pinks, veronica, coreopsis and gaillardias that are in flower now are but a token of the many perennials that may be raised from seed at home. Growing a few select varieties each year is a good way to maintain stocks of those that tend to peter out.
ST. LOUIS, June 18 (AP) -- Howie Pollet stoped a ninth-inning rally just short of a tie tonight and the flying Phillies dropped a 4-3 decision to the Cardinals.

Office clerical help, except for some highly skilled classifications, is plentiful for the first time since the war and the procurement situation as regards less skilled jobs definitely has shifted from "an employes' to an employers' market," personnel leaders declared last week.

A THREE-WEEK drought covering several Eastern states, including New York, already has done serious damage to lawns and gardens. Only several days of rain can prevent heavy loss to farm crops and gardens that are beyond the reach of the hose.
LONDON, June 18 -- British and United States officials and diplomats of other countries felt today that a new phase of difficulty and misunderstanding in Anglo-American economic relations had begun.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Administration testimony in support of the proposed military assistance program to Western Europe is being carefully prepared, in the hope that it may be received favorably by the Armed Services and Appropriations Committees of the House and the Senate.

Lack of long-range rapid transit planning is responsible for the costly difficulties in Staten Island transportation and New York would do well to study how London has handled its transit problems. Goodhue Livingston Jr., Commissioner of City Planning. said yesterday.
EVERY day we come across further evidence that architecture, engineering, interior design and furnishings are so mixed up that it's almost impossible to say where one leaves off and the other begins.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 18 -- The political situation as the farmers in the great Midwest farm belt see it probably is best summed up by the observation of an efficient Iowa farmer, widely known as Skunk River Bill. "I think 'us dumb farmers' will wait and see what the Republicans do," he said.

ROME -- The ruins of past glory remain the same. Young couples still go to see the Coliseum by moonlight. In the Forum a crumpled empty pack of American-made cigarettes lies before a bas-relief representing sacrificial animals. This brings one to the verge of some deep philosophical thought about the course of civilization.

BETTY COMDEN, in a review of R.C. Sherriff's screen adaptation of W. Somerset Maugham's "Quartet," stated that Mr. Sherriff "added a warm and not impossible ending" to the story called "The Kite." She concludes that Mr. Sherriff "treats the whole love story with more tenderness and warmth than the Maugham story does, and I think with good results."

NOW that the ferry is running again between England and America, and Hollywood stars and technicians are at liberty to cross back and forth at the discretion of their employers, the studios in and around London are tending to become more and more a back lot for Hollywood.

PETERSBURG, W. Va., June 18 -- New rains brought fresh threats of disaster tonight to the flooded Shenandoah-Potomac Valley lowlands. At least six persons already had perished in the raging waters and twenty were missing.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In the current effort of the Senate Appropriations Committee to make a substantial cut in the $4 billion asked for the European Recovery Program there is more than meets the eye. Patronage, politics and not a little Anglophobia have been going about in the guise of a genuine and compelling desire to balance the Federal budget.

The continued offering of great blocks of public utility equity securities to investors at progressively higher yields in the face of a deteriorating stock market is at the moment of paramount interest to the financial world.

IT is a fact that the best novels about Fascism and its effects in Italy have concerned themselves with the southern part of the country -- the area least known to the American as well as the Italian reading public. Silone's short novel, "Fontamara," the recent "God's Thumb Down" by Oscar DeLiso, and Carlo Levi's study.

NEW DELHI, India, June 18 -- Early signature of a truce between India and Pakistan in Jammu and Kashmir state appeared more likely today as Dr. Alfredo Lozano of Colombia, chairman of the United Nations commission on this dispute, returned to the state capital of Srinagar after a week's consultations with the Government of India.
RICHMOND, Va., June 18 -- Anti-Communist feeling in the Upper South, swelling steadily for the past two years, has reached a new peak in the past six weeks.

TOM was one of those small boys who make you believe in perpetual motion -- the kind of boy who gets all tired out trying to sit still. So it was quite natural that he should run through quicksand, but surprising that he should arrive thus in the land of Quickrun.

There were 100 happy parasols in Central Park's Sheep Meadow yesterday. They gleamed in the sun and did not "cry bitterly" when the little girls in white, stockings and gay kimonos danced gracefully around them.

LONDON, June 18 -- Important men among those economists who know Britain's problems best consider that the greatest single weakness in the British recovery effort today is failure to reduce the prices of products that Britain is trying to sell in the world market.

The Division Against Discrimination of the New Jersey Department of Education reported yesterday at Newark improved conditions in industry and education. Public institutions have removed barriers against minority groups, resulting in "dividends" for the state generally, Joseph L. Bustard, assistant commissioner of education in charge of the division, said.

New regulations, effective Tuesday, placing American business men on an equal footing with other foreign visitors in the three Western zones of Germany were the subject of strong criticism in foreign-trade circles here last week.

Pleasure boating everywhere, and even the sometimes dangerous sport of speedboating, are showing unmistakable new signs of reaching down into the teen-agers for enthusiastic popularity. Before the war only a handful of yacht clubs spent money and energy to organize junior clubs for the sons and daughters.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Atomic Energy Commission's authority to undertake costly new projects would be drastically curbed under a bill to be introduced next week by Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Despite the increase in unemployment which reached a post-war high of 3,289,000 in May, calls are still being received for executives needed in important business and industrial posts, C.A. Swanson, president of the "Men Over Forty Club," said today.

WHEN E. M. Forster was here for the first time just two years ago, this reporter jotted down some impressions of the English novelist, along with some of the then current doings of the gentleman from Kings College, Cambridge.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation, which has enjoyed an immunity from high-level criticism almost unparalleled among Government agencies, found itself this week in a state of acute embarrassment as a result of public disclosure of some of its investigative techniques.

THOSE whose summer vacation plans call for any amount of driving on crowded highways are advised by the Automobile Club of New York to have their eyes examined before setting out. While this is not customarily part of the pre-vacation planning, it makes good sense since good vision is perhaps the most important requisite for safe driving.

THIS is a story of prospecting for gold in northern Manitoba. Ricky Thompson, the 12-year-old hero, goes into the northern brush with his father and another prospector to find the origin of gold samples brought in by Indians.

On last Feb. 15, Philip C. Jessup, the American delegate to the United Nations Security Council, buttonholed Jacob A. Malik, the Russian delegate, in the lounge at Lake Success. They talked about Berlin -- then nine months under Russian blockade.

COLUMBINES have foliage as lacy as ferns, and blooms as fragile as butterflies, yet they last well in bouquets and thrive in the garden. Flowering now, they belie their delicate appearance with a long period of bloom and vigorous growth.

PARIS, June 18 -- The fall in British exports to the dollar zone in May and the fall in value of the pound on the Paris black market to the equivalent of $2.92 in the last few days have reinforced the belief in French financial circles that devaluation of the British currency is inevitable.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 18 (AP) -- The president of Vassar College, Sarah Gibson Blanding, says she recognizes as "objectionable" a student article which Roman Catholic groups maintain "attacks the sacred foundations of Christianity."

ADOLPH MENJOU and his wife, Verree Teasdale, have performed a feat which radiowise probably will pass for a miracle. They have taken that most sickly of contemporary institutions -- the "Mr. and Mrs." program -- and turned it into a fifteen-minute offering that can be heard without damage to the nervous system.
WELLESLEY, Mass., June 18 -- The International Congregational Council was created today at Wellesley College by representatives of thirty-seven countries embracing 3,000,000 Congregationalists.

THE gardener who grows roses to decorate his home is fortunate indeed, for even one bloom becomes a flower arrangement. There is no need to search for exotic plants, strange leaves or rare fruits to place with these flowers.

WITH the coming of summer and its sweltering days, thousands of New Yorkers will head for the piers along the North River to embark on one of the many harbor steamers that offer an escape from steaming streets for a few hours or perhaps a whole day.

HARVEY A. FALK of the Manhattan Camera Club received the gold medal award for the print of the year at the annual banquet last week of the Metropolitan Camera Club Council. Mr. Falk's print, which is reproduced on this page, was selected as the best of all the entries by the 100-member camera clubs of the council, which have a total membership of about 8,000.

STANTON, Del., June 18 (AP) -- Samuel D. Sidell's Allie's Pal sloshed through the mud today to beat Greentree Stable's Paddleduck in the $25,000 added New Castle Handicap by three and one-half lengths.

SISTER MARIS STELLA writes with a curious fresh innocence. The voice is clear and pure and a little breathless and very feminine. Her subject-matter is (on the whole) that of the unambitious woman writing poetry.

A COOPERATIVE plan of the International Refugee Organization and Youth Argosy, Inc., has been announced whereby 2,400 students and 2,400 displaced persons will be shuttled across the Atlantic by air in June and July.

THE year 1949 has to date been a capricious one, a year with possibly more than its share of strikingly successful individual mysteries, and certainly more than its share of flatly dull and incompetent material hardly worth publishing.

THE Screen Writers Guild last week determined on a step which may result in a significant change in film production. Guild members decided to demand provisions for leasing their work to film producers, in lieu of outright sale, in their prospective new contract with the movie companies.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Organized real estate and building interests joined with House Republican leaders today in answering President Truman's charge that the real estate lobby was fighting the Administration's multi-billion dollar housing bill with "false propaganda."

DETROIT, June 18 -- Except for Communists and pro-Communists, few in and around Detroit seem to be paying much more attention to the Communist trials and investigations than to other news. They do not compare in interest, for ex ample, with the bid the Detroit Tigers are making for first place in the American League.

All the basic important demands of the National Maritime Union were met by East and Gulf Coast steamship operators in the settlement reached Thursday morning, and progress was made on basic issues that have been hanging fire for the last ten years.

After long and honorable service as oil tankers in time of peace and war, two German-built vessels, the Motocarline and the Prometheus, formerly owned by the Panama Transport Company, a Standard Oil subsidiary, are now on the high seas under tow and headed for a British scrap-heap, it was learned yesterday.

A VERY Tulip of Fashion was Mr. Beaumaris, known also by the dandy set of eighteenth-century London as the Nonpareil, the man who, by a nod or a raised eyebrow, could set a lady at the very pinnacle of society, or conversely cast her as the season's number one wallflower.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., June 18 -- An explosion and fire in a large store of motion picture film wrecked the block-long warehouse of Progress Films, Inc., this morning.

Before 48,493 persons yesterday, the Yankees broke the Indians' six-game winning streak as Vic Raschi pitched his eleventh victory, 6 -- 3. Rex Barney permitted only five hits while the Dodgers defeated the Cubs for the eighth straight time this year, 2 -- 0. The Giants triumphed, 5 -- 4, despite a four-run rally by the Pirates in the ninth inning.

Large copper and brass interests have started a drive to stop the use of "prices at time of shipments" on fabricators' current orders. They want all fabricators follow uniform sales practices of quoting "firm prices" on the date of acceptance of an order.

FROM the beginning of our history there has been a form of lend-lease between the Old World and the New in ideas, techniques, skills, persons and property. Old World contributions to the New have been abundantly recorded and celebrated; New World contributions to the Old have been, for the most part, ignored or deprecated.

DESPITE the Communists' prolonged obstructionist tactics, a group of masterpieces from the Vienna museums will be shown next fall in New York, Washington, Chicago and San Francisco. The Soviet press has interpreted the projected exhibitions as, at least, a kind of Marshall Plan blackmail and, at most, as "Wall Street robberies."

CHICAGO, June 18 -- A second operation was performed today on Eddie Waitkus to remove congested blood from his lung cavity, surgeons at Illinois Masonic Hospital said. The condition of the 29-year-old first baseman of the Philadelphia National League team was termed favorable.

JESSE JAMES is immortal. In life he was first of America's public enemies; a lonely, hunted man who read the Bible, sang in the choir, and was scrupulously honest except when robbing banks or trains. On April 3, 1882, he was treacherously killed by Bob Ford -- "the dirty little coward who shot Mr. Howard and laid Jesse James in his grave."

Your editorial of May 28 entitled "When Governments 'Plan'" purports to comment upon a proposed bill to implement the Employment Act of 1946 by promoting continuing economic stability and growth and thereby averting extremes in the national economy.

Caroline Simon's "Causes and Cure of Discrimination" was informative and encouraging, but it omitted reference to a highly significant factor -- that discrimination may be very great in some occupations without leading to official complaints because minority group members do not usually even try to enter these fields.

MANCHESTER, Vt. -- The New England Council, whose members in the six Northeastern states give year-round serious consideration to their vacation and travel industry, spent last week-end here trying to figure out ways of insuring that this summer's tourist season would be as good as those of recent years.

THIS is Mr. Tatham's fourth in his "First-Book-Of" Series. In it he uses the same simple, appropriate terms to present automobiles that he has already used to present trains, planes and boats. The book answers the possible "Why," "How" and "What" questions of boys and girls up to 10 years old in an accurate and fascinating way.

German students, homeward-bound after a year's study in American colleges, believe they know now about "democracy." As one expressed it yesterday: "I think I got the idea -- you can't study it but you can feel it."
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 18 -- Istan displayed to a crowd of 15,678 the speed of which he was believed capable today when he won the Salvator Mile at Monmouth Park.

The brutal fact is that the people of the United States, beginning with the colonists and continuing to the present moment, have been ruthlessly, heedlessly, witlessly squandering their birthright.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Grains moved upward in fairly brisk dealings toward the close of business on the Board of Trade today. Early easiness in wheat and a ragged appearance in corn and oats were followed by a show of strength in all pits.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 18 -- Banking faces the "gravest responsibility" in meeting, the problems of the current, economic adjustment, Harry W. Davies, newly elected president of the New York State Bankers Association, declared here today.
LONDON, June 18 (Reuters) -- Champion Glamorgan, rattled Kent out for 49 runs before lunch at Swansea today, the lowest score in county championship cricket this season.
PARIS, June 18 -- Authoritative information indicates that the "quiet purge" of high Soviet officials and party leaders is even more extensive than had been indicated previously.

Dr. William S. Carlson, president of the University of Delaware, disclosed last week in his annual report that the university was considering the adoption of a "general education" program as a way of broadening the study of art, literature and philosophy in terms of present social problems.

DETROIT, June 18 -- Declaring that job security was more important today than wage increases, the Ford Motor Company today rejected demands of the CIO United Automobile Workers for pensions and higher wages and offered a counter-plan for eighteen months.

AMONG the summer theatres that will be functioning this season none will be watched with greater interest by people in show business than the one now being prepared for the nation's capital. Washington, as you know, has been without a professional theatre ever since the National turned to films rather than bow to the demands that Negroes be permitted among its audiences.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- John L. Lewis denounced equally today Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, and those who seek compromise ground in the fight over legislation to deal with strikes affecting national health and safety.

Until a decade ago one who received a lump sum payment as compensation for services rendered over a period of years was generally required to report, for income tax purposes, the full amount thereof in the year of payment. Obviously this resulted in hardship in many cases.

PARIS, June 18 -- The World Food Council today formally agreed to the termination of its International Emergency Food Committee and made progress toward a compromise on future work on international commodity arrangements.

LONDON, June 18 -- While one sector of the troubled labor front was brightened today by the announcement that wage negotiations between the railwaymen's unions and the management of the nationalized railways would reopen Monday, trouble was brewing in other sectors.

LONDON. ONE of the four most powerful men in the Soviet Union -- perhaps, behind the scenes, the most powerful of all after Stalin -- is Georgi Maximilianovitch Malenkov. Until a year or two ago, he was scarcely a name to the world outside, and to this day he is little more than a name.

RYE, N.Y., June 18 -- Richard Squires of the Hill, top seeded and pre-tourney favorite, won the Eastern interscholastic singles championship as the seventeenth annual invitation tennis tournament for private schools ended at Manursing Island Club today.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 18 -- Seven Zionist leaders were convicted tonight on charges of helping Zionists leave the country and were sentenced to terms ranging from six months to three years.

Surplus inventories of steel products in the hands of distributors and fabricators are depressing steel prices. Reductions quoted here last week, as holders pressed for orders, for the most part included lower prices on standard steel pipe, fabricated steel items, wire products and alloy steel products.

PLANTED now, certain vegetables that withstand frost will continue the productivity of the vegetable garden into the fall months. They have excellent flavor, and their seed, sown now will get a good start before hot weather really sets in.
CLEVELAND, June 18 -- The flow of iron ore down the Great Lakes is nearing record proportions, despite delays because of congestion at upper lake docks, shipping men said today.

ONE day all was serene on the family front, then, suddenly, a child wouldn't stay in her crib at night, another began taking off his clothes, a 5-year-old started to "swear," a girl in the first grade was turning into a "hell-raiser," especially when compared with her "little angel" sister, aged 11 months.

WASHINGTON. OUR Atomic Energy Commissioners have the disagreeable job of making atom bombs. That, under the law, is their chief assignment. They are currently being investigated on charges of "incredible mismanagement." But the eighteen investigators -- members of the Senate-House Committee on Atomic Energy -- face a dilemma; for they do not know how many bombs the commission has succeeded in producing.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., June 18 (AP) -- An all-woman jury last night convicted Mrs. Agnes E. Garnier of manslaughter in the slaying of her wealthy employer, John E. Owen.

The restless fleet of police motor cars, vans and trucks keep their vigil over the city's streets and respond to alarms of crime with little opportunity for idleness. Some 1,500 vehicles, according to Police Commissioner William P.O'Brien, traverse 20,000,000 miles in a year.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- A 30-year-old flying stowaway arrived here today aboard an Eastern Airlines plane from Miami, Fla.

PARIS, June 18 -- Specialists on Austria of the three Western powers met today to try to remove the most important remaining obstacles to a treaty for that country. These concern Soviet claims in the Danubian Shipping Company, in oil enterprises and in other Austrian companies. They all form aspects of the Soviet claim to former German assets in Austria.
