SALT LAKE CITY -- Vacationists at major national parks in the western states will find lodges, cabins, cafeterias and parkland highways in surprisingly good condition throughout the mountain states despite what Rangers term the worst winter since Federal recreation areas were first opened to the public.

THE New York Dance Film Society will make its debut on Thursday with two showings of its first program at the Dance Players Studio, 148 West Fifty-sixth Street, at 7:30 and 9:15. The public is invited to attend at an admission of $1.20.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor, which reported this week that unemployment had risen between mid-April and mid-May by 250,000 to a postwar high of 3,289,000, actually gets its figures via another bureau in another department.

NEW recordings of music by Mozart are always welcome in this corner, and in recent weeks there have been quite a few. There has not been time to listen to them all, but here is a report on three sets.

LONDON, June 18 -- Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin in a talk transmitted by telephone and loudspeaker to a miners' rally in Wakefield, Yorkshire, said today that "some progress" had been made in the meetings of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris, "but final conclusions have not yet been reached."
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Public Affairs Institute today proposed a series of actions for the immediate combatting of unemployment. One of them was a cut in taxes.

LILACS can hardly be regarded as temperamental in the matter of flowering, yet nonflowering among lilacs is not uncommon. This failing can generally be remedied. Adequate sunlight, extra nourishment and proper pruning will all help next year's bloom.

Dr. L.J. Coniglio and Mal Galletta of North Hills shot 33, 33 -- 66 to share the lead with Jack Lamberti and Tom Strafaci, Plandome, 32, 34 -- 66, at the end of the first round in the 36-hole member-guest golf handicap tournament at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday.

FOR the first time, the Herb Society of America will hold its annual meeting on the West Coast. The conference opens officially tomorrow in Oakland, Calif., and the first three days of the week-long program will include tours of the Marine Art and Garden Center, the Stamford University campus and the Botanical Garden of the University of California.

BOSTON, June 18 (AP) -- Boston's Red Sox made good use of bases on balls today in a six-run inning by which they defeated the Chicago White Sox, 7 -- 5, their third successive decision over the visitors.

SINCE Israel was reborn last year its citizens in great numbers have been dropping European names in favor of Hebrew ones. The Official Gazette, published by the Government in Tel Aviv, lists long columns of new names almost every week.

Russian imports in 1947 probably aggregated about $1,900,000,000, the largest in the history of that country's foreign trade to that time. This conclusion is reached in a pioneer comprehensive study of Soviet post-war foreign trade by Prof. Alexander Gerschenkron of Harvard University, recently published in The Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

With Father's Day promotions proving somewhat of a disappointment, dollar volume in New York department stores declined 11 per cent last week. Food sales among retail and wholesale grocers showed an increase on a tonnage basis, but dollar volume has declined as the result of lower prices.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Three former members of Rumania's diplomatic staff testified today that the legation here had been used by Communists to spread their propaganda and direct the activities of Leftist groups in this country.

Financial markets were subjected again last week to the usual quota of uncertainty and speculation. Labor negotiations, another break in stock prices, and conjecture regarding further readjustment in the national economy all played a part.

GOOD clean fun characterizes this frothy story of love in a laundry in Arizona. The jacket blurb credits Rosemary Taylor, who wrote the vastly popular "Chicken Every Sunday," with intimate knowledge of both the state and the trade.

NO railroad in America has been more exclusively identified with that great expanse of corn-and-hog country and wheat fields stretching from the Mississippi to the foothills of the Rockies than the Chicago, Burlington Quincy.

AROUND the world on a ship in 120 days is not quite as good as Jules Verne planned it, nor does it compare for speed with the seven-day globe-girdling offered by the airlines. But for a tourist with four months of leisure, a strong wanderlust, a love of the sea, and about $3,500 in ready cash, it makes a wonderful vacation.

WHEN famine threatened, Kalak, the polar bear, headed for the remote Bay of Seals where hunting was always good. For the same reason, Agtuk, the Endorah Eskimo chief, moved his hungry tribe there. Kalak, known far and wide as the "mist bear," was determined to raise her cubs to maturity, but Agtuk knew he could prove himself the true leader of his people by overcoming the famous bear.
DENVER, June 18 -- Albert C. Jacobs. Columbia University provost and internationally known educator, was named chancellor of the University of Denver today.
LEXINGTON, Va., June 18 (AP) -- Former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes said here today that some of the suggested new Federal programs "point inevitably to a welfare state."

FOR those who haven't made their minds up on what books to take away for vacation, this department (conscious of the fable of the donkey who, though surrounded by food, starved to death because he couldn't make his mind up) hopes to help them come to a choice among the new editions.

IT is a truth universally acknowledged, to paraphrase the famous opening line of Jane Austen's immortal "Pride and Prejudice," that the summer is a good time to read good books. It is a time for the annual and perennial slaying of the hammock-dragon of "hammock reading," a time to make up lost reading opportunities.

ALTHOUGH the Weather Bureau does not recognize the arrival of summer until Tuesday, the summer theatre circuit, no respecter of scientific convention, actually sprang into action late in May, when several of the rural playhouses, stealing a march on their fellows, struck, down the cobwebs and opened their box-offices.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 18 (AP) -- A crippled miner reported today that hooded men had dragged him from bed to witness the flogging of a neighbor three weeks ago.

REVIVAL of the U.S. Camera Achievement Awards for outstanding contributions to photography is announced by U.S. Camera Magazine. Although the event was initiated in June 1945, with awards to Joe Rosenthal for his Iwo Jima flag-raising picture and to the United States Navy for its documentary motion picture, "The Fighting Lady," the program was subsequently dropped because of postwar readjustment uncertainties.
BERLIN, June 18 -- Berliners, and indeed all Germans, are awaiting with mingled hopes and fears the conclusion of the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris.

Announcement last week by the National Retail Dry Goods Association that profits were down 48 per cent during the first quarter of the year in department stores of the nation served only to emphasize that retailers must lower their "break-even points" by cutting costs.

CHATTANOOGA, June 18 -- A growing restlessness with the whole business of spy-hunting Communist investigations, and similar activities, which in some instances have dropped to the "gossip'' level, is developing in the Deep South today as a result of recent developments.

THE Japanese school system for decades has been a favorite target of Western criticism. It is blamed for everything from poor eyesight to "banzai charges." After Pearl Harbor its reform was elevated almost to an Allied war aim.

Millions of the dollars that Great Britain needs desperately now are being siphoned off to other nations in three-way import deals for British merchandise, experts in foreign exchange conceded yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Government, fearing a slowdown of vital military production, is preparing to speed up the clearance of industrial workers for classified, or secret, jobs on military contracts, it was learned today.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 18 -- For the first time since 1938 a representative of Blair Academy carried off the Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association championship when Bob Black triumphed by 6 and 5 over Paul Kelly of Hackley School in the 36-hole final at the Greenwich Country Club today.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- The spotlight in boxing swings this week to this center of the sport as the International Boxing Club steps up plans for its second large-scale promotion within the period of a week.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 18 -- Tommy Bowles and his guest Howell Von Gerbig of the Meadow Brook Club, were forced to play twenty-one holes before a birdie 3 by Bowles produced a 1-up victory over Vivian McCree and Standish Douglas, unattached, in the upper half semi-final of the Cherry Valley invitation member-guest golf tournament today.

DURING the administration of Monaco's new reigning prince, Ranier III, there will be no speculation in the issuing of stamps at the expense of collectors, it was announced here last week by Henri Gamerdinger, the principality's Postmaster General, who holds the official title of Directeur de l'Office des Emissions de Timbres Poste.

Hitting an all-time peacetime peak, United States Quartrmaster procurements in the first eleven months of the current fiscal year totaled $427,000,000, an increase of 99 per cent over the corresponding 1948 period, it was learned last week.

THE four-hundredth anniversary of the Anglican Book of Common Prayer is being observed throughout the world this year, and especially during this month. It was on Whitsunday, June 9, 1549, that the book came into official use in England.

DAVID SPITZ, a young American political scientist on the faculty of Ohio State University, has devoted much serious thought to a defense of democracy. The result of his inquiry, however, differs from the conventional treatment.

AMERICAN readers will welcome the reappearance under new auspices, fourteen years after its first importation, of the classic work on Thomas More by the great English authority on the Tudor period. In the interval, scholarship has challenged details of the late Professor Chambers' analysis, but the book has not been superseded, and will not be for a long time.

WHEN the Rev. Jonathan Grigg was minister of Boston Town, windmills whirled on every hill and the tall masts of schooners crowded the harbor. Yet, in the prosperous days of 1688, New Englanders did not smile too readily.
PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- A crowd of 5,200 University of Pennsylvania alumni watched the Quakers bow to the Dartmouth nine by 4 -- 1 on Franklin Field today.

LOVERS of clear and simple English, who have despaired at the inroads jargon and other forms of gobbledegook appear to be making in this and other countries, ought to be encouraged by the appearance and success of this extraordinarily useful book.

I would like to comment on Allan Nevins' fine article, "Education for the Many and for Leaders, Too." Professor Nevins stresses the need of colleges to turn out effective thinkers and not college grads crammed with knowledge.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by the National Association of Real Estate Boards in reply to President Truman's comments on the public housing bill. It was made by T.H. Maenner, Omaha, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, in commenting on Friday's White House attack on realty spokesmen:
George Kinnear's article, "War in Africa -- On the Tsetse Fly," does not mention DDT or the other insecticides. Have these been used against the tsetse fly? With any success?

As a student of Germanic languages and literatures, I was extremely interested in the assertion in Prof. Leo A. Kirste's letter of June 12 that "as a necessary means of understanding, the Austrian people chose the most developed of the different tongues then spoken in their territory, the Bavarian version of what became later the German language."

SUMMIT, N.J., June 18 -- The three low scoring teams in yesterday's qualifying round of the annual Bill Hatt member-guest memorial tournament at the Canoe Brook Country Club were defeated today in their initial match play efforts.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Employment in the Chicago area declined 1.4 per cent from March to April, while payrolls were down 1.9 per cent in the same period. However, non-agricultural employment in the entire state rose 0.2 per cent in the month, halting a decline which had been in progress since the first of the year.

DETROIT, June 18 -- Lloyd Mangrum of Niles, Ill., with a three-under-par 68 today, tied with Cary Middlecoff for the lead at the fifty-four hole mark in the seventy-two hole Motor City Open golf tournament. Each has 204.

Pairings and the starting times of the first round of play in the fifth annual Women's Tri-County [Golf Championship startinl at the i lrmis Arden G. C., Old Greenwich, Conn., tomorrow were announced yesterday. The event, popularly known as the Edith Limberg tourI nament will continue through Friday.

Eight-year-old Tommy was a bright child but he kept floundering in his school work. Although in second grade, he was considerably below first-year levels in reading and writing. His difficulty was obvious -- he caught cold easily and missed fifty or sixty school days every term.

WARSAW, June 18 -- The Polish Government has decided to proceed slowly and cautiously in the collectivizing of peasant farms, and has limited this year's goal to the organization of approximately 200 model production cooperatives, according to Roman Zambrowski, secretary of the United Polish Workers (Communist) party.

Thousands of American shooters who had hoped for a return of the old national matches, open to all competitors, were disappointed again this year, for, despite the billions spent for "preparedness," Congress failed to appropriate an insignificant sum for the return of these matches.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 18 -- A week-long celebration marking the centennial of The Des Moines Register and Tribune began today.
SAN JOSE, Calif., June 18 (AP) Charley Gehringer, former major league baseball star, and Miss Josephine Stillen of Detroit were married here today after switching plans to avoid publicity.

Hunter College at its ninety-sixth commencement Wednesday evening will award degrees to 662 day and evening session students. Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. will deliver the commencement address.

FEW stories hold more drama and excitement than a well-written account, which this happens to be, of the men and women who have devoted themselves to the health and healing of mankind. And few books on the history of medicine are as complete and detailed as this which Dr. Garland has written.

The cost to the Federal Government of the price-support program on wheat from this year's crop may be the highest yet. Indications are that 500,000,000 bushels of the cereal may be placed in non-recourse loans. At the loan rate of $1.93 a bushel this would require an outlay of nearly $1,000,000,000.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 16 -- A search is now going on for a scriptural manuscript, older than any yet known, which is believed to be somewhere in Palestine, probably in the hands of a nomadic shepherd.
ONE of the simpler post-war marvels promised but not yet delivered is a book that remains open when opened. It is a device that would increase reading and reduce grease spots on books.

Fish-farming is one means of combating the acute food shortage of Asia, according to reports received by the United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources. In India and Japan, where critical food shortages menace health and progress, fish have not only provided food, but have rid some areas of malaria-carrying mosquitos and plant-destroying insects.

BELGRADE, June 18 -- The fundamental economic weakness of the Communist countries of Eastern Europe, including the Soviet Union itself, and the political problems which must be solved constitute some of the basic factors in Soviet foreign policy.

DARIEN, Conn., June 18 -- A.W.L., bay gelding owned by the Hi-Rock Farm of Warrenton, Va., and ridden by Joe Green, took an early lead with two blues in the jumper competition today at the two-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club fixture.
Leg and arm amputee veterans are rounding into shape for their night baseball game at the Polo Grounds July 26 under the auspices of the National Amputation Foundation.

Many Chinese students, stranded in this country since Shanghai's fall and job hunting for the first time in their lives, received high praise last week for "their courage and adaptability" from Roger Manstrude, acting director of International House, 500 Riverside Drive.

The first sign of a swift offensive against the utility industry's new program of "aggressive defense" came yesterday when the cry of "power trust" was revived by the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association.

TO THOREAU it was "the bare and bended arm of Massachusetts." Masefield called it the "strange curving crook of Cape Cod." To ultramodern designers its houses are blots on the landscape, yet must be accepted as the most functional models of functionalism.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- For the fourth time since the end of World War II, organized labor is fighting to achieve important objectives on the economic and social welfare front. This time, however, the "fourth round" wage demands are clouded by a murky economic situation because of increasing unemployment and a softening of some prices.
In an autmobile explosion and fire in a two-story garage at 212-214 West Eighty-eighth Street, east of Broadway, seven persons, six of them firemen, were injured yesterday at 8 A.M

IT is always risky to jump to conclusions about the eye-to-eyeness of publishers and others in the book business, but today's Sir Hubert department (see Page 3) supplies some interesting jumping evidence. For here, in effect, a respectable fraction of the trade have balloted on the question of what recent titles on other people's lists) are among the best titles.

Thirty-two foreign students will depart early today for a twenty-four-day bus trip through fifteen states. The group will leave the headquarters of the American Field Service, 113 East Thirtieth Street, at 5 A. M.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 18 -- The Yugoslav Government has permitted this correspondent to visit the fabulous but little known coal mountains in the heart of Bosnia to observe the difficult economic problems facing this country as a result of the Communist Information Bureau's blockade.

THIS is a remarkably finished work to have been written by a 15-year-old English girl. It is also a very good horse story in its own right. Its theme -- that of a young girl's deep attachment to a horse -- has been sentimentalized in some books to the point of silliness, but Miss Herald is far from sentimental.

RICH, rounded feeling and fastidious craftsmanship are consistently present in the poems of Carleton Drewry. In recent years a poem of his in a magazine was a rewarding place to stop; the experience of reading it was satisfactory.

A detour around trouble areas in which management, labor and stockholder engage in a triple cooperation is beginning to pay off for some companies. It's a new approach to the trouble of meeting the situation forced by highly competitive markets, labor's insistence on maintenance of wage standards and management's fear that pay hikes without corresponding sales might impair the company's power of earnings and reserve cash position.

ANY time that Merian Cooper and John Ford run short of filmable ideas for their Argosy Pictures Company, Mr. Cooper can draw on his own personal experiences as newspaper reporter, soldier, adventurer and movie executive with at least an even chance of coming up with a screenplay as crowded with excitement as anything a scenario writer might dream up.

EVERY now and then this department receives in its mail a letter so good, so thoughtful and perceptive, that I feel it should be shared with readers of this column, either with or without comment. The letter I have before me now has been in my files for some time.

PITTSBURGH, June 18 -- Leo Durocher gave full play to his managerial talents today and produced some extraordinary results, not the least of these being a nerve-tingling 5-to-4 victory over the Pirates in the second encounter of the current three-game series.

"AMERICA'S TOWN MEETING OF THE AIR," headed by George V. Denny Jr., the program's moderator, and accompanied by twenty-eight American leaders representing national organizations, will depart Saturday to explore the global scene in a tour of twelve foreign capitals.
The American President Lines announced last week that it had drastically revised its trans-Pacific and round-the-world cruise schedules to provide more time for shore excursions by tourists.

Someone had to cool off the red-hot and resurging Indians. So Casey Stengel sent Vic Raschi to the Stadium hill yesterday and had no reason to regret it. Raschi, though shaky in the late stages, came through handily, hurling the Yankees to a 6-3 victory over the champions, whose six-game winning streak fell by the Bronx way-side.
LUXEMBOURG, June 18 -- Western Union foreign ministers ended their two-day session here today with a complete record of agreement.

OWNERS of country hideaways eventually learn to accept their woodland lot, sunny meadow, sand dune or craggy hillside for exactly what it is. Then, by ordering descendants of plants already growing there, they manage to save themselves considerable time and energy.

CAUX, Switzerland, June 14 -- A 100-man team of amateurs, sparked by American and British followers of Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman's Moral Rearmament Corps, has been waging a frontal assault on key German Communists in their Ruhr and Rhineland strongholds for the last six months, it was disclosed at the World Moral Rearmament Congress here.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The political issue between the two major parties which is being shaped out of the current loyalty trials and investigations arose from these circumstances:

FOR a man of action and an erstwhile soldier of fortune, Stephen Fletcher Lewis, the hero of Mr. Davis latest novel, is unusually introspective, even if some of his philosophical flights are earthbound. Men may have been hardier in the days of Kipling and Jack London, but the latter-day adventurer finds the going rough and may, like Steve Lewis, be incapacitated by cardiac disorders at the age of 49.
CINCINNATI, June 18 (AP) -- Walker Cooper's big bat boomed again today and the Cincinnati Reds marked up a second straight victory over the Boston Braves, 6 to 2.

Ten top amateur golfers have been selected by the United States Golf Association to defend the Walker Cup in the biennial series against a team from the British Isles at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y., Aug. 19 and 20.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 18 -- Clinton Academy Museum has opened for its twenty-fifth season with a special exhibit of old-time spectacles, most of which were worn by settlers here in the eighteenth century.

With Democratic Mayoral candidates canceling each other out in the talking stage, the five county leaders were letting the political pot simmer yesterday in the hope that one candidate on whom there could be agreement would emerge. This has not happened thus far and an impasse appears highly probable.

MILWAUKEE, June 18 -- The marriage of Miss June Goes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Goes, to Richard Seaman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Seaman, took place here tonight in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Stoddard Patterson performed the ceremony.

NO one may beat a path to the inventor's door, save a few gratified violinists, but there is now a bow that plays four strings simultaneously. It has just been demonstrated at the International Congress of Violin Makers here, where it stirred a flutter of approbation.

IT is about time, I maintain, what with the international tourist season at hand, that those two great English-speaking peoples, the British and the Americans, get together on the names of things, especially official things.
This evening in Boston, the twenty-sixth annual conference of the American Physical Therapy Association will honor Miss Mary McMillan, one of the true pioneers in this important adjunct of medicine.

Management attorneys in this city took sharp issue yesterday with the plan of the United Steel-workers of America, CIO, to sue for all wages lost by the union's members if a strike grows out of the steel industry's refusal to bargain on pensions.

SEOUL, Korea, June 18 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea has taken under consideration a letter from sixty-two members of the Korean National Assembly recommending the withdrawal of both United States and Soviet military training missions in Korea.

At his press conferences in the Oval Room at the White House President Truman's manner is affable and courteous. The President chats with reporters crowded in front of his desk until all the correspondents -- well over 120 usually attend a conference -- have filed into the room.

GROCERY clerks all over town had my number before our family took its seventy-five mile canoe trip in northern Ontario. I was the woman who wanted dehydrated lemon juice, spinach powder, a can of butter, a dozen cans of powdered potatoes, and soup -- not soap -- flakes.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (UP) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, sought today to transfer the new coal contract talks with the United States Steel Corporation from Philadelphia to White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., next Thursday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 18 -- A tradition of almost two centuries was broken today when the Brown University Corporation elected a woman to the university's board of trustees. She is Mrs. Anna Canada Swain of Craigville, Mass., president of the Northern Baptist Convention and a member of the executive committee of the World Council of Churches.
FOR Americans who read as they travel, or vice versa, 1949 is a rubric year.

South Fifth Street, between Hooper and Keap Streets, Brooklyn, was blocked off to vehicular traffic for a half-hour yesterday by 150 irate mothers and children. The action followed the death on Friday night of an 8-year-old boy who was struck by an automobile.

THE motoring season, which is now at hand, coincides, unfortunately, with the road building and repair season, which is also now at hand. The resultant delays, detours and dust-baths are the price the motorist must pay for the smooth, straight highways on which he speeds between and after the construction projects.

DESSERTS in warm weather? They must be quick to make, for the culinary amateur has little time to spend inside when summer invites her outdoors. They must be cool to cook, for prolonged heat in the kitchen can render that room unbearable on a sultry day. And like the rest of the menu, they must refresh appetites that may lag as the mercury rises.

THE radio industry no longer is making any secret of the fact that this summer and fall probably will bring the most intense competition for new business since well before the war, with most stations and networks already starting to cut down their overhead wherever possible.

While all who drive are aware of the ubiquity of the motor truck, it is only when the statistics of the vast trucking industry are assembled that one realizes its importance in our economy. The American Trucking Associations, in its third edition of Trends, brings home sharply some of these facts.

THE author of this refreshing and unpretentious book is an English mountain - climber and former army officer, a prominent member of that select company whose vocation it is to scale the pinnacles of the Himalaya. Originally published in England in 1938 and already known as something of a masterpiece in its genre, the story tells about a flower - collecting trip to the Garhwal Range.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 18 (UP) -- Nine non-scheduled airliners were forced today to delay their departures, as technical experts began rigorous maintenance inspections to prevent a repetition of the crash which cost fifty-three lives last week.

THERE'S a worrisome suspicion among the best people down in Virginia that the social revolution is about to catch up with them at last. Whether it's the psychological aftermath of war (World War II, that is); the pernicious and cumulative influence of the New Deal, or even perhaps a delayed reaction to that faintly disreputable old free-thinker, Tom Jefferson, a rather disconcerting change seems to impend and Virginians are facing the prospect with mixed emotions.

ONE hundred years ago, a 15-year-old Norwegian orphan named Nils Thorson was grinding a knife in a small tavern in Nordal when he heard an excited voice talking about America. It was Cleng Peerson, Norse pioneer, who brought many settlers to this country.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Two smashing relay performances in open races featured the third annual interdepartmental track and field games of the Police Sports Association, staged before 5,000 spectators, including Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien, at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 18 -- The first of the debutantes of the June season on the North Shore were honored tonight at dinners and a supper-dance, a program that will continue through next week with several parties every night in country houses.

Herman Rodenberger, who is "only a young kid of 75 years, myself," believed yesterday that he had found the perfect solution for discouraging children from defacing the walls of his property and smashing windows in playing handball.

The marriage of Miss Anne Thompson Codling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Codling of College Point, Queens, to Ainslie Hayden Drummond Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Ainslie Hayden Drummond of Whitestone, Queens, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church, College Point.

LIFE, alas, no longer imitates art. It imitates the cinema. Arthur Koestler, fleeing the German advance into France, remembered a Jean Gabin movie and enlisted in the Foreign Legion in order to escape the Nazis. But not only life is copying the cinematic shadow world.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 18 -- The first steps to collective farms in Bulgaria have met the "violent opposition of the kulaks," it was stated today in the Government's English-language publication, Free Bulgaria.

Although substantial orders for fall ready-to-wear were placed by a large number of buyers in the wholesale apparel market here last week, buying was generally cautious, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Inquiries in three Central Western metropolitan centers this week brought out general agreement among the public that the Washington trial of Judith Coplon and the New York trial of eleven Communist leaders were necessary for the protection of the country.

ALONG about now, annuals that were transplanted to the garden a few weeks ago should be picking up and making good growth. However, whether they are doing as well as expected or not, there are several ways in which their progress can be aided.

The days grow long. The summer solstice approaches. Summer is here, in its heat and lushness of green, the urgent growth of spring has run its first course. The growing things have spread their tissue of chlorophyll to catch the maximum of sunlight, and from now on they will be strengthening limb and twig, fattening fruit, building toward the season's maturity.
RED TOP, Conn., June 18 (AP) -- Harvard's varsity crew, in a time trial today, smashed by 20 seconds all previous records for the upstream, four-mile course on the Thames River.

NEWARK, N.J., June 18 -- Describing these times as "a tragic era in which this conflict we call a cold war may concern and bedevil us for many years," Vice President Alben W. Barkley in an address here today expressed the hope that the Paris conference of Foreign Ministers "will produce something that will give hope and happiness to the world's two billion people."

"AND BEAR IN MIND," which made its first appearance in these pages in mid-October, 1948, was devised primarily as a means of calling attention each week to books of literary, scholarly or topical interest -- books that might otherwise receive less attention than they deserve.

A slum clearance plan for Flushing, Queens, involving the construction of a $5,000,000 housing development for 400 families and the laying out of a parking field for 1,100 automobiles, moved one step nearer realization yesterday when the Board of Estimate received a report from its chief engineer, John C. Riedel, urging approval of the project.
ATLANTA, Ga., June 18 -- The spy and Communist investigations evoked a great deal of discussion, much of it caustic, in this area this week.

Barbara Ward's "Italy Is Outwardly Poor but Inwardly Rich" brought me out of darkness relative to my parents' intense urge to return to the good life, to go home again. But to what "good life," when here they enjoy all the modern amenities, and home again would mean a two-century retrogression.

In his letter published in THE TIMES of June 5 Herbert Askwith evidences confusion of thinking as between those transportation rates which must cover the costs of service and those in which deficits can be transferred to the taxpayers.

MOSCOW, June 18 -- A young Soviet writer extols Moscow as the current center of the world's most advanced industry and the most advanced science and art and holds that within twenty-five years it will become "a city of the sun," the like of which the world has never yet seen.

For the first time since it was organized, nearly sixty years ago, the Army and Navy Legion of Valor is seeking by public subscription to raise $5,000,000, part of which is to be used in a campaign to improve and extend the teaching of American history in the nation's public schools.

"THE Inside Story" triumphs over all handicaps and presents the reader with an autobiographical story as entertaining as it is enlightening, written by an iconoclast who is able to annihilate cherished prejudices without ever mounting the pulpit or becoming a learned bore.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 18 -- Canvas-borne out on the deep blue, two score yachts tonight are on their way from here to Annapolis in the race co-sponsored by the New York Yacht Clubs, the U.S. Naval Academy and the Annapolis Yacht Club.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 18 (AP) -- Richard Savitt, second-seeded Cornell University athlete, today became the Eastern intercollegiate tennis champion as he completely outclassed Harold M. Burrows of the University of Virginia, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2.

THE principal controversy among bridge authorities lately has involved hand valuation: Should you count your high cards as points, ace being 4, king 3, queen 2 and jack 1, or should you count them as honor-tricks?

SKAGWAY, Alaska -- In the high-ceilinged old mess hall of the White Pass Yukon Railway at Bennett Station we sat down to a bountiful meal. The table sagged beneath its load of pot roast, gravy, boiled potatoes, baked beans, spaghetti, bread and butter, coffee and apple pie with Tillamook cheese.

BUENOS AIRES, June 18 -- Paul G. Hoffman's remarks before the Senate Appropriations Committee, particularly his assertion, that "every pressure we can exert" will be used against bilateral trade, touched off bitter streamers in this morning's newspaper Democracia, and the criticism is sure to continue.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 18 -- With the Newport to Annapolis race setting a blue-water example, ten boats in the International Class sailed an "ocean race" of their own today within the confines of Long Island Sound in the non-championship Y.R.A. regatta of the Larchaunt Yacht Club.
COLUMBIA, S.C., June 18 -- Gov. J. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina announced today that he would not attend a dinner here July 1 at which Vice President Alben W. Barkley will speak.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 18 -- Some of the steps taken by the United States Air Force to eliminate drag on speedy planes caused by protruding radio antennas were revealed here today at the Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. More than 600 horsepower is saved for propulsion purposes in some of the larger planes, which may have as many as fifteen receiving and sending antennas.
ROME, June 18 (AP) -- The Italian news agency, Astra, reports that Yugoslav leaders have warned Italy to cease agitation for return of Trieste and respect the peace treaty.

IN England "Journey Into Spring" has received rather extravagant praise from such popular novelists as J.B. Priestley, Storm Jameson and Howard Spring. They are delighted that a man can write as well as Mr. Clewes and still be so loyal to the conventions of sentimental fiction, delighted that he can reanimate the most venerable characters and situations of popular romance, and still sound so socially serious and so psychologically up-to-date.
HONOLULU, June 18 -- Most vacationists who have not been frightened away from Hawaii by the longshore strike are congratulating themselves for being here at this time.

To provide faster service between New York and Boston and Springfield, Mass., and to eliminate "lightly patronized" trains on the two routes, new schedules, effective next Sunday, have been set up, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company announced yesterday.

THE employment outlook for newcomers attempting to gain a foothold in the television industry is not overly bright, according to a study of the industry made by the Occupational Outlook Service of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department and released last week.

ANNAPOLIS, MD., June 18 -- Belmont Hill School of Belmont, Mass., today captured the Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association regatta and the Mallory Cup that goes with it as Leigh Quinn skippered the winning crew home through the rain in the decisive race over the Chesapeake Bay.
New aspersions on the loyalty of teachers to the American system of democratic government evoked considerable uneasiness last week among educators throughout the nation.

THOSE persons interested in religious art who visit the Demotte Galleries to see Juan de Aranoa's fourteen paintings, "A Way of the Cross," will be surprised and even shocked if they expect to find a mild version of Christ's Passion.

Three hundred and fifty students, the largest graduating class in the history of Queens College, will receive diplomas at the fifteenth commencement exercises to be held on Wednesday at 4 P. M. on the college quadrangle.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 (AP) -- St. Louis Cardinal president Fred M. Saigh said today pitcher Fred Martin wants to rejoin the Redbirds but is having difficulty arranging his release from the Canadian Provincial League.

The Quartermaster Corps will set up light housekeeping Army style in Long Island City next Friday to demonstrate how it treats soldiers in the field, according to an announcement yesterday from First Army Organized Reserve Corps headquarters.

THIS June more people are being graduated from American colleges than at any time in history. As they troop up in cap and gown to the rostrum for the traditional handshake and the diploma, the members of the class of '49 -- many of them veterans -- are breathing a sigh of relief that the years of training are over, and they can now begin to earn a living.

PITTSBURGH, June 18 -- Frank I. Snyder, 65 years old, president of the Bessemer Lake Erie Railroad, died today of injuries suffered in a highway crash Friday night in which another Pittsburgh railroad president was injured seriously.

SHIP BOTTOM, N.J. -- The Lucy Evelyn, one of the last survivors of the once great fleet of three-masted schooners that plied the Atlantic routes, is now permanently berthed on the shore of the bay between here and Beach Haven.

FONTANA VILLAGE, N.C. -- This government-managed resort in the Great Smoky Mountains, already filled to more than half of its capacity of 1,000 guests, is entering its fourth season with bright prospects. Fishermen are displaying good catches of bass from Fontana Lake and trout from the streams that empty into it.

A new effort to organize a "united front" of affected industries for repeal of the Federal 20 per cent retail excise taxes at this session of Congress was started yesterday. Letters were sent to twenty-six representatives of fur, jewelry, luggage, toiletries, handbags and accessories associations by the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations, 80 West Fortieth Street, inviting them to attend a meeting to discuss the pooling of their separate efforts toward repeal.

When an engineer has to design a bridge, dam or any other structure that falls under the head of "waterworks," he wants to know what is the biggest flood for which he must make allowances. The United States Geological Survey has tried to answer the question for years, only to admit failure.

The reports that Moslems are having a bad time in the Soviet Union will cause little surprise to those who are familiar with the character of Moslem religious faith. The nature of that belief is such that the Moslem cannot give full support to Stalinist Marxism and the result must necessarily be his persecution by the Marxist state because of his opposition.

IN his first novel Ward Thomas presents the dilemma of a moral man, afflicted with the curse of inverted love, in a society which morally condemns that affliction. He is one of the first writers to deal with homosexuality, so recurrent a subject in modern letters, on a socially conscious plane as the problem of a minority ostracized by the group.

Mr. Truman's attack of last Friday on what he called the "little group of ruthless men" who are opposing the Administration's housing program has the merit of dramatizing the housing problem. The members and backers of the housing lobby may not be as wicked as Mr. Truman thinks they are.
The second choice was the right choice in (a) the $23,675 Gazelle Stakes and (b) the $13,275 Astoria Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct, where 27,837 persons gathered for an afternoon of winner-hunting.

MISS JANET ADAM SMITH has brought together the correspondence between Robert Louis Stevenson and Henry James and the critical essays in which each refers to the other. It makes an altogether admirable book.

ONE of the marginal consequences of post-war pressure in the film industry has been the impulsive reissue of a lot of comparatively old films. And one of the singular blessings of this strictly distress policy has been the unlooked-for revival of a few priceless items from the past.
Driving homemade "hot rod" cars that can zoom along the road at 100 miles an hour was emphasized yesterday as a growing whimsy to enhance ego among some 'teen age thrill-seekers in this area.

ON this Father's Day probably the gift that millions of dads would most appreciate would be the assurance that business and their jobs are not "going to pot." Only a half-way guarantee can be offered to them, in the opinion of most authorities.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Cocktail parties in the capital noted a new military insignia last week -- the badge of the National Military Establishment, a nice piece of costume jewelry which is symbolic of the hoped-for unity of the armed forces.

FOR THIS WEEK: If the entire garden cannot be watered during a dry spell, concentrate on shrubs set out last spring or fall, on flowers in bud, and gladiolus and dahlias. . . . A spell of cool, rainy weather will be a natural control for red spider. Meanwhile, spray or dust affected plants with sulfur. . . .

In your editorial on loyalty oaths you speak of the "noonday madness" produced by our effort to deal with the Communists. The National Study Conference on the Churches and World Order held in Cleveland last March warned against those "who increase the tensions of our world by hysteria and hatred."

IT'S a long way from that perennial rural standby "Acres of Diamonds" to "15 Ways to Make Money in the Country." There's not much glitter in this latest promise to lifelong security if you'll follow "these practical, tested plans to make your farm or handcraft pay a handsome profit."

English period furniture and Georgian silver are among the items that will be auctioned on Thursday at the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street. Exhibition of the sale's material, which comes in part from the estate of the late Sophie Goman of New York, begins tomorrow.

Costa Rica, the Central American country which claims to have more school teachers than soldiers, will be the subject of an area study program this fall at Syracuse University. Open only to graduate students, the program will offer integrated research in the fields of Costa Rican anthropology, geography, history, political science and literature.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., June 18 -- With some sharp dissents echoing through the borrowed chamber of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, a majority of youthful debaters agreed today that the world organization was doing the job that it set out to do at San Francisco.

JERSEY JOE WALCOTT and Ezzard Charles, two journeyman heavyweights, will battle in Chicago on Wednesday for what may laughingly be described as the championship of the world. The winner will be striving for recognition as the successor to Joe Louis but it may take years for the tangle to be untangled. That is not to say, however, that the date of June 22 should be ignored. The historians will never ignore it. No, sirree.

The recent explosions in connection with the Eisler case are important not so much because of Eisler himself as because of the attention which they have called to the inadequacy of our present extradition treaties with the nations of the British Commonwealth.

Educational organizations and college officials were sharply divided last week in their reaction to a statement by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, in which he opposed Federal aid to education. A spot check by THE NEW YORK TIMES indicated that the educators were also as much divided on whether such aid, if it is authorized by Congress, should be universal or limited in scope.

An alarm buzzer attached to an offering box in the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, 331 West Forty-second Street, brought about the arraignment yesterday in Felony Court of an ex-convict on charges of petty larceny and possession of burglar's tools.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 18 (UP) -- A plan originating in the United States to help solve the Arab refugee problem by developing new areas in the Middle East, has been pigeonholed until there is some sign of progress in the Arab-Israeli peace talks here, reliable sources said today.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 18 -- Connecticut's members of Congress will be asked to help save the Stamford lighthouse.

PARIS, June 18 -- An estimated 40,000 sympathizers of Charles de Gaulle and half as many Communists held simultaneous demonstrations within half a mile of each other today. Fights, which had been generally feared, were prevented by the presence of 25,000 armed police and security troops.

BRUNSWICK, Me., June 18 -- Bowdoin College conferred seven honorary and 189 baccalaureate degrees today and announced at the dinner which followed its 144th commencement exercises that it had raised $1,907,734.85 toward its sesquicentennial fund campaign goal of $3,025,000.

PARIS, June 18 -- Only in its last week did the Council of Foreign Ministers become a conference. In the first three weeks there was no real discussion. The Western powers and the Soviet Union presented proposals for the unification of Germany that each side knew the other side could not accept without surrendering its basic position and its essential philosophy.

OXFORD, Ohio, June 18 -- Dr. Walter R. Agard of the University of Wisconsin was re-elected president of the American Classical League today at the closing session of its annual institute held at Miami University here, location of its national headquarters.

BOSTON, June 18 -- Although most New Englanders subscribed to the principle of tracking down and stamping out Communist activity in the nation, two recent developments left them somewhat skeptical of the methods.

Convinced that free, municipally operated parking lots are "unsound in principle," the city plans to charge a fee at its 3,000-car facility on the old World's Fair site in Queens, it was disclosed yesterday.

TWO GUNS, Ariz. -- Within sight of this sleepy Indian trading post in the north Arizona desert there is a hole in the ground which would have taken men many years to dig with the most modern excavators available.

THE United States Congress is a unique legislative body. In its 160-year history it has evolved methods of transacting business unlike those of any other national law-making organization. Starting with a House of sixty-five members and a Senate of twenty-two, it has grown increasingly complex as its membership has grown to ninety-six in the upper chamber and 435 in the lower.

I WONDER sometimes whether memory is not the core of one's own feeling of identity. If a cut is made in the stream of memory, the part that flows away ceases to be us. If this or that is dipped up in buckets and recognized as having formerly been us, it now is no more us than the hair and nails or even meaner products of the body that we have shed.

ASPEN, Col., a community with a permanent population of 1,500, is making plans to house approximately 4,000 visitors at its Goethe Bicentennial June 27 to July 16, which means that a lot of extra beds are being readied for use.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- There have been opinions voiced around the National League that Rex Barney has been a mediocre pitcher this season, but the Cubs bitterly disagree with such points of view.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 18 -- Declaring that he did not know how often in the future he would be able to speak to them, Archbishop Josef Beran today begged Roman Catholics to believe in him even if they heard he had "made a confession." He said he would never make an agreement with the state that infringed on the rights of the church.

THE operation of Boeing Stratocruisers out of New York International Airport at Idlewild will continue in spite of the breakdown last week of efforts by the airlines and the Port of New York Authority to reach an out-of-court settlement of leases at the new airport.

LONDON, June 18 -- Ted Schroeder whipped Gardnar Mulloy, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 0, today in the Queens Club tennis final. Schroeder's victory was marked by a linesman's disputed call that fanned the word war raging over the repeat performance of these two Americans in the first found at Wimbledon Monday.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed Father's Day gift items, women's and misses' summer suits, dotted Swiss dresses, cotton sunback dresses, bathing suits, decorative fabrics and metal chaise longues, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by The Retail News Bureau, Inc.

"Well," sighed Mr. X, a local book publisher, soon after the turn of the year, "maybe the dear reading public doesn't realize it, but there's a serious crisis in publishing. I suppose we in the trade are going to survive, though at the moment I doubt it."

The world's first gas-turbine cargo ship is now being built on the Clyde, Scotland. Marine gas-turbines will save much space and consume cheaper fuel oil than steam-turbines do. Gas-turbines for marine propulsion are designed for a running life of not less than 100,000 hours at full load and temperatures.

MONTICELLO -- Three major projects now being studied by resort men of Sullivan County -- the most populated part of the Catskill Mountain vacation region, which is in numbers of hotels and guests the largest single resort area in the nation -- concern transportation to and from the mountains.
Two of the prize spectacles of intercollegiate sports, the New London and Poughkeepsie rowing regattas, will be held this week, bringing down the curtain on the season.

It was a proud Jake LaMotta who arrived home yesterday morning fresh from his victory over Marcel Cerdan in Detroit's Briggs Stadium Thursday night. The newly crowned world middleweight champion, stating that "I'm going to try to be a great champion," was greeted at Penn Station by his brother and manager, Joe, and Phil Terranova, former featherweight ruler.
OMAHA, Neb., June 18 -- Interest is great throughout the Midwest in the spy trials and Communist hearings, but not enough to outrank several other subjects.
NORMAN, Okla., June 18 (AP) -- Mrs Ada Lois Sipuel Fisher, Chickasha Negro, today completed her enrollment in the University of Oklahoma Law School.

THESE two books themselves illustrate a favorite semantical distinction -- between language used to convey information (the volume by Mr. Lasswell et al.), and language aimed at producing a definite effect on the reader (the anthology edited by Mr. Lee).

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 -- While retail business activity in the Twelfth district continued to fall below last year, losses were not quite as severe during the past week. In San Francisco sales went counter to the general trend. All other areas reported losses.

CAIRO, June 18 -- Prophecies that some immense change was going to take place in the Arab world because of the outcome of the Israeli affair have disappeared into thin air. On the contrary, nearly all recent developments have turned out to be either of local significance or have intensified the tendency of each country to devote itself primarily to its own affairs or those of its immediate neighborhood.

LOS ANGELES, June 18 -- The University of Southern California Trojans captured their thirteenth National Collegiate A.A. track and field championship today. One meet record was toppled and three were tied in this twenty-eighth renewal of the event.

The American people should be "mature" enough to shun a "witch hunt mentality" whenever the question of Russia is raised, Rabbi David J. Seligson, assistant rabbi at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, said yesterday in his sermon.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. June 18 (AP) -- Ten thousand Kiwanians from the United States, Canada, Alaska and Hawaii will begin tomorrow their thirty-fourth annual convention.

This is Father's Day, But every Sunday, really, is father's day. If you doubt it, look around the parks and playgrounds in New York City any Sunday. For six days Mother has the problem of taking the small child to the Park.

WHATEVER the grown-ups choose for their vacation reading, summertime definitely means a change of pace for the younger members of the family. The beach, the tennis court, the bicycle path beckon alluringly. So does the television set, in season and out.

When President Truman referred the other day to the prevailing anti-Communist hysteria in this country he was not bringing up a new idea. It was the reporters, in fact, who introduced the subject and pressed for comment on it. Like other Americans who follow public events closely, they were aware of something unhealthy in the country's present state of emotion.
SHANGHAI, June 18 (UP) -- The Communist radio tonight accused the United States Consulate and a United States Army liaison group at Mukden of being "espionage organs."
ROME, June 18 (AP) -- Italian emigration officials have requested $32,000,000 from Italy's European Recovery Program funds to be spent in South America.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 18 -- The Federal Government is better equipped to deal with recession problems than ever before, Vice President Albert W. Barkley asserted here today. He spoke to the New York State Bankers Association, which has been holding its fifty-third annual convention at this resort.

For the past seven weeks in Lausanne, Switzerland, a strange sort of peace conference has been going on between Israel and the four Arab states that touch her borders -- Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon and Syria. In this peace conference one side never speaks to the other.

IN a high hotel apartment overlooking Central Park, a determined young woman is hard at work perfecting her arias for a fall concert tour. For two hours in the morning, with an accompanist, she runs the scales, trills high C's, practices voice and breath control, and sings her numbers over and over again.

COMING events said to cast their shadows before, and a discerning eye might see the outline of Rudolf Bing in the people who, the rumors say, may be new arrivals at the Metropolitan Opera next season.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Trade influences were pretty well balanced in the wheat market last week, as shown by irregular fluctuations within a moderate price range on the Board of Trade. The tone, however, was easy at the end of the period.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 19 -- Saving Europe from communism will not be enough to protect the world from the menace of enslavement, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York declared here today in a commencement address.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 19 -- Maj. Gen. John Bagot Glubb, British commander of the Arab Legion, said here today that the Israelis had begun general sniping during the last few days after six weeks of peace along the front held by the Legion.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers, behind the superb pitching of Virgil Trucks and Freddie Hutchinson, shut out the Washington Senators in both ends of a double-header today. A crowd of 21,818 saw the Tigers win, 9 -- 0 and 7 -- 0.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 19 -- This country still offers, by and large, more "actual enjoyment" of economic and social rights for all peoples than any other place in the world, a six-month survey of human relations by the Social Science Institute of Fisk University reported today.

Stringent curbs on the right of defense counsel to disclose at will secrets vital to national security are expected to be endorsed when leading jurists of this state open public hearings on criminal procedure in espionage cases, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period June 11 to 17 are given in the appended tabulation:

Father had the stellar role on New York's stage yesterday as the city commemorated in songs, speeches and ceremonies his fine qualities and his contributions to society in general. In short, Father's Day was quite a success here.

Manufacturers of portable lamps have been making valiant efforts to refute the statement of Marcel Breuer, architect, that he could find no lamps suitable for display in the Museum of Modern Art's exhibition house. Whether any of the newest designs would meet the architect's requirements is a moot point, but they do serve to emphasize that almost any size, shape, color or fantastic motif is likely to turn up these days in a lamp.

ROME, June 19 -- An extraordinary congress of right wing Socialists tonight reconfirmed Giuseppe Saragat as the party's leader. This decision, made at the final session, insured the collaboration of the right wing Socialists with Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Democratic Christian Government and disposed of the need of a Cabinet reshuffle.

LONDON, June 19 -- The expected has happened, and with a kind of morbid satisfaction the stock markets here have seen the industrial share index break through its post-war low point of 104.2 just because it had been predicted freely that it would do so.

The local opening of "Miss Liberty" has been deferred for the second time. It is now due at the Imperial on July 15, instead of the preceding night. The switch was made to obtain ample leeway in setting up the heavy production here, it was announced.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Labor leaders and observers of the national economy in Congress presented divergent views of the employment picture today.

New York has failed to take advantage of available means to improve living conditions in Harlem, State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman declared yesterday in an address at the annual St. John's Day celebration of the Most Worshipful Enoch Grand Lodge, A. F. A. M., held in the Mother A. M. E. Zion Church, 151 West 136th Street.

The difference between God's love and human love is that His is unending, the Rev. Dr. Albert Peel, lecturer and former moderator of the Congregational Union of England and Wales, declared yesterday at the morning service of the Riverside Church.

BOSTON, June 19 -- The nation should use its wartime-acquired knowledge to give physically handicapped civilians the same opportunities now available to disabled veterans, Dr. Howard A. Rusk of New York tonight told delegates to the twenty-sixth annual conference of the American Physical Therapy Association.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 19 -- Clarifying information about the preliminary outcome of the deliberations held in Washington this month between the Allies on one side and Switzerland on the other to remove differences of opinion on interpretation of the Washington agreement of May 25, 1946, to liquidate German assets in Switzerland was given when the chief of the Swiss delegation, Dr. Walter Stucki, held a press conference in Berne on last Thursday.

Immediate bookings on all vessels of the Cunard White Star fleet for late summer or early fall sailings are available, according to an announcement by Vincent A. Demo, general passenger manager of the company.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 19 -- A new world record was made in the obedience trials of the Dog Training Club of Northern New Jersey today when two perfect "200" scores were made by Russell H. Klipple of Havertown, Pa., with his Shetland sheepdog Captivator Tam o'Shanter. He won the graduate novice class and open class A under two of the country's top judges, Mrs. Harriet Schacht and George W. Brown.
PETERSBURG, W. Va., June 19 (AP) -- Flash floods that raged over the week-end in the Potomac-Shenandoah Valley have taken at least nine lives, authorities said tonight.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 19 -- Following is the text of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's address at the Williams College commencement here today:

The Arrow Upholstery Company, one of the largest manufacturers of upholstered furniture in the country, has purchased for expansion purposes the twelve-story loft building on a plot 100 by 115 feet at 119 to 125 West Twenty-fourth Street, from J. Swedlin, Inc., toy manufacturer.
Lewis Conger, retailer of housewares and home furnishings, to Williams Saylor, Inc. The account was previously handled by R. T. O'Connell Company.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 19 -- Representatives of 1,200,000 Congregational laymen voted today to form the International Congregational Laymen's Fellowship. Clarence C. Beasley of Boston was elected its chairman at the sixth International Council of Congregational Churches.

MEXICO CITY, June 19 -- How soon the cost of living in Mexico may go up as a result of the peso being stabilized at a dollar value nearly double what it was a year ago was the question uppermost today in the public mind here.

PARIS, June 19 -- The Soviet Union's anti-American campaign, ably seconded by that of the Communist Information Bureau, has now assumed such proportions that it is worth analyzing not only in terms of its extent but in terms of its future effect.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Two of President Truman's "Fair Deal" measures will retain their top billing in Congress this week. They are repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act and the Public Housing Bill.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 19 -Henry-Russell Hitchcock, professor of art at Smith College, will be acting director of the Smith College Museum of Art until a permanent appointment is made, Herbert J. Davis, president of the college, announced today.

Your editorial of June 15 "Work Relief vs. the Dole" appears to have missed the mark set by the Commerce and Industry Association in relating its concern over the city's projected work relief program and the mounting expenditures for welfare.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 -- The steel operating rate slipped again last week and there were no signs that bottom had been reached. The national rate was off 2 1/2 points to 86.5 per cent of rated capacity. A further decline was forecast for this week.

A one-story taxpayer containing ten stores at 3440-60 Junction Boulevard, corners of Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Avenues, Jackson Heights, was sold by the H. W. Realty Corporation to an investing client of A. Phillip Sweet, broker. It was held at $175,000.

With the arraignment of four men in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday on various charges of receiving stolen goods, violation of the Sullivan Law and grand larceny, the police announced that they had broken up a gang that in the last year had stolen about $100,000 worth of merchandise from piers.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 19 -The expensive wrist watch of the shabbily dressed man being booked for speeding caught the eye of the desk sergeant at police headquarters. The sergeant took the watch and checked its serial number against a card index file.
MOSCOW, June 19 -- The Soviet press gave detailed attention over the week-end to what was termed the growing United States economic crisis.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 19 -- Members of the police emergency squad here attempted this afternoon to rescue a youth from the waters of Newark Bay. They failed, because he indignantly refused to be rescued. The youth was John Klena, 17 years old, of 11 Gotthardt Street, Newark, N. J.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 -- Much of the guesswork in problems of space travel and intercontinental rocket warfare has been eliminated by new and revolutionary, discoveries concerning the composition and temperatures of the upper atmosphere, it was disclosed here.

The Theatre Guild is perplexed by a first-night ticket problem this season. But the Guild has discovered a remedy and is seeking the cooperation of those subscribers allotted premiere tickets. They are being requested to avail themselves of opening-night seats to three of the five plays and attend a dress rehearsal of the other two without charge, which is fair enough.

PARIS, June 19 -- The black market here for the pound sterling fell last week to the lowest rate quoted since the beginning of the year. The pound was traded at about 1,010 francs. This produces a cross rate of $2.92 for the pound on the black market when the official cross rate is $4.03.
Foreign exchanges moved irregularly last week. Business was slow and appeared to be the sole reason for the market's inaction.

Leaders of the 1949 Girl Scout contributors' campaign were announced yesterday as Mrs. Howard Phipps, city-wide campaign chairman; Mrs. Leonard Henry, chairman of the Manhattan women's committee; Mrs. Irving Berlin, chairman of public relations and Miss Dorothy Fields, chairman of the Manhattan business and professional women's campaign committee.

Rare plants from Venezuela, including a species of strychnos, from which South American Indians obtain curare, their arrow-tip poison, and specimens of a rare bamboo that they use as the barrel of their blowguns, have been brought to the United States by an expedition of the New York Botanical Garden, it was announced yesterday.
About that cute U. P. dispatch in THE TIMES of June 13:

ST. LOUIS, June 19 (AP) -- Chuck Diering singled to right in the ninth inning, scoring Lou Klein from second with the winning run as the Cardinals defeated the Phillies, 6 to 5 today. Diering earlier slammed out a homer and Stan Musial hit two circuit blows for the Redbirds.

It is good to know that the House Committee on Un-American Activities "does not desire to interfere in any manner with academic freedom, nor does it intend to censor textbooks." A recent letter on committee stationery, sent through the unilateral action of Chairman John S. Wood of Georgia, had created a contrary impression.

The Rev. Shelton Hale Bishop, rector of St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church, 215 West 133rd Street, asserted in his morning sermon yesterday that neurotic personalities could be corrected by self-help, but specified faith in God as the principal ingredient in such a remedy.

Extending its wartime gains, unskilled labor got three-fifths to three-quarters of the wage rates obtained by skilled labor in the United States last year, Prof. Leo Wolman of Columbia said in a progress report on wage studies made public yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 19 (AP) -- Jersey City captured both ends of a double-header from Rochester today, 5 -- 4 and 3 -- 1, before a crowd of 4,216.

NANKING, June 19 -- The official United States Embassy spokesman declared today that Communist charges referring to the United States consulate general in Mukden as an "espionage organ" were "too fantastic for comment."
BUENOS AIRES, June 19 -- Argentine relations with Uruguay remain touchy and are likely to get more rather than less so, in the opinion of the best diplomatic observers.

PARIS, June 19 -- The French Government announced today that the so-called Viet Nam Agreements of March 8 would be published tomorrow in Paris and Saigon. The announcement followed Wednesday's action of Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam, in proclaiming himself head of the new Viet Nam state, with the blessing of France.

ONE hundred and nine years ago today an American traveler was in Yucatan winding up his affairs before departing for his native country. He had spent nearly eight months in Central America on a combined diplomatic and archaeological expedition, which he was soon to make famous in the most popular of his several very popular books.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 19 -- Plagued by everything from vagaries of nature to a depressed market, the lumber industry of the Pacific Northwest is doing some intensive exploring of business-building possibilities. These range from development of lumber processing to striking modernization of the traditional lumber-schooner method of shipment.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UP) -- More than 400 out of 497 recipients of atomic-energy fellowships have signed loyalty oaths ordered following Congressional disclosure that at least three alleged Communists had received the grants, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

The great issue confronting the world, and the long, hard road we must travel before that issue is resolved, have been outlined anew in a statesmanlike speech by Governor Dewey at the Williams College commencement. Mr. Dewey emphasizes what most people begin reluctantly to accept as a political axiom.

Municipal issues scheduled for sale this week aggregate $105,506,180, against $51,848,600 last week. They will be headed by $30,000,000 of State of California veterans' welfare bonds for which bids will be considered tomorrow. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date now stands at $67,138,094, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

Sales of private brand merchandise produced through the National Merchandising Corporation for its 129 member department stores showed a 25 per cent increase during the twelve months ended May 31, it was disclosed here at the week's end.

In a deal involving the remaining unit of its former plant in Brooklyn, A. G. Spalding Bros., Inc., Fifth Avenue sporting goods store, has sold the four-story factory building at the southwest corner of Pacific Street and Sixth Avenue to the Seagoing Uniform Corporation.

Father's Day had a significant note for William A. Brady. The retired dean of theatrical producers reached his eighty-sixth birthday yesterday. Friends commemorated the event by sending telegrams, cards and presents to his home at 510 Park Avenue.

LONDON, June 19 -- For the first Sunday in five weeks, the northern and northeastern sections of England had normal railway services today. The end of the strikes coincided with a new threat by the railway workers of a slow-down if their wage claims were not met.

PARIS, June 19 -- The consequences of this meeting of the Foreign Ministers will be more apparent in the coming months than they are as this session closes. This was true of all preceding conferences and it will be especially true of this, which was primarily exploratory, an attempt to discover the effects of the cold war on East-West relations and plans for the future.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 19 -- Playing 2 strokes under par for sixteen holes, Dr. Ray M. Bowles and John J. Humm, the Long Island amateur champion from Rockville, defeated Tommy Bowles and his guest, Howell Van Gerbig of the Meadow Brook Club, 3 and 2, in the final of the Cherry Valley member-guest golf tournament today.

Planned for the hostess who likes to look picturesque, this summer's at-home costumes will add to the pleasure of entertaining or dining informally whether on penthouse terrace or in a country garden.

The hopeful report of an early truce possibility in Kashmir is a further tribute to the chairman of the United Nations Commission, Dr. Alfredo Lazano of Colombia. Without his having been named specifically as such, Dr. Lazano has become a genuine mediator in this complex and difficult dispute.

A vigorous defense of Harvard University's tradition of academic freedom and a pledge that the tradition would never be dishonored were contained in letters by Dr. James B. Conant, Harvard president, and Grenville Clark, a senior member of the Harvard Corporation, to Frank B. Ober, Baltimore lawyer.

Customs collections in this port, which have been showing a steady monthly decline for more than six months in comparison with the same periods last year, took a surprising upturn during May, according to a report issued by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 19, (UP) -- Following is the text of the pastoral letter that Archbishop Josef Beran requested be read in all Catholic churches in Czechoslovakia today:

HOLLYWOOD, June 19 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has acquired "To Please A. Lady," a screen story by Barre Lyndon and Marge Decker, as a prospective vehicle for Clark Gable and Lana Turner, the studio has announced. The purchase was concluded by Dore Schary, studio production chief, at a reported price of $50,000, before his scheduled departure for New York today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 19 -- More than 400 students from high school and parochial schools throughout New Jersey embarked today on the fourth annual program in citizenship training, sponsored each summer by the State Department of the American Legion.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 19 -- William Munthe de Morgenstierne, the Ambassador from Norway, declared here today that college men and women must take their responsible places to help the world achieve "not a cold peace, but a warm, brotherly peace."

DETROIT, June 19 (AP) -- National open champion Cary Middlecoff and Lloyd Mangrum, who rank among the nation's top money- winning pros of 1949, divided honors in the Motor City open golf tournament today as they played to a tie in an 11-hole "sudden death" play-off.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics split a pair of games with the St. Louis Browns today, winning the opener, 8-2, behind Rookie Alex Kellner's six-hit pitching and dropping the nightcap, 7-3, to Left-hander Joe Ostrowski.

Debt service was paid in full last year on $2,388,769,881, or 54.46 per cent, of the total of $4,386,586,652 of publicly offered foreign dollar bonds outstanding on Dec. 31, 1948, according to an analysis made public over the week-end by Dean G. Rowland Collins, director, and Marcus Nadler, research director, of the Institute of International Finance of New York University.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Veterans Administration soon will formally authorize payment of a special dividend totaling $2,800,000,000 on about 20,000,000 National Service Life Insurance policies.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Some of the beautiful sunshine that drenched Wrigley Field and 42,089 cash customers today must have seeped into the tortured soul of Manager Frankie Frisch, for all those painful Cub losing streaks finally were snapped.

After 10 o'clock at night when the green-shaded lamps in the Central Public Library reading room are snapped off, a weird quiet settles over that cavernous chamber. Passing cars send ghostly light streaking up the high walls and across the great ceiling.
Eugene N. West has been appointed general sales manager of the Lehn Fink division of the Lehn Fink Products Corporation.

VIENNA, June 19 -- That Laszlo Rajk would be arrested and charged with support of a foreign government by the Communist dictators of Hungary has been expected here ever since Marshal Tito fell out with the Communist Information Bureau and Mr. Rajk was relegated from the important post of Minister of the Interior to the meaningless appointment -- in a satellite country -- of Minister of Foreign Affairs.

Seventeen boys and girls who had been at the National Children's Cardiac Home at Miami Beach, Fla., for from fifteen to forty-four months and who have recovered sufficiently from their heart ailments to come home, were greeted on their arrival at Pennsylvania Station at 11:25 A. M. yesterday by Joe DiMaggio, Yankee outfielder and honorary Mayor of "mending hearts village." The children at the Miami Beach institution elected the ballplayer to "office" this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 19 (AP) -- Delegates from the United States, Canada, Alaska and Hawaii gathered here today for the opening of the 34th annual convention of Kiwanis International. Religious services were held tonight.

Cardinal Spellman, addressing 15,000 Catholics on the Fordham University campus yesterday, used sharp language in attacking Representative Graham A. Barden, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Education, whose bill for Federal aid to education would limit use of tax money to public schools.

Any time is a good time to be an inhabitant of a village, but June is the best time of all. The New England village is at its most amiable now; the green wearing its early summer freshness is a bright carpet dappled by clear June sunlight that filters through elm leaves not yet summer-coarsened.

Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, acting national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, in his semi-annual report to its board of directors said yesterday that forty-eight settlements were founded in Israel from January through May of this year with the aid of funds raised by American Jews.

When its flight for Copenhagen, Stockholm and Helsinki takes off from La Guardia Overseas terminal at 9:30 A. M. today, it will be the 18,522d Atlantic flight of American Overseas Airlines and its predecessor, American Export Airlines.
Ten new films, including importations from England, France and Spain, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The charge by James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, that proposed federal spending programs at home could turn the nation into a "welfare state," broke the normal Sunday calm in official Washington.
