The leading tennis professionals of the country with one exception will gather at Forest Hills today for the opening of the national championship at the West Side Tennis Club.
TRENTON, N. J., June 19 (AP) -Myron Fohr of Milwaukee won the 100-mile championship A. A. A. big car race at the New Jersey State Fair Grounds today.

Although Bob Feller was good -- better and stronger, in fact, than they had found him this season -- the Yankees dropped a 4-2 overtime decision to the Indians yesterday principally because the Cleveland outfielders were climbing the Stadium walls in superlative defense of their pitcher.
The American Labor party announced yesterday that it would nominate its own separate candidate for Mayor this fall.

Not brand new but still novel is the quick freezing of cut-up poultry and the sale of drumsticks, chicken breasts and livers in separate packages. Fresh birds sold this way have been so praised it's understandable something similar should be tried with the frozen article.

MONTREAL, June 19 -- In the face of disturbed conditions in many lines of business, office buildings throughout the United States and Canada still are bulging with tenants, according to a survey just completed by the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

Scotland's international soccer players, winding up their North American tour yesterday, before 17,000 at Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island, defeated a picked United States eleven, 4 to 0, in the first game of an international double-header sponsored by the American Soccer League and the United States Football Association.

DETROIT, June 19 -- The United Automobile Workers Union, CIO, said today that it would continue to press for $100-a-month pensions, a medical-care plan and a cost-of-living wage increase from the Ford Motor Company when negotiations are resumed tomorrow.

DARIEN, Conn., June 19 -Lanikia, bay gelding owned and ridden by Miss Patricia Kelley of New Canaan, earned 26 1/2 points to take the Working Hunter championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show which closed today. This was Lanikia's first show of the season.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 19 -- One week from today, Belgium will hold a general election that may provide an answer to the riddle of King Leopold's future. The exiled monarch's supporters expect to win a clear majority.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19 (AP) -- With Americans dominating the field events and the Britishers exceptionally strong in the track competitions, the fifteenth international meet between the combined Oxford-Cambridge and Harvard-Yale forces appears to hinge on the final event tomorrow at the Stadium.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Sears Roebuck Co. prices on its fall and winter merchandise average 6 1/2 per cent lower than those in the current catalogue and 8 per cent under the corresponding 1948 book, T. V. Houser, Sears merchandising vice president, revealed today in announcing that the 1949 fall and winter catalogue is being distributed this week.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 -- The left-wing, pro-administration faction of the CIO United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America captured control of the U. E. District 6 today by election of their full slate of delegates in Local 610, a 7,000-member local.

HONOLULU, June 19 -- Gov. Ingram M. Stainback's Emergency Fact-Finding Board drove ahead today, the fiftieth day of Hawaii's crippling longshore strike, examining a picture of the island stevedore a drawn by union witnesses in a day and a half of testimony.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, June 19 -The open-pit coal mines in the remote mountains of Bosnia that this correspondent has visited illustrate as do all national projects in Yugoslavia the struggle of the regime to pursue an independent course toward socialism in spite of and against the hostility of the Soviet Union and the Communist Information Bureau.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 -- Leo Durocher's finest calculations went right out of a window today as the Giants, cracking under the strain of uncertainty that has hovered over their efforts these recent weeks, blew wide open and allowed the Pirates to win the concluding encounter of the series, 9 to 4.

AMSTERDAM, June 19 -- Serious difficulties in Dutch-Belgian relations seem to have arisen. According to Belgian views. The Netherlands is not doing its utmost to fulfill the obligations required in preparation for economic union.

PITTSBURGH, Monday, June 20 (UP) -- About 450,000 members of the United Mine Workers ended their one-week absence from the pits at midnight. The coal mines, however, are threatened by a new walkout next month.

Citations for outstanding performance by 292 members of the Police Department were listed in general orders issued yesterday by Commissioner William P. O'Brien. The citations covered all cases acted upon by the department's honor committee since Jan. 1.

Before the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court at Rochester today arguments and brief will be presented by the Adirondack League Club against procedure by the Board of the Black River Regulating District on the proposed Panther Mountain reservoir.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 19 -- An article in the Communist organ Szabad Nep indicated today that an early trial of former Foreign Minister and Communist party chieftain Rajk is to be expected.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- While officials of the International Boxing Club were expressing confidence that their first heavyweight championship promotion -- National Boxing Association version -- will attract gate receipts of a quarter of a million, Jersey Joe Walcott, the venerable Camden, N. J., gladiator, and Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati's over-grown light-heavy-weight, entertained holiday crowds at their respective training camps with workouts that left conflicting emotions.

BOSTON, June 19 (AP) -- Ted Williams and Dom DiMaggio each hit three-run homers today, guiding left-hander Chuck Stobbs to his first major league victory and the Red Sox to a 9-2 triumph over the White Sox. A crowd of 20,358 witnessed Boston's fourth consecutive victory over the visitors.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Urging extensive industrial development as the "one sure way" of overcoming the economic lag of the South, the National Planning Association said today that a capital investment of $4,000,000,000 or $5,000,000,000 would be required, in any year comparable to 1948, if that region is to catch up with the rest of the country.

LONDON, June 19 -- Reporting a world-wide demand for British movies, Harold Wilson said today that the British movie industry was moving out of the critical production slump that threatened its existence early this year.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 19 (AP) -Robert Lawrence of New York was chosen director of the Phoenix Symphony Orchestra last night. He succeeds John Barnett, associate conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, who departed in April.

Columbia University's American Press Institute will conduct a week-long seminar on the functions of a free press in a democracy for twenty-two German editors and publishers and two Austrian newspaper men, beginning today. A group of German radio men also will participate in part of the program.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Oats held in a moderate range on the Board of Trade last week, with commission absorption evident on small setbacks, while the cash market was strong, premiums advancing. Except for the fact that oats have headed out short in many areas, the general outlook is good.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 19 (UP) -- A special "terrorism" investigator was flooded with telephone calls today in the wake of Gov. James E. Folsom's request to report any evidence of gangs of night-riders or of threats.

The recent letter of President Eisenhower to Representative Gwinn of New York regarding federal aid to education, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES for June 14, represents the general position of the large, private, heavily endowed colleges and universities on this matter.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 19 -- A $2,250,000 contract for steel to start-the second major unit of the United Nations permanent world capital in Manhattan will be made soon in keeping with the accelerated building schedule for the sky-scraper headquarters.

NEWARK, N. J., June 19 (AP) -- Newark completed its poorest home stay in eighteen years of Yankee ownership today by dropping both ends of a double bill to Montreal -- the fifth straight twin setback -- by 5-3 and 12-0 margins. The Bears made it sixteen defeats in twenty games.

CINCINNATI, June 19 (AP) -- The Braves moved back into third place in the tight National League race today with a double-header victory over the Reds, 5 -- 2 and 3 -- 2. A crowd of 29,401 saw the Braves come up with three runs in the sixth inning to win the opener, before Johnny Antonelli spaced eight Redleg hits to take the nightcap.

Alfredo Salmaggi's second season of outdoor opera at the Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island got off to a good start on Saturday night. No rain interfered, the performance was competent and there was an audience of 3,000, which was larger than the average audience for the operas he presented there last summer.

There are 18,121 assorted satisfactions to be found in child rearing and a mere 7,654 headaches, according to researchers and statisticians at the Horace Mann-Lincoln Institute of School Experimentation at Columbia University's Teachers College.
CHANDERNAGORE, French India, June 19 -- The Chandernagore referendum held today appears to have been a walkover for the Merger-with-India party.
GOTHENBURG, Neb., June 19 (AP) -- The hoofbeats of a thousand horses drummed a tattoo today for a gaudy episode in America's past -- the pony express.

In the second annual "marriage service" conducted yesterday in the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Wadsworth Avenue and 174th Street, the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, pastor, gave some advice to forty of the 600 couples he had married in his twenty-five years at the church.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 19 -- A few hours after he read that he had been named to the United States Walker Cup team again, Willie Turnesa, national amateur champion, today won an uphill match with Dick Mayer of Winged Foot against two celebrated Westchester pros, Claude Harmon, 1948 Masters winner, and Herman Barron, 1948 Goodall winner.
Major Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, asserted last night that the Arab states were responsible for the failure to negotiate a settlement of all issues in dispute.

Two books about William Shakespeare will be issued this summer. Macmillan will bring out on June 28 "By Avon River," by the poet H. D. (Hilda Doolittle). The book consists of two parts -- a poetic tribute, "Good Frend," and an essay on Elizabethan lyrics and lyric writers.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Athens reports to the State Department indicated today that the Greek Army, profiting from Yugoslav Premier Tito's split with the Communist Information Bureau (Cominform), was gaining a definite upper hand for the first time over the Communist-led guerrillas.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market continued last week to show a moderate firming tendency. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 9 to 50 points over the preceding week.

Five hundred persons attended ceremonies yesterday to dedicate Babe Ruth Memorial Field, a park department field at 162nd Street and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, which contains seven baseball diamonds and a quarter-mile track. The site is just north of the Yankee Stadium.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 19 -Calling for courageous self-reliance as "the first condition of security," President Charles Seymour of Yale today advocated development and maintenance of our national strength.
New negotiations seeking to break the deadlock between striking brewery workers and members of the Brewers Board of Trade have been going on for several days, it was disclosed yesterday.

Charles Abrams, author of "The Future of Housing," charged yesterday that statements he made in the book and in a recent newspaper article were distorted by T. H. Maenner, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Paul Robeson, the baritone and Communist sympathizer, told a wildly cheering "welcome home" rally at the Rockland Palace, 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, yesterday afternoon that he "loved" the Soviet people more than those of "any other nation."

PARIS, June 19 -- After the four-power Council of Foreign Ministers had met in secret for three hours tonight, Western officials predicted it would close its Paris session tomorrow by a limited agreement on Berlin and by instructing the deputies to complete an Austrian treaty by Sept. 1.

The nations of the world must jointly seek a remedy for the "deplorable" plight of the Arab and Jewish victims of the recent war in Palestine, the Rev. Dr. John Paul Jones, pastor of the Union Church of Bay Ridge (Presbyterian), 201 Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, said yesterday in his sermon.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -The National Council of the Young Men's Christian Association elected today Eugene R. McCarthy of St. Louis as its president for a third term.

Discussion of labor legislation in the Senate has now headed up into one of the most important and controversial of all the issues involved. Superficially, this is the issue of how Congress ought to deal with so-called "emergency strikes." Basically, however, the issue goes deeper than this.

SHANGHAI, June 19 -- The framework of a new Political Consultative Conference, which will establish "a democratic coalition government" for China, was announced tonight by the official New China News Agency as the five-day session of the new PCC preparatory committee adjourned in Peiping.

Thomas K. Finletter, resigning chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission to Great Britain, declared yesterday that "this is no time to lessen our aid" to Great Britain and Western Europe. Mr. Finletter arrived at La Guardia Airport after thirteen months as ECA head in London.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 19 -- With whistles and catcalls, Communist hecklers shouted down Archbishop Josef Beran's Corpus Christi Day sermon today in St. Vitus Cathedral. Later hecklers, shouting "Long live President Gottwald," and the police broke up a crowd of nearly 7,000 Roman Catholics chanting "Long live the Archbishop."
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -The National Council of the Young Men's Christian Association elected today Eugene R. McCarthy of St. Louis as its president for a third term.

Discussion of labor legislation in the Senate has now headed up into one of the most important and controversial of all the issues involved. Superficially, this is the issue of how Congress ought to deal with so-called "emergency strikes." Basically, however, the issue goes deeper than this.

SHANGHAI, June 19 -- The framework of a new Political Consultative Conference, which will establish "a democratic coalition government" for China, was announced tonight by the official New China News Agency as the five-day session of the new PCC preparatory committee adjourned in Peiping.

Thomas K. Finletter, resigning chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission to Great Britain, declared yesterday that "this is no time to lessen our aid" to Great Britain and Western Europe. Mr. Finletter arrived at La Guardia Airport after thirteen months as ECA head in London.
With Vice President Alben W. Barkley making the principal address, Yeshiva University yesterday closed its Dedication Week with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In the early Twenties, when this writer was doing graduate work at the University of London, the student council announced that it was going to have as its guest a visiting American university professor and monetary expert. The prospects seemed bright for an interesting and educational evening, since the visitor was to discuss Federal Reserve policy during the post-World War I reconversion period, a subject of widespread current interest.

Pride is nowhere "so painfully evident as in the churches of today, the Rev. Karl M. Chworowsky of the Flatbush Unitarian Church, Brooklyn, said yesterday. He preached as guest-pastor at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.
Pastors in the Northeast states made a fervent prayer for rain yesterday as the worst spring drought in forty-one years continued unchecked and additional crops were reported imperiled.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- An argument for the passage of a bill creating twenty-six additional Federal judgeships to relieve clogged dockets has been submitted to the Senate Judiciary Committee by a group of jurists headed by the Chief Justice of the United States.

SOME athletes perform for cash. Others do it for glory. But the most selfless athletes in the entire realm of sports have to be the oarsmen. They are the victims of a shell game of their own choosing. They climb into a lean and fragile shell and they proceed to tear out their hearts, their lungs and -- if you'll pardon the use of the only pungently descriptive word applicable -- their very guts.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 19 -- The better balanced, better mounted Bostwick Field polo team defeated the Meadow Brook quartet, 12 -- 2, in the benefit game for the Nassau County Council of Boy Scouts before a crowd of 6,000 on International Field at the Meadow Brook Club today.

RUMSON, N. J., June 19 -- Champion Sir Thomas of Rumak, English springer spaniel belonging to Mrs. William McKelvy of Pittsburgh, became best in show in the 569-dog Monmouth County Kennel Club event at the Rumson Country Club today.

Buyers in the wholesale apparel market here last week were primarily interested in shopping fall ready-to-wear lines and actual buying, especially in the dress market, so far has been moderate, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- This is the time of year when human nature becomes the major bottleneck in Washington. With the fiscal year ending on June 30, there is no time of the year when Congress is so busy and no time when the conditions of work are less favorable.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- More than 3,000 industrial executives from forty-eight states, Canada, Alaska and foreign countries arrived here today and many more are expected to arrive tomorrow to attend the annual international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from the executive vice president of the Commerce and Industry Association stating more precisely that organization's views on Welfare Department policies. We congratulate the association on taking what seems to us a more moderate and reasonable attitude than was expressed in its weekly bulletin a few days ago, which we criticized in our editorial.
H. C. Taylor's 72-foot yawl, Baruna, maintained the lead as the windjammers neared the halfway point of the 466-mile sailing race from Newport, R. I., to Annapolis, Md., last night.

Many women probably scoffed at their husbands last night if the men babbled wildly about the perils of fishing in Jamaica Bay. The wives must have thought it was just an alibi for the shortage of fish. But the fishermen were telling the truth.

A warning against so-called "service agencies," attorneys and others, claiming that they can obtain special consideration for bidders and contractors in connection with the awarding of contracts by the New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office or in the filing of claims against the Government, was issued for publication today by Brig. Gen. L. O. Grice, commanding the NYQMPO.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- The Corn Market on the Board of Trade was a two-sided proposition last week. Fair commission-house support developed at times, but the buying demand subsided on the rallies and the professional trade was inclined to follow the trend of wheat.

The number of cases on New York's public assistance rolls continued to mount in May, the sixth successive month of increases, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday. Costs a case also were slightly higher, he said, because more families -- as opposed to unattached individuals -- needed help.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Unionists may picket a struck plant even though their picketing may have the effect, incidentally, of an illegal secondary boycott, the National Labor Relations Board held in a ruling announced today.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 19 -- Social security and welfare, education and intergovernmental relations are the principal matters scheduled to be discussed at the forty-first Governors' Conference which opened today with a reception and dinner in the Broadmoor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Republicans in Congress gleefully picked up today the charge by James F. Byrnes that the Truman Administration's spending programs could turn the nation into a "welfare state."

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Lower steel prices within ninety days are expected by twenty-three out of twenty-five members of the committee on steel of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, but in sharp contrast, automobile buyers are placing larger advance orders for automotive steel.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Truman today voiced a second and an urgent appeal for Congressional approval of the Administration's $150,000,000 bill to continue and expand the South Korea recovery program.
Ten persons were injured at 12:49 P. M. yesterday when an elevator in which they were passengers fell two floors in an office building at 347 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- State Department experts on international law expressed an off-hand view today that the Chinese Nationalists' blockade declaration carried all the earmarks of an acknowledgment that war exists in name, as well as in deed.

BUFFALO, N. Y., June 20 (AP) -- Jersey City climbed into second place in the International League race, one game behind the leading Buffalo Bisons, by handing the Herd an 8-4 setback before 8,053 fans tonight.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, began today to outline the economic arguments on which the union relies to break down the resistance of the United States Steel Corporation to any fourth-round wage increases for its 170,000 hourly-rated employes.

Non-anglers may have been surprised by the Census Bureau report the other day showing that the factory value of fishing tackle sold to fishermen in 1947 amounted to approximately $58,700,000, but the fishermen themselves were not.

ROME, June 20 -- Czechoslovak President Klement Gottwald and all other Government and Communist party officials including Josef Plojhar, priest-Minister of Health, responsible for creation of what the Vatican considers a spurious "Catholic Action" in Czechoslovakia, were implicitly excommunicated today by the Roman Catholic Church.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Truman signed the Reorganization bill this morning and immediately sent to Congress seven plans to start the streamlining of the gigantic and sprawling Executive Branch of the Government.

Plans for reorganization and consolidation of Greece's telecommunications systems into a single autonomous company, free of governmental or ministerial control, but subject to governmental regulation as to rates and methods of financing, have been made known by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

From atop the Empire State Building the tall, reddish-tan buildings standing in spectacular array along the East River are an impressive post-war addition to the New York skyline. But to thousands of New Yorkers they're not just scenery. They're home.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 20 -- J. Balmont Mosser of St. Marys, Pa., president of Kiwanis International, today urged representatives of 3,000 Kiwanis clubs to call upon Congress to consider the North Atlantic Security pact at the earliest possible time.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 20 (AP) -- The War Ministry said today that members of a "seditious group" entering the country in two planes had been killed last night by the Navy at Luperon.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES on May 31 there appeared a letter from Stanley Sapery on the theft of his daughter's bicycle by two boys in Central Park. In the course of his letter Mr. Sapery erroneously referred to The Children's Aid Society.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Rebuking it as a group "brought in by Preston Tucker," Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe today denied a petition by a Tucker Corporation's stockholders' protective committee to intervene in the company's reorganization proceedings under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Last Sunday Nebraska revived the Pony Express for a day, not because it couldn't get the mail through in other ways but because a pioneer memory refuses to die. A girl of 19, a boy of 7, a man of 83 were among the riders, which was not the case in 1860 and 1861.
No parents are perfect. They all make mistakes.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 20 -- Saying that we must face the fact that we are engaged in a struggle of indefinite duration with Soviet Russia, Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, former ambassador to Russia, speaking as the personal representative of President Truman, said tonight that three things were necessary if we were to make Europe a bulwark of peace.
LONDON, June 20 -- Business in the stock market here today was confined mainly to leveling up by dealers in preparation for the close of the account tomorrow.

For the second successive year major crime in New York dropped in 1948, the annual report of the Police Department showed yesterday. Felony complaints were 13.7 per cent lower than in 1947 and even misdemeanors were 9.5 per cent below the previous year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 20 -- Rudolph Polk, former music director at Enterprise, and Bernard Luber, formerly of Paramount and now an executive of the Nassour Studios, today announced the formation of a production company to make a series of twenty-six-minute films for television transmission and theatrical and 16-mm. distribution, starring musical and ballet figures.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A wide variety of health bills is being considered on both sides of Capitol Hill, with a fair chance that several of limited scope will be enacted this session.

Twelve anonymous youngsters, students at five Brooklyn settlement houses, will receive one-man shows in a large exhibition of their art work opening tomorrow in two adjoining galleries, the Betty Parsons and the Sidney Janis, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, June 20 -- Official British sources reported today that problems of writing an intra-European payments plan had been "considerably narrowed" since the meeting of the eight-nation steering committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation ended in a deadlock in Paris two weeks ago.

There is enough bounce to delight the heart of any 6-year-old in the new foam rubber upholstered furniture designed by John Gartman which was put on display yesterday at K. J. Sloane's. It is not merely soft and comfortable as rubber-cushioned furniture always is; it actually makes the sitter feel as buoyant as a new tennis ball.

Opposition to the continued operation of the Federal Barge Lines by the Inland Waterways Corporation continues to grow among the private operators of inland waterway craft, and in virtually all ports except New Orleans, it was learned yesterday.

A deal is in the making whereby the National Broadcasting Company will take possession of the Belasco Theatre under a lease from the Shuberts, owners of the legitimate showcase. An NBC spokesman admitted yesterday that negotiations were in progress and that the theatre was "under active consideration."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 20 -- Dr. Charles Seymour, university president, conferred degrees on more than 1,100 seniors in Yale College and the School of Engineering at Yale University's graduation exercises in Woolsey Hall this morning.
ROME, June 20 -- Representatives of the farmhands' unions announced today that Italy's crops would not be harvested unless the five-week-old strike were settled.
ST. LOUIS, June 20 -- Leo Durocher, acting in his infinite wisdom, made what were intended to be a few more masterful strokes tonight, only to wind up in another disaster.
Only an optimist would go offshore for broadbill or white marlin at this season, but this week-end found two optimists successful, much to the surprise of everyone.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, charged today that the cost of a school, built for the Atomic Energy Commission at Hanford, Wash., ran more than $2,000,000 above the original estimate.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- A Protestant organization came to the defense today of Representative Graham A. Barden, Democrat, of North Carolina, for his sponsorship of a federal educational bill which would permit use of funds only by public schools.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrived at Pier 90 North River at 2 P. M yesterday with 1,670 passengers, among them Joseph D. Nunan, lawyer and former Commissioner of Internal Revenue, who has been mentioned as a possible Democratic candidate for Mayor in the forthcoming New York City elections.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld, 5 to 4, a Mississippi tax of 2 per cent on the gross receipts of the Interstate Oil Pipe Line Company's business of transporting crude oil within the state.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 20 -- Abandoning a law career forty years ago, Robert Wesley Amick decided he would rather paint than eat. He has succeeded in doing both, and testimonials to his artistry and philosophy are on the walls of several hundred homes in southern Connecticut.

A group of seven hand-screened wallpapers correlated with the geometrically patterned fabrics designed by Ben Rose are now available through decorators in the city from that designer's own showroom, which opens today at 15 East Fifty-third Street.

PARIS, June 20 -- The calling of a special session of the United Nations General Assembly to deal with international investment and technical aid to underdeveloped countries as suggested by President Truman in his inaugural address was discussed at the World Food Council today when it began a study of that problem.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Ralph S. Damon, president of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., one of the "big four" airlines, told a Senate committee here today that air transportation had better "return to the law of the jungle" than continue on the basis of half-way regulation.

Better Self returned to his winning ways at the Aqueduct race track yesterday. The King Ranch's 4-year-old contributed the fastest time of the Queens County Jockey Club's meeting for the six furlongs in capturing the Bossuet Handicap, a fixture in which he was third choice to the Gustave Ring entry of Respingo and Eagle Eye, and William Helis' Rippey.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 20 (AP) -- Senator Jack Tenney of Los Angeles, a militant foe of communism, quit the State Senate Committee on Un-American Activities today. He had been on the committee eleven years, the last nine as chairman.
With summer scheduled to begin at 2:03 P. M. today, this area's worst drought in forty-one years continued unabated yesterday with no signs of rain.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Congress approved and sent to President Truman today a $671,000,000 money bill carrying funds for work on the White House.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today ruled that the Federal Power Commission has no control over the way a natural gas company disposes of its gas reserves.

The New York Central Railroad yesterday, before Public Service Commissioner George A. Arkwright, began presenting its case for sweeping increases in commutation fares within New York State affecting more than 30,000 commuters or more than 42 per cent of the line's total passenger traffic on the Hudson, Putnam and Harlem divisions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 20 -- Three meet records were broken, two by the visitors, as the combined Oxford-Cambridge squad defeated Yale-Harvard, eight first places to five, in the fifteenth dual meet between the English and American universities at Harvard Stadium today.

Cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange climbed into new high ground yesterday. Prices advanced 10 to 27 points, with the July delivery up more than 1 1/2 cents a pound from the season's lows. Scattered buying and covering, coupled with strength in actual oils in the South and higher lard in the West aided the advance.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 20 -- Moshe Sharett, Israeli Foreign Minister, told the Knesset [Assembly] tonight that he had advised the Lausanne delegates to advocate a plebiscite in Arab Palestine to determine whether the inhabitants desired a separate state or annexation to Jordan.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Passage by the Housing of a "satisfactory" low-rent housing bill this week was predicted today by Sam Rayburn, the Speaker, after a White House meeting of President Truman with Congressional leaders.

PRAGUE, Czechoslavakia, June 20 -- The state and church reacted today to yesterday's incident in St. Vitus Cathedral and to the reading of Archbishop Beran's pastoral letter in defiance of police orders.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20 -- Several thousand Iraqi troops are camped today in Jordan, within less than two hours' drive of the Syrian frontier, in addition to those reported on Iraq's own frontier with Syria. Though there is no indication of aggressive intentions, this correspondent has just seen them personally in camps strung along the highway south of Mafraq, principally around Zerqa.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Red Sox won their fifth consecutive game tonight -- a new high for the season -- by whipping the second-place Detroit Tigers, 6 -- 1, before 33,710 fans. The victory was credited to Walt Masterson, who was forced to leave the game after pitching six and two-thirds innings because of a sore elbow.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, June 21 -- Press reports originating here that the Yangtze River mouth had been mined on June 9 were branded this morning as an "imperialist rumor-offensive" designed to impede the city's recovery by the Liberation Daily, official newspaper of the Communist party.

LITTLE WOLMI ISLAND, Korea, June 20 -- Huddled in sagging tents with little water or food, 539 Chinese refugees from Tsingtao and Chefoo in China's Shantung Province are waiting on this desolate island in Inchon Harbor for Korean Government and Chinese Nationalist officials to determine how to help them in their flight from the Communists.
BERLIN, June 20 -- The decisions of the Council of Foreign Ministers on Germany evoked no enthusiasm either in German or Western Allied quarters in Berlin tonight.

TOKYO, June 20 -- The Chinese Communist army, equipped with fresh recordings of Japanese popular music and its own version of the recent war's "Tokyo Rose," began today to "broadcast" to the people of Japan, but the initial effort was considerably less than a smash hit.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 7 to 45 points net higher on the day, with the distant months showing the most strength.

OTTAWA, June 20 -- Further verification of the extremely high temperatures believed to exist in the atmosphere of the sun was presented here today by Dr. R. N. Thomas of Princeton University Observatory.

PARIS, June 20 -- The Foreign Ministers Council session ended tonight in a fantastic anti-climax when, ninety minutes after its adjournment, Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky asked for another meeting immediately and the withdrawal of the formal communique that had just been issued.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- Eddie Stanky doubled and Elbie Fletcher drove him home with a single in the ninth inning to give the Braves a 3-2 victory over the Cubs today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Cash refunds totaling $2,800,000,000 will begin about next January to some 16,000,000 World War II veterans who took out GI life insurance policies, it was formally announced today by Carl R. Gray Jr., Veterans Administrator.

Something new was added when the thirty-second annual series of summer concerts opened at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. Besides the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, a distinguished conductor and soloist, some fine music and a responsive audience of more than 16,000, there was a permanent stage which, at long last, gives these concerts a background worthy of their importance.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 20 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights ended its fifth session here tonight after six weeks spent in drafting the future covenant on human rights and considering ways of guaranteeing the freedoms to all peoples laid down in this document.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 20 -- Congregational churches were urged today to "purge themselves from over-absorption with ecclesiastical mechanics and decision by expediency," by the Rev. Henry David Gray of South Pasadena, Calif.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 20 (AP) -- Clarke Stallworth, a reporter for the Birmingham Post, said he was attacked today while he was on an assignment to investigate activities of hooded and robed mobs. The attack, he stated, was by two men at a filling station-general store in the near-by mining community of Sumiton. He was not hurt seriously.

PARIS, June 20 -- As soon as the Austrian peace treaty is finally concluded the Vienna Government intends to press immediately for membership in the United Nations and is prepared to offer pacts of friendship to all neighboring states.

The Reorganization Act of 1949 got through Congress last Thursday, after some squabbling as to whether a one-House veto or a two-House veto would be required to suppress any action the President might take under it. Yesterday seven messages, proposing as many administrative changes, went from the White House to Capitol Hill.

A hot and bothered Congress, its collective eye set hopefully on adjournment barely six weeks from now, is being constantly reminded of matters which are imperatively in need of attention before that day is reached. However long or short this list of not-to-be-neglected issues, we trust that it will include favorable action on a bill to create twenty-four additional federal judgeships to relieve clogged dockets in the courts.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 20 -- Mrs. John Bartol of the Greenwich Country Club, Westchester open champion, won qualifying honors in the women's fifth annual tri-county championship with a two over par 38, 38 -- 76 at the Innis Arden Club here today.

Today's scheduled auction sale of $30,000,000 of California veterans' welfare bonds represents the largest offering of such obligations in the twenty-eight-year history of the state's low-cost farm and home purchase plan. The largest previous sale took place last October when State Treasurer Charles G. Johnson knocked down $25,000,000 of bonds to a fifty-eight-firm syndicate at an interest cost of 1.827 per cent.

ALBANY, June 20 -- Appointments are to be announced later this month to a legislative committee on reapportionment which will have as one of its principal tasks the assignment of making certain that too many of New York's incumbent members of Congress, State Senators and Assemblymen are not unseated as a result of the 1950 census.

Your article on the so-called powers of the water-diviner and his little twig impressed me immensely. Permit me to express my feminine opinion, and I don't mean to interfere with the diviner's divine profession. It takes less than doctors, scientists, engineers to define this mythical power; since I happen to be a farmer's daughter, I am well acquainted with such divinity, for my family had used many such twigs for such a find.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Recent attacks and repulses in the arena of American politics serve further to illuminate the great and abiding truth that professional politics is the most conservative of all trades. The same words continue to be used as the same weapons, and the tactics remain basically the same.
BATAVIA, Java, June 20 -- It was reported on high authority today that definite progress had been made in a series of meetings here toward achieving a solution of the Indonesian problem.

ESTES PARK, Col., June 20 -- There are indications of promise for the future in educational cooperation between East and West, even though some specific avenues of approach are less feasible now than they were a year or two years ago, Dr. A. Burns Chalmers of the American Friends Service Committee, Philadelphia, declared here today.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 20 -- Rabbi David Aronson, president of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, opening the assembly's annual convention here, proposed the formation of a new branch of the Zionist movement when would represent America's 500,000 conservative Jews.

Return to the United States of Thomas K. Finletter, for thirteen months chief of the ECA mission to Great Britain, marks the close of one more chapter of public service in a distinguished career. A corporation lawyer of liberal views and broad horizons, Mr. Finletter is a living example of good citizenship.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 20 (UP) -- Soviet Ambassador Anatole Lavrentiev has returned to his post here after an absence of four months and observers linked his return with reports that the countries adhering to the Communist Information Bureau were about to break diplomatic relation with Yugoslavia in an attempt to unseat Marshal Tito.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 20 -- In his first public statement on the current unemployment problem and its effects on welfare in New York State, Robert T. Lansdale, State Commissioner of Public Welfare, warned today against any work relief program based on that used during the depression of the Thirties.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Eddie Waitkus, wounded first baseman of the Philadelphia National League team, probably will leave the Illinois Masonic Hospital in a week or ten days if no complications develop, according to Dr. L. L. Braun, Physician of the Chicago Cubs, his old team.

CANTON, China, June 20 -- The Chinese Nationalist Foreign Office tonight officially notified foreign envoys that a blockade was being declared against all ports under Communist control, effective next Sunday.

VIENNA, June 20 -- News that the foreign ministers of the great powers had agreed to give Austria a peace treaty was received with joy by the Austrian Government, which remembering past disappointments had hitherto refused to comment on hopeful news from Paris.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- Right-hander Dick Fowler recorded his fifth straight pitching victory with a four-hit job tonight as the Athletics defeated the Cleveland Indians, 4 -- 1, to increase their third-place edge over the world champions to two games.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, threatened again yesterday to call a strike on the Third Avenue System for July 1. As recently as May 8 a walk-out on these lines was averted after long negotiations.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 20 -- An official Israeli spokesman said today that there had been "no snipping and no incident" along the Israeli-Jordanian front, and that the substitution of civilian police for soldiers in the disputed neutral area around the Government House in Jerusalem had been made by "mutual agreement."
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina jailed Gilbert Green, Illinois chairman of the Communist party, yesterday for the rest of the Communist trial.

MONTREAL, June 20 -- Reflecting the financial plight of nations and the difficulty of providing dollars, economy-minded representatives to the third assembly of the International Civil Aviation Assembly, which concluded here today, cut back the 1950 budget to its 1949 level.
The opening round of play in the National professional tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday was marked by the usual uneventful procession for the logical winners.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 20 -- Kennecott Copper Coropration today completed negotiations with Anglo-Transvaal Consolidated Investment Company, Ltd., by which the former will participate in the development of a gold mining lease area in Orange Free State under control of Middle Witwatersrand (Western Areas) Ltd.

Preserving human freedoms is the issue of today, Harold L. Cross, associate dean of Columbia University's School of Journalism, told a group of German editors, publishers and radio men and two Austrian newspaper workers yesterday morning at the opening session of a week-long seminar of the American Press Institute.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 20 -- Harry A. Pine of Newark was re-elected president at the closing session of the annual convention of B'nai Zion, Zionist fraternal organization, here today.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 20 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, told the quarterly meeting of city and county health officers today that there had been a marked decline in the New York State death rate since 1940, especially among mothers and infants and from tubeculosis.

MOSCOW, June 20 -- Broadway is dead as the cradle of American theatrical art, and is now dominated by commercial "hash" designed to deprive man of ideals, disintegrate his will, and educate traitors and renegades who will be faithful servants of Wall Street imperialists.

PEARL HARBOR, June 20 -- Despite the seven-week-old longshore strike that virtually severed the supply line of Hawaii's half-million civilians, the armed services have had no interruption in their supplies, a circumstance which is a sore point among some islanders.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York has made a final decision to resign by July 8, highly informed sources said here today. The decision, making possible the election of a successor this fall, was prompted, it was stated, by a desire to remove a possible impediment to the political aspirations of his son, Robert F. Wagner Jr., an avowed candidate for the Democratic Mayoralty nomination in New York.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the Jersey Central to submit to its security holders, except the Reading Company, a plan for modification of its outstanding securities.

WHEN Jim Jeffries retired as undefeated heavyweight champion of the world in March of 1905, it took Tommy Burns more than three years to gain a reluctant sort of recognition as his successor. The diehards even refused him that much acclaim and stubbornly withheld it as well from his conqueror, Jack Johnson, until the Negro giant lured a hog-fat Jeff into the ring and slaughtered him.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The United States may sue itself, the Supreme Court ruled today in a 6-to-3 decision in which it held that the Government, as a shipper, could challenge in the Federal courts an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

In your "Letters to The Times," on June 11, you printed a letter written by J. Anthony Marcus, president, Institute of Foreign Trade. This letter expresses disagreement with some of the remarks of Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith in an address before the New York State Chamber of Commerce.

An intensive course in investment salesmanship will be sponsored this fall by the Investment Association of New York, it was announced yesterday by Stanley A. Russell Jr. of Blyth Co., president of the association. The course opens on Sept. 15.
" JESSE JAMES was a lad that killed many a man;
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 20 -- Rutgers University, emptied of its regular students a week ago, was enlivened today by a new student body of 995 bankers.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Sparring four rounds against four camp mates, Ezzard Charles; Cincinnati heavyweight, today concluded training for his scheduled fifteen-round bout at Comiskey Park Wednesday night with the aging Jersey Joe Walcott for recognition as the National Boxing Association's world heavyweight champion.

The corset and brassiere market week has drawn a very large attendance of buyers to New York, according to manufacturers showing their new lines. Business on fill-in orders has been very brisk, they said, and prospects for advance orders appear to be excellent on the basis of numbers taken for later confirmation.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 20 -- Modifying his original proposal for a United Nations guard of 800 men, Secretary Trygve Lie today recommended the establishment of a United Nations field service of 300 men, to be supplemented by a field reserve panel of 2,000.
LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- The tennis set at fashionable Wimbledon was buzzing today about the panties with the lace fringe.

ALBANY, June 20 -- Don L. Stevens, assistant vice president of the New York Telephone Company, outlined to the Public Service Commission at a resumed rate hearing today benefits which he said would accrue to subscribers under the company's proposed New York metropolitan-service plan for New York City, Southern Westchester and most of Nassau County.

Communists are dangerous in this country "not because of what they do but because of what they persuade us to do to ourselves," Arthur Garfield Hays, general counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union, declared yesterday. He spoke before nearly 100 delegates at the Summer Rabbinical Institute of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion at 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, said today it was "high time" that commercial loans by insurance companies "be scrutinized so that the public may know about them."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- For the second time in as many weeks the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld the House Committee on un-American Activities in cases challenging its investigation methods.

The Flatbush Chamber of Commerce called yesterday on Mayor O'Dwyer to take action to end illegal all-night street parking in Brooklyn because it was a fire hazard, contributed to hoodlumism and hindered motorists with legitimate reason to park.

Barbecuing, which originally meant, roasting a side of beef over an open fire, has been scaled downward. Today the meat is usually in smaller pieces and cooked outdoors over a metal grill or indoors on top of the stove, in the broiler or oven.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 20 (AP) -- The Government acknowledged officially for the first time today the existence of an underground that reportedly has tortured and killed supporters of the Communist-controlled regime.

The state commanders of the Jewish War Veterans and the Catholic War Veterans joined yesterday to denounce what they described as an "ill-tempered attack" by T. H. Maenner, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, on President Truman for his support of the national housing bill.

The Dow Chemical Company had a net income of $22,074,133 after taxes, loss from property abandonment of $2,318,380 and other charges, in the ten months ended on March 31, according to figures filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The stock market moved forcefully to the higher side yesterday as buying in the last hour gave the list its second best rally of the month. With quotations raised fractions to 3 points, the composite rate showed a gain of 1.25 points on the day.

On Aug. 8, 1876, in Reno, Nev., a boy was born to two sturdy immigrants from Ireland, the father from Londonderry, the mother from Cork. The boy was named Patrick Anthony McCarran, and he is now chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee and of a subcommittee that handles immigration.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Sharp words heard in the Supreme Court served again today to emphasize the continuing clash between the "liberal" and "conservative" factions of the bench.

Arab nations are using the misery of Arab refugees as a political pawn and are planning to renew the war against Israel "at the earliest opportunity," Arthur Lurie, Israeli Consul General in New York, charged last night.

" The expected has happened," notes Lewis L. Nettleton in his weekly financial report to this newspaper from London. "With a kind of morbid satisfaction the stock markets here have seen the industrial share index break through its post-war low just because it had been predicted freely that it would."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 20 -- Yale won its 100th baseball victory from Harvard today in an ivy-steeped rivalry which began back in 1868, thus preventing the Cantabs from gaining a tie with Princeton for the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship.

Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the State University of New York, will speak at the fifth annual commencement exercises of the Fashion Institute of Technology and Design tonight at the institute auditorium, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

Up to the present time I have hesitated to express the serious doubts I have felt about the view that no one who is known to be a member of the Communist party should be permitted to teach in any higher institution of learning.

Complete overhaul to provide uniformity between laws covering chattel mortgages and conditional sales contracts in this state is "vitally necessary," according to a novel handbook for banks and other interested institutions issued here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The White Sox snapped their five-game losing streak tonight, edging Washington, 5 -- 4, behind the seven-hit pitching of Bob Kuzava. Luke Appling of Chicago was thumbed from the game for the third time in his lengthy career when he protested a called third strike by Umpire Bill Summers in the seventh inning.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Judith Coplon testified at her trial for espionage today that she was "struck dumb with fear and terror" when Valentine A. Gubitchev, her admirer, hinted that the Soviet secret police might be on their trail.

Directors of Textron Incorporated elected yesterday an executive committee composed of Royal Little, chairman; J. Linzee Weld, vice chairman, and E. A. Kingman and Harold C. Whitman, directors. In furtherance of the organization's decentralization plans, Mr. Little, president, also announced the election of Mr. Weld as treasurer with offices in Providence, R. I.

The Swift booklet on barbecuing, mentioned in today's column, also contains a chart telling how long meats may be kept at 36 to 38 degrees Fahrenheit (household refrigerator) without losing top flavor. Referring to uncooked meats, the list is as follows:

DETROIT, June 20 -- New concepts of party character and organization are undergoing tests by Republicans and Democrats in Michigan that may make the 1950 elections in the Wolverine State the most meaningful in the recent history of either party.

LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder of La Crescenta, Calif., justified his favorite's role in the Wimbledon tennis tournament today by grinding out a five-set victory over Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla.

Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday he would be "sorry" to see an important agreement reached with the Soviet Union at this time because it would serve only to mislead those willing to "trust a nation which does its business in the dark."

TOKYO, June 20 (UP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur told the Japanese today that the Soviet Government had been "extremely slow" in repatriating Japanese prisoners of war. The charge came a few hours after the Russians had announced repatriation would resume June 25.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, will support a "bipartisan" amendment now being prepared to one of the pending labor relations measures in the Senate providing solely for the use of injunctions in labor disputes affecting national health and safety.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 20 (AP) -- H. C. Taylor's Baruna held a five-mile lead tonight as forty racing yachts neared Chesapeake Bay in their Newport (R. I.)-Annapolis sailing contest.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 12 per cent last week as compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 11 per cent.

Ted Collins has turned down all offers from television stations to report the games of his New York Bulldogs, who compete in the National Football League, it was revealed yesterday. He said that he saw no reason for altering his opinion that television detracted from the paid attendance.

The short interest in stocks dealt in on the New York Stock Exchange declined to 1,609,802 shares on June 15 from 1,629,551 shares on May 13, the Exchange announced yesterday. The latter figure was the highest in sixteen years.
Continued support of the Home Advisory Council of the Home Term Court was urged yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer, who declared that the court had justified itself in its three years of existence.

Fusion leaders have been informed that District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York County would be willing to run as their nominee for Mayor if the Democratic party should name a straight organization candidate of the type of Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn.

Sixty-five Salvation Army cadets, the largest class of trainees since the war, pledged their lives to Christian service yesterday afternoon in a dedicatory ceremony in the Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The No. 1 problem of every American business is that of finding the right prices to put on products at this time, Clinton W. Bennett, national president, the National Association of Cost Accountants, declared here. He addressed the opening session of the thirtieth annual international cost conference at the Palmer House.
Mrs. Mary J. Davison started the second year of her second century last night by puffing out eleven candles on a white-iced birthday cake.

The 24,000-ton liner Chusan, which is being constructed at the Barrows-in-Furness yard of Vickers-Armstrong, Ltd. in Scotland for the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, will be launched next Tuesday, according to the Cunard White Star Line, general agents in this country for the company.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Republican minority members of the House Committee on Un-American Activities disassociated themselves "emphatically" from the projected search for Communist influence on school textbooks today, and called on the committee to drop the matter.

Clarence Jackson, 35-year-old Negro fugitive from the Ben Hill Prison Camp near Atlanta, Ga., lost his fight to prevent his return to prison yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer ordered him sent back to Georgia on the ground that he failed to prove his charges of having received "cruel or inhuman punishment."

LONDON, June 20 -- As a result of population trends Britain is in danger of a decline in her productive power and military potential and the innate intelligence of her people, the Royal Commission on Population reported today at the end of a five-year study.

WASHINGTON, June 20, -- The reaction in Washington to the slight rise in the fortunes of the Big Four Foreign Ministers Council in Paris is not unlike the response here last month to the sudden and surprising rise of the Washington baseball team.

Ticket brokers will try to test the legal right of Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh to inquire into their business. This was learned last night after a broker had refused to produce records sought by the commissioner.

A suggestion that the State Department urge Brazil to establish an "orderly and more realistic" system for liquidating back-logged and future dollar credits due American exporters was agreed on yesterday by members of the Commerce and Industry Association's foreign trade committee.

Urging that business continue to "spend for profits," James Hill Jr., president of Sterling Drug, Inc., declared yesterday that advertising "is probably the most important of all means" for achieving this purpose. Mr. Hill's statement followed three days of meetings by company committees. "
PARIS, June 20 (AP) -- Text of the communique issued by the Big Four Foreign Ministers:

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) -- Russ Meyer scattered seven hits tonight as he pitched the Philadelphia Phillies to a 7-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. The Pirates' lone run came as Ralph Kiner smashed his fifteenth homer in the sixth. A crowd of 30,066 saw the game.

Stores are continuing to modernize, but on a slightly lesser scale than in 1948, according to manufacturers exhibiting at the third annual Store Modernization Show now being held at Grand Central Palace.

Two young men, whose 16-foot overturned in a gust a mile off Coney Island, were rescued yesterday afternoon by a Police Department helicopter, with the aid of a department launch that was not affected by the problem of taking off with excess weight.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., June 20 (AP) -- Four seeded players, including Miss Betty Rosenquest of South Orange, the East's top rated woman star, breezed through their matches today as the New Jersey State Women's Tennis Championship opened at the Maplewood Country Club.

A sedan pulling a trailer, with a dying man at the wheel, jumped the curb at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street at 12:40 P. M. yesterday, narrowly missed scores of shoppers and crashed into the window of the I. Miller Sons shoe store.
Because just one more light in Times Square would be meaningless, the Police Department has deliberately fashioned a "weird" traffic signal to further the safety of out-of-town visitors.

Fred Sanford pitched the Yankees to a 4-1 victory over the last-place Browns before 28,443 fans at the Stadium last night. On the whole, it was a satisfactory performance by the righthander, for whom the Yankees last winter paid $100,000 to the St. Louis club.
NEWPORT, R. I., June 20 (AP) -- Round two opened today in the latest battle between the Van Rensselaers of Newport and the Sullivans of this summer society capital.

The downward trend in retail prices may continue for another six to twelve months and it now appears that department store sales will continue downward for the balance of the year, Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., told approximately 600 retailers here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Registration statements covering 408,573 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by five companies.

Thirty-two thousand persons obtained application forms for apartments in two Bronx projects of the New York City Housing Authority yesterday. Expected to be opened in September, the houses will accommodate 2,140 families at rents ranging from about $16.60 to $22 a room a month, including gas and electricity.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Supreme Court decided unanimously today that a new collective bargaining contract could take precedence over a veteran's peacetime seniority under the GI Bill of Rights.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The discovery of the solar system's thirtieth moon was confirmed today by Dr. Gerard P. Kuiper, University of Chicago astronomer. He revealed that the new satellite was 3,000,000,000 miles from the earth and 5,000,000 miles from its planet, Neptune, which it circles once every two years.

A princess lost her title when naturalization proceedings for 228 persons took place yesterday morning at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 70 Columbus Avenue. Federal Judge Murray Hulbert administered the oath of naturalization and distributed a pamphlet he had prepared as "supplemental" to the ceremony, "to make you better Americans."
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -The text of President Truman's message to Congress today, outlining briefly seven reorganization plans which he proposes to put into effect, follows:

Dr. Philip C. Jessup, United States Ambassador-at-Large, testified by deposition yesterday as a character witness for Alger Hiss, whose defense against a two-count Federal perjury indictment opened in Federal court.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Threshing returns in Kansas, Texas and Oklahoma are reported running well below general expectations, resulting in trade reports today that the aggregate winter wheat harvest for the country might turn out to be 100,000,000 bushels or more below the June 1 indication.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 20 (AP) -- A bad start turned into a good ending today for national amateur champion Grace Lenczyk as she shot a nine under par 66 to win medal honors in the twentieth annual Western women's open golf tournament.

New issues of public utility company bonds and stocks valued at more than $55,000,000 are to be offered to investors today by underwriting syndicates following their purchase yesterday in competitive bidding transactions. The offerings are as follows:

MILWAUKEE, June 20, (UP) -Milton Babich, 19, was convicted of first degree murder and sentenced to life in prison tonight for killing Patricia Birmingham, 16, because she gossiped about the illicit pregnancy of her older sister.

" This Is Germany," a collection of articles by twenty on-the-scene correspondents, has been scheduled for publication early next year by William Sloane Associates. The book was edited by Arthur Settel, deputy director of the American Military Government Public Information Office in Frankfort.

Continental Motors Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries, reflecting declining sales, showed net earnings of $698,171, equal to 21 cents a share, in the quarter ended on April 30, the report showed yesterday. This compares with $621,243, or 19 cents a share, earned in the previous quarter and $1,025,303, or 34 cents a share for the April quarter a year ago.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., June 21 -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, renewed tonight his attack on Governor Dewey's Republican administration for its failure to provide more state funds for local school construction. He indicated that state assistance to education would be a major issue in next year's state campaign.

BERLIN, June 21 -- The City Assembly of Berlin today demanded that the Western sectors of the city be admitted as the twelfth Land or state in the German federal republic and in a bold move to achieve a place in the latter ordered the city government to prepare for elections on Aug. 14 for the Bundestag or federal parliament.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 21 -- The question of whether the Governors' Conference will adopt a resolution recommending a cut of 20 per cent in Federal grants-in-aid to the states and that the National Government will withdraw from certain fields of taxation was the principal subject of today's session.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 -- Perseverance, a lusty three-base clout by Willard Marshall and twelve innings of stout-hearted pitching by Dave Koslo finally triumphed for the Giants tonight as they toppled the Cardinals, 6 to 5, in the second game of the current series.

Another light tackle record was established at Cat Cay when Dr. Guy R. Stoddard of Miami brought in a 435-pound tuna on 15-thread line, topping the recent 15-thread mark set by a California angler fishing the same area.

On June 2 you published a letter on "Laymen and Psychiatry" by June Bingham, a layman, which stated that "just because the tools of their profession (psychiatry) must be used with precision on the sick doesn't mean that in our laymen's untrained hands these same tools aren't also of value in understanding ourselves and our children."

The National Maritime Union, CIO, announced yesterday that its locals in twenty East and Gulf Coast ports had approved "almost unanimously" its new two-year contract agreement with shipping companies reached here last week after two months of negotiation.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Former President Herbert Hoover complimented President Truman today for taking quick advantage of the reorganization powers voted to him by Congress. He then admonished Congress that it must pass "at least fifteen other major legislative acts" to effect major economy in government.

The two-story, twenty-four-family, garden-type apartment house at the southeast corner of Tenafly Road and Ivy Lane, Englewood, N. J., which was built a year ago on an acre of land, has been sold by the Charles Towne Gardens, Inc., to the Tenafly Ivy Corporation for investment.

The town of Apollo, Pa., which has been in danger of becoming a "ghost town" because of the recent closing of its industrial keystone, the Phoenix-Apollo Steel Company, has been spared that fate -- temporarily, at least.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 21 -- Delegates to the Sixth International Council of Congregational Churches were told today that "unevangelized" areas now constituted a greater task for the church than confronted their forefathers. They were told that the world's birth rate had "greatly outstripped" the church's rate of conversion.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 21 (AP) -- Track and field stars representing the Big Ten defeated a picked squad of the Pacific Coast Conference, 70 to 62, tonight in the ninth dual meet between the two college athletic circuits.

ROME, June 21 -- The Italian Cabinet today issued a reassuring report on the state of Italy's wheat crop, which, according to agricultural experts, is on the verge of being seriously affected in some region by the farmhands' strike, and also discussed ways and means to settle the strike of seamen, which has immobilized all Italian ships, including the liner Saturnia, in Genoa harbor.

Transfer of $10,000,000 from undivided profits to the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company's surplus was voted yesterday by the bank's board of trustees. As a result, surplus now amounts to $90,000,000 and undivided profits are in excess of $20,000,000. Capital is unchanged at $21,000,000.

Broadcasts of the Lewisohn Stadium Concerts will be available two evenings a week this season instead of one because of coverage to be given by CBS. The Columbia network will pick up six concerts during the series every Wednesday night from 9 to 10:30 o'clock, starting July 6 and running through Aug. 10.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's statement today on the conclusion of the Foreign Minister's conference in Paris:
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Sid Hudson checked the White Sox with four hits tonight to capture his fifth victory as Washington won, 9 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- An unspecified amount of uranium 235, vital atomic bomb component, was officially disclosed today to be un-accounted for at the atomic energy installation in Oak Ridge, Tenn.

The South may gain more from the passage of the housing bill now before the House than any other region of the nation, and its representatives hold the key to its program in the Eighty-first Congress. Out of 435 members of the House, eighty-four come from the Southern states of Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee and Georgia.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 21 (AP) -- Miss Pat Devany, 20-year-old Grosse Ile, Mich., star, rallied on the last four holes to defeat Miss Peggy Kirk of Findlay, Ohio, 1 up, in the first round of the women's Western Open golf tournament today.
LONDON, June 21 (AP) -- Graham Greene, British author, said today the Bank of England refused to help him earn dollars in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- United States imports from Latin America rose in 1948 to a record-high dollar value of $2,508,000,000, topping 1947 by 10 per cent, the Department of Commerce said tonight.

A jury in Municipal Court, Brooklyn, returned yesterday a verdict in favor of the city in a damage suit that was the first of 137 claims brought by residents of the Marine Park area of Brooklyn over land-fill operations in the section.

PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- Negotiators representing the United States Steel Corporation were in the anomalous position today of spending most of the time listening to discussion of the merits of an issue that the company contended was not properly subject to discussion at all.
New York's costly eighty-two-day-old brewery strike really came to an end last night after the false peace of a week ago.

BERLIN, June 21 -- The three Western powers today urged leaders of UGO, railroad workers' union, to accept terms offered to Western Berlin's strikers by the state railroad directorate of the Soviet zone and end the month-old strike that has imposed a "little blockade" upon this city.

NEWARK, N. J., June 21 -- The brief message from the National Airlines office in Key West, Fla., that clicked out on the teletype machine Saturday afternoon at the airline's operations office here was strictly routine. It referred to facilitating transportation from the Washington airport for Antonio Mujica, 4-year-old daughter of Onelio Mujica, World War II veteran, who is a civilian employe at the naval ammunition dump in Key West, Fla. It read:
SAN JUAN, P. R., June 21 (UP) -- An official investigation opened today into the crash of a Strato-freight C46 plane in which fifty-three persons were killed two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A three-pronged investigation was ordered today after a report that a wartime lieutenant colonel got a $1,000 fee as a down payment on work he said he would do helping a client get a Government contract.

PARIS, June 21 -- The World Food Council today decided to create a special working party of the council to draw up a statement of its views on the expanded program of technical assistance to underdeveloped countries in accordance with President Truman's "Point Four" proposal.

CINCINNATI, June 21 -- Rain almost washed out the opening engagement of a series between the Dodgers and Reds under the Crosley Field lights tonight, and before the game had ended the Reds wished the early downpour never had ceased.

The State Department of Labor said yesterday that 506,613 workers filed claims last week for state unemployment benefits. This represented a decrease of 28,962 from the previous week, when a record 535,575 persons sought job insurance and veterans' adjustment allowances.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP) -- Elmer Valo's fifth-inning grand-slam homer was the telling wallop as the Athletics beat the Indians tonight for the seventh time this season, 8 -- 2, Philadelphia advanced to second place in the American League, four games behind the leading Yankees and half a length ahead of the Tigers.

As defense attorneys for Alger Hiss prepared yesterday to resume their fight this morning for his acquittal of a two-count Federal perjury charge, a resume of the case indicated that its result would turn on the jury's judgment of the veracity of Mr. Hiss and his chief accuser, Whittaker Chambers.

Gilbert Green, Illinois chairman of the Communist party, insisted in his testimony at the Communist trial yesterday that clauses in the party's 1945 constitution upholding American democracy should be taken at face value.
LONDON, June 21 (AP) -- Britain has ordered a warship at the mouth of the Yangtze River in China "to intervene to protect British shipping there from interference."

Earnings of the Allied Stores Corporation for the remainder of this fiscal year which ends on Jan. 31, 1950, will run about $250,000 below the monthly level of the 1948 fiscal year, provided sales continue at their present rate of 5 to 6 per cent below last year's figures, B. Earl Puckett, president of the corporation, said at the annual meeting here yesterday.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 21 -- Gov. Fuller Warren, who will be married on Sunday, today pawned his 1948 Cadillac sedan for $3,000.

Negotiations have been completed for a new contract between the Todd Shipyards Corporation and the International Unions and Metal Trades Councils, AFL, covering two of the company's three West Coast shipyards, it was made known here yesterday by John D. Reilly, president of the corporation.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 21 -- Yugoslavia has given informal but definite assurances to the United States and the United Kingdom that she has ceased to give any form of military assistance to the Communist-led rebels in Greece.

Although Senator Robert F. Wagner has been a total absentee from Washington, owing to illness, for two years and had only a part-time record of attendance for four years prior to that, leaders of neither major political party were anxious yesterday for the Senator to resign in time for a special election this fall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- Paramount and the management of the combined Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus have reached an agreement on a deal for Cecil B. de Mille to produce a Paramount film under the title "The Greatest Show on Earth," dealing with the circus, the studio announced today.

A group of about 125 members of the Harlem Trade Union Council and the Brooklyn Citizens Committee to End Discrimination on the Waterfront continued yesterday the organizations' drive against what they call "Jim Crow policies" of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, by picketing City Hall for an hour.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Truman said today that the outcome of the Paris meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers confirmed the correctness of the foreign policy the United States Government had been pursuing and the necessity for continuing that policy "with calmness and determination."
New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $18,440,000 will be placed on the market today by banking syndicates. The offerings are as follows:

Refusal of public loaders on Pier 18, Brooklyn, to let employes of a trucking concern unload an export shipment of tinplate with the help of a fork-lift truck resulted in a brief work stoppage yesterday afternoon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 21 -- Yale's president, Dr. Charles Seymour, told his faculty today that he would not ask it to take a loyalty oath. He also declared that if the Federal Government dictated "what books our students should read we had better close our doors." He pledged opposition to any "hysterical witch hunt."

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Through new methods of flexible management control, industry is finding ways to stabilize profits despite changes in the business cycle, corporation executives disclosed here today during the 30th international costs conference of the National Association of Cost Accountants.
Cold cuts hot? This idea, contradictory as it sounds, proves ingratiating in warm weather.

Soon after summer, officially only an hour and a half old, was marking up at 3:30 P. M. a high for the year of 92.4 degrees, the Weather Bureau predicted cautiously yesterday that relief in the Northeast's long-distance drought appeared as "a possibility" on its maps.

BOSTON, June 21 -- The Rev. Dr. G. Bromley Oxnam, Methodist Bishop in the New York area, commenting today on Francis Cardinal Spellman's speech on public education last Sunday, accused the Roman Catholic leader of "bearing false witness" against Representative Graham A. Barden.

The stock market remained unchanged yesterday as efforts to push ahead bogged down with a lull in trading. A moderate buying rush in the morning gave the list a momentary lift but there was no carry-through and final quotations were mixed.

MONTREAL, June 21 -- The apartment house division of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers today adopted resolutions calling for revision of the so-called "fair operating income return" established by Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods, on the ground that more liberal regulations were necessary to safeguard the investments of residential property owners.
