MINEOLA, L. I., June 21 -- Formation of a State Authority to take over and operate the Long Island Rail Road may be necessary to insure continued service, the Nassau County Transit Commission said today in a report filed with J. Russel Sprague, Nassau County Executive.
BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -- Lefty Mel Parnell became a nine-game winner as the Red Sox stretched their streak to six victories today by beating the Tigers, 7 to 1.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Government today opened its fight before the Interstate Commerce Commission to recover what had been estimated as two to three billion dollars in reparations from the railroads on allegations of overcharges on wartime shipments.

Brazil would have to stop buying in this country altogether if she were to "budget" her purchases from the United States solely in line with her net dollar income, it was declared yesterday by Jose Bettencourt Machado, acting director of the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau.

HONOLULU, June 21 -- Hawaii's employers today told the Territorial Emergency Board, which is seeking to end the longshore strike that has virtually isolated the islands for more than seven weeks, that it could not logically find any "middle ground" on which to base its findings.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Truman today appointed Mrs. Perle Mesta, widely known Washington hostess, as Minister to Luxembourg. She was active in the Truman campaign, working with Louis Johnson, now Secretary of Defense, who headed the finance committee. She was also co-chairman of the financially successful Truman inaugural ball.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -The House Judiciary Committee today endorsed a Senate-approved bill to legalize the basing point price system used by many heavy industries, as long as no collusive agreements are involved.

Senator Taft has announced that he will support an amendment which is now being prepared in connection with one of the pending labor bills and which provides for the use of the injunction, with no strings attached, in labor disputes involving the nation's health and safety. The purpose is said to be to produce a show of hands on the moot issue of the injunction.

Only a few months ago everyone was cursing the cold. Since everyone now is cursing the heat, it shows either that man is perverse by nature, or that the universe is perverse in sending forth seasons. Since there is no immediate intention of arguing with the universe -- certainly not on this kind of morning -- it may be concluded that man is perverse.

VIENNA, June 21 -- The Austrian Cabinet endorsed today a statement by Chancellor Leopold Figl that "on the basis of yesterday's published agreement of the four Foreign Ministers the chief goal of the Austrian governmental policy -- achievement of full freedom and sovereignty -- will be achieved in the near future."

The State of California sold at auction bidding yesterday an issue of $30,000,000 of tax-exempt veterans' welfare bonds maturing from 1950 to 1970 to a banking syndicate headed by Bankers Trust Company, First National Bank of Chicago and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at a bid of 103.87 for fixed interest of 2 1/4 per cent, an approximate interest cost of 1.89 per cent.

A jury of ten men and two women was completed yesterday morning in the "lonely hearts" murder trial, on the ninth day, in Bronx Supreme Court. In the afternoon session a technicality developed over the selection of two alternates and the trial was adjourned until Friday morning.

William Reid, Chairman of the Board of Transportation, said yesterday that his capital budget request for next year would include an item of $3,500,000 for the first major improvement to the Forty-second Street shuttle since it was opened in 1918 as a "temporary" subway connection between the Grand Central and Times Square districts.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 21 -- Rabbi Ira Eisenstein, leader of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism in New York City, today called for a "common religion" that could, and should, be evolved out of America's "brief but magnificent history as a nation."

A nation-wide alarm was broadcast yesterday afternoon for the apprehension of an ex-convict and another man on a first-degree murder indictment in the fatal stabbing on May 9 of William Lurye, garment union organizer.

Four young physicians who have completed one year of special training in opthalmology at the New York University - Bellevue Medical Center received awards of $500 each yesterday to conduct further research in this field.

The futile attempt of a 30-year-old Army veteran to visit his wife and child in Berlin without benefit of passport or passage money ended yesterday with his arrival here aboard the transport General Maurice Rose.

Achievement of an economic union based on the free multilateral trade and free currency convertibility policies of the Benelux nations was advocated yesterday as the answer to European recovery if worked out now.

A business "bill of rights" to "unshackle business from bureaucratic control" was proposed last night by Irwin D. Wolf, vice president of Kaufmann Department Stores and the May Department Store Company. He addressed about 600 retailers at the closing dinner of the mid-year convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Statler Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 -- An order opening the city's nine municipal swimming pools and thirty-five playgrounds to joint use by Negroes and whites was rescinded late today by Mayor Joseph M. Darst after a battle at the Fairground Park Pool. The order was in effect one day.

Three summa cure laude graduates will be among the 662 Hunter College students who will receive degrees tonight at the college's ninety-sixth commencement exercises in the Hunter Auditorium, 695 Park Avenue. They are Evelyn Ruth Charney, Florina Klingenstein Katz and Arlene Withrow.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The State Department gave its diplomatic blessing today to the efforts of the French Government to establish a stable state in Viet Nam under the former ruler, Bao Dai. The following statement was issued:

Directors of the Joseph Dixon Crucible Company announced yesterday the election of E. M. Cabaniss as president to succeed J. H. Schermerhorn, who becomes chairman of the board. Mr. Cabaniss has been with the company for twenty-five years, having served as works manager, manufacturing vice president and executive vice president.

Jack Rubin, head of the Manhattan Theatre Ticket Service, 264 West Forty-seventh Street, promised last night that he would turn over to the License Department tomorrow the canceled checks and stubs he had refused to submit to John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's largest financing operation, which also was the largest corporate financing in history, came to a close on Monday, when stockholders subscribed on that final day to $264,000,000 of the company's offering of rights to subscribe to $394,372,900 of ten-year 3 1/8 per cent convertible debentures which will be due on June 20, 1959.

When the Yankees and Giants cross paths at the Stadium Monday night for the Mayor O'Dwyer Trophy and in the interests of charity -- proceeds go to various sandlot baseball agencies -- the pre-game activities will be highlighted by the appearance of Joe DiMaggio.

Chobol Navone, operators, purchased the ten-story apartment building for seventy-seven families on a plot 80 by 100 feet at 211 East Thirty-fifth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, from the River Management Corporation in a deal reported yesterday by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., brokers, who last year also negotiated the purchase by the seller in the current transaction.

LONDON, June 21 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin, upon his return from Paris today, said that the Council of Foreign Ministers, which adjourned yesterday, had opened up "possibilities of cooperation" between the Western powers and the Soviet Union.

LONDON, June 21 -- Continued resistance of United States buyers to British goods, underlining the current drive for lowered prices through increased productivity, was reflected today in the May trade figures released by the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, said today the number of civilian employes in the Executive Branch of the Federal Government had increased in April at the rate of more than 350 a day.

Labor and management in the fashion industry, educators and Government officials paid tribute last night to the Fashion Institute of Technology and Design for its part in training tomorrow's leaders in the $23,000,000,000 apparel industry.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 21 -- Only two matches were carried to the eighteenth green as all favorites advanced to the second round of match play in the women's fifth annual Tri-County golf championship today over the Innis Arden course.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 21 -- Dr. W. Palmer Dearing, deputy surgeon-general of the Federal Public Health Service, urged public health officers today to center their efforts on problems that have grown through the years rather than concentrate on those that have shrunk. "Our goal must be to minimize this lag," he said.

Charles A, Arnold has been appointed sales manager for the retail stores division of the New York metropolitan area by Superba Cravats, makers of neckwear and mufflers. He formerly was with Wembley, Inc.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- A suit alleging that the registration statement and prospectus covering the Class A common stock of the Tucker Corporation contained "false and untrue statements" and "omitted material facts" was filed in Federal District Court here today.

Samuel Broxmeyer, who manipulated a few apartment holdings into a real estate empire that burst its seams and dropped him into bankruptcy proceedings some months ago, was ordered yesterday to appear in Magistrates' Court next Tuesday to answer a charge of unlawfully withholding property.

The National Council of the Arts, Sciences and Professions presented the first of a series of programs of its newly formed Cultural Center at Carnegie Hall last night. An appeal for funds to aid in setting up permanent quarters here and elsewhere was made.
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 22 (AP) -- Government reports today put the death toll in typhoon-lashed Japan at 106. Other reports said 563 were missing.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Rivoli, the attraction is "Take One False Step," a Universal-International comedy melodrama, starring William Powell and Shelley Winters. Chester Erskine produced and directed and collaborated with Irwin Shaw on the screen play. Marsha Hunt, James Gleason, Dorothy Hart and Jess Barker appear in support.

A handful of men and women salvaged from the fear. boredom and uselessness of the hospital waiting room were working in the bright sunlight yesterday afternoon in the social service workrooms of Mount Sinai Hospital.

The total assets of the Charles F. Noyes Company have increased about $1,234,115 and the net operating earnings for the year ending April 30, before employes profit sharing retirement fund, cooperative payments and Federal and state taxes, were approximately $362,192, William B. Falconer, president, reported at the annual meeting of the company.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson went to Paris a month ago worried about Germany and came back today slightly disturbed about China. On the way back from Paris in the President's plane, Mr. Acheson was working, not on the German problem, but on the China problem, and the tactics of the Soviet Foreign Minister in Paris help explain why.

The first houses in the 215-family Hillside Terrace development in New Hyde Park, L. I., are scheduled to be ready for occupancy early in July, the builders reported yesterday. Two models are now on display. The basic house is priced at $10,990, and the other has extra features with a total cost not to exceed $10,990.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- A campaign to establish a successor to the world heavyweight title that Joe Louis abandoned when he retired undefeated goes through its first authentic stage tomorrow night, twelve years to the day since the Bomber wrested the crown from James J. Braddock here.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 21--The Purchase Advisory Board of United Nations Relief for Palestine Refugees met today and appointed a subcommittee including Red Cross representatives that will review all future food purchases for refugee work.
MEXICO CITY, June 21 (AP) -- Mexico shut out imports today of nearly all clothing, foods and scores of "unessentials," as a measure to protect the peso.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A secondary boycott does not violate the Taft-Hartley Act when the secondary parties are railroads and railroad workers, the National Labor Relations Board ruled unanimously today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 21 -A field of 142 players, setting a record for the Westchester Seniors' Golf Association, participated in the group's annual spring tournament at Quaker Ridge Golf Club today.

The largest class in the twelve-year history of Queens College, 331 students, will receive degrees today at 4 P. M. from Dr. Margaret Kiely, the acting president, at commencement exercises on the college quadrangle.
CANBERRA, Australia, June 21 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt said in the House of Representatives here today that it was oversimplification to attribute unrest and instability in Asia solely to communism.

A New York economist yesterday called for a union of the nation's ten million owners of stocks to offset the "threat to private enterprise by powerful pressure groups and by legislation and administrative rulings."

I recently attended a meeting of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues as a lay delegate of the synagogue of which I am a member and heard delegations from various parts of metropolitan New York relate the difficulties they encountered in starting and developing new congregations.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 7 points higher to 8 points lower than on Monday in a moderate volume of business.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 21 -- In an unprecedented radio address to the nation following a Cabinet meeting tonight, Premier Antonin Zapotocky accused Roman Catholic Archbishop Josef Beran of ordering priests "to participate in political actions against the republic" and declared that "law and justice must be used against marauders, provocateurs and those who call for disorder and unrest."
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A last-hour fight against extension of the Maritime Commission's authority to charter ships is developing in the Senate.

Israel will need a minimum investment of $2,000,000,000 to absorb an expected influx of 750,000 immigrants in the next four years, Robert Nathan, director of the economic department of the Jewish Agency, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel New Yorker.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21 -- The Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued today a statement announcing that the Yugoslav Government would never renounce its territorial and reparations claims against Austria despite the fact that the Soviet Government had withdrawn its support of these claims in the agreement reached in Paris.

PARIS, June 21 -- The French Assembly today annulled credits for the completion of the battleship Jean Bart and for the construction of the aircraft carrier Clemenceau in the naval budget for this year.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 21 -- Gen. Heliodor Pika, former Deputy Chief of Staff of the Czechoslovak Army, was executed this morning.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Ezzard Charles and Jersey Joe Walcott, two ferocious and awesomely destructive tigers who haven't been fed raw, red meat for weeks on end, will rend each other limb from limb in Comiskey Park tomorrow night. Amid scenes of indescribable bloodshed and carnage they will battle for "fistiana's brightest bauble," the heavyweight championship of the world.

Coffee futures continued firm in moderately active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Demand from trade sources for the near-by delivery months, and new buying of the distant months by producing interests absorbed scattered July liquidation and profit-taking on a scale up.

Membership cards in the Pre-historic Animal Society were distributed yesterday to fifteen fifth-grade youngsters from the Munsey Park School, Manhasset, L. I., and to three children with cerebral palsy by Mitchell Pariser, 11-year-old palsy victim.

LONDON, June 21 (UP) -- Britain lodged a protest with the Chinese Nationalist Government today against the bombing and strafing of a British passenger-cargo liner near Shanghai, the Foreign Office announced.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 21 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis tournament rolled through its third round today with one seeded entry being eliminated. Jim Brink of Washington, seeded last, was upset by Glen Bassett of U. C. L. A., 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 0.

Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, denounced as "educationally ominous" yesterday the request for textbook lists sent to colleges and universities throughout the country by John S. Wood, Democrat, of Georgia, and chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- This session of Congress has "so much" to do that it will go on "indefinitely," Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, Democratic Senate leader, said today.

Robert F. Wagner has served the people of New York so faithfully for so long a period that there has been a natural reluctance to dwell upon the circumstance of his illness in recent years. The fact is, however, that Mr. Wagner last answered a roll-call in the Senate on May 7, 1947.

CAIRO, June 21 -- The Egyptian Foreign Ministry has directed the attention of the United States Embassy here to the fact that a slip placed in passports issued for Americans going to Egypt says that they go at their own risk. The Egyptian Embassy in Washington has informed the State Department that the inclusion of such a warning is now unnecessary and detrimental to Egyptian tourist trade and the development of cordial Egyptian-United States relations.

PARIS, June 21 (AP) -- A painting of a Nativity scene won a $2,000 award today for Edouard Goerg, French artist, with a chance to compete for a $3,500 prize in the United States in an international contest. The contests are sponsored by the Hall Brothers Greeting Card Company of Kansas City, Mo., which gets the right to use winning paintings on Christmas cards.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 21 -- American Airlines renewed today an attempt to obtain the Civil Aeronautics Board's permission for scheduled transport flights from the Westchester County airport in purchase.
The National Professional Tennis Championship picked up momentum yesterday at Forest Hills, with all headliners in action and the sacrificial offerings putting up a little more resistance.
The pending market offering of more than $14,000,000 of common stock of Kansas Gas and Electric Company was called off yesterday when underwriting negotiations collapsed over pricing terms.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 21 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of the Willow Brook club scored 37, 39 -- 76, three strokes over course figures, to win medal honors during the qualifying round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship over the Cherry Valley Club course today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 21 -- William (Bill) Mangin of New Jersey's Aldecress Club topped a field of sixty-seven amateurs with a gross round of 36, 38 -- 74 at Elmwood Country Club today to annex first honors in the initial Metropolitan Golf Association one-day handicap tournament in Westchester this season.

LONDON, June 21 (AP) -- Two seeded stars staved off threatened upsets before 20,000 sun-drenched fans who flocked to the Wimbledon tennis championships today. The fireworks, which looked as if they were going to blow out Frank Parker of Los Angeles and Eric Sturgess of South Africa in the first forty-five minutes, fizzled.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, June 22 (UP) -- Five National Assembly members and a political fellow-worker who last week filed a petition with the United Nations Commission for Korea to remove the United States Military Mission from South Korea, were arrested today on personal orders of provisional President Syngman Rhee.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 21 -- A significant struggle against the blockade of Yugoslavia by states in the Communist Information Bureau is taking place in little known Yugoslav oilfields, one of which this correspondent was permitted to visit several days ago.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 21 -That shining black nose of Henry C. Taylor's yawl Baruna was poking up Chesapeake Bay tonight, still in the lead in the New York Yacht Clubs ocean race of 466 miles from Newport, R. I., to here.

Municipal Court Justice Peter A. Quinn ruled yesterday in the Bronx that the procedure followed by the Consolidated Edison Company in putting into effect a gas rate increase authorized by the Public Service Commission last January was illegal.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Leaders of a bi-partisan Senate group favoring compromise legislation dealing with strikes affecting national health and safety received assurance of support today from the American Federation of Labor.
Many heavily traveled streets and parkways throughout the city now in disrepair soon will be in good shape, according to details of a broad repaving program announced yesterday.
Scientists at the city Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Welfare Island are investigating the secret of why people grow old as ardently as Ponce de Leon searched for the Fountain of Youth.

HECHINGEN, Germany, June 21 (AP) -- Princess Cecilie, granddaughter of the late Kaiser Wilhelm, was married here today to Clyde Harris of Amarillo, Tex., an interior decorator, in the Tower Room of the Hohenzollern castle by Mayor Paul Binderief of Hechingen. Later, a Protestant religious service took place in the chapel at which a refugee minister from Silesia, the Rev. Reinhard Macholds, officiated.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- The Cubs brightened the beginning of Manager Frankie Frisch's five-day suspension when they walloped the Braves, 8 to 4, today before 8,161 spectators.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Official concern over Britain's continuing dollar deficit and the resulting drain on her reserves has reached a point where observers here are receiving suggestions on how to treat the "crisis" in British affairs when and if it arrives.

SEROWE, Bechuanaland, June 21 (Reuters) -- Nine thousand tribesmen, squatting under the camelthorn trees in this African village, today continued their parley to decide whether they wanted 27-year-old Seretse Khama as their chief after his marriage to 24-year-old London typist Ruth Williams.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A stop-gap, sixty-day extension of two types of Federal Housing Administration mortgage insurance beyond June 30 was approved by the Senate today and sent to the House.

With reference to THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial of June 1 in which the Bremen liberty of press law of 1948 was discussed, I beg to send you enclosed the statement the Senate of Bremen has issued in this matter and should be grateful if you would have it published in your paper.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., June 21 -- Robert Russell, a mechanic for the Lynbrook Taxi Corporation, and his wife got unusually lucky at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, last night. They made themselves more than $3,000 on wagers at the track.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The battle between the certified airlines, regulated and subsidized by the Civil Aeronautics Board, and the aggressive young "large irregular" carriers moved toward a drastic show-down today when the CAB asked the Department of Justice to begin criminal proceedings against Standard Airlines, Inc., of Long Beach, Calif.

Purchasing agents are asked to join in an industry-wide movement to oppose reinstatement of the copper import tax, in a resolution prepared by C. Donald Dallas, chairman of the board, Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., released here yesterday.
Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations, called yesterday for extension of the Marshall Plan to the new state of Israel.

The Board of Estimate is expected to grant next Tuesday a special franchise for a couple of fourteen-foot nudes in polished aluminum to overhang the street from the facade of the new Parke-Bernet Galleries in Madison Avenue between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- The Soviet press hailed today the Paris Conference as having marked an improvement in the international atmosphere and having laid the groundwork for a peaceful postwar European solution.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 21 (AP) -- Israel told the United Nations today she would not agree to the complete internationalization of Jerusalem under any circumstances.

Jewelry with a reported value of $74,750 was stolen yesterday from a five-room suite on the tenth floor of the Plaza Hotel between 3 P. M. and 4:30 P. M., while the occupant, Mrs. George Parker of San Antonio Tex., was out shopping.

PARIS, June 21 -- The French are enjoying the bizarre touch of anticlimax that Mr. Vishinsky added to the Foreign Ministers Council when he called for another meeting and a change in the communique after the delegates had formally adjourned, drunk their farewell toasts around the bar of the Palais Rose and released their joint statement to the press.

MUNTOK, Banka, Indonesia, June 21 -- Dr. Sukarno, Indonesian Nationalist leader and President of the Indonesian Republic, declared his personal and vigorous opposition to communism in a colorful conference with touring United States correspondents in the home of Premier Mohammed Hatta atop a mountain in this small town tonight.

Ira S. Bushey Sons, Inc., have purchased the two one-story buildings on a plot 100 by 320 feet at 141 Bryant Avenue, Brooklyn, from the Howland Mutual Lumber Company. The land is used for storage of lumber. Foley Martin were attorneys for the buyers and Mortimer Redman acted for the seller.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A Democratic move blocked consideration by the Senate today of an economy resolution that would direct the President to cut 5 to 10 per cent from billions of dollars appropriated for the Executive branch for the fiscal year beginning July 1. This move, a simple objection entered by Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, set off two distinct and heated floor battles.

On and after June 27, Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company's 30-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures due on March 1, 1978, will be available at the office of Bankers Trust Company, here in definitive form in exchange for temporary certificates.

Anyone who is uncertain as to what makes a printed fabric modern will find a highly spectacular answer in the display of "Stimulus'' prints that opened yesterday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.
CHICAGO, June 21 -- A movement to make Government procurement reorganization effective at the earliest possible date is being pushed by a large number of individual purchasing agents here.

Of all the appeals that touch the heart of this great-hearted city, none is more compelling than the appeal of the blind. They live in the city of perpetual night; they cannot know the glistening white of winter, the green of spring and summer, the flame of autumn. One of the greatest of the blind put it this way:

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, declared today that "long-range military readiness" was necessary for the self-preservation of the United States against the unrelenting hostility and conspiracy of the Soviet Union.

SHANGHAI, June 21 -- None of seven passengers on the Anchises, including a United States Wac, Nilah Stroup, homebound from Japan, were hurt when the ship was hit in a Nationalist air raid. Some had narrow escapes, for explosive bullets from the strafing Mustang fighter made a shambles of the ship's topside.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Judith Coplon screamed "that's a damn lie!" but finally acknowledged at her espionage trial today that she spent two nights with a man in Philadelphia and Baltimore hotel rooms.

DENVER, Col., June 21 -- The Denver and Philadelphia mints have been ordered to coin $15,000,000 worth of Sun Yat-sen dollars for the Chinese Nationalists, Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, director of the United States Mint, revealed today.

The Most Rev. John J. Mitty, a former New York priest who now is Archbishop of San Francisco, arrived here yesterday to assemble the "Pacific Coast Pilgrimage" he is leading to Rome and Lourdes. The group of more than 200 persons sailed last night on the Queen Mary after a reception at the Statler Hotel.
Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' H Hour, winner of the Amagansett Hurdle Handicap in 1948, took it again at Aqueduct yesterday -- but he didn't have his picture taken in the winner's enclosure.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 3,423, compared with 3,173 last week and 3,077 in the similar week of 1948, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,783 arrivals yesterday, against 1,457 last Tuesday.

BALDWIN, L. I., June 21 -- Only man in the field of 110 starters to break par, Al Brosch of Cherry Valley, leader at the halfway mark in the recent United States open at Medinah, followed somewhat the same procedure and took command today in the first round of the Long Island open championship with a 69 over the Willow Brook Golf Club course.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 21 (AP) -- Savoy Stable's 4-year-old black gelding, Blackmont, won the feature race by a nose at Monmouth Park today. Sanford Stud Farms' Peacelaw was second by a similar margin over All in Fun of Grand view Stables, who took the show over the favored Manchac.

CHICAGO, June 21--Active new-crop deliveries of wheat sold above $2 a bushel on the Board of Trade today, going into new ground since Feb. 3. The full advance was not maintained but the close was 2 1/2 to 3 3/4 cents up, September showing the most strength.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 21 -- The Central Committee of the Bulgarian Communist party acknowledged in a resolution published today that "serious weaknesses and errors" had developed in the party's policy toward rural producers, especially "middle peasants."

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- In an action held to insure final passage of the Administration's national housing bill, the House Democratic caucus today voted, 147 to 8, to support the program. It was trimmed slightly to bring it into substantial conformity with the Senate-approved version.
Leading staff officials of the United Nations here and abroad will cooperate in a special European study program sponsored by the New School for Social Research, it was announced yesterday.
HAVANA, June 21 (AP) -- Official reports from the Dominican Republic said today that the revolution against the Government of President Rafael L. Trujillo had been crushed.

The results of the Paris conference have been received in different parts of the world with comments ranging from deep skepticism to the faint hope voiced by Mr. Bevin that Paris may yet serve as a foundation for further progress. The Austrians are happy at the prospect of early independence and freedom from foreign occupation, however high the price they pay, and the Yugoslavs are bitter at what they regard as their betrayal by Russia.

DETROIT, June 21 -- State and national Republican leaders in Michigan, counter-attacking a Democratic-labor coalition, said today they would stake their claim in the 1950 elections on a living platform, rid of double-talk and "me, tooism," with performance guaranteed by party and subscribing candidates.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 21 -- The Soviet Union introduced a resolution today providing that the Security Council give en bloc approval to twelve pending applications for membership in the United Nations.

A shortage of woolens and worsteds for women's and men's apparel will hinder deliveries at the height of the fall season, it was learned yesterday. Cutters who wanted definite assurance of a strong buying trend before committing themselves on fabric purchases now find that they must wait sixty to ninety days for deliveries.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The pace of business activity continued to decline in May of this year and unemployment increased to 3,300,000, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UP) -Westbrook Pegler, newspaper columnist, today was subpoenaed to appear July 7 before a House Labor subcommittee to tell what he knows about undemocratic practices in unions.

LONDON, June 21 -- British Government bonds took another toss in the stock market here today. Selling orders from large and small holders -- the former in many cases being industrial companies needing money for plant and stocks -- at the opening of the market caused the whole list to slide.

TOKYO, June 21 -- Soviet authorities in Japan today washed their hands of Japanese prisoners held in Russian satellite territories, declaring that the Soviet Union had "no connection" with the problem of their repatriation as pledged in the Potsdam agreement.

PITTSBURGH, June 21 (AP) -- Willie (Puddin' Head) Jones slashed out two home runs tonight as Eddie Sawyer's surprising Philadelphia Phils whipped he Pittsburgh Pirates, 9 to 4, for their second straight over the hapless Bucs.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 21 -- J. W. G. MacEwan, Dean of Agriculture and Home Economics of the University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Canada, told the thirty-fourth annual convention of Kiwanis International here today that "the key to world peace may be food."
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, accused the British today of giving "cooperation" to the Communist forces in China.

A 30-year-old Harlem mother threw her two young children out of a six-story window and leaped after them shortly after noon yesterday. One of the children was killed. The woman and the other child were critically injured.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman signed an order yesterday placing in receivership the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and four subsidiary companies serving 2,000,000 bus riders daily in the Bronx, Manhattan and Westchester.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today blocked proposed commutation fare increases on the Erie Railroad for the second time in less than a month.

PRAGUE, Czechohlovakia, June 22 (AP) -- Leaders of the Communist-sponsored Catholic Action Society defied the Vatican's excommunication tonight and accused the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy in Czechoslovakia of anti-state activity.

LONDON, June 22 -- The much criticized National Coal Board, which has operated Britain's nationalized coal mines for the last two and a half years, reported today a profit of about 1,700,000 [$6,800,000] for 1948. This compared with a loss of about 23,250,000 in 1947.

LONDON, June 22 -- Dealers in British Government stocks had to face a fresh rush of selling when the stock market opened here today. Again sales were for large and small accounts and more millions of pounds were sheared off market values.

NANKING, June 22 -- A series of scattered anti-Communist uprisings, in which rural rebels destroyed highway bridges, sacked military warehouses and assassinated eight officials, has been suppressed by the Communist authorities of Anhwei and Kiangsu Provinces, the New China News Agency reported today.
I suspect I am one of the "naive and dangerous" economic dilettantes referred to in your editorial "Fourth Round Economics."

DETROIT, June 22 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, today formally rejected a Ford Motor Company proposal that the union drop all demands for pensions and wage increases for eighteen months and join the company in seeking ways to provide greater job security for the 116,000 UAW members employed by Ford.
The police search for two accused slayers of William Lurye, garment union organizer, turned yesterday to the South and Southwest.
LONDON, June 22 -- A major spokesman of Britain's industrial workers declared today that prospects of Britain's earning enough dollars to pay for her dollar imports appeared to be "growing dimmer."

The New York City Transit System will have more than enough permanent civil service jobs starting at $60 a week to employ all June graduates of the electrical and mechanical courses in the city's vocational and academic high schools, Dr. C. Frederick Pertsch, associate superintendent of schools, announced yesterday.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 22 -- Four young women were presented to society tonight at dinners and dances given by their parents at country homes.

PARIS, June 22 -- W. Averell Harriman went to Brussels, Belgium, today for the meeting there tomorrow that is expected to bring a showdown in long and sharp dispute between him and Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer of Britain, over the question of introducing greater competition into European trade by a more flexible system of financing it with Marshall Plan dollars.
The cotton futures market turned somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 8 points higher to 12 points lower.

" MINK AND RED HERRING,"* by A. J. Liebling, is the second book of Mr. Liebling's glumly enthusiastic assaults on the public prints of the world. In this cheerfully saturnine installment Mr. Liebling has bright and penetrating things to say about the newspapers in such places as New York, N. Y.; Winston-Salem, N. C.; Russellville, Ark.; London, England; Paris, France; San Juan, P. R.; Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and Ciudad Trujillo, in the Dominican Republic.

TORONTO, June 22 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison, 39-year-old veteran from Little Rock, Ark., scored a record-breaking 66 to lead the field in the first round of the 72-hole Canadian Open championship today over the St. George Golf Club course.

On June 11 you carried an editorial entitled "The ECA Investment." It tends to support the efforts of the Government and the Administrator in the handling of Marshall Plan funds. It also supports the plan of Mr. Hoffman to continue the Marshall Plan on the official basis.

Top-seeded Bobby Riggs was the only one of the big favorites to lose a set yesterday as the third round in the national professional tennis championships was completed at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. Jack Cushingham of Beverly Hills, Calif., carried the two-time winner to a 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 2 score.

Chinese Communist authorities have adequate supplies of both dollars and pounds sterling to cover purchases of a considerable volume of capital goods here or in Britain, bankers here, interested in foreign trade, said yesterday. Few orders have materialized, but the Reds have sent out feelers both here and in London for steel, mill supplies and a variety of types of productive machinery, it was added.

East Coast shipping now faces the welcome possibility of genuine stability over a longer period than it has enjoyed in many years. The recent and pending settlements of major maritime disputes indicate that sea labor negotiations have entered a new and more amicable era.

Certificates for outstanding contributions to marketing research were awarded yesterday to seven individuals by the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association at its annual awards luncheon in the Commodore Hotel.

Preparations for the city's first "Clean Harbor Week" to begin June 27 were outlined to the press yesterday during a boat tour of the upper harbor conducted by Capt. J. D. Beard, USN, Supervisor of New York Harbor, whose agency is sponsoring the drive.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Ginger Rogers has asked to be relieved from her contract to play the leading roe in "Tehachapi: The Story of Molly X" at Universal-International, it was learned today from the studio. No decision has been reached by studio executives regarding the request, but it is understood that the actress will be permitted to withdraw if an adequate replacement can be found before mid-August, when the picture is scheduled to start.
PANAMA, June 22 -- A 1,006-pound black marlin, caught in Panama Bay, may provide a world record for Louis Schmidt Jr., 33-year-old American angler, who has only one arm and one leg.

OTTAWA, June 22 -- A striking case of coincidence between the occurrence of a great flare on the sun and its effects on the earth's atmosphere and magnetism was described here today by Grote Reber of the United States Bureau of Standards, and Dr. Helen W. Dodson of the McMath-Hulbert Observatory, University of Michigan.

A strike of twenty fuel truck drivers employed by the Willis Rose Corporation at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, began at 10:30 A. M. yesterday and continued through the day. The large field's light operations continued on schedule as the servicing of airliners departing for Europe, Latin America and Miami was undertaken by supervisory and office personnel.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Mr. Frank Frisch, the absentee landlord of the Chicago Cubs, was discovered lolling about in a shiny, new and white Cub uniform at high noon today. The uniform not only looked very unfamiliar but also slightly illegal. If memory served correctly, the Old Flash had been banished to durance vile by Ford Christopher Frick, the president and Supreme Court of the National League.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- A workable formula for buying needed industrial materials with minimum risks during a period of falling prices was put together by participants in an industry-wide panel discussion of materials management at the thirty-fourth annual international convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents here today at the Stevens Hotel.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., June 22 -- Two robbers, garbed as house painters, held up today the paymaster of the East Rutherford Drying Company, 480 Paterson Avenue, and escaped with $16,000 after calmly changing cars three times.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 22 -- Miss Evelyn Odom of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club supplied the upset of the first round of match play in the Women's Long Island Golf Association championship with a 3 and 2 decision over the 1948 runner-up and medalist, Mrs. Mortimer May, Willow Brook, at the Cherry Valley Club today.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- A Protestant spokesman today accused New York Roman Catholic officials of falsehoods and efforts to "raid" the United States Treasury.

William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, said yesterday that he would like to have the Long Island Rail Road's Rockaway Beach Branch transferred to the city subway system. He differed, however, with features of the long-discussed move, as renewed yesterday by David E. Smucker, a trustee and chief operating officer of the bankrupt railroad.

Unscrupulous door-to-door salesmen using faked credentials, smooth talk and glittering samples are swindling gullible housewives in the metropolitan area of millions of dollars a year, the Better Business Bureau of New York declared yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- Dale Mitchell's triple with the bases filled in the fourteenth inning tonight gave the Indians a 7-3 victory over the Athletics. Bob Lemon, who was knocked from the box by the Athletics last night, came back in relief of Lefty Gene Bearden to gain credit for his seventh triumph of the campaign.

PARIS, June 22 -- In a statement issued here today, representatives of the eighteen countries in the World Food Council called the attention of their governments to "serious food problmes likely to have far-reaching economic consequences."
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Maritime Commission replied today to criticism voiced on the Senate floor yesterday by Senator Pat McCarran in connection with its holding of the American President Lines.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The House Administration Committee today approved an anti-poll tax bill by a vote of 11 to 7. It reversed its own subcommittee.
CHICAGO, June 22 (UP) -- Three atomic scientists charged today in a statement that Congressional investigations were "effectively strangling" atomic research.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Congressional approval of the Administration's $1,130,000,000 program of military aid to this country's associates in the North Atlantic defensive alliance is urgently necessary, the Secretary of State, Dean Acheson, declared today.
Now that a few messes of school tuna have been brought in to Freeport, this week-end will see the big run of anglers if not the big run of tuna.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Bill Wight scattered ten hits to pitch his seventh victory of the season tonight as the White Sox defeated the Senators, 4 -- 1.

The steady rise in governmental employment on all levels and the attendant effect on taxes drawn from the public's pocketbook can only be viewed with concern. Senator Byrd of Virginia, who keeps the nation informed on the federal figures, has just reported that the number of civilian employes of the United States Government rose again in April, reaching a total of 2,122,710 in the executive branch.

Jeanne Mitchell made her Lewisohn Stadium debut last night, playing the Vieuxtemps Fourth Violin Concerto with Fritz Reiner and the Philharmonic-Symphony. She was heard by an audience or 6,400, plus radio listeners to station WNYC.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Philadelphia (Pa.) Electric Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 972,624 shares of its no par value common stock.

An admission by Gilbert Green, Illinois chairman of the Communist party, that the party advocates overthrow of the Government by force and violence under certain conditions was introduced in evidence yesterday at the Communist trial.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A two-phase plan for a Chinese Nationalist defense against the Communists and for United States aid to the shaky Nationalist regime was placed before President Truman today by Dr. Kan Chieh-Hou, a special representative of Acting President Gen. Li Tsungjen, who recently arrived from China.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 -- Mayor Joseph M. Darst appointed a fifteen-member council on human relations today following clashes between Negroes and whites at a city park when municipal swimming pools and playgrounds were thrown open to both races.
Strolling down Thirty-fourth Street yesterday, 16-year-old Lynn Davis of Pocatello, Idaho, found that "everybody runs like mad."
ST. LOUIS, June 22 -- The Giants were seemingly winning a ball game tonight from here to the upper end of the Mississippi when suddenly the tide changed and it almost carried Leo Durocher out to sea.

Selling by trade sources and liquidation from speculative quarters lowered cottonseed oil futures prices 41 to 46 points on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. There was thin support for the deferred months as a result of reports of softer crude markets in the South. Unsteadiness in lard also was a contributing factor in the decline.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 22 -- With a margin of 6 minutes and 2 seconds of her time handicap to spare, the 32-foot waterline sloop Alar, owned by D. Z. Bailey of the Riverside Yacht Club of Riverside, Conn., won the New York Yacht Club's race from Newport to here, a distance of 466 miles and the longest ocean contest on the Atlantic this year.

Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, will discuss the theory that education is the best weapon in combatting foreign ideologies, in a series of five informal conversation-interviews over CBS, starting July 18. He will be heard Monday through Friday of that week from 6:15 to 6:30 P. M.
Classroom dissertations on economics might not win a "most popular" award but every summer thousands of high school students find out that the lectures were not a waste of time.

LOS ANGELES, June 22 -- Application of the new "electric brain" computing machines to human affairs -- in effect providing some precise yardstick in the traditionally inexact social sciences -- was predicted today as mathematicians of several nations gathered at the University of California's Los Angeles campus for a ten-day conference on the devices.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Today's condtions should offer "some golden opportunities" for completion of construction projects offering substantial cost reduction advantages in industrial production, Oscar N. Lindahl, vice president of finance, Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, declared here today.

The ten-day heat wave that had been baking the Atlantic coastal region between southern New England and Washington appeared to be breaking up last night. However, the local drought, varying from twenty-three to thirty-one days, continued to parch the earth with no rain in sight.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 22 -- Rehabilitation is an essential service in public welfare today and public assistance given without skilled casework "is, indeed, a sterile thing," Elsie M. Bond, one of the leading public welfare figures in the state, declared today.

The stock market drifted into slightly lower ground yesterday but the lack of buying interest rather than a resumption of selling accounted for the moderate dip. In one of the dullest sessions of the year, prices hardly moved at times and most changes were in fractions, with the composite rate off 0.26 point on the day.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 -- J. Hugh Jackson of Sanford, Calif., dean of the School of Business at Stanford University, was elected president of the Kiwanis International at the thirty-fourth annual convention here today in Municipal Auditorium.

PARIS, June 22 -- France, which was a debtor to almost the whole foreign world a few months ago, is now a creditor on current account with all European countries except Britain, Belgium and Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Three self-styled "little guys" from Westchester County, N. Y., stormed up Capitol Hill today to tell the Senate Appropriations Committee that it was time "to get out your blue pencils and begin cutting the national budget forthwith."

WICHITA, Kan., June 22 (AP) -- The University of Texas, champion of the Southwest, won the first game in the National Collegiate A. A. baseball tournament tonight by 7 to 1 from St. John's of Brooklyn.
A convoy of thirty Army vehicles and trailers, shepherded by motorcycle patrolmen with sirens wailing, rumbled through the city yesterday and gave many an ex-GI a few moments of nostalgia.

William A. McDonald has purchased the three-story building at 280 Baldwin Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., where he has conducted a funeral home for many years. The seller was Florence B. Williamson, executrix of the estate of Mary McDonald. D. E. C. Somers, Inc., was the broker.

Taking at face value reports that Senator Robert F. Wagner planned to resign soon because of ill health, the Liberal party, through its policy committee, announced last night it would support former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman as his successor.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- The War Assets Administration said today that former owners of the Lido Beach Club at Long Beach, N. Y., repurchased from the Government in 1947 a war-surplus hotel on the property for $653,500. A spokesman said the agency had no comment on published reports that James V. Hunt, a Washington management counselor, received $80,000 from the owners for services in connection with the purchase.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 22 -- Virtually the same Washington boatload that won the Poughkeepsie championship a year ago was definitely elevated to varsity status today for the forty-seventh rowing regatta on the Hudson, but the California Bears are almost the unanimous choice of the twelve coaches here to win the big race on Saturday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 22--Yale University's baseball team fashioned a three-run rally with the aid of Lou Kreutzer's home run to defeat Harvard, 5--4, before 8,000 alumni families attending the annual commencement game.

Inventories of gasoline in the United States last week dropped 1,081,000 barrels to 116,403,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks of light fuel oil, however, increased 1,043,000 barrels to 61,445,000, but heavy fuel oil supplies fell 307,000 to 65,594,000.
A recent purchase by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Chardin's canvas, "Blowing Bubbles," said by the institution to be one of its outstanding acquisitions of the year, will be exhibited there today.

PARIS, June 22 -- Prince BuuLoc, chief of the personal staff of Bao Dai, ex-Emperor of Annam, announced in Dalat, French Indo-China, today that the former Emperor would assume supreme responsibility in the new Viet Nam state as "chief of Government," the French News Agency reported tonight.

A two-day moratorium on order-taking has been announced by Murray Sices Corporation, manufacturer of women's half-size suits. The company will close its books on June 30 and July 1, according to Edwin Silver, sales manager, in order to catch up on tabulation of orders already placed for the fall.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $15,148,000 for financing development costs of the Melrose Houses, the Bronx; the Stephen Foster Houses, Manhattan, and the Farragut Houses, Brooklyn.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York denounced yesterday as unfounded charges by Representative Emanuel Celler in a press statement on Monday that insurance concerns were "siphoning off" great amounts of the public's money into noncompetitive and insufficiently regulated private investments and were concealing the details of the transactions.

TOKYO, June 22 -- Inflation apparently has been defeated here. The note issue is 293,000,000,000 yen, down more than 50,000,000,000 since the year's end. Price levels have slipped more than 10 per cent from the year's peak. Financial circles expect both these trends to continue.

LONDON, June 22 -- Britain will make no further contribution to the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, Foreign Minister Bevin told Commons today. Instead, he said, the Government would "make an additional 100,000 available to British voluntary societies for the maintenance of Arab refugees, a large proportion of whom are children."
Thirty-one sons and daughters of American farm families left New York yesterday aboard the Marine Shark of the United States Lines to spend four months on farms in ten European countries.

The writer of the reply to the letter of my old friend Nathaniel Phillips, entitled "Dangers in Loyalty Oath," printed in THE TIMES of June 5, misses the point, which is simply this: A loyal American does not need an oath to assert his loyalty, whereas an oath of loyalty to anything or anybody is worthless to a Communist because he has already pledged all his loyalty to the Communist party.

Joseph Eisenberg has purchased the two-story one-family dwelling at 1149 East Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, from Gertrude Rothchild. The United Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company made a purchase money mortgage of $11,000 in connection with the transaction. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured both the fee and mortgage titles.

The American Gas and Electric Company yesterday increased its quarterly dividend by 25 cents to 75 cents, payoble on Sept. 15, and announced plans for two common stock offerings, one in October and another in the latter part of 1950.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 22 -- A Westchester County citizen's committee, asserting it represents 1,500 families, sent to the Public Service Commission and Governor Dewey today protests against the recent PSC action in extending to Oct. 31 the increased interim gas rates of the Westchester Lighting and Yonkers Electric Light and Power Companies.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 22 -- C. Norman Ramsey, vice president of the Citizens and Southern National Bank of Atlanta, Ga., was elected president of the class of '49 of the Graduate School of Banking at an election held here today during the school's annual summer session at Rutgers University.

BERLIN, June 22 -- Western Berlin's striking railroad workers, after rejecting a Western-sponsored compromise proposal for settling the strike, announced tonight that they would man switches and other installations in the three Western sectors tomorrow, making possible renewal of service on the Berlin-Helmstedt line.

NAZARETH, June 22 (Reuters) -- Israeli authorities have arrested about 800 Nazareth Arabs in a drive to smash a suspected Moslem Brotherhood underground movement in Nazareth, it was authoritatively learned here today.

SEATTLE, June 22 (AP) -- The American Association of University Women took steps today to prevent a branch group from ever again barring a Negro woman college graduate from membership. An amendment to the by-laws changed the membership policy concerning branches.

The sale of Pier 14, Hoboken, to the Bethlehem Steel Company by Webb Knapp, Inc., was announced yesterday by William Zeckendorf, president of the realty company. The property had been under lease to the purchaser since 1943 and the sum involved in the present transaction was not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Two "middle of the road" proposals for handling emergency labor disputes affecting national health and safety were overwhelmingly defeated in the Senate today. In both cases the "extreme" pro-Taft-Hartley injunction advocates and those who favored the Administration's labor bill without alteration "ganged up" to put down the compromise formulas.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 22 -- Twenty thousand Christian Arabs of the Jerusalem area see international rule for the whole region as their only hope, according to a series of opinions just gathered there.
New York's famous Metropolitan Opera House at Broadway and Fortieth Street added a $10,000 fire to its long and dramatic career yesterday afternoon.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 22 -- For almost a month, the United Nations Information Office in Prague has given day and night asylum to a Czech employe wanted by the police for suspected "anti-government" activities, it became known here today.

OLOMOUC, Czechoslovakia, June 22 -- Archbishop Josef Karl Matocha, second ranking prelate of Czechoslovakia, left his residence today to preside over the confirmation class of Catholic girls at Svaty Kopecek church. He made no reference to the church-state conflict.
The tie-up affecting six major bread and cake bakeries and their 4,200 workers in New York took a long step yesterday toward settlement.

Unusual floor coverings that are related in pattern and color to drapery designs and wallpaper are being sponsored by Julore and are available through decorators from the concern's new showroom which opened yesterday at 13 East Fifty-third Street.

An honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from New York University was conferred yesterday afternoon by the university's chancellor, Harry Woodburn Chase, upon Mrs. Jessica G. Cosgrave, founder and president of Finch Junior College here.

With prices down on blouses, scarves, hosiery, gloves and costume jewelry, retailers' accessory departments are in an outstanding position to increase both their unit and dollar sales this fall, according to speakers at the fall accessory clinic held by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers, in the Statler Hotel yesterday.

Increases in the retail price of gasoline will cost the motorists of New York State an additional $18,500,000 this year, according to estimates yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York. This figure was based upon two raises of one-half cent each a gallon since last Dec. 1.

Although there has been some decline in new business, the structural steel fabricating industry is continuing to operate at a high level because of its heavy backlog of unfilled orders, L. Abbett Post executive vice president of the American Institute of Steel Construction, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 15:

SCHEVENINGEN, The Netherlands, June 22 -- Julius Katchen, 22-year-old expatriate American pianist, scored a success tonight in the Brahms Second Concerto with The Hague Residence Orchestra, conducted by Ernest Ansermet. The concert, given in the seaside Kursaal Auditorium, opened the second week of the Holland Festival.

" Call It Treason," by George Howe, which won the $15,000 Cristophers Award, has been scheduled for August publication by the Viking Press. It is a story about a German prisoner of war who volunteered to be dropped behind the lines as a spy for the American Army.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 22 - William Bell Clark of Evanston, Ill., was elected president of the General Society, Sons of the Revolution, as its three-day triennal convention, attended by 150 delegates from twenty state societies concluded here today.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 (AP) -- The Pirates walloped the Phillies, 12 -- 3, today as Dino Restelli smacked the fourth and fifth homers of his week-long major league career before the smallest home crowd of the season.

It is a wise girl who does her fashion arithmetic in separates, for these interchangeables with just a handful of bright accessories do wonders at making several costumese possible with just a few pieces.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 22 -- Mrs. Catherine Fox Park of Glen Ridge and Mrs. Joseph J. Mason of Ridgewood took a 1-stroke lead today in the twenty-fourth annual 54-hole medal play championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Upper Montclair Country Club.

At least four American-flag shipping companies, concerned over the bombing of the British freighter Anchises and generally unsettled conditions in the Shanghai area of China, have decided to by-pass the port at least temporarily, it became known yesterday.

With rain still only a prediction, a prophecy of the fabrics which will best shed the showers was presented last evening by the New York Raincoat Manufacturers' Association in a fashion show held at the Waldorf-Astoria.

SEOUL, Korea, June 22 -- Government sources declared today that a plot to deliver control of the National Assembly to North Korean Communists coincidentally with the overthrow of the Government here had led to the arrests of the five members of the Assembly last night on charges of endangering the republic's security.

HONOLULU, June 22 -- Gov. Ingram M. Stainback's emergency fact-finding board heard rebuttal argument today and began writing recommendations aimed at settling the longshoremen's strike that has paralyzed shipping to and from Hawaii for fifty-two days.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 22 -- A quick-witted pilot crash-landed a burning American Airlines plane on the edge of a pea patch today, saving the lives of the forty-three persons aboard.

Israel has an industrial, trading and financial potential in the Middle East that may some day make it the counterpart of what England has been historically to the world but it is not a place in which to get rich quick.

In 1949 there is a new emphasis on individual responsibility instead of a "social approach to the solution of human needs," Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, told 2,500 persons last night at the ninety-sixth commencement of Hunter College.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Debate on the bitterly contested National Housing Bill got under way today with 83-year-old Representative Adolph J. Sabath, Democrat, of Illinois, exchanging blows on the House floor with Representative Eugene E. Cox, 69, Democrat, of Georgia.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- In a bout that bore not even a faint resemblance to the twenty-five title struggles in which Joe Louis engaged during his twelve-year reign, Ezzard Charles, 28-year-old Cincinnati Negro, tonight gained partial recognition as successor to the world heavyweight championship Louis relinquished when he retired from the ring.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 22 -- John Foster Dulles, who served as Republican foreign policy adviser to Secretary of State Dean Acheson at the Paris meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, said today that both within the Soviet Union and in the satellite countries "events may be shaping up to a new and intense struggle," comparable to that which took place during the Soviet purges in 1937 and 1938.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Government-owned town of Richland, Wash., is operated under a system that permits "a complete and practical throttling of free enterprise," Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, declared today.

Mrs. Vera S. Bragg's Fox Time, appearing in stakes competition for the second time, ran off with first money of $9,000 in the $12,675 Tremont at steamy Aqueduct yesterday. The sprint drew half a dozen 2-year-olds, and at the end of the five and a half furlongs Fox Time was a length and a half clear.
The police spent yesterday and part of last night grappling in Bronx waters for the bodies of two bathers believed to have been drowned.

Lewyt Corporation will stockpile production of its new and improved domestic vacuum cleaner until Aug. 20 to give dealers opportunity to liquidate inventories of the current model, Alex M. Lewyt, president, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22--Ten members of the House brought back to the Capital tonight a graphic story of appalling slum conditions still existing in New York City and Philadelphia despite herculean efforts in the last decade to eradicate them.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The profits of the country's largest manufacturing companies in the first quarter of 1949 were about 15 per cent below those of the last quarter of 1948, but 10 per cent larger than those of the first quarter of last year, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

A Yonkers policeman came ten yards into New York City at 3 A. M. yesterday to function in an emergency and if there are any complaints that he was functioning outside of his home city, he can cite the law of continuous pursuit that justifies such acts.

It wasn't easy, but the first-place Yankees split a double-header with the last-place Browns yesterday at the Stadium. None too robust, even while winning the nightcap, 10 -- 8, the staggering forces of Casey Stengel barely averted a shut-out in the opener, which went to the visitors, 5 -- 1.

A joint broad-scale sales promotion program to increase sales of men's wool clothing throughout the nation was initiated yesterday at a meeting of leading men's clothing manufacturers and the wool bureau. The program will be developed and carried out by a men's clothing manufacturers committee, headed by Michael Daroff of H. Daroff Sons.

Because in this era of scientific progress suede is no longer considered an impractical fabric it has stepped up to a leading place in the world of fashion for this autumn. Yesterday morning the press saw a preview of a handsome collection by Samuel Robert of Haverhill, Mass., at a breakfast show at Chatham Walk.

Felix Frankfurter and Stanley F. Reed, associate justices of the Supreme Court of the United States, testified as character witnesses for Alger Hiss yesterday as his defense against Federal perjury charges shifted into high gear on its second day in Federal court.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Judith Coplon cried out at her espionage trial today that she is being "framed" and that Federal prosecutors are seeking to "brand me a harlot."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 22 -- The Right Rev. Dr. Charles K. Gilbert, New York Episcopal Bishop, added his protest yesterday to others on an article in a Vassar College publication that allegedly attacked Christianity.

LONDON, June 22 -- Unilateral action by the State of Israel to create a free zone in the port of Haifa for use of the Kingdom of Jordan was reliably reported today to be under consideration by the Tel Aviv Government. Some quarters thought that the Israeli Cabinet might announce its decision on the free zone within a few days.
GENEVA, June 22 -- The problem of displaced persons cannot be solved without "radical changes" in national immigration policies, the International Refugee Organization stated today.

The latest report of the Prison Association of New York, one hundred and fourth in a series stretching back without a break to 1845, is a fascinating document on the myriad penal problems affecting this state and city.

The Maritime Commission has invited nineteen shipyards to submit bids for the construction of a combination passenger-cargo vessel for operation on the Mississippi Shipping Company's Delta Line service, it was announced here yesterday.

Two new films are on today's opening schedule. "Look for the Silver Lining," a musical in Technicolor with biographical overtones concerning the career of the late musical comedy star, Marilyn Miller, will begin an engagement at the Radio City Music Hall. June

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 22 -- A new concept of organized Jewish life in America centering on "a voluntary community dedicated to an organic view of Judaism" was advocated today by Rabbi Robert, Gordis, president of the Synagogue Council of America in an address before the Rabbinical Assembly of America.
General terms for the public offering of $22,700,000 of Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority Revenue bonds are being discussed, underwriting circles here learned yesterday.

Trustees of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, which was placed in receivership Tuesday by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman, held their first meeting yesterday to acquaint themselves with the company's problems.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Ten pitchers, five on each side, paraded today when the Cubs nosed out the Braves, 9 to 8, before 12,306 spectators.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 22 (AP) -- Alabama moved swiftly today on two fronts to unmask and punish hooded hoodlums. At the same time a Congressional inquiry into the white-sheeted mobs was ordered in Washington.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 22 -- Miss Rosalind Kaufman of Sunningdale eliminated two favorites to enter the semi-finals of the fifth annual women's tri-county championship being contested over the sun-baked Innis Arden golf course today.

Investors have "softened their attitude" toward Negroes and other minority groups in the field of housing, Thomas G. Grace, New York director of the Federal Housing Administration, asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The program to modernize two aircraft carriers of World War II, approved by the President at the instance of the Secretary of Defense, has had several good effects. It partly relieved the anxieties of those who feared, when the Navy's super-carrier was scrapped, that our military policy had become a dangerous reliance on big land-based bombers.
ROME, June 22 -- The Italian Parliament today abandoned its planned mediation efforts to settle the forty - day - old farmhands' strike because the landowners refused to be bound by its decision.

Moses H. Bresler was elected president of the Lamport Company, Inc., at yesterday's board meeting which followed the annual meeting of stockholders of the cotto goods converting and distributing firm. Gerson Reichman was elected executive vice president and treasurer.

CHICAGO, June 22--The wheat market turned reactionary on the Board of Trade today, but more aggressive buying developed in corn. The latter was up around 2 cents a bushel at one time to a new high in over two weeks, closing at the top with gains of 1 to 1 7/8 cents.

The current series of Public Utility Round Tables conducted by the Irving Trust Company under the direction of Tom P. Walker, vice president, will be concluded today and tomorrow at the bank's offices, 1 Wall Street. Senior financial officers of electric and gas-operating companies have discussed the various phases of corporate financing during the series, which has consisted of fifteen sessions.

SHANGHAI, June 22 -- As a British warship escorted one British merchantman into the mouth of the Yangtze this morning, Nationalist planes again attacked the British cargo-liner Anchises, which was forced aground yesterday in the Whangpoo River by a dive-bombing attack.

WASHINGTON, June 22---Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, and his highest military snd fiscal advisers today supported President Truman's national defense budget request with an up-to-the-minute briefing to key Senators on the world conditions viewed as making necessary such a vast outlay for arms in time of peace.

Although medical treatment for tuberculosis has been greatly improved in the last few decades the number of patients being admitted to hospitals for therapy has constantly increased, according to speakers at the annual Tuberculosis Sanatorium Conference yesterday afternoon in Triboro Hospital, Queens.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 22 -- Frank Purnell, president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and one of the nation's steel leaders, does not see much chance of any important reductions in prices of steel very soon.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Bearing out earlier forecasts of bigger pork supplies to come, an Agriculture Department survey today put the 1949 spring pig crop at 59,040,000 head. This is an increase of 15 per cent over last year's spring crop.

Representatives of the machine-tool industry reported yesterday that the downward trend of machine-tool sales has ended and more and more manufacturers are realizing they must buy new tools to cut production costs. Speaking after a closed meeting of the National Machine Tool Builders Association in the Biltmore Hotel, officials estimated that sales have "leveled off" at about 10 per cent below the 1948 average.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 22 -- Northern soft coal operators, here to negotiate a new wage agreement with John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers, said today they considered their present contract effective until Aug. 14 and that the miners can't strike then because of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Spearheaded by the League of New York Theatres, the organization of theatre owners, producers and managers, a delegation of prominent people in the legitimate and motion-picture fields will appear at City Hall next Tuesday at 11:30 A. M. to strongly protest a proposed local law that would invest the License Commissioner with broader powers over theatrical exhibitions, performers and advertising.

Dr. Margaret Kiely, acting president of Queens College, conferred degrees on 331 students, the largest graduating class in the history of Queens College, at the college's fifteenth commencement exercises yesterday aftrnoon on the college quadrangle.

BATAVIA, Java, June 22 -- The United Nations Commission for Indonesia announced today agreements reached by the Commission and the Dutch and Indonesian Republican and Federalist delegations under which Netherland troops will begin their withdrawal from Jogjakarta Friday.

The appointment of Bernard R. Mullady as assistant to the chairman of the Maritime Commission, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, was announced yesterday. Mr. Mullady served as director of information in the Federal Works Agency under General Fleming until the latter resigned as FWA Administrator to become chairman of the commission on June 6.

Details of the plan under which the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (CARE), 20 Broad Street, will supply scientific and technical books to libraries abroad, were outlined yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- A New York doctor who said he spoke for about 1,600 physicians today endorsed President Truman's national health insurance program.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled illegal today the way most building trades unions act as hiring agents for building contractors.

The Dana Corporation and its subsidiaries, primarily producers of parts for the automotive industry, reported yesterday a net profit of $6,116,321 after all charges, including $4,430,000 taxes, for the nine months ended on May 31.

The comprehensive Hopley report on civil defense, prepared after painstaking research and planning under the direction of the late Secretary of Defense James Forrestal, has been virtually shelved, it was learned yesterday.
GENEVA, June 22 -- Despite a decline in manufacturing employment, the "economic situation in the United States of America is good." Michael J. Galvin, Under-Secretary of Labor, said here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 -- Leon Gellman of Brooklyn, president of the Mizrachi Organization of America, said tonight that "under present circumstances, with the Jewish people standing at the crossroads of their history, any entertainment of the dissolution of the world Zionist parties is absurd and ludicrous."

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 22 -- Congregationalists were warned today against placing credence in the Vatican's "unilateral action" in describing the conflict with communism "in terms of a holy crusade." Protestants, they were told, "should make it clear that they are not allies of the Roman Catholic heirarchy."

The Overseas Affairs Branch of the Department of the Army asked a question yesterday. Are today's American girls a group of stay-at-homes? Despite reports that this year's college graduates will face the tightest employment market since pre-war days, 150 jobs as recreation directors in Japan, Okinawa and Guam have gone begging for three weeks.
BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- The Tigers today clubbed a quartet of Red Sox pitchers for a 13-4 victory. The loss, before 9,292 fans, snapped a Boston winning streak of six games.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation will make a net profit of $10,635,000 in the fiscal year that ends on June 30, Harvey J. Gunderson, a director of the agency, told a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- A step toward discovery of the cause of toxemia of pregnancy, which accounts for one-fourth of the maternity deaths in this country, was announced today by the Public Health Service.

Mrs. Brunhilde Eisler, wife of Gerhart Eisler, was deported from La Guardia Airport yesterday on an American Overseas Airline plane going to London. The spouse of the man described as America's No. 1 Communist said she would proceed to Poland by way of Copenhagen, thence to Berlin to rejoin her husband.

This week-end is traditionally the climactic one of the year for the ancient sport of rowing. Tomorrow at New London Yale crosses blades with Harvard on the Housatonic. On Saturday the second of rowing's Big Two regattas churns the tide and wind at Poughkeepsie.
PARIS, June 22 -- Producers of the motion-picture "The Divine Tragedy," which will deal with the Passion of Christ, have received encouragement from Pope Pius XII.

CINCINNATI, June 22 -- The Reds today finally scored their second victory in ten meetings with the Dodgers with two out in the eleventh inning -- and even then Carl Furillo's rifle arm almost nailed the winning run at the plate.
