The army in Israel is showing a tendency to play a greater role than it should in a democratic state, Hayim Greenberg, a member of the Jewish Agency executive heading its department of culture and education, declared yesterday.

In another week or so Grand Central Terminal will resemble Madison Square Garden at circus time. There will be the same milling crowd of the excited young, subdued here and there by harassed and gloomy representatives of the old.

The taxpayer containing three stores at 44-48 East Main Street in Patchogue, L. I., has been bought by Louis Cooper from Maurice Levin of Hearns Department Store for cash above mortgages of $105,000 in a deal negotiated by Arthur Greenbaum, broker. The property occupies a plot 47 by 150 feet. Rivkin Rosen represented the seller and Olesker Silvan acted for the purchaser.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 22 -- Harold L. Ickes advised Radcliffe College's 211 graduating seniors today "to be chary about taking any advice whatever from people of my generation."

MOSCOW, June 22 -- In a series of editorials and commentaries marking the eighth anniversary of the German attack on Russia, Soviet newspapers warned what it called United States and British "imperialists" that their "nightmarish plans of world domination" were headed for the same fate as Hitler.

LONDON, June 22 (AP) -- Bob Falkenburg scratched himself and Miss Gertrude Moran from the mixed doubles today to conserve his physical resources for an all-out defense of his Wimbledon men's singles tennis championship.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 22 (AP) -- Choice Cut was a driving winner of the Rivalry Purse at Monmouth Park today. The chestnut gelding, owned by J. H. Rouse, defeated six other 3-year-olds with a determined stretch charge, scoring by three-fourths of a length in 1:44 2-5.

The current American Federation of Labor contract covering operation of the Bethlehem Steel Company's West Coast shipyards will continue in force for another year without any change in wage rates or other conditions, it was announced here yesterday by D. D. Strohmeier, vice president in charge of the company's shipbuilding division. The contract was to expire on Saturday.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 22 (AP) -- Death in a prison hospital closed the record today on one of the famous kidnap cases of America's turbulent '30's.
FRANKFORT, Germany, June 22 -- A new political movement was founded today in the Rhine River resort city of Bad Godesberg by reputed militarists, nationalists and agitators.
Net income of the Electric Bond and Share Company was $2,401,207, or 46 cents a share, in the twelve months to March 31, compared with $2,795,190, or 53 cents a share in the preceding twelve months.

Was there ever an English novel written in which the characters did not at one point savor gooseberry jam? That fruit that seems synonymous with tea on a British afternoon is now enjoying its short season in New York markets. But contrary to what prevails abroad, here there are few devotees of the berries, and little is known of their cookery.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Under a system worked out with the National Federation of American Shipping, representing a major portion of the maritime industry, the Army now will begin diverting much of its overseas grain cargoes to private shipping, it was announced here today.

The extent to which business has moved nearer the customer, instead of requiring that the customer do the traveling, is revealed in an interesting survey made by the Regional Plan Association. This study puts the number of branch stores established by New York City department stores at forty-eight, most of these branches being in suburban areas.

Pointing out that extreme caution on the part of wholesale buyers is emptying pipelines of distribution, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, warned yesterday that continued restriction of cotton goods inventories could prove a costly gamble.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 22 -- The forty-first Governors' Conference, at its final meeting today, adopted a resolution pledging continued support of the United Nations, approving the European Recovery Program and urging ratification of the North Atlantic Pact by the United States Senate and necessary action to implement the pact and give it full effect.

In his statement on the results of the Paris conference, President Truman hailed the still incomplete agreement on Austria as "genuine progress," promising that country a peace settlement which will free it from the occupation regime and preserve its vital interests. The Austrians themselves are jubilant because they appear to have escaped further dismemberment and because they see fulfillment of their prayer to be "liberated from their liberators."

The six-story building at 251-57 West Forty-second Street containing the general offices and a store of the Loft Candy Corporation has been sold by the Loft chain to Southern Equities, Inc., of 295 Madison Avenue, in a deal negotiated by Albert M. Greenfield Co., brokers. The Loft interests will continue to occupy the building under a long-term lease arranged with the new owners. The structure is assessed for $860,000 and abuts the Hotel Dixie.

Special Sessions Justice Nathan D. Perlman yesterday gave a short reply and a three-month workhouse term to an admitted rent gouger whose attorney argued that incarceration would serve "no useful purpose."
BALDWLN, L. I., June 22 -- Al Brosch, the red-haired Cherry Valley Club pro, won the Long Island open golf championship for the fourth consecutive year as he posted a 54-hole total of 214.

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during May totaled 210,677,488 lines, a gain of 6.5 per cent over the like month of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. The year-to-date gain was 4.1 per cent. Categories showing May gains were: Automotive, up 26.4 per cent; retail, 9.7 per cent, and general, 8.6 per cent.

The Atlantic Union Committee, 537 Fifth Avenue, which works for a federation of democracies that sponsored the Atlantic Pact, will begin a fund-raising drive Monday, it was announced at a planning luncheon yesterday at the Building Trade Association, 2 Park Avenue.

In its appeals for help for the needy in Europe CARE has made effective use of the slogan "Our Friends Abroad Are Hungry." The organization has now announced some of the details of the program with which it hopes to meet another kind of hunger, the hunger of the mind, through the dispatch of scientific and technical books to libraries abroad.
BARI, June 23 (Reuters) -- Divers searching the submerged wreckage of the KLM plane had to give up tonight because of rough seas.
GENEVA, June 23 -- The International Labor Organization declared reluctantly today that it could not distinguish between free and puppet trade unions in the present state of the world.

Immediately after his return from Paris Secretary Acheson went before Senate and House committees to urge action on the North Atlantic Treaty and on military aid to Europe before Congress adjourns. Both these measures, he declared, are of the utmost importance if we are to maintain the firm American policy in Europe that has already stimulated a momentum toward peace.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Preston T. Tucker and six associates in the ill-fated Tucker Corporation entered pleas of not guilty today when arraigned before Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan on charges of violating mail fraud statutes and securities laws. A

WASHINGTON, June 23 (By Science Service) -- Infantile paralysis cases increased slightly during the week ending June 18, latest reports to the United States Public Health Service here showed. The latest figure for the nation is 271 cases, exclusive of Idaho.
License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey revoked last night the license of the Arrow Laundry, 1011 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn, after a hearing in his office that lasted more than seven hours.

Miss Mary H. Donlon, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board and chief architect of the disability insurance program enacted this year, is being considered by the Republican State leadership for appointment to the United States Senate in the event Senator Robert F. Wagner resigns.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -- The Senate tonight was blocked from acting on the nomination of W. Walton Butterworth as Assistant Secretary of State in charge of Far Eastern Affairs.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., June 23 -- Lloyd Ribner of Fenway, finalist last year in the New York State amateur golf championship, captured the British Victory tournament over the Sleepy Hollow Country Club course today with a 36-hole aggregate of 149.

Emphasizing that management should "listen" to employes to find out what they want to know about business, instead of merely telling them management's story, the National Association of Manufacturers announced yesterday the publication of a new booklet, "Employe Communications for Better Understanding."

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 23 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of the Greenwich C. C. and Mrs. T. A. Menzel of the home club, reached the final round of the fifth Tri-County Women's Golf championship over the Innis Arden course today.

The four-month downturn in business loans from banks in this area, which during recent weeks showed signs of leveling off, renewed its downward momentum during the week ended on Wednesday, dropping $65,000,000. Data issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed that commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City banks, after seventeen successive weekly declines, now total $4,708,000,000, the lowest level since Oct. 1, 1947.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 23 (AP) -- George Hallenbeck, president of the State Building Industry Employers, said tonight that the industry is in a "very healthy condition" in New York and that "it's a good time to build." He added, however, that the industry cannot afford to raise wages.

Liquidation of the Federal Barge Lines, serving New Orleans and the Midwest on the Mississippi River was urged yesterday by the Port of New York Authority at a hearing in Washington before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, according to an announcement made here last night.

Further evidence of the declining trend in iron and steel operations appeared yesterday when the two largest producers in the industry effected additional cutbacks and the price of the top grade of steel-making scrap dropped $2 a ton in Pittsburgh.

Blueberries, perhaps for a pie, definitely belong on this weekend's shopping list. Last Friday the fruit was 59 cents a pint. Today, as the season rather abruptly comes to its peak, the price is 29 cents in several chains, while the city-wide average has dropped 14 cents to 45 a pint.

LONDON, June 23 -- In a dramatic and eloquent speech in the House of Lords today Lord Milverton, a former British colonial governor, announced his resignation from the Labor party, which, he declared, was leading Britain toward the brink of totalitarianism.

American-flag passenger ship service between New York and South Africa will be re-established next month with the sailing on July 30 of the African Enterprise of the Farrell Lines, Inc., it was announced yesterday by James A. Farrell Jr., president.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- An examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today that the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad be permitted to obtain control of the Pullman Railroad Company.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 23 -- Israel reacted coolly today to the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission's report that criticized her attitude toward the Arab refugees. Only one or two smaller newspapers will comment editorially tomorrow morning.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- A fourteen-hit attack, which included Sam Chapman's eighth homer of the year, carried the Athletics to an easy 11-4 decision over the White Sox tonight as rookie southpaw Alex Kellner chalked up his tenth pitching triumph.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange lacked a definite trend yesterday, and final prices were 20 points lower to 3 points higher.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, June 23 -- The annual convention of the Young Republican National Federation opened here today with several hundred delegates in a fighting mood, many of them ready to battle domination of the federation by the Old Guard party leaders.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- The Braves pounded five hurlers for 15 hits today for a 12-5 triumph that split a four-game series with the Cubs.

MOSCOW, June 23 -- Dr. Frederic Joliot-Curie, chairman of the French Atomic Energy Commission, charged in an article published in the Soviet journal Zvesda today that the United States was attempting to negotiate on atomic control "with a revolver in its hand" and seeking to impose its will "under threat of war."

IN all probability more books and learned papers have been written about Edgar Allan Poe than about any other American writer. If the present Melville boom continues for another fifty years this may not always be so. But there will have to be a depressing lot of poor biographies, poor novels and poor plays about Melville before Poe is overtaken.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 23 -- Official Military Government sources said today that they were studying carefully the implications of the forming yesterday of a new political movement by a group of ultra-nationalists and reactionaries who call themselves the Association of Independent Germans.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., has finished negotiations with co-owners of Paramount - Richards Theatres, Inc., and Paramount-Richards Enterprises, Inc., and with co-owners of the Pennecom Corporation, Barney Balaban, president of Paramount, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The drive for Hawaii statehood hit a new obstacle today in a Senate Interior and Insular Affairs subcommittee report recommending that the issue be deferred until the Territorial Government stamped out Communist influence in the islands.

CINCINNATI, June 23 -- The Dodgers retained their half-game National League lead over the Cardinals today when they came from behind -- although not far -- to outscore the Reds, 7 -- 2, and take the series, two games to one.

Seven of the eight contests being claimers, there wasn't much to the racing at Aqueduct yesterday, but there'll be big doings today. For in a seven-furlong sprint that will be run fifth, King Ranch's Assault, triple-crowner of 1946 and one of the great race horses of the decade, will open his comeback campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UP) -- The Justice Department said today that a long-standing "monopoly" in the glass fiber industry will be broken up under a consent judgement handed down today by the Federal District Court in Toledo, Ohio.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday he would not request a commutation of the death sentence of John M. Dunn, convicted slayer, unless the latter provided information that might lead to the solution of unsolved waterfront crimes.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 23 -- Dr. Abraham J. Feldman, president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, embracing the Reform rabbinate, today warned against an attempt to institute any form of theocracy in Israel.

The report of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., Canadian distillers, and its subsidiaries for the nine months ended with May showed a net profit in Canadian currency of $19,643,269 after all charges.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Legislation authorizing an organized merchant marine reserve of officers and unlicensed men was received coldly today at a hearing before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Pending legislation designed to modernize the Government's role in civil aviation will be deferred until the National Military Establishment completes a survey on civil aviation in national defense, it was learned today.

RANGOON, Burma, June 23 (AP) -- The Government today announced that Karen rebels had occupied the cigar-making center of Danubyu but reported that a Burmese army sweep was recapturing villages north of Moulmein.

The New York State Plan for fighting rabies has reduced the number of dogs carrying the infection in this state to less than 1 per cent of cases reported in 1945, Dr. Alexander Zeissig, an American authority on rabies, told the New York State Veterinary Medical Society's fifty-eighth annual meeting at the Hotel Statler yesterday.
The first white marlin of the season was brought in to Ocean City, Md., on Wednesday, and was brought in from the famous "Jack Spot" off the coast of this popular sport fishing port.

Invitations to submit bids to fill the requirements of government purchasing agencies, issued in a bulletin by the Department of Commerce of the City of New York, included such items as 353,080 pounds of laundry soap, 666,000 pounds of laundry starch, 1,508,000 cotton sheets, 5,000,000 square yards of cotton cloth and 328,500 pounds of wiping cloth.

LONDON, June 23 -- Forecasting revolt unless Pakistan "will see reason," Sardar Faiz Mohammed Khan, the Afghan Ambassador to Britain, said today that his country would seek Britain's aid in her dispute with Pakistan over the future of 7,000,000 Pathans in the North - West Frontier Province and in the adjoining Tribal Area.
Charles M. Hollis has been appointed controller of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, Willow Run, Mich.

BOSTON, June 23 -- The first permanent installation of a Tracerlab beta gauge in a paper mill has been made at the Continental Paper Company's plant in Ridgefield Park, N. J., it was announced here today by W. E. Barbour Jr. of Tracerlab, Inc.

NEW DELHI, India, June 23 -- Charges of corruption among highly placed members of the Congress party in several provinces have forced themselves upon the attention of party executives here and there is now a quiet movement to "clean house" before Congress party prestige declines further.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 23 -- A new attack on the housing problem of families of moderately low income in this state, having as its basis cooperative community action to help bring rents down, was offered here tonight by Harry P. Ruppert, president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 23 -- The Rev. Paul W. Dieckman, administrative assistant at Wagner College, Staten Island, N. Y., has been named director of the Eastern States region for the $6,000,000 Christian Higher Education Appeal to be held by the United Lutheran Church in America in 1950.

Anxious to do all in their power "to reduce the present staggering, cost of production," the Committee of Theatrical Producers accepted the first report on the problem at its meeting yesterday in the Hotel St. Regis. Divided into three recommendations, the report was submitted by Lawrence Langner, temporary chairman of the subcommittee on costs.

Charles H. Silver, American Woolen Company executive, who has been mentioned prominently as a possible Democratic nominee for Mayor, announced last night that he would not seek any mayoralty designation.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Action by the Senate at this session on the Administration bill to open wider this country's doors to the homeless of Europe was promised today by Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, the Democratic floor leader.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 18 were 8 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Fifty-six Senators, constituting seven more than a bare majority of the upper House, had signed a bipartisan petition tonight to force a voting showdown on an economy resolution to direct the President to cut 5 to 10 per cent from the billions of dollars appropriated to the executive branch for the fiscal year starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- An extra allotment of $33,000,000 for grants to states for administering their job-finding and jobless payments programs was recommended today by the House Appropriations Committee.

TOKYO, June 23 -- Forged newsprint ration coupons have been revealed as a main source of the Japanese Communist party's income, the newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun alleged today. The paper said that twenty-seven had been arrested so far and that one leading Communist was still at large despite a police search.
A special order authorizing the Fifth Avenue Coach Company to charge a 12-cent fare effective at one minute after midnight tonight was issued yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Second Baseman Joe Gordon's leaping stab of Eddie Robinson's liner with the tying run on third base and two out in the ninth preserved a 4-3 victory for the Indians over the Senators tonight before a crowd of 21,694.

SEATTLE, June 23 -- The Washington, D. C., branch of the American Association of University Women seceded tonight from the national body because its convention voted to guarantee membership to Negroes.

The election of nine bankers, builders and others interested in housing to the board of directors of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council of New York, Inc., was announced yesterday by Ira S. Robbins, executive vice president.

OLOMOUC, Czechoslovakia, June 23 -- Church sources here today disclosed that two priests on Archbishop Josef Karls Matocha's staff had been arrested in his palace last Tuesday, that police had searched the palace on Thursday and Friday and that a representative of the Ministry of Education had moved into the Archbishop's consistory on Friday.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Attorney General Clark today charged there is a conspiracy to restrain trade in the making of plastic artificial eyes.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Department of Agriculture today set July 5 as the deadline for all interested persons to voice their views as to the desirability of curtailing the 1950 wheat crop.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 23 -- Dean Edgar S. Furniss, Provost of Yale University, announced today that Chester B. Kerr, a former director of the Atlantic Monthly Press, had been appointed secretary of the Yale University Press.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Hypnotism is dangerous in the hands of inexperienced persons and should be prohibited by law from being used for entertainment purposes, a consultant to the Journal of the American Medical Association asserted today in the current issue of that publication.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Directors of the Cudahy Packing Company today voted to withhold dividend payment on the common stock. Two quarterly payments of 15 cents each have been made this year, and 60 cents was paid in 1948.

PARIS, June 23 -- In view of "widespread apprehensions" in the dollar areas over food surpluses, the World Food Council today instructed its Director General, Norris E. Dodd, to prepare detailed commodity reports and recommendations for action.
Two well-known liquor brands will be reduced at retail effective July 1, and the amount of aged whisky in another will be increased without a rise in price, it was learned here yesterday.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., June 23 -- Today this city became a world center for stainless steel wire production, following the official opening of a new mill with a rated capacity of 500 tons a month at ceremonies conducted by Clifford F. Hood, president of the American Steel and Wire Company, subsidary of the United States Steel Corporation.

CAIRO, June 23 (UP) -- Premier Ibrahim Abdul Hadi Pasha announced today that Egypt's first general parliamentary election in nearly five years would be held in October and that martial law would be suspended to insure a free campaign.

Under a recently enacted statute of the state of Wisconsin, checks drawn on any bank or trust company organized under the laws of that state shall be cleared at par, effective June 20, 1949, and, therefore, all checks drawn on such banks will be received by Federal Reserve Banks for collection and credit, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York explained yesterday in a memorandum issued to all banks in this district.

Berlin, Tokyo and ten other foreign capitals will be hosts this summer to twenty-eight leaders of American business, labor, education and civic activity when America's Town Meeting of the Air celebrates its fifteenth year by taking a round-the-world tour.

Furniture production is currently running approximately 20 per cent behind last year as a result of a steady decline in retail orders since last November, according to the monthly report for May issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants for many leading furniture factories.
THE TIMES of June 17 carries a letter to the editor by Emerson P. Schmidt of the United States Chamber of Commerce, opposing the Housing Bill. The arguments raised by Mr. Schmidt are fallacious.
Rank and file bakery drivers revolted last night against the leadership of their union and rejected a tentative settlement arranged the day before with six major producers of bread and cake.

LOS ANGELES, June 23 (AP) - Fall fashions for the young fry include everything from hoopskirts to sophisticated adult styles at the Apparel Creators of California fashion show for infants-through-teens.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The possibility that some Uranium-235 has been lost at the Oak Ridge atomic energy plant has not been entirely ruled out by officials there, it was disclosed today.

PERTH AMBOY, N. J., June 23 -- Three men, two of whom were volunteer firemen, were killed and eight other men, including two firemen, were injured today when an explosion in a large asphalt storage tank started a fire that swept through the plant of the California Refining Company near the waterfront here.

The six months' custody fight for his four children by Zoel N. Lynch, California Sunday school teacher, appeared to be ended yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber fined Mrs. Marianne Lynch Teitelbaum, Mr. Lynch's former wife, and her husband, Rubin, $250 each for their failure to comply with a court order directing that the children be returned to their father.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Grain markets developed a reactionary tendency on the Board of Trade here today, general profit-taking having a depressing effect. However, the volume of business was well below that of the previous day and short covering caused a rally in wheat and corn from the low for the day.

One characteristic of honeymoons, as has been frequently remarked, is that they always end. What comes after is often more satisfactory and stable, but it is not a honeymoon. Assistant Secretary of State Willard L. Thorp applied this truism to international economic relations in his address yesterday at Wellesley, Mass.

NEWARK, N. J., June 23 -- A petition by August Klapprott, former Eastern States Bund leader, for restoration of his United States citizenship, ordered revoked by default in a Government proceeding in 1942, was denied today in a decision by Federal District Court Judge Arthur F. Lederle.

Unless a measure repealing, or reducing, the 20 per cent Federal retail excise tax can be made a "rider" on some other piece of legislation, chances are extremely slight for action this session of Congress, trade sources reported yesterday.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 23 -- Delegates to the forty-ninth annual convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of America warned American Jews today that they risk their "survival as a community" unless they provide more support for their religious and cultural institutions.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- During the week ended June 22 member bank reserve balances decreased $292,000,000 the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Librarians and library trustees of Westchester County have taken the first steps toward formation of a county library, and have heard discussions by Chancellor Wallin of the Board of Regents and others on what form proposed state aid to libraries might take. We welcome both of these events as evidence of an awakening public determination to improve library service.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 23 (AP) -- Hungary's strong man, Vice Premier Matyas Rakosi, said tonight that 200,000 persons -- about 18 per cent of the membership -- had been expelled from the Hungarian Communist party.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP) -- Maurice McDermott, a rookie left-hander, pitched a three-hit shutout tonight in steering the Red Sox to a 7-0 triumph over the Browns. McDermott faced only 28 batters in gaining his second major league victory.
Coffee futures prices declined on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Truman is expected to send a message to Congress within a month dealing with the unemployment situation, according to a group of Democratic Congressional callers at the White House today. The message, it was said, will accompany the mid-year report of the Council of Economic Advisers.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The government has invested $32,500,000 in the Lustron Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, and "I would not be surprised if they asked us tomorrow for more money," Harvey J. Gunderson, a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation said today.
TORONTO, June 23 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock, Ark., took the lead at the half-way point in the Canadian open golf championship today with a 36-hole score of 133.

LONDON, June 23 -- Interest again centered on British Government bonds in the stock market here today. Fresh selling lowered prices at the opening but around midday bargain hunters stepped in and prices began to climb back. Prices fluctuated rapidly, but at the close there were only small gains and losses.

Municipal bus operation at the base fare of 7 cents charged since July 1, 1948, resulted in a deficit of $4,574,883 for the nine months ended March 31, as compared with a loss of only $4,567,341 for the entire year ended June 30, 1948, when the fare was only a nickel.

There is no overproduction in the men's clothing industry, according to quarterly figures released jointly yesterday by the business information division of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and by the market planning service of the National Credit Office, Inc.

PITTSBURGH, June 23 -- As expected, the stoppage in bituminous coal production resulted in a pronounced drop in the level of business in the district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. Despite a fractional gain in steel mill operations, industrial production was down sharply.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 23 -- John L. Lewis president of the United Mine Workers, told a soft-coal wage conference today that he wanted to talk about increased wages, a shorter work day, and improvements in the miners' welfare and retirement fund.

RIO DE JANIERO, June 23 -- Beginning July 1, no import license will be granted unless the Bank of Brazil has ample foreign exchange coverage to take care of that particular import. This ruling came after importers had filed a complaint with the Government.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The golden network of federal grants-in-aid to state and local governments has become so precious in a time of falling public revenues that it was too much to expect the 1949 Governors' Conference to approve any move to diminish it.

HONOLULU, June 23 -- With employers and striking stevedores both convinced that they had proved their cases in four days of open hearings, Hawaii today began a week's wait for the recommendations of a five-man emergency board appointed to find a basis for settling the longshore strike which is crippling the islands' economy.

A program of modernization and the virtual reconstruction of four floors of the Municipal Building, three of them occupied by the offices of Corporation Counsel John P. McGrath, was announced yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.
FREDERICK, Md., June 23 (AP) -- For the first time in its ninety-five-year history, the Baltimore Synod-Synodical of the Presbyterian Church, U. S. A., elected today a Negro as moderator.
Bobby Riggs, top-seeded entrant in the national professional tennis championship tournament at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, had another strenuous day yesterday, his second in a row.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- After a long, heated Senate debate on the use of injunctions in national emergencies Republican and Democratic leaders agreed today that the issue was so narrowed by two strategic moves that the vote on injunctions would determine which way the whole problem of labor legislation would go.
Four hundred and eighty thousand members of the United Mine Workers of America will quit work tonight for a ten-day paid vacation that will keep them out of the coal pits until July 5.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Truman urged Congress again today to raise the salaries of Cabinet officials and top executive officers in the Federal Government. He estimated the added cost of increases he has recommended would be $1,300,000 a year, and said the expenditure would be well worth it.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 23 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, refused to yield an inch of ground here today at a critical meeting called to find means of stimulating intra-European trade through an acceptable payments plan. One of the main objects of the Marshall Plan was therefore considered by some observers to be endangered.

For the June bride who will be entertaining at her first dinner parties and luncheons this summer, a near perfect gift would be one of the interesting new place mat sets that give a cool look to the table.

While 1948 was a year of all-time newspaper highs and newspapers are now in the strongest competitive position in many years there is still much progress that can be made, according to Harold S. Barnes, director of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.
The transcript of the main portion of Alger Hiss' examination by Lloyd Paul Stryker yesterday follows:

Driving while intoxicated was designated yesterday as an increasing evil in this state directly responsible for at least 20 per cent of the highway accidents and the contributing cause of as many more.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 23 -- The murmuring pines and whispering hemlocks have been buzzing for some time now, wondering when Yale is going to beat Harvard in a boat race.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's extemporaneous remarks on the Foreign Ministers' conference at Paris, as released by the State Department following his news conference today:

On June 2 the House of Representatives passed a bill amending the DP. Act of 1948 which will be acclaimed by all those who had objections against the act as passed last year. Should an amendment on these lines be finally enacted many unjust provisions of the original act will have been removed.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 23 (AP) -- Round View, 6-year-old brown horse from the Sanford Stud Farms, won the featured Hanover Purse at Monmouth Park today. It was his first winning race since 1947, being unplaced in four starts last year and two outings this spring.

The hot sun beating down at noon yesterday was no deterrent to artists, spectators and models sitting for their portraits at the opening of a sidewalk art show on Elm Place outside the Namm department store in Brooklyn.

Beginning July 5 all Jewish displaced persons brought to the United States and who remain in or near the city will receive relief, rehabilitation and other assistance from a new organization to be known as the New York Association for New Americans, it was announced yesterday at the new welfare agency's offices, 15 Park Row.

The Board of Higher Education referred to its seven-man executive committee last night appeals for reinstatement of two City College instructors dismissed this spring. It urged "prompt consideration" of the cases and "early report to the board, at a special meeting if necessary."

MEXICO CITY, June 23 -- Vicente Lombardo Toledano, veteran Mexican labor leader, apparently has found a new field for extending his influence with the organization here of a general federation of Mexican farm laborers and workers' syndicates.

United States Industrial Chemicals, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net loss of $2,391,093 for the fiscal year ended on March 31. This was after all charges and an extraordinary inventory write-down of $4,900,000 which, after related tax credits, aggregated $3,150,000.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Strand the attraction is "Colorado Territory," a Warner Brothers Western starring Joel McCrea and Virginia Mayo. Raoul Walsh directed and Anthony Veiller produced the offering, which was written by John Twist and Edmund H. North.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 23 (AP) -- Kiwanis International today chose Miami, Fla., for its 1950 convention.

The Yankees got in the first punch of their important series with the Tigers -- and it was a crushing wallop. While 55,591 spectators sat enthralled at the Stadium last night, the brilliant but erratic Tommy Byrne spun a magnificent one-hit shut-out and the Bombers lit into a succession of four pitchers for seventeen resounding blows.

Mother is rivaling daughter these days in her quickness at adapting the latest nuances of fashion. Awakening to the great potential market that lay waiting for really smart clothes in women's sizes, designers are devoting the same attention to style details, are giving them the same youthful Verve and chic formerly reserved only for misses' sizes.

Houston Lighting and Power Company in offering its stockholders until July 11 the right to subscribe for $15,360,450 of either 2 3/4 per cent convertible debentures due June 30, 1964, or for 307,209 additional shares of common stock. A banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. is underwriting the offering by agreeing to buy unsubscribed debentures.

Styles in handiwork have changed radically since the days of the sewing circle and quilting bee but the pasttime still flourishes, a tour of needlework departments showed yesterday. This summer on the porches of country and seaside boarding houses or in the heat of the day under beach umbrellas, youngsters and matrons alike will busy themselves on projects that range from beaded evening bags to monogrammed place mats.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 -- After three successive night games the Cardinals dragged the Giants into the broad daylight this afternoon and the combination of a blazing sun and blistering heat proved all too much for the One time pulverizing Polo Grounders.

NANKING, June 23 -- The diplomatic log-jam involving the United States Consulate General in Mukden, which the State Department ordered closed May 18, appears to have been broken. The United States Embassy here received a telegram today from Consul General Angus Ward stating that he had succeeded in making contact with a Communist representative and discussing with him departure of the consulate staff.

An appeal to New Yorkers to be more cautious in their use of water came yesterday as the city received some relief from high humidity and heat, but the drought passed its twenty-eighth day here with no measurable precipitation.

SHANGHAI, June 23 -- After twenty years of hectic existence under various names the Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury today announced that it had abandoned efforts to continue publication. The newspaper, which has been a spokesman for the American community, was the first American enterprise known to have closed down since the Communists took over.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Administration's $1,130,000,000 program of military aid to this country's associates in the North Atlantic defensive alliance has been put "farther down" on the list for action at this session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- A House subcommittee voted today to let Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, accept a medal from the Government of Argentina.

The stock market threw off its indecision yesterday and forged ahead to the best level in three weeks. Thus, after a period of backing and filling, the list has regained almost half the ground surrendered in the retreat which started in mid-May.

BERLIN, June 23 -- the thirty-four-day-old railroad strike, which is blocking entry into this city by rail as effectively as any Moscow ukase, continued today after strikers' plans for "emergency service" fizzled out and the three Western commandants made no progress in a long meeting.
Faye Emerson, George Jessel and Burt Lancaster are three personalities who will be starred in their own shows when NBC launches several new programs during the next two weeks.
Alger Hiss began his life story in a hushed court chamber late yesterday afternoon. He was on th estand fifty-eight minutes. He will pick up the story thread at 10:30 A.M. today.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 23 (AP) -- Prague's fighting Roman Catholic Archbishop Beran was said tonight to have been completely isolated from his clergy and flock by Communist security police.

MONTREAL, June 23 -- Lewis H. Brown, chairman of the board of Johns-Manville Corporation, said here last night that his company has been working on a newly discovered asbestos deposit "since the beginning of the year" in the northern Ontario mining district.

Isolation and synthesis from the roots of the yellow turnip, or rutabaga, of an anti-thyroid substance that induces goiter if eaten regularly in large amounts, is announced in Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Titular Bishop Germanos Polizoides of Nyssa had been named locum tenens of the Greek Archdiocese of North and South America by its Archbishop, Timothy Evangelides, formerly Metropolitan of Rhodes, it was learned here yesterday.
BARI, Italy, June 23 -- A four-engined Dutch Constellation airliner crashed in flames in the rough seas of Bari Harbor today and all thirty-two persons officially listed as aboard were killed.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- As Ezzard Charles basked in the sunshine of his status as National Boxing Association heavyweight champion in the wake of one of the dullest bouts in title history, plans were launched today to resume a campaign calculated to establish a successor to the retired Joe Louis worthy of universal recognition as heavyweight champion.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- A new plan for Federal control of cotton planting and marketing, intended to curtail threatened postwar surpluses, was approved unanimously today by a Senate agriculture subcommittee.

PATERSON, N. J., June 23 -- The third floor of a building at 219 Paterson Street in the downtown section of this city, is now ready for occupancy, thanks to the efforts of Henry E. Neidengard of Pershing Road, Clifton, N. J.

The Board of Education renewed yesterday the public school ban on The Nation by approving a list of periodicals from which the weekly magazine had been dropped by the Board of Superintendents for the second year.
JOGJAKARTA, Indonesia, June 23 -- The situation in this Republican capital is quiet but tense tonight on the eve of the Dutch withdrawal action.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet, United States military adviser to Greece, said today he was "very optimistic" about the country's recovery, but he emphasized that American aid must be continued to win the fight against the Communist-led guerillas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- Roy del Ruth has been signed by Warner Brothers to direct Milton Berle's screen vehicle, "Always Leave Them Laughing," the studio announced today. The film, to be produced by Jerry Wald, will go before the cameras next month.

The widespread loan shark racket along the city's waterfront received a blow yesterday when three men were found guilty of lending money to a Brooklyn longshoreman at excessive interest rates and without licenses.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- Harry Bridges, indicted president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, was denied permission today to leave the United States. He petitioned the court, where he is awaiting trial on charges of perjury and conspiracy, for authority to attend a world conference of maritime workers in Marseille, France, July 13-14.

The four-story six-family building at 160 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, also containing two stores, has been purchased by Mafalda Santini from Jacob Krieger. Dawstan Realty Company was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The City of Yonkers, N. Y., yesterday sold $2,942,000 of sewer, water, street improvement, land acquisition and other improvement bonds due on each July 1 from 1950 to 1969 to a banking syndicate headed by the National City Bank at a bid of 100.23 for an interest coupon of 2 1/4 per cent, a dollar premium of $6,766.60, and a net interest cost of 2.2122 per cent.

The Coast Guard saluted its civilian helpers yesterday on the tenth anniversary of the establishment of the United States Coast Guard Auxiliary, made up largely of small boatsmen who are pulling an oar to promote safety afloat.

The City Council passed yesterday a local bill requiring that garage space be provided on the same lot as the building in the case of structures erected in the future to house twelve or more families. The measure was introduced Oct. 21, 1947, by Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat, and has been pending in the committee on buildings since that date.

Two artists add some life to the waning art season by making one-man appearances. At the Carlebach Gallery is a show of paintings, prints and sculpture by William J. Sewell, a pupil of Bourdelle, who makes no bones about the fact that of the three media, sculpture interests him the most seriously.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The keel will be laid for the New York-Mediterranean liner Constitution on July 12 at the Quincy, Mass., yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company, it was announced here today.

Techniques of a wide-range campaign to increase American women's more frequent -- and possibly more correct -- use of perfume products were outlined yesterday at a meeting of some 150 members of the Toilet Goods Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

TROY, N. Y., June 23 -- Assistant Secretary of State George V. Allen tonight called Russia the purveyor of the "world's most ruthless, imperialism since Julius Caesar" and declared that Russia's program of so-called equalization has merely been a leveling-down process to "the lowest common denominator of misery."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 23 -- Miss Evelyn Odom of the Wheatley Hills Club continued to fill the role of giant killer in the Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship tournament at the Cherry Valley club today by eliminating the defending champion, Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock, 4 and 3, in the quarter-finals.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Republican opposition in the House to the Administration's national housing bill, heading for a vote early next week, was split tonight over possible compromise attempts or continuing all-out opposition to the program.

The long-projected passenger-trailership service between San Francisco and Long Beach, Calif., seemed assured yesterday with the announcement here by the Maritime Commission that it had authorized the issuance of invitations to bid on the construction of two twenty-five-knot, 17,940 gross ton vessels for the route.
Drastic regulations designed to curb "fraudulent and unethical practices" by some automobile driving schools were issued yesterday by Clifford J. Fletcher, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner.

Ever since Congress took the bit in its teeth in 1947 and passed the Taft-Hartley Act over President Truman's veto the leaders of organized labor and the Administration have united in an uninterrupted and almost unprecedentedly bitter campaign against it. This campaign has now found legislative expression in the form of the two "Administration" bills -- the Lesinski bill in the House and the Thomas bill in the Senate.
PITTSBURGH, June 23 (AP) -- The scrappy Phillies pulled a triple play against the Pirates today, then went on to slam out a 9-3 decision for three out of four in the series.

MONTREAL, June 23 -- Airport terminal facilities offer to qualified real estate managers a new and fertile field for expanded service and increased income, Robert S. Curtiss, Director of the Department of Concessions and Revenues of the Port of New York Authority, told the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers at its closing business session today.
DETROIT, June 23 -- After months of preparation, the United Automobile Workers, CIO, submitted its detailed $100-a-month pension plan today to the Ford Motor Company. It received an abrupt rejection.
A man and his wife were killed and five firemen were injured in a collision between a fire engine and a private automobile yesterday evening in the Bronx.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 23 -- Mrs. Catherine Fox Park of Glen Ridge scored an even-par 75 today to take a lead of one stroke at the end of the second round of the 54-hole championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association. Added to her opening 80, that gave Mrs. Park a 36-hole total of 155 at the Upper Montclair Country Club course.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on June 18 were 649,351 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 158,805 cars, or 19.7 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 257,280 cars, or 28.4 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 251,945 cars, or 28.0 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

" Clean Harbor Week" has been set by Mayor O'Dwyer for June 27 to July 2. All persons "interested in maintaining a clean harbor," and that should include all of us, are asked by the Mayor to assist in cleaning up tidewater areas, including the banks, shores and beaches, and to maintain a tidy and clean waterfront for the enjoyment and use of the general public.

David Lowe is drawing upon his resources to face what he believes is the decisive test of his career in show business. He has had experience as a Broadway producer, summer theatre operator and in obtaining some of the backing for "Oklahoma!"

Dark secrets of the Belgian Congo clad in feathers, furs and scales basked in the Bronx sunshine yesterday at the New York Zoological Park as 2,000 members of the New York Zoological Society peeked at them in their cages.

MOSCOW, June 23 -- Dr. A. Kuznetzov, honored physician of the Russian Federated Republic, in a letter to the youth newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda, has called on the Communist youth organization to campaign against smoking by the young.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Judith Coplon conceded under cross-examination today that she inquired repeatedly about visiting Russia in the spring of 1948, a year before the Federal Bureau of Investigation seized her for allegedly stealing Government secrets intending to aid Moscow.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Soviet Government has definitely changed from the offensive to the defensive in "the struggle for the soul of Europe," Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today. He stated this belief as the outstanding impression he had brought back from the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in Paris.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 23 -- A dozen shrill little voices rattled the aged window panes of the Bangall School here this morning in praise of "The Star-Spangled Banner." The children stood very straight beside their small desks as they sang, and even the two 7-year-olds in the back row forgot to giggle between verses.

BERLIN, June 23 -- The organization by this autumn of a "people's democracy" in the Soviet zone of Germany is being planned at the Karlshorst headquarters of the Russian Military Government in Germany, it was learned tonight from reliable German sources.
ROME, June 23 (AP) -- Two Bishops of Rumania's outlawed Uniate Church have been tortured by Communist officials in an effort to break their allegiance to Pope Pius XII, a Vatican source said today.

TOKYO, June 23 -- The Chinese Communists now are demanding a controlling voice in writing an eventual peace treaty between Japan and the Allied Pacific powers. In this they now are informing the Japanese people they will insist on reversal of the occupation's actions over the last three years -- such as termination of war crimes trials, revision of reparations schedules and United States plans for general rehabilitation of the Japanese economy.
BUENOS AIRES, June 23 -- President Juan D. Peron for the first time in many months last night excoriated the Prensa, calling the morning newspaper by name.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Czechoslovak authorities are violating "the decencies of civilization" in their attacks on Archbishop Josef Beran, Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- A bill intended to put more telephones on the farms moved ahead a step in the House today when it cleared the Rules Committee. The House may act on it next week. Private telephone companies have opposed it.

Gilbert Green, Illinois chairman of the Communist party, changed his testimony at the Communist trial yesterday on the party's position regarding advocacy of force and violence to overthrow the Government.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23 -- Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, called on the great educational centers of this country and of the British Commonwealth of nations today to carry on "the learned traditions of those institutions to which in the nineteenth century Americans turned as toward a mecca of the intellectual world."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- "The Snake Pit" tonight won two of the five annual awards of the Screen Writers Guild for film writing excellence in 1948. The other three winners were "The Treasure of Sierra Madre," "Sitting Pretty" and "Easter Parade."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 23 -- The United States, Britain and France have agreed upon a plan to move between 100,000 and 120,000 Germans from United States and British occupation zones of Germany to the French zone.
LONDON, June 23 (UP) -- A Russian history professor is in hot water with the Kremlin for writing a book that isn't anti-American enough, it was revealed today.

Magazine Printing Guide The American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of Magazine Publishers announced yesterday recommended standard specifications for advertising reproduction materials for all magazine letterpress wet printing.

Alger Hiss, target of a two-count Federal perjury indictment, took the witness stand in Federal Court at 3:22 o'clock yesterday and entered a complete denial of the charges that he gave State Department documents to Whittaker Chambers for transmission to a Soviet spy ring in 1937 and 1938.

LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- Bob Falkenburg, the defending champion, and Jaroslav Drobny averted a couple of threatened upsets in the fifth set today to gain berths in the last sixteen of the Wimbledon tennis championships.

Three five-story buildings containing eight stores, two lofts and apartments at 803-05-07 Lexington Avenue, northeast corner of Sixtysecond Street, have been sold by the Wiefifth Realty Corporation to the 16 John Street Corporation for investment.

The 17-year-old son of an Air Force colonel has placed first in the national competitive examinations for Presidential appointment to the United States Military Academy at West Point, the Slocum Air Force Base, off New Rochelle, announced yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 23 -- Reporting on a tour of Israel and the Near East he had made under the auspices of the American Christian Palestine Committee, Mayor Stanley W. Church of this city charged tonight at a meeting in the New Rochelle High School that the United States consular service in Jerusalem was deficient.

A history of Chinese gardens, their design and architecture and their significance in art and literature will be published on Tuesday by the Ronald Press. "Gardens of China" is the work of Osvald Siren, formerly of the University of Stockholm and author of studies of Giotto and Leonardo da Vinci as well as of several books on Chinese art.

The New York State Regents examinations, which were taken this week by 700,000 high school students in the state, about half of them from New York City, were attacked yesterday for being "educational straitjackets," "cruel" and "unnecessary."

Our scout has found entertainment in the fact that the beach umbrella season is on in Manhattan -- though the island has no beaches. As bright-hued protectors of tables where two or more are gathered to seek refreshment in the open, they are out in Rockefeller Plaza, where not so long ago the skaters were skimming about on the ice.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 23 -- An Israeli spokesman said here today that the third progress report of the commission, issued yesterday, had given a "misleading" impression of the Israeli attitude toward the repatriation of the Palestine Arab refugees.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 23 -- American Jews were urged today to recognize the chief rabbinate of Israel as "the final authority in Jewish religious life," by Dr. Jacob Hoffman of New York City, president of the Mizrachi national education committee.

Two Metropolitan artists, Astrid Varnay, soprano, and Herbert Janssen, baritone, were the soloists with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Both vocalists made their first appearance at these concerts in a program devoted to excerpts from Wagner's "The Flying Dutchman" and Strauss' "Salome," which attracted an audience of 5,000.

LONDON, June 24 -- The High Commissioner of Pakistan in London tonight described as "unwarranted interference" in the internal affairs of his country a statement by the Afghan Ambassador that Afghanistan did not recognize the North-West Frontier Province as part of Pakistan and would never accept Pakistan's claim to the Tribal Area.

DETROIT, June 24 -- Charges of widespread gambling and racketeering within Local 669 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, in Paterson, N. J., were brought to light today after more than two years of suppression by the International Executive Board of the parent union.

A model of a complete community in the State of Israel planned to house 1,000 children, orphans of the war, was displayed for the first time yesterday in a brief ceremony at the Municipal Building office of Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission.

Coordinated furniture consisting of units which may be used together in a number of different combinations and worked out to fit any amount of space makes it possible for an individual to "build-in" furniture arrangements that fulfill his personal needs and satisfy his taste.
STANTON, Del., June 24 (AP) -- Crispin Oglebay's Noble Impulse won the featured mile-and-a-sixteenth Rehoboth Purse by a neck at Delaware Park today.

June 21, the arrival of the summer solstice, opened the season's greetings with a fiery red sun, radiant in vision and haloed in color, forecasting another warm day; as the day advanced, the air became humid and motionless, inducing rest and retirement to a shady nook.

VIENNA, June 24 -- After five hours of argument the Allied Council today decided to inform the Austrian Government that it had approved the electoral law passed by the Austrian Parliament at the end of May.

Scholarships were awarded to two metropolitan boys yesterday in what is believed the first instance in this country of joint management and labor sponsorship of higher education for the sons of workers.

The Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury has closed its doors for good. So ends an authentic and authoritative American voice in the Far East. Under the vigorous editorship of Randall Gould The Post and Mercury was fearless, outspoken, critical of both the Chinese Government and the Chinese Communists, thoroughly pro-Chinese and pro-American.

The screen rights to "At War With the Army," the James B. Allardice comedy, have been sold to Fred F. Finklehoffe for $50,000. Negotiations with the firm of Henry May, Jerome Rosenfeld and Charles Ray McCallum, sponsors of the stage work, were completed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Legislation to extend the authority of the Maritime Commission to sell, charter and operate vessels was passed by the Senate today after Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, withdrew prior objections on which he had based a threat to talk indefinitely if necessary to forestall today's action.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles told President Truman today that the political and psychological situation in Europe "demands quick ratification of the Atlantic pact and the active organization under it of an effective common defense."

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Legislation to define by law the currently vague meaning of air "contract carriers" was advocated today by Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 24 -- By car, taxi and train, Indians arrived here today to sample the primitive life of their ancestors. Of many tribes they were, but mostly from Brooklyn. In a clearing previously used by Boy Scouts, the Indians pitched tent, set out their souvenirs and thus began a three-day powwow of the Inter-tribal American Indian Council.

ALBANY, June 24 -- The New York Trust Company, 100 Broadway, New York City, was authorized today by the State Banking Department to open a branch office at 496-98 Madison Avenue, New York City. The department also granted permission to the safe deposity company of the New York Trust Company, 10 Rockefeller Plaza, New York City, to open a branch at the Madison Avenue address.
GENEVA, June 24 -- An effort will be made here tomorrow to launch a new international organization of non-Communist trade unions.
A wire just received from Chesapeake Bay indicates that the anglers there are getting the best striped bass and croaker fishing in history -- or at least fifteen years of history.

Clutch hitting by Larry Berra and Tommy Henrich, combined with steadfast relief pitching by Joe Page after Allie Reynolds had faltered, carried the Yankees to their second straight triumph over the Tigers, 5 -- 4, before 15,384 sweltering onlookers at the Stadium yesterday.

In accordance with a program approved at the recent Fusion committee meeting, Samuel Seabury, chairman of the group, invited representatives of the Republican and Liberal parties yesterday to confer with him to discuss formation of a joint "good government" ticket for the fall municipal elections.
When Bennett E. Siegelstein married Miss Fannie Lucather on the Lower East Side, June 28, 1904, celebrated the wedding by sending an underprivileged youngster to camp.

The Maryland State Road Commission announced yesterday that it will receive bids on $22,500,000 of tax-exempt highway bonds on July 11. Dated Aug. 1, 1949, the bonds are to come due Aug. 1, 1950 to 1964.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 24 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, announced today that Syria and Israel had accepted his compromise proposal as a basis for discussion in arranging an armistice and that the two delegations would resume their negotiations on June 28.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 24 -- Sharp competition marked the opening conformation hunter events at the three-day Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today.

Zoel N. Lynch, California Sunday School teacher, after a six months' battle, was finally reunited with his four children yesterday when their mother, Mrs. Marianne Lynch Teitelbaum, turned them over to her former husband in compliance with a court order at the office of her attorney.

LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) -- Yorkshire today triumphed over Sussex to take the lead in the county cricket championship. Yorkshire headed Worcestershire, which played outside the title series in the matches ended today.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 24 -- Steve Berrien of Upper Montclair, and A. D. Purvis, who were runners-up for the title last year, tied for the medal today as eighty-six teams qualified in the Montclair Golf Club's annual member-guest tournament.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., June 24 -- George Gilbert Wentz, 13 years old, of Huntington, W. Va., won the national boys' championship at the twenty-fifth national marbles tournament here today, after a close match with Robert Brady, 12, of Greensboro, N. C., by a score of 7 to 5.
HADDONFIELD, N. J., June 24 -- Several hundred Eskimos in the northern part of Alaska soon will have a Haddonfield minister to thank for their spiritual and physical comforts.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Proponents and opponents of the use of injunctions in national emergency labor disputes agreed today that the Senate vote on this subject next Tuesday would be close and that a few votes either way would be decisive.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A decline of 0.3 per cent in retail prices of goods and services between mid-April and mid-May, was registered in the consumers' price index report issued today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.
FRESNO, Calif., June 24 (AP) -- Long-striding James Urquhart of the University of Wisconsin won the 1,500-meter run tonight in the national A. A. U. junior track and field championships.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Rains which fell in parts of Oklahoma and Kansas, promising a further delay in harvest operations in wheat, and reports suggesting that possibly less than 50 per cent of the Kansas crop would test 55 pounds a measured bushel or more, brought in general buying of futures and closing trades were 1 5/8 to 3 cents higher.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 24 -- The National Bituminous Coal Wage Conference reported progress in its discussions and the inclusion of mines producing an additional 21,402,304 tons today. Then the conferees recessed until Tuesday.

Since the turn of the century there have been four major colonial Powers in Southeast Asia. They have been Britain, the United States, the Netherlands and France. In recent years each has taken specific actions to change the colonial relationship, and although the methods have been different the direction has been the same.

ROME, June 24 -- Giuseppe Giulietti, president of the Seamen's Union, today laid on the Italian Government responsibility for the seamen's strike, which has immobilized several hundred Italian ships, including the liner Saturnia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- A deal for June Havoc to play the leading feminine role in "Tehachapi: The Story of Molly X," at Universal-International is in final stages of negotiation, it was learned today. Ginger Rogers, who was to have played the part, recently requested the studio to permit her to withdraw from the engagement, and it is understood that Miss Havoc will replace her.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 24 (AP) -- Hero, owned by J. C. Brady and H. Oots, was the driving winner of the feature race at Monmouth Park today. The 3-year-old colt defeated Hedgewood, 1-2 favorite, by a nose in a stirring finish.
TORONTO, June 24 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison faltered a bit today but managed to maintain a three-stroke lead at the three-quarter point of the Canadian open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave its final approval to the plan by which outstanding securities of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company and certain of its subsidiaries will be altered in accordance with an agreement reached with the holders.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 24 -- Sam Match of San Francisco University and Jack Tuero of Tulane advanced to the final of the National Collegiate A. A. tennis tournament. Match beat Fred Kovaleski of William and Mary, 6 -- 2, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3, and Tuero downed Herbert (Buddy) Behrens of Rollins 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.

The theory of a quick and easy victory by an atomic blitz is heavily scored in an article, "An Admiral Talks Back to the Airmen," in the current issue of The Saturday Evening Post, which has had considerable repercussions in Washington.
BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- Ted Williams paced a 25-hit attack with his eighteenth and nineteenth homers today as the Red Sox crushed the injury-riddled Browns, 21 -- 2.

HONOLULU, June 24 -- Acting Gov. Oren E. Long succeeded today in persuading employer and union representatives to resume direct negotiations in an effort to end the paralyzing strike of longshoremen, now in its fifty-fifth day.

The pricing of substantial new issues of prime corporate bonds will continue to occupy underwriters next week. The schedule calls for public distribution of $50,000,000 of Joseph E. Seagram Sons twenty-five-year 3 per cent debentures on Wednesday.

To enable recent Puerto Rican arrivals to understand and acquire American ways and customs, the Board of Education is licensing special teachers to work half-days with parents as well as pupils, it was learned yesterday.

Eviction notices have been served upon thirty-three tenants of Ansonia House, the seventeen-story, former hotel that now provides apartments for 500 families on Broadway between Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth streets, because of withheld rents, it was learned yesterday.

If Apprentice Bill Boland had whacked Assault once with his whip, there would have been a different story to tell about the main act in the Aqueduct racing show yesterday. But Boland didn't do it, and so it was that the King Ranch's triple-crown champion of 1946 was outphotoed in the first race of his comeback campaign.

SEOUL, Korea, June 24 -- Declaring that North Korean Communists are conducting a campaign against religious leaders "that has so uniformly marked every Communist organization in Europe as essentially anti-Christ," Bishop Patrick J. Byrne, Apostolic Delegate to Korea, today denounced arrests and imprisonment of North Korean Roman Catholic clergy by Communist authorities.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, June 24 -- The responsibility of the Republican party to the farmer and to labor was the principal topic discussed today at the Convention of the National Young Republican Federation here.

DARIEN, Conn., June 24 -- Earl S. Ruscoe and his guest, David Lapham of Woodway, who won the medal in last year's tournament, repeated today as 67 teams competed for eight places in the championship flight of Wee Burn's sixth annual member - guest golf tournament.

SHANGHAI, June 24 -- With the Nationalist blockade due to begin twenty-four hours from midnight tonight the Nationalist Navy appeared to have jumped the gun. Warships stopped the Egyptian liner Star of Suez after she had sailed from Shanghai and "arrested" the pilot boat at the river mouth with British, French, Dutch and Norwegian pilots aboard.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UP) -- The Senate Labor Committee today approved a modified bill to raise the national minimum wage from 40 to 75 cents an hour, an Administration "must" for this session.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Average primary market prices declined 1 per cent in the week ended on June 21, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 153.2 per cent of the 1926 average, 2.1 per cent below four weeks ago and 8.3 per cent lower than one year ago.

"Irresistible political pressure from certain quarters" prompted a majority on the State University Commission to advocate establishment of two new, state-supported medical centers in their report to Governor Dewey and the State Legislature last year, Dr. Edmund Ezra Day charged yesterday in his last public appearance as president of Cornell University.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Sigmund Engel, 73 years old, internationally known for fifty years as a marrying swindler, was captured by police this afternoon in a Michigan Avenue luggage shop. He had been sought for the swindling of Mrs. Resada Corrigan, a Chicago widow, early this month.

American methods of rayon goods production will be followed by British mills in an effort to step up working efficiency and output of textiles, according to members of the British team of textile workers and managers.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 24 -- Sixteen women from organizations representing more than half the women in the United States, as well as millions of women throughout the world, told Secretary General Trygve Lie today that they would push strongly to have the genocide convention ratified as a legal instrument for the preservation of nations, races and religious communities.

Cottonseed oil futures were firm yesterday, advancing 4 to 17 points and closing at the day's highs on the New York Produce Exchange. Trade was small but strength in the West made for the firm tone. Crude oil markets in the South were soft.

This week the thirty-second season of Philharmonic-Symphony summer concerts began at Lewisohn Stadium. Their popularity is traditional and deserved. Music lovers will come not only from Brooklyn and Bronx but from miles beyond. Every year, we are told, subscription orders arrive from neighboring states, and from reverberating distances like Texas.

POLAND SPRING, Me., June 24 (AP) -- Evans Woollen Jr. of Indianapolis, president of the American Bankers Association, told the Maine Bankers Association here tonight that we admit to some perplexity about the intentions of the Government with respect to credit.

LONDON, June 24 -- The Conservative party called today for the establishment of a British Empire and Commonwealth advisory defense council and, if this were not possible, a Commonwealth combined military staff, with complete standardization of equipment, organization and training of all its fighting services.

PARIS, June 24 -- The first food parcels were distributed here today to refugees from behind the Iron Curtain by the International Rescue Committee, which is cooperating with the campaign in behalf of these refugees now under way in the United States.

PARIS, June 24 -- Stressing importance of proposals for increased technical assistance to underdeveloped countries, the World Food Council today closed its session here with the adoption of the program to be presented to the conference of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in November.
BERLIN, June 24 -- United States efforts to reopen rail traffic between Berlin and Western Germany were confounded tonight by Soviet zone bureaucracy.

GUNTHERING around Europe on the bright and dark sides of the Iron Curtain the hot, early days of the cold war, young William Attwood of The Herald Tribune piled up enough personal history to write one of those heavy-breathing what's-whats that always lag about a hundred days behind the news in the morning paper.

ATHENS, June 24 (UP) -- Seven months ago, on his eighty-eighth birthday, Mr. Sophoulis with astonishing recuperative powers survived a previous heart attack that his physicians had feared would be fatal.

Where is our traffic commission with the plans for traffic relief? They seem to be as silent as a church mouse. After much labor and "planning," they come forth with parking meters for a city like New York! Where are the bold and original plans required for the relief of the traffic situation in this city, daily growing worse?

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Florida Power and Light Company, Miami, Fla., received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to issue and sell at competitive bidding $10,000,000 of its thirty-year first mortgage bonds.
ALBANY, June 24 (AP) -- Chairmen were elected today for seven new joint legislative committees and a state commission created by the 1949 Legislature.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A group of twenty-one Senators today asked President Truman for assurance that the United States would not recognize the Communist regime in China and thus abrogate his "quarantine communism" doctrine.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 24 -- Mrs. T. Arthur Menzel of Innis Arden became the new tri-county golf champion after a gruelling final against Mrs. John H. Bartol of the Greenwich Country Club. The match was decided by 1 up on the thirty-sixth green of the hilly, sunbaked Innis Arden course today.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 (AP) -- The onrushing St. Louis Cardinals took over the top perch of the National League for the first time this season tonight when they downed the Braves, 8 to 4, while the Brooklyn Dodgers were defeated at Pittsburgh. Two home runs by Lou Klein and another by Tommy Glaviano were the big blows in the victory which delighted 17,998 fans.

Armstrong Cork Company yesterday reduced base mill prices of several linoleum and felt base hard surface floor coverings from 2 to 10 per cent. C. N. Painter, vice president and general manager of the floor division, said prices of Corlon, rubber and asphalt tile remain unchanged and pointed out the company cut asphalt tile prices early in April.

IDAHO SPRINGS, Col., June 24 (AP) -- Dr. Edward U. Condon objected today in a letter to J. Edgar Hoover, director of the FBI, to the use of "slanderous material about decent Americans" in official documents connected with investigations.

John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, asked five local milk distributors yesterday to absorb an increase of about a half cent a quart in the July farm price of Class 1-A milk announced by Dr. C. J. Blanford, market administrator of the New York metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that its surveys indicated little damage so far to the wheat crop in principal producing areas by stem rust and other plant diseases. The report was issued as grain markets reacted to unofficial estimates of extensive damage.

The Astral Apartments, six-story structure containing 116 suites, occupying the east block-front of Franklin Street between Java and India Streets in Brooklyn, have been sold by the Heidelberger family to the Northchester Corporation, of which Randal Holden is president.
The newly appointed receivers of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation were directed yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman to make a thorough investigation of its finances and management.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Sponsors of a petition designed to force a Senate voting showdown on a resolution that would direct President Truman to cut 5 to 10 per cent from appropriations made to the Executive Branch for the fiscal year starting July 1 planned today to take the issue to the floor early next week.

A strong movement of summer suit stocks resulting from continued warm weather will clear retailers' and manufacturers' stocks soon after July 4, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Curtailment of production of lightweight garments, manufacturers said, has also been a factor in keeping inventories down.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Lewis L. Strauss, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, raised the question of national security anew today in connection with the export of radioactive isotopes for foreign research.
The beneficial effects of adult education classes for hospital patients with chronic diseases were tangibly demonstrated last night at the Goldwater Memorial Hospital at Welfare Island.

Donald Budge, second-seeded entrant from Los Angeles, and Frankie Kovacs, the merry-making performer from Oakland, Calif., who is ranked third, came through as expected as the semi-final bracket in the National Professional Tennis Singles Championship was filled yesterday.
