WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today authorized the merger of South Jersey Power and Light Company's electric facilities into those of the Atlantic City Electric Company. It denied the Atlantic City company's alternate request for dismissal of the consolidation application for want of jurisdiction.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's special message to Congress today on aid to economically under-developed countries:

The 4,000 handicapped children who during the school year are taught at their homes by visiting teachers of the Board of Education, but for whom summer vacation means little, will not be forgotten in July and August by the city's broadcasting station, WNYC, according to its director, Seymour N. Siegel.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Truman urged Congress today to let him run the Postoffice Department as a real business. In a special message, he called attention to existing obstacles, most of them statutory, and suggested remedies.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 24 -- Han Hedtoft, steaky young Premier of Denmark, said today that the people of this hard-working little country were seriously worried about economic trends in the United States.

After a two-day respite, high temperatures and humidity will return today and probably continue through the week-end, the Weather Bureau warned travelers last night. The forecast came as the drought in this area entered its thirtieth day with no prospect of relief for withering crops.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 24 -- Present Government fiscal policies that stem from the concentration of Washington bureaucracy are today endangering the thirty-five-year-old Federal Reserve System, Dr. W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the Economic Policy Commission of the American Bankers Association, said here tonight.

Since the war Hawaii has become one of the most highly unionized areas under the American flag. Labor strength is concentrated in Harry Bridges' International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, which has reached out from the waterfront into the vital sugar and pineapple industries.
"One Man's Family," NBC's long-lived serial about the Barbour family, will make an appearance as a television show over NBC-TV starting on July 25, although no definite time has as yet been assigned.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A naval board of inquiry was set up today to investigate the cause of a fire that did $50,000 damage in a naval research laboratory warehouse early this morning.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 24 -- Consideration of the United Nations' proposed human-rights covenant and genocide convention took the spotlight here today at the opening of the New York State Bar Association's annual two-day summer meeting.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 24 -- Marine sirens, horns and the cheers of 15,000 persons -- ashore and afloat on some 350 pleasure craft on the Thames River -- joined in a bedlam of sound this evening in celebration of Yale's first varsity rowing victory over Harvard since 1935.

ATHENS, June 24 -- Themistocles Sophoulis, the aged Greek Premier supported by the Western powers to head the fight against Communist inroads from the north, died after a stroke today at his summer home in an Athens suburb.

Cheering spectators from the North Bronx had a field day yesterday as agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were literally up a tree -- trying to collar an elusive raccoon.

DETROIT, June 24 (AP) -- Automobile plants in the United States and Canada will hit a twenty-year high in monthly output for June, turning out an estimated 628,300 vehicles, Ward's automotive reports predicted today.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 24 -- Another deadlock developed today in the United Nations Security Council on the membership applications of the five countries sponsored by the Soviet Union and the seven sponsored by the Western powers.

Selection of a jury to hear evidence in the "lonely hearts" murder trial of Mrs. Martha Beck and Raymond M. Fernandez was completed yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court with the choosing of two alternate jurors. Ten days of questioning and the panelling of 600 talesmen were required to fill out the jury.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A $150,000,000 program of expanded aid to South Korea to assist it in maintaining its new republic and establishing a sound economy was approved tentatively today by the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

LORDSHIP, Conn., June 24 (UP) -- Setting a new record for major skeet shooting competition, Richard Shaughnessy of Egypt, Mass., won the 20-gauge championship at the 17th Great Eastern shoot today with a perfect score of 100x100.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 -- The Board of Regents of the University of California today promulgated a revised "loyalty oath" to be taken by all of the institution's faculty members and employes disavowing membership in the Communist party.

As the season approaches its height and the sun at the beach beats down with greater intensity, the demand for swimsuits with companion jackets becomes stronger. Helpful as a sunshade and useful as a dry-off for after a plunge, these gay little beach coats have been designed with such ingenuity that they make attractive ensembles for the shore.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. L., June 24 -- Leading a field of sixty-one teams, Gaines Gwathmey of Piping Rock and Tommy Tailer of Meadowbrook, former Metropolitan amateur golf champion, won the qualifying medal in the Piping Rock Club's invitation tournament with a best-ball score of 69, two under par.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 24 -- Bob Sweeny, former British amateur champion, and Jock McLean of Meadow Brook, turned in a sparkling 70-4-66 to lead a field of thirty-one for the medal as the annual Sands Point Gold Club's member-guest scotch foursomes tournament started today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The United States must double the current volume of its imports from Western Europe by 1951 or concede failure of the Marshall Plan. Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, told the Senate Appropriations Committee today.

At the closing of the third annual store modernization show yesterday in Grand Central Palace, retailers reported their greatest current interest to be in new types of display counters, improved top lighting and transparent store fronts which allow interiors to be seen from the front.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 24 -- The realty industry of the state and nation was sharply criticized tonight by Theodore H. Maenner, president of the National Associated of Real Estate Boards, for its failure to develop a broader and more representative organization so that it might have a more compelling voice in public affairs.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Sales of iron and steel scrap owned overseas by Government agencies are no longer restricted exclusively to buyers who will ship the scrap to this country.

Fifty-six Senators have signed a petition which is intended to force a showdown on an economy resolution to direct the President to cut 5 to 10 per cent from the funds appropriated for the executive branch of the Government during the fiscal year which begins July 1.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 24 -- More than 1,200 delegates to the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Mizrachi organization unanimously adopted a resolution today calling for the reorganization of the world Mizrachi movement to obtain "greater unity and solidarity within the forces of religious Jewry the world over and harmonious actions for the strengthening of religious life in the state of Israel."

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Judith Coplon punctuated the end of her cross-examination today with a wild ten-minute outburst in which she screamed that the Government's espionage case against her "smells to high heaven."

Testifying for the second successive day in his own defense, Alger Hiss narrowed the issue of credibility between himself and Whittaker Chambers yesterday by entering detailed denials of any spy ring association with the former Communist underground leader.

Thirty young persons from England, Ireland and the Oneonta Congregational Church, South Pasadena, Calif., who are visiting Congregational churches in the United States as "The Youth Odyssey," will have charge of the service at 11 A. M. tomorrow at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Truman today asked Congress to approve and finance his "bold new program" of technical assistance for the under-developed regions of the world.
BUFFALO, June 24 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley today told a group of publishers of weekly newspapers that government is engaging in organized propaganda and increasing its controls.

The ending of a currency preference system on imports by the Union of South Africa this coming Thursday, under which South African-flag steamship companies had a distinct competitive advantage over other lines, should make for stabilization in the trade to South and East Africa, Arthur R. Lewis Jr., president of the Seas Shipping Company, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 24 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today that the United Nations was still waiting for the Czechoslovak Government to present a bill of particulars against the 50-year-old Czech who has been taking refuge in the organization's information office in Prague.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 24 -- Further Government action to break the resistance of the Roman Catholic Church is foreshadowed by the decision of Board of Commissioners for Slovakia, sitting in Bratislava yesterday, to take "measures intended to safeguard the calm work of the Slovak population devoted to the Republic" in view of the "attempt of the Bishops and some reactionary priests to create disturbances in some places"

Six persons, including an attorney and three brothers who live in the Bronx, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy to defeat the Government's sugar rationing program from September, 1946, to March, 1947. The jury, which was formed in May, 1948, was disbanded after the indictments, but Federal attorneys will continue their investigations.

A woman telephoned the New York Academy of Medicine library recently with a serious problem. She wished to know of a quick reducing remedy that would, before vacations began, slim her into shape for a summer wardrobe.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- Not even the inspiring presence of Owner Horace Stoneham could arrest the extraordinary plunge of the Giants, who now really are tearing downhill with their brake linings gone.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 24 (AP) -- Six Uniate Church Bishops are restricted to their quarters in monasteries throughout the country but a Rumanian spokesman denied today that any of them had been subjected to torture.

The annual report of Austin, Nichols Co., Inc., and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday for the fiscal year ended on April 30, shows a net profit of $398,674, after all charges, including Federal income taxes of $250,000.

Lumber production for the week ended June 18 was 8.6 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were up 10.9 per cent and orders 6.2 per cent.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 24 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis unanimously went on record here today in opposition to any "Federal or state aid to educational institutions maintained by religious groups -- Jewish or Christian."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 -- Syrians will go to polls tomorrow to elect Col. Husni Zayim President of Syria. There are no opposition candidates.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 24 -- Sectary General Trygve Lie, formally presenting today his new plan for a guard force, to be called the "United Nations Field Service," and an international panel of peace observers, a "Field Reserve Panel," made a special appeal to both East and West to keep his suggested program out of their political squabbles.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 -- Ralph Kiner hit his sixteenth home run with two on bases in the first inning off Rex Barney and singled against Erv Palica in the eighth for the Pirates' only hits at Forbes' Field tonight. Yet his homer and a wild pitch by Jack Banta provided all the Pittsburgh runs in the opening frame for a 4-2 victory over the Dodgers.

A plan for keeping costs at or below the company's break-even point has been developed by Avildsen Tools and Machines, Inc., Chicago, Clarence Avildsen, chairman, pointed out in a letter addressed to customers, received here yesterday.

Three new pictures will open locally today. "The Red Menace," an expose of Communist operations in this country produced by Republic Pictures, will have its premiere at the Mayfair Theatre. The screenplay was written by Albert DeMond and Gerald Geraghty and the cast is composed of unfamiliar players including Robert Rockwell, Hanne Axman, Betty Lou Gerson and Barbra Fuller. . . .
A conscientious window cleaner worked so hard yesterday at cleaning a window that he came close to losing his life.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 24 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today that he had received protests from Yugoslavia and Bulgaria against alleged new violations of their territories by Greece.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- The White Sox scored their second victory of the season over the Athletics tonight, 2 -- 1, as Randy Gumpert went the distance for his sixth triumph. The loss pushed the Mackmen 5 1/2 games out of first place.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message to Congress today on reorganization of the Postoffice Department follows:

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 24 -- Miss Evelyn Odom of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club and Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson, the New York State champion, advanced today to the final round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship at the Cherry Valley Club.

Two travel guides that deal with the history, culture, legends and places of interest in the United States are scheduled for August publication. Hastings House will bring out on Aug. 10 "The American Guide," edited by Henry G. Alsberg and containing the work of some thirty editorial workers.

Although still struggling with the problem of increasing production and exports, Sweden's prospects for a more favorable trade balance are much improved, it was asserted here yesterday by a top trade authority of that nation.

Princeton University will not comply at this time with a request by the House Un-American Activities Committee for a list of books used in its social science courses, Dr. Harold Dodds, president, said yesterday.

A certificate of merit was awarded Bloomingdale's yesterday at a meeting of the Advertising Club of New York. The award was made by the Brand Names Foundation in recognition of a series of newspaper brand advertisements which dramatized for the consumer the benefits of buying well-known manufacturers' brands.
BUFFALO, June 24 -- The pace-setting Buffalo Bisons extended their latest winning streak to four straight by turning back the last-place Newark Bears, 8 -- 2, before a crowd of 6,851 tonight.

The Rev. Carlo Rossini, organist and choirmaster of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Cathedral, Pittsburgh, will have charge of music programs at St. Peter's and the other churches in Rome during the liturgical services and public demonstrations of Holy Year, to be celebrated in 1950.

Princeton University will not comply at this time with a request by the House Un-American Activities Committee for a list of books used in its social science courses, Dr. Harold Dodds, president, said yesterday.

A certificate of merit was awarded Bloomingdale's yesterday at a meeting of the Advertising Club of New York. The award was made by the Brand Names Foundation in recognition of a series of newspaper brand advertisements which dramatized for the consumer the benefits of buying well-known manufacturers' brands.
BUFFALO, June 24 -- The pace-setting Buffalo Bisons extended their latest winning streak to four straight by turning back the last-place Newark Bears, 8 -- 2, before a crowd of 6,851 tonight.

The Rev. Carlo Rossini, organist and choirmaster of St. Paul's Roman Catholic Cathedral, Pittsburgh, will have charge of music programs at St. Peter's and the other churches in Rome during the liturgical services and public demonstrations of Holy Year, to be celebrated in 1950.

PARIS, June 24 -- Britain's dollar shortage, accentuated by her difficulty of earning dollars by exports since the United States price recession, has caused American administrators of the Marshall Plan to face their most difficult decision since the Economic Cooperation Administration began a year ago, in the opinion of experts here.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 24 (AP) -- Wisconsin gained support tonight as the crew that might supply the drama in the Forty-seventh Poughkeepsie Regatta tomorrow but California and Washington ruled firmly as favorites.
TROY, N. Y., June 24 (AP) -- Formation of three new volunteer Air Reserve training units, affecting 30,000 reserve officers and men in Upstate New York and Connecticut, was announced today.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 24 (UP) -- The C-46 plane that crashed into the sea near this city on June 7 with the loss of fifty-three lives was 2,473 pounds overloaded, it was announced officially today.

The Pan American Airways Corporation will hold a special meeting of stockholders in combination with their regular meeting on July 21 in Wilmington, Del., to vote on a proposal to simplify the organization's corporate structure, Juan T. Trippe, president, announced yesterday.
LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- Miss Gertrude Moran of Santa Monica, Calif., bowed out of the women's singles event today in the greatest upset of the first week of the Wimbledon tennis championships.

BATAVIA, Java, June 24 -- The withdrawal of Netherlands troops from Jogjakarta began today. In two instances, Republican officers, who apparently had entered the city for the purpose of obtaining information, were shot and killed near the Dutch military intelligence headquarters in the heart of the city.

GENEVA, June 24 -- The committee on industrial relations of the International Labor Organization completed work today on the text of an international convention defining labor's right to collective bargaining.
Further efforts to settle New York's long-standing bakery tie-up will not take place until next week, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- Winston Churchill parted with one of his paintings today for $5,250. He had never sold one before.

Mrs. Marie Hartford Hoffman Reed Robertson must continue to pay her former husband, Louis F. Reed Jr., $1,650 a month for life under an agreement signed on June 18, 1935, in which he agreed to appear in a divorce action brought by his wife in Reno. Nev.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today that American distillers may make "Scotch type" whisky but only Scotland can produce "Scotch."

LONDON, June 24 -- The strike of Canadian seamen on the London docks ended today with a settlement between the Canadian Seamen's Union and the owners of the two ships affected. British stevedores, who had refused to handle cargoes during the strike, immediately began to unload the vessels.

The stock market reached yesterday its best level in more than three weeks. It needed only a slight margin to attain that mark in view of the previous day's strength, though, with the added enlargements held to fractions. The list made its best bid for the higher side in the morning and then remained at that level for the rest of the session.

Sophisticated New Yorkers are just as fond of old-fashioned picnics as their country cousins -- but with a difference. City dwellers, instead of packing their own lunches, may prefer to buy them ready-made, either to save time or because of a lack of kitchen facilities.

Gilbert Green, Illinois chairman of the Communist party, denied at the Communist trial yesterday that party members were trained to use the record of the 1917 Russian Bolshevik revolution in Stalin's "History of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (Bolsheviks)" as a "blueprint" for violent revolution in the United States.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 24 -- The state Department of Public works submitted to New Rochelle and Westchester County officials today a master plan for development of 9.14 miles of arterial highways to reduce traffic congestion in New Rochelle.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 13 points lower on July, while other months were 4 to 15 points higher.

Morris Gold has purchased the five-story apartment house at 2255 Creston Avenue, the Bronx, from the Notserc Realty Corporation. The building, on a plot 50 by 120 feet, contains ninety-two rooms in suites of three and four rooms. Nehring Brothers were the brokers.
A. R. Fleischmann will become assistant general sales manager of Standard Brands, Inc., effective July 1. He will continue as vice president in charge of the Fleischmann Division.
Following is the transcript of the main portions of Alger Hiss' examination by Lloyd Paul Stryker on his relations with Whittaker Chambers. Thomas F. Murphy is of prosecution counsel.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Bob Feller won his third straight game and his fourth of the year tonight, limiting Washington to seven hits as Cleveland captured an 8-2 decision before a crowd of 23,018.

There is many a man alive today who can still remember re-enacting at play the dauntless struggle of the gallant band that fought and died in Custer's Last Stand. Radio and television were not yet on hand to offer youth special programs of prefabricated fancy.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 4 -- Mrs. Catherine Fox Park of Glen Ridge and Mrs. Hobart C. Ramsey of Baltusrol finished in a deadlock today in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association 54-hole championship.

Retail sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales were believed to be about 9 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 11 per cent below last year.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 24 -- The world's 3,000,000 Congregationalists received today a blueprint of future "Christian strategy for "constructive and creative" programs to increase the "areas of economic and social health."

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Two substitutes for the Administration's National Housing Bill -- one trimming it and the other slashing it -- were offered in the House today as three days of general debate came to an end.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 24 -- Seventeen-year-old John J. Byrne Jr., of Wildwood, was inducted tonight by Supreme Court Justice William A. Wachenfeld as "Governor" of the Boys State, a youth educational program being conducted at Rutgers University under sponsorship of the New Jersey Department of the American Legion.

On June 20 you reported Governor Dewey's Williams College commencement address of the previous day, and published an editorial on it. Much that the reporter and the editorial writer said seemed to me good and sound. But the way both dealt with Africa provides another example, along with others dishearteningly numerous, of how thin is the knowledge and how poor is the understanding of Africa and Africans in this day's United States.

LONDON, June 24 -- British Government bonds had further sharp falls in the stock market here today. An early promise of a quieter and steadier day was not fulfilled. Sellers reappeared around mid-day and prices began to slide down to close at the lowest marks of the week.
The Quartermaster Corps divulged its military housekeeping secrets yesterday as it opened a five-day tent show at Forty-eighth Street and Northern Boulevard, Long Island City.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- The Athletics fought an uphill battle today to defeat the White Sox, 7 -- 6. The victory left Philadelphia four and a half games behind the front-running Yankees.

President Truman's announced plans for the reorganization of the Maritime Commission, under terms of Reorganization Plan No. 6, is expected in local shipping circles to strengthen the operation of the governmental agency, it was learned yesterday.

The over-all business situation for June continues the downtrend reported in previous months, according to the composite opinion of purchasing agents who compose the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

THIS is not a conventional love story, as its title may lead one to believe. The boy-meets-girl formula has small place, if any, in a story about young ladies looking for young men. Mr. Skidmore's Emily Hewlett is one of the best who ever went hunting.

A working model of the statue of Thomas Paine that will be erected next year in Morristown, N. J., was exhibited last night by the sculptor, George J. Lober, in his studio at 33 West Sixty-seventh Street.

Former President Herbert Hoover was among three recipients of the Grand Medal of the Association des Ingenieurs-Docteurs de France at exercises yesterday afternoon in the Cultural Relations Division of the French Embassy at 934 Fifth Avenue.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 23 -- The Yugoslav Government is seeking loans totaling $250,000,000 from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, it was learned today from reliable sources. Earlier reports that the Yugoslav Government had requested loans for sums varying from $50,000,000 to $200,000,000 were said to have represented only parts of a series of requests totaling the $250,000,000 sum.

PARIS. IF you plan to pack your bags for France this summer, you can make them much lighter and your trip much easier by leaving behind some myths about the French. The general myth of French frivolity or lightheadedness is the big item. It includes the postcard version of "gay Paree" brought home from World War I -- can-can girls, champagne corks and oo-la-la.

Martin Rarbeck, anti-Communist secretary-treasurer of District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Paperhangers and Decorators, AFL, was re-elected to union office at a meeting yesterday afternoon at the St. Nicholas Annex, 66th Street and Columbus Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Voice of America beamed to Russia and the satellite countries is doing much good to those truth-impoverished lands, but at the same time one wonders if it is as effective as it could really be.

ROME, June 25 (AP) -- An informed Vatican source said today that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty's successor in Hungary had refused to announce official recognition of the Communist-dominated Hungarian Government.

WASHINGTON -- The Bureau of Internal Revenue said last week it was studying the purchase in Canada of tickets for transportation within the United States as a means of avoiding the 15 per cent Federal transport tax.

FEW gardeners realize that hillsides or woodlands pink with laurel and wild azaleas always indicate an acid or sour soil. Home grounds with this type of soil will maintain handsomer plantings if the broad-leaved evergreens and deciduous shrubs that prefer such conditions are selected.

DARIEN, Conn., June 25 -- Wee Burn Country Club's sixth annual member-guest golf tournament advanced to the semi-finals today, with no upsets recorded in the championship flight. One match was close, however, as Homer Orvis and his guest from Woodway, Harold Clark, won from Rudolph Montgelas and C. R. Hoopes of Wilmington, Del., 1 up.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called for a national CIO campaign today to impress upon President Truman and Congress the seriousness of the unemployment problem and the need for positive "remedial" steps to solve it.

THE first Hollywood unit to film a movie in Argentina has returned home with what may be fairly described as a mixed account of cooperation and opposition encountered during the making of "The Avengers." The project was sponsored by Republic Pictures in order to utilize frozen funds.

In its last season at the quarters it has occupied since 1939, the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, grossed a total of $5,618,628 in auction sales o fart, furniture and literary property, topping last year's receipts by $400,000.
IN Mr. [John] Dickson Carr's recent biography of my father, the late Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, there is one character which he has failed to portray correctly -- that of my mother.

CINCINNATI, June 25 (AP) -- Young Robin Roberts saved the day for veteran Ken Heintzelman today as he choked off a ninth-inning Cincinnati rally to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 6-5 victory over the Redlegs.

Authorization of banks to deal in securities of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will have the most marked effect in the marketing of future issues, but few banks are likely to establish themselves as dealers in the current market, according to financial observers.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 25 -- In a series of unanimous resolutions today, the Central Conference of American Rabbis called for the inclusion of Jerusalem within the boundaries of Israel, approved the administration of the Atomic Energy Commission and urged the full adoption of President Truman's civil rights program.

THE Land of the Free series when completed will offer an over-all picture of the groups that make up our country. The stories so far published have been distinguished junior novels in their own right, and "Sign of the Golden Fish" is no exception.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- The Department of Commerce report for April, issued here last week, disclosed that total retail trade throughout the Twelfth District showed favorable gains over the same month of last year. In the Pacific Coast region, the following gains were shown: San Francisco Bay area, 6 per cent; Union County, Oregon, 18 per cent; King County, Washington, 3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Truman's proposal for the expenditure of $45,000,000 next year to assist under-developed areas of the world to raise their standards of living met a cautiously favorable reception in Congress today. Most members available for comment said they wanted to examine yesterday's Presidential message in detail, but indicated that the plan would receive sympathetic hearing.

Dr. A. Wolman, Professor of Sanitary Engineering at Johns Hopkins, says that even at this late date there are more than 9,000 communities that have no sewage systems. In rural districts 33,000,000 live in houses that have no satisfactory drainage. In 1947 more than 5,000,000 dwelling units had either no private baths or toilets at all or baths and toilets that were out of order.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 25 -- Once again the Deep South is witnessing a wave of community terrorism.

ENGLAND in 1216, when the French were invading her, is the scene for this story. Gerald, the young squire of Ravensmark, was in the thick of the fighting, as well he might be, for he was battling for his country, his captive brother and the lady Elizabeth.

EDWARD G. ROBINSON, who came in from Hollywood the other day and reiterated his denial of Communist affiliations or leanings, divulged before boarding a plane for Europe that the trip was not a vacation but strictly business.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- A report by the Department of Agriculture that damage to wheat in the Southwest has not been large sent the bread cereal lower on the Board of Trade today. Wheat sank about a cent a bushel from the previous close after opening up strong on a burst of buying.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- Economic activity in the Twelfth Federal Reserve District -- California and all or part of six other Western states -- has assumed an attitude of caution rather than pessimism. The consensus: business is in a settling process; conditions may become slightly worse before they improve, but no depression is in the making.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- After four more Congressional working days a new fiscal year of Government spending will set in. To finance operations at home and abroad, some $42 billion has been partly approved. Almost $30 billion of it, however, is still under Congressional controversy.

A new organization, the American Brazilian Trade Council, has been formed here by a group of export concerns doing the major part of their business with the largest South American country, it was learned last week.
LITERATURE is not flourishing here at the moment. It may still be reeling from the blow dealt it in 1940 by the almost simultaneous death of Verner von Heidenstam, Selma Lagerlof and Albert Engstrom.

HONOLULU, June 25 -- Statehood for Hawaii has suffered a setback through a strike of the territory's stevedores, according to a cross-section of island opinion. The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, to which 2,000 striking stevedores belong, is strong for making Hawaii the forty-ninth state.

ROME, Italy, Sunday, June 26 (UP) -- Italian customs agents disclosed today they have arrested Vincent Trupia of 377 Broome Street, New York, for trying to smuggle $500,000 worth of cocaine out of Italy by air. The inspector said the man may be linked with Charles (Lucky) Luciano, former vice ruler of New York.

THE poor harassed ticket-sellers are constantly being blamed for being discourteous. On the contrary, it's the New York theatregoer who is appallingly rude and thoughtless. I don't think any playgoer this season bought more tickets than I did and they were all purchased at the box office.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 24 -- There has been a week of feverish activity both here and in Washington as a result of the steep drop in the price of copper -- a blow to Chile's economy -- and the announcement of the proposed reestablishment of a 2-cent excise tax on importations of the metal into the United States.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 25 -- A colorful convention of the New Jersey and New York Volunteer Firemen's Association, held today at Bogota, N. J., had an unfortunate aftermath at 6:45 o'clock this evening, when eight volunteer firemen from Piermont, N. Y., were injured at Oradell, five miles from here, while returning home in their fire truck.

BOSTON, June 25 -- A drop of 2,616 in claims for unemployment compensation this week in Massachusetts from the previous week's figure of 198,514 was seen in the first Federal Reserve District as a possible leveling-off stage in post-war readjustment.

THE ubiquitous autograph hunters have found a new outlet for their specialized talents in television. The signature collectors now are making pictures of television stars as they appear on the screen and mailing their prints to the studios to be signed and sent back.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 25 -- Political history will be made in Belgium tomorrow when 5,500,000 voters go to the polls, more than double the highest number ever to have participated in a general election in this country.
LONDON, June 25 -- Contending that the shipowners were refusing to honor an agreement reached yesterday, leaders of the Canadian seamen said today their strike was on again.

THE exceptionally dry weather that we have been having this summer has been hard on lawns. But even lawns that are badly dried out and burned brown can be made green again in short order. Liberal watering is the cure.

Francis Williams states in "An Appraisal of European Socialism," "Despite their differences in economic principle, there is no reason why a satisfactory and cooperative accommodation should not be reached between the European Socialists and American capitalism." * * *

PATCHOGUE, L. I., June 25 -John A. Robbins, 39 years old, a music composer of 152 East Sixtyfirst Street, Manhattan, early today was ordered held without bail until Monday, when he will face examination on a second-degree murder charge.

LONDON, June 25 -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, 21 - year - old United States singles titleholder, was spilled out of the Wimbledon tennis championships today in a sensational upset by the two-handed shots of Australia's Geoff Brown.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 25 -- At a stormy session here this afternoon the delegates to the convention of the National Young Republican Federation elected John Tope, Navy veteran and Detroit business man, chairman of the federation to succeed Ralph E. Becker of New York.

BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., June 25 -- With her youngest crew at their stations and Comdr. Donald B. MacMillan at the helm, the schooner Bowdoin nosed her way out to sea this afternoon on the first leg of her eighteenth voyage to the Arctic.

JERUSALEM, June 25 -- Although the Roman Catholic Church and Israel do not see eye to eye on all matters currently facing them here, there seems to have been a lessening of tension between them recently. The Israeli Government's willingness to pay reparations for war damage to religious places and to check looting appears to have had a conciliatory effect.

AS the summer group exhibitions open, most of them more or less retrospective of the season's activities in the respective galleries, the visitor is impressed anew with the diversity and vitality of contemporary American painting. And certain corollary conclusions inevitably come to mind.

NO mere "legend" could have inspired the warmth which glows in this vignette, strong and delicate in its delineation, of a Mother in Israel who lived her full life in the spirit of that "virtuous woman" of whom King Lemuel bequeathed so memorable a portrait.
CLEVELAND, June 25 -- Though the economic situation in this Federal Reserve District is disturbing, the trend is not yet considered serious by industrial leaders, merchants or business men.

The coming world-wide Goethe festival will be observed at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, on Wednesday at noon when the two-hour recorded concert will feature the German author's favorite music. Beethoven's "Egmont Overture," composed for Goethe's play, will open the program and compositions by Mozart and Bach will also be heard.

ONE wonders what our friends in the Soviet Embassy in Washington will say to this able and sophisticated -- and not exactly realistic -- new novel by the author of "Marriage Is a Private Affair." Miss Kelly posits (of all things) a private affair of a most extraordinary sort inside the Soviet Embassy -- a secret, "liberal" religious movement designed to defeat war hawks in Moscow and to produce a lasting peace.

ATHENS, June 25 (AP) -- Sophocles Venizelos said today the Liberal party would not join a Government headed by Constantin Tsaldaris, Populist leader. Despite this setback, Mr. Tsaldaris continued his efforts to form a Cabinet.

TRICKY is a young red fox, inquisitive, smart and full of mischief. His curiosity gets him into trouble and produces adventures that make exciting reading. He outwits a trapper and laughs at him; he discovers the ore that prospectors are seeking and makes two friends: with Vixen, his mate, he battles with an older and larger fox and later with two eagles, and he and Vixen warn other animals of a forest fire.

ONE of the most desirable attributes of tall bearded iris -- and one that is generally overlooked -- is fragrance. For most people coming upon a large block of iris in flower are only subconsciously aware of the indefinite perfume which scents the air.

The expansion of educational facilities in the Bronx, especially in the Clason Point section, was reflected in the teaching career of Miss Isabella Stewart, principal jointly of Public Schools 107 and 69 in that borough, who was honored yesterday by present and former associates on the eve of her retirement.

AMONG its manifold phenomena, Los Angeles boasts the nation's only metropolitan newspaper with a female city editor. The paper is the Hearst-owned Evening Herald and Express. The city editor, of two years' standing, is Agness Underwood, who at 47 has managed, along with running a home and raising two children, to pack in twenty-three years as a feminine counterpart of Hecht and MacArthur's fictional Hildy Johnson.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 25 (AP) -- The head of the Ku Klux Klan in Alabama tonight ordered members to stop wearing hoods.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- The American Furniture Mart, sponsor of semi-annual home furnishings markets that have been an important factor in the development of mass distribution in the industry, is celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary this summer.

LONDON, June 25 (Reuters) -A record sixth-wicket partnership of 189 by Denis Compton, Middle-sex all-rounder, and Trevor Bailey, Essex fast bowler, enabled England to declare today at 313 for nine on the first day of the second cricket test against New Zealand at Lords.

Efforts to save pennies in the finishing of textiles to meet the demand for lower prices has posed a serious problem of quality deterioration, it was learned last week. Complaints and return of merchandise have increased, retailers said, and steps are being considered in certain segments of the textile trade to work out an over-all consumer information program to alleviate the situation.

THE Old Farmer's Almanack makes no general prognostications on the sort of summer that lies ahead. But whether temperatures are above or below normal, cold drinks will be as much a part of the seasonal scene as screen doors and air-conditioning.

SHANGHAI, June 25 -- The British steamer Foochow slipped out through the mouth of the Yangtze tonight just a few hours before the deadline of the announced Nationalist closure of the China coast from Foochow to Manchuria.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Truman finally sent his "Point Four" program for the under-developed areas of the world to Congress this week amid disturbing signs that Points One, Two and Three of his foreign policy are not making satisfactory progress.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Dr. Robert L. Johnson, chairman of the Citizens Committee on the Hoover Report, urging prompt enactment of the Tydings bill to strengthen existing armed service unification laws, warned today that "scandal will be an ever present possibility" until basic faults in the armed forces are corrected by legislation.
Stifling humidity and intense heat enveloped the city yesterday and 3,000,000 persons sought relief at beaches, a record this season for a Saturday.

FOR THIS WEEK: Look over house plants summering outdoors for any necessary watering or spraying. . . Sow again, for late bloom, seeds of quick-flowering, short-lived annuals such as sweet alyssum, poppies, nigella and portulaca. . . . Feed roses lightly when the first heavy bloom is finished, and water fertilizer into the soil. . . .

LONDON'S Covent Garden has been in the spotlight for the last three years, not only as England's first experiment in Government - subsidized opera, but because it has given ballet the same stature as opera and alternated the two in weekly repertoire. Its 1948-49 season ended on June 18, and the report is that ballet has drawn better than opera.

WARSAW, June 25 -- Disclosing large-scale losses to the Polish economy as a result of widespread sabotage, the Government has called upon the trade unions to sharpen their search for anti-state agents in industry.

THE Black Hills are a range of mountains in southwestern South Dakota with a slight spill over into Wyoming. Singers of American folksongs know the Hills as the inspiration of that mournful song of regional satire, "The Dreary Black Hills."

THIS century has seen the steady decline of faith in extreme economic solutions. Unchecked private ownership leads to intolerable economic instability, while unchecked state ownership leads to intolerable political tyranny. The result has been to drive men of good-will to seek for solutions in the center.

President Truman and Secretary of State Acheson each contributed something last week to popular understanding of our foreign policy: Mr. Truman by his Point Four message, Mr. Acheson in his press conference. Mr. Acheson was dealing with the results of the Paris Conference, Mr. Truman with a program that must start slowly and may take decades to complete.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 25 -- The Mizrachi Organization of America tonight urged the United States to reconsider its recent policy towards Israel and use its influence to induce the Arab Governments to accept its offers of direct negotiations for permanent peace.
ATLANTA, Ga., June 25 -- Business leaders in the Southeastern States, comprising the Sixth Federal Reserve District, are becoming increasingly concerned over current economic trends.

EVERY garden has little shaded corners or spots where nothing will grow -- not even grass. In these areas, only devious methods will serve to bring bright color. So-called "portable" plants seem to effect the quickest and easiest results.

THE use of chemicals as a means of controlling and destroying weeds around the home is becoming a fairly usual practice. The broadleaved weeds in lawns, ragweed in abandoned lots and poison ivy at the edge of the playground are easy victims of chemical eradication.

WASHINGTON, Del., June 25 (AP) -- King Ranch's Flying Missel equaled the Delaware Park track record of 2:02 in winning the twelfth running of the mile and a quarter $25,000 added Sussex Handicap today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The deputies to the Big Four Foreign Ministers will begin next Thursday to draft a peace treaty with Austria, the State Department announced today. They will meet in London, under instructions from the Council of Foreign Ministers, adopted at the recent Paris meeting, to have a draft treaty ready by Sept. 1.

In promotions here last week retailers emphasized garden furniture, Hawaiian floral dinnerware, men's sports shirts, bathing suits, children's suntogs, nylon taffeta dresses and lace-trimmed rayon crepe slips, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.
TOKYO, June 25 -- If present Government plans materialize, several Japanese key industries will be shaken to their foundations this autumn.
It will be Bobby Riggs against Don Budge, for the fourth time since 1942, in today's final of the national professional tennis championship at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 25 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the home club, holder of the New York State championship for the past three years, won the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship for the fourth time today by defeating Miss Evelyn Odom, Wheatley Hills, 4 and 2, at the Cherry Valley Club.
Store sales of summer merchandise, which began on a small scale during the last several weeks, will become the largest in many years by next week, retailers disclosed here yesterday.

THE big and persistent question of why doesn't Hollywood make more films specifically for children has been buzzed in these precincts of late by several organizations that have the interests of the kiddies at heart.

THERE is a new trend in the literature of natural history. We have an increasing number of books, both good and bad, that on the one hand are devoted exclusively to one animal and on the other to nature as a whole. The former are of a much higher standard.

Regarding Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's "The Case for National Health Insurance," it would be well for all sides to stop their not-so-cold war and push legislation upon which all are agreed. Whether we have prepaid voluntary or compulsory health insurance, we will need a great increase in plant and personnel.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 18 -- Statistics release by the oil industry here indicate that production during the last week of May reached 1,304,000 barrels daily, the highest average since the end of last year. Additional figures from the Banco Central de Venezuela show that Venezuela is still receiving substantially more dollars than she spends, and ended the first five months of 1949 with a surplus of $37,000,000.

TAKING the family on a transcontinental motor tour does not have to be an expensive undertaking. The writer, his wife and two children made a fifty-five-day coast-to-coast camping trip that covered the Pacific Northwest and northern California, included a dozen national parks, forests and monuments on the 9,312-mile route and cost a total of only $616.97.

A king and queen of Chinatown were selected yesterday in Columbus Park, Mulberry and Park Streets, in the fourth annual Chinese Baby Contest, sponsored by the Chinese Community Club. But after they were picked it was found that they were the only two children among the 104 entered in the contest who didn't live in Chinatown.

HE interior design of the penthouse apartment of a wealthy bachelor would not. off hand. be expected to provide furnishings ideas for the harassed middle-income mother of three. Not. at lea3t, i you take it literally. But if the expensive materials and the one-of-a-kind custom designs are divorced from the basic furnishing ideas, the elegant interior takes on a more feasible aspect.
IT could be that the long-awaited turn in retail book prices has come, although no one in the trade is delivering any orations about it yet.

THURSDAY will see the start of the July Fourth exodus to beaches and the country for the four-day week-end. July Fourth, the biggest holiday of the year in point of numbers leaving and entering the city, puts a heavy load on all transport systems.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 25 -Champion Valiant of Draham, 3year-old black and silver dog belonging to David I. McCahill of Wrentham, Mass., took the main prize in the second specialty of the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island today at the Garden City Hotel.

TIME was when a child splashing with bright paints was fondly thought to be a future genius. But in recent years the art of children has been increasingly considered an entirely separate thing, a spurt of adolescent creativeness, of greatest immediate significance but without any necessary bearing on the future.

BERLIN, June 25 -- Unwittingly or otherwise, the Foreign Ministers at Paris did a great deal toward completing the division of Germany between the East and the West beyond any immediate hope of reunion.

CAIRO, June 24 -- The United States is drafting plans in its Middle Eastern information headquarters here to wage a counter-offensive against Soviet propaganda and agitation among the strategically situated 4,000,000 Kurds.

LONDON, June 25 -- The Western European Union went into action today to defend Britain in the biggest air maneuvers since the war. For the first time in peace foreign air forces joined in "battles" designated to yield lessons in offensive and defensive tactics based on greatly improved speeds of modern jet planes.

Now that most of the nation's colleges and universities have held their commencements, the most pressing problem confronting the record number of graduates is that of finding a job. The competition this year is going to be greater than at any time since Pearl Harbor.

The announcement last week by Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson that the Navy will modernize two more of its Essex-class carriers to permit operations of heavier, longer-range carrier planes by no means ends service differences.

"THE BLACK ROBE," which re-creates typical cases arising in night court, is a remarkably successful example of television's peculiar ability to project absolute realism and naturalness. By abjuring most of the usual theatrical tricks and letting personalities speak for themselves, it is probably one of the most absorbing half hours on video.

President Truman has made a proposal which would horrify past generations of American politicians, if they could be here to listen to it. This is nothing less than to take the Post Office Department out of politics. At the present time this Department, with about 490,000 employes, is the largest business in the Western world.
USUALLY when a bridge player sits long and ponders (in the vernacular, "goes into a huddle") a bid or play, he is not really analyzing the situation and deciding what to do.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP -- With the Red Sox blasting 17 hits, Mel Parnell, southpaw ace, today coasted to his tenth victory, a 13-2 decision over the Browns, who suffered their third consecutive Fenway Park setback.

MEXICO CITY -- The dollar-short Mexican Government is studying ways by which it can make life easier for one of the country's most welcome guests -- the rentier, or long-term visitor from beyond the border, who is financially able to live in a foreign country for extended periods of time.
With proceeds to go to organizations sponsoring sandlot baseball in New York, the Yankees and the Giants will clash tomorrow night at the Yankee Stadium in the annual Mayor O'Dwyer Trophy game.

THE primrose family (primula) includes an enormous number of species and varieties. A gardener who has experienced the pleasure of growing some of the easy kinds will find the less common forms a challenge to his skill.

DAVID THOMPSON, whom George Washington called "the greatest land geographer who ever lived," is the central figure in this tale. Of Welsh blood, he was taken from a London charity school in 1784 and apprenticed to the Hudson's Bay Company.

PEARL PRIMUS, who is studying the native dances of Africa on a Rosenwald Fellowship, is apparently having herself a time. Formal recitals under the patronage of the Governor of Nigeria are so successful that they have to be repeated, the whole dance population of Benin City performs its dances especially for her and there are full-page spreads in the Nigerian Daily Times.

Prospects for increased common stock dividends to some of the 3,000,000 investors in the electric utility industry brightened perceptibly last week following such action by one of the major power systems.

Before the International Association for Dental Research Drs. John W. Hein and William G. Shafer of the University of Rochester's School of Medicine reported last week that sodium copper chlorophyllin, a water soluble derivative of chlorophyll, has produced "very encouraging results" in controlling and preventing tooth decay.

A heat-pump is a contrivance which collects heat at a certain temperature from the earth, a body of water or the air and delivers it at a higher temperature to the rooms of a residence or any other building. To raise the temperature a gas is compressed when it is returned after circulating through coils in contact with the heat source.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 25 -- The fifty-seven-room mansion of the late J. P. Morgan, which cost more than $1,000,000 to build almost forty years ago, was sold on the auction block this morning to the city of Glen Cove for tax arrears of $5,233.

Intensive competition and over-optimism in regard to consumer demand has caused the television-receiver industry to begin considerable cut-backs of the over-all industry production schedule begun on Jan. 1, an industry spokesman declared yesterday.

In the Old State Department Building in Washington, the President's Council of Economic Advisers and its staff last week were putting in long hours -- so long that the office windows shone into the late summer darkness. Nearly every day one or another of the Council went across the street to the White House for a talk with the President.

CANCER is as old as life. Plants, animals and men have died of it for thousands of years. Yet experimental research in cancer, research that deserves to be called scientific, began only fifty years ago.

Exhaustion of the soil and forest resources of this country is one of the truly serious problems facing the people of the United States. The facts of the case are slowly but surely forcing attention to this situation, which has far more direct bearing on the welfare of the nation than much of the more exciting news that properly makes the headlines.

Charles Giovinco, a 13-year-old southpaw from Brooklyn, won the city-wide marble shooting championship yesterday in the final play of the twentieth annual marble shooting tournament conducted by the Department of Parks. He defeated seventeen other borough champions.

NATIVE health and nervous energy are of course basic considerations in the matter, but these alone do not suffice to explain the elan with which many of our greatest musicians pursue their activities and live most vividly in the years beyond as well as before the biblical three-score and ten.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Dropping prices and reduced shortages are hastening the removal of Federal controls that have lingered through the war, reconversion and postwar boom periods.

IN 1543 Andreas Vesalius -- "anatomist, surgeon, teacher, philologist, artist, philosopher and poet" -- by the publication of his monumental anatomical treatise, "De Fabrica Humani Corporis," laid the foundation for modern medicine.

THE mutual economic discomfort now being shared by the American railroads, their passengers and their freight shippers will be studied at length at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing on July 13 in the St. George Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, June 25 -- Spokesmen for the 3,600 faculty members of the University of California said today they thought the new "loyalty oath" prescribed by the University Board of Regents for all university employes would be generally acceptable to the faculty.

DR. DROOZ is one of those rare dreamers who has made her dream come true. As a growing girl, she became imbued with the urge to study medicine, realizing all the while how greatly the odds stood against her. In the first place she had little or no money.

Don McNeill, the East's No. 2 ranking player who recently has not been campaigning as actively as he did back at the start of the decade when he won the National title in 1940, made his perennial appearance at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills yesterday to take part in the New York State tennis championships.

FRESNO, Calif., June 25 -- Taking first and second in the hammer throw, the New York Athletic Club moved into a substantial early lead tonight in defense of its team title in the National Amateur Athletic Union senior track and field championships.

THE chief officers of the Queen Alexandra, the big transatlantic luxury liner, want to keep the horrid news of the murder of a woman passenger aboard ship from reaching the ears of the other passengers. Unfortunately, the body is found by Peter Almsford, a nice young Englishman in an adjoining stateroom.

READERS of that long-term best-seller, "Cheaper by the Dozen," will need no introduction to Frank and Lillian Gilbreth, those pioneers in industrial engineering (i.e., efficiency experts) now presented in this full-length, sober-sided biography -- which is partly a personal history of its two leading characters, but mostly a careful evaluation of their "motion studies," and the long struggle to put these theories into triumphant practice.

DURING those periods when she was not actively engaged in having an affair with her best friend's husband Harriet Berkeley liked to fill in the time day dreaming about him -- as much as she could, that is, in the hours left over from the irritating duty of running a house for her own husband.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 25 -- Minister of Justice Alexei Cepicka today on one hand cautioned the Communists against offending the religious sensibilities of the people and on the other warned the Roman Catholic hierarchy that "it will soon find out that it is not possible in this country to force priests and laymen into anti-state activity."
SEROWE, Bechuanaland, June 25 (AP) -- Seretse Khama won the Bamangwato tribal throne for his white queen and today a sorrowing tribal chief chose voluntary exile rather than kneel to her.

NOT the Harper children, Janie and Bob, nor their soft-spoken parents frightened the pair of mockingbirds who built a nest above the garage doors. It was Paddy, the Harpers' cat, his jaws a-slavering for bird-bones, that disturbed the mockers.

Production of the Riviera, an addition to the 1949 Buick line, was announced yesterday by Ivan L. Wiles, general manager of the Buick division of General Motors Corporation. The new model resembles a convertible type but has an all-steel immovable top. It will be displayed in this city next month.

JUST the other day a casual mention was made in this space of Johnny Blood, "the truly fabulous character who played half-back for the Green Bay Packers." Johnny had entered the discussion only by the rear door because he had been held up as an example of endurance since he and Mel Hein are the co-holders of the longevity record of professional football, fifteen seasons.

EDGAR ALLAN POE has never lacked either biographers or interpreters. Baudelaire, Mallarme and Barbey d'Aurevilly saw him as a literary giant sweeping away the barriers of language. Joseph Wood Krutch has given him a Freudian classification and a French lady of title has psychoanalyzed him posthumously.

THIS new book on Yeats, subtitled "Essays on Some Principles of Poetry in the Lyrics of William Butler Yeats," by the author of the popular "Nature of Poetry," is a model of criticism, clear, compressed and enthusiastic.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 25 -- Richard L. Gray, president of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor, charged today that Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, "is biased against labor and unfair in his administration of the Taft-Hartley Law."
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- A steady but moderate slump in most lines of business activity characterizes the economic picture in the Third Federal Reserve District

The offshore fishing season started early this year, and with school tuna, white marlin and broadbill available, anglers can put to sea over the Fourth of July week-end with excellent prospects for good fishing.

ATHENS, Ala., June 25 -- Speaker of the House Sam Rayburn, in an address delivered in a region politically dominated by the States' Rights Democrats, stoutly defended today the progressive policies of the national Democratic Administration under Presidents Roosevelt and Truman.

HAVING recently returned from a five-week tour of South Africa, where I functioned as conductor and pianist in collaboration with Lauritz Melchior, I may perhaps be permitted to set down some of my impressions of the musical life in that distant land.

PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- None of the 19,800 perspiring customers who watched today's exhibition of the so-called national pastime at Forbes Field is likely to forget it. Neither will big Ralph Branca, who turned in his ninth triumph against only one defeat despite serving up five home-run balls.

WITH Franklin D. Roosevelt's portrait in black at left and a plane at right are five imperforate 30-centavos official airmail stamps received from Ecuador by Scott Publications, Inc., the respective colors being green, brown, blue, red and orange.

NO word in the reviewer's lexicon is more commonly abused than "realism." Constantly it is applied to work which is factually accurate only for that restricted aspect of life which the novelist would have you see; if he admits to your view only the debit side of human nature, he is no more a realist than the sentimentalist who prettifies life.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., June 25 -Miss Jean Woodham, 11 West Tenth Street, New York, today was named winner of the eighteenth annual award of the Kate Neal Kinley Memorial Fellowship of $1,000, established by the late President Emeritus David Kinley of the University of Illinois.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Food, apparel and housefurnishings prices in the Chicago area slipped another notch during the month ending May 15, according to a report issued here last week by the United States Bureau of Labor regional office.
GENEVA, June 25 -- A united American labor movement took the lead here today in laying the foundations for a new anti-Communist international trade union organization.

I was much interested by Jack Gould's "What Is Television Doing to Us?" but you did not tell what it will do to the eyes, if anything. Concentrated watching, hour after hour, with the slight flicker which is present in even the best sets, might have a bad effect.

The oil industry is concerned over the possible outcome of the public hearings scheduled to start tomorrow in Washington by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on prices of gasoline. That every phase of the petroleum industry, both here and abroad, may be subjected to a thorough airing is indicated by the recent statement of Senator Burnet R. Maybank, chairman of the committee, that the hearings may run a year.
WITHOUT name-calling, the bout between Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh and the theatre ticket brokers has passed from the jabbing to the slugging phase.

SCIENTIFIC methods of preserving flowers have long been practiced by the Japanese, but only lately has the garden public in this country become "preservative conscious." The current surge of interest in this subject undoubtedly stems from an almost unprecedented activity in flower arranging and showing.

In Jack Gould's "What Is Television Doing to Us?" some prognosticators are quoted as saying the growth of television will make us "a nation of lookers instead of doers," and I feel inclined to dispute this point of view.

JOHN GUNTHER, that indefatigable delver into contemporary history at home and abroad, confesses that he overcame the temptation to call his first post-war book about Europe "Inside Outside Russia." That is well, for there is nothing "inside" about the picture he presents of a Europe in an evolutionary and revolutionary ferment.
LONDON, June 25 -- Any crisis in United States-British relations over the British-Argentine trade agreement seems from this capital to be more apparent than real.
DETROIT, June 25 -- Wage negotiations between representatives of the Chrysler Corporation and the CIO United Automobile Workers will begin within a week, union and company spokesmen said today.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 -- The Democratic party, declared to have made the nation prosperous and strong by its establishment of agencies to assist the people, has no fear of opponents' epithets charging the party with developing a socialistic state, Vice President Alben W. Barkley declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Government officials concerned with the matter take a long-range view of the current unemployment situation and are, on the whole, comforted by what they see. They recognize, for example, that having 3,300,000 out of jobs today is not so serious an omen as it would have been in the Nineteen Twenties, when the total labor force was much smaller.

Scientists of the New York Agricultural Experiment Station at Geneva, N. Y., have found out why strawberries are red. The red pigment has been isolated. It turns out to be anthocyanin. Very little of it is required to give strawberries their color. One two-hundredths of an ounce to a pound of berries is enough.

TOKYO, June 15 -- The Japanese are up to their old pre-war tricks of poaching in foreign fishing fields, according to charges now being made by Soviet authorities. It has been disclosed that twenty-one Japanese fishing vessel have been seized by the Russians since 1946 for violating the "MacArthur Line" off northern Hokkaido and that one now is being held at a Russian port pending payment of a fine demanded by the Soviet.

SUN-DAL, a new and different ornamental sunflower, will be seen in some gardens this year. This new hybrid grows on a sunflower stalk, but the blooms have dahlia-like characteristics. In fact, the broad petals are shaped more like a dahlia than a sunflower.
OTTAWA, June 25 -- On Monday the Canadian people will elect a new Parliament. By their votes they will select 262 men and women out of a total of 848 candidates to represent them.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee moved today to curb the Atomic Energy Commission's authority to spend money for construction projects.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Gil Coan hit a home run with two out and one on in the ninth inning today to give the Washington Senators a 4-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians before a crowd of 9,695.

Steps have been taken to start the first national research survey of distribution costs, officials of the National Association of Cost Accountants disclosed here yesterday following their return from the society's annual convention at Chicago last week.

BERNARD BLACKSTONE offers his "Virginia Woolf" as "a commentary." "I have aimed," he says, "at presenting Virginia Woolf as an explorer of different worlds of experience -- different, but intricately related, as they all are the creations of a human mind working upon the phenomena which veil reality.
Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, who will celebrate his diamond jubilee birthday next month, had reason to beam at all hands at Aqueduct yesterday.
DETROIT, June 25 -- The first use of the hydra-matic automatic transmission outside the General Motors Corporation was announced today by the Lincoln-Mercury Division of the Ford Motor Company.

JO MORA, who has been sculpturing and painting in California since he left the Texas border four decades ago, celebrates here in words and pictures the bow-legged genus vaquero as it flourished on the Coast in the pastoral age.

MR. CAMPBELL undertakes to reinterpret all mythologies on the basis chiefly, but not exclusively, of Jung's psychoanalytical theories. Freud is cited almost as much as Jung, and Geza, Roheim, Wilhelm Stekel and Otto Rank are frequently referred to.

IN many a household the moment is at hand when Junior or Sister is receiving a last-minute admonition to be good, and careful, too: when handkerchiefs, pocket-money and travel instructions are checked over once more and a neatly combed head or so gets fond farewell pats. The youngsters are heading for summer camps.

STAMPS with aggregate catalogue values approximating a million dollars will be sold publicly through S. Serebrakian at the Hotel Astor this week. For the most part the 3,368 lots to be offered comprise wholesale quantities, representing liquidation of parts of stocks of dealers throughout the world.

MAGIC is the word that has been woven around the literary personality of Shirley Jackson, the latest to join the select corps of triumphant women short-story writers who apparently flourish in America. Of the stories that make up her surprisingly high-selling collection -- entitled "The Lottery" -- critics have said they signaled a return to an era of witchcraft and magic, the supernatural and some sort of devil worship.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Dixiana's Star Reward, an 11-to-1 shot, registered a smashing upset today in the $27,800 Equipoise Mile at Arlington Park by defeating Coaltown, beaten for the first time this year after eight victories.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 93,922, as against 142,731 a year ago, a decrease of 34.2 per cent. For 1949 to date, carloadings totaled 2,658,209, compared with 3,037,650 in 1948, a decrease of 12.5 per cent.

A VACATION canoe trip need not involve an extended safari into a distant wilderness nor need the canoeist have bulging muscles or be endowed with the wood lore of a Daniel Boone. Within a day's drive of New York City lies the Fulton Chain of Lakes with one of the most popular canoeing trips in the Adirondacks.

A week ago this column dealt with the provision of income tax law permitting compensation received by an inventor in one taxable year for work done during a number of prior years to be spread ratably over thirty-six months. In the course of the discussion reference was made by way of comparison to services rendered by a lawyer.
Barring a drastic economic upset, the paper industry can look to a flow of new products to offset price declines with increased volume, key officials declared last week.

Coming from behind to knot the score at 3 -- 3 in the seventh inning, George Washington matched it with three more in the tenth frame to defeat Tottenville, 6 -- 3, for the P. S. A. L. baseball championship of the city yesterday at Ebbets Field. Washington turned the trick although outhit, 8 to 4.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, June 25 (AP) -- The Indonesian Republic announced today that the Moscow-trained Communist leader, Tan Malaka, and three other Indonesian Communists, including the former Republican Premier, Amir Sjarifuddin, have been executed.

NANKING, June 25 -- The Nationalist order closing all ports in Chinese territorial waters from Yingkow, Manchuria, southward to Foochow on the Fukien coast, which goes into effect tomorrow, is regarded here as a clever but risky move, raising the entire question of the National Government's future status.

VIENNA, June 25 -- Austrians hoping that their soil will be free of occupation troops and a state treaty ratified by early next year were surprised at Russia's offer at the recently concluded meeting of the Big Four in Paris. The question seemed to be why Soviet Russia decided to grant Austria her freedom now on terms which could have been obtained from the Western Allies a year ago.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 24 -- Active arrangements have been initiated for the establishment of a committee of creditors, bondholders and stockholders of the former I. G. Farben chemical trust, as one of the steps in the dissolution of the monopoly and the sale of its properties.
The downward economic swing in the Second Federal Reserve District became more pronounced in the past three months.

BERLIN, June 25 -- The commandants of the Western powers in Berlin offered to the railroad strikers of the Western sectors tonight 100 per cent of their wages in West marks, and warned them that if this offer plus Russian assurances that there would be no reprisals were not accepted, unemployment relief for the strikers would be halted on Tuesday.

The first successful animal tests of the new mold-derived chemical, neomycin, against the deadly germs of human tuberculosis were announced yesterday at a conference on the experimental approach to tuberculosis, held under the auspices of the biology section of the New York Academy of Sciences at the American Museum of Natural History.

Seeking to refute an "anonymous-letter campaign" against the teaching profession, Dean Carter V. Good of the University of Cincinnati recently conducted a spot survey to determine Whether being a teacher decreases a woman's opportunities for marriage.

GERMAN genius has been embodied in three monumental figures -- one religious, one creative, one political -- who, despite the diversity of their personalities, their times and their missions, reveal a definite family likeness. This likeness lies in their immense and isolating greatness, which seems to transcend the European norm.

RICHMOND, Va., June 25 -- Business conditions generally have been sagging steadily since last Christmas, but economists believe the bottom will be reached in July. In key manufacturing industries, production then may be off as much as 35 per cent from the post-war peak.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 25 -- Business leaders in the Ninth Federal Reserve District are generally inclined to view the current economic picture as one of "necessary and orderly readjustment" rather than as containing the shadows of another depression.
"An obliging bear is more dangerous than an enemy."

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June. 25 -- The New York State Association of Real Estate Boards decided today to wage an active fight throughout the state to defeat the proposed $300,000,000 bond issue for more public housing and additional subsidies. This comes up for a vote next fall.

Sometimes coincidence is too pat. It is hard to believe, for example, that the fact that Mr. Vishinsky raised the question of a Japanese peace treaty in Paris at the same time that the Chinese Communists began their radio overtures to the Japanese on the same topic was pure chance.

WITH competition in recordings reasonably stiff even as things are, new importations keep appearing on the market to add to the problems of the domestic manufacturers and to the joys and opportunities of the customers.

In terms of a long-range prospect for favorable growth, the packaging industry can consider itself in good health, although it is in the probable final stages of re-adjustment from abnormal post-war demands and scarcities. These conclusions highlight the second in a new series of Department of Commerce quarterly reports on the industry, made available here yesterday.

THIS book, written in Germany in 1798, strikes for us today a strangely modern note. It contains, it is true, certain autobiographical allusions clear only to a scholar, and it sometimes refers to philosophical problems that were considered of greater moment in eighteenth century Europe than they are in twentieth century America.

SOUTH HARPSWELL, Me., June 25 (AP) -- The 24-year-old wife of an artist shot herself after a quarrel with her husband over doing th dishes in their automatic washer, Deputy Sheriff Norman Emerson said today.

Jimmy Mullane's blue eyes sparkled with expectation as the fireman lifted him gently from his wheelchair into the pony cart. When the dappled Shetland trundled the cart out across the sun-drenched lawn, the boy's freckled face broke into a smile and his thin hand tightened around the string of a yellow balloon.

The nation's schools are failing to teach the full implications of atomic energy, Professors Hubert M. Evans and Ryland W. Crary of Teachers College, Columbia University, write in the forthcoming issue of the Teachers College Record.

DR. D. J. RUZICKA, dean of American amateur photographers, has been elected Honorary Fellow of the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain, according to an announcement just received from the society's headquarters in London.

HUDSON, N. Y., June 25 -- Restored and renovated, Clermont Academy was dedicated this afternoon as a war memorial to the men and women from the town of Clermont, Columbia County, who served in both World Wars.

VIRGINIA EVANS has a nice talent for satire, and it is therefore regrettable that so much of her first novel is devoted to soap opera. Lloyd and Caroline Andrews, married fifteen months, living in a veterans' village near the university where Lloyd studies law, have real and funny difficulties in adjusting their temperaments to life together.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 25 -- The Suffolk County office of the Production and Marketing Administration of the United States Department of Agriculture here, of which Elmer J. Mather of East Moriches is the county representative, reports that 718 of the 1,026 commercial growers of potatoes in the county have signed up to participate in the acreage-control program of the United States Department of Agriculture for 1949.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 -- Although all shades of opinion about economic conditions may be found in the Eighth Federal Reserve District, there is not a great deal of optimism. The consensus seems to be that business will get worse.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Fifteen Republican House members today called the scheduled repayment of $2,800,000,000 on veteran-held Government war insurance "a scandalous political performance."

WESTPORT, Conn., June 25 -- Miss Jean Cochrane of Westport and her bay gelding My Chance made a strong bid for the Greenwich, Ox Ridge and Fairfield challenge trophy today at the annual Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.
