WASHINGTON, June 25 -- John R. Steelman, Assistant to the President and Chairman of the National Security Resources Board, formally brought civil defense "in the event of war" under civilian control today with the assignment of specific mobilization duties to several Government agencies.

Charges of widespread discrimination against Indian applicants for jobs in the Federal Government were made yesterday by Indian welfare organizations in this city and Washington. The Indian Bureau of the Department of the Interior was accused of relegating Indians to low-salaried jobs while advancing non-Indians to positions of authority.

The United States Army Ground Forces Band, under the direction of Capt. Chester E. Whiting of Malden, Mass., arrived here yesterday after playing for 1,000,000 listeners on a twenty-week tour of the New England states.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- Leo Durocher read the riot act to his ball players as well as to the umpires today, but lost on all counts.

AN unauthorized fourteen-gun salute to Christopher Columbus, Admiral of the Ocean Sea, had unexpected consequences for Francisco Perez, 15-year-old apprentice to a gunpowder maker. Since Columbus was returning disgraced, in chains, Francisco found himself in custody of the Spanish Inquisition, met the torturer Zorilla (who turned up later on Columbus' flagship under another name), but escaped execution and joined the entourage of the Admiral.
ST. LOUIS, June 25 -- (AP) -- The Braves cut loose with an eighteen-hit attack tonight to cool off the redhot Cardinals, 10 to 6.
LORDSHIP, Conn., June 25 (UP) -- Texas youngsers won both the junior and sub-junior titles today at the seventeenth annual Great Eastern skeet championships.

Each year at this time, when the hot summer days arrive, thousands of American vacationists head toward the beautiful resort areas of North Carolina. Not all who journey to the "Land of the Sky," however, go for play alone, for there, surrounded by the peaks of the nearby Blue Ridge and Smoky Mountains, a group of veterans are at work.

THE United States Army would like to have an official song. This may seem strange to those of us who can immediately recall at least the titles of several numbers that glorify our land forces, wholly or in part, like the "Caisson Song" (U. S. Field Artillery), "Garry Owen," "Benny Havens" (West Point); "This Is the Army, Mr. Jones" or "You're in the Army Now."

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- For the first time since the Republicans in Congress combined with the Democratic Administration to form a bipartisan front on foreign policy they engaged this week in a full-dress attack on major aspects of that policy. The sector on which they concentrated their fire is political as contrasted with such economic ventures as the European recovery measures and President Truman's Point Four, and their immediate targets were these:

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 25 -- The resurgence of a strong Germany and Japan in a relatively short time was forecast here today by James Grafton Rogers, a former Assistant Secretary of State. He spoke before 500 members of the State Bar Association.

IT has gotten so that you can almost set your clock with the censorship alarm which has been ringing over local show business in recent years. Last week the alarm was ringing again as word emerged that Councilman Edward A. Cunningham, Democrat from the Bronx, had reintroduced his bill designed to give the Department of Licenses broad powers of regulation.

In the coat and suit division of the wholesale apparel market here last week fall purchasing was heaviest on fur trimmed coats, while orders for suits were light, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

IN 70 A. D. and again in 135 A. D. the Romans wrote finis to Jewish rebellions against their domination by destroying Jerusalem. At the end of the second war they forbade any Jew ever again to set foot within the city precincts.

WITHOUT realizing his role, Louis G. Cowan, a program package producer, has turned out to be a radio trouble shooter. A year ago his "Stop the Music" helped to put ABC on the map and in two weeks -- on July 10 -- a new giveaway inspiration titled "Hollywood Calling" will be uncorked by NBC to help soothe the troubled times at that network.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- It will be sixteen months before election day, 1950, rolls around, when the seats of thirty-two members of the Senate and all 435 members of the House will be filled. In sixteen months enough new issues, foreign and domestic, can boil up to alter the whole face of our present-day existence; to challenge, even, the workings of our venerable electoral system.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The American Slav Congress was labeled by the House Un-American Activities Committee today as an organization dominated and directed by Moscow to "subvert the 10,000,000 people in this country of Slavic birth or descent." The Congress was listed as a subversive agency by Attorney General Tom Clark on Sept. 21, 1948.

NEW DELHI, India, June 25 -- The program for the nationalization of basic industries after ten years is said by commercial analysts here to be the principal reason for the current business recession in India that has been marked of late by a sharp fall in stock exchange prices.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 25 -- H. Kimball Halligan and Dr. Stephen G. Lee of Canoe Brook, the defending champions, were defeated, 2 and 1, today in the first round of the Montclair Golf Club member-guest tournament by Daniel J. Rourke and Harry Kammerer of Braidburn.
Two veteran shipping officials, Arie P. van der Burch and Alois P. Terkuhle, will retire Thursday after combined service of ninety-nine years with the Holland-America Line.

IF it can really happen as it does in "It Happens Every Spring," then it is likely that henceforth big league baseball scouts will be hunting their brand of "ivory" in campus ivory towers rather than on the nation's sandlots.
DALLAS, Tex., June 25 -- Even the business man who sings the blues feels that this is a period of readjustment rather than a depression.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- James V. Hunt, self-termed management counselor, today denied ever trying to sell "influence" in getting Government contracts and branded as a "liar" anyone who says he did.

Big business will start ordering in larger quantities per order about July 1 because present buying policies are "too tight" to suit production demands. New policies will expand purchase volumes, now restricted in many of the largest plants to one week's requirements, to a month's requirements, it was learned.

TORONTO, June 25 -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock, Ark., won the Canadian open golf championship today with a seventy-two-hole score of 271, seventeen strokes under par. The big former Army sergeant strung together rounds of 66, 67, 71 and 67 over the par-72 St. George's course to lead at every pole.

EIGHT English, one Danish and one American book were added recently to the growing list of photographic literature. The most important contribution is Howard Luray's "Strobe, the Lively Light" (San Francisco:

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 25 -- T. S. (Tommy) Tailer, former Metropolitan amateur golf champion and his partner, Gaines Gwathmey of Piping Rock, medalists yesterday with a 69, gained the semi-final round of the annual Piping Rock invitation golf tournament today.
Never in the ball game after the first inning, the Yankees succumbed to (A) Hal Newhouser, (B) the heat of yesterday at the Stadium.

PARIS, June 25 -- In quest of a compromise with Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the British Exchequer, regarding the creation of a more competitive pattern of European trade under the Marshall Plan, United States officials have made a notable concession, it was learned authoritatively today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 25 -- Bob Sweeny and Jock McLean of the Meadow Brook Club, medalists with a 66 yesterday, won two matches in the member-guest tournament at the Sands Point Golf Club today.

GREAT detectives are a dime a dozen compared to great Watsons. Since the original and immortal John Hamish himself, not more than a half dozen detectival stooges have been memorable creations in their own right. And in modern American mysteries I can think of only two: Archie Goodwin and Francis Bonnamy -- both of whom tend to eclipse in interest the detectives whom they serve.

SIGHT-SEEING with a French accent is New York's most recent tourist improvisation. Under the sponsorship of the French-American newspaper France Amerique, a series of guided tours for French visitors and residents of this city is being conducted to places of interest near New York, with future schedules calling for trips in and around the city itself.

Shortly before noon, Just four years ago today, two leather-bound 'blue books were placed on a table' hi 'the San Francisco Veterans Building. At 12:00 sharp, the representatives of fifty nations came, in turn, into the semi-circle of flags and wrote briefly on the open :pages.

As the four Foreign Ministers completed their patient labors in Paris -- with small and disappointing results -- in Quebec over four hundred representatives of twenty-eight nations have just concluded the twelfth congress of the International Chamber of Commerce. In Paris there has been disagreement and division, while in Quebec there has been a common purpose and unity.

The Rotation of new issues of preferred and common stock is being influenced increasingly in Wall Street by the impact of practices which have already transformed the business of distributing gilt-edge bonds from risk underwriting to mere brokerage accommodation for the institutional investment trade.

YOUR headline (issue of June 5), "Anthologies That Celebrate Goethe," since, explicitly, it applies to my "Goethe: The Story of a Man," is flagrantly incorrect in fact. My work is in no sense an "anthology," nor is it a collection of "gems."

Several definite and important commercial developments have already emanated from the University of Chicago's $12,000,000 atomic and metal research program as the unique project approaches its second anniversary next month.

MOST people in the movie business hire agents either to get or keep them in jobs. On two recent occasions, however, Louis de Rochemont has paid his agent to free him of entangling Hollywood alliances; first, with Twentieth Century-Fox, for which he produced three very successful films, and more recently with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

Eleven hundred officers and men of the Seventh Regiment, 107th Infantry, New York National Guard, will leave the city next Saturday to begin two weeks of field training at Pine Camp, N. Y. The regiment is part of an assemblage of 8,200 troops, mostly from New York, who will start the summer schedule there.

THE two horse enthusiasts responsible for this collection have arranged their scrapbook of horse biographies in chronological order. They begin with the inevitable Bucephalus, ridden by Alexander the Great, and conclude with the famous racer Citation.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 25 -- Far-Western rowing supremacy on the Hudson was asserted once again today when California succeeded Washington as varsity champion in the forty-seventh regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

VIENNA, June 25 -- Austria's Foreign Minister, Dr. Karl Gruber, declared today in an interview that there was "no justification," for the fears expressed in the Western press that the terms of the Austrian treaty, tentatively agreed upon in Paris, would give the Russians extraterritorial rights on Austrian soil and that these might be exploited to form a militia of the type that staged the Czechoslovak coup sixteen months ago.

The recent warning voiced by Dr. Abraham J. Feldman, president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, against attempts to establish a theocracy in Israel was lauded here yesterday by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25 -- An easterly breeze, gentle but steady, plummeted after half an hour of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club regatta today, the first Saturday event of the championships. However, in a few minutes a brisk southerly came up over the Long Island beach. It cleared away a heat haze and enabled smart sailing by the eighty craft engaged.

Liquid helium defies gravity. It climbs out of its container when it gets too cold. This has proved an unexpected asset to scientists, Dr. H. A. Fairbank of Yale University told a symposium of the American Chemical Society's Division of Physical and Inorganic Chemistry at Pittsburgh last week.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 25 -- Bulgaria and Albania were accused again today by the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans of large-scale aid to the Greek guerrillas.

TWO of the summer's major musical presentations -- the concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium and the productions of the St. Louis Municipal Opera -- will be carried by the CBS radio network. The stadium broadcasts will be heard for an hour and a half at 9 P. M. Wednesdays, starting on July 6.

Cherries are ripening, the red pie cherries which have color and tang and personality. Now is the time to make cherry jam and cherry pie, if you really know how. Cherry jam happens to be one of the best of all confections, but because it requires a cook who is also a connoisseur not a great many people undertake it.

HENLEY, England, June 25 -- The biggest post-war Henley Royal Regatta will open Tuesday with American entries in three of the ten events. There are 163 entrants in the regatta this year as compared with 150 in 1948.

WHO is the man of action? Is it Attila, Genghis Khan, Tamerlane, Charles XII? Or is it rather a Caesar, a Mohammed, a Napoleon, a Bismarck? The first batch and legions of their kind have trampled everything under them, acting in the living present, leaving nothing but devastation and death to the immediate future.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 25 -- John L. Lewis was reported today to have proposed a three-day work week to maintain the economic stability of the soft coal industry.

FLORENCE -- The first arrivals of he American summer tourists are rediscovering the virtues of Florence, which are many. Situated in a valley on the banks of the Arno, with terraced hills of glistening olive trees surrounding it, Florence is one of the loveliest and most interesting cities in all Italy.
DAMASCUS, Syria, June 25 -- The people of Syria went to the polls today and elected Col. Husni Zayim President, establishing the first Western-style dictatorship in the Middle East.

SOME indications that business is overdoing its depression a little were reported in the week. Thus, in the retail field there was a voice or two raised about under-stocking at the cost of possible sales. In industry the same idea was emphasized among purchasing agents when it was asserted that a one-week lead on required materials is too short.

RICHMOND, Va., June 25 -- Dr. Douglas Southall Freeman, Pulitzer prize-winning biographer of Robert E. Lee, announced today that he would retire as editor of The Richmond News Leader to spend most of his time on historical writing.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 25 -- A Washington-to-St Louis plane carrying Vice President Alben W. Barkley and other top Government officials made a safe emergency landing at Port Columbus here late today.
THIS second installment of Sister Mary Consolata's only mildly fictionalized family memoir demonstrates anew that a nun's antecedents can be as American as David Harum's.
BUFFALO, N. Y., June 25 (AP) -- The league-leading Buffalo Bisons made it three straight over Newark by defeating the Bears 11 -- 7, tonight.

When the Alleghany Corporation announced the acquisition of a large block of preferred stock of Kansas City Southern Railway, there was much speculation as to the source of the stock and the manner of purchase. A little snooping around revealed that the stock was the entire amount of such stock requisitioned by the Dutch Government.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., June 25 -- The blue letters on the yellow program read simply "The Children's Village Citizenship Graduation Exercises." And at 3 P. M. today the ninety-eight boys in neat blue jackets and white trousers walked slowly beneath the oak and maple trees to the platform.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 25 -- Petey Cotter developed into a successful importation at the Monmouth Park Race Track today. Shipped here from New England to compete in the Select Handi cap, the 3-year-old son of Saint Andrews scored a convincing victory in the six-furlong feature.

CHICAGO, June 25--The Chicago Railroad Fair, made possible by the cooperative efforts of thirty-eight of the country's carriers plus the Pullman Company, opened its second season today on the shores of Lake Michigan. It is to close Oct. 2.

The ebbing economic tide began slowing up last week. While a few heartening signs were observed, financial markets continued under a spell of apprehension awaiting some indication of a change for the better. Prices of shares were steadier, in the dullest trading in about two months, and for the period closed higher for the first time in six weeks.

THE Alaskan husky is a breed apart from all others. His courage, intelligence, affection, and brute strength have long endeared him to the men of the Frozen North. With keen understanding and admiration, Edward Tracy has spun an exciting, heart-warming yarn about one of these great gray huskies and his young master.

As an experiment in international cultural understanding, twenty artists who recently arrived here from ten countries will attend various schools in the United States this summer, it was announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 25 -- Five thousand American Red Cross senior and junior delegates from all parts of the United States and six insular chapters were arriving here this week-end for the four-day national convention opening Monday morning in the Municipal Auditorium.

California beat Washington in a close finish of the varsity race in the intercollegiate regatta at Poughkeepsie. Cornell was third, Navy fourth and Princeton fifth in a race delayed until early last evening by a violent rain and wind storm. Washington won both the freshman and junior varsity races again.

With good seasonal weather prevailing, sales in New York department stores last week held to the recent pattern in showing a dollar volume decline of about 9 per cent. Retail food sales remained about 5 per cent under a year ago, but grocers looked for an increase in beer sales with the settlement of the New York brewery strike and greater availability of bottled beer.

SEASIDE gardens present many problems to their owners. The short season of residence precludes the use of spring and fall-blooming flowers, and even greater limitations are imposed by wind, moist salt air and sandy soil.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 25 -- A stiff breeze that at times reached 25 miles per hour helped usher in race week at the Noroton Yacht Club today. Thirty-three Star Class boats started in the eleventh annual running of the Race Week classic.

AS the transatlantic liners sail down the harbor and out to sea, there is to the uninitiated landlubber little to distinguish one from another. Yet to seasoned Atlantic passengers who have sampled the variety of transportation afforded by the many different ship lines, each ship is unique in that it reflects in its design, service and customs the national characteristics of the country whose flag it flies.

This is Gold Cup week, at Detroit, two months earlier than usual and it will culminate Saturday afternoon with the forty-second running of the famous ninety-mile race that will bring together the country's leading fleet of unlimited power craft.

MOSCOW, June 25 -- The two leading newspapers of the Soviet Union -- Pravda, organ of the Communist party, and Izvestia, organ of the Government -- published today extensive articles emphasizing the right of Soviet citizens to own personal property and outlining the whole concept of personal ownership in the Soviet Union.

The new brick structure that has been seen rising above the level of the West Side Highway at Twelfth Avenue from Fifty-eighth to Fifty-ninth Streets -- the enlarged Board of Transportation power plant -- is now more than 96 per cent under contract, William Reid, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

Among our Communists, declared and undeclared, it has long been standard strategy to meet threats of exposure or punishment, however sober, legal and long-delayed, with loud outcries of "Witch-hunt! Persecution! Red hysteria!"

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- An intra-party row over President Truman's failure to observe patronage protocol in the appointment of a Federal district judge in Iowa headed today for a showdown in the Senate.

A minor outbreak disrupted the machine-like approval of pro-Communist resolutions at a day-long conference of the New York State Civil Rights Congress here yesterday after the Socialist Workers party, a Trotskyite group, had charged the American Communist party with favoring civil liberties "only for itself and its supporters, while opposing similar rights for its political opponents."

For three weeks of his trial Alger Hiss had sat quietly in a green leather chair in Room 1306 of the Court House on Foley Square. He had listened as the prosecution presented its case against him. Last Thursday, Mr. Hiss arose from his chair to take the witness stand in his own defense.

WHO wins baseball games? Who is the most important man in the club? Fans can argue this delicate point all evening, considering and rejecting the fielders, the hitters, even the pitchers, and inevitably come around to one unassailable view: it is the team -- the whole team working together -- that wins.
BUENOS AIRES, June 25 -- President Juan D. Peron will speak at the Casa Rosada ceremony at which the controversial Anglo-Argentine pact is to be signed on Monday, it was learned today.

PRAGUE, June 25 (UP) -- Church sources, meanwhile, reported the Communist Government had seized nine Roman Catholic convents and monasteries in Slovakia and had stepped up the arrests of priests in that province.
The Navy is now giving serious consideration to a plan to divert some of its far-reaching tanker operations to the private tankship industry, it was disclosed last week.

The letter of Raymond B. Allen, president of the University of Washington, published in your columns on May 8, in which he criticizes my article, "Should Communists Be Allowed to Teach" seems to me to need no general reply.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Business and industrial leaders of the Middle West are reported by an official of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago as "cautious and generally conservative on the pessimistic side" in their views of the economic future.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 25 -- The executive board of Brith Sholom, national Jewish fraternal order, called today on President Truman to oppose the admittance of Franco Spain to the United Nations and to veto any proposed loans to the Spanish dictator "until the nation enters the democratic fold."

IN a series of novels James Street has been vigorously writing his way through Mississippi history from the time of early settlement ("Oh, Promised Land") to secession and Civil War ("Tap Roots" and "By Valour and Arms") and now to the Eighteen Nineties.

DUBLIN, June 23 -- The United States, which has profited so much through the sons that Erin sent to the New World, is now repaying its debt, at least in slight measure, through the Marshall Plato Southern Ireland, revisted after more than a year, shows a striking advance in material prosperity, and this is due in part to Marshall Plan aid.
YONKERS, N. Y., June 25 -- Curtiss E. Frank may resign next week as Mayor of this city, according to reports here tonight.

MANY boys and girls worry about their marks, striving to get "A's" in everything; many of their parents say that they honestly don't care about high marks, are perfectly satisfied if their child passes.

A report on prophecies in food chemistry entitled "Chemistry Offers a Way Out for a 'Plundered Planet' in the World of Tomorrow," which appeared in the Science Section of THE NEW YORK TIMES on May 15 and which summarized the views of Prof. Eugene G. Rochow, calls for comment, it seems to me.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 25 -- In the Tenth Federal Reserve District, the business picture is bolstered by another forthcoming bumper wheat crop. With the Government guaranteeing farmers $1.96 a bushel, there is bound to be a big boost in money in circulation this fall.

OF all English kings who have supplied dramatists, novelists and popular historians with themes, Henry VIII has proved the most fruitful. There is about him an urgent sense of momentous happenings. For his marriages played an integral part in the Reformation, the turning point of English history.

ABOUT a year ago, Paul Hoffman's Economic Cooperation Administration was getting under way with all the frenetic excitement of a great new Government agency. Before the plaster was fairly dry, ECA's lobbies were crowded with men of the briefcase.

A carillon of forty bells, covering three and a half chromatic octaves, is being cast in the Netherlands for St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church, Lenox Avenue and 122d Street in Harlem. The total weight of the bells will be 25,000 pounds, the largest weighing 3,100 pounds and the smallest twenty pounds.

W. K. Menke, assistant general manager of sales for the Merrimac Division of Monsanto Chemical Company, has been named director of the company's general development department in St. Louis, replacing R. B. Semple, elected president of the Wyandotte Chemicals Corporation of Wyandotte, Mich.

COMPETITION in the three-color motion picture field, long the exclusive domain of the Technicolor company, has developed in recent months to a point which seems to presage a marked upswing in the production of color pictures.

JOHN ROEBURT has been a consistently responsible crime writer, deeply concerned with the human values and social implications behind criminal acts. My admiration for his attitude makes me all the more regretful that this attempt to probe the border line between valid toughness and sadism doesn't quite come off.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 25 -- Iinformation about the internal political maneuvers in the Soviet Union and the shifts of hierarchical ranking is traditionally scanty. Fundamental alterations of personnel are generally announced -- although often considerably after the event.

The Institute of Government of the Political Science Department of the University of Washington will sponsor its fourteenth annual conference July 11 to 15. The program will bring together leading state officials, civic leaders and professors. The program is designed to contribute to the solution of current problems of government and public affairs "through discussion under actual leadership."

A NEW YORK STATE speed-zone law, passed last year to make life easier for the law-abiding motorist, is being flouted by many communities in this state. As a result many drivers are being caught for speeding in outlying sections of small towns that look, to the first-time traveler, like stretches of state highway.

NANKING, June 26 -- Huang Yen-pei, who has just returned from Peiping, where he attended the preparatory meeting to the People's Consultative Conference, which will be convened in late August, declared today that the future industrial and commercial policy of the Chinese Communist regime would be based mainly on the "present industrial and commercial policies in the cities."

Saturday night's Philharmonic-Symphony concert at Lewisohn Stadium had a double -- or rather quintuple -- feature in its solo spots. William Lincer, the orchestra's first violist, played the solo in Berlioz's "Harold in Italy" Symphony, and the Philharmonic Piano Quartet filled the second half of the bill in its first appearance in this city.

With pickets in a rowboat and on foot blocking gasoline deliveries to the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, National Airlines decided yesterday to use Newark as the departure point for its daily non-stop flight to Miami.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Trade in oats was not large, but the market on the Board of Trade showed increased activity late last week, reflecting a broader New England demand for the actual grain and also the development of export business. Sales of 500,000 bushels were reported.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 26 (UP) -- A revolt within the ranks of the Alabama Ku Klux Klan shaped up today against the "public unmasking'' directive issued by Dr. E. P. Pruitt, chairman of the Klan's board of governors.

Success of the Negro's venture into full democratic rights will depend on individual performance, the Rev. Dr. Shelby Rooks, pastor of St. James Presbyterian Church, St. Nicholas Avenue and West 141st Street, declared to his Harlem congregation yesterday.

An "appreciable" number of business concerns begin to have falling profits during prosperous periods long before general business activity turns downward, and numerous other companies continue increasingly profitable operations for a time after business at large begins to slump.

After reaching new high ground for the season, cotton futures in the domestic market declined last week and closed the period with irregular net changes. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with a decline of 13 points on the near-by July contract and with advances of 2 to 56 points on later months.

Last week this space was given over to a brief dissertation on a practice which has long been popular in the administrative and legislative branches of the Government and which seemed a few days ago to have gained at least a precarious foothold in the judicial branch.

BOSTON, June 26 -- Adoption of national health insurance in the United Staates might create a demand for 40,000,000 pairs of eyeglasses, it was estimated today as the American Optometric Association opened its fifty-second convention.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 26 -- Defiantly maintaining all their positions, Roman Catholic Archbishop Josef Beran and the Bishops, in a pastoral letter read in many churches today, declared that the freedom of the Archbishop was "completely curtailed" by the secret police and that "well planned and carefully executed persecution of the Catholic Church in Czechoslovakia" was in progress.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Individuals saved only $600,000,000 in liquid form during the first quarter of 1949, or $1,300,000,000 less than in the last quarter of 1948, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
PORTLAND, Me., June 26 (AP) -- A Maine National Guard transport plane plunged into Fore River today, injuring all twenty-four persons aboard after going out of control in a municipal airport landing.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 -- Vernon A. Dorrell of Glendale, Calif., famed aviation consultant and pilot, was killed today when his light plane crashed in taking off from a private airstrip near Three Rivers, N. M. He was 43 years old.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Vince Foster "believes the Lord may not want him to fight any more" and is taking an "indefinite vacation" from the ring, his manager said tonight.

LONDON, June. 26 (Reuters) -- Striking crew members of Canadian ships in London decided tonight to send a cable to Canadian Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent protesting against alleged violations by shipowners of the four-point agreement settling the strike Friday.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 26 (AP) -- Dick Shaughnessy of Dedham, Mass., captured high-over-all honors in the seventeenth annual great Eastern skeet championships today, breaking 344 of 350 targets. It was the sixth time in eight years that Shaughnessy topped the field.

Extreme caution in the application of loyalty tests for teachers, as required by the Feinberg Law, was urged upon the Board of Education yesterday by a committee of 139 Protestant and Jewish clergymen headed by Rev. Dr. John Paul Jones.

With styles and values generally satisfactory, fall buying reached its peak in all divisions of the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Emphasis was given to fur trimmed and zip-out lining coats, accessories, corsets and brassieres.

For reasons that escape us, a large number of housewives, shrewd as they may be at bargain hunting at sale times or quick as they are at catching up the grocer for a mistake in addition, have fallen prey to one of the more bald-faced rackets that have visited the metropolitan area -- the "phony" door-to-door salesman.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Weakness in vegetable oils had a depressing effect on lard futures at times last week on the Board of Trade, but the market recovered part of the loss later on reports that Mexico was in the market for moderate supplies and that Congress had voted to extend import controls over fats and oils.

Although the American optical industry this year has every likelihood of a more than 15 per cent sales increase over 1948, the previous high, the industry must embark on a vigorous four-point program of merchandising and research.

Leaders of Congress of Industrial Organizations and American Federation of Labor groups in the city made preparations yesterday for another round of "screening" conferences in an effort to reach agreement on a Democratic candidate for Mayor who will be acceptable to both sides and satisfactory to Mayor O'Dwyer.

The neighborhood playground continued in 1948 to be the most important element in community recreation and nearly $100,000,000 was spent for its support, the National Recreation Association reported yesterday.

A new pattern in American education may be emerging in which more adults than children will be studying, according to a report by Dr. Paul L. Essert, professor at Columbia's Teachers College, made public yesterday.
Your editorial of June 20 on "The Injunction Issue," like so many previous TIMES editorials on this topic, is a plausible argument built upon a shaky foundation. Let's examine your basic premise.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 26 -- Returning to the Western part of the Sound, the Yacht Racing Association fleet had the regatta of the New Rochelle Club today, in which 104 craft participated. It was the second championship series regatta in as many days.
BUFFALO, N. Y., June 26 (AP) -- Fred Hawkins fired a 4 under par 68 today to win $750 first money in the $2,500 Transit Valley invitational pro-amateur golf tournament.

FRESNO, Calif., June 26 (AP) -Three new records were posted in the books today and a new team champion was crowned as the 1949 Amateur Athletic Union Track and Field Championships went into history behind a series of outstanding performances last night.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 26 -- George F. French 3d, 19 years old, Princeton University senior, completed his coast-to-coast bicycle ride today, less than twenty-four days after leaving Asbury Park, N. J.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., June 26 -- Fenway players repeated as winners of the Seymour Mittlemark Memorial invitation golf tournament today. The club's top threesome of a five-man team scored an aggregate of 234 on its home course for a six-stroke edge over Quaker Ridge.

LONDON, June 26 -- British oil men recently have expressed the opinion that high-level discussions should be undertaken between the British and the United States Governments to avert a price war and fight for markets that might harm both British and United States oil companies.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period June 18 to 24 are given in the appended tabulation:

After being washed by a strong incoming tide from the Upper Bay to the lower East River, a man who fell or jumped from the Staten Island ferry Knickerbocker was rescued at 10 o'clock last night by Police Launch 6 off the foot of Broad Street.

New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, will have been open officially for one year next Friday. A total of about $110,000,000 of city and Port of New York Authority funds has been expended or committed to the present seven-runway development for what is considered, in the aeronautical sense, the world's finest airport.

THE Yankees and the Giants, traditional rivals for popular favor in our village, will collide head-on at the Stadium tonight in an exhibition game which should be of vital interest to everyone in our community. The fray itself is attractive enough on its own merits but the big winner will be sandlot baseball, one of the lesser-publicized methods of combating juvenile delinquency.

When accessory designers turn their talents to creating casual clothes, the results are likely to be novel and exciting. Such is the case of Elizabeth and William D. Phelps, who have brought out a collection of country fashions. Well known for some years for their interesting designs in bags and belts, the Phelps are proving their versatility for the second time.

With a strike of 3,800 employes of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation threatened for midnight Thursday, a strong possibility arose yesterday that union members on the rest of the city's public and private transit lines might engage in slowdown tactics at the same time.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J. June 26 -- Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, national commander of the Disabled American Veterans, said today that "the recent shameful attempt" to reduce the Veterans Administration hospital program was definite proof of the challenge to the veterans' program, which has been developed in the last 30 years.

The cruise liner Italia, flagship of the new Home Lines, arrived yesterday from the Mediterranean on her initial voyage here under the flag of Panama. Bedecked with pennants and saluted by harbor craft, the once-famous Swedish motor ship Kungsholm, tied up at Pier 54, North River, shortly after 8 A. M.

FRESNO, Calif., June 26 (UP) -The cream of America's track and field crop today was chosen for a summer-time invasion of Europe as officials of the national A. A. U. wound up their 1949 meeting today.

AMSTERDAM, June 26 -- The preliminary union for the Benelux Economic Union scheduled for July 1 has been postponed. During this period of preliminary union certain commodities would have been ex-changed freely between the Benelux countries.

SAARBRUECKEN, June 26 -- The Saar is full of surprises. It is surprising to find that three-quarters of this dun-colored capital of a rich mining district was destroyed during the war and is rising again at a pace unequaled by any other German city. It is surprising to discover how much is happening in a lost and almost forgotten corner of Germany that is being quietly transformed into a province of France.

The fabulous manner of living known to Virginia City, Nev., in the days of the Comstock Lode boom is reflected in the ornate silver currently on exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York. The pieces displayed are part of a 1,350-piece dinner and dessert service for twenty-four persons.
BOSTON, June 26 (AP) -- For the fourth time in as many games the Red Sox today whipped the Browns by 5 -- 3 as left-hander Chuck Stobbs scored his second major league decision.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Truman Administration faces a double test this week in pivotal votes in the House and Senate.

HONOLULU, June 26 -- In the widst of the discussions in Hawaii of Senator Hugh Butler's report on Communism in this Territory, the Democratic party here is engaged in bitter internal battle, with the old-line leadership seeking to "purge" left-wingers.

VALLEY COTTAGE, N. Y., June 26 -- State Police at five minutes before midnight last night raided a twelve-room Dutch Colonial home here set in three and a half acres of grounds that included gardens and a swimming pool.

DETROIT, June 26 -- Thomas W. Thompson, 45-year-old president of huge Local 600 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, and a central figure in the recent "speed-up" strike against the Ford Motor Company, is expected to be a candidate for membership on the twenty-two-man International Executive Board of the UAW at the convention opening in Milwaukee on July 10.

In the last three and one-half years, 1,500,000 square yards of pavement have been laid in Manhattan, and part of this largest street repair program on record also involved the filling of 30,500 holes in the streets, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan reported yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians, behind the five-hit pitching of Steve Gromek, produced two tenth-inning runs to down the Senators, 3 -- 1, today.

The Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation said yesterday that it would manufacture and sell the "helioplane," designed by Otto G. Koppen, professor of aeronautical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, according to specifications formulated by Dr. Lynn L. Bollinger, former airline pilot and now a professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.
" If this weather keeps up, we won't have any more use for suanas," said Vincent R. Impellitteri, president of the City Council, in Central Park Mall yesterday afternoon.

The Yankees and Giants take time out from their official diamond duties and do their bit for the cause of sandlot baseball tonight at the Stadium. Before what is hoped to be a turnout of at least 40,000 fans, the local heroes will clash for the Mayor O'Dwyer Trophy in an after-dark encounter with proceeds going to organizations that sponsor and direct kids' baseball.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 25 -- Robert Sweeny, former British amateur champion and Jock McLean, Meadow Brook, turned back Frank Graven and Bob Townsend, 2 and 1, in the final of the Sands Point Golf Club's annual member-guest tournament today.

REALITY, says Norman Taylor, is something which a large proportion of the human race has never cared to take straight if it could possibly help it. The consolations of religion and the distractions of entertainment are insufficient help for men doomed to the drab business of living in hunger and poverty, in sorrow and disenchantment with their lot.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- RKO will produce a film dealing with Russo-American competition and Russian spying in the field of jet weapons, it was learned this week-end. The film, which has grown out of Howard Hughes' earlier project, "Jet Pilot," will be the first American picture to treat Russo-American ideological and diplomatic differences in terms of munitions of war.

TOKYO, June 17 -- Thoughtful Japanese increasingly are asking themselves today by what means order is to be preserved in this nation after the conclusion of a peace treaty and the departure of United States occupation troops, for which some groups here have been pressing.

CAIRO, June 26 -- The great Arab question at the moment is whether Iraq, under the leadership of the Regent, Emir Abdul Illah, and Premier Nuri as Said, is moving out of the Arab circle into an alignment with Turkey and Iran, extending the significance of the Saadabad Pact, the non-aggression treaty of 1937 among Moslem Middle East nations. The issue has agitated most partisans of the Arab League, which has its headquarters here.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 26 -- The Rev. Dr. David Philipson of Cincinnati, known as the Dean of the American Reform Rabbinate, collapsed here early today at the sixtieth annual convention of the Central Conference of American Rabbis. He was removed to Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, where his condition is reported to be slightly improved, although he is not out of danger.

PARIS, June 26 -- A major issue in the economic diplomacy of the United States, closely related to its foreign policy, will be further discussed this week by members of the steering committee of the European Marshall Plan Council.
Robert L. Riggs regained the national professional tennis championship yesterday, winning the Benrus Perpetual Trophy for the third time.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 26 (UP) -- John L. Lewis mapped coal-contract strategy today with one eye on Tuesday's United States Senate showdown on whether the anti-strike injunctions of the Taft-Hartley Law would be continued in the Administration's new labor bill.

The Alfred Steiglitz Collection of paintings and photographs will be divided among the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago, the National Gallery of Art, the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Fisk University and the Library of Congress, it was announced yesterday by Georgia O'Keeffe, executrix of the Steiglitz estate.

The swish of casting rods and the whine of reels were heard yesterday at Belvedere Lake in Central Park, where the New York Casting Club presented a casting exhibition by experts and a "spinning fishing" contest open to the public.
CINCINNATI, June 26 (AP) -- Cincinnati today welcomed home its new N. B. A. heavyweight boxing champion.

We read with lively interest the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 11, "Guinea Pigs Teach Good Eating Habits." In the subheading and in the story there is reference to hot dogs; it being stated, "boys and girls at Public School 54 who used to consume hot dogs and soda pop for lunch took a lesson from some guinea pigs and now they eat vitamin-packed meals that include milk, fruits and vegetables."

More and more radio and television stations are demanding Broadway outlets for their programs, an indication that the number of legitimate theatres is constantly decreasing. As of yesterday, a count showed that eleven houses have been taken over by radio or television.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 26 -- Since the United States and Britain formally protested against the violation of Article III of the Rumanian peace treaty, the Communist Government of that "people's democracy" has accelerated the pace of revolution with still more complete disregard for Western conceptions of human rights.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 26 (AP) -- Billy Talbert of New York City, fourth ranking amateur tennis player in the United States, defeated Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, today for the men's title in the Tennessee Valley invitational tennis tournament.

DUBLIN, June 24 -- Although Eire is now the Republic of Ireland, she is fighting as hard for her "independence" as ever. At least, that is what the highest officials in Dublin say when they talk of partition and Britain.

Here is a true story and one I think you will welcome. My husband, a schoolmaster, was giving a Scripture lesson last week about the Good Samaritan. One boy was inattentive and so he was asked to come forward and repeat the story. Here is how he ended: "And along came the good American."

A three-year search for the third man in the fatal hold-up of the Mayfair Cafe at 169 West Forty-seventh Street on July 10, 1946, has come to an end in Chicago, the police of the West Forty-seventh Street station reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Former President Hoover urged today that Congress concentrate Federal aid to education on the "real backward states."

The first test of the Paris accords on Germany is likely to come this week as a result of orders issued by the Western commanders to the Berlin rail strikers to accept a partial settlement of their grievances and return to work tomorrow morning. The leaders of the strike have accepted the Western proposal and there is no reason to assume that the workers won't.

PITTSBURGH, June 26 -- The Dodgers today walloped the Pirates 15 -- 3, in the only game of a scheduled double-header the clubs were able to complete. Thus Brooklyn retained its half-game National League lead over the Cardinals.
An eighth of a mile of Staten Island's industrial waterfront was swept by a fire that set up a spectacular curtain of smoke over New York Bay yesterday afternoon.

WNYC again is asking the Federal Communications Commission to grant a power increase to five kilowatts during daytime hours, compared to its present one kilowatt. The station also seeks permission to broadcast full time, compared to its present limited time operation, and asks for an immediate hearing to amend Section 3.25(a) of FCC Rules and Regulations.

In his capable letter published June 14 Paul Weiden gives me credit for having headed the United States delegation in the negotiations leading to the Swiss-Allied Accord of May 25, 1946. Although I was a member of that delegation, its chief was the distinguished ex-general counsel of the Treasury Department, Randolph Paul.

Having tried and failed in six previous efforts to capture a double-header, the Yankees missed again yesterday at the Stadium. They got off winging with a 6-2 victory over the Tigers and, with Vic Raschi starting the nightcap, there was reason to assume they would take the second, too.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- Pravda expressed the opinion today that the Paris Conference of Foreign Ministers had been "a bitter pill" for President Truman, and it characterized his statement on the agreement as "a mixture of immodest boasting and tendentious interpretation."

Sir Hartley Shawcross, Attorney General of Great Britain, said here yesterday that England may have to "submit to more austerities" because the gap between Britain's dollar earnings and payments had widened in recent months.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 26 -- Soft-coal operators were divided today in their reaction to a proposal of John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, to operate the mines three days a week while stockpiles were high and demand was weak.

ROME, June 26 -- Some details of a bill now being drafted, which would forbid strikes for political reasons and authorize compulsory arbitration in cases of walkouts seriously affecting the national economy, were released by the Labor Ministry for publication today.
The jitters of a week-end which are not unusual where it concerns the pound sterling, reasserted itself last week depressing the British unit to lows which are currently the cheapest in months.

Far-reaching plans to revitalize the Orient's tourist industry, hard hit by the war and unsettled post-war conditions, are well under way, according to George Killion, president of the American President Lines.
ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) -- Red Munger pitched his first shut-out of the season and slammed his first home run of his major league career today to give the Cardinals a 2-to-0 victory over the Braves.

The American Power and Light Company and the Kansas Gas and Electric Company have selected the Union Securities Corporation to form a banking syndicate to negotiate for the purchase and re-offering of 550,000 common shares of the latter company, it was announced yesterday.

When President Truman sent his message to Congress on Friday urging the Point Four program he put the right word first in describing the objectives. The program has been called one of aid for underdeveloped areas or regions, but the President didn't say it that way.
Conflicting views on the proposed Barden bill on Federal aid to education were presented from pulpits yesterday by Roman Catholic and Protestant spokesmen.
The letter of C. M. Bradbury in the issue of June 18 regarding the cause of depressions seems to call for further comment.
Eight new films, including an importation from England, are slated to arrive in first-run the atres this week. The programs follow:

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 26 -- Finalist for four successive years, James Knott and Robert Grant 3d of Meadow Brook, national racquets champion, won the Piping Rock Club invitation golf tournament by defeating Gaines Gwathmey and T. S. (Tommy) Tailer, former metropolitan amateur champion, 1 up, today

ALBANY, June 26 (AP) -- The State Motor Vehicle Bureau reminded motorists today that, effective July 1, reports on serious accidents must be filed within forty-eight hours. The change was made by the 1949 Legislature.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 26 -- Shillalah came through as expected today, winning the second Star boat race in the eleventh annual running of the race week classic at the Noroton Yacht Club.

Epicures find compensation for the dwindling strawberry supply in the appearance of other luscious berries. July is the big month for red raspberries, blueberries and currants, most of which are from New Jersey and upstate. As these go out of the market, local blackberries come into their own.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 26 -- "Pulpit oratory" was deplored as a force for religious strength here today and 300 reform rabbis were urged to develop new congregational techniques for a more intimate understanding between worshipers and their spiritual leaders.

Napkins, table cloths, towels, wash rags and babies' bibs that can be more easily washed than fabric and can be used again and again are among new paper products for the homemaker. Their low price, however, makes it feasible to discard them after one use.
An eleven-room home and half acre of land on Dogwood Lane, in Rye, Westchester County, was sold by Alfred L. Law to Edward R. Beach through E. V. Siedle, broker.

Should any sizable part of American business management allow itself to be worked into a depression state of mind by concern over increased unemployment, the results will have no foundation in sound economic fact, it was declared last week by Dr. Vergil D. Reed, associate director of research of the J. Walter Thompson Company.

Sidney B. Wood, the veteran New York stylist, seeded No. 5, and Charles Masterson of Hicksville, rated No. 7, joined Don McNeill in the fourth round of play yesterday in the New York State tennis championships at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

Sean O'Faolain, whose collection of short stories, "The Man Who Invented Sin,'' was published last November, has a new book on Devin-Adair's list for July 11. "The Irish, A Character Study" is a short history that covers the fields of political and religious history, economic and artistic development, mythology, literature, geography and social structure.
ATHENS, June 26 (AP) -- Former Premier Constantin Tsaldaris is forming a Cabinet to consist entirely of members of his Populist party, a leader of that party said tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The new rent control relaxations revealed today are at considerable variance with the previous attitude of the Truman Administration, Capitol observers noted.

Speedy action to start the proposed survey of the city's civil service structure with a view to its reclassification as a means of eliminating inequities without reduction of present pay rates was demanded yesterday by the Liberal party and the Citizens Union.
GENEVA, June 26 -- Trade union delegates from most of the non-Communist world agreed today to proceed immediately with the establishment of a new non-Communist world trade union organization.

DARIEN, Conn., June 26 -- Earl S. Ruscoe and his Woodway guest, David Lapham, who won the medal, lost the championship flight final of the Wee Burn Country Club's sixth annual member-guest tourney today, 2 and 1, to host Matthew M. Gardner and Russell Cook of Siwanoy.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 26 -- Scoring six goals in the last two chukkers, the Bostwick Field riders drove to a 9-4 victory over the Hurricanes in the weekly high-goal polo match on Bostwick Field today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UP) -- A group of left-wing CIO union leaders today accused President Truman and the Democratic Party of a "scandalous betrayal" of their election pledge to repeal the Taft-Hartley Labor-Management Law.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- A radical change in the outlook for the new winter wheat crop plus support incident to the Government loan at 90 per cent of parity resulted in wheat futures advancing on the Board of Trade here last week to the highest prices since early in February.

The hottest day so far this year was registered when the mercury touched 94 degrees at 5:50 P. M. yesterday. While it was .2 degrees short of the record for the date, set in 1943, the searing heat under cloudless skies set another mark when it averaged 85, an all-time high for June 26 and 2 degrees above the previous record mean, set in 1904.

The 1949 Roosevelt Medals of Honor have been won by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former military governor of the American zone of Germany; David Hinshaw, humanitarian, and J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, it was announced yesterday by the Roosevelt Memorial Association.

MOSCOW, June 15 -- Softly lighted and delicately scented, the Gorki Street perfume shop, devoted to the sale not only of perfume but of all varieties of cosmetics, is only one of dozens scattered around Moscow. These shops are typical of the advance made by Soviet consumer industries.

Charles Kast sold the two-family brick dwelling on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 8789 Twenty-third Avenue, Brooklyn, to Joseph L. Rappaciulo in a deal negotiated by Sam Abrams, Inc., broker. The assessed valuation is $7,500.

CINCINNATI, June 26 (AP) -- The Reds swept a doubleheader today from the onrushing Phillies, 4 to 3 in 10 innings and 5 to 2. Homer Howell's pinch-hit double won the opener for the Reds and Herman Wehmeier, giving Cincinnati its first complete pitching performance in seven games, set the Phils down with eight hits in the nightcap.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Tighe E. Woods, the Federal Housing Expediter, has issued new instructions easing rent controls, it was learned today.

Religious interchange is uniting the youth of the world in a common bond upon which to build a new world, three members and the leader of a "Youth Odyssey" said yesterday at the morning services of the Broadway Tabernacle Church, 211 West Fifty-sixth street.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of a pastoral letter recapitulating the Roman Catholic Church's side of Czechoslovakia's state-church fight as issued by Archbishop Josef Beran and his Bishops and read today in the nation's Catholic churches:
Howard Peters has been appointed project engineer of the Rollpin division of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, Union, N. J.

Word comes from Richmond, Va., that Dr. Douglas Southall Freeman has decided to retire from his post as editor of The Richmond News Leader. Virginians have known Dr. Freeman since 1915 as a brilliant and courageous journalist -- one of the major voices of the new South.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 26 (AP) -- Syracuse won a double-header for the first time this season today, beating Newark, 5 -- 4 and 5 -- 1.

Instructions in the latest techniques and equipment of the Army Quartermaster Corps will be given to 4,000 reservists tonight and tomorrow at the corps' public display at Forty - eighth Street and Northern Boulevard, Astoria, Queens.

NORWICH, Conn., June 26 (UP) -- When Susan Peters, film actress, rolls herself onto the stage of the Norwich Summer Theatre tomorrow night, it will be a great occasion for a young woman who can't even take one step.

PITTSBURGH, June 26 -- The national steel operating rate last week was off 2 points to 84.5 per cent of rated capacity. On the basis of recent orders its was expected that it would continue downward. Because of vacations and the July Fourth holiday to come it may be the downward drift will be accelerated.

WHITE OAK, Md., June 26 -- The little cluster of visitors peered into the ground-glass reflector of the camera. In the darkness of the laboratory they waited for a look at a blast of wind going 3,500 miles an hour past a foot-long model, projectile.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 26 -- Golden Boy, chestnut gelding of the Seven Star Stables of Brookline, Mass., fell on a chicken coop jump in the $500 working hunter stake at the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today and was taken from the course in a van.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday the awarding of Pulitzer scholarships having a total value of $34,000 to ten boys who will be graduated from New York public high schools this week.

PITTSBURGH, June 26 (AP) -- Potential candidates to run for office of the International Typographical Union were selected today at a special meeting of the board of directors of the union's Independent party.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 26 -- Magistrate Morris Rothenberg of New York, president of the Jewish National Fund, warned today that Israel might be compelled to close its gates to immigration unless "the whole of the Jewish people helps bolster the state's economy until final liberation is assured."

BERLIN, June 26 -- Leaders of Western Berlin's striking railroad workers agreed today to accept the final proposal of the Western powers and to send all f the 15,000 strikers who were unafraid of Russian reprisals back to work at 8 A. M. Tuesday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 26 -- On July 1 the Bank of Brazil will put into effect a new stipulation granting with each import license a guarantee to provide for sufficient foreign exchange to cover the importation.

The system, policies and practices of this city's Boards of Education and Higher Education were challenged yesterday by the Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

LONDON, June 26 -- Although the slide in prices of industrial shares on the stock market here continued last week amid wide- spread talk of an oncoming trade depression, interest in the City suddenly switched to gilt-edge securities, which have been moving downward with startling rapidity.
PARIS, June 26 -- Although figures of French production showed a sharp decline in April, they now show a recovery in May in most branches of industrial activity.

DETROIT, June 26 -- An electronic apparatus that promises to save countless patients from death on the operating table -- especially 'blue" babies and other victims of heart disease -- has been developed here by a team of four Detroit scientists.
SEOUL, Korea, June 26 -- Kim Koo, prominent Rightist politician, who for years aspired to become the George Washington of Korea, was shot dead in his bedroom today by one of his followers.

CAIRO, June 26 -- Egyptian Chamber of Deputies approved today an arms budget of 23,000,000 (about $100,000,000). This is about six times the size of the military budget before the Palestine war and represents something like one-fifth of the total income of the Egyptian Treasury.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Monday, June 27 -- The outlook for exiled King Leopold's returning to Belgium in the near future appeared to be dimming fast as returns from yesterday's elections dribbled in with their promise of a bitter surprise for the major political parties and heartening news for the Liberals, whose success surpassed even their hopes.

After fourteen years of valuable work, the National Institute of Public Affairs has "completed its mission" of recruiting and training college graduates for government service; and now the Government itself has taken over this job of proved usefulness.

Country grandfathers and grandmothers are much in demand, now that summer's hot hand is beginning to press upon city folk. This is the season when at little railway stations upstate there will be white-haired and balding grandfathers waiting for trains to discharge grandchildren, stiffly neat in their city clothes, their faces indicating that a closer acquaintance with sunshine would do them good.

On Dec. 26, 1947, 25.8 inches of snow fell in this city. Surface traffic was practically suspended. Airplanes were grounded. Trains ran hours late. In some instances they did not run at all. In others passengers were marooned between their points of departure and the points they had hoped to reach.

Retail furniture operation in 1948 was marked by a moderate advance in sales volume, a disproportionately high increase in operating expenses and lowered gross profits, according to the sixteenth annual Furniture Stores Operating Experiences Report released for publication today by the National Retail Furniture Association.

The fifth anniversary of the dedication of the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava, 15 West Twenty-fifth Street, was observed with a special service yesterday followed by an anniversary dinner at the McAlpin Hotel.

CHICAGO, June 26 -Corn developed moderate strength last week on the Board of Trade in sympathy with wheat and on official reports that more or less damage could be expected this year in Illinois, Iowa-and north-eastern Nebraska from corn borer.
CHICAGO, June 26 -- Leo Durocher was fined $150 and suspended for five days by National League President Ford Frick today and this somehow produced a startling effect upon the Giants.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- Stars who earn $5,000 a week in motion pictures are still stage struck hams. They're beating down stage doors to get on the boards for $50.
LOS ANGELES, June 26 (AP) -- Fuller Warren, Governor of Florida, and Barbara Jeanne Manning, California blonde, were married today.

LONDON, June 26 -- The industrial heart of Britain in the Midlands was "blitzed" today by some of the world's biggest bombing planes in continuation of the Western powers most extensive air maneuvers in Europe since the end of the war.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox split a double-header with the Athletics today winning the second game, 3 -- 0, after the Athletics came from behind in the opener to clinch a 4-2 victory.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 26 -- The Communist press told Czechoslovaks today that if they wanted to eat more they would all have to pitch in and help with the harvest and learn to "take care of every grain of wheat."

LAKE SUCCESS, June 26 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has made an emergency advance of $1,000,000 of United Nations funds to continue operations of the United Nations Relief for Palestine Refugees, it was disclosed today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 26 -- Herman Barron of Fenway scored an individual 34, 34 -- 68 and, in company with William J. Cobb, posted a net best-ball of 31, 31 -- 62 to top both flights of the sixth annual pro-member tournament at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today.
BRUSSELS, Monday, June 27 (AP) -- Supporters of exiled King Leopold took an early lead in the elections count, but a spokesman conceded they would not win the clear majority they had sought.

The six-story sel-fservice elevator building containing four stores and thirty-two apartments on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 2390 Amsterdam Avenue, near West 179th Street, was sold by the Edward L. Goldman Company, Edward Goldman, president, to an investing client of Joseph B. Boudin, atorney.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 26 -- Kenneth Pepperell Budd, a partner in the New York banking firm of William Iselin Co., died at Bailey's Beach today when he suffered a heart attack while trying to swim against a strong undertow. He was 71 years old.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 26 -- A general claims restitutions measure, intended to indemnify victims of Nazis with an estimated 850,000,000 deutsche marks, is under final United States Military Government staff study for approval shortly, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., the Republican National Chairman, issued a call today for a meeting Tuesday of the Republican Strategy Committee at which he will make a progress report on preparations for the Congressional campaign of 1950.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 26 -- A general claims restitutions measure, intended to indemnify victims of Nazis with an estimated 850,000,000 deutsche marks, is under final United States Military Government staff study for approval shortly, it was reported today.

The objective of many Air Force officers, since the Italian General Douhet first postulated his theories of air war soon after World War I, has been a single independent air force with all the nation's non-commercial planes under its control.

Although wholesale dress buying has been accelerated with the opening of fall lines in the last two weeks, the rate of buying gives little indication of building up a fast trend on any particular category of rayon fabrics, it was pointed out last week by textile suppliers.
SEOUL, Korea, June 27 -- President Syngman Rhee went on the radio last night to tell the nation he was "deeply shocked" by the assassination of Kim Koo, 73-year-old Rightist Korean leader.
Two busloads of orthopedically handicapped but happy girls left the city yesterday afternoon for Camp Carola, Spring Valley, N. Y., where they will spend a month's vacation.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder came from two sets behind in a storming stretch finish today to keep the American flag flying in the semi-finals of the Wimbledon men's singles tennis championship.
FRANKFORT, Germany, June 23 --Proportional representation is one of the features of the electoral law that will govern the first national elections in Germany since the days of the Weimar Republic.

MERIDEN, Conn., June 27 -- The Meiden Record Company today completed the purchase of a majority of the stock of the Journal Publishing Company, publisher of The Meriden Daily Journal, an afternoon newspaper.

LONDON, June 27 -- The Economic Policy Committee of the British Cabinet met today and was reported to have reaffirmed the Government's policy in a deadlock that has arisen within the Organization for European Economic Cooperation over the payments plan to finance European trade.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -Protection of the fundamental rights of prisoners played an important part in a long series of rulings that the Supreme Court handed down today as it ended its term and adjourned until next October.

A research organization that made a study of Negro health looking toward a program of national health insurance reported yesterday that low economic status would prevent "even inadequate care in view of the high cost of privately financed medical services today."

The lady said she had been surprised lately by the number of women seen smoking as they walked along the street. They were not the young things, as a rule, but women of a certain age who looked like they might be school teachers -- not that, any more, you could tell school teachers from other professional women.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- Hank Sauer poled a two-run homer in the fifth to give the last-place Chicago Cubs the margin by which they defeated the red-hot Cardinals in an error-riddled game tonight, 6 to 4.

Arthur H. Bunker was elected president of the Climax Molybdenum Company yesterday. Mr. Bunker, who will take office July 1, will resign as a general partner of Lehman Brothers on Thursday. Before the war he was executive vice president of the Lehman Corporation.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 27 -- Unless the American people solve the racial issue they face "a national defeat from within through loss of one's faith in their very reason for living," Dr. Charles S. Johnson, president of Fisk University, declared today.

Newspaper support for the Opportunity Drive on E series U. S. Savings Bonds in New York State has been the major factor in making advertising support of the campaign the greatest for a peacetime drive in the state, it was declared yesterday by a spokesman for the Treasury Department's New York division.

A sealed indictment was returned yesterday against an 18-year-old youth, while his companion, Anthony Nocero, 24, of 31 Moffett Street, Brooklyn, was named in two true bills in connection with the kidnaping, slugging and robbing of a Harvard student last June 16.

Price reductions of 5 to 10 per cent by some lamp producers and the offering by others of 5 to 10 per cent better values in the form of improved styling and quality at unchanged prices featured the opening yesterday of the semi-annual New York Lamp Show in the New Yorker Hotel.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 -- Merger of the St. Louis Stock Exchange with three other Midwestern Exchanges in Chicago would cause "some grave injuries" to St. Louis, George C. Smith, president of the Chamber of Commerce, said today.

A recent statement by Tighe E. Woods, Housing Expediter, calling attention to a new relaxation of regulations covering rent controls was termed "applesauce" yesterday by William E. Russell, general chairman of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee.
YONKERS, N. Y., June 27 -- A possibility that this city of 150,000 may have its first woman Mayor was seen here as Mayor Curtiss E. Frank announced today that he would resign Sept. 1.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Directors of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company today ordered halted or deferred almost half the construction in progress or scheduled under its current $100,000,000 program of improvements and expansions.

Nine instances of conflicting testimony were charged up to Alger Hiss yesterday by Thomas F. Murphy, Assistant United States Attorney, who cross-examined him, as the fifth week of the witness' perjury trial opened in Federal Court.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 27 -- New gains by Lutheran churches in this part of the country were reported here today at a convention of the Atlantic District of the Lutheran Church, Missouri Synod.

WHETHER the sons of aristocratic English families still enter the Royal Navy, "the senior service," as midshipmen aged 14 or thereabouts is unknown to me. But they did in 1901, when William Washbourne's enlistment coincided with the nautical pageant off the Isle of Wight, which was a major part of the funeral ceremonies for Queen Victoria.

TRENTON, N. J., June 27 -- The New Jersey Taxpayers Association issued a statement today emphasizing that only a beginning had been made for President Truman and Congress in making effective the $3,000,000,000 savings proposed in the Hoover Commission reports on governmental revision.
An "interfaith-in-action" carnival and bazaar, with barkers, pitch-men, and a bagpipe band, opened last night for a five-day run on the Village Square, Eighth Street and Avenue of the Americas.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 27 -- Arriving at the end of the long hot day the home club pair of Nick Totilo, assistant professional and his amateur partner, Ruppert Vernon won the Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur best ball golf tourney with a torried eight under par 32 -- 31 -- 63 over the Woodway Country Club course here today.

In a letter to stockholders concerning the annual meeting of the Segal Lock Harware Co., Inc., on Aug. 3, Louis Segal, president, attacked a slate of nominees for directors put forward by an independent stockholders' committee as "a group of untried individuals who lack the know-how required in the manufacture of your company's products and who have no way of knowing the problems about the business."
Forty-third Street is being torn up for the sixth time this year.

On the 100th court day of the Communist trial, beginning its twenty-fourth week, Gilbert Green, Illinois chairman of the party, testified yesterday for his ninth day on direct examination, More than 3,125,000 words of testimony have been taken since the trial opened on Jan. 17.

Confronted with the first major threat to transit peace since he became impartial chairman of labor relations on the city's private bus lines, Theodore W. Kheel, former director of the City Labor Relations Division, announced last night that he would hold a series of meetings today with company and union representatives.

The pair accused as "lonely hearts" killers -- swarthy Raymond M. Fernandez and plump Mrs. Martha J. Beck -- listened impassively in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday as defense and prosecution attorneys sketched differing but equally lurid pictures of the slaying of Mrs. Janet J. Fay in Valley Stream, L. I., last Jan. 4.
LOS ANGELES, June 27 -- The Oil Workers Union, CIO, is training its sights on a 36-hour week week and a negotiated pension plan for the industry's 100,000 union members.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- On the ground that a trial judge allowed a jury to assume that a quorum of a House committee was present when a labor leader denied Communist membership or affiliations, the Supreme Court by 5 to 4 today dismissed the perjury conviction of Harold R. Christoffel of Milwaukee.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 24 -- Supervision by the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration of trade union ballots for the election of officers where there is evidence of malpractice is provided for in a bill introduced in the Commonwealth Parliament.

CHICAGO, June 27 Wheat futures fluctuated in an erratic manner within a range of around 2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today, closing 5/8 cent down to l/2 cent up. Corn, after holding steady a good part of the day, firmed in the late trading and finished 5/8 to 1 1/4 cents up.

To expect any considerable reduction of the tax burdens imposed by New York City would be idly unrealistic, in view of increasing population and the known needs for capital construction. But it is not too much to hope that a new administration, taking over on Jan. 1, 1950, will set in motion a study of possible tax reforms that will simplify a structure that just grew, like Topsy, and had its origins in emergency.

With great deference may I take issue with that part of your editorial of June 16 called "The Root of Chinese Woe" which attributes to our State Department (our foreign policy) the fatuity of not knowing that the root of Chinese distress is age-old, economic and not political.
A seventeen-year extension of the contract between the city and the Public Health Research Institute was signed yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall.

MAIZURU, Japan, June 27 -- The first group of Japanese war prisoners to be repatriated this year from the Soviet Union arrived here today aboard the repatriation ship Takasago Maru, thoroughly indoctrinated with Communist theory and, according to their own statement, sworn to join the Japanese Communist party with the object of Sovietizing Japan.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 27 -- Sweden has reverted to a policy of "automatic neutrality," and, now that Norway and Denmark have joined the North Atlantic pact, the Stockholm Government cannot consider any further discussions on Scandinavian regional defense.

A first degree grand larceny indictment was returned yesterday against Sigmund O. Engel, elderly matrimonial swindler now in the custody of Chicago police, on the basis of a charge by Mrs. Pauline D. Langton of 610 West End Avenue.

ROME, June 27 -- In a statement issued at the end of a meeting late tonight, Italian shipowners announced that they would be ready to create a fund of 1,500,000,000 lire to satisfy temporarily the seamen's demands as soon as Giuseppe Giulietti, President of the Seamen's Union, called off the strike.

OTTAWA, Tuesday, June 28 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent led the Liberal party back to power for five more years in an overwhelming victory in the Canadian general election yesterday for House of Commons seats.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 28 (UP) -Moscow radio broadcast early today that Arseni Vasilyevich Tishkov had been named Ambassador to Hungary to succeed Georgi Maximovich Pushkin.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Truman is too busy to journey to Piggott, Ark., next week to attend a hometown celebration arranged there for Leslie L. Biffle, Secretary of the Senate and one of the President's closest friends.
