ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 27 -- The Pittsburgh chapter of the Red Cross was warned today to adhere to the fund-raising policies of the American National Red Cross or face suspension of its charter. The ultimatum was issued by unanimous action of the National Board of Governors as 5,000 delegates assembled here for a national convention.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Stores should make an immediate increase of about 10 per cent in their promotional budgets if they expect to get their share of sales during the balance of this year, Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division and visual merchandising group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared today.

The Municipal Art Society adopted yesterday a resolution approving the creation of a new appointive city group that would act as a clearing house of design for municipally-owned areas and their contiguous neighborhoods. It held its annual meeting yesterday at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

TOKYO, June 27 -- Fears that Britain soon will devalue the pound sterling have become general here. The Bank of Tokyo, the former Yokohama Specie Bank, asserts in its current letter that these forebodings are one of the chief influences responsible for sharp foreign trade contraction since January.

A forty-five-game schedule, including three post-season play-offs leading to the championship, is booked for the 1949 All-America Football Conference season, Commissioner O. O. Kessing announced yesterday.
BIRMINGHAM, England, June 27 -- The old controversy of whether the plays of Shakespeare were written by him or Francis Bacon broke out again at the British theatre exhibition here.

PARIS, June 27 -- Mr. Harriman returned to Paris tonight after his talk with Sir. Stafford in London, which is understood to have failed to break the deadlock between the two over United States proposals for more competitive European trade through a more flexible system of credits.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 27 -- Two five-day citizenship training programs for girls were started today on the campus of the New Jersey College for Women. In attendance are 329 high school seniors from all parts of the state.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 -- The executive board of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, submitted a conditional offer to President Truman today to suspend their long and costly Hawaiian strike.
WHITE OAK, Md., June 27 (AP) -- A top Government scientist said today that too many people were confusing secrecy with security -and "unfortunately secrecy and progress are mutually incompatible."

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The term of the Supreme Court of the United States which ended today produced a large crop of 5-to-4 decisions in cases where the issues were comprehensible to laymen as well as to lawyers and were of equal interest to both. Typical of these were the judgment in the Terminiello case some weeks ago, and the one rendered today that affected Christoffel, once president of an automotive workers' union in Milwaukee.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, today that what a hotel chambermaid saw through a keyhole could not be used to arrest and convict a man of counterfeiting.

ASPEN, Col, June 27 -- A Convocation of scholars and leaders of contemporary thought from many nations who for the next twenty days will commemerate the 200th anniversary of the birth of Johann Wolfang von Goethe, the German author, poet and philosopher, was officially opened here tonight.

PARIS, June 27 -- The adoption of a unification coefficient next Thursday by the telegraph tariffs committee of the International Telegraph and Telephone Conference, in session at the Grand Palais since May 18, is expected to break a three-week deadlock and to assist the conference in meeting the target date originally set by the French Government for ending its deliberations on Bastille Day, July 14.

The Senate is expected to vote today on the central issue involved in the controversy over the Taft-Hartley Act -- namely, the question of what provision, if any, is to be made for the protection of the public interest in the case of "national emergencies."

ELIZABETH, N. J., June 27 -- Braving heat that sent the mercury to the 90-degree mark, 500 striking employes of the Singer Manufacturing Company marched on the picket line in front of the sewing machine plant here today with umbrellas protecting them from the sun.

The Tydings bill, which provides amendments to clarify and strengthen the National Security Act, was described last week-end as a measure that would "end bickering and waste in the armed forces," and would save "at least $1,000,000,000" annually in the operation of the armed forces.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Government may bring anti-trust action against the New York Stock Exchange and other markets whose members charge uniform commission fees, it was indicated today.
ATHENS, June 27 -- Greece remained without a government tonight and most forecasts were that none would be formed before Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -Six months after he had sided with the Supreme Court majority in denying a hearing to convicted Japanese war criminals, Justice William O. Douglas handed down an opinion today terming the December action "potentially dangerous."
Emerson Radio Phonograph Corporation is guaranteeing prices of its television line to consumers as well as to dealers for thirty-day periods, Benjamin Abrams, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Three United States airmen were killed in the Dominican Republic last week after an abortive attempt to invade the island republic, it was announced today.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 27 (UP) -- The New South Wales Cabinet approved extreme emergency measures today to cope with the worst industrial crisis in Australia's history caused by the strike of 23,000 Communist-led coal miners, which began earlier today.

DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds scored five runs in a wild first inning and went on to beat the Detroit Tigers, 10-4, in an exhibition game today. Lefty Johnny Vander Meer was the winning Pitcher.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Administration tonight accepted the fact of the signing of a five-year bilateral trade agreement between Britain and Argentina, but made evident its disappointment at the need for such a deal.
TORONTO, Tuesday, June 28 (AP) -- The party that controls the House of Commons names the Prime Minister and the Cabinet.
The transcript of the main parts of Alger Hiss' testimony in Fedral Court yesterday, with Lloyd Paul Stryker resuming his direct examination, follows:

Her gaping hatches swallowing cargo for such age-old addresses as Street of the Prophets in Jerusalem and Maronite Street in Rechatz, the 10,800-ton Haifa, Israel's largest ocean-going ship, is lying alongside Pier 37 in the East River preparing to put to sea again.

With more buyers arriving to place their initial fall orders, manufacturers of costume jewelry predicted yesterday that the season will show considerable improvement over last year. Buying has started two weeks earlier this year, it was pointed out, and will give retailers more time to test best selling numbers.

School tuna seem to be holding the fishing spotlight, and most of the Brielle and Freeport skippers are convinced that the big schools now off-shore are not the advance guard but the head of the parade.

To achieve distinction in one field of activity is more than can be expected of most men; Ray Lyman Wilbur was pre-eminent in three. As physician, public servant and educator Dr. Wilbur accomplished much during his lifetime; at its close he can truly be said to have been for many years one of the nation's outstanding citizens.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., who has been acting as spokesman for his ailing father, Senator Robert F. Wagner, spent a half hour yesterday afternoon with Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, at the Biltmore Hotel headquarters.

The fear expressed in the Topics of The Times column of June 18 that American legs are suffering because of television is unfounded. As long as television remains with us in its present state there will always be the healthful, invigorating exercise accruing from the sudden forward propulsion of the body, the energetic and purposeful stride to the machine, and the relief-bringing twist of the knob to the off position.

The publicity given to "beryllium poisoning" has resulted in widespread misunderstanding so that a substantial portion of the reading public may have the mistaken idea that all forms of beryllium are deadly poison.
The men's New York State tennis championship got up a full head of steam yesterday with the arrival on the scene of William Talbert and three other headliners at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Secretary of the Treasury announced tonight that bids for $900,960,000 of ninety - one - day Treasury bills to be dated June 30, and to mature on Sept. 29, 1949, were accepted today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -- The Senate today passed a bill providing for twenty-seven additional Federal judges despite warnings that President Truman might veto it because it allegedly discriminates against Government employes.
BERLIN, June 27 (AP) -- Four-power talks are being revived here tomorrow for a new try at ending the economic deadlock in divided Germany.

NEWARK, N. J., June 27 -- William J. Fay, chief appeal examiner for the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission, today reserved decision on whether 3,200 Ford Motor Company employes at two New Jersey plants are entitled to approximately $225,000 in unemployment benefits because of layoffs resulting from the month-long strike at the River Rouge plant in Detroit.

Samuel Sharp of 1539 Rosedale Avenue, the Bronx,. a 46-year-old I salesman who swindled thirty persons out of a total of $10,000, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Harry Stackell in Bronx County Court to serve two and a half to five years in state prison.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., June 27 -- Twenty city employes, including three men who held important posts in the regimes of former Mayors Frank Hague and Frank Hague Eggers, were retired on half-pay today at meetings at the City Hall of the Municipal Employes Pension Fund Commission and the Firemen's and Policemen's Pension Fund Commission.

" My Brother Jonathan," which arrives at the Beacon Theatre Broadway and Seventy - fourth Street, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The British-made drama features Michael Denison, Dulcie Gray and Ronald Howard, son of the late Leslie Howard. Harold French directed and Warwick Ward produced the Associated British picture, which is being released by Allied Artists, from a screen play by Leslie L. Landau and Adrian Alington and a novel by Francis Brett Young.

Pier 15, at the foot of Fifteenth Street, Hoboken, N. J., has been sold by Webb Knapp, Inc., to the Hudson River Terminal Company, a subsidiary of the Kerr Steamship Company. The pier adjoins the one sold last week by Webb Knapp to the Bethlehem Steel Company.

The forward motion of the stock market came to a halt yesterday and trading coasted along at slightly lower levels. A new sharp drop in scheduled steel production and a disturbing slump on the London Stock Exchange caused traders to loosen bids and sellers found resistance levels lowered.
An 18-month-old boy was killed and fourteen other passengers were injured at 11:30 A. M. yesterday when two buses collided at the northeast corner of Fourteenth Street and First Avenue.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 27 -- Upland, a bay colt by Follow Up -- Anna S., by His Majesty, owned by Francis Killmon of Keller, Va., and driven by Ben Turlington, won the first division of the Village Farm Stake No. 15 for 2-year-old pacers for a split purse of $19,362.50 in the Grand Circuit meeting at the Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Plans for the formation of the National Exhibitors Film Company by a group of nationally known motion-picture theatre operators to finance production of films mainly by independent producers were announced yesterday after a series of week-end meetings at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
PITTSBURGH, June 27 (AP) -- A large group of Northern and Western soft-coal operators was reported tonight to have flatly rejected John L. Lewis' share-the-work plan.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 27 (AP) -- The General Electric Company and Ami, Inc., a juke box distributor, announced jointly today that an experimental juke box television system now is in operation in a luncheonette in Hoboken, N. J.

BRUSSELS, Belgium. June 27 -- While the results of yesterday's Belgian general election still were incomplete tonight there was ample evidence at hand to fill in a rough outline of the developments. The voters of Belgium have moved this country slightly more to the right without, however, contributing a solution to the question of King Leopold.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., June 27 -- George Baird Jr. of the Brookville Country Club shot 33 -- 32, 65, a new course record, to join with Don Brown, Piping Rock pro, and score 29 -- 29, 58 to win the weekly amateur-pro of the Long Island P. G. A. with the lowest score in the history of the tournament at the Brookville course today.

Eleven delegates from the United States and an equal number from eleven foreign countries will meet at Edith Macy, a national training school of the Girl Scouts near Pleasantville, N. Y., beginning tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

The operating rate of the nation's steel mills is scheduled to decline 4.5 points this week to 79.9 per cent of ingot capacity, extending the current downward movement to eleven consecutive weeks, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

NANKING, June 27 -- Gen. Chang Chi-chung, former Nationalist military boss of northwest China, has made a statement in Peiping calling on the Kuomintang regime to surrender, praising the Communists and implicitly expressing his intention to cooperate in the establishment of Mao Tze-tung's "New Democracy," it was reported here today.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 27 -- A general alarm fire wrecked a two-story brick building in the Chelsea section here early tonight, causing damage estimated unofficially at $50,000.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 27 (AP) -- A major political crisis punctuated by hints of revolution over the Government's internal policies broke suddenly in Turkey tonight.

The Yankees beat the Giants, 5-3, in their exhibition game before 37,537 fans at the Stadium last night, but aside from its effect on the losers' pride no damage was done. Rather, only good -- and lots of it -- emerged from this affair, proceeds of which were donated to sandlot baseball agencies.
MONTREAL, June 27 (Canadian Press) -- The Jersey City Giants took both ends of a double-header from the Montreal Royals before 10,714 here tonight, winning the opener 7 -- 4 and the nightcap 5 -- 3.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Retail furniture dealers were warned today that a "negligible sales increase" and "gross margin reduction" in 1948 were the warning signals for a review of present policies and adjustments of future plans and budgets.

In the current debate over "national emergency strike" provisions there is danger that important fundamentals may be forgotten in the preoccupation with choice of particular devices or sanctions to prevent such strikes. Certainly most of those engaging in the debate, in and out of Congress, assume that what is wanted is protection of free enterprise and free collective bargaining, and avoidance of compulsory arbitration or other governmental determination of the terms of labor contracts.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 27 -- A record field of ninety-six teams appeared at the historic Garden City Golf Club today to participate in the thirtieth annual tournament of the Father and Son Golf Association.

The campaign of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to win recognition from the Bell System received major impetus yesterday when the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board announced that New Jersey telephone operators had voted in favor of CIO representation by a margin of nearly five to one.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 27 (AP) -- Kaiser-Frazer will build 1,000 small final assembly plants throughout the United States if experimental units now under construction prove satisfactory, Edgar F. Kaiser said today.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 20 -- News from Washington that the Economic Cooperation Administration is considering sending geologists and topographers to survey British possessions in Africa has evoked great interest in many parts of the continent, according to reports received here.

Coming from behind in the seventh to tie the score, the Dodgers last night beat the world champion Cleveland Indians in the ninth inning, 4 -- 3, before 31,546 Ebbets Field fans who paid their money into the treasury of the Brooklyn Amateur Baseball Federation.

Although it is not likely to come in this session of Congress, legislators interested in merchant marine problems now feel certain that clarifying (and perhaps drastic) legislation will be passed on the transfer of American ship tonnage to foreign flags.
Victories of the world Communist movement in colonial areas were counted up at a conference of top Soviet scientists in Moscow, according to a Soviet report that became available yesterday.

LONDON, June 27 -- Britain's long-festering dock strike, which was believed settled last Friday, flared up again here today when 2,500 British dockers and stevedores walked out of the Surrey Commercial docks and Royal group of docks in support of the Canadian Seamen's Union.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, told the Senate today that he would vote tomorrow against his own amendment calling for injunctions or Government seizure or both in national emergency disputes if the proposal of Senator Scott W. Lucas, the majority leader, for eliminating injunctions but retaining seizure was enacted.

MOSCOW, June 27 -- A British women's delegation headed by Laborite Member of Parliament Mrs. Leah Manning reported today after an extensive tour of the Soviet Union that it had seen no evidence of employment of forced labor in Soviet construction projects nor any indication that the Soviet Union is preparing for aggressive war.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27 -- A resolution calling for destruction of the Taft-Hartley Law, "root and branch," and restoration of the principles of the Wagner Act was adopted here today at the national convention of the American Newspaper Guild.

Coffee futures continued to go higher on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Strong demand from trade interests and scattered demand from outside sources advanced prices for contract "S" by 6 to 10 points. Selling was largely profit-taking.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- The twentieth outdoor concert season in Robin Hood Dell opened tonight with a performance starring Helen Traubel and Lauritz Melchior in a newly-prepared version of "Tristan und Isolde."

Prompt action by the Governments of the United States and the Philippines to remove obstacles to private investment and trade in the islands was urged yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council. The suggestion was concurred in by the Philippine-American Chamber of Commerce in New York.

Miss Jung Yet Yee, whose recent flight from China ended at Ellis Island instead of in the arms of the man she came here to marry, has convinced the immigration authorities that she was an American citizen. Her release was announced yesterday at the district headquarters of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 70 Columbus Avenue.
The Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company reported yesterday a net income of $3,677,809, after taxes and all charges for the nine months ended on May 31.

The pastoral letter issued by Archbishop Josef Beran and his Bishops and read last Sunday in Czechoslovakia's Catholic churches brings down to date a story that comes close home to people of every faith and even to those who have no formal faith.

The city's hard-pressed waterfront recreational facilities will ultimately receive an addition of great potential importance if a bill on which hearings will be held tomorrow is approved by Congress. This bill is the latest step in the effort to straighten out a legal tangle involving ownership of some valuable waterfront property at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H, June 27 -- Maintaining that "the masses of Americans are not receiving adequate medical care," the Central Conference of American Rabbis today advocated compulsory national public health insurance. The conference, representing the reform branch of Judaism, is the largest and oldest rabbinical organization in the United States.

The new decree concerning foreign exchange on Brazilian importations, effective July 1, is simply a technical operation that shifts from importers to the Bank of Brazil the responsibility for liquidating credits at a fixed rate, it was pointed out yesterday by a top trade banking source here.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Congress was asked today to pledge the United States never to use the atomic bomb in warfare unless in retaliation for an attack by other powers using precisely such a weapon.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- James C. Creighton, 46 years old, of Fox Lake, a senior merchandiser and veteran employe of Montgomery Ward Co., and two other men were arraigned in Felony Court today on charges of fleecing the big mail order house out of $110,000 in a series of shoe transactions.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The North American Company, New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application requesting permission to distribute 2,143,156, 1/2 shares of the new common stock, $8.75 par value, of the Kansas Power and Light Company, Topeka, Kan.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 27 -- The Czechoslovak Government has silenced Roman Catholic Archbishop Josef Beran and the Bishops by banning pastoral letters and meetings of church officials unless authorized by the Government. It has declared the recent "political" excommunications invalid.
Though he is managing director of the century-old Pimm's restaurants in London, John P. Finney admitted to us yesterday that dining out in England nowadays is likely to be a dull and dreary affair.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Federal Judge Albert L. Reeves rejected a final defense bid for acquittal today as both sides rested in the nine-week-old espionage trial of Judith Coplon.

Through arrangements just completed by Schenley Laboratories, Inc., pharmaceutical subsidiary of Schenley Industries, Inc., 350 Fifth Avenue, the discoveries of scientists abroad will be available for combating human, animal and plant diseases in the United States.

The one-story garage type building at 36-09 Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the A. B. C. Motor Truck Sales Corporation, dealer in General Motors trucks, from the Hi-Line Transportation Company.

BENNINGTON, Vt., June 27 -- Pipe cleaners and cigarette butts may help psychologists discover hidden personality traits, if two experiments now under way on the Bennington College campus prove successful.
GENEVA, June 27 (UP) -- George Isaacs, British Minister of Labor, protested today that the United Nations International Labor Organization was being used as a sounding board for political propaganda.

DETROIT, June 27 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, asked the Chrysler Corporation today to grant a "blanket" wage increase sufficiently large to cover the union's 1949 demands for pensions, a health and security fund, and a living-cost pay adjustment.
ANNECY, France, June 27 -- Fear that the United States is on the verge of scuttling its fifteen-year-old policy of gradually encouraging increased imports is spreading over Europe like a plague.
William Gridensky will join Burlington Mills Corporation (New York) on July 1, in charge of sales of the designer fabrics department to the high style dress trade.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today turned down a request for a $74,103,000 loan for proposed expansion of a wartime-built steel plant in Texas.
BUENOS AIRES, June 27 -- The 1,250,000,000 [$5,000,000,000] five-year trade agreement between Britain and Argentina to which the United States had objected was signed here today.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 27 (UP) -- Mrs. Peyton Van Renssalaer testified today that she had offered "Timmy the Junkman" a free trip to Florida if he would clean up the junk pile that mars the approach to her estate in this fashionable summer colony.

Jack Benny expressed strong doubt yesterday as to whether he would begin his television career over CBS as early as next fall. "Everybody seems to think that radio will still be the thing next season," the comedian said, "and my television show is far from definite."

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Sixty-one Senators petitioned their floor leaders today to take before the Senate for a voting showdown "at the earliest practicable date" a resolution that would direct the President to cut 5 to 10 per cent from appropriations made to the executive branch for the fiscal year starting next Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -The Phillies of the National League routed their intercity rivals, the American League's Athletics tonight by the horrendous score of 19 to 2. The exhibition was played for the benefit of sandlot baseball. Willie Jones and Del Ennis hit homers for the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- With the Democratic leadership in apparent full command of the situation, the House voted down today four substitutes for the Administration's national housing bill, now rapidly approaching final passage.

The Nassau County Transit Commission has not unearthed anything new in its recent report on the troubles of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road, but has merely displayed a "misunderstanding" of matters of public record. Walter S. Franklin, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, declared yesterday.

Senator McCarran's blockade of the immigration bill is inexcusable. His performance, however, merely points up an evil that has long afflicted the Congress. We must find a way to prevent Congressional hold-overs, by virtue of their seniority and the strategic positions they are guaranteed thereby, from nullifying the will of the people, in this case clearly expressed in the elections last fall.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Almost $100,000 in counterfeit $20 bills, printed within three blocks of the White House, were seized here today by Secret Service agents who arrested four men and a woman on charges of manufacturing and passing the bogus money.
The formation of a new unit of railroad-marine personnel within the jurisdiction of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, was announced yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the ILA.

The first announcement on the nature of the sixty-sixth National Horse Show, made yesterday, revealed that the open jumper division would be expanded by two new contests and $1,000 in prize money. The show will run for eight days in Madison Square Garden beginning Nov. 1.

" This book is dedicated to women and girls, and especially to teachers of sewing everywhere -- who enjoy the feel of fabric, the beauty of textures, the precision of stitches, the smoothness of seams, and who delight always in appropriate fabrics carefully cut and made up for happy purpose."

Most bankers in this Federal Reserve District appear to be experiencing increased difficulties with loan collections and the amount of past-due paper seems to be on the rise, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The bank's observations were based on a summary of reports prepared by its representatives who, in the past three months, visited banks in fifty-five counties in the district, excepting this city and Buffalo.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UP) -Two leading House Democrats today engaged in a bitter, name-calling feud over Federal aid to education.
Government unemployment benefits have put more than $1,000,000,000 in extra spending power into the pockets of jobless workers during the first six months of this year, it became known yesterday.

Seven thousand children from fifty-eight institutions in and around New York took over Steeplechase Park at Coney Island yesterday. For the youngsters it was a revel. For the Steeplechase employes and for 500 members of the Police Department's Anchor Club it was a stiff workout.

As the crew of a police radio car prepared to launch a boat, two other policemen, both off duty dived into the East River at 125th Street at 6:30 P. M. yesterday and rescued David Donohue, 27 years old, of 229 East 123d Street.

BOSTON, June 27 -- A sharp attack by Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire on Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, House minority leader, for his stand against housing legislation developed today at a gathering of New England Republican leaders.

Customers of the Abraham Straus department store at Fulton and Hoyt Streets, Brooklyn, who attended yesterday the opening of the store, employes' fifth annual hobby show saw among the seventy exhibits photographs of snow scenes, guaranteed to take a person's mind off the outdoor heat.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday that criticisms of New York public schools by the Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York represented an ex parte statement that had made no attempt to ascertain both sides of a controversy.

Two portraits by John Singleton Copley, made on a brief visit to New York in 1771 when he was at the height of his portrait-painting career, have been presented to the Metropolitan Museum. They represent members of the distinguished Verplanck family and are on display in the Verplanck Room of the American Wing, which contains original eighteenth century drawing-room furnishings from the home of Samuel Verplanck at 3 Wall Street.

MEXICO CITY, June 26 -- Although acknowledging that last week's revolutionary attempt had failed, Juan Bosch, Dominican writer and political exile, promised today that another attempt to dislodge President Trujillo would be made as soon as he and his companions could reorganize their forces.

The percentage of accounts discounting at the end of May was higher than in the corresponding month of last year, according to the eighth annual survey of about 300,000 accounts receivable, conducted by the Chicago Association of Credit Men, and released yesterday.

Instead of being disbanded after the final performance at the Broadway Theatre on Saturday, "High Button Shoes" will be taken on a tour of the "subway circuit," it was learned yesterday. The booking arrangement will keep the long-run Jule Styne-Sammy Cahn-Stephen Longstreet musical in the metropolitan area for a minimum of three weeks.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 27 -Dr. Allen C. Johnson, internationally known Greek and Roman history scholar, has retired from the faculty of Princeton University after thirty-seven years of service, it was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 27 (AP) -- Little Harp, 5-year-old Shamrock Stable gelding, won the Domino Purse by a neck at Monmouth Park today. Grandview Stable's Royal Lover, making his first start of the year, was second, with the early pacemaker, Mrs. William Helis' Greek Warrior, third.
NEW ORLEANS, June 27 (AP) -- Advertising executives were told today they must throw away their "old-style advertising ideologies and ways of thinking" if their newspapers are to survive a recession.

Joseph Durst, operator, has purchased the W. J. Sloane Building at 571-77 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-seventh Street, and the adjoining office building at 8-14 East Forty-seventh Street, from Gerry Estates, Inc., of which Robert L. Gerry Jr. is president.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Mandatory adoption by the railroad industry of the forty-hour week without a cut in pay on Sept. 1 will be "one of the greatest emergencies in the entire history of the railroads," Gustav Metzman, president of the New York Central Railroad Company, said today.

DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- A former Michigan State Senator, who was named on Saturday by the House Committee on Un-American Activities in connection with the American Slav Congress, said today that the Michigan Chapter of the group was not Communist dominated.

LONDON, June 27 -- While Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Stafford Cripps was reviewing British gold and dollar problems British Government bonds were taking another heavy loss in the stock market here today.

The leasing of space in the thirty-six-story office building under construction at 100 Park Avenue by the Ericsson Telephone Sales Corporation, a subsidiary of the Telefonaktiebolaget L. M. Ericsson, manufacturer of telephone equipment, of Stockholm, Sweden, was announced yesterday by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting agents. Steel framework for the skyscraper office structure is expected to be completed early next week.
An interesting use of feathers and veiling gave importance to many of the fall millinery designs shown yesterday by Helen Liebert at 19 West Fiffy-seventh Street.

Joseph Fuchs, violinist, and Eugene Istomin, pianist, who shared the spotlight at the Lewisohn Stadium two years ago, were paired there as soloists again last night in the all-Beethoven program that Fritz Reiner conducted with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.

Looking ahead to the closing of the current school term this week, Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger announced yesterday that he had suggested to magistrates sitting in the Traffic Court that a minimum fine of $15 be imposed upon first offenders for driving through play streets in disregard of traffic signs.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 27 -- Winston Churchill's youngest daughter, Sarah, made her American stage debut in McCarter Theatre tonight before a sweltering but highly receptive audience. Despite a temperature that must have been above 90 on her side of the footlights, she was consistently gay and charming as the beauteous divorcee, Tracy Lord, in "The Philadelphia Story."

Renewed charges of organized gambling and racketeering in Local 669, United Automobile Workers, CIO, in Paterson, N. J., are the "last desperate attempt of Communist elements and their camp followers in the union to discredit President Walter P. Reuther," George F. Cranmore, assistant New York regional director for the UAW, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Industrial production dropped in May for the sixth consecutive month and was going farther down this month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

In the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's refusal to lend $74,103,000 to the Lone Star Steel Company of Texas to aid its expansion program, the Government may be conceding finally that the steel capacity of the country is adequate at present.

Commodore Cornelis H. P. Coster will arrive here today aboard the Holland-America Line flagship Nieuw Amsterdam on his first voyage a master of the vessel. Formerly commander of the liner Veendam, he assumed his new post in Rotterdam on June 21.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., June 27 -- A newly perfected device that photographs objects and then reproduces them in great detail on a large projection screen only four seconds later, after complete processing of the film, was demonstrated here today.
ROME, June 27 (AP) -- The United States today asked the World Health Organization for a reduction in assessment and urged that the 1950 budget be pared from $8,000,000 to $5,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 27 -- Winding up a two-week session, a United Nations subcommission that has been studying discrimination problems today approved a report calling on member nations to take steps for the protection of minority groups.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 27 --Premier Marshal Tito and his associates have no illusion concerning the fate that awaits them should they lose the struggle against the Soviet Government and the Communist Information Bureau, a struggle that will officially enter its second year tomorrow.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 27 -- The Government tonight asked the surrender, under terms laid down by the United Nations, of Adolf Mudroch, 50-year-old Czech clerk in the United Nations Information Office. He is wanted for questioning in connection "with suspicion of contacts with a group under trial for anti-state activities," the Government has said.

Although there was no stakes race at Aqueduct yesterday, that fact did not deter 15,621 fans from visiting the compact Queens County plant. Many of them were not sorry, for the racing was fairly formful, with a satisfactory number of favorites and second choices hitting the board to make the day mildly remunerative for figure followers.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular yesterday, influenced by the weakness in the July, 1949, delivery, and final prices were 36 points lower to 5 points higher than on Friday.

The progressive stabilization of European political sentiment on a middle-of-the-road basis is illustrated again by the latest election in Belgium, which has produced three outstanding results. The first is the apparent defeat of King Leopold's ambition to resume his throne.

Sweltering residents of the metropolitan area experienced a brief respite last night from the stifling heat wave as a cold front from New England passed southward over the city. A Weather Bureau spokesman said, however, that the oppressive heat would return gradually, and that the abrupt drop in temperature had given no promise of an end to the extended drought.

The Wayne, Mich., school district will offer $2,500,000 of bonds on July 11. The securities, which will bear interest not to exceed 4 per cent, will be dated July 1, 1949, and will be due on each July 1 from 1950 to 1964, with redemption optional in 1954.
The Long Island Rail Road began yesterday the two-month job of photographing its 100,000 commuters for the new, permanent, non-punch ticket it touts as a "distinct innovation in railroad ticketing."

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- More than $100 a share should be paid to preferred stockholders in the liquidation of the Engineers Public Service Company, New York, the Supreme Court ruled today in a decision upholding a finding of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
A 53-year-old house painter in Lumbertown, N. J., was arrested yesterday for a murder committed in Brooklyn in 1921.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- A formula under which Edward Small, veteran independent producer, will take over management of Eagle-Lion Films, has been agreed on by Small, Robert Purcell, chairman of the board of Pathe Industries, E-L's parent company, and Serge Semenenko, president of the First National Bank of Boston, which holds E-L notes for more than $10,000,000, it was learned today.

CAIRO, June 27 -- Three delegates of the Palestinian refugees presented to the Egyptian Government through the Arab League yesterday a petition that the Arab refugees be permitted to work to earn a living. The refugees are forbidden to take employment in Egypt and Lebanon except under unusual circumstances but are free to work in Syria and Jordan.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 9 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 11 per cent.

More than 750,000 former Arab residents of Palestine, now living as refugees in the surrounding Arab area, are "ripe" for communism, Comdr. Edgar H. S. Chandler, Navy chaplain, said yesterday at the opening session of a four-day training and planning conference of the New York Chapter of the Military Chaplains Association, held at the Sloane House Y. M. C. A., 356 West Thirty-fourth Street.

Investigation Commissioner John H. Murtagh's inquiry into ticket scalping on hit shows was extended yesterday to include every broker in the city. At the same time, counsel for ticket brokers began preparations to test the constitutionality of the state law governing ticket agencies here.

BLUEFIELD, W. Va., June 27 -- The United Mine Workers held another negotiation session with Southern soft coal operators today but made no proposal for a three-day work week such as John L. Lewis offered Northern and Western operators.

LONDON, June 28 -- A nationwide "slowdown" on Britain's nationalized railways to begin at midnight Sunday was voted today by the delegates of the National Union of Railwaymen representing nearly 500,000 of their fellow members.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Senate debate indicated today that perhaps 8 to 10 per cent, rather than a recommended 5 to 10 per cent, would have to be cut from government spending for the fiscal year starting Friday, even if a set minimum of $2,000,000,000 was to be saved in an effort to ward off deficits and increased taxes.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 28 -- Paul van Zeeland, pre-war Premier and a leading member of the Catholic Social Christian party, accepted the Prince Regent's invitation tonight to form a new Government. The Social Christian party was returned in Sunday's election as the biggest in both houses of Parliament.

Station WGMH began beaming music and merriment yesterday from a basement studio in Goldwater Memorial Hospital to the bedsides of 1,500 patients in the thirty-six wards of the institution for chronic ills on Welfare Island.

The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company is offering to its common stockholders until July 19 the right to subscribe at $16.25 a share for 415,983 additional shares of stock at the rate of one share for each seven held. The offering is being underwritten by a banking syndicate headed by Drexel Co. and First Boston Corporation.

Business spokesmen who oppose the Havana Charter and the International Trade Organization were challenged here yesterday by William L. Batt, president of SKF Industries, Inc., Philadelphia, to produce a workable alternative way to expand foreign trade.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 28 -Princeton Township and borough police have begun an intensive search for clues as to the whereabouts of W. Leonard Alexander, Philadelphia investment counselor and a 1922 graduate of Princeton University, who has been missing since June 11.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 28 -- Development of atomic power could result in creation of new industrial areas and opening of fresh fields of manufacturing activity, according to an "exploratory" analysis announced today.

Two six-story buildings containing a total of fifty-six apartments and six stores at 238 to 242 East Forty-sixth Street were sold by Theodore Simon to Maurice Wurtzel in a deal reported yesterday by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., broker. Assessed for $104,000, the houses occupy a plot 75 by 100 feet, between Second and Third Avenues, near the United Nations site.
LONDON, June 28 (Reuters) -- Complete freedom of political activity will be granted to more than half a million British civil servants.

One million children in this country will be going to camp this summer, rich child, poor child, either "roughing it" at a private camp or enjoying a summer holiday through some organization, it was reported yesterday.
Montauk's competition with Ocean City on the white marlin fishing got off to an early start, and with a 102-pound fish, which is not a small white marlin at any fishing center.

Tonight's events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Fritz Reiner, conductor, Hortense Monath, piano, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 o'clock; Guggehheim Memorial Concert, Goldman Band, Central Park Mall, 8:30; "The Man in the Moon," Lemonade Opera, Greenwich Mews Playhouse, 8:30.
Graduates of the city's academic and vocational high schools received $12,930 in art and design scholarships and prizes yesterday.

ASPEN, Col., June 28 -- The State Department's Voice of America will broadcast proceedings of the Goethe Bicentennial Convocation which opened here yesterday. The international roster of scholars and musicians which makes up the Convocation's guests will be broadcast extensively by the Voice to Germany and Austria.

BOSTON, June 28 -- Joe DiMaggio became a Yankee in good standing tonight. Too long was the wait for his official return and there were probably times during the sixty-five games he missed because of an ailing right heel that all concerned wondered if the Clipper ever would make it.

RYE, N. Y., June 28 -- After being accustomed to the Apawamis Club golf course for the past forty-four years as the sole venue for the championship, part of the field of 350 competitors in the United States Seniors Association tourney today made a bid for the title at the Blind Brook Club at Port Chester.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The International Circulation Managers' Association was warned today that "television can be a competitor" of newspapers by Abbie D. Wallace, circulation director of the New York World Telegram.

Donald McNeill, former national titleholder, gained his quarter-final bracket in the New York State clay court tennis championship yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills. With him moved ahead Irvin Dorfman and Jack Geller, both recently of Yale.

Jean Benoit-Levy, director of the Films and Visual Information Division of the United Nations department of Public Information since its formation two and a half years ago, has resigned that post, effective July 6, to return to directing feature films.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- iThe Economic Cooperation Administration today approved purchases of approximately $10,000,000 worth !of motor vehicles, textile produet and lumber and sawmill products for European recovery.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A 50 per cent reduction in the unit cost of producing uranium-235, the atomic bomb component, was announced today by the Atomic Energy Commission in a "summary of progress'' at its Oak Ridge (Tenn.) installation since Jan. 1, 1947.

Squab chickens, new in the sense they are available for the first time since before the war, are ideal for hot weather dinners. Weighing about a pound each, the five-week-old birds may be roasted in thirty minutes. As has been pointed out here before, short cooking periods promote cool kitchens.

In line with management reorganization plans, the three aircraft manufacturing divisions of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation are being coordinated under the executive direction of Robert L. Earle, who was elected yesterday senior vice president in charge of its aeronautical operation, Paul Shields chairman, announced.

SAARBRUECKEN, June 28 -- The French are not calling attention to the Saar. In Paris it is not easy to learn what is happening here. On the ground, however, you see that something very interesting is happening. This coal-seamed wooded valley on the Franco-German frontier -- "the Little Ruhr" -- is the scene of one of the most noteworthy experiments in Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Tracy S. Voorhees, Assistant Secretary of the Army, reported officially tonight that the war-making German industrial and financial cartel system had been "effectively destroyed" by the United States decartelization program.

PARIS, June 28 -- The survival of the European Marshall Plan 'Council, and of the cooperation that it has slowly and painfully elicited from its sixteen member nations, were regarded tonight as being imperiled by the British financial crisis and the Anglo-United States dispute over competitive trade that will be discussed here tomorrow by European leaders.

CBS formally announced yesterday that Ed Wynn had been signed to an exclusive contract for a weekly television program that probably will start in September. The program, originating in Hollywood, will be presented as a kinescope film recording on WCBS-TV and the Columbia television network.
HONOLULU, June 28 (AP) -- A women's boycott against The Honolulu Star- Bulletin, which lasted for a week, demonstrates the high tensions arising from Hawaii's two-month-old waterfront strike.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- A three-run homer by Duke Snider in the seventh inning tonight broke a 2-2 deadlock and gave the Dodgers a 5-3 victory over the Phils in the opener of a three-game series before a crowd of 22,997.

On Monday, the winner of Aqueduct's top race was a Challenger II colt bred and owned by William L. Brann, trained by Big Ed Christmas and ridden by Gordon Glisson. That's the way it was yesterday, too, when Escador led every step of the way in a mile-and-a-six-teenth run for 3-year-olds.

Assistant Corporation Counsel Bernice Rogers expressed willingness yesterday in Municipal Term Court to remove herself as prosecutor of an Upper Manhattan apartment house operator when she learned the attorney for the defense was her former husband.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 -Four two-reel comedies with sound, produced by Mack Sennett between 1930 and 1932, will be combined into a feature-length film by Eagle- Lion for release this fall under the terms of a deal which E-L has concluded with Mr. Sennett, it was learned today.

When the Sobieski weighs anchor on July 15 she will carry as a passenger a woman whose "fondest dream of my life" is coming true. Facing total blindness, the woman's hope of again seeing a brother and sister in Italy was made possible yesterday through the generosity of a stranger to whom she wrote an appeal for aid.
ROME, June 28 -- The Rumanian Government a few days ago arrested the last two of the five Catholic Bishops of the Latin rite who were still free, the Vatican Secretariat of State announced today.

RENO, Nev., June 28 (AP) -- Deputy Sheriff F. W. Brenzel today identified the pilot of a speedboat that sheered off the feet of a young girl swimmer in Lake Tahoe yesterday as Phil Davis, wealthy Oakland (Calif.) automobile dealer.

The start of a new fiscal year on Friday finds the Treasury facing refinancing operations with a cash balance estimated to be below normal requirements, as a result of declining receipts and continued high expenditures. Although month-end tax collections will lift the total, payments for interest on the nation's debt and meeting maturing obligations on July 1 may result in deficit financing in coming months to replenish the Treasury's working balance.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 28 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea reported today that "heavy fighting" was in progress last Sunday between forces of the Korean Government in Southern Korea and "northern invaders" on the Ongjin Peninsula, south of the Thirty-eight Parallel.

LONDON, June 28 -- After a shaky start, British Government securities began to climb today following intervention by Government broker, who bought Old Consols and the Treasury 2 1/2 per cent issue. This tempted bargain hunters into the market, with the result that there was a swift rally which brightened other sections.

NEW DELHI, India, June 28 -- Under new regulations announced today, the property and fortunes of India's native princes, once autocratic rulers over a fourth of India's vast population, have in general been reduced to an estimated one-quarter.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 28 -- Soft-coal operators unanimously turned down today John L. Lewis' proposal for uniform three-day operations of the mines.

Overcoming extreme handicaps as a result of illnesses that prevented regular attendance at school, four boys and one girl received yesterday diplomas marking the completion of elementary and high school courses conducted in the Hospital for Special Surgery at 321 East Forty-second Street.

BERLIN, June 28 -- The Western powers and the Germans have made great progress in the political and economic rehabilitation of Germany, preparing that country for the day when it can join the democratic nations of the West, "ultimately as an equal," Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Military Governor and future High Commissioner, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson formally received Jules Feldmans today as charge d'affaires of Latvia in Washington. Mr. Feldmans will fill the post vacated by the death of Dr. Alfred Bilmanis last July.

For the first time in this country an extensive exhibition of work by Italian artists since 1900 has been arranged. It will open to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art and will remain on view until Sept. 11.

Chagrined youngsters seeking to buy bicycles at bargain rates lost out to adult dealers at the 303d Police Department auction of unclaimed articles held yesterday morning in the department garage, Meeker and Morgan Avenues, Brooklyn.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, June 28 -- The Yale Glee Club appeared tonight at Amsterdam's famous Concertgebouw in the first of three Holland Festival performances. The sixty-two-man chorus, led by Marshall Bartholomew, is on a six-week tour of Europe, its first since the war.

ALBANY, June 28 -- The Appellate Division, in a four-to-one decision, nullified today the temporary. $21,500,000-a-year cut in electric rates of the Consolidated Edison Company ordered by the Public Service Commission.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The wheat market fluctuated in an uncertain manner today on the Board of Trade here, breaking late in the session and closing about at the bottom with losses of 3/4 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel. Corn was unchanged to 1 1/8 cents a bushel off, the former on the July position which acted tight throughout the session.

HONOLULU, June 28 -- A wage increase of 14 cents an hour and immediate return to work of Hawaii's 2,000 striking stevedores were recommended tonight by a five-man emergency board appointed by Gov. Ingram M. Stain-back.

Investments in plant, property and equipment by the oil industry in the United States amount to $21,700,000,000 according to a new estimate made by Joseph E. Pogue, vice president of the Chase National Bank, and Frederick G. Coqueron, staff associate in the bank's petroleum department.

Elliott Murphy's "Aquashow," a combination stage and aquatic entertainment, opened last night in the amphitheatre at the World's Fair site in Flushing, Queens, before 6,000 spectators, who paid admission prices ranging from 60 cents to $1.25.

MACASSAR, Celebes, June 28 -- The spirit of nationalism pervades this as well as other areas of Indonesia, according to direct observations and all reports on the federal State of East Indonesia, of which this city is the capital. American correspondents studied conditions here in the course of an observation swing that included Bali, another of the group of islands making up this state.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Administration suffered a crushing defeat today when, by a vote of 50 to 40, the Senate adopted as a provision of the labor bill a plan sponsored by Republican Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio to give the President both plant seizure and injunction powers to deal with national emergency disputes that affected health and safety.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, San Francisco, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 100,000 shares of its $25 par value, 5 per cent, redeemable first preferred stock that is to be offered to employes of the company.

The Rev. Dr. Leland B. Henry, executive director of the Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, denied yesterday that he had made no attempt to get the viewpoint of Board of Education officials before he released a report sharply criticizing many public school policies.

Local 450 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, announced yesterday that it had signed a new contract with the Sperry Gyroscope Company at Lake Success, L. I., which contains one of the best pension plans found anywhere in industry.

Summer dress reorders resulting from continued hot weather have kept a limited number of low-end and popular-price manufacturers busy, it was learned yesterday. The great majority of dress producers, however, are concentrating on their fall lines and a few have made initial deliveries for the new season.

ST. LOUIS, June 28 (AP) -- Howie Pollet pitched his second shut-out of the year as his Cardinal team-mates pushed across five runs for a 5-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight. Pollet allowed eight hits -- three of them doubles -- and struck out five.

TOKYO, June 28 -- Japanese officials and the press tonight challenged the impression created here that all 2,000 Japanese prisoners of war who returned to the port of Maizuru yesterday as the first group to be repatriated this year from the Soviet Union intended to join the Communist party and were under oath to Sovietize Japan.

Clint Hartung limited the Braves to three hits and clouted a decisive home run to lead the Giants to a 2-1 triumph last night in their homecoming appearance before 27,732 spectators at the Polo Grounds. The victory reduced fourth-place Boston's margin over the New Yorkers to two and a half games.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 -- Engineers from the Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory told the American Society of Mechanical Engineers here today that a few small instruments may mean the difference between success and failure for the world's first industrial atomic energy plant, now under construction at Schenectady.

Dividend payments to insured banks by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would provide a "flexible" method of adjusting the insurance agency's assessment rate, according to August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Banks Trust Company.
WOODMERE, L. I., June 28 -- Volunteer firemen from miles around sped here early this morning to help fight a five-alarm blaze right next door to the Woodmere Fire House.

I have noted with great interest the article appearing in the June 24 edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES quoting the United Parents Association spokesmen in criticism of the system of regents examinations used by the State of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways system, today asked the Government to abolish its "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" system of airline regulation.
LAKE SUCCESS, June 28 -- The United Nations agreed today to remove the right of asylum for Adolf Mudroch, the Czech employe who has been taking refuge in its Prague Information Office since May 25.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 28 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have indicated opposition to a proposal by Secretary General Trygve Lie to open the United Nations General Assembly each year with a minute of silent prayer and meditation.

New bond issues totaling $155,000,000 will be offered to investors by underwriting syndicates here today. The offerings comprise three new flotations, two representing new financing for public utility companies and the third for a distillery.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 28 -- There is evidence that Soviet economists, still publicly praying for a United States depression in the hope it will also engulf the recovery program of Western Europe, are working hard to complete a new five-year plan by Jan. 1.

The prosecution sent seven witnesses to the stand in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday in an effort to tighten the net of circumstantial evidence linking Raymond M. Fernandez and Mrs. Martha J. Beck, alleged "lonely hearts" killers, with the hammer and scarf murder of Mrs. Janet J. Fay.
The vogue of the short hairdo is continuing strong and shows no sign of fading, several of the leading hair stylists agreed yesterday as they looked ahead into autumn.

News dispatches from London yesterday indicated that something akin to a crisis atmosphere had enveloped the British capital, momentarily at least. The Government, it was reported, has decided to call a meeting of Dominion Finance Ministers, presumably to discuss what new measures, if any, should be taken "to check the drain on British gold and dollar reserves."

Mayor Math Malisheski of St. Cloud, Minn., back from a goodwill mission to Bavaria, declared yesterday that the chief interest among hundreds of Germans he had talked to was how democracy works and what it does for the people of America.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 28 -- A strong southeasterly wind made for heavy going as thirty Star Class yachts started in the fourth day of the Noroton Yacht Club Race Week today.
It seemed incongruous that a person should lose $630 in Tiffany's and advertise the loss as a "pensioner's savings."

ANNECY, France, June 28 -- The United States, Britain and the Benelux countries (the Netherland, Belgium and Luxembourg) have virtually abandoned hope of reaching a tariff agreement with Italy, it was learned authoritatively here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 28 -- The United States came out in strong support today for Secretary General Trygve Lie's new plan for a United Nations guard force but the Soviet Union indicated that its original objections still stood in spite of Mr. Lie's revisions.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The cotton market at Lubbock, Tex., will be designated a bona fide spot market under the terms of cotton marketing laws, the Department of Agriculture said today.

ROME, June 28 -- Giuseppe Giulietti, president of the Seamen's Union, today rejected the shipowners' offer to create a funds of 1,500,000,000 lire to give temporary increases in pensions and other benefits to union members while the Italian Government prepares legislation designed to satisfy the seamen's demands.

Despite economic and governmental restrictions, British advertisers are looking forward to improved conditions, it was said here yesterday by Alan Whitworth, executive director of the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, Ltd.
We hope there will be no transit strike in New York. If there is one, the place to address letters of complaint is City Hall.
The main parts of Alger Hiss' testimony under cross-examination by Assistant United States Attorney Thomas F. Murphy in Federal Court yesterday follow:

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A second attack upon the leadership of Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., chairman of the Republican National Committee, who only narrowly retained that post in a party rebellion of last January, was made today.

Thomas H. Rossbottom, by all counts dean of the fraternity of steamship operating men in the Port of New York, will retire tomorrow as the principal executive of the Panama Line, which has one of the most successful records of any service in the American Merchant Marine.

A designer who can fashion velvets and dressy hats with the same pleasant casual simplicity with which she styles felts is Irene of New York. She presented her fall collection yesterday at 16 East Fifty-second Street.

DARIEN, Conn., June 28 -- Mrs. D. H. Ellis of the home club took the lead today at the halfway mark of the first Gertrude Artel Turner memorial golf tournament by posting 91 -- 19 -- 72 at the Wee Burn Country Club.

Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Overbaugh reached the age of 101 yesterday, firm in the belief that she is one of the few persons who had been born on Manhattan Island so long ago. Family records said Mrs. Overbaugh was born somewhere near Grand Street June 28, 1848.

The story of how a filth-littered East Harlem lot will be converted into a children's playground was told yesterday by Simon Beagle, social studies teacher at James Otis Junior High School and leader of the Otis Civics, Club.

James Sauter will head the producing committee of the sixteenth annual "Night of Stars," it was made known yesterday by Nathan Straus, over-all chairman of the gigantic United Jewish Appeal benefit. The event will take place on Nov. 14 at Madison Square Garden.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 28 -- The Government does not plan to prosecute the opposition Democratic party for its alleged provocative statements at its recent congress, the afternoon newspaper Aksam reported today from Ankara, where its owner, Necmettin Sadak, is Foreign Minister.

A new boxing promotion group made its appearance on the local scene with the announcement yesterday of the formation of the American Boxing League, Inc. Heading the new organization is Jo Wiseman, a director of Palisades Amusement Park.

There was a women's luncheon, attended by as attractive a set of the middle-aged as you will find anywhere. Since the day was warm, the food was served outside, not far from a tree in which two wrens were serving up bugs to their young.

" The Purple Shamrock: The Hon. James Michael Curley of Boston," by Joseph F. Dineen, will be published Sept. 7 by Norton. In his thirty years on the staff of The Boston Globe, Mr. Dinneen covered Mr. Curley's comings and goings at close range and once was sued by the Mayor for a half million dollars for libel,

LONDON, June 28 (Reuters) -The second of a three-day test match between England and the New Zealand cricketers ended in a draw at Lords today. The final scores were England 313 for nine declared and 306 for five. New Zealand had tallied 484.

A deputy collector of Internal Revenue and a brokerage house clerk were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of accepting a $5,000 bribe from a 25-year-old model, who allegedly did not file an income tax return after making a $50,000 killing in the stock market last spring.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Officials of company and union reached a tentative agreement here this morning to end a ten-week-old strike of the vital aircraft-parts plant of the Bendix Aviation Corporation in South Bend, Ind.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -Alex Kellner won his fifth straight game and his eleventh of the season tonight as the Philadelphia Athletics defeated Washington, 6 -- 1. The left-handed Kellner limited the Senators to seven hits.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 28 -- The Executive Board of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund has approved a new allocation of $1,200,000 for feeding programs among 500,000 refugee mothers and children among Palestine Arab refugees, it was reported today from Paris.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder will go to London soon for a series of conversations with Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Stafford Cripps on Britain's dwindling dollar reserves.

Manhattan's fourth new school in the Board of Education's postwar construction program was started yesterday when city and school officials broke ground for the $1,828,170 Public School 33 at Twenty-seventh Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

Furniture that is Swedish in make but United States in purpose was displayed yesterday by its designer, Mrs. Elva T. Hodgin, in the new showrooms of Allmart Products Corporation, 41 East Forty-ninth Street.

LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- Sir Stafford Cripps said today he was satisfied that the new British-Argentine trade agreement "will be of substantial advantage to both countries and will strengthen their economies."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 28 -- The first anniversary of the Communist Information Bureau's resolution expelling Yugoslav Communist leaders was observed today with complete calm in Belgrade and, as far as could be learned, in the rest of Yugoslavia.

A "moderate" rise in the average rent increase allowed by area rent control offices was predicted yesterday by John J. Pendergast, regional housing expediter, as a result of the four new "interpretations" of regulations announced in Washington on Sunday.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Prosecutor John M. Kelley Jr. denounced Judith Coplon at the end of her espionage trial today as a "clever spy" for Russia who "hated the United States."

VALHALLA, N. Y., June 23 -- At a time when the record-breaking drought has brought replenishment of New York City water supplies to a standstill, the heat wave has pushed consumption to a new high of 1,400,000,000 gallons a day.

Over the objections of the State Housing Division the War Assets Administration is going ahead with plans to advertise for sale the 117-acre tract in Hempstead, L. I., that includes twenty-five acres at Lido Beach now occupied by 286 veterans and their families, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The vice chairman of the United States Maritime Commission. Grenville Mellen, said today a majority of the commission approved, in principle, legislative measures to provide government aid in developing the American merchant marine.
CHICAGO, June 28 -- Trial of Preston Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, and seven others on charges of violating the Mail Fraud statutes and the Securities Act has been set for Oct. 3.
Mrs. Alger Hiss joined her husband yesterday in denying a close association with Whittaker Chambers and his wife Esther as the Hiss perjury trial reached its twentieth day in Federal court.

PARIS, June 28 -- Before an audience of French screen notables, Jennifer Jones today received a French film award as the best non-French actress of 1948. The prize, the equivalent in France of the Hollywood "Oscar," was a small reproduction of the famed statue of the Winged Victory.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 28 -- Good Time, a bay colt owned by William H. Cane's Good Time Stable of Goshen, N. Y., and driven by Frank Ervin, won the first division of the 3-Year-old Village Farm Stake in 2:04 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

In a move to obtain increased selling space, Beyda Co., retailers of children's and infants' wear, have leased the store, basement and second floor at 80 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Fourteenth Street. Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., was the broker.

OTTAWA, June 28 -- Almost exactly 50 per cent of the more than 5,000,000 Canadian electors voted Liberal in yesterday's general election that returned French-Canadian Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent's Government to power with 193 out of a total of 262 seats in the House of Commons.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, threatened yesterday to tie up operation of all private bus lines in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Westchester at midnight tomorrow.
A prediction of accessory fashions for fall was made yesterday by the Fashion Group, Inc., at a luncheon meeting and fashion show held for members at the Astor Hotel.

The prison sentences of one year each, imposed last January in Special Sessions Court upon Dorothy and Pearl Bloom, both of 210 Riverside Drive, for rent gouging, were reduced to six months yesterday by the Appellate Division by a vote of four to one.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 28 -- Abandonment of its program to establish associate units on college and university campuses today was recommended to the American Newspaper Guild by Prof. Norval N. Luxon, assistant to the president of Ohio State University.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Officials of the International Shoe Company, largest domestic manufacturer of footwear, were disclosed today to be members of the St. Louis group trying to buy the Keeshin Motor Freight Lines. D. D. Walker, head of the group which has made a reorganization offer of $1,300,000, listed four International Shoe men and three other St. Louis residents as members in a letter to Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy.

A rubber airplane fuel tank, coated with a substance recently developed at the request of the Navy, showed little effects from having a 1,500-degree Fahrenheit flame blasted at it in a demonstration at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday.

That the Communist party teaches its members how to answer "lies" about its advocacy of force and violence and its allegiance to the Soviet Union was admitted at the Communist trial yesterday by Gilbert Green, the party's Illinois chairman.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 28 -- A major battle is raging in the German press and political circles over the site of the capital of the new federal republic of Germany, despite the decision by the Parliamentary Council to place it in Bonn, the Rhine River university town where Beethoven was born.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 28 -- A Military Governors grievance committee sitting in Berlin has cleared Alexander Sacks, former decartelization official, of charges that were preferred against him for his testimony before a special antitrust investigative commission.

Two banks were instructed by a Supreme Court order yesterday to withhold from Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh records he had subpoenaed in connection with his investigation of scalping on tickets to hit shows. This was part of the campaign by a broker's lawyer to force a showdown on whether Mr. Murtagh has the authority to press his inquiry that began on May 3.
The suicide of a Polish woman physician, desperate after being excluded from an examination for a New York license to practice medicine, was prevented by quick police action yesterday.

PARIS, June 28 -- Economic Cooperation Administration authorities tonight announced agreement to the deblocking of a further installment of 25,000,000,000 francs from the counterpart fund for France's use in reconstruction and equipment.

A week-end program designed to provide regular Army post facilities for the training of reserve officers and enlisted men, while at the same time furnishing accommodations for their families, will be started at Fort Totten in September, it was made known yesterday by Brig. Gen. Frank A. Allen Jr., deputy commanding general of the New York-New Jersey Military District.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Johnny Sullivan's double and Gerry Priddy's single gave the St. Louis Browns a 7-6 victory over the White Sox in 12 innings before 9,456 fans tonight.
Fifty-three youngsters in pink and blue caps and gowns at the West Side Center of the Children's Aid Society, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, yesterday solemnly chanted their class song:
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Eddie Waitkus of the Philadelphia Phillies, is slated this Thursday to meet again the girl who shot him in a hotel here two weeks ago.
LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- Two seeded men's doubles teams were knocked out of the Wimbledon tennis championships today in a pair of thrill-packed upsets.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, says it is not the function of his agency to produce business for American exporters.

One reason why New York voters this fall should approve the projected $150,000,000 bond issue for the construction of new municipal hospitals, it seems to us, was advanced by the recent Tuberculosis Sanatorium Conference when it was said that in spite of the improvement of medical treatment for tuberculosis in the last few decades the number of patients being admitted to hospitals for therapy has increased.

" The Great Sinner," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama, starring Gregory Peck and Ava Gardner, will have its local premiere this morning at Loew's State. Robert Siodmak directed and Gottfried Reinhardt produced this adaptation of Dostoevski's "The Gambler.''

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 28 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations' campaign to organize Southern workers is "the most important crusade since the early organization days of labor in this country," George L. P. Weaver, national assistant secretary-treasurer of the CIO, declared today.

That mass of cool air that moved over the city Monday night is to stay with us another day or two, though there's no rain in sight. James William Waverly Osmun, chief assistant meteorologist, monotonously figured all this out from his racks of late afternoon charts yesterday.

The president of the Automobile Club of New York, William J. Gottlieb, yesterday accused Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate of failure to place proper legal rent controls over garage and parking lots.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Bernard M. Baruch, adviser to the Government in two World Wars, today vigorously scored the Administration for its lack of a "plan of total mobilization." Further delay, he said, is a "needless invitation to disaster."

The National Collegiate A. A. has approved for registration fifteen record feats achieved by student swimmers during the 1948- 49 season, it was revealed yesterday when Philip S. Harburger, chairman of the committee in charge, released the list of accepted standards.

I was indeed surprised that an old Bierwirt like Christopher Morley would betray his confusion over the meaning of the German word Grille, as shown in his letter about Hitler's yacht. The entomological translation of the word is cricket, not grasshopper; the German word for the latter being Heuschrecke.

Miss Ruth Balick, 22 years old, of 112 East Fifty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, was in critical condition last night in Kings County Hospital after being beaten with a lead pipe in the course of a hold-up in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The six-man Commission on Renovation of the Executive Mansion today held its first meeting since President Truman signed the bill appropriating $5,400,000 to do the job.

Dr. Albert Schweitzer, French medical missionary who has operated a hospital in the jungle of French Equatorial Africa for thirty-six years after abandoning established careers as an organist and a theologian, arrived yesterday on the Holland American liner Nieuw Amsterdam for his first visit to this country.

Having just returned from the American Christian Palestine Committee's Study Tour of Israel, during the month of May, I feel that there are several conclusions I would like to share with your readers.
MOSCOW, June 28 -- The new United States Ambassador, Admiral Alan G. Kirk, arrived at the Moscow airdrome today accompanied by his wife and son.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Following is the Senate vote approving the proposal of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, to use both injunctions and plant seizure to delay national emergency strikes:
WASHINGTON, June 28 -Four smoke jumpers from Montana parachuted into President Truman's backyard today.
CLEVELAND, June 28 (AP) -- Bob Lemon pitched effectively in the pinches and drove in what proved to be the winning run as the Indians defeated the Tigers by 4 -- 2 tonight before 50,892 fans.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 28 -- Mrs. Arthur Flash of the home club won the Joseph J. Windle Trophy, a match against par, by finishing one up on par over the beautifully groomed Quaker Ridge course today.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Federal Reserve Board, after consultation with the Treasury Department, said tonight that it had adopted a program to increase the availability of credit to meet the needs of commerce, business and agriculture.

At the Moscow meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in April, 1947, the four victorious Powers agreed to a proposal made by Mr. Molotov to return all their German war prisoners by Dec. 31, 1948, at the latest. In June, 1947, the American and Soviet authorities likewise signed an agreement pledging Soviet Russia to return its Japanese war prisoners at the rate of 50,000 a month.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 2,371, against 3,423 last week and 1,822 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,017 arrivals yesterday compared with 1,783 last Tuesday.

Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Lansky sailed yesterday on the Home Lines steamship Italia, formerly the Kungsholm, for what Mr. Lansky described as a vacation in Italy. He was reported expecting to visit with Charles (Lucky Lucania) Luciano, formerly of New York and now a resident of Italy.

SHANGHAI, June 28 -- The United States Government has sent a note to Canton informing the Nationalist Foreign Office in that temporary capital that the State Department cannot admit the legality of the Nationalist declaration closing the seaports of Communist China and adjacent territorial waters.
