NEWPORT, R. I., June 28 (UP) -- Superior Judge John E. Mullen ordered a truce today in the "battle of the woodpile" between Timmy the junkman and Mrs. Peyton Van Rensselaer.

The Bulova Watch Company achieved new high records in production, sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended on March 31, according to the annual report of John H. Ballard, president, being mailed to stockholders today.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Plans to strengthen the powers of the Secretary of Defense, already incorporated in a bill passed by the Senate, met strong opposition today when subjected to initial study by the House Armed Services Committee.

The stock market lost yesterday the gains made in a week of laborious recovery and slipped fractions to 2 points in the sharpest drop in more than two weeks. Although a mild rally developed in the final hour, the bidding was not positive and the day's extreme losses were not altered substantially.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 28 -- The American National Red Cross struck out today against "coercive" attempts to federate all welfare fund drives in one annual appeal. In a pamphlet distributed to about 5,000 delegates in convention here, as well as to thousands of legislators and other persons and organizations throughout the country, the Red Cross stated its case for independent money raising campaigns.
Residential properties dominated transactions in Queens and Nassau Counties reported yesterday by brokers and title insurance companies.

The General State Authority of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania announced yesterday that it would offer an issue of $30,000,000 of tax-exempt bonds on July 14. The borrowing will be made through competitive bidding. Dated July 15, 1949, the bonds will be due July 15, 1952 to 1975.

At the adjourned annual meeting of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company held yesterday in Philadelphia, stockholders approved an increase of $9,000,000 in authorized indebtedness. This is in addition to the present authorized indebtedness of $13,000,000, of which $12,258,000 is outstanding.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 28 -- Television will never replace newspapers as a medium for store advertising, M. J. Markowitz, vice president and sales promotion manager of Alexander's Department Stores, New York, predicted today. He addressed the final session of the sales promotion and visual merchandising convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Stevens Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The House Agriculture Committee, by a 17 to 9 party-line vote, today favorably reported the Pace bill for a three-commodity trial run on the controversial Brannan production-payments plan plus all other principal features of the Agriculture Secretary's long-range farm program.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- The Philadelphia Orchestra was feted today at a civic celebration on its recent tour of the British Isles. More than seventy-five members of the orchestra heard it described as the city's greatest present-day asset and as an ambassador of good-will for the nation.
Cherry-Burrell Cherry-Burrell Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 15 cents on the common stock, payable on July 30, compared with 25 cents paid on April 30 and Jan. 31.
A record volume of 650,000 passenger cars with about 2,000,000 occupants will leave this city for the Fourth of July week-end, according to estimates yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York.

Representatives of American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations unions agreed yesterday at a two-hour conference on a list of three potential Democratic candidates for Mayor who could be sure of the support of organized labor.
A record number of workers sought state unemployment benefits last week, spokesmen for the State Department of Labor said yesterday.
NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., June 28 (AP) -- A plan for regulating the flow of water over Niagara Falls was under discussion today by a group of power officials from Canada and the United States.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was irregular yesterday and final prices were 1 point lower to 17 points higher than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- On Nov. 1 the railroads of the United States will be required to publish joint rates with the inland water carriers of the country, under an order issued by the Interstate Commerce Commission, unless they are able to overturn the decision in the courts.

The latest person to express interest in producing Seen O'Casey's play, "Purple Dust," is Kermit Bloomgarden. Probably something will come of it this time. Richard J. Madden, who represents the noted Irish playwright, is in Europe, and in his absence his office yesterday confirmed Mr. Bloomgarden's intention, saying the producer "loves the play."
HENLEY - ON - THAMES, England, June 28 (AP) -- A sunburned young American, Chuck Van Wrangel, is leading a double life at the Henley Royal Regatta -- the world's premier river-boat event.

Protest against the jailing of four of the eleven Communist leaders on trial in the Federal court for conspiracy was voiced by speakers and in resolutions at a rally last night in Madison Square Garden under the sponsorship of the Civil Rights Congress of New York.

A plaque in honor of Policeman Anthony E. Oetheimer Jr., 29 years old, was unveiled yesterday morning in the police station at 23-16 Thirtieth Avenue, Astoria, Queens. He was shot and killed March 26 in the Forty-sixth Street station of the IND Subway system, where he had cornered a thief.

Stromberg-Carlson Company yesterday introduced a new television receiver line, most units of which contain what it claims is an entirely new chassis providing greater sensitivity, more power, finer picture definition and improved tonal quality.

Coffee futures were mixed yesterday in slow trading. Trade hedge covering of the near-by delivery months and scattered liquidation of the distant months by producer interests absorbed scattered selling. Final levels for contract "S" were unchanged to 6 points higher.

BOSTON, June 28 -- Owners of large apartment houses are more successful than small landlords in getting rent increases under the new Federal rent regulations, the first official sampling today revealed.
LORAIN, Ohio, June 28 (AP) -- A new queen of freshwater ships, 678 feet long, was launched here today.

Mayor O'Dwyer visited a public seminar of the Department of Purchase attended by 300 persons in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall yesterday and, in his questions and expressed opinions, made it plain that the city's buyers had not given him proof in black and white that their purchasing system had netted tangible savings.

Robert F. Wagner, sponsor of the Wagner Labor Relations Act and many other key New Deal measures, resigned from the United States Senate yesterday because of ill health. A Democrat, Senator Wagner had represented New York in the Senate for twenty-two and a half years. He is 72 years old.
LONDON, June 28 -- Cornelia Otis Skinner returned to the London stage last night for a two-week season at the Saint James Theatre after an absence of twelve years.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Fixing of brokerage commissions through agreement by real estate boards does not violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, Federal Judge Alexander Holtzoff ruled today.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 28 -- The Ku Klux Klan and other hooded organizations had their masks ripped off today in Alabama.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Democratic leadership of the House, driving to obtain final passage of the Administration's multi-billion-dollar national housing bill, cleared a major hurdle today in marshaling the votes to defeat an anti-segregation amendment.
Basic differences in concepts of national strategy are the roots, deeply buried beneath the soil of personal and service struggles for power and appropriations, of interservice friction.

Professor Wheaton's letter on "Housing Under H. R. 4009" in THE TIMES of June 24 creates the false impression that public housing is only opposed "by a small group representing by their own admission less than 100,000 people" when the opposition comes from millions of rank-and-file Americans who are wary of the principle that some families should be wards of the Government while others are not.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The United States Government has declined to recognize the legality of the Chinese Government's blockade of ports now under the control of the Chinese Communist forces, it was learned tonight. Formal announcement is expected tomorrow.
LONDON, June 28 -- The House of Commons received firm reassurance today that no pressure was being exerted on Britain by the United States to devalue the pound sterling.

BERLIN, June 28 -- Western Berlin's railroad workers returned to work today, and although by late tonight no trains were moving on either the lines between Berlin and Western Germany or the elevated railroad in the Western sectors of the city, the thirty-nine-day-old strike appeared definitely to be over.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and his wife were among 997 passengers, who arrived here yesterday from Europe on the Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam, which was delayed briefly en route here by a collision with a fishing boat off Nantucket Lightship.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 28 -- The Presidium of the Czechoslovak People's party, which usually calls itself Catholic, published today a resolution urging members "to be on guard everywhere against disrupters of public peace and order."

The Brooklyn Appellate Division unanimously reversed yesterday a ruling by Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson awarding $18,399 to Magistrate Alex Pisciotta for salary differential allegedly due him while he was serving in the Army in World War II.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., June 28 -- The Central Conference of American Rabbis closed its sixtieth annual conference here today with the election of Dr. Jacob R. Marcus of Cincinnati, Adolph S. Ochs Professor of Jewish History at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, as president of the conference.

Having been unable to reach agreement with Soviet Russia on the unification of all Germany under Four-Power authority, the United States, Britain and France now announce their final plan for the unification of the Western sections of the country under a federal German Government.

The apartment house at 545 West 111th Street was ordered closed yesterday by Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, and Bernard J. Gillroy, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings.

OSLO, Norway, June 29 -- Norway has decided to limit the distribution of "heavy water," which is essential in certain types of atomic fission experiments, to nations that are signatory powers of the North Atlantic pact, Premier Einar Gerhardsen said in an interview today with this correspondent.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -The Department of Commerce has indicated in a report to Congress that the first inland foreign-trade zone in the United States may be opened in San Antonio, Tex.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- House Republicans joined a bipartisan Senate majority today in insistent Congressional demands that President Truman order cuts in the Government's spending.

Eddie Arcaro had an enjoyable afternoon at Aqueduct yesterday, the highlight of it being the scoring of his hundredth victory of the year on E. P. Taylor's Navy Chief in the fifty-ninth running of the Great American Stakes for 2-year- olds.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- White House circles exhibited considerable indignation today over criticism by Bernard M. Baruch of national war planning in a speech yesterday to the graduating class of the Industrial College of the Armed Forces.

Sixty-two members of the Senate are now lined up in support of action "at the earliest practicable date" on a resolution to direct the President to cut 5 to 10 per cent from the budget which they themselves have voted, or are in process of voting. If there was ever a clear case of passing the buck in Washington, this is it.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Cooperative Grange League Federation, Ithaca, N. Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 1,200,000 shares of its $5 par value common stock to be offered to present and prospective members at $5 a share.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Carl Scheib snapped a personal six-game losing streak and posted his third victory of the season tonight as the Athletics defeated the Senators, 7 -- 4.

It was only a few weeks ago that he came near to being written off the books. The wiseacres were saying he'd never be the same again. Eulogies were written -- in the past tense. The training period ended and he was under treatment. The season opened and he was sitting on the bench.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- A spokesman for the American Friends Service Committee said today that Alger Hiss had accepted an invitation to serve on the faculty of a seminar it conducts at the Holderness School for Boys, Holderness, N. H.
ALBANY, June 29 -- The Public Service Commission said today that it would take its fight to reduce Consolidated Edison electric rates to the Court of Appeals.

Prices of United States Government bonds moved up sharply yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's announcement that open market operations of the system from now on would be aimed at making credit available to business and away from keeping money rates frozen in a fixed official pattern.

Sentenced for sixty years to life after a plea of guilty to a second-degree murder charge in Bronx County Court yesterday, Leroy Payton, alias Hayward, a 20-year-old, six-foot prisoner, raised his arms as though threatening the County Prosecutor and was carried struggling from the court room.

The Giants edged closer toward a first-division berth yesterday by recording their third straight victory, and second in a row, over the Braves, at the Polo Grounds. The score was 9 -- 3 as Larry Jansen came up with a route-going seven-hit effort and his mates pounded Vern Bickford and Johnny Antonelli for thirteen safeties.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Freight carloadings in the Middle West in the third quarter of this year are expected to be 9.9 per cent below the comparative period last year, George M. Cummins, general chairman of the Midwest Shippers Advisory Board, has announced.

DURHAM, N. H., June 29 -- Declaring that large areas of the country did not provide adequate schooling, leading educators called on Congress today to pass a Federal-aid-to-education bill at this session.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 29 -- The two leading contenders in the Star Class races of the eleventh annual Race Week Regatta at the Noroton Yacht Club fought it out for the lead today in the fifth of the six races. Pat O'Gorman of Larchmont, N. Y., in Wahini, crossed the finish line 40 seconds ahead of Skip Etchells of Old Greenwich in Shillalah.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 29 -- Roman Catholics using fists and clubs attacked and drove off police who had come to arrest priests for reading or possessing a pastoral letter in at least four villages of the Zilina district of Slovakia last Sunday, a church source at Turcansky Svaty Martin reported by telephone today.

The New York City Rent Advisory Board at a closed session yesterday fixed Sept. 14 for a hearing on a petition for a 15 per cent across-the-board residential-rent increase filed by the Federal Landlords Committee, Inc., a group claiming to represent 2,918 property owners.

Africa entered the fashion field yesterday as a rich source of inspiration for color and silhouette in a showing of excellently designed fall millinery. Presented by Lenesta at her salon at 15 East Fifty-third Street, the collection was not only imaginative and handled with good taste but possessed a sure quality of wearability that will win it quick applause.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Truman's Fair Deal scored its first major triumph tonight as the House voted final approval of the National Housing Bill.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 29 (AP) -- Three American entries in the Henley Royal Regatta scored first-round victories today but a fourth was eliminated.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that it had no power to force a striking union to make up wages lost by non-striking employes during a walkout -- even if the strike was illegal.

BUENOS AIRES, June 29 -- The Argentine domestic budget for 1950 was placed before Congress last night by the Minister of Finance, Ramon Cereijo, who presented both a surplus for last year and a reduction in estimated costs for next year over 1949.

The Fourth of July picnic, that community endeavor of the Gay Nineties, included the biggest watermelons on the market. Rosy slices, dripping with juice, munched out of hand in the way they taste best, topped off the fried chicken, homemade pickles and potato salad that composed the fresh-air feast.

ATHENS, June 29 -- Alexander Diomedes, Liberal Deputy Premier for economic affairs in the recent Government, was late tonight summoned to the King's palace tomorrow to assume the mandate for the formation of a new coalition Cabinet.
TOKYO, June 29 -- Occupation officials moved today to strengthen the hand of the Japanese Government in its drive against student political activity.

A degree of stability was attained yesterday by the stock market after the set-back on Tuesday. The reversal of form was not accompanied by any bulge in business and the gain was laborious. With the composite rate up 0.47 point, the list recouped about half of the previous day's loss.
CHICAGO, June 29 (UP) -- Fall and winter catalogs issued today by two big mail order firms listed substantial price cuts ranging up to 40 per cent.

ASPEN, Col., June 29 -- A panel of seven art authorities conducted a round table discussion here today on the painting, architectural drawing and art philosophy of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe at the third day's session of the International Goethe Bicentennial Convocation and Music Festival.

NIAGARA FALLS, June 29 -- Several hundred women jammed the ballroom of the Niagara Hotel in Niagara Falls this afternoon at the testimonial luncheon held for Miss Jane Todd, president of the Federation of Women's Republican Clubs of New York State, Inc., and vice chairman of the New York Republican State Committee.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- There was a material change in sentiment in wheat over night on the Board of Trade and professional traders and commission houses were aggressive on the buying side on the basis of rumors that the Government was in the market for carlots of cash wheat in the Southwest, and continued unfavorable crop comments from the Southwest and Northwest.

LONDON, June 29 -- A statement from the International Mine Clearance Board, issued through the Admiralty today, said that with the exception of a small area between Malin Head in Ireland and the Isle of Islay, off the west coast of Scotland, the coastal waters of the British Isles were regarded as clear of mines.

The threat of a strike that would tie up all the city's private bus lines was eliminated last night when 4,000 union members, meeting at Manhattan Center, voted to accept a peace formula submitted by the major bus companies.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 29 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie is asking United Nations members to make immediate provisions for the care of 2,000,000 refugees who are continuing to "lead a difficult or even wretched existence."

Once again Richard Savitt, Eastern intercollegiate tennis champion from Cornell, defeated Sidney Schwartz of the University of Miami yesterday to gain the quarter-final round of the New York State clay court tournament at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Farm prices declined nearly 2 per cent between mid-May and mid-June, the Department of Agriculture reported today. Truck crops and food grains led the drop. Prices paid by farmers eased off but slightly.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The House Ways and Means Committee, going far toward meeting President Truman's requests, has tentatively approved broad revisions of the Social Security system entailing increased coverage, benefits and taxes.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The charter for the joint Western allied civilian control in Germany was made public today simultaneously in Washington, London and Paris. The new arrangement will go into effect after the establishment of a government of Western Germany, expected between Sept. 1 and Sept. 15 following the August elections.

Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company yesterday introduced seven new carpet grades featuring improved design and styling at lower prices during a dealer and press showing at its headquarters and New York showroom, 140 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Charter of the Allied High Commission for Germany as signed at Paris June 20 by representatives of the United States, Britain and France:

NEWMARKET, England, June 29 (AP) -- Paul Mellon, Washington and Pittsburgh banker, paid $50,400 for a 2-year-old filly today at the Newmarket sales and said the horse would be shipped to the United States.

Kirby Block Co., Inc., yesterday recommended that all stores which it services devote only 25 per cent of their lamp purchasing budgets to floor lamps. The recommendation was contained in an outline of a new stock plan for lamps submitted to member stores at a meeting of resident buying office's smallwares department in the Governor Clinton Hotel

Hortense Monath was featured as piano soloist in last night's concert by the Philharmonic-Symphony at Lewisohn Stadium. Under the direction of Fritz Reiner she made her second appearance in the summer series, this time playing Mozart's Concerto in A major (K. 488).

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Three residents of New York, officers and stockholders of H. E. Salzberg Company, Inc., engaged in purchasing railroad properties in the process of abandonment, for purposes of salvage, today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to authorize them to control the Des Moines Central Iowa Railway Co., the new name for the reorganized Des Moines Central Iowa Railroad.

MOSCOW, June 4 -- What makes a boy a hooligan? That was the question that worried the father and mother of Fedya Besonov, a bright, energetic lad in the fifth grade. Often by the time he got home from school he would be bruised and scratched from fights and adventures on the way home.

Four Bronx youths, including the alleged "victim" in the case, were held yesterday on varied charges of assault, attempted robbery and violating the Sullivan Law after police uncovered an arsenal of ten pistols, ten rifles and hundreds of rounds of ammunition.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson explained today that the United States Government was merely trying to reserve all its nationals' rights under international law in connection with the Chinese Government's closure of Communist-held ports to foreign shipping.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- Group Productions, the Charles K. Feldman Company, is preparing four properties for eventual filming probably at major studios on a participation basis, a Feldman representative disclosed today. The properties are "The Silver Whistle," a recent Broadway play by Robert McEnroe; "The Wayward Bus," a novel by John Steinbeck; "Finian's Rainbow," Broadway musical play by Burton Lane, E. Y. Harburg and Fred Saidy, and "Tender Mercy," a novel by Leonard Kaufman.
A program of reserve training for clergymen who were chaplains in World War II is being planned in the New York-New Jersey Military District and the Third Naval District, it was learned yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 -- India's dangerous food problem will be treated as if it were a war emergency, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru announced tonight. In a nation-wide broadcast he said a central food controller or commissioner would be appointed to head an intensive program to increase production and reduce costly imports.

The Board of Estimate was urged yesterday to authorize a public housing project where it now proposes to make a municipal parking lot in Flushing, Queens, and put the parking lot where the housing project is tentatively approved.

Robert L. Richards has been appointed general manager of the rayon department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. He succeeds Benjamin M. May, who has retired after forty-six years with the company.
PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner batted the Pirates to a 7-3 victory over the Reds today. He drove in five runs with a double and a grand slam homer. It was his 19th home run of the season.

PRAGUE, Chechoslovakia, June 29 -- Adolph Mudroch, 50-year-old clerk of the United Nations Information Office in Prague, went to his home here today after spending thirty-five days and nights in the office as a refugee from the Czech police.

Directors of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company voted a dividend of $1.15 a common share, payable on June 30, which compared with $1.50 quarterly distributed previously. Company states that the declaration is based on estimated second quarter earnings.

A new one-story factory building occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at 1530 Stilwell Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Frank Spadaro, the builder, to the Fairmont Iron Works for cash over a first mortgage of $30,000. The Joseph G. Platzner Company was the broker in the sale of the property, title to which was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 29 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie, of the United Nations, leaving the United States for a six-week vacation in Scandinavia, said today that the "cold war" may have been succeeded by a period of "cold peace."
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 29 -- A new edition of the East Hampton Ladies Village Improvement Society Cookbook came out here today.

A real estate broker and an apartment house manager pleaded not guilty yesterday in Special Sessions to rent gouge charges that they had mulcted $3,260 from tenants seeking living quarters. In announcing the arrest of the two men, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced that they brought to seventy-seven the number of persons charged with rent gouging since the investigation got under way last year.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday that he was not yet ready to say whether or not he desired the Democratic nomination for United States Senator. However, the impression prevailed among local Democratic leaders that Mr. Lehman would be the party's candidate, in the election on Nov. 6, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Robert F. Wagner.
Trouble may be brewing for the New York waterfront in a continued dispute over the use of public loaders, it was reported yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, June 29 (AP) -- Two Americans are among fifty-five men held in Merida as supposed members of the recent Dominican invasion expedition.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 29 -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett today received the Knesset's (Constituent Assembly) approval for his foreign policy.

ALBANY, June 29 -- The Public Service Commission announced today that it had authorized the New York Richmond Gas Company, which serves manufactured gas to 38,000 customers on Staten Island, to convert to natural gas.

LONDON, June 29 -- The Royal Commission that has investigated the British press for the last two years reported today that the present system of ownership, on the whole, was satisfactory and flatly rejected any form of state control.

CEDARHURST, L. I., June 29 -- Mrs. Henry Gerry of Piping Rock, a 30 handicap player, turned in a sparkling 43 on the back nine to finish with 42 points and win the Women's Long Island Golf Association annual point par tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

PARIS, June 29 -- Divergences in the Government over the future status of the French aviation industry resulted in a conflict that throughout today threatened a break-up of the Cabinet combination. But a compromise was reached, almost inadvertently, which promises relaxed tension and passage of the bill tomorrow.

KATONAH, N. Y., June 29 -- One of the most unusual devices for commuting to work was demonstrated here today by Alfred B. Bennett, a veteran pilot who catapults his personal plane into the air from the field beside his home and flies off after a run on the ground sometimes less than three times the length of the small aircraft.
One hundred persons who had contributed liberally to the fund drive for Boys Town, Italy, were the guests of Mayor O'Dwyer last night at a lawn party at Gracie Mansion.

When the late Dr. Percival Lowell, founder of the Flagstaff Observatory, ingeniously reasoned that Mars is a parched world engaged in a desperate, united effort to irrigate its temperate and torrid zones with water from melting polar snows he never dreamed that in 1949 inhabitants of this earth would have to think of their own fate.

Jokers about the navy of landlocked Switzerland have had the tables turned on them by the steamship General Guisan, the first vessel built specifically for the newly established Swiss merchant marine.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 29 -- The Judo-Christian cultural heritage in this country insures ultimate victory over the national evil of race prejudice and the world challenge of totalitarianism, Dr. Smiley Blanton, psychiatrist and director of the Consultation Clinic, Marble Collegiate Church, New York City, declared today.
ST. LOUIS, June 29 -- Left-hander Max Lanier, the National League's leading pitcher when he jumped to Mexico in 1946, notified the Cardinals today that he is rejoining the club.

Mayor O'Dwyer will open the new Great Kills Park on Staten Island's South Shore tomorrow at noon, it was announced yesterday. Park Commissioner Robert Moses will preside. Speakers will include Borough President Cornelius A. Hall of Richmond and City Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell.

Two babies, who in the first two weeks of their lives have flown nearly 6,000 miles, arrived at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, early yesterday morning. On June 12 their imminent birth had caused a Trans-ocean Airlines DC-4 to make an emergency landing at Prestwick, Scotland.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 29 -- The Charter for the High Commission paves the way for strict United States control of economic policies in the federal republic of Germany as a protection to the American taxpayer who is footing the bill of German recovery, according to a realistic appraisal by a high official here.

By threatening contempt proceedings yesterday against writers on the Alger Hiss perjury trial, Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman raised the issue of how far the press might properly comment on a Federal trial currently in progress.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 29 -- Rhode Island jewelry manufacturers were jubilant today with the announcement that the Canadian market, closed to them since November, 1947, will be reopened on Friday.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Herbert Hoover visited the Capitol today to add his influence to a fight against a provision in the military reorganization Bill that would create in the national Military Establishment a single military figure at the head of the three services.

Revision of the Federal Reserve Board's open market policy will not create any additional demand for loans but appears to be designed to set the stage for the initiation of the deficit financing program expected to begin early next month, bankers here asserted yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -- America's home economists set themselves a two-fold task today -- to extend their own research into family relationships and to improve the curricula of the nation's schools and colleges.

Each technical advance which raises man's spirit brings with it a club to knock that spirit down again. The airplane was invented and man grew used to traveling rapidly. Accustomed now to moving at 300 miles an hour, man, temporarily grounded by fog, feels more helpless than when he traveled by bicycle.

PARIS, June 29 -- A final attempt to compromise the British-United States dispute over means of widening competition in European trade was made tonight by the European Marshall Plan Council after Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, had shown what some described as a conciliatory inclination.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 29 -- Dr. William A. Hinton has been named Clinical Professor of Bacteriology and Immunology of the Harvard Medical School, it was announced today. Dr. Hinton, who has been with the school more than twenty-five years, thus becomes the first Negro to hold a professorship in Harvard University.

PARIS, June 29 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman, appearing today before the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly, asked for ratification of the North Atlantic treaty before the summer recess of Parliament. The session has been tentatively scheduled to end between July 15 and the 31st.

DARIEN, Conn., June 29 -- Mrs. Dwight H. Ellis of the host club became the first winner of the Gertrude Arbelt Turner invitation handicap tournament at Wee Burn Country Club today by repeating her first-day score of 91 -- 19 -- 72 for a thirty-six-hole net of 144.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 29 (AP) -- The Tennessee Valley Authority admitted today it had awarded a contract for steam power plant equipment to the second low bidder, but said other factors were considered.

Sheffield Farms, Inc., sold its former Bay Ridge plant in Brooklyn at 823 to 861 Sixty-fifth Street to the S. Cohen Realty Corporation, represented by David Soltes, attorney. The property consists of five buildings, one and two stories in height, on a plot 100 by 310 feet.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 29 -- In line with their contention that the 1948 agreement with the United Mine Workers has a month and a half to run, soft coal operators in the national wage conference will not propose any new working terms for the present, informed persons said today.

License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey issued summonses yesterday for Marshall Kalen and Barry Keith, associated in the operation of the Gray's Ticket Service, 1619 Broadway. Mr. McCaffrey said he may suspend or revoke the broker's license, because of alleged violations of the department rules.

TOKYO, June 29 -- Japanese Government officials reported tonight that increasing attempts were being made to sabotage railroad transportation following a decision of the Government Railway Workers' unions to use force if necessary to block the proposed dismissal of "surplus" operating employes.

For technical reasons, publication of Mika Waltari's novel "The Egyptian" has been postponed again -- this time until Aug. 22 -- by G. P. Putnam's Sons. Life story of a Pharoah's physician in the eighteenth dynasty, the book was written by a Finn and has already been published in that language, Swedish, Danish, Norwegian, French and German.

Recently a fist fight broke out in the House of Representatives. The cause of the "demonstration" was whether a member of Congress should be allowed to debate on the controversial housing bill for seven minutes or ten minutes; at first glance this appears to be nothing more than a picayune squabble which had best be forgotten.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The price of gasoline is high because "the market has been rigged through the curtailment of crude oil production," W. L. Heinz, secretary and treasurer of the South Carolina Oil Jobbers Association, Columbia, declared here today.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 29 (UP) -- Connecticut faced the possibility of two rival judges on numerous court benches after midnight Thursday as Governor Chester Bowles waged a three-way fight today over the right to appoint new judges.
CINCINNATI, June 29--Dr. 1 David Philipson continued to hisI very last days to follow in the path j I of his longtime friend, the late1 Rabbi Isaac 1%{. Wise, in opposition! to Jewish nationalism.

TULARE, Calif., June 29 (AP) -- Bob Mathias, the defending champion, moved into the lead of the national A. A. U. decathlon competition tonight before a near capacity crowd of almost 6,000 home town fans.

Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company's entire line of exterior and interior house paints, varnish and enamel products and paint brushes will be reduced a composite average of 9 per cent, effective tomorrow, E. D. Peck, general paint manager of the company's merchandising division announced here yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- There will be little change in down payments and time to pay in installment purchases of most home goods, the credit executives division of the National Retail Furniture Association predicted today in advance of the lapsing of the Federal Reserve Board's Regulation W tomorrow at midnight.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- The Browns used a 1-0 victory today to sweep a two-game series from the White Sox. Dick Kokos' eighth inning single decided a pitchers' battle between Ned Garver and Billy Pierce.

With Mrs. Alger Hiss still corroborating her husband in his defense against Federal perjury charges, the trial proceedings yesterday ranged from a threat of contempt citations by Judge Samuel H. Kaufman against writers on the trial to testimony that Whittaker Chambers as a boy cooled his feet by walking through a brook with shoes and stockings on.

RYE, N. Y., June 29 -- A 60-year-old West Virginian, Joseph Wells, who makes his golfing headquarters across the river in East Liverpool, Ohio, won the United States seniors title with a thirty-six-hole score of 145, one of the lowest on record in the forty-five years of competition.

LONDON, June 29 -- Holding that the Labor Government has no mandate to nationalize the iron and steel industry, the Conservative-dominated House of Lords tonight a series of amendments to the steel bill, postponing nationalization until after the general election due next year.

C. Edward Raabe, president of Woolsey Paint and Color Co., Inc. and vice-president of Sapolin Paints, Inc., New York, announced yesterday that price reductions of about 12 per cent would be made on their first grade house paints within the next 30 to 60 days.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today that thirty-seven persons who had received emergency clearance for access to atomic secrets later had been discharged because of "derogatory" information developed in full investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Polish Ambassador Josef Winiewicz said today that Poland has decided to stop placing orders in the United States market for machinery and industrial equipment.

DETROIT, June 29 (AP) -- The first Ford Motor Company union local to report results in the current company-wide strike vote disclosed today that its membership was 3 to 1 in favor of a walkout if necessary to win union demands.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve System announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 22.

BOSTON, June 29 -- Joe DiMaggio turned apparent defeat into a victory for the Yankees over the Red Sox at Fenway Park today, and in this hotbed of Red Sox rooters the crowd of 29,563 vociferously accorded the Jolter his due.

It's an old American custom to take your girl to the park in the good old summer time to listen to the band play. The hand-holding is mighty pleasant under the trees in the cool of the evening while the trumpets and the trombones tackle Wagner with restraint and do their best to make a brass band sound romantic.
The retirement, effective today, of Frederick W. Anderson, a veteran of forty-three years with the American-Hawaiian Line, was announced yesterday by the company.

The local drought has retarded the 1949 crop of Japanese beetles, the United States Department of Agriculture reported yesterday as it began its annual inspection program to control the pest in this area.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Senate decided today to bring the labor bill fight to a showdown tomorrow, as organized labor virtually abandoned its efforts to repeal or revise the Taft-Hartley Act this year.

MILAN, Italy, June 29 (Reuters) -- The second congress of the World Federation of Trade Unions opened hero today with a violent attack on United States and British trade unionists for allegedly having allied themselves with "monopoly capitalists who would prefer another war to the approaching economic crisis."

ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP) -- John A. Isaacs Jr., president of the St. Louis Stock Exchange, declared today that a merger of the exchange with others into one central exchange, which would be in Chicago, will be "the only practicable means of providing a strong market for midwest companies."

New York retailers of men's wear have given up any idea of maintaining the price of Palm Beach suits until July 11 despite possibility of penalties under the Feld-Crawford fair trade law. One Fifth Avenue store advertised the new $19.75 price, presumably for immediate sale, and other stores have indicated that they will run similar advertisements this week.

ROME, June 29 -- The Italian Social Movement [MSI] which has been accused of Fascist leanings, opened its second national congress here today. Its secretary, Giorgio Almirante, announced its political program, which included the creation of an Italian corporative state.

There were no "yes, buts" yesterday in the Wall Street securities houses. Stocks and bonds were up. Government bond prices were soaring. Municipal bond prices were buoyant. Even the touch-and-go atmosphere in underwriting houses gave way to something seemingly as rare in the financial district as the proverbial day in June.

Printed patterns with small neat patterns on dark grounds have proved so popular for home furnishings that several new versions are included in the budget-priced fall line brought out yesterday by the Waverly Fabrics Division of F. Schumacher, 60 West Fortieth Street.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 688,000 barrels to 115,715,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil supplies, however, increased 1,604,000 barrels to 63,049,000 and heavy fuel oil stocks were up 552,000 to 66,146,000 barrels.

NANKING, June 29 -- The wheezing, charcoal burning bus that was a landmark in Chungking while Nationalist China was under blockade during the Japanese war now promises to become a new feature in the traffic of Communist Nanking.

LONDON, June 29 -- Despite European payments problems, the threat of the railway unions to slow operations, and the hold-up at the docks, early dullness in the stock market here today was followed by a sharp rally in British Government bonds and industrials as professional bears bought to cover short positions.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat, of Colorado, suggested today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation put a representative on the board of directors of an airline that borrowed money from it.

Unless American military aid is given to the Republic of Korea the better armed Communist forces in North Korea will overrun the republic and eventually take over the entire country. This prediction was made yesterday by Mrs. Geraldine Fitch, a journalist and wife of George Fitch, adviser to the National Council of Y. M. C. A.'s in Korea.

The prosecution in the "lonely hearts" trial introduced yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court the keystone of its case against Raymond M. Fernandez and Martha J. Beck. This was 131 pages of typescript allegedly containing confessions by the pair to the murder of Mrs. Janet J. Fay in Valley Stream, L. I., last January.

LONDON, June 29 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder, the lion-hearted scrapper from La Crescenta, Calif., stormed from behind to beat South African Eric Sturgess today and gain the final of the Wimbledon singles tennis championship.

With the outlook for high earnings on Cuban sugar exports regarded as "very good" for the next twelve months, American exporters will find it possible to increase sales in the island republic, members of the Export Advertising Association were told yesterday at the Shelton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) -- Responsible merchants and lenders from coast to coast said today they will not return to "dollar-down, dollar-a-week" credit terms when government controls on installment buying expire tomorrow at midnight.
PARIS, June 29 -- The International Refugee Organization announced today that it contemplated using pressure on refugees believed to be slacking in efforts to re-establish themselves.

TRENTON, N. J., June 29 -- James B. Sautter, deputy state treasurer, disclaimed today responsibility for recommending all brokers from whom the trustees of the $50,000,000 State Disability Fund bought bonds for investment.

SHANGHAI, June 29 (UP) -- The apparently indiscriminate Nationalist raid was carried out by three four-engined B-24 Liberators shortly after midday. They dropped twenty bombs on the northern and western slum districts where thousands of Chinese live jammed together in rows of mud huts and rickety tenements.

Gilbert Green, Illinois chairman of the Communist party, who last week talked himself into jail for contempt of court at the Communist trial yesterday talked himself into a vital admission on the use of force and violence.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 29 (AP) -- The New York State Council of Churches went on record today in favor of confining Federal aid to education to "schools operated as public enterprises by state or local governments."
The Federal Housing Expediter could not have selected a more inappropriate time to issue his latest instructions easing rent controls, such as they are.

SHANGHAI, June 29 -- For the first time the Nationalists today sent heavy bombers over Shanghai. In the heaviest raid thus far bombs left scores of casualties in one of the city's poorest districts and missed the United States Consulate's bachelors quarters by 200 yards.
New Yorkers will be stuffing their ears with cotton this afternoon as 800,000 city youngsters unceremoniously salute the end of the school year and the start of the summer vacation.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 29 -- Employes of the Bendix Aviation Corporation plant ended their ten-week-old strike today by a vote of more than 25 to 1.

The Republic of Korea has purchased the five-story residence at 9 East Eightieth Street from Joseph L. Ennis Co., through the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker, in an all cash transaction. David Y. Nankoong, consul general, and his staff will occupy the building for consulate purposes.

Five new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Astor, the attraction is "Lost Boundaries," the adaptation of the story by W. L. White produced by Louis de Rochemont, released by Film Classics and dealing with a Negro family that "passed" as white.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and final prices were 5 points off to 2 points up on new-crop months, while the old July contract was up 26 points.

Operations of the Firestone Tire Rubber Company and its subsidiaries in the six months ended on April 30, resulted in a profit of $10,149,907 before reserve of $2,000,000 to cover earnings of certain foreign subsidiaries which cannot now be remitted, Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman, reported yesterday.

Discontinuance of the manufacture of Cheney Cravats was announced yesterday by Ward Cheney, president of Cheney Bros. Henceforth, he said, the company will confine its activities to selling fabrics to the neckwear manufacturing trade.

LONDON, June 29 -- Promoter Jack Solomons decided tonight to stage the Bruce Woodcock-Lee Savold match for the British version of the world heavyweight boxing title in London's huge White City Stadium on Sept. 6.

HONOLULU, June 29 -- The Territorial Strike Strategy Committee of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, voted unanimously today to recommend rejection of a fourteen-cent hourly wage increase as a basis for setting Hawaii's fifty-nine-day longshoremen's strike.

Starting tomorrow, in cooperation with the New York City Youth Board, six Protestant churches -- four in the Bronx and two in Manhattan -- will make their recreational facilities available to all young people in their neighborhoods instead of to members only.

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 -- India will absorb tomorrow a Princely State that legally belongs to a Hindu god. In reorganizing this state India recognizes the Maharajah's primary allegiance to this deity rather than to the Dominion Government, a unique case in dealings with the Princes here.

Banque Nationale de la Republique d'Haiti, as fiscal agent, is notifying holders of Republic of Haiti internal loan, 5 per cent series A bonds and bond certificates due on July 15, 1957, that $253,120 of the bonds and certificates have been called for redemption.
BERLIN, June 29 -- Railroad traffic between Berlin and Western Germany will be resumed on Friday, Willi Kreikemeyer, head of the Soviet zone railroad administration, said tonight.

Coffee futures continued firm on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. New life-of-contract highs were established in several delivery months of both contracts. The S contract was moderately active and in demand by trade interests.

Ole Olsen and Chic Johnson, the inveterate zanies, open their large-scale production, "Funzapoppin," tonight at Madison Square Garden. The mad doings -- there are approximately thirty stooges, a dozen harmony singers, some ten variety turns and a chorus line of thirty-six girls -- are expected to get under way at 8:30 o'clock.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 29 (AP) -- An adjourned meeting of stockholders of Eversharp, Inc., held in Chicago last May 24, has been ruled valid by the Delaware Court of Chancery.

LONDON, June 29 -- Britain's growing strike situation took still another turn for the worse today when more than 5,000 dock workers walked out in protest against what they termed a "lockout" by the employers. Their dispute centered on two strikebound Canadian vessels, the Beaverbrae and the Argomont, which have been the crux of the dock troubles for many weeks.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Federal Court jury deliberating the fate of Judith Coplon failed to reach a verdict tonight. The jury asked to be taken to a hotel for the night at 11:40 P. M. after earlier indications that a verdict might be near.
Stockholders of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company approved yesterday a plan to simplify its capital structure.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A man about 30 years old drove up to the White House shortly before 6 P. M. today, paid the taxi driver and sat down just outside the big iron gate near the northwest entrance on Pennsylvania Avenue.

A few days ago you published a news dispatch about a Pakistan aircraft dropping bombs on Mughalgai in Afghan territory. A later news dispatch said that the Pakistan Government had denied that the bomb was dropped in Afghan territory.

A bench warrant was issued yesterday by Magistrate Hyman Bushel in Upper Manhattan Court for the arrest of Samuel Broxmeyer, a Bronx real estate operator. Mr. Broxmeyer failed to appear in court for the second day to answer a summons that charges him with withholding the union dues of employes of the Ansonia Hotel at Broadway and Seventy-third Street.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 29 -- Representative Leonard W. Hall was asked today by County Executive J. Russel Sprague to inquire into the proposed sale by the War Assets Administration of the twenty-five-acre site of the Lido Beach State Housing development now occupied by 286 veterans and their families.
CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP) -- The Indians rallied in the ninth inning tonight and scored six runs to defeat the Tigers, 8 to 7, in the second game of a twi-night double-header.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Floggings and threatened burning and hanging of men and women by robed, masked and armed night riders in Alabama were described in stark detail today to a

Public acceptance of frozen concentrated orange juice as a hot weather beverage as well as a household staple has pushed June sales to an all-time record for the industry, it was reported here yesterday. Executives of leading producers estimated that sales are in excess of 70 per cent above those of June, 1948.

FIRE ISLAND, L. I., June 29 -- Prolonged drought has caused a series of freakish fires on high-voltage power poles on this sandbar in the ocean, and at shore points in the metropolitan area generally. The fires have kept Long Island Lighting Company linemen on the jump.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 29 -- New England public utilities regulators, holding their first annual meeting here, prepared today to ask Congress to lift Federal taxes which they said are a burden on the Western Union Telegraph Company and on telephone companies.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 (AP) -- A four-run fourth inning attack at the expense of Warren Hacker helped the Cardinals to a 7-4 triumph over the last-place Chicago Cubs tonight. Al Brazle, in trouble frequently, gave up 12 hits, but lasted the nine innings for his seventh victory of the year.
Under the vast blue sky of the Hayden Planetarium last night at midnight a hundred watchers stirred uneasily. They waited for the end of the earth. It came at 12:01 A. M.
Rutger Fabrics Corp, floor in 507-11 W 33d St; Bell Television, Inc, floor in 552-4 W 53d St -Voorhis, Loeb Ranges, Inc, brokers.

The State of South Dakota yesterday sold an issue of $10,000,000 of veterans' bonus bonds maturing on each July 15, from 1950 to 1953 to a banking group headed by Chase National Bank at a bid of 100.001 for 1 1/2s and 1.10s, an interest cost of 1.1399 per cent.

Five concerts of the Berkshire Festival at Lenox, Mass., will be carried by NBC radio from 4:35 to 5:30 P. M. on successive Sunday afternoons, starting July 17. Dr. Serge Koussevitsky, director of the festival, will conduct three of the concerts with the Boston Symphony Orchestra while Leonard Bernstein and Eleazar de Carvalho will direct one each.

PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation today suggested to the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, that contract bargaining sessions be resumed in Pittsburgh Wednesday, July 6.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 29 -- A bill to restrict the sale of home permanent wave kits died early today in the State House of Representatives.

PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation today suggested to the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, that contract bargaining sessions be resumed in Pittsburgh Wednesday, July 6.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 29 -- A bill to restrict the sale of home permanent wave kits died early today in the State House of Representatives.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Ratification of the International Wheat Agreement, necessary by July 1 to put that multilateral treaty into effect, apparently was assured today.

Results of the first three days of the Clean Harbor Week drive to rid New York harbor of driftwood and oil and acid pollution were reviewed on a tour yesterday by city and harbor authorities. The report was unanimously favorable.

J. Holmes Smith, a former member of the One World Award Committee, issued yesterday a public apology to the committee and three of its officers whom he had accused early in May of maladministration. Mrs. Smith, whose charges included failure to account properly for funds received, declared yesterday that he had "jumped to conclusions" and had accepted reports from former members who had "unreliable memories."

Five hundred acres of land in Oyster Bay and Huntington, L. I., have been sold by the Realty Associates Securities Corporation to Broad Hollow Estates for development, it was announced yesterday by Joseph J. Fischer, broker in conjunction with David Shaw in the deal.

SEOUL, Korea, June 29 -- The United Nations Korean Commission tonight appealed to the people of Communist-controlled North Korea to help the United Nations body penetrate the Soviet-supported Iron Curtain across the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

Sir Oliver Franks, British Ambassador to the United States, left from La Guardia Airport yesterday on an American Overseas Airlines plane for London. Although the diplomat said that there was nothing unusual about his departure, he declared that he was eager to return home while discussions that he had had with State Department and Economic Cooperation Administration officials still were fresh in his mind.

IF a fiction writer had submitted the story, no self-respecting editor would have accepted a tale so manifestly implausible and preposterous. The plot was just too silly for belief. The injured hero hadn't played a game since the previous October when he limped to the plate at Fenway Park and blasted out two doubles and two singles.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- Big Ralph Branca tonight chalked up his tenth triumph without delivering even one home-run ball as the Dodgers outscored the Phils, 5 -- 1, before Shibe Park's largest crowd of the season, 36,814.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 29 -- Urging Senate ratification of the United Nations genocide convention, Dr. Raphael Lemkin, one of its drafters, said today that the document was "overdue by 2,000 years."

Most passenger carriers expect the Independence Day week-end travel this year to be equal to or better than last year's, on the basis of yesterday's bookings. This would mean that the number of New Yorkers leaving the city for the seashore, countryside or mountains, and the number of visitors coming to the city, would be just under the record of 1947.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that he had discussed the Youthbuilder program and "certain publications" with the Rev. Dr. Leland B. Henry, executive director of the Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, but that other items in the latter's scathing report on public school policies were never touched upon.

How to have fun on the sidewalks of New York without breaking teeth, nose or head was demonstrated yesterday by thirty urchins drafted outside a Police Athletic League playground at 421 West Forty-seventh Street. Their audience was 100 men and women at a PAL seminar on directing play streets for 100,000 children forced to spend summer in the city.
Residents of New Jersey can get telephones installed a few days after making request but for many New Yorkers the waiting period remains a full year.

An economic and sociological shift, on a scale and at a tempo such as this country has seldom seen since the closing of its western frontier, is now taking place on Long Island under the very nose of New York City. Most New Yorkers are aware of it only dimly. All of them have heard of the vast housing activity and the burgeoning industrial economy, and some have seen parts of it.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Prices skidded $1.50 a hundred pounds on spring lambs today and $2 to $3 on old-crop lambs and yearlings. Market analysts said the plunge had been building up throughout this week In the latter part of May, spring lambs were selling at $34 a hundredweight and old-crop offerings at $30. Today the practical top on springers was $26.50 and on old-crop kinds, $21, with clearance incomplete.

Long Island fishing ports are expecting a record influx of anglers over the week-end. The demand for boats is so great that many of the more popular open party boats are reserved for the entire three days, and even rowboats are going to be scarce in many areas.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 29 (AP) -- The first running of the $10,000 added Regret Handicap was won by Wheatley Stable's Irish Witch in a photo finish at Monmouth Park today. Brookfield Farm's Isa was second and Allie's Pal, owned by S. D. Sidell, third.

Objections to a proposed zoning amendment giving the City Planning Commission virtually complete control over construction of public parking garages in business, retail and residential districts were registered yesterday by fourteen business and civic organizations at a hearing before the planning agency at City Hall.

Amended Economic Cooperation Administration regulations allowing American exporters to withhold confidential business information from foreign purchasers or Governments will be promulgated in Washington tomorrow, it was learned here yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 29 -- If there is some "hysteria and witch-hunting" in this country, we still have not approached the peaks of uneasiness displayed behind "the Iron Curtain," George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs said here today.

The James I. Russell Memorial Building of Roosevelt Hospital, named for the late "Doctor Jim" Russell who was a surgeon there for forty years, was opened yesterday with a ceremony in the courtyard of the hospital at 428 West Fifty-ninth Street.

"THE VIOLENT MEN"* created the United States of America whose birthday we celebrate next Monday. It is an ancient gambit to point out that some proud descendants would be singularly uneasy in their company if they suddenly happened to come to life again. Yet it gains fresh point as you read Cornelia Meigs' lucid and immensely interesting account of their troubled and magnificently triumphant deliberations in the Continental Congress between 1774 and 1776.

The executive committee of the Board of Higher Education took no action yesterday on the dropping from the City College faculty of Dr. Morris Swadesh, associate professor of sociology and anthropology, and Dr. Lee Lorch, instructor in mathematics.

The De Soto Carry-All, four-door sedan that can be transformed into a utility car, was displayed yesterday at the Chrysler International Auto Salon, 405 Lexington Avenue. The f.o.b. Detroit price is given as $2,075 and the delivered price here will be announced when quantity delivery of the vehicles begins about mid-July.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, home from a trip to Israel, said last night that the faith of Israelis in their future was based in no small measure on the encouragement and support that has been given them by the American Jewish community.

On May 3 the House of Representatives voted a new labor-management relations bill which reflected the basic philosophy of the Taft-Hartley Act but which would have modified that law so as to take account of any reasonable criticism that has been raised against it and to remove such flaws as it has revealed in two years of actual operation.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 30 -- The eleventh annual race week series of the Noroton Yacht Club was won by a Larchmont man today when the sixth and final race was declared void.

Your editorial of June 5, "A Unified Transport Policy," contains one statement to which I should like to take exception. After indicating that "the railroads are heavily taxed" you say, "There is every reason to doubt that the trucking and long-line bus industries are paying their fair share of the cost of maintaining the right-of-way which they so freely enjoy."

A national leader of the Communist party admitted at the Communist trial yesterday that the party teaches its members how to use the third party movement, in which it supported Henry A. Wallace for President last year, to help it eventually to seize power.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The present upward swing of gasoline prices "will not continue indefinitely," A. L. Nickerson, director and executive in charge of domestic marketing of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., New York, said today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30 (AP) -- The Ohio House of Representatives today adopted a resolution which in effect asked the Ohio American Legion Auxiliary to send Joan Rankin to the Girls' Nation Assembly in Washington and asked President Truman and Congress for action to end racial discrimination there.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 30 -- Mrs. Alfred Roberts' Eatontown won the featured Barnegat Purse easily at Monmouth Park today.
Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle promoted three captains to the rank of battalion chief and ten lieutenants to captain yesterday at headquarters in the Municipal Building.

LONDON, June 30 -- Philip J. Noel-Baker, Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations, upheld Pakistan in the House of Commons today in her dispute with Afghanistan over the status of territories in the North-West Frontier area.

Despite only a slight improvement thus far in the dollar collection situation in Brazil, that country "may be expected to offer a continuing good market for many lines of American merchandise," it was declared last night by George Wythe, chief, American Republics Branch, Department of Commerce.

The annual report of the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, issued yesterday for the fiscal year ended on April 30, showed a net income of $3,785,163, after all charges, including $207,700 deduction for extraordinary reserves.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- American business, exclusive of agriculture, plans to spend $4,600,000,000 on new plants and equipment in the third quarter of this year, approximately 4 per cent less than the $4,820,000,000 of the second quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commerce Department announced today.

NEW DELHI, India, June 30 -- Dr. Alfredo Lozano of Colombia, senior member of the United Nations Commission on India and Pakistan that is negotiating the dispute over the state of Jammu and Kashmir, left for New York today after his resignation from the commission.

It is well known that Mr. Jefferson distrusted cities and the spirit they engendered. For him, sitting on his hilltop, with his acres spread around, and a view of the landscape that reached to the mountains, the salvation of our Republic depended on the maintenance of agricultural pursuits and the habits of independence that came of living on the land.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Strong pressures for elimination of war-time excise tax rates on so-called luxury goods and services erupted today in separate House and Senate actions aimed at forcing the issue.
Present service rivalries are bedded deep in ancient traditions and in differing concepts of strategy.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, New York, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering to the public of $150,000,000 of twenty-five-year 2 3/4 per cent debentures due on July 15, 1974.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Former President Herbert Hoover placed the stamp of his approval today on the seven reorganization plans that President Truman has sent to Congress and, praising the Chief Executive's cooperativeness, refused to be drawn into any criticism of him.
A glance at greengrocers' stalls during excursions to market today will show that the much-publicized drought has had small effect on supplies of fresh fruits and vegetables.

ROME, June 30 -- Woodward Willoughby, head of the United States delegation at the international customs tariffs meeting at Annecy, France, arrived here by plane today in the hope of reaching an agreement that would make it possible for Italy to reduce her projected schedule of duties, which is considered too high.

TOYKO, June 30 -- The Japanese Cabinet, at a special meeting today, finally approved the expenditure of 5,100,000,000 yen [about $14,000,000] for severance pay to 200,000 Government employes who will be dismissed under the occupation austerity program.

"Chicken Every Sunday," the Rosemary Taylor novel from which Julius J. and Philip G. Epstein fashioned the Broadway play of the same name, is to form the basis of a new comedy series which NBC plans to start at 8 P. M. next Wednesday.

House passage of the National Housing Bill will go into the record as one of the most important achievements of the present Congress and one of the most gratifying. The result, won by a margin of 43 in a vote of 228 to 185, is that nearly a million dwelling units can be built in the next half dozen years that would probably not otherwise have been built.

TRENTON, N. J., June 30 -- New trials for six Trenton Negroes who have been under sentence of death since last August for the murder of an aged second-hand furniture dealer during a hold-up were granted today by the New Jersey Supreme Court.

Adoption of the housing bill by the House of Representatives was regarded yesterday in Wall Street as a long-overdue green light assuring the flow into the investment world over the next several years of about $1,000,000,000 annually of a new type of gilt-edge investment medium -- a tax-free obligation of local government backed unconditionally by the Federal Government.
CAIRO, June 23 -- Egypt is bombing the famous Egyptian fly with DDT. Planes of the Farouk I squadron are carrying out the first operation in Alexandria.

Only a small portion of New York City's thirty-eight miles of bathing beaches is polluted, the Health Department reported yesterday on the basis of 1,900 water samples analyzed in its laboratories since April.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- In the week ended on June 29, member bank reserve balances decreased $301,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Emphasizing Israel's need for an adequate merchant marine, Dr. Matthew Hindes, president of the Haifa Council of the Israel Maritime League, declared yesterday in an interview here that the infant nation would direct a large part of its navigation and foreign trade toward the United States if reciprocal agreements could be set up.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Roxy, the attraction is "House of Strangers," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama, starring Edward G. Robinson, Susan Hayward and Richard Conte. Joseph L. Mankiewicz directed the offering from a screen play by Philip Yordan and the novel by Jerome Weidman.

John Foster Dulles testified at the Alger Hiss perjury trial yesterday that on Aug. 18, 1948, he had suggested that Mr. Hiss voluntarily resign as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace to relieve that agency of embarrassment resulting from charges that Mr. Hiss had Communist affiliations.

THE football folks have been infinitely more advanced than their baseball counterparts in the use of motion pictures. For the better part of a quarter of a century gridiron coaches have tirelessly studied action shots of games, in season and out of season, as they watched for flaws and imperfections in the play of their own heroes as well as defensive lapses by the enemy which might be exploited.

ATHENS, June 30 -- At noon today King Paul handed the mandate to form a government to succeed that of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis, who died last Friday, to Alexander Diomedes, former Liberal Deputy Premier.
The state law liberalizing the issuance of junior automobile operators' licenses goes into effect today and opens the way for thousands of 'teen-agers to obtain highway parity with adult motorists.
High up on the thirteenth floor of the United States Courthouse on Foley Square a bailiff entered the Alger Hiss perjury trial at 3:47 yesterday afternoon and whispered the words. "Coplon guilty."

Since Olsen and Johnson are amiable mountebanks, it would be pleasant to be genuinely enthusiastic about the jamboree that they brought to Madison Square Garden last evening. Working on their familiar principle that ten mediocre gags are equivalent to one that is good, they have stuffed "Funzapoppin" full of noise, insanity, shooting and boisterousness, not forgetting the hearty hospitality that has made them thousands of loyal friends.

Twentieth Century-Fox will produce twenty-four to twenty-six feature films in 1950, Darryl F. Zanuck, company production chief, revealed yesterday at a press conference at the Twenty One Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street. The average cost per picture now stands at $1,709,000, he said, adding that "I don't see how we can make them for less and still maintain quality."
CLEVELAND, June 30 (AP) -- The Tigers moved up into third place in the American League today with a splurge of seventeen hits that routed the Indians, 12 -- 6.

Fighting to bar from evidence three alleged confessions, the defense in the "lonely hearts" trial won the right yesterday to examine five other statements made by Raymond M. Fernandez and Martha J. Beck, accused slayers, to Michigan authorities following their arrest there last March.

PARIS, June 30 -- Police reserves were guarding Government Ministries and most of central Paris today as the National Assembly passed the bill that provides for the reorganization of some nationalized aviation plants and the closing of others.

I am a non-smoker myself, but I am moved to write, in pity and alarm, on behalf of a friend who has not attained that lofty state. Your news item in THE TIMES of June 28, recounting the experiments of a Bennington College psychologist into the methods by which smokers snuff their cigarettes, has my friend in a pretty state of confusion.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Woodrow Wilson used to refer to Bernard M. Baruch as "Dr. Facts" because he would never give an opinion or pronounce a judgment on incomplete or unchecked information. Not until he had the essential details and was satisfied of their accuracy would Mr. Baruch take a position, and both before and since President Wilson called him "Dr. Facts" he has steadfastly adhered to this procedure.

A total of 8,801 passengers will arrive or depart today on sixteen vessels in what promises to be one of the season's busiest days for customs and immigration personnel and employes of steamship lines.
OSLO, Norway, June 30 -- Norway is prepared to resume a study of the possibilities of limited Scandinavian defense with Sweden, Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange said today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- There were cheers from proponents of public housing today and cries of disappointment from the opposition, but for members of the House, who voted virtual final approval of the program last night, there was only embarrassment.

BURBANK, Calif., June 30 -- A new two-place jet fighter plane designed to fight "on instruments" at high altitudes was announced today by the United States Air Force and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
A boatload of happy children will be aboard the Lloyd I. Seaman when the St. John's Guild Floating Hospital begins its eighty-third season today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A Federal jury convicted Judith Coplon today as a spy for Russia, finding her guilty on both counts of an espionage charge that could send her to prison for thirteen years.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of New York, called yesterday for an investigation of charges that have been made against the city public school system's policies and practices.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Wheat futures weakened in the late trading on the Board of Trade here today after showing early strength, and final trades were about at the bottom, with net losses of 3/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel. Corn was strong the greater part of the day, but failed to maintain the best prices and finished 5/8 cent higher to 1/4 cent lower, the former on the July position.

The decision of the Borden Company, Sheffield Farms and the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association to raise milk prices a half-cent a quart today was attacked yesterday by John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, as "just another example of the indifference of the 'Big Three' to the health and welfare of our people."

The Long Island Rail Road began its hearing yesterday before the Public Service Commission on its petition for an increase of 16 2/3 per cent in one-way, non-commuter passenger fares, and presented evidence to show that for the first four months of 1949 the road had incurred a net income loss at the rate of $4,176,404 a year.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development moved today to implement President Truman's Point Four program for the improvement of underdeveloped areas by sending a nine-member mission to Colombia to investigate "ways to increase the wealth of that country."

As the economy of Western Europe has been attaining greater stabilization because of the Marshall Plan, the danger of communism in that part of the world has receded in the last few months, a five-member delegation of the Jewish Labor Committee, which just returned from a two-month survey of the economic, political and social conditions in France, Belgium, Italy, Sweden, Germany and Israel, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Federal Security Agency, now slated to assume Cabinet rank by Presidential proclamation under the Reorganization Act, marks its tenth anniversary tomorrow.
Increases of 6 to 18 per cent in commutation rates for 30,000 Westchester residents who ride on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad were authorized yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

LONDON, June 30 -- Once bear covering had been completed in the stock market here today caution became the watchword, pending the outcome of the Paris monetary talks and further developments in British labor disputes.

A spirited clash between Mayor O'Dwyer and Borough President James A. Burke of Queens over a resolution calling for approval "in principle" of a combined slum clearance and public parking field project in Flushing highlighted yesterday an otherwise routine meeting of the Board of Estimate.
PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP) -- The Pirates got only four hits off Howie Fox today, but they bunched three of them in the sixth inning to beat Cincinnati, 2 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The controversial basing-point price bill was released today by the House Rules Committee for debate on the floor.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate, by a vote of 51 to 42, today wrecked the Administration's six months of effort to repeal the Taft-Hartley Labor Act.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 30 (AP) -- Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., had to come up with all the pressure golf she had today to stay in the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament. The defending champion won her way into tomorrow's quarter-finals by beating a fellow Texan, Mrs. H. C. Riedel of Dallas, 1 up, over the 6,330-yard Lincoln Country Club course.

A. B. Guthrie, author of "The Big Sky," will have a new historical novel of the West published by William Sloane Associates in October. Unlike "The Big Sky," which dealt with mountain men, the loneliest men in the world, "The Way West" deals with a substantial crowd, the members of a covered wagon train on the Oregon Trail.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The reproduction rate of college-educated women in this country has made "remarkable progress" since 1940, with an 81 per cent increase between 1940 and 1947, the Population Reference Bureau, a non-profit organization, reported today.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 30 -- Gov. Chester Bowles late this afternoon invoked a power granted him by the state constitution and adjourned the squabbling General Assembly. The House of Representatives, however, controlled by the Republicans, made plans to ignore the Governor's proclamation and to reconvene on Wednesday.

BERLIN, June 30 -- Normal railroad traffic between Berlin and the Western zones will not reopen until Sunday, although elevated railroad traffic within the Western sectors of Berlin will begin early tomorrow morning, a spokesman for the Soviet-controlled railroad administration announced tonight.

Donald McNeill, former national champion, and Irving Dorfman, recently of Yale, were the first two players to reach the semi-finals of the New York State clay court tennis tournament yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.
