PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- The Dodgers ran afoul of a road block today just when they were most confident of sweeping the three-game series with the Phillies and went down to a 4-2 defeat before a ladies' day crowd of 14,730. However, they retained their one-game National League lead when the Cardinals also lost.

OSSIPEE, N. H., June 30 (AP) -- Ralph Jennings, 49-year-old wood-chopper, was convicted tonight of murder in the first degree in the sex slaying of Ruth Eisenberg, 22, former Newark, N. J., children's nurse, who disappeared last July. The jury recommended capital punishment.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Dissolution of the du Pont industrial empire, whose total assets of $1,585,000,000, including a $560,000,000 investment in the General Motors Corporation, has gained it the reputation as America's largest industrial combination, was sought today in an anti-trust suit filed in Federal District Court by Attorney General Tom C. Clark.

LAKE SUCCESS, June 30 -- Several religious leaders representing various Christian communities in Palestine and Jordan have written to Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations urging continuation of pecial aid to Arab refugees through the next winter.

Lauritz Melchior, the Metropolitan tenor, was the soloist at the concert by the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Mr. Reiner, who made his last appearance of the season, conducted all of the program with the exception of the final group of miscellaneous songs by Mr. Melchior, which was directed by Ezra Rachlin.
Four thousand students enrolled for Columbia University's fiftieth annual six-weeks' summer session yesterday, the first day of a three-day registration period.

The late Justice Holmes is said to have inquired, when he first saw the marble front of the new Supreme Court building: "And will we ride in on elephants ?" Our highest Bench is at least massively housed. Whatever the nature of its decisions or of the pleas to which it has to listen, the ceiling will not fall in on it. But if the Judiciary is architecturally secure, the two collateral branches are not.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- Police kept a close watch over five public swimming pools today to prevent new outbreaks of fighting between whites and Negroes over non-segregation.

LONDON, June 30 -- Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett will preside tomorrow over the opening session of talks in Tel Aviv at which Britain and Israel will present claims and counter-claims. The discussions will deal with important economic and financial matters arising from the British withdrawal from Palestine, where they held a mandate for more than twenty years.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 30 (AP) -- Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., denied the Government accusations today. He issued the following statement:
Stainless steel, relegated to the kitchen for many years, has now come into the dining room.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 30 -- The appointment of Miss Ruth K. Porritt as librarian of Radcliffe College was announced tonight by W. K. Jordan, president of the college. She is now head of the Reference Department, Baker Library, Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

Overriding pleas by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, and Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, administrator of the New York University - Bellevue Medical Center, the Board of Estimate yesterday tabled a proposal that the city scrap its plan to rehabilitate the Bellevue Hospital power plant and, instead, purchase steam for the hospital from the New York Steam Company.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Washington exploded for four runs with two out in the eighth inning to defeat Philadelphia, 8 -- 6, tonight. The loss dropped the second-place Athletics 5 1/2 games back of the Yankees.

Confident that there is a solution to the difficult problems of Germany but stressing that progress can only be made in years, not months, John J. McCloy, civilian successor to Gen. Lucius D. Clay as military governor of the American sector of Germany, left New York for his post in Frankfort yesterday.

Selection of candidates of both major parties for United States Senator and designation of party candidates for Mayor and other city offices here have been postponed until after the Fourth of July, it was learned yesterday.

TULARE, Calif., June 30 (AP) -- A home town boy who went away and made good came home and did it again last night. He was Bob Mathias, the pride of this San Joaquin Valley town of 12,000, who successfully defended his A. A. U. decathlon crown in the two-day annual meet against the country's best all-around athletes.

An annual free luncheon arranged for Harlem Junior High School children at 2 P. M. on the municipal playground at 140th Street and Lenox Avenue struck a snag yesterday when use of the park was denied by Manhattan Parks Director George L. Quigley.

LONDON, June 30 -- Henry Ford, II, thirty-one year old president of Ford Motor Company, declared here today that the United States market for British motor cars had dropped sharply in the past few months. Mr. Ford said conditions in the United States as far as the automobile business was concerned had changed radically with new cars becoming more readily available and with used car prices down considerably.

Class B banks will be required to provide more than $400,000,000 next week under the terms of a call issued yesterday by the United States Treasury. The call, for 30 per cent of the Treasury's war loan accounts as of the close of business on June 29, is payable in two equal instalments, on July 5 and 7.

Michael Rabin, 12-year-old violinist of this city, has won the Edgar Stillman Kelley Junior Scholarship of the National Federation of Music Clubs, it was made known yesterday. The announcement was accompanied by word of other music-club activities.
AMES, Ia , June 30 (AP) -- The college boys fought blistering golf duels today under a hot sun to trim the field to eight in the battle for the national collegiate championship.

A party of tourists sight-seeing here yesterday included the sheriff of Chatham County, Ga. four young Negro boys and a Negro policeman from Savannah. The trip was a reward for the boys for setting an example of good citizenship for children in that city.

John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, promised the Committee of Theatrical Producers yesterday afternoon that he would aid it in seeking legislation to license theatre box-office employes for the elimination of one of the major evils of ticket scalping.

The majority of New York industrial concerns expect business in the second half of this year to be below that for the corresponding period of 1948 and most are making aggressive plans to combat the decline. This is revealed in a survey of 387 companies by the Commerce Industry Association of New York, Inc., released today.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- The pathway to four-power agreement on the German problem lies through mutual concessions, both by the Western powers and the Soviet Union, according to Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

Brock Pemberton has found himself wrapped up -- pleasantly and profitably -- in "Harvey" (his greatest success) ever since he first took possession of Mary Coyle Chase's Pulitzer Prize comedy in 1943. It's true he took time off in 1946 to experiment with "The Magnificent Heel," the Constance O'Hara play in which Peggy Wood and Bert Lytell appeared on the road; but that doesn't count because it never reached Broadway.

A hot, sticky week-end was forecast yesterday by the Weather Bureau as the driest June in the bureau's seventy-eight-year history was added to the meteorological record book. There was no sign either of a general rain to mar the long Independence Day holiday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- Janet Leigh has been borrowed by RKO from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading feminine roles in two films, "Christmas Gift," with Robert Mitchum and Wendell Corey, and "Jet Pilot," with John Wayne, the studio announced today.

NORTHPORT, L. I., June 30 -- Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University and one of Northport's most distinguished -- and elusive -- summer residents, will observe tomorrow his thirtieth year as a college president.

ANNECY, France, June 30 -- The problem of what to do to prevent a tariff war and orgy of trade discrimination in the next few years if the International Trade Organization does not come into effective being, is receiving serious examination by the United States and other major trading countries.
ASPEN, Col., June 30 -- The International Goethe Bicentennial Convocation and Music Festival, in keeping with the pattern set by its sponsors, today left Goethe entirely off the program.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 -- Jordan plans to carry on independent negotiations with Israel even if the United Nations efforts to negotiate a peace in Lausanne break down completely, an extremely well-informed Arab source alleged today.

LONDON, June 30 -- Refusal of the Soviet Union to consider Western allegations of violations of the Balkan peace treaties is likely to be interpreted as an attempt by Russia to frustrate one of the provisions of the treaties, according to the Foreign Office note sent today to Soviet Ambassador Georgi N. Zarubin.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UP) -- The liner General W. A. Holbrook will bring 1,085 more European refugees to the United States when it docks in New York Saturday, the International Refugee Organization announced today.

Bernard M. Baruch, an adviser to the American Government on industrial mobilization in two World Wars, took direct issue last night with President Truman on the status of plans for the swift mobilization of United States resources to meet any new emergency.

The coastal angler, weather permitting, should find this long holiday week-end one of the best of the season, for he is almost certain of reasonably good sport in both the in-shore and off-shore waters.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- On the eve of the beginning of a new fiscal year of Government operations, Congress found itself confronted tonight with a record sum of nearly $26,000,000,000 of proposed appropriations still not approved. This total was in addition to several billions of dollars of contracting authorizations.

A syndicate headed by William A. Levin, an executive of Galen Mills, has purchased the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 391-93 West End Avenue, southwest corner of Seventy-ninth Street, from the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company of New York, trustee for certificate holders, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Roger D. Lapham, former Mayor of San Francisco, resigned today as chief of the China program of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

A police raid on a midtown West Side loft building resulted in the seizure of 79,000 books of Irish Sweepstakes tickets, estimated to be worth $1,500,000, and the arraignment in Felony Court yesterday of three men on charges of conspiracy and contriving a lottery.

The shoe industry, from the standpoint of production, has fared very well in the first six months of 1949, it was pointed out yesterday by the Tanners' Council of America in a bulletin to members. Output, estimated by the council at 224,287,000 pairs, is only 5 per cent below the exceptionally high level of the corresponding 1948 period, and 2.4 per cent under the first six months of 1947.

WESTBURY L. I., June 30 -- For the third time in four years, Mr. and Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley captured the Jane Brooks Robbins Memorial Trophy in the husband-and-wife championship event of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Eddie Waitkus' most fanatical admirer was sent away for mental treatment today almost as quickly as she shot the first baseman with a .22-calibre rifle in a hotel room fifteen days ago.

On orders from Mayor O'Dwyer, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard and fifty of his employes began a survey last night of the 40-year-old condemned apartment building at 545 West 111th Street to determine whether any of the 1,000 tenants needed the city's aid.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee today recommended Senate confirmation of Harry M. Durning, of New York, as Collector of Customs for District 10, with headquarters in New York.

The three-game winning streak of the Giants was snapped unceremoniously yesterday. Collecting a total of only eight hits, they dropped a double-header to the Braves before a gathering of 14,536 at the Polo Grounds.

A "boom" in higher education, similar to the one taking place in this country, is now under way in the British Isles, Dr. Lillian M. Penson, vice chancellor of the University of London, reported yesterday.

A few clever ideas on blouses and skirts, one designer and one fashion editor add up to a successful business venture. At least it did in the case of Clare Potter and Martha Stout, who in less than six months started themselves in the business world.
The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it had made a plea to United States military officials on behalf of a former Nazi leader.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee today recommended legislation intended to aid collection of an estimated $40,000,000 a year by states in sales and use taxes on cigarettes.

Frank PI. Boyer has been appointed manager of the New York office at 500 Fifth Avenue of the Hansen Glove Corporation of 1Wdl-i waukee. He was formerly vice president in charge of sales for Aris Gloves, Inc.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- Leonid Utesov, one of the Soviet Union's top jazz leaders, presented the premiere of the new summer show at Moscow's Hermitage Gardens last night. The show included an apache dance number, with a male dancer garbed as a red, white and blue Uncle Sam and a woman partner in the role of the "Marshallized" European countries.

BATAVIA, Java, June 30 -- With the Dutch withdrawal from Jogjakarta completed on schedule today the way was opened for the return next week to the Republican capital of President Sukarno and the Republican Government.

Corporate bonds on the New York State legal list increased $2,500,000,000 during the year ended on July 1, and now stand at a new high level of more than $16,800,000,000, Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 25 were 6 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:
Heavy borrowings by public utility companies and local governments swelled the total of new bond financing here in June to the largest monthly figure since March, 1948.

HONOLULU, June 30 -- Hawaii's stevedoring companies agreed today to accept an Emergency Board formula for ending the territory's $15,000,000 longshore strike, and the islands' half million residents kept their fingers crossed as the strikers began voting on the board's recommendations.
Growth and change are nothing new to Long Island, but the magnitude of the growth and the direction of the change taking place there today are unique in its experience.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30 -- Any trade union can be broken if the publishers "can break our union" in the Chicago strike, Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, told the American Newspaper Guild, CIO, at its convention here today.

BOSTON, June 30 -- Proceeding on the theory that a homer-a-day will keep Dr. George E. Bennett away. Joltin' Joe DiMaggio, the no-longer-ailing pro of the Yankees, provided the winning margin today, as Casey Stengel's men made it three in a row over the Red Sox.

The Appellate Division unanimously reversed the conviction and dismissed the indictment yesterday of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, two of its officers, and an employe, who were found guilty a year ago in General Sessions of giving false information to other banking institutions concerning the financial stability of a convicted swindler.

FITCHVILLE, Conn., June 30 -- One hundred tired but happy girls arrived here today for two months at Camp Odetah, known as the "singingest camp in the Connecticut hills." The newcomers sang to Camp Odetah as they drove up to the yellow bungalows that will be their bunks for the summer.

Your readers may be interested to know that, as the only national religious agency conducting a program for the benefit of those suffering from leprosy around the world, and as one of three national groups specializing in this field, the American Mission to Lepers will spend over a half-million dollars for direct aid to leprosy mission stations during the fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 802,941 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 153,590 cars, or 23.7 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 85,427 cars, or 9.6 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 43,200 cars, or 5.1 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

An appeal for aid for the world's destitute and starving children was voiced yesterday by youngsters from twenty countries during an Independence Day celebration jointly sponsored by the United Nations Children's Fund and the Police Athletic League of this city.

Initial plans for a coordinated system of training for reserve chaplains of the armed forces were reported at the closing session of a four-day conference attended by sixty chaplains yesterday morning at the Federal Office Building, 90 Church Street.

Andrew G. Clauson Jr., Richmond member of the Board of Education, last night told 225 graduating students of the Rhodes School that Paul Robeson's "rejection" of the "American way" should "make us resolve to strengthen our democracy where it is weak."
The stock market improved moderately yesterday, but the advance caused no increase in buying interest. Fractional increases predominated and the composite rate rose 0.44 point.

Mayor O'Dwyer disclosed yesterday that Governor Dewey recently referred to him, as well as to District Attorney Miles F. McDonald of Kings County several complaints of police brutality sent to Albany from the Stuyvesant-Bedford section of Brooklyn.

PARIS, Friday, July 1 -- The long and sharp controversy between Sir Stafford Cripps and United States officials over giving a more competitive pattern to European trade was settled at 2 o'clock this morning when a compromise was accepted by Sir Stafford, Ambassador W. Averell Harriman and the European Marshall Plan Council.

Price reduction of the Gibson Distilling Company's Selected-8 blended whiskey will be advertised with the heaviest campaign schedule in the maker's history, it was announced yesterday by Davin Bunim, president. New York newspapers will be used during July to emphasize the price cut, from $4.40 to $4.05 for a fifth, Mr. Bunim said. The cut is effective today.

HENLEY - ON - THAMES, England, June 30 (AP) -- Jack Kelly and Jack Trinsey, both of Philadelphia, gained the semi-finals in the Diamond Sculls at the Henley Royal Regatta today and two Princeton University crews continued unbeaten in eight-oared competition.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 30 -- John L. Lewis told most of the country's soft-coal diggers today to work three days a week, and no more, until further notice.
ALBANY, June 30 -- The State Youth Commission announced today that it had approved an initial allocation of $694,078.07 for the expanded program of the New York City Youth Board, effective July 1.

New York's one outstanding bus strike threat -- involving the operations of the Green Bus Lines in Queens -- was averted last evening by Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private bus industry.

SHANGHAI, June 30 -- Mao Tzetung today told his followers that Communist China could not expect "genuine" aid from the Governments of the United States and Britain even though Communist parties and "progressive parties and groups" in these countries pressed for opening of trade and diplomatic relations.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The forthcoming installation of civilian control in Western Germany was interpreted by the State Department today as evidence "of the desire of the Western powers to return to the German people a greater voice in their own destiny."

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UP) Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa, today concluded a month-long presentation of mismanagement charges against the Atomic Energy Commission and the commission promised to offer its rebuttal next Wednesday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 30 -- The typically American faith in the worth and dignity of man has "taken a bit of a beating" in recent years, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce said here today. She spoke at a luncheon in Convention Hall closing the four-day meeting of the American National Red Cross.

DETROIT, June 30 -- The Chrysler Corporation will not discuss pension or medical care plans with the United Automobile Workers, CIO, this year, Robert W. Conder, director of labor relations for the company, today informed the union.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP) -- Right-Fielder Hank Edwards caught fire today and led the Cubs to a 12-5 victory over the Cardinals. Edwards slammed two home runs, scored five times in five trips to the plate and drove in four tallies.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Ferdinand Eberstadt, an authority on military organization in the Government, told the Congress today that experts overwhelmingly fear the merger of the three military departments into a single department.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee formally approved today, with a good deal of silent Republican dissent, the Administration's bill for a $150,000,000 continuation and expansion of the recovery program for the Republic of Korea.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 30 -- Maj. Gen. George P. Hays, Deputy United States Military Governor, said today that on governmental-level orders from Washington he had been unable thus far to approve the bizonal equalization-of-burdens measure, long sought by the German authorities and already approved by the British.

The greatest repair and modernization program in the history of the city's school system will begin today with the formal opening of the 1949-50 school year. More than $16,000,000 will be spent on renovating old school buildings in all five boroughs during the year.

An expanded program directed toward the eventual rehabilitation of Manhattanville, one of the city's worst slum areas, will be started officially today by the Manhattanville Neighborhood Center when Clyde E. Murray, former head worker at the Union Settlement, becomes executive secretary of the center.

Britain's Labor Government, perhaps unwittingly, struck a stout blow for a free and private press when it forced its charges of monopoly and malpractice into an investigation by a Royal Commission. The Commission's findings, after two years of deliberation, constitute a fairly full denial of the charges that brought it into existence.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 -- The American University of Beirut will launch tomorrow a major effort to increase essential knowledge of the Arab world in the United States, aided by a grant of $83,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for an Institute of Arabic Studies.

Davega Stores Corporation will continue a 10 per cent down payment requirement on credit purchases, but will extend the maximum payment period to three years on refrigerators, washers and air conditioners, A. Davega, president, reported yesterday.

Grand Central Terminal presented a scene of utter confusion yesterday as New York's younger set left town -- the annual exodus for summer camps. During the day 11,119 little campers waved good-bye to their parents.

A retirement plan for employes with more than five years of service with the New York Curb Exchange or the Curb Exchange Securities Clearing Corporation, was announced yesterday by Francis Adams Truslow, Curb president. The plan becomes effective today.

LONDON, June 30 -- Britain's twin-headed strike situation appeared today to be heading for a grave crisis as the number of striking dock workers mounted sharply and as long hours of negotiation between the railway unions and the national management ended in an "absolute deadlock."

Reginald Styers, interior decorator who has returned from Honolulu and California inspired by decorating schemes there, opened a studio yesterday at 208 East Fifty-first Street. He has also designed upholstered furniture and simplified a few period pieces, reproductions of which will be available to his clients as well as to other decorators.

DURHAM, N. H., June 30 -- If school leaders convening here have their way, the long summer vacation that began this week for 25,000,000 children and 900,000 teachers throughout the country may soon be a thing of the past.

SEOUL, Korea, June 30 -- President Syngman Rhee in a statement issued today attributed the murder Sunday of Kim Koo, opposition rightist leader, to dissension within the latter's independence political party.

The Board of Transportation, which began to function July 1, 1924, made public yesterday a twenty-fifth anniversary summary of its activities, culminating in its present position as manager and operator of "the largest and safest transit system in the world."

Enrollments in Roman Catholic colleges and universities in the United States, Alaska and Hawaii have more than doubled since the academic year 1946-47, rising from 102,655 students to 240,048 for 1948-49, an increase of 137,393 or 134 per cent, the 127th annual Roman Catholic Directory reports.

Jerome Greene has sold to the Ulrim Realty Corporation for investment the six-story apartment house for forty-eight families at 135 West Sixteenth Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, in a transaction negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co. and Michael Rozental, brokers.

All Federal departments having to do with aviation will start to move to the new Federal Building at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, today. When the move is completed on Tuesday more than 500 employes will be established there.
The cotton futures market was steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 5 to 19 points net higher than on Wednesday.
DETROIT, June 30 (AP) -- Only five boats of a possible entry list of thirty have qualified for the forty-second annual holding Saturday of the Cold Cup race, one of America's oldest speedboat events.

LONDON, June 30 -- The Big Four Foreign Ministers deputies, who are charged with drafting an Austrian peace treaty, will resume their discussions here tomorrow cheered by the notable measure of success reached on the Austrian problem by the four Foreign Ministers in Paris.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 -- The family and the school received detailed examination from the nation's home economists here today, and both were found wanting.

TORONTO, June 30 -- (Canadian Press) -- The plan for reorganization of the capital structure of the Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., will be in the hands of security holders shortly, George S. Messersmith, chairman of the board, said at today's annual meeting.

With the ending today of Federal controls on installment buying, the Association of Better Business Bureaus will begin a close watch on credit-purchase advertising for evidence of unethical or misleading claims, it was declared yesterday by Victor A. Nyborg, president of the association.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Grenville Mellen of the Maritime Commission urged today that a choice be given ship operators as to when they might deduct ship depreciation for income tax purposes.

Purchasing at the New York summer lamp show, which entered its closing stages yesterday in the New Yorker Hotel, was heavy in the case of top name suppliers and better than expected for smaller resources, according to both exhibitors and retailers.

LONDON, June 30 (AP) -- The top-seeded American team of Ted Schroeder and Gardnar Mulloy overcame controversial line decisions and two tough Australians today to reach the final of the Wimbledon men's doubles tennis championship.

PARIS, June 30 -- Abolition of the deferred rate and code rate for international cablegrams and telegrams was decided upon today, to take effect July 1, 1950, by the telegraph tariffs committee of the International Telegraph and Telephone Conference meeting here.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 30 -- Archbishop Josef Beran reaffirmed today his determination not to leave his palace "for the time being" after the Government had assured him that he was "absolutely free" to go where he wished and would provide a police guard to protect him in case there were hostile demonstrations against him.

The City of New York has borrowed $65,000,000 from twenty-six local banks and trust companies on 1 1/4 per cent tax anticipation notes dated July 1 and due on Oct. 4 and Oct. 7, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday.

In an effort to alleviate the hardships of non-ambulatory veterans of both World Wars, who are still confined to hospitals in the New York area, members of the Crossroads of the World Post, No. 310, Veterans of Foreign Wars, announced yesterday the start of an essay contest.
Coffee futures continued to advance in active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday.

James G. Conway will retire today as president of the New York Tow Boat Exchange, Inc., and also as executive vice president of the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York. A testimonial luncheon was tendered to the veteran harbor executive earlier this week.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 30 -- Miss Barbara Bruning, 17-year-old White Plains High student representing Whippoorwill, shot 39, 42 -- 81, to capture the low gross prize in the weekly women's Westchester-Fairfield one-day golf tournament at Bonnie Briar today.

LONDON, June 30 (Reuters) -- The New Zealanders triumphed over a combined services cricket team at Gillingham today by an innings and 50 runs. The scores were: Combined Services 72 and 347, New Zealanders 469 for seven declared.

One horse fell, another lost his rider, a third one bolted off the course and a fourth one was pulled up. That left seven to go the route in the $12,025 Forget Hurdle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, with the winner being Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' H Hour, highweight under 158 pounds and 9-to-2 third choice of the crowd of 14,539.

PARAMUS, N.J., July 1 -- Mrs. Joseph J. Mason of the home club won her first one-day tournament with a two-over-women's-par 37, 38 -- 5 over the Ridgewood Country Club course today in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association weekly event.

In these troubled and anxious times when the independence of men and on nations is threatened by tyranny from without and treason within, it is heartening indeed to reread that fervent expression of faith m individual liberty as proclaimed by the men of Congress in their great Declaration of July 4 1776.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 1 -- Police announced today the solution of the sudden appearance of scores of old-type gold certificates in various denominations here yesterday after tracing their source to a public dumping grounds in nearby Scotch Plains, where they said $2,790 of $3,000 worth of the notes, mistaken for stage money, was burned by refuse salvagers.

In the presence of about 500 persons who had gathered on the vast sandy expanse of newly reclaimed land, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Borough President Cornelius A. Hall of Richmond, formally opened yesterday the new Great Kills Park on Staten Island's south shore at Great Kills.

More than 140 tool manufacturers and buyers attended the preview yesterday of the new Tool Sales Shop, uptown branch of Patterson Brothers, a century-old New York hardware firm. Located at 292 Madison Avenue, displays contain more than 7,500 tools and accessories, according to Joseph I. George, merchandise manager.

SHANGHAI, July 1 -- The "cold war" between Randall Gould, editor of the closed down Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury, and the newspaper's workers reached a new climax today, more than two weeks after the presses had come to a stop.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 1 -- The Holland festival reached its climax tonight with the first of a series of five performances by the Vienna State Opera. Tonight's opera Was Mozart's "Abduction from the Seraglio,'' presented before a capacity audience in Royal Municipal Theatre.

Chief Magistrate Bromberger is to be commended for his suggestion to magistrates sitting in the Traffic Court that fines be increased for disregard of play-street traffic signs and for exceeding the speed limit within the city. Protection for play streets in the interest of the thousands who have nowhere else to play is of special importance with the closing of the school term.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The Zenith Radio Corporation reported today a net profit of $2,706,889 for the fiscal year ended on April 30, compared with net profit of $3,484,515 in the previous fiscal year. Net profit was equal to $5.50 a capital share in the 1949 period, against $7.08 in the 1948 fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee demanded a showdown today on the Administration's foreign-spending program in the light of Britain's virtual rejection of American proposals to inject a larger measure of competition into Western European trade under the Marshall Plan.

Because there are more calls for assistance from fishermen and other small boatmen on week-ends in Jamaica Bay than the Coast Guard can answer, the Coast Guard Auxiliary has been called back into rescue duty there for the rest of this summer, it was announced yesterday.

This week marked the thirty-fifth anniversary of workmen's compensation in New York State -- a landmark in the history of social legislation. Since the original New York State law went into effect more than three hundred amendments have been added to enlarge its scope, increase cash benefits an improve medical care, so that today the state pays the highest workmen's compensation benefits in the world.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 1 -- The Soviet Union today opposed Secretary General Trygve Lie's modified guard plan for a United Nations field service and a special observers' panel as a charter "violation'' that would ultimately permit infringement of national sovereignties.

RENO, Nevada, July 1 -- The Nevada State Department of Agriculture appealed for Federal aid today to combat what Harry E. Galloway, Field Supervisor for the Department, called "undoubtedly the largest and most intensely populated band of grasshoppers in modern times."

The mad and merry rush to get out of town for the three-day Fourth of July holiday was in full swing yesterday and last night. It was an exodus in traditional fashion -- trains, planes, buses and automobiles packed to capacity. An added incentive this year was the humid weather and the beckoning promise of cooler breezes and lower temperatures far from the city's brick and stone.
DETROIT, July 1 (AP) - Automotive production in the United States and Canada took a slight dip this week in estimates by Ward's Reports, Inc., statistician for the industry.

If the Dodgers anticipated an altogether happy holiday weekend at the expense of the Giants, they received a rude awakening yesterday. A stalwart pitching effort by the left-handed Dave Koslo set down the Brooks, 4 -- 1, in the opener of a three-game series, played before the largest weekday crowd of the season at the Polo Grounds -- 23,580 paying fans and 8,211 ladies' day guests.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Russians may have the chance to see a considerable proportion of two dozen American feature films which will be taken to the U.S.S.R. under an arragnment announced today. The Motion Picture Export Association said that a visa had been granted for one of its representatives to go to Moscow with the films, which have been chosen for possible purchase by the Soviet Union.

When the nurses of the Presbyterial Hospital Unit moved into Normandy shortly after D-Day there was no heat and nothing hot to eat or drink. So a stove was improvised by filling a little can with dirt, setting it in a larger can, pouring some gasoline over the dirt and throwing in a match.
CANTON, China, July 1 (AP) -The Chinese Nationalist Cabinet tonight authorized its navy to sink any ships resisting search in connection with the Nationalist "closure" of Communist-held ports.

A United Press dispatch printed in THE TIMES of June 24 under the caption "University Women Admit Negroes; Washington, D.C., Branch Secedes" contains misstatements and partial statements that create an erroneous impression. This dispatch was apparently used as the basis for an editorial in THE TIMES of June 25 entitled "Degrees of Color."

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Federal Government backed up today its offer to pay $10,000 to any one discovering a new uranium deposit in this country. It published a book that tells today's "Forty-niners" how and where to look for the mineral.
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 1 (AP) -- Vice President Alben Barkley hit back at States' Rights Democrats tonight, declaring the Federal Government must aid the States.

The Columbia Broadcasting System will sell time for the expression of opinion on public issues, Frank Stanton, president of the networks, anounced yesterday. The step is being taken, Mr. Stanton said, in view of the reversal of the Mayflower decision by the Federal Communication Commission and the intention of CBS to broadcast editorials, from time to time, in its own name.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended June 28, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 153.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 1.9 per cent below four weeks ago and 8.4 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- Fifty-six prominent Republicans in New Jersey, among them the United States Senators and the twenty-one county chairmen, will constitute a campaign, committee, for Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll in his drive for re-election.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Federal Judge Walter J. Labuy today let the Government name seventy-six new defendants in its anti-trust suit against Bausch Lomb Optical Company.
NANKING, July l -- Foreign observers waiting for more concrete signs of Chinese Communist policies wrote off today any immediate prospects that Mao Tze-tung would become "another Tito."
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Government closed up shop today on what once was the nation's biggest merchandise bargain counter.

Nine firemen were injured yesterday morning when a four-alarm fire, estimated to have caused $250,000 in damages, swept through a two-story building of a hardware and electrical supply house at 2 to 14 Stuyvesant Street near Eighth Street and opposite Cooper Union.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange had a moderately active session yesterday and final prices were 11 points higher to 1 point lower.
Four new clauses protecting buyers against price declines are now being used by large New York buying interests, leading purchasing sources revealed here yesterday.

The espionage trial here of Miss Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev, Soviet engineer, is scheduled to start July 11th in Federal Court. They have been indicted on four counts charging a conspiracy to transmit vital American documents to a foreign power.

In an action which had been clearly foreshadowed by events earlier in the week, the Senate has voted 51 -- 42 its own version of the 1948 election mandate in the field of labor-management legislation. This vote rejected emphatically the position of organized labor and the Administration that the Democratic platform called for the repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act and the substitution therefor of a revived Wagner Act of 1935.

In one of its most unusual actions, New York's legislative body, the City Council, has approved a proposal to name a street after a living Broadway producer, John Golden. Dedication ceremonies, to be attended by Mayor O'Dwyer and other civic leaders, will take place next Tuesday afternoon, the date designated by Borough President James A. Burke as John Golden Day in Queens.

Morty and A.B. Wolosoff, of the Alley Pond Park Apartments, builders, have obtained three mortgage insurance commitments totaling $4,614,400 from the Federal Housing Administration on three garden-type apartments being erected by them in the vicinity of Union Turnpike and Springfield Boulevard, Bayside, Queens, according to J. Halperin Co., brokers.

The Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam sailed from Hoboken yesterday for the Channel ports with 1,216 passengers. Among them were William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, and his wife, who will spend seven weeks in France and Italy.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark said today that although "intemperate and ill-advised charges" have been leveled at the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a result of the Judith Coplon espionage case, he has "complete confidence'' in the agency and its director, J. Edgar Hoover.

I read with interest your story of June 15 reporting sharp criticism of the Public Education Association's stand on released time for religious education in New York City's public schools and, inferentially, of your paper's handling of the news story.

Charges made two weeks ago by the Nassau County Transit Commission that the parent Pennsylvania Railroad was draining revenue from the Long Island Rail Road may have a direct bearing on the Long Island's application for increased passenger fares.

LONDON, July 1 -- Two of Britain's influential weeklies, the Economist and The New Statesman and Nation, warned the country today that settlement of the dispute over the financing of intra-European trade touched only the surface of the economic crisis facing Britain.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 1 -- The minor courts of sixty-nine Connecticut towns were in chaos today as rival claimants for the bench contested each other's right to sit. In consequence, except for the jailing of a few habitual tipplers, action was held up on criminal and civil cases and justice was at a standstill.

PRAGUE, July 1 (AP) -- Diplomatic sources had reports tonight that at least two Communist policemen were beaten to death and an undetermined number of persons injured in clashes between Catholic faithful and Government adherents in Slovakia in recent days.

A small pineapple began growing on Fifth Avenue yesterday as the channel gardens in Rockefeller Center went Hawaiian for July and August. Sugar cane lined the stairs to the sunken arcade, and banana plants, coconut trees, taro -- from which pot is made -- and huge torch ginger blossoms bloomed inside the traditional ivy border of the gardens between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets.

An agreement has been reached between Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, West 133d Street and Convent Avenue, and the Ogden M. Reid Estate for the sale of 250 acres of Ophir Farm at Purchase, N. Y., for re-location of the 103-year-old college.

Flowers are one way of dressing up a home for the festivities that accompany holiday week-ends. In the suburbs or the country blossoms will be chosen from those in gardens, fields or along the road-side. The florists' refrigerators in the city are naturally more limited at this time of the year.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 9.5 per cent in June compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 1 -- The Israeli-British financial talks opened here today with a formal spirit of friendliness but with an apparent undertone of apprehension in view of their seriousness and political delicacy. Obviously they will take many weeks as matters on the agenda are complicated and deep-rooted.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies' 1949 "Roster and Organization" was issued here yesterday. It lists 239 member agencies operating 391 offices in sixty-two cities of the United States, and fifty-one in twenty-four foreign cities.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- White House conferences next week will decide the Administration's future course on labor legislation at this session of Congress.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 1 -- The next moves by the Government in its conflict with the Roman Catholic Church are expected to develop out of three "national pilgrimages" sponsored by the Government-backed and Vatican-excommunicated "Catholic Action" Sunday, Monday and Tuesday to shrines of three Slav Saints who converted the Czechs and Slovaks to Christianity.

ALBANY, July 1 -- Five organizations that have been classified as subversive by the United States Attorney General will have the opportunity to testify July 14 before a committee of the Board of Regents as to why their members should not be barred from public school posts in New York State under the terms of the Feinberg Law.

Unassisted by any favorable news developments, the stock market again forged ahead yesterday, ending the week with averages around the best levels of the recovery movement. Advances ranged from fractions to 2 points during the day, closing generally higher on slightly larger transactions.

Nylon fabrics, decorative embroidery, and manufacturer's "secrets" have sounded the death knell of the old-fashioned, brocaded, boned "harness" which has now virtually disappeared from corset departments. Today, women find the same or better control in pretty, light and airy garments made of nylon taffeta, marquisette, lace and elastic.
BERLIN, July 1 -- This city's lifeline to the West, stifled for more than a year by blockade and strike, neared normal operation tonight when the Soviet-controlled railroad administration re

NEW DELHI, July 1 -- Indian Communists have been instructed in a circular from their central headquarters in Bombay to "look upon the U.S.S.R. as the only fatherland" and to prepare for a violent uprising to establish a proletarian state, it has been learned from party documents seized recently in police raids.

NUTLEY, N.J., July 1 -- Restoration of an abandoned school building nearly 100 years old for conversion into a museum for the Nutley Historical Society is in full swing in this suburban community. Civic groups and public-minded citizens are solidly behind the project, which probably will be completed sometime in the fall.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee withheld from public record today -- temporarily at least -- an official record concerning wartime purchases by the Government of many acres of land at Manhattan Beach, on the Brooklyn oceanfront.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Republic of Korea will fall within three months, presumably to the Communists to the north, if Congress rejects the Administration's $150,000,000 recovery program for that little country, Secretary of State Dean Acheson has declared.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Two Federal agencies today reported rising unemployment, the Census Bureau giving a June figure of 3,788,000 jobless and the Federal Security Agency giving a weekly average for June of 2,046,380 "continued claims" from persons jobless more than one week.
CHICAGO, July 1 -- Federal District Judge Michael L. Igoe today authorized a six-week delay in the reorganization proceedings of Tucker Corporation.

Unit-price dresses produced the New York market for the first half of the year are down only 10 per cent in dollar volume and running approximately the same as last year in units, it was estimated yesterday in the trade. Dollar losses which were heavy in the first two months of the year, were recovered to a large extent by increased business in the four succeeding months, observers pointed out.

CARTERET, N.J., July 1 -- A strike that began at 7 A. M. today at the local plant of the United States Metals Refining Company made about 2,000 employes idle. A token picket line was placed around the plant.

CHICAGO, July 1 (Science Service) -- A warning of a possible danger of a chemical contamination of food from a new food process was issued today by the Council on Foods and Nutrition of the American Medical Association.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Senators and Representatives moved out of their historic chambers today to make way for a modernization and roof-repair job.
Bernard M. Baruch's criticism last Thursday of our mobilization planning, and the President's retort, focused attention upon a key agency of government -- the National Security Resources Board.
TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- One half of some New Jersey crops, particularly potatoes and sweet corn, have been lost in the drought, the State and Federal Departments of Agriculture reported today.

The nation's securities and commodity exchanges will be closed on Monday in observance of Independence Day. With a few exceptions, for the brief Saturday session, all exchanges will be closed today. Canadian and European exchanges will be open on Monday.

A sharp change in Soviet financial practice to stimulate directors of state enterprises to increase profits, so that caiptal expansion this year can be financed much more out of earnings, is provided in the 1949 plan, according to a report by Soviet Finance Minister Arseni G. Zverev.

BUENOS AIRES, July .1 -- The investigation of the Argentine Institute for the Promotion of Trade, the Peron trade monopoly, which the opposition in Congress had been demanding for a full month, was turned over last night to the judicial authorities.

LONDON, July 1 -- The United States Government is quietly seeking the support of its North Atlantic Pact associates and of the "free" Asiatic powers for a coordinated foreign trading policy vis-a-vis the Communist areas of China, it was reliably learned here.
With the deadline for a national steel strike just two weeks away, the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, took its first formal action yesterday to prepare its members for a walkout.
SEOUL, Korea, July 1 -- President Syngman Rhee today gave assurance that Korea would not accept "any coalition or any Government here which has anything to do with communism, now or in the future."
A National Guard warrant officer was killed last night in Brooklyn as the result of a fist-fight that developed as passersby heckled 900 uniformed men marching on their way to summer training camp.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N.Y., July 1 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley saluted the State of Israel today and expressed the hope "that it may become a powerful influence for democratic values in this part of the world."

ASPEN, Col., July 1 -- Jose Ortega y Gasser, Spain's humanist critic and philosopher, declared here today that America in its "magnificent adolescence" and vigor was capable of "digesting" all the errors of its politicians.

One of the prized items sought by collectors of Americana, a complete set of autographs by the signers of the Declaration of Independence, is being offered for sale by a small Eastern library, it was learned yesterday.

Sharp advances were registered in coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Trading was active. New life-of-contract highs were established in most of the delivery positions. Firmness in actual coffees and in shipment offerings aided the upswing.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Maj. Gen. Leroy P. Hunt donned another star today and took command of Fleet Marine Force, Atlantic, with headquarters at Norfolk, Va.

Dr. Kingsley Davis, Associate Professor of Sociology at Columbia University, has been appointed director of the university's Bureau of Applied Social Research, Dr. John A. Krout, dean of the graduate faculties, announced yesterday.

Sidney Wood made his exit from the New York State clay court tennis championship singles yesterday as William Talbert and Seymour Greenberg gained the two remaining brackets in the semi-finals at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

DURHAM, N.H., July 1 -- Pointing to a serious teacher shortage, educators attending the national Conference on the Professional Growth of Teachers reported today that 260,000 elementary teachers in this country were not qualified or adequately prepared for their jobs.

Late reports from Martha's Vineyard indicate that those who have planned the holiday week-end at this fishing spot made a wise choice, for plenty of stripers are being caught and many of them large fish.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden July 1 -- During the last three weeks the Rumanian Government has been carrying out a round-up of remaining members of the Social Democratic party not yet in custody who have refused to collaborate with the Communist regime.
The Shepard Steamship Company is withdrawing from its Atlantic-South American freight route and has sold its company-owned fleet of four vessels, it was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, July 1 -- The first group of Japanese civilian repatriates to be returned this year from Soviet territory landed early today at Hakodate, on the northern island of Hokkaido -- without revolutionary songs, oaths to communize their nation or Communist demonstrations at the pierhead.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Scorning a mercy plea, Judith Coplon was sentenced today to serve 40 months to 10 years in prison for attempting to betray her country as a spy for Soviet Russia.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 1 (AP) - A county grand jury began investigating violence by hooded and robed bands today, delving first into the invasion of a cafe by sixty white-sheeted men.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Robert T. Barnett, who tutored some of the nation's leading golfers as well as Presidents Taft and Harding, died here today.

June electric fan volume in some local retail outlets was four times greater than comparable month last year, traffic appliance and housewares buyers reported yesterday. They attributed the fan boom primarily to the unexpectedly early heat wave but pointed out that heavier promotion also was an important contributing factor.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Directors of the American Farm Bureau Federation today assailed Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan's proposed new farm program, asserting its philosophy is "dangerous to agriculture."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 1 -- Three hundred forty-one bank officers from all parts of the country who have, during the past three summers, attended two-week sessions of intensive study at the Graduate School of Banking here at Rutgers University received diplomas at the school's thirteenth annual commencement exercises tonight.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 1 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner-designate, arrived here this evening and informally announced that he was assuming command as Military Governor immediately. It was something new to see a Military Governor, formerly a post of full generals, in civilian clothes.

LONDON, July 1 -- With dealers undecided whether to be bullish about the Paris agreement or bearish because of home transport and dock troubles only a go-slow movement was seen in the stock markets here today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The State Department has asked the Soviet Union to reconsider its refusal to permit discussion of United States complaints against Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Lucky Stores, Inc., Oakland, Calif., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 400,000 shares of its $1.25 par value common stock that is to be offered to the public by the Blair Holdings Corporation.
WEIRTON, W.Va., July 1 -- The largest pay melon in the forty-year history of Weirton Steel Company was out today for more than 12,000 employes.

The fortieth convention of the International Society of Christian Endeavor will be held Tuesday through Sunday, July 10, on the campus of the University of Toronto. More than 5,000 delegates from the United States and Canada are expected.

Eighteen Italian soccer players, captained by Aldo Campatelli and accompanied by two directors and a masseur, representing the Internazionale-Milano Football Club of Milan, arrived last night on the Steamship Mauretania of the Cunard-White Star Line for a tour of four matches.

LONDON, July 1 -- Notable advances on drafting on Austrian peace treaty were made today by the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers despite a sharp disagreement on the question of minority rights. Today's meeting was the first of the deputies since the four Foreign Ministers agreed in Paris to give the "green light" to the long-delayed Austrian treaty problem.

Denied the use of the municipal playground at 140th Street and Lenox Avenue for her annual free luncheon for Harlem Junior High School children, Mrs. Maggie (Mom) Bunn took her guests instead to the Col. Charles Young Post 398 of the American Legion at 652 Lenox Avenue. Signs posted outside the playground gave directions.
WASHINGTON, July I (AP) -- A decision of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to close two government-owned synthetic rubber plants in California became known today.
FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., July 1 (AP) -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley said today this country, in planning its military needs, must "anticipate a long period of tension."

DETROIT, July 1 -- By sundown tonight ten and ten only of the thirty-odd expensive playthings entered as unlimited, super-powered Gold Cup boats had passed the qualification tests for tomorrow's forty-second running of America's oldest and most famous speed boat classic.

As seventy more persons moved out of the heavily overcrowded building at 545 West 111th Street yesterday, Mayor O'Dwyer announced that he and his official family would provide full information on the case to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for whatever criminal prosecution may be warranted.
Thirteen ships of the Navy's Atlantic fleet will arrive here this morning for a holiday week-end visit.

John Scotto, well-known in prewar shipping circles, has been named to his former post as general agent for the French Line on the West Coast, it was announced here yesterday by Guy de Berc, general manager of the line in the United States and Canada.
AMES, Iowa, July 1 (AP) -- A severe wind and rainstorm struck the Iowa State College golf course this afternoon causing postponement of semi-final play in the national collegiate tournament.

The jailing of John Gates, editor of The Daily Worker, for thirty days for contempt of court in the Communist trial was upheld yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals. A decision by Judge Thomas W. Swan, in which Judges Harrie B. Chase and J. Joseph Smith concurred, was made public here.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Aided by a red-hot putter, Al Smith of Winston-Salem, N.C., blazed an 8-under-par 64 today to take the lead in the first round of The Washington Star Open. Smith, who has 165 pounds stacked in his 5-foot 6 1/2-inch frame, had ten one-putt greens. All told, he needed only twenty-six putts for the eighteen holes.

HONOLULU, July 1 -- Hawaii's strike-troubled population today grimly awaited the next development in the longshore walkout after members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, had voted overwhelmingly against ending the walkout on terms recommended by Gov. Ingram Stainback's Emergency Fact Finding Board.
Assault's return to stakes competition will be the chief item of business before the house at Aqueduct today on the last afternoon of the Queens County Jockey Club's three-week meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Truman sent to Congress today drafts of two bills seeking broad powers for putting into action his "bold new program" for building up the economic status and living standards of peoples of under-developed areas of the world.

The charges made against the New York City school system a few days ago were briefly put, contained almost no documentation and gave the impression of being launched in an almost casual and impromptu manner. Their source, however -- the Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York -- gives them a weight that cannot be ignored, and the gravity of some of them certainly warrants further inquiry.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 1 (AP) -- Lighthouse, paying $40.60 for $2, annexed the feature at Monmouth Park today. The 5-year-old finished a nose in front of Briar White a 50-1 shot. Singing Doll was third, while the odds-on favorite, Three Dots, ran fourth.

Recently in the Topics of The Times strong feelings of regret were expressed about the changes in appearance and character of the pharmacies in this country. Reclaiming the beauty of the past is a human yearning, especially cherished by those who have reached the age of remembering.

The "patience and hard work of police in checking pawnshops to run down clues" was praised yesterday in Felony Court as a former handyman in the Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South, was charged with possessing jewelry reported stolen from guests at the hotel.
GENEVA, July 1 -- The International Labor Organization virtually completed its thirty-second conference today with the adoption of four conventions designed to improve the lot of world labor.

PARIS, July 1 -- The Foreign Ministers of the Marshall Plan Council adjourned until August, after reaching an accord early today on European payments and on liberalization of trade. They are leaving alternates and experts to work out the details.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 1 -- The American Newspaper Guild voted today to establish the New York area, including Westchester, Suffolk and Nassau Counties, in a region by itself because of its large membership.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 1, (UP) -- Two young Negroes charged with violating Alabama segregation laws were allowed to return to their home in New Jersey today on their plea that they did not know about the racial statutes.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Looking ahead to extension of television in theatres, the Federal Communications Commission today asked three agencies to define their plans by Sept. 2.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman refused to permit the former wife of Gerhart Eisler, fugitive Communist, to testify as a Government witness in the Alger Hiss perjury trial yesterday after a lengthy argument in his chambers between opposing counsel.

Ships of all sizes, from harbor tugs to ocean liners gave the traditional whistles of welcome yesterday as the Lloyd I. Seaman, floating hospital of the St. John's Guild, made her first trip of the season around New York Harbor.

Slowly moving holiday traffic at the Holland Tunnel and a quick-witted observer of a payroll robbery at 11:30 A.M. led yesterday to the almost immediate capture of the alleged thief and the recovery of $918.
Keeping instalment credit terms on a sound basis was urged in a survey by the Consumer Credit Committee of the American Bankers Association released today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today assured Gov. Frank Carlson of Kansas that he will not clamp rigid production controls on the nation's wheat farmers unless it is "absolutely necessary."

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- Ted Schroeder did what was expected of him today and won the Wimbledon tennis championship by defeating Jaroslav Drobny of Czechoslovakia in five briskly fought but none-too-well-played sets. The scores were 3 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3, 4--6, 6 -- 4.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 1 - A team of six United Nations experts will go to Ecuador to help the Quito Government overhaul its administrative and financial setup, it was announced today.

CLEVELAND, July 1 (AP) -- With big Al Benton twirling six-hit ball, the Indians defeated the Browns tonight, 3 to 1. First Baseman Jack Graham spoiled a shut-out for Benton with a fifth-inning homer. Benton struck out five.

DETROIT, July 1 -- The immediate danger of a strike by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, against the Ford Motor Company when the present contract expires on July 15 was dispelled today. An agreement proposed by the union was adopted to extend the contract on a day-to-day basis.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The Cubs parlayed Hank Sauer's hitting including his eleventh homer, and Bob Muncrief's able relief pitching into a 6-5 victory over the Pirates today. The result left last-place Chicago only one game behind seventh-place Pittsburgh.
After being separated for fifty years, an 82-year-old retired real estate man from South Africa, was reunited here last night with his four brothers and two sisters.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The National and American League starting line-ups for the All-Star game July 12, picked by vote of 4,637,-743 fans, were announced today.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 1 -- Selecting a Green Mountain background for the start of an intensive tournament campaign preliminary to the Walker Cup matches, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie today won the medal with a 70 in the twenty-first Ekwanok Country Club invitation golf tourney.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 1 - The names of ten winners of the international essay competition sponsored by the United Nations Department of Public Information were announced today by Benjamin Cohen, assistant secretary general for public information.
PITTSBURGH, July (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America notified member-employes of the Aluminum Company of America today that contract wage provisions expire at midnight, Sunday, July 31.

A telegram sent to Senator Brien McMahon, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, by five members of the executive committee of the American Institute of Physics, approving the requirement of a loyalty pledge and non-Communist affidavit for applicants of Atomic Energy Commission fellowships, is sharply criticized by Prof. Leo Szilard of the University of Chicago in a letter published in the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, out today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Casey Stengel turned to his bench for help and found it tonight at Griffith Stadium, where the Yankees, trailing, 4 -- 1, in the ninth, rallied for four runs. Stengel then turned to the bullpen, beckoning to Lefty Joe Page, who protected this newfound "life" and the result was a dramatic 5-4 victory for the American League leaders over the Senators.

It was the Poles, serving with the Allied forces in Italy, who finally captured Monte Cassino. This is one of the many accomplishments recalled in "An Army in Exile," the story of the Second Polish Corps, by its commander, Lieut.-Gen. W. Anders, to be published by Macmillan on July 19.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Federal Government incurred budget deficit of $1,811,000,000 in the fiscal year 1949 which ended yesterday, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, announced this afternoon.

The Rev. Dr. M. Eugene Flipse, minister of the Community Church of Douglaston, 39-50 Douglaston Parkway, Queens, flew from La Guardia Airport yesterday for San Juan, P. R., to inspect mission enterprises of the Board of Domestic Missions of the Reformed Church in America.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- Eddie Joost drove in five runs and hit his seventeenth home run tonight as the Athletics routed the Red Sox, 11 to 5, behind the eight- hit pitching of southpaw Lou Brissie. Jack Kramer, idle most of the season, tried a pitching comeback for Boston but was knocked from the mound during a seven-run Philadelphia outburst in the second innning.

LONDON, July 1 (AP) -- Sir Eric Bowater, chairman of Britain's biggest paper company, accused the Government today of taking "a very substantial profit" on bulk buying of paper pulp while keeping paper prices high and production low.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 1 (AP) -- Two Philadelphia buddies -- Jack Kelly and Jack Trinsey -- will row for Henley's Diamond Sculls tomorrow in the first all-America final of the famed regatta's 110 years.

Four Negro lads from Savannah, Ga., elected yesterday to visit Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall rather than attend the Giants-Dodgers baseball game at the Polo Grounds, where they could have watched Jackie Robinson, Roy Campanella and Don Newcombe perform.

Two new pictures will open today, "Lust for Gold," at the Criterion, a Columbia film starring Ida Lupino and Glenn Ford, with a screen play by Ted Sherdeman and Richard English, based on a book by Barry Storm. The supporting cast includes Gig Young, William Prince, Edgar Buchanan, Will Geer and Paul Ford.

Newbold Morris, chairman of the board of Youthbuilders Inc., defended the stand yesterday of the Rev. Leland B. Henry, executive director of the Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, in the latter's controversy over public school policies with Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

Wearing heavy woolen suits, six Danish boys between the ages of 13 and 15 saw the United States for the first time when the Swedish-American liner, Gripsholm, arrived yesterday morning from Gothenburg, Sweden. The youngsters, all of whom are from Copenhagen, left yesterday afternoon for Spring Hill Farm Camp, in Rieglesville, Pa., where they will spend six weeks with fourteen American boys from New York and New Jersey.

DELAT, French Indo-China, July 1 (Reuters) -- Former Emperor Bao Dai of Annam today became Chief of State and Prime Minister of Viet Nam when the names of the new state's first Cabinet were announced.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -- Lew Ayres has been signed by Warner Brothers to play the leading role in "Sugarfoot," an adaptation of a 1942 novel by Clarence Budington Kelland about Arizona in the post-Civil War period. Ayres will play a Southern aristocrat who comes West after the war to find new land.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- The weltherweight title fight between Sugar Ray Robinson of New York and Kid Gavilan of Cuba July 11 will not be televised, it was announced today. The promoters said the boxers agreed that no profitable deal could be worked out for television of the bout.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- The American Home Economics Association adopted a program of legislative promotion here today as its annual convention drew to a close, and assigned itself the task of developing new ways and means to interpret democratic family life.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A renewed and urgent request for United States help was laid before Secretary of State Dean Acheson today by Dr. Kan Chieh-hou, adviser to Acting President Li Tsungjen of China. The envoy had previously laid the same plan before President Truman, he said.
LONDON, July 1 -- British interests of the Shell Oil group have rejected an offer made by the Hungarian Government for the Hungarian subsidiary of the group, it became known today.
TRENTON, N.J., July 1 -- Preparations went forward today for the retrial of six Trenton Negroes whose death-penalty convictions in a shopkeeper's murder were reversed by the State Supreme Court.

Mayor O'Dwyer swore in yesterday as members of the Board of Higher Education for full nine-year terms John Adikes, lawyer and banker, of 84-36 Wareham Road, Jamaica, Queens; Arthur Rosencrans, insurance man, of 340 Shore Boulevard, Brooklyn, and Fred H. Schildwachter, business man, of 74 East 235th Street, the Bronx.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Hedging sales largely offset reduced estimates on the Southwestern winter wheat crop on the Board of Trade today. July showed a heavy under-tone and finished unchanged to 1/8 cent a bushel higher, with gains on deferred deliveries ranging up to 1 1/4 cents.

The future of Long Island for many years to come may be determined by the plans its citizens make now to meet the problems created by the great and sudden growth of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, many residents of the island believe.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 (AP) -- Ted Schroeder, 27-year-old Californian who started the allEngland tennis tournament on June 20 as a 7-4 favorite in men's singles, justified the short odds by riaing always to the necessary heights.

ROME, June 21 -- Experts of the Italian Ministry of Agriculture were said today to have nearly completed the draft of the agrarian reform law that was announced by Premier Alcide de Gasperi last April. The draft will be discussed by the Italian Cabinet before the end of July.

When the Independence Day holiday rolls around, it is customary to wish for cloudless skies so that the millions who escape the stone and brick of cities may gain the maximum of outdoor recreation and enjoyment. This year, however, our fervent wish must be for rain of the drenching, penetrating sort.

BOSTON, July 1 (UP) - Right-hander Vern Rickford scored the winning run in the twelfth inning, on Al Dark's single, as the Boston Braves broke their third-place tie with the Phillies with a 2-1 victory tonight before a 17,058 crowd.

Retail sales again declined during the week here, according to estimates made yesterday. Department store sales were believed to be about 11 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 8 per cent below last year.

Action of the New Jersey Supreme Court in ordering a new trial for the six Negroes sentenced to death for the murder of an aged Trenton storekeeper is already being represented by the Communists and their friends as a victory won by them single-handed in the interests of fair play for Negroes in American courts.

ALBANY, July 1 -- Governor Dewey, in a statement issued on the fourth anniversary of the establishment of the State Commission Against Discrimination, declared today that its accomplishments were "a definitive answer to those of the extreme left who seek to destroy us by setting class against class, race against race."

ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP) -- With a chance to tie the Brooklyn Dodgers for the National League lead, the Cardinals took a 10-to-2 shellacking at the hands of the sixth-place Cincinnati Reds tonight. It was the Redbirds' third defeat in five games against second division opposition.
DALLAS, Tex., July I (UP) -- The movement of Chance Vought Aircraft from Stratford, Conn., to this city, which began in May, 1948, and required 1,006 freight cars, has come to an end.

A friend of this corner, who is strongly inclined toward adventure and research in the realm of gastronomy, has long made a habit of reading old menus. It is a most excellent method, he claims, of visualizing the march of change in the customs of those who purvey food and those who partake thereof.
FRANKFORT, Germany, July 1 -- In a tripartite conference of Military Government chiefs, it was decided today to retain all present licensing regulations for the political parties in Germany.

LONDON, July 1 -- The threat of a nationwide "slowdown" on the British railways from Sunday midnight ended suddenly here today as leaders of the striking National Union of Railwaymen gave way before growing public and Parliamentary opinion and decided to suspend temporarily their slowdown decision.

Ticket brokers, having filed a charter of organization, decided yesterday to elect officers and draw up by-laws. Under their new constitution a broker who injures the reputation of the business can be expelled from the association.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- John L. Lewis' order for coal miners to work but three days a week is uneconomical and will not aid the coal industry, coal operators asserted today.

The Traffic Commission's "pilot project" to test the value of parking meters was approved yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer, although he said he still was "skeptical" that the devices would help to remedy traffic congestion.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 1 -- A drive against bureaucracy and mismanagement of farms and factories has started in Bulgaria. Names of factory managers and lists of enterprises that have failed to fulfill their production quotas have been published in the newspapers recently.

The little police launch bobbed in the water, its motor idling. The five men in dungarees and sheep-skin jackets sat in the cabin and on deck. They were swapping yarns, polishing brass fittings, puttering in the engine room. It was dark.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1 - The technical committee on refugees of the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission that is now in Lebanon, in beginning its investigation will take up concrete issues and projects for resettlement of the Palestine Arab refugees with the various Arab Governments.

For the youngsters of Seventeenth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues in the south section of Brooklyn, the word gratitude is not simply a polite thanks. Yesterday a crowd of them decided to show Dr. Alexander S. Gardner how they felt about his prompt treatment of their chum, Patrick Ryan, 10 years old.
In your issue of June 23 Michael Young states:

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Fifty-four northern New Jersey municipalities, acting through the Jersey Shore Protective Committee and the Inter-Municipal Group for Better Rail Service today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to take another look at the 20 per cent increase it permitted the Central Railroad of New Jersey, with "unseemly haste," to make in its commuter fares last March.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Eddie Waitkus, 29-year-old first baseman for the Philadelphia National League baseball team, underwent another operation at the Albert Merritt Billings Hospital today to reexpand a lung which had been partially collapsed as a result of the bullet wound inflicted June 14 by Miss Ruth Steinhagen, 19-year-old stenographer.
The first city residents ever privileged to do so, Staten Islanders will begin cooking with natural gas about Aug. 1, the New York Richmond Gas Company said yesterday.

It is a strange place for a vegetable garden, the passer-by muses as he makes his way along crooked narrow Doyers Street in Chinatown. And perhaps he will stop to gaze a moment at the unexpected flush of greenery behind the high chicken-wire fence, and at the blank brick walls surrounding the 90 by 50 foot garden plot.
MONTREAL, July 1 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals swept a Dominion Day double-header from the Newark Bears before 6,611 today, 10 -- 2 and 6 -- 3.

DETROIT, July 1 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox cashed in three homers for four runs tonight as they blanked the Tigers, 4 to 0, behind the five-hit pitching of Lefthander Bill Wight. All three home runs came off Freddie Hutchinson.

RICHMOND, July 2 -- Spurned by a protracted heat wave, mountain and shore resorts report capacity reservations for the holiday week-end. Retail trade this week was slowed by the weather except in wearing apparel and vacation lines. Heavy goods movement was slack in anticipation of the removal of credit controls and expectation of price declines shortly.

The espionage statutes of the United States were written during World War I and revised near the beginning of World War II. From then until last week ninety-three persons had been convicted of espionage against the U. S. Government.
The horse of the year in 1946 was the horse of the day at Aqueduct yesterday.

THE disadvantages of his small stature were well known to Chip Fiske. From his sandlot days through his entrance into professional baseball the big, heavy hitters received the cheers of the crowds. Chip worked hard but his resentment flared forth in exhibits of temper.

Rabbis and laymen who "persist in fault-finding" about the new state of Israel were taken sharply to task yesterday by Rabbi Louis I. Newman in his sermon at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.
