THE deserved popularity of The Little Golden Books will stand up nicely with the addition of these five titles, all of which are good, and two, "The Fuzzy Duckling" and "Katie the Kitten," are even better than that. The story line, as befits tales for the very young, is always simple and includes a number of references to incidents and things in their own lives.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., July 2 -- A mob of 500 Negroes today shouted for the lynching of a white man here.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Senators Walter F. George, Democrat, of Georgia, and Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, agreed today that the Government's $1,811,000,000 deficit made it essential that Congress cut down on Federal spending.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- Georgi Dimitrov, Bulgarian Communist who for a quarter of a century stood in the front ranks of the Bolsheviki and who had been since 1945 Premier of Bulgaria, died at 9:35 A.M. today in a sanatorium about twenty miles outside of Moscow.

Drs. J. V. Swintosky, T. Higuchi and L. W. Busse, all of the University of Wisconsin's School of Pharmacy, have made the interesting discovery that if all the tiny surfaces in a thimbleful of a finely powdered drug were stretched out on one surface, they would more than cover the floor of an ordinary room.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- "O liberty! What crimes are committed in thy name," cried Madame Roland when she passed a statue of the Goddess of Democracy on her way to the guillotine. The protests that arose here against the decision of the Supreme Court this week in the case of Harold Roland Christoffel were in the same vein.

LONDON, July 2 -- As Britain's sham air war reached its climax today top ranking Royal Air Force chiefs were reported satisfied that they were well on the way toward solving any future threat from enemy high-altitude jet bombers flying at around the speed of sound.

Bank earnings in the first half of this year as indicated in quarterly statements of condition now being published reflect a high degree of stability. Earnings of the principal New York City banks as a group, for the quarter just ended, are expected to show little change from those of the comparable period a year ago.

THIS is an unusually charming story about a Mexican family living in Palos, a small village on the United States side of the Rio Grande. The family consists of Senor and Senora Castillo, Granny and the children, Rodrigo and Rosalita.

IN his preface to this new edition of John Lloyd Stephens' narrative of travel in Central America and Southern Mexico -- one of several works by Stephens which was lavishly praised and immensely popular during his lifetime -- Mr. Predmore says that when he read the tale he was so fascinated as to become convinced that it ought to have a place "among the chosen books of American literature."
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- It would take as many as 6,500 atomic bombs to destroy totally the cities of a major military power, an authority on strategic air war said today.

During the recent war elaborate and expensive experiments were made to discover a way of dispersing fog from airfields. The experiments are still going on. Some success was achieved in clearing a path for bombers and fighters, but at a staggering cost. Fogs were blown away, precipitated by chemicals, dried by oil-burners, shaken by powerful sirens that generated waves of sound so high in pitch that they could not be heard.

Robert Ferdinand Wagner, born in Nastatten, Germany, in 1877, came to America at the age of 8 as a member of a poor immigrant family. He worked his way up through college and law school, then began making street-corner speeches for Tammany, the New York County Democratic organization. He was elected successively to the New York State Assembly, the State Senate and New York's Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON. THE public career of Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, the Democratic Senate Leader, might be summed up currently by a slight paraphrase of an old spiritual. Nobody knows the trouble he's seen.

WARSAW, July 2 -- The draft of the new "family" law to be applied in Czechoslovakia as well as Poland prohibits any church marriage ceremonies prior to formal marriages in a Government registry office, the People's Journal reported today.

A 33-year-old employe of the city's Department of Welfare won first prize -- a two-week, all-expense round-trip to Mexico City -- in the vacation contest sponsored by the Greater New York Fund, it was announced yesterday.

When the skipper of a power cruiser learns enough about seamanship and really gets some deep water brine coursing through his veins he enters the now famous New York Athletic Club's predicted log race. The thirty-sixth annual repetition of this test of navigation rather than of speed over the 103 miles from Execution Light to Block Island's West Harbor win be held Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Residents of the northeastern section of the United States have been having Arctic trouble all this past month, although that may seem a paradox to the farmers who have watched their fields grow sere and to the millions of people who have sweltered through hot days and nights.

The most important fact in postwar world economics is this: The United States, rich in resources and highly productive, has been selling to other nations more than it buys from them. The result has been a chronic dollar shortage abroad. The other nations have been unable to obtain enough dollars, through sales to the United States, to pay for the goods they need from the United States.

A movement of almost 7,000 persons across the Atlantic, most of it by air at a round-trip fare for Americans that amounts to about $350, is now under way. It has been approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board for Transocean Airlines and Seaboard and Western Airlines because the scheduled lines have no capacity to meet such a mass movement.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Sam Snead played virtually flawless golf today to score an eight-under-par 64 in the second round of the $15,000 Washington Star Open golf tournament. This, coupled with his 69 of yesterday, gave him a 133 and the lead at the halfway mark in the 72-hole event.

WARSAW, July 2 -- An extensive reorganization of the Polish Government during the last six months has eliminated the Socialists from almost all important posts and concentrated power in the hands of "old line" Communists, a review of official announcements showed today.

A SUMMER visitor in the Massachusetts seacoast town of Rockport might be bewildered by the wild whoops from Dr. Carey's youngest, Rowena, astride a tree limb, but her family and friends, inured to Row's goingson, understood that the little fat girl saw herself as a lean rider spurring a mettlesome mustang.
KINGSTON, N. Y., July 2 (AP) -- A new project for the study of brick manufacture was announced today by Dean John F. McMahon of the State College of Ceramics at Alfred University.

OF the scores of stamp bills which hopeful Congressmen have introduced in the House since Jan. 3, one of the few which stands a chance of being enacted into law is H. R. 4429, offered on April 28 by Representative Dean P. Taylor of New York for postal paper in "commemoration of the World's Skiing Championships to be held at Lake Placid, N. Y., and Aspen, Col." in 1950.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- The Air Force Association, sponsor of the National Air Fair, which will open here tomorrow, was told today by W. Stuart Symington, the Secretary for Air, that he was sure most Americans agreed "with your conviction that Uncle Sam's capacity to deliver the atomic bomb anywhere in the world is a great deterrent to war."
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 2 -- The Southwest looked to Washington this week for legislative aid in three of the region's main pursuits -- cattle, copper and cotton.

ASPEN, Col., July 2 -- Despite the apparent catastrophes that have overwhelmed Europe a new form of civilization is being germinated and "amidst anguish and sweat and misery a new pattern of human existence is about to be born," Jose Ortega y Gasset, Spanish philosopher, told the Goethe Bicentennial Convocation here tonight.

OMAHA, July 2 -- A wide variety of groups were engaged in controversy this week over electric power, and how to market it. The subject is of more than passing interest because the generating capacity within the ten-state Missouri River basin is scheduled to be expanded greatly during the next few years -- largely from sources created by many dams erected on the Missouri and its tributaries under the Pick-Sloan plan.

The leading theme for the discussions of factory propagandists in Russia this month is "Fulfillment of the Five-Year Plan Regarding Volume of Output in Four Years," the current issue of Bloknot Agitators (Agitator's Notebook), issued by the Moscow provincial and city committees of the Communist party, discloses.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Deposits of high-grade manganese ore, possibly amounting to more than 7,000,000 tons, in the Serra do Navio District of Brazil are reported in a bulletin from the Geological Survey, made public today. Samplings indicate the ores average about 50 per cent pure manganese.

ROME, July 2 -- The deadlock between the United States and Italy at the international tariff meeting at Annecy, France, is expected to be broken soon as Italian officials are understood to have assured Woodward Willoughby, head of the United States delegation, who is now here, that they would consider revision of what United States circles said were excessive customs duties.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed men's sport and dress shirts, men's Palm Beach suits, misses bathing suits, cotton dresses and silk shantung blouses, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

NEW DELHI, India, July 2 -- The Central Government is initiating strong efforts from New Delhi to curb lawlessness in Calcutta and at the same time to restore the Congress party position in West Bengal Province.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- The Soviet press is devoting more and more attention to United States economic prospects. The foreign news pages are crowded these days with items reporting declines on the New York Stock Exchange, the increase in American unemployment, the growing rift between Britain and the United States in the economic and financial sphere and the repercussions in the Marshall Plan countries of Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- A group of Senators today planned to challenge the State Department's China policy with a multimillion dollar program of military and economic aid to the Nationalist forces in China.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- No Strings, 3-year-old daughter of Occupation, today raced to a half-length triumph over Calumet Farm's Two Lea in the $28,150 Modesty Stakes for fillies and mares at Arlington Park. The long-striding filly, lightly weighted at 101 pounds and ridden by the veteran Freddy Smith, earned $19,150 for Mrs. John Marsch.

On the brink of defeat at 2 -- 5 in the fifth set, Irvin Dorfman, formerly of Yale, overcame Donald McNeill yesterday to reach the final round of the New York State tennis championship at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Two joint subcommittees were named today by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, chairman of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report, to study low-income families and Federal monetary and fiscal policies.

Ernest Maass in "Israel: New Names, Old Memories" speculates on the translation of the name of Dr. Chaim Weizmann into Hebrew. I am almost sure that Dr. Weizmann will not change his name to "Degani" because the meaning of "degani" is not wheat, but corn.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 -- The original letter written at New York on April 6, 1790, by President George Washington to King Louis XVI recalling Thomas Jefferson as Ambassador to France to serve as Secretary of State, today was placed in the historical collection of near-by Washington Jefferson College.
The entire vote in the recent referendum of the 50,000 members of the National Maritime Union, CIO, to bar from membership all Communist party adherents, has been thrown out, it was learned yesteday.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 2 -- Department store sales last week rallied over the previous week's figure, but still are running well below last year's record volume. Figures from the four major cities in the district for the four weeks ending June 25 showed dollar volume of sales to be 93 per cent of last year.

THE wide range of intellect and talent that goes into the making of films -- and into the usage of this medium as a mirror for the drama of our times -- has seldom been evidenced more sharply than it was hereabouts last week with the opening of two new pictures which are as far apart as the poles.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 2 (AP) -- Another effort to learn the amount of Frank Hague's wealth met with failure today. John Warren, Jersey City lawyer who has filed a $2,000,000 libel suit against the former Mayor of Jersey City, had obtained a subpoena ordering Mr. Hague to tell exactly how rich he is.

Colonial Williamsburg may look like a piece of eighteenth century preserved, but there are life and growth in the old town. On July 4 two "new" buildings -- an arsenal dating from 1716 and a guardhouse from 1755 -- will be formally dedicated and opened to the public.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, contended today that Britain's economic policy was jeopardizing the European Recovery Program. He urged that the United States "get tough" about it.

LONDON, July 2 -- The Central Land Board announced here today it had received 935,000 claims from landowners in England, Scotland and Wales for compensation for the loss of development values under the Town and Country Planning Act. The Government has set aside 300,000,000 (about $1,200,000,000) to compensate property owners.

LONDON, July 2 -- Following a personal investigation by four Labor Members of Parliament into the growing dock strike here, one of the four, Robert Mellish, announced today that he had sent to the Home Secretary for action by the Mi-5 (British Internal Security Police) information on what he termed "an organized attempt to disrupt the nation's economy."

Mayor O'Dwyer intervened last night in a labor dispute between the Holmes Electrical Protective Service and Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, and directed both parties to meet with officials of the city's Division of Labor Relations on Tuesday.

IT has become fashionable for novelist to protest that Broadway or Hollywood has mangled his immortal masterpiece. I must be insensitive to such wrongs because I find to my deep pleasure that Messrs. Oscar Hammerstein 2d, Richard Rodgers and Joshua Logan have improved my work at almost every point.

Since early spring 1947 the Taft- Hartley Act has held the center of the politico-industrial stage. This is not because the emergence of unexpected problems has required reconsideration of the Act. For twelve years the Wagner Act spawned a lusty brood of such problems, but they were not considered indications of any need for amendatory legislation.

PROFESSOR of English at Cornell, Mr. Daiches has set himself the interesting academic question: Why read a work of imaginative literature? His answer to the question becomes a text, not by way of defense but by reason of explanation.

I have just finished reading John Willig's "Class of '34 (Female) Fifteen Years Later." As a younger sister, Class of '38 (Female), I was fascinated -- and slightly horrified -- by what I should be in four years.

UNTIL recently, lilies have been a wayward race, stubbornly resisting hybridization. During the last few years, however, breeders have broken through the reluctance of species lilies to cross freely with each other, and are developing new types and colors for summer bloom in the garden.

ANOTHER opportunity for the summer vacationer to range far from home base and see new sights in the limited period of the average holiday was opened up yesterday when American Express in cooperation with Panagra (Pan American-Grace Airways) announced new South American aerial cruises.

IN an article on bibliography in the Encyclopaedia Britannica there is a pointed reference to type - facsimile forgeries "mostly of short pieces by Tennyson, George Eliot and A. C. Swinburne, printed (or supposed to have been printed -- for it is doubtful if some of these 'forgeries' ever had any originals) for circulation among friends."

MR. NASH is the vice president of United World Federalists, Inc. He believes that only a world government with real authority over the two billion individuals who inhabit this planet can bring law and order to society.

IN its distant objectives the foreign policy of the Soviet Union is less obscure and more coherent than that of any other country in the world. The objectives embrace the ultimate victory of the world proletariat under the leadership of Moscow.

ROME, July 2 -- The second United Nations World Health Assembly ended today after having dealt with about 200 agenda items. Before closing the session, delegates of sixty-four nations decided to meet again May 8, 1950, at Geneva.

An unexpected and strong increase in buying, which extended through both ferrous and non-ferrous metals, machinery and heavy plant equipment, developed here last week. Indicating the size of the upturn among typical industrial distributors, A. J. Chartier, purchasing agent for Carter, Milchman Frank, Inc., 139 Spring Street, said the increase for that company had amounted to 25 per cent more than average sales during comparable weeks of the past two months.

Although it operated for a short season, the Kende Galleries, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York's newest art auction house, grossed a total of $1,000,000 from December to June, it was announced yesterday.

A British crisis is confronting the world. It becomes obvious that to cure it it will be necessary for Great Britain either to change her policies or to change her Government. It is vital to understand the nature of this crisis. How is it possible that we should have a British crisis after the various forms of help extended by the United States since the end of the war?

Fifty-one years have dealt lightly with Gene Tunney, the man who won the heavyweight boxing championship from Jack Dempsey back in 1926 and two years later retired undefeated, then went on to become one of America's most successful business men.

MEXICO CITY, July 2 -- When Mexico's voters cast their ballots tomorrow for members of the Federal Chamber of Deputies, they also will decide the only two issues that have made the campaigning of recent months interesting:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 2 -- Col. Gen. Ivan Goshnyak, member of the Yugoslav Political Bureau, hold a meeting of the party organization of the Ministry of Defense yesterday that the Soviet Government and other Communist Information Bureau governments had halted all shipments of war materials to the Yugoslav Army and machinery for Yugoslavia's armament industry.

I RECENTLY read the article concerning the appointment of Rudolf Bing as the new general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. I am afraid it contains several incorrect statements which are obviously due to misinformation.

IT IS as risky as it is tempting to speculate on the future direction of American painting, to try to discern the main stream as it glides under choppy cross-currents. But to epitomize is invariably to distort. Better keep eyes long glued to pictures themselves before beginning to expound esthetics.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced last week that the City Planning Commission had approved an amendment to the 1949 capital budget to provide $967,500 to construct an all-year, indoor recreation center at St. Mary's Park at the intersection of St. Mary's Street and St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx.

THIS has been a good month: Sir Osbert Sitwell's autobiographical work. "Left Hand, Right Hand," has been rounded off brilliantly in the fourth and last volume, "Laughter in the Next Room." It might have petered out as it neared the dangerous present, but Sir Osbert dominates his work to the end, and his object -- to write a book "turreted and Gothic" -- has been achieved.
EVEN a hardened Hollywoodite, dropping in on Stage 8 at the Goldwyn Studio in recent days, would have been amazed and baffled at the goings-on.

It has just been called to my attention that Gertrude Samuels in "American Traitors: A Study in Motives" quoted me as saying I graduated from Bennington College. I should like to correct this impression. I have never attended Bennington College, nor have I ever stated so to anyone.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 2 -- One of Winged Foot's consistent tournament players, Art Lynch, scored a surprising victory today in the second round of the Ekwanok Country Club invitation for the Robert Todd Lincoln Cup when he eliminated a member of the 1949 United States Walker Cup team, Ray Billows, by 5 and 4.

Production of primary aluminum in the United States set a new peacetime record in May, it was announced yesterday by Donald M. White, secretary of the Aluminum Association, 420 Lexington Avenue. The 113,840,944 pounds reported by primary producers exceeded the output of any month since August, 1944, and topped the previous peacetime record set during May, 1948, by almost 3,000,000 pounds.

DAVID FARRAR, the stalwart British leading man, known here for his stint in that fine English film "Black Narcissus," will be featured as one of Jennifer Jones' leading men in "Gone to Earth," it was divulged last week by Michael Powell.

The first post-war distilled whiskies became four years old this month and available for bonded distribution. Liquor authorities here, making conservative estimates, said that between 75,000,000 and 80,000,000 gallons of these bonded spirits will become available to distillers during the next twelve months, ending June 30, 1950.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- A mild amount of hedging pressure sent wheat slightly lower on the Board of Trade today. Prices were influenced also by declines of 1 or 2 cents a bushel for cash wheat at major terminals. Local traders were inclined to get out of the market over the holiday week-end.

A list of general officers selected for promotion to the permanent grades of major general and brigadier general that was approved by President Truman on June 28 has been sent to the Senate for confirmation.

GOVERNMENT CAMP, Ore. -- Within sight of some of the nation's hottest weather, men and women will ski all summer this year on the long, apron-like slopes of Mount Hood. Oregon's loftiest peak, 11,245 feet high, looks down onto the arid Deschutes sagebrush plains where 110-degree July temperatures are comparatively common.

WILLIAM TENNYSON'S memoir of his father was conspicuous among the official Victorian biographies in which the twentieth century found considerably less than a full and convincing portrait of a man. But even a critic so favorably situated as Harold Nicolson could not gain access to facts sufficient to account for the deep melancholy of the young poet, his social protest in "Locksley Hall" and "Maud," and his great dependence on his friend, Arthur Hallam.

LATTINGTOWN, L. I., July 2 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock, former Long Island titleholder, and Arthur K. Atkinson Jr. of the host club captured the medal today in the mixed foursomes golf tournament at the Creek Club with a 70, one under par figures.

THE newly opened exhibition, "Twentieth Century Italian Art," at the Museum of Modern Art, provides a manifold experience. It offers an opportunity to become acquainted with modern work not widely known in this country.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 2 -- Three cosmic ray experiments designed to obtain information for use in the study of high energy nuclear reactions will be conducted this summer by a group of Princeton University physicists on the U. S. S. Norton Sound.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 2 -- Whirling Fox showed evidences of the ability that long was believed to be his when he flew across the finish line today to win the Long Branch Handicap before 21,458 fans at Monmouth Park.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that his appointment of Arthur Rosencrans, Brooklyn insurance man, as a member of the Board of Higher Education was not to be construed as a rebuff to Borough President John Cashmore, Democratic leader of Kings County.

BOSTON, July 2 (AP) -- Blix Donnelly, veteran righthander, tossed a six-hitter against the Braves for a 3-2 victory that moved the Phillies back into a third-place tie with the National League champions tonight before a crowd of 21,661. One of the Tribesmen's hits was rookie catcher Del Crandall's first major league home run.

Federal aid to education was endorsed last week by a group of teachers from various parts of the country who are taking courses in Columbia University's fiftieth annual summer session. The teachers, who will be students again for the six-week session, were interviewed as they rested in the campus small park known as "The Grove" after completing registration for the session opening this week.

A reaction against nationalism and state management is spreading rapidly throughout the world, Dannie N. Heineman, chairman of the standing committee of the Societe Financiere de Transports et D'Enterprises Industrielles (SOFINA) said yesterday.

BELGRADE. PERMANENT mobilization, material and psychological, is one of the fundamental characteristics of life in the People's Democracies. As a result, the mores, social attitudes and psychology of the peoples of Eastern Europe are being diverted from the mainstream of European culture toward new cultural patterns represented by the Soviet type of civilization.

THE remarkable painting that is reproduced on these pages offers a preview of some of the masterpieces of the Vienna museums which will come in the fall to the National Gallery in Washington and subsequently to the Metropolitan Museum in New York, the Chicago Art Institute and San Francisco's De Young Museum.

PROMPTED by a visit to the Museum of Modern Art's exhibition of fifty photographs by Julia Margaret Cameron, nineteenth century amateur photographer, a reader asks, "Why were the photographers of that early period so much better than they are today?"

America's traditional swap of urban and rural populations to celebrate the Independence Day week-end had virtually completed the first phase of its operation last night. City dwellers were renewing kinship with nature and country folk were getting the feel of the good pavement.
CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP) -- The Indians put on another demonstration of cream-puff hitting today and dropped a 4-2 decision to Karl Drews and the Browns.

The presentation to Congress of "stand-by" wartime legislation -- one of the measures Bernard M. Baruch advocated as a step in proper mobilization planning -- has been indefinitely delayed under the new concept of the National Security Resources Board's functions as outlined by the President and interpreted by Dr. John R. Steelman, acting chairman.

TO persons who are considering buying a used car for a summer vacation trip, the National Safety Council has offered some timely suggestions which apply to any such purchase, whether the objective is a cross-country tour or not. With safety as its basic theme, the council has warned prospective buyers against being led astray by external good looks and advises a thorough examination and tests of the car before any decision is made.
NEW DELHI, India, July 2 -- The new taxe imposed by the provincial and state governments are being resisted in dramatic fashion, particularly by hotels, restaurants and movie theatres.
BOSTON, July 2 -- Farmers aphensive about their crops and householders watering sun-seared lawns shared drought worries throughout most of New England as the driest June in years drew to a close.
GENEVA, July 2 -- A sense of being in the midst of an economic crisis has spread across Western Europe during the past few weeks.

A TIGHT red dress, a pair of sling pumps and nylon stockings are the simple but vivid symbols of evil in this first novel of Texan farm life. "For want of a shoe, the horse was lost" -- and for a burning desire for worldly trappings, Pearl loses her soul as well as her life.

Proud and happy, 10-year-old Marian Hawco -- with braces on her legs and supported by crutches -- stood on the second floor landing of her aunt and uncle's home in Brooklyn yesterday noon. Then, without aid, she walked down the flight of stairs.
PRAGUE, July 2 -- In a temporal sense, the struggle between the Roman Catholic Church and the state in Czechoslovakia is nearly over and the state, as was a foregone conclusion, has won.

JUST before the turn of the century the Baltimore Orioles had gained the reputation of being the roughest, toughest and snarlingest bunch of hell cats ever assembled. It was a team of John McGraw, Hughey Jennings, Joe Kelley, Wee Willie Keeler, Uncle Wilbert Robinson and the like. They were so tough that they never got hurt.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- This has been a week of political crisis in Congress, and President Truman's forces have been very heavily thrown back.

CAIRO, June 26 -- Egypt is struggling with the problem of her own xenophobia and the failure or refusal of a large section of her immigrants to assimilate and adopt Egyptian nationality as a way of life and not merely as a legal status.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 2 -- The Bulgarian announcement last April 14 that Premier Dimitrov had received sick leave in the Soviet Union was followed by another that said Vasil Kolarov, dean of the Bulgarian Communist party and Foreign Minister, had taken over Mr. Dimitrov's governmental functions as acting Premier.

ERICH VON STROHEIM, one of the foremost directors of early-day Hollywood, is back in the cinema city playing the part of a silent screen director in a modern talking picture about the movies, "Sunset Boulevard." Ironically, in the picture von Stroheim will be seen directing Gloria Swanson, whom he actually directed in 1928, when they were both eminent film figures.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP) -- Southpaw Johnny Vander Meer was as hot as the Midwest heat wave tonight as he pitched the Reds to a 3-to-0 victory over the Cardinals. Not a Redbird base runner reached second base on the 34-year-old veteran, who allowed only three singles:

WISHBONE flower (Torenia fourneri) is a plant that actually likes hot weather. A distinctive bloom by itself or in the flower border, this little annual has a commendable record in my garden notebook.

SOUTH FALLSBURG, N. Y., July 2 -- An appeal to the countries in the Soviet bloc to open their doors for the free emigration of Jews to Israel was made by S. Z. Shragai, of the executive committee of the Jewish Agency of Israel, at tonight's session of the twenty-sixth national convention of Hapoel Hamizrachi, Religious Labor Zionists of America.

John L. Lewis' 400,000 bituminous coal miners are now on their annual ten-day holiday. By the time they are ready to return to work the present contract between Mr. Lewis and the mine operators will have expired. Under traditional procedure if a new contract has not been signed by the end of the vacation period one might expect the mines to remain idle until it has been.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- Pre-holiday retail disposal of general merchandise showed a pick-up here. Merchandisers figure average retail prices are now at least 15 per cent under a year ago. Philadelphia women's apparel stores sales last week were under a year ago by only 3 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- The small manufacturer -- who conducts 70 per cent of the nation's industrial enterprises -- has been warned to build himself a life-raft of "paper work" if he is to survive in the sink-or-swim competition now at hand.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 2 -- There are strong well-founded indications here that Jews and Arabs, working independently of the Lausanne conference, are making progress on a compromise concerning the refugee problem. There are authoritative reports that some form of border control for civilian traffic will soon be announced.

THE Screen Writers Guild awarded plaques last week to the writers of four films selected by the membership as the best-written American screen drama, musical, Western and comedy of 1948 -- respectively, "The Snake Pit," "Easter Parade," "Treasure of the Sierra Madre" and "Sitting Pretty."

LONDON, July 2 (UP) -- A leading British weekly said today that one reason why American tennis stars at Wimbledon aren't too popular is that the public doesn't like to see a man win because "he has more steaks behind his racket."
NORFOLK, Va., July 2 (AP) -- Rear Adm. J. E. Whelchel will swap his brass hat for a football coach's cap this week to become head mentor of the Washington Redskins.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company did not violate the law when it discharged eighty-nine foremen who refused to perform maintenance work during a 1946 strike.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- House investigators say there is evidence the Communist party will dive underground if its leaders are convicted of conspiring to overturn the American Government. Eleven of them are on trial now in New York and a twelfth will be tried later.

So many "electronic brains" have made their appearance in the last ten years that this department finds it hard to keep up with them. The "brains" are for the most part calculators that perform mathematical operations with a speed that no human lightning calculator can match.
Dust costs the American Telephone and Telegraph Company $10,000,000 a year.
John Willig's "Class of '34 (Female) Fifteen Years Later" fails to bring out one ominous fact: the failure of the college girls to replace themselves.

I regret that some inaccuracies have crept into the biographical notes which the press department of the Metropolitan Opera sent out on the occasion of my recent appointment. Although these inaccuracies were, of course, inadvertent, and not due to any misstatement by myself, and refer to appointments I held some sixteen to twenty years back, I would feel happier if matters were put right.

The vote of the coaches in the All-America Football Conference for the most valuable player of 1948 resulted in a tie between Otto Graham of Cleveland and Frankie Albert of San Francisco. Each will receive a trophy, Commissioner O. O. Kessing has announced.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Sometime next week President Truman will send to Congress one of the most important messages of 1949. It will be his mid-year report on the state of the nation's economy, prepared by his Council of Economic Advisers.

LONDON, July 2 (Reuters) -- After losing half its wickets for only 95 runs Gloucestershire put together a total of 232 against the New Zealand cricket team on the opening day of the three-day match at Bristol today. The touring team scored 73 for two wickets in reply.

In producing a new high record tonnage of raw steel in the first six months of 1949, the steel industry finally brought to an end the critical post-war shortage of this basic commodity and, according to industry spokesmen, proved that existing steel facilities are more than adequate to fill the nation's needs in the future.

THIS is a novel with the summery quality of Sargent's paintings of girls in white dresses sitting on the green grass, and with something of the amiable lightness and elegance of that series of pictures. It is a love story without any intrusion of disruptive passion.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 2 -- Three pairs of beavers brought to this area in 1920 by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission as an experiment are making it possible for thousands of city families to enjoy outdoor meals beneath canopies of lush green foliage despite the record drought.

PARIS, July 2 -- Members of the Interparliamentary Union meeting in Strasbourg today adopted recommendations to be offered to the European Council and Assembly sponsored by the Western Union that will hold its initial meeting there in August.

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 2 -- The hot, dry weather that is plaguing farmers was a boon today to sailplane enthusiasts from all parts of the country who gathered here for the sixteenth national soaring contest. Twenty-eight of them left at noon to see how far they could travel without the aid of mechanical power.

BECAUSE Gunther Ewart had made an enormous pile of money in the construction business, his relatives felt themselves to be the elite of the earth -- the usual snobbery of a well-heeled family. Their story begins durig World War I, when, following the old man's death, his children become engaged in a polite but bitter struggle for full shares of the golden stream that flows from "the Company."

A JAYHAWKER, as defined in the introduction, was an outlaw who preyed upon the freight wagons carrying Confederate cotton across Texas to Mexico during the Civil War. The Jayhawker of the title is "Captain" Christopher Dawn, a devil-may-care fellow with a dream of empire.

Greater protection to owners of trade-marks, particularly in cases where rights are contested, will be the chief objectives of a series of amendments to the Lanham Trade-Mark Act proposed by private legal and trade groups, it was learned last week

IT would be quite appropriate if the Goethe revival, inspired by the arithmetical occasion of a bicentennial anniversary, should coincide with a Schweitzer revival, celebrating the living presence, the first visit to America, of one of the very few great men of our time.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 2 -- There was but a delicate easterly breeze that went up north east, faded and needed tonic all during the championship regatta of the Port Washington Yacht Club today. The event was the first of three to be carried through Monday.

Thomas H. Keating has been named general manager of the Chevrolet Motor division of the General Motors Corporation, succeeding W. F. Armstrong, granted a leave of absence because of illness. Announcement was made also of the appointment of Louis C. Krauss as stock transfer agent for the corporation, succeeding Arthur B. Hull, who has retired.

LOS ANGELES -- This city has always been a bridge-playing center and, more than any place except New York, a great part of the playing is done in bridge clubs. In the middle Nineteen Thirties Tom Stoddard's club, with sixty-five tables going afternoon and night, was one of the spectacles of the West Coast.
Your splendid editorial on "hysteria" will help steady the national ship. May I add a parallel thought?

NEWARK, N. J., July 2 -- The possibility that State Senator Elmer H. Wene, wealthy Vineland chicken farmer, will abandon his Democratic candidacy for Governor in the fall campaign against Alfred E. Driscoll, Republican encumbent, appeared stronger today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- Although retail activity last week was still below the comparable period of last year, a slight recovery was noted. Areas which showed marked declines a week ago made comebacks of slight to outstanding degrees. Outstanding in the recovery was Portland.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 2 -- Slovak peasants armed with scythes, pitchforks and clubs are standing guard around their Roman Catholic priests to shield them from Communist police, ...

One hundred and thirty-five teachers who gave up part of their summer vacations to go back to school completed last week a unique educational project designed to counteract academic "over-specialization."

WILMINGTON, N. Y. -- About a mile from here up the road leading to the top of Whiteface Mountain lives Santa Claus. He was set up in business last week, with a red suit and flowing beard and a hearty laugh for children who are able to persuade their parents to turn off from the Whiteface Memorial Highway for a visit to Santa Claus' Workshop.

NEITHER heat nor drought lessens the effectiveness of flower arrangements throughout the house. Simple combinations of flowers or fruit are always refreshing, and the accent need not be on quantity but on availability.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Wary of the shifting economic situation, officials planning the military budget for the fiscal year 1951 will determine the dollar amount of their requests for the armed services on the basis of Aug. 1 price levels, it was learned today.

A segment of the finest in this country's sea-fighting strength sailed into New York harbor at 9 A. M. yesterday as the United States Navy's Task Force 89 of thirteen units appeared for a three-day holiday visit in which a majority of the vessels will be open for public inspection.

YEARS ago, the mother of a big family told us that she never saw her first two babies undressed until she got them home from the hospital. It wasn't until her third child arrived that she had the "nerve" to unwrap the baby when brought to her from the nursery. "And did I get a calling down!" she said.

The merger of the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast and the Pacific American Shipowners Association has become a reality with the first meeting of the board of directors of the Pacific Maritime Association, successor to the two groups, according to an announcement made here.

THE citizen of Manhattan, deciding that he cannot have lived the full life without sitting in the stands at Ebbets Field and watching the Brooklyn Dodgers play a baseball game, generally puts on quite a performance of his own.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 -- Reopening of the coal mines last week caused business in the Pittsburgh district to return to nearly the same level as in the week before the stoppage of work in the coal industry, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
CAN she bake a cherry pie? She should with the gadgets newly available for perfect pastry.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- Carl R. Gray Jr., Veterans Administrator, in a letter to Representative John E. Rankin, chairman of the House Veterans committee, turned thumbs down today on a proposal by the [Hoover] Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government that he said tended to limit veterans hospital care to men with service-connected ailments.

We live at the bottom of an ocean of air -- what meteorologists call the "troposphere." The upper surface of this aerial ocean is not sharply defined. To be sure, there is the stratosphere which lies above the troposphere, but where the stratosphere ends nobody knows. Probably there is no end.

ANDREW JACKSON, seventh President of the United States, was, as Miss Nolan points out, the first "people's President." His predecessors had been men of substance, blessed with education and culture. Young Andy Jackson, an orphaned farm boy sprung from the Carolina soil, made his own way to the top, a shining example to the young republic that democracy means what it says.
John W. Gates, editor of The Daily Worker and a defendant in the trial of eleven Communists here, had a grievance yesterday. He complained that he had been released from prison too soon.
Four hundred and ninety-one days from today -- on Nov. 7, 1950 -- the voters will elect the Eighty-second Congress.

RCA - VICTOR'S pint - sized, vinylite records, which revolve at 45 turns per minute, have been on the market for some weeks, as have been the special attachments needed to play them. Since the company was a bit slow in providing reviewers with the proper turntables on which to play the disks, there has been no report on them in this corner.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Andy Victor, assistant football coach at George Washington University, has resigned to take a similar post at Kingston (Pa.) High School where he starred in three sports.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 2 -- Ohio political leaders, puzzling over recent statements by Democratic Gov. Frank J. Lausche, expressed wonderment today as to whether the Democrats had not only lost their strongest candidate but possibly much of the power of their main issue against Republican Senator Robert A. Taft in the "key" contest of the 1950 Congressional elections.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Truman ordered a general housecleaning and inventory of government property today under the authority of a "housekeeping" reorganization act passed and signed last Thursday.

WASHINGTON. THIS generation of Americans has no intention of ending its days in a poorhouse. Nor do Americans intend to spend old age as an unwanted burden on their children. Californians have just feathered their nests by voting to guarantee most oldsters $75 a month. In Louisiana, the new Long regime, with the aid of Federal funds, is now paying an average of $47 a month to eight of every ten persons over 65.

Independence Day is perhaps our most firmly established secular day of celebration. That the date July 4 should be appropriately marked seems to have been almost overlooked, even in Philadelphia, on the first anniversary of the Declaration, but on July 2, 1777, arrangements for a dinner were quickly thrown together in the City of Brotherly Love, and Congress took an adjournment for the day.

PARIS, July 2 -- Sean MacBride, Irish Minister for External Affairs who sat in on recent meetings of the Marshall Plan Council, left Paris today, urging the summoning of a world economic conference to discuss means of balancing world trade.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 2 -- Most of the South's textile mills will close down from one to three weeks starting Monday to give workers their annual vacations. In sharp con trast with a year ago, when high production was being maintained within the industry, employes will take their holiday with a feeling of some uncertainty about their jobs.

BERLIN, July 2 -- In Berlin, where the tumult and the shouting never seem to die, recurrent crises have a diminishing effect upon citizens of the city's Western sectors. This week, in which life in the Western sectors was supposed to be moving steadily back toward normality after thirteen months of blockade, rioting and strikes occurred.

SO far as this department is aware, only once has an historical novel been introduced and recommended to the public by a professional historian. This happened recently in the case of "The Golden Warrior," Hope Muntz's splendid re-creation of the Norman conquest of England, for which G. M. Trevelyan, one of the most distinguished of living historians, wrote an enthusiastic foreword.

TRAFFIC regulations are absolutely necessary and should be strictly enforced -- against the other fellow. This opinion, I gather from my professional experience, is held by quite a segment of New York's millions of drivers. Furthermore, so the opinion goes, when you are compelled to appear in court with a summons, any reasonable judge should be profoundly impressed with your story that the alleged violation was surrounded with all kinds of extenuating circumstances.

JOHNNY'S favorite friend on Broomstick Hill is the old professor. Both love animals, and the professor has many pets and animal friends that delight Johnny. One spring day Johnny takes a trip into the woods and finds a duck with a twisted wing.

Experiments in economy measures have been seen more frequently in stores here as retailers seek new operating cost reduction methods and re-introduce old ones. Top management has been looking "anywhere and everywhere" for places to cut costs because it is now plainly evident that they must take such steps to keep going on a profit basis.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- The Pirates made a triple play today that had even the umpires bewildered for a time while defeating the Cubs, 8 -- 3.

Many business organizations are reducing budgets for personnel administration in the current drive by top management to reduce costs, personnel officials reported last week. The action is resulting in discharging of employes at the "bottom rung" of personnel administration, while middle and top level executives are performing many more functions than they did before the beginning of this year, they said.

THE big vacation season is now under way, and with thousands of workers in industry enjoying it who never enjoyed it before on a paid basis. Others, unfortunately, are on enforced vacations without pay because production in their lines outran demand at prevailing prices.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Administration chiefs were reported ready to abandon at the last minute today a speed-up strategy for Congressional action on military aid to Western Europe.

OF these four baseball books, two concern the Cleveland Indians, Boudreau's book being his autobiography (or part of it, anyhow; Lou will not see his thirty-second birthday until July 17), while Lewis' volume is a remarkably complete history of the Indians from their first game against the Cincinnati Red Stockings in 1869 -- Cincinnati 25, Cleveland 6 -- to the final game of the 1948 World Series -- Cleveland 4, Boston Braves 3.

SOMEHOW, it's a surprise when you meet an author who is different from the idea you've formed of him through having read his work. Particularly when the two ideas are diametrically opposed. That is pretty much how it was when this reporter met Philip Wylie the other day.

AS the title suggests, this tale is told in the first person by the chief character -- a woman trying to cope reasonably and sympathetically with two young, polite, but hostile stepchildren and a writer husband so engrossed in his work that he is unaware of domestic tension.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 2 -- With the establishment of the Neue Zeitung in three cities on a daily basis, a United States Military Government official said today that the paper was entirely purged of any neo-Nazi or Fascist influences it might have had, and that from now on it might safely be regarded as the spokesman of United States policy in the German language.

Financial markets gave scant recognition last week to several important developments affecting labor and credit. Prices securities turned firmer at the week-end in dull trading; the bulk of activity was centered in Government bonds in the over-the-counter market.

PINE CAMP, N. Y., July 2 -- National Guard troops from New York, New Jersey and the New England area arrived here today by special trains to start the first of four two-week training periods for Guardsmen and organized reservists.

Rare eighteenth-century Japanese prints recently purchased from the collection of the late Louis V. Ledoux are on exhibition in the Print Room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. With its purchase, the library now has one of the largest collections of the work of Kitagawa Utamaro, distinguished artist of figure prints. Five of his color woodcuts are in the display.

Although pre-holiday shopping was brisk with cooler weather prevailing, sales in New York department stores declined about 11 per cent last week, showing little variation from the current dollar volume trend. Departments featuring fashion accessories, bathing suits and summer apparel were the most active.

Dawn comes early. First-light touches the horizon and stars begin to fade. The whippoorwill, who should have cried himself hoarse only a few hours before, begins to call again; and up the hillside the robins stir and whistle their first tentative notes. The deep shadows on the hilltops resolve themselves into trees against the lightening sky.

PARIS -- Two international bodies have recently spent several days here discussing ways to make life more interesting for one of the most important men in the European economy -- the American tourist. This much-caricatured individual was the subject of conferences conducted by the European Travel Commission and the Tourism Committee of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

In the Eighteen Nineties, soon after his appointment as Director of the Bureau of Laboratories of the Department of Health, William Halleck Park, eminent bacteriologist, and his staff developed a diphtheria antitoxin that was manufactured and sold, with the proceeds going to develop a program of medical research.

Temporarily overshadowed in public attention by the Alger Hiss and Judith Coplon cases, the trial of eleven Communist leaders on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate overthrow of the Government by force and violence approached last week the end of its first half year in United States District Court.

With each team hitting four homers, including two by Brooklyn's Peewee Reese, the Dodgers rallied yesterday to crush the Giants, 13 -- 8. As the Yankees routed the Senators, 10 -- 2, Joe DiMaggio accepted an invitation from Manager Lou Boudreau to join the American League squad for the All-Star game.

TOKYO, July 2 -- Allied Headquarters today approved measures to curb widespread poaching by Japanese fishing vessels beyond the "MacArthur" line, established after the surrender, which has been the subject of international complaint.

IF your grandmother can tell a right cross from a right hook, and your mother can distinguish between a half nelson and a hammer lock, the chances are they have been pupils of Dennis James. That gentleman, who has struggled along Video Row since its infancy, probably is the only person to parlay announcing and mother into a million-dollar jackpot.
FRANKFORT, Germany, June 28 -- German press reaction has been critical of the new Association of Independent Germans which was founded under the auspices of former Nazis last week.

The end of the first half of this year finds virtually every industry in the midst of a difficult readjustment job. The degree of the readjustment so far made in the transition from a post-war boom period to normal peace-time operations, however, varies from industry to industry.

FOR the past several months members of the Television Writers Guild, a branch of the Authors League of America, have been conducting a series of panel discussions on some of the problems of their craft. At the last meeting -- ten days ago -- one writer raised the provocative point of whether television, in attempting to provide visual entertainment hour after hour seven days a week, was not destined to the mediocre.

THE most vocal apostles of air power -- Italy's Giulio Douhet, Alexander de Seversky and our own "Billy" Mitchell -- were heretics in the days before World War II. To be sure, they had their fanatical supporters -- men who flew "into the wild blue yonder" -- but most people relegated them to the military lunatic fringe.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- As a result of June's prolonged hot spell, officials of the Palisades Interstate Park report that the number of hikers on the trails in the Bear Mountain-Harriman section and at the permanent camp beside Lake Tiorati has already set a record for the early summer season.

IN his June 5 review in these columns of the McGraw-Hill edition of "The Hoover Commission Report," David Cushman Coyle pointed out that this report was available in several other forms at different prices and ended by questioning what legitimate use this "McGraw-Hill version" could have.

AT the end of the nineteenth century, Europeans could back with complacent confidence upon the road which society had traveled in the four centuries since the Renaissance and Reformation. It had been a steady if painful ascent toward more and more liberty.

NEW trends in pest control for fruit trees show many changes in the kinds of materials that are being tested. However, it takes time to learn the effect of a new chemical on natural enemies and to determine the extent of its toxicity to other animals.

ONE of the variables that usually escapes the attention of those who see parallels between our troubles and those of the Romans of the late Empire is this: the Romans had no printing presses from which rolled book after book diagnosing their ills and recommending therapeutic measures.

TOKYO, July 2 -- If he were solely responsible for Japan's economic policies, Takayoshi Aoki, director general of the Economic Stabilization Board, declared in an interview today, he would remove all controls over raw materials, allocations and prices as rapidly as possible.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP) -- The bats of Pat Mullin and Don Kolloway furnished the punch Detroit's Tigers needed today to wrest a 7-to-6 victory from the Chicago White Sox in eleven innings.

The letters received during the past few weeks from American anglers who spent considerable time and money on a salmon fishing trip to New Brunswick and Nova Scotia rivers, indicate that unless these provinces provide more adequate regulation and enforcement they will find quite a reduction in tourist income.

DETROIT, July 2 -- A Louisville business man, Wild Bill Cantrell, who'd rather risk his neck driving fast boats and fast autos than eat, demonstrated this afternoon on a sunny and smooth Detroit River before 200,000 spectators that the best speed-boat combination in America is the red and shiny My Sweetie with him crouched in the single cockpit behind its steering wheel.

The importance of the role of industrial advertising in making contact with all buying influences within a company is emphasized in a study of industrial purchasing practices soon to be released to members of the National Industrial Advertisers Association, it was announced yesterday.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 2 -- The executive committee of the Southern Regional Council disclosed today that it had sent to the Governors of the thirteen Southern states a letter urging the appointment of Negro citizens to policy-making boards in the field of public service.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- While it may be true that the Yankees never know what constitutes a safe lead when Tommy Byrne, their unpredictable southpaw is on the mound, they handed him a 5-0 bulge in the first two innings at Griffith Stadium today and this sufficed to defeat the Senators before 12,049 fans.

MYSTERY-MONGERS who write under more than one name do so usually for personal and economic rather than creative reasons; it's hard, for instance, to see any real difference between Ellery Queen and Barnaby Ross, or John Dickson Carr and Carter Dickson.

Somewhere around 2 o'clock last Friday morning an agreement announced in Paris on behalf of the European Marshall Plan Council put at least a temporary end to a crisis which might have been serious indeed for Western Europe. The question at issue was to what extent trade could be stimulated among the Marshall Plan countries by making their currencies more freely convertible.

IN the midst of the summer heat, some heavy thinking has turned up to the effect that radio and not television is still the big baby of the broadcasting industry. Jack Benny eased his foot from the TV throttle last week in remarking: "Everybody seems to think that radio will still be the thing next season and my television show is far from definite."

BERLIN, July 2 -- John J. McCloy, who arrived in Berlin today to assume the post of United States Military Governor in Germany, revealed a spirit of cautious optimism that included the anticipation of future conferences with Soviet leaders in Germany.

Reports on the examination of more than 2,000,000 factory workers throughout the country indicate that one out of every three needs eyesight correction, according to W. T. Cameron, of the American Optical Company, Southbridge, Mass.
When two military trucks of a four-truck convoy collided and caught fire at Broadway and 134th Street yesterday at 8:05 A. M., five National Guardsmen were injured.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 2 -- Jack Kelly of Philadelphia, a former bricklayer's son, won the Diamond Sculls today by twenty lengths in the 110-year-old Henley Regatta's first all-American final.

THERE was a legend in the Rio Grande country, more than a hundred years ago, that a silver horse, El Soledad, raced the wild stretches of the land. El Soledad was a descendant of an Arab stallion brought to Mexico by Cortes.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Frustration in Congress of labor's demand for full repeal of the Taft-Hartley law, an Indiana oil boom and charges of "a flagrant and open anti-Semitic policy" being carried on in certain resort areas of northern Wisconsin attracted attention this week of Central Westerners.

Two brothers who had been sought in connection with a fatal assault on a National Guard warrant officer on Friday night were being questioned by the police last night after one of them surrendered and the other later was picked up.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass. -- About $8,000,000 has been appropriated by the Massachusetts Highway Commission for completion of a four-lane, limited access highway right down the spine of Cape Cod from the Sagamore Bridge over the Cape Cod Canal to Provincetown.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 2 -- Ralph Copp of St. Louis, who is a consulting milk engineer, left by air for Paris today to serve as consultant in the milk-conservation program of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

The Rutgers University Human Relations Workshop, designed to combat racial and religious tensions, will hold its third annual session July 5 through Aug. 12. Dr. Clarence E. Partch, dean of the School of Education, said that interest in the workshop and the in-service human relations courses was outrunning the university facilities available.

In "What Prospects for the Class of '49?" Messrs. Wolfbein and Goldstein omit a rather important source of dislocation in the applicant-job question -- the matter of regional maladjustments. Some locations, well served by educational institutions, have an excess of available personnel for which another area may have an urgent need.

STANTON, Del., July 2 -- Sun Bahram scored what trackmen called the most stunning upset in Delaware Park history today by winning the twelfth running of the $20,000 added Leonard Richards Stakes through disqualification of Capot, who finished first by half a length.

CANTON, China. July 2 (UP) -- The official Central News Agency reported today that Nationalist forces had checked the Communist advance along the China coast and driven back a spearhead in the interior.

IT looks very much as if the Sadler's Wells Ballet from London is going to have a fantastic success, at least as far as attendance goes, in its first American season at the Metropolitan Opera House for four weeks beginning Oct. 9.

The Gdynia America liner Batory returned here yesterday afternoon for the second time since she was used by Gerhart Eisler as the means of escaping from this country in May. Once more the vessel was the subject of special attention from a detachment of seventeen United States Immigration and Naturalization Service border patrolmen in civilian clothes. Around-the-clock watches were set.
ST. LOUIS, July 2 -- Max Lanier, who stirred the baseball world by jumping to the Mexican League when he was the National League's leading pitcher three years ago, rejoined the Cardinals today.
YOUR article, "Films For Children," which appeared last Sunday, prompts me to respond.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Joltin' Joe DiMaggio, now in a roaring comeback after being a fixture among the New York Yankee halt and lame, will be back doing business as usual at the All-Star stand in Brooklyn July 12.

Multitudes of taxpaying citizens know what it is to overestimate or underestimate their incomes, and consequently to overpay or underpay their obligations to the Federal Government. The Federal Government itself, as the recurring Treasury statements on July first of each year show, is likewise uncertain about the future.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P.) -- The United Mine Workers Journal said today that the three-day work week ordered by John L. Lewis could be continued twenty weeks without hurting the national economy.

The Maritime Commission issued invitations yesterday to thirteen shipyards to bid for the construction of two 17,940-gross-ton combination passenger and truck trailer vessels for the Pacific Coast Steamship Company's proposed service between San Francisco and Long Beach, Calif.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Steel production in the Chicago area averaged 99.5 per cent of capacity in May, a survey of Chicago business conditions disclosed last week. Production to date has held up well, with a figure of 95.5 per cent of capacity for the week ended June 25, compared with the national average of 84.5 per cent.

DURHAM, N. H., July 2 -- American schools should take a forceful role in helping to strengthen and maintain the democratic way of life, 500 leading educators asserted today at the closing session of the National Conference on the Professional Growth of Teachers.

DURHAM, N. H., July 2 -- Despite the desperate shortage of qualified elementary school teachers, far too great a proportion of those preparing to teach are going into the secondary field. As a result the primary grades, particularly in the rural districts, face an even more acute shortage.

IT was nine years after his father's death that George Carey brought his young suburban English bride to Ceylon. There she was to be the first mistress of Elephant Walk, the greatest house in size and hospitality in the colony.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 2 -- The end of actual fighting in Palestine has given the Arab states time to return to family quarrels, and they have done so with such enthusiasm that an entirely new line-up of the Middle Eastern nations may occur -- according to reports in Arab circles, it will occur.
THE HAGUE, July 2 (AP) -- World tin concentrate production declined from 13,400 tons in March to 12,900 in April, the International Tin Study Group reported today.
SANDWICH, England, July 2 (AP) -- Amateur Frank Stranahan and Pro Johnny Bulla fired red hot scores today in their final tune-ups for Monday's start of the five-day British open golf championship.

Music IREGARD any human being, who, with proper instruction, cannot learn to draw reasonably 'well a, to all intents and purposes, a moron. He is in a stage of culture actually anterior to that of the Cro-MagrLons. As for a human being incapable of'writing passable verse, .he simply does not exist.

Three women who lease forty-two apartments in the overcrowded building at 545 West 111th Street were questioned for several hours yesterday by five aides of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. They were directed to return on Tuesday.

Harold E. Broadbooks of the University of Michigan finds that Western chipmunks exercise exclusive food-gathering rights over established areas. For females, the home range has an average extent of 2.36 acres; for males, 3.8 acres.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Self-employed persons would pay social security taxes at a rate one and one-half times that now paid by other classifications of employes under terms of a bill tentatively approved by the House Ways and Means Committee, it was learned today.

THAT called-for march on City Hall by the foes of censorship never did take place. It wasn't necessary. Apparently the threat itself was enough to stuff the bill right back where it had been, in the barrel, where show business hopes it will remain.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stockyards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Oneida, Ltd., one of the nation's major producers of silverware, has announced that it will cut the working hours of its 3,626 employes from forty to thirty-two on July 18 but will pay for thirty-six.

A DRAMATIC airplane shot of a Nicaraguan volcano in action has won first prize for H. M. Weis of Pensacola, Fla., in the first section (black-and-white division) of the Grand Leica Triple Competition. Other winners in this class were Dr. W. A. Daniel Jr., Montgomery, Ala.; Fritz Neugass, New York; Will Rapport, Brookline, Mass., and H. M. Smallwood, Nutley, N. J.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal Campaign for $250,000,000, in a semi-annual report to the national campaign executive committee yesterday, announced that 151,000 Jewish refugee immigrants had entered Israel in the first six months of this year with the assistance of Appeal agencies.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 2 -- Alemite, a 5-year-old bay owned by the Newport Stock Farm of South Plainfield, N. J., and driven by Del Cameron, captured the honors in the South Dakota, the junior free-for-all pace that featured the closing session of the Grand Circuit's two-week stand at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. A crowd of 24,934 attended.

The Giants, swinging on the ball in their best manner of old, took to trading blows with their arch foes, the Dodgers, at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but somewhere along the line they got themselves badly short-changed.

The polo limelight today and tomorrow will be focused on Bostwick Field, Westbury, L. I., as high-goal stars ride in games starting at 3:30 P. M. Today's contest will be a return one between Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes and Bostwick Field.

Private sales of United States food products to European countries can be increased three-fold under proper marketing conditions, Nathan Cummings, chairman of the board of Consolidated Grocers Corporation, largest wholesale group in the country, declared here last week.

BY now, the vegetable plot is already the source of early crops. But there is still much that can be done to increase production and to prolong the season. There is even plenty of time for further sowing.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 2 -- King Leopold's chances of being recalled to Belgium received a further setback today by the refusal of both Socialist and Liberal parties to enter into a coalition with the Catholic Christian-Socialists led by Paul van Zeeland who has been trying since last Tuesday to form a government.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 2 -- A fleet of thirty-five craft sailed tonight on the fifty-mile Stratford Shoals race of the Riverside Yacht Club. This is the eighteenth annual event, with the finish line to be established tomorrow off Cos Cob Harbor. A Coast Guard cutter followed the fleet and will help to monitor the turn tomorrow morning at the Stratford Linght.

SEOUL, Korea, July 2 -- Signs of a steady drift to military control over civil affairs in South Korea under the expanding national army are viewed with mounting alarm by the top-ranking United States military advisers here.

ROANOKE, Va., July 2 (AP) -- A Hustings Court jury today found Lee (Buddy) Scott, 16 years old, guilty of first degree murder in the church slaying of Dana Marie Weaver and fixed his punishment at ninety-nine years imprisonment.

Fall buying was brisk in the wholesale apparel market here last week, but retail budgets generally were on the conservative side with sufficient open-to-buy remaining to take advantage of any further change in prices or styles of fall merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 2 -- The seventy-sixth annual Chautauqua Assembly will open here tomorrow, and advance registrations indicate that last year's attendance of 50,000 will be equaled or surpassed.

In the days of four-power administration of occupied Germany, the seat of Allied authority was a huge building in the American sector of Berlin. There, in what had once been the home of the Berlin judiciary, the Allied Control Council met. In the spring of 1948, when four-power government broke down, the Russians and most Western officials pulled out. Last week there was activity in the building once again.

LONDON, July 2 -- For the third straight year Miss Louise Brough and Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont met in the final of the Wimbledon women's singles championship today and in a long, tense match of almost faultless tennis Miss Brough retained the title she took from her close friend and strongest challenger last year.

THE National Broadcasting Company, it would seem, is experimenting with ways and means of introducing visual variety to the telecast portion of a musical program which is being carried simultaneously by radio and video.

HONOLULU, July 2 (UP) -- The Governor's Emergency Committee today canceled all space allocations for the Hawaiian Dairymen's Association on relief ships bringing supplies to strikebound Hawaii and charged that corn and barley they imported "for cattle" was turned over to a brewery for making beer.

WE used to think of portable fans as strictly psychological devices designed to distract attention from the gloomy news that the thermometer was about to hit 92 degrees and the humidity was getting worse by the minute. Distract us they did -- by noise, by blowing the ashes out of the ashtray, and very likely by giving us stiff necks.

HONOLULU, July 2 -- Hawaiian business is realizing during the present costly longshore strike, now ending its ninth week, that it faces the major task of convincing the mainland that these islands are not a paternal overlordship of five governing families.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- The Athletics defeated the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 1, today behind the masterful four-hit pitching of Joe Coleman.

John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, and Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora of Manhattan continued yesterday to be the leading candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, with leaders of the Liberal party persisting in their determination not to accept Mr. Cashmore.

Obedience competition for dogs as it has existed under rules in effect for almost the last two years will be reviewed and suggestions for improvement probably drawn for submission to the board of directors at a two-day conference at the American Kennel Club on Aug. 18 and 19.

Post-war public money management has just zigzagged off in a new direction impelled by the spread of conviction in official Washington that the nation's Public Enemy No. 1, economically speaking, is not inflation, but the unflagging pace of the current business decline.

Jack Gould's "What Is Television Doing to Us?" cleared up many questions about what is happening with this new medium of entertainment. But the picture used with the article puzzled me. We've owned a television set for two years and during this period of faithful video-viewing I have yet to see a show which gave me the impression of needing so many lights and so much detailed apparatus.

FOR reasons which an enterprising psychologist might deliberate upon, Americans are chronic letter writers. They write to their Congressmen, editors and Aunt Bessies, among others. Above all, the salesgirl at the lingerie counter at Macy's, the soda jerker at the corner drugstore in Kalamazoo, as well as the nation's common denominator, Mr. and Mrs. John Brown and Junior Brown, seem to write to his or her favorite actor and actress.

PARIS, July 2 -- After having formed a new government for the French Indo-Chinese state of Viet Nam, former Annamese Emperor Bao Dai declared in a proclamation today that "the great powers have shown their sympathy with our people and desire to see our country take its place in the concert of free and democratic nations."

ATHENS, July 2 -- The Athens mission of the Economic Cooperation Administration reported today that $13,700,000 worth of goods and services authorized during May for purchase by Greece under the European Recovery Program had brought the total of Marshall Plan aid for this country in the fourteen months ended May 31 to $182,000,000.

Analysis of the initial phase of fall buying of women's apparel, coming to an end last week with the exodus of buyers returning home for the July 4 holiday, reveals a strong undercurrent of optimism on the season's prospects in the fact of depressing factors in the nation's economy.

AS part of its bicentennial celebration, Alexandria, Va., is presenting an historical drama, "Alexandria, Thy Sons," for one week starting July 11 in the King George Meadow Theatre. The date, chosen for its historic significance, is said to be the day on which some of the town's original lots surveyed by the young George Washington (a surveyor of 17) were sold for $78 each. The drama features the well-known figures of Alexandria's first days.

PENZANCE, England, July 2 (AP) -- The commander of the West-European Union's naval maneuvers said today the exercise had been ordered to show the world that Western nations "are willing and able to work together in case of aggression."

NANKING, July 2 -- Although the Communist policy in China has not yet taken a definitive outline it is already clear that the United States is destined to play a smaller role. Its direct effect on fundamental political developments here and in its broader cultural influence on the future Chinese society will be greatly lessened.

TOKYO, July 3 -- Communist papers have been conducting a violent campaign during the last several months against the "Primer of Democracy," textbook prepared at the instance of the Civil Information and Education Section of the Occupation for use in the public schools.
OMAHA, July 3 (AP) -- Lucien Barbour, Stanford player, will face George Counts of Oklahoma City in the men's singles final of the Midwest tennis tournament.
Four new films, including an arrival from England, are slated to open in first run theatres this week. The programs follow:

ROME, July 3 -- Italian circles this evening accused the Yugoslav Government of having violated Annex 7 of the Italian peace treaty concerning the provisional regime of the Free Territory of Trieste when they learned that the dinar had replaced the Yugoslav lira as legal tender in the southern zone administered by Yugoslav authorities.

DETROIT, July 3 (UP) -- The return of craftsmanship to automobile making is the latest goal of the Kaisers. Edgar Kaiser, president of Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, says he thinks it can be done without losing mass production that is needed to stay in the highly competitive auto market.

Factory-made furniture just imported from Denmark indicates that clean simple design coupled with a hand-craft look is characteristic of lower-price lines produced in that country. These are the same qualities that were apparent in the more elegant and more expensive Danish pieces recently shown in the European furniture and fabrics exhibition at the Architectural League.

Ben R. Lee has been appointed controller of Hearn Department Stores, Inc., effective July 11. He was formerly general manager of Saks Fifth Avenue in Beverly Hills, Calif., and controller of Saks Fifth Avenue, New York.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) -- A bases-loaded single by Jim Hegan in the tenth inning enabled the Indians to defeat the Browns, 4 -- 3, in the second game of a doubleheader today. The Tribe snuffed out a ninth-inning rally by the Browns to take the first game, also 4 -- 3.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 -- The steel industry saw its national operating rate slide 4 1/2 points last week to 80 per cent of rated capacity. This was an acceleration of the drop over the last few weeks. It resulted from a combination of a smaller volume of orders and more cancellations, coupled with users "living off inventory."

Your editorial "Mr. Truman on Housing," in THE TIMES of June 19, was most interesting. I cannot believe that the problem as stated in your editorial can be answered by your last paragraph. For more than sixteen years the New Deal, and now the Fair Deal, has been attacking privately owned industry in every field.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Beneath a merciless sun more than 200,000 Chicagoans gaped and gasped today as the Air Force put on an exhibit of aerial might as the National Air Fair opened at O'Hare International Airfield. The show was sponsored by the Air Force Association.
