NEW DELHI, India, July 3 -- Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia, India's No. 2 Socialist, and forty-two other party members were released today on orders of the Government after having served ten days of a two-month sentence for having led an illegal procession to the Nepalese Embassy here in protest against political conditions in the neighboring Himalayan kingdom.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 3 -- The foundation stone was laid today for Israel's first motion picture studio, in Herzlia near Tel Aviv. The $600,000 project, covering twenty acres, will be rented to local or foreign producers.

BUENOS AIRES, July 3 -- The Peron regime marked the completion of its university reorganization at a dinner last night at which the President, his wife and Minister of Education Oscar Ivanissevich distributed symbolic diplomas to the first permanent rectors of the six national universities appointed under the university law of 1948.

LONDON, July 3 -- Apart from a temporary technical check due to some covering of short positions, the stock markets here presented last week the same gloomy picture as before. Many factors have combined to accentuate the depression, which has been most marked in gilt-edge securities.

Undeterred by heat that made steel decks sizzle under their feet, almost 15,000 New Yorkers made the Navy stand rigid inspection for three hours yesterday afternoon as they swarmed over the super aircraft-carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt and seven other ships of Task Force 89, berthed at Manhattan docks on a three-day visit here.
The Rev. Will Wilfrid Whalen, a Roman Catholic priest who had been a playwright, author and actor, lost his life yesterday in a fire that destroyed his apartment at 349 East 144th Street, the Bronx.

Being one of those disorganized individuals for whom the municipal and state-operated beaches, with their rows of trash cans arranged in military precision, their highly manicured boardwalks, their hygienic hot-dog stands, their well-groomed bathhouses, their standing, sitting, sleeping, swimming throngs, their anxious (and sometimes unctuous) lifeguards -- and their expectant cashiers -- have little appeal, I looked on a map and spotted Long Island's Gilgo State Park as a likely seaside wilderness.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- "Ex-Hero," a screen story written by William Saroyan and George Auerbach for B. P. Schulberg ten years ago and subsequently acquired by Paramount, but never filmed, has been revived, and Sydney Boehm has been engaged by Paramount to develop a scenario from it. The story deals with the adult life of a college football star.

ALBANY, July 3 -- Charles F. Gosnell, State Librarian, reported today that a collection of documents and rare pamphlets disclosing new facts about the early struggle for independence in colonial New York had been acquired by the State Library.

SHANGHAI, July 3 (AP) -- Editor Randall Gould of the United States owned Evening Post and Mercury complied with Communist orders today and apologized for having injured four workers who besieged his apartment.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 3 -- Against a colorful background of rebel yells and traditional Southern courtesies, some 6,000 fans gathered today to honor the president of a steadily losing baseball team in a ceremony that symbolized the sportsmanship concept in Western civilization.

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers has been discussing the potentialities and limitations of atomic power at San Francisco. The potentialities are still attractive, it seems, but the limitations are formidable. Only recently Dr. Arthur H. Compton expressed the opinion that we may have to wait several decades before the first commercial atomic power plant is in operation.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A. F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, charged today that the Senate, in approving Senator Robert A. Taft's revision of the Taft-Hartley Act, "broke faith with democracy and followed in the goose-step of nazism and fascism."
CINCINNATI, July 3 (AP) -- Jim Brink of Seattle and Mrs. Magda Rurac of Bucharest, Rumania, today won the singles championships at the fiftieth annual Tri-State Tennis tournament.

LONDON, July 3 -- Britain still leads the world in fighter aircraft, and she intends to keep that advantage, Air Marshal Sir Basil Embry, Commander in Chief of the Fighter Command, said tonight. He was assessing the results of Exercise Foil, in which the Royal Air Force joined by the United States Air Force and air units of nations of the Western Union of Europe had tested for the past week preparedness under wartime conditions.

HONOLULU, July 3 -- The two-month longshore strike in Hawaii has focused attention on the island's spotted labor history and caused speculation as to organized labor's future place in the territory's economy.

Mischa Elman played his violin for more than 11,000 people at Lewisohn Stadium Saturday night, and, to judge by the response, pleased most of them. He appeared with the Philharmonic Symphony, conducted by Alexander Smallens, in a program which included two unfamiliar compositions.

RYE, N. Y., July 3 -- Breezes that have been almost as absent as rain over Long Island Sound came to life today in the regatta of the American Yacht Club, the second program of the three series championships over the holiday week-end.

Former Second Lieut. Jadwiga A. Raczynska, a brunette who once was a member of the Polish underground army and now is wanted by the Russians for smuggling Polish nationals out of Poland, arrived here yesterday as a displaced person on the Army transport Gen. R. E. Howze.
LINCOLN, Neb., July 3 (AP) -- The Women's Trans-Mississippi Golf Association championship remains in Texas hands.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat, of Virginia, today questioned the legality of John L. Lewis' order putting most of the nation's coal miners on a three-day work week. He said that a Senate inquiry would look into it.

John Moore, English novelist and essayist, will have his third volume of fictionized reminiscences published in August by Whittlesey House. "The Blue Field" continues his series of anecdotes and character sketches about the village of Brensham that began in "The Fair Field" and "Brensham Village."

After 173 years the fact that this nation is, "and of right ought to be," independent of the British Crown is not news. Nor is it the principal fact in our celebration of Independence Day. The dependence today is somewhat on the other foot. We lend and give money or goods to the old Mother Country and to other countries.

Leo Durocher, having about exhausted the mathematical combinations and permutations at his disposal, finally got around once again to calling on his regular Giant cast yesterday and the result was quite electrifying, not to mention a bit stunning, to the Flat-bush contingent in a crowd of 30,014 that sweltered in the Polo Grounds.

Ten of the fourteen attractions now playing on Broadway stages will offer special Independence Day matinees this afternoon. The forecast of "sunny and hot" weather for the holiday is far from ideal from the theatre standpoint. Patronage traditionally has been better when rain or cool winds interfered with outdoor pursuits.

In a sizzling New York summer the refrigerator alternates for the range -- or it can. Chilly creations, from soups through desserts, may be "cooked" in it. Reserving the stove for the "one hot dish" recommended by the experts for a warm-weather meal, and preparing the other courses in the icebox, keeps the kitchen -- and the kitchener -- as comfortably cool as possible.

The new spirit in which the Western Powers are conducting their occupation of Germany has been emphasized anew by Mr. McCloy in his first public statement as the new American Military Governor and designated member of the Allied High Commission for Germany.

LENOX, Mass., July 3 -- Addressing a Tanglewood audience here this afternoon, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, warned that modern America is in peril of returning to "jungle music" and "primitive sound."

BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- Young right - hander Robin Roberts pitched his third shut-out and ninth victory of the season while limiting the Braves to five scattered hits as his Phillies broke a third-place tie with the National League champions, taking undisputed possession with a 7-0 decision today.

LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Yugoslavia said today "gross violations" of the Italian peace treaty by Italy, the United States and Britain had forced her to incorporate her occupation area of the Trieste Free Territory into the Yugoslav economy.

MOSCOW, July 3 -- Izvestia, Soviet Government organ, contended today that a growing economic crisis in the United States and Western Europe revealed the bankruptcy of the United States foreign policy and lay at the heart of Western concessions that made possible the successful conclusion of the Paris Foreign Ministers meeting.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 3 -- Nassau truck farmers are saving the greater part of their crops in the current record drought that has seared lawns and dried the soil to powder by use of an ingenious portable sprinkling appartatus that assures their thirsty land of water.

MEXICO CITY, July 3 -- President Miguel Aleman, who is rounding out the third year of his six-year term, voted today in the election for the Federal Chamber of Deputies as his final contribution toward keeping the Party of Revolutionary Institutions (PRI) in control.

With eighty days of the New York racing season having been written into the records, the horses -- and the horse players -- return today to Jamaica, where the Empire City Racing Association will put on the shows for the next two weeks.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period June 25 to July I are given in the appended tabulation:
MOSCOW, July 3 -- Moscow paid final tribute today to the veteran Bulgarian Communist leader, Georgi Dimitrov, in rites such as no other foreign leader had received in the history of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UP) -Carl R. Gray, Veterans Administrator, said tonight he was setting up one of the world's biggest machine accounting systems to help get out $2,800,000,000 in insurance dividends to 16,000,000 World War II veterans.
BOSTON, July 3 -- Boston's antiquated market district, which centers on Faneuil Hall, "the cradle of liberty," may soon pack up and move to new $10,000,000 quarters.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., July 3 -- With the ten-goal internationalist, Cecil Smith, playing the leading role, the Hurricane quartet came from behind in the final two chukkers to score a 7-6 victory over Bostwick Field today.

HARVARD, Mass., July 3 -Discovery of a new comet by three members of the Harvard College Observatory staff was announced today by Dr. Harlow Shapley, observatory director. He said the comet was found on a photographic plate exposed through a telescope last night.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- July corn has been acting tight of late on the Board of Trade as the result of persistent buying by spreaders who have sold September and also on reports that a leading cash interest is heavily long of July and may stand for a delivery. Processing interests are also said to be long.

Christopher Marlowe's "Doctor Faustus" will be the initial presentation among three English dramas of the "BBC Playhouse" transcribed series to be carried by WNYC, starting this Wednesday evening and running weekly through Aug. 10. The broadcast time will be 8:30 to 9:55 P. M.
A tentative decision has een reached to charge a thirty-five-cent toll for passenger cars using the $80,000,000 Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, now under construction, it was learned yesterday.

PARIS, July 3 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle said today that the late Gen. George S. Patton Jr. "would undoubtedly have pursued his irresistible march eastward as far as Berlin if the policy of Yalta had not diverted him toward the Danube."

DETROIT, July 3 -- Almost as much excitement prevails tonight in this speedboat-mad city over tomorrow's third annual Detroit Memorial race for the Henry Ford Cup as was displayed when Wild Bill Cantrell won yesterday the 90-mile Gold Cup in My Sweetie.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3 -- Negotiations are expected to be opened soon, primarily between Egypt and Syria but with the probably eventual participation of Saudi Arabia and Lebanon, for a military alliance to replace the now moribund Arab League.

The Rev. Albert L. Neibacher, pastor of St. Lukes Evangelical Lutheran Church 308 West Forty-sixth Street, urged Americans yesterday to spend this Fourth of July trading the dollar sign for the cross as a symbol of national faith.

Every look but the "wilted look" was passe yesterday as the mercury reached 95.1 degrees at 2:50 P. M. making it the hottest day of the year so far. However, a new mark was on the way as the Weather Bureau indicated that the temperature might approach 100 today.

LONDON, July 3 -- Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee asserted today that the Communists were trying to upset Britain's "precarious" and "narrowly poised" economy as "instruments of an alien dictatorship" seeking to destroy British socialism

Over a network of strategically located FM relay stations motor vehicles equipped with appropriate apparatus are now able to report their positions and progress as they move along the main highways between Boston and Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A little group of men working within the House Armed Services Committee will try again this week to find an approximate answer to this question not yet resolved in the history of the United States:...

Representative Judd's bill to use $4,000,000 of already appropriated Foreign Economic Cooperation Administration funds to assist Chinese students in this country should have strong support and prompt approval. The need is there and the money is there.

A hit-and-run driver injured an 11-year-old boy and set off a chain of circumstances on the lower East Side last night that resulted in the police accidentally killing a woman passer-by and in the attempted lynching of the driver by enraged bystanders.

A three-point educational program by Licensed Beverage Industries has been approved unanimously by the Advisory Council of the Wine and Spirits Wholesalers of America, it was announced at the week's end. Members of the council have pledged full support.

SHANGHAI, July 3 -- In the past few weeks students by the tens of thousands have been enrolled here and in near-by cities in a gigantic educational campaign to develop armies of political workers to follow the Communist troops into the provinces of South China. The drive into South China cannot be launched until the political machinery is built to roll along behind the armies.

Development of "super" drug stores and drugs-toiletries departments in food supermarkets threaten only a limited amount of competition to progressive independent retail druggists, trade officials declared last week.

NORTH SALEM, N. Y., July 3 -- Transportation, 5-year-old thoroughbred brown gelding owned by Mrs. Elizabeth Correll of Scarsdale and handled by Gordon Wright, took stake honors at the Goldens Bridge Hounds colt and horse show at the Meadow Lane Farm today, and as a result finished with 16 points and the young hunter championship.

PARIS, July 3 -- Two events stood out in sessions of the Paris Bourse last week. The first was the reopening of forward selling, which was halted on June 11, 1940. This market before the war played a great role in France in the provision of capital. If the Paris Bourse has been somnolent since the liberation, it is in large part because the forward market was still closed.

The Rev. Dr. James D. Northey, president of the Congregational Union of Australia and New Zealand, in a sermon yesterday at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, challenged the "negative" idea of freedom prevailing in America and Australia.

FRANKFORT, Germany, June 29 -- Founded by order of Adolf Hitler in 1938, the city of Wolfsburg in the British zone is today the scene of a significant political struggle between Nazistic elements who for a short time recently gained control of the city government and the representatives of several more democratic parties.

A telephone call to the police by a passer-by who noted the license number of an automobile used for a getaway in a Brooklyn drug store hold-up Saturday night led to the arrest early yesterday, morning of six youths alleged to be members of the "chocolate soda gang."

Georgi Dimitrov, Bulgarian Communist, first came prominently into the news when the newly fledged Nazi Government tried to convict him of complicity in the Reichstag fire of February, 1933. He had what was probably the last fair trial ever held under Hitler.

TOKYO, July 3 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur, in a July Fourth statement, tonight assailed communism as "national and international outlawry." He said its treacherous use of the democratic freedoms that it intends eventually to destroy "poses the question whether such a movement should any longer be accorded the validity, the sanction and the protection of law."
Although the failures and weaknesses of the National Security Resources Board have been more conspicuous than its accomplishments, the board does have definite accomplishments to its credit.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Ralph Kiner hit his twenty-first home run today as the Pirates whipped the Cubs, 7 to 3, before a sweltering crowd of 18,128.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- The rest of the world is catching up with America's male tennis players but the United States girls still have a firm grip on their division.
PARIS, July 3 -- John W Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury, arrived in Paris by air today to begin a tour of Europe in the interests of more stable currencies and wider trade.

America's water-borne foreign trade suffered a marked decline last year in comparison with the previous year, according to a survey summarized by the United States Department of Commerce for publication today.

Recent dispatches from India have described something of a financial crisis and a general slowdown of market activities because of mistrust of the policies of the Government. The Government is committed, in principle, to the nationalization of some key industries.

Before World War II trade among the Marshall Plan countries accounted for 51 per cent of their total exports and 38 per cent of their total imports, and therefore played an important role in their economic life.

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 3 -- Sail-plane pilots entered in the sixteenth national soaring contest attempted a difficult feat today, the second day of the nine-day event. They were assigned to soar to a specific spot, lose enough altitude to be identified from the ground, and then return to the take-off point.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- All winning streaks must end, but the manner in which the Yankees, after five straight victories, forfeited theirs today at Griffith Stadium was heartbreaking. Because they messed up two eleventh-inning bunts, the Yankees lost to the Senators, 2 -- 1, with Lefty Joe Page victimized by his infield.

AMES, Iowa, July 3 (AP) -- Harvie Ward of the University of North Carolina won the National Collegiate Athletic Association golf tournament today with a 5-and-4 victory over Morris Williams Jr. of the University of Texas.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled unanimously today that a demonstration involving support of a strike violated the Taft-Hartley Law if it resulted in "physical obstruction" of the struck plant's entrances.

Summer Solstice has passed and the year starts sliding downhill. Days are still long and the sun's arc decreases almost imperceptibly. This is the good old summertime. The great majority of wild plants and trees have completed a major part of their cycle; man-planted crops push steadily toward fruition.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 3 -- Correspondents of The Times of London and of The United Press left Czechoslovakia today by order of the Czech Foreign Office and an American student who had been making tour of Slovakia for THE NEW YORK TIMES returned to Prague by order of the Ministry of the Interior.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Tenders of more than 4,000,000 pounds of cash lard on July contracts startled general liquidation in that commodity last week on the Board of Trade, and with a weaker undertone in vegetable oils, October and later deliveries declined around 3/4 cent a pound to a new seasonal low before the selling movement spent its force.
I would like to see the contact between the voter and his elected representative strengthened by the use of modern machine methods.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- E. J. (Dutch) Harrison chased Sam Snead all day in The Washington Star open golf tournament today and finally caught him with a 15-foot putt for a birdie on the eighteenth green.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3 -Starting on Labor Day in Cleveland, Senator Robert A. Taft will make a county-by-county tour to report to his constituents on the work of the Eighty-first Congress, and the problems, domestic and foreign, that he foresees. Mr. Taft is expected to be a candidate for re-election next year.

LATTINGTOWN, L. I., July 3 -- Favored teams advanced to the semi-finals of the annual mixed foursomes tournament at Creek today with the medalist combination of Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock and Arthur K. Atkinson Jr. of the home club registering two convincing triumphs.
TOKYO, July 3 (UP) -- Text of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's July 4th statement:

THIRTY years ago today a young savage with dynamite in both fists blasted the heavyweight crown off the head of the then ruling monarch under the pitiless rays of a blazing sun which wasn't half as pitiless as he was. In a murderous assault that rarely has been matched for sheer brutality in the annals of the ring Jack Dempsey knocked out Jess Willard and thus became the champion of the world.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, N. Y., July 3 (AP) -- Dr. Walter G. Robinson piloted his 225-cubic inboard-motorboat to a new world's record of 81.6 miles per hour today.

Controverting statements of an industrial recession, the Federal Power Commission's latest report of electric energy production shows that the 23,348,224,000 kilowatt hours of electricity produced by the nation's electric utilities in May was the largest for that month in the sixty-seven-year history of the power and light industry.

BRUNSWICK, Me., July 3 -- The Bowdoin College Museum of Fine Arts has hung as its special exhibition for July a joint showing of works by three outstanding contemporary American painters, all of whom have done much of their work in Maine.

Plans for the erection of a new apartment house in the Bronx were announced in connection with the purchase for all cash by Nathan Wilson, operator, of the three two-story dwellings on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 2074-76-78 Walton Avenue, near the Grand Concourse and Jerome Avenue subways.
JOGJAKARTA, Java, July 3 (AP) -- Colonel Simatupang, acting Chief of Staff of the scattered Army of the Indonesian' Republic, has returned to Jogjakarta following the Dutch withdrawal.

The Majestic Theatre property at 651-53 Fulton Street, a landmark in the heart of the downtown Brooklyn theatrical district, has been purchased by Eagle Show, Inc., headed by Louis B. Stackell, from the Siritzky interests, who have owned and operated it for the last eight years.

MOSCOW, July 3 (UP) -- The Bulletin of the Academy of Sciences published a letter today by Ilya Trainin, written before his death last Tuesday, renouncing his membership in the American Society of International Law and denouncing that group's aim.

SANDWICH, England, July 3 (AP) -- The British open golf championship will begin its five-day, 108-hole grind tomorrow with the knicker-wearing precisionist from South Africa, Bobby Locke, in the favorite's role.

With little or no money in sight to give the 40,000 employes of the municipal transit lines a pay rise for the fiscal year that began last Friday, Mayor O'Dwyer will discuss with the Board of Transportation early this week the problem of coping with the demands of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and other labor organizations for pay rises and improved working conditions involving an additional annual operating cost of $72,000,000.
ST. LOUIS, July 3 (AP) -- Gerald Staley hurled the Cardinals to an 8-to-1 victory over the Reds today, bringing the Redbirds back to one game behind the league-leading Dodgers.

DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- Shortstop Luke Appling got four hits and drove in three runs to lead the White Sox to an 8-to-4 decision over the Tigers today. Only 14,830 fans -- smallest Sunday crowd in the history of Briggs Stadium -- saw the game.
ABERDEEN, Wash., July 3 -- A pre-dawn "flash fire" whipped through a two-story residential hotel here today, trilling seven guests and injuring six other persons.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 3 -- One of Connecticut's top amateur golfers, Julius Boros of Hartford, gained the final of the Ekwanok Country Club's annual invitation tourney today along with Pierce (Bud) Russell Jr. of Troy, N. Y., former Vermont State champion and winner of the Robert Todd Lincoln Cup here in 1943.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -Eddie Joost and Alex Kellner combined forces today to lead the Athletics to an 8-3 victory over the Red Sox and a clean sweep of the series with the faltering Boston team.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3 -United States and British concerns dealing in oil and other products now opening up the Middle East, are getting together to train engineers at the American University of Beirut. They also seek to develop an engineering school that is intended to become an important center for providing technicians for one of the world's most backward areas.

Sir Hartley Shawcross, British Attorney General -- his luggage including a cowboy hat and boots and a dozen beefsteaks "the like of which I haven't seen in ten years" -- left La Guardia airport for England last night.

NEWARK, N. J., July 3 (AP) -- With Joe Valenzuela, a right-hander, pitching four-hit ball, the Bears won the second half of a twin bill from Jersey City, 3 --1, today to gain a split for the day's work. In the opener, Wally Hood blew a six-run lead as the Jerseys pulled out a 7-6 decision.

DETROIT, July 3 -- With negotiations of economic demands against the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation overshadowing other considerations, the United Automobile Workers, CIO, will move into Milwaukee next week-end for the start of its twelfth international convention.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., July 3 -- Sir Alexander Fleming, the discoverer of penicillin, dedicated the Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation today to the proposition that great discoveries most often were made by research men left free to follow the leads provided by chance or luck in the scientific laboratory.

CHICAGO, July 3 (UP) -- Homes have fallen in price approximately 10 per cent in most of the nation during the past year, but a real estate expert warned they may go up again now that the Government is entering the housing field and competing for building materials.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Further deterioration in the outlook for the winter and spring wheat crops was reported last week, and all returns now point to a reduction of 100,000,000 bushels or more of winter wheat in the aggregate in Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas, compared with June 1, as the result of various diseases.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 3 -Support for the Federal aid-to-education bill now before Congress was urged here today by Benjamin R. Epstein of New York, National Director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

With an exhibition that was close to perfection for two sets, William Talbert, the defending titleholder, defeated Seymour Greenberg of Chicago yesterday in the semi-final round of the New York State Clay Court Tennis championship at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills. The score was 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, 7 -- 5.

SHANGHAI, Monday, July 4 (AP) -- Chinese Nationalist bombers and fighters today raided Shanghai for the fourth straight day. They hit the Western part of the city where yesterday they knocked down one of the main radio station's six towers.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 3 (AP) -- American players defeated a Canadian chess team here today in an international chess match held simultaneously with contests at other border points. The final score was 29 1/2 to 23 1/2.

Liberty breaks down into delinquency and license if religion is ignored, the Rev. Gustav J. Schultheiss, director of the Institutional Commodity Services for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue at Fiftieth Street.
You have recently published several letters on the cause, and presumably the cure, of depressions.

BERLIN, July 3 -- The Political Bureau of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party of Eastern Germany demanded today that the Western powers abandon the establishment of a German federal republic in the Western zones of occupation.

The article in THE TIMES of June 17 written by your able Washington correspondent, Arthur Krock, deserves the widest circulation. It is somewhat unusual to find a Supreme Court justice writing an opinion in which he expounds in professor-like manner his social, economic and political philosophy.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Increased interest in research on the food and clothing of the American family for the purpose of raising living standards is manifest at the Department of Agriculture.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The American Legion announced today a new national program of community development designed to a spirit of "self-help" in solving local economic problems.

The heat pounded down on Dyckman Street, hard by the Hudson River in upper Manhattan, through the day, and James Reiss, Mayor of Dyckman Street and its No. 1 drum beater, wiped many a rivulet off his perspiring face. But "call me Jimmy" was a happy man.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- One big question plaguing the Western metal mining industry today is: are things going to get better or worse?

RENO, Nev., July 3 (AP) -- A wage dispute closed virtually every bar, restaurant and hotel dining room in Reno this afternoon just as the city was entering into the holiday mood. Only two hours earlier an amicable settlement had been considered almost certain.

ASPEN, Col., July 3 -- The convocation here of scholars and noted authors to celebrate the bicentennial of the birth of the German poet-philosopher Goethe is not all one of solemnity and meditation. There are light moments and minor hitches and problems, as can be attested by the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Industrial research for Mexican development has begun in a new laboratory building in Mexico City, where that country's technological problems are being studied by the International Division of the Armour Research Foundation of Illinois Institute of Technology.

The 1,455 merchant vessels now in service, which aggregate 16,985,000 deadweight tons, constitute an active American Merchant Marine that is in a much healthier state than it was prior to World War II, according to figures released yesterday by the Maritime Commission.

BOSTON, July 3 -- Twenty-five states now require loyalty oaths of teachers, while a number of others are considering legislative measures to require them, according to a report of the Academic Freedom Committee, presented today at the National Education Association's convention.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -San Francisco's Chinatown settled back today to wait for Ping Yuen.
SAUGATUCK, Mich., July 3 (AP) -- Whisper III of Grand Rapids, Mich., scored an upset victory in the Chicago-to-Saugatuck twenty-ninth annual yachting race across Lake Michigan yesterday.

The trend of cotton prices in the domestic market last week was toward a firm level. At the end of the trading week on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 9 to 26 points above the previous week's close, and with the exception of the spot month, all active deliveries advanced to new high ground for the season.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 3 -- Over the week-end Swiss bankers who underwrote the second 4 per cent Belgian Railways tax-free loan of 50,000,000 Swiss francs guaranteed by the Belgian Government and issued last month in Switzerland at 99, repayable at par in 1961, were in buoyant spirits because the loan was more than three times oversubscribed and was quoted here yesterday at l00%.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 3 -Pavane, 45.32-foot sloop owned by J. R. Lyon of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, today won the Commodore C. A. Hipkins Trophy in the Stratford Shoals race for the second successive year and also repeated for best corrected time honors.
Removal of Tighe E. Woods, Federal Housing Expediter, was urged yesterday by Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations.
A smart and easy way to give a summer wardrobe a lift this season can be found in the wide selection of interesting fabric belts being shown in accessory departments.

Making public an "American Declaration of Dependence," seventeen American writers, including five Pulitzer Prize winners, announced yesterday formation of the Writers' Board for World Government with headquarters at 7 East Twelfth Street.

As a result of the unprecedented increase in oil shipments, a record total of 8,686 ships with a net tonnage of 55,081,000 tons passed through the Suez Canal last year, according to the directors' report submitted at the annual general meeting of the Suez Canal Company at Paris on June 21.

Three years ago the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History staged five possible ways in which the earth may meet its end. This portrayal of doomsday has now been revived. With billions of years still to elapse before the earth is reduced to a dead planet, the event must have seemed incredibly remote.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Calumet Farms' sensational Coaltown and game old Armed ran one-two in the $54,800 Stars and Stripes Handicap at Arlington Park today, with Coaltown establishing a new track record of 1:48 2/5 for the mile-and- an-eighth fixture.

The Manufacturers Trust Company yesterday reported increases in both total deposits and total assets in the second quarter of 1949. On June 30 deposits amounted to $2,234,645,610 and assets were $2,407,481,056. These compared, respectively, with $2,111,607,798 and $2,284,465,405 on March 31 of the current year.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- Congressional statisticians today gave a summary of what the Democratic-controlled Eighty-First Congress had accomplished.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 (AP) -- Home runs by Dick Kokos and Gerry Priddy in the sixth inning provided the punch that gave the Browns and Ned Garver 4-to-2 victory over the White Sox in the second half of an Independence Day double-header after Chicago had walloped the home club, 12 to 5, in the opener before 6,500.

Government authorities are not interested at present in a proposal made by Liberty Liners, Inc., to construct two huge super-cabin-liners to carry 10,000 passengers each on the Atlantic, it was reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 4 (UP) -- The Air Force Association today ended a three-day show of air might designed to emphasize how the United States could meet the challenge of an aerial war. More than 200,000 persons witnessed the display over the holiday weekend.

The Trinacria Importing Company, 415 Third Avenue, has just received its first post-war shipment of two fine Italian cheeses. Though not as widely known as parmesan and bel paese, mel fino and taleggio have brought a modest measure of fame to Melso, the small village near Milan that specializes in making them.

HONOLULU, July 4 (UP) -- Hawaii's two leading newspapers, The Advertiser and The Star Bulletin, rationed their newsprint today so they might continue publication until the end of the dockworkers' strike.

A study of the functions and operations of the Board of Superintendents, top administrative body in the New York public school system, has been recommended to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, by the Public Education Association, it became known yesterday.

An audience of 8,000 assembled on the Mall in Central Park last night to hear the Naumburg Orchestra play the second of the four free concerts that the sons of Elkan Naumburg are giving in memory of their father, who founded the series and donated the stone band shell to the city.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- The rampaging Athletics ran their victory string to six today by taking both ends of a twin bill from Washington, 9 -- 7 and 8 -- 0, before 18,024. Little Bobby Shantz blanked the Senators in the night-cap as Sam Chapman crashed two homers, one with the bases loaded.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 4 -- Propaganda foundations for the next steps against the Roman Catholic Church were laid today in speeches by Minister of Education Zdenek Nejedly, Minister of Health Josef Plojhar and Deputy Premier Zdenek Fierlinger and by Premier Antonin Zapotocky yesterday.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 4 -- Finland survived the Scandinavian tempest engendered by the North Atlantic pact negotiations with calm and sang froid. Alarms and forebodings, for the most part originating across the Bothnian Gulf in Sweden, proved somewhat more than exaggerated.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 4 -- A name that has not been inscribed on the Robert Todd Lincoln Cup since 1943, will go back on the trophy as Pierce (Bud) Russell Jr. of Troy won the annual Ekwanok Country Club invitation golf tournament today.

Come mid-season, with the advent of dark sheers, and summer straws begin to take on a faded and wilted appearance. It is then that velvets, satins, jerseys and airy confections of shadowy veiling star in the leading millinery role.
Favorable conditions for grass crops are reported from various parts of the Soviet Union, according to the latest issue of Izvestia, Soviet Government newspaper, to arrive here.
MANILA, July 4 (AP) -- President Elpidio Quirino, speaking on the third anniversary of Philippine independence, again called for a Pacific Union as "our answer to the threat of Red imperialism."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- "Darling," a screen story by Ruth Brooks Flippen, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Janet Leigh and Peter Lawford, the studio has announced. The story is described as a comedy involving Broadway and a New England women's college.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 4 -- The Australian coal strike entered its second week today with no immediate prospect of a settlement but Cabinet Ministers were hopeful that the increasing national privations and the intensifying pressure of other trade union opinion would end it soon.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 4 -- The Yugoslav Government appears to be taking precautionary measures to consolidate its position in Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste against a possible maneuver by the Soviet Government proposing return of the entire Free Territory to Italy.
DUNLAP, Tenn., July 4 (AP) -- A 42-year-old veteran of World War II was whipped here by five men wearing white robes and masks.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Home furnishings prices have been undergoing an orderly readjustment downward since the January market here, Lawrence H. Whiting, American Furniture Mart president, said today at the opening of the two weeks summer home furnishings market.

HAMPTON, Va., July 4 (AP) -- Vic Scott of Levittown, N. Y., and J. B. Broaddus of Fredericksburg, Va., carried off high scoring honors today on Hampton Creek as the outboards added a noisy finish to the twenty-second annual Hampton Yacht Club regatta.
Bob Bull and Fred Kolb, fresh off the Kansas prairies by way of the aircraft carrier Franklin D. Roosevelt, looked on New York for the first time yesterday and found it a little dead, and weird.
LANSDALE, Pa., July 4 (AP) -- A new kind of steel spring was announced today by the Hunter Spring Company.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 4 (UP) -- Fire raced through the basement of Salt Lake City's largest theatre, the Capitol, today. Six hundred movie-goers were directed to safety, but one usher was missing and feared dead.

PIGGOTT, Ark., July 4 (AP) -- Vice President Alben Barkley declared here today that "the freedom of America and democracy cannot be measured by a monetary standard --it is priceless and must be defended at all costs."

In the coat and suit division of the wholesale apparel market here last week fall purchasing centered on fur-trimmed coats and zip-out lining styles, which were wanted for early retail promotions, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

NORWALK, Conn., July 4 (AP) -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, expressed concern today "that in our hatred of communism, we may unthinkingly espouse Communist doctrines of thought-suppression."

LONDON, July 4 -- An anxious House of Commons pressed Sir Stafford Cripps today for an early debate on the country's grave economic position after the Chancellor of the Exchequer had expressed hope that the newly achieved trade payments plan would speed up European recovery.
William Talbert retained the New York State clay court tennis championship yesterday to establish his second leg on the James Q. Purcell Challenge Bowl.

An alleged hit-and-run driver, captured after a wild chase Sunday night through the lower East Side, in which policemen firing at him fatally shot a woman, was arraigned yesterday in Week-End Court and held for a hearing July 19 in bail of $13,000 on a variety of minor charges.

PARIS, July 4 -- France's leading financiers and economists are prepared to tell John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, that the United States must make a new effort, supplementary to and outside the Marshall Plan, if Europe's trade with the United States is to be balanced.

Fire on the Long Island Rail Road trestle across Jamaica Bay late yesterday afternoon stopped rail service to and from Rockaway Park, inconveniencing thousands who had spent the holiday at Rockaway beaches.

PITTSBURGH, Tuesday, July 5 (UP) -- The nation's soft-coal miners ended a ten-day vacation and returned to the pits on the first shift today but most of them were under orders from John L. Lewis to work only three days a week until he wins a new contract.

The new Farrell Lines passenger ships, the African Enterprise and African Endeavor, will be the finest vessels of their class and size afloat, according to an announcement yesterday by John J. Fartell and James A. Farrell Jr., chairman and president of the steamship company, respectively.

SANDWICH, England, July 4 (AP) -- Harry Bradshaw, former Irish open titleholder, blistered the Royal St. Georges course with a 67 today to lead the field through the first qualifying round of the British open golf championship.

Mangohick, bred and owned by Christopher T. Chenery of Doswell in old Virginia (and 90 Broad Street in old Manhattan), won the first stakes of his 50-race career when he made the grade by a neck in the $23,025 Fleetwing Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

L. O. Rothschild, in his letter to THE TIMES, makes two mistakes. First, he cries out for a law making it mandatory for a branch of the Congress to consider any bill which has been passed by the other branch, and this within some definite period of time thereafter.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles said today that the Russians were "less truculent" but that their long-time objectives were unchanged.
WHEELING, W. Va., July 4 -- The North Altantic Pact follows the spirit of this nation's Declaration of Independence, Defense Secretary Louis A. Johnson said today.

A. F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, has called for a "purge" of the United States Senate. The latter, declares the rail union leader, "has broken faith with democracy and followed in the goose-step of nazism and fascism."

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., July 4 -- It had been a glorious Fourth, at least for the fishermen, for weather held fair and there seemed to be no shortage of fish along the rim of the Sound from Narragansett to the mouth of the Hammonassett.

TOKYO, July 4 -- Spokesmen for the Japanese Government and conservative sections of the Japanese public today expressed approval of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's July Fourth statement that hinted Japanese Communists might soon be denied the protection of law.

DETROIT, July 4 (AP) -- The onrushing Indians took a firm hold on third place in the American League race by sweeping a holiday doubleheader from the fourth place Tigers today. The free hitting Cleveland club pounded out a 7-3 decision in the nightcap after squeezing by in the opener with a 3-2 verdict.

LONDON, July 4 -- Neither buyers nor sellers would take the initiative when the stock market opened here today pending the expected statement on Wednesday of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Stafford Cripps, of Britain's gold and dollar losses during the last quarter and his review of Britain's economic position.

The Dodgers insured their hold on first place, regardless of operations elsewhere, by crushing the Phils in morning and afternoon games, 7 -- 1 and 8 -- 4, at Ebbets Field yesterday. Since the Cardinals broke even, the Brooklyn lead rose to two games.
ROME, July 4 (AP) -- A Vatican source said today the last Lithuanian Catholic Bishop to hold office had gone underground to continue his mission.

GREENVILLE, S. C., July 4 (AP) -- James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, reiterating today his stand against a "welfare state," declared that a similar address he had made at Washington and Lee University, Lexington, Va., on June 18, was "interpreted by some as an attack upon an individual and a political party."

MOSCOW, July 2 -- Speakers at a meeting of the Russian Historical Institute in mid-March denounced the Roosevelt New Deal and called Earl Browder, ousted American Communist leader, "a traitor to Marxism and Leninism," it was belatedly disclosed today.

GRAND JUNCTION, Col., July 4 (AP) -- The Grand Junction Sentinel says that thirty tons of uranium oxides that should have been delivered to the Atomic Energy Commision in the last two years have "disappeared into thin air." Uranium is a basic element in the atomic fission program and is obtained from ore deposits in this area.

BOSTON, July 4 -- By unanimous vote, the Department of Classroom Teachers, National Education Association, representing 350,000 American teachers, today adopted a resolution opposing loyalty oaths that singled out members of the teaching profession.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 4 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club held its annual regatta today, the third and final championship one of the holiday week-end, with a record starting fleet of 159 craft.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass. July 4 -- "Without continued American aid Western Europe will not be able to support its existing standard of life in 1952," Dr. J. Kenneth Galbraith, director of agricultural and marketing research in the economics department of Harvard University, told members of the Mount Holyoke Institute on the United Nations today.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP) -- Cliff Chambers and Bill Werle came up with two brilliant pitching performances today as the Pirates whipped Cincinnati, 2 to 1 and 1 to 0, to move into sixth place in the National League. Chambers allowed only two hits in winning the opener and Werle, a rookie, stopped the Reds with seven singles in winning the nightcap.

A nation-wide series of Eucharistic Congresses, sponsored by the American Church Union, an organization of Protestant Episcopal laymen and clergy, will be held in September, it was announced yesterday. High ranking churchmen from branches of the Anglican Communion throughout the world will take part in the services, which will commemorate the 400th anniversary of the issuance in English of the Book of Common Prayer.

The National Association of Direct Selling Companies, through a special committee, has begun work on a nation-wide three-point program to combat deceptive practices in door-to-door and other forms of direct selling, it was learned over the week-end.

New Yorkers, as well as many visitors to the city, continued yesterday to take advantage of an opportunity to look over carriers and smaller Navy ships tied up at West Side piers. Rear Admiral Thomas S. Coombs' Task Force 89 was host to about 16,000 men, women and children. This morning most of the ships will leave for a cruise, after their three-day call here.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Sam Snead withstood a gallant challenge by Skip Alexander today to win the Washington Star open golf tournament.

LONDON, July 4 -- The Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies, who have resumed drafting an Austrian peace treaty here, continued to make good progress today. Two more treaty articles were approved formally, reducing to fifteen the number that still must receive four-power concurrence, and a third article appeared to be on the verge of approval.

Textile college students seeking greater skill and "know-how" in the vital science of "human engineering" will be employed by scores of mills this summer, it was announced over the holiday by the Textile Information Service.

PARIS, July 4 -- Independence Day was observed in Paris with traditional ceremonies ending in a colossal garden party on the grounds of the American Embassy annex, to which United States Ambassador David K. E. Bruce had invited all the Americans in Paris. Four thousand persons attended, many of them tourists.

The freakish windstorm of yesterday afternoon caused temporary delays to holiday baseball games in which all three of the city's major league teams were contestants. The Newark-Jersey City double-header at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City also was held up.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 4 -- The United Nations raised the economic danger signal today with a warning that specific and urgent steps must be taken on both national and international planes to raise the world level of economic activity and ward off a "possible recession."

LONDON, July 4 -- Princess Elizabeth, heiress to the throne of England, moved today to her first official residence, spacious Clarence House, near St. James's Palace. Since her marriage, two years ago, the Princess, the Duke of Edinburgh and more recently the infant Prince Charles have lived in their own suite at Buckingham Palace.

An old New Yorker -- native to Vermont -- has been turning over in his mind, he says, an opinion about our city expressed not so long ago by a citizen of Independence, Mo. -- one who has, in addition, an intimate acquaintance, covering many years, with Washington, D. C.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., July 4 -- A "grass roots" movement is afoot in this state to interest young doctors in entering general practice in rural areas rather than flocking to cities to specialize. The Oklahoma University School of Medicine here is sponsor of the idea.
A detailed description of the New York City Youth Board's program for combating delinquency in eleven "areas of greatest need" was made public yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 4 -- An American pledge to work "unremittingly" for betterment of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union was made today at a ceremony in the Kremlin at which the new United States Ambassador, Alan G. Kirk, officially submitted his credentials.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 4 (AP) -- A long shot and a favorite won the divided Colleen Stakes at Monmouth Park today, the large number of entries making a division necessary of the race for 2- year-old fillies.

One of Broadway's biggest money earners, Michael Todd's musical, "As the Girls Go," will have to be closed temporarily after Saturday night's performance because of the illness of its star, Bobby Clark.

The average family in Videotown, secret test community near New York in which Newell-Emmett Inc., is carrying on a long-range study of the television receiver market, spent $45 in 1948 for sets. This was made known in a report of a second community census released today by the advertising agency and entitled "Videotown -- One Year Later."

CHICAGO, July 4 -- The Midwest Inter-Library Center, which was incorporated last March under the auspices of ten middle-western universities and which sets a new pattern in inter-university cooperation, will be placed on the western edge of the University of Chicago campus.
GRANDVIEW, Mo., July 4 -- Miss Mary Jane Truman handled a trowel and a dedicatory address with equal aplomb today in the laying of a cornerstone for a $30,000 community building.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Congress will reassemble this week in strange and cramped quarters to deal primarily with two major problems.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 4 -- The Lebanese Cabinet is meeting tonight to organize full-scale suppression of the activities of the forbidden Popular Syrian party as a result of attacks on four gendarmerie posts on Saturday night. A communique stated that the attackers had been frustrated except in two cases, in which three policemen were wounded, one of them seriously.

It was the custom of the late Mayor La Guardia to issue about every four years a report-booklet titled New York Advancing, which told of progress made in the various city departments. In the year in which a Mayor for 1950 through 1953 will be elected Mayor O'Dwyer also felt the need for bringing the people up to date on what their city administration had been doing for them.
DENVER, Col., July 4 -- What is believed to be the first organized course of study and training in the administration of international agencies is being conducted at the University of Denver.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Miss Martha Treml, 25 years old, was rescued by firemen today from a rock at the end of a ten-foot waterfall near Great Falls Park.
ROSENHEIM, Germany, July 4 (AP) -- Former Lieut. Gen. Ernst Maisel was convicted of nazism today for helping the Nazis force Field Marshal Erwin Rommel to commit suicide.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- Joe Angyal of New York, a member of the 1948 United States Olympic rowing squad, today won the Plaisted Mug and the senior sculling championship of the annual Peoples Regatta on the Schuylkill River.

Morris Pizer, international president of the United Furniture Workers, CIO, yesterday denounced critics of his union who recently questioned the legitimacy of the non-Communist affidavits filed by its officials.

Forty selected superintendents of schools from as many cities in twenty-seven states will open the eighth annual conference on administrative problems of school superintendents this morning at Teachers College, Columbia University. The general sessions and panel discussions of the meetings will be focused on "current challenging problems of education."

LONDON, July 4 -- In a surprise visit to London, Foreign Minister Schuman conferred today with Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin and Sir Stafford Cripps. M. Schuman was accompanied by Herve Alphand, head of the economic department of the French Foreign Ministry.

New York, from Madison Square to the outermost suburbs, celebrated Independence Day yesterday with dogged devotion to tradition. Despite the record heat, orators read the Declaration. Scarcely a firecracker cracked. It was a safe and sane Fourth.
LONDON, July 4 -- Russia, Czechoslovakia, Finland and Poland have signed interlocking one-year trade agreements for the exchange of $56,400,000 worth of goods, the Moscow radio said tonight.

General MacArthur in his Fourth-of-July statement to the Japanese was obviously moved by the need to meet the threat of disruption that is part of the Communist program in East Asia. The object of our occupation is to get Japan back into some reasonable relation to the rest of the world.

PALEMBANG, Sumatra, July 4 -- American reporters arriving in the heart of the oil country here today on an inspection tour found business booming. Oil refineries and wells are operating twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week to supply the big tankers lying at the docks along the Musi River.
More than 2,400 persons will depart for Europe this week on the liners Washington and Gripsholm, which are reported booked to capacity for their eastbound crossings.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 4 (AP) -- Cornelius V. Whitney's filly, Nasophar, steamed home today a half-length ahead of Adile to score a smashing upset in the $20,000 added Delaware Oaks, feature event of Delaware Park's closing day.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- At least 405 cities of 10,000 population or more now are financing their municipal activities with all revenues coming from non-property sources, the International City Managers Association reported today after a recent survey.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Administration officials are making plans to ask Congress for more money to aid an estimated 800,000 Arab refugees from Palestine, it was learned today.
Housing formed the bulk of real estate in Manhattan passing to new ownership in deals reported during the holiday week-end.

The British-Argentine Five-Year Trade Agreement just signed exploded like an atomic bomb on Pennsylvania and Connecticut Avenues in Washington. Mr. Hoffman of the ECA protested; the State Department officials were exasperated; American export groups groaned.
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The Cubs divided today's twin bill with the Cardinals, losing by 9 -- 4 and then coming back to win by 5 -- 0 before a crowd of 36,157.

The political scene with respect to major-party candidates for the United States Senatorial vacancy and municipal offices is expected to be drawn into sharp focus as a result of a series of developments promised for this week.
OTTAWA, July 4 (Reuters) -- Evidence of striking changes in the Canadian financial structure over the last decade is contained in a report just made public by the Government of the Dominion.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The Red Sox, well off the championship pace, captured six places to dominate the twenty-five-player American League squad named today for the major league all-star game at Brooklyn July 12.

Warner Brothers have purchased "Honeymoon for One," an original story by Manfred Kutnick, as a starring vehicle for Gordon McRae. The romantic singing star is featured in "Look for the Silver Lining," the Marilyn Miller biography at the Music Hall. . . .

ATHENS, July 4 -- Outlining the policies of the newly formed coalition Government before Parliament this evening, Premier Alexander Diomides said his administration would "immediately proceed with the implementation of organizational measures worked out within the framework of the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan for streamlining the operation of the civil services."

LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) -- A projected transcontinental nonstop light-plane flight by Johnny Mitchell, 29 years old, of Van Nuys, Calif., ended in a mountain crackup less than 100 miles away, a sheriff's investigator said today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 4 -- In an effort to convince the German people of the virtues of smashing economic monopolies, the United States Military Government has planned a series of lectures throughout the American zone.
In swirling dust kicked up by an embryo twister, the Yankees wrote a new page in baseball history yesterday as they grabbed the first game of a double-header with the Red Sox, 3 to 2.

A 23-year-old mother of three children was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Peter M. Horn in Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens, on a charge of disorderly conduct and was paroled in custody of her foster-grandfather, the complainant. She was Mrs. Gertrude Russo of 32-41 Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights.
Two small planes made forced landings in the Long Island area yesterday, resulting in minor injuries to two persons. Neither mishap was caused by the storm that swept this area in the late afternoon.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., July 4 -- Carlos Menditeguy scored seven goals, six of them in the second half, as the Jericho poloists turned back Brookville, 11 -- 9, in a high-goal match at Bostwick Field today.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 4 -- General Smith, who was introduced by Mayor Henry Morris Stryker as "one who has contributed so much, not only to our nation and the world, but above all, to world peace," also called Williamsburg symbolic of the significance of Independence Day.
A vigorous new program of American aid to China's Nationalist Government was called for yesterday by the Free Trade Union Committee of the American Federation of Labor.

The apartment building occupying a plot 141 by 150 feet and housing seventy families at 470-80 Ocean Parkway, in Brooklyn, has been sold by Ruth Knee to the Twelve Twenty Ocean Avenue Corporation for investment in a deal negotiated by Elias A. Nathanson and Harry Rubin, brokers.

DETROIT, July 4 -- R. Stanley Dollar Jr.'s California speed boat Skip-a-Long, of radical, unorthodox design with the crew crouched in a cockpit forward, not aft, of the tremendous Allison motor, today carried westward to San Francisco Bay the Detroit Memorial Trophy, named in honor of Henry Ford.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 4 -- A busload of city youngsters will start a new experience tomorrow morning when after a twelve-mile ride they arrive in the heart of the Watchung Reservation for their first taste of camp life.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 4 -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, former United States Ambassador to Russia today called the cold war a "contest of indefinite duration" but said America's mounting military might had halted Communist expansion in Europe.

A fast-growing controversy has accompanied the rush of an estimated 75,000 to 100,000 persons a year for small-scale, low-cost housing on a big scale in Nassau and, to a lesser extent, Suffolk counties. The division of opinion revolves around the question of what ultimate form the economies of these mushrooming communities will assume.

Feike Feikema, who is 6 feet 9 inches and so probably the tallest novelist now writing, is at work on a trilogy of massive proportions. The former Icwa farm boy, "hired man," filling station operator and medical magazine editor, has written four novels about the 1Vfiddle West.

ROME, July 4 -- The Italian seamen's strike that immobilized scores of ships, including the liner Saturnia, in Genoa, Naples and Savona harbors was settled this morning. An agreement was reached after forty-eight hours of almost uninterrupted negotiations during which Giuseppe Saragat, in his capacity as Minister of Merchant Marine, acted as mediator between the shipowners and the Federation of Seamen.

ARCADIA, Calif., July 4 (AP) -- Kentucky-bred Double Jay whipped seven rivals in the $56,500 American Handicap today and established himself as a major threat for the $100,000 added Hollywood Gold Cup on July 16.

An application to purchase WLIB, the station of The New York Post Home News, has been filed with the Federal Communications Commission by the New Broadcasting Company, Inc. The sale price is $150,000, $100,000 less than Dorothy Schiff, publisher of The Post Home News, paid for the station in 1944.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 4 -- A strong campaign has been started to urge Brazil to set up her own petroleum refineries because the country is spending $300,000,000 a year to import petroleum and its byproducts.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 4 -- After a full year's inquiry into the trial and execution of Meyer Tobiansky, who was condemned to death by a Haganah court-martial in Jerusalem, the Israeli Government announced tonight that the whole affair had been a "tragic mistake."

LONDON, July 4 -- The relationship between the United States, the United Kingdom and members of the Commonwealth was described tonight by Lewis W. Douglas, American Ambassador to Britain, as "the keystone of the arch of the community of nations."

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 4 -- Jacob Friedland, a member of the New Jersey House of Assembly who instigated a current investigation into profits on bonds bought by the state, made public yesterday a letter of protest to the investigating committee.

BALL players have single-track minds. They will talk baseball by the hour and rarely permit themselves to be diverted to less important topics. But it was slightly different at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. Like everyone else in the ball park -- or out of it, for that matter -- they could talk about only one thing, the weather.

TOKYO, July 4 -- Unless Japanese Government and Occupation plans are changed, the Japanese copper industry seems doomed to extinction. Since the close of the war it has stayed alive only with the aid of immense subsidies. Now the authorities plan to end those subsidies by Oct. 1.

PARIS, July 4 -- The 18,900-ton luxury liner La Marseillaise, newest addition to the French merchant marine and flagship of the Messageries Maritimes steamship company, serving the Near and Far East, returned to her port of call at Marseilles tonight after a noncommercial maiden voyage to Naples.

ASPEN, Col., July 4 -- Dr. T. M. P. Mahadevan, Indian philosopher, delivered a strong plea for greater understanding between philosophical thought of the East and West at today's sessions of the Goethe Bicentennial Convocation and Music Festival.

LONDON, July 4 -- Britain's "from the cradle to the grave" national insurance plan ends its first year of operation tomorrow. About 24,000,000 persons are contributing for its family benefits through 987 local insurance offices and, during the year, these offices dealt with 10,000,000 claims involving 40,000,000 separate payments.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 4 -- The worst squall that has swept over Long Island Sound in the memory of the oldest waterman this afternoon hit the sail racing fleet in the Larchmont Yacht Club's regatta, as well as scores of holiday boaters in small craft.

Two sectional chambers of commerce serving Upper Manhattan disclosed yesterday that they had submitted data to Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien that, they said, showed clearly that there was sufficient garage space available to justify rigid enforcement of the no-parking regulations.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 4 (UP) -- Senator Victor Gutierrez Franqui stressed Puerto Rico's desire for its own constitution in an address today at the end of the island's observance of The Fourth.

Hundreds of pleasure boats in the waters around New York were overturned by the sudden squall yesterday afternoon, resulting in at least seven drownings, tremendous property damage, numerous spectacular rescues and searches for survivors by Coast Guard air and sea craft.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 4 (AP) -- The national convention of Town-send Clubs voted unanimously today to establish a new political party.

BOSTON, July 4 -- The Giants and Braves, striving desperately to repair their damaged pennant hopes, battled each other for more than five and a half hours today before 21,714 onlookers. But after surviving a blistering heat, followed by a wind storm that held up play for seven minutes in the eighth inning of the second game, neither side showed an inch of gain.

Citing a survey showing a majority of fifty-eight leading stores' publicity directors and advertising managers favoring emphasis on fashion and quality in carpet advertising, James Lees Sons Company announced over the holiday plans for its largest seasonal campaign.
LONDON, July 4 (Reuters) -- A courageous stand of 89 by Martin Donnelly enabled the New Zealand cricket team to take a first innings lead over Gloucestershire at Bristol today.

Ted Schroeder, the new champion of Wimbledon, arrived in New York yesterday from England, extolling the British for their sense of fair play and recounting his narrow escapes in winning the most prized of all tennis titles.

Returned to New York after many years away, I find myself interested in observing "the quaint habits of the natives" of this metropolis. The strongest impression, of course, is the elegance, comfort and luxury at least of the upper and middle classes of this richest city in the world.

New decorative prints by Goodall Fabrics will be on display today at the company's showroom, 525 Madison Avenue, where they are available through decorators. The distinctive contemporary designs and vibrant colors that formerly characterized the prints offered by this concern are in the minority.
RENO, July 4 (UP) -- A carnival atmosphere prevailed in Reno today despite a strike by the city's bartenders and restaurant workers.
A heat-prostrated city got sudden and dramatic relief yesterday afternoon when a brief but violent wind storm, carrying with it swirling clouds of drought-born dust, struck out of the northwest.

LONDON, July 4 -- Despite an appeal from Prime Minister Attlee, more than 8,000 London dockers continued their two-month-old wildcat strike today, increasing the number of loaded ships lying idle to eighty-eight.
The first of a series of "white papers" reporting the activities of city departments during the first three years of the O'Dwyer Administration was made public yesterday at City Hall.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 4 -- Israeli importers functioning in collateral fields have been requested by the Government to pool their efforts with a view to obtaining the lowest possible prices in world markets. This was disclosed today by Dr. Bernard Joseph, Minister of Supply and Rationing, in describing the progress of the nation's so-called austerity program.

In THE TIMES of July 1 you published a letter from Walter W. Belson, director of public relations of the American Trucking Associations. Inc., in which he seeks to refute an editorial in which you questioned whether long-haul trucks were paying adequately for the use of the highways.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The Government has decided to unload -- at a loss of about $1 a bushel -- as much flaxseed from its huge price-support stocks as United States commercial buyers will take.

Over the long holiday week-end, the regional offices of the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the United States Weather Bureau were moved from Manhattan to the new Federal Building at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The election of W. F. Bramstedt as executive vice president and a director of the Caltex-Bahrein group of companies was announced yesterday by the California Texas Oil Company, Ltd., and the Bahrein Petroleum Company, Ltd.

A steady exodus of tenants from the condemned ten-story apartment house at 545 West 111th Street continued yesterday as tenant groups appealed to the Mayor's office and city departments for assistance. By 4 P. M. eleven more persons had been moved from the overcrowded building, bringing to 138 the total evacuated since the city shut off essential utility services a week ago.
There is apparently a sure-fire way to make city children eat spinach -- and like it. Simply let them grow it themselves.
Oftentimes Marvin Sleeper, veteran police reporter for an afternoon newspaper, would recount to his wife the tricky and ingenious methods devised by thieves.

An emphatic protest over failure to include distilled spirits and wines in a bill to remove war excise taxes from numerous commodities was made yesterday to Congressional leaders by Thomas F. McCarthy, chairman of the Tax Council of the Alcoholic Beverage Industries.

Consumer response to the first sale ever held on Arrow shirts was highly favorable, it was indicated here yesterday. The price cut, averaging close to 50 per cent under previous levels, spurred heavy sales in men's wear specialty and department stores.

CRISFIELD, Md., July 5 -- A Maryland waterman was shot fatally in Chesapeake Bay today in another of a long list of Maryland-Virginia border incidents arising from respective fishing rights of the two states.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 5 -- By signing a $50,000 appropriation bill, Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson today indicated that he would approve a bi-state compact with Missouri for development of the St. Louis metropolitan region.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 5 (AP) -- A. L. Derby's Martha Doyle tied the world record of 2:05 for trotting 3-year-old fillies on a half-mile track in winning the $15,611 Coaching Club Trotting Oaks at historic track today.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The National Coal Association contended today the three-day week ordered by John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers, in the soft coal industry, would raise production costs, "necessarily resulting in an increase in coal prices."

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 6 (UP) -- The decapitated body of Sadanori Shimoyama, president of the state-owned National Railway of Japan, was found today on the railroad tracks, a victim of suicide or murder.

Although its gas output is running behind the 1948 level, the Brooklyn Union Gas Company continues to show a sharp improvement in earnings, according to its statement covering the first five months ended May 31, 1949. Output fell, according to the report, because of the abnormally warm weather.
Three of four men accused of illegal wiretapping were found guilty last night in Kings County Court by an all-male Blue-ribbon jury.

The death toll from the Fourth of July windstorm remained yesterday at seven drownings in the metropolitan area, as belated reports from other parts of the country pushed the total number of accidental deaths to 711 for the holiday week-end.
TRENTON, N. J., July 5 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll planned today to put his new low-rent housing program into operation this week with the naming of a five-member State Housing Council.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Grain markets advanced rapidly after an easy start on the Board of Trade here today and closed at the top. Wheat rose 1 3/8 to 2 1/2 cents; corn. 7/8 to 1 1/4 cents; oats, 1 5/8 to 2 cents; rye, 2 3/4 to 3 1/2 cents, and soybeans, 4 3/4 to 8 1/2 cents.

DANVILLE, Va., July 5 -- Southern tobacco interests, whose agents have returned from visits to European centers to measure the leaf situation are not unduly disturbed by reports from London that the dollar scarcity there may necessitate reduced leaf purchases in this country.

LONDON, July 5 -- The Foreign Ministers deputies, who are drafting an Austrian peace treaty here, agreed today to establish two technical subcommittees that will study Soviet claims to oil and shipping assets in Austria and report back to the deputies within two weeks.

The Wesson Oil Snowdrift Company, Inc., processor of cotton-seed oil products, and its subsidiaries had a net profit in the nine months ended on May 28, last, of $2,376,157 in contrast to $11,646,921 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday.

The United Nations has just released a section of its 1948 world economic report which goes this week to the Economic and Social Council in Geneva. This section purports to show that Russia and her satellites increased their industrial production more in 1948 than the Marshall Plan countries did.

JAMES BRANCH CABELL, a writer who has proved on many occasions that he is a connoisseur of literary fantasy, thinks so highly of the fantastic stories of Nelson Bond, a fellow Virginian, that he has outdone himself to help launch a collection of Mr. Bond's stories, "The Thirty-first of February."* Some years ago Mr. Cabell invented this intriguing title himself, but did not use it.

The United States Court of Appeals directed yesterday the enforcement of a National Labor Relations Board order banning discriminatory hiring-hall practices by the National Maritime Union, CIO, in the Great Lakes region.
Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman urged last night that Americans make "large capital investments" in Israel to help that new state overcome its "colossal resettlement program."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 5 -- June Allyson has been named by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading feminine role in "The Big Hangover," a photoplay which Norman Krasna is writing and will direct. The story, described as a comedy "with social significance," deals with a talking dog.

TOKYO, July 5 -- The Japanese Government today formally took note of General MacArthur's statement of July 4 questioning whether the Communist party still is worthy of the protection of law in view of its attempts to undermine the orderly process of reconstruction here.

Naturally, home was the best place to be during a week-end like that. Home is not confining, so pity the poor people who went away. Pity the poor people who were confined to their automobiles, with not even room enough to stand up; who were confined to the boundaries of a golf course, or to the porch of a summer hotel.

After a night's postponement, Jose Iturbi made his scheduled appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. As he did last year, he performed in the dual capacity of conductor and soloist.

The Johnny-get-your-swimming-medal days of summer camps are over, Miss Grace Du Bois, secretary of the Children's Welfare Federation camping division, 435 Ninth Avenue, said yesterday. The emphasis today, she explained, has shifted from competitive sports to group activities.

SHANGHAI, July 4 -- Randall Gould, editor of Shanghai's American newspaper, The Evening Post and Mercury, which he closed down in mid-June, today apologized orally to his workers for minor injuries sustained by several of them in a scuffle at the rear entrance to his apartment Friday morning.

Irving Honigsberg, after a short ownership, has sold the fourteen-family apartment house at 9 Montague Terrace, Brooklyn, to the R. G. Construction Company for cash above a new mortgage of $20,000. The property is on a plot 26 by 100 feet.

The Senate debate on the North Atlantic Treaty had an auspicious start yesterday when, in a speech of high resolve. Senator Connally, Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, urged swift approval of the Pact in order to provide unmistakable proof that this time the free nations will stand together to defend their liberties against a threat from any quarter.
SEOUL, Korea, July 5 -- Public funeral services lasting more than six hours were held here today for the assassinated political leader, Kim Koo, former president of the Korean Government in exile.
Adventure beckoned yesterday to two or three young men. An offer was made for an expense-free cruise on a fifty-three-foot diesel yacht now anchored at Tompkinsville, S. I.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Alfred Roberts' 3-year-old Easton colt, Eatontown, was a galloping winner of the featured Hindoo Purse at Monmouth Park today. Eatontown defeated King Ranch's Prophets Thumb by seven lengths.

BERLIN, July 5 -- The formation of a German government-in-exile for the Soviet-occupied Eastern zone was suggested today in a front-page editorial in the Tagesspiegel, United States - licensed newspaper in this city.

Five men and two women, who had failed in attempts to have their convictions on rent gouge charges set aside by the Appellate Division or the Court of Appeals, surrendered yesterday in Special Sessions to begin serving jail sentences.

BOSTON, July 5 -- Eighty-four Latvian refugees, chancing a welcome to the United States, arrived today in Boston Harbor aboard the 119-foot motor trawler Skagens, a former German fishing vessel, which fifteen of their number had bought about a month ago in Sweden.

Beacon Pharmacies will open the first of its chain of retail drug stores in Queens in the two-story office and store building under construction by Sam Minskoff Sons, builders, at the southeast corner of Queens Boulevard and Seventy-seventh Avenue in Kew Gardens.
