EAST ORANGE, N. J., July 5 (AP) -- The United States Department of Agriculture announced today it was blockading a 128,000 square mile area on the Eastern Seaboard in an attempt to isolate the Japanese beetle.

BOSTON, July 5 (UP) -- Offering a cooling note for this scorched area, the Boston Bruins brought up the subject of hockey today, announcing that John George (Buck) Boucher of Ottawa, Ont., had been picked as coach for the coming season.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat, of Georgia, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, disclosed today that he had drafted a compromise armed forces unification bill to give more power to the Secretary of Defense, but to "make sure we never have a military dictatorship."

Creation of a six-man divisional merchandise manager set-up for Hearn Department Stores, Inc., was announced yesterday by Maurice M. Meltzer, president. He also announced that Edward Bishop, corporate secretary, has been named his executive assistant, and in addition will handle all licensed departments.

GENEVA, July 5 -- Europe's ability to make a frontal attack on the persistent dollar shortage by the development of new exports to the United States is much greater than Europeans generally realize, according to a special Economic Cooperation Administration mission headed by Wayne Taylor.

Electric and gas utility financing in the first six months of 1949 aggregated $1,368,703,214, compared with $1,052,375,426 in the same months of 1948, according to Ebasco Services, Inc., public utility and industrial consultants.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Both furniture prices and retailers' inventories are at irreducible levels, furniture manufacturers said today at the midsummer home furnishings show in the Merchandise Mart and American Furniture Mart. The expected results include (1) spirited buying of quality merchandise by retailers during the current market, and (2) a possible shortage of some furniture items this fall if the public tires of waiting for further price decreases and steps up its purchases.

Zlatko Balokovic, who was identified by the House Committee on Un-American Activities as a member of the national board of directors of the American Slav Congress, yesterday protested the committee's naming of him.

DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- The on-rushing Cleveland Indians mauled three Tiger pitchers for 14 hits and an 8-to-1 decision tonight to sweep their three-game series. Left-hander Frank Papish scattered seven Detroit hits for his first victory of the season.

STOWE, Vt., July 5 -- The Trapp Family Singers -- widow and eight children of the late George Van Trapp of Austria -- opened at their mountain retreat in the shadow of Mount Mansfield today the first of a series of four "sing weeks" to be held during July and August. Each period will last ten days, with 150 persons from all parts of the United States and Canada participating.

ROME, July 5 -- Sicilian bandits carried out under cover of darkness early this morning a surprise attack with hand grenades and machine guns against two Carabinieri barracks in the small town of Partinio, probably in an effort to replenish ther supplies of weapons and ammunitions.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) -- The ninety-eight-foot schooner Morning Star apparently held a slight lead late today in the 2,225-mile California-to-Honolulu yacht race.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Middle South Utilities, New York, today received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 560,000 shares of its common stock to the Electric Power and Light Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- Marriner S. Eccles, member of the Federal Reserve Board, said today he "strongly favors the new Government policy of letting bond prices rise on the open market in the hope of stimulating bank lending. He warned, however, that it would not be enough to halt a recession.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Economic Cooperation Administration today tempered its demands for freer European trade in favor of unity among Marshall Plan nations and accepted a "compromise" revision of the intra-European payments plan that fell far short of the competitive principle it sought to have adopted.

MOSCOW, July 5 -- Soviet President Nikolai Shvernik, it became known today, asserted yesterday that the Soviet Union was prepared to receive with attention and interest any United States proposals designed to broaden Russian-American trade and looking toward general relaxation of economic barriers.
The Health Department started operation yesterday of a mobile canine clinic to save its experimental campaign in Staten Island for the elimination of rabies.

ANNECY, France, July 5 -- The United States intends to propose new international action to combat widespread application of import restrictions and to seek a solution of the disequilibrium in international trade, it was learned here today.

LONDON, July 5 -- Sir Stafford Cripps' long awaited statement on the British economic position will be made to the House of Commons tomorrow after the country is "let in" officially on the well-known secret that Britain's dollar and gold reserves have dropped alarmingly.
BRISTOL, England, July 5 (Reuters) -- On a dry and wearing pitch the New Zealand cricketers today beat Gloucestershire by seven wickets.

The City Rent Commission has been asked to approve plans for making a completely cooperative dwelling place out of Hampshire House, on Central Park South, it became known yesterday. Of the building's 229 apartments, 147 are occupied by persons who have bought stock in the landlord corporation, 150 Central Park South, Inc.

Gilbert Green admitted under cross-examination at the Communist trial yesterday that he had pledged himself to follow the teachings of Premier Joseph Satlin of Soviet Russia and to remain forever faithful to Stalin's leadership for the triumph of world revolution.

Despite yesterday's noontime heat and sun, 2,000 Columbia University summer session students and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, university president, with other Columbia officials, ventured out of doors to the university's South Court to see one another.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- A jury of six men and six women, five of them housewives, was chosen by midafternoon today and the Federal Government prepared to begin its treason case against Mrs. Iva Ikuko Toguri D'Aquino, American-born Tokyo Rose of the Pacific war.

PARIS, July 5 -- After conversations here today between John W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury, and European trade experts, informed sources believed that the solution of Europe's trade and monetary problems would hinge on Mr. Snyder's talks in London.

The synthesis of Vitamin A by a new process that makes possible its production on a commercial scale was announced here yesterday by Dr. H. M. Wuest, director of research at the Warner Institute for Therapeutic Research of William R. Warner Co., Inc., New York.

Strong trade demand and short covering moved coffee futures prices into new high ground on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. In an active day, new life-of-contract high levels were established in most positions, with July "S" delivery selling at a new high futures price.

ASPEN, Col., July 5 -- The United States through its material aid to Europe has become a strong "spiritual manifestation" in the recovery of the Continent, Dr. Albert Schweitzer, the famed philosopher-missionary and physician of French Equatorial Africa, declared here today.

Sylvester L. Weaver has been appointed vice president in charge of television for the National Broadcasting Company, according to an announcement of yesterday by Niles Trammell, NBC president. He will assume his new duties about Aug. 1 and will have over-all supervision of the network's activities in video, including programming, sales and engineering.

Water supplies of New York City have dropped 33,000,000,000 gallons in a month to a reservoir total of 220,000,000,000, according to figures announced yesterday at the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

A 12-year-old boy from Brooklyn wrote: "The best part of this camp is that we learned to live and love each other no matter what race or religion we are. I learned a lot about good manners. I learned how to tell different leaves or plants. I learned how to swim, how to cook. * * * I even once caught a skunk which I wish I hadn't.
A cool breeze, a vagrant from some mysterious source, wafted through Bryant Park yesterday to make its welcome contribution to the New York Public Library's first outdoor concert of the season.

The establishment of a strong and democratic Europe depends almost wholly on the survival and success of free trade unionism, in the opinion of George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Truman discussed the general economic situation, the Government's financial position and the budget for the fiscal year which starts next July 1 with his Congressional leaders today. The leaders did not disclose the details of their discussion in their weekly meeting with the Chief Executive, but they did not appear to be downcast over what it had developed.
GENEVA, July 5 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council opened its ninth session here today with a fifty-two-item provisional agenda weighing, with attached documents, almost five pounds.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 5 -- The Texas Legislature today passed an anti-lynching bill providing severe penalties for persons taking part in mob action that results in death. Gov. Beauford H. Jester will sign the bill, which he urged the Legislature to pass as an emergency measure.

Ezzard Charles, the 28-year-old Cincinnati Negro who won the N.B.A. - recognized world heavyweight championship two weeks ago, was signed yesterday to defend the title against Gus Lesnevich, former light - heavyweight king, in the Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, Aug. 10.

CINCINNATI, July 5 (AP) -- Sam Becker, Cincinnati boxing promoter tonight protested the signing of Gus Lesnevich for a bout with Ez zard Charles on the grounds it was a violation of a contract he has with Lesnevich.

The appointment of a five-man interpretation committee to answer all inquiries as to the intent of the provisions of the recently approved American Standard Plumbing Code of basic minimum requirements was announced yesterday by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers and the American Public Health Association.

ATHENS, July 5 -- According to Greek military information, sustained by findings of teams of the United Nations Balkans Committee operating on the Greek-Yugoslav frontier, open Yugoslav assistance to the Greek rebels has shown a falling off since last February but it has by no means ceased.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- The Cardinals captured the rubber tilt of their three-game series with the Cubs today when they won a 10-inning battle, 2 to 1, before a ladies day crowd of 26,802.

Ten American athletes, comprising the advance guard of a fifty-four man squad that will tour Europe this summer, left La Guardia International Airport yesterday morning for Lisbon aboard a Pan American World Airways clipper.

Fewer job openings in foreign trade during the balance of this year is foreseen by the large majority of companies in that field, according to a survey of the foreign trade community made by the placement office of the City College School of Business and Civil Administration.

Though the peak of the season for plums doesn't come until September, the fruit is already in excellent supply. The price, currently 29 cents a pound, is not as thrifty as it will be later. But it is as much as 10 cents lower than the price charged for the fruit a year ago at this time.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Truman was warned today that Soviet propagandists were using Ku Klux Klan activities in the United States, lynchings and filibusters in the Senate to turn people in Africa and Asia against this country.

Rising sales, increased supply of bonded whiskies and some price reductions are expected to boost liquor advertising some 15 per cent during the latter half of 1949, it was learned yesterday. The need for distillers to make an extra "splash" with ads in order to impress consumers with improved quality resulting from older whiskies will account for most of the increase.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- United States exports of domestic and foreign goods were fractionally lower in May than April, while imports rose slightly during that period, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Housewares manufacturers will offer more "special deals" to quantity buyers at the Atlantic City Housewares Show next week than they have at any time since before the war, a buyer for a large local outlet declared yesterday. He said "inside" discounts will be given for the firs time by top brand suppliers who have stood fast against special consideration for quantity buying up to now.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 5 (UP) -- Regent Prince Charles today dismissed Premier-designate Paul van Zeeland and was reported considering calling new general elections to determine whether Belgians want self-exiled King Leopold returned to his throne.

The Long Island Rail Road reported yesterday afternoon that eastbound service to Rockaway Park and Far Rockaway across the line's Jamaica Bay trestle had been resumed in time for the evening homebound rush from Manhattan and Brooklyn.

Frederick E. Crever has been named division engineer of the control systems division of the General Electric Company's general engineering and consulting laboratory. He succeeds Dr. M. A. Edwards, who will devote full time to being assistant engineer of the laboratory.

Total deposits of The National City Bank of New York on June 30 this year were $4,579,501,332, compared with $4,444,516,006 at the end of March, according to the bank's statement of condition published today. Deposits on June 30 last year were $4,645,527,278.
Two delegations -- one described as a group that is aiming to revive ancient pilgrimages, and the second as the first major cultural expedition -- have left New York for a visit to Israel.

Your issue of June 30 contained a letter from Rhaman Pajvak, Secretary of the Afghanistan Embassy in Washington, in which the writer has made a grievance of your making mention of the Pakistan version of certain allegations started by the Afghan Government-inspired news agency Bakhtar.
LONDON, July 5 -- The big loss of gold in June, and Sir Stafford Cripps' forthcoming economic review had an unsettling effect on the stock market here today and caution again was the keynote.

P. D. Ouspensky, physicist, philosopher and author of two philosophical books, "Tertium Organum" and "A New Model of the Universe," has a new book set for Oct. 13 publication by Harcourt, Brace. "In Search of the Miraculous" is a story of his quest for a teaching that would penetrate to the real meaning of life and of his eight years of study under George Gurdjieff.

The United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation is suing the contracting firm of Blizzard-Perlman, Inc., and the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company because the plaintiff's building on the northwest corner of the Avenue of the Americas and Forty-eight Street goes over the city building line from three-quarters of an inch to an inch and a half.

I am a graduate of Yale College, a lawyer retired on account of a heart condition, and am living on an old-age pension. My breakfast costs 60 cents, my lunch 35 cents and my dinner $1.25, totaling $2.20. As against this the Department of Welfare allows me 79 cents a day, resulting in a deficit of $1.41 a day, or $42.30 a month.

HONOLULU, T. H., July 5 (UP) -- A negotiation meeting between waterfront employers and striking members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, lasted only twelve minutes today. It was broken off with a report of "no progress" and no further meetings scheduled.

Directors of the Citizen's Utilities Company increased the semiannual common dividend with the declaration yesterday of 35 cents a share, payable on Aug. 20, which compares with the 25-cent semiannual rate paid for the last two and a half years. In addition, an extra of 3/100 share of common stock for each share of common held was voted, also payable on Aug. 20.

Operations of domestic steel mills are scheduled to decline 18.7 points this week to 61.2 per cent of the industry's ingot capacity, the lowest level in more than two and one-half years, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation announced yesterday major management promotions in the engine and airplane divisions. This action follows the announcement last week by Paul Shields, chairman, of the coordination of the organization's three aircraft manufacturing divisions under the executive direction of Robert L. Earle new senior vice president.
Divided authority and divergent objectives of government departments and agencies cause loss to the American taxpayer. May I have space to outline a classic example?

BOSTON, July 5 -- In a spirited session, leading American educators today supported the report of the Educational Policies Commission that would deny members of the Communist party the right to teach.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 5 -- America's ranking tennis elect, returning from Wimbledon, gathered here today for the forty-first tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 5 -- H. Freeman Matthews, United States Ambassador to Sweden, was strongly criticized today in editorials of the two Liberal afternoon dailies in Stockholm for his Independence Day address which sharply denounced the Soviet Union and Communist ideology.

The longest Red Sox losing streak in the fifteen-year ownership of Tom Yawkey came to an end last night because a stripling of a southpaw had the stuff to halt the Yankees, 4 -- 2, before an overheated gathering of 60,252 fans.

Although Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, returned yesterday from a business trip to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and both Governor Dewey and Representative William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, were in town, neither party made any visible progress in selecting a candidate for United States Senator to run for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Robert F. Wagner.

As the Alger Hiss perjury trial reached its twenty-fourth court day yesterday. Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman announced that the case would go to the jury of ten men and two women late tomorrow afternoon.

Plans for establishing Shipherd College at Madison Barracks, an abandoned Army post near Sackets Harbor, N. Y., may be given up because of the institution's failure to obtain a charter from the State Board of Regents, it was learned yesterday.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 5 -- Angie Mainero and L. G. Brownlee of Wee Burn won top honors in the Westchester P. G. A. pro-amateur best ball tournament over the Innis Arden golf course with an eight under par 33, 30 -- 63 today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 5 -- Three days of pilgrimages devoted to Slav Saints Cyril. Methodius and Prokop, to John Huss and to symbols of Czech-Slovak unity ended today with a speech at Velehrad by Health Minister Josef Plojhar, a suspended priest, who declared: "Our nation is led no longer by [Archbishop] Beran but by [President] Gottwald."

WICHITA, Kan., July 5 -- On forty acres of gently rolling land that used to be a wheat field at the city limits of Wichita, an educational institution that in its field is perhaps unequaled in the world will open its new $2,000,000 plant about Sept. 1.

Food poisoning in the warm weather is often caused by custard filling and mild-cured ham that are improperly kept, according to bacteriologists of the United States Department of Agriculture. Illness may result even when these foods show no signs of spoilage in taste, odor or appearance.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were firm yesterday and closed unchanged to 13 points higher, with the July, 1949, delivery showing the most strength.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said yesterday that he would lead Nationalist China's struggle against the Communists and asked the United States to help if it wished to avert another world war. The Generalissimo broke his long silence in an interview with Clyde Farnsworth, Scripps-Howard staff writer, and Howard Handleman of International News Service at Taipeh, Formosa.

Midsummer is the season when a woman wants cool fashions with a look of autumn. Because younger girls want dresses with the same effect, designers are creating them this season for those who wear junior sizes and the sophisticate with a junior-sized figure.

Blanket manufacturers have about exhausted surplus inventories of all-wool blankets carried over from the last two years and are producing on orders only, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Retailers who have been buying only thirty to sixty days ahead, manufacturers said, will find themselves short of quality merchandise when it is most needed next fall.

PARIS, July 5 -- What is believed to be an unprecedented attempt to falsify a vote of the National Assembly occurred early this morning at the end of a debate on the question of death sentences meted out to three Madagascar Deputies several months ago for rebellious acts.

A new kind of self-service supermarket makes it possible for the housewife to shop for furniture with the same ease and economy that she normally shops for food. How this plan operates was demonstrated yesterday in a tour of the Neptune Furniture Company's New York Super-Market at 134th Street and Riverside Drive.

Bouncing Boots sped home the winner of the Claremont, the mile-and-a-sixteenth affair that served as the feature on the Empire City-at-Jamaica card yesterday. The 3-year-old son of Our Boots had a fairly easy time of it against six others, and beat the favored Blue Thanks b three lengths.
A thousand - foot stretch of Thirty - third Avenue, Bayside, Queens, where the narrow asphalt pavement abruptly becomes a dirt road, was renamed "John Golden Lane" yesterday.
While the night manager of Sager's Restaurant, Inc., 1245 Avenue of the Americas, recited the combination at 4 A. M. one of two masked robbers slipped on cotton gloves and opened a basement safe.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 5 -- Daniel R. Toll, president of the Princeton University class of 1949, and Alexander P. Morgan Jr., class valedictorian, head the list of 255 Princeton seniors receiving honors for distinguished academic work during their two upper class years.

Universal-International has borrowed Macdonald Carey from Paramount for the title role in a forthcoming drama, "The Bowie Story." This assignment is Carey's second at U-I. He is now co-starring with Shelley Winters in the adventure drama, "East of Java."

Extension of time payments for buyers of new automobiles will have little effect on the market here, Charles Schnurmacher, president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, said yesterday. The extension from twenty-four to thirty-six months is not considered a Selling factor, he added.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 5 -- Twelve newspaper men were named today by the Nieman Foundation at Harvard University as winners of the twelfth annual Lucius W. Nieman Fellowships. They include two city editors, an editorial writer, a copy desk chief, two state political writers, two Washington correspondents, two feature writers and two city staff reporters.

Renewed strength was evident in the Government bond market again with the end of the holiday week-end, with the best gains registered by long-term issues of Treasury bonds not eligible for ownership by commercial banks. The longest-term obligations in this restricted category -- those of September and December, 1972-1967 -- were bid up a half-point each, to close the day at 102 1/2, a yield basis of 2.35 per cent to maturity.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 5 -- Finland's basic foreign policy is to stay out of trouble. That in itself is a difficult art for a small nation situated on the Russian frontier. It is especially arduous because of the high-tempered world political situation these days.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 5 -- The great question in Syria today, it is learned from Damascus, is the extent to which proposals of the newspapers Al Nasa and Al Inkilas that Marshal Husni Zayim be made President for life are officially inspired.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 5 -- John J. McCloy, American zone High Commissioner-designate and Military Governor, outlined at a press conference here today four freedoms for German economic rehabilitation that would be part of a program for bringing about "a free, peaceful and prosperous Germany in the family of nations."

SANDWICH, England, July 5 (AP) -- A United States Army sergeant was ruled out of the British open golf championship today after finishing among the ninety-seven qualifiers along with three other Americans.

A 21-year-old unemployed father and his 19-year-old wife were booked last night at the East Twenty-second Street police station on abandonment charges for having left their partly paralyzed 5-week-old son on a staircase in Bellevue Hospital last Friday.

Mrs. Martha J. Beck signed a detailed confession of the slaying of Mrs. Janet J. Fay despite warnings by a Michigan attorney that the statement would place her in danger of a first-degree murder conviction in New York State, a witness at the "lonely hearts" murder trial testified in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday.

The estate of Otto Rutishauser has sold eight properties at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and 107th Street to the Fastel Realty Corporation. The properties consist of seven five-story buildings at 1711 to 1721 Lexington Avenue and 153 East 107th Street, on a plot 83.4 by 82 feet, and a five-story building at 175 East 107th Street on a lot 17 by 100 feet.
SHANGHAI, July 5 (AP) -- Remittances of money from abroad into Shanghai were halted today by the official Communist Central Bank of China.

The slowing up of production in Europe reported on Monday by the department of economic affairs of the United Nations is a "perfectly normal thing," William L. Batt, former vice president of the War Production Board, said yesterday. Mr. Batt, who is chairman of the board of the S K F Industries, Philadelphia, sailed for Europe aboard the Swedish-American liner Gripsholm, which left from Pier 97 shortly after noon.

Fears that an increase in the number of milk dealers would bring about criminal tactics in competition for trade were discounted yesterday by John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, at a public hearing to consider changes in Section 155 of the city's Sanitary Code.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Representative John W. McCormack, Democratic Leader of the House, declared today that a systematic "extermination of religion" is the "primary objective of the Red puppets" ruling Eastern Europe.

PARIS, July 5 -- One of the most singular cases in the annals of French justice, that of Joseph Joanovici, 44-year-old former rag-picker and iron monger from Bessarabia who had amassed a fortune of untold millions during the German occupation of France, was brought to trial today before the Court of Justice.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 16 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the flash report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 10 per cent.

PARIS, July 5 (UP) -- The International Lawn Tennis Federation today postponed for one year a decision on whether to readmit Germany and Japan to membership, and elected Russell B. Kingman of Orange, N. J., president of the group.

The Felicitas, a small Estonian yacht flying distress signals, was sighted shortly before noon on Monday by the Cunard White Star liner Britannic in mid-Atlantic and her two crew members taken aboard, according to radiotelegraphic information received here by the line yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor, Democrat, of Maryland, today urged in the Senate that this nation and others shoulder their proportionate responsibilities in resettling displaced persons.

Republican judges held their places on the benches of most of the sixty-nine municipal courts throughout Connecticut yesterday, despite the appointment by Gov. Chester Bowles of Democrats to succeed every one of the Republicans.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Senator Tom Connally appealed to the Senate today to ratify the North Atlantic Treaty quickly and overwhelmingly and thus to put up "a flaming sign to any aggressor: Do Not Enter!"

The city and its environs sweated out a third day of above 90-degree temperatures yesterday, with the eagerly awaited cold front from Canada accomplishing little in its first stages, but expected to bring appreciable relief today.
MEXICO CITY, July 5 (AP) -- Mexico gave her exporters another break today by cutting sharply most export tariffs.

LONDON, July 5 -- Representatives of the Socialist parties of five Eastern European countries, where the Socialists have lost all independent identity, ended a two-day meeting tonight by forming a Socialist Union of Central-Eastern Europe.

A new angle to the old "clip game" was revealed yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Magistrates Court by a man who should know something about clipping -- an unemployed barber. The barber, Frank Colasanti, 37 years old, who said he had no home, was brought into court on a charge of vagrancy when he could show the police no visible means of support.

Three hundred and eighty-five men, women, boys and girls, floundering about in the raging seas of Long Island Sound in the vicious squall on Monday afternoon, their seventy-seven craft in the sailing regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club dismasted, swamped or sunk -- and all rescued.

The annual women's Eastern clay courts championships got under way yesterday at the New York Tennis Club, the Bronx, with the seeded players experiencing little difficulty. Mrs. Elfi Carroll, ranked No. 1, had the easiest time of all as she advanced through the default of Mrs. Arthur Loew.
To help the homemaker make the heat more bearable there are many devices for keeping foods and drinks cold or to maintain ice in its naturally chilly state for an unnaturally long time.
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 5 (UP) -- John Boettiger, former publisher of The Seattle Post-Intelligence and The Arizona Times, filed divorce proceedings today against his wife, Anna Roosevelt Boettiger.

DETROIT, July 5 -- George Shenkar, an engineer for the city's water board, was discharged today because he refused to deny that he was a member of the Communist party. The action was ordered by Mayor Eugene I. van Antwerp following a conference with Donald J. Sublette, secretary of the Civil Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Administration leaders put off a decision today whether to try again this session to put a labor-management relations bill through the House.
When the Giants take the field against the Phillies tonight in the Polo Grounds assembled fans will view the unprecedented spectacle of two Negroes in Giant uniforms.

The membership drive of the new American Federation of Labor Brotherhood of Marine Engineers is gaining momentum and two companies have been placed under contract, according to Paul Hall, secretary-treasurer of the Seafarers International Union, AFL, sponsor of the new union.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UP) -- The Senate today confirmed Mrs. Perle Mesta as United States Minister to Luxembourg after debating whether the job called for "somebody with britches on."

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that the Commodity Credit Corporation had purchased 429,321,029 bushels of grain during the year ended on June 30. This compared with purchases of 413,172,401 bushels a year earlier.
" Born Yesterday," the Garson Kanin comedy at Henry Miller's Theatre, will close Saturday night after 1,442 performances, the eighth longest run in Broadway stage history.
May I comment briefly on the letter published on June 13 under the heading "Condition of the Statue of Liberty."

The Brielle skippers are looking to their outriggers these days, for a happy wind seems to have blown quite a few white marlin into their off-shore waters, with the weekend producing a new local record for this fish at Brielle.

The special four-man committee of the State Board of Regents studying methods for carrying out the new Feinberg law that seeks to bar Communists and "fellow travelers" from public school jobs is divided on how this is to be accomplished, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, July 5 (UP) -- Deputy Prime Minister Herbert Morrison, the Labor party's top election strategist, said today that Britain's rash of strikes was jeopardizing Socialist chances for re-election.

A long-expected split in the American Labor party between factions headed by Representative Vito Marcantonio, state and New York County chairman, and City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly, secretary of its New York County Committee, came out into the open yesterday.

Congress has now been in session for six months, and its statisticians have come up with some figures regarding its performance to date. Senate and House members have introduced a total of 8,605 bills. Of these, 1,589, or more than one out of six, have been acted upon by the various committees.

A banking syndicate headed by the National City Bank of New York was reported yesterday to have submitted the best bids for $1,740,000 of general-obligation bonds of Dallas, Texas, maturing either from one to twenty years or from one to thirty years.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Representative John M. Vorys, Republican, of Ohio, charged today that the State Department, indulging in what he called "a little power politics," accepted a $17,000,000 settlement of American claims against Yugoslavia in a bid to woo Marshal Tito away from Stalin.

SHANGHAI, July 4 -- A demand that the projected Chinese Communist coalition government receive "the major voice" in re-establishing Far Eastern stability through a peace treaty with Japan was made tonight in Peiping by Shen Chun-ju, representing the Democratic League.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- A Government attorney told Congress today a bill to legalize basing point price systems threatens to "turn back the clocks a quarter of a century" on Federal monopoly and anti-trust standards.

Selective extension yesterday of the recovery of late last week sent the stock market to the best levels since May by a narrow margin. Trading after the lengthened weekend holiday was at a slow pace; transfers on the Stock Exchange dwindling to 630,000 shares, against 720,000 shares on last Friday.
One of the "most tragic starvation scenes in the history of the world" will be witnessed in the Near East by September if additional funds are not available for Palestine refugees.

A union offer to arbitrate wages and drop all other demands failed yesterday to eliminate the threat of a strike of 650 employes of the Holmes Electrical Protective Service. The offer was rejected by company representatives at a mediation session in the offices of the City Division of Labor Relations at the Municipal Building.

BERLIN, July 5 -- The four occupation powers today ordered their respective commandants in Berlin to meet and carry out the Council of Foreign Ministers instructions to normalize life in this divided city.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Truman was assured today that the Democratic National Committee would face the elections of 1950 with $1,000,000 in the bank and all debts paid. The assurances were given by William M. Boyle Jr., executive vice president of the committee.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., July 6 -- A state-wide effort to combat what has already become a dangerous shortage of medical doctors in some rural parts of Kansas is being directed by the University of Kansas Medical School here.

After three months of declining prices, custom smelter copper prices reversed their trend yesterday and moved upward 1 cent in a day featured by many large orders. Brass ingots moved up 1/2 cent to 1 cent yesterday for all grades except one, while fabricators said fabricated copper prices would be posted at prices reflecting 17-cent copper today.
A contract calling for electrical repairs required to meet city stipulations was signed yesterday between the owner of the condemned house at 111th Street and Broadway and a firm of electricians.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee decided today to support the rider system of enforcing economy slashes in appropriations for the new fiscal year. A rider is an amendment attached to a bill, and the Republican strategy would be to attach it to a bill that the President would not veto.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today sold tin for the first time this fiscal year at the same $1.03 a pound price that it charged American producers in the twelve months ended June 30.
The stewards, three good men and true, did some movie-going before confirming the result of the best of yesterday's Empire City-at-Jamaica divertissements.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The twenty-two nations that had ratified the International Wheat Agreement by its deadline date of July 1 today launched the International Wheat Council provided for in the text of that treaty.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 6 -- The high court in Sydney unanimously upheld today the validity of emergency legislation forbidding trade unions to employ funds in furtherance of the coal strike. The legislation had been challenged by the Coal Miners Federation, the Federated Ironworkers Association and the Amalgamated Engineering Union.
Abraham Cahan, editor of The Jewish Daily Forward and probably the foremost living journalist and author in Yiddish in America, found the world progressing yesterday on the eve of his 89th birthday.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The United States Government reacted sympathetically to the outline of the British financial position by Sir Stafford Cripps, and officials were considering at least one proposal to help ease the current dollar predicament he described.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 6 -- The United States and British Military Governments announced today that they had entrusted the German coal management and its advisory council with the task of developing and preparing plans for the reorganization of the coal industry under bizonal law 75.

Government agencies have indicated their willingness to supply more data for the guidance of American foreign traders in appraising trade and credit developments in foreign countries, it was reported yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Statler Hotel.

PORT HUENEME, Calif, July 6 -- Three vessels comprising the vanguard of the Navy's sixth annual resupply expedition for United States military and civilian outposts in northern Alaska sailed from here last night.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson told Soviet Russia indirectly today that if she really wanted to expand her trade with the United States and other Western nations she should begin by lifting restrictions on exports.

MOSCOW, July 6 -- The Soviet foreign policy journal, The New Times today declared that the "nearest future" will disclose whether the Western powers desire to take practical steps to implement the Paris conference by seeking a solution of the unresolved German issues.

The purchase of a fleet of eight Victory-type cargo vessels from the Maritime Commission by the States Marine Corporation from the United States Maritime Commission, was announced yesterday by Henry D. Mercer, president of the steamship company at 80 Broad Street.

Armour Co. issued yesterday for the first time a semi-annual report of operations, disclosing a net loss of $6,512,634 for the twenty-six weeks ended on April 30, compared with the $1,756,131 loss sustained in the corresponding period a year earlier.

Lesser folk may complain it's "too hot to eat," but the gourmet goes gallantly on, hunting out fine food and wine even when New York sidewalks sizzle. One of such intrepid appetite recently discovered the Cyrano, and reported it to this department as "a restaurant that will console those who, remaining in town while their friends go shoreward, are full of self-pity."

HARTFORD, Conn., July 6 (AP) -- The Republican-controlled House today defied Gov. Chester Bowles' proclamation adjourning the Connecticut General Assembly's special session, and accused the Democratic Chief Executive of acting as a "dictator."

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Senator Hugh Butler, Republican, of Nebraska, said today it would be "disastrous" to order a trial run of the Brannan farm price plan on hogs. He said it would wreck the agricultural economy.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 6 -- Lebanese gendarmerie and troops, aided by Syrian reinforcements, have frustrated an abortive armed rebellion staged by Anton Saadeh's terrorist, fascist Popular Syrian party, the Government announced tonight.

H. Graham Morison, an assistant United States Attorney General, returned yesterday on the United States liner America from Europe, where he attended a discussion of missing persons. The meeting, sponsored by the United Nations Economic and Social Council, was held in Geneva.

Declaring that it had received inquiries on its position on gambling in golf, particularly through auction pools and sweepstakes, the executive committee of the United States Golf Association yesterday issued a statement opposing organized gambling and saying it would be guided in dealing with individual cases by the intent for which an event was conducted or the purpose for which a player competed.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A bitter floor fight appeared in prospect today as the House began debating a bill upholding the right of manufacturers to absorb shipping costs in order to quote uniform delivered prices throughout the country.

TRIESTE, July 6 (AP) -- The Greek guerrilla radio charged today that Greek Government troops freely and openly used Yugoslav soil in the Kaimakchalan Mountain area in launching attacks against the guerrillas.

Jacqueline Perves, a French nurse, who received the Croix de Guerre during World War II for capturing thirteen German soldiers single-handed, arrived here yesterday for an American vacation. Mme. Perves, who is also an accomplished airplane pilot and parachute tester, was one of 706 passengers aboard the French liner De Grasse that docked at Pier 88, North River.

Total resources of the Chase National Bank of the City of New York rose to $4,677,221,404 on June 30, from $4,461,430,548 on March 31, and $4,551,331,951 at the end of June last year according to the bank's statement of condition issued yesterday for publication today.
GENEVA, July 6 -- Britain's efforts to rally the Commonwealth to support of the pound sterling in the current crisis are being watched with the greatest interest and apprehension in Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Ellis Kinder posted his eighth victory tonight as the Red Sox defeated Washington, 5 -- 0, in a game called in the sixth inning due to rain.

Florence Reichman has fashioned her fall hats to meet the season's dress demands, according to her statement made yesterday morning at her presentation in her showroom, 1 West Fifty-seventh Street. She courts the sculptured line, one that molds the head, descends rather low in the nape and is more often than not apt to sweep down and forward on the left side.

Residents in the New York metropolitan area will be able to study American history and contemporary world issues in their own homes via television beginning early next year when, for the first time, the Board of Higher Education and the Columbia Broadcasting System will cooperate to televise a college program.
CHICAGO, July 6 (UP) -- A special court made up of three Federal judges will test the constitutionality of the new Federal Rent Control Law in hearings beginning Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Atomic bomb production is now "in the best shape ever," Dr. Robert Fox Bacher testified today as the Atomic Energy Commission began rebuttal to charges of "incredible mismanagement" against its chairman, David E. Lilienthal.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 6 -- An economic survey of Rumania reporting rising unemployment, falling production, price inflation, destruction of huge foodstocks and oil reserves through acts of sabotage, strikes and widespread discontent was published today by Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party.

About 44,000 persons -- 6 per cent of the record 721,000 who have filed claims for unemployment insurance in this state in the last six weeks -- are suffering delays in collecting their benefits, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, July 6 (AP) -- Following the text of the statement to the House of Commons today by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer:

IT was too little an item for so big a man. With factual simplicity it merely stated that Rudy York had begun his career as a manager with the Griffin Tigers of the Class D Georgia-Alabama League. After twelve years in the majors the powerfully built native of Cartersville, Ga., is back where he started from in the lower minors. He certainly eased out of the Big Time unobtrusively, didn't he?

Customer response to the extension of terms for buying cars indicated yesterday that the easing of credits would bring many additional purchasers into the market, according to Walter E. Kolb, president of the Industrial Bank of Commerce.
Declaring that he had been disturbed by reports that he was a Communist or a "fellow traveler," Canada Lee, actor, denied yesterday that he was a member of the Communist party.

John J. Woods, director of labor relations for the Department of Sanitation, is under consideration for appointment as a deputy commissioner of the Board of Transportation to handle labor problems for that agency, it was learned last night.
The political meaning of the North Atlantic pact was being debated in the Senate yesterday against the undefined -- and largely unmentioned -- background of military realism.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, said today the Treasury should finance Presidential campaigns so Federal jobs and favors would not be sold as political plums.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- The role of Tokyo Rose as a propagandist for Japan in the Pacific war was pictured today by the prosecution in the treason trial of Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino as a "glamorous job" performed "gladly" by the American-born defendant "without duress or compulsion."

LONDON, July 6 -- The Foreign Ministers' deputies for Austria devoted their entire session this morning to seeking clarification of the list of oil and shipping properties in eastern Austria that Russia is claiming under provisions of the recent Paris agreement.

TOKYO, July 6 -- The Allied occupation and the Japanese Government today faced what is ever more clearly becoming the first case since the surrender of political assassination -- an old familiar device whereby the Japanese Army's junior officers in the prewar period forced the nation into a totalitarian regime by murdering opponents.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- As the White House announced today that Monday was the "target date" for sending the President's mid-year report on the nation's economy to Congress, strong opposition to any Presidential controls was expressed by a prominent business research group.

Growing doubt that former Governor Herbert H. Lehman will consent to run for United States Senator to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Robert F. Wagner threw the situation in the Democratic party in city and state into confusion yesterday.

Three messmen of the crew of the Polish liner Batory, who jumped ship while she was docked here, were arrested at 73 East Twenty-second Street, Bayonne, N. J., at 7:30 o'clock last night in the home of Frank Antczak, a butcher.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Continued heavy buying of wheat futures by mills and cash interests, regarded as removal of hedges against large sales of flour, kept prices on the Board of Trade on the upgrade from the start today. The active deliveries sold at a new high since early February, and closed 4 1/4 to 5 7/8 cents a bushel higher, July leading.
Quartus P. Graves, who joined Eversharp, Inc., fourteen years ago as a junior salesman, has been promoted to Eastern regional manager.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill setting up the machinery for the distribution in this country of the $17,000,000 obtained from the Yugoslav Government in lump settlement of United States claims.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Increased savings deposits, total deposits and holdings of Government securities were reported by Chicago national and state banks today. Cash resources and loans and discounts were lower.

Analysis of the possible effects of the housing bill agreed upon last night by a House-Senate conference committee fails to show justification for the fears expressed by opponents of the measure that it might stifle private home and apartment building in this country.

CRISFIELD, Md., July 6 (AP) -- Maryland and Virginia, both issued murder warrants today against David Acree, 26-year-old Virginia fisheries deputy, in their wrangle over seafood regulations in Chesapeake Bay.

When at almost any moment we can look up and see the flash of silver wings above the spires of New York, it seems almost incredible that it was only twenty years ago today that the continent was first spanned in scheduled service by a combination of air and rail travel.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- With fitting and reverential gravity the Senate listened yesterday to the first prayer of its chaplain in the historic chamber to which it has temporarily been driven by architects, carpenters and masons. With the same mien Senators listened to Mr. Connally of Texas as he opened the debate on the North Atlantic Treaty by "invoking the shades of the great men who have served and struggled here."
ROME, July 6 -- Pope Pius today appealed to all non-Communist nations, regardless of their religion, to coordinate their efforts and fight communism in all its manifestations.

CRISFIELD, Md., July 6 -- State's Attorney E. McMaster Duer of Somerset County, Md., said tonight after completing his investigation of the Chesapeake Bay shooting that he would make every effort to bring to trial the two men for whom warrants were issued today.

Gilbert Green, one of the top leaders of the Communist party, admitted at the Communist trial yesterday that The Daily Worker is the party's official organ in the sense that the party officially "supports" it. John Gates, editor of the paper, had denied from the same witness stand that it is the official organ in any sense.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 6 -- Sagamore Hill, former home of President Theodore Roosevelt and one-time summer White House, is to become a national shrine.
Two alien Communists were taken to Ellis Island yesterday by agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service for deportation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 6 -- Republican judges in Connecticut's sixty-nine minor courts, striving to retain their positions, tonight named Meade Alcorn of Suffield, former Hartford County State's Attorney, to represent them as general counsel.

Yields on the Treasury's short-term securities continued to decline yesterday, despite the fact that the rest of the market for Government securities seemed to be content to get its breath after the successive price advances of the past week.

LONDON, July 6 -- Some unpublicized aspects of Britain's recent air exercises that have come to light here bring into better balance the praise that senior Royal Air Force officers and political service chiefs lavished on the British military aviation last Sunday.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 (AP) -- Johnny Hopp's ninth-inning single with the bases filled to score Phil Masi and Eddie Fitz Gerald gave the Pirates a 4-3 victory over the Cardinals tonight and their fifth victory in a row. Murry Dickson, who pitched shutout ball for six innings, got credit for the triumph before a crowd of 32,983.

A combination of circumstances in the domestic and foreign glove industries will limit the availability of women's and misses' gloves next fall, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Wholesalers' stocks cannot provide quick replenishments on re-orders as anticipated by many large retailers who have bought less than 50 per cent of their season's requirements.

CLEVELAND, July 6 -- Agreements have been signed for the sale of assets of the seventy-six-year-old Ohio Rubber Company, of Willoughby, Ohio, to a new company financed by the management of the present company and a group of investors in New York, Philadelphia and St. Louis, it was announced late today by Franklin G. Smith, president.

ALBANY, July 6 -- Governor Dewey announced today that he has accepted, with "greatest reluctance," the resignation of Charles Garside, of New York City, from the chairmanship of the State Commission Against Discrimination, in which office he has served since April 22, 1947.

Mitzi Solomon, sculptor, of 208 Central Park South, was married on Sunday to Marcus Faulkner Cunliffe, English author and teacher, in a civil ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Eggert, Barrytown, N. Y. Announcement of the marriage was made yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board voted 4 to 1 today to authorize a piecemeal union shop for employes of the Western Electric Company if a majority of those represented by the association of the Communication Equipment Workers, CIO, wanted it.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Senate today approved legislation for a long-range program to aid more than 60,000 Navajo and Hopi Indians in the Southwest.

GREENWICH, Conn, July 6 -- Seabury House, the ninety-eight-acre estate that the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States acquired two years ago, has grown in religious significance and usefulness to become the "spiritual capital" of the communion, leaders said today.

MANCHESTER, England, July 6 (Reuters) -- A hard-hitting fourth wickets stand by Jack Ikin and Ken Grieves which scored 248 runs put Lancashire in a strong position against the touring New Zealand cricketers today. At the close of play Lancashire had scored 467 for five wickets.

Paul De Kruif, who has written several books about bacteriology and medicine, has a new volume that Harcourt, Brace will bring out on Sept. 22. It is "Life Among the Doctors," an account of how man has gained the power to control disease and what that power can mean.

LONDON, July 6 -- Troops will be sent into London's dock area to unload food from ships tied up by the strike of dockworkers, George Isaacs, Minister of Labor, announced today. He also told Commons the Government was considering taking other steps.
William H. Byrne, president of Byrne Associates, Inc., of 50 Broadway, was sworn in yesterday at City Hall by Mayor O'Dwyer as acting director of the Board of Smoke Control, and went to work at once.

Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Britain's economic chief, confirmed to the House of Commons yesterday reports that there had been a serious drain on the gold and dollar reserves of the so-called "sterling area" during the second quarter of 1949.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The House majority leader, John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, denounced tonight the $300,000,000 Federal aid to education bill which an Education and Labor subcommittee approved last month and predicted that it would not become law.

THERE are so many good stories about Ford Madox Ford in Douglas Goldring's "Trained for Genius."* and so many good stories about his contemporaries, from Henry James and Joseph Conrad to Ernest Hemingway and all the Americans-in-Paris whose legion is named, that this rather admiring and combative sketch for a portrait of Ford should be widely read.

LONDON, July 6 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Stafford Cripps' declaration in the House of Commons today that the Government had not the slightest intention of devaluing the pound came too late in the day to save speculators who had bid for gold-mining shares as soon as the stock markets opened.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve System announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 29:

Richard Henderson Crowe, Staten Island civic leader who raised $267,000,000 for the Treasury Department as chairman of eight World War II bond-selling drives, was sentenced in Federal Court yesterday to three years in prison and five years probation for stealing $883,660 from the National City Bank branch where he was assistant manager.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- J. H. De La Rosa said today the late George Berry ran the International Pressmen's Union, AFL, with an "iron hand." He suggested that protests -- even from other officers -- were useless.

Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., sold yesterday $2, 500,000 of water and sewer bonds due on each July 1, from 1950 to 1989 to Phelps, Fenn Co. and associates at a bid of 100 for 4s, 3 1/4 s, and 3s, an interest cost of 3.1135 per cent.

A Nassau County detective testified in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday that Martha J. Beck described a heavy ballpeen hammer as "like the one I used to hit Mrs. Fay" and identified the toolbox from which it had been taken as the property of Raymond M. Fernandez, co-defendant in the "lonely hearts" murder trial.

The stock market pushed ahead yesterday for the fifth consecutive day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange and raised the price average to the best level in six weeks. Gains of fractions to about a point ruled, with wider advances in a few thin-market stocks, while the index advanced 0.50 point.
LONDON, July 6 -- J. Arthur Rank, leading British movie producer, said today that the British industry would have to make cheaper pictures.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 6 (AP) -- Eleven sidewheelers -- the leading pacers now in training -- will take a crack at the $25,000 National Pacing Derby tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- Samuel Goldwyn announced today that Dana Andrews will appear with Farley Granger in the screen adaption of Leo Brady's novel, "Edge of Doom," which Mark Robson will direct in October. The story deals with the murder of a priest, and Andrews will take the role of a fellow priest who helps track down the killer, to be played by Granger.

Two instructors, dismissed from City College this spring, accused the college administration yesterday of pursuing a "policy of discrimination and thought control," and declared that it Was "getting rid of anyone who might object."

On the basis of the record for the first six months, the Health Department estimated yesterday that there would be about 155,000 births in the city this year. This compares with 157,184 births last year and the record total of 171,174 in 1947.

Seeded players continued their advance in the annual women's Eastern clay court tennis championships yesterday at the New York Tennis Club, the Bronx. Steady rain toward the finish of the program resulted in three of the second-round matches being postponed to today, when play also will begin in doubles.

An all-Spanish revue, "Cabalgata," will make its New York debut this evening at the Broadway Theatre under the auspices of S. Hurok, better known for his work as a ballet impresario and for his services as tour director for the Metropolitan Opera Company.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Representative F. Edward Hebert, Democrat, of Louisiana, during persistent questioning of Louis Johnson at the latter's appearance before the House Armed Services Committee, asked the Secretary of Defense if he had ever sought "reprisals" against newspaper men or radio commentators who had disagreed with him.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The North Atlantic treaty is "the greatest discouragement to war" yet put forward because it signs in advance a "warrant of doom" for any aggressor, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan declared today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UP) -- The weather and crop-destroying insects appear to be teaming up to prevent the price-depressing grain surplus which seemed inevitable only a few weeks ago, Government officials said today.

Your leading editorial of July 5 on the Atlantic Pact debate which is now beginning makes certain statements which seem contradictory, which call for further discussion, and which make undesirable the ratification of the Atlantic Pact in this session of Congress.

WILTON, Conn., July 6 -- William Gaston of New Canaan, Democratic candidate for Congress from the Fourth District last November, was fined $50 in Town Court here today by Justice of the Peace Albert Perry.

Typical of the amount of research that milliners do in creating their collections was Mary Goodfellow's fall presentation, seen yesterday at 600 Madison Avenue. It gathered its inspiration from such varied sources as Audubon bird prints, the astral bodies and medieval head gear.

BOSTON, July 6 -- In this town the Dodgers still are duds. They have yet to win a game here this year, having dropped the fourth one to the Braves tonight, 7-5, with Big Ralph Branca being belted out within two innings for the second time in four days.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., July 6 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation voted today whether to retain or oust the present management as a prolonged bitter battle for control neared its end. The fight was between Sherman Fairchild, founder and a principal stockholder of the company, and its management, headed by J. Carlton Ward Jr., chairman of the board, and L. B. Richardson, president.

American maritime workers including seamen and longshore employes may apply a boycott to all British-flag shipping in eastern American ports in retaliation for the immobilization of Canadian ships in England, it was announced yesterday.

While there is no reason to be in a "panic" about the current unemployment situation, there should be broad community planning in case of an emergency, Peter Kasius, newly appointed deputy commissioner for the State Department of Social Welfare, declared yesterday.

PARIS, July 6 -- A plenary session today of the International Telegraph and Telephone Conference reversed a decision reached by its telegraph tariffs committee and a vote of 23 to 18 decided that urgent rate telegrams would continue to bear a charge equal to twice the charge for ordinary full rate telegrams.

Advertising in the eight major New York City newspapers during June totaled 13,318,275 lines, a gain of 4.68 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: Automotive, up 34.35 per cent; retail, 6.35 per cent, and general, 5.06 per cent.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 6 -- William Talbert and Gardnar Mulloy, the national doubles tennis champions; Donald McNeill, former national singles titleholder, and Frank Shields, finalist in the British and American championships, all of whom are competing here, will appear in a doubles match at the Yankee Stadium Monday, on the "Night of Champions" benefit program.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- Federal Judge Knight said today that assets of the Playboy Motor Car Corporation would have to be sold at public auction. He made the statement at a hearing at which he agreed to extend to Aug. 6 a deadline for filing plans for reorganization of the company.

The death sentence of Daniel Gentile, one of three convicted slayers of Anthony Hintz, a boss stevedore, was commuted to life imprisonment yesterday less than thirty-six hours before he was to have been executed at Sing Sing Prison. Governor Dewey commuted the sentence on the recommendation of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

" Follow Me Quietly," an RKO melodrama starring William Lun digan, which opens at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Richard Fleischer directed and Herman Schlom produced the offering from a screen play by Lillie Hayward and a story by Francis Rosenwald and Anthony Mann.
ATHENS, July 6 -- Of 273 deputies in the Chamber tonight, 199 voted to support the new Populist-Liberal Coalition government of Premier Alexander Diomedes. There were two abstentions.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 -- The United States Steel Corporation and the CIO United Steelworkers virtually broke off negotiations today and the union implied that the next step would be a strike of the basic steel industry ten days hence.

Mill prices of hardwood lumber, which have been declining gradually but steadily since Jan. 1, are beginning to stabilize and may increase in the near future, O. R. Cheatham, president, Georgia-Pacific Plywood Lumber Company, said yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 6 -- The United States State Department has moderated its pressure for early Israel action concerning the repatriation of Arab refugees, but this indicates no lessening of the gap on the refugee question between Washington and Tel Aviv, according to well-informed sources here today.
WILLMINGTON, Del., July 6 (AP) -- The United States District Court today approved the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation's amended dissolution plan.

Space in the thirty-six-story office building under construction at 100 Park Avenue has been rented by Philip Morris Co. through Cushman Wakefield, renting agents. The cigarette firm, which has joined a list of large national organizations in taking space in the new structure on the old Murray Hill Hotel site, will occupy the fourth floor and a portion of the fifth floor.
I Th .cotton futUreS ,-market on the New York CottOn-Exchange turned barely steady yesterday, 'and final prices were tl to 27 points net lower than on Tuesday.

BUENOS AIRES, July 6 -- President Juan D. Peron last night said that a new economic crisis was upon the world but declared his Government had anticipated it and had already taken all necessary steps to meet and overcome its effects in Argentina.

WARSAW, July 6 -- Poland has joined the Eastern European economic blockade of Yugoslavia by suspending all trade deliveries. Informing the Yugoslav Ambassador of the move, the Polish Government said today it had been taken primarily because Yugoslavia had not lived up to last year's trade obligations and was delivering nothing but nonessentials this year.
Ye Olde Town Crier clanged his bell New England style in Times Square yesterday and asked "all ye goode citizens of New York Town" to name their choice for Mayor.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 6 -- The United Nations today gave recognition to Ethiopia as the official winner in the race to ratify the genocide convention in a decision that nullified claims made yesterday for the honor on behalf of Norway.
The village of Dun-sur-Meuse in France is going to have a bronze railing on its bridge again.
Do you want to keep cool?

A new program stressing the dramatic episodes in the lives of ordinary persons suffering from minor and major neuroses will be inaugurated by the NBC television network next Thursday, July 14, at 9:30 P. M. Its title is "Theatre of the Mind."
Decorator colors are found in virtually every bathroom accessory these days from shower curtains to hampers, making it feasible to have refreshing room schemes for these often-neglected areas.

The hard fact that 700,000 World War II veterans, now receiving $20 a week unemployment benefits, will be cut off the insurance rolls on July 25 is receiving little or no attention in the press. It is difficult to believe that the fate of this large group, many with families, and the attendant consequences to our national economy, can leave the responsible press indifferent.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- Rain interrupted the Yankees and Athletics after an inning and a half tonight at Shibe Park. The umpires and 33,876 fans, the second largest turnout of the season here, waited an hour 15 minutes for the downpour to stop.

Coffee futures again moved into new high ground on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Strong trade demand and commission house short coverings advanced prices for contract "S" 24 to 44 points. July "S" sold at an all time high for futures.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Government today approved the use of twelve war-surplus ships as emergency grain storage facilities for the near-record wheat crop now being harvested. The Maritime Commission and the Department of Agriculture in a joint action, said the ships would be used on an experimental basis to determine feasibility of the plan.

The Long Island Rail Road has photographed 15,000 of its 100,000 commuters since it began such preparations June 27 for introducing a new permanent identification "pass-type" commutation ticket after Sept. 1, it was disclosed yesterday.

ROME, July 6 -- The Italian Government today appealed to the United States, Britain and France to take steps to prevent any effort by Belgrade aimed at incorporating the Yugoslav-occupied zone of the Free Territory of Trieste within Yugoslavia.
BRUSSELS, July 6 (U.P.) -- Prince Regent Charles named M. van Cauwelaert, former Catholic president of the House of Representatives, "informant," a post tantamount to Premier-designate.

ASPEN, Col., July 6 -- Dr. Albert Schweitzer, 74-year-old missionary-philosopher who has devoted his life to humanitarian service, today extolled the philosophy of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe as one that, if more widely accepted, would contribute to the well-being of society and aid mankind in its search for liberty.

Harold D. Leslie purchased the two-story dwelling at 21-12 147th Street, Whitestone, Queens, from John J. V. Sullivan. James M. McCready was the broker. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured the title.

BERLIN, July 6 -- The Soviet Union's chances of ousting Premier Marshal Tito and his followers in Yugoslavia and thus eliminating the gravest ideological challenge to Stalinist communism in the Marxist world have not improved and Marshal Tito appears secure for the remainder of 1949, in the opinion of one of the leading Western experts on the Soviet Union in this city.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 6 -- The continued absence of Acting Premier-Foreign Minister Vassil Kolarov has given rise to rumors that he is seriously ill. For some time now Mr. Kolarov has made no public appearance, and no messages were attributed to him in connection with the death of Premier Georgi Dimitrov in Russia.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Four of the six designs that won awards last January in the international low-cost furniture competition sponsored by the Museum of Modern Art and Design Project, Inc., have been accepted by manufacturers and will be put into production shortly.

BOSTON, July 6 -- At a tumultuous session that frequently got out of hand, 3,000 delegates attending the National Education Association convention voted today in favor of a flat ban against permitting Communist party members to teach in the nation's schools.

PARIS, July 6 -- Officers of the National Assembly decided today to uphold Assembly President Edouard Herriot in a contested vote that occurred early this morning during discussion of the case of three Madagascar Deputies under sentence for treason.

SANDWICH, England, July 6 (AP) -- Jimmy Adams, a chubby Scotsman, ripped off a sizzling 67 at Royal St. Georges today to outshoot ninety-five rivals in the first round of the British open golf championship.

This seems to be a woodchuck year, but either the heat or the fishing urge seems to have reduced the activity of the varmint shooters, for a number of letters have come in from farmers who report that the 'chucks are well advanced in the "pest" classification.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Tighe E. Woods, Housing Expeditor, defined the words "luxury housing accommodations" today in a new regulation to permit decontrol of such accommodations as provided under the Housing and Rent Act of 1949.
SOFIA, July 6 -- Residents of Sofia wept unrestrainedly as the body of Premier Dimitrov arrived today in a special train from Moscow.

Two-thirds of highway accidents are caused by driver errors, Charles J. Seyffer, Northeastern regional manager of the Ford Motor Company, said yesterday. Excessive speed causes more fatalities and injuries than any other single traffic violation, he added.

Columbia University's Teachers College, the home of many pioneer educational practices, reported success yesterday with its "Bookateria," a cafeteria-like bookstore that not only provides students with food for thought but also makes book-buying a lot easier.
SEOUL, Korea, July 6 -- The Korean Government asserted today that eight Soviet soldiers had been wounded by National Army forces in the fighting on Ongjin Peninsula.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 6 -- The Nassau County Transit Commission carried its running debate with Walter S. Franklin, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, one step further today.
JOGJAKARTA, Java, July 6 -- President Sukarno returned in triumph today to the capital from which he had been ejected last January by the Dutch who had interned him on Banka Island.

Stock and foreign exchange markets here reacted mildly to disclosures in London yesterday that the Empire's gold and dollar reserves had sunk to $1,636,180,000, well below the $2,000,000,000 "safety" level fixed some time ago by Britain's Treasury.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California, said today that a bill authorizing President Truman to intervene in the longshoremen's strike in Hawaii would be introduced tomorrow.

Fifteen busloads of Girl Scouts set out yesterday to trap a deluge. They left the drought-stricken city equipped with high boots, rubbers, raincoats and umbrellas to spend two weeks hunting for rain at four Girl Scout camps.

CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP) -- The usually mild-mannered Cincinnati Reds, paced by Walker Cooper's three, three-run homers, got hotter than the near 100-degree weather today as they annihilated the Chicago Cubs, 23 -- 4, for the biggest score of the major league season.

Fifteen busloads of Girl Scouts set out yesterday to trap a deluge. They left the drought-stricken city equipped with high boots, rubbers, raincoats and umbrellas to spend two weeks hunting for rain at four Girl Scout camps.

CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP) -- The usually mild-mannered Cincinnati Reds, paced by Walker Cooper's three, three-run homers, got hotter than the near 100-degree weather today as they annihilated the Chicago Cubs, 23 -- 4, for the biggest score of the major league season.

CHICAGO, July 6 -- Business in the first two days of the midsummer home furnishings show reached a more prosperous level than either buyers or sellers had expected, trade spokesmen at the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart said today.

With seven representatives apiece, the Dodgers and the Cardinals, befitting their status as the virtually deadlocked front-runners in the pennant race, dominate the National League squad named yesterday for the sixteenth annual major league all-star game at Ebbets Field next Tuesday.

Four new issues of railroad and public utility securities were sold to banking syndicates at competitive bidding yesterday. The offerings included $18,000,000 of railroad equipment-trust certificates, $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds and $5,000,000 of par value of new preferred stock.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 6 (AP) -- Jerry McCarthy's Egretta, a triple stakes winner last season as a juvenile, reached the winner's circle for the first time this year in today's feature at Monmouth Park. The daughter of Ramilles, alertly handled by Danny Johnston, led practically all the way and was timed in 1:13 for the six furlongs.
Heavy showers that began about 6 P. M. yesterday brought the first substantial relief in parts of the metropolitan area from the drought that had parched the Northeast states for forty-one days.

These are days when young gentlemen clad in slacks and pastel shirts open at the neck who venture into cool and quiet havens afforded by some of this town's elegant oases are discovering that they are greeted by suave, white-coated servitors with the words, "Sorry, gentlemen. No jackets."

Department store stocks in the Second Federal Reserve District at the close of business, May 31, were 8 per cent below the corresponding day in 1948, according to figures announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The largest individual decline was in wines and liquors, which were off 53 per cent.

One important element that seems to be overlooked in the current discussions of rising relief expenditures is the role of the private welfare agencies that are daily helping families to keep economically productive. Commissioner Hilliard himself made the point some months ago when, in addressing a meeting of the Community Service Society, he declared: "You can be sure that we in public welfare could not operate successfully without you in private welfare. * * *

With infantile paralysis cases showing an increase over the bad year of 1948 that is already described as "disturbing," if not alarming, chapter heads of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis from all parts of the country met in emergency session yesterday at the Statler Hotel under the chairmanship of Basil O'Connor, president.

A thirty-minute cloudburst on top of an earlier sprinkle that had kept the teams off the field altogether necessitated the postponement of last night's scheduled contest between the Giants and the Phillies at the Polo Grounds.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 6 -- Playing the best game of her career, Mrs. Albert Schwartz of the home club won low gross honors in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day Class B tournament over the Elmwood course today with a 47, 45 -- 92.

Operations of the pressed-metal industry in Great Britain still are hampered because of steel shortages, James M. Phillips, leader of a ten-man British "productivity team," said here yesterday during a conference over an educational tour arranged by the Economic Cooperation Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Senate and House conferees reached agreement tonight on the final form of the national housing bill which, in slightly differing versions, already has won the approval of the two Houses of Congress.

Senator Vandenberg yesterday put the great weight of his prestige behind the North Atlantic Treaty and urged its early ratification as the best available implement to discourage armed aggression. His active support of the Treaty is all the more important because he is one of the authors of the bipartisan foreign policy that routed Republican isolationism.

Fifty passengers on a ten-car Brooklyn-bound Seventh Avenue IRT express walked 180 feet along a catwalk at 8:44 A. M. yesterday when a short circuit stalled the train just south of the Wall Street station. Southbound express service was disrupted for an hour, the Board of Transportation reported.

LONDON, July 6 -- In a frank outline of Britain's grave financial situation, Sir Stafford Cripps announced today that the Government had ordered a halt in all new purchasing from the United States and Canada until at least mid-September in an effort to safeguard the country's diminishing gold and dollar reserves.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, military aide to President Truman, returned tonight from Guatemala saying he had been on vacation like anyone else.
