CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- Bud Souchock's base-cleaning double in the eighth inning gave the White Sox a 9 -- 6 victory over the Indians before 24,444 persons tonight. The victory was Chicago's fifth in as many games against the Indians here this season.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The House Armed Services Committee made it palin today that it would strengthen the authority of the Secretary of Defense only under provisions assuring Congress even tighter control over his decisions and operations.

While footloose New Yorkers with a yen for a free yacht trip flocked to Pier 6, Tompkinsville, S. I., to "sign on" as crew for the fifty-three-foot yacht Capry, its owner, Robert Cook, was sorely distressed yesterday when he discovered that thieves had broken in and stolen $300 worth of food, clothing and equipment.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- A sharp increase in outlays by public agencies sent spending for new construction to a record high of nearly $8,500,000,000 during the first half of 1949.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 6 -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, national champion from Los Angeles, dropped a set today to Alastair Bradley Martin of Glen Head, L. I., and Irvin Dorfman was eliminated by his former Yale team-mate, Jack Geller, in the invitation Spring Lake tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

David and Morton Wolfenson have sold the six-story apartment building at 1970 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, to Diamond Affiliates, represented by Herman Pedowitz, attorney. The building is on a plot 100 by 260 feet. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday the adoption of a route and general plan for a structural connection between the end of the Fulton Street subway line in Brooklyn and the Fulton Street elevated line to Liberty Avenue and 119th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens.
The Public Service Commission authorized the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday to construct three and one-half miles of gas main in Queens at a cost of $1,100,000 to carry natural gas.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 6 -- Traffic bottlenecks that could become some of the worst in the metropolitan area are developing in southern Westchester, with the problem threatening to get out of hand when New York City's Major Deegan Expressway for mixed traffic is completed to the Westchester boundary in two years, county officials warned today.

A young Brooklyn couple, who had been arrested Tuesday night on an abandonment charge, were paroled yesterday by Magistrate Philip B. Thurston for hearing July 15. The magistrate ordered a thorough investigation of the circumstances involved in their alleged abandonment of their baby son in Bellevue Hospital.

Whittaker Chambers was denounced as "a man who believes in nothing" by Lloyd Paul Stryker yesterday as the defense attorney for Alger Hiss sought to demolish the testimony of his client's chief accuser. With the case scheduled to go to the jury by 5 o'clock this afternoon, Mr. Stryker spent three hours and ten minutes summing up yesterday.

PARIS, July 6 -- In the talks that United States Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder has started here in the interests of monetary stability and liberalizing of trade, the efforts of the French are concentrated on conciliation that would prevent the tightening of tension between Britain and the United States and on preventing any British action that would jeopardize the progress that has been made by European nations under the Marshall Plan.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 6 (AP) -- Proximity, brown mare owned by Gordon and Ralph Verhurst of Victor, N. Y., today won the $10,000 Titan free-for-all trot at Historic Track.
Excerpts from Judge Samuel H. Kaufman's charge to the Hiss jury yesterday follow:

The troubles of Samuel Broxmeyer, bankrupt real estate and financial operator, spread yesterday in the Federal Building from civil to criminal jurisdiction and involved eleven other persons, including relatives, employes and a former bank official in checkkiting charges.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations will claim in two major official reports scheduled for release next week that the pattern of American industry's profits for the first quarter of 1949 justify the payment of a new round of wage increases without price increases.

MILWAUKEE, July 7 -- The international executive board of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, assembled in a pre-convention meeting, began today to adjust top-level strategy to dovetail with the maneuvers of the United Steelworkers, CIO, in effecting maximum pressure in the 1949 drive for pensions and other economic demands.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The CIO Maritime Committee told Congress today that it favored extension of a construction-differential subsidy to all American Ships in foreign trade.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 -- Mrs. Iva Toguri (Tokyo Rose) D'Aquino, accused of making treasonable broadcasts for Japan in wartime, was claiming United States citizenship more than two years after her marriage to a Portuguese, according to statements read into the record at her trial here today.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- The Indians crushed the White Sox, 8 -- 2, today with only Joe Gordon failing to share in the 17-hit attack. Before 5,186 persons, Bob Lemon's nine-hit pitching produced Cleveland's first victory in Chicago after four straight losses.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Truman said today he did not know whether he wanted authority to intervene in the longshoremen's strike in Hawaii -- authority which he has held he does not now possess.

A drive to enlist aid for American Indians among civic organizations throughout the country was announced yesterday by Oliver La Farge, the author and chairman of the American Indian Fund, 48 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Suspension of six union officers by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation at its Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, shipyard, resulted yesterday in a strike by about 1,000 ship repairmen in Local 13, Industrial Union of Maritime and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO.
WASHINGTON, July.7 -- Tighe E. Woods, Housing Expediter, said today he had recovered $1,596,735 for veterans who were cheated on new homes.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 7 -- Extensive rioting by Slovak villagers seeking to prevent the arrest of their priests was acknowledged for the first time today by the Government press, which reported sentences ranging from two to ten years imposed upon the rioters.

William H. Byrne has now been installed as acting director of the Board of Smoke Control, and certain unidentified city department heads interested in Mr. Byrne's work are reported to be concerned over the amount that the permanent budget of the new board will allow for salaries, especially those of inspectors.

Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman ordered the jury in the Alger Hiss perjury case locked up at 10:30 o'clock last night when it reported no prospect of an early verdict after deliberating for four hours and forty minutes. The case went to the jury at 4:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Orders for machine tools have been unchanged so far in the buying wave which has appeared in metals and metal products, distributors reported here yesterday. Total national orders for machine tools for June were only $20,000,000, it was learned, and the trend so far for July is at the same rate.

Radio hits the nerve of the nation. Safeguarding a fundamental principle of the American educational system is everyone's job. Programs of murder and gunplay furnish us with escapist literature, when what is needed is something to bring us sharply to our senses. We all know what impressions such programs leave on the minds of young and old alike.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A formal protest against "illegal acts" of the United States Immigration Service aboard the Russian ship Dimitri Donskoi at Elizabeth, N. J., yesterday was filed at the State Department today by Alexander S. Panyushkin, Soviet Ambassador.

SANDWICH, England, July 7 (AP) -- Sam King, the only Briton to beat an American in the 1947 Ryder Cup matches, shot his way to the front in the British Open golf championship today with the only 69 posted in wind and rain.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 7 -- Improving steadily in the final rush down the stretch, Jimmy Creed, 7-year-old chestnut owned by Silas C. Thompson of New Ross, Ind., stepped across the finish line the winner of the $25,000 National Pacing Derby at the Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Federal Government moved today into the stalled negotiations between the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO.

Net income of $14,037,700 was reported by American Foreign Power Company, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended March 31, 1949. The figure compares with $10,596,768 for the preceding twelve months. Earnings for the year were equal to $16.21 on combined first preferred shares compared with $12.23 the year before.
TOKYO, July 7 -- Japan's economic recovery has all but halted as a result, primarily, of a lack of credit, according to the newspaper Yomiuri today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The North Atlantic Treaty was attacked both frontally and obliquely today in the third day of the Senate's debate on the issue of its ratification.

Governor Dewey did not have to search hard or to think long in order to find an admirably qualified successor to Robert F. Wagner as a member of the Senate. The name of John Foster Dulles must have come to his mind promptly, logically and with gratitude that the services of so able and experienced a nominee were available to the people of New York.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 7 -Industrial research that aims to alter profoundly the economic picture of the Midwest is being worked out in many scientific laboratories in this region. Leading and coordinating this research is the non-profit Midwest Research Institute here.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- A possible compromise between the Truman Administration and Republicans on a farm program for the next two years took shape in the Senate today.

The butcher's scale read three and a half pounds, but the chicken looked scrawny to its purchaser. She snatched the bird from the storekeeper before he could clean it, deftly removed an eight-ounce slug from its gizzard and identified herself as an inspector of the city's Bureau of Weights and Measures.

SEOUL, Korea, July 7 -- The North Korean Soviet-controlled Communist regime announced yesterday it would sponsor nationwide elections Sept. 15 to create a "unified Legislature" that in turn would establish an all-Korea Government.

Perhaps Manager Eddie Sawyer of the Phillies may have a perfect right to be miffed at the omission of his Kenny Heintzelman from the National League All-Star squad. But, after last night, the leader of the Blue Jays, in all conscience, also would have to put in a strong plug for another very able southpaw.

DETROIT, July 7 -- Mayor Eugene I. Van Antwerp and the Common Council today ordered submitted to the voters on Sept. 13 a charter amendment which would sweep all Communists from the city government and thereafter prohibit Communists from holding municipal jobs.
LONDON, July 7 -- Final agreement on two important articles in the pending Austrian peace treaty was reached in a meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers deputies here today.

ATHENS, July 7 -- The General Staff reported tonight that the Greek Army's assault on rebel positions in the Kaimakchalan Mountain area along the Yugoslav border had met with success. Strongly fortified installations of the Communist-led guerrillas were said to have been destroyed; eighty-five of their defenders were reported killed, and another eighty-five captured.

ALBANY, July 7 -- State Senator Austin W. Erwin, chairman of the Temporary State Commission on Agriculture, announced today the appointment of thirteen New York City milk dealers to help develop a program for reducing costs of milk distribution there.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., July 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, commanding general of the First Army, who formerly was Ambassador to Russia, and a party of his high ranking officers toured the Army Signal Corps post here today as the guests of Maj. Gen. Francis H. Lanahan Jr., commanding general, and his staff.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Truman declared himself today to be "bullish" on the two paramount questions of the moment world peace and the economic health of the United States. His views on these matters were expressed at his weekly news conference.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -Complaints that imports of Japanese silks are driving domestic mills out of business will be carried directly to General MacArthur.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 7 -- Negotiations that will result in discontinuance of direct British financial aid to the West German economy are drawing to a close, or may be completed by this time, it was learned from official sources today.

The new public administrative and financing agency that the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania has set up under the name of the General State Authority was described yesterday to Wall Street's tax-exempt bona specialists by Gov. James H. Duff of Pennsylvania at the Bankers Trust Company.

The Reynolds Metal Company has taken a six months' option to buy 51 per cent of the common stock of the Southern States Iron Roofing Company, as part of an agreement made yesterday with this largest independent aluminum distributor in the United States, in order to increase the distribution and sales of Reynolds aluminum building products in the South.
The first 330 of an expected 600 or more veterans of both World Wars checked in at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday for the twenty-eighth annual reunion of the Second Division Association.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UP) -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark has informally approved a suggestion that Hawaii take over all its waterfront facilities and put striking dock workers under civil service, it was disclosed today.

Opposition to ratification of the North Atlantic Pact was expressed yesterday in letters to members of the United States Senate and signed by 216 clergymen, educators, labor leaders, writers and other persons in thirty states.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -- Louis B. Mayer, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer executive, in a trade paper interview today attacked film producers who make pictures bordering "on the obscene" with the excuse that the pictures are "real life stories" or that they contain "so-called messages."

That enterprising impresario, S. Hurok, who has brought us a diversity of talent from all points of the compass, is now offering an all-Spanish revue called "Cabalgata" at the Broadway Theatre. Since Mr. Hurok is a man of dependable taste, the news this morning is on the happy side.
PITTSBURGH, July 7 (AP) -- Ernie Bonham and rookie Dino Restelli collaborated against the Cardinals today to give the Pirates a 2-0 victory, their eighth in nine games.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Unfavorable crop reports from parts of the Dakotas and Montana combined with free buying of futures by mills, sent wheat futures up rapidly on the board of trade today to a new high since early last February.

PARIS, July 7 -- The French High Court of Appeals declined today to set aside a verdict of the Criminal Court in Tananarive, Madagascar, condemning two members of the National Assembly from that island to death and a third to life imprisonment for treasonable acts during the Malagasy rebellion last year.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Henri Bonnet, the French Ambassador, on behalf of the French Chambers of Commerce, gave Herman W. Steinkraus, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, a set of French-mint medals today to express appreciation for the participation of local chambers in this country in the "Friendship Train" project.
Mrs. Deering Howe's Donor, winner of ten stakes during the 1946-'47-'48 campaigns, made a triumphant return to the races in the main event of the Empire City-at-Jamaica proceedings yesterday.

City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr. took the stand yesterday as the third defendant to testify at the Communist trial and told as a Negro of his experiences with racial discrimination that led him to join the Communist party.

The Lehman Corporation, in its twentieth annual report, shows that net assets on June 30 were $43.30 a share, compared with $50.22 a share a year earlier. Signed by Robert Lehman, president, the report is released for publication today.

Governor Dewey yesterday appointed John Foster Dulles, his adviser on foreign policy and a distinguished international lawyer, United States Senator to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Robert F. Wagner.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 7 -- Israeli plans have been completed for reuniting Arab women and children with their families here. All that remains is for Egypt, Jordan and Lebanon to cooperate with Israel in setting up border immigration posts.

Negotiations between Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and the New York City Omnibus Corporation and Fifth Aveune Coach Company were opened and broken off yesterday in the space of forty-five minutes.

There was something new under the sun at Coney Island yesterday morning. Sixty-five boys and girls from 4 to 10 years old sat on the grass in Seaside Park, Sea Breeze Avenue and West Fifth Street, near the ocean, for one hour. And most of the time most of them were quiet.

In a bid for the Republican and Fusionist nomination in the forthcoming New York Mayoralty race, Percy C. Magnus, former president of the New York Board of Trade, announced yesterday that he was ready to serve as a candidate in the November election "to give this city a business administration and rid it of the political heelers."
HONOLULU, July 7 (AP) -- The union applauded today and employers opposed Senator Knowland's bill to authorize Presidential intervention in Hawaii's stevedore strike.

LONDON, July 7 -- The British Government moved troops into the strike-bound dock areas here today as the dock walkout showed no signs of improvement. About 300 men of the crack Coldstream and Scots Guards began unloading several thousand tons of meat and a party of sailors from Chatham Barracks arrived to handle winches and technical equipment.

Most Western Europeans think fairly well of the United States. This seems a reasonable deduction from the results of a survey just published by the Common Council for American Unity, after a judicious sampling of 1,702 "qualified observers of opinion in European countries."

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The House gave final approval today to a bill establishing the right of manufacturers, acting independently, to absorb shipping costs in order to quote uniform delivered prices throughout the country.

PARIS, July 7 -- Paul Giacobbi, Radical Socialist member of the French National Assembly and former Minister of Colonies, resigned today from the executive committee of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's Reunion of the French People in a dispute between the party and the group of Deputies supporting the de Gaullist position in Parliament.

SHANGHAI, July 6 -- This city was interlaced with great parades today whose sum total was probably the greatest demonstration of military strength ever displayed in Communist China. While tanks and howitzers moved up some avenues, phalanxes of workers marching along other routes threw clenched fists into the air.

Because a Federal judge is not available to try the espionage case of Miss Judith Coplon and Valentin A. Gubitchev scheduled to start here Monday, Federal Judge William Bondy postponed the trial yesterday until Oct. 15.

PARIS, July 7 -- John W. Snyder's talks in Paris, which ended with a conference with Maurice Petsche, French Finance Minister, tonight, have left the French believing that the talks with the United States Secretary of the Treasury will be a prelude to prolonged negotiations for the improvement of economic and monetary cooperation among the Western nations.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Westbrook Pegler, newspaper columnist who frequently makes labor leaders his targets, charged before a House subcommittee today that unions had become so infiltrated wth "despots, criminals and Communists" that average rank and file members had little or no voice in the organizations they made possible.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- The United Mine Workers of America and the anthracite operators agreed today to extend the terms of the present contract during negotiations for a new working agreement for 78,000 hard-coal miners.

Isaac J. Pitman, independent member of Parliament for Bath and treasurer of the International Chamber of Commerce, told British and American businessmen yesterday that intransigent union leadership was preventing increased productivity in British industry and that an ambitious educational campaign by British capitalists was needed to combat the "disease of socialism."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 7 -- A twenty-year-old Syracuse undergraduate, captain of the Orange golf team last spring, Edward Roll, won the medal in the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship with a 71 over the Hempstead Golf Club course today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The International Wheat Council today chose London as its permanent site and F. Sheed Anderson, head of the British delegation, as chairman for the 1949 crop year.

Leaders in American industry and government who were selected in a nation-wide poll of school and college students on the basis of outstanding characteristics held responsible for their success, received yesterday the Horatio Alger awards presented annually by the American Schools and Colleges Association.

LONDON, July 7 -- The firm reiteration by Sir Stafford Cripps of his "no devaluation" policy frightened some of the gold share speculators, who sold at the opening of the stock market here today. Losses, however, were smaller than recent gains because speculators hold that devaluation still is a talking point.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Republican and Democratic Senators today praised the appointment of John Foster Dulles to be the new Senator from New York.
JERSEY CITY July 7 (AP) -- Jersey City captured a doubleheader from Syracuse tonight, taking the opener, 7 -- 3, and the nightcap, 10 -- 7.
The Haytian Corporation of America has called a special meeting of stockholders for Aug. 1, to vote on a proposed dissolution of the company and the distribution of its assets to stockholders.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 7 -- The world economic and social leadership that this country can assume under President Truman's "Point Four" program for underdeveloped areas must be implemented by "an integrating religious principle," the Rev. John La Fargo declared today.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- The machinery of Federal intervention to block the threatened nationwide strike of 1,000,000 steel workers was set in motion just one hour after Mr. Murray had accused the United States Steel Corporation of acting in bad faith and had indicated a "rolling strike" starting July 16 was almost a certainty.

The summer week-end guest who would like to bring her hostess an unusual and appropriate gift will find a good selection of travel-worthy items around town right now. Most of these gifts are planned for the traveller who neither wants to lug an extra suitcase to carry his offering nor un the risk of having it broken to bits before he arrives at his destination.
BERLIN, July 7 -- Economic leaders from the Soviet zone and Western Germany met today in Berlin to try to re-establish trade relations between two sections of partitioned Germany.
LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., July 7 -- France called today for a veto-less control agency to carry out her plan for a world-wide census of non-atomic weapons and the armed forces of United Nations members.

James A. Lundy, a former president of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce and former administrator for Queens of the Office of Price Administration, was nominated last night by the Queens Republican executive committee as that party's candidate for Borough President of Queens this November. A slate of candidates for other county offices also was named.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 (AP) -- Teeing off on Red Embree for six runs in the first inning, the Detroit Tigers coasted to a 9-to-2 victory over the St. Louis Browns tonight, terminating a five-game losing streak. Rookie Lou Kretlow limited the Browns to eight scattered hits.
I'm somewhat amazed at the space THE TIMES of July 2 accorded to a letter from Washington concerning action taken at Seattle by the Convention of the American Association of University Women.

A local governmental subdivision of the Australian Commonwealth is planning to refund in this market an external dollar bond issue of more than $5,000,000 coming due early next year, with a new issue of dollar obligations, it was learned here yesterday.

At vegetable counters today shoppers will find that only a few items how the effects of the drought. Curtailed shipments have resulted in 4-cent increases on iceberg lettuce, now 19 cents a pound, and green peas, 25 cents. Long Island potatoes, 29 cents for five pounds, also are up 4 cents from last Friday's average, according to the City Department of Markets' weekly survey of food prices in retail stores.

BUENOS AIRES, July 7 (UP) -Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, former Vice Chancellor of Austria, said today he was willing to return to Austria to face charges of high treason provided he received "proper guarantees" of a fair trial.
Once more a statement by Hyman Bookbinder, the CIO economist whose letter appears in your issue of June 23, should not go unchallenged. Mr. Bookbinder says:

The New York (State) Guard was officially disbanded yesterday at the headquarters offices of the New York National Guard at 270 Broadway by Maj. Gen. Karl F. Haushauer, commanding the latter federally recognized force.

DETROIT, July 7 -- Nearly 30,000 automobile workers were made idle today by a series of disputes. Plants affected were the Packard Motor Car Company, the Briggs Manufacturing Company and the Plymouth division of Chrysler Corporation.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service took an unusual step yesterday when it cancelled the bail of an alleged alien Communist and sent him to Ellis Island in advance of a primary decision on a deportation hearing.

Pleasing to the many who have watched her talents grow with each successive collection was the fall presentation offered by Emme yesterday at Louis Sherry, Inc. Her skill has reached a full maturity. Experienced understanding directed the able manipulation of the bodies, the quiet well-thought-out detail and deft touch of the originals in many wearable silhouettes.

TOKYO, July 7 -- A Government spokesman today denied rumors widely circulating here that the Cabinet planned to declare an immediate state of emergency over the wave of violence that has arisen over the prospective dismissal of 200,000 public employes.

In keeping with the new line assumed by Moscow at the United Nations trade conference in Geneva -- where a Soviet delegate first openly advocated increased East-West trade -- Soviet President Shvernik has now voiced the same desire in a statement addressed to Admiral Kirk, the new American Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Two moves were taken in Congress today to curb the Atomic Energy Commission's spending authority, the exercise of which has figured in the current Congressional investigation of the agency.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Truman said today he would like to see the fight for repeal of the Taft-Hartley law continued at this session, but that the decision rested with Congressional leaders.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 7 -- Frank Parker, champion of France from Los Angeles, and William Talbert, the defending cup holder who follows him in the national ranking, gained their semi-final brackets today in the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament at the bathing and tennis club.

SHANGHAI, July 7 -- Officers of the United States Consulate General here had no sooner emerged from a labor "lock-in" at their office building this morning than they started a hectic search for William Olive, a vice consul who disappeared yesterday in the midst of a mammoth Parade commemorating the anniversary of the Marco Polo bridge incident that touched off the outbreak of war with Japan.

BOSTON, July 7 -- A sharp fight broke out on the floor of the National Eduation Association meeting today on the issue of holding conferences in cities that practice discrimination because of race, creed or color.

The stock market underwent a minor set-back yesterday but recovered to close on a mixed note. Price changes of a point and more were few and were confined to the high-price group, and the composite rate advanced 0.15 point. A zig-zag course was followed during the day, with a moderate decline following President Truman's statement of his bullishness on the economic situation but the late trading produced a partial recovery.

Herbert Wexler has been appointed manager of the radio and television department of Macy's New York, effective Aug. 1, to replace David Davis, retired. Mr. Wexler has been associated with L. Bamberger Co., Newark, N. J., in various capacities since 1936.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- There was a cooling-off job to be done in the City of Brotherly Love and the Yankees did it tonight. Under the lights at Shibe Park, before 36,140 rabid rooters, Casey Stengel's league-leaders handed Connie Mack's pretenders a convincing 6-2 setback, which, psychologically, could not have been better timed.

Stabilization of the American economy is unlikely until industry matches its production and distribution expenditures dollar for dollar, it was declared yesterday by Fenton B. Turck, president of Turck-Hill Co., Inc., engineers.

Montauk rang up another broad-bill swordfish score on Wednesday, when Alexander Froh of Ozone Park, L. I., brought in the third rod-and-reel swordfish of the season to the Montauk Yacht Club, a 255-pounder.

OSSINING, N. Y., July 7 -- After waiting in vain for another reprieve, John M. (Cockeye) Dunn, 38 years old, and Andrew Sheridan, 49, were executed soon after 11 o'clock tonight in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison here.

BOSTON, July 7 -- Fortune's scales tipped in favor of Joe Hatten and the Dodgers tonight as the lean southpaw hurled them to a 5-2 victory over the Braves and a two-game first-place lead over the Cardinals, who again were beaten by the Pirates.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 7 -William Hugh Morris, a director of the Ku Klux Klan in Alabama, was jailed for contempt of court today after he refused to produce Klan records for a special grand jury investigating hooded terrorism. There have been reports of fourteen floggings recently.

Investments of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System were increased $160,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday but earning assets declined $336,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

After early advances, coffee futures dropped sharply about midday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Strong demand from local trade interests and buying of the distant positions by producer interests helped the early advance.
The request of a dying man to bring to this country the two daughters he has not seen in fifty years was met yesterday at the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, 425 Lafayette Street.

The City Council referred back to its general welfare committee yesterday the proposed local law to increase taxicab rates by about 27 per cent. The measure has been pending in the Council for more than a year.
Time warped, the season fled and yesterday instead of hot July it was Christmas in New York.

"The Fountainhead," Ayn Rand's adaptation of her novel, starring Gary Cooper, will have its local premiere this morning at the Strand. King Vidor directed and Henry Blanke produced the Warner Brothers drama, Patricia Neal, Henry Hull, Raymond Massey, Kent Smith, Ray Collins appear in featured roles.

Mrs. Millicent Hirsh Lang displayed the same brilliant brand of tennis that earned her almost every title in Eastern circles a decade ago in routing third-seeded Miss Nina Irwin, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, in the quarter-final round of the women's Eastern clay courts singles championship yesterday at the New York Tennis Club.

Harry Fromkes, president, announced yesterday that he had acquired control of the Lawyers Mortgage Corporation and that its activities would be expanded. Mr. Fromkes, who was elected president in March, also was named chairman of the board at a special meeting.

HAIFA, Israel, July 7 -- Two Jebel Druse villages in lower Galilee have been saved from annihilation as the result of an agreement among the Druse tribes to end the blood feud that started when Druse warriors joined the Israeli forces and were fired upon by their comrades during an attack on these villages in October, 1948.

The greatest number of animal experiments to date with the new antibiotic named neomycin, carried out at the Squibb Institute for Medical Research, have provided "sound ground for believing" that the chemical will become a significant new weapon in fighting not only tuberculosis but other serious human infections.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Red Sox, aided by 13 walks, defeated Washington, 8 -- 3, tonight in a game called at the end of six innings to permit Boston to catch a train.

LONDON, July 7 -- Now that Britain's ailing economic position has been placed openly before the world, no time is being lost in starting Anglo-American conversations to see what can be done about closing the sterling area's trade gap with North America.
INDIAN LAKE, N. Y., July 7 (AP) -- Two Pennsylvanians, one a young minister, were drowned today in Indian Lake when, according to state police, their boat filled with water and sank.
The theory that women are out of their depth on the financial page was dealt another blow yesterday afternoon at a special talk on "Types of Mutual Funds and Their Uses."

Now that the battle for a decent national housing program has been won, may I personally and as president of the National Housing Conference commend THE NEW YORK TIMES for its very fine editorial support during the course of the long fight for the passage of the bill.

Teachers and those planning to teach who think primarily of salary and of teaching as just "another job" should get out of or avoid the profession, Dr. Arthur V. Linden, executive officer of placement at Columbia University's Teachers College, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 2 were 11 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

In your issue of June 29 there appeared an item with the headline, "Study of Marxism Backed at Parley," and a subheadline, "U N. Institute at Holyoke Told Russian Revolution Was Paramount Event." The account given of my remarks by your correspondent John H. Fenton conveys the clear impression that my principal purpose was to impress upon my audience the importance of studying Marxism, and specifically of not placing a ban upon such studies.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling more than $31,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The flotations include a preferential offering to shareholders of $7,356,658 of public utility common stock, as well as the public offering of $15,000,000 of public utility bonds and preferred stock and $8,685,000 of railroad equipment trust securities.

The new interim commutation rates granted the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company last week by the Public Service Commission, the first fare increases for Westchester commuters since 1925, will go into effect at 12:01 A. M., tomorrow, it was announced by the line yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- Virtually all electric and gas appliances have caught up with consumer demand and made the switch from a sellers' to a buyers' market, manufacturers said today. Some reported introduction of new models has stimulated sales, but others termed business in the first few days of the midsummer home-furnishings show disappointing.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will undertake its next long-term borrowing on city-guaranteed housing bonds on July 26. The offering will consist of $50,300,000 of serial obligations maturing on each Sept. 1, from 1951 to 1999. The sale is to be made at competitive bidding.
READING, Pa., July 7 (AP) -- Although Sammy Snead had one of his really good rounds of golf today, the best it earned for him was a one-stroke lead in the $15,000 Reading open tournament.

Plans for mobilizing strength behind a candidate for the Senate seat vacated by the resignation on June 28 of Robert F. Wagner were formulated yesterday at a meeting of the executive board of the New York State Congress of Industrial Organizations at the New Yorker Hotel.

A capacity audience of 20,000 persons visited Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear the Philharmonic-Symphony play music of the late George Gershwin. The program was conducted by Alexander Smallens, with piano solos by Oscar Levant.
SHANGHAI, July 7 (AP) -- Military censorship has been imposed by the Chinese Communists upon dispatches of foreign correspondents in Shanghai.

Edna Best, who has been absent from the New York stage for seven years, will return here this fall as co-star with Maurice Evans in Terence Rattigan's short plays, "The Browning Version" and "A Harlequinade," it became known yesterday.

We hope that Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate will not permit themselves to be deflected from carrying through the proposed two-year civil service job classification and pay study which offers the only promise of consistency and equity among city employes.

The new 4,200 gross ton freighter Ciudad de Maracaibo of the Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, a merchant marine jointly operated by Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela, will begin discharging cargo this morning at Pearl Street, Brooklyn.

GENEVA, July 7 -- The International Refugee Organization's general council adopted a schedule today for the final liquidation of the organization. This schedule calls for the following principal deadlines:

Reporting that stabilization of the mark is now greatly aiding prospects for increased exports from Western Germany to the United States, Henri A. Abt yesterday announced the official opening here of an office to promote such trade.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- In the week ended on July 6, reserve requirements were reduced approximately $800,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Member-bank reserve balances decreased $33,000,000 and estimated excess reserves increased from $640,000,000 on June 29 to $1,410,000,000 on July 6.

The National Bronx Bank of New York reported as of June 30, total deposits of $44,480,871 and total assets of $48,099,020, compared, respectively, with $45,387,791 and $49,722,326 on Dec. 31, 1948. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $8,993,975 against $9,324,677; holdings of United States Government securities to $20,774,417 against $20,157,528; and loans and discounts to $12,809,068 against $15,999,265.

Recent ending of credit controls has produced only a slight amount of advertising giving prominent promotion to extremely easy credit-purchase terms, it was reported yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau. It is felt that any widespread emphasis on reduced down payments and long installment terms would have been planned to break with ending of the controls July 1.

The Department of Sanitation's proposal to spend $100,000 this summer to install radiant heating devices under eight crosswalks along Forty-second Street to keep them clear of snow next winter was sent back yesterday by the Board of Estimate to Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson for further study and report.
GOSEN, N. Y., July 7 (AP) -- Jimmy Jordan drove Atomic Bomb to straight heat victories today to win the Middletown Chamber of Commerce pace at Historic Track.

Station WNYC of the Municipal Broadcasting System took note of its twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday through a recorded greeting by Mayor O'Dwyer that went on the air during the station's Masterwork Hour between 7 and 7:55 P. M.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 5 points net lower to 2 points net higher.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The House Armed Services Committee agreed today to let the President decide whether the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as proposed in an amended unification law, would be a qualified civilian or a top-ranking military officer.
"Look out from under your hats and see fashion as business," members and guests of the Fashion Group were advised yesterday at a luncheon meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel.
BOSTON, July 7 -- The Voice of America has received permission to increase its "lung power," it was announced today, and by next summer will be ready to shout its message even louder.

Charging that its negotiating committee, in reaching an agreement with East and Gulf Coast shipowners on June 14, had put "chains on the membership," the strike preparations committee of Local 33, Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, went on record yesterday as recommending rejection of the negotiating group's action.
MIAMI, Fla., July 7 (AP) -- Miami's International Airport has embarked on an improvement and expansion program to cost $11,000,000.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., July 7 (AP) -- Sherman Fairchild and his slate of directors today gained control of the aircraft company which he founded as the present management conceded defeat in the stockholders' election.

Consumption of Scotch whisky has reached its approximate peak in this country under present conditions, Arthur Gilbey, director of W. A. Gilbey, Ltd., London, declared yesterday. He has just completed a tour of ten large cities to study marketing conditions for Scotch and gin.

Forced collectivization of Bulgarian peasants has aroused so much opposition in the countryside that the Government has been forced to make significant concessions to individual farmers and to punish overenthusiastic collectivizers, it became known here yesterday.

Thomas Merton, Trappist monk and author of two books, will have his third brought out by Harcourt, Brace on Oct. 6, a year and two days after the appearance of his first. "The Waters of Siloe" gives the author's view of a monk's way of life. "The Seven Storey Mountain," his first book, has sold more than 225,000 copies since last October.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., July 7 -- Mrs. Philip Conway of the Siwanoy Country Club finished one up on par to win the fifth annual Jane Brooks Robbins Memorial tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association on the Mount Kisco C. C. course today.

ORADELL, N. J., July 7 -- The Westchester team of fifteen won the Golf Illustrated Trophy for the second time in two years by defeating the Long Island and New Jersey teams over the Hackensack golf course today. The tourney was held under the auspices of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) -- The New Zealand cricket tourists gave a surprisingly listless display of batting today at Manchester where they followed on after making 237 in reply to Lancashire's first innings' total of 467 for five declared.

New arrangements are close to completion in the parceling of radio and television rights to boxing bouts promoted by the Madison Square Garden Corporation in conjunction with the newly-formed International Boxing Club.

Aneurin Bevan, British Minister of Health, declares in an interview with John W. McPherrin, editor of The American Druggist, that the British system of compulsory universal health insurance is "inevitable in modern society" and that "America must come to it" along with the rest of the world.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas, Speaker of the House, announced today that he was inviting the governors of Texas, Louisiana and California to meet here on Monday in an effort to settle the Tidelands ownership controversy between the states and the Federal Government.

GENEVA, Switzerland, July 7 (UP) -- Russia today urged the world to outlaw the atomic bomb along with bacteriological and chemical warfare and "other weapons intended for the mass extermination of populations." A resolution submitted by Soviet Gen. Nicholas Slavin to an International Red Cross conference here declared that "it is the duty of the Governments of all countries" to prohibit the use of "atomic weapons as means for * * * mass extermination."

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- President Truman said today that he intends to speak his opinions freely about the 1950 election in Missouri. However, he added at his news conference, he may not take any part in any Democratic primary fight.
CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP) -- The Reds calmed down somewhat today, but had enough steam to push over the winning marker in the ninth inning and defeat the Cubs, 7 -- 6, in the finale of a two-game set.
ROME, July 7 -- The Italian Government today told an enthusiastic Chamber of Deputies that it would continue to demand the return of the Free Territory of Trieste to Italy.

Failure of the propeller "feathering" mechanism was partly responsible for the engine fire early yesterday that forced a westbound Pan American Airways' strato-cruiser with fifty-three passengers to return to Shannon, Ireland.

A legislative campaign to raise teachers' salaries so that the city's pay schedules will be equal to or greater than those of neighboring communities will be undertaken next year by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations, it became known yesterday.

Indications that industry-wide stabilization has developed in brass products appeared yesterday when companies which had withdrawn industrial price sheets temporarily replaced them with new quotations. A typical company was H. M. Harper Co., Inc., Chicago, brass screw machine products manufacturer.

ASPEN, Colo., July 7 -- Dr. Albert Schweitzer, the 74-year-old missionary philosopher of French Equatorial Africa, held a meeting here today with several hundred college students who are attending a Goethe Bicentennial Convocation.

While Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan upheld yesterday the License Commissioner's right to examine a ticket broker's bank statements, canceled checks and check stubs, another Broadway ticket broker's license was revoked for failure to keep accurate and adequate books and records.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Joseph B. Keenan, the chief American prosecutor of the Japanese war criminals and a former Justice Department lawyer, was chosen today as counsel for the Congressional investigation of the B-36 long-range bomber.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 7 -- A four-point program designed to revive jobs and production in New England was advanced today by Gov. Chester Bowles.

MOSCOW, July 7 -- The Soviet satirical weekly Krokodil said today that the plans of Comrade Dilman, director of the All-Union Scientific Research Institute, for synthetic and aromatic essences to issue new perfumes in honor of the Pushkin sesquicentennial smelled of "tactlessness with an admixture of tastelessness."

Steve Belloise, 162, Bronx middleweight contender, scored a unanimous decision over Tony De Micco, 165, Schenectady, in the principal bout of eight rounds last night at Queensboro Arena before 3,700. The winner, who was in command throughout, dropped his rugged foe for a no-count with a looping right to the head in the second.

TETERBORO, N. J., July 7 -- A new type of aviation center for the private pilot, the company official who flies on business and the ordinary citizen interested in airplanes was opened here today by Bill Odom, youthful round-the-world flier.

PALISADES, N. Y., July 7 -- The Hudson River Valley was recently found to extend 225 miles into the Atlantic Ocean, 105 miles beyond the point where it previously was believed to have stopped, Prof. Maurice Ewing, Professor of Geophysics in Columbia University's Department of Geology, announced here today.

Comfortable weather that brought relief Wednesday to heat-and-humidity-weary New Yorkers will continue today, the Weather Man predicted last night. His cheerful words came as reports from the metropolitan area disclosed that the recent drought-easing showers had helped some wilting crops.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 7 (AP) -- A decision is scheduled Saturday on Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty's appeal from a life sentence.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8 -- Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, United States Commander in the Caribbean, who saw President Juan D. Peron this morning, said later that any plan for standardizing armaments in this hemisphere would probably be a small scale corollary to a defense project on the North Atlantic pact level.

Retail sales continued to decline here during the week, according to estimates made yesterday. Department store sales here were believed to be about 20 per cent below the corresponding week last year and specialty store sales about 15 per cent.

Mrs. Silvia Mapelli, formerly of Denver, who lost her United States citizenship because she inadvertently voted in an Italian election and had it restored through a special act of Congress, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday afternoon on a plane from Rome.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The American people bought more of the Government's Series E Bonds during the first half of this year than in any similar period since the war, Treasury officials said today. Purchases amounted to $2,250,000,000, topping 1948's previous post-war record by 2 1/2 per cent.

I have ridden the subways in New York City for too many years to raise my voice in protest over the tortures that it inflicts upon its passengers. One can become reconciled to the crowded conditions that prevail; to the dirt and the noise; even to the smells that pervade this underground inferno.
While there was a moderate volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, only small price changes were recorded, and at the close the market was 7 points higher to 5 points lower.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 8 -- Racial discrimination in industry is costing the American economy a minimum of $6,000,000,000 a year, Joseph J. Morrow, a member of the Industrial Relations Committee of the National Urban League, declared today.

LONDON, July 8 -- The spreading dock strike took an ominous turn for the worse here today and the British Government announced that it would meet this "challenge to the whole authority of the state" by proclaiming a state of emergency and invoking its emergency powers unless the docks were operating normally again by Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The House Armed Services Committee and the nation's military leaders split sharply today over the authority and rank to be granted to a proposed chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

LONDON, July 8 (UP) -- Fifteen United States fashion experts decided after a whirlwind glimpse of London today that the British woman wears her hair longer and her skirt shorter than her American cousin, uses less make-up and looks the worse for it.

NEW ORLEANS, July 8 (UP) -- An attacker slipped behind a 65- year-old slightly deaf priest, kneeling in prayer after saying mass today, and fractured his skull, apparently with a 10-pound hook used to handle cargo on the docks.

Gus Lesnevich visited the New York offices of the International Boxing Club yesterday and signed an official contract to meet Ezzard Charles, the National Boxing Association's heavyweight champion, in a fifteen-round contest at the Yankee Stadium the night of Aug. 10.

Morris S. Rosenthal, head of Stein, Hall Co. and president of the National Council of American Importers, and Harry S. Radcliffe, executive vice president of the organization, were honored yesterday for their services to France at a luncheon held by the French Chamber of Commerce of the United States in the Essex House.

The Temporary City Housing Rent Commission was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer to issue an eviction certificate so a war veteran suffering from arthritis, his wife and 7-month-old child might move from a damp and inadequately heated basement to an upper floor of a house into which they had put their life savings.

Alger Hiss failed to win exoneration on Federal perjury charges last night when the jury that had heard his case for six weeks was dismissed at 9:01 o'clock after repeated failures to agree on a verdict.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico, the first incumbent by popular election replacing the Presidential appointment system, today predicted that his island would be highly industrialized within the next twenty or twenty-five years.

Before the Senate votes on the North Atlantic Treaty it would be well to point out to the American public that the report of the Foreign Relations Committee failed to deal with two serious objections to the treaty. The treaty is apparently out of harmony both with our Constitution and with the Charter of the United Nations.
BALBOA, Canal Zone, July 8 (AP) -- A United States Navy PB-M marine patrol plane, with nine persons aboard, crashed in flames into the Caribbean Sea while making a test flight today.

China has been commemorating this week the twelfth anniversary of Japan's attack at the Marco Polo Bridge which was the formal opening of the Second World War. Several items incident to that commemoration point up the hard road that China has traveled in those twelve years and the extraordinary way station on that road that has now been reached.

Under the title of "Academy Theatre," the National Broadcasting Company television network is planning a series of eight experimental dramatic shows in the 8 to 8:30 period on Monday nights when the Chevrolet Theatre signs off for the summer after the telecast of July 18.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 2 were 644,182 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 158,759 cars or 19.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week and 113,096 cars or 14.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year but 14,978 cars or 2.4 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 8 -- Under a full moon and as a southeast breeze was diminishing, seventeen cruising sailboats left Execution Light at 8 o'clock tonight on the 106-mile fortieth annual race to Block Island conducted by the New York Athletic Club's Yachting Department. Tomorrow morning a dozen motor cruisers will head eastward in the second half of the race and the club's thirty-sixth annual marathon for power boats.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- After hours of heated debate over the necessity for cutting governmental expenditures as against a need for attracting top-notch men to high Government posts, the House passed by a voice vote today a bill that would increase materially the salaries of the Cabinet officers and 236 other heads and assistant heads of departments and agencies.

MOSCOW, July 8 -- A growing demand in British business circles for an immediate expansion of trade between Eastern and Western Europe as a result of a sharpening crisis in British-American economic relations was alleged today by a Soviet international commentator.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (U.P.) -- Dr. Enrico Fermi, Italian-born physicist who set off the first nuclear chain reaction in 1942, said today it would be a public "disservice" to say that industrial atomic energy is "just around the corner."
Thirty-five snails arrived on a Trans-World Airway's plane at La Guardia Airport at 4:30 P. M. yesterday from Egypt.

One of the first air-conditioned churches of Roman Catholic denomination in the United States -- the Regina Pacis Votive Shrine -- is being erected at the corner of Sixty-fifth Street and Twelfth Avenue, in Brooklyn, it became known yesterday.

The State of New York has long and rightfully honored our national treaties with the American Indians who live within its borders. The State Court of Appeals stated some years ago that "the Seneca tribe of Indians remains a separate nation with powers of self-government retained with the sanction of the state" and the citizens of New York have abided by this statement as law of their land.

The market for new capital next week will be called on to distribute a public issue of $150,000,000 of long-term 2 3/4 per cent bonds of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey. A negotiated transaction under the underwriting management of Morgan Stanley Co., the big Standard Oil borrowing is scheduled tentatively to be offered next Thursday.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, attacked yesterday the principle of Federal aid for education to "wealthy" states, in a sharp controversy with a group of educators that included Dr. Earl J. McGrath, United States Commissioner of Education, and Mrs. Pearl A. Wanamaker, Washington State Superintendent of Public Instruction.

LONG BEACH, L. I., July 8 -- Sidney Roemer, 55 years old, proprietor of an iron lung exhibit here on the boardwalk, presented the mechanism to the Long Beach Hospital today after Nassau vice squad detectives closed the exhibit.

i The Twentieth Century-Fox motion picture organziation has called a "showmanship" meeting in New! York, July 27-29, for some sixty l advertising and publicity directorsi of major theatres and circuits af-' fihated and independent, it was announced yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 8 (UP) -- United States fighter plane forces in Germany were put under a single, battle-ready command today as a major United States contribution to the defense of Western Europe under the North Atlantic Treaty.

STOCKHOLM, July 8 (AP) -- Fifty paper manufacturers from Norway, Sweden and Finland are meeting today in Karlstad, Sweden, for secret discussions on the problems facing Scandinavian paper industries in the international markets.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- The upward movement in wheat prices came to a halt on the Board of Trade today, liberal profit-taking combined with a lack of aggressive support from mills and reports of an easier cash wheat basis in Kansas City resulting in a lower level.

In the excitement generated by Britain's desperate efforts to overcome the dollar shortage there has been a tendency in this country to ignore or to minimize one factor in the international trade picture for which we alone are responsible. So far into the background has this factor receded that the expiration on June 30 of the Trade Agreements Extension Act of 1948 was hardly noted.

A highly cautious attitude developed yesterday in trading on the stock market as prices held to a narrow course and closed mixed in reduced business. Changes in quotations in excess of fractions proved rare, with the composite rate raised 0.09 point.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- Billy Pierce, 22-year-old southpaw, held the Tigers to five hits tonight as the White Sox scored a 3-1 victory in the series opener before 14,183 persons. Bob Swift's second homer was the only run Pierce allowed his former team-mates in gaining his third victory.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 8 -- Hay fever may be on the way out along the North Shore of Long Island. "Operation Pollen," the name a group of society women and civic workers have given to their organization, is waging an intensive campaign in fifteen communities to stamp out ragweed.

BERLIN, July 8 -- The United States, British and French commandants of Western Berlin today ordered Dr. Ernst Reuter's city government to produce a balanced budget by Aug. 1. The commandants also demanded that they be kept closely informed of the city s "grave" financial situation until a budget is approved.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Jackie Robinson, Negro star second baseman of the Brooklyn Dodgers, said today he would fight for the United States against Russia or any aggressor because "I want my kid to have the things that I have."

While most of the city's 1,000,000 vacationing youngsters are concentrating their thoughts upon the beaches and ball parks, 500 homebound high school students will have their ears to the radio brushing up on English and history.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Mrs. Perle Mesta, Fair Deal financial figure and Widely-known hostess in the National Capital, today took the oath of office as Minister to Luxembourg. The ceremony was@ in the State Department auditorium in the presence of many notables.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 8 -- The United Nations has appealed again to the fifty-nine member states to contribute emergency funds to the Arab refugees of the war in Palestine, it was announced today.

The Holiday coupe, the latest offering of Oldsmobile division, General Motors Corporation, was placed on display yesterday at the Cadillac Motor Car Company showrooms, Fifty-seventh Street and Broadway. The vehicle is styled like a convertible unit but equipped with a permanent steel top.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 -- Owing mainly to the closing down of the bituminous coal mines for the usual summer vacations, business in the Pitsburgh district last week tumbled to the lowest level in the past two years according to the bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

The Republic of Korea, one of the last outposts of democracy in the Far East, faces swift annihilation at the hands of 200,000 Soviet-trained troops from the Communist puppet state to the north if Congress fails to grant the Seoul regime eleventh-hour military and economic aid, a group of key business and professional leaders of the new state predicted yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 8 -- The scheduled signing of a new trade treaty between Britain and the bizonal area did not take place today. A British delegation returned to London after both sides agreed that they must study further particular items involved in the 1949-50 export-import program previously agreed upon.
MISHMAR HAY YARDEN, Israel, July 8 (AP) -- A Syrian-Israeli armistice will be signed next week, the head of the Israeli delegation said today.
One of the most intensive guarding programs ever applied to American shipping is gradually taking form along the port's waterfront, according to reports from shipping sources yesterday.

MADRID, July 8 (Reuters) -- Leaders of the Spanish Falange party have asked Generalissimo Francisco Franco for fundamental reforms including an end to press censorship, the removal of price controls and better food distribution.

After deliberating for more than fourteen hours, a federal jury has reported its inability to agree upon a verdict in the case of Alger Hiss and has been relieved of further responsibility in the matter by Judge Kaufman. This is the upshot of a trial that has lasted for six weeks and of a contest in credibility which has extended over a period of nearly a year.

LONDON, July 8 -- Commodity shares came into the limelight in the stock markets here today, now that Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Stafford Cripps' review of Britain's dollar position has been thoroughly examined. Despite the Chancellor's views, speculators still hold that there is a chance of devaluation of the pound and as a hedge added commodities to the gold-mining shares they already favored.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 8 -- In a speech yesterday at Novi Sad commemorating the eighth anniversary of the Partisan uprising in Serbia, Moshe Piyade, theoretician of the Political Bureau of the Yugoslav Communist party, said that the Soviet Union's Government was pursuing the foreign policy of Czarist Russia and was employing the diplomatic methods of its imperial predecessors.

NEW DELHI, India, July 8 -- With the resurgence of the Hindu Mahasabha (Great Society) party, religion apparently has again claimed a prominent place in Indian politics after a brief period of divorce following the assassination of Mohandas K. Gandhi by a Mahasabha member.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- President Truman was represented today by Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, as strongly opposed to the action of the House of Representatives in transferring $760,000,000, originally requested for universal military training, to supply six additional groups for the Air Force.
A young father brings a message from his wife. She reports that nowadays her offspring enthusiastically attack even molded raw-vegetable salads; hot weather cannot discourage their appetites.
HOPKINTON, Mass., July 8 (AP) -- Totally blind for eighteen years, Edward R. Ray, 63-year old masseur, said today that his sight had returned.

BATAVIA, Java, July 8 -- Antonius H. J. Lovink, Dutch High Commissioner for Indonesia, said today the issuance by the Republicans of a cease-fire order now they had returned to Jogjakarta and the "beginning of cooperation to stand together for the maintenance of peace and order" could cement recent developments pointing to the termination of unrest in this part of Southeast Asia.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 8 -- Anton Saadeh, who tried from the little mountain land of Lebanon to become the Hitler of the Middle East and had maintained branches of his Syrian Popular party in the United States and Latin America, died early this morning before a firing squad.

NEW CITY, N. Y., July 8 -- Frank Laskier, 37 years old, British merchant seaman and author, was killed at 9:05 o'clock tonight when an automobile in which he was riding left the road on Route 304 here and struck a tree.

Greentree Stable's Capot, Preakness and Belmont Stakes winner and therefore the current boss of the 3-year-olds, has a rough assignment in the $50,000 added Empire City Handicap at the Jamaica track today. He'll carry 130 and make concessions up to twenty-six pounds to the seven others in the line-up.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 8 -- Leslie John McPhillips, acting secretary of the Federated Iron-workers Association, was sentenced by Judge Alfred William Foster in the Arbitration Court of Sydney today to six months' imprisonment for contempt of court in refusing to pay to the court 25,000 Australian (about $80,000) drawn from the union's bank account during passage of the Government's emergency legislation forbidding the use of union funds for strike purposes.

John Wingate and Ronald Harper, employes of radio station WOR, brought a portable wire recorder into the Alger Hiss perjury trial yesterday and ran into conflict with, Daniel J. McCartan Chief Deputy United States Marshal, who removed it as a violation of Federal Court regulations.

A strong protest against cuts in the Maritime Commission's training funds, which were recommended by the Senate Appropriations Committee Thursday night, was made yesterday by Theodore L. Kingsley, executive vice president of the Alumni Association of the U. S. Merchant Marine Cadet Corps.

A newly equipped and decorated gymnasium, swimming pool, game room, social hall and clubrooms soon will be ready for the staff of the Harlem Y. M. C. A. to offer as "bait" in a pleasant "trap" for thousands of teen-age boys.

Congressional approval yesterday of the National Housing Bill is a victory for intelligent government and a milestone of social progress. The measure is certainly one of the most important that will be written into law by this Congress, and its effects will unquestionably be felt for many years.

At an emergency meeting called yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, representative members of the American Retail Federation agreed unanimously to coordinate all action toward eliminating war-created excise taxes on various items and services.

ATHENS, July 8 -- Minister of Public Order Constantine Rentis reported today the suppression of an attempt at a Communist-inspired mutiny aboard the Greek Liberty ship Crete, while she was in the North Atlantic bound from New York for Japan.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- John Foster Dulles was sworn in today as Senator from New York, replacing Robert F. Wagner, who has resigned. Mr. Dulles, a Republican, is expected to serve only six months.

Accused of insisting on an autograph from Joe DiMaggio during the fifth inning of last night's baseball game between New York and Washington at Yankee Stadium, Frank Hanrahan, 29 years old, a grocer, of 431 East 138th Street, the Bronx, was arrested on the field and charged with disorderly conduct.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A far-reaching investigation into "monopoly power" and into the question of whether anti-trust laws long on the books fit the economic pattern of today will be started in Congress on Monday.

Cities that have smoke ordinances have assured New York's Smoke Control Board of cooperation in its preparation of rules and regulations to promote smoke abatement in the city, William H. Byrne, acting director of the board, said yesterday.

While New Yorkers were promised a pleasant week-end yesterday with sunny skies and moderate temperatures, two Northeastern states termed drought conditions within their boundaries disastrous and appealed for Federal aid.

Children's apparel bookings for fall have proven one of the brightest spots of the garment industry, it was learned yesterday. Activity continues on back-to-school buying, according to manufacturers and resident offices, as retailers seek to peak their stocks for the middle of August.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The White House said today that President Truman would speak for twenty-minutes, starting at 5 P. M., Eastern daylight time, at Soldier Field on Tuesday, July 19, when he flies to Chicago to address the diamond jubilee convention of the National Shrine.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The House and Senate quickly completed action on the compromise long-range public low-rent housing and slum-clearance bill today and sent it to the White House.

MILWAUKEE, July 8 -- The twelfth international convention of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, opening here on Sunday, will be asked to take steps toward building a $10,000,000 reserve fund to improve its bargaining position and help finance long and costly strikes, it was learned tonight.
A small committee with a long name has quietly established itself as a sort of clearing house for sifting complaints about safety hazards in the city, it was disclosed yesterday.

BOSTON, July 8 (AP) -- Vern Stephens clouted his twentieth homer of the season as the rebounding Red Sox overcame the Athletics, 7 -- 1, for their fourth straight victory tonight before a capacity crowd of 34,276 at Fenway Park.

BERLIN, July 8 -- The period since the end of the Council of Foreign Ministers meeting in Paris has been marked in Germany by a striking change in Russian tactics and a no less startling shift in propaganda emphasis.

City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr. denied on the witness stand at the Communist trial yesterday that he had ever taught and advocated force and violence for the overthrow of the United States Government or for any other purpose.

ARCOLA, N. J., July 8 -- The Women's New Jersey Golf Association held a match against par tournament today over the emerald fairways of the Arcola Country Club and when the results were in there was a four-way tie for top honors.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Modification of the German bizonal fusion agreement between the United States and Britain to conserve the latter's reduced dollar reserves was announced by the State Department today in an exchange of notes between the two Governments dated June 30.

ECA Administrator Paul Hoffman is realistic when he says that Britain's salvation lies in its own hands. But while Mr. Hoffman is aware of this, and while Sir Stafford Cripps is aware of it, it is pertinent to ask whether the British Labor party and Britain's labor union leaders are aware of it.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, said today Congressional investigators should subpoena Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, President Truman's military aide, for questioning about "5 per centers."

Mrs. Elfi Carroll, the top-ranked performer and last year's champion, continued to make progress in the annual Women's Eastern clay court title tennis by routing Miss Sheila Duggan, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, in a quarter-final match yesterday at the New York Tennis Club.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- Bangaway, co-favorite for the Hambletonian trotting classic next month, verified his high esteem today by racing to victory in the $10,000 historic Dickerson Cup in two straight heats.

The Hiss trial jury stood immovably at eight votes for conviction and four for acquittal and the outworn and currently famous typewriter that was one of the principal exhibits at the perjury trial of the former State Department official played an important part in the jury's deliberations, according to statements made by the jurors after they were dismissed last night.
John P. Ryan has been appointed general sales manager of Philco Distributors, Inc., New York division. He was formerly factory sales representative for metropolitan New York and northern New Jersey.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP) -- Rookie Catcher Del Crandall's fly to center with Marv Rickert on third base in the sixteenth inning gave the Braves a 4-3 victory over the Phillies tonight. It was the longest night game of the year and put Boston in third place in the National League.

SHANGHAI, July 8 (UP) -- United States consular officials trying to arrange the release of Mr. Olive -- arrested two days ago for "traffic violations" -- could not even get permission today to talk to the prisoner.
ELMIRA, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- Dick Comey of Weston, Mass., moved from fourth to second place today in the 1949 national soaring contest standings. He flew 168 miles to East Greenbush.

A capacity throng of 34,468 spectators watched the league-leading Dodgers turn back the Giants, 4 -- 3, at Ebbets Field last night. The Brooks made good use of two of their most effective weapons -- strong-armed pitching and offensive opportunism -- to win the tense battle.
Directors of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., have elected four department heads to vice presidential posts, R. W. Moore, president, announced yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., July 8 -- Jerome V. (Jerry) Roscoe and his guest from Siwanoy, Joseph C. Denmark, headed a field of 102 teams which completed qualifying play in the annual member-guest invitation handicap golf tournament at the Apawamis Club today.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 8 -- Back on the scene where he came into prominence in 1947, Edward Moylan today scored his first victory of consequence in the two years that have intervened since he defeated Frank Parker and Gardnar Mulloy to win the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament.

BERLIN, July 8 (UP) -- Two high United States occupation officials said today they would resign Aug. 1, and official quarters predicted that others would rapidly follow suit as part of the change-over from military to civilian control in Germany.

BOSTON, July 8 -- With only five out of 3,000 delegates opposed, the National Education Association at its closing session today adopted a resolution barring Communist teachers from membership in the organization.

Two new films are scheduled to open this morning. "The Big Steal," an RKO melodrama starring Robert Mitchum, Jane Greet and William Bendix, at the Mayfair. Don Siegel directed and J. J. Gross produced from a screen play by Geoffrey Homes and Gerald Drayson Adams and a story by Richard Wormser.

CINCINNATI, July 8 (AP) -- The Cardinals stayed two games behind Brooklyn tonight with a 6-to-1 victory over Cincinnati before 27,223 fans. Howie Pollet gave ten hits to the Reds, who had totaled 30 runs and 36 hits in their last two contests.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand I. Pecora won yesterday the three-day "people's poll" for Mayoralty candidate conducted by the International Business Men's Committee in Times Square, netting 1,430 of the total 5,207 straw votes cast.

After sharp advances in previous sessions coffee futures encountered technical reactions and eased off on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. Scattered profit-taking and July liquidation met only moderate support, as volume was thin.

PARIS, July 8 -- Curtailment of the powers of the Council of Europe over the agenda of the Consultative Assembly was demanded in a bill submitted today to the French National Assembly for ratification of the Statute of the European Union.

A negotiating committee representing nineteen Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators has reached an agreement with the Radio Officers' Union, AFL, which gives that union's members parity with those of the American Radio Association, CIO, it was made known last week.

Fedeal Judge Henry W. Goddard issued a writ of habeas corpus yesterday calling for the appearance in court Tuesday of George N. Zaikoff, alias George Pirinsky, executive secretary of the American Slav Congress. Zaikoff is being held at Ellis Island awaiting deportation hearings.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 8 (AP) -- Yugoslavia indignantly denied today charges that she had permitted the use of her territory by troops of the Greek Government to overcome Greek guerrilla forces.

Long after the scoreboard had informed them that the runner-up Athletics had bowed to the Red Sox, the Yankees widened their first-place margin to six lengths by defeating the Senators, 4 -- 3, in overtime last night at the Stadium. It required twelve innings, 3 hours 15 minutes and some crafty clutch pitching by Lefty Joe Page.

Progress in curtailing the activities of swindling door-to-door salesmen in the metropolitan area as a result of the "Fight the Gyps" campaign begun June 22 by the Better Business Bureau of New York was reported yesterday by Hugh R. Jackson, president of the bureau.

TOKYO, Saturday, July 9 (UP) -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida's Cabinet today called for an immediate revision of the police system to put it under the Premier's authority "in view of the current political and economic situation."

Jo Swerling, one of Hollywood's prominent and high-priced screen writers, whose long list of credits includes "Lifeboat," "Pride of the Yankees" and "Leave Her to Heaven," has been commissioned to develop the book for "Guys and Dolls," the forthcoming musical comedy based on Damon Runyon's short stories.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 8 (AP) -- Samuel Greenfield's High Trend, l a recent arrival from New York, !took the featured Bramble Purse at lV[onnlputh Park today.

Meeting a three - star general is even more of a thrill than riding around Manhattan in the general's yacht, according to four enlisted men who arrived here yesterday as the outstanding soldiers for the month of June in the First Army area.

Chicago announced yesterday that it will receive bids July 21 on tax-exempt bond issues totaling $18,350,000. The offerings will consist of various issues totaling $16,350,000 bearing a fixed interest rate of 1 1/2 per cent and $2,000,000 of voting machine obligations.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The housing bill passed by Congress today, estimated to cost from $10,000,000,000 upward over a period of decades, provides for 810,000 public housing units. These would be available to low-income families by aid of Government rent subsidies.

ASPEN, Col., July 8 -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, chancellor of the University of Chicago and chairman of the foundation which is sponsor of the Goethe bicentennial convocation here, declared today that despite the deficit financing of the enterprise it was proving a unique experiment in adult education.
