WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Persons in close touch with the framing of Government economic policy predicted today that President Truman, in his message to Congress Monday, would call for an output of $300,000,000,000 in goods and services a year.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Fur farmers urged today that the Federal Government use some of the money it gets from excise taxes on furs to help develop the domestic fur industry.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- United States officials in Nanking and Peiping have been instructed to protest to the highest Chinese Communist authorities they can find against the arrest, detention and treatment of Vice Consul William Olive in Shanghai, it was announced at the State Department today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended July 5, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 152.7 per cent of the 1926 average, 2.1 per cent below four weeks ago and 8.7 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

The worst part of going away for the summer is cleaning the house. Probably that is the only bad part, but it is bad enough. It will take many morning swims, at the convenient rising hour of eleven, and many afternoon naps, from 1 o'clock until 6, to get over it.
GENEVA, July 8 -- J. Donald Kingsley, assistant administrator of the United States Federal Security Administration, was elected Director General of the International Refugee Organization today.

SEOUL, Korea, July 8 -- The Communist-controlled North Korea radio, following up its propaganda drive against the United States, the United Nations and the Government of the Korean Republic, has intensified its exhortations to the South Koreans to "overthrow the puppet government of President Syngman Rhee.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 8 (AP) -- The official Communist newspaper charged the nation's Roman Catholic leaders today with attempting to set up an "anti-state underground" movement.

In the suburbs women may shop by station wagon, but in the city it is the shopping cart in ever-increasing numbers that is bringing home the bacon these days. Store buyers reported yesterday an increased or steady demand for these carry-alls on wheels, ranging from inexpensive wire mesh models for $2 and up to the Rolls-Royce equivalent of canvas and aluminum tubing at about $7.50.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Council of State Chambers of Commerce, today, assailed the Truman Administration's fiscal policies. In a statement the organization charged that the Federal budget deficit of $1,811,000,000 was a "direct result" of the Administration's failure to pare Federal spending in keeping with the decline in Federal income.

In letters to the editor you published a communication from Orville C. Sanborn, "Combating Depression," with excellent views of the causes of depressions: poverty and underproduction abroad in contrast to affluence and overproduction here.

Aggregate dollar volume of twenty important summer furniture manufacturers this year is equal to last year "or possibly a little better," Robert L. Ficks Jr., president, National Association of Summer Furniture Manufacturers, reported yesterday.

Pfc. William A. Soderman, formerly of Company K, Ninth Infantry, Medal of Honor winner of the Second Division, rejoined his associates in that Army unit yesterday. With Pfc. Jose Mendoza of San Antonio, Tex., he will be a guest at the twenty-eighth annual dinner of the Second Army Association tonight in the New Yorker Hotel.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture has moved to protect buyers of national forest lumber from being stuck with high priced timber in a falling market.

The five-story, twenty-seven family building at 916 Tiffany Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Felix A. Muldoon and others to the J. M. Z. Realty, Inc. A purchase money mortgage of $25,000 was executed at the closing of title to the property, which is assessed at $52,000.
PITTSBURGH, July 8 (AP) -- The Pirates stretched their winning streak to seven straight tonight as they defeated the Cubs, 2 -- 1, before a crowd of 36,366.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- Jack Skirball and Bruce Manning have concluded a deal to produce "Blind Spot," a screen story by Jack Leonard and James O'Hallon, for RKO release. The story is described as a psychological mystery, and Lionel Houser has expanded it into scenario form.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 8 (AP) -- L. B. (Mike) Pearson, Canada's External Affairs Minister, said today that the smaller nations in the Atlantic Pact must have a full voice in its decisions.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Rising Republican resistance to the Administration's proposed $1,130,000,000 program of military aid to European signers of the North Atlantic Treaty threatened today to cost some votes for the covenant itself.

The New York Life Insurance Company has purchased from the Tojack Realty Corporation, Cornelius G. Rourke, president, the three-story business building on a lot 25 by 75 feet at 1242 Second Avenue, northeast corner of Sixty-fifth Street, opposite the old Third Avenue car-barn block which the New York Life is improving with apartments.

Lobbying as a method of placing high pressure on Congress has often been denounced, and often with good reason; but when kept within bounds lobbies may have their uses in marshaling the facts (some of the facts, anyway) and presenting the arguments (at least on one side of the issue) for the lawmakers.

MEXICO CITY, July 8 -- The Interior Ministry announced today that official counting of votes cast in last Sunday's election for a new Chamber of Deputies seating 147 members so far has established that the governing Party of Revolutionary Institutions won in eleven out of the twelve districts into which Mexico City is divided.

Mayor O'Dwyer told a group of labor leaders, representing unions of both the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, yesterday that he would "consider" their demand that he run for re-election and give them an answer early next week.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Fluorescent lamps, used chiefly in commercial and office buildings to date, will make an early bid for a share of the home lighting market, lamp manufacturers said today. They said retailers have shown a "fair" demand for table and floor lamps of all kinds in the first week of the midsummer home furnishings market in the Merchandise Mart and the American Furniture Mart.
The price of lead advanced 1 cent a pound yesterday as heavy buying extended forward bookings so far into September they now exceed promised shipments in August.

Big game fishing is not a matter of age or sex, and to prove it Edward Besh of Sterling Junction, Mass., proceeded to haul in a 482-pound tuna from the Soldier's Rip at Wedgeport, N. S., no light task for a 13-year-old.

The departure from New York of fifty-seven passengers bound for London was delayed at least twenty-four hours early yesterday when a Boeing Stratocruiser of Pan American Airways developed minor engine trouble about fifteen minutes after the take-off and returned to New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

SANDWICH, England, July 8 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of South Africa and Harry Bradshaw of Ireland rallied from a twelfth-place deadlock today to tie for the British open golf championship with record-equaling scores of 283. They will meet in a thirty-six-hole playoff tomorrow.

A complaint has been filed with the National Labor Relations Board alleging that picketing of subway newsstands by the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, constitutes a secondary boycott in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act, it was learned yesterday.

READING, Pa., July 8 (AP) -- Big Vic Ghezzi of Deal, N. J., shooting for a place on the United States Ryder Cup team as well as for top money in the $15,000 Reading open golf tournament, exploded a five-under-par 65 today to tie Sammy Snead for the lead.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 8 -- Thirteen members of the United States Embassy staff in Prague who had hoped to spend their week-ends in Vienna got notice today of refusals of Russian passes to drive through the Soviet zone of Austria to Vienna.

ST. LOUIS, July 8 (AP) -- The Indians staved off two late rallies by the Browns tonight to win, 6 to 5, for their eighth victory in their last ten games. A two-run homer by Larry Doby in the first inning supplied the margin of victory for Cleveland.

TRENTON, July 8 -- An additional two and one-half cents increase in the state farm price of milk, because the drought has raised production costs, was requested today by the United Milk Producers Association of New Jersey. The state fixes the minimum wholesale price, but not that for consumers.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- President Truman today ordered the setting up of an emergency board to investigate a labor dispute involving the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company.

LONDON, July 8 -- The three-way talks among the United States, Canada and Britain on the sterling area's dollar difficulties are not likely to go beyond an exhaustive exploratory discussion of the facts of the situation, it was predicted tonight on the basis of the opening meeting of the three countries' representatives.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 8 -- Two New Jersey representatives, one from Westchester and the defending champion, Billy Edwards of the home club, gained the semifinal round of the metropolitan junior championship today at the Hempstead Golf Club course.

Complete restoration of electrical service to tenants at 545 West 111th Street was effected yesterday according to Louis Newkrug, a contractor, who said he had repaired the house wiring at the direction of David P. Ancowitz, head of the corporation that owns the building.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved the merger of two Kansas utility companies as part of the liquidation of the North American Light and Power Company, New York holding company.

Twelve classes and seminars for clergymen and lay leaders will be conducted at the annual conference at Silver Bay on Lake George in the week starting Wednesday, under auspices of the Home Missions Council of North America, the Foreign Missions Conference of North America, the Missionary Education Movement of the United States and Canada and the United Council of Church Women.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- What the prosecution described as a "routine" record of the wartime employment of Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino at Radio Tokyo came under almost a day-long attack by the defense in the Tokyo Rose treason trial today.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 8 (AP) -- A club car bartender crawled through flames to save the life of a 10-year-old boy on a burning streamliner train, the lad's mother said today. Twenty-five passengers were rescued in all.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Mayor Elmer E. Robinson of San Francisco denounced before a Senate subcommittee today a proposed San Francisco-Oakland, Calif., bridge as a potential menace to national defense and his city's economy.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee declared today that Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, would be legally "fancy-free" to wreck the nation's farm economy if the delayed-action Aiken Farm Price Act were allowed to take effect next year.

A long - winded, complicated preachment on the rights of the individual in society -- and also upon the privilege of a lady to change her mind -- has been put on the screen with more fervor than compelling conviction, it seems, in the Warner Brothers' film version of Ayn Rand's "The Fountainhead."

Peter Dunn, younger brother of John Dunn, who with Andrew Sheridan was executed Thursday midnight for the murder of Anthony Hintz, will be made available to the District Attorney's office for questioning sometime next week, his attorney, Arthur J. Gardner, announced yesterday.
A plea for more widespread adult education was voiced yesterday by Dean Ernest O. Melby in an address welcoming students to the summer session of New York University's School of Education.

NEWARK, N. J., July 8 -- The special Federal Grand Jury called to investigate former United States Attorney Edgar H. Rossbach's role in the income tax evasion case involving Frank P. Barile will reconvene next Thursday, special Assistant Attorney General Isaiah Matlack said today.

Several feet of precious living space may go to waste if home decorators neglect to utilize the corners of a room when planning furniture arrangements. Among space-savers devised to avoid just this problem are several new cabinet pieces.
PITTSBURGH, July 8 (AP) -- The Inland Steel Company of Chicago offered its workers a pension and insurance plan tonight, but the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, said it would reject the plan.

"Substantial changes" in the social welfare pattern of New York State probably will be recommended to the Legislature next year as the result of a study being conducted by the Special Committee on Social Welfare of the Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation, it was reported yesterday by Assemblyman Harold C. Ostertag, committee chairman.
DALLAS, July 8 -- Physicians abandoned hope today for Joan Edwards, still unconscious 173 days after an automobile accident.
ATHENS, July 8 (AP) -- The Greek Government announced today the capture of a mountain stronghold at the Yugoslav border that the Communist-led guerrillas had held through three years of civil war.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 8 -- It is clearly in the interest of United States policy to prevent any disturbance in the present balance in Finland that on one hand would permit hot-headed, tough elements to irk the Soviet Union or on the other hand would permit Finnish Communists to weaken existing Governmental authority.

PARIS, July 8 -- The National Assembly all but completed adoption of a bill tonight forbidding prosecuting authorities to press charges against a Deputy other than those named specifically in a resolution lifting his parliamentary immunity.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that it had denied a petition by Radio Station WQXR in New York designed block program tests by Station WPTR in Albany on the latter's recently authorized increased power of 50 kilowatts.

ROME, July 8 -- Charles "Lucky" Luciano, erstwhile vice king, was sent to the Regina Coeli, Rome's jail, today as Italian police officials investigated whether he had had any connection with the smuggling of twenty pounds of cocaine found June 26 in the luggage of a Vincent Trupia, who had been about to board a plane for New York at a Rome airport.

TOKYO, June 29 -- The oncoming typhoon season and the storm from Okinawa that swept over Japan earlier this month with a death-told of 1,000, have set many Japanese up in arms over the recurrence of such disasters, against which, they suggest, little if anything is done.

Morris Struhl, Inc., distributor of general merchandise, has purchased the Reed Carnrick industrial property at 164 Van Wagenen Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. The one-story building containing 23,000 square feet of space is now occupied by the Kieckhefer Container Company.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday that special discounts will be given to both resellers and consumers of heating oil and kerosene to encourage the summer filling of tanks. At the same time, the company predicted that there may be a 20 per cent increase in the demand for these products in the 1949-50 heating season over the 1948-49 season.

BURLINGTON, N. J., July 8 -- Deft, downward thrusts of small sharp - bladed knives sever the green ears from the dew - wet cornstalks. The young men move with athletic grace, ghostly figures hurling brown-bearded missiles into a hydraulic-hoist cart that is bathed in mist, moonlight and electric light.

A special three-judge Federal Court dismissed yesterday for lack of jurisdiction a suit brought by the Federal Landlords Committee, Inc., and the Diamond Construction Company, Inc., against Tighe E. Woods, Federal Housing Expediter.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 8 -- The Lieutenant John A. Larkin memorial scholarships, two of Princeton University's most honored awards, have been received by two members of the Princeton class of '52 who distinguished themselves by exceptional academic work during their freshman year, it was announced today by Minot C. Morgan Jr., secretary of the university committee on scholarships.

IN this vivid chronicle of a summer's events we have a teenage novel of assured appeal. It concerns two lonely youngsters, a girl and a boy of 14 and 17, who lived in an orphans' home. Jennie Margaret, however, had a father, Jeremy Peel, formerly a circus clown.

THE stream of American artists to Latin America, which looked promising during the war, has been tapering off. In the case of Argentina it has been checked almost entirely by the policy, instituted last November, of refusing to pay visiting musicians in American dollars.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, took the lead today in efforts to effect a compromise with Senate Republicans on the Administration's reciprocal trade agreements bill.

BOSTON, July 9 -- Wide interest was shown in New England this week in a test case initiated by Henry F. Long, Massachusetts Tax Commissioner, against a Newburyport shoe-shop machinist accused of transporting liquor from New Hampshire without a license and to evade taxes.

The British crisis and the compromise represented in the new intra-European payments agreement indicate that little real headway is being made in the cure of fundamental causes of world commerce ills, according to views in foreign trade circles here last week.
The commencement season has been marked by much academic talk concerning academic freedom. This is only natural with teachers anxious for the security of their positions.

NEWARK, N. J., July 9 -- The breach between State Senator Elmer H. Wene, Democratic candidate for Governor, and his campaign advisory committee over his failure to repudiate Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City widened today in a cross fire of statements.

As a trend of the times -- during the summer months, at any rate -- some types of television programs are doing double duty: their sound tracks are turning up, suitably edited, as radio programs, on a different day and time from the original telecast.

SO far as its literature is concerned, what is it that distinguishes our own period from any other? It seems to me that the outstanding difference is in the approach of writers to their work. I doubt if there has ever been a time in which they were so self-conscious about their function.
PARIS, July 9 -- Maybe there aren't 140,000 American tourists on the main floor of the American Express Building behind the Paris Opera, but there are that many on the face of Western Europe today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 9 -- The legislative delay in ratification by the United States of the North Atlantic Treaty and the failure, so far, to enact a military assistance program are paralyzing the national defense plans of Norway and Denmark and gradually contributing to a state of uneasiness among the people, who do not understand the technicalities of the United States Congress.

LONDON, July 9 -- Whether the calm voice of Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, reciting in the House of Commons the details of the economic crisis in which Britain finds herself at the end of the first year of the Marshall Plan, reached the ears of the hard-working, brisk-playing Briton in understandable form is the question on which resolution of the crisis most probably depends.

WHEN in August, 1944, the spearhead of the Allied advance broke into Florence, a scene of appalling and senseless destruction was found, tersely summed up in the bitter words chalked, in Italian, below the statue of Dante in the colonnade of the Uffizi: "On the banks of the Arno the Germans have left a reminder of their civilization."

BOSTON, July 9 -- The Red Sox set off a twelve-hit barrage for a total of twenty-three bases to defeat the Athletics, 7 -- 5, today and snap the six-game winning streak of Alex Kellner, the brilliant young Philadelphia southpaw, who was seeking his thirteenth triumph.

SWEET CICELY is a hardy perennial herb that makes a good background for spring-flowering bulbs and perennials, or a showy white patch for the wild flower garden in May. At that time, broad umbels of creamy white blooms appear against the fernlike foliage.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- Sales reported by Philadelphia women's apparel stores last week showed a decrease of 10 per cent from the previous week and were off 3 per cent in the four weeks' period. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 90.237 as against 116,445 a year ago, a decrease of 22.5 per cent.

DROUGHT and an early spring, which brought perennials into flower far ahead of schedule, have combined to make gardens look particularly shabby this July. And unless prompt measures are taken to repair as much damage as possible they may lok even worse in August.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 9 -- Richard Nye's Carina of the Indian Harbor Y. C., Greenwich, Conn., won the sailing division honors tonight of the New York A. C.'s annual Block Island race, a thrash of 106 miles from Execution Light, with a corrected time of 17:47:32. Carina led nearly a score of cruising windjammers in the overnight event.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 9 -- Wartime destruction of science laboratories is still hobbling education and research in Europe and Asia and is a "serious threat" to international progress, according to a country-by-country survey issued by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
EARLY in the eighteenth, century, English fiction made its way among the aspiring middle classes by masquerading as books of travel, etiquette or religious testimony.

PINE CAMP, N. Y., July 9 -- National Guard troops from seven states in this up-state Army post, with seven days of dawn-to-dusk work behind them, are preparing to move into the field this week to operate in the open for three days.

WHEN you asked us to make out a list of books on other publishers' lists brought out since the first of the year, that's what I did. Some of our friends, however, made lists of books published "during the past year."

PITTSBURGH, July 9 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette said tonight that about twenty-five members of the Republican National Committee met here today and mapped plans to force Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican, of Pennsylvania, from the chairmanship.
STUTTGART, Germany, July 9 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Isaac D. White, chief of the United States Constabulary, charged that the Russians started the shooting by an "unprovoked" attack on American troops.

PETER RABBIT is back again watching and investigating; in this group of stories he spends his time with the birds and animals of Laughing Brook and Smiling Pool. He has adventures with, among others, Longbill the Woodcock, Jerry Muskrat, Billy Mink, Beauty the Wood Duck, Snapper the Turtle, the Sawbills.

FOR THIS WEEK: Prune wistaria and rambler roses. . . . To keep birds from feasting on ripening blueberries, erect a cage of fine netting over the bushes. . . . Don't forget to water window boxes and house plants now outdoors, and to keep the bird bat filled with water. . . . Pull up pea and bean vines as soon as the crop has been gathered.
THIS attractive slim little book with its black and white drawings follows "Chinese Picked Tales for Children," published last year and translated by Dr. Tehyi Hsieh, Chinese statesman and author.

Retail store buyers of ready-to-wear, who are expected to revisit the market here in August to place orders for October and November deliveries, will be slightly less cautious than they were earlier in the year according to reports last week.

Pictures painted by children of several countries, showing varying national approaches to food, will be exhibited on Friday in the Children's Room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Continuing through September, the display will include a section devoted to hand-written, illustrated books by Argentine, Austrian, French, Swiss and American Indian youngsters, among others.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- A plea for rejection of the North Atlantic pact because it "substitutes military alliance for peaceful reasoning in international relations" was made today in an open letter to President Truman signed by seventy-five theological students, young ministers and other Christian youth, who outlined as a substitute "a program of peace."

IN 1937 Yvor Winters edited "Twelve Poets of the Pacific," which contained a modest foreword, a poem as complex as Howard Baker's "Ode to the Sea" and poetry by J. V. Cunningham and Winters himself which still holds emotion.

An oxygen tent erected by a police emergency squad and drugs failed last night to save the life of a 51 month-old elephant suffering from pneumonia that had arrived early yesterday by plane from West Africa.

SEEKERS of talent for television have joined the show business routine of you-catch-my-act-and-I'll-catch-yours. While Broadway producers sit at home and hope for a discovery on video, the TV casting directors attend Broadway plays to complete the mutual exchange of information.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 9 -Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, asserted today that the cost-of-living wage formula that was evolved a year ago in the contract with the General Motors Corporation would be dropped when the agreement expired next May.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Truman gave full approval today to a comprehensive inquiry into the anti-trust laws and their operation, to be undertaken by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, and a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee.

The Senate's investigation of the merchant marine will be a full-scale affair lasting several months and will delve into every aspect of shipping in this country, according to Senator Warren G. Magnuson, chairman of a subcommittee holding the inquiry.

Known to his intimates and business acquaintances as the "Wild Irishman" of Wall Street, Chris Devine has built his firm, C. J. Devine Co., Inc., into what most refer to as the nation's No. One dealers in United States Government securities. In reasonably busy days, his firm handles a turnover of from $100,000,000 to $300,000,000 during trading hours.

BELGIUM'S stamps for the centenary of the issuing of its first postal paper have reached Leon Monosson. Dated 1849-1949 are 90 centimes green, 1.75 francs brown, 3fr red and 4fr blue, with portrait of Leopold I (1790-1865), who was on the throne from 1831 until his death.
Returning to an old and familiar role of sticking a spoke in the Dodgers' wheel whenever their arch Flatbush foes get a trifle too chesty, the Giants spilled the Flock at Ebbets Field yesterday.
ELMIRA, N. Y., July 9 -- The final event in the sixteenth national soaring contest drew near today with the lead held by Paul B. MacCready Jr. of Weston, Mass., a 23-year-old technological student.

LISBON, July 9 (AP) -- Fortune Gordien, former Minnesota collegian now competing for the San Francisco Olympic Club, shattered the listed world record for the discus today with a toss of 185 feet 2 47/192 inches.

The first few drops make the dust jump. It seems impossible that drops of water could raise a dust cloud in a garden, but they do. They strike one of the broad leaves of a squash plant and you see a puff of dust in the air over the leaf. A catbird sings a half-song, then jeers and waits.

DALLAS, July 9 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh District during the last week picked up slightly, stimulated by widespread end-of-month clearance and midsummer promotions. Two of four major Texas cities reported decreases in sales volume, but two others reported gains. Sales for the district averaged below the same period of last year.

Senator Taft on Friday seemed to be having difficulty in making up his mind about the North Atlantic Pact. What interested him, he said, was "whether one can vote for the treaty and not for arms." Senator Watkins of Utah, an opponent of ratification, thought one couldn't.

IT WOULD be most unfortunate if Albert Schweitzer should become something of a bore for us. There is a danger. Contributing factors are the unrelieved eulogies and unqualified superlatives brought to bear on both Dr. Schweitzer's person and works.

THIS is the second book of critical articles on New York newspapers by A. J. Liebling in a couple of years. In a field which is all too short of competent critics, this puts him far ahead. There are twenty-five pieces, all from The New Yorker's Wayward Press department.

PARIS. HERE in France a Communist may be your neighbor, your concierge, your plumber. If you lived, as we do, on the Ile St. Louis, the little island in the Seine, in the Fourth Arrondissement behind Notre Dame, two out of three of the French workers you said "bon jour" to would be Communists.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 9 -- The prolonged hot dry spell focused attention on crop news over the ninth Federal Reserve district last week. Corn thrived on it, except in sections where the corn borers were active, but small grains were "heading out" too soon and grain men expected that the test weight of the harvested crop would suffer.

While Congress was hotly debating on the new unification legislation, Secretary of Defense Johnson took another practical, forward step toward actual unification. On the advice of his Medical Advisory Committee the Secretary has established the Office of Medical Director on his staff.

BERLIN, July 9 -- Demanding revision of the Allied Ruhr Authority, amendment of the Occupation Statute and the socialization of major industries, banking and credit institutions and insurance companies, the Social Democratic party has made its first formal appeal to the electorate of Western Germany.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 9 -- The Vatican Charge d'Affaires, Msgr. Gennaro Verolino, yesterday protested to the Czechoslovak Foreign Office against the arrest on the previous day of the Rev. Ludvik Smrzlik, a Czechoslovak priest employed by the papal mission as secretary and interpreter.

LONDON, July 9 (Reuters) -- The New Zealand cricket tourists dismissed Derbyshire for 121 runs in exactly 200 minutes today on the first day of their three-day match at Derby. The tourists scored 176 for the loss of five wickets.

Recently reported criticisms made by American foreign traders against new travel regulations for foreign visitors to Western Germany are, in many instances, based on misunderstandings, or distortions of fact, according to William John Logan, director-general of the military government Joint Export-Import Agency, Frankfurt am Main, Germany. He expressed these views in a letter to THE TIMES.

MANY of the hardiest perennials, resistant to heat and disease, flower lavishly in the unwelcome hues of magenta and reds tinged with blue. Their unpopularity is based not only on personal dislike but also the difficulty of harmonizing those shades with other flowers in the border.

MONTREAL, July 9 (AP) -- Col. P. D. Baird of the Montreal branch of the Arctic Institute of North America announced today four members of an institute expedition had scaled 15,700-foot Mount Vancouver on the Yukon-Alaska border.

THE Hollywood "depression," the subject of much wailing in the last year, has ended, at least for the time being, if the present level of production may be regarded as an index. The number of films before the cameras here during June averaged slightly more than forty, and the indications are that the figure may be bettered in July.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The National Labor Relations Board has run into hard and puzzling times in one of the United States Circuit Courts of Appeals, its records showed today.

TOKYO, July 9 -- There is a truce for the moment between the Government and the Communists. Two questions agitate the public: What will the Government do to end Communist violence, and, will the Communists get away with it?

BERLIN, July 9 -- "Attention, Neuruppin!" said a deep voice. "We warn you against Adolf Drube, living at number 18 Bahnhofstrasse."

WITH the radio industry gripped in an economy wave and the sales departments of the networks and stations missing no opportunity to turn up new business standards for some types of programming are being revised.

I must object to Thomas Mann's "Goethe: 'Faust and Mephistopheles'" as a hysterical portrait. Mr. Mann sets up as a "model and paragon" a personality that might appropriately yield one of those gigantic posters of Hitler.

More than 4,500,000 children in Europe have so far been vaccinated against tuberculosis with BCG, by which abbreviation the vaccine made from the Bacillus Calmette-Guerin is known. With the help of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund as many children as possible will be vaccinated with BCG in Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, Egypt, Israel and Lebanon, and millions more in China, India, Pakistan, Ceylon and other Far Eastern countries.
LONDON, July 9 -- A contest for the control of the London docks is being waged this week-end by the dockworkers union and strike leaders.
EVERY photographer -- and in these days who is not a photographer? -- will welcome the exciting chronicle, and the men who made it, that Beaumont Newhall gives us in "The History of Photography."

William Schepker, an 18-year-old former Hitler Youth member, was committed yesterday to Kings County Hospital for observation by Magistrate John Dwyer after the youth admitted that he had started two automobile fires early yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Department store sales here last week completed an eighth consecutive week of decline in comparison with a year ago. A check of Federal Reserve data covering four months, February through May, found that comparatively few divisions in Chicago department stores managed to show an increase for the period compared with the same months last year.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 9 -- Irvin Dorfman, former Yale and Columbia ace, was the only seeded player to appear for play today as the twenty-first annual Eastern clay court men's tennis singles championships started at Travers Island.

The Milano soccer team, Italian champion, will make its initial appearance of a four-game North American invasion today against a strong team selected from the four Greater New York clubs of the American League at the Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman of the Maritime Commission, strongly protested today reorganization proposals that would shear his agency of many functions.

Sportsmanship in angling is a subject that seems to be coming up for considerable discussion these days, but in view of the great increase in popularity of this sport it is not surprising that so many are concerned with what might be termed the "ethics" of its practice.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- New photographs of atomic energy installations must be cleared by the National Military Establishment before publication, it was announced today in response to wide criticism of the dissemination of map-like aerial pictures of such facilities early this year.

UNTIL recently the fine points of prizefighting were enjoyed largely by those who owned the price of a ringside seat or a pair of high-powered binoculars. Television is changing this. No longer is the manly art of mayhem screened from the sensibilities of the American family; rather, it is screened in front of the family.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -Sugar Ray Robinson will put his welterweight boxing crown on the line for the fourth time Monday night, meeting Cuba's challenging Kid Gavilan over the 15-round route at Philadelphia's huge Municipal Stadium.

Three William Bayard Cutting Traveling Fellowships, valued at between $2,500 and $3,000 each, have been awarded to graduate students at Columbia University for the 1949-1950 academic year, Dr. John A. Krout, Dean of the university's Graduate Faculties, announced yesterday.
BLACKWOOD, N. J., July 9 -- A 10-month-old baby was rescued today from a narrow ten-foot hole into which he had stumbled while playing at his home in Chews Landing.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 9 -- Federal aid to education is essential if this country is to develop a sound system of free public schools, educators attending the opening New York University summer session conference at the Chautauqua Institution warned today.

WHATEVER attitude to human existence you fashion for yourself, know that it is valid only if it be the shadow of an attitude to Nature. A human life, so often likened to a spectacle upon a stage, is more justly a ritual.

A novel three-cornered baseball game among the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers tops the program of the Night of Champions, a diversified sports show to be presented at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow night for the benefit of the Babe Ruth Memorial Foundation, the Lou Gehrig Memorial Fund and the New York Heart Fund.

PASSAIC, N. J., July 9 -- A movement that six housewives, all of them neophytes in politics, have started to obtain a change in the form of local government will get its test at a referendum on Tuesday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -The Braves came up with three runs m the ninth inning today to defeat the Phils, 4 -- 3.

ACCORDING to some authoritative counsel for parents, adults who feel jealous, or cross or blocked in some way, may take out their feelings in unkind or sarcastic remarks; young children who feel this same way may bite, or kick or pinch another child.

Culminating on Sunday in the late afternoon with a ten-mile race for the Gold Cup unlimited class, Lake Hopatcong's fourth New Jersey State Championship regatta over the coming week-end has climbed into pre-eminent importance as a big-league event.

The Senate last week began debate on the North Atlantic Treaty, in the exercise of one of its constitutional functions. That function is defined in Article 2, Section 2 of the Constitution, in these words: "He [the President] shall have power by and with the advice and consent of the Senate to make treaties, provided two-thirds of the Senators present concur."

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Ninety years ago, on Jan. 4, 1859, the United States Senate bade a solemn and affectionate farewell to the cramped and austere semicircular chamber just west of the Capitol rotunda which had been its home for forty years.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 9 -Seventeen persons were indicted today by a grand jury investigating mob violence by hooded men in the Birmingham area. A total of forty-four indictments was returned, naming some of the alleged nightriders in one incident after another.

Although the American Kennel Club committee studying the extent and possible remedies for the practice of altering the appearance of dogs for show-ring purposes has made no report, the A. K. C. has come up with suggestions on what can be done in the presence of obvious violations of the rules.

TOKYO, July 6 -- American traders and bankers express sarcastic disbelief that the Army here ever will abandon multiple currencies and place Japan's economy on a strict yen basis despite current rumors that Gen. Douglas MacArthur's assistants are considering such a step.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 9 -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, National champion from Los Angeles, lost to William Talbert of New York in the semi-finals of the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today and Frank Parker stopped Edward Moylan of Trenton, N. J. The verdict was reached in four sets in both instances.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 9 (UP) -- Harry L. Strauss' Pilaster won the sixteenth running of the $10,000 added Governor's Handicap at Narrangansett Park today after My Harriet Stable's Marine and was disqualified and placed third by the stewards.

Proposed legislation now under consideration by Congressional committees to extend governmental control over the operating rules and practices of railroads to promote safety generally is described by railroad management as an entirely new kind of Government control over railroad operations.
FRANKFORT, Germany, July 9 (AP) -- An unexplained Russian ban on truck shipments from Western Germany to Berlin spread tonight to four Soviet zone crossing points.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 9 -- The Bulgarian Government has decided on a number of memorials to Premier Georgi Dimitrov.

Homers by Whitey Lockman and Johnny Mize, each with one on, helped the Giants win, 9 -- 5, yesterday, from the Dodgers, whose National League lead over the Cardinals was cut to one game. A five-run rally in the ninth inning, capped by Sam Dente's double with the bases full, enabled the Senators to beat the Yankees, 7 -- 5.

The dollar sign has been a dominant symbol in world economics since the war. The dollar is the most widely accepted -- and sought-after -- currency in the world. The reason is that most of the rest of the world needs American goods but lacks the dollars with which to buy them.

ROME, July 9 -- Premier Marshal Tito's decision to replace the Yugoslav lira with the dinar as legal tender for Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste has caught the Italians -- and, there is every reason to believe, also the Western powers -- by surprise.

AS austerity takes over the British Empire, as the stately homes of England are sold for taxes or converted into vacation spots for city workers, characters in English novels keep on growing grander and grander.

BEFORE July has seen the last of the Japanese iris, fanciers of the bearded type are studying catalogues and listing additional varieties for their gardens. Summer is the time when iris are divided and reset, and new ones planted.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- Cultivators of rich farmlands in California and Oregon watched anxiously this week the migration of locust hordes through little populated and, for the most part, unproductive areas of northern Nevada and southern Oregon.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UP) -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, said today that there still was "a reasonable chance" of balancing the Federal budget for the current fiscal year. But he attached three big "ifs" to his statement.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., July 9 -- A group of twenty-seven Jewish and Protestant college students and high school seniors, representing church organizations in all five New York boroughs, met this week-end at Bridgehampton for a three-day interfaith seminar.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 9 -- A complete victory for the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was claimed today by Walter P. Reuther, international president, on the basis on the arbitration award.

Members of the Second Division who gave their lives in both World Wars in France, Belgium and Germany were honored yesterday by their former comrades at a memorial service in conjunction with the twenty-eighth annual reunion of the Second Division Association in the New Yorker Hotel.

LONDON, July 9 -- The Central Committee of the World Council of Churches gathered today in the historic cathedral city of Chichester to begin its second annual meeting. The Council was founded at Amsterdam last August. The meeting will last five days and will be attended by eighty-two prominent churchmen representing 155 non-Catholic Christian denominations from forty-four countries, including the United States.

THE waiving of certain restrictions in regard to aliens by Actors Equity for some visiting actress-daughter of a well known and well loved English family reduces the whole question of alien restrictions in this country to a baffling anomaly.
NORRISTOWN, Pa., July 9 (AP) -- Charlie Boswell 32-year-old former Alabama football star, today won his third National blind golf championship in five attempts.

LANSING, Mich., July 9 -- Powered by a newly designed "Gold Comet" heavy duty gasoline engine a new E-22 series of trucks and tractors was introduced today by Reo Motors, Inc. The vehicles cover a weight range of 17,000 to 22,000 pounds in the truck group and 22,500 to 38,000 pounds for the tractors.

READING, Pa., July 9 -- Sammy Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., and Cary Middlecoff of Memphis, Tenn., the golfers who have cleaned up almost everything in sight this season, were all square today after three rounds of the $15,000 Reading open.

THE trouble with Birdie Tebbetts is that he hasn't gotten around enough. Since he first came up to the big leagues in 1936 he has-been with only two ball clubs, the Detroit Tigers and the Boston Red Sox. But if he ever could have made the grand tour of the circuit in the manner of a Bobo Newsom, he'd be the best hitter in the league.

With the rate of textile production still in a decline, manufacturers and wholesalers have been able to make substantial inventory reductions, it was pointed out last week. Further price cuts, if realized between now and fall, textile men said, will be the result of continuing momentum of the buyers' market trend, and not based on a realistic appraisal of actual supply and demand.

IT REQUIRES knowledge and a great deal of courage to attempt a history of the music of the Jewish people. Peter Gradenwitz, musicologist and composer, who was educated in Prague and now resides in Tel Aviv, is well equipped for the task.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 10 -- Allan Gerdau, president of Otto Gerdau Co., New York, has signed a contract with leading pearlers at Broome, West Australia; Darwin, Northern Territory, and Thursday Island, Queensland, to take the entire production of the 1949, 1950 and 1951 seasons at 325, Australia ($1,040) for "sound" shell and 221, Australia ($707) and 125, Australia ($400) for inferior grades.

After seven and a half years of Government control the $100,000,000 General Aniline and Film Corporation, seized by the United States Office of Alien Property in the war on the ground that it was German-controlled, may soon revert to private ownership.
SALEM, Ohio, July 9 (AP) -- Samuel Floyd Keener, a gray-haired industrialist, expects to take off next week for another one of his business-getting airplane trips abroad.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, July 9 -Hungary's highest court declared today that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty should have been hanged, but it decided to let his life sentence stand because the case had "lost its original importance."

WHILE he was curator of the Dance Archives at the Museum of Modern Art, George Amberg found a great demand for a general survey of the ballet in America, and set out to supply one. But as he studied the material, he tells us, he was led away from a "sober reference book" to a "discussion of a new art and a new aesthetic."

ATLANTA, July 9 -- What to do about the financial plight of Georgia's schools and the threatened walkout of hundreds of teachers this fall unless salaries are increased was widely discussed here this week. Support seemed to be mounting behind a proposal for an extraordinary session of the Legislature to deal with this problem.

Thirteen Liberty-type tankers are to be reconverted to dry cargo status because of the low condition of the tanker market, it became known yesterday. The tankers are part of a group of forty that were sold into private ownership by the Maritime Commission during the severe tanker shortage of the winter of 1947-48.

TOKYO, July 9 -- The violent attack of Japan's Communist party on the aims of the Allied Occupation now seems to have become the principal problem of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters in its fourth year of control in this nation. This was emphasized this week

PRODUCER-DIRECTOR Herman Shumlin and novelist-scenarist Victor Wolfson may pool their talents for an independent film production in the East, the author revealed last week. The property involved is the latter's novel, "Midsummer Madness," which Doubleday will publish and which he describes as "a modern psychological story set on the New England seacoast just north of Boston."
RICHMOND, July 9 -- The Upper South sweltered this week in a heat wave that sent tempers and temperatures mounting. Interest focused on activities in Washington and problems here at home.
A REPORT on the radio activities of the United Nations, including transmissions directed to countries overseas and special programs carried by American stations, was made public here last week.
TWO years ago, in the much-discussed Everson case, the Supreme Court, by a 5-4 vote, held that a New Jersey school board could provide free bus rides for students going to Catholic parochial schools.

SINCE the war ended there have been great changes in the British Empire. Eire has gone. Burma has gone. Pakistan and Ceylon have acquired full self-government. India has declared for a republic, but has retained a defined membership in the British Commonwealth under a new formula worked out at a conference of Prime Ministers.

IT is a drastic reflection on our literary culture that a man who can write a convincing and enchanting book about bad people -- "The Prevalence of Witches" -- can write a book about good people that is no more than competent, at best, and certainly unconvincing.

JOHNNY DARLING has long been famous throughout the Catskills as a wonderful storyteller. He could take an everyday subject -- cold weather, bear-hunting, floating a log raft, buckwheat cakes or even his favorite pig -- stretch the truth somewhat and turn it into a rousing and picturesque story.

FRUIT trees that carry heavy vegetative growth are not inclined to form buds readily and so, of course, will not yield a crop. Summer pruning of apple, pear, plum or cherry trees in this condition is the chief remedy.
Meteorologically speaking, yesterday was a day to remember. It was almost perfect summer weather, the forecaster reported, the kind that he said he would take "every day in the year."

In promotions here last week retailers stressed men's sport and dress shirts, cotton and satin dresses, bathing suits, rayon and cotton yard goods, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

A GROUP project by members of the Village Camera Club to document life in Greenwich Village is now under way. The goal, according to Nat Kaufman, chairman of the project committee, is to achieve within a year's photographic work a varied and comprehensive collection of pictures that will show what the Village means to its residents and how it looks to outsiders.

MILWAUKEE, July 9 -- The publication of a suppressed report purporting to disclose widespread gambling and racketeering activities inside Local 669 of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, at the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in Paterson, N. J., was assailed today by Walter P. Reuther, union president, as a "treasonable act."

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 9 -- Billy Edwards, captain of Colgate's freshman golf team last spring, won the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship for the third year in succession as he recorded a 3-and-2 victory over Paul Kelly of Sleepy Hollow in the 18-hole final at the Hempstead Golf Club today.
PITTSBURGH, July 9 (AP) -- The sizzling Pittsburgh Pirates continued their winning ways today, taking a 13-inning 6-to-5 victory from the Chicago Cubs for their eighth straight victory.

THIS collection of sixteen stories about the Maine town Ben Ames Williams calls Fraternity will have a twofold interest. For the fiction reader it presents a community and its people, a simple, solid community and warm, human people.

CINCINNATI, July 9 (AP) -- Stan Musial blasted a home run in the eighth inning today to give St. Louis a 3-to-2 victory over Cincinnati and enable the Cards to trim Brooklyn's National League lead to one game. Musial's fifteenth homer of the season followed shortly after the Reds had moved into a 2-all deadlock.
GENEVA, July 9 -- The British Government advised the United Nations today that it believed the work of the world organization's Economic Commission for Europe should be "contracted."

Six out of ten widely used classes of industrial products are being ordered in larger volume, and some very active buying has appeared. But chemicals, rubber, electrical equipment and machine tools have not been included so far in expansions of orders from industrial buyers.

THE July meeting of the Long Island Horticultural Society is scheduled for Tuesday at 8 P. M., in the Horticultural Building, Farmingdale, L. I. Roland Schultheis will talk on grass culture and seed mixtures. Mr. Schultheis has devised means of replacing sod successfully regardless of the season.

RECENT laboratory tests on the effects of temperature on motor fuels indicate that the motorist who buys his gasoline in the cool morning hours before starting out on a trip gets more for his money than the one who waits to fill up his tank when the sun is high in the sky and the mercury has begun to soar.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 9 -- Beneficial changes in race relations in this country in the last year are of such "surprising character" that they have assumed "the proportions of an orderly revolution within the framework of our democratic society," Dr. Charles S. Johnson, president of Fisk University, declared today.

ANTONY TUDOR has created a new little work which Diana Adams and Hugh Laing will dance in its world premiere at this week's set of performances in the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, near Lee, Mass. It is entitled "The Dear Departed" and is set to music of Ravel.

Irish games, featuring hurling and football matches and exhibitions of Celtic airs by bagpiper bands, were held yesterday afternoon and evening at Croke Park, 240th Street and Broadway, for the benefit of the Catholic missions in Liberia.

ONE of the most satisfying virtues a mystery writer can possess is a vivid sense of locale. The vivid re-creation of locale is a special talent of Hampton Stone's, under any of his three names. You'll remember how the first Stone, "The Corpse in the Corner Saloon," told

Tulane University psychologists have found a striking similarity in personality patterns of patients suffering from tuberculosis and from schizophrenia, a bad form of mental disorder which is characterized by a loss of contact with reality. Work was directed and checked by Dr. Irving A. Fosberg, Assistant Professor of Psychology at Tulane and chief of clinical psychology at the Veterans Administration hospital in New Orleans.

Rule 31 in the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure begins with this sentence: "The verdict shall be unanimous." When a jury cannot agree, it is dismissed and the case declared "no trial." Cases of disagreement -"hung juries" -- are relatively rare: about one or two out of every 100 cases in Federal Court in the Southern District of New York.

THIS tough novel makes decent, even noble people out of a scorned slum family striving to change its surroundings, bearings, and guilt feelings induced by poverty. To the poor, the world -- as this title state -- is full of strangers.
MANILA, Sunday, July 10 -Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek arrived in the Philippines today for secret conferences with President Elpidio Quirino, it was learned reliably.
The 160th anniversary of the fall of the Bastille on July 14, 1789, at the beginning of the French Revolution, was celebrated yesterday on the Mall in Central Park.

Heavy drought damage to crops is expected to bring a substantial drop in demand for harvesting and shipping containers by fall and early 1950, a check of package manufacturers and suppliers disclosed here yesterday.

WITH vacationing motorists again exploring the by-ways of Upper New York State and Northern New England, traffic is on the increase over Lake Champlain's bridges and ferries. For the lake, which stretches some 107 miles southward from the Canadian border along the New York-Vermont boundary, forms a natural barrier between the Adirondack wilderness of the west and the mountain and lake resorts of Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine to the east.
The Gem argument, as furious as the tempest in which it was born, had calmed down yesterday to a gentle breeze.

Two young Estonians, who fled from the Russian-occupied zone of Germany in a home-made "yacht" -- only 33 feet long -- arrived here yesterday morning aboard the Cunard White Star liner Britannic, which rescued them 750 miles west of Ireland. The men were headed for Canada, they said.

NEW DELHI, India, July 9 -- The move by the United Nations Commission on India and Pakistan to establish a permanent cease-fire line in the state of Jammu and Kashmir is interpreted here as an effort to remove any possibility of a new outbreak of hostilities. The situation, with the opposing forces of the two dominions standing uncertainly in cease-fire positions, is tense and disappointing.

Baseball's most colorful sideshow, the annual major league all-star game, will bring the top playing talent of the National and American Leagues into direct conflict next Tuesday at Ebbets Field. A capacity throng of 33,000 will witness the spectacle, being held for the first time in Brooklyn, with the players' pension fund the beneficiary to the extent of some! $75,000.

FOLLOWING the lead of the railroads, whose two-story cars with a glass-domed observation section on top have proved so successful, Greyhound Lines has started test runs with a Scenicruiser bus. This new forty-three-passenger bus has a raised dome at the rear with a wide windshield curved around the forward section for an unobstructed view of the road ahead.

THE Battle of the Brokers, something the boys on The Street will be talking about for a long time to come regardless of the final decision, continues. Last week Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh disclosed that he'd begun drafting proposed legislation to license box-office treasurers, that he will call for amendment of the state's general business law.

" LEAVES three, let it be." That's the slogan to get you past rhus toxi-codendron (poison ivy, to use a vulgar term), a 100 per cent American, all too hardy, perennial, which is now burgeoning into its nastiest, most virulent season.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The House Un - American Activities Committee will debate at its meeting next Tuesday reopening hearings on matters some of its members believe might shed further light on the activities of Alger Hiss, according to indications at the Capitol today.
PHOENIX, July 9 -- The most animated discussion in the bucolic Southwest in recent days has centered on the seemingly alien subject of industry.

Moving forward in the face of normally "bad" news in both domestic and foreign fields, financial markets continued the recovery movement last week with stocks closing higher for the third consecutive week.
THE first half of the month-long Third Holland Festival has disclosed that this annual event is beginning to take on its own personality.

THE chase and death of the mighty German battleship Bismarck is familiar to Americans as one of the stirring naval incidents that took place before Pearl Harbor. For some six days in May, 1941, an imposing fraction of the British Navy (eight battleships and battle cruisers,

Defeating a picked eleven representing the New York State Soccer Football Association by 7 to 2, the Kamraterna team of Goteborg, Sweden, wound up its North American tour at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

FOR some unaccountable reason -possibly because the motion-picture makers have been chastened somewhat in the past year -- there has been a decided iteration in the new films that have lately come along that there is something evil and malignant about an appetite for gold.
Although clearance sales spurred retail unit volume here last week, dollar volume fell sharply in comparison with a year ago. Estimates put the decline for department stores at about 20 per cent.

IN the foreword to the present volume, the first of a three-volume biography. Professor Langsam challenges the traditional estimate of Francis, the last Holy Roman Emperor and first Emperor of Austria, as a "somewhat stupid, narrow-minded and harsh reactionary."

A GROUP of house plants worth investigating are the cryptanthus. They are useful, flowery and easy to grow. The name, from the Greek, means hidden flower. This description is not strictly accurate, for the dense cluster of small lily-like blossoms is crowded at the top of the plant in among the leaves, and so not quite hidden.

BIRMINGHAM, July 9 -- Chief interest in the South's fight against Ku Klux Klan violence now centers in Jefferson County (Birmingham), Alabama, where a Klan leader was jailed this week for contempt of court after he defied a court order to produce records of the Klan before a special grand jury that is investigating terrorism.
THE Village of Chapel Hill belongs to the University of North Carolina. The University belongs to the Village. The history of one is the story of the other.

There is an element of dismal comedy in the call of the northern Korean puppet regime for a "free" election in all of Korea. This combination of effrontery and bombast could be dismissed as merely ridiculous if it were not for its ominous overtone. North Korea has had abundant opportunity to participate in a really free election under honest international auspices.

CRANFORD, N. J., July 9 -- A ten-mile stretch of Route 4 parkway, from Cranford to Route 35, a short distance north of Edison Bridge, will be opened to traffic in December or early January, Walter L. Braybrooke, district engineer here for the State Highway Department, said today.
FORTUNATELY for the housewives who like to take things easy (and most of us are in that group), the raw-pack method of canning tomatoes and peaches has been found more successful than the hot-pack.
DETROIT, July 9 (AP) -- Are the thousands of Ford Motor Company workers made idle in a spring speed-up strike that involved two Michigan plants entitled to jobless pay?

THOUGH the deep sigh is still heard in the land, the cheerful news is that book production for January-July, 1949, has not only exceeded expectations but exceeded the actual record for the corresponding period of 1948 by about 2 per cent.

Family partnerships have come to be regarded as means of escape from high progressive personal income taxes. This is probably an unfair assumption. To prove the exception, however, can involve prolonged litigation.

The United States National Students Association established last week a committee to seek Congressional support for a program of Federally financed scholarships for approximately 300,000 college students.

BATAVIA, Java, July 9 -- Lieut. Gen. D. C. Buurman van Vreeden, newly appointed Commander in Chief of the Dutch forces in Indonesia, declared today that the main threat to a peaceful settlement of the Indonesian problem came from the Communists.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., July 9 -- Jacob Schneider, 63 years old, former prosecutor of Japanese war criminals, was found dead early today on the floor of the kitchen in the apartment of his brother, Louis Schneider, at 67 South Munn Avenue, this city.

THREE kinds of "sculpture" are encountered most frequently in American interiors. One is the poised-bird or pointing-dog group. This bronze menagerie, frozen forever on onyx ash-tray bases, is found most often in doctors' waiting-rooms, gifts of so-called grateful patients who are perhaps expressing the silent and subconscious belief that the M. D. ought to be a veterinarian.

OMAHA, July 9 -- Cattle and sheep producers this week were showing a lively, and generally hostile, interest in Secretary of Agriculture Brannan's request for Congressional permission to engage in a trial run of his "production payment" plan for supporting the hog market.

ASPEN, Colo., July 9 -- Plagued these past six months by storms, insects and plummeting mining prices, residents of the Mountain States this week were cheerfully recouping some of their financial losses by harvesting a bumper crop of tourist dollars. Heat waves in the near-by Plains States and on the Eastern seaboard were responsible for an unusually large early summer turnout.

At practically any given moment of the day or night, passengers on a ship or plane somewhere are at the movies. It may be in the elaborate auditorium of a transatlantic liner or in the blacked-out cabin of a Norwegian whaling boat, and, then again, it may be in the pressurized cabin of a plane of the South African Airlines.

GENEVA, July 9 -- It is a healthy corrective experience for an American economist to talk to European economists these days about what they think of the American "recession'' or "limited recession" or whatever name it currently goes by.
In the last few weeks former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes has delivered two addresses concerning the nature of the "welfare state" which have aroused considerable comment.

HONOLULU, July 9 -- Police arrested 106 pickets of the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union today and charged them with attempting to prevent a truck from entering a pier shed to haul away tin plate being unloaded from the strikebound freighter Hawaiian Citizen.

According to the National Geographic News Bulletin there is a town in northwestern Libya, about twenty-five miles south of Tripoli, where the highest temperature ever recorded under standard conditions was taken on Sept. 13, 1922. On that historic day the thermometer soared to 136.4 degrees. Death Valley, Calif., has an official record at the edge of 134 degrees. Higher temperatures, ranging up to 150 degrees, may occur in the low-lying interior.
DETROIT, July 9 -- When it came to building a hospital, Henry Ford started with the patient. He already had the money.
Business concerns using extreme forms of guarantee or warranty were warned by National Better Business Bureau officials yesterday that they are risking costly legal penalties in at least ten states.

Leading commercial banks here increased their holdings of United States Government bonds substantially in the last three months in an effort to employ profitably the mounting volume of funds made available from a heavy liquidation of business loans, a survey of the condition statements for the fifteen largest institutions for June 30 disclosed.

To the Isidor Bieber-Hirsch Jacobs colt Palestinian went the biggest chunk of the swag, $38,000, in the $56,100 Empire City Handicap before 28,142 witnesses at Jamaica yesterday. Capot, Greentree Stable Preakness and Belmont Stakes winner, toiled under the wire in third place.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 9 -- The idea of bringing dollars to Brazil through tourists will be launched next week by the American Chamber of Commerce for Brazil at a luncheon for John D. Montgomery, president of the Miami Beach Chamber of Commerce and vice chairman of the Florida Advertising Commission. Mr. Montgomery will arrive here tomorrow.

The evidence is strong that if the drinking water of a community naturally contains fluoride teeth are less likely to decay than if there were no fluoride in the water. Would the statistics still indicate that teeth are protected from decay if fluoride were added to the water supply?
CHARLESTON society in 1858 was a tight little aristocracy with rigid rules of behavior. No lady strikes a slave. Bad owners made bad Negroes. Little signposts to gracious living like these.

The Automobile Club of New York called again yesterday upon Governor Dewey to compel the Port of New York Authority to reduce the 50-cent toll for one-way private car passage on its facilities between New York and New Jersey, in view of the 35-cent rate tentatively established for the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel, under construction.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Just a few months ago hard-headed observers were saying it would take a decade to make good on 60 per cent of the Hoover Commission's recommendations for reorganizing the Government in the interest of economy and efficiency.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9 -- A percentage rise in the value of cargoes moving through the port of Philadelphia clearly indicates that the general cargo business here is on the upswing, the Chamber of Commerce reported today.

A SPECIAL camera back that replaces the standard back and converts one camera into four is announced for the Kodak Tourist Cameras f/4.5 and f/6.3. These folding cameras achieve versatility with the use of masks and film spool adapters which make it possible to take pictures in three negative sizes in addition to the regular 2 1/4x3 1/4-inch negatives.

The huge increase in the percentage of United States workers employed by the Government between 1900 and 1948 is described in a report of the National Bureau of Economic Research made public yesterday.

ONE of the most important problems facing our country is the aging of our population; that is, the rise in the proportion of the old. The economic effects will be great, the non-economic perhaps even greater.

AUGUSTA, Me. -- Maine women are inveterate money raisers for worthy causes. They are also first-rate cooks. In combination these two traits produce the community supper, a local phenomenon which is well worth the notice of vacationing motorists.

What seemed to be a sure-fire victory slipped out of the grasp of the Yankees in most excruciating fashion yesterday. With two out in the ninth, and the bases empty, 17,591 slumbering spectators at the stadium were roused to roaring life by a Washington rally that netted five runs. The last-ditch upsurge gave the Senators the decision, 7 -- 5.

Mrs. Elfi Carroll of Forest Hills and Mrs. Norma Taubele Barber of New York will meet for the women's Eastern clay court singles championship for the second year in a row at the New York Tennis Club, the Bronx, today. The former defeated the one-time titleholder a year ago and is favored to repeat.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 9 -- Mangohick successfully fought off the closing challenge of favored Rippey to win the Rumson Handicap, the $10,000-added feature on the program at the Monmouth Park race track today.

The economic situation in Europe today is not as critical as the military situation was when the Germans came down to the Marne in the early weeks of the First World War. Nevertheless, in Britain and on the Continent the Western democracies have reached a turning point.

ATHENS, July 9 -- A statement published today by Minister of Coordination Stephenos Stephanopoulos showed that United States aid to Greece during the first full year -- ended June 30 -- of implementation of the Marshall Plan totaled $253,600,000. He reported an itemizing of this amount as follows:

TOO often group shows seem perversely varied, satiating without satisfying. But, in two current exhibitions, there are enough good and interesting pictures to prove more than just the fact that the freedom to paint what you like how you please is not yet one of the threatened freedoms.

THE life of a displaced person in a German camp is not an easy one, even today under Western Allied army supervision, but thirteen Russians tell us in this volume why they would rather continue that harsh existence than return to their homes in the Soviet Union.

In preparing early promotions of fall coats and suits, buyers in the wholesale apparel market here last week requested rush deliveries, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, Inc., resident buying office.

THE leading players generally agree that a suit should not be rebid unless it contains at least five cards, including Q-J or better at the top. With similar unanimity, the leading players disregard this qualification about as often as any other rule in the book.

A ROCK garden need not be completely devoid of interest with the passing of the broad sweeps of color displayed in May and June. There are desirable rock garden plants which flower in late June and July, and others that take over the job as summer advances.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Navy Department is "giving the word" to its admirals and other officers on official Navy policy on unification and current controversies.

BRIONI, Yugoslavia, July 9 (AP) -- Sava N. Kosanovitch, Yugoslav Ambassador to the United States, said tonight that Premier Marshal Tito was willing to do business with the Western powers "on terms of equality."

AMERICANS are suffering these days from a great delusion -- a delusion about the atom. We are blinding ourselves with two misconceptions -- (1) that the atomic bomb insures complete security, and (2) that secrecy means security.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 9 -- So bad is the drought in the greater part of eastern Cape Province that the daily water ration in the port of East London with 75,000 inhabitants is to be reduced to two gallons a person. Sea water distributed by the municipality is being used for personal washing.

Canada Lee, Negro actor, charged yesterday that the 'lynch mentality" of American radio made "cannibals, dehumanized monsters, clowns, menials, thieves and liars" out of the Negro people whom it had "jailed in a concentration camp of silence where we are surrounded by indifference and our real words reach nowhere."

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he had received an invitation to see President Truman at the White House at 12:15 o'clock on Tuesday afternoon and that he had accepted the invitation. No reason for the invitation, which was received yesterday morning, was disclosed.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Charles H. Morse 3d, 51 years old, member of a pioneer Chicago manufacturing family and a vice president of Fairbanks, Morse Co., and two other men were killed today when their Lockheed Lodestar airplane burned following a forced landing in a cornfield at Roanoke, Ill., thirty miles east of Peoria.

FOR one reason or another, the gentle eighteenth-century recluse William Cowper continues to interest us. Psychologists delight in analyzing the causes of his recurring mental breakdowns. Literary historians find significance in his pre-Wordsworthian poetry of nature.

Thomas Mann in "Goethe: 'Faust and Mephistopheles'" does intolerable violence to the life and work of Martin Luther. Luther discovered a source of power in the Church more powerful than the sword -- the Gospel of Jesus Christ.

SANDWICH, England, July 9 -- Bobby Locke, the South African who polished his game on United States courses, easily beat Harry Bradshaw of Ireland today to win the British Open golf title by twelve strokes.

New low-priced dinnerware lines which stores "can really promote at a profitable mark-up" will feature the China, Glass and Pottery Show opening today in the New Yorker Hotel, buyers predicted yesterday. They said the assortment of promotional dinnerware will be the most extensive since before the war.

Let's give Burt Shotton his just due. It was he who "shepherded the Brooklyn Dodgers into the National League championship" in 1947, not Durocher, as Harvey Breit wrote in "The Tenth Man on the Ball Team."

CHARLES YALE HARRISON is a veteran newspaper man with experience both in the public relations field and as a fiction writer. In those fields he has jousted with the brave and the craven via cold fact and warm imaginative novels.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Building trades unions of the American Federation of Labor probably will not scrap the joint employer-employe board for the settlement of jurisdictional disputes.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 9 -- For the first time this year United States Employment Service offices reported that men were being called back to their jobs. In the Chattanooga area, which has been somewhat typical of the Deep South, unemployment rolls were reduced by some 500.

THE author of this tract is a pious Freudian and an equally pious Christian who is convinced that Freudian insights may both support and clarify the Christian faith. He expects to achieve the clarification and purification by dissipating the legalistic tendencies in conventional Christianity through Freud's conception of the character of the "super-ego."

THAT tartly logical professor, Dr. Priestley, is about to celebrate his Silver Anniversary in detection; and he is still appearing in novels indistinguishable from those which starred him in 1925. His creator refuses to be bothered with newfangled notions of psychology and suspense, and stolidly continues to concentrate on routine and workmanlike puzzle-plots.

EASTON, Pa., July 9 -- Dr. Elwyn E. Tilden Jr., Professor of New Testament and Christian Ethics at Lincoln University, was appointed today as head of the Religion Department at Lafayette College. The appointment was announced by Dr. Ralph C. Hutchison, president of Lafayette.

BOSTON -- It is possible to race through all six New England states and the islands of Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket in a week of hard-hitting sight-seeing. But to do so is to be pitifully out of step with the leisurely pace of this slow-moving summer playground.

I CANNOT condone the use of "a small vessel for holding salt at table" (in this column of June 19) to hold a refractory book open. Nor do I approve of simultaneous reading and eating. It's bad for the sight and bad for digestion.

MOSCOW, July 9 -- Ilya Ehrenburg, in an article specially written for the ten-thousandth issue of Izvestia attacked the American press today as "a gigantic lie, a swarming banality, a skyscraper of stupidity."

DETROIT, July 9 (UPI) -- The automobile industry, now turning out more cars than it has in twenty years, is feeling a pinch for salesmen. Pre-war car peddlers, who left the trade when there was nothing to sell, have taken other jobs and aren't anxious to get back in the business of eights and super sixes.
