SINCE 1921, when the focus of Irish writing shifted from England to Dublin, and when the element of Irish influence upon the traditions of English literature appeared to acquire a still greater cohesion in the figures of Yeats, the young Sean O'Casey, and the rising Irish novelists, Ireland has achieved unity in its literature.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 1 -- Thomas Playford, Premier of South Australia, will be having dinner as the guest of Lieut. Gen. John Fullerton Evetts, chief executive officer of the Long Range Weapons Range at Woomera, in the central Australian desert country in South Australia.

DETROIT, July 9 -- An arbitration decision in the recent twenty-five-day strike against the Ford Motor Company by the United Automobile Workers, CIO, handed down yesterday, was described by the union today as a complete victory for the workers.

THE resort and travel industry, which was definitely worried ten days ago about the prospects for the summer season, reversed its position to one of beaming optimism last week when the score was tallied on one of the biggest Fourth of July week-ends in history.

OLSEN and Johnson, specialists in lowbrow comedy, currently are adorning the television channels (8 P. M. Tuesday, NBC-TV) with an hour-long extract from their stage item known as "Funzapoppin." The show has moments of genuine screwball diversion but by and large it is an exhausting ordeal that falls short on real comedy talent.

SOME months ago there was occasion to report in this column on several albums issued by the Ethnic Folkways Library. These albums were concerned with the music of the Sioux and Navajo and of Equatorial Africa, and though the comment was favorable it was not expected that many collectors would have more than a passing curiosity.

SHANGHAI, July 9 -- After having been detained sixty-six hours in a wayside police station, William M. Olive, a United States Vice Consul here, was released at noon today by the Communist Public Safety Bureau.

BUENOS AIRES, July 9 -- Argentina put on today her greatest military parade for the traditional crowds lining the broad Avenida Alvear and for two special guests -- Brazilian War Minister Canrobert Pereira da Costa and Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, United States Chief of the Caribbean Command.

THE history of the steam engine has been so thoroughly recorded that another book on the subject at first sight would seem to be remarkably gratuitous. But as it happens, the story of the steam engine as an industrial prime mover has high diagnostic value, and in this sense loses nothing by repetition.

DUTCH elm disease symptoms are more prevalent, more intense and much earlier this year. This is due primarily to the drought. Although there is still no cure, experiments now being conducted indicate that chemotherapy may suppress the disease in its early stages.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The political "GHQ" of organized labor here is the scene of day and night conferences as leaders project plans and perfect machinery designed to win in the 1950 Congressional elections a real victory instead of the illusory one of last year. The rallying point for labor in the coming campaign is the same as in the last one -- that the Taft-Hartley Act must be repealed.

Although the "glorious Fourth" is not the noisy celebration it was years ago, there still was so much racket and din last week-end that most adults, at least, breathed a sigh of relief when the holiday was over.

Chu Hsi has been dead these seven hundred years, but the doctrine of Yin and Yang, or the rhythm of the universe -- a doctrine which is still older -- is of interest to modern expounders of universal history such as Arnold J. Toynbee.

BERLIN, July 9 -- Otto Suhr, president of the West Berlin City Assembly, said here today that it would not be possible to draw up a balanced city budget without continued financial aid from the Western occupation powers. Yesterday the commandants of the three Western sectors flatly ordered the City Government to produce such a budget by Aug. 1.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- Calumet Farm's Duchess Peg, a daughter of Whirlaway, 3-year-old champion of 1941, today won the $56,375 Lassie Stakes at Arlington Park in a photo finish.

As is known, oak trees and other large projects start in a small way. Because of the advance sale and advance interest and the general air of excitement, it is safe to call "Miss Liberty" a large project.

PITTSBURGH, July 9 -- The Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company, world's largest commercial soft coal producer, today opened a fight on the three-day work week instituted by John L. Lewis, United Mine Workers president, as a strategic move in the 1949 wage dispute.

Last Thursday in his suite at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey signed a document, typed on plain bond paper. It said:

ON both the foreign and domestic business fronts, simmering developments came to a boil last week. Great Britain announced the sad state of her dollar and gold reserves and her decision to out off all but essential imports from the United States and Canada.

BOSTON, July 9 -- The question of whether Communist party members should be permitted to remain in the teaching profession held the spotlight here this week at the annual summer convention of the National Education Association.

BALBOA, C. Z., July 9 (AP) -- A search continued today for eight persons missing after the flaming crash of a United States Navy patrol plane into the sea near Coco Solo. All are believed to have perished. Only small pieces of debris have been found.

THE pictures on these pages reveal that even a Soviet state cannot afford to ignore the demands of fashion. They are photographs of the fashions for the current season in Russia; called "The Soviet Look," the current mode is a compromise between the "New Look" of the West and the short skirts of the war and pre-war periods.

A DROP in motion-picture theatre attendance across the nation in recent months, amounting to as much as 15 to 20 per cent below attendance in the same period last year, is indicated by a survey just completed by correspondents for this newspaper in key cities throughout the United States.
FRANKFORT, Germany, July 9 -- A United States Army officer on border patrol in the American zone said today that he had killed a Russian soldier in a rifle duel at thirty feet.

THE arrival of Dr. Albert Schweitzer, who apparently has just been discovered to be a great man by the American press, has been one of the most significant occurrences of the Goethe bi-centenary celebrations at Aspen, Col.

FEW frustrations in life can compare with that of the man who has looked forward to building a modern house only to be told that a house designed to meet his "needs" would cost about double the $15,000 or $20,000 he has in mind.

SOME time after a new friendship had replaced a twenty-year estrangement between Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright, Sullivan gave the younger man a hundred of his exquisite drawings, signed and dated.

On July 16 the Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood opens three weeks of music by the Boston Symphony Orchestra in the famous music shed near Stockbridge, Mass. This program is the heart of the top summer music festival in this country and one that is unique among summer festivals anywhere in the world.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- City dwellers, long plagued by shortages of homes and apartments, were more cheerful here this week after passage by Congress of the Federal housing bill, new state public housing legislation and reports of lower home-building costs.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Army Chief of Staff, told the House Armed Services Committee today he doubted whether any member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff would want to become its chairman under proposed restrictions.
PARIS, July 9 -- By a vote of 423 to 182, the National Assembly late tonight approved a bill providing ratification of the Statute for the Council of Europe. The opposing votes were all Communist.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Truman's mid-year economic report, due on Monday, is expected to view without alarm the rise in unemployment but urge measures to expand production and to provide more jobs.

ZION NATIONAL PARK, Utah -- Outfitted with guides and cameras, slacks and sports shirts, the dudes are again roaming the Western national parks, and having a pleasant time of it at prices pleasing to the pocketbook.

WASHINGTON, July 9-- "Mal-administration," "equivocation," "misplaced emphasis," and "waste" were some of the terms that Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper applied to the stewardship of David E. Lilienthal last May 22 in calling for his resignation as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
MOSCOW, July 9 -- A great find of Russian literary documents and manuscripts -- probably one of the most important in recent years -- was reported by the Literary Gazette today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Senator Tom Connally, Democrat, of Texas, reassured doubting colleagues today that they could logically vote for ratification of the North Atlantic Treaty without obligating themselves to support military aid to co-signatories of the pact.

Alterations and repairs to the Prison Ship Martyrs' Monument in Fort Greene Park, Brooklyn, have been completed, Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday. Restoration work began more than a year ago to keep the shrine from falling apart.

RYE, N. Y., July 9 -- Jerome V. (Jerry) Roscoe of Apawamis and Joseph C. Denmark of Siwanoy, who won the medal with a 61 yesterday, had the closest squeeze of the championship flight in getting through the first round of match play today in the annual member-guest tourney at the Apawamis Club.

LONDON, July 9 -- Without having produced any new plans or policies, the Anglo-American-Canadian talks on Britain's dollar crisis were, for all intents and purposes, concluded today, although another meeting of the three principals will be held tomorrow.

A "COACH CLASS" version of the Boeing Stratocruiser that will accommodate either 99 or 103 passengers was announced last week by the Boeing Airplane Company. If and when the new low-cost plane is put into operation, travel experts and airline officials believe that it will mean quick travel to Europe and other parts of the world for about the same cost as the lowest steamship rates.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Grains sold at slightly lower levels on the Board of Trade today. The market got off to a lower start and remained below the previous close in most cases, although a creeping advance toward the end of trading reduced early losses.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 9 -- Despite the blow last Monday, there were ninety-six craft out on Long Island Sound today for the Manhasset Bay Club's regatta. They included seven of the Lightning Class, which was hardest hit by the squall, all thirty-seven being either dismasted, swamped or capsized.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10 -- In a week-end casting switch, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has signed Barbara Stanwyck for a starring role in "East Side, West Side," with Ava Gardner, James Mason and Van Heflin. Miss Stanwyck will take over the role of Mason's wife, previously scheduled for Miss Gardner who will move into the part of "the other woman" for which Arlene Dahl had been announced.

Making its debut before an American audience at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island, yesterday, the Milan, Italy, soccer team, champion of the Italian League, defeated a picked eleven representing the New York clubs of the American Soccer League, 8 -- 2, before 7,500.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat, of Georgia, today dropped his plan to prevent President Truman from reorganizing the armed forces. He abandoned a military unification law amendment which would have removed the military departments from the new Government reorganization law.
For the second time this season, the Yankees lost a lucrative Sunday date to the weatherman when yesterday's rain caused the postponement of the double-header with the Senators.

WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., July 10 -- The first student trip around the world by air left Bradley Field near here at 2 o'clock this morning under the auspices of Youth Argosy on a DC-4 of Transocean Airlines.

Friendship with Jesus Christ must be "a daily fellowship" and not like "a quack remedy" or something remembered only in emergencies, Dr. Frank T. Cartwright, Missionary Secretary for China and former editor of the China Christian Advocate, said yesterday at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Red Sox captured a double-header by 8-5 and 11-10 margins over the Athletics at Fenway Park today before a rain-dampened but patient crowd of 32,108. The Sox now have won seven in a row.

ASPEN, Col., July 10 -- Improved social conditions as a deterrent to the motives leading to war and the need for greater public obligation and participation in politics were two of the principal themes developed here today at a conference of scholars discussing ethics and their relation to politics.

Persistence in the face of adverse weather, plug the relief pitching of young Erv Palica and some timely hitting by Gene Hermanski, Duke Snider, Jackie Robinson, Carl Furillo and Peewee Reese, enabled the league-leading Dodgers to beat the Giants, 7 -- 3, at Ebbets Field yesterday.
NORFOLK, Va., July 10 (AP) -- A thirty-six-hour search for a ship reported afire and abandoned 360 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras ended tonight.

With the five Democratic county leaders of the city ready to designate Mayor O'Dwyer for renomination at their meeting today and with the Mayor scheduled to see President Truman tomorrow, Mr. O'Dwyer's candidacy for re-election seemed yesterday to be almost but not quite certain.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 -- Premier Marshal Tito said tonight Yugoslavia would "gradually close" her frontier with Greece to protect the Yugoslavs from the fighting between the Greek Government and the Communist guerrilla rebels.

Max Gordon, the producer of "Born Yesterday," the Garson Kanin comedy that was to have expired Saturday night after 1,442 performances, has decided to keep the play alive. It will continue at Henry Miller's Theatre with the price scale cut in half.

LONDON, July 10 -- The United States, Canada and Britain, the three principal countries concerned in the sterling area's dollar crisis, reaffirmed today their faith in the possibility of achieving "a single multilateral system" of trade in which dollar and non-dollar countries could operate together.
The belief that household insecticides containing DDT are a serious health hazard was challenged in a statement issued yesterday by the National Better Business Bureau.

ATHENS, July 10 -- The National Army has dislodged the rebels from all strongholds in the Kaimakchalan Range in the Yugoslav border region of Central Macedonia, today's General Staff communique said. The victory came after a week of hard fighting.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 10 (AP) -- Dr. Melville T. Cook, noted 79-year-old botanist and author, his wife and an Alaska pilot were rescued today from the Arctic wilderness where their plane crashed a week ago.

Increasing business costs raise the prospect of a new wave of mergers and consolidations among departme. stores and specialty shops. The insistent consumer demand for lower prices is being met with competitive cost cutting that many retailers claim has reached a practical limit.

Conservatives and progressives alike were urged yesterday by the Rev. Dale DeWitt, Middle Atlantic States regional director of the American Unitarian Association, to unite as liberals against threats to democracy from all authoritarian quarters, whether of the Right or Left.
Timely tips for summer vacationers before leaving an apartment or a house empty for two or three weeks were offered yesterday in interviews with three experts.

HONG KONG, July 10 (UP) -- A warship of China's "blockade" fleet today intercepted a British-owned freighter in Chinese coastal waters, and the Royal Navy immediately alerted a destroyer to rescue the cargo ship.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- Rental dwellings have been coming off the control list at the rate of about 9,300 a day since the new rent law went into operation on April 1, Federal rent officials disclosed today.
DETROIT, July 10 -- Mayor Eugene Van Antwerp said today that he would ask Gov. G. Mennen Williams tomorrow to call a special session of the Legislature to outlaw the Communist party in Michigan.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 10 -- Having neutralized Archbishop Josef Beran and the Bishops as active opponents by means of legal and police powers, the Czechslovak Government is expected to allow a lull to develop in its conflict with the Roman Catholic Church.
GENEVA, July 10 -- The Communists have grabbed the ball in the spreading international discussion of the consequences of the world economic recession.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 (AP) -- The Cubs put a decisive halt to the Pirates' eight-game winning streak today by sweeping both ends of a double-header, 8 to 6 and 9 to 6. The nightcap was an abbreviated six-inning affair, cut short by Pennsylvania's Sunday curfew law. A crowd of 29,317 witnessed the Pittsburgh rout.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- New analyses of laboratory waste indicate that all of the uranium 235 that vanished at a Chicago atomic installation may now have been accounted for, it was announced today.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 10 -- The final round matches in the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club were postponed until tomorrow, owing to rain.

In an effort to encourage volume shipments of goods by air, Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra) will reduce its cargo rates between 15 and 50 per cent, effective Aug. 1, on shipments between the United States and the countries on its routes along the west coast of South America, it was announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, July 10 (Reuters) -- To meet North American competition, which is ousting their products from the world's markets and threatening their main dollar sources, the paper industries of Sweden, Norway and Finland are to reduce prices for all kinds of paper except newsprint by an average of 10 per cent.
CINCINNATI, July 10 (AP) -- The Cardinals moved within a half-game of the leading Dodgers today by trimming the Cincinnati Reds in both games of a doubleheader, 4 -- 2 and 7 -- 4.

The annual "drowning season" unfortunately got off to a record-breaking start over the July 4 week-end with an appalling total of 256 deaths reported throughout the nation. With vacation time in our midst, this is a good time to note the warning of the National Safety Council that 4,000 Americans are expected to lose their lives this year by drowning and that one-third of these will be children under 15 years of age.

Just before the heat wave reached its enervating worst it was decided to cut down one of the big forsythia bushes by the living room window so as to permit what air there was stirring to enter. The other forsythia had grown so large that, obviously, two bushes were far more than the corner of the house required.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10 -- The American University of Beirut, the most important American educational institution in the Arab world, has been dragged into the center of an intense political controversy as a result of the demand of the influential Falange, Lebanese Christian political party, that the Government consider closing the university.
Every month an average of 350 dry cargo ships clear from New York for foreign destinations, carrying 17,000 officers and seaman and 2,000,000,000 pounds of merchandise.

Peter Dunn, younger brother of John Dunn, who died Thursday night in the electric chair in Sing Sing for the murder of a boss stevedore, was reported by The Associated Press early today to have been arrested in Keansburg, N. J.

Application of the Liberty Bell words, "Proclaim liberty throughout all the land, unto all the inhabitants thereof," would mean no discrimination against individuals in the United States, the Rev. Dr. John A. F. Maynard declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the French Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit, 109 East Sixtieth Street.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- Hot and dry weather in parts of the Central West and Northwest has curtailed the prospective yield of oats, but the early seeded grain apparently matured ahead of the heat, and much heavy-weight grain is expected to be harvested.

Seven sales of residential property in New Jersey were reported by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker, as follows: two-family house at 814 Twenty-eighth Street, Union City, for William Dolegal to Philip McGee; 3411 Hudson Avenue in Union City for Robert S. Herzog to Adam G. Almodovar; 2902 New York Avenue, Union City, for William Braun to Cosmo De Gennaro.
BERLIN, Monday, July 11 -- The Russians slowed truck traffic to Berlin to a trickle today after having stopped it completely for an hour in a new "little blockade" of the German capital.

A second salvage case arising from the Independence Day squall was reported yesterday by Dr. A. M. Oppenheimer of Great Neck, L. I. The dentist said that his snipe class boat had been taken in tow by Marshall E. Tulloch and the latter's son-in-law, Centre W. Holmberg Jr. of New Rochelle, N. Y., and salvage of $65 claimed.

May I comment on a letter called "Way Out of Recession," published on June 30, in which the writer advocates that a "czar" be given the power to coerce both labor and management into continuing production.
PRAGUE, July 10 (AP) -- Communist Government police have Archbishop Beran literally under lock and key in his Prague palace, a high church leader said today.
Offerings of securities scheduled by municipalities for this week total $140,481,261, compared with $28,616,878 last week. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date is $65,455,798.

MILWAUKEE, July 10 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, opened its twelfth constitutional convention today by excoriating industrial management and Wall Street as the unwitting allies of the Soviet Union who were driving America "down the road to a depression."

In your issue of June 29, under the heading of "FDIC Urged to Pay Dividends to Banks," you quote Mr. Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Bank and Trust Company. I do not find in this article any thought suggesting that the Congress enact legislation increasing the present $5,000 protection to at least $10,000.

Fall buying of moderately priced volume decorative fabrics "will gradually snowball through July and will strain to the utmost the capacity of the industry to deliver," it was predicted by Carlton G. Brose, vice president in charge of the Waverly fabrics division of F. Schumacher Co., in a statement released for publication today.

PUEBLA, Mexico, July 10 (AP) -- Three Americans, including George H. Houston, former president of the Baldwin Locomotive Company, were killed in an automobile accident 100 miles northeast of here last night.
BERLIN, July 10 (AP) -- A move by Russia to convert her uranium mines in eastern Germany to German public ownership was reported today.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building for ninety-two families on a plot 100 by 160 feet at 91 Central Park West, north corner of Sixty-ninth Street, has been sold by the Central Hanover Bank Trust Company to the 91 Park Corporation.

A 16-year-old high-school girl, wearing a green bathing suit, a white cap, and five pounds of axle grease, swam from Pier 6 at the Battery to Coney Island in 5 hours 40 minutes yesterday, as a prelude to attempting the English Channel next month.

RYE, N. Y., July 10 -- Jerome V. Roscoe and Joseph C. Denmark, his guest from Siwanoy, the medalists, won the annual member-guest golf tournament at the Apawamis Club by beating William H. Morton and Vincent Draddy of Westchester, 1 up at the nineteenth, today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, Republican leader in the upper chamber, today confirmed the report that some Republican leaders had met secretly in Pittsburgh yesterday in a new move to oust Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr of Pennsylvania as the party's national chairman.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Inside job "amateurs" are costing United States business men fully as much in annual thievery as are the "pros." So says the Continental Casualty Company in telling of causes and cures for the business man's annual crime cost of a billion dollars or so.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period July 2 to 8 are given in the appended tabulation:

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $48,754,106,211. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
Your story of June 28, "Art Control Unit Is Urged for City," calls for a few comments. I am speaking here only for myself, but I am confident that many others must feel as strongly as I do.

Soviet communism aims to dissolve the Jewish and Protestant faiths as well as the Roman Catholic, the Rev. Cyril J. Potocek of Holy Trinity Church, Yonkers, asserted yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

MOSCOW, July 10 -- Guards Lieut. Gen. of Aviation Vassily Josephovitch Stalin, son of the Generalissimo, declared in a newspaper interview today that Soviet pilots "fly farther, faster and higher" than any other airmen in the world.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- The Tigers split a double-header with the White Sox by winning the second game, 1 -- 0, after losing the opener, 4 -- 2, before 24,702 persons today.

The First National Bank of Boston reported as of June 30 total deposits of $1,311,356,155 and total assets of $1,460,910,076, compared, respectively, with $1,393,179,749 and $1,539,878,865 on March 31. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $421,513,290, against $491,660,416; holdings of United States Government securities, to $444,272,527, against $502,257,880, and loans and discounts to $531,191,609, against $491,195,439.
PHOENIX, Ariz., July 10 -- The Southwest, the traditional land of "great open spaces" and outdoor pursuits, is manifesting rapidly mounting sentiment in favor of industrial expansion.

DANVILLE, Va., July 10 -- Preparations are being made here for the annual conference of tobacco research and extension workers which will open on July 27 and last two days. More than 150 tobacco experts are expected here from the three research groups which will combine their sessions.

The Senate Committee on the Judiciary, a subcommittee of which has refused for more than a month to act on the House bill to liberalize and improve the present DP law, is scheduled to hold a meeting today. This meeting will provide a test of the sincerity of the Administration's efforts on behalf of this bill.

The Annual Report of the Bank for International Settlements remains, in its current and nineteenth year, far and away the most civilized and adult economic survey published. The report is not outwardly a controversial document; but because it is framed in long-term perspective it has a way of invoking comparisons between the present and the past.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) -- Ray Robinson, still struggling to make weight after three weeks of training, risks his world welterweight boxing championship tomorrow night against hustling young Kid Gavilan of Cuba in a fifteen-rounder in Municipal Stadium.
For the third time in four days, a Stratocruiser airplane developed engine trouble yesterday noon after take-off and was forced to return to the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 10 -- Although three Scandinavian countries, Norway, Sweden and Denmark, have made a remarkable recovery with the help of the Marshall Plan, and a fourth, Finland, has made great gains with the assistance of large United States loans, the problems of a dollar shortage, falling export markets and a fear of a United States recession are now making themselves felt.
Five new films, including an importation from England, are scheduled to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:...

PARIS, July 10 -- In demanding a reform of the French social security system at a special session of the National Assembly today, former Premier Paul Reynaud told the Deputies that social security would collapse with the end of Marshall Plan aid in 1952.

SHANGHAI, July 10 (UP) -- The Communist newspaper Emancipation Daily said today that the arrest of United States Vice Consul William M. Olive was a warning to "all American imperialists to abandon provocative actions or take the consequences."

MILAN, Italy, July 10 (UP) -- The Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions will meet in Communist-occupied Peiping, China, in November, it was announced tonight at the conclusion of a ten-day WFTU congress.

HARRISON, N. Y., July 10 -- In a game played on soggy turf and through light rain all the way, a Meadow Brook foursome led by Pete Bostwick routed Blind Brook, 12 to 8, at the Blind Brook Polo Club today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) -- Secrecy and conflicting actions today surrounded the carefully guarded Russian freighter Dmitri Donsky, which is anchored in the Delaware River off Kaighn Point.

Three thousand youngsters will go back to school this morning -willingly. At twenty centers operated by or affiliated with the Play Schools Association, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street, they will start a seven weeks program of recreation that will include just about everything from block-building to sightseeing trips throughout the city.

The dispute involving almost 1,500 bakery drivers that has kept six major bakeries shut for about nineteen weeks was ended yesterday but the drivers made their return to work conditional upon a settlement for the bakers in the plants.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -Representative Tom Steed, Democrat, of Oklahoma, criticized today what he called "Catholic interference in legislation" and said he would block all Administration bills before the House Labor Committee until it acted on Federal aid to education.

LONDON, July 10 -- The stock markets here continue to be dominated by apprehension regarding Britain's trade and economic position, and it has not been relieved by the statement made last week by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

ASPEN, Col., July 10 -- Some of the good music at the Goethe Bicentennial Convocation and music festival here escaped last night from the printed program, from the serious-minded subscribers and certainly from the conductor -- of the orchestra, Dmitri Mitropoulos.

Ceramic serving pieces so simple in shape and soft in color that they should prove especially welcome on summertime tables are being made by two ex-GI's at their combination studio-shop at 198 East Fifty-eighth Street.

NEW DELHI, India, July 10 -- France has agreed provisionally to transfer to India sovereignty over the free city of Chandernagore, 20 miles from Calcutta. In a referendum on June 19 on whether to join India or remain under the French flag, 7,473 voted for India, against 114 for France. Population of the city is about 50,000.

Prices of cotton moved in a narrow range last week, ending the period with small net declines after holding fairly steady during the first few days. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 12 to 19 points lower than the last quotations of the preceding week, when net gains of 9 to 26 points were registered.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, said today he would ask the Senate Democratic leadership to promote his plan for opening up the traditionally Democratic South to the Republican party.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Maj. Gen. Vernon E. Prichard, Chief Press Relations Officer of the Army, was killed instantly this afternoon when an explosion wrecked a yacht at the start of a picnic cruise down the Potomac River.

There are two sharply contrasting and illuminating items in the news from the Far East. In Shanghai the Chinese Communists have ultimately released an American consular officer whom they had detained and maltreated for three days. They accompanied this act with the publication of his purported "apology" and the by now familiar diatribe against all Western "imperialists."

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- With concern for the country's economy threading every major Congressional debate, President Truman's Midyear Economic Report to Congress tomorrow will be a matter of world interest.

LOS ANGELES, July 10 -- A new offensive in the battle between the major airlines and the cut-rate operators was begun here last week with a public attack on the safety factor in lower-priced operations.

ST. LOUIS, July 10 (AP) -- A two-run error by Ned Garver on Lou Boudreau's sacrifice in the fifth inning helped the Indians to a two-run lead and they went on to defeat the Browns, 7 to 4, today. The game was restricted to six innings by rain and a scheduled second contest was postponed.

LONDON, July 10 -- With only twenty-four hours left in which to call off the two-month-old dock strike or face the Government's threat to proclaim a state of emergency, strike leaders here were believed today to be running into a growing return-to-work feeling on the part of 8,000 members of the Amalgamated Stevedores and Dockers Union.

This summer the Judicial Council of the State of New York is presenting to several thousand of the approximately 30,000 lawyers of our state a reprint of the main portion of its Fifteenth Annual Report to the Legislature, with a covering letter of the council's chairman, Hon. John T. Loughran, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals.

LONDON, July 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of a British Treasury communique on the economic discussions with United States Secretary of the Treasury John Snyder and Canadian Finance Minister Douglas Abbott:...

"That smug, self-satisfied mood" that prevents us from interpreting Christianity and the Gospel in terms of action is a danger to the church, the Rev. Dr. Charles W. Kegley of Wagner College said yesterday in morning services at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, 51 Central Park West.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 10 (UP) -Peter H. Baumann, breeder of wingless chickens, said tonight that he had agreed to ship some of his special eggs to Great Britain. The first wingless-chicken eggs ever sold will be shipped to London by air next Monday in a deal with the British Government.

QUEBEC, July 10 -- A recession has set in in Canada's pulp industry, according to Elliot M. Little, president of Anglo Canadian Pulp and Paper Mills, Quebec, but "while I don't believe there is cause for panic, neither should the Canadian people, industry and government underestimate the seriousness of what is going on now in our export markets," he declared.

MIAMI, Fla., July 10 (AP) -- Rewards totaling $6,000 were offered by two local newspapers tonight for the arrest and conviction of persons responsible for beating six composing-room employes. The Miami Herald and The Miami Daily News on the front page of their Sunday issues offered a $1,000 reward in each of six beating cases.

The Brooklyn branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People renewed charges yesterday of "official misconduct" by Kings County police. It sent a letter to Governor Dewey asserting that Miles F. McDonald, Brooklyn District Attorney; Police Commissioner William P. O'Brien, Mayor O'Dwyer and city magistrates had condoned brutal treatment of Negro suspects and illegal search and seizure of their property.

READING, Pa., July 10 (AP) -Cary Middlecoff sank an all-important putt today and Sammy Snead didn't. The result was that the Memphis dentist, who holds the national open golf championship, took $2,600 first money in the Reading open by one stroke.

Activity in the wholesale apparel market here last week centered on fill-in and promotional summer dresses and purchases of fur-lined and fur-trimmed coats for August promotions, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
A three-way round-robin, involving the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers and labeled the "Night of Champions," will be staged tonight at the Yankee Stadium.

For 800,000 public school pupils July 1 meant the start of the summer vacation. But for the Board of Education it meant the beginning of the 1949-50 school year. Accordingly, Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the board's committee on buildings and sites, announced that the greatest repair and modernization program in the history of the city's school system would be under way this year.
BAGUIO, Philippines, Monday, July 11 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and President Elpidio Quirino today discussed formation of a nonmilitary Pacific front against communism.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Jim Brink, fourth seeded University of Washington star, won the Western tennis championship today by defeating Herbert (Buddy) Behrens of Rollins College, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3. Mrs. Magda Rurac of Los Angeles took the women's crown with a 2-6, 6-3, 7-5 triumph over top ranked Beverly Baker of Santa Monica, Calif.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -Cyrus S. Ching, Federal Mediation Director, was reported today to have been instructed by the White House to avoid a strike at any cost when he opens talks here tomorrow in the steel-industry contract dispute.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 10 (AP) -- Two major milk-farmer cooperatives announced today that they would work out a Class 1-A (fluid) milk-pricing formula based solely on costs of production plus "a reasonable profit."

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican, of Illinois, charged today that Federal Judge Samuel F. Kaufman showed "bias bordering on judicial misconduct" in favor of Alger Hiss at the latter's perjury trial in New York.

Despite an increase of 13.82 per cent in operating revenues, the Third Avenue Transit Corporation had a greater net loss in the first three months of 1949 than in the first quarter of last year, the company reported yesterday. The net loss was listed as $1,199,930, compared with $844,724 the year before.
LISBON, July 10 (AP) -- Americans broke Portuguese records in all but one event in a two-day track and field meet that ended today.
Options on eighteen apartments have been obtained by the Law Center Foundation of New York University for its tenants on Washington Square South, Dean Russell D. Miles announced yesterday.

IF Jackie Robinson of the Dodgers can knock out Kid Gavilan tonight and if Ray Robinson can knock out a home run against the Yankees -- wait a minute! Let's start this over. It's confusing enough as it is. A baseball festival, which is known as the "Night of Champions," is scheduled for the Stadium this evening for the benefit of the Heart Fund, the Lou Gehrig Memorial Fund and the Babe Ruth Foundation.

LUBLIN, Poland, July 10 -- More than 100,000 Roman Catholics attempted to gain entrance into this city's cathedral today to pray before a portrait of the Holy Mother Mary, which is reported to have shed tears of blood over the church's afflictions in Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- A significant step in the Government's experiments to develop synthetic liquid fuels from coals has been made at the coal gasification unit at Louisiana, Mo., James Boyd, director of the Bureau of Mines, said today.

PARIS, July 10 -- Trade figures for French overseas territories with foreign countries have just been published giving full results for 1948. Figures for the first months of 1949 are not yet available owing to long delays caused by the scattered nature of the French possessions.

A two-year study by the Police Department and the Budget Bureau has resulted in a decision to continue the Emergency Service Division as a unit of the department under a revised operational plan that will increase efficiency and provide without added personnel radio patrol service that would cost $1,024,200 if additional men were put on to perform it.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -Walter Nash, New Zealand's Minister of Finance, stopping here briefly today en route to London, said Britain with teamwork would "solve the difficulties of the present dollar shortage."

The airlines of the United States, both in domestic and foreign services, are showing a reversal upward in both business and profits that is not only unique in their own history, but outstanding in the general transportation and business trends of today.

Advertising in the eight major New York newspapers during the first six months of 1949 totaled 78,087,777 lines, a gain of 5.15 per cent over the like period of last year. Categories recording gains were: automotive, up 51.07 per cent; retail, 5.99 per cent, and general, 2.87 per cent.

Life insurance companies are planning intensified promotional efforts in the group annuity field, it was learned yesterday. The companies, it is understood, are concerned over the need for higher rates on the insured retirement programs and the increasingly aggressive competition of commercial banks.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 10 -- A choir of 3,000 voices sang the "Internationale," sirens wailed and fifty cannon fired thirty-one salvoes in salute while the body of Georgi Dimitrov was borne today on the shoulders of his colleagues of the Communist Politburo to its resting place in the newly built monumental mausoleum here.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- In a radio debate tonight with Senator William E. Jenner, Republican, of Indiana, Senator Millard E. Tydings vigorously defended the military aid program as a means of strengthening the North Atlantic pact.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 10 -- Rain which was welcomed by the drought-parched metropolitan area only provided a headache for officials of the Eastern clay courts tennis championships at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island, today, as they went to work revising schedules for men's singles play starting at 1 P. M. tomorrow in an effort to complete this twenty-first annual tourney on time -- by next Sunday.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UP) -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, called today for an investigation of state unemployment compensation laws which provide for tax rebates to employers as an inducement for offering steady job opportunities.

CANAAN, Conn., July 10 -Seventy modern "cave men," carrying flashlights and carbon lanterns instead of clubs, crawled and twisted through the muddy wet maze of Twin Lakes Cave today and then came out drenched to find themselves in a downpour a mile from the nearest road.

Two detectives trailed four suspicious-looking men through East Side streets for more than three hours last night and finally surprised them attempting to rob a man and a woman at Lexington Avenue and Seventieth Street.

In view of the state of Great Britain's economy, advertising of exports to this country is scheduled to be stepped up by the end of this year, it was reported last week by British and American trade and advertising sources.
The 1949 series of summer outdoor story hours for children will be started today by the New York Public Library. The schedule follows:

The newest report of Park Commissioner Moses to Mayor O'Dwyer shows that Staten Island, for all its small population and its relative geographical remoteness from its sister boroughs of the city, is not being forgotten in the planning and construction of parks, playgrounds and beaches. New playgrounds are to be provided to serve the occupants of the 1,429 apartments of the General Berry Houses, Todt Hill Houses and South Beach Houses.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 10 -- An important shipment of quinidine sulphate, equivalent to one year's normal pre-war import by the United States, will arrive in New York tomorrow aboard the Dutch liner Westerdam for consignment to the Bureau of Federal Supply, which will stockpile the drug as a strategic material.

The credibility of a book, "God's Underground," in which the author, a Croatian priest, reports the existence in Soviet Russia in 1945 of a resistance movement that included a Christian religious underground, is attacked by the Rev. Paul W. Facey in the July 16 issue of the Jesuit weekly America.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- July wheat and corn sold at new high prices since early last February and July soybeans went into new high ground since January as the result of general buying on the Board of Trade last week.

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 10 -- The hills overlooking Chemung Valley were crowded with thousands of spectators today as clearing weather prevailed on the last day of the sixteenth national soaring contest, and the final event took place under a beating sun that filled the skies with "lift."
Milton Sherlip has been appointed president of the Legion Fabrics Corporation, a new division of Herbert Manufacturing Company, Inc. Arthur R. Cohen has been appointed treasurer of the division.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 10 -- Donald C. Stone's 40-foot cruiser Rolling Stone III was adjudged winner early today of the thirty-sixth annual Block Island race of the New York Athletic Club with an error score of only 2.95 per cent.

Intermittent drizzle failed yesterday to end the drought, although it afforded some relief to Long Island and New Jersey farmers. Total precipitation for the day was slightly more than a tenth of an inch.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 10 -- Mrs. Rose Gelb today celebrated her 104th birthday at the summer home of her son, Edward, at 130 Elmwood Avenue here. Mrs. Gelb, who maintains her own residence at 102 Ridgewood Avenue, Newark, came to this shore resort by car to observe the event.
"No shopping, no cooking or washing dishes and no chasing after my five children. It's just heaven," Mrs. J -- of the Bronx remarked.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Air Force has made things easier for Cupid.
CHICHESTER, England, July 10 (UP) -- The Anglican Bishop of Chichester called on the World Council of Churches today to take a tougher stand against communism.

Dollar volume of building construction in New York State urban areas for the first five months of the year, totaling $362,000,000, was 62 per cent larger than in the same period last year, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi announced yesterday.
Fordham University authorities reported yesterday that the University seismograph recorded two earth shocks at 11:07 P. M. and 11:10:44 P. M., Eastern Standard time, Saturday.

KNOKKE, Belgium, July 10 (UP) -- American-produced films took nine "Oscars" tonight at the Belgian World Film and Fine Arts Festival here, although Italy walked off with the top award. Twenty-four nations were represented at the three-week event that ended tonight.

Bernard Shaw's new play, "Buoyant Billions," which will be done at the Malvern Festival, will be published in England in a de luxe edition, the Vanguard Press reports. The book will sell for 6 6s (about $25 in American money).

As the Senate debate on the North Atlantic Pact nears its end it is becoming more apparent than ever that the Pact, which has been rightly characterized as the best available implement for the prevention of new war, will be ratified by an overwhelming majority.

SEROWE, Bechuanaland Protectorate, July 2 -- If and when Ruth Williams arrives here from England, she will find that already she has disrupted a tribe, caused concern to governments and possibly paved the way for an appeal to the United Nations.
Dressing like a princess can be a reality for at least some American girls today. An evening frock, selected by Princess Margaret Rose for her own wardrobe, is now being reproduced in New York.
BERLIN, July 10 (AP) -- Soviet-controlled chain stores in Eastern Germany will cut their prices 5 to 50 per cent tomorrow.

Seven experts for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development left La Guardia airport early yesterday for Bogota, Colombia, for a three-month survey of Colombia's economy to recommend methods to increase that nation's wealth.

PARIS, July 10 -- Displaced persons camps in the United States zone of Germany will be liquidated by the end of September, 1949, Harry Greenstein, adviser on Jewish affairs to the United States Military Government in Germany, today told the opening session of the world congress of the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training.

TOKYO, July 10 -- The Japanese Labor Ministry instructed provincial Governors to wipe out political activities by trade unions today as part of the Government campaign to quash the Communist-inspired "summer labor offensive."

EAST HAMPTON, July 10 -Exchange of roles by Christian and Jewish teen-agers featured the closing session of the second annual Minden conference of the Protestant Youth Council and B'nai B'rith Youth Organization held this week-end at the Minden estate in Bridgehampton.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 -- The Independence Day holiday plus vacations cut deeply into the steel operating rate last week. National ingot production was off 18 points from the week before to 62 per cent of rated capacity. While there will be an upward movement this week, it was believed here that the rate may not be much, if any, above 75 per cent.

The striped maple is a modest member of the underwoods. Along hillside trails where the belt of oaks, beeches and yellow birches gives way to the spruces, firs and tamaracks, the slender maple saplings with green and gray vertical markings rise from carpets of ground cedar and ground pine.

Elena Nikolaidi, the Greek contralto who made a hit at her recital debut last winter, stopped the show at Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday night. She was featured in a quartet of singers who presented a French program with the Philharmonic-Symphony, directed by Alexander Smallens.

A newly designed Rolls-Royce automobile selling in this city for $14,400 exclusive of city sales tax, or $6,000 less than the price of the current model, will be displayed today by J. S. Inskip, Inc., 24 East Fifty-fourth Street. The vehicle is 14 inches shorter but is said to retain the qualities and features of the existing type.

Once again the question of statehood for the Territory of Hawaii has been brought to the fore in the Congress. To understand the true nature, the essence of the question of statehood, one is reminded of the historic days during which our Union was being formed in the face of grave difficulties perpetrated by the narrow-minded and domineering political groups.

Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Federal Court. Brooklyn, reinstated yesterday Thomas Kinch, 28-year-old disabled war veteran, and his family to the three-room basement apartment from which they had been locked out last Wednesday. Mrs. Hilda Martin, the landly, was ordered to continue the Kinches as tenants at 1452 Union Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- A small group of Republican National Committeemen will meet with party Congressional leaders tomorrow to discuss a reported demand for the ouster of National Chairman Hugh D. Scott Jr.

Kid players who get large cash bonuses for signing contracts are squeezing veteran players out of the major leagues and are forcing an inferior brand of baseball upon the fans, Outfielder Dixie Walker of Pittsburgh charged yesterday before the Major League Advisory Committee, according to The United Press.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 11 -- Development of the 1,586 acres of Westchester's Blue Mountain Reservation, south of Peekskill, into a modern recreation center for the northwestern part of the county was demanded today by Cortlandt and Peekskill supervisors at the July meetings of the County Board of Supervisors.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- The Senate Labor Committee voted unanimously today to start public hearings tomorrow on a bill aimed at ending the seventy-two-day Hawaiian dock strike.
The maritime industry is watching with keen interest the progress of Federal legislation on the issue of the hiring hall.

Construction of the new American Export liner Constitution will begin today with the laying of the vessel's keel at Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard at Quincy, Mass., it was announced yesterday by John E. Slater, executive vice president of American Export.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- President Truman today vetoed a bill to repay mine owners for losses on the wartime production of critical or strategic materials.

LONDON, July 11 -- Britain and Yugoslavia soon will sign a five-year trade pact covering an exchange of goods worth $200,000,000. It will be the first major pact signed by Yugoslavia with a Western nation since the Soviet Union instituted Eastern Europe's economic blockade of the Tito regime.

Laddie Northridge presented his hat collection yesterday at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street, working with such rich fabrics as soft, long nap melusine, hatter's plush and velvet. He used jeweled touches discreetly, a wealth of feathers, and combined colors handsomely.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Federal and regional power authorities disagreed substantially today over both the undeveloped water power resources and future electric power needs of the New England states.

LAKE PLEASANT, N. Y., July 11 (AP) -- The disappearance of public records was disclosed today in testimony during a State inquiry into Hamilton County's fiscal affairs. The records were from the town of Arietta, in the county, and covered the period from September, 1945, to May, 1948, Edward D. Siemer, Deputy State Comptroller in charge of the investigation, said.

The crackle of splitting walls and falling plaster in a three-story brick apartment house at 315 East Ninety-fourth Street, Brooklyn set off at 2 P. M. yesterday an alarm that ended with fifteen tenants being forced to abandon their quarters.

A Federal grand jury indicted yesterday a former War Assets Administration official, an attorney and two contractors for allegedly using veterans to obtain fraudulently scarce Government surplus materials that they resold for a profit of $300,000.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it proposed to add forty-two new channels to the country's television service. The action does not mean the end of the present "freeze" on new station applications, the commission said.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (AP) -- A Japanese witness testified in the Tokyo Rose treason trial today that Allied prisoners of war were not "forced" to broadcast propaganda.

ROME, July 11 -- In a strong verbal protest Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza today told Dr. Mladen Ivekovitch, Yugoslav Minister to Rome, that the Italian Government took a "very serious view" of Belgrade's decision last week to replace Yugoslav lira with dinar in Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste, which is under Yugoslav administration.

Results of the sixth annual Donaldson Awards for achievement in the theatre during the 1948-49 season were announced yesterday by The Billboard, theatrical weekly trade publication, which sponsors the seasonal honors.

LONDON, July 11 -- At least four leading personalities of the Arab world will be in London during the Middle East policy conference of British diplomats and experts called for July 26 by Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin.

CLEVELAND, July 11 (AP) -- Combined shipments of ore, coal and grain on the Great Lakes for the season to July 1 exceeded those of any previous similar period in history by nearly 400,000 tons, the Lake Carriers' Association said today.

The report of Dr. Ernest W. Thiele on "the case of the missing U-235" should set at rest these theories: (a) that a significant quantity of this material has disappeared; (b) that it was stolen by spies; (c) that this is a good example of Mr. Lilienthal's "incredible mismanagement" of the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations today laid the foundation for its "fourth round' of economic demands in the mass-production industries by releasing a report stating that "corporations as a whole can afford substantial wage increases."
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn today submitted to State officials his compromise bill providing for control of oil-rich lands of United States coasts.

It is not necessary to agree with every point and every paragraph in President Truman's mid-year economic report, sent to Congress yesterday, to say that its over-all impression is reassuring, in the best sense of the term.

The concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at the Lewisohn Stadium entered their fourth week last night, with the British conductor, Sir Adrian Boult, making his stadium debut, and the soloist being Isaac Stern, young American violinist who has played there each summer since his first appearance four years ago.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 13 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The drop for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 12 per cent.

C. L. Sulzberger's June 19 dispatch, headlined "Russian Hate Drive Erasing Friendly Memories of United States," gives us a great deal of specific, useful -- and frightening -- evidence of the intentions of the leaders of the Soviet Government. By deliberately and systematically teaching hatred of Americans to the peoples of Soviet Russia they are in fact waging aggressive war against us.

The Book of the Month Club, Inc., has leased two floors at 100 Sixth Avenue and one floor at 345 Hudson Street from the Trinity Operating Company. The total space contains about 80,000 square feet. Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., was the broker.

Plans for the new Brooklyn City Prison and Remand Shelter, estimated to cost $5,500,000 and designed to replace the outmoded and severely criticized Raymond Street Jail, received final approval of the Art Commission yesterday.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 11 (AP) -- A judicial ruling late today blocked a prosecution proposal to link E. F. Prichard Jr. to previous acts of ballot-box stuffing.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Following is the text of President Truman's mid-year economic report to Congress submitted today:
Those in search of the big tuna can move northward almost any day now, for rod and reel catches have been made at Ipswich Bay in Massachusetts and Casco Bay in Maine.

LONDON, July 11 -- Steel production in the first half of 1949 reached a record high at 7,949,000 tons, the British Iron and Steel Federation announced today. This was the highest half-yearly output ever reached and was 384,000 tons higher than the comparable period of 1948, the previous best.

ATHENS, July 11 -- Authoritative Government circles declined to comment tonight on Marshal Tito's address on foreign affairs, in which he said he would author ize the gradual closing of the Greek-Yugoslav frontier.

Another volume of anecdotes about our last nine Presidents has been scheduled for Oct. 14 by Julian Messner. It is "Dear Mr. President," by Ira R. T. Smith, who for fifty years has opened and read the mail that came into the White House addressed to the President.

ASPEN, Col., July 11 -- Science, if it is to be one of the important binding "influences of civilization," along with the arts and the law, will fail in fulfillment if it declares itself to be only a more refined instrument of group survival, Dr. William E. Hocking, Alford Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Harvard, told the Goethe Bicentennial convocation today.

PARIS, July 11 -- Daniel Mayer, Socialist Minister of Labor, in a speech that lasted through two sessions of the French National Assembly, today defended the social security system that was inaugurated immediately after the liberation.

City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr. denied at the Communist trial yesterday that the party "advocates" segregation of Negroes in a separate "nation" in the deep South, but admitted it offers them this "right" to be exercised "in conjunction with" the Communists and other "allies."

Prices of cotton futures closed somewhat irregular yesterday, as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was stepped up pending the expiration of the July, 1949, delivery tomorrow. Final prices were up 1 to 8 points, except the October, 1950, position which was off 14 points.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 11 -- Attacks on the state and Hudson County Democratic leaderships of former Mayor Frank Hague were made today on three fronts.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LAKE SUCCESS, July 11 -- Marshal Tito's promise last night to close the Greek-Yugoslav frontier as a safeguard against Greece's guerrilla war was cautiously noted today in United Nations circles, with delegates and Secretariat officials adopting the attitude of "fine but let's wait and see if he means business."

TOKYO, July 11 -- The Japanese Communist party and its affiliated unions have abandoned plans for an immediate showdown with the Allied Occupation, according to all indications tonight. While the program for a violent revolution as soon as times are ripe still stands, this has now been postponed, at least until later this year, it is apparent.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today that a supposed $44,000,000 annual saving in agriculture spending proposed by the [Hoover] Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government was "open to question."

BERLIN, July 11 -- The three Western powers are postponing their discussion of counter-measures, which can take the form only of a limited counter-blockade of Eastern Germany, pending receipt of a Russian explanation of new measures by Soviet border guards imposing a partial blockade of Berlin.

A cheerful report on an important piece of public business comes from the Citizens' Committee for the Hoover Report. More real progress toward modernizing the National Government has been made at this session of Congress, the report declares, than any observer would have dared to imagine six months ago.
GENEVA, July 11 -- The United States has advised the United Nations that it has no specific program to combat general unemployment.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- The television industry expected to produce and sell 1,500,000 receivers in the last six months of 1949, Allan B. Mills, sales manager of RCA Victor home instrument department. Radio Corporation of America, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- A suggestion that selection of a site for a second bridge across San Francisco Bay be deferred until after voters there could decide it at a referendum was made today to a Senate committee.

NEWARK, N. J., July 11 -- Joseph L. Bustard, assistant state commissioner of education, asserted officially today that "as long as the American Bowling Congress continues its policy of exclusion of Negroes from participating in its tournaments, the State Division Against Discrimination in New Jersey will resist every effort on the part of this organization to hold tournaments in this state."

LONDON, July 11 -- A charter of religious liberty, with particular references to the churches of Eastern Europe, is being drafted by the World Council of Churches representing 155 Christian denominations of forty-four countries.

TOKYO, July 11 -- Japan gradually is overcoming the credit stringency that is currently checking production and exaggerating economic problems, according to Edward C. Welsh, chief of the Occupation's Antitrust and Cartels Division.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to cut $748,820,000 from the $6,322,200,000 which President Truman requested in straight-out appropriations to run foreign-aid programs through the current fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Secretary of the Treasury announced tonight that bids for $900,684,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated July 14 and to mature on Oct. 13, 1949, were opened at the Federal Reserve Banks today.

The First National Bank of Boston reported as of June 30, 1949, total deposits of $1,419,211,777 and total assets of $1,563,028,282, compared, respectively, with $1,393,179,749 and $1,539,878,865 on March 31, 1949. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $500,983,944 against $491,660,416; holdings of United States Government securities to $539,079,233 against $502,257,880 and loans and discounts to $462,817,381 against $491,195,439.

NEW DELHI, India, July 11 -- India has lodged an "emphatic protest" with the South African Government against the enactment of the Asiatic Land Tenure Amendment Act of June 30, the Ministry of External Affairs said today.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- The Aiken Farm Law, to become effective Jan. 1, would wreck agriculture, Democrats from farm states told the House Agriculture Committee today.

A vacant plot of land, covering the entire blockfront on the north side of Pelham Parkway North, between White Plains Road and Cruger Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Christopher-Hudson Company, of which Simon R. Bregman is president, from William Webber and others.

To the gardener drought is one long discouragement, a succession of brassy skies under which leaves curl and the lawn turns brown in ragged patches. Without the hose there would be no garden at all, but even a nightly sprinkling serves only to keep plants barely alive.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 11 -- Seven criminologists and sociologists representing six countries will meet here on Aug. 1 for a weeklong conference to advise the United Nations on future programs of action in the field of crime and punishment, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Following are the factors that led the Council of Economic Advisers to inform the President, with closely guarded optimism, tha "weight of evidence" did not support a "gloomy outlook":

A comprehensive review of public assistance in this city, primarily dealing with eligibility, will be undertaken by the State Department of Social Welfare, it was learned yesterday from State Welfare Commissioner Robert T. Lansdale.
PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP) -- A Coast Guard watch of a Russian freighter was called off today as secretly as it was put on.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 11 (AP) -- Bishop Luque of Tunja has issued an interdict closing all Roman Catholic churches and chapels in Sogamoso, second largest town of the Boyaca department, and ordering priests to leave the town.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 11 -- Ghassan Tueni, editor and publisher of one of Beirut's leading newspapers and son of the former Lebanese Minister to Argentina, has been arrested for having published in his paper, An Nahar, an article criticizing the speed with which Anton Saadeh, leader of last week's rebellion, was tried and executed.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UP) -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican, of Iowa accused the Atomic Energy Commission today of "avoidance of the law" as the public phase of the congressional "trial" of David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the commission, came to a close.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- An investigating committee of the American Association of University Professors held today that teachers had a right to belong to the Communist party, but the committee simultaneously declared that proved disloyalty constituted ground for dismissal.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 11 (UP) -- President Galo Plaza Lasso declared tonight that press censorship and official restrictions on freedom of speech were inconsistent with the democratic goal of "free competition of ideas."
LONDON, July 11 -- The London docks dispute and the debate pending in the House of Commons on Britain's economic situation made for subdued conditions when the stock market opened here today.
It is the purpose of this letter to show that Britain's foreign trade difficulties are largely due to the overvaluation of the pound and not to domestic socialist policies.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 11 -- Only three seeded players saw action today in the Eastern clay courts men's singles tennis championship on the red clay surfaces of New York Athletic Club's Travers Island. Tourney officials attempted to straighten out numerous complications which arose following yesterday's postponements when rain fell.

Despite reports here of price cutting of non-ferrous metals in Great Britain, copper advanced 5/8 cent a pound yesterday in its second upsurge from recent low levels. Indications are that strong demand is slowly closing the gap in prices between primary copper and secondary copper from custom smelter sources, copper spokesmen said.

A report recently published in New York Medicine, official publication of the Medical Society of the County of New York, outlining what was held to be a new test for coronary heart disease and suggesting a dietary approach for the malady's early diagnosis and possible prevention, is criticized in letters by prominent physicians in the current issue of the publication.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Truman's decision to press no further for increased personal income and corporate taxes at this session brought general sighs of relief from Congress today.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 11 (AP) -- Under cover of a dense fog three inmates of the Newcastle County Jail broke to freedom just before dawn today.

The Maritime Commission's $100,000,000 request for ship construction during the 1949-50 fiscal year, which was previously cut to $85,000,000 by the House of Representatives, was subject last week to an additional slash of $20,125,000 in the recommendations of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

New York business industrial and financial executives responded favorably yesterday to President Truman's tax program. Points most widely endorsed, in a canvass of executives here, included rescinding the $4,000,000,000 tax increase and liberalizing provisions for corporate "carryover" losses in tax laws.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has obtained an injunction restraining an association of 300 operators of self-service laundry machine stores from continuing a "price-fixing policy" that allegedly added $4,000,000 to $5,000,000 annually to the budgets of New York housewives, it was disclosed yesterday.

Einstein's theory of relativity might have figured in the involved process by which the champion in the "Night of Champions" was determined last night at the stadium. For the record, the Dodgers scored 6 runs, the Giants 3 and the Yankees 3.
ATLANTA, July 11 (UP) -- The 145 veterans of World War II in Georgia's state prison received an offer of an eduction under the GI Bill of Rights today, with two strings attached.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 11 -- The season's biggest field for one-day competition in Westchester, ninety-two teams, turned out for the weekly tournament conducted by the Westchester P. G. A. at Fenway Golf Club today, but those who left the first tee after the first foursome might just as well have stayed home.

For the second time within a year the British Government has found itself compelled to declare a state of national emergency because of labor troubles, and for the fourth time within four years it has been forced to use troops to break a strike which threatened to deprive the British people of the essentials of life and further impair an already attenuated national economy.

Lieut. Robertson Dinsmore poked his head inside Lieut. Frank Rados' cabin on the Coast Guard's Mariposa a little after 10 A. M. He said, "Sir, we're ready to get under way." He darted back to the bridge, and the gray-haired skipper climbed topside after him. In the skipper's wake clumped Comdr. O. C. Rohnke, chief of the Aids to Navigation Section.

Entrust carried the hopes of most of the 20,282 fans at the Jamaica race track yesterday. The fleet son of Fighting Fox was installed the 19-20 choice in the six furlong Chappaqua Purse, $4,000 event that featured the card, and he justified that confidence by charging to victory over three others.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The House gave quick final approval today to a bill increasing by 50 per cent the Government's secondary market for mortgages as a step toward maintaining the present high level of home construction by private industry.
Judith Coplon avoided Valentin Gubitchev, Soviet engineer, in Federal Court yesterday as the date of their espionage trial was deferred from Oct. 15, a Saturday, to Oct. 17, a Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Republicans will get two new committee posts in the Senate as the result of the appointment of John Foster Dulles, Republican, of New York, to succeed Senator Robert M. Wagner, Democrat.

The promotion of Dr. Ralph Bischoff from associate to full Professor of Law at New York University was announced yesterday by Dean Russell D. Niles of the School of Law. Dr. Bischoff, former law librarian of the university, is also secretary of the school.

A fifteen-story apartment house is planned for the northeast corner of East End Avenue and Eighty-third Street, which has been sold by David S. Meister to East End Residences, Inc. The parcel fronts 127-8 feet on East End Avenue and 196 feet on Eighty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Federal mediation efforts failed today to break the deadlocked steel wage-pension negotiations and Cyrus S. Ching, mediation chief, referred the dispute to the White House for appropriate action.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- In a masterful exhibition of combined boxing and fighting, Ray Robinson of New York's Harlem tonight retained his world welterweight championship by outpointing rugged Kid Gavilan of Havana in a fifteen-round bout that attracted 27,805 paying fans to Municipal Stadium and receipts of $175,754.

It was a year ago this month that our home economist, Mrs. Ruth P. Casa-Emellos, found in THE NEW YORK TIMES' test kitchen that an "ice cream" low in cost and calories, high in nutrients and fine flavor, could be prepared with non-fat dry milk solids (alias dry skim milk).

LONDON, July 11 -- A Conservative member called on the House of Commons today to reject the principle of the non-discriminatory single multilateral system of trade and instead to build up an independent sterling area.

The pound sterling responded strongly in yesterday's foreign exchange market to the developments abroad, particularly the conference of John W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury and Sir Stafford Cripps, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer.
BALTIMORE, July 11 (AP) -- Fire swept through one of Baltimore's old row apartment houses today and killed a woman and three of her grandchildren.

EAST NASSAU, N. Y., July 11 (UP) -- A girl was shot and killed tonight while walking with her fiance near the wreckage of a jet plane of the Air Force, which crashed near this community on Saturday night.
The major league baseball players' pension plan, after two years of operation at a loss, is in imminent danger of folding, it was learned yesterday.

The scene of battle between left and right forces in the Air Transport Division of the Transport Workers Union for the control of twenty locals with a membership of 8,000 to 10,000 airline employes shifted here from Miami yesterday.

New twists of scarfs and costume jewelry to make fashions functional were shown last night. It was the annual accessory party presented by the makers of Glentex scarfs and Coro jewelry at the Pierre Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat, of Ohio, decrying criticism by members of the House Un-American Activities Committee of the conduct of the trial of Alger Hiss, demanded today to know whether that committee was to be used "as a partisan political vehicle."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 11 (UP) -- A former special deputy sheriff was accused today as a ring-leader of Alabama's hooded floggers in a round-up of seventeen men indicted for terrorism. A suburban police chief also was among those arrested.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The figures supplied to the President by his Council of Economic Advisers, and by him submitted to Congress today, purport to show that, while there has been a distinct drop in the levels of the national economy, a condition of prosperity exists exceeding that of the first two post-war years.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 11 -- Prophets of economic doom were assailed today by Jacob S. Potofsky, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, CIO, at a meeting of the union's General Executive Board here.

A mortgage loan of $938,000, insured by the Federal Housing Administration, has been obtained by Neilson Gardens, Inc., from the Bank of the Manhattan Company on an 108-family apartment house to be constructed at the northeast corner of Cornaga Avenue and Neilson Street in Far Rockaway, Queens.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 11 -- William Milne Jr., North Hills, and Joe Phillips of the Links club scored 31, 32 -- 63, nine strokes under par, to win the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P. G. A. in a record fiel of 109 teams at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today.

Neither the police department nor the District Attorney's office indicated yesterday any immediate interest in questioning Peter Dunn, 36-year-old brother of the John Dunn who was executed Thursday in Sing Sing for the murder of Anthony Hintz.

Alexander Bestmanoff, 51-year-old international confidence man wanted by authorities in London, Vienna and several American cities, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy to three years in prison for duping a pharmacist on Rikers Island into giving him all the morphine tablets in the workhouse dispensary while he was serving time there.

The report of the Hooker Electrochemical Company for the six months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, revealed a net income of $1,285,000 after taxes and other charges, equal to $1.32 a common share.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 12 -- Britain entered into a state of emergency today to deal with the strike of dock workers that has paralyzed the Port of London.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 -- "Tom, Dick and Harriet," a "realistic" screen comedy by Virginia Kellogg about the United States consular service, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the studio announced today. The story deals with a woman who attends the State Department's foreign service institute and then goes to Latin America as a vice consul.

NANKING, June 19 -- An intensive process aimed at eliminating "reactionary Kuomintang thought" and inculcating the masses with the ideas and disciplines of Mao Tze-tung's "New Democracy" is now taking place in China. The process is operating through a mushrooming complex of party-sponsored schools, "universities," "reindoctrination courses" and study groups.

GENEVA, July 11 -- The United States today contradicted British statements that the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe was spending too much money and had largely completed the task for which it was established.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- More curbs on "bigness" in business and stiffer penalties for violations of the anti-trust statutes loomed as probabilities today in the long-range Government program, as a House Judiciary subcommittee started an exhaustive study aimed at overhauling the so-called anti-monopoly laws.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 11 (AP) -- J. A. Goodwin's Papa Redbird, a frequent stakes winner last season, scored the initial Eastern victory of his career in the six-furlong Clifford Purse today.
