A primary fight was promised last night by supporters of Councilman Edward Rager of Manhattan if Republican leaders of the Twentieth Senatorial District denied him endorsement for re-election. This year will be the first election of city Councilmen by Senatorial Districts since the rejection of proportional representation in 1947.

While tenants of adjacent apartment houses looked on from their windows, Park Commissioner Robert Moses, Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons and Controller Lazarus Joseph took part yesterday in exercises dedicating a new playground on West 169th Street, between University and Merriam Avenues, the Bronx.

RICHMOND, Va., July 11 -- A strong plea for a reawakening of public interest in America's "ownership system" of equity capitalization highlighted the opening session here today of the thirty-second annual convention of the National Association of Securities Administrators.

The Philadelphia Electric Company is offering holders of its common stock the right to subscribe for 972,624 shares of additional common stock at $20 a share on the basis of one new share for each ten shares held of record of July 11.

A majority of the five Democratic county leader of this city -- Borough President Hugo E. Rogers, leader of Tammany; James A. Roe of Queens, and Jeremiah A. Sullivan of Richmond -- designated Frank S. Hogan, District Attorney of New York County, for the Democratic nomination for Mayor yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 11 -- Several thousand housewares buyers from the United States, Canada and other countries today took their initial look at some 22,000 items as the eleventh annual exhibit of the National Housewares Manufacturers Association opened in Convention Hall.

President Truman's mid-year economic report failed yesterday to stir a very placid stock market. Although financial circles thought the White House proposals conciliatory and a departure from his anti-business attitude of the past, neither the volume of trading nor prices varied greatly from last Friday's.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 11 -- The Security Council again postponed action today on a Soviet proposal for the admission to the United Nations of the five applicants sponsored by the Soviet Union and the seven sponsored by the Western powers.

BAGUIO, Philippines, July 11 (AP) -- A union of Pacific countries against communism was proposed tonight by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of Nationalist China and President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippines.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Business leaders greeted with approval yesterday President Truman's abandonment of his $4,000,000,000 tax increase. Although the shift was expected in view of the failure of the tax boost in Congress and the downturn in the economy, industry was heartened by this and other concessions in the midyear economic report which indicated a more conciliatory attitude.

MILWAUKEE, July 11 -- Walter P. Reuther's program to expand the powers of the international officers of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, came a cropper today on its first test in the twelfth constitutional convention.

HONOLULU, July 11 -- Fred Low Jr. chairman of the strike strategy committee, announced today that striking longshoremen in Hawaii would handle no cargo on relief ships owned or operated by the Matson Navigation Company after the next trip of the Hawaiian Refiner from San Francisco about July 20.

TRENTON, N. J., July 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today called upon the Singer Sewing Machine Company in Elizabeth and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, to break their strike deadlock and try to arrive at a settlement within the week.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture forecast today that this year's corn crop would be 3,530,185,000 bushels and the wheat crop 1,188,690,000 bushels on the basis of July 1 conditions.

ORADELL, N. J., July 11 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of The Knoll won qualifying honors in the forty-sixth annual women's Metropolitan golf championship with a 1 over women's par 30, 37 -- 77 over the long and difficult Hackensack Golf Course today.

In THE TIMES of July 5 there is an article "Uptown Garages Found Ample," in which the Uptown Chamber of Commerce and the Chamber of Commerce of Washington Heights have surveyed and found 4,688 spaces for night parking, available in garages. On this basis these chambers have recommended rigid enforcement of no parking above Eighty-sixth Street.

Former Vice President Henry A. Wallace criticized yesterday the legislative program proposed by President Truman. He suggested that the President adopt instead the program of the Progressive party, which he headed in the recent Presidential election.
HAMBURG, Germany, July 11 (UP) -- It will be a long time before German shipping can offer a major competitive threat to that of the rest of the world, a shipping expert said here today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Truman reported to Congress today that the national economy was in orderly retreat from a serious inflation. He dropped his demands for higher taxes and price controls in favor of spurs to production and employment based on a return to deficit spending and moderate pump-priming.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 11 -- The Yugoslav Government informally advised the United States Embassy in Belgrade today that it was closing the Yugoslav-Greek frontier. This information was conveyed by Sava Kosanovitch, Yugoslav Ambassador to Washington, during the course of a courtesy visit to United States Ambassador Cavendish Cannon.

You are to be congratulated on the public service you are performing in calling attention to our crosstown traffic situation on Forty-second Street. Recently at the peak of the 5 o'clock rush hour I viewed the traffic snarl around Times Square and I could not but wonder that here in the heart of the greatest city in the world a surface transportation system could exist that seems so completely out of step with the times.
It is difficult to be optimistic about conditions in Germany today, Dr. Annemarie Schindler, a national executive of the Girl Scouts of the United States, said yesterday.

A sales promotion campaign in which wrappers from Lever Brothers Company products will be good for a variety of Westinghouse Electric Corporation small appliances will begin late this month, it was announced jointly by the two concerns yesterday.

OMAHA, July 11 -- Sixty-eight chess players from twenty states, in addition to one each from Canada and Porto Rico, entered the annual open championship tournament, sponsored by the United States Chess Federation and the Omaha Chess Club, when the lists closed late today.

GIFU, Japan, Tuesday, July 12 (AP) -- An American soldier fatally stabbed his Japanese sweetheart, Army authorities said today, and then joined her in death by throwing himself in front of an electric train.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 11 -- Idris Williams, president, and George W. S. Grant, secretary, of the Coal Miners Federation were sentenced by Judge Alfred William Foster in Arbitration Court at Sydney today to twelve months' imprisonment each for contempt of court and the federation was fined 2,000 Australian ($6,400).

Secretary Snyder found an adjective yesterday for the London talks which he had just been having with British and Canadian officials. He said they were "useful." This, he said, was "the right word for it and it is a strong enough word." The Canadian Finance Minister, Douglas Abbott, went a little further.

The list of the committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York for the year 1949-50 including those elected and those appointed by the executive committee and by Robert P. Patterson, president of the association, was made public yesterday as follows:

WASHINGTON. July 11 -- In a report to President Truman on the economic state of the nation today the Council of Economic Advisers reviewed basic elements of strength and weakness in the current business outlook and concluded: "We find the prospect reassuring."

BOSTON, July 11 -- About 800 Boston fish handlers employed by thirty-nine concerns were suspended today in a dispute over overtime. Fishing vessel owners began routing their craft to Gloucester and New Bedford, Mass., for unloading.
Effects of the drought persisted in New York yesterday despite Sunday's rain, but Long Island and New Jersey reported varying degrees of relief.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A committee representing preferred stockholders of the Wisconsin Central Railway Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to compel the Canadian Pacific Railway Company to furnish information as to when, how and at what prices it became the holder of $8,370,000 of the first and refunding bonds of the Wisconsin Central, now undergoing reorganization.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, today advised less vilification in labor disputes. He suggested that both sides function as if they were trying to "sell a bill of goods" to each other.

Prices of cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange averaged higher yesterday. Light offerings, buying and covering on strength in lard and grains advanced prices 19 to 30 points. Trade interests were sellers of the spot month.

TRENTON, July 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll made two temporary appointments of Hudson County Democrats to judicial positions today. Neither appointee is identified with the party organization of former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Korea today proposed that it be permitted to arm 400,000 men as a precaution against "rash action" by the Soviet-backed North Korean regime.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Top officials of the armed forces will meet with Secretary Louis Johnson at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., Wednesday for several days of conferences, it was disclosed tonight.

The Union Securities Corporation and associates submitted yesterday the best bid for $22,500,000 of state highway construction bonds offered by the Maryland State Road Commission. The investment group bid 100 for a combination of 4s, 1 1/4s, 1 1/8s and 1 1/2s at a net interest cost of 1.4947.

Keyed to two moods, the "grand entrance hat" and the "back seat hat," the latter subtly played down to complement the costume, Walter Florell's fall collection was presented yesterday at 29 East Fifty-third Street. The majority of the novel and wearable silhouettes stressed high crowns.

Boris Karloff has signed an exclusive one-year contract with the American Broadcasting Company to do a weekly series of television programs starting probably in September, it was announced yesterday by Charles C. Barry, ABC vice president in charge of television.

LONDON, July 11 (Reuters) -- The Derbyshire County cricket team, 250 behind on the first innings, needs 150 more runs tomorrow with eight wickets standing if the New Zealand tourists are to bat a second time in the match at Derby.

Ruth Williams, the London stenographer who last September married Seretse Khama, Chief-Designate of the Bamangwato tribe of the Bechuanaland Protectorate in South Africa, was born too late to be a Rider Haggard heroine. She has become, however, if not a "She-Who-Must-Be-Obeyed," an international incident.

One survival ration for men marooned in Arctic surroundings and another for men down in blistering tropics have been worked out by the Quartermaster General's office of the Department of the Army, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- About 5,000 persons today attended exercises at which Dr. Albert Schweitzer of Lambarene, French Equatorial Africa, received the honorary degree of doctor of laws from the University of Chicago.

It will be Joe DiMaggio in center field, and Mel Parnell, southpaw ace of the Red Sox, on the firing line for the American League when its top performers face the National League in the sixteenth annual All-Star game at 1:30 P. M. today in Ebbets Field.

BERLIN, July 11 -- Although the Soviet blockade of Western Berlin was lifted two months ago, the city is still suffering from its effects, but it is suffering even more from the effects of what amounts to an economic blockade by Western Germany.

Agreements last year among the four major ports of the Low Countries and between these ports and the Allied Military Governments in Germany have been cited by J. J. Oyevaar. Netherlands transport expert, as models of international economic cooperation.

Many domestic manufacturers of dinnerware have acceded to retail demand for promotional items and are introducing or featuring sixteen to twenty piece "starter" sets to retail as low as $7.95. This was apparent yesterday as the first National China, Glass and Pottery Show, which opened for five hours Sunday, officially got under way in the Hotel New Yorker.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 11 -- Crawford H. Greenewalt, president, E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., today urged 275,000 customers, employes and company stockholders to give their "whole-hearted support in resisting" the recent action of the Department of Justice in filing an antitrust suit in Chicago demanding dissolution of the du Pont organization.

Reductions in the assessed valuations of the Hotel Lexington at Lexington Avenue and Forty-eighth Street and the Hotel Empire at Broadway and Sixty-third Street have been ordered by Supreme Court Justice Benjamin Schreiber.

Striking fuel truck drivers at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, extended picketing yesterday to include carriers of cement and other materials and supplies in a move that threatened to halt construction of three $6,000,000 hangars.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Sharp arguments flared in the Senate today after President Truman withdrew the nomination of a personal friend. Fred A. Canfil, to be reappointed United States Marshal for the western district of Missouri.

Alert police action was credited yesterday with saving the life of 11-year-old Neil Sweeney Jr. of 669 St. John's Place, Brooklyn. The youngster was playing ball with several friends in front of 610 Sterling Place, which is adjacent to the tracks of the Brighton line of the BMT subway.

THE National League is a quarter of a century older than the American League. But the brash and irreverent junior circuit is no respecter of old age. The Americans have whacked the innards out of the Nationals so often in the annual All-Star game that they have virtually won permanent possession of everything the senior loop owns, up to and including Umpire Beansie Reardon's special chest protector.
Raymond Fernandez, on trial for his life as an alleged "lonely hearts" killer, took the witness stand at the Bronx Supreme Court yesterday afternoon for the first time in the nineteen-day-old trial.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- A bearish construction was put by traders on a corn-crop estimate of the Department of Agriculture issued after the Board of Trade here had closed today, showing about 300,000,000 bushels in excess of a recent private forecast. The figures on wheat, however, were in line with expectations, and as expected hot and dry weather in the last week in June was reflected in a reduction of about 55,000,000 bushels.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 11 -- Takeshi Yoshihara, 18-year-old Nisei, reported for duty today at the Naval Academy.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 11 -- Belgium's position in the trade and currency picture of Western Europe was examined here today by John W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury, who had a series of talks with the country's foremost financiers and also with United States experts who interpret the Belgian situation for Washington.

LONDON, July 11 -- The United States was backed by Britain and France at the Austrian treaty talks here today when the American deputy, Samuel Reber, moved gingerly toward a compromise with the Soviet Union on the important financial aspects of the treaty.

Although the volume and number of long-term business loans made by commercial banks here dropped sharply in the first half of June, the average interest rate rose to 2.77 per cent from the 2.28 per cent level prevailing in mid-March, according to the quarterly report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 11 -- A Communist party circular calling the Roman Catholic Church "our most dangerous enemy of the day" but adding that the church-state conflict cannot be settled overnight but must be allowed to "ripen," became known today.

The Metropolitan Motion Picture Theatres Association, Inc., yesterday urged the passage of Senator Edwin C. Johnson's bill to reduce excise war taxes, it was announced after a meeting of that group and other movie and theatre organizations at the MMPTA, 1501 Broadway.
Large picture windows dominated five room settings that Hahne Co. of Newark, N. J., opened yesterday on the store's third floor. A sixth room tackled the problem of the windowless dinette.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, the Republican leader on domestic policy, came out today "with the greatest discomfort" against Senate ratification of the North Atlantic treaty. In a major speech, full of political implications for his own re-election campaign of next year and perhaps for the Presidential year of 1952, Mr. Taft told his colleagues that with "great regret" he was going to vote against the covenant.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 11 -- Communism in Scandinavia has suffered severe losses in influence since its initial post-war boom on the heels of Soviet military victories. But it remains a strong force as a potential fifth column.
LONDON, July 12 -- The Commonwealth Finance Minister will begin a aeries of meetings here tomorrow to consider measures to halt the drain on the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Truman sought today to avert a steel strike through an agreement by both sides to continue operations sixty days. But the United States Steel Corporation quickly rejected the proposal because it did not use the procedure of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Capt. Ragnar Ecklund, master of the American Export Lines ship Exmouth, vehemently denied yesterday that he was a drinking man or was under the influence of liquor at the time his vessel was in collision with the Greek freighter Hellenic Beach off the Delaware coast on June 5.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 (AP) -- The Japanese colonel who directed Tokyo propaganda broadcasts during the war didn't have much good to say about their effectiveness.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Federal taxes, which have devoured private investors' funds and established the Government as a lender to business, may spell the end of private management of industry, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said here today.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 12 -- Eight countries came out today in support of a move to extend the life of the United Nations Little Assembly for an indefinite term.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Vice Consul William M. Olive was handcuffed for twenty-four hours and subsisted on bread and insufficient water for three days while in the hands of Chinese Communist authorities in Shanghai, according to the official version of his treatment given out by the State Department today.

BESSEMER, Ala., July 12 -- A coal mine employe who sought to work more than three days a week -- contrary to the United Mine Workers' order -- reported he was attacked by fifty men while on his way to a pit. The attack occurred Friday night, the victim, Thomas A. Warnell, told sheriff's deputies.

SEOUL, Korea, July 12 -- After five-and-a-half months of admittedly fruitless effort to carry out the terms of the General Assembly resolution calling for the unification of North and South Korea, the United Nations Korea Commission will unquestionably recommend to the next General Assembly session that this problem be handed back to the United States and the Soviet Union.

Describing business monopoly as an "economic blackjack," Attorney General Clark has urged further curbs on concentration of economic power. He made his recommendations before a House Judiciary subcommittee which is undertaking an investigation of the nation's antitrust laws.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 12 (AP) -- The collapse of a low-cost "dream" housing project was revealed here yesterday by Chester A. Maple, secretary and member of the board of Air Village, Inc.
CHICAGO, July 12 -- Former President Herbert Hoover made an earnest plea here today to the House Armed Services Committee to act now on the armed services reorganization bill.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- House Republicans, fighting implementation of the Aiken plan as well as a "trial run" for the Brannan program, opened a drive today for a simple one-year extension of the present farm price support program.
TRENTON, N. J., July 12 -- Democratic leaders in counties that produce votes for party candidates clarified tonight the controversy stirring the entire New Jersey organization.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- John Foster Dulles, in his first speech as a United States Senator, appealed today for ratification of the North Atlantic treaty and rebuked those Republicans opposing it, a group headed by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

President Quirino of the Philippines did a statesmanlike thing in the first place when he invited President Chiang Kai-shek to come down to Baguio for a straight talk on Pacific problems. There is no need for the Philippine President to pussyfoot on the Communist menace.

LONDON, July 11 -- One central marketing organization in Canada for distribution and sale of clothing made in the United Kingdom is recommended in a report published today by a nine-man United Kingdom clothing mission that stayed a month in Canada early this year to survey the potentialities of the Canadian market.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee in reporting yesterday a fund of $3,778,000,000 for European recovery in this fiscal year earmarked an estimated $1,500,000,000 for an agricultural surplus "dumping" fund that Marshall Plan officials said would wreck that program overnight.

SHANGHAI, July 12 -- Rising waters of the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers and the lowland lakes of Central China, which have been swollen by incessant rains, led to a public statement by the Communist authorities here today instructing all party workers in this area to mobilize for combatting the admittedly serious flood situation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many thanks for your wise and farsighted editorial of July 8 concerning the city's proposed Civil Service job classification and pay study, which, as your editorial discerningly points out, "offers the only promise of consistency and equity among city employes."

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, announced yesterday that papers were being filed in Albany to incorporate the America-Italy Society, the purpose of which is to strengthen friendship with Italy by promoting reciprocal cultural ties.
L'ISLE ADAM, France, July 12 (AP) -- Alan Stack, Olympic swimming star, today minimized reports of rebellion among a group of touring American swimmers and divers.

J. Russel Sprague, Nassau County executive, repeated his demand yesterday that the trustees of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road accept his invitation to confer with the Nassau County Transit Commission on a study of financial relations between the Long Island and its parent corporation, the Pennsylvania Railroad.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 12 -- After a year of discussion the Yeshiva Farm Settlement, a rabbinical seminary that was operated in Czechoslovakia before the war, and New Caste town officials are in complete accord concerning operation of the school on the former Robert S. Brewster estate near Mount Kisco, William T. Gallagher, counsel for Yeshiva, said here this afternoon.
ALBANY, July 12 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced today that steps now could be taken toward construction of a $14,000,000 high-level bridge over the Hudson River in the Kingston-Rhinecliff area.

Demand from industrial buyers for lead continued strong yesterday, resulting in a price increase of 1/2 cent a pound by custom smelters and announcement of a new sales policy by St. Joseph Lead Company. Orders for lead at one refinery at least exceeded quantities smelters could handle, officials said.

PARIS, July 12 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, chairman of the Commanders in Chief Committee of the Defense Council of Western Union, takes the view that he is an international soldier who belongs "not to Britain but to Western Europe."
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- A twin-engine transport plane, on a nonscheduled flight from New York to Los Angeles, crashed into a peak in the Simi Mountains thirty miles north of Los...

One of a gang of motorcycle "cowboys," who have been challenging Brooklyn police to speed duels and outrunning them with "souped-up" machines, yesterday began a 360-day jail sentence for a nine-count traffic violation.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Grain mar-wets were unsettled on the Board of Trade here today, wheat, corn and oats ranging lower while rye advanced to a new seasonal high and July corn went into new ground since last February and July soybeans, since January, while deferred deliveries of the latter sold at new highs for the year to date.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Chicago's world famous old Potter Palmer mansion at 1,350 Lake Shore Drive is to be razed and two twenty-one-story rental apartment buildings erected at a cost of of $7,000,000 by a Chicago syndicate if present plans are carried out, it was learned today.

ALBANY, July 12 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Commissioner of Health, said today that there had been no evidence of unusual incidence of poliomyelitis in New York State to date, but that the State Health Department was taking all precautions to meet any unforeseen eventuality.
Over the long years -- and that dates back at least forty -- Louis (Shorty) Miller and August (Gus) Meyer have blasted everything from granite blocks to square acres of city land.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday, but fluctuations were narrow, and final closing prices were 5 points net higher to 1 point lower on the day.

Curing club feet is routine business at the Hospital for Special Surgery. But when two boys named Johnny and a third introduced as Neil displayed their normal-looking feet in front of pictures of them before treatment was started, twenty Queens housewives and business men applauded the results as miracles yesterday in a lecture room of the hospital at 321 East Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities decided today not to reopen the Hiss-Chambers case -- which it started last August -- at least pending the retrial on perjury charges of Alger Hiss, former State Department official.
New pieces added to the contemporary furniture at Pascoe-New York, 10 West Fifty-fifth Street, use new or familiar materials and decorative fabrics.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The House Armed Services Committee appeared today to have demolished any chance for the enactment of a new military unification bill in this session of Congress.

Not so long ago, furniture, glass and hardware in the turn-of-the-century style known as "L'Art Nouveau" were looked upon as examples of grandmother's misguided taste, but they have now achieved the halo of historical significance. Today at the Museum of Modern Art a small group of recently acquired examples goes on display to illustrate the importance of the style in the development of modern design.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 2,441, against 653 last week and 2,136 in the corresponding week of 1948, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,114 arrivals yesterday compared with 142 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved an agreement between the Chicago, Burlington Quincy (Burlington) Railroad and the Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad, by which the Burlington will shorten its route between St. Louis and Kansas City by sixty-five miles and once again become an active competitor for traffic between those two points.

Despite a decline in steel output in June to the lowest level in more than a year the nation's steel mills produced a new high record of 45,928,476 net tons of raw steel in the first six months of 1949, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 22 -- The time table of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, had called for postponement of a steel strike for sixty days as requested by President Truman, but the United States Steel Corporation's rejection of the President's formula cast some doubt tonight on the union plan.

LONDON, July 12 -- The four Foreign Ministers' deputies who are drafting an Austrian treaty made a noteworthy advance here today when the Soviet delegate agreed that the "profit and other income" that the Soviet Union might receive from its concessions in Austria should be determined in strict accordance with Austrian law.
ORADELL, N. J., July 12 -- One upset and two close matches marked the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf championship contested today over the Hackensack Golf Club course.

SHANGHAI, July 11 This metropolis of 5,000,000 people, which has been sealed off from foreign trade by the psychological effects of the National port closure order seems to be facing a two to three month period of special economic stringency because of domestic production gaps in two of its most essential commodities -- rice and cotton.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 12 -- Gifts, grants and bequests totaling $3,835,000 have been received by Princeton University during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1949, according to the annual financial statement released today by George A. Brakeley, vice president and treasurer of the university.

Maurice A. FitzGerald, Queens Commissioner of Borough Works, was named last night by the Democratic executive committee of that borough as the party's nominee for Borough President of Queens to succeed James A. Burke. Mr. Burke has announced that he would not seek renomination.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Truman asked Congress today for supplemental funds for the current fiscal year in the amount of $194,514,857. The largest single request was for $125,000,000 to continue extending aid to Korea.

IT was a pretty slick plan at that. Ford Frick and the rest of the National League high brass were seated in boxes along the first base line at Ebbets Field yesterday. So Billy Southworth cleverly pre-empted the dugout at third in a subtle attempt to make sure that Frick and Co. finally would find themselves on the winning side of the field.

Six concerts in the annual Chautauqua Symphony series will be carried by the American Broadcasting Company radio network starting Sunday afternoon and running weekly through Aug. 21 from 3:15 to 4:30 o'clock.

This is a day of glory for Peter the Great, venerable hippopotamus of the Bronx Zoo. But it is a sad day too, for though it brings him a new world record for longevity -- 46 years -- it brings to mind the fact that, for Pete, the path of glory leads but to the grave.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The prospect Of Kentucky's writing its own liquor labeling law to protect its bourbon whisky reputation was raised today by Guy C. Shearer, chairman of the State's Alcohol Beverage Control Board.

" No doubt about it, Mr. John is the child of the atomic age," said this writer to herself as she turned from East Fifty-seventh Street into Madison Avenue yesterday afternoon after having viewed this milliner's new fall and winter collection.
Confessions by Raymond Fernandez and Mrs. Martha Beck, who are being tried as the "lonely hearts" killers of Mrs. Janet Fay, were admitted yesterday as evidence in Bronx Supreme Court.

ENDICOTT, N. Y., July 12 -- Former Secretary of State George C. Marshall told an outdoor audience of 25,000 persons tonight that the "momentum" of the European Recovery Plan must be maintained if western civilization was to prevail.

Expansion of the services given wholesalers by the Department of Commerce and a thorough study of all aspects of fair trade was urged yesterday by the Wholesale Trade Advisory Committee at a meeting with department officials in the Statler Hotel.

Manning, Maxwell Moore, Inc., Bridgeport, Conn., manufacturers of valves, gauges and industrial instruments, are putting into effect an inventory loss prevention policy covering their 300 industrial supply distributors, executives disclosed yesterday.

A New York State electric utility company yesterday disclosed plans to build a generating plant which it would turn over to the City of New York at the end of fifty years, in exchange for the free use of 405,000,000,000 cubic feet of the city's water supply.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 12 -- Charles H. Mylander, vice president and trust officer of the Huntington National Bank of Columbus and former city editor of the Ohio State Journal, died here today at the age of 58. He had suffered a stroke nearly a year ago.

The Federal Reserve System's check routing symbol is now appearing on 76 per cent of all checks being cleared in this state, according to a survey completed as of June 1, the New York State Bankers Association reports. The total compares with 72 per cent for the state as of Dec. 1 last year.

ASPEN, Col., July 12 -- World catastrophe is inevitable if the "tribal self-adoration, which goes under the name of patriotism continues unchecked" and if mankind's expanding knowledge is not turned toward achievement instead of "trivialication," and formation of a huge "Coney Island," Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, chancellor of the University of Chicago declared here today at the Goethe Bicentennial Convocation.

The Republic of Indonesia office in New York and the Provisional Federal Government of Indonesia issued statements last night expressing their sympathy for the families and associates of the Bombay air crash victims. Both statements declared that the deaths of the newspaper correspondents had occurred in the line of duty.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Bertram D. Hulen, who was killed in today's airplane crash near Bombay, had been a member of the staff of the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES since 1926. He had joined THE TIMES after service with The Associated Press in Washington and in Boston.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- W. John Kenney, new chief of the Marshall Plan mission to Britain, thinks Britain's dollar plight is "in no sense a hopeless one."

LONDON, July 12 -- The day after the King's proclamation of a state of emergency throughout Britain, the dock strike here was still slowly spreading today. No instances of violence have been reported so far.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Increases totaling $112,597,000 a year in benefits to disabled war veterans and their dependents were approved today by the House Veterans Committee.

Directors of the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation yesterday took no action on the declaration of a common dividend due at this time. Previously shareholders received 37 1/2 cents quarterly, the last of which was on May 2.

NEWARK, N. J., July 12 -- A new attempt to seek to settle the eleven-week-old strike of 9,000 employes of the Singer Manufacturing Company of Elizabeth will be made tomorrow by the State Mediation Board.

HEWLETT, L. I., July 12 -- The Metropolitan Golf Association's senior championship title went to Tom Robbins of Winged Foot today as the 56-year-old player toured the rain-swept Seawane Harbor Club course in seventy-seven strokes, five over par.

LONDON, July 12 -- The principal effect of the dock strike emergency regulations coming on the heels of the gold and dollar crisis talks has been to cut stock market business to the minimum and most sections today were very quiet.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 12 -- Those fast growing sailors and sailorettes, who may be admirals, commodores or Wave commandants some day, took a turn today at sail trimming and jamming. It was in the New York Yacht Club's junior regatta for the boys and girls in the families of the members of the clubs in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

WIESBADEN, Germany, July 12 -- Robert D. Murphy has been selected by President Truman to succeed Vice Admiral Alan G. Kirk as United States Ambassador in Brussels, it is learned from authoritative sources.

PARIS, July 12 -- The resumption of private trade between France and Spain, and the possibility of a private loan from French banking interests to finance it, are behind an agreement reached here, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Leading a field of sixteen survivors into tomorrow's third round of the National clay courts tennis tourney are top-seeded Pancho Gonzales and second-seeded Frank Parker, both of Los Angeles.

Ten Republicans were convinced yesterday they had proven that the young Democrats have grown soft from prosperity. It was all worked out on a soft-ball diamond in Central Park in rain and fast-approaching darkness.

ANNECY, France, July 12 -- The United States handed to the Italian delegation at the Annecy Tariff Conference today a stiff note warning that Italian intransigence was threatening to make impossible completion of a new trade treaty with Washington.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP) -- Old man upset continued to hold the dominating role today as the field in the National amateur public links championship was trimmed to sixty-four.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- General Public Utilities Corporation, New York holding company, has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to dispose of its entire stock interest in Rochester (N. Y.) Gas and Electric Corporation.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 12 -- The largest Parliament in the history of Belgium was convened today, without a Cabinet in sight. Seats normally filled by Cabinet Ministers remained empty.

HAVRE, France, July 12 (UP) -- The famous French liner Ile de France will start on her first postwar trip to New York July 21, it was announced today. The ship has been completely refurbished since she was taken off troop transport duty two years ago.

Ground was broken yesterday for a Manhattan housing project of eight units or 984 apartments and cornerstones were laid for two others in the Bronx that will accommodate 2,140 families in their thirty-three units.
ATHENS, July 12 -- Marshal Tito's declaration of Yugoslavia's intention to close the frontier with Greece drew wide editorial attention in today's press.
OMAHA, Neb., July 12 -- Favorites among the seventy entrants triumphed today in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Fontenelle.
Mayor O'Dwyer agreed last night to be a candidate for re-nomination on the Democratic ticket.

CALCUTTA, India, July 12 -- At least twenty persons were injured and twenty-two arrested in a clash with police today after Premier Jawaharlal Nehru's open car had been stoned as he drove into Calcutta from the airport.

ROME, July 12 -- James D. Zellerbach, chief of the Marshall Plan mission here, today praised Italy's use of United States aid and predicted that during the second year of the Plan Italian economic recovery, which he said already was considerable, would make "a still further and more rapid advance."

LONDON, July 12 -- British newspapers were accused today of "selective treatment" in their editorial comment on the report of the Royal Commission on the Press and were told by a member of the commission they were wrong to have considered themselves vindicated by the report.

Shirley Graham, author of "There Was Once a Slave," a biography of Frederick Douglass, has a new biography coming from Julian Messner on Sept. 16. "Your Most Humble Servant" is a life of Benjamin Banneker, a free Negro born in 1731 who began the study of mathematics at the age of 50 for astronomical purposes. He was a member of the commission that determined the boundaries of the District of Columbia.

As Alger Hiss obtained Government approval yesterday to leave the Southern District of New York pending his retrial on Federal perjury charges in October, transcripts of conferences in Judge Samuel H. Kaufman's chambers cast additional light on the judge's exclusion of three prosecution witnesses.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Wheeling Lake Erie Railway Co. has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $6,870,000 of general and refunding mortgage bonds, series B, the interest rate to be determined by competitive bids.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee ended hearings today on the nomination of John Carson to be a member of the Federal Trade Commission after Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat, of Washington, criticized what he called Senate pigeonholing of President Truman's appointments.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 12 (AP) -- Mort Reed of Rochester shot a 6-under-par 66 today to take the medal in the qualifying round of the state amateur golf championship.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 12 -- A $500,000 union campaign to promote union-made men's and boys on thing was begun today by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of Amerioa, CIO, at its general executive board meeting here.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- Government safety experts said today there was "no cause for alarm" in the fact that three of Pan American's big double-decked luxury Stratocruisers had been forced to turn back from transatlantic runs recently.

Beaunit Mills, Inc., and the North American Rayon Corporation yesterday filed affidavits in Delaware Chancery Court opposing applications of some stockholders of North American for an injunction thwarting the proposed sale of the company's assets to Beaunit.

In the Georgian Room setting of the Statler Hotel, with its red plush chairs and red flowered carpet, Irving Potash late yesterday took office as manager of the Furriers Joint Council, CIO, for his sixth consecutive two-year term. Six hundred fur workers crowded the room and gave him an ovation of cheers and whistles.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 12 (AP) -- A. E. Funk Jr. today denied from the witness stand any part in the forging of ballots last fall in Bourbon County. A handwriting specialist was called to back up Mr. Funk's testimony in Federal Court.
Jewelry will have an "animated" look about it this fall if the style trends introduced yesterday by Harry Winston, 7 East Fifty-first Street, are generally adopted.

After a twenty-hour session that lasted until early yesterday morning officers of sixteen of the twenty locals of the Air Transport Division of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, rejected an application for reinstatement by the deposed leftist officers of Miami Local 500.

Dr. Carl W. Kinkeldey, who retired in June, 1943, as associate professor of German at City College, died yesterday in his home at 1041 Faile Street, the Bronx, at the age of 76. He was on the City College faculty for forty years.
Late last evening the next of kin of New York residents who were killed in the crash of a Standard Airlines plane near Los Angeles began receiving official notifications.

PARIS, July 12 -- In a stuffy courtroom, one of the smallest in the Palais de Justice, Otto Abetz, Hitler's Ambassador to France during the Nazi occupation, went on trial today before a French military tribunal of six Army and Navy officers and a civil judge.

United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey forced City Councilman Benjamin J. Davis Jr. to admit under cross-examination at the Communist trial yesterday that a number of false statements appear over his name on public records.

Better quality and a greater choice in lower price ranges were termed the main features of the Rexall Drug Company's three-day dealer show of fall and winter holiday merchandise opened yesterday at the Commodore Hotel. Some 3,500 items are being displayed.
QUITO, Ecuador, July 12 (UP) -- Freedom of the press emerged today as the main theme of the fifth Inter-American Press Congress.

The city Department of Welfare will close its fiscal year with an unexpended balance of $9,943,407 to be returned to the city, state and Federal governments, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard announced yesterday.

Two home runs and seven doubles were included in the twenty-five hits which spattered rain-drenched Ebbets Field yesterday as the American League swept to its twelfth victory over the National League in All-Star combat; the fourth in a row for the junior circuit.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 12 -- Although rain cut down on the second day's attendance at the eleventh annual National Housewares and Home Appliance Exhibit at Convention Hall today it failed to dampen the optimism of those connected with the huge show.

ROME, July 12 -- The-Communist-controlled General Labor Confederation today ordered a nationwide twenty-four-hour strike of metal workers as a protest for what it termed the dilatory tactics of industrialists in granting better social benefits, improvements of workers' conditions and wage adjustments.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- A compromise plan for reorganization of the Pittsburgh Railways system was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Sponsors said it would assure Pittsburgh "an efficient mass transportation system."

GREENVILLE, S. C., July 12 (AP) -- A joint committee of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association and Cotton Textile Institute, Inc., "unanimously" agreed here today on a plan of merger of the two organizations.

MILWAUKEE, July 12 -- Walter P. Reuther, polling more than 90 per cent of the total vote, led his administration to re-election tonight at the twelfth consitutional convention of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

This morning's newcomer at the Paramount is "The Great Gatsby," Paramount's adaptation of the F. Scott Fitzgerald novel and the Owen Davis play, starring Alan Ladd in the title role. Elliott Nugent directed and Richard-Maibaum produced from a screen play by Cyril Hume and Mr. Maibaum. Betty Field, Barry Sullivan, Macdonald Carey, Ruth Hussey, Howard da Silva and Shelley Winters are among the principals.

Russian buying of rubber for stockpiling, coupled with apparent firmness of the British pound in the market here on Monday, were held responsible for advances of 25 to 38 points in the rubber futures market on the Commodity Exchange yesterday.

A group of Wacs, who had found just one wartime unit record of the Women's Army Corps in the New York Public Library's large collection of military unit histories, turned up yesterday at the Central Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street to contribute to a more equable balance in represensentation.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Legislation to ease the entry of Mexican laborers into this country for seasonal farm work ran into opposition today from the State Department and the Federal Security Agency.

Heavy volume of car buying in the rural areas throughout the country was reported yesterday by G. R. Jones, general sales manager, Oldsmobile division, General Motors Corporation. Farmers in the southern sections are making particularly extensive purchases of vehicles in all price brackets, he added.

HONG KONG, July 12 (UP) -- Mrs. Dorothy Brandon of The New York Herald Tribune was in Hong Kong today when she learned of the crash of the Netherlands airliner near Bombay with United States correspondents whom she accompanied on a visit to Indonesia.

Gertrude Savada and others have obtained a mortgage loan of $1,150,000 at 4 per cent for 10 years from the New York State Teachers Retirement System on the eleven-story office and salesroom building at 411-13 Fifth Avenue, corner of Thirty - seventh Street.

Bankers Trust Company has been appointed New York paying agent for $3,120,000 of Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Company's equipment trust certificates series "E" 2 1/8 per cent due semi-annually on Jan. 1 and July 1, 1950 through July 1, 1961.
PINE CAMP, N. Y., July 12 -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley arrived here today by air to inspect the training of National Guard troops at this 108,000-acre Army post.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 12 (UP) -- Australian Labor Minister Edward Holloway said today a paralyzing sixteen-day-old coal strike in Australia had been "cooked up in Moscow" in an attempt by Russia to impose its tyranny on the world.

In a most extraordinary exhibition, during which baseball was displayed at times at its best but more often at its worst, the American League yesterday at Ebbets Field demonstrated once again that, regardless of the going, it still could bludgeon its National League rivals into submission.

Isadore B. Geller bought for investment from the Dyck-Tryon Corporation, Madeline Fried, president, the five-story building containing eight stores and thirty-nine apartments on a plot 100 by 95 feet at 1551-59 St. Nicholas Avenue, southwest corner of 188th Street, in a deal negotiated by Nehring Brothers, brokers.

The largest publicly-offered industrial bond issue in the history of Wall Street will be placed on the market today by an investment banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co. The offering consists of $150,000,000 of debentures of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), bearing interest at 2 3/4 per cent, and due in 1974.

QUINCY, Mass., July 12 -- The keel of the liner Constitution, a $23,000,000 passenger vessel ordered by the American Export Lines, under authority of the United States Maritime Commission, was laid here today in the yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

BAGUIO, Philippines, July 12 (UP) -- President Elpidio Quirino of the Philippines said today that China and the Philippines were "not asking anything from the United States" when they called for the formation of an anti-Communist union of the Pacific nations.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- President Truman picked the opening of the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People here today to declare again that the Government "must lead the way" in the fight against racial and religious discrimination.

LONDON, July 12 -- Increased material and spiritual aid for the churches of Eastern Europe was urged on the central committee of the World Council of Churches today by Dr. Robert M. Mackie, head of council's department of interchurch aid.
Gordon Glisson, who tops the national riding list, and Earl Sande, the great jockey of the "Golden Age of Sports," back in the twenties, had reason to do some handshaking at Jamaica yesterday.

Now for the first time Congress is considering the establishment of a permanent Federal Commission on Civil Rights. Full hearings are scheduled in several committees and Democratic leaders are hopeful that a bill can come to a vote at this session.
Following are biographical sketches of Americans who were among the victims of the airliner crash near Bombay yesterday:
Although "At War With the Army" was listed Monday to end its run at the Booth Saturday evening, there were indications yesterday that the James B. Allardice comedy might continue next week.

An all-male blue ribbon jury in Kings County Court last night brought in verdict of guilty against Robert Vaccarino, business agent for Local 30, Operative Plasterers and Cement Finishers Association, AFL, who was tried for conspiracy, extortion and violation of the General Business Law.
Franklyn W. Bair has joined Richardson, Bellows, Henry Co. as labor-employe relations and training consultant. He formerly was director of industrial relations for Associated Baby Services, Inc.
Before the strong wind and overcast turned up, the New York and New Jersey tuna chasers were reaping a harvest, and the skippers are now wondering what the weather will do to the fish.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Intensified propaganda in explanation of the aims of the Marshall Plan was urged on the State Department today by the Jewish Labor Committee of New York, members of which have just returned from a tour of Europe and Israel. Three of them spent an hour with James E. Webb, Under-Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the Western Electric Company and the Bell Telephone Laboratories will take over operation of its Sandia Laboratory at Albuquerque, N. M., to conduct atomic weapon research and production.

The fall millinery forecast, presented last night at the Astor Hotel by all branches of the industry, including the designers, the Millinery Guild and the volume manufacturers, singled out for importance the tall crown silhouette, the wide-brimmed casuals, the use of feathers, jeweled touches and snug, deep, headfitting shapes.

The Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, representing major property owners' groups of the city, moved yesterday to upset the Housing Expediter's "fair net operating income formula" and replace it with one that would assure landlords a "fair return" on the value of their holdings.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- With debate on ratification of the North Atlantic Pact nearing an end, the Democratic leadership of the Senate today assigned next priority in its considerations to an increase in the minimum wage.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of July 8 favoring a proposed two-year job study in the city service does not state the issue in its entirety. May I add a few facts?
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Buyer attendance at the American Furniture Mart is running ahead of last year, a check showed today.

The stock market resumed yesterday its upward course and although the gains were spotty and labored prices gave the best performance since June 23. Contributing to the strength, which manifested itself mostly in the final hour was the hope that a tie-up in the steel industry might be averted through the intervention of the Government.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Nine people out of ten shiver at the phrase "survival of the fittest." Most of us think that means the survival of brute strength and tremendous power. It doesn't mean that at all. The fittest are those who think quickest.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company announced today that it has formed a new subsidiary to construct a third natural gas pipeline from fields in the Southwest to the Chicago area. The $100,000,000 project, scheduled for completion in 1953, will have an initial daily capacity of 340,000,000 cubic feet of gas.
The vast city of New York would be decentralized into a system of urban neighborhoods under a major change in city planning policy recommended to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by the Citizens Union.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- The Senate Labor Committee today put off action on emergency legislative measures to end the Hawaiian longshoremen's strike. It called on its legal staff instead for a ruling on how much power the Territorial Legislature has to cope with the situation.
" That thing Eddie Joost hit off Don Newcombe in the third inning was the break of the game," said Billy Southworth, manager of the defeated National League in the All-Star game yesterday.

HONOLULU, July 12 -- Return of the Territorial Governor, Ingram M. Stainback, today from Washington set machinery in motion for a special session of the Hawaii Legislature to deal with the strike of the ILWU longshoremen, which is now in its seventy-third day.

The morning glass of orange juice is as surely a part of American gastronomy as ham on rye and ice cream sodas. But it does more than awake the palate pleasantly; nutritionists tell us it fills the daily adult allowance of ascorbic acid (Vitamin C).

The proposal for a Department of Welfare that would embrace the United States Health Service and the United States Office of Education was sharply criticized yesterday as threatening the end of "state and local control of education" by Dr. John W. Studebaker, vice-president of Scholastic Magazine and former United States Commissioner of Education.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a private Australian citizen keenly interested, like so many of my compatriots in the work of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, I would like to express my delight at the announcement made in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently that the Australian Government has made third contribution to the fund which brings up its total grant to nearly $9,000,000.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson picked up a check for $51,196 today in pay for a night's work.

TOKYO, July 12 -- British Commonwealth representatives yesterday notified Occupation headquarters they had postponed indefinitely conversations looking toward a new reciprocal trade agreement between Japan and the sterling bloc, which were due to start next Monday. The departure date for the British negotiators has been postponed.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Appropriations Committee's report disclosed that the group had taken these other actions at yesterday's closed door session:
BERLIN, July 12 -- The United States Army will push a sixty-truck convoy down the Autobahn from Helmstedt to Berlin tomorrow, it was announced here tonight.

A program to stimulate more travel to Europe, particularly during the fall and winter off seasons, will be handled by J. M. Mathes, Inc., it was announced yesterday by the representatives in America of the European Travel Commission.

Mass production methods were used yesterday by Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh in his inquiry into ticket scalping. The Commissioner asked for the revocation of the licenses of eight brokers and two others surrendered theirs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12 -- "The Big Fish," a comedy about the salmon canning industry in Alaska, was announced today by Paramount as a prospective vehicle for Bob Hope. Jack Sher has been engaged to write the scenario for production by Robert Welch. The basic idea originated at the studio, it was explained, and is designed to create a situation in which Hope can attempt farcically to be as rugged as his surroundings.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 12 -- Mrs. M. F. Kessenich of the Brookville Club scored 46, 46 -- 92 to win the gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day Class B tournament at the Rockville Club today.

A bit of American life and culture was portrayed in a Columbia University classroom yesterday by Miss Irma Henry, music teacher rom New Orleans. Before fourteen foreign students, anxious to enlarge their grasp of English and American habits, she sang Creole folk songs and street cries.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UP) -- Many United States industries are losing foreign customers because they improperly pack goods for overseas shipment, the Department of Commerce said today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 12 (UP) -- Reports from Skoplje, Yugoslav Macedonian capital, said today that wounded Greek rebels who had found refuge in Yugoslavia were not returning to Greece.

Sales of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., for the quarter ended with last June rose $12,722,000, or 25 per cent, to $63,411,000 from the $50,689,000 volume for the corresponding three months a year ago, O. Parker McComas, president, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Richmond, Va.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 12 (UP) -- Law enforcement officers today arrested a fifteenth flogging suspect. Two others on the list of seventeen who were indicted for participation in Alabama's wave of hooded terrorism were reported "out of the state."

NEW DELHI, India, July 12 -- All forty-five passengers and crew, including thirteen American newspaper, magazine and radio correspondents returning from a tour of Indonesia, were killed when their Dutch KLM Constellation roared out of a low cloud layer and exploded against the side of a hill near Bombay about noon, Indian time, today.

The thirty-first annual reunion of veterans of the Rainbow Division began here yesterday with a ceremony at the statue of the Rev. Francis P. Duffy honoring the memory of the chaplain of the 165th (old Sixty-ninth, New York) Infantry.

Quoted From the Record Passage in the House of Representatives of the bill establishing a National Trust for the Preservation of Historic Sites and Buildings in the United States does not, of course, make that establishment an accomplished fact, for the Senate has yet to act.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 12 (AP) -- Francis W. Daire, retired New Jersey newspaper editor and publisher, died Sunday in his home here at the age of 75.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 12 -- Despite the vicissitudes of intermittent showers, real progress was made finally in the eastern clay court tennis championship today at the Travers Island home of the New York A. C.

VIENNA, July 12 -- Highly placed Roman Catholic Church sources here reported today that Communist party headquarters and the Central Action Committee of the National Front in Prague had sent instructions to their district committees throughout Czechoslovakia for a campaign against the Roman Catholic Church that will lead up to the proclamation of the Czechoslovak Church and possibly other pro-Government churches as "national churches" next October.

The Benjamin Hawkins, first of twelve merchant vessels to be used for storage of grain, is scheduled to commence loading at 8 A. M. today at the Claremont Terminal, Greenville, N. J., according to the Maritime Commission's regional headquarters at 45 Broadway.

Debutantes of this season have been holding frequent meetings recently to further the plans for the novel entertainment, known as the Two in One dinner dance, to be held on Oct. 6 at the Sherry-Netherland for the benefit of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club.

WASHINGTON, July 12, Seventeen local housing authorities today awarded $24,294,000 in short term loan notes in competitive bidding, the Public Housing Administration announced today. The successful bids were at interest rates ranging from .73 per cent to .85 per cent.

Normal sixty-day open-to-buy is again the rule in furniture stores after six months of hand-to-mouth ordering, Leo J. Herr, vice president, National Retail Furniture Association, declared yesterday. He said that from now on "wholesale furniture salesmen are going to get the first break they have had in six months."
THE day the enormous cask burst and they all went swimming in what you might call post-Napoleonic vintage wine probably was their happiest time in Corsica.

RICHMOND, Va., July 12 -- "Go North, young man." This Greeley-like advice was given here today by A. L. A. Richardson, president of the Toronto Stock Exchange, largest and oldest in Canada, in an address before the National Association of Securities Administrators in annual convention.
The Soviet Union has refused to participate in the international film festivals to be held this year at Cannes and Venice on the ground it is being discriminated against by revised entry rules.
Federal Judge William Bondy was critical yesterday of the Government's action in holding on Ellis Island an alien Communist who wants to leave the country voluntarily.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Administration spokesmen in Congress joined today in offering legislation designed to produce 2,000,000 new homes a year through liberal Federal aid to private builders.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., offered yesterday $2,000,000 of Akron Union Passenger Depot Company's first-mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, series A, due on July 1, 1974, at 100 per cent and accrued interest. The bankers had won the award of the issue wth a bid of 98.10.

The Welfare Department, which since December has been printing some copies of its monthly publication, The Welfarer, in braille, primarily for the department's nineteen blind typists, presented several issues to the New York Public Library yesterday for its sightless readers.

BEAUNE, France, July 11 -- Burgundy apparently is not worried about California as a rival wine producer. It hopes that Americans will drink lots of California wine and less whisky. In this way, Burgundy hopes, more Americans may come to esteem the rare products of Burgundy.

The four - story eight - family apartment house at 200 Crown Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by William T. Hunter, Philip G. Cole Jr. and Dwight M. Mills, as trustees of the estate of Philip Gillett Cole, to Benjamin Brownfeld. The Cruikshank Company was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Loans now under consideration by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development total about $100,000,000 and the institution is "thinking" of offering a new bond issue in that amount "sometime after the turn of the year." Eugene R. Black, the bank's newly elected president, disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the markets in the Union Stock Yards by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Aroused by eighty letters from theatre-goers who said they were unable to buy tickets for the new musical, "Miss Liberty," Investigation Commissioner John W. Murtagh said yesterday that his office would inquire into ticket distribution for that show.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- A new foodstuff known as mushroom mycelium, grown in "soil" consisting of tubs of water containing synthetic chemical nutrients or leftover materials from fruit and vegetable canneries, was reported today to the Institute of Food Technologists.

Mayor O'Dwyer and an official party of ten will leave La Guardia airport at 11:05 P. M. today on a flight to Mexico aboard an American Airlines plane. The Mayor's office announced yesterday that the Mayor and his party were scheduled to return aboard a National Airlines plane due at La Guardia at 4:45 P. M. on July 23.

The country's passenger-ship construction program, in which six vessels costing $150,000,000 are in process of building, is threatened as a result of criticism of Maritime Commission subsidies, it was disclosed yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers, CIO, announced today that members of his union would strike on Saturday against steel producers who did not accept President Truman's sixty-day peace formula for the industry.
Directors of the National Automotive Fibers, Inc., declared yesterday a 40-cent dividend on the common stock, payable on Sept. 1. The company paid 25 cents a share on March 1 and June 1, this year.

GENEVA, July 13 -- Reappraisals of the intra-European payments agreement reached in Paris on July 1 have led to a conviction in United States and Continental financial circles that Britain was pulled further toward "multilateralism" than at first had seemed likely.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Opposition to the Brannan farm program erupted in the House today into a Democratic revolt that spelled almost certain defeat, even for a "trial run."

PARIS, July 13 -- Figures now being screened by experts of the European Marshall Plan Council here indicate that, on their own estimates, the dollar shortage of the participating European countries for the year that began July 1 is expected to amount to $4,566,000,000.
In the dawn of last Christmas morning a five-day game of tag in New York Harbor ended distressfully. Distressfully, that is, for the fellow who got tagged.

TRENTON, N. J., July 12 (AP) -- State Commissioner of Labor and Industry Harry C. Harper said today there were "positive indications" that the business recession was leveling off and the cycle beginning to swing upward.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux, the attraction is "Once Upon a Dream," a British-made comedy featuring Googie Withers, Griffith Jones and Guy Middleton. Ralph Thomas di rected and Antony Darnborough produced from a screen play by Patrick Kirwan and Victor Katona.

It would be difficult to pick the star of last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium, for Frances Magnes played two violin solos with uncommon musicianship and Sir Adrian Boult led the Philharmonic-Symphony in as distingiushed a manner as we have heard in recent months.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 13 (AP) -- Mort Reed of Rochester, redheaded medalist in the state golf tourney, burned up the links again today to win his first-round match.

Moved by complaints of commuters, the State Public Service Commission has persuaded the Long Island Rail Road to abandon its plan to make commuters display the proposed badge-type ticket all the time they are riding the trains.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended on July 6, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Although in some circles there was continued griping yesterday over the method of selecting All-Stars, the general feeling was that the quicker the 1949 classic at Ebbets Field would be forgotten, the better. Certainly, most National Leaguers felt that way and turned their thoughts to the second-half race, which gets under way tonight.
NORTHAMPTON, England, July 13 (Reuters) -- The New Zealand cricketers batted throughout the day and scored 456 for seven wickets against Northamptonshire.

Robert Montgomery will become a radio network commentator in September when he starts a fifteen-minute program to be broadcast one evening a week. The network has not been designated, but there is a likelihood that it will be the American Broadcasting Company.

Although legislative action on new Brazilian foreign trade and exchange controls has been delayed ninety days to allow official study of revised regulations, the problem is essentially one of determining what American products will not be imported, an informed official declared yesterday.
Following is a complete list of the dead, not all of whose bodies have been identified, and the injured in the crash of a non-scheduled airliner yesterday in California:

In the rod mill where white-hot wire is drawn from burnished copper ingots, a "team" of thirty Negroes and white men, naked to the waist, works steadily to exceed the day's production quota. As better results mean more money in everyone's pocket, there's no time for prejudice.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A protest against proposed establishment of film quotas for Western Germany was lodged with Secretary of State Dean Acheson today by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Export Association. He said, in a letter, that the Joint Export and Import Agency of the Bizone Military Government is considering such an arrangement.

The six-story eighty-four-family apartment building at 1684 West Tenth Street, corner of Kings Highway, in Brooklyn, has been sold by the Corhal Realty Corporation to the East Coast Realty, Inc. Murray Adler was the broker and the attorneys were Samuel Halpern for the seller and Joseph S. Wohl for the buyer.

Your editorial remarks under the caption "Chinese Anniversary" in THE TIMES of July 9 leave something to be desired. Concerning the ignoble part played by officials of the Government, a part which contributed substantially toward the present unfortunate political condition of China, your editorial is strangely, though perhaps charitably, silent.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 (AP) Iva Toguri D'Aquino might have been conscripted into the Army to do propaganda work for Radio Tokyo if she had refused to do it as a civilian, a former Japanese Army officer acknowledged at her "Tokyo Rose" treason trial today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, repeated to Congress today his appeal for $623,125,682 to provide "critically and urgently needed" construction for the armed forces here and overseas.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Kansas-Missouri-Iowa region of the Missouri River Basin probably will need almost three times as much electric power in 1970 as it used in 1946, the Federal Power Commission said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- William H. Hastie, Governor of the Virgin Islands, defended "radicals of every persuasion" last night, and told the fortieth annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People that public officials who did not fight discrimination were a greater menace to national security than the radical groups now being tried for disloyalty.
ALBANY, July 13 (AP) -- Low bids totaling $2,450,859 were received today by the Public Works Department for highway projects in Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Reporting formally today on its $299,871,420 cut in European recovery funds, the Senate Appropriations Committee warned that the European Recovery Program could not succeed unless participating nations eliminated trade barriers and made currencies mutually acceptable.

Negotiations between representatives of an American Federation of Labor bakers union and six major baking companies broke down after a five-hour meeting yesterday at Warwick Hotel, 65 West Fifty-fourth Street. The plants have been idle four and a half months.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Veteran Frank Parker, gunning for his sixth title, advanced to the quarter-final round of the National Clay Courts Tennis Championship tourney today and Pancho Gonzales, a fellow Californian, moved ahead with him.

Eight Canadians paddled into port yesterday thirteen days after setting out from Montreal in a nineteen-foot canoe borrowed from the Y. M. C. A. The B'nai Brith Youth Organization sponsored their 400-mile jaunt down the St. Lawrence and Richelieu Rivers, Lake Champlain, Lake George, the New York State Canal and down the Hudson River from Troy to Dyckman Street.

LONDON, July 13 -- With half of the port of London now idle as a result of the slowly spreading dock strike, Prime Minister Attlee today threw the full weight of the Government's authority into a special plea to the striking dock workers to return to work and to "cease to allow themselves to be dragged, for ulterior motives, into a quarrel which is none of theirs."
CHICAGO, July 13 -- Judge Elwyn R. Shaw ruled in Federal District Court here today that Section 204J -- the local option clause of the 1949 rent control extension law -- was unconstitutional.

The Nestle-LeMur Company will merge with the Joubert group of companies, as a result of stockholder approval last week, Lee E. Nadeau, president of Nestle-LeMur, Connecticut manufacturers of hair-waving machines and beauty-parlor supplies, announced yesterday.

Colorful pictorial maps accurate enough to be endorsed for educational purposes and attractive enough to be used for decorative accents were displayed yesterday by the Hagstrom Map Company at the Blue Bowl Restaurant, 157 East Forty-eighth Street.

In line with industry's drive for closer employe understanding of its operational problems, the billion-dollar Consolidated Edison Company today will begin mailing to 30,000 employes an illustrated report of 1948 activities that deviates sharply from the statistics-ridden annual statements usually sent to stockholders.

PRAGUE, July 13 -- A circular to regional national committees signed by Communist party Secretary Rudolf Slansky and another from party headquarters to Communist officials in the Gottwaldov district -- the texts of which were disclosed today -- prescribed methods by which the government-supported Catholic Action is to be built up and recalcitrant Roman Catholic priests isolated or punished.

ALBANY, July 13 -- Vice Chancellor John P. Myers of the Board of Regents announced today that the hearing tomorrow in connection with the board's inquiry to determine which organizations should be listed as subversive under the Feinberg Law would be limited to receiving statements from the representatives of five organizations.

ROME, July 13 (AP) -- There are some 330,000,000 Roman Catholics in the world to whom the new decree applies, according to a recent unofficial estimate. A Vatican source estimated, July 1, nearly 3,000 Roman Catholic priests and members of religious orders were imprisoned in Soviet-orbit nations.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Truman today requested the United States Steel Corporation, Republic Steel Corporation and Bethlehem Steel Corporation to reconsider their refusal to go before a Presidentially named board and to present their side of the dispute with the United Steelworkers of America, CIO.

MOSCOW, July 13 -- The newspaper Pravda charges United States Secretary of State Dean Acheson with deliberate distortion of the Paris conference results in a futile attempt to bolster the "cold war" policy and increase support in the United States Senate for the North Atlantic pact.

BOMBAY, India, July 13 -- A simple private funeral service was held here this afternoon for five of the thirteen United States newspaper, magazine and radio correspondents who were killed in the crash of the Dutch KLM Constellation near Bombay yesterday.

The fifty-two railroads serving the Eastern district face a financial crisis that can be eased only by an immediate increase in passenger fares, eight railroad officials testified yesterday at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Truman told the American people in clear and simple terms tonight that "we are not in a depression" and that wise decisions in the next few months could change the current business slump into an ascending trend of employment, production and prosperity.

The Home Lines of Italy, which entered the transatlantic passenger field with the liners Atlantic and Italia this year, has placed a third vessel, the Argentina, in the Mediterranean service, it was announced here yesterday by the Cosmopolitan Shipping Company, Inc., North American agents for the line.
The drought was broken in this area Tuesday evening, in fact if not in official record.
Steam shovels were removing rock yesterday from a site at Wadsworth Avenue and 187th Street for a new school in the parish of St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church.

Raymond M. Fernandez and Mrs. Martha Jule Beck, known as the "lonely hearts" case defendants, heard assistant District Attorney Edward Robinson Jr. of Nassau County, read their statements of the Jan. 4 slaying of Mrs. Janet J. Fay yesterday in Bronx County Court.

A campaign against imports of Japanese-made knitted gloves was announced yesterday by the Association of Knitted Glove and Mitten Manufacturers. With an expected 385,000 dozen pairs to be imported this year, association officials predict that the industry here will be forced out of business if current conditions continue. American made gloves cannot compete in price because of the relatively high wage rates here in comparison with those in Japan, it was said.
BERLIN, Thursday, July 14 -- Trade talks between Eastern and Western German economic groups were broken off temporarily today
ATLANTA, Ga., July 13 -- The Georgia Supreme Court ruled today that counties with substantial Negro populations must put Negroes on their grand jury and traverse jury lists.

With the announcement yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer had decided to run for re-election as the Democratic nominee, efforts of opposing parties to come to agreement on a satisfactory fusion candidate went into high gear.

Initial distribution of shares of the first company formed to invest in the gas industry and related fields will be made today in a public offering of 440,000 shares of Gas Industries, Inc., by an underwriting group headed by White, Weld Co.

MILWAUKEE, July 13 -- After winning complete control today of the top international offices of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, Walter P.
