Reuther prepared to submit to the twelfth constitutional convention a proposal that would give the executive leadership the power to reach down at its pleasure into the locals to single out for possible expulsion any of the 1,000,000 members who opposed its regime.

A woman functionary of the Communist party in Boston took the stand at the Communist trial yesterday to refute testimony that Boston party leaders had helped carry out a conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman of New York was accused from the House floor today of attempting to "intimidate" the press at the recent trial on perjury counts of Alger Hiss, former State Department official. The charge was made by Representative W. Kingsland Macy, Republican, of New York.
BERLIN, July 13 -- The Taegliche Rundschau, official organ of the Russian occupation forces, today opened a violent attack against the Vatican.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- An Air Force captain has successfully bailed out of a jet plane flying 555 miles an hour with the aid of a new seat-ejection device, it was announced today.
Political and military thunderheads hang above the Orient, and the present outward calm precedes a coming storm.

PARIS, July 13 -- Otto Abetz, Hitler's Ambassador to occupied France, maintained at the second hearing of his trial today that he had worked in the interests of France in the hope of achieving a united Europe.

Fifty-five of Park Avenue's new aluminum electric light poles form forty-eighth Street to Ninety-sixth Street will be equipped with letter boxes to match in color. The installations began yesterday at the northeast corner of Fiftieth Street with Postmaster Albert Goldman watching the proceedings.

Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, said yesterday on his return from England thaat a fourth round of wage increases in this country would prove a threat to the national economic structure.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, Thursday, July 14 -- A sixty-truck American military convoy was speeded through the Soviet zone frontier checkpoint by Russian guards early today with less than a minute's pause for clearance.

BAD HOMBURG, Germany, July 13 -- Western Germany will soon be thrown open to investment by foreign private capital, it was stated today by competent United States authorities. Since the occupation such investment has been banned in order to prevent further inflationary tendencies from having their effect upon the distorted German economy.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- John D. Clark, a member of President Truman's Council of Economic Advisers, today asked Congress to investigate monopoly control in labor unions.

Establishment of an "unlimited policy" on cooperative advertising was announced yesterday by the Wings Shirt Company. Under the plan, it was said, retail stores will receive a 33 1/3 per cent allowance on newspaper advertising. Also, no ceiling is placed on dealer expenditures for newspaper space.

Senator John L. McClellan of Arkansas was the sponsor of an amendment quietly slipped through a meeting of the Senate Appropriations Committee on Tuesday which might be described as changing the European Recovery Program into an Arkansas relief program.

Seventy-five persons rescued two men from a truck yesterday when the vehicle overturned two blocks from Brooklyn Police Headquarters; then some protested to patrolmen after an ambulance from Jewish Hospital, a half mile away, was thirty-five minutes in arriving.

The unpredictable manner in which the Soviets keep their agreements is being illustrated once more in Berlin, where they first imposed and have now lifted another "little blockade" on truck traffic to the German capital. They have closed eleven of the twelve routes they had ordered opened up in May and until yesterday had reduced traffic on the one remaining route to a dribble of three or four trucks an hour.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, July 13 -- Katherine Dunham "wowed" a sedate Amsterdam audience tonight in the Netherlands debut of her "Caribbean Rhapsody." The colorful collection of Negro songs and dances had been billed as "the surprise of the Holland Festival," which proved an understatement judging by the audience reaction.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- American and Canadian scientists will use a mystery to try to solve a mystery in experiments this summer twenty miles above Hudson Bay, Canada, the National Geographic Society announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Truman and Miss Mary B. Womack of St. Louis, a classmate in high school days, had a regular "reunion" today in his White House office. She is now a teacher of first-grade pupils in the Dewey School in St. Louis.

Charges by Polish and Czechoslovakian delegates to the World Health Assembly at Rome that the United States had not made penicillin production methods available to the world are "more political than scientific," Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, surgeon general of the United States Health Service, said yesterday.

Strong buying continued in nonferrous metals yesterday and for the first time since last spring zinc shared in the demand. Prices of lead increased 1/2 cent, to a new 14 cent level, requiring some metal products companies to issue new prices before the ink was dry on bulletins announcing the previous day's levels.

A committee representing nearly all of the smoking pipe manufacturing industry was formed yesterday to explore means of improving product promotion. The action was taken at a meeting of executives representing some twenty-one manufacturers with members of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors' executive committee in the Statler Hotel.
LOS ANGELES, July 13 (UP) -- Earl Carroll's desire that his memory as a theatrical producer be perpetuated by a memorial with statues of beautiful girls was upheld in court today.

Jack Kupferman, 22 years old, of 1689 Clay Avenue, the Bronx, left jail on Rikers Island yesterday morning after having served fifty-eight days in lieu of $170 in fines for eight restricted-area parking violations. He was met at the jail door by Walter G. McCarthy, warrant officer of Downtown Traffic Court, with seven other parking summonses that Kupferman was said to have avoided by giving false registration data.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- The deal for Irving Allen and Franchot Tone to produce "The White Tower" independently for RKO release has been called off because of casting problems, and RKO, which owns the screen rights to the property, has taken the project back with the understanding that Allen will produce the film as an RKO employe.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain store companies declined 4.4 per cent in June, compared with the corresponding month in 1948, according to a compilation covering forty-three companies made by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 13 -- William D'Olier Lippincott, who has been serving as a member of the administrative staff for the last three years, has been appointed assistant dean of the college at Princeton University, it was announced today by George A. Brakeley, vice president and treasurer of the university.

WARSAW, July 13 (AP) -- Poland's official press agency reported that a woman was trampled to death and nineteen other persons were injured today in a stampede to see a "weeping Virgin" miracle in Lublin, in eastern Poland.

WAYNE, N. J., July 13 -- Harold Sanderson and Dr. Stephen G. Lee of Canoe Brook clipped six strokes from par at the North Jersey Country Club today to win the annual pro-amateur medal play championship of the New Jersey State Golf Association.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and closed 11 to 22 points net higher.

LONDON, July 13 -- The Commonwealth Finance Ministers' conference opened today with a review of the policy of all nine countries represented toward the problem of getting a long-term permanent solution of the sterling area's dollar deficit.

Total rayon shipments during the first six months of this year amounted to 412,400,000 pounds, or 23 1/2 per cent less than the corresponding period of last year, according to the Rayon Organon, statistical bulletin of the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., released yesterday.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 13 (AP) -- Dominave, owned by the Harborvale Stable, and his running mate, Always Home, dominated the running of the New Jersey Futurity before 14,610 fans at Monmouth Park today.

An early fall presentation of "Twelfth Night" was announced yesterday by Roger Stevens, an investment broker of Ann Arbor, Mich., who has produced numerous plays for the Detroit Drama Guild as well as actively participated in the Ann Arbor Dramatic season.

With the aim of increasing off-street parking facilities in New York, the City Planning Commission at its meeting at City Hall yesterday adopted zoning amendments designed to simplify the procedure for winning city approval of new sites for public garages.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 13 (UP) -- Eastern Europe, from the Black Sea to the Baltic, has begun harvesting bumper crops, the largest since the war, a United Press survey showed today.

The eleven-story loft building at 830 Broadway and the adjoining ten-story lofts at 832-34 Broadway, between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets, have been sold by Hearn Broadway Builders, Inc., to the Rorgan Realty Corporation, which intends to occupy part of the property.
PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- Five individuals and four kitchen-equipment manufacturers were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.
CANTON, July 13 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek will tour the free South China provinces soon to boost morale there against the Communist armies, government sources said today.

Every imaginable shade of green from a smoky chartreuse to deep forest has been used in decorating all the rooms in a ranch type of model house opening to the public today. The house is part of the Saddlewood Hills Development in Hillsdale. N. J. Modernage of New York with Paul McCobb, decorator, planned the color schemes and selected the furnishings.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP) -- The New England Council said today that a steel-making plant in New England is "economically feasible" with the use of Labrador-Quebec ores which are expected to be available in 1952.

United States domination of world textile markets is rapidly drawing to a close, it was warned here yesterday by Frederick W. Richmond, president of the United States Foreign Corporation. The post-war export boom in textiles, he said, is a thing of the past, and foreign importers, who in recent years were eager for any goods offered by American exporters, are now buying with considerable caution.

Two unscheduled events of the past few days have given a decidedly new twist to the forthcoming campaign to elect a Mayor of New York City. On the one hand, Mr. O'Dwyer, after having twice announced firmly (May 25 and June 9) that he could not and would not be a candidate to succeed himself, has now decided that he spoke both too firmly and too soon.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 13 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations will concentrate its efforts for 1949 and 1950 in 153 marginal Congressional districts, where two and one-half per cent of the vote either way will affect the fortunes of liberal and pro-labor candidates.

Scribbled postcards gave assurance that everyone safely had reached camp. This was good to think about, since the nearest camp was 300 miles away, as a crow would fly pursued by demons. A quiet summer loomed, beckoning to long afternoons at Jones Beach, to cool evenings before the radio, to deep and thorough rest in the mornings.

The strong Australian Davis Cup team arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Queen Elizabeth, the first contingent of what promises to be the finest representation of foreign tennis players to come here since pre-war years.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP) -- Two college age youngsters stole the spotlight today as the National public links golf championship progressed through the third and fourth rounds, cutting the field down to sixteen by nightfall.

The New York County executive committee of the Liberal party met yesterday at headquarters in the Claridge Hotel and designated Murray Baron, County Chairman, for nomination for Borough President of Manhattan in what was described as the party's first step "to oust the Rogers-Mancuso Tammany machine from control of that office."

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson opened his weekly news conference today with a tribute to three members of the State Department Correspondents Association who were killed in the airplane accident at Bombay yesterday. The transcript of what he had to say was as follows:
HARTFORD, Conn., July 12 -- Stockholders of two Hartford insurance companies, one wholly owned by the other, will be asked to approve substantial increases in the capital stock of each.

The efforts of various state regulatory bodies to keep production of crude oil within the amount demanded seem to be meeting some success. The nation's crude oil output last week dropped to the lowest level since the week ended on Feb. 1, 1947.

SALISBURY, Md., July 13 -- Down here where Maryland, Delaware and Virginia form the area known as the Delmarva Peninsula, chickens are big business. This is, in fact, the world's biggest poultry raising section, with a hatchery that turns out more than 1,000,000 chicks every three weeks and a plant that quick freezes about 75,000 pounds of fryers daily five days a week throughout the year.

ONE day last week a Boston photographer asked Birdie Tebbetts to pose for a picture with a bat in his hands. It was the most flattering suggestion that ever had been made to the veteran catcher in all his years as a major leaguer. The incongruity of it so appealed to his sense of humor that he just couldn't resist a quip.
An insulation failure in one of the Pennsylvania Railroad tunnels under the East River put forty-one trains out of service from 4:05 to 6:49 o'clock last night.

Matching prints on wallpaper and fabric, and correlated designs used on draperies and rugs, may be used to reiterate pattern in a small room where the sameness of the print may lend a feeling of space. Matching furnishings may also be used to solve the opposite problem in an oversized room where repetition of a motif on furniture, walls and floor serves to hold the room together.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 13 (AP) -- A fifteen-year-old mystery of the art world -- what happened to the prize-winning paintings of the late Alfred Juergens, a giant among American impressionists? -- has just been solved.

The Olympic Star, third of a $36,500,000 six - tanker building program of the Olympic Oil Lines, will be launched tomorrow from the Bethlehem Steel - Sparrows Point, Md., shipyard, A. S. Onassis, president of Olympic, said yesterday. The super-tanker will be sponsored by Mrs. Howard C. Sheperd of New York, wife of the president of the National City Bank.

SILVER BAY, N. Y., July 13 -- Three hundred Protestant clergymen, mission officials and church workers were warned here tonight by the Rev. Dr. Merlyn A. Chappel of the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America that until missionary activity became the "major business" of the church, Protestantism would continue to lose ground in its battle against secularism and materialism.

Joseph E. O'Grady, director of the Division of Labor Relations, said last night the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and representatives of the jointly owned Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York City Omnibus Corporation would confer in his office at 2 P. M. today because he regards the dispute as "pretty serious."
Fred J. Walters, vice-president of Hotpoint, Inc., has been appointed director of the marketing activities of the company. For the last two years he served as vice-president of industrial relations.

LONDON, July 13 -- An appeal to the World Council of Churches to use its influence to halt the dismantling of German factories was made today by Pastor Martin Niemoeller of the Evangelical Church in Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- In a major extension of the Rural Electrification Act of 1936, the House today voted, 282 to 109, to permit long-term 2 per cent Federal loans to bring telephone service, as well as power, to the nation's farmers.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 13 -- The legal battle to obtain vital records and membership lists of Alabama's Federated Ku Klux Klan, Inc., moved forward today on two fronts.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 -- Air safety inspectors today said they doubted that there was any connection between a fight aboard a Standard Airlines transport yesterday morning and the crash of the twin-engine plane a short time later in the Santa Susana Mountains, near Chatsworth.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 13 (AP) -- Three oil companies cut prices 10 cents a barrel today on certain low-gravity Texas crude oils. The cuts meet a decrease started Friday by Humble and met Monday by Magnolia.

Magistrate John A. Dyer of Brooklyn Traffic Court deserves a word of thanks for imposing virtually the maximum penalty on the 22-year-old speed maniac who drove a borrowed motorcycle along Flatbush Avenue in the rain Sunday night at ninety miles an hour, on the wrong side of the street and without lights.

RICHMOND, Va., July 23 -- Francis Adams Truslow, president of the New York Curb Exchange, took a Sherlock Holmes look here today at the stock market and said he found "clues that suggest a case of incipient suicide, and not a murder."

The records of all men's years on earth are full of risks known and cheerfully accepted. Men went to sea when the motive power was the strength of their backs; they faced storms and unknown waters with the crudest of sails and no charts or instruments to guide them; they died of want and disease; they were wrecked on strange shores.
Following is the text of President Truman's radio address to the nation last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 13 -- Reclamation of 120,000 acres of farmland from beneath the waters of the Zuider Zee is one of four projects in the Netherlands that are being supported by the release of more than $90,000,000 of Marshall Plan counterpart guilders, it was announced jointly today by the Economic Cooperation Administration mission and The Hague Government.

A new citrus purchasing plan which guarantees orange growers a minimum price of $1 a box and includes regular advance monthly payments to aid in financing crops is to be put into effect immediately by Vacuum Foods Corporation, it was made known here yesterday.

A new two-passenger 1949 roadster was presented yesterday by Crosley Motors, Inc., and will be on display today at Macy's and the showrooms of Fine Car, Inc., 429 East Seventy-fourth Street. The city delivered price, exclusive of city sales tax, is $950.

Two-thirds of the persons on home relief in one area in New York State suffer from physical or mental disability, a recent study shows. Eighty per cent of the public assistance cases in another area have illnesses ranging from tuberculosis and arthritis to serious mental conditions and alcoholism.

In your editorial "The Pact Debate" of July 11 you dismissed rather lightly, I fear, an important initiative of ten Senators who on July 8 joined Senator Sparkman in a bipartisan resolution pointing the way toward a more effective implementation of the North Atlantic Pact than now proposed by the Administration in its forthcoming military aid bill.

In accordance with a decision reached the night before, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he was a candidate for renomination on the Democratic ticket, ending the uncertainty that had prevailed since his announcement of his desire to retire at the end of his present term on Dec. 31.
LONDON, July 13 -- Idle conditions with no decided trend, pending the outcome of Empire dollar talks characterized most sections of the stock market here today.

A banking group headed by the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo was high bidder yesterday for a new issue of $1,014,000 of Boston Metropolitan District bonds maturing Aug. 1, 1950 to 1969. The syndicate submitted a bid of 100.05 for a 1 3/4 per cent coupon. The group plans to reoffer the bonds at a yield of 0.75 per cent to a dollar price of $100.25, according to maturity.
Loew's, Inc., in its report yesterday of operations for the forty weeks ended on June 9, showed increased earnings over a corresponding earlier period for the second time this year.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Dandilly, a 4-year-old filly, easily led the field, including the Kentucky Derby winner Ponder, in the $27,450 Myrtlewood Handicap at Arlington Park today.

Greek Ship, full brother to one stakes-winner and half-brother to another, did some stakes-collecting on his own account at Jamaica yesterday. He scored a length victory in the $12,200 Wakefield, a six-furlong sprint for 2-year-olds.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 13 -- The Union of South Africa finally and flatly turned down today the United Nations General Assembly's request that South-West Africa be incorporated into the trusteeship system.

ORADELL, N. J., July 13 -- Mrs. Evelyn Smith of Wykagyl, former British internationalist, continued today to be the "dark horse" in the forty-sixth Women's Metropolitan golf championship as she reached the semi-final round on the Hackensack Golf Club course.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 13 -- Milovan Djilas, member of the Yugoslav Politburo and head of the Propaganda Section of the Central Committee of the Communist party, asserted today that the Soviet Government was preparing to make a deal with the West to liquidate the Greek rebellion.

Ezzard Charles, Cincinnati boxer who is regarded as the heavyweight champion by the National Boxing Association, signed formal articles yesterday to oppose Gus Lesnevich in a fifteen-round bout at the Yankee Stadium. The fight is scheduled for Aug. 10.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 13 -- Making his first appearance in the tournament after being held up by engagements at Spring Lake and the rain, William Talbert defeated Alexander (Zan) Carver today in the Eastern clay courts tennis championships at the Travers Island home of the New York A. C.

After early easiness in slow trading, coffee futures rallied sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Demand for the distant positions by producer interests helped to steady prices. Final levels for contract "S" were 2 to 18 points higher. Contract "D" also rallied in late trading. Volume was thin. Closing prices were 5 to 24 points higher.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 13 -- The Jersey City Board of Education today reversed itself on a resolution adopted on July 6 which granted certain salary increases to school officials.

The present impasse in the steel industry, with a nation-wide strike at the end of the week looming as at least a definite possibility, is a sobering illustration of what can happen when the Government plays politics with basic legislation.
The Babylon and Bay Shore tuna clubs will wage their annual tuna hauling contest on Saturday, with ten boats from each club competing, and as long as the fish are taken trolling, no holds are barred.
ROME, July 13 -- Following is an official translation from the Latin of the decree by the Congregation of the Holy Office on excommunication of Communists:

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- Harry Bridges, president of the CIO Longshoremen's Union, today asked Congress to hear his charges that Hawaii's "big five" companies were trying to break the union and "maintain monopolistic control" of the island's economy.
Mayor O'Dwyer's statement announcing his candidacy for renomination, issued yesterday at City Hall, follows:

Her Majesty Queen Juliana has sent a personal message of sympathy to the families of those who died in Tuesday's tragic air crash in Bombay, and I wish to convey to you, on behalf of the Netherlands Government and myself, feelings of deepest regret and sorrow on the death of your valued associate.

The projected new, fast, streamlined ferryboats for the Staten Island-Battery run moved further from realization yesterday as the city discarded bids that were submitted on May 6 and called for new construction estimates.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- An eleventh-hour agreement between officials of the Inland Steel Company and United Steelworkers of America on continuing negotiations for sixty days averted tonight a threatened shutdown of Inland's great producing facilities.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The United States accused Russia today of using recent labor disorders in Japan for propaganda purposes, and denied United States Occupation authorities were trying to "repress" labor and "democratic elements.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UP) -- Harry Bridges, president of the CIO Longshoremen's Union, today asked Congress to hear his charges that Hawaii's "big five" companies were trying to break the union and "maintain monopolistic control" of the island's economy.
Mayor O'Dwyer's statement announcing his candidacy for renomination, issued yesterday at City Hall, follows:

Her Majesty Queen Juliana has sent a personal message of sympathy to the families of those who died in Tuesday's tragic air crash in Bombay, and I wish to convey to you, on behalf of the Netherlands Government and myself, feelings of deepest regret and sorrow on the death of your valued associate.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- An eleventh-hour agreement between officials of the Inland Steel Company and United Steelworkers of America on continuing negotiations for sixty days averted tonight a threatened shutdown of Inland's great producing facilities.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The United States accused Russia today of using recent labor disorders in Japan for propaganda purposes, and denied United States Occupation authorities were trying to "repress" labor and "democratic elements.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities, at two public sessions today, provided witnesses for minority groups with a forum on which to defend their patriotism and declare that Communist drives to dominate them had failed.

THE Book-of-the-Month Club, still hospitably and hopefully choosing new books by celebrities who have written better ones (recent examples: Pearl Buck's "Kinfolk," John Gunther's "Behind the Curtain"), has now taken for its parishioner Vincent Sheean's "Lead, Kindly Light: Gandhi and the Way to Peace."*

The richness of the Italian Renaissance was recalled yesterday at 6 East Fifty-third Street when Mme. Pauline showed her fall millinery, a restrained and carefully designed collection. Transmitting the period's elegance by sculpture-like folds and manipulation, the presentation's marked simplicity proved vastly pleasing.

ROME, July 13 -- In a sweeping decree marking the latest Vatican step in the world-wide struggle between the Roman Catholic Church and communism, the Congregation of the Holy Office today warned Catholics throughout the world that all those who "defend and spread the materialistic and anti-Christian doctrine of the Communists" would incur major excommunication.

Ground has been broken for a two-story garden type apartment house on a plot of two and one-half acres at the northwest corner of South Ocean Avenue and Front Street in Freeport, L. I. The building will contain fifty-six apartments in two to four and one-half suites.

Four out of the five New York State counties with the largest number of manufacturing establishments in 1947 were located in the greater New York City area, it was revealed yesterday by the Department of Commerce in a preliminary report of the 1947 Census of Manufactures covering a summary of statistics for selected local areas.

Sale of 1,000,000 shares of common stock, par value $100,000,000, by the New York Telephone Company to its parent, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was authorized yesterday by the Public Service Commission. Proceeds from the issue will be used to retire an equal amount of short-term loans made to finance the subsidiary's expansion.

MOSCOW, July 13 -- Soviet astronomers have pledged themselves to fight relentlessly against "cosmopolitan formalism" and particularly against the Western theory "of so-called relativistic cosmology" and "reactionary-idealistic 'theory' of a finite widening of the universe."
MELBOURNE, Australia, July 13 -- Two developments today strengthened the Commonwealth and New South Wales Governments in their fight against the striking coal miners.

Reflecting cutbacks by the various State regulatory bodies in an effort to keep production and demand in balance, output of petroleum last week declined to a daily average of 4,667,750 barrels, a drop of 152,200 from the 4,819,950 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. For the week ended on July 10, 1948, output had averaged 5,480,400 barrels daily.

ATHENS, July 13 -- Clashes in the Kaimakchalan and Paikon Mountain ranges of Central Macedonia between National forces and "rebels who had returned from Yugoslavia," as the General Staff described them, were reported in today's Army communique.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- An effort to have the Senate disavow any obligation of the United States to help rearm the North Atlantic Treaty nations was begun today by Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, the Republican floor leader.

Declaring that New York "seems to be becoming an arsenal," Presiding Justice Matthew J. Troy of Special Sessions Court yesterday sentenced Emilio Giosa of 221 East 113th Street to six months in the Workhouse for illegal possession of firearms.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 13 -- Two wills left by Msgr. Felix Di Persia, former pastor of Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church here, have caused an unusual legal action highlighted today by the ruling of Hudson County Judge John Drewen that American beneficiaries under the first will must show cause Nov. 4 why a will made in Italy a year later should not take precedence.

OMAHA, Neb., July 13 -- Of the seventy experts representing twenty states, Canada and Puerto Rico, who started Monday night in the annual tournament for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation, only three have survived with clean scores of 3 -- 0 after three rounds.

The Benjamin Hawkins, first of twelve vessels from the Hudson River reserve fleet designated for grain-storage use here, was being loaded yesterday at the Claremont Terminal in Jersey City, according to the Maritime Commission's regional headquarters at 45 Broadway.

Reflecting cutbacks by the various State regulatory bodies in an effort to keep production and demand in balance, output of petroleum last week declined to a daily average of 4,667,750 barrels, a drop of 152,200 from the 4,819,950 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. For the week ended on July 10, 1948, output had averaged 5,480,400 barrels daily.

ATHENS, July 13 -- Clashes in the Kaimakchalan and Paikon Mountain ranges of Central Macedonia between National forces and "rebels who had returned from Yugoslavia," as the General Staff described them, were reported in today's Army communique.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- An effort to have the Senate disavow any obligation of the United States to help rearm the North Atlantic Treaty nations was begun today by Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, the Republican floor leader.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -- Del Ennis' home run in the last half of the ninth inning broke up a pitching duel between Kenny Heintzelman and Max Lanier and gave the Phillies a 1-0 victory over the Cardinals tonight.
Created and sponsored by three outstanding showmen, the musical comedy, "Miss Liberty," will open here tonight at the Imperial Theatre.

The bilateral trade agreement negotiated between Argentina and Western Germany was strongly attacked yesterday by the Tanners Council of America in an "open letter" addressed to Senators and Representatives of tannery and shoe-manufacturing states.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Eighty-five research grants, for a total of more than $1,200,000, were awarded today by the National Heart Institute to medical schools and hospitals in twenty-one states.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- President Truman today referred to Henry Wallace and other sponsors of a civil rights conference in New York as that gang.

Total loans made by banks in this area dropped $248,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, but earning assets rose $47,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. According to its weekly data covering the reporting New York City member banks, business loans accounted for $23,000,000 of the decline in borrowings

Cottonseed oil futures moved irregularly higher on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. The bulk of the trading was in the July delivery. Prices advanced 10 to 18 points early on firmer crude and lard markets and reacted 14 to 28 points on profit-taking.

Hosiery shipments in May totaled 10,898,219 dozen pairs, compared with 10,875,236 during the same month of 1948, the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reported yesterday. Delivery of women's full - fashioned increased to 2,474,044 dozen pairs, compared with 3,341,442 in the previous May.

Leaders of the Republican and Liberal parties agreed last night on Newbold Morris, former Republican President of the City Council and No Deal party candidate for Mayor in 1945, as the Fusion party candidate for Mayor.

A recently completed, specially designed Wine tanker, the 5,700-ton deadweight, French-flag vessel Canteleu, is loading cargo in New York for her maiden voyage which will take her to Israel under a one-trip charter to the American-Israeli Steamship Company.

THE intermission for the All-Star game is over and the curtain arose yesterday for the second act of the tense baseball mystery melodrama, a veritable Whodunit. The first act set it up beautifully and prolonged the suspense. The second act will be forced to provide the denouement. As the final half of the show begins there is no way of guessing how the plot will unravel.
BOSTON, July 14 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard, the Chicago Cubs' hard-luck right-hander, turned in a four-hitter against the Braves tonight to gain his third victory of the season, 3 -- 2.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat, of Louisiana, said today that Federal enforcement of civil rights could provoke violence and "calambitous consequences."
INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa., July 14 (AP) -- Twenty-five hundred underprivileged boys started a happy-go-lucky vacation at this military reservation today as guests of the commonwealth.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 14 -- Preliminary estimates indicate that 250,000 units will be sold by electric washer industry factories in June, H. P. Nelligan, president of the American Washer and Ironer Manufacturers Association revealed here today at the annual meeting.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Castel Beau, 6-year-old gelding owned by Sydney I. Crew of Cincinnati, scored an upset victory in the $22,750 Grassland Handicap over the turf course at Arlington Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Unless the warring groups within the Republican party can find and agree upon the national chairman who can bring harmony to the party, Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania will not resign from the chairmanship, he said in a statement issued today.

CALCUTTA, India, July 14 -- A bomb exploded at a corner of the huge parade ground here today while Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was calling on a mammoth meeting to "face the Communist trouble squarely."
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP) -- Tokyo Rose had no particular fooling of right or wrong about her wartime propaganda broadcasts for Japan, Clark Lee, former war correspondent, testified today.

LONDON, July 14 -- As 14,000 striking dock workers here showed no signs today of heeding Prime Minister Attlee's personal appeal to return to work the Government, through its newly created five-man Emergency Docks Commiteee, ordered 2,000 more troops into the docks to insure an uninterrupted flow of food and other vital commodities.

Coleman Roger Rafferty from County Sligo, Ireland, a fireman employed on the Boston City, a ship of the Bristol Lines of London, found the heat of Hoboken intolerable yesterday morning. At 3:30 A. M., after tossing restlessly in his bunk for several hours, he came up on deck to whistle up a breeze.
OMAHA, Neb., July 14 -- Chicago today wrested from New York the lead in the United States Chess Federation's annual open championship at the Hotel Fontenelle. Seventy players are competing.
The United States Court of Appeals upheld Federal Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday in jailing three defendants for the rest of the Communist trial.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 14 -- Together with almost every European nation benefiting from the Marshall Plan, Western Germany shares one major problem. How can it export its manufactured goods to the United States until the existing high tariff barriers are lowered?

WAYNE, N. J., July 14 -- Andy Lapola, Preakness Hills professional, scorched the North Jersey Country Club layout with a six-under-par 65 today to take a four-stroke lead in the New Jersey State Golf Association open championship.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The first definite indication that the reorganization plans President Truman sent to Congress June 20 were being received favorably came today when the Senate Expenditures Committee approved four of them and scheduled hearings for next week on two others. Action on the seventh plan was deferred.

Buying at the first National China, Glass and Pottery Show, which entered closing stages yesterday in the New Yorker Hotel, has been spotty, exhibiting manufacturers and buyers agreed. Substantial orders were placed by small china and glass stores but department stores and buying offices limited purchases to fill-ins, they said.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 14 -- The Building Industry Worker's Union decided today that its bricklayer members would not maintain or repair furnaces using coal that the Government plans to transport from the northern coal fields to Sydney at the weekend.

The orange-crate grandstands rocked with cheers yesterday as the Quinn sisters won their events in the West Ninety-eighth Street meet sponsored by the Police Athletic League. Youngsters from 2 to 13 years old yelled and kicked their heels, while their parents leaned perilously from tenement windows to lend encouragement.

The Senate debate on the North Atlantic Treaty is being prolonged beyond original expectations and is taking a turn which is beginning to cause misgivings among other signatories. Some of them question our determination to live up to the treaty's obligations and our willingness to unite our efforts with theirs for the collective defense of the North Atlantic area and the preservation of peace and security.

Publication of an advertising reference and source book, "One Hundred Best Retail Advertisements," was announced yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The 124-page volume, compiled by Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the association's sales promotion division, carries editorial comment on the winning ads.

ROME, July 14 -- Two attempts to postpone Parliamentary debate on Italy's ratification of the North Atlantic pact were defeated today. The Chamber of Deputies immediately proceeded to listen to speakers for various political parties.

LONDON, July 14 -- A new austerity program was laid before the British people today by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, who announced that Britain would reduce her spending in the United States and Canada by $400,000,000 in the current fiscal year.

The $358,355 trolley track removal-widening-repaving project in Forty-second Street from Second Avenue to Twelfth Avenue will be formally started at 10 A. M., Monday, by Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan, with a brief ceremony at Second Avenue and Forty-second Street, it was announced yesterday.

BERLIN, July 14 -- Dr. Andreas Hermes, the Soviet Union's non-Communist missionary to Western Germany, has returned to the Russian zone after what he considered a highly successful attempt to sell a "national front" to politicians of the three Western zones as a substitute for a partitioned Germany.

In the first intensive study of its kind ever conducted by the city, the Department of Health has drawn preliminary conclusions on the summer weather conditions that make New York's death rate climb sharply.
CANTON, China, July 14 (UP) -- Retired President Chiang Kai-shek, arriving here to rally the anti-Communist forces, today appealed for "national unity" to save China from the Communists.
The economic crisis in Europe can be alleviated only by large-scale global cooperation, in the opinion of Ernest L. Schimmel, vice president of Bell Howell International Division.

A quaint custom of the times dictates that a man while on his annual vacation must acquire a deep tan. It is no longer clear precisely when and how the cult of the sunburn originated. It seems to have had its beginnings in the Twenties, with a number of other odd practices having their roots in men's search for new experiences and freedoms, and it soon attracted hordes of followers.

Inspired by the delicacy and charm, as well as the colors, of a potpourri of roses. Erik Braagaard turned his attention in his collection yesterday at 10 West Fifty-sixth Street almost entirely to the youthful small hat tipped to lay against one cheek.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, July 14 -- Benjamin Britten's "Spring Symphony" received a ringing ovation tonight in its world premiere at the Holland Music Festival. The cheers of 3,000 persons who jammed Amsterdam's Concert Hall, including such celebrities as Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Britain, showed that this was the great event of the festival.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Sir Adrian Boult, presented an all-Beethoven concert with Claudio Arrau, pianist, as soloist, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. The program, which consisted of the Overture to "Egmont," the Sixth Symphony and the "Emperor" Concerto, attracted an audience of more than 13,000.
TOKYO, July 14 -- The women of Japan's upper middle class have found a diversion that promises to do for them what bingo does for their American sisters. It is the stock market.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Russia withheld manganese and chrome shipments to the United States in May for the second consecutive month, the Census Bureau reported today.

Investigation Commissioner John W. Murtagh announced yesterday that Robert E. Sherwood and Irving Berlin, authors of "Miss Liberty" opening tonight at the Imperial Theatre, and Moss Hart, co-producer of the musical, would go to his office today at their own request to discuss ticket sales for the show.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were 3 points lower to 28 points higher at the close than on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman made it clear today that he was opposed to lending $50,000,000 to the Franco regime in Spain because the United States does not have friendly relations with that Government.

Gen. A. W. Greeley said in his classic book on "American Weather," published in 1888, that "it is difficult to define what is a drought, as meteorologists have not agreed upon this point." James W. Osmun, assistant chief meteorologist for the New York City Weather Bureau station, made substantially the same remark to this newspaper's reporter on Wednesday.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation approved yesterday a loan of $34,000,000 to the Lone Star Steel Company of Dallas, Tex., to assist it in an expansion program, Harley Hise, chairman of the government agency, announced yesterday.
GENEVA, July 14 -- A new approach to the problem of mobilizing private capital to aid the United Nations in promoting economic development has been made recently in Switzerland.

The Department of Commerce will present five radio programs on the business situation over most of the NBC network on Sunday afternoons, effective July 24. They will be heard in the New York area by transcription over WNBC on Saturdays at 4:30 P. M., starting July 30.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- The House today sent to the President for signature a bill to outlaw back-pay suits for so-called overtime on overtime.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Brannan wants to broaden the law permitting limitations on interstate shipments of fresh and dried fruits and vegetables, tobacco, nuts and a few minor products. He said the law should include all field crops, such as grains, cotton and soybeans; livestock, poultry, eggs, honey, honey-bees and fruits and vegetables for canning.

I am interested in the letter published on July 10 under the caption Academic Freedom, and bearing the signature of my old friend Philip Marshall Brown. I believe I am in emphatic agreement with Professor Brown about the ends to be sought; but I would like to cross swords with him on the matter of method.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The leadership of the Republican minority in the Senate ruefully admitted today that it could find no committee posts for John Foster Dulles, the new Senator from New York, that suit his talents but do not invade seniority rights of other party members.

The Civil Aeronautics Board began yesterday to look into the business practices of travel agencies and travel clubs booking passengers for non-scheduled or irregular airlines. Should it find any violations of the Civil Aeronautics Act of 1938, criminal proceedings against the violators would be possible.

Two letters bearing the signature of Mrs. Janet J. Fay, who was bludgeoned to death in Valley Stream, L. I., a few days before the notes themselves were written, were admitted as evidence yesterday in the trial of Mrs. Martha J. Beck and Raymond M. Fernandez, the "lonely hearts" pair accused of her murder.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates this afternoon won the award of the first $30,000,000 of bonds offered by the Pennsylvania General State Authority. The group's bid will produce, for a combination of coupons, a net interest cost of 1.74131 per cent.
There's plenty of news for weekend shoppers. But most of it is damaging to budgets, the weekly survey of the City Department of Markets shows.

Now that the House Rules Committee has decided to permit debate on farm legislation at this session of the Congress, the belief in the cotton and grain trades is that the final outcome will be an extension for another year of the present program which provides for supporting prices of the principal crops at 90 per cent of parity.
CLEVELAND, July 14 (AP) -- Bob Lemon hurled his tenth victory of the season for the Indians tonight, defeating the Athletics and Alex Kellner, 7 to 1.

Nineteen Boy Scouts from Troop 11 in San Leandro, Calif., did their good deed for France's Bastille Day yesterday by visiting the Statue of Liberty with their hosts from the Young Men's Board of Trade.

EL VERANO, Calif., July 14 -- Mrs. Ruth Denny, 63 years old and a granddaughter of a "forty-niner," defended her 100-acre farm today against a crew that appeared this week to build a bridge across Sonoma Creek.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -- Paramount today confirmed reports that a deal for the purchase of screen rights to Sidney Kingsley's Broadway play, "Detective Story," is in progress in New York. The studio, however, describes as premature a further report that a deal had been closed.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate is now completely entangled in the dispute over the methods, means and timing of military assistance to Western Europe to which ratification of the North Atlantic Treaty would commit this nation in the event of armed aggression against that area.

ALBANY, July 14 -- In an impassioned speech before a special committee of the State Board of Regents today, Mrs. Lillian Gates, legislative representative of the New York State Communist party, charged that the Feinberg Act barring Communists from public school jobs was unconstitutional and that the party would never accept a ruling based on an "illegal precedent."

Increased standardization of industrial products and techniques will help step up output in Great Britain and create more dollars for world trade, a group of English industrialists agreed yesterday. The men, members of a team surveying simplified American manufacturing practice, attended a reception in their honor at the English-Speaking Union, 19 East Fifty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Paul Robeson, Negro singer and actor, was identified as a member of the Communist party "for many years" today by a former member of the national committee of that party.

Largely as a result of the extravaganzas characteristic of the House Committee on Un-American Activities under the former chairmanship of Representatives Dies and Thomas, the procedure guiding Congressional investigations -- or lack of it -- has long been a cause of some concern.

Indications appeared yesterday that convinced some industrialists here that the bottom of the downward trend in some durable goods lines had been reached, and that an upward movement has begun. In metal products lines, price reductions have dried up, and the "buying strike" which existed generally throughout June has definitely ended, they said.

PARIS, July 14-- Roman Catholic leaders here said today that they expected the Vatican's statement that Catholics adopting Communist doctrines thereby excommunicated themselves from the church would serve to enlighten and warn those in France who had followed the Communists without fully understanding that party's creed and aims.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that the city planned 60,000 low-rent slum clearance apartments to be constructed in the next six years under the public housing section of the Federal Housing Act of 1949, which President Truman signed Tuesday.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- The governing committee of the St. Louis Stock Exchange today signed a contract to participate in a new Midwest stock exchange here. The action amounted to a formal overruling of four member firms which recently have voiced opposition to the merger with the Chicago Stock Exchange and others. Earlier, the St. Louis exchange membership had voted 82 per cent in favor of the plan.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox scored four runs on one hit in the third inning and went on to trim Washington, 6 -- 2, before 8,004 tonight. Sam Mele batted in both Senator runs as Billy Pierce scored his second straight victory and fourth, of the season for the White Sox.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 14 (AP) -- The Czech Government took a hand in the Swiss international tennis tournament today by ordering two Czech stars off the courts. The action left an American, a Spaniard and a Yugoslav exile to fight it out for the men's singles title.

Basic decorating principles used by the Sachs Quality Stores recently in furnishing the New York City Housing Authority's Woodside Homes model apartment may be studied in a "Decorator's Digest" just printed by that store.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Department store sales for the week ended July 9, were 7 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Percentage changes from like periods of 1948 were listed as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UP) -- Scott W. Lucas, Senate Democratic leader, today rebuked members of the House for demanding an investigation of Federal Judge Samuel Kaufman's conduct of the Alger Hiss perjury trial in New York.

HONOLULU, July 14 -- A suit for $1,500,000 in damages, plus $20,000 a day for every day that "illegal acts" by the unions continued, was filed in Federal Court here today by the Matson Navigation Company against Harry Bridges' International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, its striking longshore locals in Hawaii, and two maritime unions.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 -- Leaders of branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in session here, made known today a series of legal actions to end discrimination and segregation in southern states. Cases filed were described as steps to correct abuses against Negroes in schools, transportation and in public services.

PITTSBURGH, July 14 -- The United States Steel Corporation's counter-proposal to President Truman was believed here tonight to be unacceptable to the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, inasmuch as six other producers already have agreed to the President's sixty-day truce formula without reservations.
The Board of Higher Education rejected last night appeals of Dr. Lee Lorch and Prof. Morris Swadesh for reinstatement as teachers at City College.

BERLIN, July 14 -- Having relaxed, temporarily at least, some of their restrictions on truck traffic to Western Berlin, the Russians opened a propaganda campaign today against continuation of the Anglo-American airlift.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 14 -- The executive committee of Israel's General Labor Federation (Histadrut) instructed its trade union department to accept pay cuts of $6.78 a week when it negotiates a quarterly cost-of-living agreement with a manufacturers' association tomorrow.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 14 -- Bob Sweeny, 1937 British amateur titleholder, set a new qualifying round record in the Long Island Golf Association's amateur championship today by carding a 67 over the Meadow Brook Club course. He accounted for the medal by a two-stroke margin.
DETROIT, July 14 (AP) -- The Red Sox, propelled by Al Zarilla's home run with Bobby Doerr aboard in the eighth, turned back the Tigers, 5 to 2, tonight in the opener of a three-game series.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A World Congress of Religious Instruction, to be held in Rome as a special feature of the 1950 Holy Year, was announced here today by the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine.

Coincident with the announcement by the Southern Company yesterday of a net income of $13,573,627, or $1.13 a share, in the twelve months to June 30, directors of this successor holding company for certain properties of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation said they would give consideration to increasing the annual dividend rate of 60 cents a share at their meeting in September.

Graceful rectangular cigarette boxes trimmed with embossed designs which repeat the motifs on silver-plated cigarette lighters may now be had to use as companion pieces with four of the Ronson Company's table-lighter design. Another new note is the introduction of colored enamel on a small lighter designed for bedroom use.

ROME, July 14 (Reuters) -- Pope Pius may make an important pronouncement when he broadcasts Sunday to the people of Berlin. It is regarded as likely that the speech will provide a further indication of the tactics of Roman Catholicism in its drive against communism.
A letter from a contributor in your paper of July 11 prompts me to offer my long-felt opinion on the causes and possible cure for the dirty streets of New York.

In the argot of the boxing racket the term splash is used to describe a fight in which the foreordained loser takes a dive. And you don't have to be conversant with H. L. Mencken to understand what the latter term implies.

DETROIT, July 14 (UP) -- The nation's auto makers, with an all-time record production week in prospect, agreed today that they probably would not feel the full impact of a steel strike until September.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 14 (UP) -- British officials charged today that displaced persons were supplying narcotics to a German ring that smuggled at least $1,000,000 worth of material into the United States each year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 14 -- Iraq is undertaking to form a military bloc of Eastern states from Egypt to India as a barrier to the spread of communism, according to a report appearing today in the Cairo newspaper Al Ahram, under banner headlines.
A total of $51,986 was paid for seized, abandoned and unclaimed merchandise at an auction sale held yesterday afternoon by the United States Customs Service at 201 Varick Street.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Wheat marketing quotas for the 1950-51 crop year were officially abandoned by Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today.

TOKYO, July 14 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today asserted that the Soviet Union had been frustrated "in a nefarious plot to absorb Japan into the Soviet orbit of influence," and that its disappointment was the explanation of such charges as that of Alexander S. Panyushkin, Soviet envoy to the United States, that the United States policy was brutally unfair to labor.

The Police Department and the Department of Hospitals began independent investigations yesterday to determine why an ambulance took thirty-five minutes to reach the scene of a Brooklyn traffic accident Wednesday afternoon. One victim died later in Kings County Hospital.

MR. CARRUTHERS signed the slip for two frosted glasses of Mariners' Comfort on the club veranda overlooking Debenture Bay. He carefully removed the straw, wished he could remove the nautical design that relentlessly wreathed everything on the premises, and raised his glass to his friend Walgrove Snood, the literary banker.

Lothar Wolff, vice president and associate producer of Louis de Rochemont -ssociates since 1947, has been named to plan and direct motion-picture activities for the Economic Cooperation Administration. He is on the way to Paris where he will be attached to the Office of the Special Representative.

With one-thirtieth of the population of the world, the United States holds rather more than seven-eighths of the world's gold monetary stocks. We hold it, we keep it, we bury it. We have forgotten the common-sense observation of Horace, "There is no luster in gold underground."

Preliminary discussions concerning flotation of $233,000,000 of bonds with which to finance North Carolina's "atomic age development plan" were held yesterday by Brandon P. Hodges, the state's Treasurer, and local bankers.

The stock market continued yesterday to advance despite the threat of a strike against some of the important steel producers. Prices were sustained by a return of public participation and the composite rate showed a gain of 0.44 point. Although the advance was a bit more labored than in earlier sessions this week, the morning provided the only hesitant period of the day.

FRANKFORT Germany, July 14 -- Allied economic experts here believe that the United States will be the only one of the three Western powers to make a direct contribution to German economy when the trizonal fusion agreement is worked out in about three ninths.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman and the country's steel producers were still deadlocked tonight on the Chief Executive's proposal to avert a steel strike scheduled for midnight tomorrow.

Karen Goodman, the 11-year-old girl whose legs have been crippled by cerebral palsy since birth, said good-by to her friends at La Guardia Airport and walked up the ramp into a Pan American Airways plane that started her at 8 o'clock last night on a 9,000-mile flight to her home in South Africa.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 14 -- The news of the Vatican's excommunication of active Communists was neither published nor broadcast in Czechoslovakia today, and the editor of Rude Pravo, organ of the Czech Communist party, said that it would not be mentioned in tomorrow's paper.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman did not persuade Mayor O'Dwyer to change his mind and agree to run again, he said at his news conference today. Mayor O'Dwyer called briefly at the White House last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- A 43 per cent increase in infantile paralysis cases in the last week was reported today by the United States Public Health Service.

Salmon fishing reports from New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Quebec and Newfoundland are improving, and those who have been waiting for conditions to get right might move quickly before another change sets in.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 14 (AP) -- Ray Billows turned back two contenders today in a bid for his sixth state amateur golf crown.

DARIEN, Conn., July 14 -- Miss Barbara Bruning of Whippoorwill captured her second women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association low gross prize in three weeks with a round of 38, 42 -- 80 at the Wee Burn Country Club today. The triumph was by five strokes in a field of eighty, thirty-five of whom had scores which soared with the thermometer and as a result didn't post. Ladies' par for the course is 38, 39 -- 77.

ROME, July 14 -- Italy's Roman Catholic clergy and members of religious orders, about 80,000 strong, were mobilized today for the new anti-Communist campaign waged by the Vatican. Its immediate effort is to break or at least to weaken the Italian Communist party, which claims to have 2,000,000 members.
Staging one of their rare ninth-inning rallies, the Dodgers last night scored twice to tie the Cincinnati Reds in the last ditch frame, then pushed over the winning run in the tenth to win, 6 -- 5.

Mayor O'Dwyer left La Guardia Airport at 11:16 o'clock last night on an American Airlines plane bound for a vacation in Mexico City, where he will be a guest of President Miguel Aleman. He is expected to arrive there at 8 A. M. today.

BOMBAY, India, July 14 -- Indian officials, representatives of five governments and about 300 others representing business and civic organizations and the journalistic fraternity of Bombay gathered in the town hall at noon today for a public tribute to the forty-five persons, including thirteen United States correspondents, who lost their lives in the crash of a Dutch KLM Constellation near here on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today denied motions by nine corn products manufacturers to dismiss a complaint which charges them with conspiracy to fix prices and with price discrimination. Eight manufacturers joined in asking for dismissal of the entire complaint.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- A higher glutamic acid content may be responsible for the superior flavor of young and of freshly harvested vegetables, according to a report to the Institute of Food Technologists here today.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, defending champion, and Frank Parker, seeded Nos. 1 and 2 respectively, today advanced to the semi-finals of the national clay courts tennis tourney.

SAG HARBOR, L. I., July 14 -- It is seventy-eight years this month since the bravely canvased Myra, last of the Sag Harbor whalers, stood out into Shelter Island Sound with summer breeze swelling her sails, yet there are some among the village folk who remember her.
Complaints of monopoly practices and racketeering in the metropolitan area's $35,000,000-a-year linen supply industry have been made to the Department of Justice, it was learned yesterday.

SILVER BAY, N. Y., July 14 -- "The three great perils" facing modern civilization were defined today by the Rev. Dr. Charles T. Leber of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. as "the unexpected acceleration of world revolution," "a universal psychosis of suspicion" and "substitution of atomic might for Almighty God."

LONDON, July 14 -- The stock market today followed closely the pattern of the last few days, with narrow and indeterminate movements in most sections during the morning, while the afternoon saw a firmer trend in gilt-edge securities, industrials and dollar stocks.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman set into motion today his new program for moderate pump-priming spending in areas of the country affected most by economic declines and unemployment. He took this action as Congress erupted into lively debate and off-stage controversy over his proposed fighting off of a depression with deficit spending.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Drought-stricken New Jersey was declared a disaster area today by the United States Department of Agriculture.
PITTSBURGH, July 14 (AP) -- Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans hit a hot streak of golf on a hot day to lead the field in the first round of the $16,500 Dapper Dan Open on the Alcoma links today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- In the week ended on July 13, member-bank reserve balances decreased $474,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 -- Casey Stengel and his Yankees, who had been warned that the turn in the 1949 pennant campaign might bring rougher sailing, embarked on the second half of their pennant quest tonight feeling perhaps just a trifle apprehensive.

Ogden Mills Reid, former editor of The New York Herald Tribune, left a gross estate of $9,478,112, of which $5,780,702 was bequeathed to the Reid Foundation, a non-taxable, charitable corporation, according to an estate tax appraisal filed yesterday at the offices of the State Tax Commission, 80 Centre Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 14 -- In the blackest of several recent economic surveys put out by the United Nations, the vast area of Asia and the Far East was described today as so riddled by malignant, utter poverty as to undermine any idea of enduring peace.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A world economic program to take up the slack left with the scheduled ending of the European Recovery Program in 1952, based on broad cooperative planning, was urged today by Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, of New York, in a House speech.
Statistically the City Department of Welfare's task is tremendous. Its 7,000 employes care for 334,000 persons, including the sick, the aged, the blind, widows and children and the needy unemployed.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 14 -- Sale of The New Orleans Item to David Stern and associates was announced today by Ralph Nicholson, publisher. Mr. Stern is a former Philadelphia and Camden, N. J., newspaper executive. The sale price was reported to be approximately $1,700,000.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Truman held a two-and-one-half-hour conference tonight with key policy men from Congress and the Administration on the question of giving to Great Britain technical information on the production of atomic bombs.

The number of cases of infantile paralysis reported to the City Health Department since the beginning of 1949 is "well above" the average for the last twenty years, but it is still too early to determine if this will be "a bad polio year" here, Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, declared yesterday.
LONDON, July 14 -- The United States, British and French diplomats who are engaged here in four-power discussions of an Austrian peace treaty ran into a deadlock today.

ORADELL, N. J., July 14 -- Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook, the defending champion, and Mrs. R. M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, who met in the final of the 1948 Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship at Nassau, will meet again tomorrow in a thirty-six-hole battle for the title over the Hackensack golf course.

NORTHAMPTON, England, July 14 (Reuters) -- A sound innings of 147 not out by D. Barrick enabled Northamptonshire to avoid the follow-on today when they resumed their match against the New Zealand cricketers here.

Yesterday Mr. Fred of John-Frederics showed his determination to hat, and in some cases "high-hat," the American woman this fall and winter. The collection that he presented in his showroom at 29 East Forty-eighth Street, was full of sound millinery wisdom.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Department of the Interior reported today that a civilian Governor probably would go to Guam next month. Guam's present Governor and military commander of the Marianas, Rear Admiral Charles A. Pownall, is to retire Sept. 1.

LONDON, July 14 -- The World Council of Churches tonight called upon all churches and Christians in totalitarian lands to resist all attempts to make them waver in their faith. In a militant declaration, issued at the close of its conference in Chichester, the Council's Central Committee told Christians that the "liberty which they receive from their Lord cannot be taken away by the violence or threat of any world power or destroyed by suffering."

In December, 1938, the astronomical section of the Soviet Academy of Sciences passed some vituperative resolutions in which "modern bourgeois cosmogony" was said to be in "a state of deep ideological confusion" because it had abandoned the universe of Newton and Laplace for the closed universe of Einstein and his followers.

MILWAUKEE, July 14 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. assailed Benjamin Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, today for what the young member of Congress from New York called "an abject abdication of responsibility" in refusing yesterday to accept President Truman's plan for mediation of the threatened national steel strike.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The amount of the British dollar deficit was estimated officially here today at about $397,000,000 and the only "short run" solution for it was held to be a cut of $33,000,000 a month in purchases in the United States beginning around next September.

ATHENS, July 14 -- United States Ambassador Henry F. Grady presented awards of the Legion of Merit, in three degrees, to twelve high ranking officers of the Greek Army, Navy and Air Force at ceremonies tonight at the embassy residence. Lieut. Gen. James A. Van Fleet and other officers of the United States mission here, British officers, Greek Cabinet Ministers and members of diplomatic corps were present.

PARIS, July 14 -- Bastille Day was commemorated here today under a torrid sun with the traditional military parade in the morning and with a giant Communist counter-parade in the afternoon dedicated to "peace" and to the defeat of the North Atlantic pact.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration today invoked its most drastic authority to ground the airplanes of Strato Freight, Inc., a non-scheduled company that operated a passenger airplane in which fifty-three persons died off Puerto Rico last month.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 14 (UP) -- A United States proposal that the Inter-American Press Association be reorganized to free it from government ties, sanction or support was adopted today by the bylaws committee of the Fifth Inter-American Press Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- A strike called to change an unexpired contract is illegal, an examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today. The examiner, John Lewis, said such a strike was outlawed by the Taft-Hartley Act, whether or not the contract contained a no-strike clause.
ALBANY, July 14 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of Robert H. Thayer of Glen Cove, L. I., to a five-year term as a member of the New York State Commission Against Discrimination.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 14 -- Irvin Dorfman, former Eastern intercollegiate tennis champion from Yale came perilously close to disaster today before gaining his quarter-final bracket in the Eastern clay court title tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today decided to have a public hearing on the plan of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., to buy three major West Coast broadcasting outlets. The case may provide an opportunity for the commission to state formally its future policy on granting radio permits to persons or corporations which have had anti-trust judgments entered against them.

Net profit of the International Shoe Company for the six months ended with last May amounted to $4,476,525, compared with $6,949,461 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the mid-year report mailed yesterday to 11,000 stockholders.
New Yorkers appeared yesterday to be taking the bus strike in stride, both literally and figuratively.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 9 were 595,321 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 48,861 cars, or 7.6 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 159,779 cars, or 21.2 per cent, less than for the corresponding week last year, and 211,796 cars, or 26.2 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 14 -- Richard F. Crandell, picture editor of The New York Herald Tribune and journalism lecturer at Columbia University, accepted the Democratic designation today to run for Mayor of White Plains in the autumn election.

Down payments on installment purchases made in retail credit jewelry stores throughout the country reached an all-time low in May, according to a survey completed yesterday by the National Association of Credit Jewelers. Statistics compiled in the survey disclose that the average down payment was 13.62 per cent of the retail price of the merchandise.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 14 (UP) -- Edward F. Prichard Jr., former general counsel for the Democratic National Committee, was found guilty today of stuffing ballot boxes in last November's Presidential election and sentenced to two years in the Federal penitentiary.

With Larry Jansen twirling one of his better games, the Giants launched the second-half drive for a first-division berth with a fanciful 4-3 victory over the Pirates last night at the Polo Grounds. Yielding only four hits and fanning seven, including three in the ninth, Jansen outpitched Southpaw Bill Werle in an errorless contest before 22,677 fans.

TOKYO, July 14 -- Joint exercises looking to the defense of Japan are now being carried on by units of the British Pacific Fleet with the United States Fifth Air Force stationed here, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today. Wheat showed relative strength early but dipped sharply in the late trading, partly in sympathy with soybeans and closing trades were 5/8 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel lower than yesterday, July leading.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Final attendance figures at the mid-year home furnishings show are expected to be of near-record proportions, a spokesman for the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart said today. Registrations during the second week have been heavier than usual, it was said, indicating that last year's summer market total might be exceeded.

Seven more persons, including three former War Assets Administration officials, were indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding the Government in disposal of scarce surplus materials.
Orders for zinc continued active yesterday, producers reported. Demand was sufficient to indicate that buyers have now returned to the market in sizable numbers, industry spokesmen said.
A 31-year-old war veteran was shot and killed last night as he attempted to capture two men who were fleeing after robbing a liquor store in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A new tactical thrust against the North Atlantic Treaty was put in today while President Truman was confidently calling for its ratification by the Senate without reservations.

Police science and a woman's wakefulness both played a part yesterday in trapping a "cat burglar" who admitted, the police said, that he had committed at least sixty midtown hotel burglaries in the last eighteen months.

The notorious "lady in mink" was used to prove quite a different point than the original one in a survey on public welfare published yesterday in our news columns. Originally she was cited as a glaring example of the misappropriation of funds for public assistance.

BUENOS AIRES, July 14 -- Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, former United States representative on the Inter-American Military Board, and members of his party received Argentine decorations today in a ceremony at the Casa Rosada. The decorations may bring on questioning in Washington.
A "quickie" strike over the disciplining of four mechanics cut off bus service yesterday for 925,000 riders in Manhattan and Queens and spread at midnight to lines that normally carry 200,000 more.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- The City Products Corporation, formerly the City Ice and Fuel Company, announced today the purchase of all the capital stock of Frank Pilley Sons, Inc., dairy and poultry products processor, of Sioux City, Iowa.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Under the threat of an impending Presidential executive order, the House Armed Services Committee made an adroit about-face today and unanimously approved a part of the Unification Bill that it had rejected in full two days ago.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The State Department charged the Yugoslav Government today with making more difficult a settlement of the status of Trieste by introducing dinars as legal currency in the part the Yugoslavs occupy. The Italian lira circulates in the zones occupied by the United States and Great Britain.

There is every reason why there should be a fundamental clash between the Soviet Union and the United States in the Far Eastern Commission over the occupation policies pursued by General MacArthur in Japan. Technically the clash is over methods of administration.

Delbert Clark, former Berlin correspondent and present Director of Educational Activities of THE NEW YORK TIMES, has signed a contract with Bobbs-Merrill for a book about Germany, "Again the Goose Step: The Lost Fruits of Victory."

Well-founded reports were current in Wall Street yesterday that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will soon make a token loan to Yugoslavia. The move, however, is not to be confused with the large-scale financing that is being sought from the bank by that country.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 (AP) -- Sammy Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., shrugged off a storm and a bad hole today to shoot his second straight 67 and take the lead in the $16,500 Dapper Dan open golf tournament.

VIENNA, July 15 -- Laszlo Rajk, former Hungarian Minister of the Interior, who fell from the graces of the Communist Information Bureau and was arrested June 18, will be brought to trial on charges that include the selling of military information to the United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia, Cavendish W. Cannon, well-qualified Hungarian refugee sources reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The National Military Establishment has formulated a new policy to increase the role of small business in its procurement, a spokesman told the House Judiciary Committee today.

WAYNE TOWNSHIP, N. J., July 15 -- Emery Thomas, Forest Hill professional, stroked out a second two under par 69 today to take a three-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the New Jersey open championship at the North Jersey Country Club.

The H. J. Heinz Company, in the fiscal year ended on April 30, had record sales of $174,877,723, a gain of 3.2 per cent over sales of $169,455,201, in the year to April 30, 1948, according to the annual report issued to stockholders and employes yesterday by H. J. Heinz 2d, president.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- Howie Pollet pitched and batted the Cardinals to a 1 -- 0 victory over the Phillies tonight. The St. Louis hurler held the Phils to six hits and drove in the only run of the game with a single in the seventh.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 15 (AP) -- Judge Paul Leahy today entered an order in United States District Court approving the dissolution plan of Commonwealth Southern Corporation. He handed down his opinion after a hearing on a motion by Alfred J. Snyder to rehear the arguments against the plan. Mr. Snyder and Elizabeth C. Lownsbury head a group of stockholders.
