Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday gave the Government until Monday to file a memorandum attesting to the legality of the arrest of Ferdinand C. Smith, 54-year-old former secretary of the National Maritime Union and an alien Communist.

The prosecution in the "lonely hearts" murder trial announced yesterday that it would rest its case on Monday. Defense testimony will start Tuesday and should be completed "within about ten days," Herbert E. Rosenberg, defense counsel said.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- One pressman suffered minor burns and twenty-three other employes of The Chicago Defender, a Negro weekly newspaper, were driven from their jobs early today when a gas bomb was hurled into the pressroom.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- The United Mine Workers Journal today defended the three-day week ordered by John L. Lewis, president of the union, and said the "coal miners are ready and willing to mine all the coal the operators can sell."

TOKYO, July 15 -- Under trade agreements between Japan and Latin American countries, now about to be signed, between 60 and 65 per cent of Japan's exports will be machinery and only 30 per cent textiles. Pre-war proportions were 7 per cent for the former and 50 per cent for the latter.

There was no suspense for the Ladies' Day crowd of 18,328 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday, as one and all, including the 8,581 cash customers, had the loveliest time imaginable watching the league-leading Dodgers shellack the seventh-place Reds, 11 -- 5. It was the Brooks' second victory in a row over the Cincinnati club.
DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- Detroit's hit-hungry Tigers burst out in a rash of seventeen safe blows today to whip Boston, 8 to 7, and snap the Red Sox' eight-game winning streak.

LONDON, July 15 (UP) -- Princess Elizabeth, heir to the throne, and her husband, Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, are settling down in their first real home, a four-story house that has every convenience that a gadget-minded housewife in the United States might dream of.

Larkspur, zinnias, asters and many a summer flower common to gardens are starting to reach the city's flower market. No matter how abundant they become in shops or in anyone's garden, they still need proper cutting to show off advantageously in flower arrangements.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade were unsettled today. Wheat had a heavy undertone from the start and failed to show rallying power, closing 3/4 to 2 cents a bushel lower than yesterday. July corn declined 2 1/8 cents but other months were unchanged to 1 1/8 cents up.
Getting the fall season off to a fine start are the unusual accessory tricks that several leading designers have worked out.

The House Armed Services Committee has moved conservatively but correctly in approving budgetary unification in the defense establishment. This is a point at which the service branches are agreed and therefore inter-service rivalry need have no bearing on the issue.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (UP) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen today called a strike for July 22 against Western lines of the Southern Pacific Company to enforce demands for larger crews. It would halt passenger and freight runs on roads operated by the system in seven states.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- More than twenty-five persons attached to the United Nations in New York City are being investigated to see if they are linked to iron-curtain spy rings, Attorney General Tom C. Clark disclosed today.

More than 600 lumber mills in the Northeast have gone out of business in the last six months because of a sharp drop in orders, R. E. Broderick, executive secretary, Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, said yesterday. He emphasized that they were all small wartime concerns not equipped financially to continue operations in anything but a peak sellers' market.
A woman for Congress was the Democratic party campaign slogan in Brooklyn yesterday, as Mrs. Edna F. Kelly was designated for the Tenth Congressional District at Kings County Democratic headquarters.

A campaign will be started this fall by Annis Furs to establish its label as a national brand name in women's fur coats, it was announced yesterday. In tying up with retail outlets, Annis has prepared newspaper mats and other material for promotion on an exclusive basis of one store in a city.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- Committee assignments for newly appointed Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican, of New York, were held up again today when Republican leaders rejected a Democratic proposal for reshuffling coveted seats.

Three men who established some sort of a record in the matter of vicious circles were ordered in Felony Court yesterday to be held for the grand jury on charges of burglary and possession of burglar tools.

ALBANY, July 15 -- The Board of Regents approved today a recommendation by the board of trustees of the State University that the university's medical centers be located in Syracuse and Brooklyn, with the Syracuse University College of Medicine and the Long Island College of Medicine becoming a part of the university.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 -- Payment of war risk bonuses to seamen on ships entering Chinese coastal waters is provided in a ninety - day agreement signed by the Pacific Maritime Association with two American Federation of Labor seagoing affiliates, the Masters, Mates and Pilots, and the Sailors Union of the Pacific.
ROME, July 15 -- Mr. Snyder praised the Italian Government today for its use of European Recovery Program funds that, he said, were "bearing fruit."

GREENWICH, Conn., July 15 -- Joseph G. Davis of the host club and his guest from Garden City, Richard Remsen, won the medal in the tenth annual Greenwich Country Club member-guest tournament as a week of qualifying-round match play was completed today.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Unopposed in the actual voting by a dissenting stockholder group, the management slate of Eversharp, Inc., was elected to fill nine board posts today at the often-adjourned annual meeting. The opposition committee, although its members took part in wrangling that extended the meeting throughout most of the day, refused to vote any of its proxies and did not even file them for the quorum count.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Sixteen swift 2-year-olds were named today to compete in the $75,000 Arlington Futurity at Arlington Park tomorrow. This is the first of the major juvenile events of the year which are run under futurity conditions.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP) -- Trustees of the San Francisco War Memorial Opera House late yesterday banned the scheduled fall appearances of Kirsten Flagstad, soprano.

Although grocery profits have dropped to about 3 per cent of gross sales compared with 4.6 per cent in 1939, members of the industry are optimistic that sales for the balance of the year will continue to be good, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., declared yesterday.
Richard Helbig has been appointed floor coverings buyer for Interstate Department Stores, Inc., 111 Eighth Avenue.

One new film will arrive on Broadway this morning. It is "Calamity Jane and Sam Bass," a Universal - International Western in Technicolor, starring Yvonne DeCarlo and Howard Duff, at the Criterion. George Sherman directed and Leonard Goldstein produced from a story by Mr. Sherman and a screen play by Maurice Geraghty and Melvin Levy.
GENEVA, July 15 -- Jaroslav Drobny and Vladimir Cernik, Czechoslovakia's top tennis stars, announced today that they had refused orders from their Government to return to Czechoslovakia.
The Lordland Realty Corporation, represented by James J. Leibman, attorney, bought for invest-I merit the apartment house at 348 East Fiftieth Street, in the vicinity Of the United Nations site.

GENEVA, July 15 -- Impressions collected by Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder on his European tour now nearing its end are likely to exert considerable influence on United States foreign economic policy, in the opinion of members of the Secretary's party.
The following books of a religious and inspirational nature have been published recently:
ATLANTIC CITY, July 15 -- The eleventh annual national housewares and home appliance exhibit closed its doors in Convention Hall late today on what could be described as an optimistic note.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, today termed "cross-education" among Army, Navy and Air Force personnel as "the long-range answer to sound defense planning."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Senate agreed today, in the ninth day of a progressively more bitter debate, to vote next Thursday on the issue of ratifying the North Atlantic Treaty and the defensive alliance that it forms.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 -- The Yankee steamroller was still rambling along tonight and so smoothly did it flatten out the tail-end Browns that Casey Stengel, riding in the driver's seat, could not have been any more comfortable had he been home in his rocking chair.

Declaring that a "public-be-damned" attitude characterized the present control of the distribution of theatre tickets by the owners of theatres. Inevstigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh demanded yesterday that distribution be entrusted to the play producers.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 15 -- Alabama's inquiry into violence by masked mobs wound up in confusion today when the investigating grand jury was recessed after disclosures that one of its members also was a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

The twenty-three-day strike of twenty fuel truck drivers servicing New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, was ended yesterday when the men voted unanimously to accept a new flat rate of $1.50 an hour and return to work.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A measure designed to fight off an economic recession by building up a national production level of $300,000,000,000 a year, as proposed by President Truman was handed to the Senate today. It was sponsored by sixteen Democrats and two Republicans.

PITTSBURGH, July 15 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, repressed tonight whatever pleasure he may have felt at the acceptance by the United States Steel Corporation of the Presidential truce proposal.
William Striffler, 25 years old, of 2206 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, made three big mistakes last Sunday.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, July 15 -- Slightly more than a month ago a prayer was read in the pulpits of the staunchly Roman Catholic Rhineland and Ruhr at the behest of Joseph Cardinal Frings, Archbishop of battered Cologne.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 15 -- A plan for a university to serve all United Nations trust areas in Africa was ruled impractical today by a special committee of the Trusteeship Council.

ORADELL, N. J., July 15 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley became the new champion of the Metropolitan district when she conquered Mrs. Mortimer May of Willow Brook, 6 and 5, in the 36-hole final of the forty-sixth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tourney at the Hackensack Golf Club today.
DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- Automotive plants in the United States and Canada reached an all-time record output of 155,350 cars and trucks this week, Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 15 -- Declaring that the Democratic party in New Jersey must be "unbossed by any single individual," Mayor John V. Kenny expressed confidence today that State Senator Elmer H. Wene, the party candidate for Governor, would be successful in November if the campaign is conducted on such a basis.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 -- Harry R. Bridges, president of the ILWU is on his way to Washington to testify on the Hawaiian strike situation and has made no known threats against West Coast shipping as a result of recent moves in the Islands, according to the union's headquarters here.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 15 -- The United States-British Bipartite Commission agreed today to initiate deconcentration action against the UFA Film Company, pre-war Germany's biggest motion picture organization. As in the case of I. G. Farben, plans are being projected to break the company into small units and put them on public sale.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 15 -- Acting Secretary General Byron Price of the United Nations issued the following statement today on Attorney General Clark's charges.

"From Cave Painting to Comic Strip: A Kaleidoscope of Human Communication," by Lancelot Hogben, a biologist and medical statistician, has been scheduled for October publication by the Chanticleer Press. It is a reconstruction and a study of the 25,000 years of man's literacy and a "blueprint"I for the conquest of world illiteracy, i
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Truman signed today the public-housing bill in which Congress enacted the initial phase of his "Fair Deal" program.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 15 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist Government answered today the Vatican's excommunication of active Communists by declaring that anyone who attempted to enforce excommunication would be prosecuted for treason, and by disclosing the draft of a law placing all churches under direct state control.

SILVER BAY, N. Y., July 15 -- Japan is encountering her first "real test" as to whether she will become more genuinely democratic or will swing to the extreme left or the extreme right, the Rev. Dr. Thoburn T. Brumbaugh of the division of foreign missions of the Methodist Church said here today.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- A survey of American life and customs was presented to the readers of Red Star today by the writer, V. Korionov, with the assertion that "only the idiocy of an oversatiated beast of prey" can explain the horrible American conditions that "doom millions to hunger, illness and lingering death."

Lumber production for the week ended July 9 was 30 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by trade associations. Shipments were 6.2 per cent below last year and orders 4.7 per cent.

Does THE NEW YORK TIMES really believe that a free American citizen is wrong in calling for the defeat at the polls of some public servants with whose policies he disagrees? Is that evidence of an intolerance toward other men's views?

Directors of the Glenn L. Martin Company yesterday announced a major reorganization of top executives of the forty-year-old pioneer aircraft manufacturing company. Glenn L. Martin, president of the company since he founded it, relinquished that position to move up to the newly-created post of chairman of the board of directors.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP) -- The defense in the Tokyo Rose treason trial sought today to show that Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino tried to send veiled messages of information to this country during the war. The woman has been on trial here for ten days.

Frederick R. Livingston, a lawyer and specialist in labor arbitration, announced yesterday that he would hold a hearing next week on a disputed wages contract clause involving Atlantic and Gulf ship operators and the American Radio Association, CIO.
CLEVELAND, July 15 (AP) -- The Athletics knocked Bob Feller out of the box tonight and defeated the Indians, 8 -- 0, for their first victory in seven starts.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 15 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery asserted here tonight that the nations of the West already were at war with communism. Addressing members of the Royal Netherlands Society, the chairman of the Western Union Commander in Chiefs' Committee said:

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Average primary market prices advanced 1 per cent in the week ended July 12, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 154.2 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.3 per cent below four weeks ago and 8.9 per cent below the comparable week of 1948.
GREAT NECK, L. I., July 15 -- Mrs. Ira Drazin and Mrs. Robert Trepner, Glen Head, scored 37, 31 -- 68 to win low net prize in the one-day women's member-guest tournament on the Glen Oaks links today.

The acceptance by the big producers of President Truman's strike truce in the steel industry saved a wavering stock market yesterday from going into a tailspin. Morning losses were radically reduced or eliminated and in some cases turned into moderate gains after Bethlehem broke the wall of the "Big Three" steel companies and bowed to the White House proposal.

Judge Augustus N. Hand of the United States Court of Appeals refused yesterday to reinstate the bail of three defendants who have been ordered remanded for contempt of court for the duration of the Communist trial.

LONDON, July 15 -- The Commonwealth Finance Ministers held a plenary session today to discuss the short - term measures announced yesterday by Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, to halt the drain on the sterling bloc's gold and dollar reserves by the slashing of dollar imports.

Leaders of the Republican, Liberal and City Fusion parties and a representative of the Fusion Commitee, headed by Samuel Seabury, met yesterday but failed to name candidates for Controller and President of the City Council on the Fusion ticket headed by Newbold Morris.

The dog days are upon us, and the proper care of one's dogs upon this two and four-footedly congested island is no less a problem than at other seasons. Doggy people and their prancing pooches are on the increase. The uncurbed evidence of this is often collected from our sidewalks by unsuspecting shoe leather.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Truman today named a three-member board to sift the disputed wage-pension union demands in the steel industry under a sixty-day strike truce accepted by the industry and the United Steel Workers of America, CIO.

Vincent Polo, world traveler of Spanish descent and a confidant of the great Spanish and Mexican bull fighters, was arrested yesterday on a 1947 indictment for theft of $26,036 from Jose Martin, matador of Mexico City.
Seatrain Lines, operator of freighters carrying fully loaded freight cars, announced last night that it had temporarily cancelled all sailings to Cuba because of labor conditions on the island.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Senate Committee on Appropriations voted today to slash $1,010,000,000 from the funds that the House had approved for the armed services for the current fiscal year. Its action would cut some $433,000,000 from the budget estimates submitted by President Truman, who already had drastically reduced the requests of the services.
The first post-war Congress of the International Association for Liberal Christianity and Religious Freedom will be held from Tuesday through July 24 in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

In selecting Newbold Morris as the Fusion candidate for Mayor in this year's election, Republican and Liberal leaders have made a logical and an honorable choice. Mr. Morris was closely associated with the La Guardia Administration for eleven years. He served successively as Assistant Corporation Counsel, as a member of the old Board of Aldermen and as President of the City Council.

HONOLULU, July 15 (AP) -- The sixty-five-foot schooners Flying Cloud of Honolulu and Gallant of Newport Harbor, Calif., rounded Molokai Island today and sped for Honolulu with good chances to win the Los Angeles-Honolulu yacht race.

On his day off Dan Stampler isn't averse to broiling a steak over an outdoor fire. But it's hardly the recreation one might think. Mr. Stampler operates the Steak Joint, 58 Greenwich Avenue, a restaurant named after its specialty. His way of enjoying himself seems like more of the same from a workaday world, a busman's holiday; he finds nothing strange in it, however.

Furniture retailers may have to cope with a limited case goods shortage in the fall, store executives declared yesterday. If August furniture sales of many department stores and large home furnishings chains are successful, their inventory position will force them to buy well ahead through Sept.
The Department of Hospitals will install two-way radios in emergency ambulances, it was learned yesterday.

Net income of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the three months to June 30 amounted to $54,390,000, equal to $2.30 a share, compared with $52,293,630, or $2.33 a share, in the same 1948 period, it was announced yesterday.
Irony was the keynote of the weather news yesterday.

In contrast to the National Education Association, which would bar Communist party members from the teaching profession, an investigating committee of the American Association of University Professors has held that Communist party members should have the right to teach in our schools as long as they are not proved guilty of professional unfitness, "more than normal bias," or acts of outright disloyalty.

I. Robert Feinberg, 37-year-old former assistant general counsel of the old National War Labor Board, was named yesterday impartial chairman to act in any disputes that may arise under the existing contract between the Publishers Association of New York City and the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, an independent union.
The difficulties of feeding the State of Israel could easily be solved if Israelis would only listen to Symon Gould, who left for that country yesterday aboard the Gdynia America liner Sobieski.

BUENOS AIRES, July 15 -- Three of President Juan D. Peron's key economists will go to Washington to enable the new joint United States - Argentine Trade Commission to proceed toward a definite resolution of the two countries' long-standing commercial problems.

Burl Ives has been signed to bring his extensive repertoire of American folk songs to the American Broadcasting Company network as the summer replacement for Walter Winchell. The ballad singer, who accompanies himself on the guitar, will be heard on Sunday nights at 9 o'clock for seven weeks starting July 24 and continuing through Sept. 4.

One out of every nine children in New York received care last year from the city's Department of Welfare. The total public cost of caring for these children was $79,800,000, of which the city spent $28,000,000. Foster care of children used $12,000,000, the entire cost of which is borne by the city.

BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- Lefty Warren Spahn clinched his tenth victory with a homer with one on in the second inning tonight as the Braves defeated the Cubs, 6 -- 1. Jeff Heath made his first start in the outfield since fracturing his ankle last September.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP) -- A damage suit alleging monopoly and restraint of trade in the vanadium industry was filed today in the United States District Court here.

A man is shown stepping up to the door of a prosperous-looking apartment house and ringing the renting agent's bell. As soon as the summons is answered he says he is interested in renting an apartment. The applicant looks like a good financial risk and seems like a desirable tenant. But when he gives his name, "Berkowitz," the renting agent's face becomes expressionless. "Sorry." Mr. Berkowitz is not wanted.
Three thousand Organized Marine Corps reservists, in battle dress and carrying weapons, will move through the city this morning as they leave for and return from summer training in southern camps.

Long Island Sound will have its yearly crest in number of racing yachts assembled when the Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-first annual Race Week starts today. Provision has been made for all the craft in the Sound Association list as well as many visiting ones.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 15 -- Billy Talbert, first seeded player, survived the quarter-final round of the Eastern clay courts tennis championship tournament today, defeating fifth-seeded Irving Dorfman, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 9 -- The ambitious Russo-Swedish postwar project whereby the Soviet Union was to obtain Swedish merchandise running into the equivalent of hundreds of millions of dollars on both long-term credits and on a barter basis, appears to have failed dismally.

A major problem of international trade was well and tersely set forth by Orville Sanborn in his letter to you as involving "acceptance of foreign currencies, investments abroad of such currencies and the financing of developments abroad."
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Promoters of fraudulent Canadian oil and mining stock soon will face a new international line-up, it was indicated here today.

MILWAUKEE, July 15 -- The United Automobile Workers broke out its heaviest artillery today in a frontal attack against the Ford Motor Company that switched the main fourth-round wage rise offensive of the Congress of Industrial Organizations from "Big Steel" to "Big Auto."

Improved laboratory procedures for diagnosis of fungus growth causing athlete's foot were reported yesterday to delegates from eight northeastern states at the fifty-third annual conference of the New York State Podiatry Society in the New Yorker Hotel.
The cotton futures market was steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 3 to 11 points net higher.

According to THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 26 the report of the House Un-American Activities Committee on the American Slav Congress listed among the organizations "actively associated with the American Slav Congress" an organization named as "the Czechoslovak National Council of America, New York City."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A committee representing twenty-nine organizations today asked Representative John Lesinski, Democrat, of Michigan, chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor, to call a session of the committee to vote on Federal aid to education.
PITTSBURGH, July 15 (AP) -- The country will lose a sizable quantity of steel production even though steel workers ended their strike threat.

The Civil Aeronautics Board ended yesterday another phase of its investigation of travel agencies and clubs booking passengers for the non-scheduled airlines and announced that the next stage of its survey would take place in Washington on July 25.
PRUEM, Germany, July 15 -- A French Army depot exploded tonight, killing twelve Germans, injuring scores more, and leaving hundreds homeless in the vicinity of this West German town.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 15 (AP) -- Five airlines were honored here tonight at a dinner for perfect safety records on scheduled flights in 1948.

LONDON, July 15 -- The Rev. Dr. Franklin C. Fry of New York City, vice chairman of the Central Committee of the World Council of Churches, told a press conference today that the "Christian Church does not fear competition with any other ideology on earth for the allegiance of mankind."

The "quickie" bus strike that now threatens to become an all-out test of strength between union and management is also a test of something more than that It is a test of the sense of responsibility and good faith of the Transport Workers Union. This is because, only six weeks ago, union and management agreed to the establishment of an impartial chairman whose principal function was to settle disputes such as this.
Customs collections at this port tumbled severely in June, after the previous month had shown the first rise in a long time.
PARIS, July 15 -- Otto Abetz, German Ambassador during the Nazi occupation, maintained today that he had deported art from France in order to preserve it from war damage.

A charge of child abandonment against Michael Zaccaro, 21 years old, a $41-a-week stock clerk, and his wife of 974 East Ninety-sixth Street, Brooklyn, was dismissed in Felony Court yesterday afternoon.

Dr. Horace A. Bacus, economist for the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, testifying yesterday before a Presidential fact-finding board in support of the brotherhood's demand for a second fireman on diesel-electric engines, declared that the nation's railroads were saving $150,000,000 annually in fuel costs by using the diesels.

Cottonseed oil futures prices were 30 points lower to 10 points higher on the New York Produce Exchange yesterday. July, which expired at noon, was the heavy loser. There was some trade buying of the September delivery. The deferred months were featureless.

One of the best things about the announcement of the release of Marshall Plan counterpart funds in the Netherlands is the glimpse that it gives us of actual aid and recovery in operation. Much of the discussion of our aid program has been in either political or rather super-economic terms.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 15 -- Membership in the Communist party does not constitute sufficient grounds for dismissing a teacher or professor, two prominent educators declared here today. They argued that a teacher should be ousted only for incompetence.

TOKYO, July 15 -- Anti-Communist members of the Central "Struggle" Committee of the Japanese National Railway Workers Union walked out of the organization's session today after the committee, by a narrow margin, had voted to "warn" the government against the dismissal of surplus railroad employes, now being carried out under the occupation's retrenchment policy.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The expected Pancho Gonzales-Frankie Parker showdown for the national clay courts tennis title was half in the making today as Parker bounced into the final with his hardest-earned victory of the tournament.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 15 (AP) -- Bounding into the lead in the opening strides, W. Julian Walden's Fighting Fan easily won the Monmouth Park feature race today.

Jacob A. Malik, Soviet deputy foreign minister and his country's chief delegate to the United Nations, sailed for home yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth. Smilingly warding off questions on the world political situation, he remarked that "when on leave, there is no comment."

MILWAUKEE, July 15 -- The two top leaders of the Progressive Unity Caucus, anti-Reuther faction of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, were expelled from the union today. The action was taken on charges of "treasonable conduct" in connection with the publication of a suppressed report containing allegations of widespread gambling and racketeering in a Paterson (N. J.) local.
BENA, Minn., July 15 (AP) -- Youth paced the way today in the first lap of the annual 450-mile canoe race down the Mississippi River to Minneapolis.

In a recent editorial (July 6) we commented on a report of the United Nations Secretariat which, we said, "purports to show that Russia and her satellites increased their industrial production more in 1948 than the Marshall Plan countries did." The U. N. Press and Publications Bureau informs us that "nowhere in the report is there any attempt to make such a comparison."

If and when Alexander Lidor's "A Springboard to Nowhere" arrives on Broadway it will be under the banner of Lawrence Shubert Lawrence, nephew of Lee and J. J. Shubert and general manager for the Shubert interests in Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The Senators blended six hits with a walk and Luke Appling's throwing error to score six runs in the eighth inning and trim the White Sox, 9 -- 4, before 3,619 fans today. All told, the Senators collected 18 hits -- their season high.

New York and New England industrial executives expect that Government orders will be channeled to distressed industries in these and other areas, in line with the recently announced program to aid industries in which employment has been reduced.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- East and West came forward today with "harmony" candidates for chairman of the Republican National Committee.

ALBANY, July 15 -- Beginning immediately, boards of education in New York State will be required to investigate annually all teachers and other public school employes to determine if they have committed subversive acts or are members of subversive organizations.

The four-story building at 509-515 Livonia Avenue, Brooklyn, containing nine stores and twenty-one apartments, has been sold by Giuseppe Diliberto to Philip Bachman. Presto Realty Company was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today asked President Truman and Congressional leaders of both parties for immediate action on civil rights legislation. The association asked in telegrams that a special session of Congress be called, if necessary.

The Democratic executive committee of Kings County yesterday designated Borough President John Cashmore and District Attorney Miles F. McDonald for renomination. The meeting was held at the party headquarters at 4-5 Court Square.
BERLIN, July 15 (AP) -- Russian guards confiscated West marks from Berlin-bound truck drivers on the Helmstedt-Berlin highway for a few hours today, then let them pass unquestioned.

SHANGHAI, July 15 -- A process of basic economic reorganization, involving the transplanting of a number of factories and removing from 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 persons from the world's fourth largest city, has been advocated by the Sin Wen Jih Pao (Daily News) here as part of a plan to make Shanghai less dependent on "foreign imperialism" and to integrate it into the new national economy.

OMAHA, Neb., July 15 -- Play in the Open championship of the United States Chess Federation was put off today because of the annual business meeting at the Hotel Fontenelle and several gatherings of the board of directors.

LONDON, July 15 -- In spite of cuts in import from the dollar areas and continuance of the London dock strike, the stock markets here showed today a surprising degree of firmness in gilt-edge and industrial issues before the week-end.

MEXICO CITY, July 15 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York started his vacation here today with a protocol spree that kept a score of motorcycles roaring through the city so fast not even lottery peddlers could accost him.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Bituminous coal production for this year is running 12.4 per cent behind last year's output for a similar period, the Bureau of Mines said today. The bureau estimated total production for 1949 through July 9 at 260,868,000 tons, a decrease of 36,850,000 from last year.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 15 -- Johnny Humm of Rockville successfully began the defense of his Long Island amateur golf title in the match play rounds of the twenty-sixth annual championship over the Meadow Brook club course today, while two former champions were being eliminated.

HONOLULU, July 15 -- Attorney for the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehouse men's Union, CIO, in Hawaii today filed a legal counter-attack against the Matson Navigation Company with a $966,000 libel claim against the line and one of its strikebound freighters, the Hawaiian Wholesaler.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 15 -- Observers in Belgrade consider the timing of the British and United States notes protesting the Yugoslav currency change in Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste and accusing the Yugoslav Government of treaty violations, as unfortunate at this particular time, but view the diplomatic incident as only a temporary setback in the progress achieved toward the general improvement of relations between Yugoslavia and the West.

With 1,125,000 bus riders already forced to seek other transportation, Michael J. Quill, head of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, threatened yesterday to add an additional 1,800,000 to their number by striking the Third Avenue Transit System.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said today it was considering taking steps to hold minimum producer prices of top grade milk in New York City at current levels during August.

LONDON, July 15 -- The British Government tacitly acknowledged today that its efforts to mediate the dock strike here had temporarily failed and that, as a result, a deadlock had now set in between more than 14,000 striking dock workers on the one hand and their employers, who are fully backed by the Labor Government, on the other.

The windows, the millions of windows, the eyes of the city, are wide open now, for it is summer. We sit by the sills, peer at the opposite walls or over the roofs, and pray for a breeze, for peace and quiet, for a chance to think, as we sit by the everlasting sills.
SHANGHAI, July 15 (UP) -- Communist authorities today ordered the United States Information Service in Shanghai to close down immediately all the services operated for the Chinese people.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 15 -- Two major controversies over express highways in southern Westchester were increasing in bitterness today, with state officials holding most of the control over routes. Both highways are to be built soon by the state to speed mixed traffic.

The King Ranch, winner of the stake with Assault in 1947, will go after the money with Flying Missel and But Why Not in the $50,0O0 added Butler Handicap at Jamaica today. The entry probably will be favored in this final-day feature of the Empire City Racing Association's two-week meeting.

ROME, July 15 -- The Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano attacked the Communist press today for what Osservatore Romano called deliberate misrepresentation of the new decree of excommunication against communism as interference by the Roman Catholic Church in political matters.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Tennessee Natural Gas Company, Florence, Ala., today proposed a 90,000-share common stock sale to help pay for a 142-mile pipeline from Selmer, Tenn., to Huntsville, Ala.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 15 (AP) -- Ray Billows won his semi-final match in the state amateur golf tournament on the eighteenth green today after his opponent lost a one - hole lead by accidentally kicking the ball.

ALBANY, July 15 -- Following is the text of a rule adopted today by the Board of Regents concerning the disqualification or removal of public school employes for membership in subversive organizations:
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The Packinghouse Workers Union, CIO, today jumped into the national labor-management pensions fight with demands on Swift Co.

Annoyed by the invasion of youthful gangs from neighboring areas of Westchester into the Riverdale section of the Bronx on Thursday night, Magistrate Arthur Markewich held twenty - three youths in $1,000 bail yesterday in the Youth Term of the Bronx Magistrates Court.
LONDON, July 15 (Reuters) -- The match between Northamptonshire and the New Zealand cricketers ended in a draw at Northampton today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- The deal for John Garfield to star in three pictures for Warner Brothers and for the actor and his business partner, Bob Roberts, to produce three pictures independently for Warner release has been called off, and Roberts and Garfield will instead devote themselves to straight independent production, it was learned today from a Roberts representative.

Although several giant tuna have been taken in the traps along the northern New Jersey coast, the anglers have been unable to bring in one of the big ones despite the tons of mossbunker chum that have been expended in the effort.

One year after the consolidation of the New York City rapid transit system the directional signs at transfer points are, with few exceptions, still as inadequate and inconspicuous as on the first day of operation. Passengers transferring from one subway system to another are in too many instances unable to find their way on the first try without losing direction at least once.

Your editorial of July 13 discussing the debate on the Atlantic Pact between Republican Senators Dulles and Taft brought to mind a consideration which may have an important bearing on this controversy.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 15 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, charged President Truman tonight with embarking on a program of deficit spending that would lead to "a totalitarian state."

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Every House Republican "who is on his feet and breathing or shows any signs of life" was under orders today to be on hand next week to vote against the Brannan farm bill. The command was issued to the 171 GOP members by Representative Leslie C. Arends, Republican of Illinois, the party's whip whose job it is to get out the vote.
CANTON, China, July 15 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek tonight called for stern defense of this provisional Nationalist capital against the Chinese Communists.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UP) -- The Senate Labor Committee today approved a "remember Centralia" bill granting authority to Federal mine inspectors to close dangerous coal shafts.

Your editorial of July 13 discussing the debate on the Atlantic Pact between Republican Senators Dulles and Taft brought to mind a consideration which may have an important bearing on this controversy.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 15 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, charged President Truman tonight with embarking on a program of deficit spending that would lead to "a totalitarian state."
ARCADIA, Calif., July 16 -- Solidarity, a California-bred colt, put the big-name horses to shame today when he rolled in to win the $100,000 Hollywood Gold Cup Handicap.

First reports of comparisons of the volume of industrial purchasing for the first six months of 1949 with previous peacetime years show that new high records have been established by some industries, it was learned here yesterday.
BIENNE, Switzerland, July 16 -The watchmakers of Switzerland announced today an 8 to 15 per cent increase in the prices of Swiss watch movements.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 16 -- Clarence Phelan of Islip, L. I., past commander of Busy Bohm Post, was elected Suffolk County Commander of the American Legion today, suceeding William F. Duncan of Huntington.

THE night that Lila Ash plunges down the log chute to her death everyone, including Sheriff Jess Roden, considers it a tragic accident. But next morning, when Roden examines the ground at the head of the chute, he discovers unmistakable evidence that the girl's death was no accident and, as a result, he realizes that one other person in the little logging community knows it too.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- At the risk of being repetitious, it was Sammy Snead again today in the Dapper Dan open golf tournament.

HOW much to tip? That always tricky question, never yet resolved satisfactorily, becomes a major issue each summer as the population moves about. Week-ending New Yorkers worry about how much to tip their hosts' servants.

BOSTON, July 16 -- New England industrialists, who were most impressed by that part of President Truman's message abandoning a tax boost, continue to be apprehensive over the future. They use the term apprehension, rather than outright pessimism, because they feel that the downward pitch of post-war readjustment has not been quite as steep as was originally feared.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- A synthetic substitute for African and East Indian palm oil has been developed by scientists at Armour Research Foundation and soon will be tested in the manufacture of hot dip tin-plate, the Illinois Institute of Technology announced today.

OMAHA, Neb., July 16 -- Not quite equal to the task of breaking the hold of Albert Sandrin of Chicago on first place in the United States Chess Federation's open championship tournament. Larry Evans of New York, nevertheless drew with the Western expert in the fifth round at the Hotel Fontenelle today.

REFERRING to the letter from Mary Conan Doyle printed in your June 26 issue: A book published in London by Methnen Co., 36, Essex Street, Strand, London, W. C. 2, in 1943, by Hesketh Pearson, entitled "Conan Doyle. His Life and Art," apparently received very little attention in this country.

FROM the day the calico kitten arrived at the cloth factory he was the special pet of the workers and highly approved of by the big boss. He was not afraid of the roaring machinery, of the huge steam rollers on which he did his difficult once-a-day trick; and he knew enough to stay out of Big Tom Cat's domain, the storeroom.

PARIS, July 16 -- In a sweltering court room, into which a blazing, July sun pours through windows opening on the Seine, Otto Abetz, Hitler's Ambassador to occupied France, appeared on trial this week for war crimes which uncomfortably revived French memories of all the sufferings of a period just starting now to fade.
HOW little we know of this continent of ours.

The almost incredible series of maneuvers that culminated in last Tuesday's decision by Mayor William O'Dwyer to for re-election was confusing, but not surprising. In both his personal and public life the Mayor is, in mathematical terms, a variable and not a constant. His decision appears to make it probable that Mr. O'Dwyer will be re-elected.

EASTERN gardeners may not be able to grow all saxifrages, but, with the exception of S. florulenta, none of the encrusted kinds is apt to offer any difficulty. My favorite is S. lingulata, which has been growing for fifteen years in my garden without any attention.

RETAIL trade last week throughout the nation continued to follow the pattern which has become familiar since the beginning of the year. Compared with the brisk business and higher prices of 1948, sales again yielded fewer dollars to stores than the corresponding week last year.

IT is difficult for adults to see everyday objects as children see them. They have been using spoons and shoes for so long that these are just spoons and shoes. They have been feeling the wind and the rain for so long that these are just wind and rain. But to children, spoons, shoes, wind, rain are all new experiences.

HEMEROCALLIS are indeed the perennial for all places, all soils, all locations. Even during the hot, dry weather of the past six weeks, which has taken its toll of other perennials, the innumerable members of the daylily family have gone right on blooming in great variety and profusion.

Oppressed by the heat, threatened with claustrophobia, many New York apartment dwellers are laying hands on various forms of reading matter and moving out to the parks. You see them sitting in long lines on the park benches.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 -- Amid a clashing and flashing of thunder and lightning, a number of astonishing developments came to pass today, not the least of these being the scoring of four runs by the Brownies in the first inning of the series finale with the Yankees.
TIJUANA Mexico, July 16 (UP) -- The word is getting around that Americans can avoid the 15 per cent United States tax if their airplane tickets are bought in Mexico.

American export groups are preparing to fight new attacks on the principle under which they have been allowed since 1918 to combine as associations for joint dealing with foreign buyers without prosecution under the anti-trust laws, it was learned yesterday.

TOURNAMENT bridge, though it is a sedentary pastime, is acknowledged to be a very strenuous game. The competitor comes out of a day-long session about as exhausted as a golfer who has played thirty-six holes, and for substantially the same reason -- the nervous strain of trying to do the right thing every time.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont, a ranking farm Republican, said today that the new farm program of Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan was dead for this session.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -Philadelphia women's wear shops reported 10 per cent less sales last week than in the same 1948 period. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 80,660, as against 110,079 a year ago, a decrease of 26.7 per cent, and for 1949 to date 2,940,854, to compare with 3,408,126 last year, a decrease of 13.7 per cent.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 16 -- Don McNeill, national champion in 1940, who several years ago decided to concentrate on business rather than tennis, came to the end of his trail in the Eastern clay court singles championship today. Pitted against Eddie Moylan, the crisp hitting performer from Trenton, N. J., McNeill, who now lives on Long Island, bowed, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, in a semi-final test.

DROUGHT and the limitations on watering imposed by many communities have wilted gardens along the Atlantic seaboard. But they have also brought into sharp focus the importance of summer mulching as the only possible way to prevent the garden from completely drying up under these circumstances.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- Pitcher Bob Kuzava and Second Baseman Cass Michaels paced the White Sox to a 5-1 victory over the Senators today.
LOS ANGELES, July 16 (AP) -- A San Francisco youngster, who never before had reached the final round of any tournament, won the national public links championship today.

Mosquitos are regarded as probable carriers of encephalitis, called sleeping sickness in this country, though it has no connection with African sleeping sickness. According to Dr. W. McD. Hammon of the University of California there has been a steady and dramatic drop in the number of cases diagnosed in Kern County, Calif., in the three years since more vigorous mosquito-control measures were instituted.
LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- Bill Nankeville splashed through pools of water to win the mile in the British Amateur Athletic Association championship in the meet record time of 4:08.8.

Beth Harber's letter reacting to my article "Causes and Cure of Discrimination" requires a reply. She is entirely accurate when she writes. "Discrimination may be very great in some occupations without leading to official complaints because minority group members do not usually even try to enter these fields."

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 16 -- Colonel Mike came from way back to win the Lamplighter Handicap at the Monmouth Park race track today. The 3-year-old owned by Eugene Jacobs responded ably to the sharp guidance of Jockey Basil James to defeat Mrs. Alfred Roberts' Eatontown by two lengths. Third place went to Near Thing, owned by Mrs. G. S. Smith.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 (UP) -- CIO United Steelworkers started the nation's mills and furnaces booming on a sixty-day strike-free run today.

THE moral of this book is, "Don't throw anything away; somebody'll want it." Morgan Towne (whom this reviewer strongly suspects of being the prolific Carl Drepperd in coveralls) contends that every accumulation of rubbish more than twenty-five years old contains at least something that can be sold somewhere for a profit.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Discussions between the Army and a Presidential committee on the use of Negro service men have been brought to a virtual stand-still by the Army's determination to conform to local opinion on racial matters, it was learned today.

A method by which flavors and aromas can be both evaluated objectively and depicted was described at last week's Institute of Food Technologists by Dr. S. E. Cairncross and Mr. L. B. Sjostrom of Arthur D. Little, Inc. A panel of trained tasters determines which "flavor notes" can be identified individually from the over-all flavor blend, how strong these "notes" are, and also how strong is the basic blend of flavor.
Two men were taken into custody yesterday at the Ralph Avenue Police Station in Brooklyn in connection with a fatal shooting which followed the hold-up of a Brooklyn liquor store Thursday.

ASPEN, Col., July 16 -- The unique cultural "pilgrimage" and music festival devoted exclusively to re-evaluating the life and work of the eighteenth-century German poet-philosopher Johann Wolfgang von Goethe came to a close this week in this small Rocky Mountain town.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -The new public housing program will start slowly, but in its allotted six years will cover nearly every large American city and many smaller ones in a $7,000,000,000 building drive. This became evident today through an Associated Press survey that showed that sixty-one cities in states where laws now permit subsidized low-rent housing have plans in varied stages of readiness for about 256,000 units.

TRENTON, N. J., July 16 -- The recent "sound and fury" within the New Jersey Democratic organization has led to speculation whether the leaders' dissension will be fatal to the chances of their candidate for Governor, State Senator Elmer H. Wene.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 16 -Brazilian officials are confident that Brazil will receive the financial help she needs as a result of the negotiations now taking place in Washington. Press dispatches from Washington report favorable progress has been made in the talks.

MEXICO CITY, July 16 -- Mayor O'Dwyer's decision to break off his vacation and fly back to New York tonight was reached at noon, Mexican time, after he telephoned New York this morning and learned the bus situation was becoming worse.

FLORENCE, Italy. VISITORS drawn to Florence this year by the fame and charm of the city, or by its current celebration of the five hundredth anniversary of the birth of Lorenzo the Magnificent, will sooner or later come to the place where the most beautiful bridge in the world used to be.

TOKYO, July 16 -- Employers hit by dwindling purchasing power and the virtual nonexistence of credit continue to meet their difficulties by failing to pay wages. The Labor Ministry reported today that 895 concerns were short 858,000,000 yen in wage payments in the first half of June.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 -- The cold war and its effects on the maritime industry are scheduled for discussions at the third biennial convention of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, opening here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A device for reducing the rolling motion of ships by as much as 80 per cent will be tested next month off the turbulent Virginia Capes, the National Military Establishment announced today.

JAMES FORRESTAL spent much thought, while Secretary of Defense, trying to analyze why, on so many questions of major strategic import, the Army and Air Force tended to differ from the Navy. He never got beyond an obvious, though fundamental, answer.

BERLIN, July 16 -- There is every indication that during the present period of comparative peace in Germany the Russians are mobilizing their political forces for a final intensive drive against the establishment this autumn of a federal republic in Western Germany, according to well-informed United States political observers here.
MOSCOW, July 7 -- What is the true road which a Soviet youngster should take toward fame and glory?

A PERENNIAL that is too easy to grow sounds unbelievable. This charge, however, could be made against daylilies or hemerocallis. Because they flower by the thousands along roadsides, the challenge that horticultural varieties present to gardeners is likely to be ignored.

LAST year Bill Ballinger's first novel. "The Body in the Bed." was faster, brighter and fresher than most recent entries in the bosoms-and-brandy sweepstakes. This year's sequel is a pitiful letdown, a shabby museum of every cliehe of plot, style and action which has served over the years to pull the private-detective novel down from the level on which Hammett established it.
LUXEMBOURG, July 16 (AP) -Defense Ministers of the five Brussels Treaty nations announced today they had reached agreement on a unified plan of arms production and service supply.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today capped 2 1/2 years of spadework aimed at stamping out what it terms wildcat promotions of football howl games by empowering a nine-man committee to map a code of standards governing post-season gridiron enterprises.

HIGHLY recommended for young train travelers by Judith Cauman, Director of the Boardman School, is Salt Dough, a clean, non-messy, non-staining plastic medium requiring no apron. Even hand-washing isn't absolutely necessary.

ALTHOUGH Yukon and Klondike are the names most commonly associated with the romantic appeal of the gold-boom country, it is not necessary for motorists living along the Atlantic Coast to make the long' journey to the Far North to observe the workings of a modern gold town.

THE derricks and pipes of the oil fields and the domes and towers of the refineries will have added meaning for the reader of this book. For almost every page of text there is a dramatic black-and-white photograph which serves to illustrate a step in the story of oil, how and where it is found, and how the various operations in refining produce the hundreds of different results.

GRAND RAPIDS, Minn., July 16 (AP) -- The defending champions, Thomas A. Estes-Eugene Jensen from Minneapolis, set another record today in winning the second leg of the Minneapolis aquatennial canoe derby.

LENOX, Mass., July 16 -- The first public concert of the Tanglewood season, the fifteenth Berkshire Symphonic Festival, was given tonight before an overflow audience beneath the arcade from the 1,200-seating capacity theatre concert hall.

Denunciations of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as an instrument in the establishment of "fascism, American - style," were made by speakers at the opening of a two-day session of a Bill of Rights Conference attended by 700 persons yesterday at the Henry Hudson Hotel.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 16 -- The Communist party called today for a no-quarter fight to crush the Czechoslovak hierarchy of "our greatest enemy -- the church."

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Whereas business men in the Central States were almost uniformly pessimistic about conditions three months ago, a substantial number of them have in the meantime become relatively optimistic, in the belief that they can foresee the "bottom" of the decline which has been going on here for varying periods of months in various lines.

STORIES of faraway lands, of animals that talk, of magic and miracles, appeal to most young people. When such stories are carefully selected by individuals equipped with a knowledge of children, a wide familiarity with source materials and a sound appreciation of literary values, the result is a real contribution to any child's library.

ON the sunny south side of the gray stone Treasury Building in Whitehall Street, the most powerful and controversial figure in post-war Britain sits at a crowded but orderly desk in a pleasant office whose tall windows frame the Houses of Parliament and Westminster Abbey.

BERLIN, July 16 -- For the first time since V-E Day the people of Western Europe are spending what resembles a normal summer. Despite the uncomfortable impasse between East and West, which shows scant signs of being solved, there are no rumors or threats of war such as there were last year and in 1947.
LONDON, July 16 (AP) -- Winston Churchill contributed 25 (about $100) today to a defense fund for former German Field Marshal General Fritz Erich von Mannstein.

Saks Fifth Avenue will open a branch store in Pittsburgh about Sept. 6, Adam L. Gimbel, president of Saks Co., announced yesterday. This will be the seventh Saks Fifth Avenue branch and will occupy 20,000 square feet of space on the sixth floor of the Gimbel Department Store Building in that city, he said.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -Senate Republican Leader Kenneth S. Wherry described President Truman's deficit-spending program tonight as "a terrible blunder." He said the Administration's welfare proposals would cost more than one trillion dollars in the next half century.

WARSAW, July 16 -- Hilary Minc, Poland's Deputy Premier and economic chief, told a Polish United Workers party conference that the party's policy has encountered "furious attacks by reactionaries and the doubts of certain of our comrades concerning a possible drop in agricultural production due to restrictions of village capitalists," newspapers reported today.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 16 -Arthur W. Davis, who retired last year as controller of Standard Brands, Inc., food distributors of 595 Madison Avenue, New York, was killed last night when an automobile in which he was a passenger was in collision with two other cars at Houston, Pa., near Pittsburgh, according to word received at his home at 61 Beechmont Avenue here.

TOKYO, July 16 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida, in a public statement this evening, called on the Japanese people to remain calm in the face of what he called Communist attempts to "fan discontent, stir up hate and incite the rabble to violence" over the Government's retrenchment program.

THE emphasis now appears to be on the making of important pictures on two shoe strings, or less. Within recent months the producers of "The Quiet One," "Champion" and more recently "Home of the Brave" and "Lost Boundaries" have regaled the press with the inside story of how expensive pictures are made on what Hollywood calls "a low budget."

ATLANTA, Ga., July 16 -- President Truman's report to the nation this week on the economic situation found people in this area maintaining widely divergent views on what had happened to the country's economy and where it was headed.

LONDON, July 16 -- The unofficial strike of part of the London longshoremen over a dispute between rival seamen's unions in Canada has embarrassed Britain's Labor Government and the leaders of union labor at a critical political and economic time for both.

This next Tuesday afternoon for a few hours the wards of eight public and voluntary hospitals in New York will be visited by a number of small units of professional musicians. Known as the "Ward Strollers," the musicians in the hospitals for the aged and chronically ill will feature sentimental and familiar tunes, while similar units in the adolescent wards will "give out" with jazz.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The names of eleven United States delegates to the seventeenth International Navigation Congress at Lisbon, Portugal, have been selected by Maj. Gen. Lewis A. Pick. Chief of Army Engineers, and sent to the Secretary of State for approval.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Harrison E. Spangler of Iowa asserted today that the Republican National Committee members would choose their own new chairman, without outside help.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The President in his economic message to Congress this week abandoned, at least temporarily, the ascending tax unit in the formula of taxing and spending by which President Roosevelt and his successor carried all but one of the general elections in the United States since 1932. The President acted outside the Taft-Hartley law in asking his three-man board of inquiry not only to find out the facts but also to make recommendations.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 16 -- The Lebanese Falange, strong Christian political organization that suggested last week-end that the American University of Beirut might have to be closed in the public interest, has recanted after a week of furious attacks in the Lebanese press.

While in England, Mary Allistair discovers she has a bad heart, but bravely disregarding it, continues her trip to France and Italy accompanied by (enter the strong and silent hero) Ben Roderick.

ALTHOUGH experts differ on what constitutes a drought and what determines its end, neither they nor the homeowner questions the fact that there has been a serious one throughout a wide section of the Eastern States.

Financial markets were firm again last week, making the fourth consecutive period in which equity values started the climb from the year's low point made in mid-June. President Truman's economic report, released on Wednesday night -- which was more temperate in its tone toward business than earlier documents -- bolstered sentiment.

The title of Henry Steele Commager's article, "The Real Danger -- Fear of Ideas," suggested great promise. I thought he would put his finger squarely on the ideas of which we are afraid. But he never did say specifically, "This is it!"

LASZLO HALASZ is dickering with the agents of the Austrian composer, Gottfried von Einem, to produce the latter's opera. "Danton's Tod," with the New York City Opera Company. No contracts have been signed and the English translation has not yet been settled, so it is not likely to be along until after the fall season.

BELGRADE, July 16 -- Marshal Tito's speech of July 10 announcing the closing of the Yugoslav-Greek frontier completed a long-drawn-out duel which began last autumn to prevent the Soviet Government from encircling Yugoslavia to the south.

THIS brief biography by a teacher at Vanderbilt University is the best-documented book thus far on William S. Porter, the almost legendary O. Henry -- the man nobody (at any rate during his New York City years, 1902-10) actually knew.

The recent efforts of local authorities in various Southern States to unmask the Ku Klux Klan are symptomatic of an encouraging approach to the problem of race relations below the Mason-Dixon line. Various court rulings in behalf of Negro civil rights, following the pattern set by the United States Supreme Court, are examples of the same trend.

The latest report of New Jersey's Division of Discrimination indicates improved employment practices and educational facilities. New Jersey is one of the eight states with anti-discrimination commissions. When New York established its State Commission against Discrimination four years ago a chain reaction of similar efforts followed around the country.

In promotions here last week retailers emphasized taffeta dresses, faille suits, slide charm bracelets, silk shantung blouses, velvet and felt berets and frozen lollipop kits, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Truman appointed Paul A. Porter today to succeed Mark F. Ethridge as United States member of the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission. The appointment was said at the State Department to be subject to confirmation by the Senate.

The wildfowlers have been a rather gloomy group since the reports were issued on the poor nesting and rearing conditions prevalent throughout a good part of the Canadian breeding grounds, but the latest report from Ducks Unlimited will banish much of this gloom.

AT a recent Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, boys and girls discussed sex education and came to some remarkable conclusions: home is the best place for a child to receive sex instruction, but mothers and fathers are not equipped to give it; parents often get emotionally upset when confronted with questions about sex; home, church and school should supplement one another in giving sex education.

The night skies of midsummer don't get much attention, unless there is both a full moon and a cool breeze. Besides, full-leafed trees and full-fledged mosquitos get in the way. But the stars are still there, though at first it may be hard to find the familiar groups.

The procurement program for the country's first superliner, the United States, is already well advanced and vast quantities of materials are either moving toward the giant dry dock selected for building or are in process of manufacture, it was reported yesterday.

The gray-haired woman stepped up to the change booth at the Eighty-first Street station of the IND Subway and pushed a dollar into the cage. She smiled. "Thanks a lot. It was very nice of you," she said.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Board of Inquiry appointed to recommend a basis for settling the wage-pension dispute in the steel industry will meet on Monday at the White House, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UP) -- The Navy will spend part of its fiscal 1950 building appropriation on a "completely new" type of propulsion for submarines, it was revealed today. Experimental work on this "radical change" will be abnormally hazardous and secret, the Navy said.
Being a Frenchwoman, I was much interested in Ann Hightower's "If Paris Is Can-Can, New York Is Tom-Tom," for she says just the things I have been telling my American friends for twenty years.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 16 (AP) -- Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie won his seventh state amateur golf crown today with a victory over John Ward of Syracuse in a match that went 39 holes.

Thousands of members of Lions International from North, South and Central America are streaming into New York this weekend for their thirty-second annual convention.

SO-CALLED tree or standard roses make a notable contribution to any garden. Planted directly in a bed of bush roses where blooms are apt to be about the same level, their height relieves this monotonous, flat effect.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Defending Champion Pancho Gonzales of Los Angeles today advanced to the final of the national clay court tennis tournament with a 6-2, 5-7, 6-4, 6-1 triumph over Vic Seixas of Philadelphia.

A woman who had been stabbed to death and her husband unconscious from fatal stab wounds near the heart and from gas poisoning were found in their one-room ground floor apartment at 44 West Sixty-fifth Street yesterday afternoon by her brother and a group of neighbors.

NEWARK, N. J., July 16 -- The Newark Evening News declined today to act on a demand by former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City that it abandon publication of an announced series of articles about him advertised as "Frank Hague, Last of the Bosses," which is to start tomorrow.

AS the dog days of the art season approach and artists scatter far and wide to consolidate their gains or not to consolidate them, city dwellers can take the abbreviated summer course in contemporary American painting that is given by the various group shows about New York.

OMAHA, July 16 -- Midwest business men, bankers and officials are playing their economic cards very close to their vests these days. But there has been, in the past few weeks, a gradual spread of the belief that this region may not suffer recession pains as severe as those felt on either Coast.
GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 16 -- Jaroslav Drobny defeated his fellow Czechoslovak exile, Vladimir Cernik, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, to gain the final round of the Swiss tennis championships today.

Although the major steel companies relented at the eleventh hour on Friday to accept President Truman's proposal for a sixty-day truce in the steel wage dispute, they did so reluctantly and served notice that they have not weakened in their resolve to resist major concessions on wages and other benefits to their employes.

SARATOGA SPRINGS is calling upon its favorite contemporary native son, movie and stage star Monty Woolley, to help launch the eightieth August meeting at the famous old track on Monday, Aug. 1. This day, which has been appropriated by the Chamber of Commerce and converted into "Saratoga's Monty Woolley Day," will mark the opening of the four-week race meeting at the Spa.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 16 -Regional scholarship awards totaling $16,200 have been presented to seventeen outstanding secondary school graduates by Princeton University for the academic year 1949-50, Minot C. Morgan Jr., secretary of the university committee on scholarships, announced today.

Four years ago yesterday the first atom bomb was exploded in a test at Alamogordo, N. M. The test culminated what President Truman called "the greatest achievement of organized science in history." The bomb was the product of a four-year effort by three nations -- the United States, Britain and Canada.

MR. DOUBLEDAY'S "Studies in Poetry" might be described as a design for critical taste. It is "a realistic introduction to the critical reading and analysis of 165 poems by diverse poets from many ages." No one can foretell how students will react to any given textbook, but I should be glad to take a chance with this one.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- Officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People were reluctant today to discuss rumors that Walter F. White would not return to the association as its secretary next year at the expiration of a leave of absence.

The New York waterfront, which is often accused of providing employment for a criminal element, may soon be crisscrossed by licensed private detectives. This is predicted in the shipping industry because of the manner in which the state fingerprinting law covering pier guards is being enforced here.
MR. HALE'S new novel concerns a clash of philosophies and the dilemma that confronts a happily married woman for whom telling of the truth may mean the sacrifice of her world.

ROME, July 16 -- Socialists who support Communist doctrines also will incur excommunication, Vatican circles said today. Officials observed that the decree issued last Wednesday applied not only to members of the Communist party but to all those Catholics who deliberately and freely defended and spread the materialistic and anti-Christian doctrine of the Communists.

HONOLULU, Jury 16 -- Hawaii Stevedores, Ltd., newly organized longshore firm, started unloading the strike-bound Isthmian freighter Steel Flyer in Honolulu harbor today, but not until after ninety-six pickets of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, had been arrested for attempting to block the newly recruited nonunion men from the pier.

MOSCOW, July 16 -- Soviet press in dispatches from Berlin today sharply criticized the Anglo-American airlift, which, it charged, was being maintained at the expense of the German public only for the financial benefit of British and United States capitalists.

Despite good unit turnover in response to strong retail promotions, dollar volume of sales continued to sag here last week. Department store trade was estimated at about 15 per cent under the comparative week of 1948.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Dickey Stable's Growing Up collected the winner's share of the $7,500 added Betsy Ross Stakes at Suffolk Downs today, finishing the five and a half furlongs three and a half lengths in front of Irving Gushen's George's Girl.

THIS department, being about to take its annual leave, has been struggling against its natural tendency to urge its constituents into a course of vacation reading which it probably will leave severely alone. BOSTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Braves took the odd affair of a three-game series with the Cubs, 9-1, today by blasting three pitchers for a total of fourteen hits for Johnny Sain, who turned in his best pitching performance of the 1949 season.
The Cunard White Star liner Britannic will leave New York next winter for a fifty-four day Mediterranean cruise to nineteen ports in Africa, the Middle East and Europe.
FRANKFORT, July 16 (Reuters) -- Germany's famous ceramics industries, whose products adorned dinner tables all over the world before the war, are gradually returning to normal.

" THANATOPSIS" is the first book issued by The Tiger's Eye, the literary and art quarterly now in its second year. Herbert Cahoon's previous work consists of verse plays and criticism. This beautifully printed book is a collection of short lyrics and occasional poems, intuitive and spontaneous, neatly phrased, most of them rather somber.

IN between running down to the Riviera and kindred Continental forays a man should hardly be willing to fiddle with a typewriter. But, writes Joshua Logan, the co-author and director of both "South Pacific" and "Mister Roberts," he's managed to get through three pages of his contemplated adaptation of Chekhov's "The Cherry Orchard."
CLEVELAND, July 16 (AP) -Gene Bearden, the Indians' top rookie last year, gained his first victory since June 15 today, defeating the Athletics, 7 to 3.

THE coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats in the Eighty-first Congress brings to a focus the perennial question of party realignment. On the face of it, the condition of the Government is unsatisfactory, and lays the United States open to ridicule by our enemies and distrust by our friends.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 16 -- As Local 401 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, and the recently-organized Independent Singer's Employes Union, prepared today for an election to be conducted by the State Mediation Board to determine which will serve as bargaining agent of 7,000 workers of the Singere manufacturing Company here, the independents charged that the older union was Communist-infiltrated and promised to ban Communists from their organization.

CASTING, always a problem in developing a new show, is proving to be a major headache for the Columbia Broadcasting System in the preparation of its television version of the "Amos 'n' Andy" series scheduled for presentation next fall.

SOMETIMES a book takes you by surprise. It arrives without recommendation; it bears an unknown author's name; its subject seems not too vital, and its approach not too ingenious. It begins quietly, continues unassumingly and ends by charming you completely.

Every faith, ideology and institution had disappointed Vincent Sheean: "I had come to the end of my tether in the West."

PETER QUINCE, the hero of Max Brand's latest posthumous thriller, was quite a lad. He could ride like George A. Custer, rope like a rodeo champion, shoot like Wild Bill Hickok, and love any girl who came along so long as her name was Mary.

COWES, Isle of Wight, July 16 (UP) -- The first of the team races in the British-American Cup series for yachts of the Six-Meter International Class was won today by the British vessels with a score of 24.25 points to 12.

THE Philatelic Agency at Washington has established a new record for sales of mint stamps and stamped paper to collectors and dealers within a single fiscal year. The Postoffice Department disclosed last week that the agency's income during the twelve-month period ended on June 30 totaled $4,136,122.01.

DUMFRIES, Va. -- In early colonial days a man from this little settlement, located about thirty - five miles south of Washington on U. S. Route 1, made a trip to New York City and brought back a rather patronizing report. "New York is a growing place," he said.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 16 (AP) -- Charles Amandoles of Latourette, S. I., turned in a competitive course record in the first round of the Metropolitan Public Links championship today. His 70 strokes were two below par for the west course of the Essex County layout.

ALBANY, July 16 -- Whether teachers and other public school employes who are members of the Communist party shall be permitted to retain their jobs is a question that has been occupying the attention of the State Board of Regents for several months and particularly since July 1, when the Feinberg Act became effective.
