Despite extensive deterioration in the wheat crop since June 1, the country this year will harvest near-record grain yields. With large carryovers from previous crops, the task of handling the surpluses will be rather difficult and the Government will have to make heavy advances to the farmers to support prices.

NEWARK, N. J., July 16 -- Carl Holderman, state president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and other leaders in the group who have demanded a realignment of leadership in the Democratic party in New Jersey without former Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, were upheld today in resolutions adopted by the group's political action committee at a eeting in the Riviera Hotel here.

MOSCOW, July 16 -- A Russian clerk named Kraykuteny, in 1731, inflated a balloon with "disgusting and stinking smoke" and rose "higher than the birch," thus becoming the first balloonist, more than fifty years before the Montfolfier brothers' famous ascensions in France.

IN recent years the theatre has become so appallingly artistic that it has even achieved the dubious accolade of a Book-of-the-Month Club selection ("Death of a Salesman"). This is, of course, gratifying: but one can find among drama lovers an unfortunate substratum of low-brows, escapists and other moral lepers who feel that, while intellectual elegance is excellent, its overwhelming spread has ushered a certain old-time zest right out of the theatre.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N. J., July 16 -- Big league speed boat racing returned today to Jersey's largest inland lake for the first time since the pre-war and pre-rationing days of 1941, with a resumption of the state championships for the outboard fleet as a curtain raiser for the Gold Cup craft and other inboard classes tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Robert L. Johnson, chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report, urged passage today of a "full" military unification bill that would correct "the glaring deficiencies" of the measure now before the House of Representatives.

Four men, including a soldier on furlough, were arrested yesterday on charges of assault and robbery for mugging three men Friday night in the vicinity of St. Mary's Park, Alexander Avenue and 149th Street, the Bronx.

ROME, July 16 -- John W. Snyder, United States Secretary of the Treasury, today attended two meetings with Premier Alcide de Gasperi, five Italian Ministers and several financial experts, with whom he discussed questions relating to the European Recovery Program, President Truman's program for underdeveloped areas and Italian financial policy.

BUENOS AIRES, July 16 -- The withdrawal of the Peron regime's subsidies on basic foodstuffs has led to widespread protests over rocketing prices and a full-scale renewal of the Government's drive against speculators.

SILVER BAY, N. Y., July 16 -- Most Protestant leaders in this country are convinced that war with Russia can be avoided "without compromise of basic convictions," the Rev. Richard M. Fagley, co-secretary of the Department of International Justice and Good-will of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, said here today.

GENEVA, July 16 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, and David L. Morse, Director General of the International Labor Office, submitted an agreed recommendation to the Economic and Social Council today for establishment of a joint fact-finding commission to investigate violations of trade union rights.

In failing to provide for "national emergency" strikes in somewhat the same manner as the Taft-Hartley Act, the President headed into a veritable storm.

After only two days of what was to have been a nine-day stay the Mayor last night boarded a plane that was due at La Guardia Airport at 8:50 A. M. today.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, expressed his sympathy last week for "the emergency existing among Chinese students [in this country] and the dire straits in which many of them find themselves through no fault of their own."

LONDON, July 16 -- The weight of critical opinion today was that Sir Charles B. Cochran, grand old man of British show business, had not put up in "Tough at the Top" a serious rival to American musical comedies flourishing on London stages.

BERLIN, July 16 -- Like a man regaining the use of his legs after a grave accident and long convalescence, the people of Western Germany are moving falteringly toward a new political life. For the first time in sixteen years there is a free political campaign in Western Germany and sometime this autumn the first freely chosen democratic government since the end of the Weimar Republic will assume control of the German Federal Republic.

As department and specialty stores find it easier to hire employes trained to operate highly specialized departments, store executives predicted here last week, the number of leased departments in such stores may be consequently reduced.

INSECT photography can be a lively or a lethal affair, depending on the nature of the specimen and the temperament of the photographer. For leisurely picture - taking and carefully planned set-ups, insects have to be either killed or temporarily immobilized.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 16 -- Charges that Leonard Irving, Democratic Representative in Congress from President Truman's home district and president of the Hod Carrier's and Common Laborer's Union, has diverted the union's funds to his own use were contained in a petition for accounting filed today in the Circuit Court.

PARIS, July 16 -- Arguing that he had done his best to reduce to a minimum the German damage in France, Otto Abetz, Hitler's Ambassador during the Nazi occupation, today disclaimed responsibility for the death of former Interior Minister Georges Mandel.
SUNNY JIM FITZSIMMONS, taking his ease in the shade of a tree on the clubhouse turn at Jamaica, was asked if he could provide any details about his first day of work at a racetrack.

ONE of the few things which have survived the decline of the Socialist movement in America is the memory of the life and work of Eugene Victor Debs. He was a flaming evangelist of socialism and universal brotherhood during an ascendant phase of capitalism.

LONDON, July 16 -- Hopes of settling the dock strike, which has tied up the port of London for the last twenty days, improved today after an exhaustive six-hour meeting between the executive committees of the two striking dock unions and top officials of the Ministry of Labor.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Central Intelligence Agency reported today that at least twenty-nine representatives of foreign governments cleared for admission to this country were "high-ranking Communist party officials" presumably working "against the interests of the United States."
RICHMOND, Va., July 16 -- A feeling of cautious uncertainty, brightened by occasional touches of optimism, persists among business men in this area.

BOSTON, July 16 -- Waterfront observers are expressing concern over the Boston Fish Pier's latest work stoppage which entered the week-end with no solution in sight. More than 800 fish handlers employed by the thirty-eight member companies comprising the Massachusetts Fisheries Association were suspended last Monday in a dispute involving overtime.

EUREKA SPRINGS, Ark. -- A vacation within the reach of every pocketbook has been the rallying cry among the operators of Ozark Mountain hotels and tourist courts this year, and it has paid off with a busy season that will continue well into October.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A decade of war and post-war transition has built up throughout the country a tremendous backlog of needed public improvements that could be called upon to help absorb the shock of a serious business depression.

" PINK MAGIC" is the pretty name invented by the "I" in this story for the wiles of women -- specifically of very young women in their early teens. The engaging narrator of this love-and-adventure midsummer's tale is a girl of 16 -- 5 feet 11 inches tall, weighing 165 pounds stripped, wearing glasses, and called Lambie (short for Ursula).

A WEALTH of sprightly illustration gives the latest addition to The World In Color Series the charm and fascination of an entertaining animated cartoon. Its predecessors were "France: Paris and the Provinces" and "Great Britain: England, Scotland and Wales."
HOLLYWOOD. THE fire that swept the back lot at Universal-International left thirty years of movie memories in ashes when it burned the saloon on the oldest Western street in Hollywood on June 22.

LONDON, July 16 -- Aggravation of an old digestive ailment will force Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, to enter a Swiss clinic for about six weeks of special treatment, it was announced tonight from 10 Downing Street, Prime Minister Attlee's residence.
CANTON, China, July 16 -- The Nationalist Government established a Supreme Council today to direct the fight against the Chinese Communists under the leadership of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

In many ways the Roman Catholic Church and the members of the religious bodies internationally organized under the title of The World Council of Churches are in disagreement. The schism which produced Protestantism is four centuries old; that which created the Greek Orthodox Church is older still.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Army suspended two major generals today on suspicion of improper conduct in the awarding of military contracts.

ALBERT SCHWEITZER, the 74-year-old Alsatian philosopher, missionary, doctor, writer and musician, is, first of all, very large, very bulky, almost cumbersome in physique. His mustachios are dense and enormous. His head is bold and granitic, his eyes are, in context, small and of a gentle intelligence.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -Miss Dorothy Head of Wilmington, Del., gained the final of the women's Middle States tennis championships today at the Cricket Club, St. Martins, by defeating Miss Sylvia Knowles, Newport, R. I., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The "welfare offensive" -- the drive for pensions, greater security and higher wages -- by the major unions of America's mass-production industries centered this week on two fronts -- steel and automobiles.

Last week Harrison Salisbury, this newspaper's Moscow correspondent, cabled the news that the Soviet Acadedy of Sciences had rejected the closed but expanding universe of the relativists and the Western-conception of the origin of the solar system. The decision was accompanied by the usual blast against bourgeois science.
REHOVOTH, Israel, July 16 -Resettlement of the Arab refugees under a comprehensive plan of rehabilitation was advocated today by President Chaim Weizmann, who will leave soon for Switzerland.

The influx of veterans into the nation's system of higher education has about ended. When the colleges and universities reopen in September, fewer than ten in one hundred of the freshmen will be veterans; two years ago it was not unusual to find anywhere from 75 to 90 per cent of the male student body composed of veterans.

THE Negro problem has not been exhausted as a film subject despite the emergence of two fine treatments and three more pictures in prospect. Last week John Wexley told this corner that his noted drama, "They Shall Not Die," inspired by the Scottsboro casc, which the

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y, July 16 -- American public schools should be open all year, with teachers receiving a month's vacation, prominent educators proposed here today. They recommended that all children receive a month's free camping and that more emphasis be placed on professional upgrading of teachers during the summer.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 16 -- Construction of a new six-lane Atlantic Beach Bridge to end one of the worst bottlenecks for traffic bound for the South Shore of Long Island will be started this fall, it was disclosed today.

International attention in the world of speed boating will center this week and next on Detroit where after a lapse of sixteen years competition will be resumed for the British International Trophy, better known as the Harmsworth event.

An unusual Biedermeier pianoforte, several Biedermeier desks, chairs and settees will be included in an auction sale on Thursday at the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street. The sale begins at 11 A. M.
HONOLULU, July 16 (AP) -- Six more contestants in the transpacific yacht race rounded Molokai Island today and headed for the Diamond Head finish line.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 16 -- Lord Mayor Ernst Reuter of Berlin appealed today to the military governors of the three Western zones to do something about assuring greater access to and from the former capital from Western Germany through the Soviet zone.

A SURVEY of shipping lines here last week disclosed that late-summer travelers to Europe will find ample space becoming available in first-class accommodations in the middle of August. Cabin-class space is expected to begin easing up from the early summer peak travel period late in August.
Several groups of Organized Marine Corps Reservists left from New York yesterday for maneuvers at Southern camps and flight training at air stations
Maritime labor representatives urged the United States Maritime Commission last week to deny permission for any steamship company to absorb extra insurance costs in its freight rates.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 16 -Circuit Judge George L. Bailes said today that as a matter of law the request of the grand jury investigating mob violence in this area that it be examined as to fitness could not be permitted. He said that the "screening" of the grand jurors was officially completed when the jury was organized.

THE scheduled domestic and international airlines of the United States have passed the mid-year mark of what promises to be one of the best years for traffic and revenue in their history. There is even a good possibility that it may be the best year they have ever had.

The award of the Euretta J. Kellett Fellowships to Bernard W. Wishy, 24 years old, of 373 Riverside Drive, and James M. Zito, 24, of 230 Sixth Avenue, Newark, N. J., was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean of Columbia College.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 16 (UP) -The Inter-American Press Congress voted today to request the Governments of American republics that have closed newspapers to "afford ample guarantees for their reappearance."
PALOMAR OBSERVATORY, Calif., July 16 (AP) -- A huge new telescope known as the 48-inch Schmidt begins mapping the universe Tuesday night.

JAMES P. WARBURG is an indefatigable exponent of the tradition that the prerequisite of peace is an "informed, alert and articulate public opinion." In this latest of his volumes of American foreign policy (his fifth since the war), he conducts a sort of one-man institute of international relations.

WAYNE TOWNSHIP, N. J., July 16 -- Emery Thomas, Forest Hill Field Club professional, won the twenty-ninth open championship of the New Jersey State Golf Association by four shots today by scoring a seven-under-par 277 at the North Jersey Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Adolf Hitler was receiving conflicting estimates, through the German Foreign Office, of opinion and reactions in the United States during the crucial months leading up to the invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1939, it was revealed in a publication of captured German state papers made public today by the State Department.
LONDON, July 16 -- Prospects for an Austrian treaty seem brighter now than they have since the four-power talks first began two years -- and 175 meetings -ago.

The recent public controversy between a Maryland legislator and the Harvard authorities over the alleged disloyalty of certain Harvard professors emphasizes an issue of national importance. The problem is how to minimize the internal menace of communism by new laws, practices and arrangements without unduly impairing individual freedom of expression.

A NINE-WEEK motor tour through France, Italy, Switzerland, Belgium and Holland has sold us completely on the advantages of European travel by car. We covered 4,400 miles at a cost of $230, or a little more than 5 cents a mile.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 16 -Putting with an expert touch, Frank Strafaci of Pomonok gained the final of the Long Island amateur golf championship today and will make a bid for his fourth title in this tourney when he meets James Paul of Piping Rock tomorrow over the Meadow Brook Club course.

LOUIS B. MAYER, head of the MGM studio, who normally avoids the press, last week issued a statement to a Hollywood trade paper attacking producers who make pictures bordering "on the obscene" under the guise of telling "real life stories" or of delivering "so-called messages."

MARGUERITE CLARK, medical editor of Newsweek, has accomplished two difficult objectives in "Medicine on the March." The first is the excellent documentation of the scientific and medical advances made during the past few years.

FICTION emanating from the Mediterranean has included some of our most vivid war writing. Anyone venturing into that ancient sea must be measured against John Hersey, John Horne Burns and Alfred Hayes. Too bad for Martin Quigley, author of this feeble novel, which unpardonably reads as if it were pieced together from V-mail letters somebody saved.

In a drive to combat the high rate of foot disease and deformity now said to afflict 80 per cent of all Americans old enough to vote, public school authorities, podiatrists and various civic groups will start this fall the first comprehensive foot-health program ever undertaken among school children throughout New York State.

President Truman's announcement that he will not insist upon tax increases should help to clarify the Administration's attitude toward business. There is no doubt but that his persistent demands for more taxes have been a disturbing influence not only upon those contemplating expansion of production but on those awaiting an opportunity to invest profitably in new enterprise.

THE Linhof Technika III 4x5 camera will soon be available without lenses or range finder at $325, according to Burleigh Brooks, Inc., importers. The camera is now sold at $550, complete with coupled range finder and two lenses, the 15cm Schneider Xenar f/4.5 in Compur A shutter and the 9cm Schneider Angulon f/6.8 lens in Compur delayed-action shutter.
Last week's debate on the North Atlantic pact often was couched in the unrealities of a "never-never land" of the Senate's own creation.

Favored by abundant June rains, grain harvest prospects in the Ukraine and adjacent areas in the Soviet Union appear bright, according to reports in Soviet newspapers that have arrived in this country recently.

BERLIN, July 16 (AP) -- A New York soldier who says he was held, questioned and mistreated for months in the Russian zone of Germany will be treated for malnutrition and then tried for having been absent without leave, United States authoriies said tonight.

THIS book is a primer in foreign relations. It aims to describe and define the influences that shape a nation's foreign policy and to delineate the methods by which the foreign policy is executed. It devotes considerable space to the structure of the foreign-policy agencies in four countries: the United States, the U.S.S.R., Great Britain and France.

IN a slender volume of fewer than a hundred pages is revealed a clear picture of one of the most attractive personalities in American education. The background of the portrait is painted in the two gracious encomia by District Attorney Hogan and former Ambassador Carlton J. H. Hayes; the man depicts himself in his eighteen short talks to students, alumni and colleagues during his three years as acting president of Columbia.

IT is a curious phenomenon that out of the plethora of literature on Ireland, no social history with a large perspective, no psychological study of the people, had been written until with this book Mr. Sean O'Faolain started to fill the gap. To help him write "The Irish," which he describes as "a creative history of the growth of a racial mind," O'Faolain could find only two "civilized" books.

DETROIT, July 16 (UP) -- The automobile industry is puzzling over what is keeping the new car market at dizzying heights when some other industries have hit a slide. All major makers and most of the independent companies are shoving production schedules higher and higher to meet the demand for cars.

ROME, July 16 -- The decision of the Congregation of the Holy Office to excommunicate all those Catholics who "knowingly and of their free will" remain in the Communist party and in any manner or form support and disseminate Communist doctrine brings into sharp focus irreconcilable differences between communism and catholicism. More than that, it is designed to mobilize all Catholics throughout the world against what the Vatican considers the arch foe of the Church.

A change in the admission policy of Washington and Jefferson College. Washington, Pa., will now permit consideration of applicants on the basis of their secondary school records. Two years ago the institution adopted a policy requiring all applicants to take the College Entrance Board's scholastic-aptitude test. Now, tile college says, "it is felt that entrance examinations cause undue delay in acting upon applications for admission.
Mayor O'Dwyer's decision yesterday to cut short his vacation in Mexico because of the bus strike marked the seventh time that he has been forced to curtail his holidays.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, outlined today the assistance available to farmers under the Housing Act signed by President Truman yesterday.

THERE'S a certain amount of censorship going on in television. It's aimed at laundering the children's classic fairy tales which border on brutality. When it comes to presenting some of the folk legends in visual form, considerable revamping often is necessary before a seal of approval can be gained from modern child psychologists.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 16 -- Whether the famous old stone tower here was of Colonial origin or earlier will be determined this fall, William S. Godfrey Jr., Harvard archeologist, who is on his second summer of excavation here, said today.
MOZART wrote the six quartets dedicated to Haydn in his late twenties, while Beethoven composed the six in his Op. 18 in his early thirties.

IN his first script for radio in two years, Norman Corwin last Sunday offered over CBS a documentary which focused some long overdue attention on the less publicized functions of the United Nations. With Lee J. Cobb giving a superb reading in the role of the narrator, the broadcast, entitled "Citizen of the World." stood out as a generally restrained plea for the individual's active interest in solving the problems of the world.

Chiang Kai-shek has stated that Nationalist China, the Republic of Korea and the Philippines are going forward with a pact in Asia for opposition to the Communist advance. This agreement does not have great military significance at this stage, but it does have moral importance.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -Third baseman Willie Jones made three of the seven hits the Phils got off Harry Brecheen today as the Phils defeated the Cards, 4 to 2. One of Jones' hits was a home run and the others were singles.

COMMERCIAL aviation suffered the most costly and tragic single day in its history last Tuesday when two air transports half a world apart crashed and killed a total of eighty passengers and crew members. The first and bigger of the two accidents happened near Bombay.

The decision by the Administration not to increase corporate taxes this year is resulting in a revival of a number of deferred industrial construction programs, it was disclosed here yesterday by Guy B. Panero, head of the Guy B. Panero engineering concern at 420 Lexington Avenue.

OUT of the combination of late Hammett, middle Hemingway, a routine smuggling plot, copious slugs of symbolism and a vivid Mexican background, Mr. Phillips has managed to contrive a singularly baffling book, in which the one great mystery is the author's intent.

THIS is a good-natured, rambling and quite personal book about an interesting writer. Mr. Walsh has read his bibliography, talked with his hero and made up his own mind. No better formula for carrying out a task of this sort has been devised.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- While Congress is still toiling over six major appropriations bills for the fiscal year that began two weeks ago, the executive departments in question have been doing business just as though there were nothing unusual in the situation.

SHANGHAI, July 16 -- Censorship regulations for the foreign press and radio were promulgated today by the Shanghai Military Control Commission to protect "the security of people's lives and property" and to prevent "military sabotage by imperialists and Kuomintang remnants" during the present control period.

THE repertory for the second annual American Dance Festival, to be held at Connecticut College, New London, from Aug. 12 through Aug. 21, has undergone several alterations since it was originally announced back in March.

AN examination of the state of the Hollywood film industry will be offered by the CBS network in a series of five consecutive broadcasts, starting on Monday, July 25. To be presented at 6:15 P. M., Monday through Friday, the series will follow this schedule:

HEADLIGHT glare and "one-eyed" cars together are factors causing 60 per cent of the automobile accidents that occur at night. With 1,700,000 automobiles on the highways that are more than seventeen years old and more than 13,000,000 vehicles past the ten-year mark, vacation motorists are warned by the National Safety Council and the American Automobile Association to give particular attention to the illumination systems of their cars.

How good is your memory? Banks here are in the process of paying out money to those who remember well. They have started another campaign to find depositors, or their kin, who have left deposits in their banks undisturbed for many years.

New York is building on a grand scale unequaled since the Nineteen Twenties. In all parts of the city whole blocks of shabby buildings are being ripped down, and great excavations are being dug in the soil and blasted into the rock. On these sites are rising -- or soon will rise -- huge frameworks of steel and stone, wire and concrete.
LONDON, July 16 -- The British crisis has given impetus to the most thorough reassessment of Europe's economic prospects witnessed since the war.

Buyers of ready-to-wear and soft lines here last week were more liberal in their commitments on fall requirements compared with previous weeks, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

The investigation of murder in Texas, according to this report, must be peculiarly difficult; the nicest people are apt to show up in your hotel room to draw a bead on you, or to confuse a murder situation by firing shots in the air just for the fun of it.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Internal Revenue Bureau is getting stricter than ever about collecting income taxes from prize winners. Today the bureau said that, from now on, winners of an essay prize awarded by the American Bar Association would have to pay a tax on the amount received.

GERMANDER, or Teucrium chamaedrys, is an attractive edging plant that is hardy and pest-free, and remains evergreen even during the winter months. It has all the attributes of boxwood as an edger, but is infinitely easier to grow and survives our severe Northern winters.

The strongest team that the professional American Soccer League can assemble will line up against the Milano eleven from Italy at Randalls Island today starting at 3 o'clock. The contest, third of the visitors' four-game tour of North America, will be the last one in the metropolitan area.

Before the war we were worried by a birth rate that had steadily declined from 1915 to 1936. By 1947 nearly all the ground lost in the preceding twenty years had been regained. If this upward trend continues the population will increase by over 45 per cent in a generation. But will it continue?
The rivalry of public power projects appears to have had a salutary "big stick" effect on the private electric utilities.

MILWAUKEE, July 16 -- Taking up the role of field general in the 1949 campaign of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in its drive for increased wages and employer-financed social benefits, Walter P. Reuther gave his aides a final briefing today before his return to his headquarters in Detroit. There he will direct the strategy against the Ford Motor Company.

THE old rule regarding glass houses and the peril of throwing stones in the vicinity of same is one which the Warner Brothers have apparently overlooked in their fantastic motion-picture version of Ayn Rand's "The Fountainhead."

THE public seems to believe, and perhaps rightfully, that the owner of a work of art has a moral obligation to exhibit it. The tenant of a spectacular modern house by a "name" architect has a devilish time maintaining his privacy.

IT'S a neat trick to pick the title of your novel from the writings of one of its characters. Miss Osborne has done just this. "It is such a little voyage to love, but a dangerous one" is from the pen of Stephen Brent, as supercilious and egotistical a novelist as you're likely to meet in a day's journey -- and Honduras, where you do meet him, must be farther away than that.

Several hours after he had been carried off in a stolen automobile, 4-year-old James Francis Quinn was found asleep and unharmed yesterday morning in the car in which he disappeared. The automobile was found abandoned at Rockaway and Van Wyck Boulevards, South Ozone Park, Queens.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 16 -- Assembled from the waters of five coastal states, sail-racing skippers and crews gathered here today for the opening regatta of the fifty-first annual race week at the Larchmont Yacht Club. There were 310 starting craft, with between twelve and fourteeen hundred sailors and sailorettes manning them.

ON July 28 on Chincoteague Island, off the eastern shore of Virginia, the unique wild pony auction which annually attracts hundreds of bidders is scheduled to take place. The Chincoteague wild pony lives and breeds in the marshlands abutting Chincoteague Inlet.

Upon the willingness and ability of the United States to develop an import surplus depends eventual solution of the problem of the foreign trade gap, according to the conclusions of a study completed yesterday by a group of Tufts College economists for the National Association of Manufacturers.

ONE is in receipt of the Broude Brothers edition of forty-one of the fifty-odd symphonies Mozart is known to have written, though some of them never reached publication. This edition was begun some three years ago and completed last year.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 16 -- Medalists Joseph G. Davis and his guest from Garden City, Richard Remsen, won their opening match of the Greenwich Country Club's tenth annual member-guest golf tournament today, but one of the other favored teams fell by the wayside.
LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- There are indications in the Pacific Southwest of considerably more assurance now about business conditions than existed last spring.
CLEVELAND, July 16 -- Senator Robert A. Taft's attack on the North Atlantic pact has his Ohio political foes chuckling with glee.

NEW DELHI, India, July 16 -- Investigation of the Dutch KLM Constellation's crash near Bombay last Tuesday in which thirteen United States correspondents lost their lives will begin formally early next week in Bombay.

WITH the accurate observation that too much bad food is dished up in the name of sea-air hunger the authors of this tight and ship-shape guide to eating afloat have pointed the way to everything from how properly to fry an egg to the preparation of some fairly elaborate small-boat menus.
CHICAGO, July 16 -- A brown streak named Wisconsin Boy sizzled to a surprising seven and one-half length victory today in the $74,975 Arlington Futurity at Arlington Park.

EGYPT'S motion picture industry, which produces in Arabic some fifty films annually, plans to release English and French versions of a few films in the international market. Efforts are also being made to procure contracts for production here of more films by European companies.

Clerical aptitude and performance tests are being used by an increasing number of business organizations to reduce the high replacement costs for female office employes, Charles B. Haverin, first vice president of the Office Executives Association of New York, declared in an interview last week.

The disclosure late last week that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is considering competitive bidding for the sale of its next bond issue has resulted already in active discussions among investment underwriters seeking to form groups to submit bids, when, as, and if it is offered, it was learned yesterday.

The New Statesman and Nation, Great Britain's left-wing Labor weekly, noted in a recent article: "Nowadays a good Chancellor of the Exchequer must be unpopular." Britain's present Chancellor of the Exchequer, and also her Minister of Economic Affairs, is Sir Stafford Cripps.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -The metal mining industry will have to get Government help if it is to remain alive, Congress was told today.

Representatives of the 400 alumni of the University of Denver from New York and three adjacent states attended a reception yesterday to Albert C. Jacobs, provost of Columbia University, who is to become chancellor of the Western institution in the fall.

Walker Cooper's second homer of the game, hit with one on in the tenth inning, lifted the Reds to a 7-6 victory over the Dodgers yesterday. Scoring four runs in the first, the Browns halted the Yankees, 4 -- 2, in a contest curtailed by rain to five and one-half frames.
DETROIT, July 16 (AP) -- Four home runs and Mel Parnell's four-hit pitching enabled the Red Sox to humble the Tigers, 11 to 1, today.

Ten home runs splattered over the Polo Grounds yesterday. Four doubles and a triple added to the general excitement. But not enough of the commotion was created by the Giants, with the result that a gathering of 20,001 saw Leo Durocher's band thrust aside in both ends of a double-header with Billy Meyer's Pirates.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A bill to prohibit Justices of the United States Supreme Court from appearing as character witnesses in any action in any court in the country will be introduced Monday by Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican, of New York.

MISS FOLEY'S annual prodigious labor in combing the magazines for outstanding American stories is again rewarded in a volume that should please most tastes. As usual, it serves to draw attention to new talents, and Miss Foley is especially struck by the fact that for the first time in our literary history short-story writers are appearing in large numbers on American campuses.

The total number of church members in the United States is computed at 77,000,000 in the Yearbook of American Churches, published last Friday under auspices of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.

A petition for rehearsing of the adverse decision on the National Maritime Union's use of hiring halls on the Great Lakes has been filed with the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, it was made known yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- A strong buying movement in rye, carrying that grain up more than 8 cents a bushel at one time, featured dealings on the Board of Trade today. Soybeans also spurted, jumping about 5 cents at times.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 16 -Conversations with businessmen and industrialists in the Mountain States reflect a rising optimism concerning the region's economic prospects. But this feeling is based on the recent slow rise in the price of metals, rather than on the Administration's statements concerning the economic health of the nation.

The most disturbing domestic question before the nation in recent weeks has been this: Is America facing major recession? Last week there were developments, which, if they did not provide a complete answer to the question, at least shed strong light on the problem involved.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A fight shaping up to force Congress to quit July 31, as the law says, may be lost before it starts -- because of a legal technicality.
LONDON, July 17 -- Two attempts by the London dockers to extend the three-week-old strike involving 14,600 men were defeated today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -Members of Congress reported today a mounting volume of mail calling for changes in the fifteen-year-old law providing for insurance of bank deposits. Two main themes were being sounded:

Overshadowed for the moment by more dramatic world events, an election campaign is getting under way in Germany which is bound to have repercussions far beyond that country and poses many delicate problems for both the Germans and the Western Powers.

Another book about Germany by another of our "top brass" has been scheduled for publication early next year by Doubleday. It is "Decision in Germany," by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, who for four years was American Military Governor of Germany.

Price has proved no barrier to fashion in the New York Dress Institute's fall collection of fashions to retail under $25. In its recent showing the velvet trims, the pockets, panels, profuse use of buttons and the smart coat types -- all leading trends of the season -- lent their importance to modestly priced but chicly designed autumn dresses.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17 -- Twelve members of the Syrian Popular party, whose Fascist-oriented leader, Anton Saadeh, was executed a week ago Friday, were condemned to death late last night by a military tribunal following a mass trial of sixty-seven held for having taken part in the party's recent armed rebellion.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 17 -- Israel indicated to the world today that, despite a hard war and current economic problems, she was still able to offer the pomp and ceremony that any normal nation would expect on the anniversary of Army Day.

Mayor O'Dwyer's swift return from his Mexican vacation has had its effects. TWU President Michael J. Quill has decided not to call a strike on the Third Avenue Transit System. This is taken also to mean that he will not ask for "supporting action" from the subway and bus workers employed by the Board of Transportation.
Clarence Derwent, president of Actors Equity Association and a British subject, was detained without explanation for six hours yesterday at La Guardia Airport by immigration authorities.

Civilization can no longer tolerate the institution of war and the setting apart of people because of differences in race, the Rev. Dr. John M. Pearson, former superintendent of the New York Methodist District, declared yesterday morning at St. Mark's Methodist Church, 137th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, a leader in the economy forces of Congress, today branded President Truman's economic advisers as a "strange group of men" whose "fanciful ideas" should be investigated by Congress.

The betting was ten-to-one the Giants and Cardinals wouldn't get their double-header started at the Polo Grounds yesterday. But they got in one game and Eddie Dyer's band crushed the proteges of Leo Durocher by a count of 10 to 1.
DUBLIN, July 17 (UP) -- Anti-Communist Irishmen beat up several alleged Communists today and tried to throw them into the rain-swollen Liffey River before club-swinging police dispersed them.

Quiet settled on the foreign exchanges last week and for the first time in months the market shook off the nervousness which had the probable devaluation of the pound sterling as the motivating agent. Business was in good volume, influencing a general upward movement of rates.

Fall coats and suits were reordered in the wholesale apparel market here last week, and some coat buyers in the market devoted almost half their budgets to fur-trimmed coats, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
PINE CAMP, N. Y., July 17 (AP) -- Eighty-five hundred New Jersey National Guardsmen and organized reserve units moved into Pine Camp today to begin two weeks of training.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- Production men in the steel mills who are responsible for actual operations had one of the toughest times of their careers last week. They did not know what to take off in the way of furnaces or what to keep on, but at the week-end they were back where they started before talk of a strike began.

SARAFAND, Israel, July 9 -- The Israeli Government is fast approaching a crisis in its immigration problem, but it is a problem the Government believes it can handle if it gets sufficient time and money, and obtains cooperation from those for whom it is endeavoring to provide sanctuary.

For antiquarians, historians, restaurant-goers and others, it's not the same this summer in Riverside Park. That once lovely landmark, Claremont Inn, is boarded up and neglected by the city fathers as it suffers fallen arches and other infirmities of age.

In its first change of ownership in more than fifty years, the three-story dwelling on a lot 20 by 102.2 feet at 129 East Eightieth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, was sold by Irving Levy to Michael C. Berg in a deal negotiated by L. J. Phillips Co., Brokers.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, declared today he was in "complete accord" with the proposal to make his agency a full-fledged department but said he was "unalterably opposed" to taking the Public Health Service away from it.

SILVER BAY, N. Y., July 17 -- A proposal that the major Protestant missionary agencies join forces to send a fact-finding commission of high ranking church leaders to Indonesia was made here today by the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, president of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary, New Brunswick, N. J.

American Quakers urged the United States yesterday to take a bold initiative toward a time-table agreement with the Soviet Union by dropping the barriers to East-West trade, setting up a unified "neutral" Germany and placing the atomic bomb stockpile under United Nations seal.

The Chinese Communists, after a somewhat faltering start, are beginning to put on the pressure in Shanghai. The censorship is now being tightened and foreigners are feeling the need to get out. Thus another illusion is being shattered. Obviously there will not be "business as usual."

Congratulations on your excellent editorial, "A Civil Rights Commission," which appeared in THE TIMES of July 13. THE TIMES' stand in favor of such a commission comes as a sign of hope to the many who have been disheartened by the civil rights setbacks in this session of Congress. Your presentation of the case was sound, clear, direct.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 -- Juvenile delinquency in this city has reached a post-war low, Municipal Court Judge Nochem S. Winnet, chairman of the Crime Prevention Association and the Community Chest, disclosed in a special joint report.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- North American wheat crop prospects have suffered serious deterioration in the last six weeks. What promised to be a near record yield has gone glimmering. Reports last week suggested that a further downward revision in both the United States and Canadian yields would be necessary as the result of dry weather in parts of the Dakotas, Montana, Alberta and Saskatchewan.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Nothing has occurred so far this month to mar the outlook for a near-record corn crop, and some experts express the belief that if there is an ample supply of moisture and no hot winds the final yield may exceed the mark of 3,650,000,000 bushels harvested last year.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 17 -- Legal preparations were being completed today in a case that is designed to call on the United States Supreme Court to determine whether an organized Ku Klux Klan must produce its membership lists on demand of public officials.

The Public Service Commission, recognized as pace-setter among the nation's state regulatory agencies, will present to Governor Dewey and the Legislature this morning its 280-page annual report which shows that increases in rates amounting to almost $44,000,000 were granted to utilities in this state last year.

Expansion of the ring manufacturing concern of J. R. Wood Sons, Inc., of 216 East Forty-fifth Street, has resulted in the company's becoming "roughly $10,000 richer" with the sweeping up of "lost" gold dust from nooks and corners that previously had been inaccessible.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican, of New York, said today he was sorry so much ruckus was raised over a post he never sought on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

OMAHA, Neb., July 17 -- The national speed championship at chess changed hands today when, in the eighth annual series for that distinction, George Kramer of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, the 1945 State titleholder emerged the winner in a field of forty-two players.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The Great Lakes, second only to the railroads in the country's transportation system, are becoming an increasingly busy inland waterway in the highly industrialized section of the Middle West, a survey disclosed today.

PARIS, July 17 -- Because of a sharp increase in exports, France in the first six months of this year was able to cover 69 per cent of her imports, compared with 51 per cent last year, according to customs figures issued here today.

SHANGHAI, July 17 -- The technicality of "shop guarantees" was reported today to be temporarily delaying the homeward flight from Nanking of the United States Ambassador, Dr. J. Leighton Stuart, and his party, including John M. Cabot, Consul General in Shanghai.

Unarmed and unaided, a former All-Southern Conference star fullback captured two burglars, one of them a prize fighter, outside the office of his automobile accessory business in the Bronx on Friday night.

HONOLULU, July 17 (UP) -- Gov. Ingram Stainback reported increasing support today for his plan to impose permanent Government control over Hawaii's docks. There were indications that the idea was distasteful to both the stevedoring companies and the striking longshoremen.

ALBANY, July 17 -- State Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh, reported today that a state-wide survey revealed that many communities in the state were developing a balanced technique for dealing with old-age problems.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Claims for unemployment insurance fell during the week ended July 9, "largely" because of the July 4 holiday, the Bureau of Employment Security reported today.

PARIS, July 17 -- International press transmission rates were debated today by members of the Telegraph Tariff Committee of the International Telegraph and Telephone Conference, which has been in session here since May 18. The decisions, some of which will increase, and others decrease, press rates, become effective July 1, 1950, unless reversed by a plenary session to be held later in the month.

The closing on Saturday night of the comedies "At War With the Army" and "Two Blind Mice" reduces to thirteen the number of productions now offered on Broadway -- a new low for recent years. Last season at this time there were sixteen attractions on local stages; in 1947 there were nineteen and in 1946 twenty-two shows were doing business in mid-July.
TAVARES, Fla., July 17 (AP) -- A Florida sheriff told today of "talking pretty fast" to disperse a mob of about 100 armed men who came to take two Negroes from his jail.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 17 -- Foreign observers here remarked today upon the inconclusive state of Yugoslavia's negotiations with Western Governments, banks and private corporations for economic and financial assistance to overcome the effects of the blockade by the Communist Information Bureau.

The Block Drug Company of Jersey City will spend more than $1,000,000 in the next six weeks to introduce its Amm-i-dent toothpaste, it was announced by the company in a statement released for publication today. Like Ammi-dent toothpowder, which the Block company introduced earlier this year, the toothpaste conrains ammonia-releasing ingredients which are claimed to help prevent tooth decay.

Outstanding work in research and development by officers of both the Air Force and the Navy are recognized by awards for 1949 made public by the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences. The Thurman H. Bane Award, which goes to an officer or civilian of the Air Materiel Command for "an outstanding achievement in aeronautical development," is awarded this year to Capt. Harold W. Robbins for his contributions to jet-assisted take-off for cargo aircraft.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP) -- Lefty Kent Paterson hurled the Cincinnati Reds to a 3-2 nightcap victory to give them an even break with the Boston Braves today before 18,560 fans. The Tribesmen pulled out a 5-4 decision in the opening game when Eddie Sauer drove in Eddie Stanky with two out in the ninth inning.

Contortions should not be necessary to pick up a water pitcher, and a streamlined cover should not be put on a pencil-sharpener that was never meant to fly through the air. These were two conclusions about the function of art that won complete agreement yesterday among the eighty delegates to the third annual summer conference of the Committee on Art Education at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

BERLIN, July 17 -- In an impressive show of Roman Catholic faith, an estimated 40,000 Berliners attended today an outdoor pontifical mass celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of Pope Pius' priesthood. The Pope addressed the faithful by radio from the Vatican.
BERLIN, July 17 (AP) -- The leading Communist newspaper in Eastern Germany denounced Lutheran Bishop Otto Dibelius of Berlin today. It called him a warmonger and an instrument of American aggression.

Twenty - eight recommendations intended to bring about an ordered, economical development of governmental statistical activities are presented in a report by the National Bureau of Economic Research, released for publication today.
This is a bird of a story about two blue jays, and Max Rosenberg, a printer, is the authority. In between deep yawns from lack of sleep, Mr. Rosenberg yesterday morning related these facts:

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- The Pirates gained a 2-to-1 victory over the Phillies today in the first game of a scheduled double-header called at the end of five innings. The nightcap was postponed because of rain.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The Yankees spent a long and arduous afternoon today alternately pleasing and displeasing a crowd of 41,727 onlookers and wound up accomplishing very little. For by splitting a twin bill with Jack Onslow's obstreperous White Sox the Bombers blew a fine chance to open a little more distance between themselves and their panting pursuers.

Completion of arrangements for one of the largest single air-freight shipments to be flown here from Europe -- fifteen tons of fine woolens and worsteds made in Italy -was announced at the week-end by Seaboard Western Airlines, Inc.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 17 (AP) -- CIO United Steelworkers at four Timken Roller Bearing Company plants in Ohio accepted today the concern's offer of a new one-year contract, Harry Mayfield, president of the Columbus local, announced.

The distinguished vintner of California, Herman Wente, departed for Europe yesterday for a six-week tour through the wine country. He has to be back by the last of August, when the grape-pressing starts on the West Coast. Asked about the weather out there in relation to the current crop, he said it was too early to tell; next month is the one that counts.

The proposed amendments to the city's zoning laws approved last week by the City Planning Commission to ease future procedure for constructing parking garages were assailed yesterday by Harris H. Murdock, chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, as "a clear violation of the city's charter."
Five new films, including imports from France and Italy, are scheduled to open in first-run theatres this week. They are:
Norman K. Van Derzee has been appointed vice president in charge of sales for the Hudson Motor Car Company, Detroit. He succeeds the late George H. Pratt.

For the first time podiatrists can measure precisely any harmful distribution of body weight on weak or disabled feet, 400 delegates from Eastern states to the fifty-third annual conference of the New York State Podiatry Society were told yesterday.

A resolution calling for restored civil liberties for members of the Socialist Workers party, a Trotskyite organization, was decisively rejected yesterday by 800 delegates to a Bill of Rights Conference at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- The purchase of screen rights to "Detective Story," Sidney Kingsley's current Broadway play about a Manhattan policeman, was announced this week-end by Paramount. Henry Ginsberg, vice president in charge of production, closed the deal by telephone on Friday, following his return from New York earlier in the week, but the studio refused to divulge the price to be paid.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 17 -- Taking a real soaking, not only on the chin but from scalps to foot soles, the crews of 284 craft today went through the second session of race week at the Larchmont Yacht Club. The water came both from the skies above and salt splash underneath.

The growth of foreign merchant fleets and their increased competition, combined with a leveling off of United States foreign trade, have had little effect on the size of the active privately owned merchant marine, the National Federation of American Shipping, Inc., reported yesterday.
GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 17 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny, the man without a country, today won and lost in the finals of the Swiss tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- The CIO News said today that President Truman's successful effort to avert a steel strike "demonstrated that it's not necessary for the Government to 'crack down' with an injunction when somebody starts shouting 'national emergency.'"

LOS ANGELES, July 17 -- The University of California at Los Angeles said in a press release today that a simple, quick and inexpensive method for measuring the growth or decline of cancer had been developed by two members of the staff of its medical school, Dr. Philip M. West and Dr. Jessamine Hilliard.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 17 -- Frank Strafaci of Pomonok regained the Long Island amateur golf title today at the Meadow Brook Club by turning back James Paul of Piping Rock, 7 and 5, in the 36-hole final staged amid an intermittent drizzle.

DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers swept a double-header with the Philadelphia Athletics today, Paul Campbell's eleventh inning single winning the nightcap, 5 to 4, after Ted Gray had pitched an 8-to-0 victory in the opener.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N. J., July 17 -- Two of the country's most spectacular top-flight speed boat pilots who have been fairly itching for a match race, finally came together this wet, rainy, rough afternoon and after three heats totaling 30 miles for the Governor s Trophy, it was Harry Lynn in his La-Ha-La who took the honors, leaving Guy Lombardo in his Tempo VI the runner-up.

The eighty-two-ton Navy flying boat Caroline Mars bobbed gracefully on the waters of Jamaica Bay as a motor launch approached. Seconds later the launch's passengers -- sixteen teachers, including three women -- climbed agilely up the gangplank and scrambled into the hull of the big plane.

The year's first shipment of coca leaves, from which the drug cocaine is made, arrived here yesterday aboard the Grace Line's Santa Elisa. The shipment weighed forty-six tons and was one of the largest ever carried at one time, company officials said.

ROME, July 17 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Italian Communist leader, accused the Roman Catholic Church today of having failed "to secure justice." He said the Communist party would continue to defend the rights of oppressed people despite the threats of excommunication, "in which no one believes any more."
PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- The Middle States (Philadelphia) squad defeated the Eastern Association (New York area), 5 -- 4, today in a junior Wightman Cup tennis match for girls up to 21 years.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 17 -- Roman Catholic priests in many churches throughout Czechoslovakia read today a declaration affirming loyalty to "our beloved Archbishop Dr. Beran and all Czechoslovak Bishops" and asserting that most of the priests' signatures endorsing the Government's "Catholic Action" movement had been obtained "by cunning, by pressure and by fraud."

BERLIN, July 17 -- One tangible result of the "cold war," the blockade of Berlin and the resulting airlift, would seem to be a development of a distinctly new relationship between the Western occupying powers and the people of this traditional citadel of Prussianism.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Studies made by the Navy from the firing of two high - altitude rockets have revealed that scientists had greatly underestimated cosmic ray impact in the region above the earth's equator.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period July 9 to 15 are given in the following tabulation:

A "healthy tanned body" without "a healthy grace-filled soul is nothing more than a beautifully embalmed corpse," the Rev. William T. Greene said yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, in warning vacationists that they must never take "a vacation from God."

LOS ANGELES, July 17 -- By a vote of 407 to 29, the International Association of Machinists, District 720, was authorized today to call a strike of the organization's 4,500 members in the El Segundo plant of the Douglas Aircraft Company.

After the labor unions succeeded in restricting immigration there was a flowering of invention. With the supply of cheap foreign labor virtually cut off we saw the introduction of machines that would dig a trench for an oil pipeline across half the continent, of others that would unload 10,000 tons of ore in a few hours and thus do away with the wheelbarrow.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July l7 -- German reaction to the financial difficulties of Britain has disclosed hope that Allied Military Government policies regarding plant dismantling and other economic restrictions in Germany will be modified.

The nation's steel companies notified President Truman on Friday that, in accordance with his suggestion, they would submit their side of the current dispute with labor over wages and pensions to a fact-finding board of his choosing.

HONOLULU, July 17 (UP) -- The 46-foot sloop Kitten appeared the probable winner of the trans-Pacific race today as six boats streamed past Diamond Head during the night to bring the number of finishers to eleven.

BERLIN, July 17 -- The authority and prestige of the German Communists in the Soviet zone of occupation have been so weakened during the last two months that the Russian high command is considering a complete purge of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party's leadership once a "national front" is established, it was learned today from an authoritative Western source.
VIENNA, July 16 -- The Salzburg seminar in American studies sponsored by the Harvard Student Council will begin its third summer session at Schloss Leopoldskron, just outside Salzburg, Monday.

David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, and Gen. Lucius D. Clay, former American Military Governor of Germany, have won the 1949 Freedom Award, it was announced yesterday by former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, president of Freedom House.

SHANGHAI, July 17 (UP) -- The Communist New China News Agency said today that floods were "threatening the existence of millions of people" in China and that the party would lose the confidence of the people if they failed to deal efficiently with the crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A bitter tug of war within Congress shaped up tonight over the program for further unification of the armed forces proposed by former President Herbert C. Hoover and his associates on the Commission for Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 -- A considerably reduced menagerie was unloaded from the Pacific Far East ship California Bear here this week-end after a rough voyage from Siam.

BUENOS AIRES, July 17 (UP) -- The newspaper Prensa devoted four columns today to unofficial "highlights" of a proposed law that would give the Government of President Juan D. Peron almost complete control of Argentine intellectual activity.

VALLEY FALLS, R. I., July 17 -- The Cistercian Community of the Abbey of Our Lady of the Valley has chosen a site on the Alta Crest Farms, Spencer, Mass., for its new home. Negotiations for transfer of the property have been completed by the Right Rev. M. Edmund Futterer, Abbot of the community, and Richard S. Sagendorph, owner of the tract.

Christianity was emphasized as an adventure rather than an investment for the modern age by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

WILDER, Vt., July 17 -- Farmers along the Connecticut River in this state and in New Hampshire, already faced with, condemnation proceedings against their land to make room for the Wilder Dam of the New England Power Company, pin their waning hopes on a prediction by Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, of Vermont, that the Federal Power Commission would be ordered to reopen hearings on the case.

The opposing views of Communists and believers in religion have brought about the underlying conflict in the world today, the Rev. Leland B. Henry, executive director of the Commission on Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street.

Although prices of spot cotton in the domestic market last week moved somewhat lower, futures prices registered moderate net gains. At the close Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange futures showed a net gain of 19 to 45 points.

Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, made public yesterday a proposal that if adopted by the Board of Estimate would provide a new lift bridge to carry Broadway over the Harlem River at 225th Street.

Total expenditures for national advertising in newspapers during 1948 reached an all-time high of $389,261,000, according to a report by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, issued for publication today.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 17 -- Thomas J. Watson Jr., vice president of International Business Machines Corporation, has accepted the chairmanship of the fourth annual United Nations Week observance, it was announced today by the American Association for the United Nations.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday that a record number of 2,302 boys and girls, enrolled in the work-study program of the New York public high schools, earned $1,181,255 in the year that ended June 30.

The Opportunity Shop of the Community Service Society will hold a sale throughout this week to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the organization. Proceeds from the event, which will open today at the group's headquarters, 46 West Forty-seventh Street, will further the maintenance of the Society's medical and dental clinics.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July l7 -- The opinion frankly stated in Turkish Government circles that additional economic aid from the United States is more urgently needed than additional military assistance is emphasized by developments here.

MOSCOW, July 17 -- New Soviet jet planes described by the press as looking as if they had come "from the arsenal of interplanetary flight" were demonstrated for the first time publicly today in the Soviet Aviation Day show at Tushino airdrome, just outside Moscow before Premier Joseph Stalin and a half million spectators.

Naval air reservists stationed in classrooms at three widely separated points in the East will receive training instructions by television in a series of Navy programs to be carried by the National Broadcasting Company. The activity is a part of the teaching-by-television research experiment being conducted by the Navy's special devices center at Port Washington, L. I., where the series will originate.

STONY POINT, N. Y., July 17 -- Despite heavy showers, 500 Boy Scouts, including two from Luxembourg, participated this afternoon in the dedication of Camp Bullowa by the Rockland County Council of Boy Scouts.

HOLLYWOOD, July 17 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator on Palestine, received today the Spingarn Award from the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, "principally for his priceless contribution to the settlement of armed conflict in the Middle East."

Mayor O'Dwyer is against the renomination of Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan and views with favor a movement to persuade Special Sessions Justice Irving Ben Cooper to seek the Democratic nomination for that office, it was learned yesterday from sources close to City Hall.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Representative Lawrence H. Smith, Republican, of Wisconsin, a lawyer, said today that Justices Felix Frankfurter and Stanley F. Reed set a "degrading precedent" by testifying as character witnesses in the perjury trial of Alger Hiss.

The threat of a strike on buses and trolley cars of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation evaporated at 9 P. M. yesterday, eleven hours after Mayer O'Dwyer had returned to New York from his abbreviated holiday in Mexico.

LONDON, July 17 -- The British Government prepared today for a "caretaker phase" in its economic administration during the six-week absence of Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, who has been grappling with the immediate and long-term aspects of the dollar crisis.
Much as a coalition of non-Communist Pacific countries is to be desired, it is questionable whether Chiang Kaishek is the proper person to represent China in such a union.

When, in January of this year, Governor Dewey named Bruce Bromley to be a judge of the Court of Appeals to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Judge Thomas D. Thacher, we called the appointment the choice of the best available material for a bench which ranks second in importance only to the Supreme Court of the United States.

LONDON, July 17 -- Despite the fact that Britain and also the Government are faced with a double crisis in the form of the dock strike which has forced the Government to declare a state of emergency and adopt equally urgent measures to meet the serious threat of another economic crisis, the stock markets in the past few days pulled themselves together and staged a moderate recovery after a prolonged period of tension and weakness.

The increasing use of large windows in houses and apartments has created new attitudes toward the design of curtaining materials. The large expanses of glass used in picture windows make it necessary to provide a fabric sheer enough to admit light but still endowed with some quality that blurs the view from the outside enough to insure a degree of privacy.

A double-header was advertised at Ebbets Field yesterday and sincere and energetic attempts were made to squeeze in both Dodger-Cub games between the raindrops. This was not possible, but none among the 23,176 fans demanded a refund. For the one conflict completed was one of the season's best and resulted in a nerve-tingling 4-3 victory for Burt Shotton's Brooks.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UP) -- President Truman was called upon today to suspend his own military aide, Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, as involved in the same investigation of military contracts that led to the suspension yesterday of two other major generals of the Army.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- Eddie Waitkus came home today. The star first baseman of the Philadelphia Phillies arrived here on a flight from Chicago at 4:33 P. M. Some 500 fans waited for his arrival despite a light rain and gave him an ovation as he stepped from the plane.

New York is too big already and steps should be taken to halt its growth in population, the Rev. Solon David Morgan, minister of the First Unitarian Church, Flushing, Queens, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Irving Sabo, furniture designer, believes a designer has to do more than put ideas down on paper. He not only plans but actually makes all the pieces he has worked out for specific settings. As a result, some of his pieces, especially seating units, have the handcrafted look and simplicity associated with products of early craftsmen.

Negotiations that were carried on for four years have ended in the closing of title on a forty-acre tract with a lake on Maple Lake Road, Maple Lake, Kinnelon, N. J. The property was sold by Lewis N. Smith, in whose family it had been held for more than 150 years, to Maple Lake Associates, Inc., representing a group of Newark physicians who wanted a vacation place within an hour's ride from Newark.

An increase of more than ten million tons of shipping at the Port of New York in the fiscal year ended June 30 over a comparable pre-war period was noted yesterday in vessel entrance and clearance figures released by Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales retained the National clay courts tennis title today with a four-set triumph over Frankie Parker, also of Los Angeles, 6 -- 1, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3.
New Yorkers by the thousands did something about the weather yesterday. They kept out of it.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Dr. Edwin G. Nourse, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers and formerly an economist for the Brookings Institution, today sounded a warning to business men and consumers against hoarding, going into "the storm cellar,'' or waiting for "pre-war prices."

Your editorial of May 26 "'Coddling' the Airline" was fine and served a double purpose. It pointed up the deplorable facts in Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker's statements to the Senate Airline Investigating Committee that the certificated airlines are not disposed to walk the rough road of efficiency and economy while the primrose path of air mail subsidy is open to them.

ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP) -- The last-place Browns, who had dropped ten of eleven games to Washington this season, swept a double-header with the Senators, 15 -- 8 and 7 -- 4, today. Rookie Roy Sievers sparked the St. Louis attack with five hits in seven trips.

GENEVA July 17 -- The Swiss Federal Council discussed last week the circumstances under which Switzerland might be able to accede to the desires of other countries in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation by collaborating in a new multilateral payment system for handling intra-European trade in 1949-50.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 17 -- Mike Priano, of the New York Athletic Club won the Metropolitan A. A. U. senior individual long-distance swimming championship today, pacing the Winged Foot mermen to a repeat victory for the senior team title.

PARIS, July 17 -- For the first time in five weeks, the Bourse has shown a marked tendency toward firmness. A week ago, official indexes had fallen to the lowest level in three years. That was the case of shares of Metropolitan France, whose general index on the basis 100 for 1938 was 923 on July 8, the lowest since October, 1946.
I read with interest the review by Waldemar Kaempffert of Rorschach test results at Tulane University in patients with tuberculosis and schizophrenia.

Cheered on by a crowd of 9,000 at Triboro Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday, the champion Internazionale-Milano team of Italy swept to a brilliant victory over an all-star professional eleven picked from the clubs affiliated with the American Soccer League.

Development of a new short-necked metal nineteen-inch direct view television receiver picture tube which gives a 203 square inch picture of "greater clarity than ever before" was announced over the week-end by Allen B. DuMont Laboratories, Inc.

NEW DELHI, India, July 17 (Reuters) -- Acting swiftly on Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's report on his fact-finding tour of West Bengal, the Congress party Working Committee tentatively agreed today, it was understood, to a general election in the province before the end of the year.

CLEVELAND, July 17 (AP) -- A ninth-inning home run by Vernon (Junior) Stephens broke a 1-1 tie as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Cleveland Indians, 2 -- 1, in the second game of a double-header today before 73,599 fans.

In commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the death of Johann Strauss, the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra presented a concert devoted to his music Saturday night at the Lewisohn Stadium, before an audience of 14,000. Robert Stolz conducted, and Marita Farell, soprano, and Kurt Baum, tenor, were the soloists.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 17 -- Henry D. See teamed with his guest from Round Hill, George Flinn, a one-time Yale golfer, to complete a succession of surprises and capture the tenth annual Greenwich Country Club Member-Guest Tournament today.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 17 -- William Talbert of New York and Edward Moylan of Trenton fought for almost two hours without reaching a decision today as rain interrupted their final round match in the Eastern clay court tennis championship at Travers Island.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- More than 100,000 visitors to the diamond jubilee convention of the Shrine -- the Ancient Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine of North America -- were moving on Chicago today by airplane, train, ship and automobile.

New flight traffic patterns worked out jointly by the Police Department and the Civil Aeronautics Administration, which went into effect last March 1, have reduced materially the number of complaints of stunting and low flying, it was disclosed yesterday.
Lions from around the world roared their aproval yesterday of the selection of a 17-year-old North Carolina schoolgirl as "Queen of the United States."

AMSTERDAM, July 17 -- The release of 240,000,000 guilders of the Marshall Plan counterpart fund for four major reconstruction projects, announced last Wednesday, had a mixed reception from the Dutch press. The release was made for building of houses for industrial workers, for reclamation works on the Zuider Zee, for redistribution of farmland on Walcheren Island and for agricultural improvements.

Plans for a Bronx housing development were announced in connection with the purchase by Dansal Builders, Inc., of a vacant plot 103 by 91 feet at the northeast corner of Watson and Olmstead Avenues from Robert R. Page. Assessed for $13.500, the property was bought through Walter J. Dickerson, broker, and will be improved with five two-family dwellings.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, said today that he intended to inform the public about the activities in this country of 100 or more aliens he suspected of having a background of spy work abroad.

Plans for a Bronx housing development were announced in connection with the purchase by Dansal Builders, Inc., of a vacant plot 103 by 91 feet at the northeast corner of Watson and Olmstead Avenues from Robert R. Page. Assessed for $13.500, the property was bought through Walter J. Dickerson, broker, and will be improved with five two-family dwellings.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, said today that he intended to inform the public about the activities in this country of 100 or more aliens he suspected of having a background of spy work abroad.

DETROIT, July 18 (AP) -- Rookie Outfielder Johnny Groth of the Detroit Tigers found his way back to the home-run trail today as he walloped a pair of four-baggers while the Bengals were dropping a 13-8 decision to the Philadelphia Athletics in ten innings.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A new effort to settle through extraordinary negotiations in Washington the strike that has crippled Hawaii ports for seventy-nine days emerged today as a Senate committee took up the stalemated controversy.

The recent decline in prices of French calfskins to a point where they are attractive to American tanners was described yesterday by the National Shoe Manufacturers Association as "one of the most wholesome and encouraging developments in foreign hide and skin markets since the war."
WILMINGTON, Del., July 18 (AP) -- E. I. duPont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced today that its sales for the first half of 1949 were up 9 per cent over the same period of last year.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- J. Edgar Hoover reported today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation helped add $100,477,335 to the Treasury cash-fund during the last twelve months. This "return to the taxpayer" on FBI expenditures, he said, included these amounts:

GLASGOW, July 18 (Reuters) -- In a fighting second-innings stand against the New Zealand cricketers, the Scottish opening pair, G. Willatt and T. Closskey, put on 138 unbeaten today after Scotland had followed on 286 runs behind.

Ten thousand orchids in leis and several thousand more as cut flowers reached the Hawaiian garden in Rockefeller Center yesterday. They have been placed on display in the native hut, which stands between two of the planted pools.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Senator Cain, in his speech today, declared that the framers of the North Atlantic security pact had made a mistake by omitting Franco Spain. He cited what he termed Spain's strategic position in event of a war with communism.

MENTION was made in this space recently of the fact that Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, the great trainer of race horses, will celebrate his diamond jubilee birthday on Saturday. He was born on July 23, 1874.
TRENTON, N. J., July 18 -- The New Jersey Assembly investigation of investments made for the $50,000,000 state disability fund closed today in a conflict of testimony.

While a small Republican minority in the Senate stages its last maneuvers against the North Atlantic Pact, Governor Dewey, titular head of the Republican party, has called for ratification of the treaty with "real enthusiasm," in order to dispel any doubts about the determination of the United States to live up to it.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Jackie Robinson, Brooklyn Dodgers' star, dealt in blunt philosophy about Negroes, communism and racial discrimination today as he appeared before the House Committee on Un-American Activities to dispute a declaration by Paul Robeson, singer and actor, that Negroes would not fight against Russia.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture and author of a new price support program for agriculture, recommended today that Congress study, along with his program, "monopoly" in the food manufacturing, marketing and transportation industries.
