WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Considerable mystery surrounds a delay in releasing the report made by the special naval investigating board that inquired into the death of James V. Forrestal, former Secretary of Defense.

The "Ozzie Harriet" radio program will be presented next fall by the American Broadcasting Company under a new ten-year contract signed by the network with Ozzie Nelson and his wife, Harriet. The program was heard on CBS last season.

The gas industry has revised upward its estimates of construction expenditures for the five years through 1952. For the period, according to the American Gas Association, it will spend $3,500,000,000, rather than the $3,300,000,000 estimated in October, 1948.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The closing of the United States Information Service offices in Shanghai and Hankow by order of the Chinese Communists was denounced today by the State Department as an act of "totalitarian dictatorship."
A 61-year-old father who had not seen his son for eighteen years found him again yesterday -- in Bronx Magistrate's Court, charged with assault and robbery.

The American Export liner La Guardia arrived here yesterday morning with 490 passengers from Palermo, Naples and Genoa. Among them was Dr. Julius M. Rogoff, a Professor of Endocrinology and Experimental Medicine at the University of Pittsburgh.
CLEVELAND, July 18 (AP) -- Cleveland Indian rookie Mike Garcia hurled six-hit ball tonight as the Indians beat the Red Sox, 1 -- 0, before 34,632 fans.

The sterling market here yesterday was strengthened by a ruling by the Canadian Foreign Exchange Control Board. This permits Canadian residents to buy sterling in the New York market for forward delivery for payment of shipments of merchandise of British Commonwealth origin.

Senator Byrd of Virginia has proposed a Congressional investigation of the views of President Truman's economic advisers. Some passages of the Economic Council's report (which accompanied Mr. Truman's message to Congress a few days ago), he declares, "seemed to reflect more the ideas of Lord Keynes than of American free enterprise."
Jackie Robinson, in a roundabout way, served notice on Boss Branch Rickey of the Brooklyn Dodgers yesterday that he wants more money in 1950.
LONDON, July 18 -- Statements allegedly confessing to some of the most gruesome crimes in modern history were read today in the little country court house at Lewes, Sussex.

Recent independent action by at least four leading business groups, aimed at "heading off' any general flouting of advertising truthfulness as competition grows, was hailed yesterday by advertising officials as assurance that such damaging practice will be kept to a minimum.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 18 (UP) -- The present secret five-year agreement under which the United States receives uranium from the Belgian Congo's production is scheduled to expire at the end of this month, Government sources said.

Antique Markets, Ltd., store tenant of the five-story business building at 521 Madison Avenue, has purchased the property from Sol Stern and others The property, on a plot 20 by 85 feet, is assessed at $160,000. It contains a store on the street floor and another one on the second floor and lofts on the upper floors.
The contest for Mayor of New York became a three-cornered one last night when the executive committee of the American Labor party designated Representative Vito Marcantonio for the nomination.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- The combined strength of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines fell off to 1,613,400 men on June 30, largely because of expiring enlistments in the Army.
CLEVELAND, July 18 -- The State of Connecticut yielded its last territorial claims in Ohio today.

GENEVA, July 18 -- If there is laxity in the control of narcotics in displaced persons camps in the British zone of Germany, British military authorities are responsible for it, the International Refugee Organization asserted today in an unusually sharp statement.

To help combat the extreme poverty, disease and crime in India trained welfare workers are a first need of that nation, it was reported yesterday by Miss Elmina R. Lucke, who has just helped to establish the second school of social work in all Asia.

Scots pipers from Canada, rumba dancers from Cuba, Indian dancers from Colorado and dancing girls from Florida mingled the rhythms and melodies of their home communities into a varicolored demonstration yesterday as 7,000 members of Lions International paraded down Fifth Avenue.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 18 -- A step toward closer coordination between Russia and Czechoslovakia on church policy and other subjects was seen by foreign observers today in an official announcement that six Cabinet Ministers had departed for Moscow to spend "one month's holiday in the Caucasus combined with study" at the invitation of the Soviet Government.

Clarence Derwent, president of Actors Equity Association, sent a telegram to the Department of Justice yesterday, demanding that the "unexplained mystery" of his six-hour detention at La Guardia Airport on Sunday be cleared up.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- United States officials were reported sharply split today on the question of giving atomic bomb secrets to the British.

Freedom House, in giving out its Freedom Award for 1949, found it impossible to decide on a single candidate. It has therefore made two citations, one for Gen. Lucius D. Clay, who retired in May as Military Governor for the United States in Germany, and one for Chairman David E. Lilienthal of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress on Reorganization Plan No. 8 for armed services unification:
The nature of ambulance calls in this city last year does not justify the use of doctors on all ambulances now, according to a study made public yesterday by the Hospital Council of Greater New York.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement today by Jackie Robinson, Brooklyn Dodger baseball player, before the House Un-American Activities Committee:

Fake use of the survey, or poll-taking, technique, as a "door-opener" in direct selling has been brought under effective control, it was announced yesterday by the division of research practices of the National Better Business Bureau.

The combination strike and lockout that has kept 2,500 bakers employed by six of the city's major bakeries idle for twenty weeks appeared to be settled last night with a majority of the workers voting to accept a new contract calling for a wage increase.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 18 -- Long Island Sound's windwafts, full of oddities, produced another today in the way of a lifting breeze. It was in the third regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week.

GUATEMALA, July 18 -- Col. Francisco Javier Arana, chief of Guatemala's armed forces, was presumed to have been killed today when he and a military aide were ambushed on a one-way bridge near this capital city.

LONDON, July 18 -- Ranking theologians throughout the world will make a three-year study of political and historical differences that keep the Protestant and Eastern Orthodox Churches apart, a meeting of representatives of the World Council of Churches decided at Chichester, Sussex, today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- Six dental concerns and the president of one of them were sued $450,000 damages today in a suit filed in the United States District Court.

Governor Dewey spoke out bluntly yesterday against European nations that accept United States aid and push "pet projects of socialism or nationalism" that might stand in the way of economic unity among the Marshall Plan countries.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 18 -- Attacking New York State's Feinberg law, which provides for the removal of Communist or subversive teachers from the school system, prominent educators called today for the repeal of the act at the next session of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration today announced approval of the purchase of $27,719,000 worth of United States tobacco for Marshall Plan use.
HONG KONG, July 18 -- A new Communist offensive is sweeping southward through Nationalist-held China on a 400-mile front, the Chinese Communists asserted today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Representative Frank B. Keefe, Republican, of Wisconsin, called today for "a minute examination" by the House Judiciary Committee of all the facts and circumstances relating to Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman, particularly with regard to his conduct of the trial of Alger Hiss.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Senate's bipartisan spokesmen for the North Atlantic Treaty were accused today of offering only "vague generalities" which obscured the obligations the treaty would put upon the United States.

Production of a new nine-passenger Dodge station wagon was announced yesterday by the Dodge division, Chrysler Corporation. Shipments of the four-door models are now being made to dealers here and throughout the country, according to company officials.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18 -- The police locked and sealed today the headquarters and other Beirut offices of the Lebanese Falange, strong Christian paramilitary political organization, which suggested a week ago that the American University here be closed.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 18 -- Oscar Zinn and Pete Burke of the Glen Oaks Club scored 34 -- 31, 65 as the first team to post a score, and it proved to be the winner in the weekly amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island Professional Golf Association at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn crepartment stores declined 13 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash'report issued: yesterday by the Federal Reserve! Bank of New York. The drop for! the four weeks ended last Saturday was 12 per cent.

Increased social legislation, greater community effort and wider social action in professional teacher organizations are required today to meet all the needs of children, Dr. Rome Gans, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College, yesterday told 500 summer session students in Horace Mann Auditorium.

OTISVILLE, N. Y., July 18 -- In the foothills of the Catskill Mountains on the outskirts of this Orange County village, the New York City Health Department owns a rolling 100-acre farm where it raises animals for the production of biologicals that help to keep New Yorkers immune to disease.
ATHENS, July 18 (AP) -- United States and other foreign news correspondents were barred today from visiting northern Greece, where Government troops were fighting Communist-led guerrillas.

PARIS, July 18 -- Better relations between Western Germany and the other Marshall Plan countries appeared likely today when it was learned that the French are now expected to sign a trade agreement soon with the Joint Export-Import Agency, representing the French, British and United States occupation zones.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Four days ago in this space it was noted that, for talent and effectiveness in getting their causes favorably publicized, the current "left" groups far surpass advocates of the "moderate" viewpoint, reversing the situation that long prevailed in this country before 1934.

Matthew J. Diserio, the Republican-Fusion-Liberal nominee for president of the City Council, is a Republican and justice of the Domestic Relations Court. He was a close associate of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, who appointed Mr. Diserio to various public posts.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP) -- Sammy Snead pumped his pars and birdies out of Alcoma's soggy fairways as methodically as the oil well that stands behind the eighteenth green to win the $2,600 top prize in the Dapper Dan open golf tournament today.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 18 -- Pacing the largest field ever to compete in a Westchester County P. G. A. pro-amateur best-ball event, Claude Harmon, pro of the home club, and his amateur partner, Ellis Baum, deadlocked with Sal Di Buono, pro at Bonnie Briar, and A. R. Hughes of Siwanoy over the difficult east course of the Winged Foot Golf Course today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (AP) -- A young Japanese, wartime supervisor of Radio Tokyo, testified today that Mrs. Iva Toguri D'Aquino, as "Tokyo Rose," committed what the Government charges were eight open acts of treason against the United States.

Marc Blitzstein's musical version of Lillian Hellman's drama, "The Little Foxes," will make its local debut at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre on Oct. 31. Cheryl Crawford, sponsor of the venture, concluded the booking arrangement with Louis Lotito yesterday. Before arriving here, the musical offering will test its wings in New Haven and Boston.

Members of an employes' savings fund at the Eldred Manufacturing Company, 50 Eldridge Street, were scheduled to have been off on their vacations yesterday. Instead they sat in Felony Court and glumly heard the fund treasurer explaining how their vacation savings had evaporated from $4,700 to $8.

Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., first-seeded in the junior division of the eastern junior and boys tennis championships which started yesterday at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, sparked the field into the third round. Sixth-seeded Roger Young of Great Neck, L. I., was eliminated.

Officials of the Brooklyn Plasterers Contractors Association were advised yesterday in Kings County Court to disclose the business practices of the organization or face maximum penalties as alleged participants in a conspiracy that increased building costs in Brooklyn an estimated $1,000,000.
May I say a few words in answer to "Old Age Pensioner," whose letter appeared in THE TIMES of July 6.

PARIS, July 18 -- The national congress of the Socialist party, which has five members in the French Cabinet, today condemned the Government's policy in Indo-China and urged that an armistice be sought with the Indo-Chinese Nationalists through international mediation.

BOSTON, July 18 (AP) -- Lanky Ewell Blackwell and Eddie Erautt limited the Braves to three hits, including Tommy Holmes' fourth homer of the season, today to give the Cincinnati Reds a 6-1 decision that evened their 1949 competition at seven games all.
The bond market will be treated to two joint municipal offerings early next month.

The Federal Government charged in a brief filed in Federal Court yesterday that the escape of Gerhart Eisler from this country had proved that "foreign sources" had embarked on a program of aiding their agents here.
BATAVIA, Java, July 18 (UP) -- The Dutch Government today announced postponement of the Aug. 1 Hague conference at which the Dutch were to grant sovereignty to the Indonesian Republic.

Though a homemaker may find it a little heavy to manage, her husband can pick it up by its handle and carry it like a suitcase. It's the new portable electric refrigerator that goes off for a week-end in the country, stowed away in the trunk of a car full of freshly cooked food.

The case for the superliner is being hotly debated pro and con in shipping and government circles, heightened by the disclosure last week that the nation's first such ship was threatened with cancellation.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, July 18 -- The Palestine Conciliation Commission of the United Nations reopened its sessions here today after a recess lasting more than two weeks.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Carroll R. Daugherty, chairman of the President's Steel Industry Board, sent telegrams today to sixty-four steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, inviting them to hearings on the steel wage dispute in New York on July 28.

All negotiations for settlement of the five-day-old bus strike were broken off last night after officials of the two struck companies announced that they would file damage suits for $1,100,000 against Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, CIO.
That part of Governor Dewey's speech at the Lions convention dealing with international affairs follows:
LONDON, Tuesday, July 19 (AP) -- More than 100 police were called out to quell a three-hour fight between white men and Negroes last night and early today in East London.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active and final prices were 12 to 29 points net higher.

LONDON, July 18 -- The dock strike that has gradually throttled more than half the Port of London, causing the British Government to declare a national state of emergency, entered upon its third week today. The number of striking dock workers mounted to more than 15,000 out of a total force of 27,000.

LE HAVRE, France, July 18 -- President Vincent Auriol today held up the newly reconverted Ile de France as a symbol of the amicable relations existing between France and the United States. The French President was the principal speaker at a ceremony aboard the 45,333-ton vessel marking her imminent return to the North Atlantic passenger lanes after a war-imposed absence of almost a decade.

New York, which makes a pleasant specialty of welcoming organizations to hold their conventions here -- and welcoming none more heartily than the great service clubs -- has received a compliment in kind. This is the first time that the Lions International has chosen for its annual gathering the same city two years in a row.

The two-story taxpayer building at 5121 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, under lease to the H. C. Bohack Company, has been sold by the trustees of the Henry C. Bohack estate to the J. S. G. Realty Corporation, of which William A. Gould is president.
LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- The text of a communique issued today by the Finance Ministers of the British Commonwealth follows:

Opening day retailer attendance at the fifty-eighth annual summer furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue, totaled 3,100 -- an all-time record, J. J. Melniker, exchange president, reported last night.
What a little community effort can do to erase an eyesore and health hazard was demonstrated yesterday at dedication ceremonies for a new playground at First Avenue and 115th Street.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Working capital of business corporation reached a record of $65,800,000,000 during this year's first three months, a Government report said tonight.

REVENGE, if one of the least admirable human passions, is surely one of the most natural. It need not be a question of an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth and a blood feud. Humiliation, wounded feelings, hurt pride and a sense of injury sometimes seem to cry for a turning of the tables, a reply in kind, poetic justice. So paranoiacs in positions of power revenge themselves on mankind in general

LONDON, July 18 -- The stock market made a cautious and slow start today owing, probably to the ending of the account tomorrow and because the new account extends over the August bank holiday. As a result price movements in most sections were confined to narrow limits.

The United States Treasury yesterday issued a call on its war loan accounts with the nation's larger banks. The call, on the Class B institutions, requires payment of 20 per cent of such deposits as of the close of business on July 16, in two equal instalments, on July 22 and July 25.
COWES, Isle of Wight, July 18 (AP) -- Great Britain took a commanding lead in the British-American Cup competition for Six-Meter yachts today by scoring its second victory, 21 1/4 points to 14.

Two Georgians took a chance on an Ohio kitchen in the basement of Madison Square Garden yesterday As they filled out registration cards for the drawing one of their shopping bags tipped over and out fell a hodge-podge of souvenirs collected in a morning of free shopping at the thirty-second annual convention of the International Association of Lions Clubs.

OMAHA, Neb., July 18 -- Stoutly resisting another effort to oust him from first place in the National open championship tournament at the annual meeting of the United States Chess Federation, Albert Sandrin of Chicago today defeated Jeremiah F. Donovan of Brooklyn in the sixth round after thirty-seven moves.

DETROIT, July 18 -- Contract talks between the United Automobile Workers, CIO, and the Ford Motor Company approached a critical stage today as 106,000 hourly rated workers put in their first full shifts on "borrowed time."

Opportunity knocked last night and the Dodgers were home at Ebbets Field to answer. With the runner-up Cardinals beaten earlier by the Giants, the pace-setting Brooks fashioned a nice if not neat 3-0 victory over the Cubs and soared to a two-and-a-half length lead over the Redbirds.

Pierre Monteux and Nathan Milstein are both rare spirits, and last night they collaborated in a program at the Lewisohn Stadium that will surely be remembered in the annals of that outdoor amphitheatre, where many a city-prisoned New Yorker has been comforted by beauty during a trying summer.

There comes a time in the life of almost every man when he suddenly realizes he is growing, as they say, a trifle plump. The word fat must be disregarded at whatever the cost to truth, honesty or appearances around the middle.
CHICAGO, July 18 -- Large receipts of cash grain failed to have the depressing effect expected by brokers in general.

Amid the roar of pneumatic drills and the metallic ring of pickaxes, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers officially started yesterday morning the long heralded job of removing the abandoned trolley tracks in Forty-second Street and repaving the thoroughfare from Second Avenue to Twelfth Avenue.

NEWARK, N. J., July 18 -- The fight between a Congress of Industrial Organizations local and an independent union to represent 7,500 workers in the strike-bound Elizabeth plant of the Singer Manufacturing Company will be decided by secret ballot on July 27.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania announced tonight that he would resign next month as chairman of the Republican National Committee.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 18 -- Five hundred unemployed immigrants living in abandoned Arab homes in Ramleh squatted outside the offices of the Government Labor Ministry today, demonstrating for "work and bread." The demonstrators said that they would spend the night there and would Be joined tomorrow by unemployed from Lydda.

Horse racing fans in the local area made the truncated trip to Saratoga yesterday. It wasn't much of an ordeal, for all they had to do was to follow the same pattern they had pursued the two previous weeks, namely go to the Long Island Rail Road station, get on the race train, and get off at Jamaica.

The dollar amount of export drafts sent to Latin America by leading banks for collection but not yet paid, rose $10,000,000 during June and at the end of the month stood at the "unprecedentedly high level" of $155,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Brooke Cadwallader presented his fall collection of scarfs yesterday at 724 Fifth Avenue. Here were such fanciful depictions as Santa in a pen line drawing, peering from a chimney top, Neptune and his undersea court, cavorting kittens and prints of postal cards from Nassau with their messages.

There is an instructive contrast in the addresses of Dr. Ralph Bunche and Mr. Paul Robeson that were given in Hollywood and New York, respectively, over this past week-end. Dr. Bunche and Mr. Robeson are persons of prominence. They are both men of great ability.

Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh said yesterday that "the great majority" of ticket brokers should be eliminated because of sharp practices. He already has promised to ask for the revocation of licenses of half the city's sixty-six ticket brokers.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 18 -- By an 8-to-3 vote, the Working Committee of the United Nations Commission on Conventional Armaments approved today a French plan for a global census-taking of non-atomic weapons and troop strength.

Italian industrial production continues at a fairly satisfactory level, according to Signor Ivan Matteo Lombardo, Italian Minister of Industry and Commerce. Peter G. Treves, editor of "Economic News from Italy," now on a fact-finding tour of that nation, interviewed Signor Lombardo and outlined his views in a communication received here yesterday from Rome.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- Victor Mature will play the leading role, that of a gangster, in "Mr. Whiskers," at RKO late this fall, the studio announced today. Warren Duff, who has been signed to a term contract by RKO, will write and produce the film from a story by Erwin Gelsey about a foreign-born racketeer, who, on the eve of deportation, suddenly realizes the significance of American citizenship.

The individual who wrote the Bert Hulen editorial which appeared in an issue immediately following the Indian mountain plane tragedy knew the man, knew him as we, his fellows in the National Press Club, knew him. In fact, there was no middle ground. If you knew Bert you knew him as he was -- honest, plain, straightforward, truthful.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced it had revoked the broker-dealer registration of F. H. Winter Co., New York brokerage firm, for "willful violation of the broad prohibitions" of Federal securities laws.

BERLIN, July 18 -- Although the Russians have broadcast their desire for East-West trade talks in Berlin throughout the Western world during the last four weeks, they made no effort to push the subject at today's meeting of the four powers in Berlin.
American teachers from kindergarten to college will sail today to "swap classes" for a year with British teachers.
The stock market added yesterday another notch to its recovery effort, although the further advance proved of a creeping nature and devoid of any interesting features.

An increase of one-half cent in zinc prices yesterday accompanied by larger orders reported by producers, reflected a substantial increase in requirements of galvanizers and die-casting foundries, zinc smelters reported. Indicating the range of increased volume, one large producer said orders booked so far this month are already 50 per cent larger than total orders for zinc metal in June, for his company.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., July 18 -- Msgr. John O'Grady, executive secretary of the National Conference of Catholic Charities, Washington, D. C., today termed the recent enactment of the Public Housing Bill to provide 800,000 family units "a victory," but added "something remains to be done to provide housing for the middle class group."
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- A drive to force another House showdown on Taft-Hartley repeal was sidetracked today when only half a dozen legislators appeared at a meeting called to map strategy.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Truman moved today to clear a legislative snarl on Capitol Hill by submitting to Congress a reorganization plan to strengthen the unification of the armed forces undertaken two years ago.

BERLIN, July 18 -- Although the current Communist propaganda line stresses the idea of German unity; although East-zone Communists are amalgamated with the Socialists under the label of "Einheit" (unity); although the party program today hammers away at the concept of a "national front," there is good reason to believe that Soviet policy is still to keep Germany divided at all costs.

LONDON, July 18 -- The Finance Ministers of the British Commonwealth countries, whose talks on the sterling area's dollar crisis concluded here today, agreed to recommend that their Governments make cuts in dollar purchases equivalent to the 25 per cent reduction already ordered for the United Kingdom.

GROVELAND, Fla., Tuesday, July 19 -- Mobs of white men roamed the pine woods of Lake County early today, burning rural Negro houses. Law enforcement officers and National Guardsmen threw up barricades to save larger Negro communities.

Motion picture audiences responded enthusiastically to a newsreel summary of Senator Edwin C. Johnson's program for reducing excise taxes to pre-war levels, it was reported yesterday by Oscar A. Doob, executive of Loew's Inc., and chairman of the Metropolitan Motion Picture Theatres Association.

Mrs. Genevieve B. Earle, first woman member of the City Council, who once battled twenty consecutive hours on the Council floor before admitting defeat on her county government reorganization proposals, announced yesterday that she would not seek re-election.
Trading in the new No. 6 sugar contract was begun yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Activity was good with all elements of the trade participating in the trading.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 18 -- The British Military Government has eased its licensing restrictions on political parties in the British zone to test openly the political sympathies of the German population. The British are interested especially in the German attitude toward an extreme rightist group, whose activities have been partly banned in the past.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson signed three bills today to increase disability and unemployment benefits for Illinois workers. Injury and sickness benefits under the workmen's compensation and occupational disease laws were increased 15.4 per cent across the board by the bills.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -- The third biennial convention of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, opening here today, was called upon by the union's officers to "set its sights on the forty-hour week at sea," with or without the support of the National Maritime Union, headed by Joseph E. Curran of New York.

May we take issue with Ely Culbertson's letter in THE TIMES of July 14 and express our agreement with your editorial of July 11. Mr. Culbertson's support of the "U. N. pilot plant" resolution introduced in the Senate in connection with the Atlantic Treaty debate is open to criticism primarily on three basic points:

ATLANTIC CITY, July 18 -- Edwin Barringer, executive vice president of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., of Washington, D. C., said today there was a modest note of optimism in the industry and that the belief was that scrap iron has taken the bulk, if not all, of its readjustment.

Reflecting a ten-day strike in February and a smaller volume of traffic, the Philadelphia Transportation Company reported yesterday that system operations in the first half of 1949 resulted in a loss of $1,314,497, compared with a net loss of $479,138 in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Lt. Gen. Leroy Lutes, staff director of the War Munitions Board, defended today foreign purchases of materials for the nation's stockpile as necessary to guard against shortages in case of war.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Prospects of Congressional action to cut excise taxes this year reached a new low point today.

The future of the Protestant church in the world rests on "all of us finding ourselves tied together by our Christian faith," Dr. Albert Schweitzer, missionary philosopher of French Equatorial Africa, declared here yesterday at a luncheon at which he and his wife were guests of honor.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP) -- The Pirates exploded for seven runs in the eighth inning, driving four pitchers to the showers, as they defeated the Phillies, 7 -- 2, today for their fourth straight victory and their fourteenth triumph in the last eighteen games.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States today called upon organized labor to forego its fourth-round wage and economic-social demands and on industry to lower prices as rapidly as possible.

Buyers at the twenty-eighth semi-annual curtain and drapery show, now at the New Yorker Hotel, reported yesterday that although dollar valume for the industry is off at retail levels, unit sales are actually up compared with last July. Approximately 150 manufacturers have display space in the hotel.

NEWARK, N. J., July 18 -- A $267,000 agent fee suit brought by war contract agents against the William Steinen Manufacturing Company of Newark was dismissed today by County Judge Richard Hartshorne. The plaintiffs, who contended they had obtained $2,000,000 in World War II Navy contracts for the local concern, were Alexander H. Stone of Washington; Murray B. and Sarah Stone of this city and E. David and Anna L. Stone of South Orange.
A walk-out yesterday morning of 400 dockworkers at the American Export Lines Jersey City terminal tied up operations on two of the company's vessels. Piers D and F were idle from the work stoppage.
LONDON, July 18 (UP) -- Mr. Bevin, defending Government policies on Great Britain's financial crisis, said tonight in Commons that the United States was "as much a welfare state as we are."

Final plans prepared by David B. Steinman, consulting engineer, for reconstruction of the roadways and trusses of the Brooklyn Bridge between the Manhattan and Brooklyn anchorages were forwarded to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works.

A high bounder that caromed off, the bat of Willowy Willie Rigney and came down to Eddie Kazak's waiting hands with the uncertain speed of a feather completely changed the course of events for the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday in their finale with the Cardinals before 10,977 of the faithful.

CHICAGO, July 18 -- The Yankees went to some tremendous lengths tonight to make their final tune-up for their forthcoming Cleveland series a rousing success. But in the end, which came in the last half of the tenth, it was no go.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- A "Buy American" amendment by Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, has been put on the 1950 military appropriation bill in an effort to check purchase of low-cost Argentine beef by the armed forces.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 18 -- The Merion Cricket Club, one of the foremost tennis organizations of the country, with its beautiful lawns and setting, came back prominently into the picture today as the venue of the first of the big grass court tournaments of the season.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18 -- David Michel Torino, for thirty years publisher of the Intransigente, the most outspoken opposition paper in rural Argentina, has leased his paper to three friends on the grounds that Government harassment made it impossible for him to continue as publisher.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UP) -- The Senate Military Appropriations subcommittee approved today an amendment to the $15,000,000,000 armed services bill to permit the Government to recapture "excessive profits" on Federal contracts.
TOKYO, July 18 -- The Japanese Government, with the approval of the Occupation, is now embarked on a thoroughgoing campaign to purge Communists from vital public services.

SILVER BAY, N. Y., July 18 -- Three hundred Protestant mission officials, church workers and clergymen voted here tonight to ask President Truman and the American Red Cross to send "immediate relief" to the millions of flood sufferers in China regardless of their political affiliations.

Luxury fabrics for home furnishings that have unusual durability and take to soap and water without damage have become a reality with the advent of some new fabrics woven from nylon yarn. These fabrics, ranging in texture from sheer net to heavy piled velvet, are available by the yard in a wide range of colors through decorators and stores in this city.

Community facilities in many of the large housing developments in the metropolitan area now range from craft workrooms to well equipped "tot lots" for pre-school children, representatives reported yesterday. Not luxuries, but necessities, they are planned as substitutes for the yards, cellars and attics that families once had for play and home work.
BUFFALO, N. Y., July 18 (AP) -- A reorganization plan for the Sterling Engine Company was filed in Federal Court today.
ROME, July 18 -- John W. Snyder left this morning by plane for Turkey after three-day conversations with Italian officials, during which he listened a great deal and said very little.
PIPESTONE, Minn., July 18 (AP) -- The career of Vincent Lee Foster, 22 years old, Omaha welterweight boxer, ended in death today. His automobile plowed into the rear of a cattle truck near here.
Just when the fishing gets good, along comes the weather.

The prosecution in the "lonely hearts" trial rested its case at 3:15 P. M. yesterday after a police expert had testified to finding human blood splattered over a furnished apartment in Valley Stream, L. I., scene of the alleged hammer-and-scarf slaying of Mrs. Janet J. Fay last Jan. 4 by the defendants, Mrs. Martha Jule Beck and Raymond Martinez Fernandez.
Fishing in the Rockaways is not always productive, but if it occasionally lacks in angling excitement it produces few dull moments if our recent excursion is a typical example.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 19 -- The Greek Government complained to the United Nations today that the Communist Information Bureau had sharply stepped up its "undeclared war" against Greece to offset the effects of Yugoslavia's recent pledge to keep completely out of it.
A showdown on Mayor O'Dwyer's demand that Hugo E. Rogers resign as leader of Tammany and retire as a candidate for renomination for Borough President is scheduled for today.

Veterans who with their families occupy 286 emergency housing units at Lido Beach, L. I., may have until Sept. 30, 1954, to find new homes. This was announced yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, and Walter F. Downey, regional director of the Federal Government's General Services Administration -- War Assets Office.
DETROIT, July 19 (AP) -- President Truman sent a telegram today to Recorder's Judge George Murphy on the death of Supreme Court Justice Frank Murphy, his brother. He said:

Fifty sales students at the City College Midtown Business Center will conduct tomorrow a one-day campaign to sell $5,000 worth of tickets for the National Amputation Foundation's amputee veterans' baseball game next Tuesday night at the Polo Grounds.
GUATEMALA, July 19 (AP) -- The Guatemalan Government summoned troops from outside the capital today to aid loyal detachments holding the National Palace against a rebel attack.

A vision of a "Lions International City" that is to rise thirty miles south of Chicago was evoked yesterday for delegates from twenty-six countries at the convention of Lions clubs in Madison Square Garden.

Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn moved to aid 400 war veteran patients in the Manhattan Beach Veterans Hospital yesterday when he asked Federal officials to delay their transfer until the new Fort Hamilton Veterans Hospital was ready to receive patients.
Following is the text of President Truman's address yesterday at the Shrine convention, in Chicago, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

BERLIN, July 19 -- The recent Vatican decision to excommunicate Communists is reported to have caused a "large part" of the German East zone Christian Democratic Union members to ask for separation from the Communist-controlled National Front.

The plan for installing snow-melting radiant heating systems under eight Forty-second Street pedestrian cross-walks as part of the current track-removal and repaving operations struck a snag yesterday. Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell rejected all bids submitted on the heating contracts.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- A resolution asserting the "right of self-determination" of the National Union of Cooks and Stewards, CIO, was sent back to committee by the third biennial convention here today as "not strong enough."

ROME, July 19 -- A dispatch to the Rome newspapers from Orta Nova today said that a parish priest in that southern town had been threatened with bodily harm when he refused to impart absolution to a dead woman whose coffin had been draped with a red flag.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 19 -- Murray Vernon Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., Hotchkiss golf captain, led the small field over the Garden City Country Club course today in the metropolitan district's sectional test for the United States Golf Association junior championship.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A Republican effort was started today to rally about a single proposed reservation all the outright and incipient opposition to ratification of the North Atlantic treaty as it stands.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Paul G. Hoffman, Economic Cooperation Administrator, told key Senators today that the European Recovery Program was seriously threatened by several committee amendments to the second year's appropriation.

NEW HAVEN, July 19 (AP) -- The payroll reduction which the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad started six months ago will continue three months more, Laurence F. Whittemore, president, said today. Steadily declining revenue makes the move necessary, he explained.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 19 (UP) -- A Czechoslovak Government spokesman told Roman Catholic priests today that mass reprisals would be taken against the clergy and their congregations if the Vatican excommunication order against Communists was carried out.

ALBANY, July 19 -- A court fight by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein to halt what he termed "profiteering in sorrow" ended successfully today when the Court of Appeals refused to permit the Kensico Cemetery Corporation to sell part of its property to another cemetery organization.

Five persons were slightly injured at 2 P. M. yesterday when the Erie Railroad ferryboat Meadville crashed into the pier at the south slip, North River and Chambers Street. Pier damage was estimated at $20,000. The injured were discharged from the Beekman Hospital after treatment.

LONDON, July 19 -- With a smile on his handsome face, dapper, 39-year-old John George Haigh, who confessed to killing nine persons and drinking their blood, listened without a sign of emotion to the death sentence passed on him today for the murder of a 69-year-old widow.
DETROIT, July 19 -- Frank Murphy, associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, died here of a heart attack in his sleep today in the Henry Ford Hospital. He was 59 years old.
HAVANA, July 19 -- Reports that the Cuban Government will obtain a loan of $100,000,000 to $200,000,000 in the United States has brought a wave of protest from various sectors in Cuba.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumed during June totaled 600,495 bales of lint and 121,992 bales of linters.

The City of San Francisco announced yesterday that it will offer $11,500,000 of various purpose bonds in the market on Aug. 8. Details as to the date which will be affixed to the issue and when the bonds will fall due have not been released as yet.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The melodramatic stage-setting for the meeting at Blair House on the night of July 14, at which conferees of unusual importance weighed the request of Great Britain for data and materials essential to the manufacture of atom bombs in that country, appears to have been the consequence of naivete and dormant imaginations and not at all of design.

Some financial observers are of the opinion that one of the mistakes likely to be made marketwise in the next two months is the assumption that the upturn in trade, slight as it is, registers the fact that the bottom of the recession was witnessed in June.

Ticket brokers asked yesterday that Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh be replaced in his inquiry into ticket scalping by an impartial commission to be appointed either by Governor Dewey or Mayor O'Dwyer.
LONDON, July 19 -- The ending of the account, together with the continuance of the dock strike, restricted business in all sections of the stock market here today.

Furniture selected to blend well with the built-in living room bookcases and bedroom dressing table unit that a part of the all-steel Lustron home may be seen in the five-room model house that opens today on the fifth floor of Bamberger's store in Newark.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Repeal of wartime excise taxes and reduction of other levies to prewar levels was recommended today by the steering committee of the National Planning Association. Prospects for Congressional action at this session remained doubtful.

The Soviet Union is suffering from a serious shortage of kindergartens, nurseries and other child care centers, according to an editorial in an issue of the newspaper Izvestia that has just arrived in this country.

BOSTON, July 19 (AP) -- Elbie Fletcher's three-run homer plus Lefty Warren Spahn's highly effective six-hit pitching gave the Braves a 5-2 victory in the opener of a three-game series with the Cardinals tonight before a sweltering crowd of 24,650.
The quarter-final rounds of both junior and boys divisions were filled yesterday in the eastern tennis championships at the West Side Club in Forest Hills with one seeded casualty listed for the day.

The repaving and removal of trolley tracks in Forty-second Street, which New Yorkers delight in calling "the busiest street in the world," are at last under way and the pneumatic drills have begun tearing up the roadbed in the block between Second and Third Avenues. From now on until the end of the year there will be plenty of noise along this crowded artery.
CONCORD, N. H., July 19 -- The New Hampshire Senate took the first step today to make the state live within its income for the next biennium by passing an "austerity" budget of $21,827,494.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- President Truman declared today that the the totalitarian system -- by which he no doubt meant the Kremlin -- would either destroy itself or abandon its attempt to dominate the world by forcing other nations into its pattern.

Net assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation on June 30, last, before deducting funded debt, amounted to $61,399,318, equal to $10.32 a common share, compared with $63,557,710, or $10.88 a share, on Dec. 31, 1948, and with $50,505,431, or $11.94 a common share, on June 30 a year ago, the report disclosed yesterday.

The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad, which carried 66,000,000 passengers last year, will incur a deficit estimated at more than $1,600,000 in 1949 unless it gets an immediate fare increase, John J. Fritsch, controller of the company, declared yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., July 19 -- With a strike threatened for tomorrow midnight, negotiations between the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company and representatives of the Telephone Workers Union of New Jersey reached a deadlock here tonight.

Swedish-made furniture has turned up in showrooms around New York, and pieces have been interpolated into domestic room settings. Now a five-room model apartment has been decorated with furniture and accessories of Swedish origin by Hazel Hancock, interior consultant of Rainbow House, Manhasset, L. I.

A five-length victory by a 111-to-1 shot, the longest-priced winner in recent years on the New York racing circuit, stirred considerable excitement at Jamaica yesterday. It also set up a $1,199.50 daily double, glossiest of the local campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- If Gus Lesnevich goes through with his proposed heavyweight title fight against Ezzard Charles in New York City on Aug. 10, he will be suspended in forty-seven states, the National Boxing Association said today.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 19 -- A new, low-cost printing press especially designed for small newspapers was given its first trade demonstration here today by its creators, the Wood Newspaper Machinery Corporation.

The children, freed from the sound of the school bell, have been shipped off to camp or already have been underfoot to the degree that mother thinks longingly of the good old school days. The high school and college seniors have marched forth to stamp their marks on the pathways of life.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 19 -- Members of the New York State Flower Growers Association, holding their fourth annual convention at the Long Island Agricultural and Technical Institute here, were cautioned today against putting too much stock in revolutionary strides made in insecticide chemistry since the war.

BERLIN, July 19 -- Indications have been received here that the Soviet Union has drastically changed its repatriation policy for German prisoners of war and is now seeking to indoctrinate with careful ideological training the majority of the captives before permitting their return to the Western zones.

Substantially all of the holdings of Albert H. Wiggin and certain other interests in the stock of Amerex Holding Corporation have been acquired by the Equitable Securities Corporation and Union Securities Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Details of the transaction were not disclosed.

CLEVELAND, July 19 -- The front-running Yankees, who have been leading the American League parade ever since opening day, crashed head-on into the Indians today, and the recoil produced an effect not wholly expected by Casey Stengel.

CLEVELAND, July 19 -- Directors of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen tonight named William P. Kennedy, general secretary-treasurer of the union since Jan. 1, 1947, and active in its affairs for thirty-five years, as the new president of the 215,000-member independent union. Mr. Kennedy is 57 years old.

Judge Harold M. Kennedy in Federal Court, Brooklyn, rescinded yesterday an order he had issued on July 11 directing a Brooklyn landlady to reinstate a 28-year-old disabled war veteran and his family to the apartment out of which she had locked them.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Republican leaders pictured today a "wide open race" for a national chairman to succeed Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. of Pennsylvania, who announced last night that he would resign.

The United States Maritime Commission has completed its first revision of the operating differential subsidy contract form to meet post-war conditions. An announcement to that effect by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman, was released here yesterday from the commission's Atlantic Coast District Headquarters, 45 Broadway.
DETROIT, July 19 (AP) -- The Tigers blew a six-run lead but finally edged the Senators by 7 to 6 tonight with Virgil Trucks getting credit for his twelfth victory of the season in a relief role.

Nine newspaper advertising directors and one newspaper representative executive have been named to the pulans committee of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, it was announced yesterday.

United Aircraft Products, Inc., manufacturers of spun aluminum cake and muffin pans, will merchandise its line through more than 200 super markets operated by Grand Union Stores Corporation, John M. Meyers, UAP president, revealed yesterday.

Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, disavowed yesterday recent attacks by other leading real estate operators on Tighe E. Woods, Housing Expediter, for his formula to allow landlords "fair net operating income."
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- At least one of the two Supreme Court Justices who testified as character witnesses at the Alger Hiss perjury trial in New York did so under subpoena.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Brannan farm program suffered new setbacks in Congress today, but supporters refused to concede defeat in their fight for a limited "trial run."
MOSCOW, July 19 -- Sir David Kelly has inaugurated his new role as British Ambassador to Moscow with a discussion in the Kremlin with Premier Stalin.

Reflecting record sales in the first half of this year, the Libby-Owens-Ford Glass Company reported yesterday net earnings increased to $9,105,831 from the $7,103,850 in the initial six months a year ago.

Governor Dewey predicted yesterday that New York state, which he said now led the nation in care of the mentally ill, would in two years be doing more in the field of mental hygiene "than all the rest of the states put together."

BUENOS AIRES, July 19 -- Dr. Carlos Elbio de Oliva Paz, until recently President Juan Peron's dentist and last September the bearer of a gift from Senor Peron to President Truman, has been barred by the Government from the practice of his profession.

The stock market held yesterday to the recovery course, but interest in the further upturn was dwarfed by trading in Commonwealth Southern, which accounted for about half the day's business. Volume in the low-price shares of the utility holding company, which is

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Grain markets continued on the upgrade on the Board of Trade today, stimulated by a belief that the peak of the after-harvest movement of oats and winter wheat had been passed, and by limited hedging pressure resulting in wheat being up 1 1/2 cents at one time, corn, 2 cents and oats 2 3/4 cents.

Jackie Robinson scored four hits and no errors in his testimony in Washington on the relationship of Communism to the struggle for Negro civil rights. Simply and effectively, he made these points, which reveal that Jackie Robinson is a whole lot more than one of America's great baseball players:

SHANGHAI, July 19 -- "Bandit suppression campaigns" have been launched against "Kuomintang underground workers, disbanded soldiers and recidivist robbers" operating along the eastern end of the Lung-Hai Railway and around Lake Tai, about fifty miles west of Shanghai, it was reported today.

Operations at the American Export Lines' Jersey City terminal remained at a standstill yesterday, as no action was taken to get the 400 dock workers who refused to work on Monday morning back to work. The men attended yesterday morning's shape-up, but refused to respond to the dockmaster's whistle.

Communism "looks upon the school and the teacher as an especially choice means of achieving its evil ends," Dr. John K. Norton, director of the Division of Administration and Guidance at Columbia University's Teachers College, told 1,000 teacher-students yesterday.

In an all-cash transaction, the two - story taxpayer containing seven stores and seventeen offices on a plot 100 by 150 feet at the northeast corner of Columbus Avenue and West Sixty-seventh Street was sold by St. Louis University and Elizabeth C. Smith to the 161 Columbus Avenue Corporation.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Chicago today had the most colorful parade of its history, and one of the largest, in the five-hour procession of 15,000 exotically garbed Shriners over a three-mile route to Soldier Field, where they heard President Truman in a foreign policy pronouncement.

The Department of Sanitation had two potent weapons in the strong right-hand pitching of Myron Zarski and the powerful clubbing of A1 Cuccinello at Yankee Stadium yesterday. Zarski and Cuccinello and two five-run innings added up to a 12-0 triumph over the Police Department in the annual clash staged for the benefit of the Welfare Honor Relief Fund of the Department of Sanitation.

ALBANY, July 19 -- The Court of Appeals, in a 4-to-3 decision, ruled tonight that the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company had the right to bar Negroes from its Stuyvesant Town housing project. The high court affirmed lower court rulings dismissing an action brought by three Negro war veterans who had applied for apartments in the housing project.

An investing group organized and controlled by Sidney Feldshuh has purchased the ten-story apartment house at 90 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, from Punia March, Inc. The property, on a plot 66 by 171 feet at the corner of President Street, contains fifty-four apartments.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 19 -- George Baskiel, playing from the Queens Golf Club, scored 33, 36 -- 69, three strokes under course figures, to lead a field of 153 in the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Cherry Valley club today.

The Finance Ministers of the British Commonwealth have now announced that they will support the new Cripps austerity program, and will reduce their own dollar imports by 25 per cent. Neither Sir Stafford nor the Commonwealth Finance Ministers regard this step as more than a stop-gap measure.

When we needed Spain and cultivated the friendship of the same head of the Spanish state that the editors of THE NEW YORK TIMES criticize as a "mean and vindictive little man" (THE TIMES, July 16, 1949), an editorial was published in this newspaper praising the appointment of Dr. Carlston J. H. Hayes.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Americans for Democratic Action, impatient with those who want to "let nature take its course," today wrote an economic program suggesting immediate and long-range steps to obtain full employment.
Chanda celebrated his move uptown from 425 Fifth Avenue to 30 West Fifty-seventh Street with a smart cocktail opening yesterday afternoon at which he exhibited his fall and winter hats.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 19 (AP) -- A court battle to halt the sale of the assets of the North American Rayon Corporation to Beaunit Mills, Inc., was launched here today.

The first large-scale local exhibition of work by the Austrian expressionist artist, Oskar Kokoschka, opens to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art. About fifty paintings, together with a selection of drawings, lithographs and illustrations and an early piece of sculpture, are included.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture is considering a program to encourage private interests to build new grain storage facilities by guaranteeing to use them for a minimum period.
Fred M. Hunt has been appointed Boston zone manager of the Packard Motor Car Company, Detroit. He formerly was Eastern regional manager, with headquarters in New York City.

A temporary injunction was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally barring an American Federation of Labor maritime affiliate from continuing a strike against a tugboat for refusal of her owners to hire a cook as part of the crew.

The Lynch Corporation declared yesterday a 20-cent dividend payable to common stockholders on Aug. 15. This represents a cut of 10 cents from the previous quarterly rate maintained since February, 1947. The last disbursement of 30 cents was made last May 16.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 20 -- Russia accused Italy today of violating the terms of the Italian peace treaty by signing the North Atlantic pact. She made the charge in notes sent to Italy, the United States, Britain and France as the Italian Government debated ratification of the pact.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Vern Stephens' two-run single highlighted Boston's three-run ninth inning spurt as the Red Sox defeated the White Sox, 6 -- 4, before 22,998 persons tonight. Ellis Kinder allowed eight hits in outpitching Marino Pieretti to gain his tenth victory.

Conveying machinery sales have shown a marked increase during the past month and a wide variety of new uses are being developed by warehouses, chain stores, hotels, hospitals and five and ten cent stores, A. P. Anderson, sales engineer, Samuel Olson Manufacturing Co., Inc., Hoboken, N. J., disclosed here yesterday.

At 11:35 A. M. yesterday 2-year-old Edward Masone clambered on a radiator in his bedroom and peered out the partly open casement window at the lawn thirteen stories below. His mother and father were only yards away in the next room of their small apartment at 466 East Tenth Street in the Jacob Riis housing development. They thought the boy was asleep in his crib.
BERLIN, July 19 -- In a surprising move Hans Jendretzky, leader of Berlin's Socialist Unity (Communist) party, today demanded free elections for a city government.

SILVER BAY, N. Y., July 19 -- America needs more "preventive" and less curative religion, the Rev. Dr. Mark A. Dawber, co-executive secretary of the Home Mission Council of North America, said here today at the annual interdenominational Silver Bay Missionary Conference.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Harry Bridges said tonight that he hoped that the national Congress of Industrial Organizations would recognize his union's interest in affiliating itself with a new world maritime labor body sponsored by the WFTU.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- Ken Heintzelman scored his second straight shut-out and his eighth victory in a row as the Phillies blanked the Cubs, 1 -- 0, tonight. Andy Seminick's single sent Willie Jones home from second in the eighth with the only run.

TRENTON, N. J., July 19 -- Living costs, which include such essentials as food, rent, clothing, fuel and light, furniture and house furnishing and miscellaneous necessities, were 1.8 per cent lower during June of this year than in the same month of 1948, but still 78.1 per cent higher than in the similar period of 1939, the pre-war year, D. T. Pitt, statistical supervisor of the New Jersey Department of Agriculture, reported today.

The defense opened its case yesterday in Bronx County Court in the twenty-fifth day of the so-called "lonely hearts" trial, after Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora denied nine motions seeking freedom for the two accused as murderers.

In my opinion a long-term solution to the re-establishment of an equilibrium of payments in the balances between this country and Britain can be found only when trade between us and the sterling area is liberated from discrimination between "hard" and "soft" currencies; when the principle is recognized that each country is entitled to trade in its own national, stabilized currency.

The appointment of Capt. E. J. R. Pollitt as chief marine superintendent of Cunard White Star Limited was announced yesterday by Harold P. Borer, general manager of the company in this country. Captain Pollitt, a veteran of more than thirty years' service with Cunard, succeeds Capt. B. H. Davies, who is retiring after a long and eventful career.

Giorgio Papa, an Italian high school boy who attributes his success to apiarian activities, arrived here yesterday on the liner Vulcania to begin a vacation at an American boys' camp, his prize for winning a nation-wide essay contest in Italy.
John Warren Weiss admitted he's a perfectionist. "More so than I should be in this world of commerce," he sighed.

The Health Department created yesterday a division of poliomyelitis to strengthen its facilities for handling the problems of "a serious disease with a widespread public concern." The division will be a part of the agency's Bureau of Preventable Diseases.

PARIS, July 19 -- The most prominent witness for the prosecution, former Premier Paul Reynaud, testified today in the trial of Otto Abetz that the latter cherished a "political hatred" for him, Leon Blum and the late Georges Mandel.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- The first three-week fall wholesale market since before the war will open here next Monday as several large groups moved their opening date forward one week to coincide with an early market date announced by the Millinery Displayers Association.

Guaranty Trust Company of New York has been appointed agent to accept subscripitons for additional shares of capital stock of Maracaibo Oil Exploration Corporation and to transfer, split and group subscription warrants.
GLASGOW, July 19 (Reuters) -- Despite stubborn resistance by Scotland, the New Zealanders won by ten wickets today. The tourists scored 423 and 16 for no wicket against Scotland's 137 and 299.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Ruth Torgerson, the defending champion, downed her first round opponent, 7 and 6, today in the state women's amateur golf tourney at the Onondaga Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- It was confirmed officially today that last Thursday night's mysterious meeting at Blair House between President Truman and top diplomatic, military and Congressional officials was for deliberation of the question whether Great Britain should receive information and materials to enable her to produce the atomic bomb.

MEXICO CITY, July 19 (AP) -- The National City Bank of New York demanded today that the Bank of Mexico return about $2,000,000 requisitioned during last year's devaluation. National City asserts that the government bank had a right to take only about one-third of the money and at the market rate instead of the old pegged price.

An expert hired by the Pennsylvania Railroad to improve dining-car service trimmed eight ounces off steaks and pared butter allotments to cut costs, Fred Carpi, vice president in charge of traffic, testified yesterday under cross-examination at an Interstate Commece Commission hearing.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Railroad operating revenues showed a further drop last month as compared with June, 1948, the Association of American Railroads reported today.

NEWARK, N. J., July 19 -- An agreement for election among employes of the strike-bound Singer Manufacturing Company in Elizabeth, N. J., to determine the bargaining agent for the workers, was signed here this evening by the interested parties. The election will be held from 6 A. M. to 10 P. M., July 27, in School No. 1, Elizabeth.

"Challenging Years," the autobiography of Stephen S. Wise, which he completed just before his death last spring, has been scheduled for publication in September by Putnam. It is an account of more than fifty years in which he established the Free Synagogue, helped found the American Jewish Congress and World Jewish Congress and worked to bring better understanding between Jews and Christians.

TOKYO, July 19 -- Maj. Daniel C. Imboden, head of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters press section, today accused Japanese Communists of attempting to intimidate Japanese newspapers and foreign correspondents and threatened jail sentences might result if these tactics were continued.

Seventy-five members of the eighty-nine-piece high school band from Odessa, Tex., here for the Lions convention, were stricken yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel with "heat exhaustion," according to a hotel physician. All but two or three were on their feet within a few hours.

There is more than a little good news for the voters of the city in the negotiations and discussions which are now rounding out the various tickets for this year's municipal elections. The Republican-Liberal-Fusion group has strengthened its hand with the choice of Harry Uviller for Controller and Justice Diserio for President of the City Council.

ALBANY, July 19 (AP) -- The state may use tolls collected from the Mid-Hudson Bridge at Poughkeepsie to pay interest charges on its investment in the structure, the Court of Appeals ruled unanimously tonight.

HONG KONG, July 19 (UP) -- Chinese Communist troops driving southward from the Yangtze River threaten to cut off 200,000 Government troops along the Canton-Hankow railway, advices reaching Hong Kong said today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The identity of a successor to Associate Justice Frank Murphy of the Supreme Court was one of the prime topics of conversation here today, but the discussions were entirely speculative.

Two Navy freight and supply ships, carrying 100 members of the Reserve Officers Training Corps of two schools -- the University of Tennessee and Washington Jefferson College -- docked yesterday at the New York Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- No further steps will be taken by the American Federation of Labor to seek a "suitable" labor relations bill in the House at this session of Congress, according to a consensus of 300 leaders who met here today. The meeting was under the auspices of Labor's League for Political Education, the political arm of the AFL.

OMAHA, Neb., July 19 -- Tightening up the race for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation, Larry Evans, champion of the Marshall Chess Club of New York, today drew level with Albert Sandrin of Chicago. Evans won his seventh-round game with George Kramer of Kew Gardens, L. I., while Sandrin was held to a draw by Anthony E. Santasiere, 1945 open champion, in a real fighting game.

ALBANY, July 19 -- The Court of Appeals held unanimously today that accountants might not engage in and charge for the giving of legal advice in relation to the tax laws. There was no written opinion.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 19 -- The fiftieth anniversary tournament of the Pennsylvania State tennis championship lost two of its top men in the singles today as Edward Moylan of Trenton and William Vogt of Philadelphia were eliminated in the second round.

ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP) -- Four home runs and some effective relief hurling gave the Browns a twilight-night double-header victory over the Athletics tonight, 9 to 4 and 5 to 4. It was the second double triumph for the Browns in three days and their fifth straight victory.

Formation of an advisory committee to explore the feasibility of holding an International Trade Fair in New York City in the autumn of 1950 was announced yesterday by James S. Carson, vice chairman of the Colonial Trust Company. Mr.
LONDON, July 19 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, left his troubles at the Treasury this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration said today it has agreed to finance the purchase of $12,930,000 worth of Canadian and United States lumber for recovery use in the United Kingdom.

Daniel Boone Schirmer, a Boston Communist functionary called to refute Government evidence in the Communist trial, became so tangled up yesterday in a maze of admissions, contradictory testimony, refusals to answer and "don't recalls," that Federal Judge Harold R. Medina commented on his forgetfulness and inconsistency.
Mayor O'Dwyer took personal command yesterday of efforts to settle the six-day-old bus strike.
New debt securities valued at $23,100,000 were marketed at competitive bidding yesterday by three public utility companies and a railroad.
COWES, England, July 19 (AP) -- The United States moved back into the running in the British-American Cup yacht series today by winning the third race by 22 1/4 to 13 points.

GENEVA, July 19 -- The economic development of backward areas need not cost hundreds of millions of dollars, Norris E. Dodd, Director General of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization, said here today.

If there were need for reassurance as to the acute "safety consciousness" of our certified airline operators, it should be provided by the incidents which have occurred recently in connection with some of the early flights of the new giant liner, the Boeing Stratocruiser, as operated by Pan American World Airways.

BERLIN, July 19 -- Although the British section of the Berlin airlift "probably" will be reduced starting Aug. 1, no firm decision has yet been reached on the timing of the expected reduction of the United States part in the operation, it was learned from an authoritative United States source today.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Commodity Exchange Authority reported today that trading in wheat and cotton futures shrank in the fiscal year which ended last month, while that in fats and oils went up.

Delegations returning from Israel make a mistake in saying everything's wonderful there, Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations and vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, declared yesterday at the McAlpin Hotel.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Flood threats in the middle Rio Grande Valley of New Mexico pose a hazard to operations of top-secret weapons projects at Los Alamos and Sandia, N. M., the Senate Public Works Committee was told today.

In what is known to the craft as a "rocking chair" game, the Giants mercilessly hammered the Reds into a 13-3 defeat last night at the Polo Grounds. They hit safely and robustly in every inning and scored at least once in each frame.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 19 -- The United States-British Bipartite Board has ordered an investigation of occupation costs and other mandatory charges to Germans with a view to reducing them sharply, it was learned today.

LONDON, July 19 (AP) -- Benny Goodman is solid with Londoners on his first visit to Britain. The Chicago-born clarinet player, dubbed the "King of Swing" back in the Thirties, opened last night at the Palladium Theatre.

Reports from Washington about top - level conversations on the problem of this country's relations with Great Britain and Canada in the field of atomic energy give evidence of a lack of familiarity with certain historic and scientific facts, knowledge of which should help clarify thinking on the subject.
MILFORD, Mich., July 19 -- New safety factors are emphasized in the design and construction of the new Buick special, shown in a preview today at the General Motors proving ground here.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 19 -- Miss Peggy Mackie and Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood took a two-stroke lead in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Scotch foursome tournament when they hit alternate shots to score 37, 41 -- 78 over the Sunningdale Country Club course today.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,892, compared with 2,441 last week and 1,494 in the similar week a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 818 arrivals yesterday against 1,114 last Tuesday.

Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe are at work on a new musical that will be offered for sponsorship to Cheryl Crawford, who produced "Brigadoon," the opus by the same writing team that had a 581-performance run after opening here on March 13, 1947.

LONDON, July 19 -- Britain's National Dock Labor Board laid down the law to the more than 15,000 striking dock workers here today, ordering them to "resume work at 7:45 A. M. Thursday" or risk the loss of their minimum wage and other hard-won benefits encompassed in the National Dock Labor Plan.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Federation of American Scientists announced tonight that representatives of fifteen national organizations are opposed to a proposal by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, that would require a Federal Bureau of Investigation examination of all holders of Atomic Energy Commission fellowships.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 19 -- As suave and well dressed as ever, Gerard Graham Dennis, the international jewel thief, was taken into Westchester County Court under heavy guard today and sentenced to serve eighteen years to life in Sing Sing Prison by Judge Elbert T. Gallagher.

Today's lone film newcomer is a French importation, "The Barber of Seville," opening at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. This adaptation of the Rossini opera, based on the play by Beaumarchais, was produced by Claude Dolbert with the cooperation of the orchestra and chorus of the Opera Comique of Paris.

Under the heading "Make Pay Secondary, Teachers Are Told," in THE TIMES of last week, Dr. Arthur V. Linden, executive officer of placement at Columbia University, is reported to have criticized teacher groups "that can get together only over salary issues" and neglect "the basic and fundamental spiritual aspects of teaching."

The prices of all domestic products of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., will remain unchanged for the balance of the year. Maj. Gen. Frank R. Schwengel, company president, declared yesterday. Even in the event of competitive costs, Seagram prices will remain firm, he said.

With the announcement of dates yesterday for the fall stakes contests at the Aqueduct and Belmont Park tracks, it was revealed that reductions have been made in the added-money values of fourteen of the twenty-six contests. The reason:

There was considerable futility displayed at Ebbets Field yesterday but in the end it was the Pirates who excelled in production of that undesirable element, and the Dodgers pushed over a run in the ninth to win, 4 -- 3 -- their eighth victory over the Bucs in eleven meetings.

PARIS, July 19 -- Harry Bridges, head of the International Longshoremen's Union on the United States West Coast, was elected yesterday president of the International Union of Seamen and Dockers, which has just been created in Marseille under the aegis of the Communist-led World Federation of Trade Unions.

An hour-long television show combining elements of vaudeville, audience-participation and the give-away will be presented at 10 P. M. Fridays over WJZ-TV, starting on Aug. 5. To be known as "A Couple of Joes," it will present Joe Rosenfield, who now offers "Big Joe's Happiness Exchange'' on WOR, and Joe Bushkin, pianist-composer.

Taking to the nation his case for the decisive measures of American foreign policy, President Truman yesterday urged again both the ratification of the North Atlantic Treaty and adequate appropriations for the European Recovery Program. He did so in a non-partisan and almost philosophic discussion of the principles and motives of American foreign policy in a world menaced by totalitarian dictatorships.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 19 -- The organization of a new political party among the Slovenes in Austrian Carinthia to fight for union with Yugoslavia and oppose the Austrian Communist party as well as Austrian Government parties at the forthcoming elections was announced today in Belgrade.

In a radio broadcast late yesterday afternoon, John E. McCarthy, president of the city's strike-bound bus lines, and Michael J. Quill, president of the striking Transport Workers Union, proved just how far apart they now are.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 19 -- After a million miles of travel by automobile in the last forty-two years, Herbert A. Hover, 81 years old, and his wife, Mata, 72, were preparing like a couple of enthusiastic youngsters here this afternoon to embark on a 50,000-mile motor tour of this country, Canada, Mexico, the West Indies and South America.

An annual decrease in copper production of more than 400,000 tons appears likely if curtailment of production in this country and abroad continues at the present rate, C. Donald Dallas, chairman of the board, Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., disclosed here yesterday.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 19 -- Surprise was expressed here today at reports of the effect on the sterling market in New York of the easing of the Canadian currency regulations to help Canadian importers obtain sterling at the current New York price.

In the death of Justice Murphy the nation has lost a public servant who devoted an active life to the service of the public. Whether as prosecutor, judge of a criminal court, Mayor of Detroit, Governor General and High Commissioner of the Philippines, Governor of Michigan, Attorney General of the United States or Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, Frank Murphy did not deviate from the course of righteousness as he saw it.

The weary straphanger, accustomed to having subway doors slammed in his face and to the assorted other indignities of underground travel, will find transit workers ultra-solicitous about his comfort if the threatened slowdown materializes on the city subways.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Net income of corporations in the first quarter of this year dropped to an estimated $2,400,000,000 after taxes, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported here today. This total was about 18 per cent below that for the preceding quarter and 16 per cent below that for the 1948 quarter.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Government is seeking some means other than direct subsidy to help the mining industry, with emphasis on the mineral prospector and small mine operator.

Sixteen civic and business organizations announced plans yesterday for a last-ditch fight against the proposed zoning amendments for parking garages adopted July 13 by the City Planning Commission. The amendments are scheduled to come before the Board of Estimate for ratification or veto tomorrow.
It has come to my attention that a magazine racket misusing the good name of Boys Town is being carried on in various communities throughout the United States without our knowledge or sanction.
