The move of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company in taking advantage of the convertibility guarantee clause of the Economic Cooperation Administration in establishing an industrial instrument plant near Glasgow, Scotland, is proving "highly successful,

PRAGUE, July 19 -- While some of the Ministers responsible for the state's church policy are away in Moscow and while the peasants are bringing in the harvest, the Czechoslovak press this week has begun the long, hard grind of propaganda build-up for church-control measures that will be put into effect when Parliament reconvenes in the autumn.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Federal Reserve Board tonight changed the payment deadline for persons who buy stocks on a cash basis.
The trouble with New York, Phil Palaske said yesterday is that there aren't enough places to pitch a tent.

Another retail outlet for Crawford Clothes, Inc., is planned at 150 East Eighty-sixth Street, where the clothing concern has leased the store, basement and second floor from Mrs. Leila F. Dunlop. Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., was the broker.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 -- Gary Cooper has sold the screen rights to "The Girl On the Via Flaminia," recent novel by Alfred Hayes, to Leland Hayward and Anatole Litvak, Cooper's representative here disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Mexican Government today suspended negotiations with the United States for an official loan to develop the production and marketing of Mexico's petroleum resources. The suspension was announced jointly by the two Governments.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 19 (AP) -- Defending champions retained their honors in the 1949 Chicago-to-Mackinac Island sailing race which ended in a brisk breeze today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- The Washington Post said tonight in a copyrighted story that President Truman had ordered a searching investigation of "five per centers" and their "obliging friends in high-placed government positions, no matter who is embarrassed."

SHANGHAI, July 19 -- While the Communist drive into South China appeared to be gathering momentum, the Peiping radio today announced new victories in the Northwest, which carried reinforced Communist armies to Paoki, guarding the approaches to Szechwan from the north.
SEATTLE, July 19 -- A twin-engined C-46 passenger plane with twenty - eight persons aboard crashed and burned in a South Seattle housing project tonight. At least three persons were believed dead.

Coffee futures advanced sharply in early trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. New outside buying and short-covering, along with demand for the distant delivery months by producer interests, helped establish new highs for the current delivery position.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 19 -- Sailing, which is the use of wind for propulsive power, is a matter of catching the breeze in canvas and using it skillfully when there is plenty of it.

Could it be that the various campaigns and drives to "fight" polio, cancer, tuberculosis, heart disease, etc., are in reality inoculating the minds of the people with the very fear and cause of the disease which the medical profession is trying to eradicate through research made possible by the funds raised?

United Fruit Company, in its report yesterday for the six months ended on July 2, estimated its net profit at $24,176,000, or $2.75 a share, compared with $27,025,000, or $3.07 a share, earned in the initial half of last year.
The cotton futures market closed steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with final prices 1 to 7 points net lower on the day.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State and War, to Senators John Foster Dulles and Irving M. Ives of New York, on the North Atlantic treaty:

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- President Truman said tonight that Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president of THE NEW YORK TIMES, had acknowledged he was "misinformed" when he told Pope Pius XII in 1948 that Mr. Truman had no chance of election.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 20 (UP) -- An Alabama official said today that Ku Klux Klan members had been identified by the insignia on their "bedsheet" uniforms as participants in four of the recent floggings in the Birmingham area.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Secretary of State Acheson described as "utterly without foundation" today a Russian protest that Italy's membership in the North Atlantic defense alliance violated the Italian peace treaty.

The pace of the recovery in the stock market was slowed somewhat yesterday although another fairly broad advance lifted the list a bit. Strength in the steels and rails helped maintain the advance but volume diminished as activity lessened in the low-price utility section.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 20 -- Although not all the members of the Long Island team appeared at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today to participate in the practice session for the annual triangular team matches tomorrow, Frank Strafaci, Long Island titleholder, made his presence felt with a round of 67.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Oats and soybeans led the grain markets to higher levels today, July beans selling at a new high since January and came within 7 1/2 cents of the seasonal top, while the new crop months went into new ground for the year.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, chairman of the Joint Congressional Commission on Reconstruction of the White House, announced today the appointment of three engineering aides.

The Doehler-Jarvis Corporation, with five plants making aluminum and zinc base die-cast products, has developed a new die-cast frame automobile door which requires use of the largest die-casting machine so far developed, H. H. Doehler, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, Allentown, Pa., registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposal to sell 75,000 shares of $100 par cumulative preferred stock. The utility said the proceeds would help finance new construction estimated to cost $75,000,000 by the end of 1952.

Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio upheld yesterday the right of License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey to revoke the license of Louis Cohen's theatre ticket office, 174 West Forty-eighth Street.
NEWARK, N. J., July 20 -- Paul Robeson, a singer whose classic rendition of "or Man River" is considered unsurpassed, restated here tonight: I'I am a radical and I am going to stay a radical."

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UP) -- President Truman solemnly decorated Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan with a medal labeled "Operation Union Station" memorializing the military aide's brush with reporters here early this month, Newsweek magazine reported today.

A $2,500,000 to $3,500,000 program of redesign and improvement has been undertaken by the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad with a view to luring back some of the 43,000,000 passengers it has lost since 1927, Morris Cohon, president of the road, disclosed yesterday.

If there can be any doubt that television is sweeping the country, there is certainly no doubt that it is sweeping through the realm of home furnishings. A television set in every room is an accomplished reality in the seventeen interior settings at the Abraham Straus midsummer furniture show that will open today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 20 -- Classified junior sailors had their session at the Larchmont Yacht Club today in the break of Race Week. Boys and girls who had not reached their eighteenth birthdays this morning manned 156 sailing craft as skippers and crews.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 20 -- The successful wind-up of all four Israeli-Arab armistice negotiations was hailed here today as an impressive achievement for the United Nations and as a vivid demonstration again that the world organization could be a potent instrument for preserving peace.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- Maxwell Shane, who recently joined Twentieth Century-Fox as a writer - producer - director, has purchased screen rights to "The Hickory Stick," a 1948 novel by Virgil Scott for independent production, Shane's Hollywood representative announced today.

The new commercial treaty with Italy goes far in assuring fair treatment for private United States investments in that country and should serve to stimulate new dollar investments there, H. J. Heinz 2d, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, declared here yesterday.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein filed formal objections yesterday to an intermediate accounting by two executors of the estate of Hiram Edward Manville, who left gross assets of $14,499,000 when he died in 1944. Mr. Manville had been chairman of the board and president of the Johns-Manville Corporation.

A nine-point formula to increase profits of depressed industries was outlined here yesterday by Raymond E. Bell, management engineer, 726 Jackson Place, Washington, D. C. Mr. Bell advanced his formula in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, following conferences with industrial executives here.
HONOLULU, July 20 (AP) -- The race was decided, but two more yachts finished the gruelling 2,225-mile transpacific yacht event today, leaving three still at sea.

Local 702, Motion Picture Laboratory Technicians Union, AFL, announced yesterday that it had set midnight, July 31, as its deadline for a strike against sixteen New York laboratories processing films for the American motion-picture industry.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 -- For the first time in the country's modern history, Lebanon is introducing universal compulsory military service. Announcing a decision to that effect today, the Government reported an additional appropriation of $4,000,000 for national defense.

In its first change of ownership in eighty years, the four-story store and loft building on a plot 27 by 69 by 26 by 53 feet at 8 West Broadway and 223 Greenwich Street, just north of Vesey Street, was sold by the estate of Adolphus Koffman and the Continental Bank Trust Company, as trustees, to a client of George Kittner, attorney.

Twenty-six delegates from seventeen nations arrived by air yesterday from Paris for the first International Student Service conference in the United States since 1931, to be held from July 25 to Aug. 3 at Wells College, Aurora, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Former Secretary of State George C. Marshall said today that the North Atlantic pact would "immeasurably" strengthen the security of the United States and improve the prospects for lasting world peace.

Unseeded Bill Merriam, an 18-year-old youth from Coral Gables, Fla., playing his first junior tennis circuit, yesterday upset third-seeded Tim Coss of Washington, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, as the semi-final rounds were completed in the Eastern junior and boys' championships at the West Side Club, Forest Hills.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP) -- Hank Sauer drove in all of the Cubs' runs with two homers and a triple tonight as they defeated the Phillies, 4 -- 3, in eleven innings. The triple came in the eleventh with Andy Pafko on base.

A decline of 2,299,000 barrels was recorded last week in the nation's gasoline stocks, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies at the end of last week amounted to 111,464,000 barrels, against 113,763,000 a week earlier.

BERLIN, July 20 -- Western zone commandants today sent a note to the Soviet transportation chief, Maj. Gen. Pavel A. Kvashnin, asking him what he intended to do about the fact that railroad employes working in the East sector of Berlin and living in the West sector of the city are receiving no West marks in their pay envelopes.
CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 20 -- One million new elementary teachers will be needed in this country in the next ten years, but only 200,000 will be available, noted educators declared here today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and closed unchanged to 5 points higher.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 20 -- The United States moved formally today to drop the work of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission until the Soviet Union had accepted the control plan of the majority.

The B-36 investigation, scheduled to be started by the House Armed Services Committee next Monday, can help greatly, if it is a wise and reasoned inquiry and not a witch hunt, to clarify public and service opinion about one of the great issues of our time.

If someone will move that Lions' Day be celebrated at the Polo Grounds each time Dave Koslo pitches, a fellow named Dave Koslo gladly will second said motion. Last year when the international fraternal order was here the southpaw blanked the Reds, 5 -- 0.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 20 -- Silence on the part of High Commissioner-designate John J. McCloy as to his future organizational and staffing plans has resulted in a wave of uncertainty even among high officials in the present United States Military Government force.

The State of South Carolina sold yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 of state highway bonds maturing from Feb. 1, 1951, to Feb. 1, 1959, to a banking syndicate headed by National City Bank, here, at an interest cost of 1.3889 per cent. The winning bid was 100.0831 for an interest rate of 1.40 per cent.

MOSCOW, July 20 -- Anatoly Surov, young Soviet playwright, charged today that President Truman's atomic conference last week took up the question of "bringing atom bombs nearer to the target of attack," namely, the Soviet Union.

PARIS, July 20 -- Gen. Kurt von Choltitz, the German general who withdrew from Paris without executing his orders for the destruction of the city, testified today that Otto Abetz, as Nazi Ambassador, had supported him in his refusal to obey the orders.

Ralph F. Gates, former Governor of the State of Indiana, was elected yesterday president of the Wm. Penn Fire Insurance Company to succeed Joseph B. Simon, who has resigned. With the exception of P. H. Mell, executive vice president, the entire board of directors resigned, including Mr. Simon, R. Sturgis Ingersoll, and Charles Denby.

Details of industrial advertising budgets by product for the years 1949, 1948 and 1939, and a breakdown of appropriations by media will be among highlights of a study by the National Industrial Advertisers Association, it was announced yesterday.

ROME, Thursday, July 21 -- The vote taken by the Chamber of Deputies on ratification of Italy's entry into the Atlantic pact was annulled early this morning when Giovanni Gronchi, Christian Democrat president of the Chamber, made the startling announcement that the counting had shown that more votes had been cast than the number of Deputies present at the session.

Cooperative tenants who saw only blueprints and floor plans when they bought apartments in the non-profit Queensview Community six months ago now can see exactly how their dreams will look when materialized eight months hence.

Figures indicating that rent rises granted to landlords here under the new "fair net operating income" formula may be fewer but larger than those permitted under previous "hardships" rulings were released yesterday by John J. Pendergast, Regional Housing Expediter.

TOKYO, July 20 -- Japan today assumed the unaccustomed role of shipper of relief food. The first of three consignments for strikebound Hawaii left tonight on the American President Liner President Cleveland, due in Honolulu July 27.

We agree with the City Planning Commission that the mounting increase in the use of motor vehicles has created serious traffic congestion in New York's streets, especially in the main business sections. It is also true, as the commission says, that this congestion has resulted in serious interference with the primary function of our streets -- the free movement of traffic essential to the health, safety and general welfare of the public.

Three new issues of public utility company bonds totaling $18,250,000 will be placed on the market today by banking syndicates which bought them on Tuesday at competitive sale. The public offerings are as follows:
I should like to comment on an article in THE TIMES of July 7 concerning the shortage of physicians in Kansas.

BERLIN, July 20 -- John J. McCloy, United States Military Governor and High Commissioner-designate to the coming German Federal Republic, tackled one of his most difficult problems -- Berlin and its relationship to the republic -- in a conference today with Ernst Reuter, Berlin's Lord Mayor.
DETROIT, July 20 (AP) -- The Tigers pushed over three runs in the eighth inning today to register a victory over Mickey Harris and the Senators, 6 -- 5.

The State of New York has fifteen million people; Pennsylvania has ten million; Hawaii one-half million. Mr. Mantel, in his letter in THE TIMES of July 11, argues that Hawaii should be "given her chance as an equal" by being admitted to statehood.
HONG KONG, July 20 (UP) -- Chinese Communist columns were reported advancing steadily through South Central China today, meeting little opposition.

Greater emphasis on the sale of haberdashery and possible later addition of men's suits, hats and outerwear to lines now carried in D. A. Schulte, Inc., cigar stores is being planned for the 186-store chain. H. Cornell Smith made these disclosures following the announcement of his appointment as president of the Schulte group yesterday.

Hearings were opened yesterday on Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for a $150,000 survey of reclassification and wage adjustment in the city's civil service system. Presiding was a committee of two -- Joseph A. McNamara, president of the Municipal Civic Service Commission, and Thomas J. Patterson, director of the budget.

Mayor O'Dwyer won one of his demands on Hugo E. Rogers yesterday when Mr. Rogers resigned as leader of Tammany and the Tammany executive committee elected Carmine G. DeSapio, a leader of the First Assembly District, to succeed him.

The Republican Intercounty Committee for the Return of Good Government to New York City held a special meeting last night at the National Republican Club and instructed its executive committee to prepare a militant campaign program for the election of the Fusion city ticket and report at the next meeting of the full committee.
Your editorial of July 8 regarding Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed two-year study of reclassification completely misrepresents the position of the New York District, United Public Workers of America, CIO.

Teach the masses of Asia, Africa, the Pacific islands, South and Central America to read their own languages, give them technical and material aid "without any political strings attached" -- that is the way to win the cold war against communism, Dr. Frank C. Laubach asserts.

LONDON, July 20 -- Still smarting with annoyance over the National Dock Labor Board's unauthorized "back to work" order, issued yesterday to striking dock workers, the British Government was authoritatively reported today to be planning to dispense with the services of Lord Ammon, chairman of the board and chief Socialist whip in the House of Lords.

The air and the public prints are both filled these days with plans for houses. They stress mother's own type of kitchen, wood-burning fireplaces, garages and the kind of heat which seeps through the floors or ceilings rather than in the old-fashioned way, through radiators.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A record-smashing grain export of 686,074,000 bushels for the crop year 1948-49 was reported today by the Department of Agriculture.

An increase of 234,511 shares in the short interest to a total of 1,844,313 shares on July 15 over the 1,609,802 shares a month before was reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The information, compiled by the Exchange from its members and member firms, does not include short positions carried in the off-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.

A move that may eventually lead to a reduction of $50,000,000 annually in the over-all operating expenses of the nation's maritime industry and save the Army's Transportation Corps an additional $3,000,000 has been taken by President Truman in the reactivation of the Maritime War Emergency Board.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 20 (AP) -- The defending champion and a former titleholder scored easy victories today to advance to the quarter-finals of the state women's amateur golf tourney.

PARIS, July 20 -- Speaking to the French Cabinet today of the expected ratification of the North Atlantic pact by the United States Senate tomorrow, Foreign Minister Robert Schuman said that military aid by the United States to the European signatories seemed a "natural consequence" of that ratification.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 20 -- After three and a half months of hard, tedious bargaining, Syria and Israel signed an armistice agreement today. Both sides agreed to keep their military forces behind their international frontiers and to establish demilitarized zones in the contested areas.

A Polish couple, who allegedly became German citizens during the war but who later posed as slave laborers of the Nazis to gain entry to this country as displaced persons, were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday.

Increased sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended with June over the same periods of last year were shown by the General Foods Corporation in a statement issued yesterday by Clarence Francis, chairman.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 -- A bold gangland ambush early today left Michael (Mickey) Cohen, leading Los Angeles bookmaker, only slightly injured but caused critical wounds to three persons with him -- one a special agent of the State Attorney General assigned to guard him in a mysterious decoy operation.

ATHENS, July 20 -- The public welfare division of the Economic Cooperation Administration's mission here reported today that the number of refugees in Greece as a result of the war against the Communist-led guerrillas had been reduced by 20 per cent.

While the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Stafford Cripps, is in Switzerland on sick leave his place will be taken by the Rt. Hon. Clement R. Attlee. Mr. Attlee is, as everybody knows, Prime Minister and First Lord of the Treasury. In that position his powers are comparable with those of an American President.

Raymond M. Fernandez, co-defendant in the "lonely hearts" trial, denied on the witness stand in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday that he had any part in the slaying last Jan. 4 of Mrs. Janet J. Fay in Valley Stream, L. I.

NEWARK, N. J., July 20 -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced here today that it had acquired about 100 acres along Morris Turnpike, in Millburn, and tentatively plans a development of a large community shopping center, patterned after that of J. C. Nicholas Country Club, in Kansas City, Mo.

Public Realty Corporation has sold the five-story building at 4124 Fourth Avenue, corner of Forty-second Street, in Brooklyn, containing seven stores and fifty-seven apartments, to the 751 Realty, Inc. The property is assessed at $170,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $91,000.

CLEVELAND, July 20 -- The Yankees may pick up a lot of fresh wounds and splinters as the road to a pennant gets perhaps a trifle bumpier, but getting them to roll over and play dead still remains the year's most mystifying problem.

Favorable reports filed yesterday by the City Planning Commission and by Thomas J. Patterson, Director of the Budget, set the stage for Board of Estimate approval of construction of the first phase of a $1,623,250 recreation center to be built in St. Mary's Park, St. Ann's Avenue and St. Mary's Street, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that application of a union's by-laws that were in aid of a secondary boycott was illegal under the Taft-Hartley Act.

OMAHA, Neb., July 20 -- Larry Evans of New York and Albert Sandrin of Chicago remained unscathed after eight rounds of play for the open championship of the United States Chess Federation, with scores of 6 1/2 -- 1 1/2, but they did not win today.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Two Lea, leading all the way, soundly trounced five 3-year-old filly rivals in the $25,000 Cleopatra Handicap at Arlington Park today.

A net income of $2,976,343 was cleared by the Douglas Aircraft Company in the six months ended on May 31, or $2,551,392 more than the $424,951 earned in the corresponding period of the previous year, according to the report issued yesterday.

LONDON, July 20 -- The Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies who are drafting an Austrian peace treaty today approved a treaty article waiving Austrian claims against Germany and at the same time guaranteeing the restitution of Austrian property now in Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Federal Communications Commission, in preparation for the hearings on the proposed plan to add forty-two new television channels to the country's service, requested today research and experimental data from experimental television stations.
GENEVA, July 20 -- The Economic and Social Council asked Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations in a resolution adopted today to start an immediate investigation of slavery.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., July 20 -- For the first time since the end of the war, the American consumer is being given full opportunity to exercise his right to "the fifth freedom -- the freedom of choice," Prof. Erwin H. Schell, head of the Department of Business and Engineering Administration, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, declared tonight.

Ed Wynn's television show will become a Thursday night feature on the Columbia Broadcasting System network starting Oct. 6. It will be broadcast each week from 9 to 9:30 P. M. Another development in formulation of plans for the series is that it will be sponsored by the Speidel Company, watch band makers.

Allocations of virtually all Wedgwood dinnerware patterns to 750 American and fifty major Canadian retailers have been ended, Hensleigh Wedgwood, president, Josiah Wedgwood Sons, Inc., revealed yesterday. The company, American distributing branch of Josiah Wedgwood Sons, Ltd., English dinnerware producer, is retaining quotas only on some highly styled bone china patterns in limited production in the English parent concern because of continuing skilled labor shortages, he said.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- Lou Klein's two-run double off the left-field wall gave the Cardinals a ten-inning, 6-4 victory over the Braves tonight after the former's ace, Howie Pollet, had been belted out of action in the second session.

Herman Lipski, deputy collector of customs in charge of the enforcement division at the Port of New York, yesterday became the first member of this agency to receive the Certificate for Meritorious Civilian Service. The award, made by Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder, was presented to Mr. Lipski by Edward H. Foley Jr., Under Secretary of the Treasury, at ceremonies in the rotunda of the Custom House, Bowling Green.

Fred L. Johnson, vice president of Belding Heminway, Inc., was elected president and a member of the executive committee at yesterday's board meeting held here. He succeeds William G. F. Price, who has resigned from these offices because of poor health.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 20 -- Eighteen-year-old Tony Trabert of Cincinnati established himself as one of the most accomplished young players coming up in tennis in extending the national titleholder, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, to 7 -- 5, 11 -- 9 today in the Pennsylvania State grass court championship at the Merion Cricket Club.

BELVIDERE, N. J., July 20 -- Yale University will receive a $100,000 endowment fund from the estate of Mrs. Andre Massenat, it was learned today when her will was probated before Warren County Surrogate Clayton Willever.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer was not really fighting Tammany but was seeking to gain control over Tammany and every other Democratic county machine.

A QUICK way to handle the impending Harmsworth Trophy international motorboat races would be to say "Gar Wood" and hurry off to Larchmont for a look at the current Race Week sailing events. It would be quick, but the wrath of various Canadians and Englishmen might be painful.

It is unfortunate that leaders in education should twist figures so as to incorrectly portray the facts. Witness the report made by Dr. Francis S. Chase of the University of Chicago before the N. E. A. Convention. To quote from your Benjamin Fine, "This well-documented study disclosed that the proportionate expenditure of national income for public schools dropped from about 3 per cent to 2 per cent in the last ten years."

Announcement yesterday by the Board of Water Supply of the opening of bids for the twenty-five-mile East Delaware tunnel of the Delaware Aqueduct indicated that the city would save almost $6,000,000 over the most optimistic advance estimate of water supply engineers.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Administration forces, their ranks divided, fought what appeared to be a losing battle in the House today for a limited "trial run" of the Brannan farm program.

A bus strike settlement sponsored by Mayor O'Dwyer was accepted last night by the two struck companies, but it will not become final unless the 3,300 strikers vote for it this morning by secret ballot.

The next six weeks will be busy ones for the competitive shooters, for during this period the national titles will be decided in trap, skeet, rifle and pistol, with a number of newcomers threatening to topple the crowns from veteran shooters.

Fashions are really stepping out these hot summer days. Now along comes Gotham Hosiery with a new color range for fall. Their most extreme shades are called Venetian -- inspired, it is to be assumed, by that rollicking musical "Kiss Me, Kate."

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The close attention which an unusual number of House members paid this week to Representative Keefe of Wisconsin throughout his long summation of the Alger Hiss trial was not only because he presented his case in court-room manner.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The White Sox slowed down the upward surge of the Red Sox by winning an 8-7 thriller today. It was Boston's fourth defeat in the past fifteen games.

Giovanni Buitoni said yesterday that in Italy they called a product like his new one "capelli d'angelo -- hair of an angel." One in the food news department described it less poetically as "the skinniest spaghetti I have ever seen."

The New York-Brooklyn Yankees, who on Monday are to open their All-America Football Conference training camp at Cheshire, Conn., yesterday signed Gilbert Johnson, Southern Methodist passing ace, to a contract. Johnson, a 6-foot 2-inch quarterback, was a torpedo man in submarine service during the war.

PARIS, July 20 -- Negotiations for a European payments agreement to finance international trade, long delayed by a dispute between Britain and the United States. have now been blocked by a sharp difference between the Swiss and Americans regarding the terms of Switzerland's participation.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The AFL's Labor League for Political Education will "point up" the 1950 Senatorial contests in states where it has "better than an even chance to win."

A strange silhouette appeared against the clouds over Long Island at noon yesterday and the spectators lining the observation deck at La Guardia Airport turned their attention from the arrivals and departures of the modern airliners operating there.

Trustees of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, which is being reorganized under the National Bankruptcy Act, applied to Federal Judge Samuel H. Kaufman yesterday for an order directing them to put an eight-cent fare into effect as soon as it was approved by the Public Service Commission.

BUENOS AIRES, July 20 -- With Dr. John A. Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, as guest speaker, a conference of Protestant leaders from all over Latin America has begun here a discussion of Protestantism's role and of the religious situation in general in all countries south of the Rio Grande.

TEANECK, N. J., July 20 -- The loneliness and idleness that often attend retirement have been banished effectively for at least thirty-five residents of this community, the members of the Teaneck Retired Men's Club.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson accused the Communist regime in Czechoslovakia today of violation of the United Nations Charter by efforts to suppress freedom of religion; and, by implication, he included all Soviet satellite states in his indictment.

Tired from household tasks, Mrs. Earl Deas of 500 West 146th Street, sat rocking her 5-month-old daughter Earline in her fifth-floor apartment yesterday. It was about 9:30 A. M. and soon Mike Caparino, the ice man, would arrive.
The Lions convention overflowed yesterday from Madison Square Garden to the Polo Grounds and the United Nations headquarters, and to theatre matinees and shopping districts.

NEWARK, N. J., July 20 -- A threatened strike by 5,000 plant equipment workers of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company was averted late tonight when representatives of the Independent Union of Telephone Workers signed an agreement on the company's terms.

It is long past time for the Administration to prove the sincerity of its pledges in behalf of a more liberal and honorable DP bill. More than six weeks ago the House approved such a bill, but it has been pigeonholed ever since in a Senate Judiciary subcommittee, presided over by Senator McCarran.

HONOLULU, July 20 -- Police held twenty-eight striking pickets of the International Longshoremens and Warehousemens Union, CIO, without bail tonight after pickets attacked nonunion employes of the newly organized Hawaii Stevedores, Ltd., in a melee that resulted in twenty-three men being injured, at least one seriously.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 13, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Home-hungry service men and economy-minded Congressmen today eyed Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods' personal low-cost housing project -- a one-bedroom dwelling with half an acre of land in near-by Virginia, built to sell for only $6,750.

DANBURY, Conn., July 20 -- The 300 members of the city's seven volunteer fire companies are hotter today than a general alarm blaze and the reason is not this afternoon's scorching temperatures in the high nineties.

Certificates permitting the Law Center Foundation of New York University to press eviction suits against tenants of a Washington Square block have been issued by Francis M. Johnson, area rent director for lower Manhattan, it became known yesterday.

The American public has not been told just what request has been addressed to our Government by Great Britain in the matter of the atomic bomb; but from the background material supplied by William L. Laurence in an article in our newspaper yesterday it is possible to draw certain reasonable conclusions.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Purchase of The Washington Times-Herald by The Chicago Tribune was announced tonight. The sale was made by seven employes of Mrs. Eleanor Patterson, editor and publisher of the Times-Herald until her death July 24, 1948, who inherited the newspaper under her will.

BERLIN, July 20 -- The only way to relieve the artificially induced overpopulation of Western Germany is to raise the level of industry in the trizonal area, to permit the large-scale emigration of Germans to labor-short parts of the world and to obtain modification in favor of Germany of the existing de facto frontier with Poland, United States authorities in Germany have concluded.

A group of American track and field stars, the largest to leave this country since last year's Olympic Games, will leave from New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, today for Oslo. There they will be met by a smaller force from this country, whom they will join to compete against the top performers of Sweden, Finland, Norway, Denmark and Iceland in a three-day meet at Oslo on July 27, 28 and 29.

Giovanni Bagarotti, Italian violinist, made an excellent impression at his Stadium debut last night with the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under Pierre Monteux. Heard as soloist in the Concerto in G minor by Bruch, the highly gifted artist gave a distinguished and completely satisfying performance of this exacting work.

The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn has taken over more than $100,000,000 of mortgage loans covering more than 40,000 homes in this state from the Home Owners Loan Corporation, George C. Johnson, president of the bank, announced yesterday.

Actors Equity Association yesterday voted to reprimand David Burns, actor, in connection with charges of conduct unbecoming an Equity member filed last week by George S. Kaufman, playwright-director. A hearing of the charges was held Tuesday afternoon by Equity's governing body, the council, but action was reserved until yesterday.

Once again the eyes of the world turn with anxious inquiry to Washington, where the Senate is scheduled to vote today on the most momentous measure ever sponsored by the United States in times of ostensible peace -- the North Atlantic Treaty, which unites more than 300,000,000 people of the Atlantic community in an all-for-one-and-one-for-all alliance in defense of peace and their own freedom and security.

New highs were established yesterday in several positions and spot July "S" contracts established a new high for futures in a day of active trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Final levels for Contract "S" were 17 to 49 points higher on sales amounting to 15,750 bags.

Shifting infielders to the left when Ralph Kiner is at bat is no defense against a home run, as Manager Barney Shotton found out to his sorrow yesterday at Ebbets Field, when the Pirate slapped down his league-leading Dodgers, 8 -- 6.

Four 16-month-old indictments against six professional bondsmen and two alleged runners accusing them of violating the state insurance law by conspiring to solicit business were dismissed yesterday by Judge Nathan R. Sobel in Kings County Court. The indictment gainst a ninth defendant, named as a runner, was upheld.

The ten-story and penthouse apartment building for forty families at 220 West Seventy-first Street was sold by the 220 Corporation, Irving S. Wolper, president, to the Jaxell Corporation, a client of Benjamin Jaffe, in a deal reported yesterday by M. A. Spinrad and Earl Douglas Hansen, Inc., brokers.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) --Today's report of{ the livestock markets here by the Department [ ot Agriculture follov:s:

Prices of copper-based alloys have been increased by smelters making casting ingots, spokesmen revealed here yesterday. New prices reflect recent increases in both copper and zinc prices, executives said.

Louis Feder began making wigs of all shapes and curliness at the age of 14 in his native Austria. Yesterday he celebrated an anniversary in his studio at 545 Fifth Avenue -- his thirty-fifth consecutive year of covering heads. The count was 45,000 wigs for men, women and children.

St. Clare's Hospital yesterday announced that bids will be opened today at the hospital, 415 West Fifty-first Street, for a seven-story and basement nurses' home and training school to be erected on Fifty-second Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

SEATTLE, July 20 -- Investigators of the Civil Aeronautics Board began study today of the wreckage of a twin-motor passenger plane in an effort to learn the cause of engine failure which plunged it into a group of houses on its take-off from Boeing Field late last night.
CLEVELAND, July 20 (AP) -- Center Fielder Larry Doby of the Indians was fined tonight after he made a futile attempt to steal home in a game with the Yankees.

A zoning variance for twenty-one years has been granted to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, permitting the organization to erect its proposed $950,000 structure at East Ninety-second Street, York Avenue and East Ninety-third Street, Harris H. Murdock, chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, said yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 20 -- Adding an 80 to their first-round 78 for a 36-hole tally of 158, Mrs. Bernard Freeman and Miss Peggy Mackie of Inwood won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association scotch foursome two-day event over the Sunningdale Golf Course today.
The "old switch game" backfired badly in Brooklyn yesterday on two middle-aged confidence men, leaving their intended victim $10 richer at their expense, instead of $690 poorer, as they had planned.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A House Judiciary subcommittee today heard two lawyers of widely disparate backgrounds describe monopoly in industry as the direct road to socialism.

Two important factors in the showing of designs in John Walther fabrics yesterday at the Hampshire House were the handsome texture effects lending surface interest and the subtle blending of rich colors. There was a strong feeling for understatement, of perfecting detail and achieving deep elegant color tones rather than bold ones.

Charles Buchen, 52-year-old former regional officer in the surplus property disposal section of the War Assets Administration, pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to a four-count indictment charging fraud in the disposal of surplus materials.

Venturesome banking syndicates continue to reach for new bond issues put up for sale at deadline bidding. Issues that were "sticky" or "slow" days ago are moving out and primary buyers are probing about to find the safe minimum for establishing new resistance points on the yield-spread charts.

" The Vital Center: The Politics of Freedom," by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., has been scheduled for Sept. 8 publication by Houghton Mifflin. In it the author of the Pulitzer Prize winner, "The Age of Jackson," examines what we mean by democracy and what we are doing to preserve free society in an industrial age.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- After two years of resisting the Taft-Hartley law provision requiring that union officers sign non-Communist affidavits if the union is to use the machinery of the National Labor Relations Board, the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union, CIO, capitulated today.
LONG BEACH, L. I., July 20 -- The regular Democratic organization here announced tonight its candidates for supervisor, city judge and five city council posts.

Anyone who has admired the kind of furniture known as "architects' modern," but who has been chilled by the antiseptic atmosphere of many architect-designed interiors, should be delighted with the new rooms that opened yesterday at Bloomingdale's.

The Brooklyn Plasterers Contractors Association, in violation of its certificate of incorporation, paid dividends to its members and exacted $94,153 in assorted levies, David Eisenberg, an accountant for the State Attorney General's office, testified yesterday in Kings County Court.

MOSCOW, July 20 -- It would come as no surprise in Moscow if within a few days the new United States Ambassador, Vice Admiral Alan G. Kirk, received an invitation from the Kremlin to come and pay his respects to Premier Stalin.

DEDHAM, Mass., July 20 -- Judge Arthur W. Davis of Norfolk County Probate Court today granted to Barbara Hutton Troubetzkoy custody of her 13-year-old son, Lance, until Sept. 15. Her attorneys filed a petition this morning requesting that the boy be allowed to extend his stay in Europe with his mother instead of returning to his father, Curt Haugwitz Reventlow, in Newport, R. I., on July 26, the date set last May.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson called on Israel and the Arab states today to send delegations to the Lausanne meeting of the United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission with "full authority" to negotiate a settlement of all outstanding issues.
Marc Hoffman has been appointed general manager of the, newly-created airfoam division of the Englander Company, Inc. He formerly was controller.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Truman flew back to the capital today from Chicago and the diamond jubilee of the Mystic Shrine of North America. He made the flight in two hours and three minutes on the Independence.

BOMBAY, July 20 (AP) -- A Royal Dutch Airline (KLM) plane will leave for Amsterdam Friday with the ashes of twenty-two of the forty-five persons killed in the crash of one of the line's planes near here July 12.
MONTREAL, July 20 -- Brendan Macken of Canada will meet Billy Sidwell of Australia when the Davis Cup tennis teams of the two countries open their American zone series here tomorrow.

TOKYO, July 20 -- Japanese repatriates from the Soviet Union, all of whom have received thorough training in Communist thought, now have adopted a new technique as they return here. This is silence and a sit down policy with which they resist the Japanese program of sending them back to their homes.

Directors of the New York Seven-Up Bottling Company, Inc., a division of Joyce Seven-Up Bottlers, Inc., yesterday elected three executives to vice presidential posts, John M. Joyce Jr., president, announced. They include Sidney P. Mudd, in charge of operations; John P. McCann, in charge of production and John J. York, in charge of finance.

A gelding named Detective -- his sire is Reaping Reward -- won the first of the Saratoga-at-Jamaica stakes races yesterday. Apparently beaten high in the stretch, he stuck gamely to the task and was rewarded with a neck decision at the end of the six furlongs of the $12,250 Albany Handicap for 2-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Tighe E. Woods, Housing Expediter, reported today that in May and June 50,752 landlords' petitions were granted, increasing rents on 98,608 rental units. Rents were increased an average of $6.50 per month per unit, or about 19 per cent, the announcement said.

LONDON, July 20 -- Any help that President Truman's appeal to Congress not to cut Marshall Plan aid might have given to the stock market here today was offset by the continuance of the dock strike and the clash of opinion between the Dock Board and the Government.

NEWARK, N. J., July 20 (AP) -- Reverberations of the recent Jersey City Commission election were heard today in Superior Court as a stevedore contractor sought to halt what he termed a threat to his operations arising from political differences.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Justice Felix Frankfurter of the United States Supreme Court said today he "deemed it an unnecessary formality to be formally served with a subpoena" to testify as a character witness at the recent trial in New York of Alger Hiss on perjury charges.

According to advices from Washington, the American Federation of Labor "has abandoned all hope of repealing the Taft-Hartley Act at the present session of Congress." The Federation's leaders are reported as concluding, at the end of an all-day discussion, that it would be a "waste of time" to continue their efforts.

Certain to find favor with women who want fine quality furs without exaggerated styling were those offered yesterday at Arnold Constable's fall showing. Here were the season's fashionable forty-inch coats, the shorter topper, such luxurious combinations as mink lavished on Persian, the fitted and flaring back silhouette.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 20 -- District National Action committees throughout Czechoslovakia today summoned more representative groups of Roman Catholic priests and nuns to mettings at which notice was served on the religious personnel that what were called "treasonable" attempts to enforce the Vatican's decree of excommunication of Communists would be met by reprisals not only against individuals but against the religious orders to which they belonged.
Old Shep, the Bronx Zoo's only specimen of the rare kea, a parrot-like bird that doesn't talk -- only screams -- died yesterday of arterio sclerosis, the zoo announced. Old Shep was 28.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 20 (AP) -- Adile, a red roan from the barn of Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords, easily won the Monmouth Oaks today, scoring a length-and-a-half victory over William Helis' Delta.

ANYONE who has ever taken an airplane ride or even contemplated going up in one of those flying contraptions should be interested in Oliver La Farge's "The Eagle in the Egg,"* the fabulous story of our wartime military air transport service, excellently told by the author of "Laughing Boy."

SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 20 -- Foreign Minister Vassil Kolarov, veteran Communist revolutionist and close friend of the late Georgi Dimitrov, was tonight named Mr. Dimitrov's successor as Bulgarian Premier.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Senate reached tonight the beginning of the end of its long debate on the North Atlantic treaty, on the eve of the overwhelming ratification that clearly was in prospect.

GUATEMALA, July 20 (AP) -- A military revolt against the Government of President Juan Jose Arevalo died out today. Calm spread over this capital after twenty-four hours of fighting that followed the assassination Monday of Col. Francisco Javier Arana, chief of the armed services.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, Director of the National Bureau of Standards, attacked the House Un-American Activities Committee, former and present, in testimony today before a Senate Rules subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy staged a sequel today to last Thursday night's secret discussion at Blair House, President Truman's temporary residence, of proposals to share more fully atomic-bomb secrets and materials with Great Britain.

LONDON, July 20 -- A picture of Britain's struggle for economic survival was drawn today in overseas trade returns for June. In that month the adverse balance of trade was the biggest in twenty-one months.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., July 20 -- Decrying the economic "defeatism" which he said now pervaded the nation "from board room to bar room," Charles Luckman, president of Lever Brothers Company, urged today that American business revitalize its efforts so the country would not worry itself into illness amid untold possibilities of expansion and prosperity.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Peace-time uses of war plants in the South and the effect of wartime experience on the future growth of Southern manufacturing are analyzed in a report made public today by the National Planning Association's Committee of the South.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 -- The biennial convention of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, today reaffirmed its autonomy stand and called upon other Congress of Industrial Organizations unions to "oppose any effort by the top leadership of the CIO to expel any union because it insists on the right of self-determination."

The patent system in the United States is far less likely to be used these days to evade responsibility under the nation's anti-trust laws than in the past, Herbert A. Bergson, assistant attorney general in charge of the Department of Justice's anti-trust division, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Former Senator John A. Danaher of Connecticut eliminated himself from consideration for the Republican National Chairmanship tonight, asserting that his legal practice here would prevent his acceptance.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina declared from the bench in the Communist trial yesterday that use of false names and "clandestine" methods by the defendants and their associates was an issue on which the Government had the right to cross-examine defense witnesses.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Truman signed into law today a bill outlawing certain overtime pay suits, including verdicts won by New York longshoremen in the Supreme Court.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad had an estimated net income of $6,846,000 in the first half of this year, Roy B. White, president, estimated yesterday. This would compare with $9,180,133 in the first half of 1948. He estimated gross revenues at $190,285,000, compared with 192,900,872.

HELENA, Mont., July 21 -- The Missouri Inter-Agency Committee endorsed in general today the principles of the Department of Agriculture's long-range plan for control and development of land and water resources in the Missouri River Valley.

A "new faction" of Local 1247, International Longshoremen's Association, was blamed yesterday by American Export Lines for the work stoppage at its Jersey City terminal. Four hundred longshoremen refused to report for work on Piers D and F last Monday morning and have remained out since then.

Although the Interplayers, whose headquarters now are in Carnegie Hall, gave an intelligent reading to Sean O'Casey's "The Silver Tasie" last night, there is no reason to reverse the negative verdict that first greeted the play when Mr. O'Casey presented it to the directors of the Abbey Theatre in Dublin.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -The military's bacteriological warfare plant is faced with the same problem perplexing the atomic material factories -- disposal of highly dangerous waste products.
DETROIT, July 21 (AP) -- The Tigers put on their hitting shoes and slammed out fourteen hits, including three homers, to whip the Senators, 6 -- 3, today and sweep their three-game series.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A far-reaching national school construction bill was agreed upon today by a Senate Labor and Public Welfare subcommittee. It will be reported to the full committee tomorrow.

Although sales of the General Electric Company and its consolidated affiliates for the first half of this year were larger than those of a year ago earnings were 15 per cent less, according to the report of Charles E. Wilson, president, released today.

LONDON, July 21 -- For a dress designer to rob the trunks of his clients for dresses and coats to stage a fashion display shows courage, particularly when some of those models were designed as far back as 1933. To form a balanced picture of creative art from such a necessarily haphazard choice demonstrates a type of genius.
Are we to Suffer forever the inconvenience and potential danger attendant on having parades routed on Fifth Avenue? During the Lions' parade, Manhattan was bisected for hours.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Winston Churchill's surprise over and distaste for the "unconditional surrender" policy adopted by the Allies in World War II were shared by former Secretary of State Cordell Hull and not a few others in the wartime administration of President Roosevelt.

Democratic and Republican leaders of Manhattan will forget their differences to join in a coalition designed to insure the defeat of Benjamin J. Davis Jr., only Communist member of the City Council, it was learned last night.

DETROIT, July 21 -- A strike against the Ford Motor Company was precluded for nearly three weeks today when the United Automobile Workers, CIO, invoked the Michigan Labor Mediation Act to have the state supervise a strike vote.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, assured Senators today that adequate plans for defending Alaska were in operation, but he asked to tell about them only at a secret session.

TOKYO, July 21 -- Embarrassed by declining export markets and mounting stocks, Japan's Foreign Trade Ministry is pressing for a reduction of floor prices imposed by United States occupation authorities. Recommendations covering forty-nine major categories in which floor prices are considered above international levels are about to be submitted, it is understood.

The recovery drive of the stock market met considerable resistance yesterday in the form of profittaking. While it was only the second slip the list has made this month, the widest inroads since June 28 were sustained. Offerings were not of major proportions, but bidders backed away upon the appearance of pressure and prices drifted to a lower level.

Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., has reduced suggested list prices of its new Purlpoint wilton carpeting grade to $12.95 a square yard in broadloom widths and $9.75 a linear yard for 27-inch merchandise, a company spokesman disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate today ratified the North Atlantic Treaty, free of any reservation, by a vote of 82 to 13.

I have read the letter of George F. Bauer in your issue of July 16 suggesting a step in the direction of international monetary stabilization by a gold-coin standard, whereby any holder of thirty-five non-gold dollars on demand anywhere, any time, could have them converted into one ounce of gold, and vice versa.

Samples of eight parking meters were subjected yesterday to the first of a series of mechanical tests that will determine the final specifications for competitive bidding for the city's trial order of 1,000 to 1,500 machines.

Six of American Overseas Airlines' seven scheduled outbound and inbound flights at La Guardia Airport were canceled yesterday when a strike of the airline's radio communication officers, members of the Flight Communications Officers Association, AFL, began early in the day.

LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- The following are excerpts from the House of Commons debate in which both Winston Churchill and Foreign Secretary Bevin discussed the late President Roosevelt's "unconditional surrender" demand at Casablanca:

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The firing on the other side of the Potomac that is now being heard in Washington is oratorical and its present phase definitely will end on a fixed date. In these respects it differs from the warlike sounds in Virginia that reverberated in the nation's capital eighty-five years ago.

WARSAW, July 21 -- Poland's Minister of National Defense, Marshal Michal Zymierski, today ordered the firing of twenty-four salvos from twenty-four guns to mark the fifth anniversary of Liberation Day tomorrow. Thousands of workers were busily putting the finishing touches to an impressive number of industrial and housing projects, officially scheduled to be opened tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today ordered thirtyfour states to cut back next year's wheat plantings in order to stay within the national allotment of 68,900,000 acres set last week.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Federal Communications Commission denied today the request of the Television Broadcasting Association of New York for a partially lifting of the "freeze" on new television channels.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A sudden upturn in the number of home loans made to veterans has halted a long decline in the GI home-loan program, the Veterans Administration said today.
The cotton futures market closed steady, 3 points lower to 13 points higher, yesterday with a moderate volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.
DAPHNE, Ala., July 21 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic priest announced yesterday plans were under study for establishing a Girls Town for underprivileged girls on the Alabama Gulf Coast.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 21 -- Four months after their names were designated by the United States and British Military Governments the twelve members of the German Steel Trustee Association have not yet been officially installed, it was learned today.

Conclusion of an armistice between Israel and Syria is good news in itself and good news because it is a considerable triumph for the United Nations. Reports from Tel Aviv, Washington and Lake Success all agree that great credit for the settlement is due to Ralph J. Bunche, the Acting U. N. Mediator, and his assistants.

The attraction of Artur Rubinstein playing the Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto drew 19,800 to the Lewisohn Stadium last night. It was the second largest audience of the season, being only 200 short of the record set at the Gershwin concert two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -Officials said today the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had loaned $2,000,000 this month to the Lustron Corporation, making the Government lending agency's stake in the prefabricated housing concern $34,500,000 so far.

Due to increased production costs and a desire to maintain the quality of Swiss jeweled watches, minimum prices on all watches and movements produced in that country will be increased on Oct. 31 between 8 and 15 per cent, depending on type and size, it was announced here yesterday.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 21 (UP) -- Australian dock workers today called a 24-hour protest strike for next Monday after two of their stevedoring union officials had been jailed for contempt of court.

An initial distribution of $600,000 to Columbia, Harvard, Yale and Princeton Universities, beneficiaries under the $34,000,000 Eugene Higgins Scientific Trust, for the advancement of their scientific programs, was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Standard Airlines, Inc., one of the major noncertificated airlines, today was ordered to cease operations. A Federal court order backed up a decision to this effect by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, White House military aide, will be free to tell any Congressional committee anything he knows about "five per centers," President Truman said today. General Vaughan was standing behind him as the President answered questions in this regard.

In your editorial of July 16 concerning the vital subject of whether Communists should be allowed as teachers you agreed with the arguments of the National Education Association, feeling that a member of the Communist party is not suitable as a teacher.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A group of Hawaiian stevedoring companies affected by the eighty-two-day-old strike of longshoremen today advised the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service that they would not negotiate in Washington.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 21--Mrs. Richard Hellmann of Scarsdale and Miss Louise Nichols of Hudson River tied for low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association with identical nines of 41, 41 -- 82 over the long and difficult Tamarack course today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The House, dealing the Truman Administration a severe defeat, decisively rejected the Brannan farm program today and passed a bill to continue the present agri cultural price support system for another year.

The team of Arthur Schwartz and Howard Dietz has been signed to do a series of original musical revues over the CBS television network every other Thursday evening from 8:30 to 9 o'clock starting Sept. 29. Mr. Schwartz will produce the series as well as compose the music, while Mr. Dietz will contribute to the writing of lyrics.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The State Department today politely but firmly turned down the proposal of the American Friends Service Committee that the United States put its atomic bombs under United Nations seal.

Dr. Frank C. Laubach, who is an adult education specialist, is performing a public service when he stresses the importance of campaigning against illiteracy throughout the world. He is also on firm ground in linking this to the concepts of Point Four as part of the fashion in which underdeveloped areas and their peoples can be assisted.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -Secretary of Defense Louis Johnson scrapped sixty-three more military committees and boards today, raising to 133 the number of such units he has ordered discontinued since April 1.

Possibly the happiest news to come from any of this week's home furnishings events was the announcement made yesterday by Charles S. Shaughnessy, vice president of Macy's, that prices of wood furniture have taken a downward turn for the first time since 1941.
THE Clifton Lawn Tennis Club of Arrochar, S. I., in the Borough of Richmond celebrates its seventy-fifth anniversary tomorrow.

MOSCOW, July 21 -- There are now two worlds -- the world of good and the world of evil. The world of good is led by the Soviet Union and the evil forces are represented by the United States and the West.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (AP) -- The Japanese wartime zero hour program was originally designed for entertainment only, George Mitsushio, former Radio Tokyo officials said today.

BOSTON, July 21 (AP) -- For the fourth time in as many starts against him, the Cardinals teed off on Johnny Antonelli, the Braves' $70,000 bonus southpaw, for a 3-1 victory today to gain the odd decision of a three-game series.

A real estate broker who allegedly mulcted $11,000 from twenty-two complainants for whom he was to obtain apartments, was released in $2,500 bail yesterday in Bronx County Court by Judge James M. Barrett after he had been arraigned on two indictments and four counts of grand larceny in the second degree.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 (AP) -- The revived St. Louis Browns overwhelmed, Philadelphia, 15 -- 2, tonight for their sixth straight triumph but the Athletics came back to win the second game of a twinight doubleheader, 3 -- 2. Hank Majeski drove in the winning run with a triple in the eighth inning of the second game.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee, having voted a cut of more than $1,000,000,000 in the $15,900,000,000 approved by the House for the armed services this year, has scheduled a showdown for tomorrow on whether $635,000,000 of $835,000,000 already appropriated for stockpiling of critical and strategic materials shall be returned to the Treasury.
DANBURY, Conn., July 21 -This city's volunteer firemen made plans today to prevent their eight-day carnival, opening tomorrow, from going up in smoke.

PARIS, July 21 -- Officials of the Economic Cooperation Administration here are wrestling with the problem of how to supply "free" dollars -- dollars to be spent without United States control -- to Belgium and Switzerland to finance loans in their own currencies that they would make to debtor countries under the European payments plan.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 21 -- An unusual deal in interstate finance, which for weeks has been the basis of a financial mystery puzzling the nation's highest investment banking circles, has been brought into the open here by a dispute among Minnesota state officials.

ALBANY, July 21 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, in response to an inquiry from the State Department of Audit and Control, ruled today that the more than fifty supreme court justices in the Third and Fourth Departments to whom the 1949 Legislature voted $5,000 pay increases, might collect the additional compensation as of April 26, 1949, when Governor Dewey signed the bill.
GENEVA, July 21 -- The United States proposed today that the United Nations cut drastically the size of its 1950 program for technical assistance to underdeveloped areas.

One of the worst things to have in any home is a new piano. By "new" there is not necessarily meant one fresh from the factory, perhaps still wrapped in its original cellophane, but only one that is new to the home. Such a piano brings out the worst in everyone.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 21 (AP) -- Dr. E. P. Pruitt, the ranking Alabama Ku Klux Klan leader, resigned today as a grand jury prepared to take new evidence in the state's war on masked mobsters.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Heavy Short-covering in July soybeans advanced that grain 10 cents a bushel, the daily limit, at one time on the Chicago Board of Trade today, putting it at a new seasonal high, with closing trades at net gains of 6 3/4 to 7 1/4 cents. Deferred deliveries of soybeans showed a heavy undertone and declined 2 1/2 to 3 3/4 cents, on the day.
The Maritime Commission plans to reply to criticism of its ship subsidy policies early next month, Major Gen. Philip B. Fleming, chairman, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A broad inquiry into alleged monopolistic practices of labor unions will be opened by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on Monday and continue into August, it was announced today by Senator A Willis Robertson, Democrat, of Virginia.

For want of a better feud, Walker Cooper brought his case against Leo Durocher and the Giants into the open yesterday at the Polo Grounds. In his first appearance under Coogan's Bluff since he was dealt away to Cincinnati, the former New York backstop walloped a grand slam homer in the third inning.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 21 -Long Island's golf team retained possession of the Stoddard Trophy by defeating representatives from Westchester and New Jersey in the triangular matches over the Bonnie Briar Country Club course today. The series was first held twenty-one years ago.

Attacking President Truman, Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer, the Communist party of New York State, of which Robert Thompson is chairman, issued a statement yesterday, declaring that the "great upset of 1948" had been followed by "the great betrayal of 1949."

The recently established Board of Smoke Control acquired its first permanent member yesterday, other than those ex officio, when Mayor O'Dwyer in his office at City Hall swore Henry Dominick McEvoy of 59-32 156th Street, Flushing, Queens, into the post.

CHICAGO, July 21 (UP) -- The Journal of the American Medical Association warned today that many persons suffered serious reactions to hay fever drugs and reported the death of a baby who accidentally drank one of the drugs.

BERLIN, July 21 -- The four occupation powers, meeting in Berlin today, agreed upon the procedure for future meetings on the restoration of trade and transport between Eastern and Western Germany, according to a communique issued tonight.

Rocky Graziano. East Side fighter who once held the middleweight championship of the world, signed yesterday to meet Charley Fusari of Irvington, N. J., in a ten-round bout at the Polo Grounds on the night of Wednesday, Sept. 14. The fight will mark Graziano's first start in a local ring in three years.

A two-and-a-half-hour meeting on wages yesterday between officials of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, resulted in no agreement, and the union has appealed to the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service for intervention.
HONG KONG, July 21 (UP) --Nationalist sources reported today that twelve Communist armies were driving south and west from Communist territory.

ATHENS, July 21 -- The report of the Salonika group of the United Nations Special Commission on the Balkans, made public here today, stated that the Yugoslav Greek border had already been closed on July 7, on which date its members interviewed two Yugoslav officers in the vicinity of the Yugoslav frontier Post 39.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered a collective bargaining election giving a place on the ballot to the Congress of Industrial Organizations' United Furniture Workers of America for the first time under the Taft-Hartley Law.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -- Recognition of "the new China" was demanded of the State Department and Congress today by the biennial convention of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO, which denounced official American policy toward China as "disastrous," "suicidal," "bankrupt and dead."
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a plan for modifying the first mortgage gold bonds of the Montana, Wyoming and Southern Railroad Company.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Preston T. Tucker sought permission today to study a SEC report on activities of his automobile company, alleging his reputation had been damaged by stories based on the report.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 21 -- The Italian Government is engaged in a series of complicated diplomatic maneuvers to try to force Premier Marshal Tito to surrender Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste (now controlled by Yugoslavia) to Italy and to surrender all claims to Zone A (controlled by the United States and Britain), it was learned today from responsible sources.

CALGARY, July 21 (Canadian Press) -- Frank M. McMahon, president of the West Coast Transmission Company, said today his company is going ahead with plans for a $100,000,000 natural gas pipeline from Alberta to British Columbia despite the recent prohibition of gas exports by the Alberta Government.

BUENOS AIRES, July 21 -- Acting on President Juan Peron's orders, Dr. Roberto Ares last night released the first detailed statement on the financial position of the Argentine Trade and Promotion Institute (the IAPI) since the agency was established in May, 1946.

There must be something to the old saw concerning the amount of game you see when you don't have a gun, for on a check-up along the Wallkill River and its feeders, we counted exactly thirty-one woodchucks, all within 150 yards.

The appeal of Police Commissioner O'Brien for special care in avoiding accidents to children is one that should be taken to heart. It is always hard to keep children, released from school during July and August, away from the dangers of traffic, especially in congested sections of the city where playgrounds are at some distance.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 21 -Gov. Chester Bowles today removed John T. Dunn Jr. as chairman of the State Liquor Commission and appointed Maj. John C. Kelly, second in command of the State Police, to succeed him.

Carmine G. DeSapio, the new leader of Tammany, announced yesterday that he would ask Hugo E. Rogers to withdraw as a candidate for renomination for Borough President of Manhattan and that he expected substitution of a candidate satisfactory to Mayor O'Dwyer and the Democratic voters of the borough.

ALBANY, July 21 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey conferred with Port of New York Authority officials today in an effort to end the dispute between the Authority and major airlines over Idlewild Airport. He said after a meeting with two commissioners and several staff members of the Authority that he was looking into the matter because he believed "a solution should be found."

Top-seeded Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., gained the junior final of the Eastern junior and boys tennis championships by defeating Allan Schwartz of Chicago, seeded fourth, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 0, at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

Proposals by Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, to slash $635,000,000 from the Government appropriation for raw materials stockpiling jolted the rubber market severely here yesterday. Prices declined 1/2 cent a pound in the heavy selling that followed word of Senator Thomas' proposal.

Acceptance by labor and management of the Mayor's proposals to end the bus strike has brought welcome relief in a situation that was becoming intolerable. A shut-down of any large segment of New York's transportation system is more than the city should have to put up with, particularly when caused by such irresponsible strike action as Mr. Quill's Transport Workers Union took last week.

The property at 106-8 Eleventh Street, Hoboken, N. J., known as the Marguarete Apartments and containing twenty-one suites, has been sold by the Alcar Realty Company to the Agra Realty Company. Louis M. Tamarin was the broker.

LONDON, July 21 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin complained today in the House of Commons that "nearly all the difficulties arising in remodeling Germany" resulted from a demand, originated by the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, for Germany's unconditional surrender.

LONDON, July 21 -- As had been expected, Lord Ammon, chairman of National Dock Labor Board, which has been in open dispute with the British Government over the handling of the dock strike, resigned today his office as Captain of the Gentlemen-at-Arms, which carries with it the duties of chief Government whip in the House of Lords.

RAHWAY, N. J., July 21 -- Four men and a woman, riding in a borrowed jeep to escape the heat, were killed here today when a truck loaded with twenty-four tons of sheet steel overturned and crushed them on the highway.

ROME, Friday, July 22 -- The Chamber of Deputies yesterday ratified Italy's entry into the North Atlantic pact by a vote of 323 for, 160 against and 8 abstentions. The bill will now go to the Senate, where discussion on it is expected to begin next week.

GAZA, Palestine, July 21 (AP) -- Communist Arabs jailed by the Egyptian Army said today that three Israeli Army officers secretly were directing a campaign to spread communism among the 216,000 Arab refugees in this area.

Lions from twenty-six countries ended their convention here yesterday and headed homeward under a directive to spur their 385,000 club members to new efforts for international understanding and peace.
COWES, England, July 21 (AP) -United States boats, continuing a great comeback, moved into the lead in the British-American yacht series today by winning the fifth race.

Yugoslavia is not in the "Soviet orbit" and is not "satellized," Sava N. Kosanovitch, Yugoslav Ambassador to the United States, declared here yesterday on his return by plane from consultations with his Government.

Planning for an expansion of his beer distributing business, John Lynch Jr. has purchased a vacant plot of land, 40 by 93 feet, at the northeast corner of Merrick Road and North Grove Street, Valley Stream, L. I., from Rosealie Niedhammer.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Matching a 5 per cent increase in motor freight rates that went into effect yesterday between Middle Atlantic States points, and between those points and New England, the Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a 5 per cent increase for New England motor carriers.

The internal strife that has beset the fledgling Burmese nation since it received its independence from Britain in January, 1948, has decreased appreciably, Gen. Bo Ne Win, deputy prime minister and defense minister of Burma, declared yesterday.
LONDON, July 21 -- Britain's service chiefs were today called into the opening session of the conference of British Middle East diplomats and experts over which Foreign Secretary Bevin presided.

HAIFA, Israel, July 21 -- After touring the Middle Eastern countries Justice William O. Douglas of the United States Supreme Court said today he had observed what he believed to be an awakening in the form of a political and economic renaissance that, if allowed to prosper, would give new meaning to this entire area.
MEXICO CITY, July 21 (AP) -Mexican financiers may lend Mexico the money she needs for oil development and which she failed to get from the United States.

LONDON, July 21 -- The House of Commons will debate the report of the Royal Commission on the press next Thursday on a Government-sponsored motion calling upon the House to "welcome all possible action on the part of the press to give effect to the commission's conclusions and recommendations."
LONDON, July 21 -- "Isn't it too bad that the King and Queen aren't here," said the American woman as she strolled across the broad, parched lawn of Buckingham Palace.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Truman, at his news conference today, described as relatively unimportant the meeting on atomic energy information for foreign governments which he called at Blair House on the night of July 14.

CLEVELAND, July 21 -- Four former presidents of the Pressed Metal Institute were honored tonight at a banquet that climaxed opening sessions of the convention of the National Association of the Metal Stamping Industry.

IVOR JOHN CARNEGIE BROWN, a Scotsman and since 1919 a drama critic, believes that the best approach to William Shakespeare is the obvious one through the theatre door. If not much is known about the small town glover and leather merchant's son who made good so spectacularly in London, one thing at least is certain.
