CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 21 -The Yankees have gone back to rolling over the enemy and, as the Bombers evacuated the banks of Lake Erie late this afternoon, Field Marshall Casey Stengel was happy to report the situation once again was well in hand.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- William Wyler will produce and direct the screen version of Sidney Kingsley's play, "Detective Story," which Paramount bought last week for a cash payment of $285,000 plus a prospective participation in revenue by the author, the studio announced today.
Raymond M. Fernandez, one of the two defendants in the "lonely hearts" murder trial, testified yesterday that he had taken no part in the hammer slaying of Mrs. Janet J. Fay.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Department store sales in the week ended July 16 were 9 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

On June 7 THE NEW YORK TIMES published a letter from Monteith Gilpin of the Society for the Prevention of World War III concerning Swiss-held German assets. I believe that the attention of your readers should be called to the fact that the letter contained certain errors.

The Federal rent control authorities' policy on allowing rent reductions to tenants whose landlords discontinue attended elevator service was clarified yesterday by Max N. Bass, Regional Rent Attorney.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., July 21 -Failure of industrial management to achieve genuine unity of purpose and action within its own ranks is the most important cause of industrial unrest in this country, Douglas McGregor, president of Antioch College, declared today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, asserted today that, if he should become Secretary of Welfare, he would not ease up in any way in his advocacy of national health insurance.

Todd Duncan, the baritone, who is best remembered for his portrayal of Porgy in "Porgy and Bess," may be seen here during the coming season in the leading role in "Cry, the Beloved Country," it became known yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Ruth Torgerson, a three-time winner, moved into the semi-final round of the state women's amateur golf tourney today with a 2-and-1 victory over an old rival. The Garden City player beat Miss Hilda Swanson, whom she also defeated in the final of the 1947 tourney.
This week saw egg prices go up again at retail, consumers may be dismayed to learn. The smoked ham often coupled with them at breakfast also rose, and so did fresh pork and chickens.

About 1,000 pickets paraded in front of the United States Court House in Foley Square yesterday to mark the first anniversary of the indictment of twelve members of the Communists' national board on a charge of conspiracy.

Rising to the responsibility which history thrust upon it, the Senate has approved the North Atlantic Treaty by the overwhelming majority of 82 to 13. It has done so after defeating by similarly decisive majorities all efforts of a small band of die-hard opponents who, from a variety of motives, sought either to defeat the Treaty or to repudiate its obligations and its promises by saddling it with nullifying reservations.

The Board of Education approved unanimously Yesterday the annual awarding of contracts for public school textbooks, although Charles J. Bensley, a member from the Bronx, protested strongly against the absence of volumes on the list designed to improve relations among racial and religious groups.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -The House Un-American Activities Committee said today that Dr. Giovanni Rossi Lomanitz and Dr. David Bohm, both atomic scientists, had belonged to a wartime Communist cell at the radiation laboratory at the University of California at Berkeley in the early 1940's.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell signed an order yesterday staying the Immigration and Naturalization Service from rearresting Benny Saltzman, 54-year-old former Communist, or changing the terms of the $500 bond in which he is free on a deportation charge.
LOS ANGELES, July 21 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, today sent the Security Council a final report on his successful mission to halt hostilities in Palestine.
Harsh yellow light from street lamps fell on the gaily clad square dancers whirling on the concrete of Central Park's Mall. The young man from Buffalo Gap, S. D., looked bewildered.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -The House Labor Committee rejected today, 18 to 7, a move which would have killed the Fair Employment Practices Bill, a major plank in President Truman's civil rights platform. The group then decided, 19 to 6, to vote on the bill itself a week from tomorrow.

Savings banks in this state are continuing to gain deposits at a higher rate than last year, and during the first six months of 1949 registered an increase in deposits of $392,405,000, John Adikes, president of The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, reported yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 21 -- A five-man fact-finding committee of American Protestant churchmen headed by the Rev. Dr. John Howland Lathrop, pastor of the Unitarian Church of the Savior, in Brooklyn, will visit Czechoslovakia beginning July 26 to investigate the church situation, the official news agency announced tonight.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 21 -An unexpected volume of opposition has developed against a plan to create a national shrine at Sagamore Hill, home of former President Theodore Roosevelt and onetime summer White House. As a result, Mayor Alfred Lee Loomis of Cove Neck, and trustees of that incorporated village, where Sagamore Hill is situated, are awaiting further developments and perhaps abandonment Of the proposal.

Indication that the recent trend of rising prices in the Government bond market may be leveling off was suggested by the shading of quotations yesterday throughout the whole list of Treasury obligations. Basic sentiment at present levels for the term bonds is firm, however, and the pause may be only time out for profit-taking.

LONDON, Friday, July 22 -The Soviet Government, in notes to the United States and Britain, delivered Tuesday, has reiterated its refusal to discuss Western allegations of violations of the peace treaties by Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania, the Moscow radio said today.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -President Truman said today that he believed negotiations for a Mexican oil loan will be resumed soon.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Following is the Senate Vote on ratification of the North Atlantic treaty, together with the three votes that preceded it:

LOS ANGELES, July 21 (AP) -Ike Williams retained his world lightweight title tonight when he scored a fourth-round technical knockout over Enrique Bolanos of Mexico City before 17,000 fans at Wrigley Field. Referee Jack Dempsey stopped the fight after 2 minutes 40 seconds of the round.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- In the week ended on July 20, member-bank reserve balances decreased $91,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

ALBANY, July 21 -- Clifford J. Fletcher, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, said today that motorists were not complying properly with the new law, in effect since July 1, requiring reporting of accidents within forty-eight hours, and that the department was prepared to suspend drivers' licenses if necessary.

The one-story taxpayer property at 408-412 South Broadway in Yonkers, N. Y., has been conveyed by Paul Gourary to a client of Edward J. Davis Co., co-broker with Cushman Wakefield, Inc., in the transaction. The property, on a plot 85 by 200 feet fronting on South Broadway and Romaine Avenue, had been held at $75,000.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 21 -In a hodge-podge of weather, that included a squall, but a weakling compared with the blustering one on the fourth of July, there was a renewal today of the place-scoring competition in Race Week at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
Substantially lower earnings for the first six months of this year than those for the corresponding period of 1948 were reported yesterday in the midyear statements of two large oil companies.
ALBANY, July 21 -- Governor Dewey appointed a committee of State officials today to map plans for State action in dealing with any further decline in business conditions and employment.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UP) -John D. M. Hamilton, who was the Republican party's only full-time paid chairman in recent history, said today that the party should revive the practice in replacing Representative Hugh Scott Jr.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 16, 1949, totaled 724,100 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 128,779 cars, or 21.6 per cent more than for the preceding week, and 167,980 cars, or 18.8 per cent, less than for the corresponding week last year, and 195,635 cars, or 21.3 per cent, less than during the corresponding week two years ago.

NEW HOLLAND, Pa., July 21 (AP) -- A barn destroyed by fire three weeks ago was rebuilt today almost as fast as it burned down. Nearly 300 neighbors of the barn's owner helped replace the structure that was damaged July 1.

The Commonwealth Southern Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for approval of the certain details incident to its dissolution, and also of the distribution on Oct. 1 of its holdings of its subsidiaries in accordance with the plan and order of the United States District Court of Delaware.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -A powerful sixty-three-member economy coalition in the Senate today broadly hinted that it might try to tack on to an appropriation bill its measure to force President Truman to cut spending 5 to 10 per cent.
DEDHAM, Mass., July 21 (AP) -- A decree granting Mrs. Barbara Hutton Troubetzkoy extended custody of her 13-year-old son was protested today by an attorney for her former husband, the boy's father.
ANNECY, France, July 21 -- Britain has proposed emergency action to establish international control of prices of the major commodities entering world trade.

PARIS, July 21 -- While the military prosecutor, Capt. Paul Flicoteaux, declared that the minimum penalty for Otto Abetz, German ambassador to France during the Nazi occupation, should be twenty years at hard labor, Maitre Rene Floriot, opening his plea for the defense today, said Abetz had befriended the French and helped save Paris and must in all fairness be acquitted.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 21 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council adopted today a favorable report on the United States' administration of its Pacific trust islands.

For the second time in five games, Luis Olmo, the strong young Puerto Rican who jumped to the Mexican League, yesterday delivered a ninth-inning hit that won a ball game for the Dodgers and it seems incumbent upon Branch Rickey and Barney Shotton to send a special message of thanks to Commissioner A. B. Chandler for reinstating Luis.

United Air Lines, Inc. reported yesterday that net earnings of $3,147,382 realized in the second quarter of this year enabled it to reduce the net loss for the first half of this year to $175,754. This compared with the $1,021,515 loss sustained in the initial six months of 1948.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 21 (AP) -Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago and Johnny Palmer of Badin, N. C., fired a best-ball 60 today, eleven under par, to tie the eleven-year-old tournament's record as the $15,000 four-day Inverness invitation four-ball matches opened.

NEW DELHI, India., July 21 -The Government opened a conference here today on evacuee property, a problem almost as powerful as the Kashmir issue in determining relations between India and Pakistan. High-level conferences have produced no solution, and the dissatisfaction of the evacuees in both Dominions, besides aggravating inter-Dominion feeling, has become an internal embarrassment to each Government.

LONDON, Friday, July 22 -- The United States Senate's ratification of the Atlantic pact was greeted with restrained satisfaction in London political circles last night, although no great fear had been evident that the debate would end otherwise.

That important factor in foot racing -- a good start -- was denied America's trackmen yesterday when they were delayed 3 hours 20 minutes before they were able to take off from Idlewild International Airport. A total of forty-two athletes, representing the cream of the nation's talent, was aboard as the Scandinavian Airlines plane finally took off and soared into the northeast en route to Oslo, Norway.

BERLIN, July 21 -- The United States Military Government headquarters here announced today that it would drop all its press licensing in the Land (State) of Hesse as of tomorrow. The Military Government will, however, maintain some control of the press through a set of regulations forbidding the Hessian press to make "malicious attacks" on the Military Government as well as banning the propagation of Nazi ideas.

ROME, July 21 -- Italy has suggested immediate independence for Tripolitania and independence between one and two years for Eritrea to the United States, British and French Governments, Italian circles said today.

Out-of-town tourists and native New Yorkers both find plenty of diversion and entertainment during vacation time in the city, thanks to the extensive program of outdoor recreational activities arranged for them by the Department of Parks. The seventeen outdoor swimming pools and the sixteen miles of municipally operated beaches are naturally the most attractive facilities during the warm weather.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 21 -- Opening the campaign for Germany's first free general elections since the Weimar Republic, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, leader of the Christian Democrats, declared here tonight that only his party could stave off Russian envelopment of all Europe.

ROME, July 21 -- Religious and doctrinal reasons alone caused the Sacred Congregation of the Holy Office to issue its recent decree excommunicating Catholics who willfully belong to or support the Communist party, an official of the Congregation told the Religious News Service here today.

Bank clearings in twenty-five leading cities of the United States aggregated $13,164,390,000 for the week ended July 20, a slight decline from the $13,195,508,000 reported in the preceding week, but 7.7 per cent less than in the corresponding week of 1948, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The board of directors of Pan American Airways Corporation was increased to sixteen member with the election by stockholders yesterday of General of the Army George C. Marshall and David S. Ingalls, former vice president of Pan American.

Within the foreseeable future the city is destined to benefit from the construction of two new bridges in the metropolitan area and the rehabilitation of another. All three should materially aid traffic conditions and it is to be hoped that the governmental departments involved will push the plans as fast as possible.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today blocked, pending investigation, an effort by the New Jersey and New York Railroad to increase commutation fares between New York City and New Jersey points. The carrier is controlled by the Erie Railroad.

The City of Chicago yesterday sold bond issues totaling $18,350,000 to a syndicate of investment banking houses headed by Smith, Barney Co. at an interest cost of 1.8747 per cent. The bonds consist of $16,350,000 of obligations issued for various purposes and maturing from 1951 to 1966, and $2,000,000 of voting machine obligations due in 1968 and callable in 1950 and thereafter.

ABOARD S. S. ILE DE FRANCE, en route to New York, July 21 -- Dressed with gay signal flags and glistening from stem to stern, the French liner Ile de France sailed from Havre at 1:50 P. M. today on her first post-war run as a luxury ship.

Nineteen examples of good fall fashions by New York designers were modeled during a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group, Inc., held yesterday at the Astor Hotel. The speaker, Mrs. Gwen Randolph of the Albert Woodley advertising agency, and the commentator, Miss Nancy White, chairman of the day, said that these were fashions at a moderate price.

A $1,000,000 chlorinated benzine producing plant has been placed in operation at Natrium, W. Va., by the Columbia Chemical division of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, it was announced yesterday by E. T: Asplundh, vice president in charge of the company's chemical operations.

A dog that died while trying to protect her three newborn puppies won for them last night the promise of care in private homes. Two boys who were an indirect cause of the dog's death by a police bullet in a vacant lot at Sixty-fifth Street and Maurice Avenue, Woodside, Queens, said they would take two of the puppies.

Dr. Herbert J. Phillips, ousted from the faculty of the University of Washington last January as "incompetent to teach the truth" because of "clandestine" activity in the Communist party, was called as a defense witness yesterday in the Communist trial.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Administration is preparing to send to Congress very soon, perhaps tomorrow, a proposed $1,450,000,000 program of foreign military aid, of which $1,130,000,000 would go to this country's associates in the newly ratified North Atlantic Treaty.
The eight-day-old strike that cut off normal bus service for 1,125,000 riders in Manhattan and Queens was ended last night on the basis of Mayor O'Dwyer's arbitration formula.

A large realty holding on the upper East Side passed to new control yesterday with the sale by David S. Meister, operator, of the seven dwellings and garden at 1199 to 1207 Park Avenue and 109 to 117 East Ninety-fourth Street. The property forms an "L" around the northeast corner, which contains the home of Mme. Ganna Walska McCormick.

More than 8,000 home furnishings stores and many department stores throughout the country will participate in Home Fashions Time from Sept. 22 through Oct. 1, John F. Dempsey, director, Home Furnishings Industry Committee, revealed yesterday.
PARIS, July 21 -- The French Parliament will begin debate on the Atlantic pact tomorrow and is expected to ratify it by Sunday.

A biographical study and evaluation of John L. Lewis by Saul Alinsky has been scheduled for October publication by Putnam. "The Name Is John L. Lewis" is based on the author's long acquaintance with the labor leader and his access to Mr. Lewis' records and files.
Ted Atkinson tried his best to do a favor for a friend at Jamaica yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Following is the text of the North Atlantic security pact, as ratified today by the Senate:

Plans for development of the unimproved parts of the 1,258-acre Flushing Meadow Park in Queens are to be prepared by Park Commissioner Robert Moses under an appropriation made yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- With the Atomic Energy Commission offering $10,000 rewards for each acceptable discovery of uranium deposits, a growing army of amateur prospectors annually is buying more than $200,000 worth of a new-type Geiger counter designed to aid them in their search for the deposits, it was learned yesterday.

A bewildered and perspiring postman slid his heavy load of mail to the lobby floor of the building at 545 West 111th Street yesterday. He mopped his brow, picked up a batch of letters and gritted his teeth as he began comparing addresses with more than 800 names listed on a pillar opposite the sixty-nine letter boxes that serve the entire house.
John W. Stevens has been named director of sales of the chemical division of Celanese Corporation of America.
LONDON, July 21 -- June's trade gap and the continuance of the London dock strike had a restraining influence on the stock markets here today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Japanese contracts for knitted gloves to be exported to this country, approved by occupation authorities in Japan, have almost wiped out this year's market for domestic makers of that type of glove, it was learned here today.

A recent newspaper account told the story of a young couple who abandoned their 6-week-old son in a hallway, asking that the authorities give him badly needed care, as they did not know how else to get this.

OMAHA, July 21 -- Another triumph for Chicago over New York in the open tournament of the United States Chess Federation was recorded in the ninth round today as Albert Sandrin, former Illinois state champion, defeated George Kramer, the 1945 New York State titleholder and the present national speed champion, in thirty-five moves.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 21 -Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, the national champion; Victor Seixas, Herbert Flam and Sam Match, the four top ranking players here, gained their places in the semi-finals of the Pennsylvania state tennis championship today on the turf of the Merion Cricket Club.

BERLIN, Friday, July 22 -- German reaction to Senate approval of the North Atlantic pact is compounded of relief and hope except in the Soviet zone, where Walther Ulbricht, of the Political Bureau of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party, described it as "a menace to peace."

Gov. Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico was officially welcomed to New York at 1 P. M. yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer and members of the city administration in a brief ceremony at City Hall in the presence of 500 persons.

A new series of six newspaper ads stressing importance of child safety was announced yesterday by the Advertising Council. Prepared by the volunteer agency, Young Rubicam, Chicago, the series is part of the over-all safety campaign carried on in cooperation with the National Safety Council.

PARIS, Friday, July 22 -- It is certain that from the Strait of Gibraltar to the Arctic Ocean a wave of relief developed in Western Europe last night when word arrived that the United States Senate had finally ratified the North Atlantic pact.
PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) -Dick Sisler and Buddy Blattner struck the big blows today as the Phillies whipped the Cubs, 8 -- 4, in the final game of the series.

Business loans made by banks in this area declined for the twenty-first consecutive time during the week ended on Wednesday, falling $101,000,000 to a total of $4,484,000,000, the lowest point since Sept. 3, 1947. According to the data on the reporting New York City banks, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, repayments by subsidiaries of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were a major influence in the latest reduction.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A House monopoly inquiry today heard testimony that the women's clothing industry was being "squeezed" between great textile manufacturing combines and powerful buying groups. The condition was pictured as "threatening the very existence" of the manufacturers.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 -Continued support for the Progressive party was voted today by the third biennial convention of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, CIO. The delegates took this action after defeating overwhelmingly a resolution declaring "the policy of the national CIO of no third party at this time has been proven to be a correct policy.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Congressional approval at this session of the Administration's plan to help rearm non-Communist Europe was conceded today as probable by some of its strongest critics.
William A. vIarsteller and Robert P. iYIelius have been elected qce presidents of the Rockwell Manufacturing Company, Pittsburgh.

Commissioner of Investigation John M. Murtagh moved his waterfront investigation into its second phase yesterday, calling on the International Longshoremen's Association to close its membership books.

American tariffs and subsidies are paving the roads to socialism, John C. Lincoln declared yesterday before 100 disciples of Henry George, nineteenth century author and political economist famous for his theory of a "single tax" on land.

COWES, England, July 22 (AP) -The United States retained the British-America Cup for six-meter yachts today by registering its fourth straight victory in the 1949 series. Today's score was 20 1/4 points to 16.
CLEVELAND, July 22 (AP) -- Centerfielder Thurman Tucker's single in the tenth inning scored Pitcher Mike Garcia from second base tonight to give the Indians a 2-to-1 victory over Washington.

PARIS, July 22 -- The official publication of the Archdiocese of Paris carried today a communique stating that Abbe Jean Boulier, a French priest often associated with Communist activities, would no longer have the right to say mass after Sept. 14.
Coney Island is the poor man's paradise, but the Coney Island Court is the poor judge's madhouse, to hear Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate tell it.

ROME, July 22 (Reuters) -- Socialists are not affected by the Vatican excommunication decree unless they adhere to Communist theories, Msgr. Alfredo Ottaviani, assessor of the Holy Office, said in a press interview tonight. The decree against Communism was issued through the Congregation of the Holy Office.

TOKYO, July 22 -- Prompt and determined action by the Government appears to have won it a breathing spell in its battle with the Communists. Newspaper and political observers generally agree that the Communist-planned "labor offensive" originally scheduled for late July and August will almost certainly be delayed for two or three months.

ALBANY, July 22 -- The State Health Department announced today that 174 cases of poliomyelitis had been reported in New York City and eighty cases in the upstate area so far this year. One hundred and fifty-seven of New York's reported cases and forty-seven of the up-state cases were reported between July 1 and 22.

MONTREAL, July 22 (Canadian Press) -- Australia's tennis doubles pair of ambidextrous John Bromwich and Frank Sedgman swept to a straight-set victory over Canada today in the doubles fixture of the North American Zone Davis Cup tie.

THE TIMES front-page story of July 17 reports that "Inspector McKenna said it would be difficult to detect violators, but that 'if we do we will bring them into court'," in relation to low-flying planes, whose right to fly and flying brings monetary profit to the City of New York but confiscation of peace and quiet to us near the airport.

NEWARK, N. J., July 22 -- There will be no further public hearings until early in September in the investigation of the state's purchase of $3,405,000 of New York housing bonds, it was disclosed this afternoon by Augustus C. Studer, chairman of the investigating committee.

The Budd Company reported yesterday for the first six months of 1949 the largest sales and earnings in its history for a first halfyear period. It also reported that there had been no curtailment of delivery schedules. "On the contrary," said Edward G. Budd Jr., president, "two of the company's automotive customers have recently increased schedules," and the backlog on June 30 amounted to $130,000,000.

BOSTON, July 22 -- As an Army band finished the closing bars of "The Star-Spangled Banner" at Commonwealth Pier today, Josef Bujak, 28 years old, a Polish farmer, stepped ashore to become the 50,000th displaced person to arrive in the United States under the act of 1948.

"There is every reason why an everyday aluminum kitchen coffee pot should be entitled to the same artful design as a handwrought sterling silver service," it was said yesterday by Baron Erik Fleming of Stockholm. He then proceeded to explain what he was doing about it.

TRENTON, N. J., July 22 -- After hearing the arguments of defense counsel, Mercer County Judge Charles P. Hutchinson reserved decision this afternoon on an application to free in bail three of six Trenton Negroes, granted a new trial for a shopkeeper's murder.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Some twenty-five building trades unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and representing nearly 100,000 Chicago area craft workers have received or will receive wage increases ranging from ten to fifteen cents an hour.

Your issue of July 15 correctly quotes me as calling the policy of the Communist party "contemptible" at the July 14 hearing of the New York Board of Regents. However, the context in which the quotation appears confuses both the meaning and the intent of my remarks on this subject.

VIENNA, July 22 (UP) -- The Government announced today the arrest of twenty-one persons accused of smuggling $3,000,000 worth of metals and machinery from Austria into Russian-dominated Eastern Europe.

Awarded a hard-won Bachelor of Science degree after twenty years of study at night, Elwood Gaskins, 41-year-old employe of the Ford plant at Edgewater, N. J., is preparing to become a full-fledged medical doctor the hard way.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -House Democratic leaders are trying to work out a compromise that will permit action this session on the $300,000,000 Federal aid-to-education bill, it was disclosed today.
The fortieth annual general Bible conference of the Stony Brook Assembly will begin at 7:45 o'clock this evening at the Stony Brook School, Stony Brook, L. I., and continue until Aug. 6.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell signed an order yesterday calling for the release in $5,000 bail of Peter Harisiades, 46-year-old Greek newspaperman who is being held at Ellis Island on a deportation warrant charging him with having been a member of a party advocating the forcible overthrow of the Government.

OTTAWA, July 22 -- Finance Minister Douglas Abbott reported to the Canadian Cabinet today on the recent financial talks in London and in a press conference said that no loan from Canada had been asked in London and none was contemplated at present.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 -- A fight to save San Francisco's 1949 opera season was continued today after the board of trustees of the War Memorial Opera House, for the second time, had voted to ban Kirsten Flagstad, the Wagnerian soprano, from the building.

Calling service on the Hudson tubes "notoriously inadequate," Donald Spence, director of the Department of Revenue and Finance of Jersey City, declared yesterday that the Hudson Manhattan Railroad should not get a proposed 5-cent increase -- to 15 cents -- in its interstate fares.

Dr. Albert Schweitzer, 74-year-old French medical missionary and philosopher, saluted the American people and American medical science yesterday as he left for his African home, ending his first visit to this country.

Coffee futures were strong and active in yesterday's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. New high levels for the life of the current delivery position were established. Strong demand for the distant months from producer interests, along with short-covering, advanced prices in Contract "S" 24 to 44 points above Thursday's closing levels.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent in the week ended July 19, according to the Bureau of Labor Statisitcs. The index was 154.3 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.8 per cent higher than four weeks ago, but 8.6 per cent below the comparable week of 1948.
ALBANY, July 22 (AP)--John Foster Dulles is favored as the Republican candidate for United States Senator by a representative cross-section of Republican county leaders in New York State.

Anthony V. Martino, the wartime private who established a second family on Staten Island while his wife and two children in Waterbury, Conn., mourned him as a casualty, was returned here under guard last night from Walter Reed General Hospital, Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today it had unanimously dismissed a petition filed by the Michigan Bell Telephone Company for an election among its employes now represented by the Communications Workers of America, CIO.

Lower prices on men's wear fabrics are expected when the mills open their lines for spring early next week. According to predictions yesterday in well informed quarters in the men's clothing industry the decline will range around 8 to 8 1/2 per cent on standard worsteds.

LONDON, July 22 -- In a bid for return to office in the next general election, the British Conservative party proposed today to take Britain backward several steps on the road to socialism that the country has followed for the past four years -- but not to return to complete private enterprise by any means.

James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, said here last night that members of his union playing in Chicago hotels, cafes and theatres serviced by the Boone Electrical Company, a franchise holder of the Muzak Corporation of New York, have been called out.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Senate Labor Committee recommended unanimously today a year's extension, with modifications, of the "52-20" program of unemployment benefits for veterans.

GENEVA, July 22 -- The British Government released here and in London today a document purporting to be the text of Russian forced labor laws. The document will be circulated to members of the United Nations Economic and Social Council and will provide the basis of British attacks on Soviet forced labor policies when this question comes before the Council later this session.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a transfer of $19,500,000 of debentures in the Cuban Electric Company, Havana, as a step toward reorganization of the utility's holding company parent.

ALBANY, July 22 -- Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, declared today in a memorandum that under the Feinberg law it was the "primary duty" of school officials to take "positive and immediate action" to eliminate any teacher adjudged guilty of subversive activities in the classroom or outside.
HONOLULU, July 22 (AP) -- The Federal District Court paved the way today for a Circuit Court test on whether admiralty law could be used to force unloading of strikebound cargoes.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Senate Committee on Appropriations voted today to require that $275,000,000 of contract authority already granted by Congress for the stockpiling of critical and strategic materials for war emergency be recalled.

"The Atlantic Pact," by Halford L. Hoskins, a reappraisal of American foreign policy in the light of present commitments to aid the Western powers, went to press yesterday on the announcement of the Senate's ratification of the North Atlantic treaty, Public Affairs Press of Washington reports.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 22 -- The implied threat, repeated several times, that German Communists would instigate a strike against dismantling, highlighted today a welcome for Max Reimann, West German Communist leader who was released from a British Military Government jail two days ago.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 22 -New efforts will be made on Monday at City Hall here to end the strike of 400 longshoremen and dock checkers on Piers D and F of the American Export Lines which began last Monday.

SEOUL, Korea, July 22 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea today announced it was suspending all press conferences as a result of the arrest of five Korean newsmen assigned to cover the commission.

PARIS, July 22 -- The French National Assembly started tonight its debate on ratification of the North Atlantic treaty -- a debate that is expected to last through tomorrow and bring a vote late Sunday or on Monday. The session recessed at 11:30 P. M.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., July 22 -Industrial management must enter the field of adult education for workers if it hopes to win support to the cause of free enterprise, Robert K. Burns, executive officer of the Industrial Relations Center of the University of Chicago, declared today.

Advertising in newspapers of fifty-two cities during June totaled 192,287,124 lines, a gain of 4 per cent over the like period of last year, an analysis of Media Records showed yesterday. Categories recording gains were: general, up 9.4 per cent; retail, 6.8 per cent, and automotive, 5.1 per cent.
DUESSELFORD, Germany, July 22 (AP) -- Three foreigners and one German won their way into the semi-final round of an international tennis tournament today.

Blistering hot and humid weather that has steamed most New Yorkers for the last four days was being chased out of town last night as a cooler, drier air mass preceded by a band of showers started flowing into the metropolitan area. The result, according to the weather maps, will be a fair and more pleasant week-end.

The Harben Construction Corporation, headed by Nat Eisenberg, has obtained a mortgage loan of $482,600 on the forty-one one-family residences being built in the vicinity of Dry Harbor Road, between Eighty-fourth and Eighty-fifth Streets, in Rego Park, Queens.

Industrial spokesmen are convinced that cutbacks in procurement for national defense and strategic materials for stockpiling will occur, but they will affect 1950 and later purchases, and not current procurement plans.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 22 -- Forty-nine teams teed off in the New Jersey P. G. A. weekly pro-amateur best-ball tournament over the Crestmont Golf Course today.

MILWAUKEE, July 22 (AP) -Gov. Oscar Rennebohm's Commission on Human Rights declared today that the American Bowling Congress tournament should not be brought here because the A. B. C. practices racial discrimination.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Maj. Gen. Glen E. Edgerton, retired, an Army engineer with experience from Alaska to Iraq, today took over his new job as executive director of the Joint Congressional Commission on Reconstruction of the White House.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 22 -- Andrew W. Cordier, executive assistant to Secretary General Trygve Lie, predicted today that the fourth regular session of the United Nations General Assembly, which will convene at Flushing Meadow on Sept. 20, would need ten weeks to complete action on the sixty items on its agenda.

A note of alarm and a spark of hope appeared in the same mail yesterday, both dealing with salt water fishing. Anyone who looked forward to a big day with weakfish at Peconic Bay last spring and came home with a mess of porgies and mighty few and very small weakfish could understand the alarm.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Short-covering in July soybeans advanced the price 10 cents a bushel, the permissible limit for the second straight day on the Board of Trade and the close was at the top to 2 7/8 cents less. July corn broke sharply in the late trading and was off as much as 6 3/8 cents at the last while July oats were 2 cents up to 1 3/4 cents off.

After listening to a long explanation by a defense witness at the Communist trial yesterday of what he said he and other Communists had done for coal miners, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina turned toward him and asked:

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 22 (AP) -Sam Snead and Dick Metz, although shooting one of the poorest rounds of the tourney, dashed into the lead in the $15,000 Inverness four-ball golf matches today with a 4-up victory over Freddie Haas and Dave Douglas.

City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly filed a $100,000 slander suit in Supreme Court yesterday against Ewart Guinier, his opponent for the American Labor party's nomination for Manhattan Borough President. He charged he had been subjected to "public contempt, ridicule and disgrace."

Pronounced a paranoiac by Kings County Hospital physicians, Charles Van Newkirk, who shot ormer Representative Elisworth B. Buck at St. George, S. I., on April 5, was committed yesterday by Thomas J. Walsh, Richmond County judge, to Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane at Beacon, N. Y. Judge Walsh made the condition that if Van Newkirk, who is a former marine engineer, regained his sanity, he would have to face prosecution.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -A measure was introduced in Congress today to limit bank holding companies and restrict the amount of stock they may own in other banks.

The Handicapped Children's Home Service, 219 West Tenth Street, New York 14, was organized to meet the needs of thousands of ill or handicapped children who are confined to their homes for weeks, months or years, shut off from ordinary fun and play.

Recommendations for improved export packaging on American overseas shipments, originally planned to be based on combined surveys of shippers and shipments, are considered now to be largely dependent on findings of the latter, it was learned yesterday.

Arthur L. Pawliger, one of the four jurors who voted for the acquittal of Alger Hiss on a perjury charge, said yesterday that he had been subjected to a series of annoying telephone calls since the end of the trial July 8.

James F. White has been appointed general manager of the Audograph Company of New York, Inc., 521 Fifth Avenue. J. Beverly Miller, has been appointed sales manager for New York, New Jersey, Eastern Pennsylvania and Maryland.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -Heeding President Truman's request, the Senate Labor Committee today approved a bill to provide $150,000,000 a year for five years in Federal aid to states for hospital construction. That is twice the present allotment.

HONG KONG, July 22 (UP) -- At least 150,000 Communist soldiers are moving south from Shanghai toward the Changsha-Kanhsien area to reinforce the Communist armies in the battle for South China, the Nationalist air force reported today.

On Tubabao, an islet off Samar in the Philippines, there is a group of refugees from China, mostly White Russians, referred to as Shanghai DPs, who are anxiously awaiting the verdict of the world on their future fate.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The House Ways and Means Committee has rejected President Truman's recommendations for Federal participation in general relief to the needy and for establishment of a new "variable grant" formula to be used in allocating public assistance funds to the states.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., July 22 (AP) -- In a bid for her fourth State golf crown, Mrs. Ruth Torgerson downed her semi-final opponent today in the State women's amateur golf tourney at the Onondaga Country Club.

BERLIN, July 22--Communist leaders in the German People's Council demanded today that, in the interest of national unity, the political leaders of Western Germany drop plans for the establishment of the Federal Republic and join them in the formation of an all-German council.
BOSTON, July 22 (AP) -- Del Crandall's two-on triple in the fifth inning tonight clinched a 5 -- 3 victory for the Braves over the Pirates that may be an extremely costly one.

Mayor O'Dwyer swore in yesterday at City Hall the fifteen members of a Committee on Homeless Men that will coordinate the work of public and private agencies in caring for men in need of homes because of changing economic conditions, including increased unemployment.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 22 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council completed tonight its survey of all the trust areas falling under the supervision of the world organization and wound up its fifth session.

The Economic and Social Council of the United Nations has approved a resolution that asks for an immediate, nonpolitical and world-wide investigation of the problem of human slavery. No action that it has taken since its formation could have been of more far-reaching significance.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 22 -- Ratification of the Atlantic pact by the United States evoked the remark by the Prague radio that the Senate had approved an "aggressive pact that, as has been pointed out before, is directed at the Soviet Union and the Peoples' Democracies."

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Members of the Dairy Transport Association of Middletown, N. Y., made up of truckers carrying fluid milk in tank trucks from the New York City milk shed, today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to block proposals of the Delaware Hudson, the New York Central, the Rutland, and the New York Ontario Western Railroads to reduce their rates on fluid milk in the milk shed by about 27 per cent.

Facing the flags of the nations for whose liberation Simon Bolivar fought more than a century ago, Otto Shoenrich, president of the Pan American Society of the United States, called yesterday for a reaffirmation of the ideals that inspired the "George Washington of South America."

WARSAW, July 22 -- Praising the Poles for their accomplishments in repairing the ravages of war, President Boleslaw Bierut today exhorted a nation-wide audience to greater efforts in fulfillment of the six-year plan. President Bierut was chief speaker at impressive ceremonies marking the fifth anniversary of Liberation Day, celebrating the entry of Soviet and Polish troops into Poland in 1944.
PARIS, July 22 -- Otto Abetz, who was Hitler's Ambassador in Paris during the Nazi occupation, was sentenced to twenty years at hard labor as a war criminal by a French military tribunal late today.

A sedan of ancient vintage topped the rise of First Avenue at Fifty-ninth Street the other morning and then started downhill toward Sixty-first Street. There, at the corner, a policeman sitting in a motorcycle side car turned to his partner disgustedly.
CANTON, China, July 22 -- A Tibetan source said here today that a revolt had broken out in Lhasa against the Chinese Nationalist Government, which claims jurisdiction over Tibet.
LONDON, July 22 (AP) -- The Mosco radio charged today that Roman Catholic excommunication of Communists was a Vatican contribution to "the cold war that Anglo-American reactionaries are waging."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 -Arthur Knapp, at the helm of the International sloop Bumble Bee, and Bill Luders, with his Surf, went into the point-scoring of Larchmont race week tied today. It meant that each had beaten the same number of craft in the class over six sessions.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 22 -- By the thin margin of a single stroke, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales escaped defeat today in the semi-final round of the Pennsylvania State tennis championships on the Merion Cricket Club turf.

OSLO, Norway, July 22 (AP) -- A forty-two-man track team, selected from all parts of the United States, arrived in Oslo by plane tonight after a record-breaking nonstop flight of 9 hours, 58 minutes from Gander, Newfoundland.

CAMDEN, N. J., July 22 -- Federal District Court Judge Thomas M. Madden said today he believed the father and son who gloried in the name of the "C.O.D. Hoaxes," and plagued Floyd Deblaker, former police chief of Audubon Park, N. J., with practical jokes needed a "good thrashing."

WASHINGTON, July 22(UP) -The House Armed Services Committee today approved a $613,815,682 program of "top priority" military construction, including new housing for 7,798 families at Army, Navy and Air Force posts.

Mrs. Jan Burke's Ceara, claimed for $10,000 early in the month, won his fourth straight race at Jamaica yesterday. The gelding gave a front-running exhibition in the sprint for two-year-olds, beat off all challenges and made good with three-quarters of a length to spare. Monte was second and La Nappe third.

WASHINGTON, July 22--Senate debate on its $5,473,724,000 money bill for financing foreign aid through the current fiscal year opened today in an atmosphere indicating that heavy cuts proposed for the Marshall Plan would stand.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 22 -- A 17-year-old linksman and a golfer playing in his first tournament shared honors in the annual William Henry Beers Memorial competition of the Metropolitan Golf Association at the Knollwood Country Club today.
Your news story of June 28 "Art Control Is Urged for City" and the very interesting comments thereon made under date of July 6, 1949, by William Lescaze, call for further discussion.

The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company reported operating revenues of $233,563,049 yesterday for the twelve months ended on last June 30. The figure compares with $194,985,471 a year before. Earnings per share of capital stock for the period were $5.52, compared with $3.75.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 10 to 19 points net off on the day.
CAMDEN, N. J., July 22 -- The United States District Court in Camden was an uncomfortable spot for income tax evaders today.

Reflecting substantially larger sales, the net profit of the Studebaker Corporation and its subsidiaries in the six months ended with last June increased to $11,724,931 after all charges from the $8,126,553 earned in the initial half of last year, according to the report announced yesterday.

A new dramatic series, written, produced and directed by Carlton Morse -- who performs the same duties for the radio program, "One Man's Family" -- will make its debut on the NBC television network on Friday in the period from 9 to 9:30 P. M.
PARIS, July 22 -- Albouy inaugurates the fall millinery openings with tall cone-shaped jesters' caps, youthful calots and profile berets.

HELENA, Mont., July 22 -- The Montana Power Company was accused today of endeavoring to persuade Congress to nullify the Federal Reclamation Law by withholding funds to prevent the Bueau of Reclamation from installing public power facilities at the $25,000,000 multiple-purpose Canyon Ferry Dam and Reservoir near here.

OCEANSPORT, N. J., July 22 (AP) -- Forging to the front in the opening strides, James Cox Brady's steady-going Basis today turned in an easy victory in the featured Johren purse, witnessed by 11,702 fans at Monmouth Park.

The stock market backtracked again yesterday as further steam was withdrawn from the recovery movement. The retreat, however, was limited, with a considerable churning of prices around the previous close and the composite rate reduced 0.20 point.
CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 22 -- Educators today urged Congress to adopt the national school construction bill, approved yesterday by a Senate Labor and Public Welfare subcommittee.

ALBANY, July 22 -- Heads of colleges and universities in the State University system have been informed by Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the State University, that they will receive building priorities to a total of about $25,000,000, it was learned today.

The volume of trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange swelled abruptly at the opening yesterday with the marketing of $9,026,500 of the new 3 1/8 per cent ten-year convertible debentures of the American Telephone Telegraph Company.

Representatives of employes' groups expressed divergent views yesterday at a hearing on Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for a 150,000 survey of reclassification and revision of pay scales in the city's civil service system.

Acting at the request of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service has scheduled a joint conference with representatives of the union and the Bethlehem Steel Company for Thursday, at 2:30 P. M., Frank H. Brown, regional director here of the Government agency, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The consumers' price index rose 0.2 per cent between May 15 and June 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor reported today. The increase was ascribed largely to higher food costs.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 22 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, representing 20,000 production workers at nine plants of the Aluminum Company of America, today rescinded action that would have made a strike possible, effective at midnight July 31.
Barney Shotton's forces lost the opening skirmish in the battle for first place in the National League, which opened under the Ebbets Field lights last night before 33,120 Flatbush fans.

A powerhouse explosion, attributed in part to hot weather, shut down the East Side IRT subway and Third Avenue elevated line, together with connecting Bronx service, for fifty minutes last night. West Side IRT trains were not halted, but those bound for the Bronx were sidetracked or turned back at Ninety-sixth Street.

If Michael Todd can hire the proper talent, he will institute a two-a-day vaudeville policy at the Winter Garden beginning September. According to someone who ought to know, the showman's variety plans are rather ambitious. They call for a $6 top for evening performances and $3 for matinees, offering top performers of various branches of show business.
A strike of radio operators against American Overseas Airlines ended yesterday when both parties agreed to resume service and then sit down to continue negotiations to settle the labor dispute.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 22 -Prompt approval of a $1,450,000,000 program of military aid covering Greece, Turkey and other countries in addition to those which signed the Atlantic Pact was urged tonight by Francis H. Russell, director of the State Department's Office of Public Affairs.

DETROIT, July 22 -- Tommy Byrne, a lefthander inclined at times to be more than a trifle wild, seems to have developed a curious penchant for taming the Tigers and tonight, in the presence of 51,076 somewhat disconcerted onlookers, the Yankee southpaw really made Red Rolfe's Bengals roll over and do tricks.
Cardinal Spellman accused Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday of anti-Catholicism and "discrimination unworthy of an American mother" because of her opposition to Federal aid for parochial schools.

Looking at New York from the inside only is one of the habits of New Yorkers which assists in inviting from the inhabitants of the more open spaces of our country their sincerest flattery. That consists, as was noted in this corner a while ago, in finding us at least as provincial as they are.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Improvements at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to cost $1,700,000, of which the Federal Government will pay half, are scheduled for the current fiscal year as part of a $67,273,519 national program announced today by the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

Retail sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales were believed to be about 13 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 12 per cent below a year ago.

LONDON, July 22 -- The deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, who are engaged here in drafting an Austrian peace treaty, added today one more agreed treaty article to their list, bringing the total to six. Unagreed articles number thirteen.

Miss Sarah Anne Ide, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Knox Ide of 1040 Fifth Avenue, and Miss Cornelia D. Ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Richards Ford of 530 East Eighty-sixth Street, are among the many young women who will make their formal debuts at the Grosvenor Debutante Ball to be held in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton on Nov. 26.
The text of Cardinal Spellman's letter to Mrs. Roosevelt follows:

HONNINGSVAAG, Norway, July 20 -- In this outpost of Norway on the fringes of the Polar basin above lat. 71 degrees N. the North Atlantic pact is none too popular. Inhabitants of the uppermost reaches of King Haakon's realm fear the pact may involve them with the Russians sooner or later -- and most people here view the Russians as their good friends.

OMAHA, Neb., July 22 -- Anthony Santasiere of New York tonight moved closer to Albert Sandrin of Chicago, leader in the national open chess championship, with an eleventh-round victory over George Kramer of Kew Gardens, N. Y., in a Sicilian Defense lasting forty-seven moves.
The police withheld yesterday for three hours information on a routine automobile accident in which a priest was involved on the ground that it "would defeat the ends of justice."

IN 1943 the trustees of Columbia University laureled Upton Sinclair with a Pulitzer Prize for a novel called "Dragon's Teeth," the third volume in his enormously sympathetic perpetual-motion portrait of a gilded Socialist, Lanny Budd. The award seems to have been regarded with considerable favor on various sides at that time. The world has moved rather restlessly in many directions since that day.

LONDON, July 22 -- Russian industrial production amounted to 101 per cent of the target figure for the second quarter of 1949, although some industries failed to fiulfill their quota of certain essential products, the Moscow radio said tonight.

The alcohol beverage industries tax council has organized committees from all industry levels in twenty-five states and the District of Columbia to oppose high liquor taxes, it was learned here yesterday.

The Economic Cooperation Administration is the strongest support of the whole economic and political structure of Europe, Charles P. McCormick, United States employer delegate to the recent International Labor Organization conference in Geneva, said last night on his arrival on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania.
In a sort of dress rehearsal for the real event that is scheduled for tomorrow, the Cubs yesterday gave Frankie Frisch a "day" at the Polo Grounds, after a few disquieting moments.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP) -- Vern Stephens blasted his twenty-fourth home run and Ted Williams his twenty-third of the season tonight in leading the Boston Red Sox to a 4-2 verdict over the St. Louis Browns. Mel Parnell went the route and gave up eight hits in gaining his thirteenth victory against five defeats.

BERLIN, July 20 -- Western German industrial recovery really began only after last year's currency reform but has since made such remarkable progress that production is now at a rate of 90 per cent that of 1936, the last year before national economy was completely warped by preparations for war.

The chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, Mr. Robertson, has announced that the committee will begin, on Monday, a broad inquiry into alleged monopolistic practices on the part of the labor unions. The hearings will be directed initially into the coal industry.

New York City Omnibus and Fifth Avenue buses resumed operation yesterday after an eight-day strike as Theodore W. Kheel presented three "major measures" designed to prevent recurrence of the strikes and strike threats that have plagued the city's private transit industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -Deborah Kerr was named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading feminine role in "King Solomon's Mines," which the company will produce in British East Africa in September. An advance production unit was dispatched to England on the way to Nairobi today, and Miss Kerr is expected to leave for Africa about Sept. 1, after she finishes her assignment in "Please Believe Me."

This is with reference to the news item in THE TIMES concerning the refusal of the Board of Higher Education to reinstate Dr. Lee Lorch as instructor in mathematics at the City College. I am writing this letter individually as an alumnus of the college, although I am a member and secretary of the City College Alumni Committee Investigating Discrimination, which has carefully gone into the matter of Dr. Lorch's non-reappointment.

The Board of Estimate has shown excellent judgment and foresight in setting aside $336,000 for Park Commissioner Moses and his aides with which to draft plans for partially developing the unimproved portions of the 1,258-acre Flushing Meadow Park in Queens.
LONDON, July 22 -- Ending of the London dock strike failed to help the stock market, which finished the week on a quiet and uncertain note today.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 22 -With a cast of forty-six, headed by Akim Tamiroff and Jessica Tandy, "Now I Lay Me Down to Sleep" had its world premiere last night at Stanford University's Memorial Auditorium.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 (AP) -- Lightweight Champion Ike Williams today mapped plans for an invasion of the welterweight ranks and turned a deaf ear to accusations that he thumbed his way to a four-round technical knockout over Mexico's Enrique Bolanos last night.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -- The Senate Public Works Committee approved today a $100,000,000 program to help states plan public works projects and start a survey of Federal work-making plans.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 22 (UP) -- A grand jury returned four more indictments today in connection with recent terrorism by hooded floggers here and said it was considering one against the Ku Klux Klan as a whole.

ROME, July 22 -- Osservatore Roano today dedicated most of its first page to a detailed account of the United States Senate's ratification of the North Atlantic pact, which, it said, reflected the "will of free nations."

License Commissioner Edward T. McCaffrey disclosed yesterday that two more ticket brokers' licenses had been forfeited in the city's inquiry into theatre ticket scalping. These two raised to thirteen the number of licenses lost since the investigation was started on May 3 by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Cash dividend payments reported by United States corporations rose to $193,300,00 in May, an increase of 14 per cent over the $170,400,000 paid out during the same month a year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Coal industry officials will lead off testimony Monday at the opening of the Senate Banking Committee's investigation of labor union practices. Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat, of Virginia, reiterated that the committee might propose legislation to "protect the public from labor monopolies" if the evidence warranted.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Tracy S. Voorhees, Assistant Secretary of the Army, has received and forwarded to United States authorities in Germany, it was learned today, a letter from Samuel S. Isseks, New York attorney and former member of the Army's decartelization investigating committee, that charges misrepresentation by Mr. Voorhees of the committee's report on American efforts to break the German industrial and financial trusts.
Where kitchenette cooks are concerned, no need to labor the point that an oven operating at full tilt produces too much heat for comfort on a day typical of a New York summer.

Saying that he had been "placed in the role of a sacrificial pawn in the game of political chess," Hugo E. Rogers, Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday his withdrawal as a candidate for renomination on the Democratic ticket.

With the approach of August, the marketing of new issues of securities promises tc g, into the usual midsummer low gear, except possibly only in the field of taxexempt local governmefi' borrowing. Distributors of prime corporate ecurities have litl;le inventory on hand and the prospect of new supply at the moment is scant.

New silhouettes and styling of handbags to carry with light or dark sheer and prints are being featured for mid-summer use. The clutch type of handbag has made a strong comeback in styles for every occasion. The newest shape in this category is the elongated, shallow version.

When does a young upstart, say like the State of Ohio, attain a maturity at which it can be reasonably entrusted with its patrimony? The State of Connecticut thinks the 147th year is about right and, accordingly, has released to Ohio the last acre of land it held in that state to do with as it sees fit.

The property at the northeast corner of Shore Road and Oliver Street in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, formerly the home of William F. Kenny, has been sold by Realty Associates, Inc., to a client of Dreyer Traub, attorneys, who plans to improve it with an apartment building.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- The White Sox scored eight runs in the first inning in handing the Athletics a 12-0 trouncing before 22,365 tonight.

LONDON, July 22 -- The dock workers in London voted overwhelmingly today to end their strike, thus terminating one of the most embarrassing and troublesome incidents in the history of the British Labor Government. When nearly 16,000 dockers resume their jobs on Monday the strike, which is alleged to have been Communist-inspired will have lasted exactly four weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) -Fine relief pitching by Robin Roberts enabled the Phillies to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 2 -- 1, in the first game of the series tonight. Roberts relieved Russ Meyer with the bases loaded and none out in the eighth and allowed the Reds only one run.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -A Senate Judiciary subcommittee today approved a sweeping Communist control bill providing ten-year jail sentences for plotting to set up a Soviet-style dictatorship in the United States.

The property at the northeast corner of Shore Road and Oliver Street in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, formerly the home of William F. Kenny, has been sold by Realty Associates, Inc., to a client of Dreyer Traub, attorneys, who plans to improve it with an apartment building.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UP) -A Senate Judiciary subcommittee today approved a sweeping Communist control bill providing ten-year jail sentences for plotting to set up a Soviet-style dictatorship in the United States.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 23 -- Varied divertissements are being planned for the fifty-fourth annual Village Fair under the auspices of the East Hampton Ladies Village Improvement Society to be held here on Friday.
It was with great interest that I read the observations contained in the letter of Samuel Pleasants of July 17.

WEEK-END gardeners in particular are interested in material that will furnish pleasing effects with a minimum of maintenance. Plantain lilies (hostas) do exactly that. Even more serious gardeners find these undemanding plants a blessing in hot, muggy weather.

Publication yesterday by the Board of Transportation of figures covering revenues of concessions in subways, elevated lines, buses and trolley cars disclosed that the city had hit a $3,932,333 jackpot for the eleven months ended last May 31.

With the government now definitely committed to deficit financing for at least four years, a change seems to be taking place in the economic psychology of the nation. It found reflection in the action of the stock market, where prices edged forward for the fifth consecutive week.
