RICHMOND, Va., July 23 -- Virginia's liveliest Gubernatorial campaign in thirty-two years goes into its final week tomorrow, with a prospect of more thundering oratory before the voters go to the polls on Aug. 2.
ANNECY, France, July 23 -- The deadlock in the Italian - United States tariff discussions has been broken.

The message of the President on the economic situation that was delivered on July 11 is -- while not reaching the extremes of the program of the CIO -- based on a conception of the economic process which can only be termed purchasing power theory at its worst.

A DECADE ago Heinrich Eduard Jacob, a German novelist and biographer, a former inmate of Buchenwald, gazed at the Statue of Liberty. as his boat drew into New York harbor. Now, after long and painstaking research, he has published this volume about the American poetess whose sonnet, praising the mighty "Mother of Exiles" who welcomes the "homeless, tempest-tost," is engraved upon the pedestal of the statue.

IN his third novel, the Welsh writer, Gwyn Thomas, is concerned with his region's past. The reader who follows Alan Leigh, the harpist, over the mountains to Moonlea will find there a town of one hundred years ago with neat rows of workmen's cottages, the mansion of the ironmaster, and last of all the smoking foundries.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., July 23 (AP) -- Mexico's ban on the use of Mexican laborers in Texas was blamed today for a big increase in the number of aliens entering the United States illegally.

N. PETER RATHVON, who resigned as president of RKO last year after Howard Hughes bought control of the company, has entered the field of independent film financing on an extensive scale at a time when most other money sources, including the banks, have drastically curtailed their investments in motion pictures.

CRITICS and publishers are as fond of "package deals" as any advertising man. They like to tie up books with a bright red ribbon and a catchy label. First they created a dewy entity known as The Great American Novel. And when this never appeared, they hatched a crisper tag, The War Novel.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Reiterating his belief that the United States should at once declare war if Russia moves against Western Europe, Senator Robert A. Taft denied he was being an "isolationist" when he led the vain effort to block the North Atlantic Pact.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Inquiries tonight indicated that Chicago hotels were heeding the warning of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, that his union members would be barred from playing there if they did not shut off music piped into the hotels by wire.

Surrounded by rolling lawns and beautiful trees, the trim red-brick colonial buildings of the Burke Foundation in White Plains have for many years served convalescent patients from Westchester County and New York City. Either without cost or on a part-pay basis, hundreds of men and women have benefited from several weeks of rest there after medical or surgical treatment.

Announcement last week that the Home Loan Bank Board finally had adopted a revised code of regulations for Federal savings and loan associations caused considerable surprise and embarrassment in banking circles. Because of the industry-wide opposition the board's proposals aroused when originally offered in March, and the Congressional hearings that were scheduled as a result, bankers were caught unaware by the move.

NEWARK, N. J., July 23 -- One thousand cab drivers of this city who, like "hackies" everywhere, have a sharp eye and an ear always tuned in, have been actively enlisted by the police in crime detection and prevention, it was disclosed today.

TEL AVIV, Israel July 15 -- An American firm of consulting engineers has drafted plans for a $60,000,000 deep-water harbor, designed to give this city the finest port in the Middle East, and a $4,500,000 fishing harbor for ancient Caesarea, midway between Tel Aviv and Haifa.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 23 -- Plans are being formulated for the fourth annual fair in behalf of the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary. The event will be held on Aug. 5 and 6 on the grounds of the church, parish house and parochial school in Hill Street. The Rev. George H. Killeen is pastor of the church.

MOSCOW, July 23 (UP) -- Moscow newspapers, angered by Winston Churchill's contribution to the defense fund of a former Nazi field marshal accused of war crimes, charged today that he was trying to enlist the German as a "future ally."

PROBABLY no issue is more nearly central to our times than that of liberty versus authority. The problem is always before us, embodied in newspaper headlines, cold war communiques, court decisions, in the latest novel, poem or play.

IT would be difficult, one is tempted to say impossible, to find two Catholic anthologies more different in purpose, import, format, etc., than the two volumes listed above. Father Thornton's "Return to Tradition" provides generous selections from a wide variety of Catholic writing -- English, French, Irish and American -- since 1830.

CLEARLY, this summer is turning out to be the winter of the theatre's discontent. As the statisticians have been wailing, fewer attractions have managed to survive the heat than in years; the alarming scarcity of a commodity known as good scripts continues, and television, as radio did before it, is cutting into the available supply of playshops.

America's three-billion dollar industrial supply and machinery industry is up-grading management and sales activities and adding new sales engineering functions to supplement services rendered to industrial plants in pre-war days. These facts were revealed here yesterday in a report of a survey of progressive practices among distributors, disclosed by Carl Meister, general sales manager of the Atlas Chain and Manufacturing Company of Philadelphia.

Scoring twice with two out in the ninth inning, the Cardinals again beat the Dodgers yesterday, 5 -- 4, and moved within half a game of league-leading Brooklyn. Art Houtteman limited the Yankees to five hits as the Tigers triumphed, 2 -- 1, with two runs on George Kell's double in the first.

SHANGHAI, July 23 -- With Shanghai still completely cut off from sea and air links with the outside world, a severe case of "blockade jitters" is developing here among foreign residents eager but unable to leave China. This nervousness is especially acute among United States businessmen involved in complicated labor problems and contractual difficulties in the midst of a deepening economic depression and a continuing "anti-American imperialist" campaign.

PARIS, July 23 -- Communist efforts to block the North Atlantic Treaty as "another Munich" were defeated today in the National Assembly, which then postponed discussion of the treaty's ratification until Monday. The Palais Bourbon, where the Assembly met, was guarded by a large force of police, but there was no attempt at a demonstration and no crowd outside.

EDISTO ISLAND, S. C. -- Clustered along the South Carolina coast, only a few miles off U. S. Route 17, between Charleston and Beaufort, lie some islands that are rarely visited by tourists. Yet for the motorist who likes to explore unusual and unfamiliar territory, a side trip to this salt-water country is well worth the time and effort.

SPOKANE, Wash., July 23 -- A 312-pound gorilla and a 185-pound panther, accidentally locked in the same cage, fought a mortal battle for two and a half hours before 400 spectators at a resort near here last night.

The seventh race at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday was run with Pinkertons lining the rail in front of the grandstand, many of the bettors irate and the announcer's "call" barely audible through a chorus of booing.

Since the end of the war the American public has read and heard a great deal about the myriad difficulties confronting public-school teachers, including low pay, congested classes, overage buildings and antiquated textbooks and teaching materials. On the whole the reaction has been sympathetic.

Adventure beckoned to twenty-four Boy Scouts from the Metropolitan area as they headed out yesterday for the old Santa Fe trail in New Mexico. The boys are on a twenty-five-day junket into the mesquite country traveled by such pioneers as Kit Carson and will use modes of travel and transportation that date to the time of the Spanish Conquistadores.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Some 16,000,000 veterans will be able to begin on Aug. 29 to file their claims for a share of the $2,800,000,000 Government life insurance overpayments due them.

MUSSORGSKY'S "Kovant-china" will be one of the features of Edward Johnson's final season as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. Another will be a revival of Puccini's "Manon Lescaut," last sung there by Lucrezia Bori in 1930.

CERTAIN speculations are endlessly engaging to the novelist, as they must be to the reader: Suppose Hitler did not die in his Berlin bunker, suppose he escaped and is loose somewhere in the world -- what then? Or suppose Jesus came back to walk the earth, or the Devil?
Music and dance events scheduled for the week in the city's parks follow:

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- In eleven sections, each larger than a box-car and weighing up to thirty tons, a complete cement kiln, described as the first ever shipped overseas, left here today for Puerto Rico on the 5,000-ton freighter Ponce.

TO the layman the practice of medicine has always had an aura of glamour about it. Similarly, a Far Eastern setting suggests exotic and bizarre adventures. A combination of both should prove irresistibly fascinating.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- A mystery witness has told Congress that the United Nations Secretariat under Trygve Lie is terrorized by Communist agents who force employes to become their tools.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The International Typographical Union disclosed today that its members have paid $19,826,725 in strike assessments since 1946 to follow what the union president, Woodruff Randolph terms "the only policy that would protect the ITU under the impact of the Taft-Hartley Law," its predecessor, the Wagner Act, and to force employers to inlcude the union's laws in contracts.

FOR THIS WEEK: Dust the undersides of cucumber leaves with rotenone to get rid of aphids. They also cause the sticky drip from maple trees. Spray them with nicotine. . . . Pull up stray plants of ragweed or spray a colony with 2, 4-D before they flower. . . . Bushier plants result from pinching chrysanthemums, but it should be done no later than this week. . . .
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 23 (AP) -- A smart breeze and a perfect summer day marked the start of a 366-mile yacht race to Halifax, N. S., today. Seven of the twenty-one entries are from Halifax.

WHILE "Old Vic Drama," by Audrey Williamson, is a record of the plays produced and acted by the Old Vic Theatre Company of London in the years between 1934 and 1947, it is also something of a record of the progress of the Old Vic Theatre during that time.

VACATIONISTS bent on spending a summer holiday along southern New England shores have a good choice of local steamship lines for a day's outing along Cape Cod or for a trip to various vacation resorts in the area.
ARCADIA, Calif., July 23 -- Ace Admiral, breaking Man o' War's 29-year-old world record, won the $50,000 added Sunset Handicap today as the Hollywood Turf Club meeting ended with a flourish.

THE major recommendation to most moviegoing these days is the fact that most movie theatres are air-conditioned -- and, baby, it's cold inside! That is no stop-press information; air-conditioning is now as customary as ice.
ITHACA, N. Y., July 23 -- John Francis Moakley, for fifty years coach of track and field at Cornell, retired today.

Brucellosis or undulant fever, which afflicts man and animals, is treated successfully with various antibiotics, but Drs. Morton S. Bryer, Emanuel B. Schoenach, Ronald M. Wood and Perrin H. Long hold out the prospect in the Bulletin of the Johns Hopkins Hospital that aureomycin may be the best.

THE specialized humor of Abe Burrows, the determinedly mad wag who has made a career out of inverting song titles, is back on the air in a half-hour dose at 9:30 on Monday nights. This time CBS has accorded the comedian the cooperation of its production department -- an orchestra, guest stars, etc -- and obviously is out to make Mr. B. self-supporting.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and its affiliated unions are running more than fifty summer school sessions for about 5,000 selected students, CIO headquarters estimated today.

CARLTON E. MORSE, writer of the "One Man's Family" radio series on NBC, arises in his suite at the St. Moritz hotel every morning at 5:30 o'clock, cooks his own breakfast of steak and fried potatoes (sliced very thin) and then sits down to a stint of script writing.

The French Line, which since the war has maintained a cargo service between the Pacific Coast and Europe with Liberty-type freighters, announced yesterday the resumption, after almost a decade, of express, freight and passenger service on this run.

THE retrospective exhibition of work by the Austrian expressionist Oskar Kokoschka which has opened at the Museum of Modern Art does considerably more than bring before us an artist's development. In fact, the exhibition seems to me much less important in itself at the moment than for what it reveals of the art of our period.

The twenty-fourth annual Music Memory Contest of the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts will be held Wednesday, Aug. 3, at 8:30 P. M., in Central Park. Excerpts from twenty compositions performed at the concerts during the current season will be played by the Goldman Band, and contestants must identify each of the works and its composer. Anyone who is not a professional musician may participate in the competition.

RICHMOND, Va., July 23 -- The Upper South had its eye this week on the good old summer time -- and not much else. Over most of this essentially rural area, corn was in full tassel and summer hay crops were a lush green from abundant rains.

AN F. Scott Fitzgerald fan named Betty Field has returned to the screen, after a five-year absence, as the heroine of his best-known tale, "The Great Gatsby." The actress claims, though, that her reappearance as Daisy Buchanan was more a matter of coincidence than of appreciation.

The fifth annual conference of the Henry George School of Social Science heard a labor union delegate declare yesterday that the rank-and-file worker in American industry could and must be taught the basic elements of economic theory.

Independent organizations which innocently entered into warranty contracts for servicing television sets -- contracts now held a violation of New York State insurance laws -- are in little danger of wholesale prosecution, it was learned last week.

The new cargo-passenger vessel Irish Oak, third unit of the Irish Shipping, Ltd., post-war fleet of new vessels, is due to arrive here this afternoon and will start the return leg of her maiden voyage tomorrow evening, it was announced yesterday by John Gammie, vice president of the States Marine Corporation, 90 Broad Street, agents for the Irish Line in this country.

Three hundred persons gathered at the base of the Statue of Liberty's pedestal yesterday to commemorate the birth 100 years ago of Emma Lazarus, whose poem "The New Colossus" is inscribed on a tablet near the main entrance to the statue. Miss Lazarus died in 1887.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The National Labor Relations Board unanimously threw out secondary boycott charges today against a group of building unions in Pennsylvania, but the unions' victory probably is a paper one. They have been under a temporary injunction for nearly ten months, which was long enough to complete the building project with the labor to which the unions objected.

THE non-fiction career books by Mr. Floherty are tops. They are technically sound, filled with valuable advice and often more exciting than fiction. His latest, devoted to the careers of the camera men, is one of his best.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Administration officials are divided on the feasibility of a unified direction for all governmental activities abroad, according to a summary of views made public today by Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat, of Arkansas, chairman of the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Departments.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Flour buying in the Northwest gave support to wheat futures on the Board of Trade today. Mill brokers took to the buying side and advanced prices about a cent. Other grains held to a firm course without making any substantial gains.

ATHENS, July 23 -- George Koufoudakis, formerly secretary general of the Greek Seamen's Union (OENO), told reporters here today that the Communist parties of the United States and Australia, as well as of most of the European countries in the Western bloc, had used the union as a revolutionary agency for the spread of Communist doctrine and to foment unrest on ships and docks.

THE establishment of a Norman J. Coleman Award was announced by the American Association of Nurserymen at their annual convention in San Francisco last Wednesday. Originated in honor of the first Secretary of Agriculture, it is intended to stimulate research in the field of horticulture.

Current Congressional hearings on the proposed omnibus civil rights bill, introduced by Senator McGrath and Representative Celler in both houses, besides calling for the establishment of a Federal Commission on Civil Rights, also seeks to reorganize the civil rights activities of the Department of Justice.

JOGJAKARTA, Java, July 23 -- Republican and Federalist leaders in Indonesia announced at the end of their two-day conference here today that they had reached an agreement on the creation of a United States of Indonesia, to be known as the Republic of Indonesia Serikat (United).

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- It is like trying to assemble a jig-saw puzzle with many pieces missing to assess the full significance of the secret discussions proceeding here on the question of cooperation with Great Britain in the development of atomic energy.

The North Atlantic Pact has passed the Senate a little less than a decade after the beginning of the Second World War and about three decades after a previous Senate threw away some of the hope of peace by refusing to accept the League of Nations. Last Thursday's ratification vote marked a great step forward in a historical movement which has been going on for a generation.

AFTER certain events last fall -- well, one event -- it became evident that someone was going to write a book kidding the pants off the poll takers. It may or may not be a healthy sign that this has now been accomplished by a member of the public opinion industry itself.

OZZIE NELSON and his wife, Harriet Hilliard, who last year were heard on CBS and before that on NBC, will be working under the ABC network banner this fall. They signed a contract under which the network will have first call on their services for a ten-year period, it was said.

Representatives of the Women's Swimming Association carried off the six metropolitan senior championships at stake in the A.A.U. outdoor water carnival held yesterday at the Flushing Meadow Amphitheatre in conjunction with the Department of Parks' city-wide finals for boys and girls.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23 -- Minister of Foreign Affairs Edvard Kardelj said today, in a statement to the Tanjug News Agency, that the Communist Information Bureau's campaign against Yugoslavia was responsible for the decision to close the Greek frontier and withdraw support from the Greek guerrillas.

THIS book, packed with information about the wonders of modern science and technology, is a series of dramatic stories of atomic power, electronics, radar, jet propulsion, television, and a wide range of other subjects interesting to young people with a scientific turn of mind.
Imminent fatherhood is an extenuating legal circumstance, it was decided yesterday in a Brooklyn Court.

Application forms will be available tomorrow for quarters in the three new public housing projects scheduled to open in the fall, it was announced yesterday by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

DOROTHY WHIPPLE'S new novel, "Because of the Lockwoods," is a mature, unusual, consistently interesting book which deals, incredibly enough, with a heroine who is poor but proud, and a villain who literally defrauds widows and orphans.

IT is not true that every soldier discharged from the American Army after World War II remained for a few years in Europe and then returned home to write a book about his experiences. It only seems that way. But it would be a safe bet, I should think, to describe William Attwood as the only one of the lot who remained abroad and later returned with a cheerful book.

Spectators at Staten Island Airport watched in amazement when they saw a small Aeronca plane go aloft at 6:05 P. M. yesterday, with a man hanging onto the craft's rudder. It was the plane's pilot. He had been dragged 100 feet along a runway in a vain effort to stop the ship, started accidentally by a girl passenger.

The third annual Old-Timers' Day has been set for the Yankee Stadium on Sunday afternoon, Aug. 21. It will be designated "Connie Mack Day" in honor of the 86-year-old pilot of the Athletics and will be featured by a two-inning game between Mr. Mack's all-time A's and a group of old-time Yankees also selected by him.

The South American arrow poison, curare, has been a source of interest and challenge to research since it was first described by the Italian Peter Martyr in 1516. Curare is made in remote jungles from numbers of different plants in accordance with a ritual known only to a few primitives.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 23 -- In the opinion of political observers the question of King Leopold's return or abdication is becoming a long-term issue.

Before William Sarich, 37-year-old taxicab driver, found himself in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of felonious assault, the following rapid procession of events had taken place, according to the police:

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 23 -- John Gennerich and Jack Mullin, his guest from Wykgagyl, who tied for the medal in the qualifying round, won their opening test as match play began today in the Siwanoy Country Club's first member-guest invitation best-ball handicap golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, national commander of the Disabled American Veterans, bitterly attacked the ratification of the North Atlantic Pact and President Truman's veterans program today.

MONTREAL, July 23 (UP) -- Australia advanced to the final round of the North American Zone Davis Cup eliminations today by completing an expected 4-to-1 victory over Canada as Frank Sedgman and Billy Sidwell won the last two singles matches.

OMAHA, July 23 -- Midwest farmers and ranchers were absorbed last week in the problem of keeping the soil on the farm and making that soil more fertile, more productive and hence more profitable. Soil conservation was the answer they were giving to pessimists who wail that future generations will go hungry because the soil is wearing out.

PARIS, July 23 -- On his way to Evian Les Bains for a holiday, British Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin spent two hours before and during luncheon today with Foreign Minister Robert Schuman. Officials said they had reviewed the state of French and British trade in connection with the Marshall Plan and the problem of the former Italian colonies in North Africa but without reaching any decisions.

Ten years ago, on the eve of Hitler's attack in Europe, America played a secondary role in the world. The national policy was expressed in the Neutrality Act of 1937, which sought to insulate the United States against foreign entanglements. America's chief international commitment was the Monroe Doctrine's loose pledge to Latin America.

BOSTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Belair Stud's 4-year-old My Emma helped celebrate Trainer Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons' seventy-fifth birthday today by coming from last place at the far turn to capture the thirteenth running of the $10,000 added Hannah Dustin Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

To keep Brooklyn's extensive street and highway system in "a highly serviceable condition" maintenance employes made 51,659 minor repairs last year, according to a report submitted yesterday to Borough President John Cashmore by the Bureau of Highways and Sewers.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Soviet industry now is within striking distance of completing the five-year plan in four years, a report by the Central Statistical Administration on the results of the first six months of 1949 declared today.
However praiseworthy are the endeavors of the Quakers to find a basis for solution of the present crisis between East and West, their approach to the problem is fallacious.

The "old look" is rapidly being restored to Coney Island, with reconstruction of the famous Steeplechase Pier reported yesterday to be nearing the half-way mark. The news was greeted enthusiastically by old-timers who had used the pier for sun bathing and fishing.

High temperatures took toll of retail trade here last week, although total volume was aided by the spending of delegates to the Lions International convention. Department store sales followed the previous pattern, with volume estimated at about 13 per cent below last year.

Protests over the Veterans Administration's plan to close its 350-bed Manhattan Beach (Brooklyn) Hospital about Nov. 1 "are not justified by the facts and are unnecessarily causing undue alarm among the 315 patients in the hospital, staff members and others who are sincerely interested in the veterans' hospital program," a spokesman for the Veterans Administration asserted yesterday.

A major problem for the strategists of the Democratic party since last fall's election has been to weld into a cohesive political force the two large blocs of voters who elected president Truman -- labor and the farmers. The aims of those two groups are frequently contradictory.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 -- The old steamer Yale, which during the heyday of coastal shipping operated between San Francisco and Los Angeles with 800 passengers in fine accommodations, passed through the Golden Gate this week en route to the scrap heap.
LONDON, Sunday, July 24 (UP) -- Marshal Alexander M. Vasilevsky, Soviet Minister of the Armed Forces, called upon the Soviet Navy and shipbuilders today to "further strengthen" Russia's naval might.

NANKING, July 23 -- Reports reaching this Communist-held city say rebellious peasants in Manchuria are carrying on guerrilla warfare. Responsible Chinese sources say the peasants have blown up bridges, destroyed railway roadbeds and committed industrial sabotage.

Preparation of concentrated extracts of a long sought factor essential for the building of the red blood cells is announced in the current issue of the Hospital Bulletin of the University of Michigan.

NANKING, July 23 -- The Military Control Commission today ordered the United States Information Service office in Nanking to cease all public activities. The order was contained in a notification handed to Josiah Bennett, director of the Nanking office, by Huang Hua, director of the foreign affairs bureau.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 23 -- The American Export Lines piers at Exchange Place here were idle again today as the strike begun last Monday by 400 longshoremen and dock checkers continued.

IF summer is here, can fall be far behind? -- so thinks the recent high-school graduate who is lucky enough to be going to college when September rolls around. Just how much of a change will it be from the school life she has been familiar with for the past twelve years?

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Farmers in the Central States are looking forward to generally excellent crops this year, and to earnings during the next twelve months somewhat reduced from the high war and post-war levels, but substantially above pre-war levels.

Re "A Stirring Song for a Singing Army," by Sigmund Spaeth, what a lot of sissy braggadoccio in the five sample songs quoted! Imagine an iron-and-guts Army of the United States of America puling ladies' sewing circle sentiment like that! If our soldiers want to sing it must be something with punch to it.

A nation-wide campaign beginning Sept. 15 by the American knit glove industry against Japanese importations "to prevent the destruction of our entire $15,000,000-a-year American industry and other industries" was announced yesterday by J. A. Milstein, president of the Association of Knitted Glove and Mitten Manufacturers.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed faille coat dresses, juniors' dance dresses, rhinestone jewelry, men's summer slacks, basque shirts and miniature cameras, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.
DETROIT, July 23 -- For years it was Gar Wood's job to defend for the United States the world's supremacy in speed boating for the British international trophy, better known as the Harmsworth.

WHAT great novelist is being "celebrated" this year for his birth and next year for his death? To make the question fairer, perhaps we should add that the occasion is being celebrated primarily in France, while the rest of the world marvels at this spectacle of the good German Goethe

Hanson W. Baldwin's "Two Great Delusions About the A-Bomb" is revealing truth. Clinging to the sense of security built upon the awesome splendor of the disintegrating atom is akin to having the sense of safety which the United States felt, say, after the Battle of Manila Bay in 1898.

PRINCE ALBERT of Saxe-Coburg, the husband of Queen Victoria, died in 1861. Since then he has been known as a virtuous bore. The Queen, by her long period of inconsolable mourning, her incessant references to "my beloved Albert," and her series of ugly monuments and reluctantly eponymous descendants, founded this reputation.

RUNNING a dog kennel as a means of making a living could come under the heading of heavy-duty work, as Iris Benway knew. But there was nothing harrowing about it until a rival kennel owner, a thoroughly unpleasant man, was found with his throat slashed in her kennel's stripping room.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- Representative Graham A. Barden, Democrat, of North Carolina, expressed fear today that a storm of religious controversy had endangered approval by Congress of a $300,000,000 program of Federal aid to education.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 -- Ratification of the North Atlantic pact by the United States Senate has provided ammunition for scattered groups in the Middle East that insist that the countries must join in a mutual defense pact. The real spokesmen for the idea, although working unostentatiously, seem to be members of Turkish and Iranian diplomatic services.

HAMMERFEST, Norway, July 22 -- Reports of fishermen operating from this and other ports on the "roof" of the Scandinavian peninsula appear to indicate that the Soviet Union's naval base at Murmansk, 265 air miles to the southeast, is far from being dormant.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 23 -- Seeded teams advanced today in the annual men's invitation doubles tournament at the Maidstone Club, with Gardnar Mulloy and Bill Talbert, No. 1 ranking team, favored to win out in the final tomorrow afternoon.

One hundred and forty-seven youngsters arrived late yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Terminal after a three-week vacation at the Police Athletic League's summer camp, Fox Lair, in the Adirondack mountains.
HONOLULU, July 23 (AP) -- Striking longshoremen appealed to President Truman today to end Hawaii's eighty-four-day dock tie-up "on its merits."

SHANGHAI, July 23 -- In the wake of costly floods and a drought, a surprisingly effective Nationalist coastal blockade and the reappearance of Chiang Kai-shek on the international political scene, the Chinese Communists kicked off again this week on a new multiple offensive pointing toward the two last major Kuomintang centers on the mainland.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- American foreign trade since the end of the war has been the great factor in the world's economy. American exports have fed the peoples of Western Europe and provided the essentials of recovery. American imports, on the other hand, nowhere near balance the exports.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- All-out repeal of wartime excise taxes at this session of Congress was urged today by Senator Walter F. George of Georgia. He said it would stimulate business and employment.

A serious threat to the spirit of free enterprise and the continued growth of American industry has resulted from the chaotic condition of the American patent system. This was the statement made yesterday by T. Irving Potter, president of Potter Halsey, Inc., management consultant concern, and holder of more than fifty patents.

Strangers Within the Gates Visitors from all parts of the country who flock to New York every summer remind many New Yorkers that they too were once visitors who decided to stay. No one offered to give them the place; on the contrary, they were willing to pay a good price for the privilege of staying on.

MANCHESTER, England, July 23 (Reuters) -- A century fifth-wicket stand by experienced Martin Donnelly and 21-year-old John Reid, playing in his first test, helped to rescue New Zealand in the third test cricket match against England at Old Trafford today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 23 (UP) -- William Hugh Morris, jailed Alabama Ku Klux Klan leader, accepted a challenge late today to produce Klan records for a grand jury and was released under $500 bond.

IN hundreds of summer camps the traditional center of group activity is the evening council fire where young campers gather to sing, tell stories, play games and perform stunts in an atmosphere of good fellowship. To All camp leaders and counselors who would impart to the modern camp-fire some of the beauty and mysticism which the ceremony held in the ritual of the American Indian, this unusual book is highly recommended.

IN his article of July 17, entitled "In a Glass House," Bosley Crowther said to Warner Brothers, the producers of my picture, "The Fountainhead," that a Hollywood studio should not produce a picture on the theme of man's integrity, because some writer of integrity, such as Miss Rand, might become unhappy about the adaptation of her work to the screen and cut all the prints of the film to shreds.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 23 -- The two principal rivers of the Southwest, the Colorado and the Rio Grande, were centers of regional attention this week as Congress continued consideration of major projects on them.

Columbia College has named three visiting professors who will spend the coming academic year studying, "through actual participation," the college's program of general education, Dean Harry J. Carman announced yesterday.

AN exhibition of work by four contemporary photographers will open Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art and continue until Sept. 25. The photographers, whose prints will be shown on separate walls of a single room, are Ralph Steiner, Wayne Miller, Frederick Somers and Tosh Matsumoto.

LE HAVRE -- The secret of French-flag passenger-ship operations has always been an emphasis on excellent cuisine and service, but the refurbished liner Ile de France, due in New York Wednesday on her post-war maiden run, is imbued with a third element -- atmosphere.

A BOLD exploitation program, backed by top quality pictures, was proposed the other day as the first step for a broad campaign designed to stimulate public interest in the movies. Calling for a united industry effort to shoo away box-office blues, Gael Sullivan, executive director of the Theatre Owners of America, suggested that a national "Fall Film Festival" be held during the month of October.

BOSTON, July 23 -- New England business men will ask Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer for a fair share of Federal funds, but "no leaf-raking handouts" when he sits down with them here on Monday at the outset of his national fact-finding survey of unemployment.

THESE are three recent titles in the British series of short monographs on English novelists which Alan Swallow is publishing in this country. As a series it can be warmly recommended to both students and general readers.

MOSCOW, Sunday, July 24 (Reuters) -- Russia, in a note published today by the official news agency Tass, accused Yugoslavia of making a secret deal with Britain ceding her territorial claims on the Austrian border area of Carinthia.
FRESH fruits are approaching the year's peak in kinds and quantities. This is the season when nature plays into our hands by offering us perfection in flavors.

POSTMASTER General Jesse M. Donaldson made available last week a photograph of the design of the stamp which will be issued next month to mark the final encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, at Indianapolis from Aug. 28 through Sept. 1.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 23 -- Melvin (Chick) Harbert and Bob Hamilton had a strangle hold today on the top prize of $4,000 with two rounds to go in the $15,000 Inverness four-ball golf matches.

Bankers and foreign traders yesterday were giving close study to the new regulations promulgated by the Chinese Nationalist Government establishing the Republic's currency upon a silver basis. The consensus here was that the move substituting the silver yuan for the former gold yuan was logical from a psychological point of view and likely to bring some order out of the nation's muddled monetary situation.

LONDON. NEVOZVRASHCHENTSY (Non - returners) -- this is how the mass of Russian DP's, who have refused repatriation, and other Russian refugees in Western Europe describe themselves. Together they form a large proportion, perhaps more than half, of the million or more expatriated men and women now in European countries.

A special course for American students will be given during the 1949-50 academic year at the University of Stockholm. The main subjects to be studied are Swedish social, economic and political conditions and the Swedish language.

PROFESSOR JOAD teaches philosophy in Birkbeck College, London. Much experience in adult education has trained him to write simply and clearly. From his facile pen has flowed a stream of books setting forth the principles and practical applications of Platonic realism in philosophy.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 23 -- Fifty carloads of size B potatoes purchased by the Production and Marketing Administration of the United States Department of Agriculture in Suffolk County this week to support the price to the growers have been shipped to dairymen and other livestock men in up-State New York to be fed to farm animals, mostly cattle.

THIS is the open season for hitch-hiking, and the Automobile Club of New York warns motorists that this is a good time to be on guard against "thumbers" as well as the variety of assorted rackets that are springing up along highways crowded with a record-breaking number of tourists.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- Philadelphia women's apparel stores reported a gain of 8 per cent above a year ago in a dollar volume sale compilation for last week. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 100,185 as against 136,170 last year, a decrease of 26.4 per cent, and for 1949 to date totaled 3,041,039 to compare with 3,544,296 last year, a decrease of 14.2 per cent.
THE myth of Leonardo da Vinci has grown to such magnificence that if he had not lived it would have been justifiable to invent him.

THE Agricultural Society of South Carolina was founded at Charleston in 1785. Since its organization, the Society has been closely connected with the history of the state; its members have been drawn from all walks of life.

OLIVER LA FARGE, in his modest preface to this book, explains why he wrote it. Though a history of the Air Transport Command, and not a skimped one, it is no formal history, nor intended to be definitive. It is the story of that course of events by which the old Ferrying Command, shifting a few planes around the Country in short hops, was built into the phenomenal ATC.

Sympathetic nerves are so called because they control organs that function automatically. Sometimes such nerves do not function properly. Result: blood vessels are involuntarily constricted, blood pressure goes up alarmingly.

HANDSOME color pictures of gardens that appear in catalogues and magazines often evoke a strong sense of frustration in the average homeowner. "Now why can't my garden look like that?" he is apt to mumble bitterly.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18 -- Argentina's little-publicized Diligenti quintuplets attained their sixth birthday Friday, July 15. It was celebrated the following day so that nothing might interfere with school. That is typical of the way the children are being brought up -- everything normal, no special privileges and emphatically no exploitation.

DETROIT, July 23 -- The Yankee dash down the homestretch of the current Western trip stubbed a toe today as Art Houtteman, Detroit's 22-year-old righthander whose career almost ended in an auto crash last spring, tripped the Bombers with a neat five-hitter to win for the Tigers, 2 to 1.

BERLIN, July 20 -- On Aug. 14, elections will be held in Western Germany to elect a lower house of the Bonn assembly. Just as last year's currency reform disclosed the real wealth existing in the Western zones, the August balloting may show the real political feeling in that area.
The Milano soccer team will make the final New York appearance of its tour today when it meets a picked United States squad at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. The game will start at 3:30 P. M.
An optimistic appraisal of this country's economic future was given yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund in a report based on a large-scale survey of America's needs and resources.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Department store sales here marked the tenth consecutive week of declines in comparison with last year. A check of Federal Reserve records on department store sales, starting in 1938 when the compilation was begun, revealed that the extent of the decline is without precedent.
JOGJAKARTA, July 23 (AP) -- A government on the West European model is the reported choice of Indonesian political leaders for the projected United States of Indonesia.

GIVEN the Statue of Liberty on the one hand and Robert E. Sherwood, Irving Berlin and Moss Hart on the other, a cautious theatregoer is likely to expect something with spirit and flavor. For these three men are notable for talent, conscience and good-will.
IF roses are to bloom well in fall, they cannot be neglected now. Of the several measures to be taken, watering is, of course, the most important.

An experiment in local government enterprise by which fast-growing metropolitan area communities seek to end stream pollution through a joint sewage disposal undertaking financed by tax-exempt revenue bonds is approaching the critical money-raising phase.

GIANT tree ferns ad exotic blossoms have transformed The Channel gardens in Rockefeller Center for July and August into a typical Hawaiian scene. To make this possible, 20,000 pounds of plant material was flown the 5.051 miles from Honolulu to New York during the last week in June.

MR. SINCLAIR "hopes" that this, the tenth, is the last of the Lanny Budd volumes. If it is, all faithful Buddists will recognize, as do I, the sort of nostalgia they first experienced in their youth upon coming to the end of the "Three Musketeers."
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Three-day work week in bituminous mines is "seriously affecting'' coal shipments through Lake Erie ports, the National Coal Association said tonight.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 23 -- The significance of the grand jury investigation into masked-mob activities in this area lies in its dramatization of the conflict between the Ku Klux Klan and the New South.

Allocation by the Economic Cooperation Administration of funds to cover the export of American leather to Western Germany is expected to bring about "more realistic prices" for hides and skins in world markets. The allocation, put at around $3,000,000, represents less than 1 per cent of United States leather output.
ST. LOUIS, July 23 (AP) -- The Red Sox had a field day with Brownie pitching today as Boston clubbed out nineteen hits for a 16-to-5 rout of St. Louis before a slim crowd of 2,169.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Chinese Embassy has asked the State Department to reconsider its decision to publish, before the end of July, a so-called White Paper on Sino-American relations, it was learned today. There is no indication that the department's plans have been altered.

TAIPEH, Formosa, July 19 -- Although Formosa is now the Nationalists' main bastion, the internal situation has deteriorated during the last few months. Up to last August the island had a relatively stable currency. When the gold yuan was introduced the Formosan dollar was tied to it against the wishes of local bankers.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Representative Tom Steed, Oklahoma Democrat, wrote Mrs. Frank lin D. Roosevelt today that Cardinal Spellman's letter criticizing her stand on Federal aid to public schools was "a masterpiece of distortion, misrepresentation and deliberate twisting of the truth."

THERE are special reasons why Pennsylvania should have laid down rich beds of folk-tradition in the past two centuries. "Keystone" is fact as well as figure of speech. The natural resources of the state are such that most aspects of the nation's development are recapitulated in local history.

THE writing of biography, principally because of rising costs of various kinds, has become an avocation rather than a profession. It has rarely been a lucrative calling. On the other hand, autobiography can be very rewarding indeed -- particularly if the author has led some world power to victory in a war.

In recent years the wampum-getting ability of Tammany Hall -- the New York County (Manhattan) Democratic Committee -- has declined. With the growth of other counties' population, Manhattan has become less important in city, as well as state and national, politics.

More than half of the states have asked for a rating of their mental hospitals, it was reported yesterday by Dr. Ralph M. Chambers, director of inspection and rating of mental hospitals for the American Psychiatric Association.

PHILATELY'S first likeness of "Ste-Madeleine," otherwise Saint Magdalene or Mary Magdalene of Biblical times, is shown on a 1-75-francs olive-brown stamp issued by Belgium to commemorate the Gerard David Exposition at Bruges this month.

DETROIT, July 23 -- To date this has been a baseball campaign of singular and at times totally unexpected developments. The Giants started the year with what most everyone, including their owner, Horace Stoneham, considered a pretty robust, healthy ball club.

CONSIDERED the mainstay of grandmother's garden, phlox, which is starting to flower now, has never slipped into the category of "old-fashioned" plants. On the contrary, it still forms the backbone of many a midsummer perennial border, for phlox will provide color through those blistering days when few other perennials show bloom.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Air Force achieved its full and final independence as a member of the armed forces today.

LONDON. IN July of next year five years will have elapsed since Britain's Labor party won its national victory at the polls and established Clement Attlee as Prime Minister of His Majesty's Government. According to the Parliamentary Act of 1911, a new general election must be held in Britain at least every five years -- that is, in this case, by July, 1950.

COBLENZ, Germany, July 23 -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, warned at an election rally here today in preparation for the Aug. 14 elections for the Bundestag against propaganda for a unified Germany until the Soviet zone was as free as the three Western zones.

LONDON, July 23 -- Matching the forcefulness of Mr. Churchill's language, Prime Minister Attlee described the Conservative election statement of policy today as "one of the most dishonest documents that I have ever read" and a "wonderful mass of confused thinking."

READERS and writers of mystery fiction have long debated, and not always temperately, whether political content is desirable in fictional melodrama. William O'Farrell gives us the definitive answer: it's not only desirable, it's ideal -- when it is as admirably integrated into the personal, emotional plot as it is in "Thin Edge of Violence."

A MAIN trend in British production appears to be the loan of players from overseas. Aside from the Hollywood stars who are currently playing in our back yard, there is a raft of actors from the French studios.
CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP) -- Sparked by Bob Feller's five-hit pitching, the Indians punched across two runs in the eighth inning today to defeat the Senators, 5 to 3, before 21,000 fans.

LONDON, July 23 -- As plans were completed today for full resumption of work in the London docks, a new crisis approached on the uneasy labor front. Developments in the patched-up dispute over the railwaymen's wages brought renewed danger of a widespread slowdown through "working to rule" on the publicly owned railways.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 23 -- Three Rings won the $25,000 Monmouth Handicap at Monmouth Park today, and in so doing registered more than a mild upset in the presence of 22,811 specttors.

OMAHA, Neb., July 23 -- Winning his final game in the twelfth round from Herbert Hickman of Pittsburgh, with a Sicihan Defense lasting forty moves, Albert Sandrin of Chicago today captured first prize from an original entry list of seventy in the Open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- Coaltown, the nation's top handicap star, today streaked to his tenth victory in eleven starts this season in winning the $54,700 Arlington Handicap by three lengths.

In a move expected to have vast educational implications, eleven Southern states have entered upon a mutual plan to aid one another in developing a sound program of higher education. For the first time in the history of this country, a regional system of education has been established. It will go into effect this fall.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 -- Victor Seixas of Philadelphia, winner of the crown in 1946 and 1947, defeated Sam Match of San Francisco, the defending title holder, in the Pennsylvania State tennis championship today on the turf of the Merion Cricket Club.

WOLVERHAMPTON, England, July 23 -- Winston Churchill charged here today that the Labor Government had "dissipated" overseas assets, including about 2,000,000,000 (about $8,000,000,000) of United States and Canadian subsidies.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 23 (AP) -- Willie Pep, world featherweight champion, underwent a minor operation today forcing a postponement of his title bout with Eddie Compo. The fight was to have been held at Waterbury on Thursday.

Brooklyn police were searching for a mugging victim yesterday as two men accused of the attack were arraigned before Magistrate Abner C. Surpless in Felony Court on a grand larceny charge brought by a policeman.
Re Ira Freeman's "Pessimistic Note on a Pest," there is a cure for poison ivy, and it was made known by Johns Hopkins Hospital (or college) about 1932.

The race among pipeline companies for the lucrative natural gas business among eighty - six utilities in the New England area will receive a lively impetus at the end of this month when New England and Southwestern financial interests disclose details of a plan that has received the approval of state officials in the area, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- Senate investigators said today that the names of some members of Congress as well as military oficers and Government officials had been found in the secret diary of a Washington "5 per center."

LONDON, July 23 -- A year ago British motor-car manufacturers could sell in the United States, as soon as it was unpacked, every automobile they could ship. The British cars had only half the horsepower of the average United States car.

HARTFORD, Conn. LAST November, somewhat to the surprise of my party, the pollsters and myself. I became Governor of Connecticut. I won by the second slimmest margin in the modern history of Connecticut elections -- 2,225 votes.

Increasing opportunities for the acquisition of home furnishings and decorations in the medium-price bracket were reported yesterday by the Plaza Art Galleries, Inc., 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, in an end-of-the-season survey of the last year's auction trends.
GENEVA, July 19 -- Facts collected by the Secretariat of the United Nations show that very few member states comply with United Nations recommendations in the economic and social field.
LENOIR, N. C., July 23 (AP) -- Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson today took note of "foreign movements" in the world and urged the United States "to be awake and to keep our powder dry."

YOU cannot blame Capitol for releasing standard works that were recorded in Germany a good many years ago, since every company wishes its catalogue to be as comprehensive as possible. Through its deal for the Telefunken catalogue, Capitol feels that it can set up a catalogue of staple items speedily.

In "Gossip of the Rialto" you have reported that Joshua Logan, making an adaptation of Chekhov's play, "The Cherry Orchard," plans to call his play, "The Wistaria Trees," and to stick as close to the original plot as possible. You add that he wishes only to translate the play in terms of people and places the American public can more easily comprehend.

ONE of next season's novelties, if all goes well, will be the first American tour by a company of Maori dancers from various New Zealand tribes. Alexander Levitoff, who managed Pavlova's European tours in her last seasons, and who now makes his headquarters in Melbourne, Australia, has finally succeeded in organizing the project.

American Overseas Airlines resumed operations yesterday after a two-day strike of radio operators had forced the cancellation of all Europe-bound flights and had grounded some United States-bound planes. The first outbound flight since Thursday, a DC-4, took off from La Guardia Airport at 9:50 A. M. with twenty passengers for Berlin.

IN this atomic age, with the President of the United States advocating a Columbia Valley Authority, it is practically axiomatic to think of the Columbia River in terms of kilowatts and nuclear fission. Yet the most dramatic era in the history of the Northwest's great river may have been during a time when white men knew nothing of the unseen force of electricity.

Plans were made here last week by leaders of the liquor industry to prevent heavy price-cutting this fall. They are beginning to concede that the recent Supreme Court decision declaring mandatory fair trade unconstitutional will be upheld in the Court of Appeals, New York State's highest tribunal.

Before the steady, methodical stroking of Mrs. Elfi Carroll of the Seminole Club of Forest Hills, Mrs. Norma Taubele Barber, who through the past decade and a half has ranked with the top racquet wielders in the East, went down to defeat as the once postponed final of the women's Eastern clay court tennis singles championship was held at the New York Tennis Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California, raised the possibility today that President Truman was considering the transfer of atomic bomb information to Great Britain without obtaining Congressional authority.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The announcement by Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr. that he was calling the Republican National Committee together on Aug. 4 to tender his resignation served to clear the way for a change in leadership long demanded, but introduced a time element that may prove troublesome.
Leading shipping men from ports throughout the nation have accepted committee tasks in the sea transport mobilization survey of the National Security Resources Board, it was announced here yesterday.
PRAGUE, July 23 -- A call to resistance against Government encroachment on the religious domain was clandestinely distributed to Roman Catholic priests of the Prague archdiocese today.

Labor in general may have temporarily abandoned attempts to win repeal of the Taft-Hartley Law but maritime labor, which is hampered by the law's restriction against hiring halls, is making all-out efforts to obtain passage of legislation that would remove this "bar to peaceful employer-worker relations."

TOKYO, July 23 -- Borrowing Allied wartime propaganda techniques, Japan's Communists are attacking both the Japanese Government and Gen. Douglas MacArthur's occupation with "wall newspapers." Seventy persons have been arrested on charges of circulating untrue rumors and thereby violating occupation directives.

NEW DELHI, July 23 -- Economic distress and the accompanying growth of communism and political cleavages have put the Congress party Government on the spot as its first two years in power in free India near an end.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N. H. -- The White Mountains National Forest in New Hampshire has a unique combination of wilderness trails and well-equipped lodges for the use of hiking vacationers. The hiker may roam amid unspoiled, wild country all day and still pass each night in a fully equipped cabin where he may get prepared meals.
BOSTON, July 23 (AP) -- After spotting the Braves' Lefty Warren Spahn an early 9-4 lead, the Pirates today settled down to a grim battle and gained a 12-9 victory with a six-run rally in the ninth.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 23 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission today expanded its line of "hot atoms" to increase their use in scientific research -- including the fight on cancer.

UNTIL, Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette, went to America to win fame and glory in the colonies' struggle against the British, about the only important independent decision he had made was to be inoculated against smallpox.

ALBANY, July 23 -- Experiments aimed at an eventual decrease in the population of state mental hospitals through promotion of psychiatric treatment as part of general hospital service will get under way shortly at Roosevelt Hospital in New York City and Ellis Hospital in Schenectady, Governor Dewey announced today.

Four years ago next Tuesday the British Labor party swept Mr. Churchill out of office and Mr. Attlee into office. The date of Britain's next election remains uncertain, but the political atmosphere is growing hotter. On Friday the Conservative party published a booklet stating in fairly precise terms what it would do and undo if it could.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Congressional leaders rejected today a proposal that they share directly in picking a new Republican National Chairman. The proposal was made by Sinclair Weeks, Massachusetts National Committeeman, former Senator and former Republican national treasurer.

ST. Lo, France. ST. LO today, five years after its liberation by the American First Army, looks to the future, not the battered past. Its solid Norman inhabitants have brushed away many of its ruins, filled in others.
AN amateur photographer, just back from a vacation on Cape Cod, looked at her pictures of sand dunes and surf, and found them wanting. She was disappointed, and puzzled.

AS part of that state's effort to attract tourists, Mississippi is installing roadside parks along its principal paved highways. The State Highway Department already has completed twenty-four of the parks on routes most popular with motorists.

DAMASCUS, Syria, July 23 -- Syria's outspoken attitude of goodwill toward the United States, which is immediately encountered here by anyone seeking political information, was exemplified today when President Zayim decorated two Americans as well as a Frenchman associated with their work.

Seymour E. Harris' "What to Do With Eighteen Million Aged?" is important, first because of its highlights and second because of its omissions. It would be interesting to have Mr. Harris turn his gifted pen to an analysis of the number of geniuses along with ordinary mortals who attained their greatest productivity in the later years of their lives.

FOREST PARK, Pa., July 23 -- Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican-Liberal, of New York, called on President Truman today to appoint a Near East Development Commission to implement Point Four in the Near East by giving technical and financial aid for the area's economic development.

EVER since the Society in American Series was initiated -- and very successfully -- by Cleveland Amory's impudent yet accurate "The Proper Bostonians" the public (and presumably the publisher) has hoped for a sequel, on some other city, of equal wit and readability.
BRIELLE, N. J., July 23 -- A 158 1/2-pound mako shark leaped out of the sea this afternoon right into the lap of Michael Perkins of Bayonne, N. J., fishing for tuna off the charter boat Bingo III.

A sweet serenity now possesses the world around us, almost too sweet and too serene for those whose philosophy is based on constant struggle. For the struggle now is the measured reach toward growth and maturity. The green world is fully green. The early rush for a place in the sun is over.

For six innings at the Polo Grounds yesterday the Giant attack was under restraint. Leo Durocher's band couldn't do much with the offerings of Warren Hacker, a fast guy with a knuckler and a tantalizing individual with a sinker ball.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 23 (AP) -- Buffalo's West Side Rowing Club played the poor host today and stroked to an eight-point lead in the seventy-fifth renewal of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen's annual regatta.

MAY I ask the privilege of continuing the controversy with the McGraw-Hill Company about the Hoover Report (in the July 3 issue) -- in order, if possible, to help stir up interest in the point made by Mr. Benjamin?

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 23 -- Fifty-five thousand out of an estimated 200,000 Germans still in Czechoslovakia have applied since Jan. 1 to the joint United States, British and French military permits office here for permission to emigrate to Germany.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 23 -- A beginning has been made here on the separate university for Negroes in this state. Progress so far has been limited to a liberal arts college and a small school of journalism. Revised plans for buildings do not include a medical school but an appropriation for a school of pharmacy to be opened in September has been approved, officials announced today.

The first lady of America's hotel industry wields a magic wand when it comes to turning losing ventures into glowing profits. Mrs. Maria Kramer, who guides the destinies of the Lincoln Hotel in New York and the Roosevelt in Washington, D. C., has time and time again flabbergasted the men who rule over nation-wide hotel chains with her financial and business ability to transform "white elephants" into going concerns.
ROME, July 23 (AP) -- The Italian Government will participate financially in all oil companies, a communique from the Interministerial Committee for Reconstruction disclosed today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 23 -- Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, announced today the first post-war increase in tuition fees and three other charges at the university. At the same time he announced the state university would ask the legislature this year for the funds needed to reduce drastically or eliminate tuition fees.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 23 -- Sex education should be introduced in every elementary and high school in the United States, Dr. Theodore Brameld, Professor of Education Philosophy at New York University, said here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 23 -- Russian affairs at the United Nations are being handled these days by a new acting Chief of Mission, a man who has received much less public attention than other important Soviet delegates.

WEATHER conditions have considerable influence on the types of insects and diseases most prevalent in the garden. Powdery mildew and red spider spread rapidly during dry weather, while such diseases as rose black spot and other leaf blights thrive on rain.

THE greatest curse of Ireland has not been English invasions or English misgovernment; it has been the exaggeration of Irish virtues -- our stubbornness, conservatism, enormous arrogance, our power of resistance, our capacity for taking punishment, our laughter, endurance, fatalism, devotion to the past, all taken to the point where every human quality can become a vice instead of a virtue.

Vanishing humidity and cool breezes made the city fairly comfortable yesterday. At the same time a warm sun that kept afternoon temperatures in the middle eighties sent sizable crowds to metropolitan beaches and other resorts.
A new chapter in the history of the United States of America opened last week when the nation decided that in the atomic age security could not be found within the national borders.

PERSONALITIES are considered by many as obscuring factors in the cultivation of an art. "We are tired to death of these 'personalities,' these men who cause the public to think of the man instead of the art, the virtuoso instead of the interpretation," and so forth.

C. E. Hooper, who specializes in telling radio's greats where they stand on the airwaves, made some recent "Hooperatings" of New Brunswick's salmon and came up with a poser. "What's the record number of jumps of a hooked salmon?"

A total of 104 will start play tomorrow in the Fairfield and Westchester women's open golf championship for the Elizabeth Wheeler trophy at the Winged Foot Club in Mamaroneck. Competition will continue Tuesday and Wednesday.
The British Road Research Laboratory is experimenting with cream yellow, red, green and blue asphalt at a cost not very much greater than that of ordinary asphalt.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 23 -- It was learned here on reliable authority that the United States Government was not expected to restore Marshall Plan aid to Indonesia until the present turbulent state of affairs there was greatly improved.

It was very generous and courageous of H. I. Brock in his "In the Good Old Summertime" to conclude with these truthful words, "things were better, etc." Many will doubt him, but I recently convinced a group of youngsters of the same thing.

LAWYERS in mystery fiction offer varied attractions, from the slickness of Perry Mason to the earthiness of Arthur Crook, but Miss Frost's Marka de Lancey is the first crime-solving lawyer to feature gold-flecked eyes and off-russet hair.

The new Intra-European Payments Agreement represents the maximum available in view of the British dollar position, but falls far short of what had been originally hoped for by the American-Belgian group, according to the consensus reported in an analysis of the agreement and its background, completed last week by the National Foreign Trade Council.

MEXICO CITY -- Spring-like climate and mild rains that clear the air every afternoon here should be attractions enough for veterans of the United States' summer heat. But, if things to do and see also are "musts" for a vacationist, Mexico City has these in variety and quantity.

CELEBRATING would hardly be the word -- but, anyway, Frank Lloyd Wright came to our town recently, pretty much just to talk and take walks to see what he could see. Particularly, one suspects, to see any new evidence that would heighten his repugnance to New York.

In the case of the industrial phases of such development it has recognized that the technical as well as the financial aid needed must come from non-governmental sources.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 23 -- It was learned here on reliable authority that the United States Government was not expected to restore Marshall Plan aid to Indonesia until the present turbulent state of affairs there was greatly improved.

Anglo-American cooperation in developing the atom bomb had its genesis on Oct. 11, 1941, when President Roosevelt wrote a letter to Prime Minister Churchill. He suggested that "any extended efforts on this important matter might usefully be coordinated or even jointly conducted."

LARCHMONT, July 23 -- With fan added 275 competing craft today, the Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-first annual Race Week out on Long Island Sound wound up with 2,009 starts of sailing creations over the eight-days. The final regatta, following the squall yesterday which sort of snapped the whip over the fleet, was the best sailing one of the summer.

The Yearbook of American Churches, published recently under the auspices of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, computes the total number of church members in the United States at 77,000,000. This, it is pointed out, is a ratio of better than one in two of the population, compared with one in fifteen 150 years ago.

WHETHER the ups downs of fashion have any place in the home is open to question. But as far as the march of style goes, it must be admitted that the furniture industry is getting to be more like the fashion industry every day.

BOSTON, July 23 -- City-dwelling New Englanders, to whom the continuing drought chiefly is a matter of parched front lawns, learned this week that an expected half-cent drop in the price of milk on their doorsteps probably would not materialize because of what the dry spell had done to the farmers.

BOSTON, July 23 -- Downtown Boston stores have been doing a considerably better business than have the stores in most New England cities. Reports from such centers as Cambridge, Providence and Springfield show that sales have been in the neighborhood of 15 per cent or more below a year ago.

On April 12, 1948, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the State of New York for the First Department held that a certified public accountant, in giving advice on a tax problem, was unlawfully practicing law. (The New York County Lawyers Association, petitioner, vs. Bernard Bercu, respondent).

ONE of the many paradoxes confronting parents today is the repeated advice to remember that a child is not a small-sized adult but should be treated as a young, immature individual who can only slowly learn to be a grown-up.

SOME of the winners of Dodd. Mead's semi-annual Red Badge prize contest have written only indifferent sequels to their prize novels; others have never turned out another book. But the Red Badge contest has discovered a few such major mystery writers as Hugh Pentecost, David Keith, and Christianna Brand; and if his second novel is to be trusted, that list will be augmented by the name of last year's prize-winner.
LEEDS, England, July 23 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of South Africa, big money winner in United States golf tournaments, said tonight "I don't ever have to play golf in America again."
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The deadlock between labor and industry on wages and welfare benefits tightens as the mood of both sides appears to grow more adamant against "compromise."
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 23 -- Judge Charles Edward Wyzanski Jr. of Boston has been named to the board of trustees of Smith College, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan proposed today that the European arms program be put on a stop-gap basis pending formulation of common defense plans by signers of the North Atlantic treaty.

LISBON, Portugal, July 23 -- Portugal should accept and ratify the North Atlantic treaty with sincere enthusiasm, states a report of the Corporative Chamber published today. Under the regime of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar the Corporative Chamber acts in a technical advisory capacity toward the National Assembly, which has been specially summoned for Monday when it is expected the Government will ask it to ratify the pact.
THE loftiest Goethe celebration ever -- the three-week bicentennial fracas held this month at Aspen, Col. (alt., 7,900 feet) -- has come and gone, but reports of proceedings are still drifting in.
Is there a planet between Mercury and the sun?

RETAIL sales last week had no distinguishing characteristics. The public bought merchandise at the same rate as in recent weeks, making purchases carefully and deliberately. While the weather was humid and hot, little could be said for or against its effect on business here.

A proposed 5-cent fare increase for interstate passenger traffic on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad would result in a 20 per cent decrease in passengers and would materially affect bus service feeding the road in Jersey City, a traffic expert testified yesterday.

A ninth-inning rally materialized at Ebbets Field yesterday but it brought only anguish to the Dodgers and the 28,396 cash customers who had turned out hoping to see the Brooks regain the ground they had lost the night before.

The action of the House of Representatives last week in extending price supports for the principal agricultural products for a year, if concurred in by the Senate, probably means the maintenance of present food prices. In that it will stimulate the production of crops which are eligible for support, the cost to the United States Treasury of the farm aid plan next year may be the largest yet.

EARLY next month Northwest Airlines will begin the first domestic Stratocruiser service in the United States, linking New York and the Pacific Northwest with eight-hour flights, and New York and Minneapolis-St. Paul with flights lasting little more than three hours.

EARLY next month Northwest Airlines will begin the first domestic Stratocruiser service in the United States, linking New York and the Pacific Northwest with eight-hour flights, and New York and Minneapolis-St. Paul with flights lasting little more than three hours.
IT is agreed that a "reverse bid" -- that is, a rebid in a relatively high-ranking suit -- shows a strong hand. There is less agreement on whether, or when, such a bid is a forcing bid.

The University of California at Los Angeles announced last week that Drs. Philip M. West and Jessamine Hilliard of its medical school had discovered a way of finding out if a cancer is growing or not and thus informing a physician whether or not his treatment is doing any good. It took eighteen months to develop the growth test.

OMINOUS news of a spreading grasshopper plague is heard in many states of the West. One nesting area near Sheridan. Wyo., was reported in June with a grasshopper population of 1,500 per square yard -- and a population of 30 to 200 is deemed critical.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 23 -- An investment of dollars in a program of "subversion" to win Iron Curtain countries away from the Soviet Union was suggested here today as an alternative to the proposed program of $1,450,000,000 in military aid to implement the Atlantic pact.

I object to the criticism by American fashion authorities of Soviet fashions. In rejecting Soviet control of press and politics, we must not become so petty as to sneer also at irrelevant matters. I thought the Soviet fashions quite attractive.

PITTSBURGH, July 23 -- An economic study showing the net combined cost of the United Steelworkers' pension and social security demands to the United States Steel Corporation would be 10.99 cents per man-hour was released here tonight.

PITTSBURGH, July 23 -- An economic study showing the net combined cost of the United Steelworkers' pension and social security demands to the United States Steel Corporation would be 10.99 cents per man-hour was released here tonight.

Beginning immediately, Continental Copper and Steel Industries, Inc., producers of many industrial equipment items, will expand its work force to reach a post-war high of 3,000 employes by Dec. 1. The company is also introducing group insurance plans and some other "fringe" benefits, Ernest G. Jarvis, president, disclosed in an interview last week.

BUENOS AIRES, July 24 -- On the eve of a major peronista rally, which the President will open tomorrow evening, the Opposition bloc in the Chamber of Deputies has been making the most of two issues that, it is felt, the Government no longer can afford to ignore.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, today joined a Congressional drive to block any sharing of atomic bomb secrets with Britain or other Atlantic pact allies.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP) -- A House Interstate Commerce subcommittee is expected to approve tomorrow a compromise that may clear the way for action at this session on the Administration's $300,000,000 Federal Aid-to-Education Bill.
Andrew S. Halley has been appointed treasurer of the Parafine Companies, Inc. He was formerly a manager of Price, Waterhouse Co., in San Francisco.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Mike Guerra hit a two-run homer off Chick Pieretti in the ninth inning to give Philadelphia a 6-4 second-game decision over the White Sox today after the Athletics won the opener, 7 -- 2, before 25,087 fans. The twin triumph gave the Mackmen the series, two games to one, for their fourth and fifth victories in the past seventeen games.

ROME, July 24 -- The Pope today urged Catholic women, especially mothers, to combat the inroads that Communism is making in family life. He asked mothers to give their children moral education in accordance with Christian principles.
For the seventh successive month the city's public assistance case load increased in June, Welfare Commissioner Raymond M. Hilliard reported yesterday.

Faith and hope can help overcome the sense of futility and helplessness that the individual feels when facing the colossal economic, political and social forces in the world today, the Rev. Dr. Clayton E. Williams, pastor of the American Church in Paris, said yesterday at the morning services of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

BETHPAGE, L. I., July 24 -- Two F9F-3 Panther jet planes are scheduled to take off from the landing strips at the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation here tomorrow and streak across the nation in five and a half hours flying time.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 24 (UP) -- Only five surviving Union Civil War veterans plan to attend the eighty-third and last encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic here next month, it was disclosed tonight.

The story of the flight of a 3-year-old boy and his father to Europe from Brooklyn will be told today to a Kings County grand jury. Before his disappearance the boy was in custody of his mother because his parents had been separated.

The report of the Corn Products Refining Company and its subsidiary sales companies, issued for publication today showed a net income for the six months ended with June of $5,671,140 after charges, including $3,188,000 provision for Federal income tax.

NEWARK, N. J., July 24 (AP) -- Vern Taylor hurled the Baltimore Orioles to a three-hit 5-0 shut-out over the Newark Bears in the second game of a double-header at Ruppert Stadium today. The Bears captured the opener, 2 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Theodore Yntema, a vice president of the Ford Motor Company, said today it was "practically impossible to have in the next year or two a (business) collapse like that of 1930-32."
Subways sprouted another bumper crop of suntanned straphangers last night to complete a week-end of perfect concessionnaire weather.
