HAMILTON, N. Y., July 24 -- The Rev. Edward A. Conway, associate editor of the magazine America, said today that formulation of United States military strategic policy on the basis of the atomic bomb had led the country to the brink of "moral suicide."

Municipal issues scheduled for sale this week aggregate $67,133,900, compared with $44,676,534 last week, according to a compilation by the Bond Buyer, The largest issue consists of $50,300,000 bonds by the New York City Housing Authority for five housing projects on which bids will be received tomorrow.

The Alfano Realty Corporation, Murray Karnal, president, bought the five-story loft building on a lot 43 by 72 feet at 351-53 West Broadway from the Prestmoor Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Jacob Slade, broker. Occupied in its entirety by the Upton Sales Corporation, the building was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $73,000.

BUENOS AIRES, July 24 -- Differences between the World Council of Churches and the International Council of Churches of Christ, which held separate meetings in Amsterdam last year, are now in evidence here on a smaller scale. What is unusual about this situation is that it has arisen in an overwhelmingly Roman Catholic setting.

Members of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., were urged over the weekend to speed up delivery of wage information requested by the State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance under its newly adopted system for determining eligibility and amount of benefits due.
W. Averell Harriman, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration in Europe, returned to the United States yesterday for a series of conferences in Washton.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 24 -- Hung up helplessly for hours in a glassy calm, the fleet in the Stamford Yacht Club's championship regatta today managed to finish when a light southwest by south breeze that had fallen flat picked itself up again.

BOSTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Pirates came from behind twice today to sweep a double-header from the Braves, 4 -- 3 and 7 -- 6. The Pirates' Ralph Kiner belted his twenty-seventh homer in the first inning of the nightcap after Johnny Hopp tripled and scored on a wild throw.

As a result of a capital-adjustment program, the United States International Securities Corporation can again qualify as a "regulated investment company," C. Douglas Dillon, president, announced in the company's semiannual report yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- Orson Welles, who is filming in Mogador, Morocco, his own adaptation of "Othello," is preparing a photoplay based on Homer's "Iliad" and "Odyssey" as his next project, it has been disclosed here this week-end by Richard Wilson, Welles' partner in Mercury Productions.

Interest in the foreign exchange market last week was shared by the Canadian free dollar and British pound sterling as this revolved around a ruling by the Foreign Exchange Control Board of Canada on July 18 which licensed their nationals to participation in the sterling forward market here on imports of Empire origin.

PARIS, July 24 -- The pound sterling underwent a further decline on the black market last week to the lowest figure that has yet been quoted. It was traded at 920 francs, although the official rate is 1,096 francs. On the same day the dollar was quoted on the black market at 345 francs and the Swiss franc at 86.50.

FIFTY-EIGHT days after D-Day in Normandy First Lieut. Paul Roth, a 25-year-old infantry platoon leader, had had nearly as much as he could take. Roth was a good officer, an effective leader and a brave man. But continuous front-line combat without relief, continuous responsibility for the lives of others under the most frightful conditions of modern war, had frayed his nerves and exhausted his body.

Eight hours a day -- with the exception of Sunday, his day off -- bespectacled Eugene Ruffalo pushes change through the cashier's window on the uptown side of the Washington Square station of the IND subway system.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 24 -- The theory in this part of the world last spring was that if any country in Scandinavia joined the North Atlantic pact the Russians would be very angry indeed, Finland would be in danger, Sweden would be threatened and the entire Baltic would become what the Swedes called "an area of tension."

The long-range shipping program contained in a bill introduced in the House last month by Representative Schuyler O. Bland, is commended by the National Federation of American Shipping in a tweny-two-page pamphlet. Mr. Bland is chairman of the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board today upheld the discharge of an employe under a union shop contract even though the employe had offered his union dues and initiation fee.

Tina Leser's recent round-the-world trip, planned as a honeymoon-vacation, turned out to be the basic inspiration for her entire fall collection of sportswear and at-home costumes designed for Edwin H. Foreman, Inc.

PARIS, July 24 (Reuters) -- Fuasto Coppi of Italy today won the Tour de France, grueling 25-day bicycle race over a course of more than 3,000 miles, which is considered to be France's greatest sporting event.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 (UP) -- The mother of the famous flier Amelia Earhart, missing since a round-the-world flight in 1937, said last night her daughter "died in Japan" on a United States Government mission, and not in the Pacific Ocean.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 24 -- Negro educators in Texas are expressing concern over what they term a denial of trade education to Negro youths in the public schools of the state. Some of these educators say that modern industrial high schools have been constructed for white youths out of public funds, and that a system of discrimination in training will soon eliminate Negro youths from the skilled crafts.
Five films were scheduled as of yesterday to open at Broadway houses during the week. The line-up follows:

A charge was made here yesterday by a group of clergymen that this country's heritage of religious freedom had been "thrown into doubt" by the conviction of Larry Gara, Bluffton (Ohio) College teacher now serving eighteen months in prison on charges of counseling a young man hot to register for the draft.

Homemakers who are used to assembling toys for junior, gadgets for the kitchen and similar small items may now use their skill in putting together furniture that has been received from Sweden in "knocked down" form. The assembling -- which is to be done with screwdriver and according to complete directions accompanying every piece -- is planned not as a pastime but as a money-saving feature, since "KD" furniture is easier and cheaper to ship.

ST. LOUIS, July 24 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox trounced St. Louis, 8 -- 4, in the second game of a double-header today after the Browns rallied for a 9-8 verdict in the opener. Dom DiMaggio extended the number of consecutive games in which he has hit safely to 20 by punching out two hits in each contest.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., July 24 -- Posting their second consecutive 63, Dr. Skip Hughes of the Blairmont Country Club, Holidaysburg, Pa., and George Reed today won the Forest Hill Field Club's member-guest golf tournament with a total of 126 for the thirty-six-hole route.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 24 -- Investments in Israel during the first half of 1949 in housing, communications, transport, rural development and industry totaled $60,000,000, David Horowitz, Director General of the Finance Ministry, disclosed today. He said this implied that economic expansion had kept pace with the growth of population.

SHANGHAI, July 24 -- The fall of Changsha, capital of Hunan Province and key city on the railroad to the provisional Kuomintang capital of Canton, appeared imminent today, with Communist columns converging on the city along five routes.
The present hysteria over the alleged granting of atomic energy fellowships to persons whose loyalty is suspected stems in large part from public ignorance.

Educational institutions and health organizations were the principal beneficiaries of large-scale philanthropies in the year ended June 30, a survey released yesterday by the John Price Jones Company, Inc., showed.
ALBANY, N. Y., July 24 (AP) -- The Pittsfield, Mass., polo team registered its fifth straight Tri-State League victory today by defeating Albany, 8 -- 7.

LONDON, July 23 -- Although Great Britain is still in the midst of trouble over railways, docks and dollars, with still more blowing up over the agricultural crisis, the temperature of the stock markets dropped somewhat last week. So, also, have prices, although the fall has been fairly gentle and has caused no bruises worth mentioning.

The heat wave last week flooded the wholesale apparel market here with orders for summer apparel, moving supplies of summer shirts, dresses and accessories almost to a vanishing point, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Wheat showed considerable strength on the Board of Trade last week, especially since there is more than an ample supply of the actual grain to cover domestic needs and to provide for large exports and still leave a heavy surplus at the end of the season.

LONDON, July 24 -- Some British labor observers consider, they indicated today, that the London dock strike, which is scheduled to end tomorrow with the return of more than 15,000 men to their jobs, was a victory for the Communists, who are alleged by the Government to have engineered and managed the strike.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- A broader export demand, including an inquiry for 11,000,000 pounds for shipment to Australia, combined with reports that a Government loan might be made on cottonseed and strength in cotton oil, sent lard futures higher on the Board of Trade last week.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds pushed over a run in the ninth inning of the second game to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 4 to 3, and sweep both ends of a double-header today after romping off with the first game, 10 -- 1.

To prove its assertion that the Federal Government will derive little difference in income whether the excise tax is repealed or retained, the American Fur Merchants Association has submitted an analysis of the financial operating structure of the entire fur industry, from farmer-trapper to retailer.

OSSINING, N. Y., July 24 -- Sixteen Roman Catholic priests and two brothers departed late today for lifetime mission posts in Africa, Japan, Hawaii and South and Central America after the thirty-second annual departure ceremony at Maryknoll Seminary here. Four other Maryknoll priests will go from the West Coast.
Representatives of five experimental-theatre groups met here yesterday to form the Off-Broadway Theatre League, through which they plan mutual assistance.

MANILA, Monday, July 25 (AP) -- A Government air and ground attack on a band of Hukbalahap peasant guerrillas wiped out more than 100 in the Carabello Mountain district of Central Luzon, official sources said today.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today urged Carbon Black Export, Inc., of 55 Fifth Avenue, New York City, to change certain practices which allegedly violate the anti-trust laws.

Frankie Frisch got a lot of presents from friends and admirers yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Leo Durocher got the gate from Umpire Lee Ballanfant. Along with these contrasting incidents the Giants got a sudden attack of hitting paralysis, or something, in the face of Chicago pitching, and the Cubs got a couple of ball games before a gathering of 22,419.

One more important forward step has been taken toward a settlement of some of the political and economic problems of Indonesia. Representatives of the Indonesian Republic and of the Indonesian Federalists have reached a working agreement upon the proposed political structure of a United States of Indonesia.

PITTSBURGH, July 24 -- Last week the steel industry operated at 78.5 per cent of its ingot capacity, up 5.5 points from the revised rate of 6.3 per cent in the week before. The loss in the previous week was due to precautions taken in case a strike developed.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 24 -- Plans for harnessing water resources on a vast scale to transform much of the parched wastes of Israel's Negeb desert into a livable, crop-bearing region are outlined in detail in a report submitted here for study during the first United Nations Scientific Conference on the Conservation and Utilization of Resources.

The excursion boat Colonel Frank H. Adams, bound from Coney Island to Manhattan with seventy passengers, developed engine trouble yesterday as she entered the Narrows and was forced to tie up at Fort Lafayette, island off Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.

COLDWATER, Mich., July 24--Two taxicab companies, one here and the other at Angola, Ind., twenty miles to the south, have found a way to help the Lord and help themselves. They take people to church on Sunday free of charge.

If the present generation is to be "empowered" by religion, its starting-point must be "more than a glow of satisfaction over the conduct of a service," the Right Rev. John T. Dallas, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Details of a real estate transaction last year in which the Long Island Rail Road sold 14.74 acres near the heart of Long Beach to a private individual for $12,000 when the assessed value of the land was $203,760 were made known yesterday by the Nassau County Transit Commission.

I must agree with Dr. Max Mannheimer that it was complete idiocy to lower the driving age to 16 when all statistics indicate that the 18-24 group is a menace to the highway. I have not been able to figure out why the Automobile Association of America sponsored this bill.

Sigmund Romberg made his fifth annual appearance as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra Saturday night at the Lewisohn Stadium before an enthusiastic audience of 14,000. Kirsten Kenyon, soprano, and Gene Marvey, tenor, were the soloists.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Federal Trade Commission charged today that General Foods Corporation was in violation of Federal law for discriminating between purchasers in the price of Certo land Sure-Jell, two pectin products used in jelling fruit and fruit juices. The complaint stated the practice had led to reducing "maerially" the company's competition in this field.

A Negro fraternity, Omega Psi Phi, announced yesterday that an interracial chapter would be started this fall at Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N. J. The plan followed a decision by the national body to fight racial discrimination within Negro college organizations.
Back in May when vacation schedules were drawn, the selection of a place to spend two hard-earned weeks was casual and light-hearted. Why rush? Let's look around a bit and find what we really want.

Mental illness, like many other diseases, is often more easily prevented than cured. As with other diseases, early diagnosis is important. Frequently the emotional disturbance from which a patient is suffering is accompanied by some kind of physical ailment, and a double problem is presented.

SHORT BEACH, L. I., July 24 - Just like any other 6-year-old youngster, Peter Klappert couldn't wait yesterday when his uncle, Edward Klappert of 2 Sportsman's Avenue, Freeport, slowed down his cruiser to anchor in the bay here for a day's outing.

SHANGHAI, July 24 -- The Communist official New China News Agency circulated last night an article in both the English and Chinese language services attacking Assistant Secretary of State George V. Allen for a statement attributed to him on the closing of the United States Information Service in the Communist area of China.

Approved by the United States Maritime Commission of the transfer of two freighters of the American-Hawaiian Line to foreign interests has been protested by the Maritime Commission of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, according to Hoyt S. Haddock, executive secretary of the labor group.

HONOLULU, July 24 -- Gov. Ingram M. Stainback said today that he probably would recommend that the Territorial Legislature take over the strike-bound Hawaii docks when it meets in special session here on Tuesday.

The taxpayer building occupying a plot 85 by 140 by 90 feet at 75-85 South Ocean Avenue, in Patchogue, L. I., has been purchased By Nathan Wilson, the operator, from the Chippewa Realty Corporation. Henry Baker was the broker.

A curly-haired 5-year-old child, bedridden nearly two years with infantile paralysis, arrived here yesterday from Southampton, England, with her parents. They hope that medical treatment in this country will enable her to romp and play again.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Argentina's El Trebol Polo Club won the Inter-American polo series today by defeating the U. S. All-Star team, 9 -- 5, for its second straight victory.

Under the scope of the Papal decree excommunicating Communists, Catholics are forbidden to read Communist publications "for information, professional reasons or curiosity," the Rev. Edwin B. Broderick of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared at solemn mass yesterday.

VALDOSTA, Ga., July 24 (AP) -- The 1949 tobacco auction season opens Tuesday and this year's crop of flue-cured cigarette-type leaf is a bumper one. The market -- both domestic and foreign -- looks strong. Packed warehouses are ready for the first sales in nineteen towns in South Georgia and two in Florida.
Quality and quantity of the California Bartlett pear crop have never been better, we have just learned from the trade.

LONDON, July 24 -- Lewis W. Douglas, United States Ambassador to Britain, will undergo a major eye operation for removal of a cataract at Middlesex Hospital here tomorrow, the United States Embassy announced today. He entered the hospital tonight.

Uncorking a sizzling second-half attack that netted four goals, the nimble-footed Milano soccer team of Italy notched its fifth victory since arriving in this country by halting the United States All-Stars, 5 to 1, before 9,000 fans at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

LONDON, July 24 -- With the publication of the Conservative party's program and Winston Churchill's declaration of policy yesterday the line has been drawn between Britain's two major political parties for the next general election. But to many political observers, including some dismayed Conservatives, the line seems very thin indeed.
BUFFALO, N. Y., July 24 (AP) -- The senior and 145-pound eight oared crews of Buffalo's West Side Rowing Club made a romp today of the seventy-fifth renewal of the National Rowing Regatta.

BOSTON, July 24 -- The $11,500,000 campaign for the Children's Medical Center, the outgrowth of a dream of a young Union Army surgeon who conducted street-corner campaigns for funds here eighty years ago, has passed the half-way mark with receipt of contributions amounting to $6,500,000, Frederick Ayer Jr., campaign chairman, said today.

DETROIT, July 24 -- Fetched up from the shadows by a ninth-inning homer by Johnny Lindell that tied the score and exploding four runs in the eleventh, the Yankees closed their Western trip today on a resounding note as they toppled Red Rolfe's Tigers, 6 to 3, before 39,795 in Briggs Stadium.

Too terrible for 34,042 fans to endure, the third straight setback of the Dodgers by the Cardinals, a 14-1 convincer at Ebbets Field yesterday, caused a rearrangement atop the National League standings. For the first time in exactly a month first place does not belong to the Brooks and there are quite a few who insist that the panic is really on.

BERLIN, July 24 -- An administrative shuffle that will move the bulk of United States Military Government officials out of Berlin by Aug. 10 will be announced this week, according to reliable sources in the Military Government.

A complaint that a man friend of a divorced mother inflicted "cruel and inhuman" punishment upon her three children, who have since been taken from her custody, has been dismissed, it was announced yesterday by Dudley F. Sicher, Domestic Relations Court justice.

The final worship service in the auditorium of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, before the edifice is torn down to make way for a twenty-one story store and office building, was conducted yesterday morning. The congregation numbered 400.

Rear Admiral Ellis M. Zacharias, retired, author of "Secret Missions," has a new book on Putnam's list for November publication. "Behind Closed Doors: The Secret History of the Cold War" is based on documents, many previously unpublished, assembled by analysts under the Admiral's direction.

The Council on Foreign Relations has awarded its first resident fellowships for American foreign correspondents to Henry R. Lieberman, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in China, and Robert Clurman, now assigned to The United Press cable desk and former UP Nanking bureau manager, it was announced yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 24 -- Armed partisan resistance to Rumania's Communist Government has become so widespread geographically, although small in terms of unit size, that the Bucharest regime has ordered special shock detachments of militia to attempt to clean it up, current reports say.
I have a suggestion to offer with regard to the dollar shortage resulting from the apparent deficiency of British exports.

Reorganization of Local 968 of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, which revolted against union headquarters control last spring, has been started by the union's New York District Council, Joseph P. Ryan, ILA president, reported yesterday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 24 -- Dr. Ezequiel Padilla, 57 years old, who came into voluntary exile here three years ago after his Partido Democratico candidacy for the Presidency of Mexico failed, is leaving by train tonight for a five-week vacation on his ranch outside Mexico City.

After moving into new high ground for the season in the earlier part of last week, cotton prices in the domestic market eased and finished the period showing irregular price changes. At the close on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 11 points to up 37 points from the close of the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Senate will buckle down tomorrow to the job of passing the foreign aid bill, which includes funds for the European Recovery Program's second year. Administration leaders were girding to defeat restrictive amendments to the $5,723,724,000 measure and to increase the amount.

City College and the New York School of Social Work of Columbia University will share the books from the library of the Russell Sage Foundation, one of the most complete collections in the field of social work, it was announced yesterday.

BERLIN, July 24 -- The average Berlin shopper, whether out for food, clothing or anything else, is faced with what may well be the most incredible retail confusion in Europe. Not only are there two currencies, West and East marks, but prices for identical items may and do vary by as much as 100 per cent in two shops on the same city block.

CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP)--Behind the double home-run hitting of Pitcher Bob Lemon and First Baseman Mickey Vernon, the Cleveland Indians today swept a double-header from the Washington Senators, 7 to 5 and 5 to 2, before 51,353 fans.

Education must increase its efforts to perpetuate the American way of life and to help maintain world peace, according to a "charter of public education" made public yesterday by Dr. Paul R. Mort, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College.
PARIS, July 24 (AP) -- Italy defeated France today in the doubles and took a 2-to-1 lead in the European zone Davis Cup tennis finals.

One serious obstacle to full modernization in the textile industry is pre-war government regulations which prevent adequate allowances for the depreciation of machinery, it was declared over the week-end in Boston by the Textile Information Service.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 -- Richard Gonzales' first effort of the season on American turf was crowned with success today as the 21-year-old National champion from Los Angeles won the Pennsylvania State title with one of his most convincing performances.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 24 -- While Czechoslovak school children are vacationing, their teachers this summer are attending political courses.

OMAHA, Neb., July 24 -- Albert Sandrin of Chicago, winner of the national open championship tournament, today received the brilliancy prize from Elbert A. Wagner Jr. of Chicago, retiring president, as the annual meeting of the United States Chess Federation came to an end.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 24 -- The Soviet Union was accused today of uprooting thousands of Russian Jews from the Ukraine and White Russia in "brutal and sudden deportations" to clear its border zones for possible war.

In your July 20 issue you carried an extremely interesting and provocative editorial entitled "Communist Shutout." It purported to be an analysis of Jackie Robinson's statement before the Un-American Activities Committee concerning the much-distorted Paris Peace Call Paul Robeson made to the Negro people.

Following up the ratification of the North Atlantic Treaty, President Truman will submit to Congress today a military assistance program totaling $1,450,000,000 for the coming year to increase the effective strength of the free nations of the world to resist aggression and thereby help to safeguard both peace and our own security.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 24 (AP) -- Communist Premier Antonin Zapotocky bluntly defied the Vatican today and pledged the allegiance of Czechoslovakia to Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 24 -- Two events last week, occurring almost at the same moment, have focussed attention in Switzerland on steps that would have to be taken to ressuscitate the economic life of Germany quickly enough to give Europe a chance to become self supporting before the Marshall Plan aid ends in 1952.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $48,488,230,874. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
MALONE, N. Y., July 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Liza Murray McGee, 93 years old and a bride of a year, took her first airplane trip today and exclaimed afterward that "it was just like a ride into heaven."

A year ago the Supreme Court handed down a finding which has come to be known as the "overtime-on-overtime" decision. The case grew out of claims brought by a number of New York dock workers, and the effect of the ruling was to give rise to a large number

The African Enterprise, latest addition to the Farrell Lines fleet, which will be the first post-war passenger liner to operate between the United States and South Africa, will arrive here early this morning after a trial run from yards of the Gulf Shipbuilding Corporation at Mobile, Ala., where she underwent complete reconversion during the last six months.

The controversy between Cardinal Spellman on the one hand and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman on the other over Mrs. Roosevelt's stand against Federal aid for parochial schools was discussed yesterday in several pulpits.
In your editorial of July 14 entitled "Mr. O'Dwyer Changes His Mind," you said:

PASADENA, Calif., July 24 -- A national drift toward collectivism, penetrating even into the attitude of management in dealing with employes, was cited with concern last week by participants in a conference on profitable personnel policies marking the tenth anniversary of the Industrial Relations Section of the California Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Mrs. Magda Rurac of Los Angeles won the thirty-seond annual women's Middle Atlantic tennis tourney today with a 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3 victory over defending champion Mrs. Ann Gray of Washington.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., July 24 -- Industry must win the support of its workers by adopting the Communist technique of "personal conversion on a one-by-one basis," Forrest H. Kirkpatrick, dean of Bethany College at Bethany, W. Va., declared yesterday.

DAMASCUS, Syria, July 24--The capacity of the Middle East to resist pressure from the north may be increased by Syrian and Turkish plans to develop the great curve along the Mediterranean coast, thus joining Asia Minor to the Levant coast as a gateway to the Middle East, according to sources here.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- In the face of rising sentiment for "interim" military aid to North Atlantic Pact partners at this time, rather than the full program, the White House stated today that the scheduled $1,450,000,000 plan would be submitted to Congress "as written."

Hardness of water is directly related to sales of all types of soaps in the United States, according to a new study called Sales of Package Soaps and Synthetics, Laundry Bars and Toilet Soaps, which was prepared by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association for presentation to advertisers and agencies in the soap field.
The Rev. George R. Hewlett, rector emeritus of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Newton, N. J., attacked yesterday the concept of "a watered-down religion" without creed or faith.

If your offspring are enthralled by the discordant wail of the latest bebop record, don't give up hope for their musical taste and run for a soundproof room. Their addiction to this strange new jazz, if encouraged, should develop naturally into appreciation for more recognizable and bearable forms.
FRANKFORT, Germany, July 24 -- Thomas Mann, accompanied by his wife, returned to his native Germany today as much a figure of public discussion as when he left in 1933 in protest against the Nazis.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the period of July 16 to 22 are given in the appended tabulation:

The Rev. Dr. Sidney M. Berry of London, secretary of the newly formed International Congregational Council, asserted in a sermon here yesterday the validity of "the mystical side of religion," which, he said, had been clouded over by psychological terminology.

One of the troubles involved in putting out a newspaper is that it has to be done with words. In fact, there are enough words in a copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES each day to make two good-sized novels. On a Sunday the measurement is better done with a weighing scale.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Poor highway systems over the country are the greatest obstacle to economical, low-cost automobile transportation, an analyst of the Brookings Institution reported today.

TOKYO, Monday, July 25--Sixteen Americans were injured, one child was killed and millions of dollars in property damage was done by a 150-mile-an-hour typhoon that lashed the island of Okinawa for eight hours Saturday.

Two Navy sounding rockets of a type known as the Aerobee have been fired from the deck of a Naval vessel at sea to an altitude of more than sixty-five miles and have recorded valuable data regarding cosmic rays, the Navy announced here yesterday.

All but "a very few" of the 175 manufacturers surveyed recently by the National Industrial Conference Board report an adequate supply of working capital for 1949 and into 1950, it was announced over the week-end. Most executives expressed satisfaction with their companies' present capital structure.

LONDON, July 24 -- A committee of sixteen representing non-Communist trade unions in all parts of the world will meet here tomorrow to begin drafting a constitution and program for a new trade union international to rival the World Federation of Trade Unions. The organizations to be represented here have withdrawn from the WFTU because they believe it to be subservient to Communism.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 24 (AP) -- In the most spectacular scoring splurge the 12-year-old tournament has ever seen, Melvin (Chick) Harbert of Detroit and Bob Hamilton of Landover, Md., today won the Inverness four-ball golf tournament and $4,450 in prize money.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has given notice to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, that it plans to terminate its contract with the union covering the network's engineers and technicians.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Strong opposition to President Truman's plan to give Cabinet status to a new Department of Welfare, headed by a layman and succeeding the present Federal Security Agency, was voiced today by Dr. Louis H. Bauer, of Hempstead, N. Y., chairman of the board of trustees of the American Medical Association.

NARVIK, Norway, July 23 -- This militarily important terminus of the 300-mile Swedish iron ore railway from Luleaa, on the Bothnian Gulf, is keeping a watchful eye on Communists, both those in its own midst and their comrades from Sweden and Finland.

LONDON, July 25 -- Renewed weakness of British Government funds on fears of fresh labor troubles on the railways was a principle feature of the stock market here today. Jobbers had to deal with a fair amount of selling and all round declines up to five-eighths of a point had been recorded at the close.

Adherents of the "refrigerator" school of thought on what to eat when the weather is sultry advocate chilled foods. Others say that soups, beverages and so on that are hot from the stove have a more cooling effect. The Sherry-Netherland reaches a neat compromise on these opposing theories in one of the features of its summer menu, cold curried chicken.

SEOUL, Korea, July 25 -- trial of ten Koreans, charged with the murder on March 17 of Mrs. Horace H. Underwood, wife of an American educator and missionary here, was disrupted at the opening session today when the accused refused to reply to questions put to them by the presiding judge unless all the defendants were present in the court room.

The racing program at Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday did not contain a feature event as such, but that omission failed to deter 18,147 fans from turning out for the activity. And the activity was sprightly enough, with the performances of the thoroughbreds and their riders proving satisfactory enought to the majority of the onlookers.

A major-sized rumpus in speedboat circles appeared yesterday to threaten a serious rift in the United States defense of the famous Harmsworth trophy, scheduled only three days hence, on Friday and Saturday, at Detroit.

" Four things," said Socrates, "belong to a judge: to hear courteously, to answer wisely, to consider soberly, and to decide impartially." In the thirty-five years he has graced the Federal bench, Augustus Noble Hand has more than met this ideal. No appointment to a United States District Court has ever been happier than Judge Hand's appointment by President Wilson; none to the Circuit Court of Appeals more fitting than his promotion by President Coolidge.

The Museum of Modern Art has announced the acquisition for its permanent collection of one of the most celebrated of Picasso's paintings, the larger of two versions of "Three Musicians," painted in 1921. It has been obtained through the Mrs. Simon Guggenheim Fund, which previously had made possible the purchase of Picasso's "Dog and Cock" of the same year and his "Girl Before Mirror" of 1932.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was irregular yesterday and final prices were 5 points higher to 20 points lower.

Immediately after signing the instrument ratifying the North Atlantic Treaty President Truman submitted to Congress yesterday the long-heralded "Foreign Military Assistance Act of 1949." The purpose of this measure is to give force to the Pact by helping the free world arm itself for individual and collective self-defense against further Soviet aggression.

A LITTLE more than a decade ago Ladislav Hecht, then the best tennis player in Czechoslovakia, if not on all the Continent, became an exile and took up his home in the United States. It was his good fortune that he and his bride came to America on their honeymoon before Hitler announced that the Sudetenland was his last demand upon Europe.

BUENOS AIRES, July 25 -- President Juan Peron called tonight for a purge and reorganization of the party that bears his name. He addressed an unprecedented meeting of 6,000 delegates and told them that present-day opposition stemmed from the old Union Democratica, which, he said, had been "formed, directed and paid for" by former Ambassador Spruille Braden.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Federal Judge Elwyn R. Shaw ruled here today that the Housing and Rent Act of 1949, the rent control law, was unconstitutional. The ruling will be appealed, however, and pending a decision by the Supreme Court rent controls will continue in effect.

The Armco Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries earned $7,703,772 in the three months ended with June after all deductions, including Federal income taxes, Charles R. Hook, chairman, reported yesterday.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 25 -- Thomas Mann, back in Germany after a self-imposed exile of sixteen years, tonight firmly reminded "impatient" Germans that nazism was worse than the "foreign rule" about which they now complained.

MOSCOW, July 25 -- President Truman, in the opinion of Pravda, has embarked upon the "doubtful and slippery" road of attempting to mask the failure of the Marshall Plan and the American economic crisis by charging the Soviet Union and the "People's Democracies" with opposing the cause of peace and refusing to engage in international collaboration.
DETROIT, July 25 -- It was a long time coming, but the world of small animals got a break today -- human-tested relief from summer itch, eczema, hives and numerous other allergies and complaints.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 25 -- Reliable reports have now been received from the Soviet Republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia indicating that not only has the process of "socialization" there been accelerated with a dramatic increase in forced collectivization of agriculture but elements considered unreliable by Moscow have been deported Eastward.

The appointment of Frank J. Keeler as chairman of the advisory committee of the Red Cross Blood Program of the Greater New York Chapters was announced yesterday. Mr. Keeler, who is an assistant vice president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, succeeds Gordon Lamont, advisory chairman since 1947, during whose term of office the program was begun.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- One Government employe who paid a total of $7.43 into the Civil Service Retirement Fund now is eligible to receive retirement benefits of $17,500 a year, a House Civil Service Committee report disclosed today.

The Chinese Communists have closed down the last office of the United States Information Service in the areas under their control. They have done so with a storm of abuse directed at Americans in general and at Assistant Secretary of State George V. Allen in particular. Thus ends a program whose sole design was to be helpful and friendly.

A new impartial chairman to settle all disputes between the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations and Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL, was designated yesterday. He is George Marlin, former Deputy City Controller.

Despite price increases yesterday, orders for lead and zinc continued strong. Increased demand for aluminum brought an end to recent distressed-sales discounts for aluminum casting alloy ingots. Further nonferrous metal advances are expected soon, it was stated in trade circles, but it is believed they will not be more than 3/4 cent in lead and 1/2 cent in zinc.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Guerrilla warfare in Greece is being suppressed and economic conditions in that country are improving, United States Ambassador Henry F. Grady said today upon his arrival here for consultations on American assistance to Greece.

Four hundred officers and staff employes of the United Steel Workers of America, CIO, gathered yesterday afternoon at the Commodore Hotel for a semi-aannual meeting on the eve of hearings by a Presidential fact- finding board named earlier this month to avert a steel industry strike.

BERLIN, July 25 -- During recent months the Russian policy of transplanting border populations considered potentially subversive into the interior of the Soviet Union has been accelerated, Western sources said here today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- Alfred J. Snyder, counsel for a large group of Commonwealth and Southern Corporation stockholders, said today that he would accept a Federal District Court dissolution plan without further appeal.

Government by default has never been the American way. Yet unless the people of the United States, through their elected representatives in Congress, assert themselves quickly on a vital matter of public health, they may be saddled with an undesirable change in the Executive Branch of our Government.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 25 -- The staff committee of the United Nations unanimously resolved tonight in special meeting that the repeated "spy" accusations made against the organization's employes during the course of Congressional hearings constituted a "reprehensible attempt" to interfere with the United Nations.

LONDON, July 25 -- Pencil-slim skirts with tailored jackets slightly longer than last year's were shown in London today at the first three autumn collections of the Incorporated Society of London Fashion designers. The skirts were a little shorter than those of last season, about fourteen inches from the ground.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The program of military aid asked today by President Truman was not believed, in any informed quarter, very likely to be approved in all its details. Even the Administration's Congressional leaders avoided unqualified predictions that it would go unaltered through the Senate and House.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder, who returned today from a three-week tour of Europe, said flatly that there was no discussion of any new loan to Great Britain while he visited London.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Jewelry sales, which hit the $900,000,000 mark last year, will slip to about the $800,000,000 level this year and continue to slide in 1950, William Wagner, executive secretary of the National Association of Credit Jewelrs, predicted today at the opening of the National Jewelry Fair which the association sponsors.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- Housing Expediter Woods will appeal the Chicago decision on rent controls. Federal attorneys said a stay of execution of the ruling would be sought until the issue can be determined by the Supreme Court, which will not be in session until October.

PARIS, July 25 -- A political controversy in the National Assembly almost as hot as the weather developed today over a decision by Daniel Mayer, Socialist Minister of Labor, approving work and vacation bonuses for employes of the national social security system.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Admiral Lea projected himself sharply into the field for Saturday's $90,000 Classic Stakes by scoring an impressive victory over Ponder in the $5,000 Omaha Purse at Arlington Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Senator John Foster Dulles, Republican, of New York, newest member of the upper chamber, is slated for assignments to the Post Office and Civil Service and the Rules Committees.

An eighteen-month investigation of an interstate "rigged" policy ring with an estimated "take" of $50,000,000 yearly has resulted in the detention of eleven persons in three states, including the secretary of the Cincinnati Clearing House Association, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.

BAYVILLE, L. I., July 25 -- Quick thinking and cool action by a motor boat owner prevented serious casualties at 6:15 P. M. today when his twenty-six-foot cabin cruiser, Pride and Joy, exploded and burned off Oak Neck Point in Oyster Bay.

Pierre van Paassen, author of "Days of Our Lives" and "The Forgotten Ally," has a new book listed by Dial Press for Sept. 12 publication. In "Why Jesus Died," the author, who was ordained a minister of the Unitarian Church in 1946, presents what he calls "a startling revelation of the unknown circumstances'' surrounding the life and death of Christ.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The arms program presented by President Truman today was projected as a necessary implementation of the North Atlantic treaty and a bar against aggression, framed within the objectives of the United Nations, the State Department said.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 25 -- Herman Barron of Fenway set the pace for all members of fifty-three competing teams in the Westchester P. G. A. pro-amateur tournament at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today with a two-under-par 68.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today said transportation by Seatrain, Inc., in the side tanks of its specially constructed vessels (which carry freight cars) of petroleum and petroleum products from Texas City, Tex., and New Orleans to the port of New York, was outside its jurisdiction. It issued an order exempting such transportation from regulation.

OSLO, July 25 (AP) -- The biggest event in Scandinavian track sport since the Olympic Games at Stockholm 37 years ago takes place in Oslo on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday when the United States meets Scandinavia in a junior Olympic meet.

The stock market returned momentarily yesterday to the recovery side, but the force soon melted away into a mixed close. While the gains topped the losses by a substantial margin, they were of a limited size and generally without meaning.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Spokesmen for the soft coal industry today told members of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee that the three-day work week in Eastern pits decreed by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, had raised operating costs and sharpened the hazards of mining.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 25 -- W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, said today that this country's possession of the atomic bomb was "a force for peace" because we have the airplanes to deliver it against an enemy.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores dropped 11 per cent last week below the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline for the four weeks ended last Saturday was 13 per cent.

Plans for a summer refunding of the $6,000,000 of outstanding dollar bonds of the Metropolitan Water, Sewerage and Drainage Board of Sydney, Australia, have been abandoned, largely because of the reported unwillingness of holders abroad to agree to a conversion, it was learned here yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- After eighteen years at Warner Brothers, Bette Davis, who has battled the studio in the courts and out of them because of contractual and casting differences, will become a free agent if present negotiations between Warners and the actress' representative are successful.

BERLIN, July 25 -- The Third Battalion of the Sixteenth Infantry Regiment, which has been the backbone of the United States Army's garrison in Berlin through the last year of the "cold war," will be withdrawn this summer in accordance with a general realignment of the administrative and military organizations in Germany, a reliable source said tonight.

Velvet and velveteen hold the center of the fashion stage for fall. So extensively have these two fabrics been used, both for entire costumes and as accent, that they have become the password to style for the autumn of 1949.

The United Service Organizations will key its program to the desires of military personnel of all ages and not just the teen-age group, representatives of six USO operating agencies emphasized yesterday.

Seventeen British architects, engineers and builders who will spend six weeks studying American construction methods were welcomed yesterday by representatives of the Anglo-American Council on Productivity and the Economic Cooperation Administration, which are sponsoring the tour.

The use of natural gas in New York City will soon begin with the conversion, starting Aug. 1, of household appliances in Staten Island homes. This development culminates years of study and research on ways to distribute this natural resource economically from the oil and gas fields in the West to the country's metropolitan areas.

The Pressed Steel Car Company, Inc., reported yesterday that its consolidated net earnings for the six months ended with June totaled $1,526,881, in contrast to the net loss of $666,493 shown in the same period a year ago.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 25 (AP) -- Onkahya, a glistening white yawl from Chicago, won the biggest honor in the Port Huronto-Mackinac Island sailing race today.

Businessmen "students" who registered two years ago for a highly technical course designed to provide industry and agriculture with better shipping containers are preparing now for the "senior semester" leading to graduation next spring.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., July 25 -- The eighteenth-century garden of the historic Moffatt-Ladd House will be the setting here on the afternoon of Aug. 9 for the annual garden party of the National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New Hampshire.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., July 25 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, said today that the company was feeling the adverse effects of a return to a buyers' market.
The Communist-dominated states of Eastern Europe owe their existence to the Russian Army's intervention in their internal affairs, a top Soviet theoretician has declared.

While homeseekers obtained 16,300 application forms for apartments in nearly ready projects of the New York City Housing Authority yesterday, the authority revealed that it had moved to obtain Federal aid for the first of a series of eighteen additional projects.

BERLIN, July 25 -- The Russians announced today they would reopen eight highways to Berlin closed in the "little blockade" July 9. Traffic was reported to have started moving on two of the roads early this morning.
FRANKFORT, Germany, July 25 (AP) -- Forty-one German police officers from the Russian zone have deserted to the United States zone in the last month, United States officials said today.

Because a time limit of 4 o'clock had been placed on the game, the Cardinals and Dodgers played to a 4-4 tie in nine innings at Ebbets Field yesterday and the Brooks hurried away for Chicago still half a game behind the league-leading Redbirds.

The unhappy controversy which has arisen over Mrs. Roosevelt's comments on the Federal Educational Finance bill and Cardinal Spellman's reply to those comments should not be allowed to obscure the important issue at stake. This is to what extent the Government may aid children attending sectarian schools without impairing the mandate of the First Amendment that "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion."

It is again typhoon season in the Pacific and again Okinawa has suffered severe damage. One child was killed and sixteen persons suffered injuries. The note of comfort in the most recent dispatch is in the sentence, "Ample warning of the storm's approach apparently prevented heavier casualties."

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- A number of Senators told Secretary of Labor Maurice Tobin today that many small business men lacked confidence in his department. He blamed "a propaganda drive," but they sharply disagreed.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 25 -- Frank C. Nash, the United States representative on the United Nations Commission for Conventional Armaments, charged today that the Soviet Union's opposition to a world-wide census of armed forces "is bottomed simply on the Soviet's unwillingness to let the rest of the world know how far they have gone in arming themselves for the world conquest which is their avowed goal."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Urging home rule this year for the District of Columbia, President Truman declared today that it was "little short of fantastic" that Congress should continue to devote so much time to acting as a City Council for the nation's capital.

CONCORD, N. H., July 25 (AP) -- Former Controller Stephen B. Story and Donat F. Cote, Manchester contractor, were sentenced today to from six to fourteen years imprisonment and fined $5,000 each for defrauding the state.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The text of proposed foreign military aid legislation, as released by the State Department, follows:
This is a plan on behalf of the older worker, the man or woman of 45 or more, who through no personal fault is in the position of having to seek new work.
May I congratulate THE TIMES on the very fine column by Arthur Krock in the issue of July 14 on the penetration of "left-wing" writers into every area of public-opinion forming?
PARIS, July 25 -- Foreign Minister Robert Schuman replied today to the publicly expressed French fears that the Atlantic pact eventually might include Germany.

LONDON, July 25 -- The British Government, which has just seen a month-old London dock strike come to an end, was confronted today with the threat of labor unrest in two more industries of vital importance to Britain's economic recovery -- the nationalized railways and the nationalized coal mines.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 25 (AP) -- In a ding-dong stretch battle which saw the lead change hands with each stride, Mrs. O. L. Nyberg's Irisen drove to a nose victory over Mrs. Joseph W. Camac's Flood Town in the featured six-furlong Sorcerer Purse at Monmouth Park today.

The master and chief officer of the tanker Gulfstream, which was in collision on Jan. 19 with the Coast Guard icebreaker Eastwind of the New Jersey coast, were found guilty yesterday of negligence and their licenses were suspended.

Back from the West where only recently they had toppled their arch pursuers, the Indians, in a blistering series, the Yankees made a heroic effort at the Stadium last night to show a home-coming crowd of 71,354 just how such things are done.
LOS ANGELES, July 25 (UP) -- A key witness in the gangland shooting of Mickey Cohen is missing, Fred N. Howser, State Attorney General, said today. He expressed fear of foul play.

The W. T. Grant Company plans a retail branch outlet in Elizabeth, N. J., where it has leased about 40,000 square feet of space in a two-story building to be erected at the northwest corner of Broad Street and Caldwell Place. The A. F. Roe Company of Jersey City was the broker.

The award of the George R. Henderson Medal of the Franklin Institute to John Van Buren Duer, retired railroad executive and mechanical engineer, for his resourcefulness and contributions in the coordination of railroad engineering matters, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- House Democratic members conducting an investigation of "monopoly" gave strong indication today that they were considering a bill to limit the size of private companies as a means of controlling their power.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 25 -- Top officers in the Reserve ranks of the armed forces assembled here today for a showdown fight with the Pentagon over make-up of the National Military Establishment.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Attorney General Tom Clark today put three more groups on the Government's list of subversive organizations. He classed all as Communist in a report to the Loyalty Review Board, which heads the program of checking on the loyalty of Government employes.

PLYMOUTH, N. H., July 25 - The American Friends Service Committee defended today in a statement its retention of Alger Hiss, former State Department official tried recently in New York Federal Court on charges of perjury, as leader of its seminar here on the United Nations and international relations.

DAMASCUS, Syria, July 25 -- Mohsen el Barazi, Premier and Foreign Minister of Syria, said today that the Syrian Government would welcome a United States plan for settlement of the Palestine problem and that Syria would study it with greatest interest.

The suggestion that the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, close its membership books, which was made last week by Investigation Commissioner John M. Murtagh, was rejected yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, ILA president, on the ground that it could put the union in the position of violating the Taft-Hartley Law.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., July 25 -- To raise a sum like $1,200,000 for a hospital in a rural county of fewer than 37,000 persons looks like an impossible task. But it's being done in Hunterdon County, N. J., where $810,000 has already been subscribed.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Colonial Airlines has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for a quick ruling on the line's challenge of the new United States-Canadian air agreement.

Sharply criticizing Superintendent of Schools William Jansen and his professional staff, James Marshall, a Manhattan member of the Board of Education, has charged that the priority order of the 1950 school construction program was determined by neighborhood "clamor" rather than by actual need.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Mills were heavy buyers of wheat futures on the Board of Trade today and the demand did not let up until near the close, when hedging pressure increased and caused a recession of around 1 cent from the high, with the close at gains of 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UP) -- The Secretary of Labor, Maurice J. Tobin, today raised minimum pay in the country's major steel producing areas to a top rate of $1.23 an hour for work on Government contracts involving more than $10,000.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, announced yesterday after conferring with a majority of the members of the Tammany executive committee that State Senator Joseph Zaretzki, of the Twenty-third District, had been designated for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Manhattan.
STOCKHOLM, July 25 -- Premier Tage Erlander of Sweden said today that on the whole he was optimistic about the economic outlook in the United States.

ROME, July 25 -- The 100th anniversary of the birth of David Lubin, American founder of the International Institute of Agriculture, which had its first seat in Rome, was commemorated today with a solemn ceremony attended by President Luigi Einaudi, Premier Alcide de Gasperi and many other high officials of the Italian Government.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today new laws are needed to prevent the dumping of inferior United States merchandise upon foreign nations.

MANCHESTER, England, July 25 (Reuters) -- Believing that England planned to make an all out bid for victory over New Zealand in the third cricket test today a big crowd sweltered in the oppressive heat at Old Trafford expecting to see a batting feast.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, commenting in her newspaper column yesterday on Cardinal Spellman's charges that she was anti-Catholic and intolerant, said she bore "no ill feeling toward any religion or toward any people of high or low estate because they belong to any religious group."

OTTAWA, Ont., July 25 (Canadian Press) -- A government official said today that the Canadian-United States air agreement could be suspended if the United States made any serious effort to hold back an application by Trans-Canada Air Lines for a Montreal- New York air route.

NEWARK, N. J., July 25 -- Superior Court Judge William J. Brennan Jr., refused today to issue an order of restraint against six leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, in the Jersey City dock walkout. He said that he was satisfied that there were elements of a labor dispute and therefore no mandatory injunction would be issued without further proof taken in court.

TAMPA, Fla., July 25 (AP) -- Four law enforcement officers in Polk County were arrested today on Federal indictments charging that they beat up two Negro prisoners in violation of the Negroes' civil rights.
SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, July 26 -- President Syngman Rhee's office this morning revealed that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek had accepted an invitation to visit Korea "in the near future."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The United States formally ratified the North Atlantic treaty today and the Administration at once asked Congress for $1,450,000,000 with which to help arm the countries of Western Europe entered in that alliance and other non-Communist nations, among them Iran, Korea and the Philippines.

Safeway Stores, Inc., plans a !new super market in the Bronx [where it has purchased a vacant parcel, about 200 by 125 feet, at ,2121 Westchester Avenue, northeast corner of Olmstead Avenue, from Land Properties, Inc. Joseph Howard Katz was attorney for the seller and Noonan, Kaufman Eagan acted for the buyer.
A mass of hot air from the Midwest arrived here early yesterday morning, sending the temperature up gradually until it reached a high of 91 degrees at 6:25 P. M.

GENEVA, July 25 -- France and Belgium proposed today creation of a United Nations high commissioner for stateless persons and refugees as a permanent United Nations organ for dealing with refugee problems. The commissioner would succeed the present International Refugee Organization when that body is liquidated, soon after mid-1950.

The one-story taxpayer containing eight stores on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 41-02 162d Street in Flusi-ung, Queens, .has been purchased for investment by Nathan Ratkin from the Getlee Realty Corporation, builder. The building was erected about a year ago.

The National Broadcasting Company is reported to be working on a new series of telecasts to be called the "Armed Forces Hour" in which all branches of the military service would participate. The plan is for the network to provide the time and facilities and the armed forces the talent.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 26(AP) -- A 150-mile-an-hour typhoon that had ripped across Okinawa Saturday has "immobilized" Communist-held Shanghai, United States Navy authorities reported today.

Brand names guide 1,185 high school and college students in approximately seven of ten purchases, it was reported yesterday in a survey made for Brand Names Foundation, Inc., by the Student Marketing Institute of New York. The findings were based on 61,389 inquiries concerning purchase of eighty-six products made during the past semester among students of forty-four high schools, colleges and universities throughout the country.

United States Government purchases of rubber for stockpiling purposes bolstered the rubber market here yesterday and as a result rubber futures closed on the Commodity Exchange 5 to 12 points higher than Friday's close. Just how much the Government contracts involved was not disclosed but total trading for the day did not exceed 230 long tons.
New York University confirmed yesterday that its camp on Lake Sebago, Palisades Interstate Park, had curtailed activities since the death last Thursday of a student afflicted with poliomyelitis.

Another virtual give away of land at Long Beach by the Long Island Rail Road was charged yesterday by Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino, representing the Second Assembly District in Nassaau and Republican leader of Long Beach.
Depletion of natural resources constitutes a threat to the human race, Governor Dewey declared yesterday at ground-breaking for a twelve-acre conservation exhibit in the Bronx Zoo.

TOKYO, July 25 -- Large scale reductions soon will be made in the non-military sections of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters, it was reported credibly here today. Orders to this effect, it was understood, already have been sent out quietly and preliminary conferences held.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 25 (AP) -- Bobby Locke, the British open champion, was scratched today from major golf tournaments in the United States.
" Tagged" for violating rules against low flying in the metropolitan area, an airline captain is due to make an explanation in Municipal Court in Jamaica, Queens, Thursday.

Carelessness by smokers continues to account for greater fire loss in this city than any other single cause, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle said yesterday. In 1948 there were 5,637 such fires with losses totaling $3,285,450.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Industrial production dropped in June for the seventh consecutive month -- reaching a three-year low, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The city's Premature Infants Emergency Service received a call last month from a small hospital in Queens. A patient being treated for shock as the result of a minor automobile accident had just given birth prematurely to twin boys. The hospital's two incubators were occupied.
Demolition of a building famous in art auction history began yesterday as workmen dismantled for salvage the former home of the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

" New York Builds." So runs a headline in our Sunday Magazine. And, as New York builds, it tears down what it has built before. That has been the history of the town from the beginning. The process was speeded up when the town became a city.
Kidder, Peabody Co. will offer to investors today 28,739 shares of $10 par value 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of the Mutual Telephone Company, Honolulu, Hawaii, at $10 a share.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., House Republican leader, said today he will demand a showdown Wednesday on whether Congress must adjourn by Aug. 1 or pass a resolution extending the session.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- A report by the House Un-American Activities Committee said today that a woman employe of the United Nations once acted as a courier for the Communist party while working for the United States Government.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A solidly knit band of Southern Democrats, battling against heavy odds to prevent a House vote on the anti-poll tax bill, forced seven roll-calls today before the House leadership could get a rule for consideration of the measure.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The tentative decision reached by the leaders of Congress to pigeonhole for this session the Lodge-Gossett-Kefauver amendment to the Constitution emphasizes once more that on proposals of this kind all American politicians are fundamentally conservative.

BOSTON. July 25 (AP) -- A freighter captain and the skipper of a thirty-eight-foot pleasure boat accused each other today of having kept a poor lookout when the vessels collided yesterday killing one woman and demolishing the small craft.

The $1,000 Eli Lilly Co. Award in Biological Chemistry has been awarded to Dr. Irving M. Klotz, Associate Professor of Chemistry in Northwestern University, it was announced yesterday by the American Chemical Society.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- People are taking longer to pay up on charge accounts, a Federal Reserve Board survey of retail credit showed today.

Inspectors of the City Department of Health reported yesterday that they had made contact with 2,150 retail drug outlets in the city and embargoed 425 bottles of "presidon", a suspect sedative preparation, in 304 stores. All stores in the city will be checked within a few days.

Two men held up a dozen customers and clerks in the Brand Chatillon Corporation retail jewelry store at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street at 4:35 o'clock yesterday afternoon and ran out with four diamond pieces valued at $368,500.

Just when it appeared there wasn't much of anything to cheer about in the off-shore situation over the week-end, Captain Carl Forsberg of Freeport sent out a rather excited report that a tuna weighing 341 pounds had been taken in the Mud Hole.

Mayor O'Dwyer issued yesterday a proclamation designating today as "Employ Amputees Day" in New York. The proclamation, urging attendance at tonight's amputee war veterans' baseball game at the Polo Grounds, follows:

PARIS, July 25 -- Italy won the final round of the European Davis Cup competition from France today by capturing the last of two singles matches that remained in the three-day meeting in sunbaked Roland Garros Stadium. The final score was three matches to two.
CAIRO, July 25 (AP) -- King Farouk shook up the Egyptian Cabinet today in a reported move to broaden the Government as a step for general elections in the fall.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 (AP) -- A statement that, at times, seemed more of a defense document than prosecution was read by the Government today at the "Tokyo Rose" treason trial of Iva Toguri d'Aquino. The statement was made by the 33-year-old defendant to Frederick Tillman of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Sugamo Prison on April 30, 1946.

As an "example to others," three men, who were convicted in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, of lending money to Brooklyn longshoremen at excessive rates of interest, were sentenced yesterday to one-year penitentiary terms.

PARIS, July 25 -- The Preparatory Commission that has been laying the groundwork for the initial meeting of the Council of Europe in Strasbourg on Aug. 8 has submitted its report to the ten participating Governments, it was learned today. Its contents were not made public.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., Loew's, Inc., and the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation were directed by a Federal statutory court yesterday to divorce their theatre-holding interests from their business of producing and distributing pictures.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A compromise bill to aid school children was cleared by a House subcommittee today.
The "lonely hearts" murder trial in Bronx County Supreme Court was disrupted yesterday afternoon by a near riot of would-be spectators outside the courtroom.

The world's largest light bulb is being installed in the marquee of the Rivoli Theatre in Times Square to illuminate festivities marking the world premiere of the new Twentieth Century - Fox movie, "Come to the Stable," tomorrow night.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 25 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century took a 1 stroke lead in the Elizabeth Wheeler 54-hole medal play tournament when she toured the east course of the Winged Foot Golf Club with 39, 39 -- 78 today.

BOSTON, July 25 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer began today his survey of nation-wide economic conditions by observing that it was "practically impossible" to foresee a depression and that the "real danger" lay in "people getting scared."

Musical instrument sales volume this year will show a drop of 15 to 25 per cent, according to manufacturers attending the music industry trade show and convention which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel. Total sales are running below the $250,000,000 volume attained in 1948, they said, but unit volume has held up surprisingly well in the face of the general decline of all types of consumer goods.

LONDON, July 25 -- British official circles let it be known today that they still considered American military aid to Europe, as proposed by President Truman, a virtually indispensable corollary to the North Atlantic pact.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 25 -- An authoritative Government spokesman said here today that any permanent solution of the economic future of Western European countries depended upon their acceptance of an economic federation that permitted the development of a large, single, highly competitive home market.

PARIS, July. 25 -- The French Foreign Office denied today that France had "ever had any intention of asking or preparing" for the political annexation of the Saar territory. It is already joined economically to France.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Senate voted, 41 to 30, this evening to keep a joint Congressional committee and a staff of experts watching the spending of American dollars for foreign aid.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Truman Administration intends to discuss details of its proposed $1,450,000,000 foreign arms program only in closed session of Senate and House committees, it was learned today.

Ultra-high frequency television service, on which the Federal Communications Service will open hearings in August, is probably three years away and will not be required in most of the metropolitan centers now served by very-high frequencies, it was asserted yesterday by William Balderston, president of the Philco Corporation.

Yesterday's session of the Communist trial was adjourned because of the illness of a juror. This was the third day lost for the same reason. The same juror has been involved each time. If, as appears likely, he is unable to continue today, the trial is expected to proceed with an alternate juror in his place.
HAYWARD, Wis., July 25 (AP) -Wisconsin waters have upped the world muskellunge record for sport fishermen another three pounds -- to 67 1/2.

Jean Anouilh's French play, "Ardelle," now on display in Paris, where it is said to be a box-office magnet, will be brought to Broadway this fall by the new firm of James Colligan and Don Medford, it was announced yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 25 -- The appointment of Mrs. Clarice H. L. Pennock as director of field work in the social sciences at Vassar College was announced here today by Miss Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of the college.

The State of Iowa announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Aug. 17 on $8,750,000 of veterans' war service compensation bonds. This is the first borrowing of an authorized total of $35,000,000 of bonds to be used, along with $50,000,000 of the State's surplus funds, to finance payment of bonuses estimated to aggregate $85,000,000.

GLEN COVE, L. I., July 25 -- Webb Institute of Naval Architecture graduated this afternoon its first post-war class not originally a part of the Navy V-12 program, and it was announced that all graduates had employment offers in the shipping and ship-building industries.

Unaware that her husband had disappeared at sea from the Norwegian America liner Stavangerfjord, Mrs. George U. Bauer came down from her home in Brookline, Mass., to meet the steamer yesterday morning.

COMPARED to the Irish and the Scots the Welsh inhabit a small and backward province in the great empire of English literature. English writers have generally scorned the Welsh: "Taffy was a Welshman, Taffy was a thief." Shakespeare, who wrote in the reign of a Queen with much Welsh blood in her veins, ridiculed his Welsh characters, Fluellen and Owen Glendower.

Despite the present unsettled state of industrial activity, common stocks of sound enterprises remain a desirable investment for that portion of an investor's funds which may be placed in equities, trustees of the Massachusetts Investors Trust said yesterday in submitting their report for the three months ended June 30.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The text of President Truman's message to Congress today on the foreign arms aid program follows:

My attention has been called to a letter from Harold F. Smith published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on July 4 under the heading "Overcivilized Beaches" in which the statement is made that sections of as yet undeveloped state beaches such as Gilgo should be opened to unrestricted use by those who wish to avoid charges for our facilities and protection.
PARIS, July 25 -- Calots dipping down over one ear, high pointed caps inspired by those of the elves and sprites in fairy lore, are Gilbert Orcel's gay and youthful contribution to fall millinery.

BERLIN, July 23 -- Agitation for the establishment of part or all of the government of the Western German Federal Republic in Berlin and the growth of national opposition to industrial dismantling in Western Germany are two of the most delicate problems the Western powers must handle in the tricky period before the republic is organized.
The text of Mrs. Roosevelt's column in The New York World-Telegram yesterday follows:

Price reductions on men's wear fabrics for next spring ranging up to 19 per cent under fall levels were announced yesterday by the American Woolen Company. The drop exceeded advance expectations in the men's clothing industry, and represented one of the largest percentage price cuts made by the company at a seasonal opening since World War I, company officials said.

The drawing power of a Tchaikovsky concerto played by a top-flight artist was demonstrated again last night when 21,000 people converged on the Lewisohn Stadium to hear Jascha Heifetz play that composer's violin concerto. The audience set the record for the season, and 1,000 of the would-be listeners had to be turned away.

NEWARK, July 25 -- Augustus C. Studer Jr., chairman of a citizens' committee appointed by the New Jersey Legislature to investigate alleged irregularities in state bond purchases, said today his committee would hold another hearing on the matter early in September.

Price reductions on women's wear worsteds for next spring, ranging from 8 to 18 per cent under fall levels, were announced yesterday by the American Woolen Company. The decline amounts to 20 to 47 1/2 cents per yard and is not as sharp as that which featured the company's opening on Monday of men's wear fabrics.

ST. LOUIS, July 26 (AP) -- The Cardinals' bats were hot tonight in a 9-to-5 triumph over the Phillies. Lefty Harry Brecheen hurled the route for St. Louis, which increased its National League lead to one game and a half over the second-place Dodgers.

BOSTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Red Sox unleashed a nine-hit, ten-run eighth inning tonight to slaughter the White Sox, 11 -- 2, and give young Maurice McDermott his fourth victory in the six games he has pitched since being recalled from Louisville in June.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) -- Sam Chapman's single with two out in the tenth inning scored Eddie Joost from second with the run that gave the Athletics a 5-4 decision over the Browns tonight.

In an all-cash transaction, the two five-story store and apartment buildings on a plot 40 by 129 feet at 138-40 East Thirty-fourth Street were purchased for investment by the 138-40 East Thirty-fourth Street Corporation, Benjamin Teicholz, president.
PERRY, Fla., July 26 (AP) -- Ernest Thomas, identified as the fourth Negro in the recent Groveland rape case, was shot and killed by a posse north of this community today.

TUXEDO, N. Y., July 26 -- An act of good samaritanship cost a taxi-driver his life near here today. The driver was Joseph Richman, 43 years old, a mountain hack chauffeur of 106 Finlay Avenue, the Bronx. He was killed by a trailer truck while walking along Route 17 to get some milk for a baby who was a passenger in his car.

LONDON, July 26 -- The Moscow radio broadcast tonight the text of a Soviet note to Yugoslavia alleging that many Soviet citizens permanently resident in Yugoslavia had been imprisoned for many months without trial. The note demanded their immediate release.

HONG KONG, July 26 (UP) -- Communist forces were reported today to have broken through the Nationalists' major defense lines in the Changsha area, 275 miles north of Canton. Communist troops were said to be driving on Hengyang, 220 miles north of Canton, and the last major Government defense point between the Reds and the provisional capital.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 26 -- Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, the President's aide, said today that President Truman favors a small, well-trained active armed force, backed up by a large reserve force.
