WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- A House Armed Services subcommittee today voted to ban "special order" sales by military stores whereby servicemen buy anything from furs to refrigerators at cut-rate prices.

CINCINNATI, July 26 (AP) -- The Reds pounced on rookie Johnny Antonelli for four runs in the first two innings tonight and went on to beat the Braves, 6 to 3. Home runs by Sibby Sisti and Bob Elliott were the only damaging runs off Kent Peterson, Cincinnati southpaw, who survived a shaky start.

A Baptist pastor, whose parishioners in Milwaukee collected $3,000 for his trip here, was flown into Newark Airport yesterday and then transferred to the Bellevue Hospital Rehabilitation Center for treatment of paralysis caused by a broken neck.
LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- British newspapers expressed fear today that Congress might pare the United States' arms-for-Europe program to the point where it would be ineffective.

Treasury financing in the fiscal year ended on June 30 reflects the various changes which the economy has been undergoing, and the period marks a "year of transition," the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in a study of the year's developments, released yesterday.

Bernard M. Baruch, governmental adviser on industry in two world wars, called yesterday for a defense and economic union of Western Europe, after which "we will be able to help them to help themselves."

PARIS, Wednesday, July 27 -- Repeated tumult and exchanges of insults in the Chamber of Deputies and fist fights in the adjoining corridors marked the final stages of debate in the National Assembly yesterday on the North Atlantic treaty, which was expected to be passed by a large majority in a session that was continuing this morning.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, announced yesterday the organization designations for Democratic nominations for members of the City Council in Manhattan. This year Council members will be elected by Senatorial districts, of which there are six in Manhattan, instead of by the proportional representation method that formerly prevailed.
Your editorial "It Is the Child That Matters" (July 26) went far to clarify the confusion which is widespread on the issue of Federal aid to children attending private schools.
PALO ALTO, Calif., July 26 (AP) -- A hopeful picture of the current business correction was given today by speakers at Stanford University's eighth annual business conference.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 26 (AP) -- There was a refund of $12,566 at Monmouth Park today when Emma Downs' Likarock, a scheduled starter in the featured fifth race, was not placed in position for the start and Starter Bill Schamehorn, failing to notice her in the rear of the starting barrier. sent the remainder of the field on its way.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Administration was put under heavy pressure today by Republican foreign policy spokesmen to make a voluntary cut in its $1,450,000,000 program for helping to arm much of the non-Communist world.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 26 (UP) -- Circuit Judge George Lewis Bailes today called a special session of the Grand Jury for 9 A. M. on Thursday to continue investigating masked gang terrorism cases in the Birmingham area. Solicitor Emmett Perry requested that the panel be convened.

The present retail price of milk will continue through August because of the extension yesterday by the United States Department of Agriculture of the July minimum farm price of $5.24 a hundred-weight for class 1A milk.
A strike by 600 members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, AFL, against the Holmes Electric Protective Company, 370 Seventh Avenue, seemed imminent yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, July 26 -- The women's branch of the peronista party came into being tonight at a meeting at which Senora Eva Peron was hailed with excitement far transcending anything displayed at the opening of the convention last night.

LONDON, July 26 -- British Government funds took another tumble in the stock market here today. Dealers again had to face a steady stream of selling and, with no bargain-hunters about, lost as much as 5/8 point.

As foreshadowed in the debate on the North Atlantic Treaty, the Administration's foreign military assistance program is running into considerable Congressional opposition. Indeed, this opposition appears to be more formidable and on a broader front than anticipated, and may subject the whole bipartisan foreign policy to its severest test.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Munitions Board of the National Military Establishment told Congress today that the stockpiling of critical raw materials was a deterrent to war, and it recommended that the world "be informed of the fact" when the reserve program had been completed.

ROME, July 26 -- Osservatore Romano published today an authoritative interpretation of the Holy Office excommunication decree against Communists to erase all doubts as to its meaning and to foil attempts by anti-clerical parties to distort it.
WEST POINT, N. Y., July 26 -- A dam and lake on the West Point reservation were named Stilwell Dam and Stilwell Lake this afternoon in honor of the late Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell.

The New York City Housing Authority yesterday finished about 80 per cent of the permanent financing of Mayor O'Dwyer's program of city-backed, non-cash-subsidy public housing by borrowing $50,300,000 on tax-exempt bonds maturing serially from 1951 to 1999 at a net interest cost of 2.7748 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged three Chicago brokerage concerns with stock market manipulation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 26 -- The Swedes are staying out of the North Atlantic pact not only because their politicians believe in neutrality but because their government is convinced that in the event of war their country will get most of the advantages of the pact without assuming any of its obligations.

A defense witness at the Communist trial yesterday confirmed Government evidence that party schools taught both immediate and ultimate party goals and that the latter included setting up a dictatorship of the proletariat. He also verified the fact previously brought out by the Government that some students at these schools used only their first names.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 -- Lifting of a ban against Kirsten Flagstad, the Wagnerian soprano, appeared certain late today to Acting Mayor George Christopher, with the result that the board of directors of the San Francisco Opera Association announced indefinite postponement of cancellation of its 1949 opera season.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 26 (AP) -- Minor league baseball clubs have approved their first player draft meeting in history, President George M. Trautman of the minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues said today. The draft meeting will open Monday, Dec. 5, at Baltimore, two days before the start of the annual convention.
LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- The British Walker Cup golf team, which will sail Friday for New York, lost a match with a professional team today, 3 to 2. A second match will be played tomorrow.
Convinced that there is an unprecedented need for escapist plays, Brock Pemberton has taken options on three comedies with a view to producing one or more of them during the coming season.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) -- The defense in the Tokyo Rose treason trial got this Army statement in the record today:

WARSAW, Wednesday, July 27 -- The Polish Government agreed today to start negotiations with the Roman Catholic Church aimed at settling church-state differences and at the same time issued a full-scale blast against the Vatican's order excommunicating Catholics working for communism.

Brookmeade Stable's Sky Miracle, a 3-year-old gelding named for his sire, Teddy's Comet, lost the lead a couple of times in the main event of the Saratoga-at-Jamaica racing show yesterday, but still managed to take the decision. He was the 2-to-1 favorite of the crowd of 16,428.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the lease of the properties of the Wheeling Lake Erie Rail Road and the New York Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, the alternative adopted when it was found that holders of Nickel Plate preferred and common stock would have been dissatisfied with dilution of their equity by a merger of the two companies.

The City of Perth, a new combination cargo and passenger vessel of the Ellerman Bucknall Steamship Company's $100,000,000 post-war fleet, will make her maiden voyage to India, Pakistan and Ceylon on Friday.

The highest net income for any first half-year in twenty years was reported yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation for the first half of 1949. Net income up to June 30 was $94,052,265, equivalent to $3.12 a common share, compared with $53,443,018 or $1.56 a share in the same period last year, after allowance is made in the 1948 figure for the three-to-one stock split of last May.

Henry Dreyfuss, industrial designer chosen by the Hudson Manhattan Railroad to lure back some of the 43,000,000 fares the line has lost in the last twenty-two years, discussed tentative plans for the project yesterday.

Clashes between Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, and spokesmen for the "Big Three" in the steel industry, marked the first meeting here yesterday of the Presidential fact-finding board named to avert an industry-wide strike last July 16.

Two men whose flight Monday with $368,500 of jewelry from a Fifth Avenue shop was halted by the police and a civilian bystander were held in $50,000 bail each yesterday by Magistrate Edgar Bromberger.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range yesterday, and final prices were 2 points higher to 1 point lower than on Monday.

DONALSONVILLE, Ga., July 26 (AP) -- Mayor C. L. Drake of Iron City, a South Georgia country town, said today that on Sunday, July 17, he had beaten off with gunfire a mob of Ku Klux Klansmen who tried to kidnap him.

Renewed life was injected yesterday into the advance of the stock market and, although the upswing proved laborious at times, gains of major proportions occurred throughout the list. Sparked by strength in the motors and steels, backed by the rails, the price average rose 0.67 point.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- More than three-fourths of the displaced persons entering the United States so far have been Catholics and Jews, Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat, of Nevada, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said today.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 26 -- Adding a five-over-par 79 to her first-round 78 for a thirty-six-hole total of 157, Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century took a seven-stroke lead today in the Elizabeth Wheeler fifty-four-hole medal play golf championship at the East course of the Winged Foot Club.

BERLIN, July 26 -- Both the United States and British military governments announced today their intention of transferring key personnel from Berlin to Western Germany and their unswervable intention to maintain the cause of the West in Berlin.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Economic Cooperation Administration approved today the purchase of $45,968,000 of cotton from United States suppliers.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Norton bill outlawing exaction of a poll tax as a requirement for voting in Federal elections swept through the House today, 273 to 116.

The first offensive in the District Attorney's drive on a $50,000,000 interstate "rigged" policy ring was in the mopping-up stage last night as nine of the eleven men most wanted were in jail, one was scheduled to be brought to New York under guard within forty-eight hours and the eleventh was free in $35,000 bail.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 26 -- The "halt Abdullah" movement in connection with the Palestine settlement is taking on considerable dimensions, with the Arab Higher Committee, an old opponent of the King of Jordan, in the forefront, supported quietly but determinedly by Egypt and Syria.

PLYMOUTH, N. H., July 26 -- Another war may destroy a major part of civilization and can be prevented only through the establishment of a world government, Alger Hiss, former State Department official, declared here today.
LONDON, July 26 -- A slight increase in tonnage of ships under construction at the end of June, as compared with the previous quarter, was reported today by Lloyds Register of Shipping.

MANCHESTER, England, July 26 (Reuters) -- England and New Zealand played to a draw in the third test cricket match today, with the final score showing New Zealand 293 and 348 for seven; England at 440 for nine, declared.

Local medical groups and individual doctors are taking a serious view of what is said to be an increased amount of pseudo-medical representations of "home remedies" and nostrums in advertising, it was learned yesterday. The largest volume, it was noted, appears to be in mail-order advertising, and recently has appeared in other than so-called "thriller," or "sensation" types of publications.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will place on the market today $13,000,000 of new 3 per cent debentures of Columbia Gas System, Inc., due in August, 1974, at 101 1/8 to yield slightly less than 2.94 per cent.

Directors of the Dewey Almy Chemical Co. have ordered an interim dividend of 15 cents a share, payable on Aug. 8, to bring the total for the first half of this year to 50 cents a share. In the first half of 1948 dividend payments were 70 cents a share.

The balances and safeguards of our federal system sometimes make progress difficult and devious. The Maritime Commission is charged by law with the responsibility for an adequate merchant marine. It was instructed by President Truman to plan a program of passenger ship construction, in order to rectify a deficiency that gave concern to the National Military Establishment.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a union could picket the operations of one employer at another employer's premises if the premises were the actual site of a primary labor dispute.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 26 -- The historic "Church of the Presidents" on Ocean Avenue, where seven Presidents worshiped during summer vacations along the Jersey shore, has abandoned its services this summer through lack of a congregation and depleted operating funds.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- A resolution requesting President Truman to call a convention of representatives of the six nations sponsoring the Atlantic pact to explore the possibilities of imme diate federation among themselves was introduced in the Senate today by eighteen Senators and in the House by four Representatives.

Traffic and sanitation violations are hampering recreation of children on designated play streets, the clean streets committee of the Women's City Club reported yesterday at a forum in the auditorium of The New York Herald Tribune, 230 West Forty-first Street.

Parental attitudes primarily determine parent-child relationships, according to "The Dynamics of Parent-Child Relationships," by Dr. Percival Symonds, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College. His book has just been published for counselors and psychotherapists by the college's bureau of publications.

The Fawcett Building, a twenty-one-story store and office building at 67 to 73 West Forty-fourth Street, and the adjoining three-story business structure at 1140-44 Avenue of the Americas have been sold by Fawcett Publications, Inc., to the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Norman Tishman, president, reported yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 -- Audie Murphy and Wanda Hendrix (Mrs. Murphy) will play the leading roles in "Sierra" at Universal-International, the studio announced today.

" Stafford Cripps: Britain's Master Statesman," a biography originally scheduled for January publication, has been advanced by John Day to Oct. 20. Eric Estorick, the author, who was for many years Sir Stafford's secretary, has based his book on private data.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Senate's long investigation of the conduct of trials of seventy-four Nazi Elite Guards sentenced for the Malmedy massacre of nearly 200 American soldiers captured and disarmed during the Battle of the Bulge in December of 1944 was bluntly denounced in the Senate today as "a whitewash."

This is the season of the year when it becomes increasingly difficult to persuade Congress to finish its unfinished business before seeking greener (and cooler) pastures, but President Truman makes a good point when he urges the House to act on the Home Rule for the District of Columbia Bill before adjournment.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Ted Gray stopped Washington on five hits and dealt the Senators their eleventh successive defeat tonight as Detroit posted a 6-2 victory. Aaron Robinson led the Tigers' twelve-hit attack with his ninth homer and a single.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- The House Judiciary Committee today approved a bill to authorize the Justice Department to withhold bail from "undesirable aliens" who have been convicted of crimes or ordered deported.

Newbold Morris, Republican-Liberal-Fusion candidate for Mayor, attended last night a meeting of the executive committee of the City Fusion party at the Piccadilly Hotel, thanked its members for their support and described the party as a perfect vehicle for the votes of independents and Democrats dissatisfied with the leadership of their party.
QUITO, Ecuador, July 26 (AP) -- A revolt against the Government of President Galo Plaza Lasso flared and died in a matter of hours here early today.

Unable to load in Jersey City because of a dock walkout, the American Export liner Excalibur, was loaded at Pier 2, at Court Street, Brooklyn, and sailed yesterday on a forty-five day Mediterranean voyage.

NEW DELHI, India, July 26 -- A resolution by Afghanistan's National Assembly, repudiating treaties with Britain regarding tribal territories, has brought a warning from Pakistan that such a course is "very dangerous" and invites claims upon Afghan territory by Iran and the Soviet Union, the Pakistani High Commissioner's office here revealed today.
HONOLULU, July 26 -- Gov. Ingram M. Stainback today asked a joint special session of Hawaii's Legislature for power to operate the islands' docks to end the stevedore strike that began on May 1.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 26 -- Israel's immigration absorption problem, which has been one of the state's principal worries, passed its crisis this week when figures showed that the number of new arrivals now equaled the number being absorbed. For the first time since the immigration wave, the numbers immigrants camps remained static.

LONDON, July 26 -- Douglas Jay, Economic Secretary to the Treasury, declared today that "the ever insistent dollar problem" that was plaguing and perplexing Europe and most of the world would last for "many years -- perhaps fifteen or twenty years -- to come."
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt. July 26 (UP) -- Premier Hussein Sirry Pasha succeeded tonight in forming a new Cabinet.

Racking up two runs in the top of the eleventh, the Montreal All-Stars beat the Brooklyn All-Stars, 9 to 7, in the fourth sandlot game staged for the benefit of the Brooklyn Amateur Baseball Foundation at Ebbets Field last night.
BERLIN, July 26 -- During a brief meeting held this afternoon the Deputy Military Governors of the four occupying nations agreed to a protocol for future discussions of quadripartite problems.
HAMILTON, N. Y., July 26 -- American private capital was reported prepared today to invest as much as $2,000,000,000 annually in foreign countries.
COWES, Isle of Wight, July 26 (AP) -- A ten-engined, 140-ton flying boat, which its makers claim is the biggest in the world, was unveiled here today.
NANKING, July 26 (AP) -- The Chinese Communist high command has ordered its armies to capture the Nationalist provisional capital of Canton before Aug. 15, it was reported authoritatively today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Senate, by a vote of 41 to 37, added $74,000,000 this evening to the $3,628,380,000 recommended by its Appropriations Committee for keeping the Marshall Plan in action through its second year.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,484, against 1,892 last week and 1,025 in the corresponding week last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 666 arrivals yesterday compared with 818 last Tuesday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 26 -- The fifty-ninth annual invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club started this morning with an entry of fifty players headed by the National champion and defending Cup holder. Richard Gonzales of Los Angeles. At the end of the busiest opening day in memory, the field had been reduced to sixteen.

The Red Cross blood program has "a job to do in raising health levels, particularly among the coming generation," Read Admiral Ross T. McIntire, national administrator of the program, said yesterday at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

I feel that it is my duty to join the large number of your readers who will deplore the bitter and unjust attack made upon Mrs. Roosevelt, as reported in your issue of July 23, because of her comments on Federal aid to education. It is not for me to seek to defend Mrs. Roosevelt against the unworthy charges made against her.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- The Dodgers didn't have to wait for the result of the Cardinals' game tonight to find out whether they would remain in second place after the Cubs had finished with them this afternoon.
BUFFALO, N. Y., July 26 (AP) -- Remington Rand, Inc., told its stockholders today that general business "has already hit rock bottom and will turn upward."
A work relief program to clean up littered vacant lots was recommended yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on Unity.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Truman told a group of visiting German and Austrian journalists today that the United States had a "great many wonderful newspapers" and expressed hope that they had received some good out of them.

The increasingly popular practice of combining two or more different woods in one piece of furniture is illustrated by the new group of designs from California that is the highlight of the midsummer furniture show at McCreery's.

Scoring unnamed and "uninformed critics" who "have recently voiced loud expression of 'phony' alarm about the growth of life insurance," Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, said yesterday that "they should be just as alarmed about the growth of the United States because the one has paced the other."

ALBANY, July 26 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey acted tonight to break the deadlock over leases between the Port of New York Authority and the major airlines that had blocked full use by the airlines of Idlewild, the New York International Airport.

TOKYO, July 26 -- Governmental and business circles are greatly concerned over the prospect that tax revisions may be considerably delayed. They have gained this impression from reports that Carl S. Shoup chief of the United States tax mission, is not satisfied with the Bank of Japan price indices as a basis for permitting corporations to revalue their fixed assets.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Thurman Arnold, former chief of the Justice Department's Anti-Trust Division, told Congress today he would let unions have monopolies of the labor supply but would define and limit their legitimate objectives under the anti-trust laws.

Ethel Merman will be starred in a new comedy radio series over the National Broadcasting Company's network, starting Sunday, from 9:30 to 10 P. M. The program will be built around situations which closely parallel the actual experiences of the singer and comedienne in her entertainment career.
Mrs. Martha Jule Beck, one of the two defendants in the "lonely hearts" murder trial, testified yesterday that she had tried to commit suicide six times in the last year and a half.

The first "off-hours" educational and vocational training program for personnel of the Naval Air Training Command will be started next Monday at Pensacola, Fla., it was announced yesterday by Capt. Maurice M. Witherspoon, retired Navy chaplain and newly-appointed director of the project.
DETROIT, July 26 -- Frank Murphy, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, died virtually a "penniless man," his brother, George, a judge of the Recorder's Court here, said today.
GENEVA, July 26 -- United States plans to aid the development of economically backward countries are merely a new form of colonialism, the Soviet Union charged today.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has sent to Cardinal Spellman a four-page letter in reply to his statement that her writings on the Barden Federal aid-to-education bill revealed her as anti-Catholic and discriminatory, it was disclosed yesterday.

AMONG the newspaper men who perished in that fatal plane crash near Bombay was George Moorad, an able and widely experienced foreign correspondent. His untimely death robbed the world of journalism of a young and talented member and deprived Mr. Moorad of the pleasure of seeing the publication of his second book, "Lost Peace in China,"* which is now published.

Officials of the Philco Corporation are hoping to increase television sales by door-to-door selling and a new promotional stunt to encourage the accumulation of a down payment. This disclosure was made yesterday by Raymond B. George, sales promotion manager, at the first showing of the company's new lines in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

More than ninety exporters engaged in South American trade endorsed a resolution yesterday, at a meeting of the American-Brazilian Trade Council, petitioning the United States Government to take appropriate steps to liquidate $150,000,000 Brazilian dollar indebtedness at the earliest possible moment.

" Come to the Stable," a comedy about two penniless nuns from France who manage to build a hospital for children in the little town of Bethlehem, Conn., will have its premiere tonight at the Rivoli Theatre. Loretta Young and Celeste Holm are co-starred in the film, produced by Twentieth Century-Fox from a story written for the screen by Clare Boothe Luce.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 26 -- Mrs. W. C. Bernard of the Fresh Meadow Club shot 83 -- 13 -- 70 to win the low net prize during the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Garden City Country Club today.

TOKYO, July 26 (UP) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today that the known death toll in the typhoon that hit Okinawa was two, with the death of a Filipino construction worker who died of injuries received in the storm Saturday.
Modification of the Government's rule requiring use of synthetic rubber in the manufacture of rubber products firmed prices in natural rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 26 -- Mrs. Gordon McGrath of Piping Rock and Mrs. A. B. McFadden of Meadow Brook scored 34, 38 -- 72 to finish in a first-place tie with Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry, Meadow Brook, and Mrs. A. K. Atkinson Jr., Creek, 36, 36 -- 72, in the opening round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association partners' four-ball thirty-six-hole handicap tournament, at the Creek Club today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 26 -- Dr. John Howard Lathrop, Unitarian minister of Brooklyn, N. Y., declared on his arrival from Amsterdam by air tonight that reports he was going to investigate the church situation in Czechoslovakia were "nothing but rumors" and untrue.
Public and private agencies concerned with poliomyelitis rallied yesterday to combat what Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard called "a mild epidemic."

LAKE SUCCESS, July 26 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie has flatly rejected a demand by the Czech Government to strike off twenty-four Czech employes of the United Nations from the quota permitted Prague under the geographical hiring system, it was disclosed today

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 26 -- An offer by Local 401, United Electrical. Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, to have its officers sign non-Communist affidavits in accordance with the Taft-Hartley Act if the Singer Manufacturing Company agrees to ease its stand on "standards," the incentive pay system and major issue in the eighty-seven-day-old strike at the huge sewing machine plant, was rejected today by the company.

SHANGHAI, July 26 -- The list of casualties mounted to at least twenty-nine dead today as Shanghai surveyed the extensive damage caused when a sixty-mile-an-hour typhoon combined with high tides to inundate large portions of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UP) -- Federal anti-trust officials were upset today over admission of Remington Rand, Inc., to the international suit over the stock of General Aniline and Film Corporation, a pre-war subsidy of the huge German munitions organization, I. G. Farben.

Harris H. Murdock, chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals, renewed yesterday his attack on the proposed amendments to the zoning law that would give the City Planning Commission power to pass on individual applications to build public garages or establish parking lots for more than 200 cars.

Policies of state, county and city purchasing agents throughout the country are being revised to take advantage of recession price and supply trends, it was disclosed here yesterday in a report of the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing, Inc., Washington, D. C. Now policies in six out of fourteen purchasing departments reported upon require venders to give municipal or governmental buyers the same price reductions extended to industrial buyers on purchased items.

Ninety-nine tanned and healthy youths eager to see New York sprang down the gangplanks, said the story in this newspaper the other day describing the arrival at the Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn of a hundred Reserve Officers Training Corps members aboard two Navy ships, out of Newport News, Va.

It was like looking in the mirror yesterday for James W. Packman, 60-year-old male nurse, of 114 West 238th Street, the Bronx. Striding down the gangway of the Queen Mary he saw his own image, even to sturdy build, sandy hair, brown suit and hornrimmed spectacles.

ROME, July 26 -- The Italian Cabinet met today and empowered Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza to reject the Soviet protest note that accused Italy of having violated the Italian peace treaty by joining the North Atlantic pact.
ABOARD THE ILE DE FRANCE, July 26 -- The French liner Ile de France will steam slowly into New York harbor at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow to claim her place among the produest of Atlantic queens.

LONDON, July 26 -- The second day of London's autumn and winter fashion previews saw exhausted manikins in furs and winter coats envying fashion writers who had, almost without exception, brought fans to salons to combat the continuing heat wave.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 -- Andy Hansen had a couple of weak moments at Forbes Field tonight in his second start of the campaign. In a sympathetic display the power in the Giants' line-up suddenly went limp, so their bid to get out of the second division underwent a jarring rebuff as the Pirates crushed them, 4 to 1, before an overflow gathering of 35,041 overheated fans.

Five East Side youths decided to go for a cooling swim in the East River yesterday afternoon, but before their swim was over a tugboat, a fireboat, a police launch and a Coast Guard cutter had raced to their rescue and a Police Department airplane had been alerted.

As head of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice from 1938 to 1943 Thurman Arnold was not only an energetic foe of business monopoly; he was largely responsible for developing the philosophy toward monopoly that prevails today in the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission.

LONDON, July 26 -- The threat of unrest on Britain's nationalized railways seemed to have eased slightly today after a nine-hour meeting here between George Isaacs, Minister of Labor, his top aides and a deputation from the powerful National Union of Railwaymen, which is seeking higher wages.

Great Britain's reduction of imports may be a necessary immediate step but Britain can only solve its monetary problems by selling more to the United States and buying more from this country, Walter Nash, Finance Minister and Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand, said yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 26 -- The people's republic of Czechoslovakia, in its present dispute with the Roman Catholic Church, is seeking to solve the "medieval" problem of clerical interference in internal government policies, Zdenek Fierlinger, acting head of the state, told this correspondent today.

Reduction of motor vehicle accident hazards as a result of a 300 per cent increase in expenditures for projects this year in the state highway system was forecast yesterday by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- Selling developed in all grains on the Board of Trade today and the markets showed no tendency to rally, final trades being about at the bottom. Bearish sentiment was created by a lack of mill buying in wheat and and a report of the Department of Agriculture showing record stocks of corn and oats in all positions in the country on July 1.

NEW CASTLE, N. H., July 26 (AP) -- Stricter enforcement of the rule prohibiting defensive holding was asked of the nation's football officials today by the National Association of Collegiate Commissioners.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 26 -- Not only are drought conditions persisting in many parts of the South African Union, but reports from most areas south of the Sahara show that the calamity threatens to become continent-wide. Africa generally is suffering from the worst drought in 100 years.

Today our readers "write" this column. Herewith a handful of some of the most interesting inquiries addressed to this department recently, covering, among other things, the opening of clams for a party dinner, the making of elderberry wine at home and the pressure canning of tomatoes. Working out the answers enlarges not only readers' knowledge, but in many cases our own, too.

A novel touch to the fall showing of fur and cloth coats yesterday at I. J. Fox was the glimpse of the original canvases presented at the opening of the collection. Stress was laid on cape detail, flange folds that curved across the front or back extending down into the sleeves, wide rippling revers, luxurious collars and pocket detail.

Injury No. 45 for the Yankees, who already have clinched the disability title in the American League, bobbed up Monday night on the big toe of Tommy Henrich's right foot, it was learned yesterday. It is unlikely that Old Reliable, currently first baseman of the league leaders, will be available for at least a week.

With raw cotton prices only about 12 per cent below their 1948 peak, the decrease in the price of cotton textiles has been almost entirely at the expense of mill margins, according to an analysis of market conditions by the Cotton Textile Institute.

Net income of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and its subsidiaries for the twelve months to June 30, amounted to $36,730,280, equal to $2.37 a share, compared with $34,590,726, or $2.06 a share, in the preceding twelve months, it was announced yesterday.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 26 -- President Jose Figueres officially confirmed today that he would shortly resign the leadership of the junta Government and head a new "national coalition" party at the Congressional elections next October.

United Medical Service enrolled 37,093 new members in June, it was announced yesterday by its president, Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, making New York's Blue Shield Plan the largest voluntary medical care plan in the world. Service membership now totals 1,410,899, an increase of 48 per cent since June last year. Dr. Heyd expressed hope that the system would not be superseded by a compulsory governmental one.
TARANCON, Spain, July 26 -- A gigantic explosion wrecked the Tarancon military arsenal today, destroying dozens of near-by buildings and trapping screaming residents in the wreckage.

A new isolation ward for the city's dog population suffering from distemper, a project long in contemplation at the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals, 350 Lafayette Street, will be a reality by fall.

Prison sentences ranging from six months to ten years and fines totaling $69,500 were imposed yesterday by Judge Louis Goldstein in Kings County Court on an association of plastering contractors and nine individuals.

ROME, July 26 -- Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza and United States Ambassador James C. Dunn today exchanged instruments of ratification of the Italian-United States treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation concluded last year.

SHANGHAI, July 26 -- The attempt of Randall Gould, American Editor of the Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury, to close down the paper reached a new crisis today as workers held him in his office to enforce a demand that he abide by a Military Control Commission ruling that he must continue to pay wages until it is "settled" whether the paper will close down.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Industry is viewing with concern new activity at the Labor Department in connection with the determination of minimum wages to be paid for work on Government purchases of $10,000 or more.

Earnings of the Gulf Oil Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries declined to approximately $49,476,000 in the first six months this year from $77,124,000 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 (AP) -- The Williams-Bolanos lightweight championship fight last Thursday night netted the Lou Costello Jr. Foundation $18,450 out of gross gate receipts of $108,297, it was announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 26 -- Jack Patroni, Apawamis pro, and Romeyn Scribner, golf captain at Apawamis, combined for a 62 that won, the Westchester County Golf Association's best-ball pro-amateur tourney at the Knollwood Country Club today after a match of cards.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 26 -- The last two of three preliminary elimination races in the annual Long Island Sound junior girls championship series for the Gregory Taylor Trophy were sailed today off Southport Harbor, and the Pequot Yacht Club's title defenders topped five qualifiers for the final set of four races beginning today.

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- Louis Segal, president of the Segal Lock and Hardware Company of (395 Broadway) New York City, said today two stockholders' groups are seeking to gain control of the firm in separate actions.

NEWARK, N. J., July 26 (AP) -- The Newark Bears put at least a temporary cooler on the Rochester Red Wings' pennant drive tonight by scoring a 5-4 victory, with Pat Seerey's two-run homer in the seventh providing the margin of victory.
PARIS, July 26 -- The British Government now estimates Britain's dollar deficit for the year that began July 1, for purposes of Marshall Plan aid, at $1,518,000,000.

PARIS, July 26 -- A sincere and lasting reconciliation between France and Germany as future partners in a federated Europe was described as a necessary condition to peace by Gen. Joseph - Pierre Koenig, French military governor in Germany, in a statement made public today.
HALIFAX, N. S., July 26 (AP) -- Eleven yachts, led by the Valkyrie of Marblehead, Mass., have completed the 366-mile annual racing classic from Marblehead-to-Halifax.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 27 -- The House of Commons, beset by exceptional heat and fatigue, rose a few minutes before 1 o'clock this morning after having been in session more than thirty hours, except for an intermission of two hours and twelve minutes.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 26 (AP) -- University of Virginia officials said tonight the school had again rejected the National Collegiate Athletic Association's "sanity code."

LONDON, July 26 -- The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, the supreme court of the British Empire, dismissed today the appeal of the Australian Government from the judgment of the Australian High Court that its act nationalizing banking was unconstitutional.

SAINT JOHN, N. B., July 26 (AP) -- The defending champion, Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, and Dick Chapman of Osterville, Mass., advanced easily today to the third round in the Canadian amateur golf championship, but a little-known Quebec player provided most of the thrills.

Sixteen-year-old Gil Stah of the Queens Central Y. M. C. A. rolled up a total of 271.2 points to easily win the 3-meter low-board fancy diving championship, a feature of the junior Metropolitan A.A.U. swimming meet held in conjunction with the Brooklyn public parks title competition at McCarren Park yesterday. Steve Mitakis of New York City, with 263.8, was runner-up.

Veteran bond men long hardened to winning or losing bond issues at deadline bidding by the way the decimals fall were amazed yesterday that the two rival syndicates bidding for the last 1949 issue of bonds for New York City-aided housing came up at bidding time with the same interest cost to the fourth decimal point.

LONDON, July 26 -- Mainly as a result of the raising of the school-leaving age by one year, the number of pupils in Britain's public supported schools increased by more than 320,000 in 1948 as compared with the previous year, the Ministry of Education reported today. The school-leaving age was raised by Parliament after the end of the war to fifteen.

BOSTON, July 26 -- Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer completed today a twenty-four-hour "trouble shooting" survey of the New England economic scene and headed back for Washington by air with four specific proposals for stimulating business here.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 26 -- Aubrey S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, said today that Israel would ask the Security Council to restrict shipments of arms to the Near East despite the conclusion of armistice agreements between Israel and the Arab countries that took part in the recent fighting.
DETROIT, July 26 (AP) -- My Sweetie tonight joined Jack Schafer's Such Crust I and Stanley Dollar's Skip-a-Long as the third United States entry for the Harmsworth Trophy races Friday and Saturday.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the House today passed the anti-poll tax bill:

Ernest Bevin's recent allusion to the United States as "a welfare state" is likely to be resented by many citizens who look upon our country as the paragon of capitalism and a haven of free economic enterprise.

PARIS, July 26 -- The Cabinet reached a compromise tonight on the question of vacation bonuses for employes of the National Social Security system, thus easing considerable strain, caused by the bonus measure, on the cohesion of the governmental majority.

MUNICH, Germany, July 26 (AP) -- Dr. Josef Mueller resigned as Bavarian Minister of Justice today in protest against United States Military Government intervention in the prosecution of Bavaria's political stormy petrel, Dr. Alfred Loritz.

New models shown for the first time in New York by television manufacturers attracted hundreds of dealers yesterday at the music industry trade show and convention in the New Yorker Hotel. Most manufacturers agreed, however, that dealers are showing extreme caution in placing television orders, even though the new models carry lower price tags.

The three parcels of land at Long Beach assessed at $203,760 and sold by the Long Island Rail Road for $12,000 are turning into a white elephant because of the obstinacy of the Long Beach City Council, the purchaser's lawyer said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The House approved today and sent to the Senate a compromise bill creating twenty-seven Federal judgeships.

The Transport Workers Union, CIO, announced that it would reply today to the demands of Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private bus industry, that it give him a chance to straighten out disputes before strikes were called. Mr. Kheel had threatened to resign unless both companies and union accepted his proposal.

Release of the first series of public service ads prepared by the Advertising Council with the cooperation of a group representing retailers, media and mat services was announced yesterday. The series consists of eleven ads on the economic system, radio spot announcements and a fact sheet for creation of original ads.

Theodore W. Kheel, impartial chairman of the private bus industry, won a victory yesterday when the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and four private bus companies answered his threat to resign unless they agreed to adopt three measures he suggested, by yielding to his request.

Piano manufacturers exhibiting their lines at the music industry trade show and convention in the New Yorker Hotel are optimistic concerning fall prospects, it was learned yesterday. Almost all dealers visiting the show have cleaned out their piano inventories in the last few months and are in a position to buy, according to manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 20, the Federal Reserve Board reportd today:

PARIS, July 27 -- Both European and United States officials dealing with European recovery said today that the increased estimate of British dollar shortage for the current year, though submitted to the European Marshall Plan Council here, presented a problem that exceeded both the resources and scope of the Marshall Plan Organization.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The House Banking and Currency Committee said today it would ask the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to disclose circumstances and amounts of loans it has made to the Lustron Corporation of Columbus, Ohio.
I want to congratulate you and THE TIMES on your editorial of July 19 on European unity.

PANAMA, July 27 (UP) -- President Domingo Diaz Arosemena was reported to be in an "extremely grave condition" tonight after suffering another relapse and members of his family were summoned to his bedside.

FORT WORTH, Texas, July 27 -- Thirty-eight competitors, all under 20 years old and from fifteen different states, in addition to eight from Canada, started play today in the fourth junior champ ionship tournament arranged by the United States Chess Federation.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Following is the vote that had the effect of scuttling an amendment in the foreign aid money bill that would have frozen a portion of the funds for the purchase of United States surplus farm products. Technically the vote overturned a ruling by Vice President Alben W. Barkley that the amendment should not be barred on the ground it amounted to legislation in an appropriation bill.

I should like to comment on Miss Bachrach's letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 22, condemning the stand of the National Education Association that Communists be excluded from the teaching profession.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Successful isolation and quantity production for the first time of ACTH, the life-giving hormone from the pituitary gland recently found at the Mayo Clinic to bring back to normal patients crippled by rheumatoid arthritis, was announced here today by the Armour Laboratories.

A new low, fair-trade price of $29.95 for its full-size bed blanket will be the basis of a new fall promotion by the General Electric Supply Corporation on its electric automatic blankets, it was announced yesterday. The program will be supported by dealer cooperative advertising, radio and newspaper group advertising, it was said by James F. Galloway, manager of traffic appliances.

NEW DELHI, India, July 27 -- Dr. Syama Prasad Mookerjee, Minister for Industry and Supply, told a gathering of industrialists today that the Government's industrial policy was designed to afford full scope to private enterprise to operate in a large sector of industrial activities.

H. L. Bradbury has been appointed manager of railway sales for the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, Union, N. J. Walton B. St. John has been named general sales manager of the aircraft section, Aeronca Aircraft Corporation, Middletown, Ohio.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 27 -- Arthur Larsen of San Francisco, Tony Trabert of Cincinnati and Felicisimo Ampon of the Philippines were unexpected casualties today in the fifty-ninth annual invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

GENEVA, July 27 -- The Soviet forced labor system is far more highly developed than anything known under the Czars, if data in the hands of the British and United States Governments can be relied upon.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 27 -The annual Turf Charity Ball of the Monmouth Park Jockey Club of which Amory L. Haskell is president, will be held on Saturday night at the clubhouse. Various divertisements have been planned for the event

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Three Republican Representatives today introduced a bill to provide Federal aid to education on a basis of need, as advocated by former President Hoover, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, and Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 27 -- The Ford Motor Company and the Israeli Government ended two months of negotiation today with an agreement that will bring an initial consignment of $4,000,000 worth of cars, trucks and parts to this country.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Escaping the doldrums that have held them in thrall for the last four games, the Dodgers moved with briskness and authority to a 7-3 victory over the Cubs today before a Wrigley Field throng of 32,262, all save 2,200 boys being cash customers.

General Motors Corporation produced a record number of motor vehicles in the second quarter of this year for the highest net sales in any three-month period in the company's history, according to the report of Alfred P. Sloan Jr.,
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Recently -- and perhaps temporarily -- the National Military Establishment, storm center of inter-service frictions, has developed a somewhat smoother working team.
PLYMOUTH, N. H., July 27 -- The American Friends Service Committee Seminar took special note of temperature in the nineties here tonight by celebrating Christmas.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 27 (AP) -- A suit charging Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., with wasting assets was dismissed today by Chancellor William W. Harrington.

Failings in the present system of business education were sharply criticized yesterday by speakers at the tenth annual Summer Session Business Education Conference held by New York University's School of Education.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 27 -- South Africa, whose monetary reserves have fallen to one-quarter of last year's, must undergo "a substantial measure of austerity," Michael H. de Kock, governor of the Reserve Bank, warned today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The board of directors of the American Society of Newspaper Editors condemned today the acceptance of state government jobs by some Illinois newspaper men between 1941 and 1949.
MILAN, Italy, July 27 (AP) -- Italian police hurled stones and used threats of arrest to drive away photographers who tried today to get pictures of Winston Churchill taking a swim.
Riverdale Builders, Inc., bought a plot of land 140 by 187 feet on South Broadway, Yonkers, N. Y., from Romeo Vellozzi. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

A suit for $100,000 damages for injuries suffered eighteen years ago by an infant through exposure to radium was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court when Mount Sinai Hospital and two physicians moved to dismiss the complaint on the ground that it did not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.

HONOLULU, July 27 (AP) -- CIO stevedores, on strike eighty-eight days, will go back to work long enough to unload four barges from the West Coast and a motorship. Henry Schmidt of the International Longshoremen's and Warehouse-men's Union, said today that arrangements had been made with shipping agents to handle the five cargoes.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 27 -- The Roman Catholic Church in Czechoslovakia is now engaged in preparing a secret underground resistance against government efforts to "gain control of" its organization because the quarrel between followers of the Vatican and followers of communism has gone so far that "there is now no possibility of an entente with the state."

It was pretty hard for a sports page reader to miss knowing that Cal Johnson caught a 67 1/2-pound muskellunge in Lac Court d'Oreilles in Wisconsin last Sunday to establish a world record because the story, embellished by a picture, got considerable attention in the metropolitan press.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 -- Looking like a man who had stumbled fully clothed into a turkish bath, Wes Westrum strode to the plate in the seventh inning in the steaming cauldron that was Forbes Field today with instructions to bunt, and failed.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 27 -- Mrs. Joseph E. Davis and her daughter, Mrs. J. B. Balding of The Creek Club, annexed the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother-and-daughter championship with a score of 43, 40 -- 83 over the Westchester Hills course today.
The city of Detroit, Mich., announced yesterday that it will receive bids until Aug. 3 on $4,500,000 of street railway bonds dated Aug. 15, 1949, and due from Aug. 15, 1951 to 1968.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday and final prices were 1 to 5 points net higher on the day.
BELFAST, July 27 (AP) -- Bobby Locke of South Africa was one stroke back of the leaders in third place today at the end of the first round in the Irish open golf championship.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 27 -- As a result of a disagreement between Herbert C. Pell, former United States Minister to Portugal, and the National Portuguese Museum-Pell Foundation, Inc., the collection of Portuguese art presented by Mr. and Mrs. Pell to the foundation in 1946 may be withdrawn.
A drop of 33 per cent in net income and 18 per cent in operations during the second quarter of this year, compared with the first, was reported yesterday by the Republic Steel Corporation.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 27 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century, by adding an 83 to her first two rounds of 78, 79 for a fifty-four-hole total of 240, won the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy, emblematic of the medal play championship of the Westchester and Fairfield counties, over the East course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP) -- The Cardinals took full advantage of Hank Borowy's wildness to push across three runs in each of the first two innings for a 7-to-3 victory over the Phillies tonight. Two home runs accounted for the tallies off the offerings of Cardinal hurler Red Munger, who scored his ninth victory of the season.

Naples is 11 years old. Until last Saturday she had never been in a hospital to stay. Yesterday she sniffed the antiseptic smells of Mount Sinai with the air of one who did not find them good. Still, she was not complaining.
Wreckers will come to 2135 Powell Avenue, the Bronx, this morning and start demolishing Trinity Lutheran Church, a house of worship that has served its congregation for twenty-three years.
CINCINNATI, July 27 (AP) -- The Braves had to travel 13 innings today to subdue the seventh-place Reds, 9 -- 7 and it was Mary Rickert's two-run homer in the fourth extra frame that won the game.

Thousands of Queens residents were delayed while going home from work in the rush hours yesterday afternoon when violent thunderstorms flooded the Queens lines of the IND subway, stopping all service on the system for one hour and three-quarters.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Detroit battered Washington pitching for thirty-two hits in a twilight-night double-header, but gained only a split as the Senators captured the firs game, 7 -- 6, to snap an eleven-game losing streak. The Tigers compiled seventeen blows behind Freddie Hutchinson's four-hit hurling to take the second game, 11 -- 0.

BERLIN, July 27 -- The four commandants of Berlin continued today to toy cautiously and courteously with marginal problems afflicting this divided city in their second meeting to "normalize" Berlin's life.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 27 -- Mrs. Gordon McGrath of Piping Rock and Mrs. A. B. McFadden of Meadow Brook turned in a second-round 34, 35, four strokes under par, to finish with 72, 69 -- 141 in winning the Women's Long Island Gold Association partner's four-ball best-ball thirty-six-hole medal play tournament at the Creek Club today.
HAMILTON, N. Y., July 27 -- Norman Thomas urged today that the United States use its moral influence to win the reduction of military forces in every country to the "police level."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27 -- The text of a speech that Mao Tzetung, Chinese Communist chairman, delivered to the party in Yenan in May, 1941, was published today in the July issue of the Yugoslav political monthly Thirty Days.
The text of Mrs. Roosevelt's letter to Cardinal Spellman follows:...
OSLO, July 27 (AP) -- A strong United States track and field squad trailed Scandinavia, 104 1/2 to 78 1/2, tonight after the first of three nights of competition in the "Little Olympics."

Leon Fleischer, pianist, made his Stadium debut last night with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Pierre Monteux. The extremely gifted young artist undertook the formidable task of performing both the "Symphonic Variations" of Cesar Franck and the Liszt Concerto in A major, and accomplished this feat with signal success, his work as soloist in each of the masterpieces maintaining a lofty level of achievement.

WINNIPEG, July 27 (Canadian Press) -- The Winnipeg Grain Exchange today announced that it will continue trading in coarse grain futures after the Canadian Wheat Board takes over the handling of oats and barley Aug. 1.

In what is believed to be the first instance of its kind, twenty-one Negro drama students and three members of the drama faculty of Howard University in Washington, will tour leading Norwegian cities, offering a series of performances of plays by Henrik Ibsen.

ALBANY, July 27 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced today that immediate steps would be taken to give farmers freer use of the highways for oversized farm vehicles. The announcement followed a conference with agricultural leaders and state department heads.
A potentially great thoroughbred raced for the first and last time at Jamaica yesterday.

Out of the heat of Washington, and the trough of inaction into which Congress seemed for a time to have bogged down, some welcome and constructive measures are emerging. The most recent of these, now lacking only formal Senate approval of a conference report already accepted by the House, is a bill to create twenty-seven new Federal judgeships.

The price of lead advanced 1/4 cent here yesterday to 14 1/2 cents a pound, it was reported by leading smelters and refiners. This was the second increase of 1/4 cent a pound this week and was followed by price rises for lead products by National Lead Company and other processors.

Any Fusion administration must have the votes of the Borough President of Manhattan if it is to be assured of a proper working majority in the Board of Estimate, Newbold Morris, Republican-Fusion-Liberal candidate for Mayor, said in an address last night.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- While current personal income and retail sales levels have declined from the peaks attained at the end of 1948, they compare favorably with figures of one year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today. The main shrinkage in business activity, it reported, took place in manufacturing in the past twelve months.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 18 -- In preparation for the implementation of the new constitution of the federal republic of Germany (the West German state), special committees of the existing German agencies are seeking to work out an organizational plan for the executive ministries in the new government.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The military services offered today to drop their mail-order retail business in metropolitan centers, but a Congressional group said that it was not enough.

SHANGHAI, July 27 -- The confinement of Randall Gould, United States editor of The Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury, and Charles Miner, representative of the publisher, entered its second day this afternoon with the workers who held them providing only a "starvation" ration.

Brooklyn Union Gas Company raised the dividend for payment on Sept. 1 to 40 cents a common share, compared with 25 cents paid in March and June, the latter two declarations after a lapse since August, 1947.

Dennison Duble, 57-year-old resigned banking official of Cincinnati and self-admitted vital cog in the rigging machinery of an interstate policy ring, arrived under guard at La Guardia Airport late yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Edward L. Ryerson, Inland Steel Company chairman, said today the substitution of politically appointed fact-finding boards for collective bargaining was "not a good thing for the country." This comment on President Truman's recent maneuver to forestall a steel strike was made in a letter to stockholders accompanying the report of net income amounting to $7,033,304, or $1.43 a share, for the second quarter.
ATLANTA, July 27 (AP) -- Georgia lawmakers put a final, battered stamp of approval today on a $20,500,000 new tax plan pushed by Gov. Herman Talmadge.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, parent company of the Long Island Rail Road issued a long and strongly worded statement yesterday charging Nassau County authorities with misrepresenting facts and playing politics. At the same time it denied any impropriety in sales of real estate by the Long Island and said it welcomed a thorough but "non-political" inquiry into its relations with the subsidiary road.

HONG KONG, July 27 (UP) -- Nationalist Government sources said today that Gen. Pai Chung-hsi, Central China commander, had evacuated Hengyang, his latest headquarters, as the Communist drive south gathered momentum.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- Former Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts today called on local committees throughout the nation to seek Congressional support for the Atlantic Union Resolution introduced in Congress Wednesday.
Just what would have been the outcome had the second game of the series between the Yankees and Indians gone its allotted distance at the Stadium yesterday will remain an unsolved problem.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The teen-agers showed in the national junior amateur championship today that they can shoot sub-par golf, too.

The Fentriss Estate, represented by the Chase National Bank, sold the five-story apartment building on a lot 18.9 by 100.5 feet at 313 East Fifty-first Street to a New Yorker who plans to alter the house and occupy one of the apartments.

"Scene of the Crime," a cops-and-robbers melodrama from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will open this morning at the Capitol. Van Johnson, Arlene Dahl, Gloria De Haven, Tom Drake and Leon Ames head the cast. . . . The new film at the Palace, starting today, will be "The Big Cat," an outdoor melodrama produced by Eagle Lion and featuring Lon McCallister, Peggy Ann Garner and Preston Foster.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Employment in non-agricultural establishments rose slightly from May to June, but there was nothing resembling a new trend.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- Julius and Philip Epstein, the brother-screen writers, have been signed by Samuel Goldwyn to write and direct the screen adaptation of "Folly and Farewell," a 1936 Saturday Evening Post story by Richard Sherman, which Goldwyn has owned for more than a decade.

The State University of New York has approved a priority list of twenty-seven construction projects totaling $24,723,298 for fourteen state-supported institutions of higher learning, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the university.

LONDON, July 27 -- A heavy bout of selling today drove down British Government securities to the lowest point since the black days of Dunkerque in 1940. Official stocks slumped under mounting pressure and selling continued after the official closing of the Stock Exchange.

LONDON, July 27 -- Hector McNeil, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, said in the House of Commons today that the Soviet Government had consistently evaded attempts to get the United Nations to investigate forced labor.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A southern coal operator testified today the union-imposed short work week increased mining costs 69 cents a ton in a group of mines that were surveyed, and that some of these costs would have to be passed on to the consumer.

The Ford Motor Company, Henry Ford 2d and four other defendants in a $251,100,000 anti-trust suit by Harry Ferguson, Irish-born inventor, denied in Federal Court yesterday that they had infringed his tractor patents or conspired to destroy his business of distributing Ford-manufactured tractors.

SAINT JOHN, N. B., July 27 (AP) -- Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, the defending champion, was eliminated from the Canadian amateur golf tournament today by Tommy Riddell of Quebec, one up in 19 holes.

A CASUAL admiration for the color of a locality, a cheerful general intention of being entertaining, and a merciful brevity, bring this morning's novels, Mr. Preen's Salon,"* by Robert Tallant, and "Vigilante,"+ by Richard Summers, together.

LONDON, July 27 -- British Treasury officials in London emphasized today that the British memorandum recently presented to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation in Paris was not a bid for aid from the United States in Britain's current dollar crisis but a realistic estimate of the sterling area's dollar deficit for 1949-50.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- The president of one of three Chicago brokerage firms charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with stock market manipulation today denied the charge.

MOSCOW, July 27 -- The leading philosophical journal of the Soviet Union, Problems of Philosophy, has called upon Soviet psychologists to undertake wide-scale critical discussion of basic psychological problems and "the tasks and trend" of their whole work.
A group of standard room units that small-scale builders may arrange easily and economically to make a variety of complete houses is the object of a research project announced yesterday.

Active trading in rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday advanced quotations 11 to 18 points. The turnover rose to 1,300 long tons, compared with slightly more than 700 tons on Tuesday. Trade and commission house buying was attributed by the trade to reports of further Government buying of natural rubber for stockpiling purposes.

The tactics of Senator McCarran's immigration subcommittee in releasing a bitter attack on the Secretary General of the United Nations by an unnamed witness can hardly be condemned too severely. The procedure is all too reminiscent of that employed by the House Un-American Activities Committee in the flamboyant days of its former chairmen, Messrs.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation's highest military authority, will start for Europe on Friday to make a first-hand diagnosis of the defense situation across the Atlantic.

BRIGHTWATERS, L. I., July 27 -- Death by violence first introduced itself to George Petit Le Brun more than fifty years ago as a means of keeping alive. Since then he has studied more illegally induced cases of rigor mortis than an undertaker.

Prince Wan Waithayakon, Ambassador from Thailand to the United States, presented a jeweled plaque yesterday afternoon to Church World Service at the headquarters of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., 156 Fifth Avenue.

Mystery surrounded yesterday an alleged assault upon S. S. Abbate, superintendent of terminals for the American Export Lines, who is now in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, recovering from an operation on a shattered kneecap. The versions given by Mr. Abbate and the investigating detective differed greatly.

PARIS, July 27 -- Rose Valois is an exponent of height in hats for the coming winter, but not in the towering cone-shaped crowns already shown by several houses. Her crowns are skull caps fitting well down toward the nape of the ate their height. Berets, moulding front.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 27 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine, reported to the Security Council today that "the military phase of the Palestine conflict is ended," and asked the Council to transfer his remaining functions to the Palestine Conciliation Commission.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Grain markets today reversed their action of yesterday and closed at the top on the Board of Trade. Buying was stimulated by reports exporters were inquiring for cash corn, oats and soybeans with intimations that 100,000 bushels of oats and 200,000 bushels of soybeans had been sold.

PARIS, July 27 -- Fourteen thousand organized seamstresses of Paris, the famous "midinettes," whose skill is one of the foundations of French pre-eminence in the field of fashions, went out on strike today after their employers' association had rejected demands for wage increases.

The Revere Realty Company, a subsidiary of the Alliance Realty Company, has obtained a first mortgage loan of $600,000 at 4 per cent for 10 years from the Union Square Savings Bank on the seven-story and six-story apartment buildings at 221-33 West Twenty-third Street and 214-26 West Twenty-fourth Street, it was announced yesterday by James Boyd, Inc., broker.

Asserting that the selection of the Democratic candidate for Borough President of Manhattan would be a test of the new leadership of Tammany, members of the Coordinating Committee of Independent Democrats sent yesterday a telegram to Mayor O'Dwyer at City Hall urging him to use his influence to get Tammany to designate a candidate whom liberal Democrats and independents would support.

Men's clothing manufacturers continue cautious in fabric commitments, with no great wave of buying resulting from the price reductions announced earlier this week on men's wear worsteds for next spring, it was reported in the clothing industry here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Secretary of State Dean Acheson in effect assured Congress today that there would be no exchange of atomic weapon information with Great Britain or Canada with out the full knowledge and, if found necessary, the approval of Congress.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development reported today a net income of $10,610,247 for the year ended June 30.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Vice President Alben W. Barkley declared tonight that "everyone in the Government from President Truman down" is anxious to reduce taxes, but added that world conditions and the country's obligations precluded any tax relief in the present session of Congress.

Last week the House rejected emphatically the Pace farm bill, a version of Agriculture Secretary Brannan's policy recommendations. Having done that, it voted to repeal the present (Aiken) law, which, although it has been on the statute books since 1948, does not actually become operative until Jan. 1, 1950.

Households planning to preserve peaches will find prices lowest next month, when heavy movements of the fruit are expected from New Jersey, Virginia, Maryland, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. According to the New Jersey Peach Industry Committee, the peak period will be from about the second week in August through the second week in September.
LONDON, July 27 -- Gallantly upholding the value of women legislators, the House of Lords approved today a motion calling for legislation to admit peeresses in their own right to sit in the house.

Wearing her new post-war dress, said to be the most expensive outfitting in maritime history, the French liner Ile de France moved majestically through New York waters yesterday to complete her first voyage as a reconverted luxury liner.

A move toward self-discipline in the New Jersey wholesale liquor trade will be made with the appointment of a trade administrator, it was learned here yesterday. The appointment will be made in the near future, it was understood. The term of office and salary has not yet been decided, it was said.

The stock market experienced considerable difficulty yesterday in holding its ground. An extension of the recovery appeared probable at the start but the list soon drifted into irregular and narrow channels and closed mixed. Price alterations in excess of a point were few and the composite rate fell 0.18 point despite the fact that stocks to register gains outnumbered those with losses.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 27 (AP) -- John L. Lewis preferred today to gamble for more wages for his soft coal miners rather than keep the contract they have for another two years.

It was humid that day, and so hot that any activity beyond a mild mental exercise clearly was dangerous. Through that heat came a letter. Written in beautiful eighteenth-century prose, it announced indignantly that a member of the household, then away at camp, had been taken with matches.

The Rubel Corporation has purchased the ice manufacturing property of the Holler Ice Manufacturing Company on Boston Road, near Dyre Avenue, the Bronx. Chambers Chambers were attorneys for the seller and Yellin Levy acted for the buyer.

Medical authorities throughout the city yesterday strengthened their first line of defense against the threat of a serious poliomyelitis outbreak. They urged housewives to watch for symptoms of polio and to protect sick children against overexertion.

Plans for consolidation of the Fulton Trust Company and the New York Trust Company, with the latter as the surviving institution, are rapidly nearing completion, it was reliably reported in financial circles yesterday. No details regarding the proposed transaction were disclosed but it is believed that it will be a merger on a cash basis.

Judge Nathan R. Sobel in Kings County Court reserved decision yesterday on the application of James A. Powers, president of the Brooklyn branch, National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, for permission to examine the minutes of a hearing before the grand jury in the fatal shooting last May of Herman Newton, 22 years old, by an off-duty patrolman.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 28 (UP) -- A typhoon that struck Okinawa Saturday and hit Shanghai three days later was revealed by an Allied headquarters report today to have been one of the most destructive on record.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 27 -- Byron Price, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, has protested to Secretary of State Dean Acheson the recent action of a Senate subcommittee in publishing testimony alleging Communist terrorism in the Secretariat, it was announced today.

NEWARK, N. J., July 27 (AP) -- Public Service Coordinated Transport reported $5,393,555 more revenue today from bus and trolley operations than it anticipated when it asked for the increased 7-cent fare.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 27 -- Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., champion of Wimbledon, set the pace for a succession of decisive victories in the opening round of the Women's Invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today.

An investment banking group headed by White, Weld Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will offer today a new issue of $15,000,000 of Illinois Power Company's first mortgage 2 7/8 per cent bonds, due in 1979, at 100.50 to yield about 2.85 per cent. The bonds were sold by the utility company to bankers at competitive bidding on Tuesday.

SEOUL, Korea, July 27 -- Korean National Defense headquarters today reported intermittent artillery fire was being exchanged between North Korean Communist forces and South Korean troops across the Thirty-eighth Parallel at Kaesong, ancient capital city forty-five miles north of here.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 27 (AP) -- The veteran Joe Angyal of the New York Athletic Club won the first major championship of the Royal Canadian Henly Rowing Regatta today in the 145-pound quarter-mile dash.

A committee headed by Robert Moses sharply criticized the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company yesterday for allegedly failing to provide adequate parking facilities at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village.
A new method of shipping garments by air, which will bring Western markets two to five days nearer to Eastern dress manufacturers, was inaugurated yesterday by Slick Airways, Inc.

WARSAW, July 27 (AP) -- High Roman Catholic sources were silent today on the Government's announcement that it had agreed to their request for talks to settle the church-state cold war in this Communist-led country.

LONDON, July 27 -- Lester Hutchinson, Member of Parliament, who made a speaking tour of the United States in May under the auspices of Henry A. Wallace, was expelled from the Labor party today. He was the seventh legislator purged in the past fifteen months in an effort mainly to rid the party of rebellious, Left-wing, pro-Soviet elements.

LONDON, July 27 -- Henry Cotton, three-time winner of the British Open golf championship, announced tonight he would not be available to play for Britain in the Ryder Cup match against the United States. Sept. 16 and 17.
Mrs. Martha Jule Beck testified yesterday that she was alone with Mrs. Janet J. Fay just before the 66-year-old widow was bludgeoned to death last Jan. 4.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Administration rejected today the appeal of Republican foreign policy leaders that it voluntarily cut down its $1,450,000,000 program to help arm Western Europe and other non-Communist areas.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn, Democrat, of Texas, ruled in the House today that Congress did not have to pass a resolution to continue in session beyond July 31.
Hypnotic therapy was credited yesterday with restoring her memory to a housewife who apparently had been suffering from total amnesia for the last nine years.

SUMMIT, N. J., July 28 -- Suntanned Tommy Goodwin, who spends most of his time at Nassau in the Bahamas these days, captured the medal in the Metropolitan Amateur Golf Championship at the Canoe Brook Country Club today with a 36-hole total of 144.

The Propeller Club of the Port of New York has furnished to its membership a list of the representatives of the various Congressional districts in the New York area and requested that every member write to his member of Congress and urge prompt and favorable action on H. R. 5346, a bill generally referred to as the long-range shipping program.
A First Army bugler sounded the call to colors yesterday outside the new Manhattan Red Cross blood center at 70 West Fortieth Street to signal its formal opening.
BERLIN, July 27 (UP) -- Two Russian Army officers were rescued tonight from a German "lynch mob" by German and United States military police, the German police reported.

BOSTON, July 27 (AP) -- A Coast Guard inquiry into a fatal harbor collision between a freighter and a pleasure boat ended today with the conducting officer announcing evidence had been obtained to bring negligence charges against both skippers.
