TEL AVIV, Israel, July 27 -- The former Stern group commander, Nathan Friedman-Yellin, who was detained for several months in Acre prison before he was elected to the Knesset [Assembly] protested today in the Assembly against the Government's decision to establish an institution for the insane in the prison.

Kyle MacDonnell, television singing star, will return to the National Broadcasting Company network Saturday evening in a new program. "For Your Pleasure," from 8:30 to 9 o'clock. The singer has been absent from television since her Sunday night program with Earl Wrightson was canceled five weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted 15 to 10 today to extend social security coverage to some 750,000 commission workers who were exempt from the law last year.

A new pier to replace the old Grace Line terminal at West Fifteenth Street will cost the city considerably more than the original estimate, it was reported yesterday. The terminal was destroyed by fire in September, 1947.
The United Steel Workers of America, largest union in the Congress of Industrial Organizations, bowed reluctantly yesterday to the non-Communist affidavit requirement of the Taft-Hartley Law.

I was very much surprised at your editorial of July 16 on "The Bus Strike." You say, "* * * and although the root of the difficulty may well lie in the city's foolish policy preventing a further rise in fare * * *"

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- Lithe, a 9-2 shot carrying the colors of her owner-breeder, Hal Price Headley of Lexington, Ky., galloped to an easy victory in the $25,000 added Matron Handicap before 16,113 at Arlington Park today.

To yield to "demands that Federal aid to education be achieved through abolition of the Constitution's First Amendment" would be "the most abject retreat in all our history," Dr. John K. Norton, Professor of Education at Columbia University's Teachers College declared yesterday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt disavowed yesterday in a letter to Cardinal Spellman any bias against the Roman Catholic Church and affirmed her intention to speak out on public issues as she sees them no matter what opposition develops from individuals or groups.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 27 (Canadian Press) -- Australia's coal strike today moved toward a climax when the Government decided to move all available troops into the coal fields immediately, and mining union leaders scheduled mass meetings to discuss a return to work.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A rarely used parliamentary tactic, sprung after four days of consideration by the Senate of the $5,723,724,000 foreign aid appropriation bill, abruptly sent the bill back to the Appropriations Committee late today for complete review.

The troublesome question of overtime-on-overtime, which was a major factor in last winter's dock strike, has now been eliminated as a recurrent handicap to peaceful relations between dockers of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and their employers. ILA leadership had joined with employers in the maritime as well as other industries in pressing for corrective legislation.

Things turned out fine last night for 7-year-old Christine Mary Leonard, who arrived here yesterday from Scotland aboard a Scandinavian Airlines plane. But there had been times during the day when all her world seemed dark.

After a successful tour of the United States and Canada, the soccer players of the F. C. Internazionale-Milano, champions of Italy, sailed yesterday on board the steamship Mauretania of the Cunard White Star Line bound for Havre. From there they will entrain for Milan.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee pigeon-holed the Brannan farm program as such today and instructed a subcommittee to draft a new agricultural price-support bill with existing law as the basis.

I find myself puzzled and disappointed by the recent articles in the newspapers concerning the firing of Dr. Ernest Klein from the Blood and Plasma Division of New York University Hospital, following publication of an article in New York Medicine written by him, involving the possible connection between high hemoglobin and coronary thrombosis.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- United States airmen in Britain were ordered today to steer clear of Leftist mass meetings while in uniform. A Third Air Division spokesman said this was "part of our general policy of keeping out of the public eye."

More opposition was voiced yesterday at the third of a series of hearings on Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for a two-year, $150,000 survey of reclassification and wage adjustment in the city's civil service system.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Donald R. Richberg today denounced as "sheer hypocrisy" attempts by the Government to suppress monopoly in industry while it protects "monopolies developed and controlled by labor managers."

For seventy years neighborhood residents have pointed to a sidewall of 39 Beekman Place to authenticate their claim that Nathan Hale, Revolutionary War hero, had been hanged at this site overlooking the East River. Under the eaves of the five-story dwelling a large fresco in the weathered stucco facade depicts the famous spy standing between two files of British soldiery.

ROME, July 27 -- The Italian Communist party announced today that on June 30 it had 2,242,719 members, including 214,000 members of the Youth Federation, as compared with 2,115,231 members on Dec. 31, 1948.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina ruled yesterday that a defense witness at the Communist trial must give the names of party members who attended a 1945 Chicago training school.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- President Truman today increased the Russian immigration quota by eighty-six persons a year because the Soviet Union has taken over Bessarabia and parts of Bukovina under the Rumanian peace treaty.
GENEVA, July 27 (AP) -- A sixty-nation international conference decided here today that prisoners of war in any future conflict should not be forced to dig up mines and dud bombs.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 27 (AP) -- Casemate roared to the second stakes triumph of his young career today when he won Monmouth Park's $10,000 added Sapling Stakes by a length from Christopher T. Chenery's Hill Prince, the solid favorite that stumbled at the break and might have been best.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 27 -- A collective-bargaining election to determine whether Local 401 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, or a newly formed independent union should represent the employes of strikebound Singer Manufacturing Company in Elizabeth resulted in a victory tonight for the CIO union.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Jersey Central Railroad having certified to the Interstate Commerce Commission that the plan for volutanry modification of its outstanding securities, proposed a year ago as an alternative to the long-drawn-out reorganization by court action, had been accepted by more than three-quarters of the holdings, the ICC today approved the plan and certified its approval to the Federal District Court.

LONDON, July 27 (UP) -- European currency restrictions forced Benny Goodman today to cancel his proposed tour of Europe where half a dozen countries awaited anxiously to see what had happened to American music since the war.

PARIS, July 27 -- With the French Assembly's ratification of the North Atlantic treaty early today, after a night-long session, it appeared as if the Queuille Government was safe until after the summer recess.

Sure success items for a college wardrobe made up a lively fashion showing yesterday at Arnold Constable. Judged by a jury of young men, the collection ran the gamut from campus togs to pretty dance frocks.
BOSTON, July 27 (AP) -- Lefty Mel Parnell won his fourteenth game of the season for the Red Sox and his third shutout by holding the White Sox to three scattered hits today for a 6-0 victory.

A clean - cut - appearing young couple from Louisville, Ky., were charged by the police yesterday with staging a hold-up at the Music Box Bar, Broadway and Ninety-third Street, at 2:30 A. M., and stealing $152.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 27 -- Important developments in education and re-education in a "people's democracy" -- graduation of the first class of army officers recruited entirely from the ranks of workers and farmers and political courses for scientists -- were announced today.

A note of economic optimism was sounded yesterday by Leland I. Doan, president of the Dow Chemical Company in the company's fifty-second annual statement which revealed record sales and earnings for the third consecutive year. Reduced demand for many products was experienced in the closing months of the fiscal year that ended May 31, but some strengthening in others aided the over-all sales picture, he said.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined a further 895,000 barrels to 110,569,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compares with supplies of 111,464,000 barrels a week earlier and of 100,641,000 a year ago.

The General Telephone Corporation announced yesterday plans for early acquisition of the Oxnard Home Telephone Company and the Santa Paula Home Telephone Company, both in southern California and owned by Francis H. Crosby.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Leaders of American industry, education and public affairs concluded a two-day discussion with the military services today on problems affecting the welfare and morale of the armed forces.
GENEVA, July 27 -- Neue Zuercher Zeitung, one of Europe's leading newspapers, announced today that it had recalled its Prague correspondent, Dr. Hans Tutsch.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The State Department announced today that two Russian naval officers had been designated by the Soviet Government to come here for negotiations on the return of three naval icebreakers and twenty-eight frigates that Russia received under lend-lease during the war.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) -- The Athletics spotted the Browns five runs in the first inning and then came from behind twice to win the second game of the twi-night double-header, 8 -- 6, after taking the opener, 7 -- 3. The twin victory ran the A's winning streak to five straight.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (AP) -- An accusation of bribery got into the Tokyo Rose treason trial today.

Substantial progress toward the opening of an International Christian University in Japan, which will rise on the grounds of a wartime fighter plane factory, was reported yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph E. Diffendorfer, president of the Japan Christian University Foundation, who returned last week from a two-month visit to Japan.

HUMBOLDT, Tenn., July 27 -- The millionth consumer of electric power generated by the vast Tennessee homestead for twenty-six will be formally "hooked up" at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow in colorful ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- A thorough review of United States policy toward the Far East, with the aid of non-Governmental counsel, will shortly be undertaken, Secretary of State Dean Acheson announced today at his news conference.

OLATHE, Kan., July 27 (AP) -- A 25-mile-an-hour wind smashed fuselages, wrenched off delicate wings, cracked up small craft and blew others away today in the opening of outdoor competition in the National Model Airplane Meet here.

The flags and whistles and cheers that greeted the rebuilt, resplendent Ile de France on her arrival here yesterday were something more than a traditional harbor welcome. They carried the mind back, with a certain nostalgia, to those days before the war when this same ship, less sleek than now to be sure, was a queen -- or, rather, a gay and charming princess -- of the broad Atlantic.

The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday for the first half of this year a consolidated net income of $21,953,129 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $3.63 each on the 6,047,139 shares outstanding. This comparies with $36,481,282, or $6.03 a share, in the same period of 1948.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Senate Rules Committee today upheld the elections of four Senators, from West Virginia, Texas, Oklahoma and Michigan, whose seating had been contested.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UP) -- A group of Senate Republicans headed by Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, is planning to try to force action this year on liberalized displaced-persons legislation.

A representative cross-section of the men who decide the investments for millions of people, the New York Society of Security Analysts, were taken on a verbal tour behind the balance sheet of industry yesterday. Addressing the group at a downtown luncheon meeting, John L. Burns, a partner in the management consulting firm of Booz, Allen and Hamilton, said that most problems in business have grown out of success, rather than failure.

JOE LOUIS will assume a new role today, according to the word released by the build-up department of the International Boxing Club. It seems that said International Boxing Club is concerned with "selling" a heavyweight bout between Ezzard Charles and Gus Lesnevich to a far from palpitating public at the Yankee Stadium next month.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 27 (UP) -- Kirsten Flagstad, Norwegian opera star, said today she would not accept a New York Metropolitan Opera offer to sing in New York, Boston and Cleveland next March. She said her schedule was filled until 1951.

After a tumultuous debate the French National Assembly has approved ratification of the North Atlantic Treaty by the decisive vote of 398 to 187. This is better than a two-thirds majority, when only an absolute majority was necessary. In fact, since the opposition votes were cast almost entirely by Communists representing Moscow it may be said that the delegates representing France voted for the Treaty almost unanimously.
In your issue of June 14 in the column entitled Topics of The Times I read with great interest and some surprise that remarkably little is known about the origins of the Stars and Stripes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 28 (AP) -- The golfing wrecking crew took over the Keller public course today and two of their number tied for the lead in the Western open tourney at 67, five strokes under par.

Robert Haven Schauffler, author of biographies of Beethoven, Brahms and Schumann, has a new biography on Putnam's list, which will be brought out on Aug. 26. Mr. Schauffler has based "Franz Schubert: The Ariel of Music" on the recent discoveries of Prof. O. E. Deutsch, foremost Schubert researcher, correcting many misconceptions about the composer.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, today opposed President Truman's plan to give the proposed Welfare Department control over Federal health services because it "completely subordinates health and education to welfare."
The New York Society for Ethical Culture advocated yesterday that Congress eliminate from aid-to-education legislation all provisions that would grant funds to non-public and parochial schools.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 28 (AP) -- A battle loomed tonight among America's reserve officers on the air power versus sea power issue. Delegates to the Reserve Officers Association representing 11,000 Naval Reserve officers adopted a resolution criticizing the Joint Chiefs of Staff for scrapping a projected $100,000,000 super-carrier.

It was ten weeks ago yesterday that vaudeville returned to the Palace Theatre after an absence of fourteen years. Public interest in its revival was lively because of nostalgic recollections of famous Palace bills during the theatre's golden age and because of widespread publicity about the return of variety.
CHICAGO, July 28 {AP}--Today's reoort of e livestock markets here by theDepartment of Agriculture follows.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 28 (AP) -- Divisions of a six-furlong event for $7,000 to $6,000 claimers featured today's program at Monmouth Park, and Mrs. E. J. Reed's War Glance and H. C. Boorse's Donna Boorse won their respective runnings.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 28 -- Miss Barbara Bruning of Whippoorwill, 17-year-old White Plains High School senior, won the metropolitan junior girls' golf championship with a one over women's par 40, 36 -- 76 at the Westchester Hills Country Club today.

Frieda Denenmark, 17 years old, of 406 Sheffield Avenue, Brooklyn, has won one of the ten National President's Scholarships of 1949, given annually by the American Legion Auxiliary to children of dead war veterans, it was announced yesterday. Miss Denenmark will use the $600 cash grant provided under the scholarship to study at the Washington Square College of New York University.
William Gargan will be starred in a new series of adventure programs, "Martin Kane, Private Eye," which will receive separate radio and television presentations beginning next month.
Prices on the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned steady yesterday and closed 12 to 18 points net higher than on Wednesday.

Operations of the National Distillers Products Corporation and its wholly owned domestic subsidiaries in the six months ended with June, resulted in a net profit of $11,002,621 after all charges, according to the report issued yesterday.

PARIS, July 28 -- A continuing strike for higher pay by about 1 ,000 seamstresses has made almost certain delays of at least one to two days in the presentation of fall and winter collections by the Paris dressmaking houses, it was learned today.
Wharton County, Tex., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Aug. 1 on $1,000,000 of road bonds dated July 10, 1949, on March 10, 1952 to 1969, and callable on March 10, 1959.

The Bancroft Prizes, awarded annually by Columbia University for "distinguished writings in American history," have been presented this year to Samuel Eliot Morison, Professor of History at Harvard, for his "The Rising Sun in the Pacific," and to Robert E. Sherwood, author and playwright, for his "Roosevelt and Hopkins," it was announced yesterday.

DETROIT, July 28 -- General Motors Corporation will begin the construction immediately of a Diesel-electric locomotive plant in London, Ontario, and enploy 1,000 persons at capacity, C. E. Wilson, president, announced here today. The new facilities will have a capacity of one Diesel-electric locomotive per day, and will build locomotives for all classes of railway service, he said.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported increased sales and earnings for the three and six months ended on June 30, in its mid-year statement released today.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Sale of the Alliance Life Insurance Company, Chicago, to the Republic National Life Insurance Company, Dallas, for $3,600,000 has been announced. Theodore P. Beasley, president of Republic National, said an arrangement for the reinsurance of Alliance life business by the Dallas company had been approved by the Illinois insurance director and the chairman of the Texas commission.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 28 -- An exhibit of nineteenth-century paintings by Americans opened in Guild Hall here today as part of this community's activities as a center of art on the south shore of Long Island.
LONDON, July 28 -- British labor's I increasing demands for more wages were answered today with a small cut in the cost of living.
"The Girl from Jones Beach," a romantic comedy produced by Warner Brothers, will open this morning at the Strand. Ronald Reagan, Virginia Mayo (the girl) and Eddie Bracken are the principals.

Producers of both types of the long-playing records voiced their intentions yesterday to continue along present lines at a merchandising forum held in conjunction with the convention of the National Association of Music Merchants in the New Yorker Hotel.
W SHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Coul G. Strandlund said today he has "nothing to hide" from Congressional investigation of the Lustron Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, which he heads.

SEOUL, Korea, Friday, July 29 -- President Syngman Rhee attacked today what he termed the "little lieutenants and colonels" of Gen. Douglas MacArthur as a "tremendous handicap not only to MacArthur but to American Japanese policy as well."
Jobless workers won't be able to go on vacation while drawing state unemployment insurance checks, under a ruling made public yesterday by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner.

Mrs. Paul Robeson, wife of the singer and a graduate of Columbia University's Teachers College, told 400 Columbia students yesterday that legislation and education were the only way to end racial and religious discrimination. She spoke at a meeting in the McMillin Academic Theatre called by the Columbia chapter of the Young Progressives of America to protest alleged discrimination at Columbia.

The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday Hospital Commissioner Marcus D. Kogel's request for funds to pay 200 new nurses on a premium basis for emergency service in polio wards in city hospitals.

PITTSBURGH, July 28 -- With a keen appreciation of Pittsburgh experimental impulses and a deep feeling of gratitude for the authority in stocky Sid Gordon's bat, the Giants are heading further into the West tonight in the National League's first division after closing out their three-game series against the Pirates with a victory before a ladies' day gathering of 26,267.

An expansion program involving three major changes in passenger services of Moore-McCormack Lines between New York and South America was announced yesterday by Leo E. Archer, general passenger traffic manager.

The mercury climbed to 95.2 degrees yesterday, .3 of a degree short of the record for the date, to mark the second hottest day so far this year on the eleventh consecutive day of the current heat wave. The official forecaster, meanwhile, predicted at least another forty-eight hours of sultry weather.

ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP) -- The Cardinals made it three straight over the Philadelphia Phillies today with a 16-hit assault that ran the score to 10 -- 2, while the Phils stumbled through with five errors.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- After Senate and House differences had been resolved unanimously in conference a few hours earlier, the Senate adopted today a bill designed to tighten the unification of the armed services in the interest of greater economy and efficiency.

NEWARK, N. J., July 28 -- Four witnesses were called today before Superior Court Judge William J. Brennan in connection with an application for an injunction against six leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, who are allegedly responsible for an eleven-day work stoppage at two piers of the American Export Lines in Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board discovered today that the bargain aircoach rates of scheduled airlines are opening up new traffic markets, but apparently not to the extent expected by some enthusiasts.

DALLAS, Tex., July 28 -- Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan said today that farm income is "the key to prosperity" and therefore we must expand our domestic markets to absorb surpluses that he said would result from a reduction in export demand.
Most retail stores will raise butter prices 2 cents a pound today after wholesale listings yesterday neared the Government support price of 62 cents a pound put into effect on Wednesday.

The prolonged decline in business lending activity by banks in this area showed the first sign of leveling off during the week ended on Wednesday. Rising $3,000,000, after twenty-one consecutive weekly decreases, business loans made by the reporting New York City member banks now total $4,487,000,000, according to the figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- A rent control tangle snarled the Senate tonight and virtually blocked progress at the week's second night session planned to speed important measures.

E. R. Squibb Sons, pharmaceuticals manufacturer, will increase its advertising for its fiscal year, started July 1, it was announced yesterday by Caleb Coffin, advertising and public relations director, during the first of a series of sales meetings, held in the Statler Hotel.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 28 -- Decisive victories were the rule as the leading women tennis players of the country advanced to the quarter-final round of the invitation tournament at the Maidstone Club today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- June Allyson was named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading feminine role in "The Reformer and the Red Head," and Dick Powell, her husband, was signed by the studio for the male lead.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Truman announced today that the United States, Great Britain and Canada would hold exploratory talks on the questions of sharing atomic energy information and allocating supplies of uranium ore.

Luis Munoz Marin, first popularly elected governor of the Territory of Puerto Rico, appealed here yesterday to American investors to help his homeland in the continued post-war development of its economy "because of the proven record of the people of Puerto Rico to help themselves."

The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday the controversial zoning amendment for parking garages. Effective Aug. 13, it will permit the construction of parking garages for 200 or more automobiles in business, retail and residence use districts throughout the city with the approval of the City Planning Commission and a majority vote of the board.

The casual dress picture for fall, previewed yesterday in the David Crystal showing at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, gained interest from the new weaves and handling of fabrics as well as from such high-lighted detail as pockets, touches of velvet and grosgrain, the use of buttons and scarf trims.

Lamb prices dropped yesterday from record-breaking levels for the first time in more than a month. In its weekly survey of retail food stores, the City Department of Markets found that substantial reductions of from 4 to 10 cents a pound have occurred on all cuts.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Outside the State Department, where the high policy is never to indicate dissatisfaction with any act or statement by the Labor Government of the United Kingdom, there are a good many influential persons in Washington whose most consuming and immediate desire could be stated in the form of a want-ad.

WHEN Christopher Columbus first encountered the Indians of Haiti and Cuba he was charmed by their liberality, hospitality and friendliness. The Indians in their turn were awed by their white visitors, who seemed to them at least semi-divine. The same good start was made nearly everywhere as Europeans and Indians first met each other.

One of the six New York defendants in the crackdown on an interstate policy ring went free on $40,000 bond yesterday, another's $50,000 surety bond was being investigated and a third's application for bond reduction was denied.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's prepared statement made today before the House Foreign Affairs Committee in support of the European arms program:

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 28 -- Richard Gonzales, national champion from Los Angeles, fought off a dangerous challenge by Irvin Dorfman of New York today to gain the semi-final round of the invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

LONDON, July 28 -- British Government issues continued to fare badly in the stock market here today. At the outset jobbers marked down prices as much as 1 1/2 points, which was unprecedented for Government securities.

FORT WORTH, July 28 -- Keeping up with Arthur Bisguier of New York, the titleholder, three other contenders for the junior championship of the United States Chess Federation were tied at 3 -- 0 at the completion of play in the third round today.

During this season of long twilights home is not the haven for the young it will be in the winter, when dusk comes quickly. Then, when it is cold and wet, a light in the window will be an invitation to take refuge from the gloom.

C. V. Witney's Mount Marcy won Horse-of-the-Day honors at Saratoga-on-the-L. I. R. R. yesterday. A brow-mopping crowd of 15,482 visitors to Jamaica saw him take the six-furlong main event with a handsome, front-running performance.

BOSTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Red Sox made a clean sweep of their series with the White Sox today as Ellis Kinder racked up his eleventh victory with a 6-1 verdict in blistering heat before a crowd of 5,651.

BERLIN, July 28 -- Elections will be held in the five Laender (or States) of the Soviet zone between September 15 and the new year, it was learned today from German Communist sources close to the People's Council.
The New York Trust Company will absorb the Fulton Trust Company of New York under the terms of a cash merger agreement involving a purchase price of $5,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, July 29 -- Judged by its reception, Arthur Miller's "Death of a Salesman," which opened at the Phoenix Theatre last night, should have a long run in London. There were fifteen curtain calls and a big hand for Paul Muni as Willy Loman, but he resisted the clamor for a curtain speech.
CINCINNATI, July 28 (AP) -- Boston slugged out an 11-to-2 victory over the Reds today as Warren Spahn coasted to his twelfth mound triumph of the season. He gave six hits.

OSLO, Norway, July 28 -- The American military arms program is a political issue not only in the United States but in the Norwegian Parliament as well, and what Capitol Hill decides to do about it may very well affect the outcome of the Norwegian general election on Oct. 10.

From time to time the Russians observe cynically that the sole purpose of the Marshall Plan is to furnish a dumping-ground for surplus American products. The genesis and the administration of the Marshall Plan give the lie to these Russian statements. But the debate on the new foreign aid appropriation bill makes it clear that there are at least some members of Congress who would like to validate the Russian point of view.

LONDON, July 28 -- In Saint Dunstans - in - the - West, Fleet Street's own church, a memorial service was held today for thirteen American newspaper and radio correspondents killed in an airplane crash in India on July 12.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Big Ralph Branca pitched his first complete game in a month, the Dodgers assaulted four pitchers for eleven hits, including three home runs, and made it two straight over the Cubs by a 7-1 score at Wrigley Field today.

The Dwight School, a college preparatory school at 72 Park Avenue, was ransacked early yesterday morning by burglars who apparently were suffering from the heat. They turned on electric fans to cool themselves while they worked, and they failed to turn them off when they left.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The National Institute of Mental Health announced grants totaling $489,584 today to continue the financing of thirty-five research projects on mental and nervous disorders.

The stock market continued yesterday to find it difficult to move forward and did little more than drift aimlessly. The pace of trading was slow and even the low-price utilities failed to engender the heavy turnover prevalent in recent weeks.

The Masque and Lyre Light Opera Company, which heretofore has based its operations in Elmhurst, Queens, last night invaded the upper reaches of Manhattan and auspiciously launched the good ship "H.M.S. Pinafore." Offering it as the first in a series of five Gilbert and Sullivan works to be given at the Jan Hus Playhouse on East Seventy-fourth Street, the troupe gave a good account of itself in a spirited performance.

Gross income of the Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries for the first half of 1949 amounted to $187,257,987, a gain of $11,178,274 over the $176,079,713 reported for the same 1948 period. Net income, however, declined $728,239 to $10,850,288, according to the report issued yesterday by David Sarnoff, chairman.

One of the most discouraging aspects of the controversy over proposals either to permit or deny the use of federal funds for the support of the parochial schools is the speed with which the argument by epithet has been used. It is exceedingly unfortunate that Cardinal Spellman has taken the lead in this, dubbing Congressman Barden "a new apostle of bigotry," and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's discussions "documents of discrimination."

MAPLE SHADE, N. J., July 28 -- An early morning gambling raid, in which state troopers forced their way into an armored casino and arrested 187 men, put Jersey justice, as exemplified here, on a production-line basis today.

Net income of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for the first six months of this year was $28,409,961, a gain of $968,861 over the $27,441,100 reported for the comparable 1948 period, Gwilym A. Price, president, said yesterday after a meeting of the board of directors.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 28 -- The routine arrest of a New York husband and wife for the alleged theft of $4,500 merchandise from a home here resulted today in solving at least fourteen thefts totaling $50,000 in Westchester County, New York, Long Island and New Jersey in the last two years, Police Lieutenant Joseph Faulkner said.

A 1949 dual-purpose utility automobile designated the Kaiser Vagabond was presented yesterday by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation at the showroom of the Kaiser-Frazer Sales Corporation, 1710 Broadway. The delivered price here was given as $2,359.05 exclusive of sales tax.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 -- A six-weeks inquiry by the Los Angeles County grand jury into alleged corruption in the police department culminated today in the indictment of Clemence B. Horrall, recently resigned chief of police, and four high-ranking officers.

Paul Hanchock, who lost his right hand during wartime naval service, may get the better job he wants. Now an elevator operator in the Veterans Administration Building, 252 Seventh Avenue, he is anxious to add typing to his skills as a basis for a better job, and yesterday he set about it.

LONDON, July 28 -- The likelihood of a "go slow" strike on Britain's nationalized railways was removed temporarily today when delegates at the conference of the powerful National Union of Railwaymen voted by a narrow majority to accept the terms of reference of the Government's newly created Board of Conciliation.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The United States Government will return on Aug. 4 to deficit financing for the first time in more than three years.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Bureau of Narcotics reported today that there had been an "extremely disturbing" increase in the smuggling of cocaine into this country and called New York a collection point for imports of the narcotic from Latin America.

Chester Williams of Crockett County, Tennessee, is not the Tennessee Valley Authority's millionth customer. He is merely the millionth consumer of TVA power. The distinction is that TVA is a wholesaler of electricity and that Mr. Williams is a member of a cooperative which buys TVA current.

Rollie William McDowell, 40 years old, of a St. Louis suburb, must have taken to heart the kindly advice of the florists, candy-makers and other gift people on how nice it is to surprise your wife occasionally. Last night Mr. McDowell took home to his wife two adopted orphans from Ireland without first telling her.

SHEFFIELD, England, July 28 (Reuters) -- A century by Norman Yardley, former captain of England's team, and an aggressive innings of 51 by young Brian Close helped Yorkshire gain a first innings lead of 60 against the New Zealand cricketers on the second day of their match here.

Demand has increased and prices have firmed on steel drums, industrial buyers declared here yesterday. Weakness which developed last month has virtually disappeared, it was stated, and orders are now increasing on producers backlogs.

Acting in accordance with one recommendation of a special committee headed by Robert Moses, the Board of Estimate yesterday approved amended plans to provide parking facilities for 730 automobiles in connection with the construction of the proposed $32,000,000 New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Department sales in the week ended July 23 were 11 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1948:

Guaranty Trust Company of New York is trustee, registrar and paying agent for $3,500,000 of New Jersey Power and Light Company first mortgage bonds, 2 7/8 per cent series, due June 1, 1979. The bank has also been named co-paying agent for $1,511,000 Town of Tonawanda, N. Y., drainage district bonds.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 28 -- Byron Price, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, today assured members of the Secretariat of his continued confidence in them despite recent attacks on them in United States Congressional committees.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Representative . John Lesinski, Democrat, of Michigan, chairman of the House Labor Committee, said tonight that aid to education legislation "has no chance" at this session of Congress.

TOKYO, July 28 -- In their fight to prevent Japanese editors from printing the truth about communism, the Reds are subjecting editors to "pressures and various types of miserable harassment, some of which borders on intimidation," Major Daniel C. Imboden, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's press officer, declared today.

The first major unit in the city's waterfront rehabilitation program, the reconstructed pier at Thirty-third Street, Brooklyn, is nearing completion at a cost of nearly $1,000,000, G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, announced yesterday.

Containing ten apartments and three stores, the three-story building at 382 Keap Street, in Brooklyn, has been sold for investment by Fred Senft to Sam Rampil, who insured title with the Home Title Guaranty Company. Jacob M. Aufrecht was the broker in the sale of the property, which occupies a plot 24 by 100 feet and is assessed at $20,000.

Industrial purchasing men here have called in soft coal producers to ask what deliveries of coal can be expected next fall when cool weather sharply increases industrial consumption schedules, it was learned here yesterday.

CANTON, China, Friday, July 29 (AP) -- A Communist drive from the north has penetrated to the outskirts of Changteh in the heart of the Hunan Province ricebowl, Nationalist dispatches said today. It appeared to be a significant flanking operation.

The largest earnings for any six months in its history was reported by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the country's second largest steel producer, at the quarterly meeting of directors here yesterday.

GREEK FRONTIER POST 20, on the Yugoslav border, July 27 (AP) -- Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia is closing the Greek-Yugoslav frontier to guerrillas, but border relations between the two countries remain frigid.
A flip of a coin decided yesterday who should have the distinction of being the first blood donor at the new Manhattan Red Cross center, at 70 West Fortieth Street.
Alex Smith Sons Carpet Company, which previously paid 50 cents a share in each quarter, declared yesterday a dividend of 30 cents on the common stock, payable on Sept. 10.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters accepted an invitation yesterday from the New York State Temporary Commission on Agriculture to form a committee of local union members engaged in processing and distributing milk to work with the commission on a study of cutting milk costs.

LONDON, July 28 -- Britain's newspapers were warned today that unless they established a General Council of the Press for their own improvement, as recently recommended by the Royal Commission on the press, the Labor Government might consider creating such a council by legislation.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- William Wagner, executive secretary of the National Association of Credit Jewelers, said today he was neither "disappointed nor overly elated" by Vice President Barkley's talk last night before the jewelers. Mr. Barkley failed to give assurance of removal or modification of the 20 per cent excise tax, a message expected by many jewelers on the basis of widely circulated reports at their Stevens Hotel fair.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Judge Alexander Holtzoff ruled in Federal District Court today that the court had no right to set aside Federal loyalty board findings under which a Government employe was discharged.
TOKYO, July 28 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur virtually wiped out the United States Military Government in Japan today.
A retired Post Office employe arrived in New York yesterday after a 4,225-mile walking tour that took him fourteen months.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 28 -- After suffering nine years from an amnesia attack that left her with no recollection of the past, a comely, blue-eyed, blonde woman, 26 years old, stepped into a doctor's office on Main Street here today and was reunited with two of her brothers.
LONDON, July 28 -- A Government stock broker teamed with small private investors today to stem the sharpest slump in a decade in British Government securities.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Joseph E. Moody, president of the Southern Coal Producers Association, told Congress today that if the soft coal operators resisted the short work week imposed by the United Mine Workers by closing their mines they would play into John L. Lewis' hands and might invite Government seizure and bring new and permanent problems.

Almost one-third of the estimated $12,000,000,000 spent annually for record storage space could be saved by American business and industry if microfilming of business records is legalized. This was declared yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., in a letter to Representative Emanuel Celler, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- During the week ended on July 27, member-bank reserve balances increased $71,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Landlords to whom D-115 forms have been sent by the New York City Rent Advisory Board were urged yesterday to fill out and return the documents. Joseph D. McGoldrick, board chairman, said the data requested was necessary for consideration of a plea for a general 15 per cent rent rise here.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- An Atlanta youngster knocked the teenagers' longest hitter out of the national junior amateur golf championship today. Walter (Tony) Baker, a 17-year-old from Bobby Jones' home town, staged a brilliant comeback to eliminate Pat Schwab of Dayton, one up, in a 19-hole battle.

President Truman has acted quickly -- too quickly, we think -- in choosing a successor to the late Justice Frank Murphy of the United States Supreme Court. He has passed over the names of eminent men of long and outstanding judicial experience -- and many such names were doubtless suggested to him.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 28 -- Governor Dewey called today for American aid "right now, this summer" for the Chinese Nationalists to restore their confidence. The Governor, the principal speaker on the final day of Colgate University's first annual Conference on American Foreign Policy, recalled that he had predicted in a speech in November, 1947, in New York the present state of Chinese affairs, then said:

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- Mrs. Kathleen B. Durant, former Wac captain, who was convicted in 1946 of stealing the Hesse crown jewels, has been paroled from the Alderson (W. Va.) Federal Reformatory for Women after serving one-third of a five-year sentence.

ROME, July 28 (AP) -- Communist Governments seeking to prosecute Roman Catholic priests for excommunicating pro-Communists are likely to run up against a stone wall because rarely if ever will an individual priest be called upon to do so, a Vatican informant said today.

The new motorship Olga Maersk, latest addition to the Maersk Line of the Moller Steamship Company, Inc., will leave here tonight on the second leg of her maiden voyage from Denmark to the Far East. The vessel left Copenhagen on July 7, in command of Capt. A. U. Rorup, a veteran of twenty-five years service with the line.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A possible future of almost overwhelming abundance, well-being and material progress for the United States in the next hundred years was foreseen today by a well-known organization generally devoted to sober research and conservative treatises on economics.

LONDON, July 28 -- Minister of Defense A. V. Alexander as well as the chiefs of staff figured prominently in the conference of Britain's Middle East diplomats and experts summoned by Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin that ended today, the Foreign Office revealed tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended July 23 totaled 718,516 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The Yankees, though held together by tape and patching plaster, apparently still have what it takes to head the procession in the American League flag race.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation of Jersey City, N. J., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan to liquidate.

This writer has the deepest respect for the good-will of Mrs. Roosevelt and of her championing of human rights. His Eminence Cardinal Spellman has made an attack on a public figure which, I believe, was unwarranted and which is providing many genuinely anti-Catholic spokesmen with an opportunity to sharpshoot at the "intolerance" of the Roman Catholic Church under the cloak of hastening to Mrs. Roosevelt's defense.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Legislation calling for repeal of wartime excise taxes to ease the unemployment situation and stimulate consumer purchasing power was urged here today by two business associations.

The Delman Shoe Shop at 754 Fifth Avenue opened its doors yesterday with a new group of autumn styles. It is obvious from the collection that both the closed and the open silhouette continue to share favor with the customer.
OSLO, Norway, July 28 (AP) -- James Fuchs of Yale bettered the world shot-put record tonight as the United States moved within six points of Scandinavia in the "Little Olympics."

Trading in rubber futures continued active on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday. Prices advanced moderately early in the day, weakened somewhat around mid-day and steadied in the final market hours. The turnover was 1,320 long tons, the highest of the week. Prices at the close were unchanged to 7 points net lower.

BROADSTAIRS, England, July 28 -- A raiding party of Saxons from Denmark successfully invaded England today for the second time in history. Fifteen hundred years after Hengest and Horsa landed here, the bronzed and bearded Saxons leaped from a long boat with flashing spear and shield -- this time to face a massed array of loudspeakers, newsreel cameras and joyous tourists.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- A two-day meeting of 105 Republicans from twenty-seven states began here today with a keynote address assailing both the Republican national leadership for "me-tooism" and the "socialistic trend" of the Democratic Administration.

Sweltering summer visitors to New York might pound the simmering sidewalks for hours never suspecting that the city has its own old swimmin' hole -- probably the biggest, cleanest and most thoroughly enjoyed one in the country.

LONDON, July 28 -- Many visitors from the United States and the Commonwealth have been ordering tailored suits and ensembles while on holiday in London during the past four months. As a result, Digby Morton, who specializes in tailormades, showed today a smaller autumn collection than usual, the workrooms having given precedence to visitors' orders.

SUMMIT, N. J., July 28 -- After the opening two rounds of match play, all three former titleholders competing in the forty-seventh metropolitan golf championship today were eliminated at the Canoe Brook Country club with Art Lynch of Winged Foot Assuming a leading role.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 28 -- The 350 feet square display of Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. Van Beuren, containing more than twenty varieties of flowers in bloom, received the award of the Chamber of Commerce Bowl for the outstanding exhibit at the Casino Flower Show here today.

The principal influence in "the astonishing restoration of production, financial well-being and general air of prosperity now prevailing in Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg consists of the free trading agreements among those countries.

DETROIT, July 28 -- Although thousands of American dollars have been spent since last winter in building speed boats to defend here tomorrow and Saturday, the Harmsworth, or British international trophy, this regatta-mad city tonight was practically unanimous in favoring the foreign challenger, E. A. Wilson's Miss Canada IV from Ingersoll, Ont., which his son, 37-year-old Harold Wilson, will drive.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 28 -- In theory Czechoslovakia is today the scene of the greatest struggle between the Roman Catholic Church and a political state since the days of the reformation and counter-reformation. A papal decree now has decided that no true Catholic also can be a militant member of the Communist party without suffering ipso facto excommunication.

The long-awaited expansion of the weekly issue of Treasury ninety-one-day discount bills is to get under way in August, just about a month after exposure of the market to the cheap-money leavening carried by the Federal Reserve System's recent shift in its open market operations objective.

ROME, July 28 -- An article published today in the Communist weekly, Vie Nuove, was believed in Italian political circles to have given the first indication of the tactics the Soviet Union intended to apply in Italy to counteract the effects of the Vatican excommunication decree against Communists.
Mrs. Martha Jule Beck swore yesterday that she was not trying to shield Raymond M. Fernandez, her co-defendant in the "lonely hearts" murder trial.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, commander of the Sixth Army, today ordered an investigation of "alleged irregularities involving civilian and military personnel at the Oakland Army Base" and preparation of a written report with recommendations.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Administration's $1,450,000,000 program for foreign military aid was the lowest expenditure that "makes sense" to a free world in fear of Soviet aggression, Secretary of State Dean Acheson told Congress today.

SHANGHAI, July 27 -- The Liberation Daily, official Communist party organ, indicated today that the party had decided to abandon its "lenient attitude" here and resort to sterner measures as a means of coping with economic problems created by disastrous central China floods and the Kuomintang blockade.

At the same time yesterday that Governor Dewey was making a frontal attack on what he described as the Administration's "no-policy-at-all" in respect to China, Secretary Acheson was indicating to the House Foreign Affairs Committee that this policy would not be changed. Governor Dewey called for prompt military aid to the Government of China to save it from being engulfed by the Communists.

NEW DELHI, India, July 28 -- General elections will be held in West Bengal within six months in an attempt to solve the political difficulties of that province, according to a decision taken tentatively today by the Congress working committee, executive body of India's dominant party.

Through force of continued competition in the food industry, wholesale grocers are cutting operating expenses and adopting new efficiency methods to a degree never before reached in the food business, it was disclosed here yesterday.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, July 28 -- The United Nations Palestine Conciliation Commission announced today that the Arab and Israeli delegations had agreed that the Lausanne conference should continue "with a view to the definitive settlement of the Palestine problem and to the establishment of a just and permanent peace in Palestine."
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UP) -- Housing Administrator Tighe E. Woods today exempted from Federal rent control all housing accommodations used for educational or charitable purposes.

BUENOS AIRES, July 28 -- A long news dispatch to Time magazine about allegations of police tortures here, which are the subject of a Congressional investigation, was taken from the postoffice on July 22, and is now in the hands of the Federal Police Chief, Gen. Arturo Bertollo, whose own men are the subject of the inquiry.
BUFFALO, N. Y., July 28 (AP) -- The commanding general of the First Air Force called today for intelligent management and approved business principles in the nation's defense expenditures.

Anonymous "crank" telephone calls to the International Telegraph and Telephone Building, 67 Broad Street, yesterday morning, warning that "four bombs will go off at 11 o'clock," set detectives of the Bomb Squad and Emergency Crew No. 1 on an hour-long search of the thirty-two-story structure in the heart of the financial district.

Economic reforms already undertaken in Italy are constructive but "substantially greater" efforts toward solution of that country's basic economic problems appear necessary if political stability is to be based on solid foundations, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York declares in a study of Italian conditions.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Truman said today that he had asked Attorney General Tom C. Clark to fill the existing vacancy on the Supreme Court and Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democrat, of Rhode Island, to become Attorney General.

CULPEPER, Va., July 28 -- Vice President Alben Barkley hinted romantically today that he might soon crown "a queen of my own," thus rekindling speculation that he might be contemplating a second marriage. His first wife died two years ago.

Hearings on the deportation of Alexander Bittelman, 58-year-old Communist national committeeman who is charged with advocating the overthrow of the Government by force and violence, were resumed yesterday at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 70 Columbus Avenue.

The return of the French liner Ile de France is impressive evidence of the faith shared by France and America that "the troubles of our post-war world are not insurmountable," Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri said yesterday.
HONOLULU, July 28 (AP) -- The Senate and House agreed today on the terms of a bill to put Hawaii into the stevedoring business and try to reopen the islands' strikebound ports.

PARIS, July 28 -- Four members of the French Cabinet resigned today and then, responding to an appeal by Premier Henri Queuille, resumed their posts to prevent a Cabinet crisis. The Premier made it plain that he would himself resign if they refused to return.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Tigers mauled the Senators, 13-to-7, today with a seven-run rally in the ninth inning.
DEDHAM, Mass., July 28 (AP) -- Perhaps the world's richest mother -- Barbara Hutton Troubetzkoy -- can keep her only son with her for the summer because she is poor in health.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- Soviet sport is creating a new type of athlete, an athlete motivated by ethical, comradely, sportsmanlike principles, who personifies the concept of the new Soviet man on the playing fields or in the boxing ring, according to the newspaper Soviet Sport, organ of the All-Union Committee on Physical Culture and Sport.
Schenley Distillers, Inc., one of the nation's largest producers of liquor, announced yesterday that it hoped to schedule radio or television advertising this fall or winter.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The $5,723,724,000 foreign aid programs remained snarled tonight in the Senate Appropriations Committee, to which the bill for approval of the funds was returned yesterday after four days of floor debate.

The Sale in 1945 by the Long Island Rail Road of two parcels of Hempstead business property -- the third such transfer of presumably valuable land at prices reportedly far below their worth -- was defended yesterday by the Pennsylvania Railroad, parent company of the Long Island.

GENEVA, July 28 -- The United States lost a battle today in its struggle to make the United Nations an effective agency for furthering economic development and bringing technical assistance to the world's under-developed areas.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 28 -- The United Nations called today on the Big Five and Canada to attempt to find a way out of the disagreement on atomic energy control.

The prospect of prolonged peace in the bus industry was bolstered yesterday when six additional companies indicated they were ready to cooperate fully with Theodore W. Kheel, recently appointed impartial chairman of the private bus field.

SHANGHAI, July 28 -- Confinement of two Americans involved in the long-standing dispute over the closing down of The Shanghai Evening Post and Mercury ended today at 4:30 P. M. shortly after police arrived and talked with the workers who had held them for more than two days and nights.
The final report of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche as Acting United Nations Mediator for Palestine marks the happy end of a dramatic chapter in the history of the Middle East.

Today's music events: Guggenheim Memorial Concert, Edwin Franko Goldman, conductor, Central Park, 8:30 P. M.; "The Man in the Moon," Lemonade Opera, Greenwich Mews Playhouse, 8:30; Juilliard Summer Symphony, Walter Hendl, conductor, Joseph Fuchs, violinist, Juilliard Concert Hall, 4.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Governor Dewey of New York and Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, who fought it out for the Republican Presidential nomination a year ago, have been conferring by telephone on the Republican National Chairmanship, which becomes vacant Aug. 4.

Philip Murray, president of the United Steelworkers of America, announced yesterday that the union wanted concessions from the steel industry totaling 30 cents an hour, including a 12 1/2-cents-an-hour wage increase, 11.23 cents for pensions and 6.27 cents for social insurance.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina warned defense counsel at the Communist trial yesterday that he was preparing to take action if they did not heed his commands for orderly procedure and stop interfering with the administration of justice.

WATCHING Prof. Casey Stengel manage a pennant-contending club for the first time in his career seems to reveal talents few believed he possessed. Yet he must have had them all along, since Casey, come Saturday, will be a rising 58, and certain it is he didn't learn it all over night when they named him to lead the Yankees last fall.

COLUMBIA, Mo., July 28 -- Dr. Walter Miller, Professor Emeritus of Classical Languages and former dean of the Graduate School at the University of Missouri and former editor in chief of the Standard American Encyclopedia, died here today. He was 85 years old.
PANAMA, July 28 - First Vice President Dr. Daniel Chanis was sworn in as Provisional President of Panama by the Supreme Court this morning.

PARIS, July 28 -- Military observers in closest touch with the problem of armaments for the new French Army said today that France's own armament industry could begin to roll as soon as the exact mission of the French Army was defined in relation to the collective defense of Western Europe.

LENOX, Mass., July 28 -- The twelfth Berkshire Festival opened here tonight with Serge Koussevitzky, the moving spirit of the enterprise, conducting the Boston Symphony Orchestra in a concert that, despite threatening weather, drew 7,000 persons.

Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the State University of New York, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Lawrence L. Jarvie as executive dean for two-year institutes and community colleges, and Dr. Hermann Cooper as executive dean for teacher education.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- A one-time bootblack with an entree to the White House was a witness today at a secret session of Senators investigating alleged "five per centers." He is John Maragon, who appeared before a subcommittee looking into reports that persons claiming influence with Government officials have been seeking to get Government contracts for business men, for a 5 per cent fee.

Local managers of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, representing all its thirty locals and two joint boards in New York City, met yesterday and, with one dissenting voice, endorsed Newbold Morris for Mayor, Harry Uviller for Controller and Justice Matthew J. Diserio for President of the City Council.
PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 28 (AP) -- Joe Angyal, 32-year-old New York fireman, and Jack Guest Jr., Toronto youngster, became the first double winners today in the Canadian Henley rowing regatta.

A bolt from California has descended upon the vast army of fishermen whose main delight lies in outwitting the small-mouth black bass. That the blow should fall at the height of the vacation season, when every resort lake and stream is teeming with avid anglers seeking this voracious fighter, makes the situation the more grim.

PARIS, July 28 -- The statement to the House Foreign Affairs Committee by Secretary of State Dean Acheson today and the announcement yesterday of the forthcoming visit to Europe by the United States Chiefs of Staff have led high French military authorities to hope for the early drafting, under American leadership, of a strategic plan for the defense of Western Europe.
The American Continental Congress for World Peace, 49 West Forty-fourth Street, announced yesterday that a peace congress would be held in Mexico City, Sept. 5 to 10.
A sharp curtailment in job opportunities for teen-agers was shown yesterday in a survey of six agencies concerned with child welfare.

The ashes of ten of the American news writers killed July 12 in the crash of a KLM Royal Dutch Airlines plane at Bombay arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, aboard a Dutch airliner from Amsterdam.
Fred Schmidt, formerly president of the Electric Power Equipment Corporation, has joined the I-T-E Circuit Breaker Company as assistant to the president.

The uncompromising arrogance of those who refuse to cooperate in establishing peace might diminish in the atmosphere of a military hospital, Rear Admiral Walter S. DeLany said yesterday. The Commandant of the Third Naval District was the principal speaker at cornerstone ceremonies for the permanent section of St. Albans Naval Hospital, Queens.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Soybeans continued their sensational advance on the Board of Trade today, rising 9 1/4 cents a bushel at one time to a new seasonal high price on all de liveries, and closing trades were at gains of 6 3/4 to 8 cents, the November position leading.
Mrs. Martha Jule Beck testified yesterday that she felt justified in telling lies "if the circumstances warrant."

Station WPIX will introduce a new series of original television dramas on Monday from 8 to 8:30 P. M. under the title of "Theatre Time." The initial show will be a three-act play entitled "Lost Child," written by Alfred Bester, and starring Luise Rainer and Vinton Hayworth.

ATLANTA, July 29 (AP) -- A county grand jury today filed formal charges of assault with intent to murder against Judge Robert Carpenter, accusing him of shooting John Lockwood, his former associate and friend.

In the July 26 issue of your newspaper I read an article under the title "Indonesia Backs Accord." In the article it was stated that the latest Van Royen-Rum Agreement of May 7, 1949, called for "Dutch withdrawal from territory claimed by the Indonesian Republic as a preliminary to final settlement of their difficulties."

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Truman set up today an Advisory Committee on Management Improvement, with Thomas Morgan of New York, president of the Sperry Corporation, as its chairman. The committee consists of twelve members.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- The Senate today voted, 45 to 42, for a $2,407,000 cut in funds for Housing Expediter Tighe E. Woods on the grounds that he is decontrolling rents and does not need the money.

We recently discussed briefly here a report issued by the United Nations showing the economic trends among the various countries of the world for the year 1948. Tables in that report indicated, among other things, that production in Soviet Russia and its satellite countries had increased at a greater rate than it had in Western Europe.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Opposition to Federal aid for housing and education, as leading to socialism, was among fourteen points unanimously adopted today at the end of a meeting here on ways and means to "revitalize" the Republican party.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 29 (UP) -- George Moran, who won fame as a member of the comedy team of "Moran and Mack," the original "Two Black Crows," is in an Oakland hospital under treatment in a charity ward.

SUMMIT, N. J., July 29 -- The champions of New Jersey and Westchester, Joe McBride and Joe Gagliardi, will meet tomorrow for the Metropolitan amateur golf title in the 36-hole final at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Negotiations between the Roman Catholic Church and the Czechoslovak Government would be "peaceful" but to the advantage of the Government, a Czechoslovak Embassy official declared today.

Woolen goods price reductions announced this week have caused confusion in the women's wear trades, it was learned yesterday. Buyers of garments anticipating reductions in price, it was said, will find the market holding firm mainly because the categories of goods most in demand show little, if any, decline that can be passed along.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today authorized Tennessee Gas Transmission Company to extend its main pipeline from northeastern Kentucky to Buffalo, N. Y., and increase its lines' capacity to more than a billion cubic feet daily.

Since transportation over city streets by bus lines first replaced the amiable pace of our ancient trolley cars, the threat of strikes and innumerable walkouts in the bus industry has hung over several million passengers who daily ride the surface lines. For the first time hope of a permanent peace now looms in the industry.

BUENOS AIRES, July 29 -- A formal diplomatic note on the question of press and radio censorship was delivered to the Argentine Foreign Office at noon today by Lester Mallory, Counselor of the United States Embassy.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The following is the text of a statement delivered today to the House Foreign Affairs Committee by General Omar N. Bradley, Chief of Staff of the Army and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He spoke for the Joint Chiefs of Staff as well as for himself:

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation announced yesterday it will break its largest national advertising campaign in Chicago on Sunday with the first of a series of full-page newspaper ads on its new 1950 television lines. Similar ads will appear in thirty-two markets, and pages and double-spreads also will be used in Sunday roto sections and national magazines.
LAKE SUCCESS, July 29 -- The United Nations Atomic Energy Comimssion -- three years old last month -- decided today to suspend its work indefinitely.

July sales of Rheingold beer will set an all-time record for Liebmann Breweries, Inc., Philip Liebmann, company president, said yesterday. He made this disclosure at a press preview in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of the contestants for Miss Rheingold of 1950.
LAMBERTVILLE, N. J., July 29 -- Everybody in this Delaware River town of 5,000 is busy these days preparing for Lambertville's one-hundredth birthday party Aug. 24-28.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 29 (AP) -- Carolyn K Stable's Joy C., under a strong ride by the successful apprentice, Willie Downs, today accounted for the featured Red Bank purse at Monmouth Park. Joy C. was overlooked in favor of several other juveniles in the five and a half furlong dash and paid $19.60 to those in the crowd of 11,183 who fancied her chances. Time for the distance was 1:07.

FORT WORTH, July 29 -- Arthur B. Bisguier, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, defending his national title in the fourth annual junior championships here, went into the lead today with five straight games to his credit.
WAYNESBURG, Pa., Saturday, July 30 -- Waynesburg is looking for a new tradition. It didn't rain yesterday -- nary a drop, though it most always rains here on July 29.
FALL RIVER, Mass., July 29 (AP) -- Loss of nearly 1,000 jobs impended today with announcement of the closing of the 21-year-old cotton goods manufacturing division of the Arkwright Corporation.

There may be those who will shun the returned vacationist, with his head filled with incredible stories of piscatorial exploits and his pockets crammed with overexposed snapshots of other vacationists in baggy bathing suits, until such time as he becomes immersed once again in his humdrum life, but there is one person who rejoices at the traveler's return.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 29 -- The Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association women defeated the Connecticut State women in their annual inter-association team match at Brooklawn today. The invaders, captained by Mrs. George J. Brady of Scarsdale Golf Club, squeezed past the Nutmeg squad of fifteen by a two-point margin, 23 1/2 to 21 1/2.
A fractious car that purportedly broke down two or three times a week furnished a comfortable living for Nathan Resnick, 39 years old, of 163 Madison Avenue, until 10 o'clock last night.

Backlogs of orders have started to grow again for manufacturers of large power shovels and construction equipment, industry members revealed here yesterday. Larger orders are being entered for both short-term and long-term delivery.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Buying of wheat, based on expectations that the Government would make liberal purchases of it in the immediate future and that there would be a rush of flour buying following announcement of the amount of the export subsidy, turned prices upward after a small dip early, and closing trades were at net gains of 1/2 to 1 1/2 cents, September leading.
The semi-annual report of the St. Joseph Lead Company covering the six months ended with last June, released today, disclosed a consolidated net income of $4,852,390, after taxes and all charges.
BUENOS AIRES, July 29 -- The Peronista party convention closed today with a declaration that President Juan D. Peron's re-election in 1952 was essential.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it will support grower prices of 1949 crop cotton at a base rate of 27.23 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The $5,700,000,000 foreign-aid bill was rewritten by the Senate Appropriations Committee late today and submitted for retrial before the Senate and the parliamentary rules which last Wednesday blocked conclusive action after four days of floor debate.

The New England Gas and Electric Association reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the twelve months to June 30 amounted to $1,799,647, compared with $1,432,769 in the preceding twelve months. After sinking-fund requirements, share earnings amounted to $1.25 and $1.06, respectively.

HONG KONG, July 29 (UP) -- Communist armies fanned out in three directions from captured Chuchow today while hard-pressed Nationalist forces withdrew toward their "mountain redoubt" between Hengyang and Kanhsien.

A former Army Air Forces sergeant, who carried a German automatic pistol and a little memorandum book allegedly listing twelve previous and seven prospective hold-ups, was arrested at 8:10 o'clock last night as he was about to enter the Erie Railroad ticket office at 11 Rockefeller Plaza. He was charged with assault, robbery and illegal possession of a firearm.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., July 29 -- The desire of millions of Americans for economic security, accompanied by the growth of a powerful national state and a "liberalized" Constitution, menaces individual liberty and self-government, Donald R. Richberg, former head of the National Recovery Administration, declared here tonight.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- In sharply contrasting games, the Indians and the Red Sex divided a day-night double-header. Boston won a well-pitched, afternoon contest, 2 -- 1, and the world champions gained a 9-3 decision tonight.

The Weather Bureau here turned on its new radar set yesterday morning the weathermen took turns scanning the skies 100 miles around the city in search of a rain-cloud. At a late hour in the afternoon not a one had been found.

ALBANY, July 29 -- State Health officials said today that many water shortages had been reported from small communities as a result of the prolonged drought, but that the state had been able to cope with them "one way or another."

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)--Mason Rudolph of Clarksville, Tenn., beat Joe Turnesa Jr. of Ferndale, N. Y., 5 and 4, today to enter the semi-finals of the United States Golf Association's national junior tourney.

LENOX, Mass., July 29 -- The students, musicians and neighbors of Tanglewood, following the example of many other communities, today celebrated the bicentennial of the birth of Goethe. They heard a speech, in which he was extolled, and participated in music he helped inspire.

DETROIT, July 29 -- Practically coasting down the home stretch to the finish line and winning as he pleased, Danny Arena, driving Jack Schafer's Such Crust I of Detroit, tonight captured the first of the 42-nautical-mile heats of the British International regatta for the famous Harmsworth Trophy.

WEST POINT, N. Y., July 29 -- Sixty-four midshipmen from the United States Naval Academy received a roaring welcome from West Point cadets today as the midshipmen arrived at Camp Buckner, an infantry training post, in traditional Navy fashion -- by boat.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The General Services Administration announced today the sale of three Government-owned aluminum plants to the Permanente Metals Corporation, an affiliate of the Henry J. Kaiser industries.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 29 (AP) -- A $5,000 steel tower erected for a new all-Negro radio station here was a mass of twisted wreckage today. Police said a cable supporting the 210-foot tower had been sawed through.

New Yorkers suffered yesterday in the hottest day of the year. A merciless sun pushed the mercury up to 97.8 degrees at 4:10 P. M., according to the official Weather Bureau reading atop the Whitehall Building at the Battery.

After a stormy legislative trip the measure to promote the unification of the armed services has emerged into smooth sailing. The Senate has unanimously adopted the House-Senate conference version of the bill and House approval is now regarded as assured. When this bill is adopted in the House, probably Monday, one of the major legislative tasks of this session of Congress will have been accomplished.

LONDON, July 29 -- European signatories of the North Atlantic pact, and especially the five Brussels Treaty powers, are keenly awaiting the ten-day visit to Europe of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff. Europe's military leaders want to hear United States' ideas on how the Atlantic Defense Council should be set up under Article 9 of the North Atlantic treaty.

DETROIT, July 29 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production in the United States and Canada this week will total 138,223 units, Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today. Included in the total will be 113,452 cars and 21,921 trucks built in the United States and 1,633 cars and 1,217 trucks made in Canada.
TRENTON, N. J., July 29 -- New Jersey's recently enacted loyalty oath for political candidates was attacked in the courts today by the Progressive party, whose nominees will refuse to take the oath.

First choice for flower arrangement during the next few weeks is quite likely to be gladioluses. Not only will they be more plentiful than at any other time of year but also will be seen in a wider variety of colors.

DETROIT, July 29 (UP) -- A Federal judge ruled today that an employer was justified in returning ex-servicemen workers to subordinate jobs they held before the Second World War even though they held higher posts when they entered the service. Levin said he had "litle doubt that General Motors was within its rights" in demoting three veterans.

TOKYO, July 29 -- With only slow and virtually unarmed coast guard craft Japan is fighting an uphill battle against narcotics smugglers from China and Korea, according to Brig. Gen. Crawford F. Sams, chief of the Occupation's public health and welfare section.

Dennison Duble, 57-year-old former Cincinnati bank official and admitted figure-manipulator for a "rigged" interstate policy racket, was paroled without bail yesterday at his own consent, into the protective custody of the District Attorney's office.

AUBURN, N. Y., July 29 -- A general slackening of student interest in cultural and religious subjects was reported today by Rabbi Arthur J. Lelyveld, national director of the B'nai B'rih Hillel Foundations. Addressing 150 delegates from the United States and twenty foreign countries attending the International Student Service Conference at Wells College, Aurora, N. Y., Dr. Lelyveld said:
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- An attempt to resume general cargo shipments to strikebound Hawaii will be made next week by the Matson Navigation Company, the company announced today.

NEWARK, N. J., July 29 -- A deposition taken today in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, from S. S. Abbate, terminal manager for Piers D and F of the American Export Lines, Jersey City, will be read into the records tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Potato growers were warned today they must consent to stricter Government controls or risk losing Federal price supports.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange developed a slightly easier tone yesterday and final prices were 1 to 15 points net lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- At least seventy-five Hungarians, many of them the victims of Communist persecution, have reached the United States illegally on papers forged by a Paris passport ring. Representative Francis. E. Walter, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, chairman of a Judiciary subcommittee studying immigration problems, disclosed that immigration officials had rounded up the Hungarians.

One way for a man to stand above his fellows is to take a broadbill swordfish on rod and reel. For example, the offshore boats have been cutting ruts in the waters about Montauk all summer and only four have made port with broadbill aboard, and that's considered good.

Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed investigation of salaries paid to 140,000 city employes is a waste of money, Herbert S. Bauch, president of Local 1140, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, AFL, declared yesterday in the Municipal Civil Service Commission's office, 299 Broadway

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- The Athletics extended their winning streak to six straight -- their longest of the year -- by defeating the Detroit Tigers, 5 -- 3, tonight as Shortstop Eddie Joost came through with a game-saving catch with the bags loaded and two down in the ninth inning.

BERLIN, July 29 -- The United States and British airlift, principal foundation of the Western victory in the battle for Berlin, will be reduced gradually, beginning next Monday, Aug. 1, an official announcement by the two powers said today.
