WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development today granted a $15,000,000 loan to the Netherlands for reconstruction or modernization work to be carried out through twenty-four individual industrial projects.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Counterfeiters are hardly making expenses by their operations, U. E. Baughman, chief of the United States Secret Service, said today in his annual report to the Treasury Department.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that the New Jersey Safety Coordinating Committee urgently recommends that motorists traveling to and from the New Jersey shore use the Staten Island route over Outer-bridge Crossing wherever possible to avoid delays during periods of heavy week-end traffic.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The volume of installment plan credit rose above nine billion dollars in June for the first time in history.

Losses which may be sustained by banks through acceptance of counterfeit United States currency or coin are now covered by the blanket bond for bankers, under standard form No. 24, it has been announced by the Surety Association of America.

SHANGHAI, July 29 -- Former Chinese and Sikh employes of the United States Navy seized the main entrance of the United States Consulate here today and said that if their demands for severance pay and cumulative wages were not met they would stay and "starve."

ROME, July 29 -- In a strongly worded speech that reflected his deep resentment, Premier Alcide de Gasperi tonight attacked the British Government for what he said was its opposition to a settlement of the question of the former Italian colonies that would be favorable to Italy.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board today recommended dismissal of secondary boycott charges against a local union, finding that the picketing of a building site actually was primary action and could not be held responsible for the secondary action that resulted.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- "Shadow of a Hero," a new novel by Allan Chase, has been acquired for the screen by Monte Proser and James Nasser, it was learned today from George Wilner, Chase's agent here. The story deals with political corruption in a small town, and the price paid was $32,500, which include Chase's services as scenarist on the film, according to Wilner.
PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Buffalo West Side Rowing Club has a real fight on its hands this year at the Canadian Henley regatta.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 29 -- Five incorporated villages of the North Shore that have been receiving protection from the Nassau County Police Department are going to set up their own police force.

The New York Junior League will give a ball for its provisional members who are debutantes of the season on Nov. 24, Thanksgiving night, in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, with the proceeds to be devoted to the Junior League Welfare Fund. Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr. heads the committee for the dance, and Mrs. Duncan Van Norden is a member of the junior committe. Former presidents of the league will receive at the ball.

ROME, July 25 -- Neo-fascism as well as communism has been beaten down in Italy in the last few years. No one can say that one or the other -- especially communism -- will never rise again in a desperate situation; but far from being desperate, Italy's condition has improved in extraordinary fashion.

An overtight administrative budget has forced state unemployment insurance authorities to stop making test audits of employer records to discover whether the employers are "chiseling" on their insurance tax payments.

A music festival, in which the Salvation Army Territorial Staff Band and members of the Ocean Grove Choir will take part, will open the fourteenth annual Salvation Army Week-end at the Ocean Grove Auditorium, Ocean Grove, N. J., at 8:15 P. M. next Saturday.

DALLAS, Texas., July 29 -- This country's farm program for cotton is an example of compromise among conflicting interests in a democracy, Bushrod W. Allin, chairman of the Outlook and Situation Board of the Department of Agriculture, declared today.

MOSCOW, July 29--Prof. B. Raikov wrote in Komsomolskaya Pravda that a Russian scientist named Kaverznev had published at Leipzig in 1775 a work in German called "Changeability of Animals." Kaverznev declared that animal species were not immutable, as proclaimed by Linnaeus, but that they could change under the influence of environmental factors such as food, temperature and terrain.
Harold Feistel, general passenger manager of the Home Lines, received a cryptic message yesterday from the master of the liner Italia, now heading for New York from Mediterranean ports.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- An independent manufacturer said today breaking up of what he called a "soap monopoly" of three big producers would result in a 40 per cent drop in soap prices.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm prices eased slightly between mid-June and mid- July.

The sharp reduction of the civil affairs administration in the occupation of Japan is a direct challenge to the Japanese. The Military Government teams throughout the country have been the real backbone of administration. Theoretically they were merely advising the Japanese.

PARIS, July 29 -- At Maud et Nano's opening the calot receives novel interpretations. It is edged in large scallops. It is open in a deep inverted V in the center front, or a V in the center back from which flows veiling.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- General crop prospects in Europe are relatively favorable despite hot, dry weather between mid-June and mid-July, the Agriculture Department reported today.

New, fast, streamlined ferryboats for Staten Island commuters moved closer to realization yesterday as G. Joseph Minetti, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, opened new bids for the construction of the boats.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- Hundreds of children slid down the trunk of a life-sized pink elephant at the fifty-fourth annual Village Fair here today.

Army Transportation Corps installations in New York and elsewhere in the United States and overseas will observe this weekend the seventh anniversary of the corps' establishment. The Army's youngest service was formed as a wartime expedient on July 31, 1942, and has since operated on a global basis, carrying troops, their equipment, civilian aid materials and Army dependents over thousands of sea miles.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., July 29 -- Mrs. H. C. Ramsey of the home club, playing a brilliant 41, 36 -- 77, captured low gross honors in the weekly one-day Women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament over the difficult lower course of the Baltusrol Club today.

Arthur Krock in his column in THE TIMES on July 19 presented a left-handed compliment to Americans for Democratic Action, examining its so-called "superior articulation" with deep concern. Anyone who reads Mr. Krock's column with any regularity knows that he represents an active symbol of the equal strength -- at least -- of "articulation" from the right.

The Liberal party offered yesterday to take Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, as its candidate for Borough President of Manhattan if Tammany would nominate him, provided he was assured of "complete independence" in the conduct of that office.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29 -- The Yugoslav propaganda services today joined the Eastern European Communists' attack on the Vatican. Tanjug news agency reported from Rome that according to information supplied to the Italian state statistical office, the Vatican's investments in Italian industry totaled 17,000,000,000 lire [slightly less than $30,000,000].

The seven facilities of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority produced the highest income in the sixteen-year history of the agency in the first six months of 1949, George E. Spargo, general manager, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 29--A clearly defined strategy already is in being for the common defense of the North Atlantic treaty alliance in event of war, with the atomic bomb and the American strategic air arm holding "the first priority."

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Tyre Taylor, general counsel of the Southern States Industrial Council, told the Senate Banking Committee today that the "liberals" who have emphasized the need for an expanding economy have been silent about the union-imposed short work week in the Eastern soft coal mines.

A short circuit in a subway powerhouse, caused by the record heat, halted service at 7:14 o'clock last night on the East Side IRT line in Manhattan and the Bronx, the Third Avenue elevated and part of the IRT system in Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- A Senate Agriculture subcommittee "substantially agreed" today to stand pat on the price-support provision of the Aiken farm bill, despite its overwhelming rejection by the House.

Retail sales declined during the week, according to estimates made here yesterday. Department store sales were believed to be about 10 per cent below the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were also 10 per cent below last year.

NEW DELHI, India, July 29 -- The fear of a Communist uprising in Chandernagore, French free city twenty miles from Calcutta, which will soon be transferred to India, has been communicated to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and other officials here by Arun Chandra Dutt, Chandernagore Minister of External Affairs, and Deben Das, president of the Chandernagore Administrative Council, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced plans today for putting into effect on Monday cut-rate prices for wheat and flour to be sold abroad under the new International Wheat Agreement.

LONDON, July 29 (Reuters) -- Four Canadian former crewmen of the 7,168-ton ship Argomont, one of two formerly strike-bound Canadian vessels that were the cause of the four-week London docks stoppage, were remanded in custody today until next Wednesday on a charge arising from a bottle and glass attack on two non-striking crewmen of the other vessel, the Beaverbrae.

PLYMOUTH, N. H., July 29 -- The final session today of the American Friends Service Committee Seminar on International Relations was enlivened by discussions on whether the creation of the United Nations Organization was a step toward the ultimate establishment of a world government and prevention of war.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- John Maragon, a former bootblack who once had a White House pass and auto parking privileges, demanded today that Drew Pearson, a columnist, be called to testify in the Senate investigation of "5 per centers."

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Browns drove four runs across the plate in the tenth inning tonight to defeat Washington, 6 -- 2. Ned Garver went the distance against the Senators, scattering nine hits, to post his seventh victory.
BATAVIA, Java, July 29 (AP) -- Dutch and Indonesian Republican leaders agreed today on a cease-fire order to clear the way for formal peace and independence talks next month at The Hague.
TRENTON, N. J., July 29 -- Two moves by defense counsel for release in bail of six Trenton Negroes, awaiting a new trial for the murder of a shopkeeper, failed today in Mercer County Court.

LONDON, July 29 (AP) -- The Moscow radio tonight accused the United States and Britain of talking about forced labor in the Soviet Union "to disguise the fact that slave labor exists in capitalist countries."

Your disquisition on the newly plump has a large omission. Being a woman, with a sense of duty, I bring it to your attention. Exercise: it should have been mentioned. You can get it running the vacuum cleaner or looking for something in the attic. I refer you to that eminent logician Winnie-the-Pooh (nom de plume for Teddy Bear), who stated "A bear, however hard he tries, grows tubby without exercise.
I wish to register an emphatic protest against a misleading statement in the dispatch from Prague by C. L. Sulzberger, in your issue of July 27.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Average primary market prices declined 1.0 per cent in the week ended on last Tuesday, July 26, according to the United States Department of Labor. The index was 152.8 per cent of the 1926 average, 0.1 per cent lower than four weeks ago and 9.6 per cent below the comparable week in 1948.

A 48-year-old widow fired four shots at a city marshal and a score of policemen yesterday morning in a fruitless attempt to prevent the eviction of herself and her blind mother from their apartment at 348 East Nineteenth Street. A mover, hired by the marshal to assist in the eviction, was slightly wounded in the cheek by flying glass.
PINE CAMP, N. Y., July 29 (AP) -- Trains and trucks rumbled in and out of Pine Camp tonight, bringing in advance elements of the New York National Guard and taking home New Jersey soldiers.

LONG BEACH, L. I., July 29 -- Opposition to the proposed route of the new Long Beach expressway bringing a six-lane super highway through the main street of Long Beach was voiced today by the officers of the Long Beach Chamber of Commerce, Long Beach Merchants Association and Long Beach Real Estate Board. Plans were made for a mass meeting to arouse the entire city to the disadvantages of the plan.

William Raisch has purchased the two-story dwelling at 86-56 Palo Alto Avenue, Hollis, Queens, from Henry L. Holt and plans to remodel the premises before occupancy. John P. Bianca was the broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

A reduction since the first of the year in the cost of materials used by the steel industry has been sufficient to permit a 30-cent an hour wage and pension increase without curtailing the record profits set by the industry in the first half of 1949, the United Steelworkers of America, CIO, asserted yesterday.

LONDON, July 29 -- Marshal of the Royal Air Force Lord Tedder, who was Deputy Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force under Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in the late war, has resigned as chief of the British Air Staff. He will be succeeded by Air Chief Marshal Sir John C. Slessor.

A group of Queens civic leaders and officials of the Civil Aeronautics Administration were airborne witnesses yesterday of the problems confronting airline pilots who have to conform to set traffic patterns over airports without flying low enough over densely settled areas to cause a disturbing noise.

Things are looking up for Earl Sande. The great jockey of the Babe Ruth - Jack Dempsey - Bobby Jones era in sports, now the trainer of Clifford Mooers string of race horses, had a two-for-two afternoon at simmering Saratoga-at-Jamaica yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- A $2,339,457 expansion program of Kansas-Nebraska Natural Gas Company, Inc., Phillipsburg, Kans., was approved today by the Federal Lower Commission.

The bout between Ezzard Charles and Gus Lesnevich, scheduled for the Yankee Stadium for the night of Aug. 10, will not be regarded as for the heavyweight championship of the world, it was announced yesterday by Eddie Eagan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Moscow is directing a stream of its choicest epithets at Associate Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas for his vacation visit to Iran.

DEAR UNCLE JOE: I hate to begin all my letters with talk about my financial needs, but this business of gathering information for the great patriotic fatherland where, as the fellow said, all men are equal, but some men are equaller than others, is expensive, and I wish you would send me a tidy bale of bourgeois-reactionary-warmongering-redbaiting - witch-hunting-imperialistic dollars right away. They're such a comfort to have around.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 (AP) -- The jury in the Tokyo Rose treason trial was excused today while the judge, the lawyers, the reporters and the defendant donned earphones to hear recordings of "Orphan Ann's" wartime broadcasts from Radio Tokyo.
LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., July 29 (AP) -- Thirty-two-year-old William Mihalo of Detroit today won the fifteen-mile event of Lake George's first annual international walking races.

SHANGHAI, July 29 -- A complete reversal in the American attitude toward the prospects of foreign business in China has taken place here since the first few weeks of Communist rule. Originally encouraged by the discipline of the Communist army, the zeal and honesty of Communist political workers and the party's apparent eagerness to trade on a nonsentimental basis, American business men have gone through a steady process of disillusionment.

Concerned about the lack of knowledge among its membership in relation to rules governing working conditions. Actors Equity Association and Chorus Equity have decided to hold four meetings this season at which instructions will be given to new members "covering the history and government'' of the association, it was announced yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 29 -- There are many diplomatic observers in Prague who feel that both the Vatican and the Czechoslovak Government have made tactical mistakes in the developing conflict between the Roman Catholic religion and the Communist state here.

Directors of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $4 a share on the 213,052 shares of 6 per cent cumulative participating preferred stock, payable on Sept. 1. In January April and June of this year, the company distributed $1.50 a share against arrears on the issue, which amounted to $77.50 a share on June 30, 1949.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- The country's four top-ranking women tennis players reached the semi-final round of the invitation tournament at the Maidstone Club today.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 29 (AP) -- Australia's Davis Cuppers received a scare today before they subdued a pair of stubborn brothers from old Mexico to take a 2-0 lead in the opening singles matches of the American zone final.

The Port of New York Authority was called upon yesterday from two different sources to tighten up enforcement of regulations governing the cargoes carried by trucks through the Holland Tunnel, and to improve and modernize the tunnel's fire-fighting equipment.

The twenty-fifth Bayside-Block Island Auxiliary handicap yacht race -- the oldest event of its kind in the country -- started on schedule yesterday with nine craft slipping past Stepping Stones Lighthouse under power. The start was held in a flat calm and all skippers elected the option of using engines to get under way.
ALICE, Tex., July 29 -- W. H. Mason, 51-year-old newspaper and crusading radio man, was killed today on a street of this south Texas town.

The private sale of 2,000 shares of common stock of the Christiana Securities Company, the $3,000-a-share personal holding company of the du Pont family, was announced yesterday by the First Boston Corporation and Laird, Bissell Meeds.

GARY, Ind., July 29 -- The weather continued to picket the Gary women's citizens committee pickets today as they stood in front of reputed gambling places and houses of prostitution. Yesterday the heat forced many of them off the streets and today the rain was equally discouraging.

An estate holding on the West Side passed to new control in a cash transaction reported yesterday by E. H. Ludlow Co., brokers, who sold the one-story taxpayer on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 2503-09 Broadway, between West Ninety - third and Ninety - fourth Streets, for the Eugene Higgins heirs to the 2505 Broadway, Inc., Harry Pasternak, president.

The current hot weather wave penetrated the stock market yesterday. In a session unmatched in almost a month for its dullness, prices barely moved and the few changes of more than fractions had no relationship to the general trend.

Grace Di Fiore pitched the boys' softball team of Vacation Playground 208 to a 4-1 victory over the visitors from Vacation Playground 181 yesterday. In a startling comeback after losing 20-0 the day before the Flatbush Flipper allowed only two hits and further confounded her rivals by blasting a homer in the first inning with two men on base.
OSLO, July 29 (AP) -- The star-spangled American track and field team capped an uphill climb tonight by winning the "Little Olympics" and its accompanying decathlon competition.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 29 (AP) -- The New York State department of the American Legion opposed after a controversy today a proposal that would substitute a point system in civil service for the absolute preference now given veterans.

Four men, one an ex-convict free in $10,000 bail on a grand larceny charge were accused by a Federal grand jury yesterday of violating the Gold Reserve Act of 1934 as part of a scheme that allegedly led to the diversion of $2,500,000 in fine gold to the European black market.

Continuation of the Federal excise tax of 20 per cent on the retail sale of furs will react adversely upon the employment of approximately 250,000 farmer-trappers, according to a survey made for the American Fur Merchants Association by the American Management Counsel, it was announced here yesterday.

PARIS, July 29 -- By a majority of three votes Premier Henri Queuille's center coalition cabinet today escaped defeat but was weakened considerably in prestige just on the eve of a parliamentary recess.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The House "monopoly" committee today invited H. A. Toulmin Jr. of Dayton, Ohio, patent lawyer and author of a series of authoritative books on patent and anti-trust law, to submit drafts of proposed measures to revamp all current antitrust law.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- In one of the finest performances of his career William F. Talbert of New York defeated Herbert Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., today, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0, to reach the final of the fifty-ninth annual invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President, declared last night that the United States "must move at once to set up a world-wide development fund through the United Nations in place of the one-sided wasteful funds we are now spending abroad to build up arms."

BERLIN, July 29 -- Although the Soviet Military Government and the German Communists have imposed a number of restrictive measures against the Roman Catholic Church in the Soviet zone, there is as yet no organized over-all campaign against the Church, and the decree of Pope Pius XII excommunicating Communists will be used sparingly, a Catholic source declared today.

The Huffman Boyle Company has leased the Morris Essex Roller Arena on the Morris Turnpike in Springfield, N. J., and will convert it into a retail furniture store. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.
Stanley R. Klinger has been appointed vice president of Klinger Bros. Corporation, Pontiac dealer with showrooms at 1141 Lexington Avenue and service station at 421 East Ninety-third Street.
BERLIN, July 29 -- Unemployment in Western Berlin is growing at what Military Government officials here acknowledge to be "a terrifying rate."

Double features are responsible not only for the "repetitious trash" on the screen but also are keeping a large part of the public away I from the movies, Al Lichtman, vice president of Twentieth Century-Fox, declared yesterday. He added that only the theatre owners have the power to discontinue the depression-born bargain policy, "the main cause of the hue and cry of bad pictures."

Chef Gaston Magrin, head of a kitchen staff of 122 on the newly remodeled Ile de France, sat down yesterday with some fifty food writers from the metropolitan press for a luncheon that followed out the French culinary tenet that "meals must be tuned to the climate."

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 29 -- The Government of Israel has informed the United States that it will accept 100,000 Arab refugees when peace has been proclaimed, it was learned today. But it still insists that, pending the peace settlement, it will accept only members of the Arab families now in Israel.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 29 (AP) -- A suit filed in Federal Court here alleges that the president and directors of the Iowa Electric Light and Power Company have defrauded the company of nearly $4,000,000. The suit, filed yesterday by Edwin T. Hughson, Buffalo, a stockholder, asks a complete accounting.

PARIS, July 29 -- The final planning for the meeting at Strasbourg that will be the first step toward the forming of a European Parliament will take place in Paris next Friday, the French Foreign Office announced today.

The Automobile Club of New York warns motor vacationists with an excess of good-will toward strangers to beware of hitch-hikers and the ingratiating smiles of "thumbers" on the highways. Motorists are told that the benevolent spirit which prompts a "lift" for the asking may result in robbery or other serious trouble as return for a generous deed.

ST. LOUIS, July 30 (Saturday) -- The Cardinals and Dodgers achieved a new high in frustration when, at nine minutes after 1 o'clock this morning, they trotted off the field after having played their second consecutive tie game.

Here on week-end passes, twenty-one soldier-patients from the Valley Force General Hospital in Phoenixville, Pa., began last night "to see the sights" as guests of the 52 Association of New York, Inc.

CINCINNATI, July 29 -- The Giants were completely baffled by the 22-year-old Herman Wehmeier at Crosley Field tonight, and, before a gathering of 16,480, lost a chance to strengthen their hold on fourth place in the National League.

Tables of natural walnut, primavera and mahogany, whose tops remain completely unaffected by such household calamities as a burning cigarette or an overturned highball glass, may sound like a dream to the average homemaker, but actually they are a reality.

WASHINGTON, July 29--Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the Rockefeller Foundation and General Education Board, and Dr. Everett Case, president of Colgate University, have been selected as the two non-governmental consultants to aid in a searching review of United States policy in the Far East, it was learned today.

"The Neurosis of Man," by Trigant Burrow, M. D., a report on the basic causes of human conflict, will be published by Harcourt, Brace on Thursday. The author presents the results of thirty years of research in the field he has called phylobiology, viewing crime, war and insanity as evidences of a social pathology.

MOSCOW, July 29 -- The newspaper Izvestia today published an account of what it described as a "medieval decree" by the Vatican excommunicating from the Catholic Church all Catholic Communists and sympathizers.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Truman Administration's fair employment practices bill was cleared by the House Education and Labor Committee today, 14 to 11, and preparations were im mediately made to by-pass the hostile Rules Committee in bringing it to the floor.
TOKYO, July 29 -- The Japanese press and public today generally approve Gen. Douglas MacArthur's order yesterday drastically reducing the American Military Government here.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich, July 29 -- The Reserve Officers Association, 236 to 206, today in effect gave a vote of confidence to Defense Secretary Louis Johnson on his cancellation of the Navy supercarrier program.

Berkshire Farm at Canaan, N. Y., aptly described in the title page of its 1948 annual report, just issued, as "a modern promised land where unwanted boys are wanted and where security and faith are given to boys who previously have known only failure or cruelty," has been responsible for remolding more than 3,000 boys for good citizenship in its sixty-three years of service.

Two traffic innovations were adopted here yesterday. The Department of Traffic Engineering used automatic counters for the first time and also disclosed that it had hired a woman traffic engineer to take charge of surveys.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Duck shooters will get ten days more hunting next fall, Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug said today.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- The "big three" of the nation's ranking three-year-olds -- Ponder, Capot and Palestinian, today were named to race four mighty respectable challengers in the $88,750 Arlington Classic, which winds up Arlinton Park's meeting tomorrow.

In commenting on a suggestion for a gold coin standard of $35 per ounce, Sir Chunilal B. Mehta, in a letter to you on June 22, mentions additional steps besides mine in the direction of international stabilization.

LONDON, July 29 -- A draft constitution for a new international of non-Communist trade unions was approved by an international committee today for submission to a constituent conference of trade union organizations in London from Nov. 28 to Dec. 7.

New technical facilities that will aid the State Department's Voice of America broadcasts in reaching listeners in Europe and the Middle East are being constructed in Tangier, it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, July 29 -- British Government bonds were much quieter, today after yesterday's sea-saw movements. When the market opened, stocks began to climb as "bears" sought to cover. Improvement continued and gains up to a half had been recorded by the close.

A co-owner of a restaurant in the Bronx herded his customers to safety last night seconds before a three-ton moving-van type truck crashed into his establishment after rolling down an incline out of control. The vehicle demolished a twenty-foot wall and window, pushed a bar back 18 inches and cut beer and water supply lines.
The State of Montana announced yesterday that it will offer for sale on Aug. 15 an issue of $5,000,000 of University of Montana building bonds dated Sept. 1, 1949, and due from Sept. 1, 1950 to 1969.
VIENNA, July 29 -- A worldwide appeal for the return of Mozart's gold watch and gold ring was made today by Dr. Carlton Smith, director of the National Arts Foundation of New York.

KOZANI, Greece, July 29 (AP) -- The Greek High Command and United States military advisers are making a final inspection of Greek combat units before launching an offensive against the Communist guerrillas. The drive is planned in the Grammos and Vitsi mountains on the Albanian frontier.

Perhaps it is because they are in sixth place, going nowhere in the race and are "loose" at all times, but whatever the reason, the White Sex have been giving the pace-setting Yankees considerable trouble lately. They've been tough, even while succumbing to the admittedly superior New Yorkers.
ROME, Saturday, July 30 -- The Senate approved early today a motion endorsing the Government's decision to sign the Atlantic Treaty. The vote was 175 to 81.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29--The Coast Guard cutter Iroquois was churning through the Pacific at eighteen knots an hour tonight, taking an iron lung to an Army transport on which a 6-year-old boy had been stricken with poliomyelitis.

ALBANY, July 29 -- Governor Dewey announced at 11:05 o'clock tonight that "great progress" had been made in a thirteen-hour conference in his offices here toward settlement of the two-year-old Idlewild Airport dispute.

When the Ile de France swept proudly into New York Harbor the other day in her $25,000,000 new outfit, she was hailed as a symbol of the renaissance of France. This is certainly what she meant to the French who crowded the beaches and jetties of Le Havre to speed her on her way.

United Artists announced yesterday that "Home of the Brave," dealing with anti-Negro prejudice, has been "passed for exhibition by Lloyd Binford, Memphis censor." Mr. Binford has gained considerable attention in recent months for refusing to permit the showing in Tennessee of pictures with mixed Negro and white players.

Forty-two more cases of poliomyelitis were reported to the Health Department in the last twenty-four hours in New York City. Three hundred and six cases have been reported this year, 150 of them in the past week.

Federal Judge Harold R. Medina began the curtailment yesterday of such defense testimony in the Communist trial as deals solely with "peripheral" matters instead of directly with the main issues in the case.

WILLIAM PRESCOTT is probably the most exasperating man in recent fiction. He is at once subtle and crass, intuitive and bumptious. He is a wizard at business, piling up millions, yet he makes his big decisions on sheer emotional impulse.

Drew Middleton's "Hans Schmidt: "Portrait of a 'Kleiner Mann'" shows again the jealousy and hate the German people, young and old, have for the French. Hans Schmidt is typical of his race in flaunting its desire for power and in his regret that the Germans have not been recognized as the superior race.

During World War II a good many members of yacht clubs and units of the United States Power Squadrons contributed to the war effort by service with the Coast Guard Auxiliary. It was not beer and skittles. Business men tore away from their offices donned real or makeshift uniforms and spent nights and days as members of various units and flotillas.

FROM Pierce Egan's picturesque if not always reliable "Fistiana," through the three thick volumes of Henry Downes Miles' precise, rewarding "Pugilistica" to Trevor Wignall's "Story of Boxing" and other modern works, the English prize ring has gathered around it an impressive literature.

OMAHA, July 30 -- The isolationist brand worn long by the Mid-West has rubbed down almost to the point of extinction, with the result that this region is applauding the Atlantic Pact and its side commitments almost as vigorously as seaboard sections.
LONDON, July 30 -- Prime Minister Attlee denounced today as "abuse and misrepresentation of the grossest kind" Winston Churchill's campaign charges against the Labor Government.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The House Armed Services Committee today set Aug. 9 for the start of its long-awaited investigation of the Giant B-36 bombers and conditions surrounding their selection, which became a subject of controversy in early spring.

THE novel of suspense is replacing the straight detective story to such an extent that even so old a hand at the deductive problem as Clifford Knight is abandoning it for the pursuit formula. He brings to the new field his one real virtue, a vividly communicated sense of locale (in this ease Los Angles, Lake Arrowhead, and the Arizona desert), and all his familiar vices of wooden characterization, unlikely dialogue and preposterous plotting.

NEW LONDON, N. H. -- Old Home Week is to be lengthened to Old Home Month in New Hampshire this year as the state observes the fiftieth anniversary of this custom during August. Gov. Sherman Adams has issued a proclamation calling for celebrations throughout the month, and communities across the state are making special plans to entertain visitors and native sons who will return from all over the country.

PAUL PINE, a noteworthy private detective, who is all there both above and below the chin and who did fairly memorable work in "Halo in Blood" and "Halo for Satan," is now on another case -- this time one of those seemingly routine jobs of finding out what became of an attractive girl who left her home in a small town and went to the big city (Chicago) in search of fame and fortune.

In more than two-thirds of the plants included in an industry-wide survey, production is either on the up-grade or holding to previous schedules, and order booking reveals the greatest strength since the start of the decline in general business. But some price adjustments are still to be made, according to the report for July of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
Columbia University has appointed six new members to its faculty and promoted fourteen, Albert C. Jacobs, university provost, announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, July 30 -- The United Nations said today that Secretary General Trygve Lie and his staff had nothing to do with the granting of Consultative status to the Women's International Democratic Federation.

BOSTON, July 30 -- Attention has been focused upon the unfavorable aspects of New England business by this week's visit of Secretary of Commerce Sawyer to Boston, where he had conferences with New England business leaders on what the Government might do to bolster New England industry.
THE fragrant harvest of herbs begins in early summer, with the gathering of green leaves for immediate use in salads. But the bulk of the crop is cut in August, for drying and future use.

A PEDIATRICIAN and a former nursery schoolteacher seem the logical combination of authorities to provide that long-needed answer to the young child's question, "Where was I before I was here?" Every parent knows that this question and similar questions are coming their way at some time and all have a slight feeling of uneasiness as to how to handle them.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The State Department formally announced today the appointment of Raymond B. Fosdick, former president of the Rockefeller Foundation and Dr. Everett Case, president of Colgate University, as consultants to Secretary of State Dean Acheson in the projected complete review of United States policy regarding the Far East.

GENEVA, July 30 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council decided today, after strong Russian objections, to ask the International Labor Organization to establish a fact-finding and conciliation commission to protect trade union rights.

ATHENS, July 30 -- The possibility of the establishment of normal relations between Greece and her northern neighbor, Yugoslavia, seemed diminished today when information reaching the Greek Government reported that an unspecified number of Greek nationals residing in Skoplje, capital of Yugoslav Macedonia, had been arrested.
HOBOKEN, N. J., July 30 -- Three gangs of longshoremen, numbering approximately sixty men, walked off Pier 9 here early today.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Commitments for new industrial facilities in the Chicago area totaled $7,813,000 in July, reports from thirty-five companies indicated. The total outlay for plants for the first seven months this year was $60,933,000.

"RELIGION," wrote Karl Marx, is a "fantastic realization of the human being. * * * The struggle against religion is therefore indirectly the struggle against that world whose spiritual aroma is religion. * * * Religion is the moan of the oppressed creature, the sentiment of a heartless world.

LONDON, July 30 -- The Royal Institute of International Affairs reported today that Eastern Europe was facing an economic crisis that might force 10,000,000 unemployed and unwanted peasants into slave labor camps.

OTTAWA, July 30 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent, whose Liberal party won an overwhelming victory in the Canadian general election June 27, will return to his office on Monday after a vacation and it is expected that he will shortly announce that the new Parliament will open September 15.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 30 -- To compel Union Free School District 13 to provide adequate school facilities, state aid may be withheld, it was learned today.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 30 (AP) -- Delaware Power and Light Company today reported a net income of $1,565,445 for the first six months of 1949, equal to $1 a common share, compared with $1,098,029, or 80 cents, for the same period of 1948.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 30 -- Plans to turn Sagamore Hill, home of President Theodore Roosevelt, into a national shrine have been blocked by the Board of Trustees of the village of Cove Neck, it was announced today.

In a dual role unusual in this country, a Bavarian-born friar following in the footsteps of St. Francis of Assisi is the architect for a new building unit, to be started within a few days, in the fast-growing St. Clare's Hospital group in the area just west of Times Square.

THE second American Dance Festival at Connecticut College, New London, has announced the full repertoire for its season of eleven performances in Palmer Auditorium. The participating groups are those of Valerie Bettis, Jose Limon and the Dudley-Maslow-Bales Trio, each of whom will present new works, several of which have not as yet been titled.
ATLANTA, July 30 -- This is the feeling over much of the Southeast today: Russia is beginning to soften her attitude, and the tension in the East-West "cold war" is diminishing.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission, announced yesterday that he was ready to run for Borough President of Manhattan on the Democratic and Liberal party tickets with the understanding that, if elected, he would have a free hand in the conduct of that office.

MISS HACKETT'S book comes at a time when Wellesley is celebrating its seventy-fifth anniversary and is a history of that women's college in Massachusetts. It is a history of expansion and one that has, in some ways, paralleled the development of the country.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 30 (AP) -- Jersey City erased a four-run deficit tonight to sweep its three-game series with the league leading Buffalo Bisons, 6 -- 5. The victory gave the Little Giants undisputed possession of second place and put them within two games of the Herd.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 30 -- A Socialist three-member delegation headed by Premier Paul-Henri Spaak will leave tomorrow for Switzerland to seek elucidation from King Leopold on his attitude toward a proposal to settle by plebiscite the question of his return to the throne.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 30 -- The Echo Bay Yacht Club played host to the eighteenth Y. R. H. championship regatta today, opening its annual two-day series on Long Island Sound.

THE three remaining major defendants in the Government's 11-year-old anti-trust suit (Loew's Inc., Twentieth Century-Fox and Warner Brothers) were dealt a body blow last Monday when a Federal statutory court here ordered total divorcement of production and distribution from exhibition.

By utilizing the "plentiful opportunities" in Italy for private investment, American business can "powerfully promote Italian recovery," according to Signor Roberto Tremelloni, Italian Minister of European Recovery Program affairs and permanent Italian delegate to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Administration was reported working today on a proposal to reduce the size and scope of President Truman's $1,450,000,000 foreign arms program.

SHANGHAI, July 30 -- Chinese and Sikh former employes of the United States Navy who swarmed into the United States Consulate here yesterday morning were still there tonight, although they had relaxed their siege to allow all but three key consular officials to go home.

WHAT the Chinese Communist forces have been doing in the way of stampissuing has not been officially disclosed. Some light is thrown on the situation through the receipt last week by J. H. Stolow of two series thought to have been printed in Russia.

PRICE cuts on 8mm and 16mm movie cameras and a projector are announced by the Keystone Manufacturing Company. The $116.50 Keystone 8mm magazine K-40, with the f/2.5 fixed-focus lens, is now $99.50. With the f/1.9 focusing lens, the K-40, formerly $145.50, is now $124.50.

As the week-end approached our national legislators seemed to be in something of a dither. An unexpected parliamentary explosion in the Senate had temporarily removed the foreign aid programs from action on the floor. They will be back again presently, but in the meanwhile valuable time has been lost.

SHIRAHAMA, Japan, July 25 -- Checked for the moment in its attempt to stimulate a "labor offensive" against the policies of the Occupation, the Japanese Communist party is making a vigorous drive to extend its power in the farm and fishing villages that are the homes of one-third of this nation's 80,000,000 population.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 30 -- This community's general support of the Atlantic Pact and the arms program belies the strong isolationism which has marked its thinking in the past.

ONLY because France has been spared any incidence of bobby-soxers, Gerard Philipe is free to walk the sidewalks of Paris without fear of bodily harm. At 27, after six pictures, he is most certainly the ranking younger idol of those French women who can afford the movies today, and his photographs unquestionably must be the most popular current item on bedroom walls from Dieppe to St. Rafael.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Hotels, hospitals and other organizations serving the public plan to spend $9,000,000,000,000 within the next twelve months to improve their operations, it was reported today. The expenditures will be for new construction, maintenance, refurnishing and re-equipment.
FORT MONROE, Va., July 30 -- Gen. Jacob L. Devers, chief of the Army Field Forces, will retire Sept. 30, the public information office at Fort Monroe, site of AFF headquarters, announced today.

WITH the summer vacation season just about half gone, resort operators are generally congratulating themselves on the fact that the season is proving to be better than they expected as recently as four weeks ago.

THE Floods of Bristol, slave-traders and merchants extraordinary, were too colorful and cocksure to be confined to a single best-seller. Here, in another outsize saga that can match "The Sun Is My Undoing" for action, pace and excitement, Mass Steen carries on to the turn of our century the story of "this monstrously endowed family."
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 30 -- Comdr. John P. Bracken of the Navy Reserve was elected president of the National Reserve Officers Association today as the convention of the association ended here.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 30 -- Lebanese police have started a general drive against Communists in the final stage of a determined effort to free the country from active seditious elements after crushing the Syrian Popular party's rebellion.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Charles F. Brannan, the Secretary of Agriculture, has promised Senators full cooperation on any farm price-support plan they draft.

DENVER -- A drive up the rugged highway that leads to Pikes Peak is almost as much of a thrill today as the sight of that towering mountain was to the gold hunters of 1858-59 who coined the phrase "Pikes Peak or Bust."

EVERYTHING that has happened and is happening in Communist-dominated Czechoslovakia could happen in western Europe. This is the special lesson provided for western Europeans as the Communists complete the spread of their absolute authority into the last non-Communist sectors of Czechoslovak life.

RICHMOND, Va., July 30 -- Charges that national labor organizations were trying to dominate Virginia's primary election for Governor on Tuesday took the spotlight here today as the four-cornered race moved into its final phases.

Showers splashed the city last night several hours after the mercury had reached 94.2 degrees. It was the fourth consecutive day in which temperature in the nineties had been aggravated by muggy humidity in the fifties.

AT this summer's wholesale markets there were numerous indications of a trend toward increased use of metal in furniture designed for formal "front room" use. Illustrated here are samples from the biggest metal-and-wood collection -- the series of living-room, dining and bedroom pieces designed by Tommi Parzinger for Salterini.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 30 -- Allie's Pal, guided by the rail-minded Jockey Johnny Gilbert, won the $18,050 Molly Pitcher Handicap at Monmouth Park today. Competing against a field of five others including the favored My Emma, Allie's Pal, running in the silks of Samuel D. Sidell, scored a two-length victory in the mile-and-a-sixteenth test.

Anticipation of a fall pick-up in industrial activity and clarification of steel union wage demands last week had little effect on financial markets, which moved ahead, albeit at a slower pace. The mixed character of earnings statements now being published, blending with a spotty improvement in some lines, was overshadowed by the cumulative effect of rapidly deteriorating economic conditions in Europe.
ST. LOUIS, July 30 -- It begins to look as though the Dodgers are not serious about beating the Cardinals, or if they are their performance does not match their intent.

SALEM, Ore. AMERICANS are leaving the farm. Three million fewer people live on farms today than in 1940, although the population of the United States has soared by nearly 14,000,000 during the interval. Could this be why my colleagues from the soil view me with suspicion and mistrust as we sit under Oregon's turret-like Capitol dome?

HOLIDAYERS who must go down to the sea for their vacations but who cannot get aboard an ocean liner, or prefer not to, are having fun these summer days sailing on windjammer cruises and in yachts that can be hired.

The proposed program by a group of Quakers with respect to the future relations between the United States and Soviet Russia will doubtless receive favorable comment in communistic circles. In the minds of the proponents of the program, however, I do not believe that that was intended.

PROPAGATION by cuttings is one method that is used to increase the supply of plants which are difficult to raise from seed, do not come true from seed, or fail to set seed at all. Now and throughout August many trees, shrubs, vines and groundcovers may be inexpensively reproduced in this manner.

PARAGUAY is one of earth's paradises. Sooner or later those insatiable travelers, the norteamericanos, are bound to discover it, because there is not anything wrong with it except revolutions. All the people this reviewer knows who have lived in Paraguay -- a fair number -- love it; whenever it is mentioned to them you can see the gleam in the eye which means "I, too," have dwelt in Arcady."
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- The Republican-Southern Democratic House coalition that scuttled Taft-Hartley repeal prepared today for a repeat performance on the Administration's wage-hour bill.

The 1949 American Merchant Marine Conference to be held in conjunction with the annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States Will open a three-day session in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Oct. 19. This year's convention will be the club's twenty-third.

THOSE who dine regularly in Hungarian or Austrian restaurants savor stuffed cabbage; stuffed peppers are standard with every American housewife. The time is right, in view of the bounty from summer gardens, to apply this excellent method to other members of the vegetable kingdom.

AFTER more than half-a-dozen years, Noel Coward is coming back to the screen in his own version of his own short play "The Astonished Heart." No one is more surprised than Mr. Coward to find himself on a movie set again, but it seems that circumstances fixed it for him.

HONOLULU, July 30 -- Representatives of the seven struck Hawaii stevedoring companies and of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, CIO, met for one hour here this afternoon at the Iolani Palace at the request of the Territorial Legislature and then announced that they had made no particular progress toward settlement of the ninety-one-day-old dock tie-up.
The Bull liner Puerto Rico arrived in New York yesterday afternoon from Baltimore where she was reconditioned for her new owners by the Maryland Drydock Company.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration is planning an attack on practices under the veterans' education program that it says approach racketeering. H. V. Stirling, the agency's assistant administrator, said today that some of the 1,400 new private schools catering to veterans that had opened in the last year bordered on being rackets.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UP) -- The International Federation of Transport Workers recommended today that 5,000,000 members in forty-five countries boycott 800 Panamanian ships and the vessels of any country where Communist-controlled unions refused to work cargoes sailed by federation members.

THE Western Reserve. which Harlan Hatcher fondly calls New Connecticut in Ohio, was originally a tract of some 3,000,000 acres reserved by the State of Connecticut. When the Atlantic states ceded their transmontane possessions to the Federal Government in the Seventeen Eighties, Connecticut retained a section extending roughly from the western boundary of Pennsylvania 120 miles westward and then northward to Lake Erie.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- A proposal to sell 211,225 shares of common stock in Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, Owensboro, Ky., a gas pipeline operator, has been registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Police Sgt. George F. W. Kreig, 45 years old, of 4765 Carpenter Avenue, the Bronx, assigned for the last four years to the East Sixty-seventh Street station and due for retirement at 11:59 o'clock last night, received a complete hunting outfit -- from boots to gun -- by the patrolmen at the 4 o'clock "turnout" yesterday afternoon.

LONDON -- Resourceful Britons, subject to national currency-control regulations which limit their spending abroad, are finding ways to gratify their love for travel in spite of the restrictions on their vacation budgets.
On Oct. 21 the Metropolitan Museum of Art will open the largest exhibition ever staged in this country of the works of Vincent Van Gogh.

Responsibility for the collision between a Navy Hellcat and the Eastern airliner in which sixteen persons were killed was attributed last night to the pilot of the naval plane by Leslie P. Arnold, vice president of Eastern.

Retail trade during the remainder of the year has a good chance of showing better results than during the months which have passed, many retailers asserted here last week. Although they do not expect a marked improvement in August, beginning with September and on through the holidays they are hoping for smaller declines in comparison with last year.

"Stay in the house," Ira Henry Freeman advises in his "Pessimistic Notes on a Pest," and thus avoid poison ivy. But how did the birds and animals get immune? By staying in bird-houses and heated barns?

BOSTON, July 30 -- Although some groups were disappointed by Secretary of Commerce Charles Sawyer's failure to offer a panacea for New England's economic ills this week, those who took the long view saw his "trouble-shooting" survey in the light of a stimulating diagnosis.

NEWARK, N. J., July 30 -- A preliminary injunction sought against six officials of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, in connection with the walkout of 400 longshoremen and checkers at piers D and F of the American Export Lines in Jersey City was denied today by Superior Court Judge William J. Brennan. The ruling was made after a three-day hearing here.

Scoring twice in the eighth inning of a seesaw contest, the Cardinals downed the second-place Dodgers, 7 -- 6, last night and increased their league lead to two and one-half games. The White Sox toppled the Yankees yesterday, 9 -- 2, by routing Vic Raschi in the fourth.

BOSTON, July 30 -- More than 1,500 Waves from twenty-seven states, meeting here today for their third annual national reunion and the observance of the seventh anniversary of the establishment of the Women's Reserves, were told that the Navy had just completed plans for assignment of enlisted Waves to units overseas.

The announcements concerning the formation of an advisory group to study our Asiatic policy have emphasized that the study will be on a broad regional basis. It is felt, presumably, that only in that way can we escape being trapped in fruitless controversy at a number of specific points. Obviously this will not meet the demand for prompt and effective action, but it should lay the basis, over a period, for wise and consistent courses.

LONDON, July 30 -- The Admiralty announced tonight that the warship Amethyst had evaded Communist batteries and rejoined the Far Eastern Fleet. The sloop's escape was made known in a message received by the Admiralty. It said: "Rejoined the fleet.
MY first night at a youth hostel -- it was up in Plymouth, N. H. -- found me suspicious. Kid stuff, and at 50 cents a night the clientele attracted probably would be noisy.

A fair number of reorders for zip-out lining coats and fall dresses and sportswear were received by the wholesale apparel market here last week, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buying office.

SHANGHAI, July 30 -- Representatives of the city's industries conferred yesterday on plans for a mass migration into the interior. Meanwhile, a published survey indicated that more than half of Shanghai's factories now are at a standstill.

CHARLES BLESSINGTON, a mild-mannered, conventional and intelligent British Treasury official, reaches Berlin in the August of 1945, intending to transact some financial business with the Control Commission. However, an unexpected and violent encounter on a dark street corner transfers him abruptly into the intelligence business and sends him cloak-and-daggering around Germany at a recklessly dizzy pace.

READER, I will lay a bet with you. I offer to eat neither my words nor my bonnet, but I'm willing to wager a sonnet against a triolet that this review I am writing in an early July heat wave will be read by you about the time the snow flies.

BUENOS AIRES, July 30 -- The Inter-American Evangelical Conference, in its closing session here this afternoon, approved a "message" to the estimated 3,000,000 Protestants below the Rio Grande denouncing as "anti-Christian and anti-human" any political, social or economic system "which diminishes or exploits the human personality or prevents its free expression."

THE four Golden Goose Chap Books listed above represent the beginning of a hopeful experiment in the publishing of poetry. Robert Wirtz Emerson and Frederick Eckman, who edit and publish the magazine The Golden Goose in Columbus, Ohio, are apparently convinced that poetry need not spell bankruptcy and sudden death to the publisher.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Calumet Farm's Ponder gave 32,047 Chicago racing fans, the biggest turnout of the year, a re-run of his sensational Kentucky Derby victory today at Arlington Park in the twenty-first running of the $87,750 Classic.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Congress has been in session now for seven months and President Truman's effective relationship with that body has been running usually from only the tolerably good to the distinctly bad.

Marini Pigini, a gentleman of grandiose gesture, has roamed the world over. "But where in the world," he demands, "is there such a town as Castelfidardo with its 10,000 men, women and children and everyone an accordion maker!"

CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP) -- "Threats of violence" prevented Dennison Duble from breaking off with the alleged $50,000,000-a-year tri-state numbers ring, a member of the law firm representing the resigned secretary-manager of the Cincinnati Clearing House Association said today.

THIS book belongs with the basic documents of World War II. It was time that General Anders told the full story of that savagely efficient Polish Second Corps, which planted in blood the Allied flags atop the Cassino monastery, and time that Anders spoke his own mind.
DETROIT, July 30 (AP) -- The automobile industry is aiming at the sale of at least 4,000,000 new cars this year.

DETROIT, July 30 -- Speed boating's top level international trophy, the famous Harmsworth, for which wealthy sportsmen have spent millions since 1903 when the late Lord Northcliffe, then Sir Alfred Harmsworth, created the exciting competition, will stay for at least another year in the United States where Gar Wood brought it in 1920.

An ancient mariner stopped a wedding guest on the strand recently, fixed him with a glittering eye and began to talk. The wedding guest could not choose but hear. The subject was taxes. "Well, what about taxes?" "They're awful." "Real estate taxes?" "No, income taxes."

THIS account of the effort of the French Parliament to control the foreign policy of the Third Republic was written in 1939, but publication was delayed by the war. Its value, however, to those who seek to understand the French tragedy -- and also the good and bad effects of popular control of foreign policy -- has not been diminished.

Harold Preece, 35 years old, who gave his address as Ward 17, Ellis Island, cooled off last night by jumping or falling overboard from a ferry bound for Ellis Island. He was fished out of the water by two men in a boat sent out from a passing Staten Island ferry and was taken to the Beekman Street Hospital little the worse for his experience.
Drew Middleton in "Hans Schmidt: Portrait of a 'Kleiner Mann'" leaves the impression that not only Hans but Mr. Middleton himself believes that "after the defeat of 1918 came fifteen years of chaos."

BERLIN, July 30 -- Dr. Ernst Reuter, Lord Mayor of Berlin, said today that he had launched an urgent appeal to the Western commandants to assist the city in getting Immediate Marshall Plan help as "the only hope" in Berlin's "disastrous financial condition."

HOLLYWOOD. METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER is currently developing three properties which involve conflicts in subject-matter with competitors, although Metro spokesmen officially explain, in tones of quiet dignity, that the company is simply interested in making good pictures and can take no cognizance of the activities of lesser breeds of producers.

Statements made by Senator Joseph McCarthy of Wisconsin -- that imported Japanese gloves were undermining the American knitted glove industry -- were challenged last week by New York importers. Japanese gloves coming into this country, they held, represent a small portion of the total gloves sold here and do not compete unfairly with the American product.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., July 30 (UP) -- P. A. Katzin came happily to the airport here today to greet his wife, 5-months-old daughter and brother.

LONDON, July 30 -- Britain's Labor Government is approaching a grave time of trial both at the polls and in the world's market places and the Government's degree of success in surmounting the country's marketing problems may have a vital effect on the outcome of the next general election.

A LITERARY masterpiece, Mr. Lynes' article was like a fresh, invigorating breeze cutting through the heat wave. Drawing a line between intellectuals as a caste, or group, and men who are intellectual but don't set themselves apart from society, was just one of the effective expositions made in the article which is chock-full of sense.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 30 -- Interest in the "cold war" between Russia and the democratic nations has waned in the Pacific Northwest, despite the recent overwhelming approval by the Senate of the North Atlantic Treaty.

A FIRST novel about post-war college days, "Thanks for the Ride" is a gay, lighthearted book that evidently draws heavily on its young author's personal experiences. They seem to be shared generously among the three students -- Jerry, Bob and Greg -- with personal identification going at a guess to Jerry, the brilliant, literary and sophisticated one.

Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger committed Mrs. Sarah Marie Doig, 50 years old, to Bellevue Hospital for mental observation yesterday when she was arraigned in Felony Court on charges of felonious assault in firing a rifle Friday at city marshals and police who were evicting Mrs. Doig and her blind, 88-year-old mother, Mrs. Sarah Maloney, from their ground floor apartment at 348 East Nineteenth Street.

Sharp gains in industrial and agricultural production are claimed for Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia in recent Soviet press articles marking the ninth anniversary of the incorporation of those countries into the Soviet Union.

Combined registration in all the institutions of higher education in Illinois this fall will drop below the figures of the last three years, the Bureau of Institutional Research at the University of Illinois predicted last week. The bureau estimated that the state's 106 colleges, universities, junior colleges and professional and technical schools would have an enrollment of 145,000.

Freshmen who enter the College of Liberal Arts and the School of Education at Northwestern University in September will have the opportunity to enroll in a new course called "Introduction to the Sciences of Human Behavior." The course represents a combination of key concepts and materials now presented in three separate introductory courses in the departments of anthropology, psychology and sociology.
TO bridge players and writers alike, the "squeeze" is the most dramatic of all plays: A sure trick vanishes for one side, an impossible trick appears for the other.

The wishful prospect in official Washington of private investment opening up the world's undeveloped areas is seen in ironic relief currently against the marketing delay which Puerto Rico has run into in the insular territory's effort to finance continued expansion of its basic utility plant -- water supply, sewerage and electric power -- in the private financial markets of the continental United States.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 30 -- The opening race in the Atlantic Coast championship of the Lightning Class produced a big surprise this afternoon as forty-three boats sailed six miles twice around a triangular course off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

THERE is much talk about the troubles of our modern theatre and many complaints about the scarcity of exciting new scripts to draw customers to the box office. In these arguments very little is said about the playwright and his problems, or what may be needed to help him produce.
THESE four books offer young readers constructive suggestions for amusing themselves and answer, with varying degrees of satisfaction, the perennial question, "What shall I do now?"

BERLIN, July 30 -- There is no clearer indication of the manner in which nationalism is pervading the political campaign in Western Germany than the emergence among the leaders of the various political parties of a tendency to claim the exclusive ability to modify the Ruhr statute and end industrial dismantling.

IN his letter from Sweden June 26 your Stockholm correspondent has given a rather partial picture of the literary life in this country. If you were informed by some London correspondent that J. B. Priestley were the hope of literary recovery in England I suppose that you would find such a statement strange; a similar piece of information was given by your correspondent about literary life in Sweden.

John J. Corson's "Our Pension Madness" might have rendered a service by mentioning the political pampering of some of our civil servants in New York City -- our police and firemen -- who can retire after twenty years' service.

EQUIPMENT newly perfected by NBC engineers will be used on Tuesday to tell an unusual story in "Episode Three" of the "Lights Out" series on the NBC television network at 9 P. M. The new development, it is said, makes it possible for the first time to maintain continuity of action, including scene changes, on both sides of the screen in a "split screen" television show.

A third group of 350 boys is enjoying the facilities of the Clear Pool Camp in Carmel, N. Y., conducted by the Madison Square Boys Club of 301 East Twenty-ninth Street as part of its annual vacation project for 1,400 boys.

RICHMOND, Va., July 30 -- There is little feeling now in this area about the "cold war." Last winter, when spy investigations were being widely publicized, a rather strong spirit of hostile tension, tightened by the "Pumpkin Papers" enmity, was evident against the Soviet Union.

MR. LYNES in his sprightly "Intellectuals Vs. Philistines" neatly divides us into two classes. I feel there is an intermediate class, of which I am a member. I would dislike being caned an Intellectual as much as I would being called a Philistine.

To the Music Editor: I read with interest and enthusiasm Mr. Downes' Sunday article on Mme. Landowska, and followed -- naturally with approval -- his explanation and correction of the misinterpreted word "klavier."

Two French liners sailed yesterday within an hour for Europe, but one of them got no further than Staten Island anchorage waters. The 45,000-ton Ile de France, on her "maiden" voyage after reconditioning, departed from West Forty-eighth Street with 1,202 passengers, at 11 A. M. An hour later the De Grasse left the same pier with 680.

A COMMERCIAL radio deal involving the American Broadcasting Company has some ingenuities about it that rival horse-swapping transactions. Last year Douglas Leigh, the sign creator, leased one of his advertising blimps to ABC and in return was given credit for commercial radio time on the network's owned and operated stations.
HOW long has it been since you've been a "patient" in the Fathers' Room of the obstetrical ward, waiting for your wife to produce a twentieth-century wonder? Funny place, the Fathers' Room.

WORKABLE knowledge, acquired by a team of specialists, is available for those who want to increase the wholesome living of youngsters and emotional maturity of future adults. It is seldom dramatized so enjoyably as in this instance.

IN such novels as "V as in Victim" and "H as in Hunted," Lawrence Treat established himself as one of America's most distinguished mystery novelists. A man of warm psychological sensitivity, he showed a unique ability for at once clarifying the most detailed jobs of police procedure and humanizing the men who carry out those jobs.

The first of the season's katydids have been scraping out their night calls this past week. They have faltered a bit, uncertain in rhythm and untrue in pitch; but there they are, unmistakable -- katydids in the hot, humid July night. And if one believes the old superstition that it is only six weeks from the first katydid to the first frost, early September will bring crisp nights.

Last week any or all of these phrases could have been applied to the weather in much of the United States. Throughout the East and Midwest this month, average high temperatures have ranged from three to six degrees above the average high over the years.
Employes of the Bell Syndicate and three affiliated agencies will return to work tomorrow under an agreement ending an eleven-week strike.

Joseph A. Barry in his "Appraisal of the Communists in France" repeats the fable that Communist resistance began only after Russia was attacked. When France was invaded, more than a year before the Nazi attack on Russia, the French Communist Central Committee, though outlawed by the Munichites who were preparing France's

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Testimony of a woman, who described herself as a former Communist, that Russia had used the United Nations to "reinforce" spies in this country was made public tonight by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

FOR weary motorists who would like to relieve the strain of a cross-country drive by halting for a few minutes of rest and relaxation, the New York State Department of Public Works has begun to construct a chain of off-pavement parking sites along highways within the state.

Poland, after Italy, is the most Catholic country in Continental Europe. More than 91 per cent of its people are communicants of the Roman Catholic Church -- compared to Hungary's 74.8 per cent and Czechoslovakia's 69.8 per cent. Polish Catholics account for almost half the Vatican's following in the satellite nations of Eastern Europe.

MOSCOW, July 30 -- Pravda charged today that the excommunication of Communists by Pope Pius XII was dictated by international reaction and that it constituted a decree of anathema against "one-third of mankind."

ROME, July 30 -- Seamen's railroad and telephone strikes are threatened as a result of new demands by the workers, mostly for wage increases. The shipowners considered the seamen's demands, which could increase the cost of crews by about 200 per cent, so excessive that they refused even to discuss them.

Casey Stengel, observing his birthday yesterday at the Stadium, must have concluded, before his Yankees engaged the White Sox, that the first fifty-nine years are the hardest. With his league-leading club facing the sixth-place occupants, while the two leading contenders were cuffing each other about Boston, the pilot of the New Yorkers was entitled to grin and accept congratulations.

CELEBRATING this year its ninetieth birthday Cooper Union, art school and museum, is a memorial to a remarkably far-sighted man who put the nineteenth-century dream of an alliance between art and science on a practical basis.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 30 -- Dr. Luigi Crocco, Italian pioneer in research on jet propulsion and an authority on it, has been appointed head of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim jet propulsion center at Princeton University, it was announced today by George A. Brakeley, vice president and treasurer of the university.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Representative Arthur G. Klein, Democrat, of New York, proposed today that Congress print 500,000 copies of a statement made July 18 before the House Un-American Activities Committee by Jackie Robinson, second baseman of the Brooklyn Dodgers.

IN December, 1846, a little group of "doctors of the old school" met in the Lyceum of Natural History at 561 Broadway to found what they called an Academy of Medicine and Surgery. In 1946, the present New York Academy of Medicine celebrated its hundredth birthday with many sessions setting forth the accomplishments of medical practice to date.

Drew Middleton's "Hans Schmidt: Portrait of a 'Kleiner Mann'" seems to me misleading and arrogant. While no sensible person condones Hitler's ideas and brutality, it nevertheless is a fact that the winners grabbed the opportunity to smash Germany's industry and its workers.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- One of the greatest acts Washington has ever seen is now playing a return engagement. The star is Dean G. Acheson, Secretary of State, and the business is that of persuading doubtful or flatly opposed members of Congress to support, in detail as well as in substance, foreign-policy legislation proposed by the Administration. For skill, daring and the dramatic element of suspense this performance has been fitly compared to sword-swallowing.

SHEM, Sheerness and Taprobane; quadrant, sextant and octant; Anaximenes, Anaxagoras and Anaximander; alidade, astrolabe and chronometer; Philadelphus and Stilpo of Megara; latitude, longitude and the ecliptic; cinnamon, myrrh and sandalwood; Prester John and Gog and Magog -- all these, and seemingly thousands more, are the rich and romantic ingredients of this book.
MUNCIE, Ind., July 30 -- This polio-stricken city has risen to the emergency by producing quickly and cheaply made iron lungs, constructed mainly with alcohol barrels and vacuum-cleaner parts.

THERE have of late not been wanting editions of the great books or lists of them with accompanying admonitions. We have been scolded and dragooned into reading -- for only by so doing (we have been informed on the highest or at least the most articulate authority) are our souls to be saved, our minds to be disciplined and our spirits uplifted.

OLDTIMERS frequently are prone to complain that there isn't enough sentiment in baseball, that the pursuit of the dollar so engrosses the men who operate the game they give little thought to other matters.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 30 -- Czechoslovakia's Ministry of Foreign Trade recommended to the Soviet-dominated Council for Economic Mutual Assistance earlier this year that it should "devise some means to paralyze the effects of the Marshall Plan by interfering in Marshall Plan countries."

FORT WORTH Tex., July 30 -- Arthur Bisguier, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, successfully retained the National junior championship as the fourth annual contest for the title, sponsored by the Fort Worth Chess Club, the Texas State Chess Association and the United States Chess Federation, came to an end tonight.

The city's "mild epidemic" of poliomyelitis saw thirty-five new cases, seven less than the year's record set the previous day, reported to the Department of Health for the twenty-four-hour period ending at 9 A. M. yesterday. Two more deaths were also reported, bringing the year's total to twenty-one.
President Truman, in his Inaugural Address last Jan. 20, set out these three immediate objectives for American policy toward Western Europe:

PAUL TRIPP not only is the creator and author of the half-hour weekly fantasy program for children which goes under the intriguing title of "Mr. I. Magination," but also is the star of the show as the slim, curly haired and wholly engaging engineer of the train which takes viewers to Imagination Land each Sunday night at 7:30 o'clock over the CBS television network.

IN a brief foreword, Mr. Peeples informs us that this free-hand exercise in romance is based on the life of Joaquin Murrieta, who, if not "the greatest outlaw in American history," was certainly our most prolific murderer, with more than three hundred notches on his gun before he was dropped (by Three-Finger Jack) in a dusty corner of Nuestra Senora de los Angeles.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 30 (AP) -- Sam Snead caught and passed the leaders in the Western Open golf tournament today, firing a seven-under-par 65 in the third round for a 54-hole total of 201.

HEAVEN knows what Herman and Verman will think about it, but the immortal Penrod Schofield has turned editor. He is now pushing 60, or rather 58, or rather a mere 48. These, in any case, are the approximate ages of three Indianapolis brothers -- John, Donald and Booth Jameson -- to whom "Penrod" was dedicated by a doting Indianapolis uncle once upon a time.

The other day a fisherman looked down from the high elevation of one who had taken a forty-pound striped bass and told the story of George Hough, a Jackson Heights Virginian who also was a striper man.

Net profit of the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company and its subsidiaries for the first half of this year was $8,395,117 or $3.88 a share on 2,160,319 common shares, the report disclosed yesterday. This compares with $8,113,614 or $3.84 each on 2,120,310 shares in the initial six months of 1948.
N quoting of books, quote such authors as are usually read; others you may read for your own satisfaction, but not name them.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- David E. Finley, director of the National Gallery of Art, announced today that a display of South African contemporary art would open there tomorrow and continue through Labor Day. The exhibition, sponsored by the Government of the Union of South Africa, was selected by the Union Department of Education in collaboration with the South African Association of Arts.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 30 -- Prof. Heinrich Bruening of Harvard University, one-time Chancellor of Germany, can expect to get a delayed Doctor of Philosophy thesis next autumn from the editor-in-chief of one of the leading Lebanese newspapers who is spending three months in prison.

A collision in mid-air yesterday between an Eastern Air Line DC-3 and a Navy fighter plane six miles north of the McGuire Air Force Base at Fort Dix, N. J., resulted in the death of sixteen persons. The victims included all twelve passengers aboard the airliner, one a five-month-old baby girl, the crew of three, and the pilot of the Navy ship.

I wonder how many of your readers were horrified at Artist William Sharp's juxtaposition of the Democratic donkey and the Republican elephant in the cartoon illustrating David Cushman Coyle's fine article, "No Splintering of Our Party System."
