PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 30 -- Rejecting two Yugoslav notes accusing the Czechoslovak press and radio of slandering Yugoslavia, the Czechoslovak Foreign Office today in turn accused the Yugoslav press and radio of conducting the "vilest campaign" against Czechoslovakia.
SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., July 30 -- Two noted best-in-show winners were defeated at the Rockland County Kennel Club's show today.
Emory Richards has been appointed general manager of the Airedale Worsted Mills, Inc., and Lippett Worsted Mills, Inc., in Woonsocket, and the Lincoln Spinning Mills in Pawtucket, R. I.

Commissioner O. O. Kessing announced yesterday that the All-America Football Conference would start its thirteen-game exhibition schedule next Friday night. At that time Jersey City will play the Bills at Buffalo.

H. D.'s latest volume is the first she has published 1946, when with "The Flowering of the Rod" she concluded a trilogy of poems written in London during the war years which included "The Walls Do Not Fall" and "Tribute to the Angels."

THE idle man is the barrenest piece of earth in the orb. There is no creature that hath life, but is busied in some action foI the benefit of the restless world. Even the most venomous ind most ravenous things that are, have tieir commodities as well as their annoyances; and they are ever engaged in some action which profiteth the world, and continues them in their nature's courses.

SIX and 7-year-old listeners and lookers, 8-to-9-year-old readers will find in these two picture books answers to some of those innumerable questions they ask concerning the world around them. In "I'll Show You How It Happens" the author explains such diversified mysteries as the workings of a steam engine, canal locks, a bascule bridge and such natural phenomena as light and shadow, the birth of a dragon fly, the source of spring water.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The Phillies captured both ends of a double bill with the Cubs today, 4 to 3, and 9 to 1, before a crowd of 33,461.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- English-language textbooks used in the middle grades of Soviet schools have been attacked in the publication Foreign Languages in the Schools for reflecting "at best the ideology of philistinism and reconciliation" and failure to instill respect and compassion for the oppressed peoples and hatred for the exploiters.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Spending authority of the Economic Cooperation Administration and a number of other government agencies expires at midnight tomorrow for lack of congressional action.

Mother Nature, as the pictures on these pages show, has an ingenious way of turning out animals that do not at all fit man's conception of what an animal should look like. These eleven unusual specimens are part of a consignment of 187 which recently reached the Bronx Zoo from Africa and which are now on public view.

Summer registration in New York City's fourteen public high schools now stands at 30,000 -- the largest summer enrollment in the United States and greater than the year-round enrollment of many school systems in the country. Approximately 24,000 boys and girls are giving up their vacations to continue their studies in ten day schools, while 6,000 adults are studying in four evening high schools.

The first action by the Federal Trade Commission against fraudulent use of marketing survey, pollster and similar deceptive devices in door-to-door selling was described by National Better Business Bureau officials yesterday as one of the most encouraging developments in the drive on such practices.

IT'S only a matter of hours now before July turns the corner into August and it is safe to say that no one along The Street, not to mention the sweltering populace at large, will regret the passing. Although the new month doesn't promise too much at the moment in the way of heightened action, it is at least a step in the right direction.

The American public on Friday received a clear statement of what military aid to our partners in the North Atlantic pact means. Defense Secretary Johnson told the House Foreign Affairs Committee that the amount asked for this purpose in the Administration bill was "the barest minimum essential."

Lower costs which are virtually guaranteed by American manufacturers could go far to solve Great Britain's problem of dollar deficits by increasing British industrial productivity. But these remedies have been pushed far into the background, industrialists revealed here yesterday during a canvass of experts on industrial cost reduction practices.
SAINT JOHN, N. B., July 30 (AP) -- Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N. C., came from behind today to win the Canadian amateur golf championship, 1 up in 38 holes.

Failure of the steel companies to emphasize the coal strike of the spring of 1948 and its effects upon production and sales in that period when making their quarterly statements here last week was criticized generally in financial circles yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The United States position on a defense system for the North Atlantic treaty nations, it became known today, favors an extension of the regional grouping idea expressed by the five-nation Western Union organization.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 15 -- The figures for the Syrian census, just released, have given strong support to the proponents of the Syrian solution of the refugee resettlement problem. In Lebanon, which is determined that Palestine refugees shall not resettle here because there is already overcrowding and chronic unemployment, the figure showing that the density of population in Syria is one-sixth that in Lebanon has made a strong impression.

THERE was jazz in the Twenties, swing in the Thirties and, in the Forties -- bebop. The last "bears the same relationship to music as tonsilitis" and "sounds like a hardware store in an earthquake," according to two of the opinions which preface this slim volume, but the author hears in bebop the influences of Debussy, Schoenberg and Stravinsky, as well as Dixieland jazz.

WITHIN the past twenty-five years the Negro problem has changed from a sectional to a national and finally to a world problem. The migration northward after World War I and throughout the depression years grew into a mighty river during World War II.

The refurbished luxury liner Ile de France, which sailed from New York yesterday on the return leg of her maiden run, is the latest unit in a French post-war maritime program envisaging operation of 3,000,000 tons of shipping by 1952.

BOSTON, July 30 -- Evidence that tension over Russia had lessened here during the last three months was manifest in the indifference which greeted the ratification of the North Atlantic Pact. What sentiment was expressed chiefly was in favor of the pact as a means of further backing up the Marshall Plan.

DALLAS, July 30 -- Department store sales in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District last week were slightly better than sales of the preceding week, but fell below sales for the same week in 1948. Midsummer clearance sales and early fall promotions were the greatest sales factors.

WITH the acquisition of Picasso's "Three Musicians" (one of two versions painted in 1921, the other, slightly smaller, in the Gallatin Collection, Philadelphia Museum), the Museum of Modern Art is able to present to any skeptical visitor an extraordinary group of that controversial painter's major achievements.

PARIS, Sunday, July 31 -- Premier Henri Queuille, after a near defeat on Friday, succeeded yesterday in obtaining a vote of overwhelming support of the Cabinet's cautious financial program from the National Assembly, which is scheduled to start its summer recess today until Oct. 18.
McKITTRICK, Calif., July 30 -- A big deposit of fossil bones of prehistoric animals preserved in asphalt, resembling the famous La Brea pits in Los Angeles, is under exploration here.

NOW that New Directions has come out with "Personae" ($3.50), the collection of Ezra Pound's poetry except the work-in-progress "Cantos," it might be a service to attempt dispassionately to see into the verses, to gauge their movement, color and impact.

Discovery of long-sought methods for separating white blood cells, red blood cells and blood platelets (minute plate-like bodies) from one another and from the liquid portion of the blood (plasma) opens the way for the first time for their utilization in the treatment of human ills.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 30 -- Mrs. Margaret du Pont, national tennis champion from Wilmington, Del., went down to defeat today in the semi-final round of the Women's invitation tournament at the Maidstone Club.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 30 --Gil Bogley, the favorite from the start, won the Western junior tennis crown today with a 6-4, 6-4, 6-4 victory over Jerry DeWitts of Oakland, Calif.

To the Music Editor: I WAS interested in Roman Totenberg's article "On Violins and Bows" in a recent Sunday TIMES, but interested only as to why the baroque type of bow should be called periodically to our attention. Why should anyone be interested in its being brought back to life?

FOUR present-day photographers, with little in common except the medium they use, are represented in a new show arranged by Edward Steichen which opened last week at the Museum of Modern Art and will continue until Sept. 25.

DETROIT, July 30 -- In a letter prepared for publication in Rouge News, company plant publication, the Ford Motor Company, while urging its employes to participate in the Aug. 8 strike vote set by the State Labor Mediation Board, warned them that if a strike occurred it probably would be a long one.

CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- Grains got off to a weak start and never showed any rallying power on the Board of Trade today. Dealings were fairly active during the first thirty minutes, but after that the market just loafed along with the trend lower.

LONDON, July 30 -- The House of Commons held its first Saturday session since the eve of World War II today as millions of Britons started in bright but cool weather on the biggest holiday rush of the year.

UNTIL his untimely death in December, 1947, Harold Stannard was a feature writer on The Times of London, specializing in Anglo-American affairs. This posthumous essay aims at nothing less than a comparative analysis of the structure and purposes of the British and American Constitutions.
SALEM, N. H., July 30 -- St. Michael's won the Lawrence Suburban League pennant last night -- thanks to a snake.

FORT WORTH, Tex., July 30 -- The seventh annual Yale Summer School of Alcohol Studies was completed this week on the campus of Texas Christian University with students from thirty-nine states and five foreign countries in attendance.

THE American Stamp Dealers' Association, Inc., which has members in all parts of the country, will stage its first National Postage Stamp Show here Nov. 18-20 in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and East Thirty-fourth Street.

The Soviet Union, which was expected to become a leading competitor on the world's post-war sea lanes, has failed to play a dominant role among maritime nations in the four years, since V-J Day, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

BERLIN, July 30 -- The Special Experts Committee of the four occupation powers made its first move today toward settling the sharp differences that have developed between Eastern and Western German economic bodies during the last month.
I BELIEVE Mr. Cortesi explained to you why I was unable to answer your letter sooner.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A twenty-five-year campaign for the use of Federal funds to help raise the educational standards of public schools has become embroiled in a religious controversy of such bitterness that the once-bright prospects of success at this session of Congress have now grown exceedingly dim.
FORT DIX, N. J., July 30 -- Two explosions were the first indications the few witnesses of the plane crash had that sixteen bodies would be found on the lush meadows here.

Andrew Lo Bianco, 56 years old, a motion picture projectionist, stabbed his estranged wife, Mary, 38, to death yesterday and then committed suicide with a hunting rifle at their home, 1158 Eighty-third Street, Brooklyn.

MIDSUMMER finds a widely assorted harvest waiting to be gathered in the vegetable patch. The chief advantage of home-grown vegetables is that they may be picked at their prime, and eaten without delay.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Dr. Phillip Hench of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., will head a committee of medical scientists who will study for the Federal Security Agency newly discovered methods holding promise of alleviating rheumatic diseases.

Savings bankers have discovered that only 7 per cent of the $10,700,000,000 deposited in the savings banks of New York State is owned by persons less than 30 years of age. The information, together with other significant data on the deposit structure of the banks, was developed in a survey just completed by the research department of the Savings Banks Trust Company.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 30 -- St. Catharines won the club championship at the sixty-seventh annual Royal Canadian Henley today, but had to split honors of the four-day program with Joe Angyal of the New York Athletic Club who won the Canadian singles title.

The efforts being made to hold prices generally at the abnormally high level of the post-war period are bringing about important changes in many industries. With every industry attempting to increase its efficiency to reduce operating costs to meet competitive conditions, the relative position of each to the over-all picture probably is undergoing the most rapid change on a large scale in history.

A complete reversal of utility industry's policy on public power in the United States may result from the disclosure made yesterday by the president of a $500,000,000 utility system in the southeast. Also, to the consternation of his startled colleagues in other utility companies, he answered affirmately the long-controverted question: Can public and private power co-exist harmoniously?

THERE'S something about New Mexico that impels a visitor to react in one of three ways: go reeling into its most inaccessible villages; try (with no recently recorded success) to outsmart a Navajo for his rugs and silver jewelry; or to settle down forever and go into New Mexico politics.

DURING the annual fall fair season this year, beginning early in August and continuing into November, millions of farm folk and curious city dwellers will be able to visit more than 375 major and minor exhibitions in the six New England states, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP) -- Pitching his first complete game since June 19, Virgil Trucks snapped the Athletics' six-game winning streak today as the Tigers romped to an 11-to-0 victory.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 30-- Residents of the Mountain States are giving little discernible attention to the "cold war," the Atlantic Pact or the Administration's arms program. Editors at two of the region's major daily newspapers state, "Letters either pro or con on such matters arrive at the rate of one or two a week," although their desks may be snowed under with communications dealing with traffic hazards, rent control, reclamation and union labor.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30 -- The Italian Minister to Yugoslavia, Enrico Martino, today called on Premier-Marshal Tito to discuss the situation created by the Italian Government's refusal to sign a Italio-Yugoslav trade agreement.

WARSAW, July 30 -- The battle between Church and State in Poland appeared to be joined this week when the Minister of Public Administration, Wladyslaw Wolski, received Warsaw's Bishop Zygumunt Chronomanski and told him the Government was ready to start talks aimed at settling mutual problems.

A rise in the number of outpatients and bed patients served during the last five years at an increased cost of patient care was revealed yesterday in the annual report of St. Luke's Hospital. The institution at Amsterdam Avenue and 113th Street is entering upon its one-hundredth year of service.

FEW perennials are more rewarding than the various types of monarda, in full flower now. They are adaptable to sun or shade, wet or dry locations, and have colorful and continuous bloom, fragrant leaves and flowers.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 22 -- Business circles in Australia regard the decision of the conference of Commonwealth Finance Ministers to reduce purchases in the dollar area by 25 per cent as a depressing stopgap. While eager to help Britain in her economic struggle, they are asking for some more imaginative approach to solution of the dollar problem.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 30 -- Richard Gonzales, national tennis champion from Los Angeles, lost a marathon opening set of twenty-six games to Gardnar Mulloy today but had the youth and buoyancy to come through the winner as his older rival from Coral Gables, Fla., faded from fatigue in the excessive heat in the semi-final round of the invitation tournament at the Meadow Club.

The announcement by Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters that local military government units in Japan will be withdrawn soon "will be greeted with great satisfaction by all Japanese," Tetsu Katayama, chairman of the Japanese Social Democratic party, declared yesterday.

FOR THIS WEEK: Sprinkle every day, although not to the point of sogginess, pots of perennial and biennial seeds. . . . Cut spikes of gladiolus with a knife, and always leave at least three leaves to help the bulbs ripen. . . . Spray with nicotine sulfate or dust with sulfur to control aphids on nasturtium and golden glow.
CANTON, China, July 30 (AP) -- The Chinese Nationalists reported today successful counter-attacks had removed the Communist threat to Hengyang, 265 miles north of Canton.

Your editorial of July 24 recited a record of achievement on the part of THE NEW YORK TIMES of which you have every right to expound. I feel impelled, however, to question your assertion that about three decades ago the "Senate threw away some of the hope of peace by refusing to accept the League of Nations."

OVERSEAS travel prospects for millions of Americans in the middle-income brackets are beginning to show signs of improvement. In addition to private interests, Government circles have recently undertaken a serious study of ways to tap what is believed to be a vast and as yet untouched market for international tourism in the United States.

Several weeks ago in a Midwestern city a group of physicians and leaders in welfare, community services and civic organizations met to discuss problems of chronic disease and our aging population. When the facts were on the table one of the discussants shook his head sadly and said, "Maybe the Nazis had something when they put the old, dependent, chronically ill and disabled people out of the way."
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 30 -- Brazil will place restrictions on capital investments in the sense that capital must enter Brazil in liquid cash, it was learned today.
As a native Virginian, I was much interested in Cabell Phillips' "New Rumblings in the Old Dominion." I think the writer laid insufficient stress on one point.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- Representatives of the constituent unions of the Associated Actors and Artists of America convened tonight, by invitation of the Screen Actors Guild, to work out a plan for a television authority to cover labor organization and jurisdiction in the complicated television acting field.

WHILE the fleets of both United States and foreign airlines are composed of American-built piston-driven transports and must remain so, for economic reasons, for some time to come, Brutish aircraft producers last week took a step forward that will have repercussions throughout the whole air transport industry.
Two questions for Prof. Seymour E. Harris ("What to Do With Eighteen Million Aged?")

ALICE, Tex., July 30 -- With public indignation at a high pitch over the slaying yesterday of W. H. (Bill) Mason, 51 years old, crusading radio broadcaster, Texas Rangers disclosed today that five men made a shotgun attack last night on a dance hall Mr. Mason had denounced in one of his programs.

MANY gardeners have the idea that a pool is nothing more than an expensive breeding ground for mosquitoes. Actually, it is more apt to act as a deathtrap for mosquitoes and, as for being expensive, a pool can cost a little or a lot, depending upon how elaborate a one is wanted.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- John Maragon was questioned for the third day by the Senate's "five-per center" investigators today, then sparred with reporters who asked whether he had been involved in a 1946 customs duty incident.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 30 -- Australia moved a big step nearer a showdown with the United States in this year's Davis Cup challenge round by closing out Mexico, 3 -- 0, in the North American zone final with a straight set victory in today's doubles match.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- A battle of thirty hits between Washington and St. Louis ended in a victory for the visitors today by an 11-9 score. It was the fifteenth loss for the Senators in their last sixteen games.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30 -- The Yugoslav Government rejected today in most violent terms the Soviet Government's demand for the release of thirty-one Soviet citizens arrested by the Yugoslav security police on charges of espionage, sabotage, counter-revolutionary activity and collaboration with the Germans during the occupation of this country.

Although the President's Mid-year Economic Report, transmitted to the Congress on July 11, is not a detailed statement of his tax policy, it contains three specific recommendations. One of these is intended to increase the revenues and the other two would be expected not to deplete the revenues seriously.
GIBBSBORO, N. J., July 30 -- Forty-five firemen were overcome by fumes from exploding naphtha tanks here today as 800 firemen battled a blaze at the million-dollar John Lucas Co. paint plant.

The children committed last year by the Children's Court of New York or referred by other community agencies for treatment at Hawthorne-Cedar Knolls School are more emotionally disturbed than in past years. And more of them come from families in the higher economic brackets.

NARRAGANSETT, R. I., July 30 (UP) -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democrat, of Rhode Island, said today that he would tell President Truman Monday whether he would accept the nomination as Attorney General of the United States.

Borough President John Cashmore will officiate at 10:30 A. M. Wednesday at ground-breaking ceremonies at Allen Avenue and Knapp Street for a new $1,290,000 civic improvement in Brooklyn's Gerritsen Beach section.
Two men were slightly cut by glass and four women were treated for shock yesterday morning after an explosion and fire in a two-family house at 379 New Jersey Avenue, Brooklyn.

THE most striking difference between this English historical romance of the nineteenth century and a myriad others is that our present-day predilection for literary neurotics has finally invaded the never-never land of the period piece.

EVERY so often this writer likes to pull out that pretty postulate -- to wit, that the movie customers go for characters with whom they can identify themselves -- and hold it up as a yardstick against the current crop of films.

I read with interest and concern the reports in your distinguished paper on the debate a few days ago in the House of Commons between Mr. Bevin and Mr. Churchill on President Roosevelt's insistence at Casablanca in January, 1943, on a policy of "Unconditional Surrender" toward the Axis Powers, and also your editorial comment on that subject on July 23.
Extremely high temperatures again affected retail trade here last week. Department store sales were estimated to be running 10 per cent or more below the like week of last year.

BUENOS AIRES, July 30 -- The purge of the peronista party, foreshadowed by President Juan D. Peron in opening the party's national convention last Monday, began yesterday, when former Governor Waldino Suarez of Santa Fe Province was arrested on a train near the border of the Territory of the Chaco.

THE next hundred years may quite possibly see the transformation of the Amazon basin, one of the largest of the earth's "empty spaces," into a vast tropical granary and a home for millions of people from overcrowded lands. Such an eventuality would have far-reaching effects on the social and economic future of mankind.

The American Kennel Club has found that about 90 per cent of those questioned on whether the present limit class should be scrapped in favor of a bred-by-exhibitor class think that the change would be a good one. The rest, of course, want to keep the limit class.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 -- Women's apparel store sales last week were only 1 per cent below last year's like period. Pennsylvania Railroad carloadings last week totaled 100,745, as against 137,661 a year ago, a decrease of 26.8 per cent.
A thirty-week course in the management of institutional laundries will be offered by the City College Midtown Business Center starting Oct. 4, it was announced yesterday.

Don Connor, 16-year-old star from Balboa High School, Canal Zone, captured a major portion of the honors at the men's senior Metropolitan A. A. U. championship swimming meet in the Sunset pool, Brooklyn, yesterday. The program was sponsored by the Department of Parks.

The American Diabetes Association, Inc. 1 Nevins Street, Brooklyn, announced yesterday appointment of J. Richard Connelly as executive director. He will complete plans with Dr. Howard F. Root, president of the organization, for the Diabetes Detection Drive, which will begin with Diabetes Week, Oct. 10-16.

SUMMIT, N. J., July 30 -- In one of the greatest comebacks in the history of the metropolitan amateur golf championship, Joe McBride of Arcola, New Jersey titleholder, vanquished Joe Gagliardi of Winged Foot, Westchester champion, in the final by 1 up at the thirty-seventh hole at the Canoe Brook Country Club today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 19 -- German authorities, with the aid of Allied Military Government experts, have worked out a comprehensive proposal for agricultural improvement in Western Germany. It would be based on aid from the Economic Cooperation Administration through the use of 270,000,000 Deutsche marks in the counterpart fund as well as contributions sought for in the technical assistance and cultural exchange program (President Truman's Point Four.)

COLUMBIA, Mo., July 30 (AP) -- A group of former service men attending the University of Missouri said today they had been evicted from a Federal-financed dormitory to provide quarters for women students. They appealed to President Truman and members of Congress for assistance.

PITTSBURGH, July 30 (AP) -- A civil suit filed by a group of sixteen owners of preferred stock, charging fraud, against Pennsylvania Industries, Inc., will be contested vigorously, President J. H. Hillman Jr., has informed stockholders.

The most fantastic of all post-war veterans bills now is being considered in Chairman John E. Rankin's House Committee on Veterans Affairs. This is the bonus measure whereby all Second World War veterans or their next-of-kin would be paid $3 a day for every day of stateside service, $4 a day for every day overseas, and an additional $500 for a wound.

"WHAT do you think can be at the foot of the rainbow?" Dormouse puzzled over this question, as who has not, and decided to find the answer. First he asked his friends the hedgehog, the shrew, the king-fisher and the trout, but none of them knew.

[T is now August and the sun is somewhat toward his declination, yet such is his heat as hardeneth the soft clay, dries up the standing ponds, withereth the sappy leaves and scorcheth the skin of the naked. Now begin the gleaners to follow the corn cart, and a little bread to a great deal of drink maketh the traveler's dinner.

OMAHA, July 30 -- The farmer is in the mood to be wooed. But he is too busy right now to respond fully to the politicians' love call. And he won't get around to saying "I do" to one major party or the other until the Congressional elections roll around in 1950.

MR. Reynolds roars genially down the corridors of time shouting "Beaver!" Without splitting a hair, he writes of a tangled subject lucidly. He takes history on the chin and tells us all we shall ever need to know about beards, "their social standing, religious involvements, decorative possibilities and value in offense and defense through the ages."
SYDNEY, Australia, July 30 (UP) The Communist-dominated central committee of the miners' union voted today to continue Australia's paralyzing, five-week-old coal strike without consulting the miners.

FOR the first time, that memorable cinematic figure, the mustachioed man who holds the mortgage, has turned on his exploiters. Last week, foreclosure proceedings were concluded against three motion pictures, "Voice in the Wind," produced in 1944 by Arthur Ripley and Rudolph Monter: "Christmas Eve," produced in 1947 by Benedict Bogeaus, and "Bachelor's Daughters." produced in 1946 by Andrew Stone.

THE Atlantic Pact is now a part of official national policy, but it is not yet a part of national thinking. As was the case with the Monroe Doctrine, this new doctrine must go through a considerable period of incubation and particularized application before it is assimilated into the fabric of our national life.

HERE is Julius Caesar in all his arrogance, brilliance and ambition. Mary Louise Mabie has done a stupendous amount of historical research on Caesar -- not even forgetting his falling sickness -- and she has come up with a credible though not an exciting novel of his career.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Irving Gushen's Lefty Jim, backed down to a 7-5 favorite by the crowd of 15,126, today won the $7,500 added Myles Standish Stakes pretty much as he pleased at Suffolk Downs.

THURSDAY marks the first anniversary of the Metropolitan Opera's famous cancellation notice after management and labor failed to agree on the terms of their contracts. When the cancellation was rescinded nineteen days later there was an expression of earnest resolve and pious hope that all union contracts for 1949 would be concluded by June 30 of this year.

With manufacturers, chain stores and mail order houses placing substantial orders for cotton textiles to be delivered in the next ninety days, a long dull period for the primary cotton goods market has come to an end, it was pointed out last week.

HARRISON, N. Y., July 30 -- Forty-three men and women, members of the Order of Scottish Clans and its sister organization, the Daughters of Scotia, took off this evening in an American Overseas Airlines plane on a pilgrimage to their native heath. The flight was the first transatlantic crossing from the Westchester County airport here by an American Overseas plane.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP) -- Cleveland's world champion Indians crept within three and a half games of the American League leading New York Yankees today by rallying for four runs in the tenth inning and a 10-6 decision over the Boston Red Sox.

CARSON CITY, Nev. -- The famous Virginia Truckee Railroad is still very much alive despite reports to the contrary. The 7:15 A. M. train still chugs out of Reno, "the biggest little city in the world," bound for Carson City, "the smallest capital in America," and after an hour's layover here goes on to Minden, returning to Reno in the late afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The first step in the long and difficult process of restoring the military power of Western Europe was taken this week when the President sent to Congress a military assistance program which, if enacted, will again make the United States the "arsenal of democracy."

Conceding twenty pounds to this year's Dixie Handicap winner proved to be too much of an assignment for Ben F. Whitaker's My Request as the Saratoga-on- the-L. I. R. R. race meet ended yesterday. The main event was the $22,900 Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap, and Brookmeade Stable's Chains, under 106 pounds, won it by a neck from My Request, who carried 126.

RETAIL trade received no help from the weather last week as temperatures soared, humidity stifled shoppers and thunder showers left the streets hot and steaming. Department store sales seemed about the same as the previous week.

About 7,000,000 persons in the United States are crippled by rheumatoid arthritis, while thousands of others are the victims of rheumatic fever. The latter is responsible for more than a third of the annual deaths from heart disease. Treatment of these two afflictions has been one of the major medical problems of our time.

Sam Tamburo of Penn State has accepted coach Herman Hickman's invitation to join the Eastern College All-Stars, it was announced yesterday. The All-Stars will oppose the New York Giants on Thursday night. Sept. 1, at the Polo Grounds. The game will be the eleventh annual Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund classic.

"ASK Christopher Morley about himself," a friend of Mr. Morley said to this writer, "and he'll tell you about Joseph Conrad." The friend was accurate. Mr. Morley was full of Mr. Conrad -- and particularly so, it being the twenty-fifth anniversary of Conrad's death -- and it was only through his interlocutor's perseverance that Mr. Morley temporarily became the man who made friends with himself.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 30 -- The Central Action Committee of the National Front put on sale today a forty-eight-page booklet called "The Treason of the Vatican and the Bishops." It consisted of the text off speeches made at the meeting of the Central Action Committee on July 15, when its chairman, Minister of Justice Alexei Cepicka, announced that enforcement of the Vatican's excommunication of Communists would be dealt with as treason.

THE Berkshire Music Center, following Dr. Koussevitzky's plan of bringing annually to this summer school a leading modern composer, not oly to teach there but to stimulate, by his ideas and the perspectives that he may unfold the creative workers in the composition class, has this year as its guest Olivier Messiaen.
TOKYO, July 30 -- Japan's blackest forebodings regarding the effects of the occupation's economic policies are being borne out.

A survey on the deteriorated world market for American exports covering thirty-four areas and countries was made available here last week by Alltransport, Inc., international freight forwarder, as compelling evidence of the United States' need of greatly increased imports.
BUFFALO, N. Y., July 30 (AP) -- Louis E. Drago, newly elected commander of the New York Department of the American Legion, pledged today to fight communism "to the nth degree."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Gay Brewer Jr., a quiet 17-year-old Kentuckian, won the second National junior golf championship today with a 6-and-4 victory over his long-time friend, Mason Rudolph of Clarksville, Tenn.

THE literary event of the season -- whatever coming season it is -- should be Ernest Hemingway's new novel. It will be published about ten years after "For Whom the Bell Tolls." During this period, Hemingway has consolidated his position as a literary spokesman for the United States and a sort of roving Ambassador of Letters -- perhaps the first native novelist to fill this role so well since the death of Mark Twain.

THERE probably is material for a dozen political homilies in the fact that two of Germany's best-selling books today are Ernest Hemingway's "For Whom the Bell Tolls" and Franz Halder's "Hitler As a Military Leader." Each book represents a major reading trend in Western Germany and Western Berlin.

BOSTON, July 30 -- National Commander Perry Brown of the American Legion suggested today that the Federal Government adopt legislation enabling veterans to start co-operatives to provide housing at reduced costs.

The "scuttlebutt" was one of the main attractions yesterday to the 2,100 persons who boarded the Navy's light cruiser Worcester and two destroyers of Task Force 89 at Pier 26, North River and Beach Street. To the landlubber, the "scuttlebutt' is a water fountain.

In promotions here last week retailers stressed fur lined coats, rayon faille dresses, boys' corduroy outfits, girls' cotton plaid dresses, lace-trimmed slips and plastic-covered chairs, according to a survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Retail News Bureau, Inc.

MANY a writer of a book with New Orleans' French Quarter as background has striven so desperately to impart the physical charm of the place -- listing eagerly its pastel houses, crumbling patios, overhanging galleries trimmed with wrought iron lace -- that his research has burst through the fabric of his narrative and destroyed its pattern.

A study by the Brookings Institution serves to confirm anxieties that have been felt of late by all concerned with transportation over the road, either of passengers or goods. The study finds that most of today's roads are not adapted to the requirements of heavy volumes of high-speed traffic resulting from shifts in population and a notable and growing trend from urban to suburban areas.
ALICE, Tex., July 30 (AP) -- District Attorney Sam Reams said today that Sam Smithwick, held in the slaying of W. H. Mason, had made no effort to obtain his freedom, Mr. Reams added, drily:

Arthur Krock's two pieces about the superior articulation and articulateness of advocates of the welfare state have a praiseworthy degree of generality seldom reached in discussions of social problems. Natural scientists again and again have proved that adequate generality resolves disagreements which at first announcement seemed irreconcilable.

DAHLIAS do not flourish in hot weather -- neither plants nor flowers. Because of the prolonged drought and high temperatures, extra care has been necessary, and continues to be of importance for a full crop of bloom in September.

WHILE the summer, when the big shows take a holiday, is normally a period of musical fill-ins on the radio, the National Broadcasting Company's network currently is freighted with what might be called summer stock.

Now busily planning for the new school year, which opens on Sept. 12, New York City school officials are concerned with the numerous problems that have arisen in recent months. Because of an increased birth rate, which will bring an estimated 215,000 additional children to the schools by 1954, the Board of Education must expand facilities that in many instances are already overcrowded and inadequate for the needs of their neighborhoods.

HACKETTSTOWN, N. J. -- A point of unusual interest to motorists bound for the Poconos on U. S. 46 is the $1,500,000 State Fish Hatchery about a mile south of here, which supplies more than 90 per cent of the fish that are used to restock New Jersey's lakes and streams.

A recorded concert of special interest to teen-agers, of unusual folk songs that have never before been played in public, will be heard on Friday at 8:15 P. M. in the 761 East 160th Street branch of the New York Public Library.

THE literary event of the season -- whatever coming season it is -- should be Ernest Hemingway's new novel. It will be published about ten years after "For Whom the Bell Tolls." During this period, Hemingway has consolidated his position as a literary spokesman for the United States and a sort of roving Ambassador of Letters -- perhaps the first native novelist to fill this role so well since the death of Mark Twain.

The Dolphin, owned and skippered by W. B. Lockwood of the Essex (Conn.) Yacht Club, captured the twenty-fifth Bayside-Block Island auxiliary handicap yacht race over the week-end. The craft arrived at the Bayside Yacht Club dock yesterday morning at 10:27:10.

Henry Pferr, 33-year-old Brooklyn glassblower, was the only bather at Coney Island yesterday who swam a distance estimated by his associates at twenty-five miles -- from Steeplechase Pier to Pier A, the Battery, and return.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 31 -- In independent "informal" talks with the respective United States Army, Air Force and Navy commanders in Europe, the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff began today preparations for a week-long series of top-level military conferences with representatives of other member nations of the North Atlantic pact.
SAN MIGUEL ALLENDE, Mexico, July 31 (AP) -- Some 125 GI art students here have nowhere to study, and after today they will have nothing to live on.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 -- The Atomic Energy Project of the University of California at Los Angeles issued today a warning of serious radiation hazards in devices being distributed commercially to eliminate static through the employment of thin strips of the element polonium.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 31 -- In a comeback bordering on the miraculous, William Talbert of New York defeated Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, the national tennis champion from Los Angeles, 6 -- 5, 5 -- 7, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, in the final round of the fifty-ninth annual invitation tournament at the Meadow Club today.

FORT MONROE, Va., July 31 -- The news at this post, historic in Army tradition, is that "Jakie" Devers, Serial Number 0-2599, is moving out of his great white-pillared house -- quarters of the commanding general here -- preparatory to his retirement on Sept. 30 from the Army he has served so long.

The purchase by Yale University of the Isham collection of the private papers of James Boswell is the second large transfer of Boswell and Johnson material in less than a year, it was learned last night.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Trial Counsel Club, with a membership of 750 specialists in negligence cases, recommended yesterday an extension of pre-trial hearings in New York County to lighten the congested calendar backlog in the State Supreme Court.

PARIS, July 31 -- Completing its program for the session, the French Parliament adjourned late today for the summer recess until Oct. 18. It thus virtually assured two and one-half more months of life to the present Cabinet and gave to Premier Henri Queuille a free hand to deal, on one hand, with important pending international affairs, and on the other, to take action to dispel rising labor unrest.

PITTSBURGH, July 31 -- The slight betterment in steel activity last week could be traced to some fears of labor trouble later in the year, according to reports here. Some customers are taking no chance that steel operations may not be tied up later with a strike and are ordering at a little heavier rate.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 31 -- Ocean Township, which once embraced the city of Long Branch, Asbury Park, Eatontown, Bradley Beach, Ocean Grove, Allenhurst, Deal and the Atlantic Beachfront as far north as the Highlands, opened a one-week celebration today in observance of its 100th anniversary.

The total revenue of the municipal transit lines for the fiscal year ended June 30 exceeded total operating costs by an amount sufficient to retire only $11,067,500 of the outstanding $18,745,000 of short-term debt incurred in 1947 and 1948 to cover past operating deficits.

Opposition to the terms of the foreign military assistance program has assumed such proportions that determined efforts are under way in Washington to induce the Administration to accept a "compromise" which would cut down the size and scope of the program to a mere fraction of its present self.
ALBANY, July 31 -- Assemblyman Elisha T. Barrett, Bayshore Republican, made public today details of a proposed automobile title law to be submitted to the 1950 session of the Legislature.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- The twenty-third annual championship tournament of the American Contract Bridge League got under way here today with twenty-three teams competing for the national amateur team-of-four title.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 -- Judy Garland, who was suspended from salary by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer on May 10 for walking out on her assignment, "Annie Get Your Gun," has notified Metro executives that she will return to the studio this week, it was announced.
SHANGHAI, July 31 -- The escape of the Amethyst struck the British community of 2,500 to 3,000 here with complete astonishment today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A pair of home runs by Sherry Robertson and another by Eddie Robinson gave the Senators a 7-3 victory over the Browns today. Sid Hudson limited St. Louis to five hits in gaining his sixth decision.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Truman Administration has no intention of sponsoring legislation before this session of Congress to repeal the wartime increases in excise taxes, it was learned today from competent authority.
You have devoted such space, editorial and otherwise, to your views concerning a new displaced persons law that I hope you will find room for the following:

PARIS, July 31 -- Government technicians now have concluded the operation of transforming into dollars the customs statistics on foreign trade. The principal result of this has been to show that exports toward the dollar zone are on the decline.

Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia, one of the nation's leading exponents of sound fiscal and economic policies, had some pointed observations to make a few days ago, in a radio address, concerning the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

ANNECY, France, July 31 -- The delay in Congressional action on the charter of the International Trade Organization is placing the United States Government in increasing difficulty as it seeks to protect United States' interests in the rapidly changing world trade situation.

After being the scene of fifty automobile accidents in six months, a perilous stretch of Grand Central Parkway, between Horace Harding Boulevard and Kew Gardens Loop, Queens County, now is posted with warning signs. The dangerous sector is about one and a half miles long on a heavily traveled section of the parkway.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., July 31 -- Packing more power up front, Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes made full use of a one-goal handicap to beat Alan Corey's Old Westbury side, 6 to 4, in the final of the sixteen-goal tournament for the Westbury Challenge Cup at Bostwick Field today.

The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation transacted the largest volume of sales in its history in both the quarter and nine months ended with June, according to the report issued for publication today. The volume for the June quarter was $99,717,073, an increase of $3,473,483 over the record March quarter this year and $10,541,720 larger than in the June quarter a year ago.
BERGEN, Norway, July 31 -- The city that illustrates best the contemporary policies and problems of Norway is not Oslo but the ancient and beautiful city of Bergen.

HONOLULU, July 31 -- The consensus of twenty eminent philosophers who attended the East-West Philosophers' Conference just ended at the University of Hawaii is that the peoples of the East and West have a great deal more in common than even these thinkers realized before the conference.
The Coast Guard, a strategic branch of the armed services charged with the nation's maritime safety, will celebrate its 159th anniversary on Thursday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 31 -- Borba, official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist party, asserted today that the Papal decree excommunicating Catholics of Communist persuasion may have reprecussions inside some Communist parties because of the low standard of Marxist education and indoctrination among the rank and file membership.

WARSAW, July 24 -- Russian electric-powered tractors and other scientific achievements that "compel nature" to yield abundant harvests are convincing Poles who have had an opportunity to see these advancements that collectivization must be hastened in Poland.

It was with much interest that I read the full report of the American Friends' plan regarding American-Russian relations. Their conclusions are, in my estimation as an engineer and business man, steps which must be explored if the world is to get out of the present quagmire.
BERLIN, July 31 -- The United States, Britain and France have embarked belatedly on two basic tasks that must be accomplished before the Government of the German Federal Republic can function freely.

SPARTA, AT. J., July 31 -- Best in show in the annual event of the Lake Mohawk Kennel Club today went to a Scottish terrier, Bowery Emperor of Flornell of Vigal, owned by Mr. and Mrs. H. Alvin McAleenan of New York and handled by Phil Prentice. The decision was made by Edwin Megargee, president of the Scottish Terrier Club of America.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 31 -- Kirsten Flagstad sang the title role in Beethoven's "Fidelio" at the Festspielhaus here last night, making her first appearance in Austria since before the recent war. She scored a great personal success, which was, however, only part of the even greater success scored by the entire ensemble under the direction of Wilhelm Furtwaengler.

Fall purchasing in the wholesale apparel market here last week centered on fur-trimmed and zip-out lining coats, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Dress orders stressed back-to-school promotions, nylon dresses and novelty fabrics.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The State Department struck back today at the Chinese Communists' suspension of United States Information Service offices in five of China's principal cities.

CINCINNATI, July 31 -- For his share in the flare-up with Umpire Lee Ballanfant which climaxed yesterday's exciting Giant triumph over the Reds, Manager Bucky Walters today was under suspension for five days and fined $150 by President Ford C. Frick of the National League.

The stringency of foreign exchange, import restrictions by foreign governments and, to some extent, increasing foreign competition are three causes for the drop in foreign sales in recent months, according to the majority of companies surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board.
Five new films, including an importation from China, have been scheduled to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

During 1948, when transatlantic air travel showed a 9 per cent increase in passengers over the previous year, the United States international airlines carried a smaller percentage of the total passengers than they did in 1947.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- The Bureau of the Census is busy laying the groundwork for the biggest counting job in the nation's history. The $70,000,000 project may have an important bearing on the living habits of everyone in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Legislation by Congress to prevent specifically the exchange of atomic bomb secrets with other nations was demanded tonight by Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, Republican floor leader.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Grandammer doubled and scored on Dick Sisler's single to give the Phillies a 5-4 victory over the Cubs in ten innings today before a crowd of 18,926.

A young Manhattan couple, who had expected to spend all Sunday continuing their frantic search for suitable living quarters, were awakened early yesterday morning to learn that they now own a $16,000, six-room furnished house.

BUFFALO, July 31 -- Alfred Worsdell Jr., first deputy commissioner in the New York State Department of Commerce, told 600 retail grocers here this afternoon that the business economy of the state continues at a high level and that the outlook is bright.

As dusk enveloped the Stadium yesterday and it became obvious that the Yankees and White Sox, scoreless after nine rounds in the nightcap, would be stopped by darkness -- the umpires said the tenth would be the last -- Old Folks Luke Appling took it upon himself to decide the outcome.
TOKYO, July 31 -- Political lines are now being sharply drawn for the legislative battle in the extraordinary session of the Diet that will be summoned late in September.

HARRISON, N. Y., July 31 -- The Westchester foursome, with Nine-goaler George Oliver taking over the No. 3 position, routed the Albany Polo Club, 8 to 3, before close to 2,000 fans in Tri-State League action at the Blind Brook Polo Club today to move within a game of the pace-setting Pittsfield quartet.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 -- Resolutions pledging international action by maritime labor, if necessary, to resist any attempts at destroying union hiring halls or at employing in ship crews "stool pigeons" against Harry Bridges were adopted at the Marseille meeting at which the Maritime Federation of the World was created.

The logistical problems of high chairs, cribs and baby-sitters have been added to the woes of supply sergeants and officers as a result of a system of training reserves at Fort Tilden, Queens -- the Week-End Training Program.

Present sales trends and growing consumer demands give indications that the beer industry will continue to expand during the next ten years, the United States Brewers Foundation disclosed last week. A study of the industry presented in logarithmic graphs projected through 1960 is included in the Brewers' Almanac of 1949, which was to be mailed to members of the Foundation today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -The votes of the delegations from New l York. New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls during the I period July 23-29 are given in the appended tabulation:

BUENOS AIRES, July 19 -- One of the most important and tangible evidences of President Juan D. Peron's "Plan of Government" -- which used to be called the Five-Year Plan -- is the "gasoducto," or pipeline, which now lacks 125 miles of its completed span of about 1,100 between this capital and the southern oil port of Comodoro Rivadavia.

LENOX, Mass., July 31 -- Rain dampened the first week-end of the Berkshire Festival, nevertheless the two concerts drew more than 23,000 people. The program last night, which began with fair weather, attracted 14,200 or 500 short of the record; and despite an all-morning drizzle, more than 9,000 made their way here for this afternoon's event.

A life of Lydia Estes Pinkham, one of America's most amazing women, will be published by Farrar, Straus on Aug. 22. "Lydia Pinkham Is Her Name" presents the story of the successful business woman, originator of a new form of advertising and author of a treatise on the "facts of life," as well as the history of the multimillion-dollar business she founded.

The Columbia Broadcasting System and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers are nearing a new contract agreement covering the network's staff of engineers and technicians. CBS had served notice that it would terminate the old pact with the union last Friday, when the two sides appeared to be deadlocked after more than two months of negotiations.
LONG BEACH, L. I., July 31 -- The parishioners of the Peoples Community Church of this seaside resort town consider themselves among the most fortunate of churchgoers.

JUNEAU, Wis., July 31 (AP) -- Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, came to the heart of the Midwest's dairyland today to strike back at the House of Representatives for rejecting his farm plan aimed at high farm income and cheaper food.
CANTON, China, July 31 (AP) -The Chinese Nationalists reported both gain and loss today in the fighting for the vital rice-bowl province of Hunan.

Absurd as it may seem, we are beginning to suspect that the average Russian has a not-so-secret hankering to play the stock market in Wall Street. This suspicion arises from perusal of some recent copies of Pravda and Izvestia, those twin organs of Soviet enlightenment.

"Rejoined the fleet. No damage or casualties. God save the King." This is the fashion in which an already decorated radio operator on the British sloop Amethyst reported the almost incredible dash down the Yangtze of that gallant ship. This story of the escape from the Communist batteries has already jumped into the front ranks of the modern sagas of naval warfare.

CHICAGO, July 31 (UP) -- Representatives of the rival National Basketball League and the Basketball Association of America will meet in New York Wednesday to complete what probably will be the merger of the two professional circuits, it was learned authoritatively today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP)-- i Hepresentative Ralph W. G-winn, Republican, of New York, said today that the Government would soon be under full control of state socialism unless the American people fought against it now.

There can be lasting peace, individual happiness and the just society only if individuals are prepared to work hard for them, the Rev. Dr. Albert Peel, former chairman of the Congregational Union of England and Wales, declared yesterday.

With "Two-A-Day," essentially a variety program built around four prominent "names," which Michael Todd is planning to present Sept. 7 or 8 at the Winter Garden, Mr. Todd intends to resuscitate the old "buy" system, whereby brokers purchased tickets in advance over a certain number of weeks.

Actors Equity Association was asked yesterday by the Off-Broadway Theatre League to reconsider its ban against appearances by Equity performers in local experimental theatre companies that have no contracts with the union.

PHILADELP, July 31 -- In a letter made public here today, George V. Allen, Assistant Secretary of State, said an exhibition of the works of Frank Lloyd Wright, noted American architect. which Arthur C. tfaufrnann, executive head of Girnbels, will sponsor in Florence, Italy, next spring, should make a genuine contribu[tion to relations between the two countries.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 31 -- Yale University announced today that it had acquired the Isham collection of the private papers of James Boswell and that the papers would be published in their entirety.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 31 (Reuters) -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner-designate for Germany, said here today he thought it was important that a permanent Jewish community should again develop in Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP)The National Labor Relations Board reported today that its output of decisions in the past year under the Taft-Hartley Law was 137 per cent greater than the annual average under the old Wagner Act.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 31 -- In a dramatic meeting, the abbots, monks, mothers superior and nuns of Bohemia and Moravia warmed the Communist leaders of Czechoslovakia's "people's democracy" that they intended to remain faithful to the Pope and that the "future life" would demonstrate who will conquer in the mounting struggle between church and state.
YASNAYA POLYANA, U. S. S. R., July 31 -- In a quiet forest glade rests a grassy mound strewn with fresh flowers that is one of the world's great shrines.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- President Truman cut short his week-end holiday at "Shangri-La"' today to welcome Mrs. Truman back from Missouri.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Argentina's El Trebol Polo Club continued its mastery over the United States All-Star team today by overwhelming the American squad, 13 to 3, in an exhibition match.

A plea to modern man to reach out beyond his own littleness and narrowness was voiced yesterday by the Right Rev. John T. Dallas, retired Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
J. L. Buckner has retired as vice president of Corn Products Refining Company after thirty-seven years with the concern.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Demand grew in Congress today that, as a condition of the program to supply arms to its North Atlantic pact partners in Europe, the United States get "black and white commitments" from these nations for unified military action as a defense policy and in case of attack.

The strategic oil industry of Rumania, which supplies fuel both to the Soviet Union and to the Soviet satellites in Eastern Europe, failed to fulfill its plan for the first two quarters of this year, a Cabinet communique broadcast by the Bucharest radio and reported last week by Government monitors has disclosed.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 31 (AP) -- Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., fired a five-under-par 67 to give him a four-round total of 268 and the Western Open golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Proposals by the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government for changes in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation were attacked today by that agency as an "excursion into the controversial field of political economy."

The Intercultural Choir of the Harlem Branch Y.M.C.A., under George Byrd, made a highly favorable impression at its debut concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. With Nell Tangeman, mezzo-soprano, as guest artist, the new choral organization gave remarkable account of itself in a noble and exacting series of offerings.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers blanked the Philadelphia Athletics in both ends of a double-header today, 3 -- 0 and 6 -- 0, to move into fourth place in the American League pennant race a half game ahead of the A's. It was Detroit's third consecutive shut-out over Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -House Administration leaders have agreed to a compromise 75-cent minimum wage bill that would bring about 600,000 new workers under the Wage-Hour Act, it was revealed today.

LONG BEACH, L. I., July 31 -- With two members of the State Legislature presenting opposing views, the question whether the newly proposed Long Beach Expressway, connecting the City of Long Beach to the Belt Arterial Highway System, would be a boon or a detriment to the city was discussed at an emergency meeting this morning of sixty heads of local civic, fraternal and trade organizations.

The tuberculosis death rate in the United States last year was 29.8 in 100,000 population as compared with 33.5 in 1947, according to provisional figures made public yesterday by Dr. James E. Perkins, managing director of the National Tuberculosis Association.

SHANGHAI, July 31 -- Bleary-eyed and unshaven but still retaining a sense of humor, 39-year-old Reuben R. Thomas, of Rosebud, Ark., resumed his "negotiations" with former employes of the United States Navy here early this morning after an all-night talk-fest broken only by a half hour of sleep atop a filing cabinet.

RICHMOND, Va., July 31 -- State Senator John S. Battle, candidate of the Byrd organization for Governor, was quoted at even money today against his three Democratic opponents in the hard-fought primary to be decided on Tuesday.

ATLANTA, July 31 (AP) -- The Atlanta Journal reported today that seven editors and three former editors of weekly Georgia newspapers that supported Gov. Herman Talmadge were now on the state payroll. The Journal said they had been added since Mr. Talmadge took office last November.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 -- The Dodgers today proved their ability to do something a lot of the folks back home were beginning to doubt -- that is, beat the Cardinals, and a season's record Sportsman's Park crowd of 32,965 cash customers could offer corroborative testimony if it were needed.

Matamis na bao is a confection that Filipinos have been making for generations from the milk of the coconut. It's as sweet and smooth as honey, with a flavor that's truly that of the nut from which it is prepared. Mandalay coconut syrup, reappearing here after several years' absence, is a "modernized" version of this age- old delicacy, the product of an American who has lived for many years in the Philippines.
JERSEY CITY, N. J., July 31 (AP) -- Montreal snapped Jersey City's winning streak at four straight today, taking the opener, 15 -- 11, and the nightcap, 7 -- 6, in 11 innings.
Bonds called before maturity for payment in July totaled $37,987,000 compared with $76,996,000 in the preceding month and $20,711,000 in the corresponding month of 1948.

The Navy named a special four-man board of inquiry yesterday to fix responsibility for the collision Saturday between an Eastern Air Lines DC-3 and a Navy F6F Hellcat, which resulted in the loss of sixteen lives.

Frank Massimino bought for occupancy from Kingdon Pagel and Muriel Pagel Elliott the two-family dwelling on a lot 40 by 100 feet at 1257 Seventy-ninth Street, Brooklyn, assessed for $9,000. The house contains a two-car garage and was sold through the Bulkley Horton Company, broker, and the Colonial Realty Company, co-broker.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 31 -- The Lightning Class almost did not get in its full three-race series for the Atlantic Coast championship as the two-day program wound up at the Larchmont Yacht Club today. After the fleet managed to get around a triangular course of three and a half miles in light northwesterly breezes this morning, the wind fell flat.
AMSTERDAM, July 31 -- The problem of the equilibrium of the Dutch payments overshadows that of arriving at a Benelux Economic Union, according to Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations proposed today that unemployed workers receive jobless pay equal to 50 to 85 per cent of their regular earnings as a means of sustaining purchasing power and restoring full employment.

The United States "split religion from life long before we split the atom, and the destruction of one natural union is every bit as explosive as the destruction of the other," the Rev. Timothy J. Flynn declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He is a member of the cathedral staff.

The Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, pastor of the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church at 174th Street, suggested in his morning sermon yesterday that psychiatrists and clergymen learn more about each other's fields, which he said were closely related.

LONDON, July 31 -- The Covent Garden opera season will open on Sept. 29 with the first performance of "The Olympians," by Arthur Bliss, with a libretto by J. B. Priestley, the first opera to have a premiere there since the war and the first new English opera to be presented by the Covent Garden Opera Trust.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- An announcement of the conclusion of a one-year trade pact between representatives of "Manchurian People's democratic authorities" and the Soviet Union was carried by all Soviet newspapers and broadcast by the Soviet radio.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $48,486,637,874. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange in July was the heaviest in three months, due to the heavy turnover in low-price utility issues, the volume was the smallest for a corresponding month since 1942. Sales crossed the million-share mark in seven sessions, the heaviest of which was 1,588,820 shares on March 19, when about half of the day's volume was in Commonwealth Southern stock.
I wish to commend THE NEW YORK TIMES for its pertinent and timely editorial entitled "Street Hazards" in THE TIMES of July 22.

When a piano was put into service yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church to pinch-hit for an ailing organ, the Rev. Dr. Peter K. Emmons of Scranton, Pa., guest pastor, told the congregation he was "glad it happened" during his visit.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 31I -- Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., Wimbledon champion, won the invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today for the third time, to gain possession of the highly prized Woodin Gold Cup.

The Rev. Dr. Hillyer H. Straton, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Malden, Mass., predicted in a sermon here yesterday afternoon that the challenge of communism would force Western Europe into a United States of Europe, in which, he maintained, "the wedding of a vital Christian faith with the democratic process" would play a major role.

It is a recent claim of Mao Tse-tung, the ideological architect of Communist China, that Dr. Sun Yat-sen's purposes for the Chinese people were identical with those sought by the Communist regime, although it is asserted his methods were wrong. This is subtle propaganda that will not bear the light of history.

Alpha Delta Sigma, a national professional advertising fraternity, has presented awards to three ADS college chapters for the best sample public service campaign submitted by active undergraduate ADS chapters on Advertising Council projects, it was announced for publication today by the Advertising Council, Inc.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 21 -- Political party platforms for the Aug. 14 elections for the Bundestag in the new Federal Republic of Germany disclose that the voters' decision probably will be based on the double-barreled issue of socialism and centralism.

HOOD RIVER, Ore., July 31 -- A fireworks celebration by the "Crag Rats," a mountain-climbing organization, last night disrupted airline traffic near Mount Hood and convinced one pilot he was seeing a new form of flying disks.

Pound sterling moved erratically last week as the financial horizon continued overcast with uncertainties. The setback in "governments'' on the London Stock Exchange to the lowest in a decade, and corresponding weakness in stocks, had a distinctly bearish effect upon the British unit.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat, of Georgia, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, predicted today that the House would pass Tuesday a compromise unification bill giving the Secretary of Defense, Louis Johnson, broad new powers over the Army, Navy and Air Force.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Brannan agricultural plan was denounced by Senator Edward Martin, Republican, of Pennsylvania, today as a proposed socialistic strait jacket for the American farmer.

BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- Maury McDermott, slim rookie southpaw, pitched the Boston Red Sox to a 3-0 decision over the world champion Cleveland Indians today, squaring the current series between the clubs at two victories each. Only one Cleveland base runner reached third against McDermott, who struck out seven and walked three in winning his fifth victory. It was his second shutout.

The complicated task of relocating public utilities now in the bed of First Avenue in front of the United Nations development between Forty-second and Forty-eighth Streets will be started today, Borough President Hugo E. Rogers of Manhattan announced last night.

The twenty-first annual report mailed today to stockholders and employes of General Mills, Inc., showed that the second highest earnings in the company's history were made in the fiscal year ended on May 31.
LONDON, July 31 -- Another crisis in Britain's affairs approached very near last week. This time it was a crisis of confidence.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- An intensified attack on the problem of fire on aircraft in flight is being undertaken by the Government, it was disclosed today. The Civil Aeronautics Administration said its technical development center at Indianapolis had scheduled "four entirely new attacks on fire."

On May 13 an explosion of chemicals being transported on a truck through the Holland Tunnel resulted in injury to more than sixty persons and damage of more than $500,000. Since then, the United States Attorney's office in Newark has been investigating a possible violation of the Interstate Commerce Commission's regulations affecting the transport of dangerous cargoes.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UP) -- A move by Americans for Democratic Action to unite liberal forces for the 1950 Congressional elections ran into difficulties today when labor and Democratic political strategists indicated that they felt it would be better to "leave well enough alone."
BATAVIA, Java, Monday, Aug. 1 -- A cease-fire agreement between the Indonesian Republic and the Netherlands was signed formally in a secret session early today at the United Nations headquarters.

SEA BRIGHT, N. J., July 31 -- Coast Guardsmen from the Sandy Hook station continued to act as water traffic officers today by chasing amateur fishermen in small boats from in-shore operations close to bathers, between here and Long Branch.

FRANKFORT, Germany, July 31 -- The Catholic Church and the powerful Socialist party clashed today over a pastoral letter that Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party in the British zone, charged was an attempt to swing votes to the Christian Democratic Union in the Aug. 14 election.
Twelve new cases of poliomyelitis in the city were reported yesterday by the Health Department for the twenty-four-hour period ended at 9 A. M.

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Aug. 1 -- Australia's Labor Government, bitterly angered over a crippling coal strike it charged was Communist-led, threatened today to wipe out communism in the Commonwealth.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- A steam generator used in the past almost exclusively for heating railroad passenger cars has been adapted for use as a power and heating unit in new industrial applications.

PITTSBURGH, July 31 (AP) -- Pinch-hitter Tom Saffel singled home the tying and winning runs in a thrilling three-run ninth inning rally today to give the Pirates a 6-to-5 triumph over the Braves and a split in their double-header. Boston routed Pittsburgh, 9 to 1 in the opener before a crowd of 27,105.
